Next, we tried the goat empanadas. Again, the sauces on the empanadas were so flavorful. I loved the crunch of the onions over the warm, crisp empanadas. The goat meat was soft and tender.

We tried the bucatini and pork shank from the meats section of the menu. The bucatini noodles tasted freshly made and had a creamy sauce on it. We really liked this dish. The pork shank is MASSIVE. The meat falls right off the bone. It's so tender and the two sauces that come with it are perfection. I love the pickled radishes and naan that come with it as well.

We didn't save room for desserts. We were too full from the taste adventure we got to partake in.

This may be one of the best restaurants I've ever been to. The flavors were unreal and it was absolutely amazing.

Absolutely amazing. We saw a last minute reservation on Open Table for 4:30 and booked it that afternoon. By 5pm almost the entire restaurant was full. Hostesses were very friendly to me and the others I saw them seat.

The two seater tables were very tight and next to each other and tables had to be pulled out a bit for the booth person to get in and out.

Server was very knowledgeable about menu items and recommendations based on our likes. They suggest sharing everything and 4 dishes for 2 people. Our 3 filled us just fine; salad, crab cakes and pork shank. All to die for!!!

This place is incredible. I finally was able to get a reservation at 7:15 last Friday, and after one visit, it has instantly climbed to the top of my list in not only Chicago, but also nationwide. 4.5 stars on 7500 reviews speaks for itself in the Yelp universe.

You HAVE to have a reservation if you want a table here, and likely will have to make that reservation weeks in advance if you plan on coming on a weekend. Wait times exceed 2-3 hours, as this restaurant is situated on Randolph Street in the insanely popular "West Loop" neighborhood in Chicago, which is quickly becoming one of the culinary capitals of the country. They're neighbors with the notorious "Au Cheval" amongst others. From what I understand, the bar is first come, first serve, and you can order from the full menu here if you're willing to hawk seats.

Stephanie Izard has been getting a lot of press recently, and in my opinion, she deserves even more. I cannot emphasize how pleased I was  with this meal. I had done a fair amount of research on yelp beforehand, so I had a pretty good idea of the fan favorites. Dress is very casual as well, which is an added bonus.

After about a 15-minute wait, we were seated and ordered a bottle of white wine, which was reasonably priced. They also comped us some focaccia for not having our table ready when we were seated. I'm allergic to shrimp, so we steered clear of all shellfish dishes, but here are my less-than definitive rankings of everything we ordered (favorite to least):

Roasted Cauliflower
Pan Roasted Halibut
Sautéed Green Beans
Blueberry Bourbon Baba
Grilled Pork Belly
Chickpea Fritter Chaat
Ratatouille Focaccia
Skuna Bay Salmon
Braised Beef Tongue
Wood Fired Lamb Ribs

I would HIGHLY recommend you get AT LEAST everything up until the Focaccia. Seriously do not skip the cauliflower... even if you don't like vegetables. I could eat this all day. The salmon and beef tongue were pretty average in my opinion, though my friends RAVED about the salmon. The only dish I didn't care much for was the ribs, but these came second-to-last, and I was pretty full at this point. They are a bit fatty, so it really depends how you like your meat. My friend said this was his favorite dish. This was MORE than enough food for the 4 of us, and we all had arrived extremely hungry.

I know that the goat empanadas, scallops, squash blossom rangoon and crab cakes are also really popular. Gives good reason to return.

As if this place wasn't already spectacular, the service was stellar (we left well over 20%+ for tip), as they were really diligent all night. Our waiter also "sequenced" our food out, as we ordered all at once, which demonstrated the expertise / knowledgeability of the waitstaff here. There was 4 of us dining, and all said, even with the wine and dessert, this meal came out to under $70 / person, which is incredible for a meal of this caliber.

A+, would give 6 stars if I could, and you're almost certain to love, regardless of your demographic. Concurrently a great place for any kind of date, but you shouldn't feel guilty coming in with kids either. Fingers crossed that Izard + Co. will get the praise they so deserve from the folks over at Michelin next year.

Ambiance
The Girl and the Goat is a super duper modern rustic look and feel inside.  They have an open kitchen to see all the action.  We had a seat for two so it was in those long tables where one is close to the next table.  It's easy to hear the chatter of the next door table.

Food
Wow, the food did not disappoint.  So many good dishes for a great value at such a high class restaurant like this.    

-Goat satay:  Very well cooked.  Tasted almost like lamb.
-Pig's face: reminds me of lechon kwali of the same Philippines dish. Doesn't taste like pork, can tell more with the middle.
-Beef shank: Fall off the bone, very tender very moist. Goes well with kimchi, ranch, butternut squash, and the naan.
-PB&J: Definitely peanut butter taste with some ice cream on top.  The brittle is very good.
-Birthday ice cream desert -Crunchy brittle with vanilla ice cream is delicious.

Service
I thought the customer service is pretty good.  We were able to get a birthday desert since it was my fiancee's birthday.

Food is really good, but the place is a little bit noisy which makes difficult to have a conversation, however food wise and service they have 5 stars!

El lugar esta bonito y la comida muy rica, es un poco ruidoso lo que lo hace difícil para tener una conversación pero la comida, bebidas y servicio son excelentes

Oh my gosh, what a wonderful meal! My husband and I finally used a gift card we had received for this restaurant and it was such an enjoyable experience. The server was so great, really helped with giving us recommendations. Everything is shared, they recommend 2-3 plates per person. We decided on bread, green beans, salmon, oven roasted pig face, confit goat belly, and caramel corn malt balls to top it all off. Seriously, everything I ate was delicious. I think my favorites were the salmon, it definitely was way better than it is described on the menu, and the confit goat belly, which was rich and decadent. I left extremely full and extremely satisfied. Highly recommend!

Let's be serious, what can I really add here? This place is AMAZING. One of the star restaurants of Chicago, yet unassuming and inviting without a hint of snobbery. The chef shows off her skill with this restaurant - each dish is carefully curated to be packed with great flavors, unique enough to leave you wondering how they made it. We came here to celebrate a special occasion and couldn't decide what to order but our waiter was super helpful at recommending a good combo and amount of food.

Food: Let's just say it now, first things first - you HAVE to get the green beans. Schwaa? You are going to a top restaurant to get.. green beans? For real, I have never had green beans that good - I am still dreaming of the sauce and presentation. We also had the beets which were great, the soft shell crab (to die for), the pork shank (to die for) and a few cocktails (loved "It's always sunny in oaxaca" - so good, just sweet enough but not too sweet, complex taste with a bit of spice on the rim!).

Bottom line, one of the best restaurants and dining experiences of my life - would highly recommend you come here! We made reservations waaaay in advance (weeks) but it seems like you can walk in on non-peak days/times and get a spot. You HAVE to check this place out!!! PS the day we went, our waiter said the chef was in the line cooking. How cool is that!!??!

My D.C. friend texted me earlier as his plan had changed and he would not make it to Chicago after all, leaving me alone to dine on a Sunday evening. Perhaps I'm not as emotional as I used to be, or perhaps I am too sick to care, either or I was not offended, I was alone and I had my eyes set on this wildly popular restaurant. Only 0.8 mile away from my hotel, I walked faster than I thought and almost missed it. I went to the bar area and got a single seat as I was dining alone and the restaurant was booked, as per usual. When you have 7000 plus reviews and still get a 4.5 stars you wonder what is the appeal, so it's really the curiosity that led me here.

I had limited appetite so I went for a goat belly and poke, and duck tongue because I actually have eaten duck tongue before and liked it. Sure enough, both dishes were pleasant and small portioned and perfect for a table for one. I also got some ice tea to chase down my salty, highly processed, yet delicious food.

I understand just about anyone who has been to Chicago more than once or twice has been here before, but until recently I rarely come here and I don't know the food scene.

So when I got home and told my fellow traveler friends, they all said, "Oh yes, it's not a Michelin but it's so good, I've been there." It led me to believe that I'm really the last person in the know about Chicago's eats, but at least now I have checked off one restaurant that everyone knows about. If I'm right about this, I'll be back here in September for another meeting after D.C.

On that topic, I have not written back to my D.C. friend, who probably thinks I'm pissed at him. I'm not, I just got busy. I should probably tell him that I had gone here, I bet he's eaten here too, along with the rest of his fellow ex white house staffers under the Obama administration, along with at least half of the entire Yelp population. It's that good.

This place is probably on all the must-eat/try restaurants in Chicago and it definitely lives up to the hype. If you weren't keen enough to make a reservation two months in advance, you might be lucky to snap a seat in their waiting area where you can order from the full menu without having to wait for 2 hours to be seated.

Between 2 people we shared 5 plates and everything tasted incredible. The ponzu oysters, rock shrimp, and cauliflower are must try's but I think just about anything from the menu would be good.

pics.caption: Ponzu mignonette oysters are a must try
Pseudo-dining/first come first served dining area

review.des:
I've been waiting years to get back to Chicago to try out this gem touted by my friend Anthony B. And tonight was the night!
We sat at the bar (first come first served). You can also reserve a table but when I called 3 weeks prior, they had already been fully booked for a Sunday night!
The room was filled with the younger set: people aged 25 and up to 60s. Dress was casual due to the millennial crowd but not pretentious.
The bartender was great. We didn't order drinks but he gave us suggestions and and recommendations like we were ordering top shelf booze! Great staff everywhere! All of them were so incredibly helpful!

Course #1:  Kohlarabi salad with fresh fennel,  toasted almonds, roasted shiitake mushrooms, Dutch beemster and pears!  A unique pairing of flavors both sweet, savory and with a gentle crispness.

Course #2: Roasted Lamb ribs in blueberry tamarind glaze with fresh scallions! It's meat candy at its finest!!  After your first bite you will want a huge plate of this stuff!

Course #3: Wood grilled broccoli with melted Smokey Bleu Cheese and spiced crisped rice! Smokey deliciousness! Who would have thought broccoli could be healthy AND yummy!!

Course #4: Goat Belly Confit with bourbon butter, crab & lobster with fresh fennel!  I have to admit that I wasn't sure you could pair surf and turf like this, but OMG it was fabulous! Sir, I'll take ten more of these to go!

Course #5: Seared Diver Scallops with wild maitake & wood ear mushrooms in an oyster sauce brodo with a squash brandade! Again, a culinary masterpiece!

I always like to have a sweet finish. But there were two desserts I had to do and I figured I'd let them each duke it out for the honor of being number one!  It was a tie:

Dessert #1:
Sponge cake with a gooseberry shortbread crumble, honey mousse, whipped cream and gastriqué!

Dessert #2:
Homemade Malted vanilla ice cream with caramel corn and crispy chocolate shell!

OMG fantastic!  I just died and went to a gastronomical heaven!!

4.5 stars for being inventive here. Hip ambience at this top chef restaurant. The lighting was a bit too dark for me.

I would recommend getting half portions whenever possible (eg. ravioli, cauliflower, shishito pepper) to try the maximum amount of dishes here.

MUST HAVE:
Duck Tongues with tuna and black bean poke, crispy wontons, piri piri - this dish was phenomenal. Never thought that fried duck tongue would go with tuna but it does! Great balanced of flavors and textures. Don't get scared of duck tongues which were deep fried and little bites mixed into the entire dish.

SOLID:
Roasted Cauliflower with pickled peppers, pine nuts, mint - the cauliflower is a bit over cooked but really liked the pickled spicy pepper here, which saved the dish. They doused it in parmagiano cheese (which wasn't indicated on the menu). I would have preferred it without it. They should have indicated it on the menu so people can opt out.

Escargot Ravioli - bacon tamarind sauce, escarole and celery, crispy & carmelized onions. Interesting dish. Liked the caramelized onion in this dish. The sauce was a bit too salty.

SKIP:
Pan Fried Shishito Peppers - parmesan, sesame, miso. This dish was trying to be inventive but felt short on the mix. The shishito peppers were just way too hot (1 out of 3/4 were spicy). The Parmesan creamy crust was an interesting test but just didn't go with the crunchy spiky shishito.

pics.caption: Grilled cauliflower - ask for the cheese on the side. Pretty good.
Nice ambience even though it was a bit darker than what I prefer.
Duck tongue with tuna poke - phenomenal

review.des:
Oh my goodness - one of the best restaurants we visited while in Chicago. We weren't able to get a reservation so we walked in at 5 pm (30 minutes after they opened) and were able to snag a table right away at the bar.

I started off with a puttin on the spritz cocktail, which was so refreshing and hubby had a local ipa. We got the goat Empanadas and omg so flavorful! They were served with a blueberry pick which was so unexpected but so amazing at the same time. Then we had the soft shell crab cakes which had blackberries and a soy glaze. Again, so unexpected but the flavors pair so well with each other. Next had the cauliflower and the mint was good in every bite! Last, we had the pork bucatini. A bit salt but great nonetheless.

Such. Great. Food.

Walked in with no reservation and didn't want to wait for a table so we sat at the bar (just me and one other person). We ate very comfortably at the bar but if you do want a table, make a reservation. The bar tender/server was extremely helpful! Great service! We had the such a fun-gi bread, sautéed green beans, seared scallops, and pan roasted arctic char. The combination of ingredients was surprising and amazing. Also loved how the place was decorated, comfortable setting

Update: 10/27/18

Back for another visit to "The Girl and Goat", and happy to say this experience was on par with our first. Had reservation for 6:30pm on a Saturday night (very busy) and was seated by 6:28pm. The staff was dressed in Harry Potter theme for Halloween which was funny.

We ordered the following on this go around:

Smoked Apple Pirogies
Wood fired Lamb Ribs
Duck Tongues
Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face
Goat Neck
Chocolate Pavlova Says-a-Me! (Dessert)
Sticky Tasty Crunchy Toffee Yummy Cake (Dessert)
All Nighter (Cocktail)
Talkin About Chai-Town (Cocktail)
Rory McIlroy (Cocktail)

Everything was top notch just like our last visit. We purposely tried new things this go around, since each item is always so good. The exception being the Roasted Pig Face... hard to not get that one again.

Favorites had to be the Lamb Ribs (one of the best things I've had in my life) and the Goat Neck (more food than other entrees... this was a special so probably not always available).

As usual you get through a couple small plates together and think -- "Man this is good but will it fill me up?" Then by the end you are totally stuffed.  

We definitely spent more this time ($36 on just cocktails).  The All Nighter is good but wow is it strong. Probably why they give you half a glass worth lol.

We will be back. Hard to beat this place.

Coming from New York City, I have to say this was one of the best meals I've had in 2018 so far. I had reservations for 2 on Sunday 9pm and the restaurant was packed. It was spacious, dark and loud. The service was fantastic from the moment I stepped in.

The waiter suggested 6-7 plates to share between 2 people. Unless you're starving I'd say 3-4 plates is more than enough!

We ordered:
- Goat empanadas: Good! The pico and cheese was an interesting twist giving it a burst of flavor. I only wished the portion was bigger.

- Confit goat belly: My favorite of the night! The confit was PERFECT! Crispy and super fatty melttt in your mouth delicious. The crab and lobster were soaked in this addictive buttery sauce. I almost licked the plate clean.

- Pork shank: Great! The pork shank was huge, crispy on the outside and tender on the inside. It came with a creamy buttermilk dressing and kimchi sauce that wasn't too overpowering. I LOVED the warm buttery naan. I felt that the pork itself wasn't that special. It needed the side condiments.

- Lemon make you happy: I was stuffed by the time I got to dessert. The lemon cake came warm. Very good but I thought the cake was way too sweet.

- Bubba watson cocktail: This was delicious but sadly weak with the alcohol. I had the rest of my meal with red wine.

Chef Stephanie Izard did an incredible job with the menu. She took flavors from different cultures all over the world. The combination with the ingredients paired perfectly! Such a memorable dinner. I highly recommend making reservations in advance. By the time I left around 11pm, there were still people waiting to be seated!

Went here for a team lunch and thought it was great. Cute atmosphere, friendly staff, and most importantly - delicious food. I went here for a lunch with some co-workers and we all had a great time. Highly recommend!!

With the amount of reviews this restaurant has I was really hoping it would live up to the hype which it did.  Most of the dishes here were excellent, if i had to put the them in order of my favorite to least it'd go something like this.

1. lamb ribs
2. soft shell crab
3. kohlrabi salad
4. wood oven roasted pig face (its like a breakfast plate)
5. chocolate pavlova
6. ratatouille focaccia
7. pork belly
8. sweet onion brioche
9. roasted beets
10. hamachi crudo
11. roasted cauliflower

The service here is pretty good, some of my party would disagree, but the server seemed fine to me.  If you'd like to try a refreshing cocktail try the "puttin' on the spritz", it's fruity and tangy.   One item that looked awesome that we didn't order was the pork shank, we saw many of those come off the kitchen line.   We came here with a big group so we all got to try a bunch of things (9 people) which i'd also recommend doing.  
 If you're coming from out of town then I'd suggest making reservations far in advance.  For our party of 9 we had to make reso's 2 months in advance and we could only get 5pm on a Friday.

Might be my favorite restaurant in Chicago.

Interior - Decorative, classy, and fun.

Service - Good. Dishes are timed on point to make sure you enjoy each item sufficiently before the next dish is delivered so you aren't swamped with 3 dishes at the same time all out of order.

Roasted cauliflower (pickled peppers, pine nuts, mint) - There is cheese. Delicious, salted, savory, soft, and tastes like home.

Escargot Ravioli (bacon tamarind sauce, escarole & celery, crispy onions) - Couldn't taste the escargot. Resembled more like flattened dumplings in some broth. Loved it.

Pan roasted halibut (marcona almond butter, white asparagus . blueberry nuoc cham, beech mushroom) - Fish sauce!! It was truly delicious and honored the Vietnamese fish sauce taste without watering it down. Must order.

Crisp braised pork shank (buttermilk dressing, grilled spring onion & radish kimch, naan) - Pork falls off the bone. Delicious, savory, soft. Naan is decent but the pork is so good without it.

Lemon make you happy (lemon​ pound cake, sorrel ice cream, almond crunch, cheesecake sauce) - My husband hates lemon and pound cake but he ate it all. Must order.

The Jam (Old Forester Bourbon, strawberry shrub, saison) - The perfect refreshing summer strawberry drink.

I wish I could understand the hype-- maybe I just ordered the wrong things considering I'm a pescatarian. 45 minutes after opening the restaurant was SLAMMED on a Sunday night. I was lucky enough to snag a seat at the high top communal table that has a full menu with full service.

I had the hamachi crudo, the salmon tartar, and the "crab cake" while the flavors of the three dishes wasn't bad, it didn't leave a lasting impression. My man friend said "it was one of the best meals of my life." I really don't see how. Another foodie friend of mine agreed- the place was a little lackluster. The salmon tartar with strawberries & avocado was the better of the three dishes, and the only thing I'd be able to whole-heartedly recommend. Being from Vegas, I don't care about price whatsoever. Bring it all out, and don't even look at the price. In this situation I really did feel taken advantage of when I was being charged $18 for the hamachi and only 5 small strips (about a bite and a half) of fish on the plate.

I almost thought about coming back to give it a second chance before the trip was over just to try the other items on the menu, but with so many other amazing choices in Chicago, I had to pass.

This restaurant definitely lives up to its amazing reviews. I was in Chicago for a few days and was told this place was a must. It's based on ordering small plates -- the waitress recommended 3-4 for two people eating. The seared scallops with the summer sausage succotash were divine. The best thing I ate however was the pork shank with naan, peach slices, and two amazing sauces. It was my birthday and on top of the dessert we ordered, they brought me another delicious little treat as well. This place is perfect if you are looking to spend a bit more money on food. I didn't even mind though because it was one of the best food experiences I've ever encountered. Our waitress was super friendly and the rest of the staff were super attentive and continuously made sure we had everything we needed. I'll be dreaming of this food for years!

You must go at least once and look for Elaine, the Girl with the Star Wars tattoos.

Listen, I just had the greatest night of my life at Girl & the Goat. We flew in from SF and had a terrible first foodie experience the night before. With empty stomachs we were hopeful this place would meet our expectations . It exceeded them by leaps and bounds.

We had 14 dishes, 1 of them so nice we had to have it twice. Sounds like a lot, but it's meant for sharing and there were four of us. My husband and I, my broke college foodie daughter, and my young pre-teen baby foodie. They recommend 8 dishes or so for 4 people but everything was so good we just kept going!  

From beginning to end, the entire staff was welcoming and the service was impeccable. It was beautiful and busy in there, but you would never know it because the service was so outstanding. Our waitress Elaine was very sweet, knowledgeable, & had great suggestions. From the drinks to the dishes she thought we would like and even some off menu suggestions, she was killing it.
I'm definitely not a professional reviewer, I just know how this place made me feel so if I don't describe the dish adequately, sorry!
All of the dishes were great but the stand outs for us were the hamachi(refreshing and light and flavorful AF), the lamb ribs(falling off the bone and we ordered it twice), the string beans, goat carpaccio(It was beautifully presented and it was tasty), Branzino in spicy shrimp sauce(so perfectly made, I could've eaten this by myself) confit goat belly(lobster shrimp and goat-oh my! but it works! The bourbon butter was very nice. ) octopus on pepita mole is so good...I mean I guess what I'm saying is, it's worth it. It really is.

Gluten free bread that is actually delicious. I'm not gluten free, my hubby is, and usually I have to sit there all "Yeah, this is umm, good." But I actually meant it this time. If I wasn't told it was GF I would've never guessed.

When a friend of mine mentioned that the Girl & the Goat was one of the best meals they've ever had in their life, I knew I had to make a trip out during my Chicago vacation. The universe must have been on my side the day I tried getting reservations because after a few minutes, I was able to snag a 7:30 dinner on my first night. (FYI: the restaurant will call you 2 days before your reservation to confirm.) When we arrived, the restaurant was completely packed (and it was a Wednesday night)!  The G&G definitely emits an overall vibey/classy/cool/ comfortable feel. I like that people dressed up but it's lowkey enough to wear jeans.

Okay, so on to the food! Our server (who was very nice and accommodating) recommended 5 plates for a party of 2. We ordered: 1) the sesame grape sourdough with BLACK SESAME BUTTER *yum!!*  2) goat empanadas 3) braised beef tongue 4)shishito peppers 5) roasted pig face.
I was completely blown away with the flavors & the execution of the dishes! The g&g is probably one of tastiest dining experiences i have ever had!

My only pit of the evening was the Carmel corn and malt balls dessert. It was extremely salty! My boyfriend and i couldn't finish it because the salt was just too overpowering. :(

I'd say this place is a bit too hyped and I debated between 3 or 4 stars. Gave it 4 stars since I only tried it once and maybe I ordered too much/got full of the first items considering I dined alone here.

I ordered the chickpea fritters, pig face, and these dumpling things. I thought the fritters were good but nothing to write home about. I found the pig face too salty / too heavy for me, but this was also one of the dishes that came out last. The dumplings were also good but I thought the chickpea fritters were more interesting.

I'd consider trying this place again with a larger party so I can try more items. The cocktails were fine, but considering I had just come from The Aviary, it's hard for any cocktail to measure up.

Echoing a lot of what I've read about this place.  Was lucky to get a reservation from a friend.  Service was fantastic.  The food was great, especially the goat empenadas.

Cocktails were also very good, we were seating right next to the famous painting.

I'd say for the price and pain of entry, I can't quite give it 5 stars.  The food is great but I can also get meals around that rival it for a little cheaper with less of a hassle.

I will still probably be back, like it a lot.

T H E    S T O R Y
- If you are a foodie living in Chicago, you have to try Girl & the Goat. We have come for drinks and apps before, but finally got the chance to have a full dinner.

T H E    G O O D
- Service: Our waiter was friendly, knowledgeable, and gave great suggestions as well as accurate descriptions of menu items.
- Pretty much everything we ordered exceeded our expectations. My boyfriend and I really liked the following:
      - Crab Cake
      - Goat Empanada
      - Goat Belly
- Ambiance: This is a great spot to come for a girls night, with a group, with your family, or on a date.

T H E    B A D
- No complaints here.
- Make sure and make reservations in advance, this place is always booked weeks in advance.

T H E    S T A R S
- I gave 4 stars because I was a fan, but it is still not one of my favorite places to dine in Chicago.

This place is fun and definitely different in terms of food.  Everything was prepared very well and seemed to have a lot of Asian influences in the food.  Great family style restaurant to dine with friends.  4-6 people would be nice to try a lot of stuff.

Get:
Roasted cauliflower - nice flavors and topped with the pickled peppers.  Balanced.
Beef tongue-felt like it was more of  a light salad that was well cooked and balanced
Wood oven roasted pig face - flavor and texture overload here. Definitely a favorite
Crisp braised pork shank-the skin was so crispy and the portion was big.  Another favorite
Goat confit - not gamey, and paired nicely with the crab.  Very rich dish and portion was tiny.

Skip:
Sautéed green beans - it reminded me of an Asian dish that didn't differ too much other than the price

Service:
Everything came out fast and waiter was very knowledgeable.

If you can get a reservation, definitely worth going here for a splurge.

Returned after a long hiatus thanks to a friend passing through town who was hellbent on visiting izard's origin story...

Snagged a table for two and proceeded to order too many dishes (according to our waiter who normally would be correct but just didn't know who he was talking to...). So here's the damage:

goat empanadas - awesome- meat was tender and not gamey, crust was crispy, topped with creamy goodness...get them

Braised beef tongue- ok- chips were a little oily, but good acidity from the salsa verde to cut the richness of the meat, just not my cup of tea though

Cauliflower - yum - and I don't even like cauliflower... well seasoned with peppers that added a little kick

Calamari bruschetta- disappointed- this is the one that kept getting rave reviews but I found it oily, salty and a little fishy... actually liked most of the components except for the actual calamari

Halibut - ok - a little bland and fish was slightly over cooked, mushrooms were yummy though

Green beans - winner - the veggies were killing it- creamy, crisp, well seasoned

Confit goat belly - pure indulgence- so rich and decadent between the butter sauce, lobster and confit goat - delish but a few bites is all it takes

Service was great and the waiter was so impressed (or scared) by how much we were able to consume that he brought by a complimentary dessert even after we turned down ordering one (I'm betting that he just wanted to see if we could actually eat more - challenge accepted).  Lemon pound cake with sorrel ice cream was a nice end to the meal

A few misses for me but overall a great meal that also checked a box for my traveling foodie friend

I had an incredible dinner at Girl & the Goat!  

I booked my reservation about two months in advance, and the only opening available the entire weekend was at 10p on a Saturday.  Basically, book your reservation WELL in advance.

If you like popcorn chicken, you must get the duck tongues!  The perfect crispiness on the outside and the soft, tender inside is definitely reminiscent of the perfect popcorn chicken.  I loved the duck tongues, but my favorite dish was the duck tartare.  Very tender meat and had many diverse textures on the plate, and I loved the duck crackling on it!

Going into my meal, I was the most excited for the goat belly confit, but it ended up being my least favorite meal of the evening; the goat belly confit was a bit too indulgent and sat heavy with me.  Moreover, it was the most one-dimensional dish as many of the flavors/textures were lost in its buttery sauce.  However, if buttery textures are what you're seeking, then I think you'd love this dish!

I had a delicious cup of tea after my dinner, and incredible/well-paced service throughout my meal.  It is definitely worth the investment to make a reservation and enjoy the incredible flavors and textures offered at Girl & the Goat.

This might be my favorite restaurant in Chicago. I've come here almost every time I've visited, and I've never been disappointed. There are so many reviews already, so I will keep it short.

Favorites: soft shell crab (on scallion pancake and blackberries), chickpea fritters (how is it perfectly crisp and creamy smooth?!), the jam cocktail (despite the name not super sweet, very funky), any of the seasonal desserts (lemon pound cake with sorrel ice cream this trip).

Every item is well crafted and delicious, and the above just scratches the surface of its offerings. Service is always very kind and generous. I've walked in without reservations with max of 2 people and usually get seats at the bar any time between 4:30-6:30pm. Plus of sitting at the bar is that the bartenders are amazing and very fun, you can order mini size plates of all the veg items so you can do a little tasting, especially if you're eating by yourself. Can't wait for our next trip back!

review.des:
I will get fat!

Food is so good, you can't stop even if you are stuffed! From beginning to the end everything was exceptional, except the service. We wanted to try drinks of the menu to try everything and mine was fine but wife's drink was a bit to sweet. But we didn't complain, the server asked how are the drinks and wife replied "it's okay" and the server had an attitude for the rest of the night. But we overlooked that because food was really good. All and all we want to go back and try somethings that we didn't the first time and give it another go. I highly recommend the lamb chops as the slide right off the bone with no effort.

The gf and myself ended up at this location as it is one of the hottest restaurants on Randolph and seemed to be relatively difficult to book. After arriving on a weekday night, the place was fully packed and difficult to walk inside the restaurant itself.

After getting seated, it was nice to see the open kitchen and really seeing the hustle and bustle of the kitchen staff working along with servers. The bar is nearby and people were drinking and talking loudly over the music and overall the restaurant just seemed extremely lively. The lighting was dim and the bathroom may be a bit of an adventure (it's located downstairs and no shared bathrooms, only private bathrooms in a long hallway) but it was great to see the effort invested into building such a cool restaurant.

Supposedly the restaurant menu does change according to season and we ended up ordering the duck tongues, bucatini, and wood oven roasted pig face. The pig face was amazing and had crazy taste profiles and perfectly fried potato stix strings that gave each bite a nice crunch. The bucatini was heavy but tasty and tasted even better with sprinkled red pepper flakes on top. The duck tongue was easily the highlight of the meal because we were surprised by the ahi tuna on the bottom of the tongues. The crispiness of the duck tongues worked well with the "freshness" of fish and the wonton strips gave everything a bit more texture.

It's easy to tell that this place goes over the top with taste profiles and experimenting with new combinations. I would highly recommend for anyone to experience the ambiance and food at this restaurant if they were ever to visit Chicago!

So much has been written about how great this place is and I get it.  I can understand the cult-like following and applaud the restaurant's success.  In my opinion, though, that success is due mainly to the staff.  There is zero pretension in the place!  It gives off the feel of the local family restaurant.  It's first-rate food, but world-class people.

Thanks for making us feel welcome.

After patiently waiting for a year to land a weekend reservation at G&G, we were able to snag seats for our anniversary - and what a true gift it was to eat at one of Stephanie I.'s restaurants. It comes as no surprise that on a Saturday, the place was packed and people were standing and looming around the bar. From our food to the customer service/waitress,
we were so utterly impressed that it made the wait worthwhile! If dining at G&G you must (of course) try the pig face, grilled baby octopus, goat confit and scallops. The portions are perfect and three to four plates were sufficient for two people (we just had to get more since we had finally made it in).

Crisp Braised Pork Shank - buttermilk dressing, grilled spring onion kimchee, naan

review.des:
Girl & the Goat is not just hype- this culinary experience might be in my top 20 meals. I'm always looking to try something new. I like to challenge my tastebuds and be able to say- oh yeah, I ate that.

The ambiance of this restaurant was relaxed; a little dark for my photo liking, but I loved the subtle goat decor. I ordered the Girl & the Goat Cab Franc, which had  great, full bodied taste.

Our server explained that our party of two should order 3-5 plates, as everything is meant to share. He told us he planned to bring the dishes out in order of lightest to richest, which I truly appreciated. One of the bartenders we met in the Somerset used to work here and mentioned we could ask for half orders of the veggies (a big hushed power move, as we got to try more things!)

We ordered the sautéed green beans (6/10) and the roasted cauliflower (10/10!), the goat carpaccio (8.5/10), duck tongues (10/10!) and the escargot ravioli (7/10).

I would definitely love to go back and try more of their entrees options.

We go here every year for a holiday dinner, and every year it gets better and better. The service, ambiance, and of course the food are always amazing. Get the pig face, it sounds weird but is SO GOOD.

The menu is unique. I don't really eat goat but theirs were great. Lots iof interesting options. I took out one star because everything came out all at once squeezed onto our tiny table, which was extremely crowded. Plus the food got cold by the time we could eat them. Pork shank became really dry instead of crispy and moist when we had our first bite. My favorites were Duck Tongues, Chickpea Fritters and Goat Carpaccio. Green Garlic Pierogies, Sweet Onion Brioche Smoked Salmon Cream Cheese, Goat Empanadas were decent. Caramel Corn & Malt Balls were too salty for me.

Our server informed the table next to us they could order smaller portion instead of the regular dinner plates. I wish she told us that while we ordered. We told her we wanted to try a lot of the dishes on the menu but couldn't possibly eat that much and ended having lots of leftovers.

I'm so impressed by Girl and the Goat!! I made reservations about 2 months in advance and eagerly counted down the days until my trip to Chicago. We were seated immediately when we arrived.

Goat Liver Mousse came first. A little jar of the pate was served with freshly made crumpets, red onion morstada, and bread and butter pickles. Who knew that savory, tangy, sweet, sour, crunchy flavor would work so well together? Each bite was a harmony in my mouth. I'm so glad the liver was not gamey at all. I would lick that jar clean if I could haha oh wait I basically did...

Next was the Duck Tongues. I didn't quite know what to expect, but I was impressed! The slivers of tongue were fried and chewy so good! They were served with a tuna and black bean poke (so fresh), crispy wontons, and peri peri. The sauce definitely packed some heat and worked well with the duck tongues.

The last dish was the Seared Diver Scallops, which were incredible! 2 large scallops served with a roasted miso brown butter aioli, blood orange, smoked beet, and pistachio. I don't even like beets but I ate every piece up in this dish! The pistachio added great crunch to the tender scallops. My favorite dish this time!

I didn't have any room for dessert, but I'm sure I'll try them next time!! Stephanie Izard, props to you. It's so rare that I love every single tapas style dish at a restaurant, but here I did!

We got super lucky and sat down after 10 minutes of walking in (without prior reservations)! If you don't have reservations, this place is usually a 3 hour wait. MUCH WORTH.

I've never been to a restaurant where I fell in love with every single dish and drink that I ordered.

Drinks:
- Local 75
- the highlander
- best of three (MY FAVORITE)
- hefeweizen beer

Food:
- mojo spiced shrimp
- pan roasted halibut
- goat liver mousse (MY FAVORITE)
- goat empanadas
- crisp braised pork shank

Dessert:
- lemon make you happy (best lemon cake I've ever had)

Prices were so reasonable and the staff were amazing! I wanted to come back the next day to try the rest of their menu.

Awesome dining experience. The pork shank was tremendous and delicious. Also liked the Walleye which was fried with tempura batter-crispy outside and warm tender inside. They recommended 2 dishes per person so we ordered all the seafood dishes and some other meats. The goat belly was ok, but a little gamey. They also made birthday cookies for sister in law. Overall awesome place and food.

We have loved and now frequented all of the GG eateries. Hopefully LA too soon!
My first intro was GG diner and then the French Mkt (3 years ago) when they were there. I still dream about that goat chili. Magical Flavor profiles that are just done exactly as they should be.  All is right in the GG world as far as I'm concerned.  Amazing feat to have this many eateries that all execute so well and CONTINUE to do that.. Be it the food, the service, decor. Please do not ever go away.

This place is worth the hype!! To avoid writing an essay, I'll try to summarize the experience (and include any tips) in bullet format below:

- Yes, it is super hard to get reservations. Tip: use rezhound (website, free) to input the dates and times you'd like a reservation and they will email you as soon as a spot opens up! You can use this for any restaurant that takes reservations. I was able to get a spot on Halloween at 7:30pm a week before :)
- The atmosphere is casual, you definitely don't have to dress up.
- The portion sizes vary widely. If you order the right dishes, you can leave full for just $50 for the two of you.
- The service is amazing. Special shout out to Elaine who made the entire experience a night to remember.
- We had the short ribs (only skippable thing, smaller portion), goat empanadas (you only get two but they are SO GOOD!), cauliflower (favorite dish of the night and I don't even like vegetables that much!), pig face (iconic dish, good size portion), and pork shank (HUGE portion! If you get this and another medium size plate, it should be more than enough for two).

Overall, this place is amazing and actually worth the hype. Check it out!

Wow. Just wow. Girl and the Goat definitely lives up to the hype in my honest opinion. For years I've been skeptical about trying the main restaurant as I wasn't sure if I would enjoy it. Who wants to eat pig face? Well I'm really glad I was wrong.

Making reservations for a large group (8 people) last minute is possible if you don't mind going at 9 pm. Even then the restaurant is popping! I'm pretty sure you could even come with a smaller party or just with two people if you don't mind walking in during the tail end of their hours.

Being our first time there, our server explained how it is essentially tapas style, and recommended we get 6-8 dishes to allow us to try a variety of items. Off the top of my head, we had the Brussel sprouts, sautéed green beans, roasted cauliflower, seared scallops, bucatini, crisp braised pork shank, and the wood oven roasted pig face.

I consider myself to be pretty picky with what I eat, but man... everything we tried just blew me away. I'm no food expert so I can't really describe it, but the flavors that were coming out of each dish was incredible. My favorite dish was the pig face. You would think "GROSS! THATS A FACE" but man... I dream about that dish from time to time. Mixed with the sunny side egg, it's really creamy and tender.

TLDR; girl & the goat is a definite must try if you're ever visiting or live in Chicago and have never been. The flavors that are coming out of their Dishes are wild and incredible. Probably one of my favorite dining experiences.

Visiting Chicago, a friend told me "you have to go to Girl & the Goat". Boy this restaurant did not disappoint. This restaurant was by far the best restaurant I ate at during my 4 days in Chicago. The diversity, quality, and creativity of the food is what caught my eye. This needs to be the place you splurge in Chicago!

Grilled marinated quail. I have never had quail before but what an introduction. I was a little hesitant but glad I tried.Juicy with a great salad on top to complement.

Skuna bay salmon. Served chilled, extremely tender. The mix of strawberry, avocado, and asparagus actually made this my wife's favorite dish.

Sauteed green beans had a great fish sauce vinaigrette that was a perfect complement to the heavier meat dishes. Our waitress gave this to us on the house as a recommendation of her own! Excellent recommendation.

Pig face. Another item that I was a little skeptical about but loved the porky taste and was essentially like a great sausage/egg dish you might have for breakfast, just a lot fancier!

Pork Shank was a ton of meat and very tender. I literally could slide the bone out as the meat was prepared so well. The naan and dipping sauce were excellent as well. We barely were able to finish this dish due to the amount!

Complimentary cake for my birthday at the end was very sweet of our waitress as well. The service, explanation of the menu was excellent. We loved our location on the bar stools in front of the kitchen. We saw our food being made and the kitchen hummed in harmony. Each person had a set group of foods they made and they all did it so well. This is a must eat place in Chicago. I hope you go!

pics.caption: Pork shank and the kitchen in the background

review.des:
4.5/5 so I'll round up to 5.

WOW, this was a great experience. We had snagged 715pm reservations on OpenTable once they'd opened up more, about four weeks before arriving in Chicago - previously, only 945pm and later was available.

Our waiter told us that most people order 4 to 6 dishes, as they are tapas and meant to be shared. Dishes range from $12-26ish. Once you order your dishes, he will then bring them out one by one, I believe he went from lightest to heaviest dish.

I can't pick a favorite because they were all fantastic but I can tell you what we ordered. We started with the goat empanadas; I don't usually eat goat but these were great. After that, the green garlic pierogies, and the chickpea fritters. The fritters were probably my least favorite but their side was great: quinoa and pomegranate seeds, which I never would have thought to put together. We also had beef short ribs, which were the most tender short ribs I've ever had, and we ended with the chicken dish, which was actually large and could be eaten as a meal.

My friend also got the fried oysters and a half order of the scallops (literally ONE scallop, haha) and enjoyed both.

The 4.5 stars vs 5 comes from the fact that although our water glasses were always refilled, our waiter didn't check on us that much. Also, the couple to our left got a free dessert (it was their anniversary apparently) and the group to our right also got free dessert (no apparent reason why) but for us, he just offered the dessert menu. We were stuffed at that point anyways but I wonder why we were not offered a complimentary dessert.

Expect to spend about $40+pp here, but I'd definitely come back... All of the food was delicious.

Had a great experience! We definitely indulged and ordered a wide variety of food and drinks, as a  party of three we all shared most of the food and there's nothing that we didn't like, we will definitely visit again and recommend to everyone that's in Chicago.

Really excited to try this place from the great reviews and local recommendations. However, the food was a disappointment, and the tapas did not wow us.

Yes, we know it's tapas, but the portion is still SMALL for tapas at the menu price. Flavors are a bit heavy and salty for us. Will not go back.

This is my favorite upscale restaurant on Randolph. We've been here a few times and have tried different things each time. Everything was great but small so get multiple things and share.

Getting reservations here can be difficult but they do have bar seating with a full menu. If you are able to get reservations I'd recommend asking for the chefs table. They set you right in front of where all the food is prepared. It's a really fun culinary experience.

7000+ reviews... how do we not try this place?? Getting a reservation is not easy unless you do it way in advance... anticipation is building.  The ambiance gets an A+ for sure. Hostesses and waiters are just super. The menu is very unique and I just wanted to try everything. Our waitress had to put a stop to our eyes devouring everything on the page and we limited to 6 dishes. Actually 7 dishes but she forgot about the pig face and we felt like stuffed pigs after our meal anyways.

Dish #1: Oysters- raw : I'm not a fan of oysters but these were good. Went very well with my refreshing glass of Rose.

Dish #2: Diver Sea Scallops: These were perfectly cooked. I really liked the pistachio and smoked beets on the top. Yum!!

Dish #3: Sautéed Green beans: this dish seems so simple and plain but it was one of my favorites. I did pick out the sautéed onions but the fish sauce with cashews was bomb! I literally ate the entire plate.

Dish #4: calamari bruschetta: What you think you will get is not what is on the plate but try it and you will be forever thankful. The calamari is so fresh and well prepared. I hate celery but the one in here was fantastic. Highly recommend!

Dish #5: escargot ravioli: This was good but not my favorite. I usually really love escargot but this mix of flavors was a bit too rich for me. My sister absolutely loved it.. so order it anyways.

Dish #6: Duck tongues: This dish is served with tuna and black bean poke which I really liked. Lots of wonton chips too. Interesting combo of flavors.

Then dessert.... malt balls with popcorn was fabulous, unique and rather tasty. Our waitress also brought us complementary lemon cake which was not to shabby.

You would be a fool not to try this restaurant at least once when in the city!

First thing I noticed was that all young women had colorful painted nails and all young man had good looking shoes.
The food followed with the plates offering nice presentation of texture, color and most importantly taste.
Like in any other place, it is a hit or miss.
Duck tounges (yes, little duck tounges) were fried but did not lose texture and did not taste oily. The combination of other ingredients really complimented it. It is so good that it will extract smiles from you face.
Goat liver paste with pickled raisins and delicious fried dough made me thing that I am back in Paris. So much great taste in small doses.

Pavlova desert was so salty and sweet at the same time, and had no fruit component and I could not finish it due to non agreeable taste.

This is a nice place where you can get a lot of wonderful (artistic) small dishes for a half of cost in NY or DC, considering how fancy the place was.

The greatest! The tastiest! One of my favorites in Chicago. Wish she'd bring back the deviled eggs though. :(

Everything I've had here is a flavor explosion. Service is exceptional.

I gasped. I licked a plate. I made an awkwardly forward comment to the bartender in my joyous food haze (she's female and I'm happily married to a man).

My sister and I are on a sister weekend in Chicago and wandered from our hotel on a Saturday night hoping to score a table at one of the west loop hot spots. We came in around 545 and scoped the bar. After spotting a woman sipping a cappuccino (telltale sign of end of a meal!), we set up camp behind she and her dining partner to snag the seats. Brilliant! Seated by 6 and ready to roll.

Sangiovese in hand (yum! Fruity! Another glass, please), we scoped the menu. We settled on beets, shishito peppers, cauliflower, goat belly, and pork shank. Stand outs for me were the Parmesan peppers (that's one of the plates I finger swiped to get more deliciousness), goat belly (the sauce was soooooooo rich and savory! The bartender laughed when she caught us trying to scrape up sauce with our forks and fingers to not let it go to waste), and the pork shank.

The pork shank made me moan. I mean- the red sauce and naan with some of the crispy fork tender meat- I really think that bite of food is in my top 5 bites of my life. Do NOT not order the pork shank. Hands down, my favorite of the night.

Service was impeccable, food stellar, and experience perfection. Thank you. I hope to return again!!

AMAZING (and so worth waiting for our 9:45 pm reservation)!

We were nervous to try the pig face, as it was quite out of our comfort zone. It ended up being the best part of the meal! The meat was very crispy and fell apart perfectly. The egg and other ingredients were a bit soggy, but it was still an amazing dish.

Definitely recommend the goat empanadas (also a bit out of the comfort zone, but very worth it!!!) and the peppers. The cauliflower was good but overpowered by the other dishes. The dessert was great as well-definitely would get it again.

The server recommended 4-5 dishes for two people, but we felt 3 would have been enough (especially with dessert).

pics.caption: So many unique elements to this dessert! Very good
So glad we ordered this! Definitely will order again
Roasted Cauliflower- very good! Unique pairing with mint leaves and slightly spicy peppers

review.des:
Rated as one of the top 10 restaurants in Chicago you want to book waaaayyyyy in advance for special events. That said, they have a walk in waitlist that can sometimes be less than an hour. Another option is to walk in and hang around the bar. It is a full service bar and you can do a full dinner at the bar. Walking in around 6:30 we have gotten a spot in under 15 minutes.

The menu changes as per the chef. We loved the calamari bruschetta and were disappointed when the chef pulled it off (after about 2 years) since she wasn't getting good calamari.

I don't think there is even a single dish that has disappointed. That is saying a lot. Since the portion sizes are a little small, you end up getting 3-5 dishes per visit. After multiple visits here, that is a lot of dishes.

That said, it is a little heavy on the pocket book. With drinks for 2 you can expect a triple digit check. Try it out on a special occasion with your special someone. You won't regret it.

pics.caption: Old fashioned - nothing like the Madison, WI stuff but still pretty good

review.des:
The hype is real! Definitely make a reservation a few weeks ahead of time. A few months ahead of time would be recommended if you're looking to dine at prime dinner times like Friday or Saturday night. I finally planned ahead of time to enjoy dinner at Girl & the Goat on my most recent trip to Chicago and really enjoyed my experience.

Plates at Girl & the Goat are meant to be shared. For our group of four, we each got a cocktail, shared the foccacia bread, two veggie dishes, and four meat dishes. Perfect amount of food. My favorites were the roasted cauliflower, wood oven roasted pig face, and crisp braised pork shank. The flavors across the dishes were playful, unlike anything I've ever had, with Asian influences like the creamy cashew nuts in the green beans, spicy Kimchi flavors in the sauce that came with the lamb shank, bright mint cilantro flavors. I loved the layers of savory, sweet, bright, refreshing flavors in the dishes.

Great experience. Service was attentive and food came out quickly. Girl & the Goat is not only a nice place to grab dinner, it's an experience to fully emerge yourself in, that creates conversation about everyone's favorite topic, FOOD!

I was really looking forward to have dinner at this restaurant.  I've scheduled my reservation many weeks in advance.  However,  when I arrived to the restaurant a few minutes before my reservation, a table was not available and I had to wait 15/20 mns.  Once a table was available and was sat down I was very uncomfortable how close to each other the tables were.  But, I was so excited and looking forward to having dinner at this place, I put that small detail to the side and went ahead and ordered appetizers and dinner.  The food was really good but being so closed to the other table made my dinner very uncomfortable.  I could hear clearly what the couple next to me was  talking about and it was very disturbing.  Believe me, you don't want to know.  
Maybe I would visit again and ask for a better spot.

If a picture is worth a thousand words, what is the worth of over 7000 positive yelp reviews and counting? My wife and I decided to find out for ourselves.

Our entire dining experience was exquisite. What made it so good? It was the culmination of a hundred little things. Obviously the food was the MVP. There is so much thought that goes into each item on the menu. For instance, the sourdough bread was delicious on its own, but it was exceptional paired with the whipped feta and red onion mostarda.

Do yourself a favor and get the crisp pork shank. It was my favorite thing. Again, alone this entree is amazing. Crisp outer shell with fall-off-the-bone and juicy meat inside. But paired with the buttermilk dressing, grilled spring onion kimchee, and homemade naan it was a one-of-a-kind experience!

If I have done a poor job using words to express how delicious this place is, take a look at my photos. They speak for themselves.

The Girl & the Goat is taking the restaurant scene in Chicago by a storm. You'll want to see for yourself why it's so good!

Here's my deal: Coming from NYC, when you tell me that there is an hour plus wait for a restaurant, you assume the food is damn good or the place has an unjustified cult following. So you can only imagine how excited I was to come here... Unfortunately, I think this restaurant falls in the latter, largely due to Chef Izard's Top Chef acclaim. I found the dishes to be very heavy and the flavor contrast was too strong and callous .. It lacked the cohesion I typically seek in an award winning restaurant.

We came in on a Monday evening and waited a little over an hour for a table. I genuinely felt they would've seated us earlier if we stuck around (we went to a nearby bar to kill time), as we were seated minutes upon returning, despite the hostess informing us that there may be an additional 30 min wait. Anyhow.. we ordered the beet salad, escargot ravioli, beef tongue, pork face, and goat confit.

--The beet salad was delivered with arugula and ?radicchio, bathed in a vinaigrette. For me, I was unsure if the beets were fresh or canned.. it was slivered finely, and when you ate it with the green bitters, the contrast was so potent that it made it difficult to enjoy the subtle sweetness of the beets. For reference, my fav beet salad ever is Jean Georges' Public Kitchen and/or from ABC Kitchen .. This just missed the mark IMO.

-- Escargot ravioli was delicious by itself but it sat on a salty beef broth that was far too strong and overwhelmed the ravioli. I would recommend this dish if you knew how to construct your bite: would suggest plating the crunchy onion on top of the ravioli, and allow it to sit on the SMALLEST amount of broth in your spoon .. only then did it become more palatable for me.

-- Beef tongue: very much like a warm salad but no grain. Probably one of the more solid dish but the vinaigrette was too heavy to allow the savoriness of the tongue to stand out. There is a lot of texture in this dish but it was hard to construct a bite as the crisp (I think it might've been fried wonton/dumpling skin?) was oversized, so the different ingredient ratio was problematic.

-- Pork face is legit a rip of a Filipino sig sig. I wish they would give credit where it is due .. Deep notes of tamarind and vinegar, with great crispiness of the pig cheek/ears. Prob another one of my fav dishes largely because it reminds me of classic Filipino food in Queens, but very disappointed that it failed to credit a culture that mastered this dish for ages. And for $16-18 (don't remember exact cost), it was def overpriced compared to the aunties in Woodside that make it for $8-10 (and, trust me, they make it way better).

-- Goat confit was perhaps the most confusing thing I consumed all night. The goat didn't taste like confit cooking .. more like abbreviated braising. Meat was musky and muscular. It was accompanied by lobster which was deliciously sweet and drizzled with a cream reduction. The lobster by itself was great, but to add it as a complimentary note to the goat was very confusing and, personally, didn't mingle well. This dish was just unharmonious IMO.

Overall: it just wasn't my cup of tea. The different flavors within one dish contrasted too sharply for me to enjoy. It felt like the dishes were generated whimsically without much thought to its cohesion .. or maybe that's the intention? Moreover, I actually found the dishes to be heavy (ie overwhelmed with vinaigrette or the roux? coated the respective meat too much) that I felt absurdly gluttonous after eating here. And, for the record, portions are huge by NYC standard. If I had to do it again, I prob would've ordered no more than 4 dishes.

Would I recommend? I guess if you're into sharp contrasting flavors and rich cuisines, but, maybe for the more scrupulous tongue, it might be best to skip. I personally don't understand how this restaurant acquired such glowing review .. have a meal at other restaurants with notoriously long reservation wait time  - Chef's Table, Eleven Madison Park, Daniel, Per Se- and then get back to me about how it compares.

pics.caption: Escargot ravioli- ravioli was great but beef broth was salty as heck.
Roasted beef- the bitterness of the arugula and greens was too much to balance the sweetness of the beet
Goat confit- very confusing dish overall. Unharmonious.

review.des:
I love great service, and my experience here was just that--incredible service. We sat at the bar and Lily took care of us. She was wonderful--super friendly, and incredibly attentive--even when it was crazy busy. Her cocktails were perfection, and all of her food recommendations were totally on point. She even went the extra mile when I told her I had a seafood allergy, and she grabbed a menu and crossed out everything that even had a hint of seafood in it so I wouldn't get sick. AMAZING.

Of the items we ordered (and we ordered many!), my favorites were:

- It's always sunny in Oaxaca (cocktail)
- Merlot/Cabernet blend
- Chickpea Fritters
- Warm Marinated Olives
- Pan Fried Shishito Peppers (these are very cheesy, btw...)
- Kohlrabi Salad
- Focaccia - (with the amazing yuzu harissa butter...omg...)
- Lemon cake with Sorel Gelato (tasted like spring!)

pics.caption: Warm Marinated Olives - OMG, get these!

review.des:
My review is divided in 3 categories - Atmosphere - Service - Taste

Starting with

Atmosphere: I would say nothing fancy or overly crowded in this place. It was calming and very nice. I would say I loved the atmosphere of the restaurant and would rate 5 stars.

Service: Our server(s) were all good, nothing amazing or nothing bad about them. They knew about the food and was able to answer the questions we had. I would rate them as 4 stars.

Taste: I will start with what we ordered: Wood Grilled Octopus, Goat Empanadas, Broccoli, Scallops, Beef tongue, Pig Face.

In the same order above:

Wood Grilled Octopus: It was by any means bad but was not the greatest, it had heavy cilantro taste. Overall it was OK. 2.5 Stars

Goat Empanadas: They were good, had a very nice smokey taste. 3 stars

Broccoli: Nothing out of ordinary it was an OK side dish. 2 Stars

Scallops: This was the best dish of the night and the best scallops I have ever had in my life. 5 stars

Beef tongue: Both myself and my wife was not a fan of it. It was more of a salad with 2 pieces of beef tongue. 2 Star

Pig Face: It was good, different and joyful a bit on the greasy side but hey it is a pig. This is a good size share plate, it was a bit much for a party of 2. I suggest to order less than 6 plates if you want this dish for a party of 2. 3.5 stars

Given you have to wait for a long time to get a reservation at this place my expectation was very high and Girl & The Goat was not able to fulfill my expectation.

I have not rated the drinks but I would say Ring of Fire was also a great cocktail.

Despite my initial skepticism, Girl & the Goat is well deserving of its 4.5 star rating. I'm always suspicious of restaurants that are universally hyped. And Girl & the Goat falls squarely in that bucket. There wasn't a single person who I told about my upcoming trip to the restaurant who didn't "ooh" and "aah" about it. Which made me eye roll a bit.

Anywho, it turns out that Girl & the Goat is worthy of the hype. Most of the dishes we ordered were excellent, including the scallops, octopus and hamachi crudo. Other dishes were really good, although I'll probably try other things next time I'm there (e.g., the chickpea fritters, oysters and "breads"). I was really looking forward to trying to goat empanadas, but I was so stuffed by the time they arrived that I could only muster one bite, and I feel like I can't fairly judge them based on that bite.

Food aside, I was also really impressed with the staff. In my experience, the staff at trendy restaurants is often pretentious and annoying. But here, everyone from the hosts to the servers to the busers were friendly, respectful and seemed genuinely welcoming (shout out to my man Einstein, in particular). For me, this actually elevated the experience to a solid 5 stars.

We had a reservation here at 10:30 on a friday night.

What we ordered: sweet onion brioche | goat empanadas | pan roasted halibut | seared diver scallops | calamari brushetta | duck tongue | wood fired lamb ribs

Taste: favorites were the scallops, duck tongue, ribs and empanadas
brioche was good but the bread could have been warmed or another bread.

Food came out fast and our server was super helpful.

Everyone knows this place is AMAZING. I wasn't able to get a reservation, but we showed up at exactly 4:30 and were able to snag seats. (We did have to share a large table with a couple other groups, and were told that they needed the table at 6pm. It was all handled graciously and we understood they were trying their best to accommodate walk ins)

My one regret is that I came here with only one other person, so we weren't able to try as many of the dishes that we would have liked. They do say it's small plates, but each plate had a significant portion, and we were VERY stuffed by the end of five plates.

Overall the food is AMAZING, perfectly cooked, flavors that I didn't even know would go well together. It's just so good. And yes, please order the Goat dishes, it's phenomenal, I don't know how they do it.

Overall, I'd love to get a big group to come here and just order the entire menu.

The wait at this restaurant is totally worth it. I showed up at 430 and they were willing to seat us right away, but my table wasn't ready. We went back around 6 to put our names down and they said it will be a 3-4 hour wait. We went to a restaurant around the corner for 3 hours for drinks and snacks and then came back to Girl and the Goat for a drink before our table was ready. IT WAS WORTH THE WAIT!

I am so happy that I came back to this place for the meat dishes. We sat down and were talking about the duck tongue amongst ourselves. Finally when the waitress came over to take our order I instantly ordered the duck tongue and then we continued to order the rest of our dishes. Before we even finished ordering the rest of our dishes the duck tongue came out! We had no idea how she did it (did she over hear us talking about it before? did someone else over hear us ordering it and bring it out?) we had no idea, but she did not leave to punch in the order from when we told her we wanted it to when it came to our table and we were so happy and so amazed!

the duck tongue is a MUST. it is definitely the most delicious dish that we had here with tuna, black bean poke, and crispy wontons. How could you go wrong?

The focaccia although good- just tasted exactly like it sounds- like focaccia.

The beets, although they also tasted exactly like they sound, I am obsessed with fresh beets and these were fresh! With green beans, white anchovy, bread crumbs, and an avocado creme fraiche I thought this was a unique spin on beets compared to the classic beets/greens/feta dish that you get at most restaurants lately.

The seared diver scallops with toasted miso brown butter aioli, blood orange, smoked beet and pistacho were easily the best scallops I have ever had.

The waitress recommended the sauteed green beans. Who knew that these could be so amazing? With fish sauce vinaigrette and cashews.

My absolute favorite touch was at the end. We ordered 3 of the 4 desserts and they brought us the 4th dessert for free to try because how could we not try them all? Every single dessert was amazing and the one we didn't order (the caramel corn and malt balls) turned out to be the best one so don't make a mistake and not order it!

Horrible foods!
I've been to so many restaurants around the world. This is the top 5 most overrated restaurant.
We came to visit from California. We saw the 4.5 star from thousands of people. We were so excited and made 2-3 months reservations in advance.
Everything was so salty. We could not even finish cause salt. It was horrible and very disappointed. Will definitely not come back and recommend to anyone.

While planning our girls only chicago trip, we made reservations for a party of 3. When we arrived at the restaurant we the hostess greeted us right away.  I really enjoyed the atmosphere of the restaurant, it was nicely dimmed i would say.  He then brought us to our table.  We ordered first round of drinks and the a couple of dishes to share.  We ordered (sorry i don't remember all the names on the menu), salmon poke salad, blueberry bread, lamb empadas, cow tongue, and another lamb dish.  Its ironic how its called girl and the goat, because i dont eat lamb at all.  But everything else i had here was delcious.

Went here on our trip to Chicago based on many recommendations from friends. We went a bit overboard to say the least, but it was because everything was so good!

We ordered the sourdough bread to start (not pictured), 2 sides of green beans, chickpea fritters, goat empanadas, halibut, goat belly, and 2 orders of pig face. I will say the portions were quite small, but everything was so rich that it became filling quickly.

Green beans: were a little salty for a couple of people in our group but were just right for me as I love salt.

Chickpea fritters: super rich and delicious. The quinoa on the bottom was even better!

Goat empanadas: these were ok. I liked the sauce they came with more than anything.

Halibut: I hate cooked fish. Like, really hate cooked fish. But my wife forced me to try the halibut and man was it good. The sauce was super flavorful, the fish just fell apart in your mouth. So good!

Goat belly: this was so tender and melted in your mouth. The crab and lobster on top was the right combination of flavors.

Pig face: I know it sounds weird, but it was crispy, soft, and full of flavor. I'm not a huge fan of eggs, but I went along with it for the experience.

The bill came to around $160 for all of this. We will definitely be back to try some of the other things on the menu next time we are in town.

Definitely make a reservation though as it got full real quick. We brought our 2 year old and they were pretty accommodating for a child!

Loved it!! We luckily grabbed a 6:45pm reservation the day of for party of 3. We ordered almost everything on the menu and loved every dish.

Here's what we ordered:
- Chickpea Fritter
- Seared Tuna
- Mojo Spiced Shrimp
- Seared Diver Scallops
- Crispy Short Ribs
- Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face
- Goat Empanadas

Amazing is an understatement!!!
That Pork Chop OMG !!!
Service   soooo much food !
They even gave us dishes that they wanted us to try for free! I can't forget the Scallops!!!
I didn't want anyone to ask for one ...LOL
Great job guys you're amazing!!!

Getting into one of Chicago's most popular restaurants is actually less difficult than it may seem. All you need to be willing to do is be a little more flexible with your dining time. I was able to walk in and get seated immediately with a group of four people at opening time (4:30 pm) on a Saturday. If you do not have a reservation, I would definitely recommend coming here right when it opens for your best chance at being seated.

The food here is pretty good overall. We ordered just a tad too much but ended up finishing off everything anyways:

-Breads (Ratatouille Focaccia, Peter Piper Bread, Blueberry Sourdough) - we ordered all three breads...perhaps a mistake since we got very full very quickly, but they were all pretty good. I enjoyed the baba ganoush spread that came with the focaccia. The Blueberry Sourdough tasted similar to a blueberry bagel and the sourdough taste was not very strong (a positive thing for me since I am not a huge fan of sourdough).
-Roasted Beets - I love beets and this dish was refreshing and a nice start to the evening
-Seared Scallop - the two scallops were enormous and nicely cooked
-Soft Shell Crab Cake - not what I was expecting but pretty good regardless. Rather than a crab "cake," it was more like an enormous tempura soft shell crab on top of a "cake." It was covered in a slightly sweetish sauce.
-Sautéed Green Beans - for being one of the more popular dishes, I thought this was only okay. The sauce was a little too heavy for my taste but the crisp texture of the beans was a nice touch.
-Bucatini - nothing too impressive about this pasta dish. The pork shoulder in this dish was a little too salty.
-Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face - one of the restaurant's signature dishes. Unfortunately, at this point in the meal, we were so full that it was hard to enjoy this dish to the fullest. I did eat a couple bites and enjoyed the sweet, crispy taste of the meat.

I regret ordering too many breads in the beginning and not saving enough room for the signature Pig Face at the end. That being said, I did enjoy most of the dishes we ordered. Girl & The Goat is a great place to bring visitors from out of state to show them a bit of the innovative Chicago culinary scene.

American Express Platinum card comes with a $550 annual fee, but it surely has its perks! I got a reservation a few days before my trip and email conformation within a couple hours after calling. But if you don't have such services provided by credit cards, I recommend booking 3-4 months ahead or even earlier. P.S. if you book through AMEX, they'll give you a $75 set menu with no price written on it...  (don't fall for it) their à la carte menu is much better, so ask for it!! Onto the restaurant itself... IT'S FREAKING LOUD IN HERE!!! And I can hardly see during nighttime, but the food was pretty good. Also, these servers seemed confused and messed up a lot of orders (even ours and the table next to us).

Pan Roasted Halibut ($21)- 4/5 Enjoyed the mushroom, unique blueberry nuoc cham and marcona almond butter. Halibut was cooked perfectly and was juicy and tasty with the sauce.

Wood Fire Whole Branzino ($26)- 4/5 If you're into Thai/spicy dish, this would be for you! Chili shrimp broth and green papaya salad was delicious with the Branzino. Branzino was deboned and nicely cooked, good to share for two!

Sweet Corn Pierogis ($16)-4.5/5 Yummy yummy! Loved the sauce, the sweet & juicy tomatoes, and pierogis!  

Berry Tasty ($11)- 3/5 I liked the sourness from these little scattered bits and pieces and also the strawberry/blackberry, but the whip cream reminded me of mascarpone (which makes me want to throw up). The jelly was alright- not crazy about it, but I guess it's unique, it doesn't have a lot of flavor.  

Keep Dreaming ($8)- 3/5 Cheese wasn't really impressive and nothing really unique and it's also really small. Crackers weren't that great either.

Super imaginative family style food. Impeccable service. Lively atmosphere. Cool cocktails. Great for a group or a date night. I can see why G&G is so popular. 4.5 and I'll round up.

There were some hits and misses to the dishes, overall I thought there was alot of value since the ingredients were high quality and unique. Pretty much most of their menu is under $20.

I was impressed with my cocktail, The Morning Ritual ($12?), it had creyente (fancy) mezcal, ancho chile, coffee bitters, along with vanilla-maple, and lemon. Really complex and unique since it started off spicy and smokey then finished off refreshingly sweet.

Their sweet onion brioche ($5) 3/5 with salmon cream creese and pickled relish was solid. Good start of the meal with it's contrast of flavors.

BRAISED PORK SHANK ($26) 5/5 - Perfectly cooked with the crisp exterior and fork tender interior. The buttermilk dressing and squash-shiitake  kimchi was interesting. Our waiter told us a cool story about how this dish originated.  

DUCK TONGUES ($17) - 4/5 These were interesting crisped pieces of dense meat. The tuna and black bean poke along with the crispy won tons made for a really interesting and contrasting dish. Just a little too salty though.

GOAT CARPACCIO ($14) 5/5 - Not gamey at all while the smoked trout provided an interesting texture of salt.

ESCARGOT RAVIOLI ($17) 4/5 - The bacon tamarind sauce was an umami bomb.

STEAMED MUSSELS ($16) 2/5 - Just too salty for my tastes. The banana squash and perilla (type of mint) was interesting.

CARMEL CORN AND MALT BALLS dessert ($11) 6/5! - Blew my mind. It had magic shell. Magic shell over vanilla malt ice cream and popcorn carmel?!?! Sweet, salty, crispy, crunch, smoothy, melty. Everything you want in a dessert.

Made a rezzie a month in advance. It's worth a try.

Overhyped or I ordered the wrong things three times.

My palette was very confused by this place. Sometimes it was trying to be Asian. Sometimes Mexican.

Cocktail was good. Strong.

Food:
Cauliflower - salty. The sliced jalapeños did nothing for the flavor. The grayed feta was interesting but added little to the dish

Goat empanadas - about the only good item
I tried and even so it was 4/5 stars. For 16$ I got two glorified dumpling size empanadas. The meet was delicious though.

Chickpea Fritters - this was just off. So many flavors and nothing matched or went well together. Thai mint leaves with some seedless pomegranate seeds. The chickpea were literally 4 chickpeas interspersed. I got the half order of this and thank god.  The half order came with two cheese fritters.

It's not as amazing as other people claim.  I remain perplex to the great ratings.

pics.caption: Chickpea Fritter - just trying to be too many flavors

review.des:
Food Ordered that we really enjoyed:
- Branzino (SE Asian flavors.)
- Broccoli (enjoyed the smokey flavors)
- Cauliflower (pickled, so don't order if you don't like sour flavors)
- Octopus

More Unique stuff we enjoyed as well:
- Chickpea
- Duck Tongue (we enjoyed it, but note that its on the fatty side)
- Pig Face (kind of similar to asian cuisine but not exactly alike so its worth ordering)
- Dessert: Aw, Honey Honey

The Goat Capriccio itself didn't have much flavor, could have skipped it.
The Hamachi Crudo was not bad, but not a stand out.
