I haven't been to many restaurants where almost all the dishes were amazing.  It was our favorite meal in Chicago. I can't wait for them to open their second store in LA next year!

Girl in the goat was highly anticipated dinner that we planned three weeks in advance. I recommend making reservations as early as possible, the earliest we could get in was 11:30 PM. It was still buzzing when we got there.  Sidenote: the food scene in Chicago was nothing less than amazing and girl and the goat blew our mind.

We Wanted to try as many dishes as possible so we went all out and splurged. Starting with the ratatouille focaccia with baba ganoush and squash tzatziki (looking back now we probably didn't need the bread but it was warm and delicious in the dipping sauce). We had the sautéed green beans which were rich in flavor. The confit goats belly melted in our mouths with the bourbon butter and lobster and crab, this was a favorite! The pork shank was my husbands favorite and one of the most substantial of the plates. Of course we had to try the wood oven roasted pig face and this was my favorite. Another melt in your mouth dish and the sunny side egg on top, yoke dripping over pork just sent my taste buds over the edge.  We also had a seasonal dish of calamari that was great. We had a great experience there. It was already after midnight when we were finishing up but the wait staff was still actively bringing out food. Our waiter was so good at explaining each dish that came out as well as the ingredients that were used. We could see the chefs through the open kitchen concept which I really enjoyed. If I was to go back to Chicago, hands-down I would return to Girl & The Goat. If I'm being honest, I would say it's a selling point for a trip alone.

pics.caption: 11:30pm and this place is still buzzing

review.des:
Do they really need another 5 star review? Probably not, but I'm going to leave one anyway. There are few restaurants where I'm willing to suffer the indignities of booking months ahead just to get a table at the unheard-of hour of 10:30 (I'm old and grumpy and need my sleep--don't judge), but G&tG is one of them.
I've eaten here several times over the years, including one particularly epic meal at one of the large group tables in front of the kitchen, when Stephanie Izard herself was kind enough to come take a photo with all of us fat happy stuffed people.
The menu is large and rambling, but I've loved and often been surprised by almost everything I've ordered off it--even things that I normally wouldn't be excited about (I've tried and failed, sometimes badly, to recreate the wonderful roasted cauliflower dish!) This latest stop saw us greedily asking for a second order of the confit goat belly (bourbon butter is good for you, right?).
The service is friendly, efficient, and helpful (paralyzed by fear of FOMO when faced with the menu? They'll take care of you.)
Cocktails are strong and tasty. And have amusing names.
In short, I love it. If you're planning a trip to Chicago, step 1 should be making your reservation here.

Squash Blossom Crab Ragoon - One of my surprise favorites for a small bite.  The dish itself is not pinned down to any specific region or style of cuisine in the world. There was a multi-cultural approach to the composition in my opinion. The breading was delicately soft, yet still sturdy enough the hold the filling. The inside was actually quite liquidy, which isn't a bad thing but took me off guard. The crab flavor is fresh and is not buried by the other ingredients.  

Their Sourdough bread is actually worth ordering. Plenty of blueberry sweetness, along with that tang that sourdough has. The sauces and schmear gave it a further dimension that  offers depth and comfort.  

The Goat Empanadas are solid, but I thought they would be amazing. The braised goat on the inside reminded me of peppered steak, with that distinct goat taste. The breading was a little starchier than I would like, as the flavor itself wasn't memorable. But they are still worth getting if you have a big appetite. I like that you can order them in any sized quantity.  

Grilled Broccoli - Not as good as I hoped, but it primarily relies on the smoked bleu cheese sauce from underneath. Not as refined in composition as I would like, but there's something base satisfying from the sauce itself. The broccoli was OK, but since the sauce was the main attraction, they didn't do much to the broccoli.

Goat Belly Confit - This was not meant for any mere mortal, but for the gods! The fatty, gamy goat belly blended harmoniously with the lobster, while the bourbon butter intertwined an unholy marriage of flavor that destroys the stratosphere. If you ordered bread, sop up some of the bourbon butter once you're done with the meat. Honestly, this dish is worth Michelin star status. I absolutely recommend everyone order this, even if you are stuffed to the gills.  

Lamb Ribs - With the wet rub they use, these bad boys are basically meat candy! Fall off the bone, plenty of candied char, with the lovely gamy taste to reign it all in. This is definitely still tapas size, but don't be afraid to order these.  

Pork belly - Asian inspiration is strong with this one! The sour cherries and bok choy are a great combo to the slices of pork. Although I had envisioned a block of pork belly, they shave it down to thin slices and sear it to resemble pork chop pieces. This was the favorite dish at the table, so even the pickiest of people can appreciate this one.  

Green Beans - Our server actually brought us out a decent size sample of the green beans, as he recommended we try them. I generally dont like green beans, but I figured I would give them a shot. They definitely tasted like fresh, boiled green beans, with a bunch of sauce drizzled on top. This was probably my least favorite part of the meal. There wasn't anything special about it IMO. I dont see how this could be the dish that created the restaurant. Im glad my server let me try it for free, but its not something I ever care to have again.

Chicken - Our waiter wrote this down by accident, so they gave it to us for free once they understood their error. I usually don't order chicken from places because its usually the most conservative dish on the menu. Surprisingly, they did a great job giving this tired old bird some new life. The chicken itself was moist, and they focused on just dark meat (makes sense from the gamy-centric focus). The  plating was a work of art with all the colors and shaved vegetables they used. The honey ramp glaze was the real show stopper of this meal. The sweet yet earthy taste brought me back for more with each bite.  

Popcorn Dessert - What a lovely dessert! Salty from the popcorn, creamy from the chocolate malt ball ice cream, and lightly sweet all around. It truly felt like having movie theater popcorn (light at the butter) with milk duds. They gave a good portion where two dainty people can share, or one hungry person.  

Overall I was quite pleased. For a laid back, trendy atmosphere with 15 - 22 dollar price point per plate, it's a casual fine dining experience that takes the formality out of the equation and offers damn good food. I can see now why all the locals love this place.

Simply amazing. Arrived for our reservation at 8:30 Saturday night. It was very crowded and took a bit of time to get seated.

Atmosphere was very relaxed and chill. Service was prompt and friendly. The food came out at a good pace as well.

The food was very interesting. There were so many combinations of different foods that most people would never have expected to be paired together, but went together beautifully. 10/10 would recommend. Items we got included the skuna bay salmon, pan fried shishito peppers (vegan), squash blossom crab rangoon, duck tongue, roasted cauliflower, goat liver mousse, goat empanadas, braised beef tongue, and the wood oven roasted pig face, plus 3 desserts. Favorites at our table were the pan fried shishito peppers and the goat liver mousse. While the squash blossom crab rangoon was good and a great concept, it tasted as good as other crab rangoons you can get elsewhere, so I would recommend trying another item on the menu.

The one that started it all.. Stephanie Izard's Girl & the Goat has been instrumental in turning Chicago's West Loop into a culinary mecca.

Not sure how it's taken this long or me to visit. After all this time, I naturally assumed G&TG wouldn't live up to all the hype.. I was wrong.

By far the best way to experience the Goat is to grab a couple of drinks and a few plates to share. The wood-fired lamb ribs were fall-off-the-bone tender and bursting with flavor due to the blueberry-tamarind glaze. The goat empanadas were flaky and delicious on their own, but being perfectly paired with grilled pineapple-blueberry pico and roasted poblano cream truly sent your taste buds into the stratosphere.

Was lucky enough to grab a table with no wait by stopping in right after work on a Thursday night. Highly recommend you come in early, make a reservation weeks in advance, or be prepared to wait.

If you're like me, and have somehow managed to avoid this place for this long.. You don't know what you are missing out on. Highly recommended.

pics.caption: Goat Empanadas w/ Grilled Pineapple-Blueberry Pico & Roasted Poblano Cream
Wood-Fired Lamb Ribs in a Blueberry-Tamarind Glaze

review.des: So I'm a little conflicted! Most of the dishes were tasty, but I think the place is overrated and too pricey compared to other small plate restaurants. The squash crab Rangoon was flavorless (if anything tasted like oil) and small. The halibut was delicious, although I've had better at another small plate restaurant. The pork shank was good but not worth the price, according to my husband. The blueberry bread and caramel corn ice cream were really the stars of the show. The bread was warm with a hint of sweetness. And the caramel corn ice cream was a good portion size, super sweet, and beautiful presentation. One of my favorite desserts in the city! Service was very good and our waitress was quite knowledgeable. We had a nice experience but It didn't live up to the hype. I'd rather go to a different small plates place.

Although Girl & the Goat was an experience like no other, it didn't totally live up to the hype for me.

The service we received from the waitstaff was outstanding. After telling my server that I didn't like cilantro, she went to the kitchen and marked up every menu item that contained cilantro for me--something that no one has ever done for me before. It definitely made my ordering process a lot easier.

However, the food was, in my opinion, a mixed bag that ranged from average to amazing. The Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face, the dish that I had the highest expectations and hopes for, turned out to be quite average. On the other hand, I was blown away by their simpler dishes such as the Sautéd Green Beans (I normally hate green beans and this dish made me love them!) and the Crisp Braised Pork Shank (it was a big 'ole piece of pork with some naan on the side).

Overall, Girl & the Goat is an experience that everyone should at least experience--just don't expect the food to fully live up to the praise people have given it.

pics.caption: Sticky Tasty Crunchy Toffee Yummy Cake: the cake was  excellent
Chocolate Pavlova Says-A-Me: another highlight of the night; the perfect medley of flavors and texture
Crisp Braised Pork Shank: my favorite dish of the night; the meat was so tender it literally fell off of the bone (the naan was also great!)

review.des:
Hands down my favorite restaurant in Chicago (and maybe even in the country). The menu changes from time to time but I have been there 3 times already and have not been disappointed yet (Last two times the menus were the same). You really cannot go wrong with anything you order here.

We made reservations every time and all were made well in advance so we were able to get a time that we liked, rather than waiting a ridiculous amount of time in line or eating at an odd time. You really have to make a reservation 90 days in advance!

Most recently, we ordered the roasted cauliflower, seared diver scallops, braised beef tongue, wood oven roasted pig face, calamari bruschetta, duck tongue, chickpea fritter, olive yu(zu) focaccia, and and goat empanada. The beef tongue, pig face and scallops were my favorite this time around! All three of these were super tender and cooked perfectly. Wasn't really a big fan of the chickpea fritter unfortunately- it was plated beautifully but the texture on the inside of the fritter was a little odd for my liking and the fritter itself was a little bland.

I like the ambience to this place, it's pretty hip and really good vibes, but is not good for kids as it may be a little loud and the menu isn't very kid friendly.

Absolutely delicious. Got a 10:30 pm reservation few weeks before coming to Chicago, and came to the restaurant around 9:30 hoping for an open table. The place was still packed but we got sitted around 10 at the two seats facing all cooks! This is amazing view to see all the chefs cook the dishes put to your table in seconds. We got:
- pork face - creamy and crispy
- cauliflower - loved it, cooked so well!
- goat belly - very interesting flavours, generous amount of lobster and crab on top as well
- green bean - very flavourful! Chef in front of us just cooked it and handed to us :) love the experience!
- pork shank- omg at this point we are both full already and this is giant. Flavour is good but unfortunately we can't finish it.

Great night overall and will definitely recommend this to anyone who is coming to Chicago for a visit.

I've always wanted to try this place out and was able to make last minute Reservations.  This place did not disappoint.  The food was delicious and everything came out one at at time piping hot and ready to eat.  It's all tapas style and definitely nice to share with 2, even 3 ppl at the table.  We had the ponzu oysters, very sweet and tasty.  The shishito peppers are yummy but nothing too fancy about.  The duck tartar is amazing must try !! The rye bread is delicious, the apple spread is really addicting.  The scallop is sooo good ... they are a good size.  In all I really enjoyed my meal here!

Girl and the Goat was amazing. We had a reservation and came early. They seated us on time. The server was friendly and recommended that two people usually get 4-6 dishes to share. We got 11 dishes (lol!). The kitchen decides what order they come out in from lightest to heaviest.

We ordered:
Sweet Onion Brioche bread - 10/10 This was by far my favorite. I felt stupid ordering bread at such a nice restaurant but omg, I would have felt stupid if I HADNT ordered this. I loved it so much i actually ordered another one in the middle of my meal. The bread is soft with a slightly sweet onion smell to it and it came with a pepper relish and the yummiest cream cheese (with a hint of smoked salmon) I've ever had. It was such a perfect combination of warm bread with creamy and cool cream cheese. THIS DISH IS TO-DIE-FOR.

Raw Oysters - 9/10 Fresh and tangy, loved it! Only downside is that it came with 4 :(

Green garlic pierogies - 8/10 Soft and creamy on the outside and crunchy and delicious on the outside. The corn and mushroom relish underneath was amaaaazing.

Escargot ravioli - 6/10 This is the first time I've had snail and it wasn't bad! The broth was a little salty though.

Goat empanadas - 9/10 I loved the mushroom and aioli that came with the empanadas. The meat was tender and juicy and very flavorful.

Goat belly confit - 4/10 I found that the crab meat didn't really belong but this dish is usually a huge hit with everyone.

Sauteed green beans - 7/10 Really enjoyed these green beans. They were blanched well so they still had a bit of crunch to them. The vinagrette on them is delicious and the peanuts were a nice surprise. However, there was SO MANY green beans that this was where I started to fill up. Beware, this is a huge dish (in comparison to the others). I sort of wish this came out more in the middle of the meal and not towards the end.

Crispy pork shank - 10/10 A huge crispy pork shank came out with a ranch and buffalo dressing and a piece of naan bread on the side. Wow!!  The pork was so crispy on the outside and so juicy on the inside that I was able to just pull the bone clean off of the meat. I actually found that the meat itself was so flavorful that I did need or use any of the sauces it came with. All I needed was the naan bread. This is also a huge dish by itself too.

Caramel corn and malt balls - 10/10 What a fun dessert!! The scoops of vanilla had a crunchy chocolate coating and the light and airy but sweet popcorn was an interesting play on textures to contrast the cool and creamy vanilla. Sounds simple but it was a delight to eat.

Note: we really wanted to try the calamari bruschetta but it wasn't available that day. Apparently, not every dish on the menu is available every day. Every morning, each dish on the menu is made by the chefs to assess the quailty of the ingredients. If they are not up to par, that dish is not served that day.

Chef Stephanie Izard is a culinary genius. All of the food was unique, playful and interesting and I am excited to try her other restaurants. The only downside of that evening is that I didn't get to see/meet the chef herself.

I think this review will probably be repetitive about how amazing the experience was. I noted in the reservation that It was for a birthday dinner, and they gave us the best seats in the house at the chef's table. We were able to oversee all the dishes being made, which made our decision about what to order that much easier and fun! We started out with the goat empanadas, cause we felt It was our duty to order a goat dish at a goat restaurant, and they were highly recommended. They were absolutely delicious--fried to perfection and topped with some cheese, mushrooms, sprouts, and onions atop an orange sauce. The meet inside was super flavorful and It was a perfect portion for two. We also ordered the octopus, which was so good. It came over a pepita mole sauce and pickled banana squash. It was bursting with flavor, not fishy at all, and a great texture. We also ordered the wood grilled broccoli, which were charred to a wonderful crisp. The blue cheese sauce that accompanied It added a nice flavor as well as an addition of what seemed to be Rice Krispies for some texture. We got a complimentary kohlrabi salad that was super yummy. It was filled with so many different greens, adding so much flavor, such as fennel, beemster, roasted shitake, pear, etc. It was also dressed very nicely! Next, we had the wood fired lamb ribs, our favorite dish by far. They were so extremely tender and filled with so much flavor. They were absolutely delicious. Lastly, they gave us a complimentary birthday dessert of caramel corn and malt balls. The Caramel corn was crunchy and reminded me of an upscale Cracker Jack. The ice cream was so yummy and the chocolate shell was delicious. It was a perfect way to finish off all the goat restaurants!

Absolutely wonderful. After dying to try this place for 2 years, I finally got a reservation, and let me tell you, it was worth the wait! This is a culinary experience like no other. We explored the menu and tried:
Sweet corn pierogies
Chickpea fritter chaat
Goat empanadas
Wood fired lamb ribs
Grilled pork belly
Bread (forgot the kind) w/salmon cream cheese
Chocolate pavlova
The waitress gave us a complimentary side of the green beans, very good. My only critique is that the lamb ribs were 90% fat, no meat. We told the waitress, and she very kindly comped them and gave us more empanadas instead - liked that! Everything was a wonderland of flavors. If this place isnt on your list, it should be!!!!!

Yes the reservation process sucks but if you can get a seat then its totally worth it! I've never been disappointed by the food/services here and they always have something interesting and new on the menu
The pig face is one of my favorite dishes! Please get it!
Also I don't love lamb but my boyfriend says the lamb ribs were the best he's ever had in his entire life. So don't skip on that either if you like lamb!

Oysters-Raw.
Confit duck belly.
Roasted cauliflower.
Lamb ribs.
Whole branzino.
Malt chocolate ice cream with caramel popcorn.

You're welcome.

A tale of a million emotions.  A real toss up between a three and a four star review.

First, I really wanted to go here, so I went onto OpenTable and looked up available times, and they stunk.  Basically, during the 5 days I was going to be in Chi-town, they had 1030 pm on a Sunday night.  That's cool, no big deal, but we happened to walk by two days earlier and I stopped in and asked if they had any earlier time.  I was told no.  But when I got back to the hotel that same day, I checked on OpenTable and they had 845 pm.  This pissed me off.  First of all, the restaurant should recognize that me booking through OpenTable costs them money, that's how the platform works, and if they'd just rebooked me themselves while I was standing there, it would have been free.  I wish the guy would have said, "If something earlier opens up, I can let you know."  Anything is better than just "no", and going home and seeing the answer is yes.

Anyway, we arrived on time for our reservation but had to wait a bit around, like 15 minutes or so after our reservation time.  We were sat in the main dining area, and it's very cramped and very noisy. I moved the table about two inches away from another table, and a server assistant came by and pushed it back and told me not to do that.  So you can imagine when they then proceeded to sit a woman next to me that smelled like she bathed in perfume, I was not pleased. I hate the smell of perfume, especially when I'm eating.  So since I knew I wasn't allowed to move over, we had to move.  We got moved to the area closer to the bar, and we were happy because the table was shorter, so we were sitting closer to each other.  We were in the hosts' butts, but we didn't mind.

Service was hit or miss, we waited a long time for repeat drink orders, and had to flag someone down.  Food was good but nothing that stood out as being the best anything I've ever had - the pig face was quite good, and so was the goat liver mousse.  I come from a huge city as well, though, so this kind of food is not inaccessible to me.  

Overall, we had a good meal, but I wouldn't go back next time I'm in Chicago.

Nothing beats the flavors, service and food here. Everything was excellent. Came here with the suppliers and enjoyed a few cocktails to start with followed by appetizers and food and two bottles of wine later. Finishing off with two desserts. Still a remarkable place in Chicago to dine with your friends. Check out my pics. Trust!!

Ordered:

Roasted Cauliflower
Sauteed Green Beans
Soft Shell Crab Cake
Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face
Crisp Braised Pork Shank
Confit Goat Belly
Pan Roasted Halibut
Caramel Corn & Malt Balls

Our favorites were the crab cake and the pork shank.  Order more naan for the pork shank.  it's not enough and the meat is so fatty, it's not good to eat it by itself.

Overall it was a good meal but not earth shattering good.

This is my absolute favorite restaurant in Chicago. After taking a hiatus for a year, I was super excited to revisit to see the changes to the menu. We tried the new flatbread and it was so scrumptious! It had a flakey crust with tons of herbs filled with robust flavors on top. We had a few of our usual dishes like the green beans which are to die for! We also had the new baked chicken which was topped with a ton of garnishes that included thinly sliced apples! The chicken was cooked perfectly, super tender!

The service and ambiance never disappoints! We had the opportunity to sit at the chefs table and I was astonished by how all the chefs work together and make these dishes!

pics.caption: Creating my fav Sautéed Green Beans!
Sitting at the chefs table in awe of how all these dishes are made!

review.des:
Get a reservation bc this place is BUSY, even during the weekday!!!! Came from out of town for one night and had to choose carefully what I put in my stomach. Glad i chose this place. I ordered the fried duck tongues and the oven roasted pigface. The duck tongues were amazing! Ive had nasty duck tongues in the past and was hesitant to order but so glad I did! The texture and flavor was amazing! And the combination together with the Tuna poke and fried wontons was heavenly.

The pigface was good too. I didn't appreciate it as much until I read an article on serious eats website that it was made with the actual face of a pig . If you google "pigface serious eats" you could see behind the scenes of how It is made. It's pretty graphic and not for the faint of heart!!!

Next time I visit Chicago, I will definitely come back here. One of the few places that has left a memorable impression on my extremely picky taste buds!!

Went back and it was uhmazing again. Duck tongue def my fav as well as pig face. Just wish the duck tongue was larger cuz it was sooooo good. I lied the bread with the salmon spread but I have had better bread there before. Braised short rib was not my favorite but people I was with loved it. The meat itself was great but the sauce was a bit too sour. Pierogies were really good but there are better items. Loved the scallops. Goat empanadas were amazing as usual. Bucatini left something to be desired. Complimentary green beans were really really good. Loved them. Confit goat belly was wayyy too rich and buttery ( never thought I would say that)

Update: went back and tried the shrimp and rhubarb which was def too tart for me. The lamb ribs with the blueberry glaze was amazing...just falling off the bone Perfect. Popcorn dessert was very good. Had the scallops with beets and I just didn't dig it this time. As usual, duck tongue and pig face were the main hits. Oh also. The salmon spread bread was amazing...not sure what I was thinking before

When you visit a city a lot and ask people for restaurant recommendations and just about everyone says the same one, then you have to go there, right?!  

Girl & the Goat is that place.

On several trips I tried to make a reservation, but it was always full. I didn't try this trip, thinking that it would be impossible to get a last minute reservation. But because I asked some colleagues again for recommendations and Girl & the Goat was mentioned I decided to give it a try....score! Dinner for 2 @ 7.

We got to the restaurant just in time for our reservation and checked in. The host informed us that it would be a little while because several tables had paid, but they were taking their time. No problem. We decided to sit in the bar area and have a couple of drinks. I ordered The Best of Three--it was awesome! Ketel One Vodka, pimms #1, cucumber and lime. So refreshing and not too sweet. My dinner companion had a White Russian.

We sat enjoying our cocktails for a few minutes, taking in the decor and buzz of the place--it was packed! A host came by to update us and said our table would be a couple more minutes because they were cleaning it. After a brief wait, they informed us the table was ready. We closed out our tab and made our way to the dining area.  

If you want an intimate place, this isn't for you. If you don't mind basically sitting with the neighboring table, then you're all set. We luckily were sat by 3 folks on our left who were nice and chatted with us a bit. On the other side was a couple who were either arguing or just didn't feel like talking to each other. You know the couple that sits at dinner not talking to each other...that was them.

The waiter stopped by to greet us and apologized for the wait. 'No need to apologize,' we said. 'It wasn't long.'  He explained that everything is served family style and he recommended sharing 6 things since it was two of us.

The menu is pretty diverse and totally interesting. They had a nice selection of vegetables, seafood, chicken, pork, beef and of course, goat. We studied the menu while he was gone and were ready to order when he showed up with complementary bread with smoke salmon mousse and pickled peppers because we had to wait beyond our reservation time. Wow! That was impressive that they take service that seriously. We ordered the rest of our meal and he would determine how to bring our and order the courses.

We were ready for refills on our cocktails so I got a martini and my dinner partner ordered Best of Three. We tucked into the bread and dip, and it was super. I haven't been eating a lot of bread because I've been watching carbs but it was so worth it.

Our first course showed up, which was the hamachi crudo. The crudo has a puffed black rice, which gave it a cool crunch. It also had pickled kumquats and a soy-chili vinaigrette, which added the right amount of kick. It was great.

Next up was roasted cauliflower and roasted shishito peppers that had Parmesan and miso...so yummy! The cauliflower was interesting too with mint and pickled peppers. I was already super full but we had two more things coming, so I had to muscle through.

Then came the goat empanadas. I have never had goat but felt compelled to try it since this place is known for it. The empanadas seemed like a good entry-level option. They were so good! The meat filling reminded me of pulled pork.

The final thing delivered was the crispy beef short rib. I was so full I could only try one bite. It was also good but my food coma was setting in, so maybe 25% of my tastebuds we're engaged. #regrettoofull

So glad I gave it one last try to get a reservation. This was definitely an experience and the food is something I won't forget.

pics.caption: Beverages. White Russian and Best of Three.

review.des:
I have long awaited to try one of Stephanie Izard's restaurants after watching her kill it on all the best cooking shows and WOW this was amazing!  Even on a Tuesday night, the was place was packed with a very long wait so we had to stake out the bar.  These were highly coveted seats and it still took over an hour to snag spots.

For 3 of us we had:
olive yu(zu) focaccia
pan fried shishito peppers
roasted cauliflower
hamachi crudo
pan-roasted bass
crispy beef short ribs
wood oven roasted pig face

Everything was soooo good!!!!  Melt in your mouth good!  The bread, baked fresh daily across the street at Little Goat Bakery, is a great way to start the meal.  Personal favorites amongst the dishes were crudo and bass.  The only dish I wouldn't order again is the cauliflower - it wasn't bad, but not as exciting as the rest.

Of course we had to have dessert.  We ordered the caramel corn & malt balls, and they treated us with a chocolate pavlova says-a-me on the house!  We could not have been happier with the desserts.  Both were outstanding and we happily left with full bellies!  Totally worth the wait and cost

This was one of the top restaurants on my list to try in Chicago. We had made reservations 2 months in advance.  The earliest time we could get on a Monday night was 8:45PM.  So book early if you guys plan to try this restaurant.

We started out with Goat Liver Mousse. I was hesitate at first to try it thinking it might be gamey but my bf convinced me it was good. Turned out he was right. Everything went well together. Next we had braised beef tongue. Nothing special. I wouldn't order this again. Crispy Beef short ribs and Goat Empanadas were good. My favorite dish was probably the Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face. That was delicious.  For dessert, we had the Caramel Corn & Malt Balls. It was pretty good. Service was on point.

Overall the restaurant was good but not as good as I thought it would be with all the reviews they have on Yelp.  Maybe I came in with too high of an expectation. Would I come back? I probably would if it was a special occasion.

Perfect dining experience. The server was very knowledgeable yet not intrusive in our experience at all. The food was outstanding. Every moment was phenomenal. I know Yelp likes longer reviews, there's simply no more to say: our experience was perfection.

The food here is the best. One of the most creative chefs ever. Stephanie Izard brings creativity and complexity to everything she makes. Nothing is disappointing here. Each dish amazes you more than the last one!

pics.caption: The food here is nothing short of amazing! Everything Stephanie Izard makes is complex and unique. The flavors all blend so well!

review.des:
Great food and ambiance. Appreciate that Chef Izard and her restaurant group provide great food at a price point attainable by us "common folk".

Get the pork shank and crispy duck tongue- must!
Also very accommodating staff, helped us with identifying foods to order that were safe for a food allergy in our party.

Must go, worth the wait.

All I'm saying is: "I went to see a girl about a goat and THE HYPE IS REAL!"

Okay, it's not all I'm saying. It's just the first thing I'm saying. Well, been wanting to go here for years, just haven't gotten around to it. Finally, I did today and it was everything I dreamt it would be.

Heard a lot about how it wasn't as good as it used to be and blah blah blah. But, how it is now...well, it's delicious. Side note: our server was amazing and I think it made the whole experience more enjoyable that he was nice and really took the time to talk with us. All his recommendations was up to par.

We picked the following plates: roasted beets salad, sautéed green beans, seared diver scallop, bucatini, and goat empanadas.

And everything was perfect...I mean, PERFECT. Wait, did I emphasized the P-E-R-F-E-C-T-I-O-N of each dish to the t.

The beets were roasted the way it should (my friend who I went with does not like beets, I told her that she just hasn't tried the right kind of beets because roasted well, beets are like candies, and this converted her into liking beets). Those anchovies and bread crumbs perfectly sprinkled the saltiness and crunch that countered the sweetness and softness of the beets.

The green beans were fabulous, the cashew and fish sauce vinaigrette...simplistically delicious. Fish sauce is somewhat a staple in the Asian cuisine, so I grew up with it used on my food, and to see them use it in a vinaigrette...genius!!!

The sweetness of the blood orange highlighted the saltiness of the scallops along with the touch of the pistachio crunch. Holy cow, party in the mouth, it just worked. Honestly, at first, I was confused by all the different flavors, but just give it a moment to register and it's quite a ride of complex flavor and texture experience. Mind-blown!

That bucatini...how perfectly cooked. There was a firmness to the bite of the noodle that you want and that flavor profile was so simple and magical. And the braised pork shoulder just melted.

And of course, you can't go without trying a goat dish. That goat empanada was pure heaven (at least what I envision heaven to be). That aioli was cracked out flavor...and what I mean by that is it probably has crack mixed with it because it's was sooo addicting, I would lick it off the chopping board it served on (you can judge me all you want, I'm snorting that sh** right then and there...that's how good it was). The empanada shell was fried flawlessly, it was flavorful by itself. Then, there's the goat...that majestic goat. It was not "gamey" as some goat tend to be when cooked wrongly. It was a texture of a good steak, but with that extra flavoring that you can only get from a goat. It was euphoria to eat such a dish. Plus, the apple and mushroom combo...just wow. This dish was the epic mic drop to the whole Girl and the Goat experience.

I was lucky enough to get a reservation for two last Wednesday evening at 6:00 pm. The place was packed as usual. I can't reiterate how much I love this place!

We started off with a cocktail made of gin, earl grey tea, fruit juices and other yummy delights (okay, I did not remember all of the ingredients) garnished with a caramelized orange slice. We ordered the beet salad (amazing!) and blue cheese pierogis. I am not a big fan of blue cheese, so these were more for my partner. We had the sea bass as a second course, and then the pork shank and pig face for our main dishes. Oh. My. Goodness!

The pig face is a classic but the pork shank is a must try. It is quite the portion! It is served with naan and some sauces, so I made and ate them like tacos!

For dessert, we each got one. I got the green tea ice cream on top of a black sesame pastry of sorts (had the consistency of a macaroon) filled with chocolate. It was quite good and may be a little too sweet for some. My partner had the sweet potato cake (again, I am not a fan of sweet potato).

Service was excellent as usual. Our server was helpful in recommending some of our dishes. Also the staff came around quite frequently to refill water and to switch out our plates after each course. Impressive!

Seriously had the best meal on our trip to Chicago! We showed up after the Bulls vs. Warriors game! Go WARRIORS!!! Didn't have to wait long at all! The cocktails were great! Service was wonderful and the food was delicious!!! The ambiance was great, I LOVED the open long kitchen! $14 for the cocktails were so worth it! You can tell some talent went into creating the cocktails list!! I appreciate that! (My boyfriend and I went to the John Hancock signature room and spent $18.50 on a Hennessy sidecar...no big deal-basic cocktail for almost $20!!!! Should have come here instead both nights for drinks!!) definitely will come back again on our next trip back! Thank you for the great meal!!!!

Fantastic meal! We booked last minute with Amex Platinum Concierge and were offered a special Amex 10 course tasting menu. After initially declining and asking for the regular menu, we were overwhelmed with decisions and decided to go with the tasting. It was delicious. There was not a course that we did not thoroughly enjoy. Highly recommended.

Enjoyed the lamb. This place is a staple and never fails to get the job done.

Service is good, food is better and really  a must go if you haven't been.

To begin, much how we began, the Maitre'ed is a prick and so full of himself it hurt. We were told a 2 hour wait, 3 hours later we were told "You're moving up the list." What does that mean exactly? Oh at least another 45 minutes or so.

We waited, if only to pull back the curtain on this magical oz.  as we were seated we Asked first 2 employees what they recommended - only to be told they had not eaten the food yet. They avoided all other questions until the well scripted waitress made her appearance...(oh wait - someone did say you won't be disappointed in anything... spoiler alert-
You'll be disappointed in everything).

We told her there was a mushroom allergy  and revieves separate  menu- told kitchen could not make any accommodations (appreciation to waitress  who admittedly went above and beyond to get a menu we could work with).

Now to food: we ordered the squash blossom crab Rangoon- props for lots of crab meat, points lost for it tasting like anything fried I could get anywhere; The halibut- sauce was you know, decent, the halibut was, you know, average and fishy and the broccoli (which inexplicably came last) which was bigger than both entrees we ordered...and btw it was burned.

Over all score: 2. Look there are tons of adorable and delicious places in close neighborhood (bad hunter, etc) with more pleasant people & more inventive food- fried lemons - yum!). This is simply
not worth the hype.  Glad everyone is orgasming over  this place - at the end of the day it's  2 stars for food - hard 0 for experience.  Come on down a few pegs guys- your food isn't nearly good enough for your attitude to last.

Girl & the Goat was recommended by every person I know that has visited Chicago and listed as one of the top restaurants on every travel guide I've looked at online! My thoughts: totally lived up to the hype!

MAKE A RESERVATION IN ADVANCE ON OPEN TABLE. Was told by the hostess that wait times can be up to 3 hours without a reservation!

Ambiance and service here was amazing. Modern, but cozy vibes inside. Perfect date night spot! I love that you can see into the kitchen. Interesting paintings of goats all over the walls.

Food: Dishes are tapas style meant for sharing. Our server recommended 2 dishes per person. Things I tried: hamachi crudo, pan roasted halibut, bucatini, and goat belly. I highly recommend you try all of these items! Amazing flavors in each dish. If you still have room for dessert, the chocolate pavlova says-a-me is great. Not too sweet, but hits the spot.

I'm typically not into splurging at American restaurants with small portions, but Girl & the Goat was worth it! May be one of the best restaurants I've been to yet. Flavors were absolutely amazing, and service was top notch!

That months in advance reservation and the high price tag are both worth it. Girl & the Goat is one of my top ten dinners of all time (which is why I proceeded to go to Stephanie Izard's other Chicago restaurants shortly after).

It was such a happy (despite the dim lighting) atmosphere- I think everyone was just relieved they finally got a reservation (!!!), but were also delighted by the food.

Food Highlights:
1. Cauliflower: Delicious, and complimentary?? They just plopped it down, without us asking for it but I'm not complaining!
2. WOOD OVEN ROASTED PIG FACE: A must. We ordered it because we were intrigued, but saw that every single table around us also ordered it so we'd made the right decision.
3. Caramel Corn and Malt Balls: I love popcorn and I love malt, and Stephanie's a genius for bringing together this beautiful pair.

It's hard to give a restaurant 5-starts after so much hype - the expectations are simply too high. But Girl & the Goat totally met those expectations - the food was simply delicious, non-pretentious, and elegant. We liked every dish we tried. The vibe was good, the surroundings were great.

The only negative was the service - I felt a real arrogance in the hostess/waiting staff (not everyone). I felt an attitude of "we're so damn good and popular that we can treat you however we want". I didn't like that.

Still, the food trumps all - 5-stars.

Stellar! Seriously from start to finish this place was fantastic. We came in with no reservation and the hosts were incredibly friendly and said they could seat us if we agreed to only dine for an hour and a half (perfect, done!). Owen was our server and he was so gracious and helpful the entire night. I came in with my two cousins who are legally blind and he was so patient with us but it wasn't just Owen, the entire wait staff was on point. The food, well what can I say that hasn't been said before...near 10s all the way across the board. The pork shank was my favorite. Will be back, thank you!

As mentioned by the majority, this place is booked up for months but my occasional OpenTable browsing finally paid off and I was able to snag a reservation for 2 at 6:15pm on a Wednesday.

Our server was super nice! He started off by explaining that the menu is categorized by type (fish, veggies, meat, etc.) instead of the usual appetizer, entree. He recommended 4 dishes for 2 to share and heres what we ordered:

Tempura Walleye - Fried Battered Fish 2.0!! Fresh, crispy and not greasy at all. The sauce was delicious. It tasted just like Vietnamese fish dipping sauce but the addition of gooseberries made it extra special

Mr. Sweet Potato bread - couldn't stop eating! Loved the fluffy texture and the savory cream cheese

Seared Scallops - every bite was wonderful and I ate every single thing on that friggin plate!

Confit Goat Belly - Mega flavorful goat belly topped with scrumptious lobster and crab - need I say more?  

Sticky Toffee Crunchy Cake - luscious texture and Im obsessed with the sour cream ice cream

Aw honey honey - (yep we ordered 2 desserts, dont judge) the sponge was alright but the honey mousse and whip were divine!

I dont know how to not abruptly end this review so I'm just gonna end it by saying, stop reading this review and get yourself a reservation! :)

Stephanie Izard is a GENIUS. Girl and the Goat is a must-visit for those of you who love big name chefs and/or downright affordable, yummy food. (If you've never heard of Chef Stephanie Izard, she was a former winner of Top Chef!)

I wasn't able to get a reservation the week I was visiting Chicago (so call at least 2-3 weeks in advance!) but decided to stop by as a walk-in customer anyway. For two people, the wait during dinner rush was 75 minutes. PASS. We opted to seat ourselves in the lounge area and order food from there. No wait is always a win-win for me~

We ordered:
-Roasted Cauliflower (3.5/5): it was good but nothing special. Definitely use your money on more unique items.
-Chickpea Fritter (4.5/5): quinoa tabbouleh, feta, and tahini vinaigrette. Oh my God. It was amazing. Good balance between tangy ingredients and more subtle accompaniments. I only wish the portion was a tad bit bigger.
-Duck Tongues (5/5): my favorite dish! Also includes tuna and black bean poke, crispy wontons, and piri piri sauce. This dish is all about contrasting textures - crunchiness from the wontons and duck tongue and tenderness from the poke!
-Crisp Braised Pork Shank (4/5): naan, squash-shiitake kimchi, and buttermilk dressing. Very tender and well made. I loved the kimchi and dressing, but overall expected a little more from the dish. Cauliflower excluded, the pork shank was the less "exciting" option compared to the fritter or duck tongue.

Overall, I love G&tG!!! Highly recommend this place for visitors to Chicago ^_^

pics.caption: Duck Tongue (my favorite dish of the night!)

review.des:
Finally got around to trying this place and it lives up pretty well to the hype. Service was knowledgeable and ambiance is more on the casual side with a high noise level.  

Started with the Pyramid Scheme cocktail which was delicious - recommend if you like smoky glenmorangie.
Hamachi crudo - pretty small portion, but it was really fresh and citrusy.
Goat liver mousse - loved this spread and thought everything tasted great together. Generous portion where you didn't have to think about rationing the mousse - very important.
Escargot ravioli - the pasta and the crispy onions were delicious, but the broth was on the salty side.

Would be interested coming back and trying more plates!

Congratulations to Stephanie Izard and her G&G crew on celebrating their 8th Anniversary.  

While it's difficult to describe something in any finer detail that hasn't been hashed over a few thousand times in previous reviews. I can only pile on with my remarks describing my experience.

There is an energy and excitement that emanates from that establishment. You can sure feel it from almost from the moment when you walk in. Almost like radioactivity, complete with the glowing when you leave, except in a good way!

The rustic wood interior is definitely the first impression that will strike you upon entry. Warm and inviting. The open kitchen along the back wall with the chefs working away behind it are an impressive vision.

The wait staff are in constant and frenetic motion & energy like bees in a giant hive. It is loud. Patrons are expressing their enjoyment of their experience and sharing it with their companions.

The food and how it's prepared & presented is also very unique as are the flavors & smells that accompany them. The eyes rolling back into your head kind of experience!

I would encourage you to go there to experience it, to 'get' what's going on there. Like trying to describe what it's like to be a parent to someone who's never had kids....except only the good parts about being a parent.

I have had the great privilege to enjoy a meal there twice in the past 2 years. Both experiences were very different each time. I hope to have the opportunity to again walk thru those doors once more in my life since I live in the SF Bay Area. I can hope to duplicate the previous positive food experience. We in the Bay Area got nothin' on G&G!

While most of the food courses are extremely gratifying, their desserts are just Off The Hook! You could easily try every dessert offered (I have!) and love every single one of them.

G&G is one of those 'Bucket List places that you'd be crazy to miss. You won't be disappointed.

Came only here for their desserts. Each dessert is $11. I got the Pavlova. It has ice cream, sesame whip, and chocolate. I thought it was really good. The shell is really sweet but the chocolate was bitter so it was a good balance. It has a black sesame flavor if you like that. It's good for two to three people.

I also tried the blueberry ice cream. That one was okay. It was like any other dessert.

Service was great! They're quick, attentive, and friendly.

I would come back again to try their dinner menu.

Officially obsessed after my first visit. Girl & The Goat lives up to all the hype + more. This spot is an absolute DIVINE experience & well worth the wait if you didn't make reservations (Tip: make reservations!).

Shared plates are the focus here, and we made sure to pick a variety of plates including the focaccia bread (the spread was unlike anything I've ever tasted before), Potato-blue cheese pierogis, goat-chorizo pizza scallops & Apple dessert to end with. I have no bad things to say about any of these dishes - they are meant to savor your taste pallet to the max. Service was attentive for the most part. The drink menu is also pretty vast as well.

TL;DR: GO HERE! There's a reason Girl & The Goat is considered one of the best spots in Chicago.

As hyped as it gets.

You ask for recommendations to go out and eat in Chicago, and of course, you'll get an earful about the ol girl & the goat. Girl & the goat this. Girl & the Goat that. But i've got to say, this spot is worth every penny for a mouthful of their food.

Easily the standouts which deserve honorary mentions:

1. Goat Liver Mousse - The bread that they provide along with this dish is absolutely spectacular... They were as fluffy as pancakes while the outside remained as crispy as a baguette fresh out the damn oven. You can literally slap anything onto this bread and it'll be good. The bread definitely made this dish... my god.

2. Seared Diver Scallops - The scallops are quality. They were cooked to perfection. How could anyone not?

3. Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face - I've had some dank lechon so I was not too crazy about this dish, but everyone absolutely raves about this one. It's most definitely worth ordering.

4. Crisp Braised Pork Shank - More fatty crispy pork to your face after having some pig face. I still thoroughly enjoyed this dish but it most certainly needed the sauce provided.

Now i'm going to be that guy.

That guy who is recommending the same overrated, yet highly deserving restaurant that others preach about. Thank you for brainwashing me with your culinary propaganda. I am a loyalist.

This is my first review of 2018 and I am so happy the timing worked out such that we had dinner at Girl and the Goat on New Year's Day!

First, a big and grateful shout out to Jake (or did I hear wrong and it's actually, Jay?)! He went above and beyond for our group. Some of those dining had very specific dietary restrictions. Jake literally takes out a pen and starts writing on the menu! He would scratch out dishes not viable for them and even note which ones could be modified. We were all amazed! He checked up on us very regularly and his recommendations were on point.

The service was great. Your glass doesn't stay half empty for long when it comes to water. They are watching it like a hawk. The food comes out piping hot and they replenish your table with clean plates very frequently.

The bathrooms are downstairs and are individual ones. I didn't ask if there is an elevator for those who may not be able to use the stairs but may be worth asking about.

The ambiance is kind of dark but it works.

The food is incredible. My favorites were both desserts ( see my pictures) which I give five stars as well as the skirt steak. The steak was succulent and bursting with flavor. I was amazed. Five stars for that steak! The pierogis are really good and I'm not usually a fan of blue cheese but you can hardly taste the blue cheese which was great for me. I give that 4.25 stars. Cauliflower 4 stars. Everything else between 3.5 to 4.0 stars.

All in all, a great experience. You need reservations way in advance so be sure to plan weeks to months in advance!

I finally had an excuse to try this popular restaurant when a friend from New York paid a sudden visit. It was Thursday dinner at 7pm, and there was an hour and a half of wait time for a table. We just hung around the bar with a cocktail since we had a lot to catch up anyway. About an hour later, we had seats on the bar and ordered food.

The food is pretty good here (surprise surprise). I enjoyed the scallops a lot (I wish there were more than 4 pieces of it though). The cauliflower was okay (a bit too salty). The fish dish was spectacular in visual and flavor. The goat loin was, well, interesting. And the dessert fine.

For the friendly and energetic vibe alone I'd be happy to come back.

I've returned a few more times for the Goat Leg Dinner and it's become a much anticipated event every couple years. The place has plenty of things going for it if you don't make that advance reservation, but I couldn't see myself going and not getting goat. It's an expensive experience, but it's so worth it. I've yet to find anything like it elsewhere.

We most recently made another reservation for a table of 6 at 7pm on a Wednesday night. This reservation was set up over a month ago, so plan ahead! It seemed emptier than previous visits, which I thought might mean the hype had died down. But the place was packed, per usual!

We split a bottle of Grenache wine and the server suggested we get a couple small plates to share. Naturally, we each ordered our own and then some. We got a few familiar dishes - Roasted Cauliflower (except it's changed a bit from the original recipe and I like both but prefer the original) and Pan Friend Shishito Peppers (same as it ever was, still a favorite!). Newer items to us were the Goat Liver Mouse (melt in your mouth good!), Grilled Cuttlefish (so good we ordered another round), and Duck Tongues (tasty).

The goat came and was a welcomed sight. Some might find it boring to have a predictable dinner, but I find comfort in knowing what to expect from this and still manage to be blown away each time. I was under the impression we got another 6 lbs, but our friend swears it was 14 lbs (and then I found myself trying to math it in my head by comparing its size to my little dog who is 9 lbs, and that's kind creepy... anyway, I think it might just be 14 lbs). There was more than enough for our group to get their fill and enough leftovers for each of us to bring a bit home.

Dessert could have very well have been the Pineapple Right Side Up cocktail that I ordered, but we threw caution to the wind and got one of each of the desserts on their current menu. The black sheep was the Cha Cha Cha Chocolate & Chorizo. It wasn't bad, just not the best. Everything else was perfection!

This review basically mirrors what I wrote in my first, but it's nice to keep people updated and let them know that after all these years they can still rely on Girl & the Goat to deliver and delicious, memory-making meal.

pics.caption: Yay For Gjetost, Caramel Corn & Malt Balls, Sticky Tasty Crunchy Toffee Yummy Cake, and Cha Cha Cha Chocolate & Chorizo.

review.des:
I'm not going to say much here because it's adding a drop in the ocean of good reviews they have. What I will say is that I came here for our anniversary dinner and we were treated very well even though we got a last minute reservation. The food was obviously quite good and I made sure to take plenty of photos and I think it's good to just let them speak for themselves.

I'll add that their house beer paired well with all the food options and they obviously work to make sure your entire experience is well worth it.

If I could give this place 10 out of 5 stars, I would. It was just THAT good.

When you walk in, the ambiance is cool and inviting. Modern and clean. Somewhat dark but not too dark.

Dress is nice but casual.

The dinner plates are small, so between 4 of  us, we ordered TWENTY things! We were super full and had some to take home, but each thing we ordered was amazing!

For "appetizers" we ordered the roasted beets - awesome! The Chickpea fritters - they tasted AMAZING but there were only two small fritters - not much food for the $15 price. Everyone raves about the green beans. My brother-in-law loved them, but I thought they tasted a little too salty from the fish oil or soy sauce. Plus, they had cashews and Im not a cashew fan. They were good but not great. We also ordered the pan fried peppers - really good!

For "entrees" we ordered the halibut - one of my favorite things of the night. It was a party in my mouth! Seared scallops - not a fan of scallops, I don't like the texture, but the food around it was good.

Pig face - uh-mazing! Like bacon and eggs but 120 times better!

Grilled chicken - fabulous! Pork shank - ooohhhh sooo good!
GOAT loin - first time I've ever had goat meat and it was amazing! I loved how it was prepared with a little tahini yogurt and delicious little pitas! YUM!!!! Seriously some of the best food I've ever tasted!!  You MUST go here!

Now I need to try her other restaurants!!!

What a creative menu, fabulous atmosphere, very good and friendly service! All in all a fantastic culinary experience! In the company of three lovely ladies I had the opportunity to try the broccoli, cauliflower, scallops, octopus, pork shank, Apple pierogi, and goat empanada, accompanied by a great malbec. For dessert, the honey sponge cake and the vanilla malt ice cream were delicious flavours to wrap up our dinner. Absolutely recommend and look forward to go back next time I visit Chicago.

As a huge Stephanie Izard fan, I had seriously hyped this restaurant up, and it didn't disappoint. It was definitely the best restaurant my friends and I ate at in Chicago.

The drinks were delicious and the food was even better. This restaurant is best for shared plates, so we tried a bunch of things. We had the calamari bruschetta, soft shell crab cake, lamb ribs, fresh focaccia, and 3 different deserts: the French toast one, the maltball and Carmel popcorn one (shown), and some chocolate hazelnut one-- all fantastic.

On top of the great food and drinks, our waiter was wonderful. Definitely would come again if I was back in Chicago!

Yum! This place is often packed - worth the wait as you can grab a glass of wine and enjoy the city atmosphere of good people enjoying great tastes. It is an opportune time to check out what others are ordering and savor the good service. Even on a busy night the staff are sure to notice and at least let you know what your wait might be if you are a walk in. Reservations are recommended, even if you call on the way you are likely to move up in the line quicker.

Things take time to come out yes, however it is a more relaxed way of enjoying the company you are with over a glass of wine before you dine. If you are in a rush for a meal and want service right after you order maybe it is not the spot for you... every place is different - if you're in a rush just stop in for wine and an appetizer at the bar, worth the visit at least once! For us we will be back!

This was one of the first restaurants I went to when moving to Chicago and I was amazed.

From the drink list to the service, everything was impeccable.

They have different sections of food, so a friend and I picked from every section. Wow it was a lot of food!

My favorite was definitely the Goat Empanadas and the Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face. It's a must try! The goat is very tender and flavorful. The pig face was a great combination with the sunny side up egg. Vegetable wise I would try the Roasted Cauliflower.

I definitely recommend going here and ordering to share for the table. It's fun to order many items and share with everyone.

Stephanie Izard is the best!

Went here back in August with my girlfriend after waiting 3 months for our reservation. It is definitely worth the 3 month wait! Every dish we tasted was better than the next. The staff is very friendly and helps you navigate the menu with ease. We split a total of 6 dishes and left feeling way too full but also very satisfied. Book a reservation now because you do not want to skip out on Girl & the Goat!

While visiting Chicago for the first time, friend had this place bookmarked. She said people have recommended this place to her as a must try.

I remember thinking, this place is good. Famous chef. But.. it's OK.
Nothing was exceptional. Portions were small. We had made reservations but was running late due to rain. They were nice about it and sat us down when we got there.

Decor was very pretty. Would be perfect for date night or girls night out.

Amazing, extraordinarily tasty food and a totally unique dining experience.

Yes, dishes here are a little pricey and you will most likely need to make a reservation at least a few days in advance to guarantee seating, but it's worth it.

My party was a total of three people and we previously had a 10pm reservation, but we got lucky and a 7:15pm spot opened up and we grabbed it right away. When we all arrived, we were seated right away.

The suggested way to order here is to choose a few dishes that you would like to share with your table and the servers will bring them out one at a time when they are ready.  We ordered the Sautéed Green Beans, Goat Empanadas, Seared Diver Scallops, Confit Goat Belly, and Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face.

Every single one of those dishes was bursting with incredible flavor -- the green beens had a delicious creamy, salty sauce that was paired deliciously with cashews. The goat empanadas were topped with goat cheese and mushrooms, which is a glorious combination in my opinion. The scallops had an extremely pleasant texture and had so many different flavors blended together -- salty scallops with sweet beets and a creamy sauce. The goat belly and pig face was extremely tender and juicy and just melted in your mouth. Unfortunately, I did not try any of the desserts, but I will definitely will next time!

I have never had service as incredible as the service I had received at Girl & the Goat. Even though the restaurant was completely packed, our server took the time to explain the most popular dishes from each of the menu categories and was very helpful with helping us decide what to order. She checked on us after the perfect amount of time went by (not too often, but also didn't completely ghost out on us). Other servers brought our dishes fairly quickly, were very attentive to refilling our water, and replaced our plates after each dish was brought out.

My dining experience here was extremely memorable and I know I will be coming back someday (hopefully soon).

BF: Where are we going for dinner tonight?
Me: You're going to be a goat!
Hashtag Girl & the Goat

People are not exaggerating when they say to make reservations months in advance, or get stuck with a 10pm slot (which I guess works well for people on Pacific time). Alternatively, I believe you can you can order off the regular menu if you snag a seat at the bar.

We arrived early and got drinks at the lounge area. Like the rest of the restaurant, the area was comfortably casual, service was prompt and friendly, and the cocktail menu was I-want-to-try-everything intriguing.

(++) I loved my LOCAL 75, which showcased Chicago's local specialties with Chicago Distilling Co. Ceres vodka and Chicago London dry gin infused with Asian-inspired flavors of black cardamom, yuzu, and lemongrass, with a finish of sparkling wine for good measure. The boo got the MORNING RITUAL with Creyente mezcal, Amaro Sfumato, Ancho Reyes, Chamargo de Chile, coffee bitters, vanilla, maple, lemon--as expected from the lengthy list of ingredients, it was thought-provoking and something you may Ernest Hemingway to drink before writing a novel. The $13 price tag is definitely justifiable considering the craftiness of the cocktails and the general classines of the whole Girl & the Goat schpeel.

(++) Our typical trick at fancy restaurants is to order the bread, because while it may seem overpriced, it is unlikely to disappoint and does a good job of filling you up amidst the rest of the dainty fine-dining-esque plates. The OLIVE FOCACCIA ($7) was indeed hearty and was on the artisan bread level with the asiago crusted exterior and pull-apart soft interior. The harissa butter was interesting but to me tasted too much like regular whipped butter, so I opted for the olive oil dip instead.

(+++) Though simple sounding, the SAUTEED GREEN BEANS ($12) lives up to its reputation. The beans themselves are fresh and sauteed to the perfect al dente texture, given a twist with the fish sauce vinaigrette, a crunch with the cashews, and a creaminess with the aioli. It's the homemade staple perfected to Chicago bucket list status.

(+++) The CONFIT GOAT BELLY ($16) was the most refined dish of the night, a delicate balance of melt-in-your-mouth goat belly (yes, it is similar to pork belly but more gamey), lobster and crab, and fennel, then glazed with bourbon butter. There is a lot going on and it takes awhile for it to all sink in. I suggest eating this dish in small bites in the true spirit of fine dining so that you can pick up on the complexities.

(+++) The CRISP BRAISED PORK SHANK ($26)... is huuuuggggee! I think the most amazing part is its texture, which was something of a gradient from a crispy roasty exterior to a buttery fall-off-the-bone interior. Although there was so much meat, it never got boring because of the heterogeneity of the meat and the DIY flavor options with the buttermilk dressing and curry sauce. The squash-shiitake kimchi kept things interesting as well with its provocative fermented tones, and the naan had a very thin texture with a puffy, doughy composition that reminded me of Taiwanese green onion pancakes. The touches of fusion seem a bit sporadic, but the creativity made it a memorable dining experience.

We were so stuffed (thanks to the bread and the giant pork shank) that unfortunately left had no room for dessert. Being the crazy Yelpy foodie that I am, I made sure we returned before leaving Chicago in order to try Girl &  the Goat's famous goat cheese dessert.

(+) The YAY FOR GJETOST ($11) featured the gjetost (goat cheese ice cream), which had a delicious full-bodied flavor. You could taste the cheese, though it wasn't pungent per se and it was heavily incorporated into a lusciously creamy ice cream. In my opinion, the focus shifted somewhat too much to the accompanying apple cake, and it was too sweet for my tastes with the candied almonds and ample caramel sauce.

(++) I preferred the STICKY TASTY CRUNCHY YUMMY TOFFEE CAKE ($11) (it's not as much of a hodgepodge as it sounds). The sweet potato based cake was unique and earthy, pairing well with tart gooseberries. Again, I think it was made too sweet with the toffee sauce, toffee crunch, and brown butterscotch ice cream (though deliciously indulgent).

Overall, we really enjoyed our visits to Girl & the Goat. The price is very reasonable, considering the quantity of quality food. The style is casual-trendy with stellar high-caliber cooking and a backdrop of a chic rustic ambiance--perfect for trying Stephanie Izard's genius cooking without the stuffiness of fine dining.

review.des:
A MUST in Chicago!! Definitely a unique menu that you won't really see anywhere else. Everything we ordered was delicious. Flavors were bold and went well together in every dish. I'm sure you can't go wrong with any of the menu items.
I didn't care for the family style seating (where they put you with strangers in a table if you have no reservations). So plan ahead!!

This place had so much hype , we had to check it out. The service was great, food was hit or miss. Not a large selection for a vegetarian but my friends, who happily ate goat, found one item to be good, another just ok, not really hype worthy...at least the food is photoworthy for instagram....we sampled a total of 5 dishes.

review.des:
If asked to choose my favorite restaurant in Chicago I would say this place. I've gone at least 5 times for various occasions since I moved here and I remember the first time I ate here...the food just kind of hit me differently than a lot of other restaurants try to but fail. I don't even have recommendations for you. Just grab your favorite bottle of Malbec or Cab and have fun with the menu. They'll switch up some dishes seasonally. It's a hot date place, has amazing cocktails for networking, or maybe you want to show off Chicago to a visitor/family? Yep, this is a good option. Just make sure to plan for the wait.

Stephanie Izard created this restaurant before she won Top Chef. This restaurant has to be the reason why. In a short time, it's a Chicago staple.

She has other restaurants -
Duck Duck Goat has a phenomenal atmosphere, but OK food in my opinion. Better for taking Instagram pictures than setting a memorable impression.

Little Goat is also OK. When people find the the line to this place to be 2 hours long I always hear lets go there instead. Same head chef, same food right? WRONG.

Again, plan ahead. Grab a cocktail nearby before dinner.

Girl & the Goat, for me, was the story of a Guy and a Gut ... because it just might be the best meal I've ever savored. Actually, it might be the best two meals I ever overindulged in because after eating and drinking enough for one meal at the bar, we moved to the dinner area and started all over again. By the time we rolled out into the Chicago chill, my gut had grown as much as my appreciation for a Girl & the Goat.

We tried several cocktails. My wife liked the "All Becomes One" or the "Best of Three", but the drink I returned to over and over again was the "Boondock Saints."

As my buzz grew, the stream of delights from the kitchen seemed endless including:

* Fresh Bread with Jam & Butter

* Pan-fried Shishito Peppers with Parmesan, Sesame, & Miso

* Goat Ribs with Smoked Apple-Potato Purée

* Crisp Braised Pork Shank with Buttermilk dressing & Squash-Shiitake Kimchi

* Braised Beef Tongue with Masa, Vinaigrette, & Salsa Verde

* Escargot Ravioli with Bacon Tamarind Sauce, Escarole & Celery

* Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face with Sunny Side Egg, Tamarind, Cilantro, & Potato Stix

* Duck Tongues with Tuna and Black Bean Poke, Wontons, & Piri Piri

* Caramel Corn and Malt Balls (Vanilla Malt Gelato) with Chocolate Magic Shell

For this guy and his girl ... and my growing gut ... the Girl & the Goat just might be the GOAT (Greatest of All Time).

What compelled me to visit Girl and the Goat (and Little Goat Diner) was honestly because I love watching food network, and finally realized it was one of Iron Chef Stephanie Izard's restaurants.

I think this is a great restaurant to visit as a bucket list restaurant, and I enjoyed my experience, but I don't know if I was impressed enough by the food to come again.

We didn't make reservations but managed to snag a high top table on a Friday night. It was a bit of an awkward process, since we were told we could grab whatever space was available, and the available space was between several groups, making us feel at first as if we were intruding. The restaurant itself is very nice. It can be intimate or a very sociable hub.

The menu is recommended for sharing. Our waiter recommended 4 or 5 dishes for a meal, but my boyfriend and I ordered 3 and were quite satisfied. 4 would have been a stretch and 5 would have definitely meant leftovers.

Hamachi Crudo: It wasn't my favorite. The Hamachi was cut a bit thick. There were very few and small pieces of pork belly on it (by few, I mean 4), and it honestly reminded me of diced, fried spam.

Duck Tongue: I've never had a poke bowl before. I've never really liked the idea of deconstructing sushi and taking the delicate-ness out of the dish. In this case however, the little bits of sashimi were actually quite refreshing and enjoyable, without being overbearingly raw and making me feel like a carnivore. The duck tongues were cooked perfectly. This was one of my favorite dishes. The flavors were complex but very complimentary.

Lamb? I don't remember the name of the dish. But, it was delicious and literally falling off the bone. I would have liked if there had been some spicy sauce available on the side. It was a great dish, but after several mouthfuls of meat, some transformative flavors midway could have elevated the dish even more.

Nothing more to add actually. Fellow yelpers got it right!

Psst....if you cannot find reservations, just show up at 5 pm sharp ;)

10 star service and food!

Highlight of the dinner nevertheless was the pig face! Everything coming off of a pig's face except for the brain! wood oven roast pig face, served perfect sunny side egg, tamarind, cilantro, red wine-maple and fried potato stix. amazing amazing amazing! Each bite put me to tears! This dish has millions of flavor yet complex in texture. I was quite full already when this dish was served and I still managed to lick the plate at the end! This is an amazing work I will come back for more!

Goat empanadas was awesome and I was allowed to order half order only, same as veggie dish.

Must must try!

Visited the windy city with the mindset of eating amazing food & this place did not disappoint.

Girl & the Goat gets packed and they have a full house every night so make sure you make a reservation ahead of time. I booked like a month before my visit and I ended up with a 4:45pm dinner on a Monday night, which seems crazy early for dinner but it was better than not having a reservation at all.

We ordered the following:
-Potato bread: A moderate sized bread round served with a red pepper sauce and a yogurt chive one. The yogurt chive one was my fave but if you mixed the two, you also get an amazing new sauce that the bread works really well with. The bread itself is pretty much a french with herbs and bits of potatoes in it. It was nice, soft and fluffy in the inside and crispy on the outside. We couldn't stop ourselves and ended up eating the whole loaf before our other dishes came.
5/5

-Branzino: Whole branzino fish bathed in a red fresno chile sauce, topped with a green papaya salad. The green papaya topping reminded me of the typical ginger slivers you find on a whole fish dish at your typical Chinese restaurant. The skin on the fish was nice and crispy. The sauce had a kick to it but it was not insanely spicy, worked really well with the fish. Loved that the fish was deboned but we did find some occasional bones towards the front of the head and the tail (our server had already warned us and we are no strangers to eating non-deboned whole fish)
5/5

-Crispy Pork Shank: This dish was amazing, the pork was so crispy on the outside, yet so tender on the inside. I was blown away when our server dropped off the dish and stabbed a fork into the middle of the shank, the fork literally melted into the meat as if it was butter on a warm loaf of bread... We snapped a couple of pictures and went straight to digging into it. The shank was served bone in. I lightly picked up the bone and the meat around the bone just fell off effortlessly. The dish is paired off with a kimchi sauce, a white light garlic sauce, a naan looking bread that tastes like a peking duck bun and some slivers of kimchied radish? This dish basically reminded me of a play on peking duck but with Korean fusion and with pork instead of duck.
5/5

-Bucatini: I wanted pasta so I got me some. The pasta itself was a little salty for my liking but all the flavors were there. The bucatini was cooked al dente and topped with tender pork shoulder and heirloom tomatoes. Super yummy, my husband killed most of it because he liked it so much.
5/5

-Toffee cake: Dessert cake made with sweet potatoes, topped with toffee, served with a butterscotch ice cream and some tart fruits. This dish was our least favorite. The savory dishes here definitely overshadows the sweet dishes here. We could've gone with it but we came so far and we had to at least try their desserts.
3/5

We had 5 dishes and our bill came out to be under $100! Will definitely be coming back next time we are in town to try their other yummy dishes! Highly recommend coming here!

I heard about Girl & the Goat a few years ago when I was many miles away from Chicago.

How?

I don't really remember. Foodie news travels far and wide, my friends. All I know is that Girl & the Goat has been on my foodie bucket list for a while now.

About a month ago, friends came for a visit and we all headed to Chicago for a night of Hamilton and foodie fun. We tried to get reservations at Girl & the Goat. But, it was not to be.

Little did I know, a month later opportunity would come a-knockin' and I would answer the door with eager taste buds and fork in hand.

As one does.

So, it was with a happy heart that I entered Girl & the Goat on an unusually warm December evening.

I was with a fantastic group of foodies who were game for trying a wide variety of dishes. Girl & the Goat is small plate, family style dining, so that worked well for our group.

Normally this is the portion of the program (ie: review) where I would provide you with the standout dishes. Those dishes that are so divine, they shine a little brighter than the rest.

The problem? Every dish Girl & the Goat serves shines brightly. I cannot possibly pick a favorite. From the chickpea fritters and potato blue cheese pierogies to the seared diver scallops and crisp braised pork shank--it was a swing and a hit, hit, hit.

We decided to finish off the evening with every dessert they serve.

Because, dessert.

They are all divine (chocolate chorizo--what?!?) and offered something for every taste (the salty/sweet combo lovers, chocolate lovers, etc).

It's a rare thing to have such an exemplary experience from beginning to end.

But, that is what you get at Girl & the Goat.

That was the most full I've been from a meal in a very long time.

And, it was completely worth it.

Get to it!
