review.des:
Wow. I will say I am typically never a fan of expensive small plates but Girl and the Goat was an exception. We were a group of 7 (definitely get reservations ahead of time) and ordered 17 dishes (waitress recommended 2-3 dishes per person but we like to eat). I'm not a big goat/lamb/meat in general fan so I'll give my take on my favorites but pretty much everything we ate was raves about.

From the breads section, get the sweet onion brioche. That relish is bomb and the salmon cream cheese was a subtle touch. I hate olives so the olive bread was not for me but if you like a strong olive flavor, check it out.

From the vegetarian section, I recommend the green beans, cauliflower, and pierogis. I absolutely hate it when restaurants make vegetables bland but this was not the case here. Everything was packed with flavor and had multiple components that somehow all worked beautifully together. Roasted cauliflower was the best from this section. Beet salad could be skipped.

I love seafood so I liked everything we tried from the fish section - calamari (be warned it's not fried), crab Rangoon, and halibut. The halibut has a nice sear to it and worked well with the mushrooms. The creamy squash in the rangoon was a creative and delicious twist. The bruschetta underneath the calamari was bomb.

From the meat section, the winner from everyone else at the table was the lamb ribs. The pork shank was tender and the naan was great if it came fresh from the oven. The pig face was like a breakfast dish and was ok, and the grilled chicken had a nice rub to it.

From the goats section, the goat empanadas were deemed alright. Apparently the meat was ok but the empanada shell was tasty. The goat belly was pretty meh and also took a while to come out of the kitchen so we were all pretty stuffed by the end.

What sets Girl and the Goat apart from the other expensive tapas style restaurants I typically hate is the service. Maybe it's because we were such a large and expensive party, but we got the olive bread on the house. When the goat belly took too long to get to our table, the waitress gave it to us free of charge. Then we had some issues with how hot the restaurant was (heat wave in Chicago today) and had asked the waitress if there was a way to cool it down (there wasn't but she brought lots of ice to us), she politely explained the situation and then gave us two free desserts on the house to make up for the heat. This is service I rarely see these days and I was very impressed. I will definitely be back the next time I'm in Chicago to try out the rest of the delicious menu

Honest review: (hit n miss) good food but not the best food I ever had prolly wouldn't come back due to the hassle of getting a seat (think if they were open even earlier it would make it less crowded they have to accommodate the crowd in some way make recommendations or come on a weekday at 4:30 u can sit at the bar or eat at the waiting area otherwise u will wait 2 hours (second time coming here first review still relevant because most of the dishes haven't changed since i been here so read both). Service: whenever there are more then 1 hostess beware for snotty bad service like why do u need 3 hostesses. The servers gave good recommendations they said the ingredients  they refilled ur water n they were so kind loved it but it gets kind of sluggish when it gets supper crowded and when they want u to leave. the best things were the duck tongues/ halibut/ beef tongue/  whole branzino/ pigface/ chickpea fritter/  empanada/  chocolate pavlova/ lemon cake
i think if they cut the menu down from like 4 pages to 1 n jus focused on like 12 dishes this restaurant would make better food n be more consistent like plz shorten the menu n update the menu the same things from like years ago are still on the menu wish the dishes she made on iron chef would be on the menu also fix desserts their basic in flavor

chickpea fritter chaat $15:  not the best chaat I ever had was expecting more spices but really tasty. The fritters were amazing supper crispy yet light just put more 2 wasn't enough their that good. The carrot humus was really good loved the sweetness wish there was a lil heat to off set it. Loved the pickles strawberries adds acidity my only complaint it needs salt so add capers or something salty

goat empanadas $16: i usually dont like empanadas because their not complex but this was really flavorful. The empanada was really crunchy and not greasy the aioli was really flavorful wish there was more. Loved the veggies on top for freshness my complaint is i wanted more blue cheese i love blue cheese n would have loved blue cheese on top
Instead of queso fresco im mexican n hate that cheese it has no flavor to it

calamari bruschetta $18: worst dish of the nite. Its a very bland dish and the goat cheese and calamari dont go together at all. The bread was amazing and the goat cheese was really good. The bacon was terrible because it wasnt crispy it was flabby and soggy like they boiled it. The green tomatoes didnt work at all dont know why it was there. its also hard to eat the dish very messy

Beef tongue $17 best dish of the nite. The salad on top with the sweet sauce was to die for put more. Then the beef tongue was tender and crispy. The salsa verde was really fresh like a pesto. Loved the pickled onions for acidity the issue was the masa their way to big and to thick  make them smaller

wood fired whole branzino $27: amazing fish was really crispy and seasoned just take out the gills plz thats like common knowledge n wish it was a more unique fish. The papaya salad is what makes the dish it adds so much flavor and texture. The broth is good just dont put to much tomato in it wish it was thicker to . If there was bread, rice or noodles would really bring everything together

Pig face $19 ( its like everything u want for breakfast all in one dish) amazing the pig face is supper crispy the fries add texture the maple syrup with the pork is the best combination the aioli is to die for. The egg was overcooked though and they dont put enough of the sauces it needs a lot of tje maple syrup and a lot of the aioli to make the dish work i would ask for extra maple syrup and aioli on the side

Goat neck $27 was good not great idk if it was the yogurt or the beans but that was the only thing with flavor the goat is tender but not flavorful just was expecting more

Chocolate pavlova $11: tasty its not to sweet the black sessame makes it taste like popcorn the meringue was crispy. If i had any complaints it would be to put a lil salt or chili for complexity. The desserts biggish so it does need more icecream

Lemon pound cake $11 amazing i dont like lemon or acidic food but this was really good. It wasnt to acidic which i loved the perfect balance of acidity and sweetness wish the cake was moister but loved the crispy sugar on top. The icecream was amazing but was to hard and not enough

review.des:
Overall, this was a great meal at an affordable price!

Started with the olive yuzu focaccia. Nothing kicks off a meal better than warm fluffy bread fresh out of the oven. The accompanying yuzu-harissa butter was amazing, and I probably applied more of it on the bread than I should have...

Next came the sauteed green beans with cashews. I am usually miff about ordering pure veggie dishes, but this dish was delicious. The beans were fresh, crunchy, and the portion is quite generous. It was a tad salty though.

I tried the confit goat belly next. It tasted great, but I wish the portion was bigger - it came out to one bite each for me and my friend. The other elements of the dish strangely tasted a bit sour? I also didn't think that the lobster and crab on the dish didn't really go with the goat taste...

Best dish of the meal was crisp braised pork shank. There is a LOT of meat, and it is falls right off the bone and melts in your mouth. The other elements of the dish are fantastic as well. It comes with some naan so you can make some pork tacos (hehe), buttermilk dressing, and some seriously tasty squash-shiitake kimchi.

Food was absolutely amazing. We started with the chick pea fritters and they were so light and tasty. The apple rye bread was fresh and the butter was fantastic. We moved onto the pig face but I dared to eat only one bite. It was good but the thought of it gave me the creeps. The pork shank was my favorite. Crisp on the outside and it fell apart on the inside. I would recommend it. Of course the waiter, who was super cool,  recommended the chocolate pavlova for dessert. I was so full from dinner I couldn't possibly eat dessert. But miraculously I ate it all. Great staff and awesome ambiance!

I heard of this restaurant when I first moved to Chicago 10 years ago, but it's always so booked up. Finally I found one reservation for tonight. Lots of people already told me how amazing this place is, so my expectation was quite high already.

Starter:
Onion brioche was warm and fluffy. The butter and jelly that come with it were both delicious. This is probably the best tasting bread i've ever had.

Goat empanadas was also delicious. Crispy empanada shell and the mushroom go very well with the meat filling.

Veggie:
Roasted broccoli was my favorite. It has rice crispy treats as the topping.

Entree:
Roasted pig face - sunny side up egg on top of the pig face meat... Pig face was super tender and melted in your mouth.

Dessert:
Caramel popcorn and malt balls - the popcorn adds texture to the dessert

Everything was super delicious and was gone within a min or two after it was served lol The meal was beyond my expectation. I'll definitely go back to try other dishes and hope it won't be too hard to reserve.

This is truly a 4.5 rather than a 4.

Girl & the Goat seemed like this legendary restaurant that was so hard to get a reservation for.  I made a reservation here months ago for a Friday night at 10:15pm (the best time I could get).  Considering how busy this place is, I had very high expectations.  I watched Stephanie Izzard on Top Chef years ago and was very excited to finally try her classic, legendary restaurant.  

When you walk in, you are greeted nicely by the hosts and it has a large, but cozy feel to it.  It was decorated for the holidays and I loved how tasteful they ornaments were.  It wasn't gaudy or corny, but really beautifully decorated.  The restaurant had a rustic feel to it but it wasn't trying too hard.

Our server was great - she was very easygoing, helpful, and not snobby at all.  The people taking the plates and refilling the water were very polite as well.  Sometimes when you go to more well-known restaurants in the West Loop, you can get pretentious vibes from the servers, but I did not feel that here at all.

Being a pescatarian, this place is pretty meat-heavy and a haven for goat-meat lovers.  Being a foodie though, this place had been on my bucket list for quite awhile.  They were accommodating with making some dishes vegetarian/pescatarian-friendly, which I really appreciate. We ordered a bunch of smaller plates for sharing.

We started out with the olive focaccia bread served with a yuzu-harissa butter and lime olive oil.  The olive pieces soaked up the lime olive oil flavors and the yuzu-harissa butter was unique and delightful.  I absolutely loved every second of this dish being an olive lover.  I don't see harissa on many "New American" menus so I appreciated the uniqueness of it.  

The second plate consisted of raw oysters served with a lemon mignonette.  The oysters were so fresh and some of the best tasting oysters I have ever had in Chicago.  The mignonette was a wonderful complement to the more intense oyster flavors.  The oysters were just the beginning of our adventures with seafood that night.

The grilled cuttlefish was also a unique assortment of flavors.  It was good but I wasn't taken by anything really.  I did really like the hot mustard and pistachio lemon relish.  The fingerling potatoes were a nice texture addition to the different texture of the cuttlefish pieces.  The cuttlefish had a really nice texture and was grilled, but had more of a subtle flavor.

My favorite dish of the night were the potato blue cheese pierogies.  If you knew me, you'd be surprised that this was my favorite dish because compared to the other dishes, the flavors weren't super unique, but it just all blended really well together and tasted delicious.  The blue cheese was a zesty, exciting flavor paired with the more mild potato flavor.  I really loved the maitake mushrooms served on top of the apple relish.  I am not super into apples but I really enjoyed the relish because it wasn't dominated by the apples.

We ordered the sautéed green beans as a side because the server had raved about them.  But I was kind of underwhelmed by them.  They were not super flavorful and were a bit bland for my tastes.  They weren't extremely bland but just not that great.  I did like the cashews but the fish sauce could have been stronger.

We ended our meal with the Calamari Bruschetta, which was also another highlight.  The calamari was sautéed perfectly and was served on top of the goat milk ricotta and apples.  It was not your typical bruschetta and I appreciated how creative of an approach this was.  I am not crazy about apples but the goat milk ricotta was heavenly.  
Unfortunately, we were too full for dessert because we had too many small plates.

I did really enjoy this experience but probably hyped it up too much in my head.  I think there are other restaurants in this echelon that have more options for me and have more exciting flavors.

Heard a lot about this restaurant, wanted to see the hype and here for a birthday celebration.

Service: 3.5/5 stars,
reservations @10p. I called around 5p to see if we could bump up the reservation to anythung earlier cause i know sometimes restaurants have last min cancellations. Lady on phone was not very friendly and sternly said "We are fully commited already". Waitress was nice but not available or visible when we actually needed her. Had to ask nearby waiter a few times.

Food: 3.5/5 stars
Basically overpriced tapas, small tiny plates and strong flavor. Don't come hungry.
Rioja wine - always get. Delicious
Duck tongues - delicious, loved the sauce and mixture, ingredients were fresh. Interesting.
Cauliflower- good but not amazing but overpriced $13.
Goat belly - tender meat, sauce was too sweet. True to size of 3 dominoes stacked flat on each other.
Grilled octopus - literally 6 tentacles smaller than a pinky & potato. More thick sauce
Rye bread - ok, butter ok
GuavA sorbet W/pickled mango- BEST THING

Overall: Food is interesting overall and tasty but extremely small and overpriced. Service needs some improvement. Try it just to check it out. I would not personally recommend nor return.

The attention to detail is astounding here. The food is made to pefection and arrived quickly. Presentation is surpassed only by flavor with everything in balance. The spirits list is hand picked and well thought out. Cocktails were delicious, especially the mezcal. This is a can't miss, come early if you're an out of towner.

Without a reservation, I was able to get a seat at the bar without waiting. The bartender was super nice and friendly - gave me a rundown on the menu, and advised that I order half-sized dishes, given that I was a lone diner.

Obviously, I completely forgot about this and ordered full-sized portions of everything.

What ensued was a meal of larger-than-expected portions. I quite literally ordered double what the lady beside me had ordered. While many people may cower in fear at the prospect of eating meals of this size, I took it as a challenge.

The meal was big but so was my appetite, and I proudly finished the meal without a crumb to waste.

Now: the food itself was solid. I ordered the sautéed green beans, chickpea fritter, scallops, and roasted pig face.

The first dish, the sautéed green beans, were a little saucy for my tastes. They also concerned me, since it was the first plate, and much larger than I had expected. The chickpea fritter was positively fantastic - crunchy and soft and seasoned perfectly. The roasted pig face was a joy, and mixing it up was as fun as the entire experience could be. The chickpea fritter and pig face wholeheartedly deserve 5 stars, while the other courses ranged between 3-4 stars.

The ambience was solid - but not so good to elevate this to a 5-Star restaurant, IMHO.

(Not pictured: the sautéed green beans)

I have heard so many great things about this place so I knew that I needed to fit it into our 3 day trip somehow. Reservations were already booked up once I tried looking a couple weeks ahead of time, but I read a lot of tips saying there was little to no wait for walk-ins. We arrived 10 minutes before opening on a Friday night just in case, and it paid off! The bar seating is first come first serve for those who do not have reservations. We sat front and center at the bar so service was really fast, we were done in an hour!

The menu consists of shared plates and you order everything in the beginning and then they will bring them out to you one by one, which I thought was a great system so you could focus on each dish by itself. We started with the hamachi crudo, light and refreshing and perfect for the hot sunny afternoon. Next was the goat empanadas, because why would you come here and not order goat?! I could tell the difference in taste from your typical beef or chicken, but it wasn't bad in any way, just unique. The blueberry salsa was probably my favorite part. Then we had the escargot ravioli. I would've never ordered this on my own but I'm glad that my boyfriend did! It's served in this bacon tamarind broth but it really reminded me of minestrone from its smell and color. I think the crispy onions were the perfect touch. Last but certainly the best item of the night, wood oven roasted pig face! It comes topped with a beautifully cooked egg and it was so tender you didn't even need a knife. The pork just melts in your mouth! I definitely recommend this dish to anyone who comes here!

The prices are steep but I can see why it's worth the money and the wait. The flavor combinations are so unique but they all worked so well together. This restaurant deserves more than 5 stars!

Great food, worth paying for.

Wound up going here when our original plan for dinner had a four hour wait. They sat us immediately, even without a reservation, and proceeded to take great care of us.

We had five dishes between three people for dinner, and that was plenty. Our server recommended two dishes per person, and we were skeptical but it was about right.

We had a vegetable, two fish dishes, and two meat entrees, all of which were delicious. I don't know how they got the lamb ribs so tender, with a nice crunchy crust - but it was incredible. Clearly my favorite, although my dinner companions preferred the softshell crab cake.

We did go on to order desert, and it's not every day I can find a pavlova. It was well executed, with a nice blend of slaty and sweet, and even a small crunch from the toppings.

Worth a trip, and I'd love to go back!

I'm usually quite skeptical of restaurants that have a lot of hype. When I learned that my husband made reservations at Girl & the Goat three months in advance (for our anniversary), I wasn't completely sold. But the day finally rolled around, so it was time to see what the hype was all about.

The restaurant is on the smaller side, with fairly dark styling and an open kitchen in the back. Between all of the conversation and the music, it is quite loud, but I didn't feel that it distracted from the experience. In fact, it lends itself well to the casual tapas-style dining.

We waited 15-20 minutes for our reserved table, which wasn't too bad for a bustling Saturday night at peak dinner hour. Our server was prompt and fairy attentive. She recommended 4-5 plates, so that's what we did.

We had the olive focaccia bread as a starter. I'm not a big bread person, but I thought it was pretty good (albeit a little on the dry side). It had a strong olive flavor. For the other plates, we did the hamachi crudo, pan-fried shishito peppers, braised beef tongue, and goat empanadas. Everything was very good. I liked the empanadas the best, with the shishito peppers a close second. For the price, the hamachi seemed a little on the skimpy side, but it was delicious... I don't think I'd order it again, though.

I felt myself getting full halfway through the goat empanadas (our last plate), so the server was spot-on with her ordering quantity suggestion.

All in all, I would say that Girl & the Goat came pretty close to living up to the hype. I really enjoyed the experience, and there's no denying that Stephanie Izard is a talented chef. Each dish was carefully thought out and executed well. I wouldn't walk in without a reservation and wait 3 hours for a table... but for a special occasion, this was worth the effort and price.

One more note: I'm probably the only person that noticed this, but I couldn't help but take note of the music being played - late '80s through mid-'90s alternative. My inner teenage self was going nuts that Beck's "Devil's Haircut" was playing in a nice restaurant! If you're a Gen-Xer, you'll enjoy the soundtrack.

I don't know if it was because I wasn't hungry, but I honestly do not understand the hype about this place. My friends and I made reservations for 9pm a few weeks in advanced and we ended up showing up at 6-7pm due to change in our plans. Luckily we just had to wait about 40 minutes to get seated for 4 people.

We tried roasted cauliflower, duck tongue, goat carpaccio, goat empanadas, scallops, and brussel sprouts. Honestly, nothing was really memorable. None of the dishes gave me a "wow thats delicious" as other Yelpers described. Actually, I take that back. I did not like the scallop dish at all because whatever sweet flavor they added to it left a really bitter after taste.  I also found it strange that the waitress mostly recommended the veggie tapas as the most popular.

At the end of the day, I was not impressed especially since the bill was pretty high.

This was probably my favorite dinner that I had in the few short days I spent in Chicago for Thanksgiving (even over Alinea!). My spouse and I had reservations for 10:15 PM, which is super late if you know me (my ideal bedtime is usually around 9:00 or 9:30 haha) but it was so worth it!

We were seated at the "chef's table", basically two seats at the counter in the back where we could see everything being made. It probably isn't for everyone (they checked with us to make sure it was okay), but we loved it! We saw them making the desserts and some other items and it just made the experience more memorable.

Our server was super helpful when we told her my dietary restrictions. She took a sharpie and crossed off the items that had ingredients I couldn't eat and wrote substitutions for ones that could be modified.

We had the goat empanadas, roasted cauliflower, and bucatini. The goat was cooked really nicely and had a great flavor in the empanada. I loved the cauliflower, which had the perfect consistency of just slightly crispy on the edges, cooked all the way through, but still firm in the middle (not soggy). The bucatini noodles were delicious and filling. They brought us a half order of malt balls with ice cream on the house, which was a super nice gesture. The stand out for me, though, in terms of food was the toffee cake! Soooo good! There were gooseberries which added a nice tang to it all, toffee bits all crunched up into it, and butterscotch cake. Yum!

I expected it to be on the pricey side, but it was worth it! I would be happy to pay it again to try more of the items next time I'm in Chicago (and/or when I'm not pregnant so I can eat more things).

pics.caption: Amazing amazing dessert with toffee cake, ice cream, and gooseberries

review.des:
6706 reviews, are you kidding me. The most reviewed restaurant in Chicago, and its not even close. #2 has 1145 less reviews (The Purple Pig). So whats with the hype for this place  which is one of the hardest tables to get.  A very popular chef with a huge following, and some pretty extraordinary flavors!
  Its  a small plate place, they recommend around 2 per person shared, we got 5 for the 3 of us and were the right kind of full, with drinks of course! I hate green beans, but the ones here are legit!! The Goat ribs and Sea Bass had a whole lotta flavor. I would pass on the beef tongue.
   Great looking place with some pretty nice vibes, service is top rate as expected. I would say it meets the hype, and will deff be coming back to eat alot more!

I've been here three times and while I enjoy some of the food the space is cramped and the loud music does not facilitate conversation.

The front lady who greets you is extremely unkind and impolite but the gentleman is pleasant and friendly!

Plenty of vegetarian options and I've tried all them of them and enjoyed them!

Highlights are:

Peppers
Pirogies
Fried chickpea
Cauliflower
Chocolate desert / shell

This was one of my wife and I's stops during our Thanksgiving vacation. I made plans a little late and was having trouble getting a good reservation time, so we settled for 10:15pm. My wife's bedtime is usually around 9:30pm, but she was so eager to check this place out she didn't even care about the late reservation time.

As we were closing in on our late reservation, we were both exhausted and almost bailed. It was cold, we spent the whole day at the Museum of Science and Industry, and we weren't terribly hungry. We made the decision to still check it out and was I glad that we did!

The restaurant didn't look terribly busy when we entered, but I would still highly suggest making reservations. We told the hostess we had reservations, she quickly found our names, then said something about a chef's table. I wasn't really sure what she was talking about, so I just said sure that's fine. To my surprise, we were seated on two high chairs facing the kitchen, watching the chef's prepare the food! Score! This was so fun, as we got to see the chefs interact with the servers and all the different plates that were going out.

For dinner we ordered the following: goat empanadas, roasted cauliflower, and bucatini. All the dishes were spectacular, my favorite being the bucatini. I really wasn't expecting much from this dish, it was a spaghetti like pasta, with milk braised pork shoulder, and heirloom tomatoes. Sounded pretty plain, BUT this dish made my eyes light up! Wow, everything was cooked to perfection, and tasted incredible!

Though we were stuffed, we still decided to go for the desserts. We ordered the sticky tasty crunchy toffee yummy cake (yes that's the name), and we got a small order of caramel corn and malt balls on the house! My favorite was the one with the yummy cake. The combination was so interesting but worked so well, sweet potato cake with butterscotch ice cream, gooseberries, and toffee? Really delicious, I would definitely order this for dessert again.

The meal was a little on the pricey side, but if you are in the mood to treat yo' self, check this place out. It is so worth it! Make a reservation though.

Went on a Thursday night.... full house... there was no wait, 7:30 reservation. I went with my husband and my father. Excellent service... our waiter suggested 5-6 plates, so we did 6
They came out in this order..

Steam mussels....  good but not enough bread to deep in the broth

Scallops .... They melted like butter, my only complain would be the price .... it came with only two scallops

Goat empanas- VERY GOOD... plate came with two small size empanadas ... :( Would I order them again, yes, but pricey for the amount of food you are getting!

Lamb ribs- too gamey

Pig face- the dish I was looking forward to and guess what I Would NOT order it again! Is a breakfast meal... one egg on top of two pieces of thick bacon... nothing special about it... just go to Wildberry Cafe and you'll get a better dish and more filling for the same price

Pork Shank- WE LOVED, but were too full to finish it, since it was the last dish to come out. $29

I order a cocktail ... best of three... very good, but pricey $14

6 small dishes except for the pork shank, one cocktail $150 plus gratuity...

I don't think I will return anytime soon. We loved three dishes (shank, mussels and empanadas), liked the other, and could careless about the pig face and the lamb ribs. The restaurant is nice but loud (expected) ...  I would skip the pig face 4 sure, don't understand the hype behind it ... service was excellent!

The food is so well done. This is kind of place where you order one thing and feel full all day. They are helpful and accommodating of folks who have celiac disease. I only wish they had more vegetarian or vegan options.

I'm not sure if this place is overhyped or I didn't order the right dishes. I thought it was good food but didn't really understand why people go so crazy over this restaurant.

Sautéed green beans - We got these because we wanted veggies to balance out the other stuff and people hyped them up on Yelp. Don't get these, I've had better green beans in Chinese restaurants. They were too salty for me. There are other things on the menu way better than this.

Duck tongue with tuna and black bean poke - This was my favorite dish because it was unique! The duck tongues come in small fried slices and to me, they have the texture of innards (like stomach) but instead of being really chewy, they melt in your mouth. I liked this dish but then again, I like the weird stuff.

Seared diver scallops - A close second to the duck tongue. These were really tender and the sauce they used with beets was really different from what is usually paired with scallops. This dish was delicious but they only give you two scallops.

Confit goat belly - Pretty tasty and it comes with big chunks of lobster and crab. I enjoyed it because I rarely eat goat or lobster. It was good but not the star of the show in my opinion.

Apple pie ice cream dessert - I'm not usually a fan of sweet and savory but I tried this because the waiter recommended it and it sounded different than your normal dessert. I didn't enjoy this dish very much - the saltiness overpowered the other flavors. Next time, I would try a different dessert!

Between my friend and I, the meal (including a glass of wine each) came out to around $60 a person. The price is to be expected from a famous place like this but I left wondering if what I ordered was worth the price.

Our hotel got us reservations for a Tuesday at 4:45pm which was the best we could get for only being in Chicago a week to film one of the Chicago shows. We arrived a little late bc our Uber took the wrong exit but still seated promptly upon arrival. The row of 2 top tables are very close together and the table has to be pulled out just to get in. The waitress was very knowledgeable and we are vegetarians so it makes ordering pretty limited yet easy. All the food came out super quick almost too quick and at first I felt rushed but then it slowed down a bit and I didn't feel that anymore. We had the Mr. Sweet Potato bread w a cream cheese spread that was delicious. Next up was the chick pea fritters w hummus - there's only 2 cubes of fritters so beware these are really good but there's only 2!! Then we had a the salad which was nice to share and lastly the broccoli dish which was our favorite and a larger portion! Dessert menu was hard to choose bc everything sounded great but we went w most popular malt balls and caramel corn! Yum!
A few notes about service: it's top notch! The manager stopped by twice to check on us and he was from CA like we were so we chatted a long time about how they are opening one up in the arts district in LA.
The waitress knew we were disappointed w the size of the fritters so she "found" one more for us and brought it out compliments of the chef. It was very unexpected and very nice' it actually turned the night around for us!

We get the hype - it's the total package! Service. Ambiance, delicious food choices for all!
It's the real deal and you need to check it out!

pics.caption: The chick pea fritter (you get 2 cubes)
The malt balls and caramel corn

review.des: This place is everything you think it would be. It's beyond delicious! My friend and I went for our birthdays without a reservation and were seated right away because we were willing to sit outside by the fire. The food came out quickly and they pieced it together so it came out lite to heavy. They gave us both a birthday surprise at the end and the bill was cheaper then we expected. Not an everyday kind of restaurant, but an experience restaurant. You have to try it at least once.

Just WOW. This was one epic meal, and at a VERY reasonable price. My friend and I ordered 6 plates, plus two desserts. The final bill was far less than expected.

The food blew me away. The flavor profiles and design were stunning. Arctic Char, Pig Face, and Lamb Ribs were the stars, but every plate of food makes you savor every single bite. It's that good. This meal was one for the ages.

Service was impeccable, and the atmosphere was very welcoming.

I cannot properly put into words how much I enjoyed this meal. I cannot wait to return, when I go back to Chicago.

We went on an off day and we were able to get a walk in reservation with minimal wait. We were surprised to get in as early as we did since there is so much hype surrounding the place.  All in all the food was average, I was expecting something better because of the name recognition but was disappointed with the flavors in the end. I felt that they were trying to include too many flavor profiles in the food. The ambiance and the service was outstanding! Maybe we just tried the wrong dishes when went. We plan on going back and giving another chance when we are back in the neighborhood.

Easily one of my top places to go to in Chicago. The food is so well thought out. Every flavor in each dish comes together perfectly so an amazing tapas-esque meal. You definitely need to try the pig's face if you eat meat. It sounds strange, but it will be one of the most tender and flavorful dishes you ever eat.

Is it really worth the wait ?
Really depends on what you wanted to experience. I made my reservation two months in advance. The presentations of the food is spot-on. Not too sure about the flavor profile presented in one or two dishes here. Maybe it's just me who has rather a peasant's taste buds, the dish hamachi crudo doesn't seem to click with me. Despite that, braised beef tongue, duck tongues , goat empanadas were really good. The dessert,, "Aw, honey honey", was standard.

To me, the definition of good food is something that makes you crave, a good restaurant is a place that makes good food that keeps you wanting to go back, it's clean, fresh , healthy but doesn't have to be fancy. Unfortunately, Girl and the Goat is not that place for me. But overall, it's a really good yet interesting experience. If I have friends coming to visit again, I'll take them to Girl and the Goat.

So happy to be able to dine here! We worried we wouldnt have the chance while in Chicago for the weekend.

*Tip: if you arent able to get a reservation arrive around 4 (30 mins before opening) to get a table. Downside is early dinner but im sure youll be hungry with all the walking.

We were seated in front of the kitchen for a great view while we eat. Our server came to us  immediately with a huge smile, explained the menu- sectioned by vegetable, seafood, and meat dishes, and took our drink orders.

We ordered 4 dishes, a dessert, and a drink.

1. Green beans: cooked in a fish sauce melted in mouth. It was fantastic. So much flavor yet still had their fresh and crispness.

2. Scallops: sauteed in a coconut suace had a perfect creamyness to it.

3. Skirt steak: cooked to perfection and topped with a light pickled  veggie. It was delicious.

4. Goat ribs: topped with a yogurt cream, was good but a little gamey for my taste.

5. Caramel popcorn and chocolate covered ice cream: perfect way to end dinner. It was the perfect sweetness and offered many flavors with the crunchy caramel popcorn the hardened chocolate and delicious ice cream.

The manager came over to see how our experience was and made some recommendation for our evening out on the town after dinner.

The best was that this place is affordable. The quality and service surpasses a price tag. They really do go above and beyond.

Truely a pleasure dining here, had a great experience and would recommend it to anyone in town!

I get it. The food is cool and different and tasty but super heavy but hey, it's Stephanie's world and we love it.
I find the service very rushed. At these prices one should be allowed to be leisurely. I felt hustled. My friend and I were celebrating and the whole meal lasted 45 minutes. So much for festivity!
More on the food: the menu doesn't change too often. I love the breads. The rest of the food is fatty, heavy and tasty!
I felt not so good after from the rich food.
Cocktails are very fresh and clean, so there's that!

Love this part of town
Great spot to be there at 6pm and sit at the bar.
Love the low lamps and ambience

For my 2nd trip to Chicago, reservations were made months prior for me to eat at Girl & The Goat. From what I've heard... it's hard to get a seat without reservations - especially since the owner won Iron Chef. I was excited to try it even more due to the popularity and status of this restaurant.

Our server gave us great recommendations for what to order because it was all our first times. Girl & The Goat is known for their variety of exquisite small plates, so it's best to share with others... which was perfect because we wanted to try everything!

[B]READS
Sweet 'n spicy brioche $5 | honey sambal butter, spring lamby jam

[G]OATS
Goat empanadas $16 | avocado smash, grilled pineapple-blueberry salsa, queso fresco

[V]EGETABLE
Sauteed green beans $12 | fish sauce vinaigrette, cashews

[F]ISH
Seared diver scallops $18 | english pea-quinoa "tabbouleh", tahini vinaigrette, chinese sausage

Pan roasted halibut $19 | marcona almond butter, white asparagus, blueberry nuoc cham

[M]EAT
Wood oven roasted pig face $19 | sunny side egg, tamarind, cilantro, red wine-maple, potato stix

Crisp braised pork shank $26 | buttermilk dressing, stone fruit kimchi, naan

When the last of our food (the MEATS) arrived... my boyfriend, his sister and I realized that maybe we might have ordered 1-2 plates too many because our stomachs were becoming full. We underestimated their small plates and portions. We could have passed on the bread and perhaps something else. I also did not care for the empanadas. The halibut was delicious, but I like seafood dishes in general so this might be biased. My FAVS were definitely the green beans, scallops and pig face. Would highly recommend those. If my stomach had more room, I think I would have enjoyed the pork shank more.

After dining here, I can see what all the hype is about. Great service and food. Now that I've experienced it once...if we do come back as a group we know what to order. I made a list specifically of things I want to try next and my favorites. Now we can limit ourselves to fewer plates and not get stuffed too fast!

Disturbingly good
You know when you have a bite of something that is on a different level? Like you get punched in the face. The world freezes for a second. "That was really good. How is it that good? What is going on? Where am i? What is the meaning of life."

Come back to earth, new dish, repeat. Same thing for 10 different dishes. No drugs involved. It is exhausting. I want to cry. I need to eat overcooked pasta with Ragu for a month.

I love a good small plates place, it's so exciting to see which will come out first! Fried polenta, cheesy shishito peppers, goat carpaccio, empanadas, bone marrow, what will it be?! All of the dishes we tried were unique and exceptional. Between 4 people, I think we shared about 7-8 total plates. Each dish provided enough food for a decent tasting, though some items were so good I could have definitely gone for more. We didn't leave feeling stuffed, but were satisfied.  Without drinks, our bill with tip was around $200.

Definitely make reservations ahead of time if you want to dine during traditional dinner hours. You can probably get a last minute reservation if you don't mind eating dinner at 4pm. We reserved a table about 6 weeks in advanced and the only slot available for Saturday was a 9pm. When we showed up the place was super packed and bumpin'! We were seated immediately and our waitress was extremely helpful and did not hesitate to answer any questions. If you're planning a trip to Chicago, make a reservation to see what all the fuss is about, you won't regret it!

Make a reservation and be ready to sit extremely close to your neighbors and have good conversations.

Price: About $120 for 2 drinks, 2 apps, and 2 main dishes.

Food:
Roasted Cauliflower - I really enjoyed this. It was flavorful with a nice crunch
Grilled baby octopus - Tender and tasty.. not too saucy.
Kohlrabi salad - not bad, could live without.
Pan roasted sea bass - you can never go wrong with sea bass.
Goat ribs - A little too salty, but other than that, tasty.

Service: Good.

Honestly, there is so much more on the menu that I want to try. This place is definitely one that I will return to.

There's no surprise that this restaurant has 4.5 stars with 7000+ reviews. Every time a friend of mine asks for a recommendation in Chicago, I will point them to the Girl and the Goat. Absolutely delicious food! I still dream about the bone marrow I had here. The ambiance is sophisticated and the service is very welcoming. They are open to any questions you may have with their food or drinks and can also help you make suggestions with your choices. You definitely want to make a reservation as they are booked weeks if not months in advance. This was definitely a highlight for me when I came to visit Chicago. I would definitely put this on your itinerary if you're even just thinking about it!

I was so excited for GATG. I'm not sure if it was the build up of a 3 month wait for a table, but I was not "wow-ed" as I expected. The flavors of the food, while interesting, was not a stand out to me.

We started off with the Mr. Potato Bread: the bread was fluffy and freshly baked. I was a big fan of the chipotle butter. The yogurt spread, while tasty wasn't anything completely amazing.

Goat Carpaccio: This was an interesting take on goat. The roe on it was also interesting. You could taste some of the gaminess of the goat. One of the more interesting and unique dishes.

The Squid Bruschetta: I think our mistake may have been ordering this along with the bread. This is heavier than the term bruschetta may lead you to believe. The squid had a dark sweet flavor. While the squid was well cooked and made a good compliment on top of the bread, this dish was almost too heavy.

Pig Face: Again I'm not sure if expectation was the enemy here. The pieces of pork were crispy with a sunny side up egg on top. It was reminiscent of a hash. Again it's a heavier dish.

I think there were notes of brightness I was missing in the heavier dishes. Overall the dishes were good, but I was more expecting mind blowing flavors. In addition to the food the service was mixed for us. The bar tender was attentive and clearly passionate about his beer. The server however made us feel rushed. She seemed like she couldn't wait to get use to leave and brought us the check before we even finished our meal.

I'd definitely want to try to come again, maybe strategize better with our ordering (?). Good restaurant, but I don't know if its a 3 month wait restaurant.
Malt ball ice cream was AMAZING. Great atmosphere and fun tapas. Make reservation waaayyy in advanced!!

My husband and I tried our luck without a reservation on Halloween Saturday (props on the flawless execution of Dumbledore and Umbridge!) to celebrate our 3 year anniversary-- after a 40 minute wait we snagged a couple corner seats at the large community tables in the lounge area. We ordered a couple beers, 6 small plates, a dessert and an espresso. Bill was $132 and worth every penny!

Experience, ambiance, surrounding people and guests, service, support staff, restrooms, even the Harry Potter theme for some of the staff costumes-- this place is wonderful before the food even enters into the equation!

We ordered: smoked apple pierogis, sweet potato bread, goat empanadas, mussels, beef tongue, and pig face. Sweet potato cake and sour cream ice cream for dessert.

Dark Matter espresso was served with integrity, piping hot and with some delicious crema intact by the time it reached our table.

10/10 across the board.

This place is phenomenal! Enjoyed it the first time I came to chicago and enjoyed it even more the second the time! Everything is literal perfection, from the service to the food. Service is beyond exceptional. The style of serving is family style, meaning each dish is meant to be shared. The food comes out whenever it's done. When the food runner brings your food, he tells you everything that's in the dish. When you're finished, he immediately takes your plate away. It's the small details that you appreciate, especially when ordering a lot of food. The food itself is so delicious, and presentation is on point. Their food choices may be something you're not used to eating, but I feel like that makes the experience more worthwhile. My personal favorites were the pig face, pork shoulder, and goat belly! Don't be afraid to expand your tastebuds!

pics.caption: Wood oven roasted pig face: $16 A MUST

review.des: I'd say more of a 3&1/2.... The atmosphere was great- and the two ladies who sat next to us were the best part of the meal. They were wonderful and sitting 1 ft. Away from us. The server was okay- my boyfriend said he didn't like tomatoes and then asked about a few different dishes and then recommended one that he chose and when it arrived it was draped with tomatoes. :/ little disappointed by that...

Every travel guide notes that no visit to Chicago is complete without a meal at Girl and the Goat, and it's easy to see what the hype is about.
Dinner reservations should be made ahead of time, and make sure to arrive with your whole party to be seated together. All meals are served tapas style and designed to be shared, and with a wide selection of vegetarian, seafood and other meat options, there is something for everyone.
The goat courses are the highlight dishes for sure. I don't eat goat often, but from experience have found that they can suffer from being too gamey. Our waiter made some welcome suggestions, and I highly enjoyed the goat empanadas. The wood fired lamb ribs were delicious as well.
As the titular first restaurant of Stephanie Izard's Goat restaurant series, and one of the staples on Randolph Street, it's worth coming for at least one meal.

I had been there a few times, but it was my girlfriends first time. They were cool about switching our table from a communal spot to our own table. I also like sitting at the bar in the back that is overlooking the kitchen. Every dish we had was great. The kohlrabi salad and the beet salad are both refreshing. The oysters were good but could have been colder. The hamachi dish was different. There was some crunchy things in there that reminded me of a cereal from my childhood. I think it was Super Golden Crisp. The squash blossom Rangoon was probably the most creative dish. It was everything the traditional crab rangoon is but the squash blossom added even more to it. The goat loin was delicious. Not a big dish though. U can't go wrong with any of the cocktails either.

pics.caption: Hamachi crudo with Super Golden Crisp

review.des:
This place is fantastic.  Believe the hype.  Even on random weekdays, this place is packed.  Dishes are unique to the restaurant and packed with curious ingredients and interesting flavors.  

Don't skip the branzino or pig face - excellent dishes.

Closer to 4 1/2 stars--this place is exceptional, and absolutely worth the hype! There were some tiny missteps with food, but the service, atmosphere and overall quality did not go unnoticed.

First and foremost, this was some of the best, non-fussy service I've ever experienced. We had a very knowledgeable, friendly server; she kept our water and wine glasses filled. (We ordered a bottle of white, which was kept on ice throughout the meal--nice touch!)

The cadence of the meal was perfection! Usually with small plates, you get a hodgepodge of whatever comes out of the kitchen first. This felt like we got a staged, 5-course meal of small plates, one right after another, with courses cleared in between. Small details, but they certainly enhance the experience of the meal.

The food! Our first "course" was the sweet onion bread, which came with a salmon cream cheese and pickle relish. The bread was excellent--you could taste the onion in the bread. The salmon cream cheese was really really subtle; my friend is a huge smoked salmon fan, and she couldn't really taste it. I personally loved the subtlety; it was like putting lobster butter on bread. The pickle relish was great, too! It added a nice tang and spice to the dish.

The goat empanadas are really yummy! The empanada itself is good, but not exceptional...but I did like what came with it; the addition of pineapple and blueberry was surprising, but it worked SOOO well! Very tasty!

Then came the pan-fried shishito peppers. A good dish! I wouldn't have ever thought to combine parmesan cheese and miso, but it worked! There was a bit too much of the cheese for our liking, but the peppers were nicely cooked and it was unique combination of flavors!

Then we had the escargot ravioli, which was one of our least favorite dishes. The broth was rich, but the bacon made it too salty; it tasted like it had been over-reduced. It also had an unpleasant sour flavor. Pasta of the ravioli was nicely-cooked!

The highlight was the pig face--it was like breakfast for dinner on a plate. The egg was a tad overcooked, but the crispy pig face was really good, and the subtle taste of maple was really yummy. And the potato stix gave it a nice salty crunch. Highly highly recommend!

We also got dessert. We tried the caramel corn and malt balls, and as a thank you from the kitchen, they gave us a small tasting portion of the lemon pound cake. (Very nice touch!)

The caramel corn and malt ball dish is suuuuuuuper sweet and very rich. I only had a couple bites. The caramel corn is very good, but the malt cream was a bit too rich. It also came with some sort of salty, chewy, taffy-like candies(?) which made it a few ingredients too many. Decent dessert, but a bit decadent.

I devoured the lemon pound cake! It was super light and tasty; the ice cream it came with was perfection! We thought it was avocado, but apparently it's a sorrel ice cream! It gave it a really nice fresh kick to the dish--highly highly recommend!

Overall, top notch service, great food, and for the amount of food we got plus a bottle of wine, for the quality, the price tag was not as bad as we expected!

Still a special occasion place, but worth the visit and the hype!

My husband and I arrived early before they opened hoping to get a seat at the bar because we didn't have reservations. We ended up getting the best seats in the house! We had front row seats overlooking all of the chefs hard at work. The kitchen runs like a well oiled machine and Executive Iron Chef Izard inspects every plate before it is served. The chefs were working hard and having fun and it was an incredible experience.

The food we ordered was fresh, flavorful and unique. We ordered Goat Empanadas that had the perfect balance between moist savory meat and golden brown perfectly cooked dough. The pineapple salsa provided the refreshing citrus counterbalance.

The wood fire grilled broccoli with bleu cheese was to die for! It paired perfectly with Peter Piper Bread with  honey poblano butter and pickle relish.

The service was fantastic and friendly. Our server Jake was very thoughtful to point out everything that had shellfish in it because of my allergy. My husband loved the Bronzino. He said the skin was perfectly crisp and shrimp broth it was served in was so good it could stand alone as a soup.

The Goat Satay I ordered was upscale Gyro flavors with Tzatziki sauce.  The goat had the same texture as what you'd expect from perfectly done lamb on a spit.

Overall, Iron Chef Izard & the Goat exceeded our high expectations!

This restaurant 100% lives up to the hype. I waited months to come here and it was worth the wait! It is a family style menu so you order a bunch of dishes to share. I think the goat empanadas were a highlight for me, mainly because I was nervous to eat goat and it ended up being one of the most delicious things I've ever had. Every single dish was a knock out though!

When my friends and I decided to take a trip to Chicago, we made sure to make a reservation at Girl & the Goat. I'm so glad we did. We came about 15 minutes before our reservation, but still got seated right away, which was amazing. We decided to order 5 dishes for 3 people and that was more than enough especially because we'd been eating the whole day.

Roasted Cauliflower: this was a great dish to start off with. It was light and flavorful. I couldn't stop eating it.

Skuna Bay Salmon: one of the most amazing salmon dishes I have ever had. I thought it would be weird putting strawberries with salmon, but it was actually good. The strawberry balanced out the fattiness of the salmon. There is a little kick of heat, which made me want more.

Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face: my favorite dish of all! The pig face just melted in my mouth. The sauces balanced out the saltiness of the pig face and together, it's just amazing. I wanted to order another one.

Crisp Braised Pork Shank: ordered this based on the reviews on yelp. I actually was not a fan of the pork shank. Alone, the pork shank didn't have enough flavor, big paired with the sauces, it was good. The dish is also served with naan, and everything together was pretty good.

Goat Belly: this dish was very small. I actually didn't even know where the belly was because it was covered by onions and greens. The goat belly is also served with lobster. It was so small that I wasn't sure what I was tasting, but it was still delicious.

All their dishes weren't heavy and I would definitely recommend trying all of the dishes I ordered.

Just as amazing as the first time I visited 5 years ago. I've been one other time too, with a large group, and everyone ordered their own meal which is really NOT the way to go. It's much more fun to share and try out different dishes on the menu.
This time around, I came with 2 friends and we ordered the green beans, goat empanadas, pork shank, scallops, and chocolate pavlova for dessert. Note: many of the dishes come with 2 pieces so you have to add on if you want a 3rd - we had to do this for the scallops and empanadas but it was so worth it - amazing. The pork shank was just awesome - totally fall off the bone but crispy on the outside perfection. No complaints on the green beans but I've had the broccoli before and prefer it for a vegetable dish. I truly never knew broccoli could taste so good! But be sure to save room for dessert - the chocolate pavlova came with sesame ice cream, which was a unique and delicious combination. And if you're not sure how much to order, the servers are flawless and there to help every step of the way.
Girl & the Goat always keepin it 100.

pics.caption: Goat empanadas - one of my favorite dishes

review.des: Always gets a five stars from me!! Branzino, pork shank, and broccoli were delicious. Amazing meal!! :)

Girl & the Goat was such a mouth watering dining experience!

They recommend 5 - 6 small plates for 2 people but honestly we were SO STUFFED after 4 plates and 1 dessert each. Plus we each had 2 cocktails.

We didn't have reservations so we waited in line 15 min before they opened with several other people. We ended up snagging a bar spot and we were there for about an hour and a half eating dinner. Don't fret if you don't have a reservation! Just be savvy about getting a spot at the bar.

- GET THE BREAD. I don't care if you can't eat bread or you're on a diet. Just do it. You'll thank me later. The potato bread is AMAZING. Hands down, bravo.
- Butter chicken had an amazing flavor
- The Empanadas were a favorite
- Their cocktails were superb, my favorite was the take on a pineapple upsidown cake with a dried pineapple on top
- The caramel popcorn with chocolate dipped vanilla ice cream was the STAND OUT desert.

The only gripe I had was the tiramisu let me down (too bitter for me). Everything else was TOP notch.

Make it a point to check this place out! Stephanie Izard is a genius chef.

Oh. My. Goodness. If you haven't been.... YA NEED TO GO! From start to finish everything was FABULOUS! We had 11 different dishes for 4 people -- yes that is entirely too much food and we were all stuffed. Service is great here and they were super helpful. I highly recommend trying the green beans, goat empanadas, and pork shank. You won't be sorry. Definitely make reservations! This place is packed!

I want to like this restaurant. Maybe I need to go again without the high expectations that I had coming in this time. We made a reservation 3 months out. Got to the restaurant and was promptly seated which was nice. We ordered the "Mr. potato bread, goat carpaccio, calamari bruschetta, and pig face. I did like 3/4. But I didn't love any of them. Wasn't a huge fan of the calamari bruschetta. Thick bread that turned soggy, although the calamari was cooked well. Again, I was anxiously awaiting for 3 months to go here so maybe I had unrealistic expectations.

The wait staff was hit and miss. The people serving the food were great. Specifically the guy who served my beer. Told me a little story about the brewery to make the experience more enjoyable. However, our waitress made us feel like we were being pushed out. She brought us the check before we were even done eating our main dishes.

Will update if I go again, but it might be a while.

What a delicious meal on my first night during a weekend trip in Chicago!?! Stephanie Izard, top chef winner and Chicago native, has outdone herself with an innovative menu of family style small plates/tapas with bold flavors and Mediterranean influence. Whether you are an adventurous eater, ready to indulge in duck toungues, roasted pig face, and goat empanadas or you love more traditional fare such as succulent ramp marinated chicken, tender baby short ribs, and sautéed green beans, Girl and the Goat has something delicious for everyone. A dining experience at Girl and the Goat, located in the trendy west loop, is highly coveted, so make sure to make a reservation well in advance. We made our reservation a few months in advance on OpenTable. Initially there were only reservations available at 10:45 pm on Thursday, however we checked back and reservations opened up. We ended up making a reservation at 7:30 pm on Thursday. They were very busy but we were seated quickly. There are plenty of tables throughout the restaurant and also communal style seating on a long booth in the center of the restaurant, which is where we were seated.
The server explained the menu, that a group of two diners typically orders four to six dishes to be shared and that the dishes would be served starting with the lightest and ending with heaviest. Some dishes can also be served as half orders which was advantageous for myself since my dining companion has an aversion to seafood while I love it and wanted to try a little bit of everything. Most dishes range from $12-$28 a piece.

The goat empanadas, piqued our interest and we were so glad we ordered these as they were one of our favorite items that we tried here. The goat empanadas were served as two, with miso-blue alioli, chanterelle mushrooms and apple giardiniera. The sauce was so flavorful and the goat meat was tender and delicious. If you have never consumed goat meat before, it's almost reminiscent of pulled pork, very tender, flavorful, and delicious.

Next up were the chickpea fritters, served with quinoa tabbouleh, chickpeas, pomegranate seeds, feta, and a tahini vinaigrette. The combination of flavors was amazing. The fritter had a polenta or tofu like texture. The sauce was delicious. Next we had the green garli pierogies, served with a scallion sour cream, and tomato rhubarb relish, very tasty.

Service has the illusion of being attentive as there were certain employees throughout the restaurant who's only responsibility was keeping everyone's water glass filled and plate-ware and utensils fresh and clean. However, our main waiter never came back and checked on us throughout the entire meal after the first initial order taking, even though he checked on the family next to us several times. I had to wave him down to add a couple seafood dishes to the order and a cocktail.

I ordered the fried oysters. They were delicious! If you've never had fried oysters, I'd equate them to the flavor and texture of a fried mushroom. I also had a half order of scallops, which was one scallop, since my friend doesn't like seafood. The scallop was garnished with brown butter alioli, blood orange, smoked beet, and pistachios. The flavors and garnishing was great but I actually thought the scallop was slightly undercooked.

Next up were the crispy beef short ribs, my other favorite menu item, served with avocado and grapefruit. The meat was melt in your mouth tender...so delicious. Finally we were served the ramp marinated grilled chicken, a very generous portion, large enough to be a meal of its own, served with shaved carrots, red peppers, and spicy peanut crunch. Bone-in chicken was fall off the bone tender and the combination of flavors was unique and delicious. I also really enjoyed the cocktail that I ordered, It's Always Sunny in Oaxaca, mezcal, mango, turmeric, ginger, cinnamon, and cayenne...subtly spicy and very tasty. I would definitely order this again. A couple next to us ordered the pork shank, a very large generous portion, served with pita bread and various dipping sauces which looked and smelled amazing. I will definitely be ordering the pork shank upon my next visit.
The family next to us, was offered a complimentary dessert by our same waiter, even though they said they were too full. However, we were not offered a complimentary dessert. It seemed like when I had inquired about half orders, in regards to seafood, that our waiter toned down the service which doesn't seem right since we spent $136 on our total bill between the two of us. If we had been checked on at least once throughout our entire visit, my review would have been 5 stars. Despite the service, the food was innovative, unique, and delicious and I would still return. I'd love to try some of the adventurous menu items like duck tongue, escargot ravioli, and pig face during my next visit. Girl and the Goat is a dining must during any Chicago visit.

We walked in on a Saturday night without reservations, were lucky enough to get bar table seats immediately. The bartender/waiter was very helpful and attentive. This set up the good mood for the entire meal.

For drinks, you need to get the Charles Grey! You won't be disappointed. Food wise, since they are all small plates, you can get a big variety of food. We got the Softshell "crab cake", Calamari Bruschetta, and Goat loin. And we also got a complementary dish - green bean with cashew. Every dish has a special kick to it.

I took down 1 star because overall the food is a little too salty. Everything else is perfect!

It was late and we were looking for a bite when we stumbled into G&TG. The patio was closed so we sat at the bar and were treated to one of the most professional experiences we have had in Chicago.

The bartender was very knowledgeable of the whiskies and he explained in detail the order of business as to their small plate offerings.

This is a small plate restaurant and for us it was perfect for our late nite dining. We ordered three plates and that was enough for us to share.

The Green Garlic Pierogies were tasty raviolis delicately laced with smoked tomato relish....after enjoying this treat we were anxiously awaiting the next dish which was...

The Chickpea Fritter. I'm not a big fan of feta but in this case it perfectly matched the Chickpeas adding a creaminess that was unexpected. Then came the...

Goat Shank. A surprising amount of meat, tender and inviting. We cleaned the bones on this one.

The reason only 4 stars is because of the price. We understand the cost of doing business is high in this part of the world but this place was expensive for our rural Northwestern budget. Having said that, if money is not an issue you will have no problem enjoying what G&TG has to offer.

The food here was so good! We didn't have reservations and went in expecting a wait, but were able to immediately sit down outside (if you're not willing to sit outside, the hostess said it was a 1-2 hour wait for the dining room, which would still be well worth the wait). The cocktails and the food were amazing - would highly recommend the goat empanadas. If you're dining alone or want to try more food, you can get half portions for some of the dishes.

Ok so here goes. I was able to snag a Saturday reservation 2 days prior to my visit here at Girl & The Goat. Lucky me ; ) . So, we had a good experience here. Aside from the hostess trying to seat us in two chairs facing the kitchen we had a good time. I immediately asked for different seating and the experience went well from there. But keep in mind people---it's just food. Nothing was completly mind-blowing. We're not super humans lol. Food is def overpriced,  but hey you wanna be fancy for the night right?
I honestly don't think it's worth 2 months in advance reservations like the rest of you had to do. And by the way, the street to the left of the building has street parking if you don't wait to pay $16 to park. (The whole street was completely empty). To keep the bill light we didn't order cocktails. After tax and tip our total came to $107

We ordered;

-Mr. Potatoe Bread: Monkey style bread. Very soft and came out warm. It comes with cream cheese and relish. Didn't care much for the relish.
-Shoshito peppers: had a 1/2 order. It was pretty bland. Nothing really special to be honest.

-Cauliflower: Prize of the night. Hands down a great dish and very flavorful. (It didn't come with a cheese topping either.)

-Lamb ribs: Very flavorful as well and a hint of that "gamey" taste. Succulent.

Pork shank: Huge and it fell off the bone. It was ok. Tasted good.

Dessert- for dessert we got this popcorn with ice cream. I really didn't care for it. The popcorn was too salty and it just didn't top of the night. Server was attentive and friendly and the bathrooms are clean and private occupancy styled.

Absolutely loved it.

It was pricey but well worth the spend. The meat dishes were so rich and flavorful. To go into details:
- The Pork Belly was very reminiscent of the duck and plum, but with pork belly! the meat was tender and the tangy sweetness of the plum helped offset the saltiness of the meat.
- The Confit Goat Belly was rich and decadent. The buttery sauce blended wonderfully with the goat, crab, and lobster and the slices of fennel really helped to keep the flavor from being overwhelming.
- The Goat Liver Mousse was essentially foie gras without the tortured duck. It had a very strong and sharp taste, not meant for every one, but a little bit spread over bread or biscuit with a dash of their goat jam was perfect for any patte lover.

In terms of the space, we stayed outside where there was less noise. It looked a little dark inside too, so if the weather is nice out, do enjoy it outside!

pics.caption: Confit goat belly (with crab and lobster meat)
Goat liver mousse with raspberry and goat jams

review.des:
The duck tongue is awesome. Full of flavor but not heavy at all.
The green been is also great, pig face is not taste like FACE. The pork shank is meat lover's favorite, but a little rich for me. The service is good

I really would like to rate this place a bit higher but I was not blown away by the food flavors. It seemed like the flavors didn't blend well together to deliver the punch and hype of the town.

This place is arguably one of the busiest restaurants in town. The menu looks and sounds amazing! Super creative combinations of ingredients that I have not seen elsewhere. That alone is a good reason to visit for the innovative menu!

It's very dark and loud inside with the music. Definitely creates a fancy and hip spot of town atmosphere.

We got the squid bruschetta, escargot ravioli (couldn't taste much escargot in it at all), goat confit belly with bourbon butter and lobster/crab.

Fantastic. Totally lived up to the hype. Came here right when they opened at 4:30pm on a weekday and had no problem being seated, relieved I didn't have to make a reservation for 3+ months out.

We ordered the bread, cauliflower, halibut, and lamb ribs. I probably wouldn't order the bread again, it was fine but nothing special. The cauliflower was divine, each piece browned to perfection and great flavors with the mint and nuts. The halibut was alright, very moist and flavorful, and I liked the mushrooms that came with it. The lamb ribs were awesome, extremely fall-off-the-bone tender, with great flavor and caramelization on the outside.

The four items were plenty for two people to share, but if I could do it all over again, I would have ordered a second vegetable instead of the bread. The service was good. Overall, I really enjoyed my visit and it is well deserving of the high rating. The next time I return to Chicago, I will make sure to come here again.

Service is excellent. Water constantly refilled, cocktails strong and tasty (awake all night, Oaxaca, old fashion, Chai town, fireside), food is thoughtfully prepared. Highly recommend reservations. Arrived early and we were seated immediately. We were a party of two, but wished with had a couple of friends with us so we could try more dishes. Some favorites were pork shank (tender and flavorful), roasted beets (delicious and refreshing), woodfire oysters were mouthwatering, scallops cooked to perfection. The yummy cake dessert is a must!!!!

Every time someone says they're going to Chicago, I always ALWAYS recommend Girl and Goat!

Make a reservation because they fill up FAST! It is a fancy place to eat and very dimly lit. TRY THEIR GOAT EMPANADAS!! Ugh so freaking good!! Their raw Kusshi oysters are also delicious!

Service was also super on point!

Easily the most memorable meal I've ever had, and quite possibly the best.  The only other meals I've had that could compare were at Gordon Ramsay Steak in Las Vegas and a little place in Buffalo called Martin Cooks (which is no longer open), and I think the food here was more creative.

First off - call ahead for a table at least 3 week's ahead of time.  I called a little over a month in advance as my wife and I were traveling to Chicago for our tenth anniversary, which I did let the staff know when I booked the reservation.

The place was packed at 7:45 on a THURSDAY.  We started with a couple of drinks at the bar.  My wife had a very well-made traditional old fashioned, and I had a slightly more modern gin concoction that was garnished with cinnamon.  Both were very tasty.

The restaurant is pretty well laid out - there's a pretty spacious lounge for waiting, a sizable and well stocked bar, and you can see into the kitchen from practically every table.  However, if you are very fortunate, the host will lead you to two bar chairs that directly overlook the grill station in the kitchen - the chef's table.

From there, we had a full view of the kitchen and all the food going out, which informed on which dishes we ordered.  Everything from the grill and oven is wood-fired; and the chefs in the brigade are on point even during the busiest rush.  They do suggest 2-3 dishes per person, which are served family style.  We settled on duck tongue, the shishito peppers, a grilled broccoli dish, scallops, lamb ribs, and goat belly, and a reasonably priced 2011 Bordeaux.  (The head-on branzino and octopus also looked amazing, but we did not try those dishes).  

Everything that came out was 5 stars.  The duck tongue was nice and crispy.  The Shishito peppers combined with a Parmesan cheese crust gave a nice degree of heat that didn't overpower the flavor of the peppers and cheese.  The grilled broccoli was served over a wonderful tahini yogurt sauce, the scallops were served with this rich oyster sauce that I could've eaten a whole bowl of by itself.  The lamb ribs were falling from the bone, and the goat belly was remarkably tender and earthy.

We finished off the meal with two terrific desserts- a chocolate pavlova with chocolate ice cream and caramel inside the crust, and grape gelato combined with peanut butter cake and cookie crumbs that called to mind the flavors of a peanut butter and jelly sandwich.

If you love great food, you must eat at this restaurant at least once.  Although it's tough to get a table at, it isn't all that expensive - even with a decent bottle of wine, 6 dishes and 2 desserts our total bill was less than $200.

Totally enjoyed my experience here! Got a variety of stuff to try but our favorite was the goat confit. I understand their menu changes frequently but if it's there when you- try it! They also gave me a small treat for it being my birthday dinner which was nice and totally unexpected. Definitely one of those places I'd recommend people try at least once!

What an experience. My husband and I made a reservation months in advance for my birthday last year. When we arrived, we were seated at what felt like a VIP table for two at the counter overlooking the kitchen! It was like dinner and a show getting to watch all of the activity behind the scenes, see what went into each dish, and observe the care and skill that the line cooks had for the dishes they were focused on. The food was great, and as someone with a gluten intolerance, the waiter was very knowledgeable about what would be suitable options for me. We topped off our meal with a delicious rhubarb dessert that came with a small candle in it. My husband (who doesn't generally like sweet things) even loved it because the flavors were so unique.

The Girl & the Goat is a very hyped restaurant in Chicago, and our table alone made our visit delightfully memorable. Also, Stephanie Izard is doing interesting things in relation to sustainability, composting, and building relationships with local farmers to bring local food to the table, so in addition to the great food and service, you can also feel good about supporting an ethical dining venue.

Fantastic! From beginning to end.

We went for a date night and I wanted to leave my boyfriend for Stephanie Izard by the end of it.

Awesome time; can't wait to go back the next time we are in Chicago! Chef Izard's menu is brimming with interesting options and bold flavors. Don't be shy about trying goat! Its taste is not overwhelming, rather similar to lamb. The wood burning oven adds depth. All dishes were balanced and well executed. Good wine list that fits the menu and concept. Vibe is fun and casual, and the service is awesome. Really can't ask for more!

Atmosphere
- Convivial and friendly, the space is casual and relaxed,with rustic design elements and an open kitchen.
- Bustling, jam packed on a holiday weekend and could be noisy. Two tops a bit close to one another.
- Dress is nicer casual, no need to get super dressed up.
- Wood burning ovens make it a touch on the warm side in dining room.

Food
So hard to choose from all of the incredible options. Flavors are bold but impeccably balanced. Dishes are perfect for sharing, and its nice to sample a range of Izard's creativity. Execution was top notch, truly enjoyed everything. We had:

- Pan Fried Shishito Peppers (parmesan​, sesame, miso - $12): Not particularly noteworthy, but well done nonetheless.
- Roasted Cauliflower (pickled peppers, pine nuts, mint - $13): Peppers add a nice tang/acidity, while the char and smokiness from wood burning oven was excellent.
- Goat Empanadas (grilled pineapple pico, roasted poblano cream, queso fresco - $16): Salsa lends a nice freshness, well balanced. Goat was not overwhelming with all the other ingredients; a good choice to try goat if you are hesitant.
- Goat Ribs (perilla marinated heirlooms, pickled grape tomato, green plums, tahini yogurt, wood fired pita - $29): Amazing, super tender and paired with the yogurt and pita a perfect bite.
- Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face (sunny side egg, tamarind, cilantro, red wine-maple, potato stix - $19): Don't let the name intimidate! It's just roasted pork - no strange textures or sights. The flavors are incredible, especially liked the tamarind and maple which add just a touch of sweetness.

Beverage
Wine list had plenty of high quality and reasonably priced offerings. We really loved the 2014 Élevée Pinot Noir ($110) which paired nicely with our goat and pork dishes. Did not get a chance to try the cocktails, but there were a number of alluring options for sure.

Service
- Our waitress did an awesome job, great with recommendations.
- Very hospitable and attentive.
