review.des:
This place has been on my list to go for a couple of years now. After my girlfriend and I saw Chef Izard win Iron Chef Gauntlet, we knew we had to make a trip out to Chicago. We thoroughly enjoyed all the dishes we ordered and there were so many others we wanted to try.

-seared diver scallops: i really enjoyed the crispiness of the pigeon peas and rice with the soft perfectly seared scallops
-szechuan sea bass: this was my favorite dish of the night.  the szechuan peppercorn gave it that classic numbing flavor.  it reminded me of a mapo tofu except with a delicious piece of sea bass
-roasted cauliflower: big portion of cauliflower with pine nuts.  goes well with the meats
-goat neck: this was the rotating special for the night.  the goat meat was really tender and served with eggplants and tomatoes
-crisp braised pork shank: this came last and we were already getting full at this point.  it is a massive piece of pork shank and the meat pretty much fell of the bone

The restaurant is in a great space and has a really laid back atmosphere.  You get the feel of a fancy restaurant without it being overly stuffy.  The meal cost us the same as dinner the night before at Blackbird and we got more dishes and food at Girl & the Goat.  The only criticism I can offer is that we ordered a "tiramisu" that was more bread on the bottom and not a traditional tiramisu. I wouldn't order that again but all in all this restaurant definitely lived up to the hype and I can't wait to come back again.

Girl & the Goat is in my top 5 favorite restaurants in the city. I've been a couple of times, with different menus, and each time has been absolutely fantastic.

While everything was amazing, my highlight last visit was the Bucatini with milk braised pork shoulder. Oh. My. Mind Blowing! Just a super memorable dish.

The cocktails ands vibe of therestaurant are amazing as well.

Iron Chef Izard is an absolute culinary marvel.

The hype is real! I have been here a couple times and it is always to go with at least 4 people. This will allow you to try a lot more dishes as it is a shared plates menu. What I like about this place is the food is high class without feeling stuffy.

Each time I have been here, I order the green beans - trust me the fish sauce makes this dish! I tried escargot for the first time with the escargot ravioli. I was not sure what to expect with escargot but I liked the dish! My favorite is the pig face. Sounds strange but tastes so good! The pig face is usually the favorite each time I've come here with different friends.

Overall I prefer Duck Duck Goat and Little Goat but it is still a fun culinary experience.

Tip: be careful if you made reservations on OpenTable and they call you saying a spot opened up a little bit earlier. They cancel your OT reservation so you don't get your points. I had that happen and they wound up seating us an hour before my original reservation anyways because it was slow.

I usually don't give five stars, but the service and food was absolutely amazing!

There was a group of 7 of us visiting from California and we wanted to make sure we planned at least one nice dinner. Girl & the Goat has the most reviews and stars, so we decided this was the place. We tried making reservations online with Open Table, but unfortunately they only had a few small tables left for a late reservation. What the heck, we booked two separate tables for our party.

The evening we arrived, we checked in with the host and she was gracious enough to sort out the reservations so we could all sit together! That impressed us immediately. Our server was very detailed and made great recommendations from the menu. Our food was brought out from light to heavy dishes, in a timely manner so we didn't have to wait for the next dish.

The food was to die for! TO DIE FOR. I can't say how much I was impressed with every dish! We licked clean the 13 or 14 dishes we ordered! No leftovers!

Bravo guys!

Delicious! The hype is right. I brought my wife here for her birthday and it was everything we'd hoped. The way they set up the reservations, you kind of have to plan several months in advance, but the restaurant didn't feel over-crowded or crammed with people. There was comfortable space for everyone, and we felt well attended to by the staff.

The menu was delicious and creative - definitely high quality. My wife and I shared four plates (olive loaf, beet salad, goat empanadas, and a beef dish for main course) and all were perfect! I wish it wasn't so hard to get into, although I know why it is, because we'd go all the time!

The goat is really cute, too!

Decided to stop by here for a super early dinner on Saturday right after they opened. It was a good idea to come early since we were able to grab seats at the bar (non bar seatings are reservation only!). The place was also packed when we were leaving.

The service here was amazing throughout the meal. The interior of the place was super classy and bright.

- Goat Carpaccio: Super well made dish. I love how there were salmon roe on top of the carpaccio that gave it a nice savory touch with the fish oil. Great appetizer to start.
- Braised Beef Tongue: Extremely tender meat and I only wish there was more! The flavor also the salsa verde went really well with the greens and meat.
- Calamari Bruschetta: The grilled calamari was so fresh and delicious. The bruschetta was a bit too heavy for my taste and one of the bread was kind of stale.

Overall a great meal. Apparently you can do half orders for some dishes? But I'd definitely double check.

This restaurant was on my top go to bucket list, while traveling to Chicago.  The food, ambiance, and service is spectacular. Our server Jerson, was very knowledgeable and attentive. He informed us on how to order, the dishes are like tapas, small and good to share. Between the two, we ordered four plates to share. The Hamachi Crudo, Seared Diver Scallops, Braised Beef Tongue and Confit Goat Belly. Everything was delicious, my top two favorites, the scallops and goat belly. When I come back to visit, this restaurant will be my first stop. Love it!

FYI, try to make reservations ASAP & if there is room for dessert, order the Caramel Corn & Malt Balls!

If you can get a seat, don't pass it up.

I come to Chicago every year for a work event. For the past few years I've looked to book a table about 3-5 months in advance and the only seatings are too late in the evening for my clients to join us. So I wasn't sure if I'd ever get a chance to eat here.

This year I was so excited when a colleague mentioned they had an open spot on their reservation. I JUMPED at the chance and was not disappointed.

I think we ordered everything on the menu. And all the drinks.

I don't remember what we ate, but I do remember it was all delicious. No real need to review what's already a super mega popular place, but when on yelp, one must leave a review. So voila.

My boyfriend and I arrived at Girl & the Goat around 7 on a Thursday evening. We were able to be seated right away at one of their communal tables outside.
- Atmosphere: I was only inside the Girl & the Goat for a few minutes, but the decorations were pleasant and the restaurant was loud as it was full of people. The communal table outside was a little squished, but if you are committed to eat at Girl & the Goat it's a good option.
- Food: We ordered olives, green beans, and cauliflower off the veggie section. The olives were over-marinated and the cauliflower was just okay, but the green beans were incredible. I usually choose to avoid green beans, but with these I kept going back for more. We had a special pork shank with naan for our main. The meat was tender and delicious.
- Service: Our server was friendly and lead us in the right direction with the green bean and pork shank recommendations. It was sometimes hard to get his attention since we were stuck in the middle of the communal table.
- Value: I think the value is okay. I would definitely pay the money for the green beans and pork shank, but the others weren't worth the money.
Overall, there are some delicious items at Girl & the Goat, but I wouldn't inconvenience myself to eat there again.

I had been to Chicago once before and when I wanted to make reservations about two weeks in advance there were none available. So please if you want to come and know ahead in advance, make reservations. The only reservation we got at the time was at 10:45pm! Insane! But I still made it happen! And I don't regret it! The food was amazing! The shank was so crispy outside and inside it was perfectly soft! The same with the ribs! The beet salad was delish! I am huge on beat, but sometimes they can taste like dirt if not done right! The drink was everything I expected! The flavors are exquisite for all the items we ordered! Wanted to get more but I was already full and couldn't even finish my items. I so recommend this to anyone that is big on food or just coming to Chicago to eat! The ambiance is super chill.

Everything we ordered was way too salty and heavy. Moreover, we could barely hear each other due to the noise level. The music was loud and the patrons were just way too rowdy. However, given how popular this establishment is on Yelp, I would probably give it a second a chance.

The food was great.
We ordered the bread and lamb ribs. The lamb ribs were delicious as well. Great wine selection too!The service was great.Great menu...unique.  My only reason for not giving 5 stars is due to price. I think for the price point, the size of some dishes should be larger. The next time I return to Chicago, I will make sure to come here again.

A friend took me and my wife here for our birthday dinner and we enjoyed a bunch of really amazing food in a really hip atmosphere.  We were lucky to get a reservation by checking the website every few hours and were there only a few hours later to enjoy.  

We ended up getting a bunch of food as a result of our very friendly and attentive server's recommendations.  Overall, we ended up getting 11 dishes between the three of us and that turned out to be maybe 2 dishes more than we had the stomach for.  Don't worry though, we didn't waste it any of it!  

The food was really unlike what I'm used to at any restaurants.  The menu features dishes using a diverse set of ingredients from different cultures and brings them together in ways that work very well.  Oddly enough, my top three didn't include any of the meat/seafood dishes we got.  The top was definitely the sauteed green beans with the fish sauce vinagrette.  The shishito peppers came out to be a close second, which we got with bread crumbs instead of parmesan because my wife couldn't eat cheese.  That said, using the bread crumbs for the "vegan" version of this dish made it super super delicious.  The third was our dessert - the sticky tasty crunchy toffee yummy cake (had to check their website for that name again).  That cake was really yummy, just as they said! So worth getting!

That said, not everything was a hit with our table - we were not the largest fans of the wood fired oysters or the fried oysters (our friend thought the fried ones were okay though).  

Overall, this place is definitely worth a visit.  The food is very interesting and definitely an experience that's giving a try.

pics.caption: Sticky Tasty Crunchy Toffee Yummy Cake - a mouthful in terms of name and deliciousness!
Crisp braised pork shank - quite a bit of food!

review.des:
It has been over 4 years since my last visit to Girl & the Goat and in that time, I moved to SF and gained a greater appreciation for different types of food.

We didn't have reservations and when we walked in around 8pm, we were told that the wait would be 2.5 hours. We decided to go hang out somewhere else and came back less than 2 hours later to find out that we had already been called. As it turns out, the wait was not that bad after all.

So many things on the menu caught our attention. We started with some raraouille focaccia bread that was served with whipped feta and tomato jam. So good! Then, we moved onto wood fired oysters, which my friend loved more than I did. My favorite small dish were the squash blossom rangoon. I loved the soft fried texture of the squash blossoms and the smooth filling.

I was getting pretty full already but our main dishes hadn't even arrived yet. The crispy braised pork shank was a winner - 5 out of 5! It reminded me a lot of carnitas, and I absolutely loved the crispiness. The portion size was generous and we were not able to finish it.

The reason we couldn't finish the pork shank was because we had also ordered goat neck. For any goat lovers, this is an excellent dish.

Damn.
Dude.
Wow.

This place. Is really good.
Note it's smaller portions but each dish is incredibly rich and packed with flavor.

Best dishes were definitely the pigs face and lamb ribs in blueberry-tamarind glaze. Serious kudos to the chef who came up with the pigs face. Ingenious mix of textures and flavors. Lamb ribs (4 pieces per order) Man, so juicy and fall-off-the-bone. The glaze was superb. So savory, the perfect balance of sweetness and char. We also got the halibut, goat belly, and duck tongue. All were delicious.

Next top (by a small margin) for me was the halibut. Great flavor and also was a good break from the richness of all the other dishes. Then goat belly. Boy, this dish is super rich. Amazing punches of flavors. Each bite is an experience.

As for drinks. I got the Charles gray and absolutely loved it. Not too sweet with a flavor depth that hits your whole mouth.
My friends got the spritz. Highly recommend for whoever loves grapefruit/ citrus drinks. Highlander was also good.

In all, this place lives up to the hype one of the best restaurants in Chicago.

Wow, if I could give this place more than 5 stars I would.  Best meal ever!!!  I would have to say it was one of my top 4 favorite/best meals of my life.  So glad I was able to snag a reservation few weeks before my trip!  I also had an amazing server who recommended the best dishes.  We ordered everything he recommended and every dish turned out to be so amazing.

-sauteed green beans
needed some kind of veggie/greens with the meal and this was a gerat choice
-seared diver scallops
oh man, this dish was so flavorful i can still taste it when i look at the picture.  the scallops were so perfectly cooked and fresh.  the scallops by itself were the most flavorful scallops I ever had.
-pan roasted sea bass
this one was ok.  I liked the different flavors playing with each other but not sure if I am a fan of the szechuan sauce.
-crisp braised pork shank
this was so tender but a bit greasy.  So good with the bread they give you though and love the pickled side dishes that come with it.  so necessary.
-goat empenada
good appetizer!
-bucatini
omg this was so good and perfectly al dente.  definitely better than Bestia in LA!!
-some kind of pb&j flavored dessert
don't know what this was but there was peanut brittle and jam and it was so good.

I really wish there was a G&TG in la :(  I miss this meal

Quick last minute work trip, I was extremely lucky to grab last minute reservations at a normal dinner time on a Sunday evening. The food here is out of this world- one of the best restaurants I've ever been to, without a doubt. Food came out course by course (aka one dish at a time).

First out was the mr. potato bread, at the recommendation of our server. It came out warm a chewy, with slight crust to the outside. While it was delicious on its own, I couldn't help but using the chili​ cheddar butter and chive yogurt that came with it...we had to stop ourselves to save room for the other 4 dishes we ordered!

We also got the chickpea fritters and pan fried shishito peppers. We were convinced the peppers were not spicy, although warned there may be one or two spicy ones in there. Lucky me with the first pepper in my mouth, holy hell! Scared me from eating many more...they were good but I'd go for the green beans next time, which looked really good (and a huge portion). I let my other half eat most of the peppers, while I ate most of the chickpea fritters, which were absolutely delicious and unexpected. Four cubes of creamy inside, yet crispy outside, of almost a polenta like texture and taste, served with crispy quinoa tabbouleh, feta, and a tehini vinaigrette-  the creativity and uniqueness of all of these ingredients worked so well together. It was really hard to share this!

Next were the goat empanadas, 2 decently sized empanadas, served with grilled mushroom& apple giardiniera, as well as a miso-blue aioli- also delicious. All the flavors worked so well together, it was a hearty dish. Don't be afraid to try goat- if you're gonna do it, this is the right place for it! I'd had it before so knew I liked it, but this is a place to be adventurous at! I believe the goat menu changes seasonally.

For the main course, we went with the crisp braised pork shank after reading so many popular reviews about it. It was enormous and served with buttermilk dressing, some sort of amazing hot sauce, squash-shiitake kimchi, and a good sized piece of pillowy naan that was used to put the pork and sauces on before devouring it!

All in all, it was an amazing experience (except for when the dishes came out so fast after each other at the beginning of our meal then had to wait quite a while for the last one). Fairly priced, and absolutely delicious. Stephanie is Izard is creative and talented- every single ingredient worked so well together and made for a spectacular dinner. Will certainly be back here and highly recommended. Make reservations well in advance if you don't want to be eating after 9pm!

Very hip place with innovative and creative dishes and drinks. The only reason i didn't give this place 5 stars is because with all the hype, I had very high expectations going in but felt like the place is trying a bit too hard.
Everything we ordered was delicious but missing the wow factor.
Good service in general and great place for date night.

This was the first time I've booked a table months in advance, but I now can understand why people go crazy over Girl & the Goat. Similar to Little Goat (their more casual sister restaurant and one of my faves in Chicago), everything on the menu is so fresh and unique. To quote my review of Little Goat: As one would expect from one of Stephanie Izard's brainchildren, you won't find the dishes here anywhere else. Since it's predominantly tapas style, you get to try a wide variety of food too.

Everything we ordered was delicious, some more than others, but I wouldn't say it justifies the prices and the need to make reservations so far ahead, ergo 4 stars. If you want a more affordable taste of some quality Izard food without a reservation, I highly recommend Little Goat (especially if you want brunch food).
Such a good time. Seated at the bar very quickly and got great service from the bartender even though the place was packed!. Will come again!

Probably the best food I've had in Chicago! Reservations are hard to come by but it's worth the wait. There are so many gluten free options! I'm gluten intolerant but my friend, who is not, wanted to get everything gluten free so we could share all plates. The waiters were very nice and accommodating. When possible they gave the gluten part of the meal for my friend separate from the meal so she could still enjoy the dish as it was supposed to be served! There is home made gluten free bread here!!! It was a little dense but still very good. The goat empanada was so good and juicy. The wood fired lam ribs melted off the bone. Wood oven roasted pig face was to die for. The crisp braised pork shank was a little drying. Overall, it was such a great experience!
Felt like it was ok. Dishes were good but tasted like other restaurants I've been to. Good to try, but not sure I would come back.

8/20/2017 - Wonderful dining experience! It was a pretty busy evening and the restaurant was completely packed. Thank goodness for our Open Table reservations. The lighting was pretty dim and the tables were pretty close together. I really didn't notice the décor as much as I would have liked to.

Our server was wonderful and very knowledgeable. We ordered the following:
* Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face, Sunny side egg, tamarind, cilantro, red wine-maple, potato stix
* Roasted Cauliflower, Pickled peppers. Pine nuts. Mint
* Hamachi Crudo, Crisp pork belly. Chili aioli. Caperberries
* Caramel corn & malt balls, Vanilla malt gelato. Popcorn caramel. Chocolate magic shell

All good, solid  and balanced meals. I wish we would of ordered more dishes since the plates were quite small. We ordered one of each of the categories on the menu, Vegetables, Fish and Meats. The dessert was spot on, I really want to try those malt balls again.

pics.caption: Pig Face w Sunny Side up Egg

review.des:
Wonderful restaurant! I have been here multiple times. The atmosphere is great with the beautifully decorated walls out of charcoaled wood and the dim lighting. Although it has been in business for several years now, the place is still always full if you walk in without a reservation so make sure to make one at least a week ahead. If not, you always have the option to get a drink at the bar and wait but who knows how long that wait could be. My friend told me that she once waited for two hours!

The food is great for the price. It is contemporary American food. Their special is goat, as the name suggests, and pork. The pig cheek is so creamy and soft. I also like their string bean dish that has a miso-based sauce with peanuts. I usually get their veggie appetizers and meat mains. The pasta and other starch dishes are very average so I wouldn't go for it. Their cocktails are tasty. I love their old fashion and any mezcal based ones.

We were able to grab a reservation for 9 pm after a spot opened up a day before our trip to Chicago. This place was on top of our list of places to try during our stay and it did not disappoint.

Food:
+ Sweet corn pierogies - The BEST dish of the night. I would go back just to have these again. The corn was so fresh and crunchy(?) which complemented the other ingredients very well. Wished there were more than 4 pierogies :(

+ Soft shell "crab cake" - Probably my second favorite of the meal. The crab was crunchy on the outside but soft on the inside. It had a unique flavor and we could definitely taste the "tangy mayo, soy glaze,  blackberry, snap pea"

+ Seared scallop & sausage summery succotash - Scallops were big, perfectly cooked and paired well with the succotash. Not generally a big seafood fan, but this was good!

+ Wood oven roasted pig face - This was underwhelming based on other reviews.. maybe because it was the last dish and our stomachs were getting full, but my friend and I both thought it was too oily and heavy. The first bite was good, but we progressively realized it was a little too salty with each bite and couldn't finish it in the end.

Service:
+ Great service overall
+ Accommodated our request to be seated earlier than our reservation time since we arrived much earlier than anticipated - we did have to sacrifice indoor seating, but that wasn't much of an issue for us
+ Our server brought out each dish at a timely pace so we could enjoy each one for it's uniqueness. However, considering we were super hungry and each dish was devoured within minutes, there was a lot of sitting and waiting in between

Ambience:
+ We were seated outside on a communal table so we couldn't experience the inside of the restaurant, but based on a quick glance inside, it was dark with eclectic artwork hung on the wall and more communal tables
+ Noise level was pretty high due to the amount of people, which was expected
+ Not much personal space between seating since everyone sits right next to or pretty close to each other

I made a reservation at Girl and the Goat because I heard good things about it. It was for a reunion with a couple of high school friends who are studying in colleges across the country (so we cannot meet often). It was simply great - the foods, wine selection, service... We ordered 3 main dishes (1 veggie, 1 seafood, 1 meat), a bottle of white wine, 2 servings of bread (1 mushroom, 1 sweet potato. I heard good things about it and were my favorite) if I am not forgetting anything. We paid about 50 per person. A bit pricey for students but we wanted to have a special meal and it was worth it.
I'm giving 4 stars for overall because I tried to confirm reservation multiple times at different times by calling back to the number they left in my voicemail and kept getting stuck because the line was unavailable. Also, the seating was a bit cramped because there was no space between my seat and the other table's. These are factors that did not affect me too much since I am a student who only rarely enjoy this kind of fancy outing so have lower expectations but it might affect other people.

Another Chicago bookmark checked off!

We've had extraordinary luck with not having to wait at any of the top dining spots in Chitown and this was no exception--even during prime dining hours! The patio seating was perfectly fine since we were by the heater and actually made it more romantic.

The menu was divided by V (veggie), F (fish), and M (meat). We only picked dishes from the latter two but were pleasantly surprised when our waiter gifted us with the roasted cauliflower. I wouldn't have thought to combine the ingredients together that was in there but as Steve Jobs says "It just works". It's the best cauliflower I've ever had and couldn't resist from almost finishing the entire bowl.

The brioche was decadent as expected especially with the whipped butter which tasted almost like frosting. The Kalbi beef ribs had the most perfect smokiness that had me sucking the bones wishing there were more lol. What can I say about the scallops? I love scallops as much as Christen (Scallop Fingers) on Bachelor in Paradise so this was a no brainer selection.

Lastly the Pig Face came out. Is this what they called me in the kitchen behind my back? I thought I was the goat? Anywho I had to peel back the egg to reveal what was underneath bc I couldn't find any pics on Yelp to show what it actually was (you're welcome for my post now). It was a couple pieces of super tender slices of marbled pork surrounding a heap of extra crispy hash browns. Mixed together and chopped up was the BKM on how to chow this dish down.

We were too full for dessert and opted to walk off the meal towards Millenium Park which isn't too far away. What a great dinner and great service. Thanks for all your hospitality.
Service was amazing, our waiter explained everything perfectly, and the bar made delicious cocktails. Get the green beans! And goat, of course.

Girl & the Goat has a great atmosphere, attentive staff, and has the best small dishes.

You can get reservations here, but it's a bit tough as they tend to already be booked for normal lunch/dinner hours. With a reservation, they won't seat you until all members of your party arrive.

The service was phenomenal. They were always there in a good way - not the type of server who interrupted our conversation, but was a ghost who would sneak in to refill our drinks and gauge when we were ready for the next course. Their timing on bringing out courses was on point; they always brought out the food right when we finished the current course.

The food - this is obviously the best part. Keep in mind that they serve small dishes so they usually recommend 1-2 dishes per person depending on your appetite. The food always came out hot and they often brought us new, heated plates so the sauces wouldn't bleed together. The dishes themselves were well crafted and had a great blend of textures and tastes. As a bonus, the presentation was executed well too. I would love to sit at the chef's table sometime and see them make the dishes!

My favorite things that we tried were the Kohlrabi salad, the grilled yellowfin tuna, and the crisp braised pork shank (I don't eat pork often, but I made an exception here).

This is my new favorite restaurant :)

Make your reservation now! We luckily got a two person reservation a week out but the next reservations were three plus weeks away.

The place has an open kitchen and they seated us right in front of the activity. They have two two-seat tables facing the kitchen and would highly recommend asking if you can reserve those because we loved watching the food being cooked and the crazy action.

We started with the chickpea fritter chaat - the chickpea fritters were really nicely fried while still being light. Then we got the grilled pork belly which was AMAZING and a must order! The pork belly was crisp while the bok choy and bean sprouts had some type of lime vinaigrette that added an amazing citrus punch to the dish. Next we got the calamari bruschetta which was another star!! The calamari melts in your mouth and pairs perfectly with the bread spread with goat cheese. Then we had the goat empanadas - empanadas sometimes get dry in the filling but these were perfect and had subtle but great flavor. For our last entree, we got the pig face - the dish is super interesting. The pork is fatty and amazingly soft and the sauce is almost syrupy and slightly peppery. Lastly for dessert we had the chocolate pavlova - at this point, we were stuffed and probably should have gotten the lighter berry dessert but no regrets! I'm not a big fan of meringue, but the caramel brittle and sesame ice cream pulled everything together.

My favorite dishes were the pork belly and calamari bruschetta but everything was seriously amazing. Also the service was five stars too - our waiter was super attentive and our water was never less than half full.  This place deserves all the hype and more!

I'm sad to say that this place has really lost a few steps.  The menu is basically the same that it has been for 4 years.  The chefs seem to just be going through the motions.  The servers and hostess are more worried about when you'll free up the table, as to how you are enjoying the meal.  Apparently you are now required to place your full order when you sit down, as opposed to order it as you go, which goes completely against every tapas experience I've ever had and enjoyed.  So feeling rushed and having to order all at once, we ordered quickly and missed a few things that looked interesting at other tables.  Our server was really bad; she checked on us once, never asked about how the food was, made us feel rushed, doesn't seem to like her job, etc and somehow she doesn't know the pricing because she charged us more for a drink at the table than what we paid at the bar, even though it was the same drink (unforgivable when you charge me  $21 for a "well" Old Fashioned).  I know liquor is marked, up but my wife's two wines were only $30.  In all, there were way too many details being missed, the food is mediocre, and it is WAY to over priced for the quality and flavor.  There are PLENTY of other restaurants in Chicago that care about your dining experience and about producing world class food.  Try them.  I think Stephanie has too much going on right now to focus on TGATG, which is a shame, because 2 year ago the food and service was still really good.

Honestly my favorite restaurant in Chicago! Since we couldn't get a reservation, we decided to head to the restaurant early. We arrived around 5 pm and were able to find seating at the bar.

We ordered goat carpaccio, calamari bruschetta, and the braised beef tongue. All of them were unique and amazing dishes. I liked the braised beef tongue the best - it was tender and well flavored. The goat carpaccio paired with trout roe was a surprising combination but worked magic. The bruschetta was on the heavier side, but the calamari was sautéed and tender.

The ambiance of the place is loud and lively with trendy decoration. It was absolutely packed by 5:30 pm so I would recommend going early if you don't have a reservation. The service is great as well (they just kept on refilling my water). I think this restaurant is a must-go if you ever visit Chicago!

I was so looking forward to my first visit to one of Stephanie Izard's restaurants, having been a fan since her first season onTop Chef. Maybe we took a risk by coming in on a Sunday night especially on Labor Day weekend. Maybe my expectations were too high. But I have never been so underwhelmed by a restaurant as I was tonight.

Firstly, our server, though kind, was obviously rushed and had a large area to take care of. He took our order all together, drinks and food, and then the food arrived a good 5 minutes before we got our cocktails. The food itself had great concepts and great flavor profiles but was really poorly executed by the kitchen. Our smoked fries were cold and we sent them back. The second time they were hot from the fryer but this is not something I expected one of Chef Izard's restaurants to have to fix. Our two dishes - the pork belly pancake and a goat burger bahn mi style - were lukewarm and lacked anything that made them memorable. Honestly I couldn't really have told you that the burger was goat.

The small piece of belly pork was delicious but so hidden under a mountain of slaw it was hard to find. The pancake was lukewarm and greasy. We didn't dare risk dessert so walked across the street for amazing gelato at Bombabar instead which redeemed the evening.

Wasn't sure of eating goat at first, but yeah this place was so  and had great culinary experience.   Everything runs so smoothly here.  We liked everything we ordered.  Ribs were very moist and sweet.  Carpaccio was sweet and citrus with crunch( chips and green).

I had one free day in Chicago before work meetings started.  After asking three people for restaurant recommendations, Girl & the Goat made everyone's list, so I knew I had to stop by and check it out.

I arrived just after 6pm on a Sunday, with no reservation, but was hoping to snag a single seat at the bar.  The bar/lounge area was completely full, but in less than 5 minutes, a seat opened up at the bar.  

The server noted that several of the appetizers could be ordered in half portions (yeah!), to allow people to sample a number of the selections - they recommended 2-4.  

After cross-referencing recommendations from my neighboring seat-mate and server, I decided on the Sauteed Green Beans; Chickpea Fritter; and Goat Empanadas.  I didn't leave a morsel behind of a single dish!  

Fun atmosphere, great food - would definitely recommend.

I've heard that food in Chicago can compete with NYC restaurants so I had to take advantage when I came here for work!

Girl & the goat is definitely one of the best restaurants I've been to. Everything we got had such impeccable flavor. Stephanie Izard knows what she's doing!

The green beans with the fish sauce and cashews were so good! A bit too salty once you eat too much, but the first few bites are heaven.

The calamari bruschetta is a very rich dish with the bread, calamari, apple, ricotta cheese, and probably a few more things I forgot, but I enjoyed the bites.

THE PORK SHANK. The star of the show. Probably some of the most tender meat I've ever had. Right amount of fat to give it a little more flavor, but still chunks of meat. The sauces and naan that come with it are so good and make the best combo for a mini taco! I will forever dream about this dish.

I've been here twice, and the food is quite good. Drinks are solid, but there are definitely better cocktail programs in the area if that's what you're in search of.

If you are in search of a tapas restaurant where you can share and try new flavors and reach outside of your comfort zone, you will enjoy this place. A solid place to visit if you're in Chicago.

Went here for my birthday last week -- I was not disappointed. Apparently it is impossible to get a reservation so we showed up to the "first come first serve" section near the bar and had no issues finding seating (granted this was a Tuesday afternoon).

We ordered a plethora of options, all reasonable portions for two people. The Calamari Bruschetta was honestly to die for. The texture and flavors were so rich and savory. I would go back just for that order alone. My other favorite was the goat empanadas which were an excellent opening dish and cooked to perfection.

The drinks were strong, and delicious -- and the dessert we had was amazing. Obviously the cost is on the pricier side, but I think it is well worth the cost.

10/10 would come back for another special occasion.

All I can say is wow. Seemore was the server that I had at the bar and he made the experience an unforgettable one. He was so engaging, fun and educational at the same time. I got the shishito peppers, scallops and lamb ribs. Every dish was better than the other. I wish I had more room so I could try more dishes. I was talked into trying the caramel corn dessert and it was sooooo amazing. It was so worth it and definitely lives up to the hype. I will definitely go back and try more dishes when I come back to Chicago.

What a five star experience from the food to the service to the cocktails! Make a reservation well in advance and plan to enjoy yourself. Don't forget to order dessert!

The restrooms were clean and the staff was friendly. It's all small plates and they recommend sharing. There were four of us and we had 8 dishes and two desserts. The server wanted to make sure we didn't order too much. Wish we didn't live out of town because it's amazing.

My husband and I went to Girl & the Goat on a Saturday evening for his birthday. We had 9:45 reservations and it was super packed. We arrived slightly early but were seated right at 9:45pm.

I was super impressed by the service here.  Everyone was so friendly and everything was incredibly seamless from bringing out the food to refilling drinks. Service here truly is top notch.

The food was just as impressive as they say. We had the cranberry bread (Amazing), goat empanadas, sea bass, chickpea fritters, and chorizo pizza. All of the food was great. My favorite was the chickpea fritters and my least favorite was the pizza, but it was in no way bad. We also received a free dessert for my husbands birthday which was super nice.

This place is a must when in Chicago. It is a bit pricey, our bill was $120, but it is completely worth it.

Welp. Here I am with review number 6,347 for Girl & the Goat... I don't have any new, earth shattering insight that hasn't been mentioned 6,346 times before. (Save for the handful of lunatics who didn't like this spot for some obviously unfounded reason.) So, I suppose I'll just give you a quick recap of our most amazing meal last night...

Our order consisted of:

Blueberry pickled pepper cornbread
Green beans
Cauliflower
Corvina
Scallops
Malted milk & caramel corn

Our most amazing server, Hunter, sent us the lamb and donut compliments of the house. Our dessert came with 2 candles since we were celebrating our anniversary.

Girl & the Goat is perhaps our favorite restaurant in the whole wide world. Duck Duck Goat gives them a run for their money but service at Girl & the Goat gives them the slight advantage. (Did I mention how much we love Hunter?!?) Stephanie Izard is such a jewel in Chicago's crown. I only wish someone of her caliber would decide to call Charlotte home.
Haven't been in a little while but we had an amazing meal at one of those small tables near the kitchen. Get the pig face. It's life changing.

My fellow Yelpers you must eat here when in Chicago! We wanted to try it all & only had a couple of hours before heading to the airport. But I'm elated to say we did well. My beverage of choice for the maiden eatery was the Boondock & the Goat Empanada's came as starters &  were simply amazing flavors in our mouths. Crispy yet soft in the center with toppings from heaven. We next proceeded to savor the pan fried shishido peppers and green beans which were tasty beyond expectation! Next arrival were the wood fired lamb ribs which we inhaled with much joy. We waited more than expected to but finally got our Branzino & felt more than satisfied since our first mission to the Girl and the Goat was accomplished.  We will return on our next journey to Chicago!

This was probably the best culinary meal I had while I was visiting Chicago.  There's a reason this restaurant is so packed...so make a reservation early! Here's what I had:

Beet salad - Who knew that anchovies would go so well with beets?  This dish was pretty tasty for being so healthy.  Pro tip: Don't freak out when you take a massive red dump the next day...it's not blood :-P
Seabass with starfruit and coconut risotto - While the coconut risotto was awesome, the sea bass itself was underwhelming because it was overcooked.  This was probably the only "disappointing" dish I had, if I can even classify this as disappointing.
Bucatini - A very savory pasta dish, I really enjoyed the flavor of the meat.  It was a bit too rich for my wife, but I really liked it.  The pasta was cooked perfectly al dente and had a nice texture.
Scallops - Best scallops I've ever had.  Miso butter with blood orange wtf? But oh man, was this dish good.  The scallops literally melt in your mouth.  Amazeballs.
Mussels - I didn't even know what Perilla is until I tasted it, which to me is a combination of cilantro and a hint of mint.  These mussels are definitely top 3 in my book.  Don't skip on this, the herby-buttery-garlicy broth and fresh mussels will blow you away.
Beef tongue - This isn't your standard Korean BBQ quality beef tongue.  The tongue is literally filet mignon tender and delicious.  I enjoyed that it was seasoned with vinaigrette.
Chocolate Pavlova - Think giant chocolate macaroon with sesame ice cream.  This dish was a nice way to end the dinner.  

Due to the excellent culinary experience I had here, I give this restaurant 5 stars.  However, what's up with the whiskey cocktails here? A high end restaurant like this should be able to provide you a whiskey ice ball instead of ice.  If you order whiskey cocktails here that include ice, make sure you ask for it straight up to improve the overall experience.

We checked out The Girl and The Goat while visiting Chicago from Texas. We thankfully made reservations a few weeks in advance, as they were very busy even on a Tuesday night. They recommended ordering at least two plates per person, which ended up being a perfect amount of food. We tried the goat belly, duck tongues, branzino, and pigs head, all of which were divine. The best bite we had was definitely the goat belly with a little bit of the lobster/crab topping. Everything was cooked prefectly. If we had one recommendation for improvement, it would be timing. We received several plates very quickly, and then waited what seemed like a very long time between our third and fourth plates. This didn't diminish our experience at all, but it seemed incongruous with the rest of the evening. Overall, we would highly recommend.

I did my research and damn I'm glad I did. This place is the business.

Raw oysters - super tasty - a little on the small side. Wouldn't order it again but I wasn't necessarily disappointed with it. Just wish there was more goodness to eat.

Braised beef tongue - very flavorful. It had this asian fusion but a little more Americanized. The braised beef was tender and didn't overpower anything but actually paired well with the rest of the meal and was very light.

Sautéed green beans - so much full flavor. Very light and I didn't feel gross. The green beans were crunchy but cooked through. It was actually very delicious. I feel like it's hard to get the flavor and cook it to perfection and they hit the bullseye.

Pig face ------------))) I'll move to Chicago to have this meal. Crispy, bursting with freaking flavor, it was like pork belly that wasn't super chewy. It just worked with the egg in so many ways.
This place definitely lived up to its expectations and when I do come back to Chicago, I will be visiting  this place again.  

Oh and my girlfriend destroyed the lemon cake.  Just FYI guys - if you want your girl to do things later on- lol give her desserts. Jk but honestly it made her happy and that's what's important. Good food, good company=HAPPINESS!

3.5 stars.

Potentally overhyped like crazy? My friend I was visiting decided to pick here as my parting dinner because she heard a lot about it. It was me, my friend, and her boyfriend, and the line was a whopping TWO HOURS. I have never waited that long for food ever, so maybe that brought it down. **HIGHLY RECOMMEND A RESERVATION** Otherwise, this place is so not worth it. We went back to the apartment to nap, came back at the time they said we would get the table, and STILL had to wait before they seated us. The restaurant is dimly lit and packed. Pretty good ambiance for a date, I will admit. Again, if you're going on a date, REZZIES, YO.

We ordered sauteed green beans, seared diver scallops, pan-roasted bass, crispy beef short ribs, duck tongues, and the sourdough.

Obviously, the bread came first. It's kind of hard to mess up bread. The feta was a nice touch, I preferred it to butter. It's just so foreign to me that we pay for bread? I don't know.

Next, came the duck tongues. Can I just the idea of duck tongues is morbidly hilarious? All these ducks with no tongues. Anyway, they tasted like French fries that had been cooked in duck oil. To be honest, that might have been a better way to make this dish, rather than what was served. It captured my interest at first, but was no longer fun after the first couple tongues. I was more interested in the tuna chunks. I would hardly call it "poke" though. That's rude.

We got the crispy beef short ribs next. Honestly, the star of the whole dinner. I highly recommend this. I really enjoy how they made the meat crispy without overtly frying it. What magic. The relish of avocado and the ruby red grapefruit chermoula really completed the taste of it. This was the peak of the dinner.

After that, we received the scallops. They were okay. I couldn't really taste the aioli or blood orange. Just you're usual ole scallops.

The pan-roasted bass was decent. I'm Chinese-Filipino, so I really appreciated the pork belly adobo. The sticky rice-coconut jus did not have enough coconut to it. Starfruit was interesting but tasty. The bass, however, left much to be desired. Unmemorable. Like, as I write this review, I literally cannot remember what it tasted like.

The dishes are tiny as heck, especially for the price. Maybe the experience was dampened not only by the wait, but earlier in the day, we had the best dim sum I've ever had in my life, and for six of us, it came out to $21 each. It was more than enough food. Here, for three, it came out to around $39 each for three people, and we were just barely full. The portions are TINY. Three scallops?

The restaurant boasts "global influence," and it's really sad because a lot of these dishes should not cost as much as they do. Butter chicken? Adobo? Come on now. My mom makes better adobo than this and for a lot cheaper. I wouldn't come here again unless someone else paid for me. It's a shame because there are so many good looking dishes on the menu, but it's another case of expectations vs. reality. Maybe we were just unlucky or something because I'm desperately trying to like it as all the previous reviewers did.

One of the best restaurants I've ever been too. The menu is straightforward and compact; but it offers a variety of dishes. There are many unique combinations of food, and the tastes of each are complex. The dishes were almost too advanced for my tastebuds. There are so many flavors working at the same time in each dish, I cannot single out a particular item on the menu. Try them all, they are all amazing. 4.87/5.0 stars

Our entire meal was so beautifully done and it was all delicious!! Our wine was amazing and all of the staff were friendly and so great to interact with. We really loved our experience at Girl and the Goat!! Our waiter was friendly, attentive, and so wonderful. We had the shishito peppers (I got the hot one first. Haha) the squash blossom Rangoon (100% would recommend) the pig face (EVERYONE ORDER THIS) and the goat confit.
We loved it soooo much! Thank you to the servers, the chefs, and all the staff. You made our trip worth it :)

We made a reservation for six a few weeks back and got a nice table next to the kitchen but we still shared the table with another party of six. The atmosphere is busy,casual and loud. We ordered almost 1/3 of everything on the menu. My favorite were the shrimp with aguachile sauce and the goat empanadas. Everything was delicious overall, the plates are brought out from lightest (seafood) to heaviest (meat)...within and hour all of the 11plates in our order had come out. It felt a little rushed. The service was great with servers coming around cleaning ever so often and cleaning table, placing new plates and serving water. There was a 3 hr wait for walk-ins. Glad we made a reservation!

Really amazing place! Excellent service all around! Made reservations 3 months in advance in order to get a somewhat decent time slot. Good size plates for 2 people. One thing I noted that I really felt stood out was that the wait staff made sure to ask about any allergies and they seemed very adamant and careful about adhering to any allergies, which I feel not many restaurants may do. We ordered 4 plates and 2 desserts and it wasn't too pricey! The calamari bruschetta and pig face are musts! Will definitely be back in the future!

Wow. Be prepared for a culinary adventure of unique ingredients and respectful snout-to-tail utilization.

We came here for our first meal after our marriage and were congratulated by each staff member that encountered us (how did they know?!) Our server suggested 4-5 dishes for a party of 2, then brought each out in order of lightness to heaviness. We opted for the fall-coccia, corn perogies, sea bass, goat's neck (favorite), and pork shank.

Each dish was painstakingly presented and thoughtfully composed for balance of flavor and color.

Outstanding. I wish we had room for dessert, but next time we'll opt for 4 dishes and a dessert!

pics.caption: Delicious sea bass with grapes. A bright and unexpected flavor combination!
These sweet corn perogies were a perfectly balanced bite. The accompaniment made the flavors sing!
Say yes to the "fall-coccia". The mushroom butter was to die for.

review.des:
This is by far one of the best restaurants I've ever had! Once we booked our trip to Chicago, I knew I had to get a reservation at this restaurant so we got booked our reservation several months in advance. Below are a few dishes we enjoyed:

Calamari Bruschetta - When I was reading reviews of this restaurant, I instantly knew we had to try this dish. I was so glad I did because it was amazing! The flavors melt in your mouth and the bread was perfectly toasted. Definitely order this dish!

Pan Roasted Halibut - The fish was perfectly pan roasted and the flavors of the vegetables worked really well with the dish.

Wood Grilled Broccoli - This vegetable dish was recommended by the staff and I can see why. It sounds simple - just broccoli, right? But, when you mix the broccoli with some cheese and crispies, it's a game changer! This is the perfect dish to complement the heavier flavors of the other dishes.

Woodfire Glazed Lamb Ribs - Another amazing dish! The ribs were perfectly marinated and cooked to perfection. It wasn't too gamey in flavor. Highly recommend this if you like lamb!

Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face - Several reviews mention this dish as their favorite dish. If you've ever had a fried egg with pork belly, the flavors are pretty similar to this dish. Overall, this dish was good but not amazing in my opinion. It may also be because it was our last dish of the night and we were pretty impressed with their other dishes.  

Goat Empanadas - When they have an entire menu on the side dedicated to goat dishes, we knew we had to at least order one to try it out. The empanada was perfectly crispy on the outside and the filling inside was amazing. It's a bit pricey considering it only comes with 2 but the it was pretty good. The pineapple-blueberry salsa was really refreshing and was a nice spin to the dish.

I would recommend making reservations beforehand because this restaurant was completely packed on a weekday night. Prices are pretty reasonable for the quality of their dishes. I can't wait to visit this restaurant again!

Small shareable plates and flawless service made this a great experience.

Had 10 different plates - mix of vegetables, fish and steak. All unique, all flavorable, all excellent.

It can be difficult to get a table here and now I understand why. Highly recommend this dining experience especially if you have a larger group.

I'm going to have to restrain myself from making a G.O.A.T. joke but this restaurant, which I had heard was the greatest of all time, did not dash my untarnished hopes in the least.

I'm born allergic to many things (besides immature/errant dudes and children who are at the thresholds of puberty), and that includes: fish, all nuts, tahini, etc etc etc. Might as well have been this entire place because the waiter did a head nod thing, and then came back with a menu more marked up than my business analytics final. We ordered what I could eat, and that was:

Green garlic potato pierogies: Had bok choy crème. smoked tomato rhubarb chimi. If I say those ingredients out loud, I feel like I would gain street cred but in reality, I haven't the slightest idea what most mean. You heard it here first. The dish was a solid 4/5.

Braised beef tongue: so tender that I could have been biting into a substantial cloud. 5/5

Wood oven roasted pig face: the most popular menu item, but it tasted like a glorified bacon and eggs deal. I did really enjoy it, but I thought the beef tongue blessed my buds better. 4.5/5

Stephanie Izard is quite the fan of sprinkling those crunchy noodle things on top of every dish. One of my friends called it "annoying", but I never minded the texture. If you ever bring any of these dishes home though, (which you won't because the portions are toddler sized) , the crunch of these fried noodles will melt into your food and you will want to break up with your dish.

This is a dining experience everyone should at least try once. But you must make your reservations months in advance in order to get into this great restaurant. We made ours exactly 3 months in advance. Our server Owen was amazing, super nice, knowledgeable and was always checking on us but not in an annoying way. Loved having him as our server. All the dishes are small plates so he suggested we order everything at once and then he brings them out in the order that you should eat them. So we had all the seafood first, vegetables and then the meat at the end.
Goat empanadas were so good. Meat was tender and the shell was crispy.
Mojo shrimp had a very strong lime, cilantro taste while it was good not my favorite.
Scallops were AHHHHHMMMAZING
Halibut was so good
Green Beans fantastic
Pig face, is not actually the face. Lol but its crispy pork with an egg on top was flavorful and tasty!!
Our final entree was the chicken and that was moist and flavorful too.
For Dessert we had the caramel corn and malt balls!! All i can say is OMG!!!!
One of the best meals ever!!!!

Definitely come here and expect a wait.  We got lucky and grabbed a seat at the bar.  We ordered 3 dishes.  Calamari, Short Rib and Scallop dish.  

The portions were small and the calamari didn't come.  We asked about it a couple of times and the waiter said it was coming.  He replaced the calamari with some type of vegetable dish that did not taste good at all.

I had higher expectations from this place since the reviews had been so good.   I won't be returning.

It took us a month for a reservation and I can totally see why.  This place is spectacular.  We started with cocktails: the Very Old Fashioned and the Best of Three did not disappoint.  Best of three was very fresh with a hint of sweetness.  Next we got the sourdough bread with whipped feta and pickled onions.  I almost skipped this as I thought it would be "filler" but the salty smooth feta and picked onions were fantastic with the crusty sourdough. Next up was the kohlrabi salad-- loved every bite-- definitely a well thought out salad.  The shishito peppers were really amazing-- slightly spicy but savory and crunchy.  My husband also got the goat carpaccio which was not gamey at all, the roasted pig face (which he thought was spectacular).  Do not miss the pork shank!!!  It is super crunchy in the outside and melts in your mouth on the inside.

pics.caption: Crisp Braised Pork Shank-- Make sure you get this!  The best!
Pig Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face
Kohlrabi Salad-- one of my favorites

review.des:
A bit disappointed. Food didn't live up to the expectation of a highly and widely recommended restaurant.

Octopus: decent but not very memorable.
Shishito peppers: strange that every pepper was spicy as hell. Flavor was pretty good though.
Goat belly: too buttery
Tempura walleye: best dish of the night. Tempura was on the heavy side but flavor was good.
Roast pig face: didn't really like this dish. a more runny egg would have made the dish better.
Pork shank: better than the pig face but still not that great.
Chocolate pavlova: good but too sweet.

Very friendly service but the food, what an adventure.  
So fun !!!!!!!
Pig face is actually pig cheeks and shredded up.  Awesome and great whimsy play on words

I tried goat , which I have had in Indian restaurants but this time it was in a skewer.  Delicious !

It was a great time ,  and it's not THAT expensive.
Being a tourist in your own city is a blast

Surprise, surprise...another 5 star review for Girl & the Goat.

I've been here a few times when the family comes to visit. The menu changes slightly whenever we visit, but the green beans remain a favorite of ours.

The service is always spot-on, cocktails are amazing, food is unique, etc.

You'll definitely need a reservation a few months in advance, but I've seen some lucky folks get in without one (very rare).

This place is good. If you live in Chicago then definitely try it. It's a place that you try once and then tell everyone you did it to feel cool. Dishes are unique and tasty, but they are dishes you'd only want to have once. Service was great and the desserts were good.

A little overhyped.

A long overdue review, but first, congrats to Chef Izard for becoming the next Iron Chef America, well deserved!

If you're a foodie visiting Chicago, Girl & the Goat is a must-try. I highly recommend making reservations beforehand because they do fill up! My girlfriend and I arrived a bit earlier than our reservation, but they suggested to grab a quick drink at the bar or to walk around the neighborhood.

Escargot Ravioli - Unfortunately, my least favorite dish of the night, not because it was bad, but it just wasn't as complex as the other dishes we ordered. Slight earthy-ness with the sauce, but nothing too special.

Duck Tartare - Recommended! Different flavors and textures with each bite, it was one of the most fun dishes to eat of the night.

Woodfire Glazed Lamb Ribs - I've grown to love lamb and this dish did not disappoint. Comes with four pieces, sticky, saucy, great flavors.

Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face - Runny egg, potato sticks, tender pork, mix it all together for the perfect brunch flavors. Loved it!

Goat Empanadas - Crispy outside, meaty filling, then add the guacamole and blueberry pineapple salsa, what a combination!

Confit Goat Belly - Goat, crab, lobster, woaahhhh, what a great combination. Recommended!

Chocolatey-Chocolate Cake - We had room for one dessert and really wanted to try the shiitake gelato. We were totally caught off guard with the flavors, but it worked so well together.

We ordered a few of the cocktails to pair with our meal and it seems like we made a mistake not getting the Pan Roasted Halibut, but we were completely stuffed. There is a chef's table option that I would love to try in the future. What an incredible dining experience, well worth trying out, will be back!

Definitely one of our very favorite restaurants in Chicago!  Truly 5 star!
Chef Izard does amazing things with each and every item on the menu and not a one was anything less than stellar!

My guest and I love to share plates, so this was perfect for this style of enjoying a meal!  Trevor, our server, was friendly, helpful, attentive, but not overbearing.  He was professional and helpful as well!  

After looking over the wine list we decided to begin with a bottle of the Girl & the Goat Red wine.  It had a comfortable price point and for a Walla Walla Cab, it was a solid wine!

Then we dug in -- BIG TIME!  

We began with Squash Blossoms and the Goat Empanadas for appetizers.  My guest loved the Blossoms the best of these two while I thought the Empanadas were just a touch higher on the deliciousness scale!  They truly reminded me of the empanadas I enjoyed in Chile, where I fell in love with them so that is high praise from me!

Then we got serious!  We had the scallops, the walleye, the green beans, and the lamb ribs.  Each was spectacular and amazing in their own way!  Truly amazing!  Each was cooked to perfection and with wonderful seasonings, flavors, and aromas!  Served hot and with each dish fully explained to us by the server as they each came to our table, in perfect order and not rushed at all.

The green beans are something else and out of this world!  Do not miss them!  The scallops were absolutely excellent and then the jackpot arrived -- the walleye and the lamb ribs.  Again my guest and I were split.  She said the lamb ribs outranked the walleye by a bit, while I insisted the walleye was a touch above the lamb ribs!  If we weren't so full by this point we'd have had a second order of each just to settle our argument, but instead settled for a very nice cappuccino and an espresso.

This is a wonderful eating experience in a great food city so do yourself a true favor and do not miss Girl & the Goat!

Love this place as I read about it in several magazines and had dinner here.  First of all the ambience and the vibe are awesome.  The menu is full of delicious options that will blow you away.

For starters we ordered the pan fried shishito peppers with fresh parmesan, sesame and miso. We also ordered the chickpea fritter with whipped feta, heirloom tomato, stone fruit, and served with nicoise olives.  For dinner we had the pan roasted halibut with marcona almond butter, white asparagus, and blueberry nuoc cham. My friend ordered the grilled walter's chicken green harissa, confit salsify, grilled grapes, and black lime gremolata. We also tried the kalbi beef ribs with sweet corn coblettes, and served with grilled okra relish.  We also got an order of the goat carpaccio with smoked​ trout roe. olive-maple vinaigrette.

Five Stars for awesome ambience, great service, and delicious food!

As soon as I booked my trip to Chi I went straight to open table to make a dinner res for Girl & the goat! Since I had never gotten the chance to dine there when I lived in Chicago so, my visit was the perfect opportunity to finally experience it!

On the way there our foodie über driver recommended that we try the pigface and vegetables. His advice sounded legit to me so we went with it. We decided on the himachi crudo, the roasted cauliflower the pigface and carnal corn and malt balls for desert.

The crudo was delightful, light and fresh, but way too small in my opinion.

The cauliflower was nicely roasted, minty and topped with delicious pine nuts.

The pig face was flavorful, but too gelatinous for my liking. But..what can you really expect from a dish titled pig face?? haha.

Finally, the caramel corn and malt balls was so delicious, obvi! :)

Overall, it was a nice experience and our server was very attentive. Glad I got to finally try it!

I have been to Girl & the Goat several times, and have loved it!  The service is amazing, the food is excellent and I love sitting at the bar when I walk in w/o a reservation.  I take all out of town guests there and they love it too.  I was in last Thursday w/ my sister and we ate at the bar.  Gerson was amazing, friendly, accommodating, and I have diet restrictions and they always take of that SO well.

Girl and the Goat was the one of best meals that I've had in Chicago.
I was so amazed that it lived up to its hype! I remember seeing Bourdain enjoying in delicious bites (escargot ravioli) during an episode of the Layover in 2012.

Booking the restaurant was quite the ordeal. You had to go to the website, click, hover, wait and wait for a good reservation to open up on Open Table. The first reservation that I got was 10:00pm, then 9:00pm, the best one that I kept was 8pm.

We arrived half an hour early and thanks to the table that left before us, our table was ready in 5 minutes. I know that Bourdain stated that he was surprised about how big the restaurant was in his show but it is larger than any of us expected. Two dining rooms separated with a divide and both sides were bustling with diners, staff and chefs.

The three of us went with much anticipation and excitement. The menu is farm-friendly and vegetarian friendly. The food was rich, unctuous and very novel.

We ordered:
1) The escargot ravioli, which had a surprisingly palate cleansing seafood taste compared the savory rich bacon-y pig-bone broth that the escargot was bathing in. I was so enamored with the sauce that I tried to drink it. DON'T. Its very salty.

2) Duck tongues- I loved this! The duck tongues were fried bits of protein with a spicy piri piri sauce and mixed with tuna and black bean. It was very appetizing, spicy and refreshing and so unique! Something that I've never had before.

3) Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face. I thought this would arrive on the pig's head. Surprise! Instead, the pig's face is boiled down, flattened like a hamburger and has a sunny side egg on top. This tasted like simmered savory bacon and that runny egg mixed so well with the pig face.

4) Beef tongue. This was a like a deconstructed beef tongue tortilla/taco. Beef tongue with crispy tortillas, beef vinaigrette and salsa verde. This was an excellent way to eat savory tender beefy tongue. We put the tongue slices on the tortilla with salad and salsa verde. I wanted a whole bowl of this for myself.

5) Crisp braised pork shank. This was the best version of pork shank that I've ever had. The pork shank was tender, fall off the bone and the outer parts crisped in jus and butter. The fresh piece of buttery soft naan was perfect to roll up bits of the pork and stone fruit kimchee. The kimchee could have used more spice but the dish altogether was an excellent idea! I only wished that we had more naan!

Loved Girl and the Goat.

review.des:
I keep coming back to Girl & the Goat, in a city where there are a million amazing restaurants to be had, because the experience always feel seamlessly choreographed from service (pacing out the arrival of your shared plates perfectly, super attentive water refills, etc.) to ambience to the genuinely playful food.

New things I tried this time with my friend Lisa included:
- my new favorite, the chickpea fritters; like agedashi tofu with a middle eastern flavor, super soft creamy chickpea cubes with crispy fried coating, and a quinoa tabbouleh with pomegranate seeds to add brightness.
- calamari bruschetta; calamari and goat bacon, with diced green tomatoes, make for very rich flavor. We started our meal with brioche so I was regrettable too full and had to abandon some of the bread.
- dessert! My favorite of the two we had was the lemon shortcake though the sesame seed ice cream that came with the pavlova was always refreshing. The only reason we made it to dessert was because of our server's strong instinct to preemptively cancel our second pork dish -- which we wanted, but were regretting when we were halfway through our meal and already painfully full. Bless you for reading our minds.

Shoutout to Owen and Einstein for taking care of us and making our dinner a lovely, memorable experience!

pics.caption: Lemon Make You Happy and the Chocolate Pavlova Says-A-Me

review.des:
This place was packed on a weeknight! So difficult to even find a seat at the bar. Definitely make reservations for this place more than a day in advance, because they seem to be consistently booked several days in advance.

String beans (4.5/5) - String beans are simple, but this dish packs a punch! Definitely a lot of flavor going on here with the fish sauce vinaigrette. The cashews also add a nice crunchy texture to the dish but I don't feel like that was needed for texture as the beans were already crunchy, which is a good thing for beans! Crunchy beans are the best and indicates the beans were cooked properly. Just a little too saucy for me, but I still highly recommend this dish as a starter

Escargo Ravioli (2.5/5) - I was unfortunately not impressed with this dish. You get 6 ravioli which were super thin and I could barely tell there was any escargot in here. The bacon tamarind sauce, crispy onions, and celery also just added too much  'diced/firm' texture to the dish, so I felt it was unneeded and there were just too many elements going on. This also contributed to the plating that was not very refined because they were trying to incorporate too many elements and ended up putting it together kinda sloppily. My biggest cripe though, is that this dish was too salty. Some dishes are on the salty side, but this was too much.

Pork Shank (4/5) - This is a large shank that comes with butternut squash kimchi (it's not really kimchi but rather pickled without the spiciness/acidic flavor). The pork is deep fried very quickly, so the outside is crispy. I like this unique manner in which this pork is prepared, however, I feel like it falls short just a bit. Reason being if you happen to take a piece of the pork tha tis all on the outside, you're just gonna get the skin and it tastes very very dry and grindy. You really have to cut the pork in a manner in which you get the inner soft parts, but also outer crispy parts. I would like to see the chefs cut it for you, but in a deeper 'score' like manner such that the presentation of the entire shank is still maintained, but it's cut in a way you'll fully enjoy the taste. Either way, the flavors of this dish is really solid

Goat belly (5/5) - By far my favorite dish of the night. It's a very small portion, but executed with so much thought and finesse. This goat belly is served with lobster, crab, and fennel. It's almost like a surf and turf, with a lot more thought behind it (Rather than just throwing meat and seafood on a dish). The goat belly was rich, but the addition of the crab and lobster provides a refreshing lightness that tones down and complements the richness of the goatbelly. The fennel added a really nice texture and rounded out the profile of the dish overall.

pics.caption: lamb shank. flash deep fried. not bad.
goat belly. highly recommend, but don't expect a good portion. just for taste

review.des:
I'll start things off with a quick warning, reservations fill up 2-3 weeks before the day. Without a reservation, the wait at 8 pm is about 2 hours. The bar and lounge area is open seating and first come first serve, so if you're a seasoned bar/lounge seat scrapper then you're in luck.

We hung out at the rail behind the bar counter for a few minutes. We missed the first open seat but the second one was ours. A wild couple suddenly appears out of nowhere and goes for the seat but the bartender informs them that we were here first. Seated in 20 minutes, awesome!

The menu is all shareable small plates, separated into catagories, veggies, fish, meat, bread, oyster, goat and dessert. After being given a few recommendations, we ended up ordering 7 dishes.

1. Green beans with cashews and fish sauce vinaigrette
2. Escargot ravioli with bacon tamarind sauce
3. Duck tongues with tuna and black bean poke
4. Pan roasted corvina with grape, Szechwan pepper and yogurt sauce.
5. Squash blossom Crab Rangoon, fill yogurt and almond
6. Seared diver scallops, English pea quinoa, tahini vinaigrette, Chinese sausage
7. Goat belly, bourbon butter, crab, lobster and fennel.

I'll just start by saying that everything was delicious. The green beans were perfectly cooked and the fish sauce vinaigrette reminded my girlfriend of the food of her people (I'm kidding but serious at the same time). The escargot ravioli was savory and delicious with a hint of the classic musky snail flavors. The crispy duck tongue was a delicious balance of textures and flavors. The corvina had a bit of a Szechuan kick to wake up the palate and refreshing tart grapes. I can go on but just go try it yourself, everything kicks ass.

Atmosphere: 5/5
Food/drink: 5/5
Cost: 4/5
Service: 5/5
Overall: 5/5

pics.caption: Duck tongue with tuna and black bean poke
Sautéed green bean with cashew and fish sauce vinaigrette

review.des: Been wanting to come here for a while and finally did tonight. Reservations were for 5pm, which may seem too early, but on a Friday after the work week, it couldn't have come sooner. Despite the early time, the place was still busy. They recommend two dishes per person. Portions are meant for sharing. For starters, we had The Sourdough. The red onion mostarda was my favorite spread that came with it. We ordered the Potato-Blue Cheese Pierogies, Wood Grilled Broccoli, Seared Diver Scallops, and the Crispy Beef Short Ribs. All were delicious. He had the 18th Street's The Fox & The Goat beer and I had the Dark Matter drip-coffee. For dessert, we had the Chocolate Pavlova Says-A-Me! It was like a piece of heaven. Can't say enough good things about the food and service. I can't wait to come back and try the other dishes.

So we finally made it to The Girl and The Goat. It was a 9:00pm reservation on a Monday night, and the weather was really crappy. They were still at capacity.
We arrived early and grabbed a couple drinks at the bar. The service was fast, and by the time our drinks came out, our table was ready. The hosts, servers, and bartenders we dealt with were all very personable.
The first two drinks were very creative, but tasted too much like medicine for our taste. Later in the meal we ordered the Old Fashioned and The Charles Grey, and those were both very good.
For the meal, we ordered the focaccia (were both thought it was good), the broccoli (both thought it was really good), the bucatini (it was good), the chickpea fritter (awesome), and the grilled butter chicken. That was a big disappointment. I asked for the bucatini to be made without the tomatoes. He verified that I really didn't like tomatoes and left them out. The chicken dish was loaded with tomatoes. If it didn't have tomatoes, I still don't think I would have liked. It was a fork and knife dish, in sauce, and it had all the bones in it. I assumed it would have been deboned chicken breast. I tried a couple bites and left it alone.
The table was cleared several minutes later and I let them take the chicken away.
We also tried the popcorn ice cream malt ball dessert (really good), and the sweet potato cake dessert (amazing).
I never send dishes back, nor expect them to be taken off the bill in the super rare occasions that I do, but this time I was "kinda" hoping it might be taken off. I never did say anything though, so maybe it's my fault, but it was still there. I did not deduct a star for it. I'd probably give them 3.5 stars, but not 3. What was good, was good to excellent, but the medicine drinks and the chicken were just too far from good to rate them higher.
I still recommend The Girl and The Goat, but I don't know if I'll go back.

pics.caption: Wood Grilled Broccoli. Sorry we started before the picture. Highly recommended.

review.des:
**MAKE YOUR RESERVATIONS AHEAD OF TIME - LIKE MONTHS.  ITS WORTH IT.**

This place was on the top of my list for Chicago restaurants to try when visiting from NY - and let me tell you something, when I snagged a reservation for a Saturday night during Presidents Day weekend at 8:45 - it was just the beginning of a great experience.  

Even though I had a reservation, I still had to wait about 10 minutes for my table - not particularly happy that I was seated literally right behind the hostess stand.  It was a tad uncomfortable, but nevertheless - our server, the food, and the ambiance of the whole restaurant made this a truly memorable dinner.

We were told that the dishes on the menu, were mainly meant for sharing - so we went ahead and got several dishes to share.  We tried the calamari bruschetta, wood fired shrimp, crispy beef short ribs, crisp braised pork shank and the cauliflower.  The dishes were portioned well.  Pro tip - mix all the components of each dish into one bite, and you're taste buds will thank you for it.

Most surprising dish of the night was most definitely the calamari bruschetta - it was simply amazing.  The texture of the whole dish tied so well together. Every single component just wow'd my tastebuds. Most disappointing dish was the braised pork shank - the flavors were a little awkward, and did not mix well in my opinion.  It was very interesting, but I would probably skip the next time I visit and try something else.

Overall, this was a great experience - and will most definitely be returning my next trip to Chicago to try out the other dishes.

Months later - whenever my friends are booking a Chicago trip, my first recommendation is to score a reservation for Girl & the Goat. Most definitely a great overall experience.

3 stars for the service. I got a table on the patio, hard to find a waiter out there.
5 stars for the food. I had a flatbread with chorizo and cherries.

Service: 5/5
Ambiance: 5/5
Food: most of the time 5/5 but occasionally (to my taste) 3.5/5

This is arguably among the most well-known restaurants in Chicago, and reservations are fairly hard to come by, so definitely try to make the reservation 2 months ahead of time, when the reservations open up on OpenTable. I had a party of 7, and even though we made the reservation pretty far ahead in advance, the only time slot available was for 5pm. Still a reasonable time and we happily took it.

HIGHLY RECOMMEND for large parties - calling ahead and ordering the goat leg. The goat leg is usually 9-10 pounds, and costs $25/pound. The restaurant says it will feed up to 12 people. With some additional veggie dishes and between seven people, we ate about 85% of it. Not sure how far in advance this call needs to be made (we called about 24 hours ahead of time) but the way that the bone cleanly fell out tells me that it must have been cooked or soaked for hours. Even my picky Asian grandmother was loving the delicious, melt-in-your-mouth goat meat!

Our waitress recommended that we order some vegetables in addition to our goat leg, so we got two orders of the shishito peppers and two orders of the roasted cauliflower. The shishito peppers must have been topped in a lot of cheese and then baked, and wasn't my favorite dish because of the richness/saltiness. I typically prefer the clean taste of vegetables, maybe with a little added. I've been to Girl & the Goat before, and had a similar experience with the broccoli.
