Made a reservation 3 months beforehand and our options were already very limited. Basically we chose between a 5pm or 9pm meal so we opted for the latter. The service during our visit was average. Waitress was polite but not particularly friendly.

For dishes my friend and I semi-shared the following:
-Brioche w/ Sambal butter & lamb jam: This place seems to be known for their elevated breads and they did not disappoint. The sambal butter was very light and had the slightest kick to it. It was just the right flavor to balance out the bread's sweetness or to go with the lamb jam. Personally I would have liked it a bit stronger though. The brioche itself is full of butter. The texture is amazing and at the end of your bite, your mouth still has a coat of butteriness enveloping your taste buds. And if that's not enough fatty goodness for you, the lamb jam will give you another dose of fatty sweet flavor. (4/5)

-Duck Tartare: My absolute favorite dish of the night. I love duck in all it's forms but I've never had it raw and I wish I had tried this sooner. The duck has a bit more bite to it compared to raw beef or fish but it's still not tough. The pickled gooseberries and fried brussels sprouts add a variety of textures and flavors to the dish too. Despite everything that this dish has going on, it's still a very clean tasting dish. Also the duck fat lavash is out of this world. The duck fat in it doesn't make it heavy but it certainly makes them addictive. If I could I would purchase a giant box of these to take home with me and use it on every spread I have (5/5)

-Goat Liver Mousse: If you don't like goat, can't deal with liver, or all the above, this dish is not for you. However if you love a good pate and can take your gamey meats, this dish will delight your tastebuds. The mousse portion was small because that's all you need but texturally it was so fluffy and creamy. It didn't have any of the grittiness that comes with bad liver. The pickles also added a nice sweet, crunch, sour component to the dish. The mousse was served with the duck fat lavash that I made clear about how obsessed I am with them. They were also served with the warmest, moistest, most delicious crumpets I could ever imagine. (4.5/5)

-Pig Face: By far my least favorite dish. I didn't hate it but it was just so average. I guess for the price it's not bad and it is filling but I wouldn't waste my 3 month reservation on this dish. (3.5/5)

-Rhubarb and Goat Cheesecake: Technically my friend's dessert but I took a few bites. It's not quite what I expected but it works. The main thing I noticed is that it's quite a savory cheesecake. It's not very sweet and the various herbal elements remind me more of savory dishes so it didn't quite satisfy my end-of-the-meal sweet tooth. It's still quite tasty but not something I would get again. (3.5/5)

Overall, my experience here was phenomenal and I would most definitely come back again.

---The Re-Return: Multiple great items- bread, duck tartare, goat mousse---

While researching for our long weekend in Chicago this restaurant came up almost every time and I'm so glad we were able to go. We were celebrating our 7th wedding anniversary and this was our dinner out. We ordered several dishes, hamachi crudo, squash blossom rangoon, duck tongues, goat carpaccio, and goat belly. The only negative I had on any of the dishes was the squash blossom rangoon really needed salt and of course at this level of restaurant there isn't any on the table. The almonds it came with had no salt as well, so this didn't really help. However, this was my only criticism. My favorite was the goat belly. It's served with bourbon butter and crab and lobster. I was almost disappointed that I had to share it with my husband as I could have easily eaten it all myself. We finished with the chocolate pavlova and the caramel corn and malt balls. I think it says a lot about a restaurant when they spend just as much attention on dessert as the main meal. I couldn't decide which dessert was better and my husband and I were scraping the bowls at the end. Just as I found this restaurant researching I will be sure to recommend it to any of my friends visiting the area.
Resturant dishes were so unbelievable  the flavors are so unique and leaves me wanting more!

Top 3 restaurants in Chicago.

However, it's a shame the portion sizes have gone down, while prices have gone up.

Green beans - about 50% less quantity, 50% more price - so in essence - Double the price :(
Great restaurant, fantastic ambience definitely a place where you can order different type of plates and share them! Food is great and a fantastic spot will be back!

This restaurant was recommended to us by friends, and it is extremely popular! I went here on Yelp to see if I could reserve a table, and there was only one available for my husband and I at 10:15 PM! I went ahead and made the reservation, and boy, this restaurant was certainly packed out!

Immediately when you enter the restaurant, you are hit by how beautiful, cozy, and high quality the interior of the restaurant is. The idea behind this restaurant is interesting: it's tapas style, which my husband and I had already experienced at another restaurant called The Purple Pig.

The menu is simple and broken up into three categorie: meat, fish, and vegan, I believe. We went with the server's recommendations since it was our first time here. We had the appetizer of goat empanadas, and wow, those were delicious!

We then ordered a vegetable dish that was comprised of green beans and almonds; that was yummy as well.

I ordered the halibut, and my husband ordered the the goat ribs. The ribs were incredible and fell right off the bone. The halibut was probably my favorite dish of the evening, and it tasted wonderful! Our server informed me that the chef there has the halibut out as a special spring dish. So if you happen to go there during the spring, I highly recommend you order the halibut!

We tried a different type of dessert. I forget the name of it, but it's the first one on the list. It was definitely interesting and unique, and I'm glad we tried it, but I'm not sure if I would order it again. I am definitely more of a traditional desserts, like cheesecakes, regular cakes, ice cream, things like that. This dessert, while tasty, was a little too different for me.

All in all, this restaurant was absolutely amazing, and in my opinion, is a definite place to go if you're in the Chicago area.

One of our friends really wanted to try this place. I think he made a reservation quite in advance but we still ended up sitting in a table of 12 (we were 6) and shared the table. The place is super busy so I can see why the sharing was necessary, did it bother us? Eh. It's just not same you know... but the food was definitely delicious, we had a good time and the waiters were on point.... you make the best of it. We made it in so no complaint there. :]

Before eating here, I honestly wondered if this place was over hyped. After my wonderful experience here, I fully believe that Girl and the Goat deserves all of the praise it gets.

Getting a Saturday night reservation can be difficult, but you can sometimes get a seat at the bar or table if you come right after they open.

Service: The service was perfect from start to finish. Due to an event going on downtown that blocked off several streets, my friend was unable to join me for our dinner reservation. My boyfriend was able to come in her place and got there about 30 minutes after my original reservation.  Despite how increasingly busy they were getting, the restaurant was still able to get us a table immediately after he arrived. I appreciated how accommodating the Girl and Goat employees were under these circumstances.

Cocktails: Pyramid Scheme and Morning Ritual. The Pyramid Scheme is a scotch based cocktail that was more on the fruity side. The smokiness from the scotch was present, but not overwhelming. The Morning Ritual was a great spicy cocktail.

Chickpea Fritter (10/10): Great Mediterranean style dish with delicious toppings on top of the fritters

Pan fried shishito peppers (10/10): I never really imagined parmesan, sesame, and miso working well with shishito peppers, but it tasted great. The portion was also generous.

Grilled Octopus (9/10): The octopus was extremely fresh tasting and cooked perfectly.

Goat Empanadas (8/10): The empanadas were good, but they wouldn't be on my list to get next time. The meat inside the empanadas didn't have the most impressive flavor.

Price Point/Value: This restaurant encourages shared plates and a majority of the dishes are about $15-$20 each. Some of the bigger meat dishes are around $25. Cocktails are $14. Breads are $5. For two people, they typically suggest that you order about 4 dishes.

I'm a Stephanie Izard Groupie, what can I say. Everything she touches turns to gold.

Little Goat - Gold.
Duck Duck Duck - Gold
Girl and the Goat - after 7 plus years: PURE GOLD.

Visited Girl and the Goat recently after a five-year hiatus. After 7+ years, Girl and the Goat still feels like it is the hot new spot on restaurant row. Music is on point. A little Beyonce, a little rock, perfect playlist. They have everything down to a science and it's really a treat to dine there. Props to you Stephanie Izard.  

Made a reservation for (2) and a request for the Chef's Table for my boyfriend's birthday.  Not only was the food delicious from start to finish... the service, the atmosphere and the overall vibe of the entire night was a 10.

I would highly recommend this experience for any celebration dinner to really take the dining experience up a notch. (note: the Chef's Table does not take reservations, but you can request it in your reservation and hope for the best).

Now, to the food:

- GREEN BEANS (these are not your grandmother's green beans). Damn. One of the best
       things I ate. The sauce, the cashews, all brilliant.
- Escargot Ravioli -  Not my favorite item, really rich.
- Pig Face: One of the pillars of the menu, and the perfect combo of sweet, savory.
- Bucatini - One of the best pasta dishes I've enjoyed. Perfect to share, as it's heavy.
- Duck Tartare: This stole the show for me. Everything worked perfectly together and
       comes with delicious duck fat crackers.

We had to make reservations 2 months in advance, but it was worth the wait! My wife and I ordered about 5 small plates to share between the two of us, and everything was amazing and perfect. It was very attractive inside, and bigger than you would expect. Prices were high, but actually fairly reasonable considering the excellent quality of the food and wine. We really want to come back again, too bad we have to wait 2 more months!

What a fantastic spot! Book early, they fill up quickly. The menu is very diverse and features a lot of crazy proteins. Also, a majority of the time you can see Stephanie Izard herself working the line and sending out amazing food. Very cool experience
Fabulous dishes, so different, creative mix of fruit in sauces. Really delicious!!  Had kohlrabi salad, roasted cauliflower (amazing) , halibut, lamb ribs.

Updated:

Went back here while on another work trip to Chicago and it did not disappoint! It's my favorite place in Chicago now! Excellent food, service and atmosphere!

This time I had the salad that started with k and the halibut. Both was fantastic! I have the blueberry cake dessert and my friend had the chocolate one. The chocolate one, with salted caramel, is one of the best desserts I've ever had. I am looking forward to coming back to this restaurant! Incredible and super worth it!

Service: 5 stars
Food: 3 stars
Dessert: 5 stars

My colleague recommended we visit this restaurant on a recent work trip to Chicago. I don't eat meat and she thought it would have some good vegetarian options for me.

Here's the scoop:

1. Beet salad - way way too salty... wouldn't get it again
2. Cauliflower - best of all
3. Shashito pepper - 2nd best
4. Shrimp - decent

However, the upside down pineapple cake was INCREDIBLE! I would go back just for that! It was perfect soft and moist in the middle and the cognac ice cream was to die for! Ambience in the restaurant is nice too.

pics.caption: Shashito peppers... pretty good but wish it had a kick
Upside down pineapple cake with cognac gelato - AMAZING!

review.des: Everything we had were delicious. The only thing is that the portion size is just too small and price too high.

pics.caption: Wood Fired Skirt Steak, very tasty by too small

review.des: This place is cool I really like the food in the service. Bathrooms could've been cleaner but I enjoyed my experience.

The short ribs are a must! The cauliflower was also really good. We got the empanadas and escargot ravioli which I would pass on next time. You can definitely find great food on the menu. I would go back but probably try some other items. We had half great items and half not-so-great. I love the shareable concept though!

ALWAYS GREAT,. I prefer the seats near window adjacent from the bar... What is fresh from market is what is best... STEFANIE Has been and always will be consistent for Modee she's open to the present..
she isn't the FIRST FEMALE TOP CHEF FOR HER BEAUTY!!! GURL got skills ...

I love this place. Great food, great vibe. Be warned, though: Lots of other people feel the same way, so it can get pretty crowded. Still, staff is friendly and works to make sure everyone is attended to and taken care of.

food looked nice as an exotic plate but not delicious! the only thing I thought that was delicious is the lamb ribs otherwise not worth the money. The menue is neither simple ,easy to read nor understand. What my husband & I had were:
1- olive bread: nice & the spread of butter was ok
2- roasted beans: it was actually burned with parmesan on top
3- roasted cauliflower: it was good compared to the one mentioned. I actually liked it but wouldn't imagine myself craving for it & re-ordering it again
4- lamb ribs: DELICIOUS!

The lamb ribs were great! I also had the confit goat belly where the combination was very unique, a cheese spread, and one of their desserts. I wasn't blown away unfortunately and the flavors of the other dishes weren't anything very special that I couldn't get anywhere else for cheaper/more portion. It was solid food, I just didn't think it lived up to the hype unfortunately.

We wanted to try Girl and the Goat for a long time and finally got a chance to on a Monday night. We ordered a few different plates for two people. We started with the Mr. Potato Bread which was nice and warm and had little bites of potato throughout. There were two types of spread that came with the bread and both were delicious. Next we had the Goat Empanadas on the recommendation of the server. Although the empanadas were flaky and crispy the filling and blue cheese aioli did not taste good to me. My favorite plate of the night was the Chickpea Fritters. It was a delicious mix of roasted chickpeas, fresh mint leaves, feta cheese and pomegranate. This plate was a must try! We also had the Pork Shank which was served with a ranch and red sauce. The pork was crispy on the outside however the plate itself was alright.

Overall the service was great, the ambiance was perfect for dinner, the prices were high, and the food was good.

My girlfriend and I visited the Girl & the Goat during a short trip to Chicago after hearing all the rave reviews about this establishment. We booked a couple weeks in advance and were able to score the last reservation available. Although the food was good it was nothing amazing and quite frankly seemed a bit hyped.
The four dishes that we tried were: Veal Tartare, Calamari Bruschetta, Goat Empanadas, and the Roasted Pig Face. The Winner of these dishes was easily the Veal Tartare and it was the first dish we had so we figured we were going to be in for a great meal. The Calamari Bruschetta was the runner up and the other two dishes completely underwhelmed.
All in all it was an average dinner experience and with the wide variety of choices in Chicago I couldn't see myself going back to Girl & the Goat.

Not that the Girl & the Goat is in any desperate need of reviews or accolades, but this restaurant really is amazing and it deserves to be ranked as one of the best places to eat in this great city of Chicago.  I've not encountered a single restaurant that is quite like this, and when a restaurant can say that it stands alone in the type of cuisine it is delivering, that's pretty phenomenal.  Way to set yourself apart from the crowd, Girl & the Goat.  I had always known there was something special about this restaurant, but could never say what it was that made it this way.  If I'm being honest, it is still difficult to verbalize what makes this restaurant so special aside from the obvious.

With all this praise and affirmation, I have to say that I was beyond excited when my fiancé asked me, "By the way, you want to go to Girl & the Goat?"  Now that I have realized just how sought-after this restaurant is, it makes me laugh at how nonchalant he was when asking me if I wanted to go here.  It makes me laugh even more when thinking of how easily we got in, but then again we did wander in here right when they opened up at 4:30pm.  Though it was not excessively busy at this time, it was still teeming with people.  There was an army of 10 staff members waiting at the hostess stand, seemingly just waiting to do some crowd control for the people who would be swarming in to the restaurant soon enough.  

As it was, my fiancé and I sat at the bar and had a very lovely conversation with the bartender who flattered us by asking if we were professors at UIC...the flattery made me like our bartender instantly, but he proved himself to be a great waiter.  He made several suggestions for food, only one of which we listened to,  and worked to ensure our entire experience was one that we wouldn't easily forget.  Though the bartender was trying to offer a combination of light and heavy food selections, we just went all in and chose some of the richest stuff available.  Because, you know, that's what we do.  Go big or go home, as they say.

We ordered the gouda and bacon appetizer which was essentially the warmest loaf of bread accompanied by gouda cheese and some amazingly creative bacon-bruschetta like spread.  It was spectacular, but not nearly as spectacular as the cuddlefish.  I have never in my life had cuddlefish, but I've come to see the error of my ways - this is a dish I need to indulge in more often.  However, I doubt anyone will do it up quite like here.  This dish had such a zesty and complex flavor profile that worked like I wouldn't have expected it to.  As much as I loved the cuddlefish, the mac-daddy of it all was the goat shank.  Yes, there were some fatty parts to it, but for the most part this shank was cooked perfectly and the meat simply fell off the bone.  This goat shank is one of the most luxurious things you can eat - it's somewhat simplistic, but so decadent.  

My fiancé and I split everything I mentioned, and it was plenty of food.  Our bartender told us that people usually order 2-3 dishes for themselves, but I could not imagine this!  Get some beers (they have Three Floyd's) and cocktails in you and you'll be bursting at the seams if you order 2-3 dishes for yourself.  Not to mention, your wallet would also be bursting at the seams...it get's prettttty pricy here.  The cost of the food could be an inhibitor, but everything is gourmet and this is wonderful place to celebrate occasions...so save up and splurge here!  It's absolutely worth it.

P.S. I still desperately want to know the story behind why it is called Girl & the Goat!

It's ridiculous how much in advance you need to make a reservation for this place. Got mine 2 months ahead. Was curious when we got there about all the hype and believe me this place lives up to it. Right from the eclectic wall art to the unique collection of dishes, I was floored! We started with the cauliflower and the goat liver mousse, both were absolutely amazing. Even my husband who is not a fan of liver enjoyed the dish. We then ordered the salmon and the pork shank which turned out to be the highlight of our dinner.
Can't wait to go back to try the rest of the menu!!

I don't get the hype. The food wasn't terrible, but it also wasn't memorable. For the amount of effort it takes to plan in advance to secure a reservation & the overall cost I was expecting more.

The restaurant is small plates style so you order multiple different things to try. What they're well known for is the "pig face" dish which is basically an escalated diner style hash with pulled pork and a sunny side up egg.

There's nothing wrong with those flavors obviously, but it's just something a home cook with a crockpot and a frying pan could make.

On the bright side, this place seems fun to drop by and a grab a drink with friends.

freaking fantastic. this place is always booked but my boyfriend and i managed to get a 7:45 reservation on a monday night. our waiter was very friendly and answered all our questions about the menu.  and of course, the food was amazing as expected.

we ordered:
- cranberry walnut brioche - so warm and tasty (4/5)
- goat empanadas - my favorite! (5/5)
- sautéed green beans - weird because so many people like the green beans right? this was my boyfriend's favorite! how can veggies taste so good?! (5/5)
- hamachi crudo - good but I don't think I would get it again (4/5)
- pig face - tasty! basically a sunny-side up egg on top of a pig's face! (5/5)
- caramel corn & malt balls - waiter recommended this dessert and we are so glad he did. it's ice cream with a chocolate shell and caramel popcorn! um...yum! (4/5)

the two of us finished the above and were satisfied and quite full. :)

can't wait to be back!

Finally! I've been wanting to try our Girl and the Goat and finally had the chance to while attending a work event. The service was great and very accommodating to different dietary restrictions. Which should be expected for a private event. We tried a variety of different dishes and I loved most! My favorite was the salmon!

This is literally the best restaurant I have eaten at, and I'm a NERRRRRD. Everything is extremely unique and mind blowing, the service is unreal and quick and the atmosphere slays. DO NOT miss out. If you're in Chi, you must go here.

Definitely a must-try restaurant in Chicago and a difficult place to find a seat. Got here at 530pm on a Friday and there wasn't a table available for a few hours. There was availability outside, but I was in no mood to eat in sub 40 degree weather (it never gets this cold in LA). The outdoor seating would be fantastic once the weather warms up in the summer. Bar was completely packed, but luckily there was seating available at the couches and we avoided a wait.

Ordered 4 dishes between the two of us and it was the right amount of food in this tapas style restaurant.

chickpea fritter- good mixture of flavors complementing the deep fried chickpeas. it's a good dish, but it wasn't very memorable. kind of regret choosing it over the roasted cauliflower once we saw the table next to us order the cauliflower

goat empanadas- this was cooked very well. just make sure you eat it immediately before it gets cold. liked that it's not greasy like a lot of other places. however, it's definitely the most expensive empanada I've ever had, as it was 2 empanadas for $16. I wouldn't recommend getting it because although it's good, you can get something of similar quality at a bakery for a fraction of the cost

Pan roasted halibut- my favorite dish of the night. this was absolutely fantastic. definitely get this dish

Wood oven roasted pig face- this was my 2nd favorite dish of the night. Great mixture of fatty goodness between the pig face and the egg.

Service was attentive but not annoying. Just wasn't that comfortable sitting on a couch and would've really liked a table. Otherwise, it was a great dining experience and I would recommend it to locals and visitors. Just remember to book a reservation or come early, because it gets packed (a few parties were staring us down like wolves, waiting for us to leave our seats as we were eating).

Fantastic food and service. This is now one of my favorite restaurants in Chicago.

We had 6 dishes between two of us. Everything was presented well, and tasted great.

The soft shell "crab cakes" weren't a traditional crab cake, but they tasted amazing.

The fried duck tongues were a surprisingly delectable treat.

The whole experience was made by how knowledgeable our waiter was. Once we chose our dishes he was in charge of putting them in order and pacing them to come out at the right time. The extra effort was noticeable, and it truly made the experience exceptional.

For the price point of this restaurant I felt like the service was somewhat lacking - the food came out in a stranger order that could have been improved. That being said, the food was very delicious and the recommendations we got from our server were amazing. This place was inventive and delicious, and if I lived in Chicago I would come here all the time!

It wasn't that busy on a Friday night at 8pm, despite its popularity. We had no reservations and were seated immediately, but I suspect we may have been lucky.

Everything about the Girl & the Goat screams perfection. The ambience, cocktails, service and of course; the food. I have tried to replicate the Cauliflower dish multiple times to no avail, which is bad for my fiance who has to eat it but good for me because it's another excuse to make our way back to get the real deal.

Always a must for out of towners coming to stay with me.

I had heard so much (all wonderful things) about this restaurant from many Chicagoians, and I just had to try this place before I left.  Honestly I didn't share their experience.  
- Be prepared for a long wait no matter what time of day in the week it is.  You can sit at the bar which is first come first serve.  You can make a reservation about a couple weeks in advance if you want to sit at a decent hour.
- The place is so loud you can barely hear the bartender.  We were lucky to find a spot at the bar and only waited about 15 minutes. Our bartender/waiter was very nice but of course you get a bit of a different experience sitting at the bar.
Here is a rundown of the items we ordered.  It's tapas style so for two people 4-6 dishes is plenty. We had 4 dishes plus a dessert.  
Chickpea fritter- this was the best dish I had here.  It was paired with quinoa and had lots of amazing flavors. I wished there was more.  
Empanadas - the outside shell was cooked very well. As far as the goodies inside the shell, it was just ok.  
Roasted cauliflower - nice touch with the pickled peppers and mint but there is so much cauliflower one can have. I wish the portion size was smaller with this dish and more with the chickpea fritter.  
Pan roasted sea bass - could not eat it. Probably one of the worst tasting dishes I've eaten in a very long time.  Sorry to the chef but the major problem with it was the mint vanilla yogurt that was paired with the fish. Yogurt and fish should never be paired together.  On top of it, the vanilla and mint made it taste even worse.  There were just many competing flavors and textures that just shouldn't have been on the same plate.  
Our bartender had asked us how we liked everything and we were very honest with him.  He asked us to pick something else on the menu and we chose a dessert and he was kind enough to bring us two types.  Thank you!! The desserts were good. We had the apple cake and caramel corn and malt balls desserts.
This place was kinda hard to get a reservation so we had dinner on the later side which was fine by me. The wait staff was excellent. The food was good. The place was cool.

This was the highlight of our Chicago trip, and my favorite meal out of all the places we dined at.  We spent a lot, but a lot of it was due more to the drinks (those added up quickly at $14 apiece).  All in all, we spent $70 on drinks and $90 on food, lol.  The drinks were oddly the only part I didn't enjoy.  I tried Bananas in Cabanas and the Spritz, but ended up preferring my water...  My husband ended up getting 3 "Ring of Fire"s - so I think it's safe to say he enjoyed his drinks more!  

We lucked out and ended up having amazing seats right by the kitchen.  We were able to watch every dish being made, and it was such a treat!   Even though we had ordered our food already based on our server's recommendations, everything looked delicious and we were second guessing if we should have ordered...well... everything!

We ordered the homemade sweet onion brioche with smoked salmon cream cheese and pickle relish (from their sister restaurant across the street), goat empanadas, grilled pork belly, and wood-fired lamb ribs.  They must have liked our reactions because they also gave us a chickpea fritter chaat on the house!  That carrot hummus was great, and Melissa gave us the great tip of using it on our homemade brioches too. :)

All were EXCELLENT, but oh.my.god. the lamb ribs... this was our our finale and it was the most soft, succulent, and flavorful lamb I've had in my entire life.  If we weren't so stuffed, we would have ordered it again.  To give you an idea of how good... I would return to Chicago JUST for this dish again.  If you get one dish, let this is the one.  If you aren't sure if you like lamb... this would be the creme de la creme to figure that out.  If you don't like this?  You don't like lamb.

From our seats, we could easily see that this place was a well-oiled machine and had their techniques down pat - whether it be Melissa on dessert, Jasmine on salads, or Eli on the empanadas ("Nada!")... it was truly watching artists at work.  They were so meticulous about plating, and the service staff were also impressive and helping to set up as well.   They were a great team, helping each other during the hectic dinner rush.  At one point, a waiter had about 15 desserts on his tray (I was truly afraid for him) but he balanced that thing as if it were nothing!

We truly enjoyed the camaraderie of the staff.  Seeing Melissa, Eli, and Jasmine keep their cool in the pressures of crowded, insanely busy kitchen, but still finding the joy in what they do and taking hilarious jabs at each other made it such a fun experience.  We also had the inside scoop on what Melissa thought were the best desserts (who would know better than the dessert chef!?).  She recommended the Matl Balls and the seasonal Rhubarb pie, and even let us know we could order mini-versions (since we were so full but wanted to try both).  We never would have thought to have tried the Rhubarb pie, but we're so glad we did.  It was even better than the malt balls and I heartily recommend it if you have the chance.

If only I could do my 5 day Chicago trip over!  I would have come here and try different menu items (+ the lamb ribs) at least three times!

This place is worth every penny.  If you visit Chicago, make it a point to go here!

pics.caption: Mini Malt Balls with popcorn (left) and the seasonal Rhubarb pie (right)
The best Lamb Ribs I have ever had in my life!
Homemade Brioche with salmon spread and pickle relish!

review.des: Service was great. I went with great expectations, and i was not wowed. Apparently everyone i know who visited chicago has been to this place... While not bad at all, i just want to say: only because you use gochujang on a dish,,it doesnt make it korean.... I posted pix of everything that our party ate

pics.caption: Pork shank w peach kimchee, im korean yo, this was interesting but not quite kimchee, the peach was fresh and an interesting interpretation

review.des: Stopped by pretty late without a rezzo expecting to get a seat but the place was packed. We ended up getting sat outside witch worked out great. We let our server order for us and she did not disappoint! Every bite from the first  course to dessert was delicious. She was even kind enough to send out a couple desserts on the house! We left happy and full to say the least.

It was wild.  It was hectic.  It was NOT what I expected, but it was amazing.  The one important thing I can say is "try the pig face".  It may weird you out slightly, but trust this southern girl who went to Chicago just to eat.... this stop was a highlight of the trip.    It was still going strong at 10 pm... so get a reservation whenever you can and curve your day to make it work.   It is so worth it!

There's a lot of hype with The Girl and the Goat.  It does seem unfair to compare this restaurant to the juggernaut restaurants of the world; simply stating that my palate may have been diluted eating at fine restaurants in San Francisco, New York and other places in Chicago.

Maybe, I should have gone when it first opened and may have a different attitude towards the shared plates but I had better goat dishes and interpretations of oysters and deviled eggs.

The cocktails were strong and the only complaint I had was our waiter messed up our order and didn't provide the bread dish we requested which would have satisfied the 7 dish order to share.

He even had the audacity to say to me that we ordered a lot of food.  What's your problem? No one has ever stopped me from ordering as much food and alcohol as I wanted.  So check yourself.  If I ask for your opinion, I would have asked for it.  Otherwise, you can keep your comments to yourself and keep your paying customers happy.
One of the best restaurants in Chicago. We've been multiple times and are thrilled with our food, drinks, and service every time we go!

This is no diner, it is a slick slice of heaven whose menu pivots around goat.....and every bite is amazing. I ordered the goat chili chess fries and it was so full of flavor that I did not want to share it with my lovely wife, who loves chili cheese fries.  Because I was not sure if this would be enough food, which it could have been, I had started with a smoked tomato gazpacho.
I loved everything about this place. We sat at the counter and got a chance to see the whole kitchen process. They seemed like a well oiled machine, churning out yummy food. If you are in ChiTown, take the trip out to this place, it is so worth it.
If you're feeling adventurous then this is a place for you! Interesting menu, a little nervous to try some of the things but no regrets, they were all delicious!

I have been wanting to try the West Loop restaurant The Girl & the Goat since it opened in 2010, and recently I was finally able to! My husband surprised me with Sunday evening reservations (tables for Friday and Saturday nights were booked three to four months out), but when the day finally came I looked at the menu and thought that I was going to chicken out (no pun intended). I knew right away that this would be the perfect experience to write my first blog post about, so I decided to get adventurous and put my fears (and hopes of one day having a baby goat as a pet) aside.

Rather than a traditional menu that is broken up into appetizers, entrees, and desserts, this menu is divided into veggies, bread, fish, and meat. There is a separate menu that highlights the goat options because, well, of course! 

In addition to the cool artwork, inviting ambiance, and eclectic menu, this restaurant should be on your must try list because co-owner and executive chef Stephanie Izard is a total badass! Izard was the first female chef to win Top Chef (4th Season), and is a Chicago native. She opened her first restaurant at the age of 27, and currently has two other restaurants Little Goat Diner and Duck Duck Goat in the West Loop and Fulton Market District, respectively.

The items we ordered:

_Appetizer_

   -It's Gouda (bread)

_Dinner_

   -Grilled Cuttlefish

   -Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face

   -Steam-roasted Goat Neck

_Desserts_

    -Chocolatey - Chocolate Cake

    -Caramel Corn and Malt Balls

    -Pineapple Fun Side Up

Dint live up to the hype and price. Veggie options are more than other places - doesn't mean they are great.

Maybe the waiter was having a bad day but I did not find the service so great either.

So I haven't really figured what's the fuss all about.

As scrolling down to find a place to grab a bite I saw this restaurant and wonder how did they get nearly 7k reviews and still have a nearly 5 ish rating. That i knew i had to check this place out. got a reservation on opentable for a late saturday (10.45 ish) and when i got there there were a lot of open tables. the food is beyond spectacular and the drinks were absolutely some of the best cocktails I've ever had in life!! Order some raw oysters, scallops, oven roasted pig face and the pork shank! avoid the escargot ravioli and the hamachi though, it was okay just not as good as the others!

pics.caption: Escargot Ravioli, just okay. if i were to return i wont get this

review.des:
Anytime I'm in Chicago, Girl & the Goat is one of the first stops that I make and now that I live here I will be frequenting it much more often! Definitely make a reservation well in advance - it's packed every night of the week so while you can get full service at the bar, it's unlikely you'll find a spot if you just walk in during prime dinner hours.

We had a few of the staples but tried a few new dishes as well. Always get the fried oysters, pig face and the green beans. We also tried the green onion pierogies, lamb ribs and the chickpea fritter. All were delicious and beautifully presented!

Waitstaff is friendly, attentive and knowledgeable. You can tell there is a mentality of every table being important to every server as opposed to just their section. They truly work as a team to make sure your experience is seamless and you're never left wanting for anything. Our server in particular was super patient, kind and willing to answer questions and make recommendations. She even sent the chickpea fritter to the table as a gift to welcome me to the city when I told her that I just moved to Chicago.

Only thing to note is that Girl & the Goat is VERY loud. It's not overwhelming but conversation is pretty difficult if you're not sitting right next to the person you're talking to. If you're trying to have a conversation over dinner and don't want to yell, I would ask to sit on the outside patio (assuming the weather is nice of course).

10/10 would recommend. If you're in Chicago for any length of time Girl & the Goat is a must try.
the food was okay. went for my birthday and forgot that it existed until it showed up in a list of places that i should try.

The hype is real! Having heard so many good things about Girl & the Goat and having it bookmarked for years, I finally had the chance to dine here last week. Making reservations on OpenTable was surprisingly easy, and they had a plethora of spots available. Maybe it was because I ate at 10:30pm, but it also meant I was not dealing with trying to secure one of the toughest reservations in town.

The restaurant is pretty big, with a lounge, bar seats, and tables. Their decor is as bold and globally influenced as their menu. I like the contrast between the industrial decor with all the rustic, exposed brick. High ceilings, open kitchen, open restaurant - despite their well-known name and awards, this restaurant gives nothing but chill and cozy vibes. The 90s music brought an equally lively and nostalgic feel to our dining experience.

We ordered the following:

+Pan fried shishito peppers with parmesan, sesame, and miso
+Roasted cauliflower with pickled peppers, pine nuts, and mint
+Chickpea fritter with whipped spiced yogurt, sorrel chutney, and a mango-citrus relish
+Hamachi crudo with crisp pork belly, chili aioli, and caperberries
+Wood oven roasted pig face with a sunny side egg, tamarind, cilantro, red wine-maple, and potato sticks

My favorites were the roasted cauliflower, chickpea fritter, and pig face. I love that the menu contains foods from all around the world. There's definitely a lot of Mediterranean influences but if you look closely at the ingredients, it's all over the place. This place is not for the non-adventurers, the picky eaters. Everything is creative and speaks to Executive Chef Stephanie Izard's spunk. The food here is complex and well-executed, but none of it is pretentious or flashy. Flavors are all very balanced, which is quite surprising when you see the variety of dishes that exist on the menu.

Highly recommend ordering the chickpea fritter and the pig face, which is a signature dish here. The service is just as spot-on as the food. This is an experience worth trying - just make sure to book your reservation in advance!

pics.caption: Pig Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face

review.des: Get ready for an experience. This place from the moment you walk in is different. That's a good thing though. I ended up dining almost family style with 3 other couples. We all had our separate food orders but shared a table like a family. It was pretty unique. The menu is something different and truly meant for someone whom is ready to take on a culinary experience. I wasn't prepared to say the least. I was very impressed with the service speed and attentiveness of the staff as well. The food portions are meant to be shared with one other person. You're getting what you pay for in the food department. The atmosphere was on the louder side but overall there was always something different to be seen and observed. Great time. Can't wait to go back and try more.
Finally a popular place that lives up to the hype.  The staff is super nice and the food is incredible.  Food prices are pretty good considering the quality and popularity of the restaurant.

Our best dining experience when we were in Chicago last week. We went for the early seating, at 4:30. They want you out by 6:00 to make room for the reservation crowd, and we finished at 5:50, so it worked out fine.

The decor is open and classy without being fussy. Service was spot-on the entire time. We had a wonderful meal and a great time, and it wasn't even that expensive.

The weakest item we ate was the first; green garlic pieroges. They seemed uninspired to me. Pork shoulder was very good, served with naan and pickled radish. The two best dishes were the halibut, perfectly cooked, tender and flaky, and the goat belly, which was superb.

I would definitely put this restaurant on a list of suggested places to eat if one visits Chicago.

I came here with like 15 people or something, forreals. It was a big party, so we made a reservation like a month before or something. We were just visiting Chi-town so we wanted to see what foooood this city has to offer. Girl & The Goat with its thousands of review and near 5-star rating... damn! What a feat. So of course we had to come here.

SO. Ok. We were mostly drunk (posted at a bar prior to this), so I actually didn't want to continue the drinking once we got here. Plus I don't really like to drink while I eat (but I like to eat while I drink) so there's that. We ordered a TON. TON. of food. I mean, we had a lot of people, and the dishes here are great for sharing. So I just took advantage of the situation/my drunk friends, and ordered a shit ton:

1. Green garlic potato pierogies - BOMB. I mean, potatoes.. wrapped in dough and fried, and garlic??? Dream come true.

2. Shishito peppers. Actually... I've had better elsewhere. But my friends liked it!

3. Goat liver mousse. It came with some pickled stuff that I didn't really touch, crisps, and some yummy toasty bread that almost felt like a fried mantou married a biscuit. Bread was BOMB lol. The mousse was good too, but I couldn't eat too much of it because it was so rich. Nice combo with the bread though.

4. Duck tongue. AWESOME dish. I'm slightly confused though, the description on the menu said tuna and black bean poke. Is it duck or is it tuna??? Cos it tasted just like tuna. Plus I didn't know people eat duck tongues.. and poke-style. BUT whatever it is, super duper tasty. The crispy wontons paired well.

5. Goat empanadas. Good.. I think? Actually I don't think this was that memorable, but still pretty good.

6. Braised beef tongue. Super tasty! I love me a good beef tongue, and theirs was cooked perfectly. Super tender and flavorful.

7. Seared diver scallops. Sooo good! I love scallops, and these were plump, sweet, and seared perfectly. It came towards the end of our meal, so I was getting kinda full by this time... but definitely a good one.

8. Grilled pork belly. Very yummy! Very nice cook and flavor, but to be honest I like pork belly in KBBQ more lol. I like my pork belly very crispy, which this wasn't, buuut still super delisssshhus though.

9. Roasted pig face! I thought it sounded very weird but then I like cabeza tacos (cow face?) which.. also sounds weird but so tasty! Turns out THIS dish was the tastiest of all. I think it was my fave for the night. It comes with a nice egg on top, which of course means yolk porn. Very rich dish, and I wish it came earlier in the dinner. I would've had more room to eat it! The pig face was super flavorful, tender, and had this.... crispy gelatinous thing going on? Hard to describe, but quite unique. Overall, TASTY AF!

10. Last dish.. calamari bruschetta. I was pretty damn full by this dish lol. But it was good! I like calamari, and this was a good one. Not much else to report. Yummy.

SOOOOOO. LOTS of delicious dishes, but also a few ok ones too. Glad I got to go!

Fulton Market is jammed packed with unique and delicious restaurants. Girl and the goat is no exception. The food is served tapas style. You should order 2-3 dishes per person.I ordered the grilled octopus. It was served with pistachio and creamy aioli. Then I got goat empanadas and the jellywich for dessert. It was all delicious and very very filling. Definitely stop by!

Best meal in Chicago!! Every course was better than the last. The green beans were so good. The pork shank was huge and way bigger than the other dishes. We got 5 hunts to share between the two of us and we were stuffed by the end (and we have big appetites!).

Definitely order the green beans and whatever goat dishes are special that night. We had the confit goat belly and it was superb.

The staff was so kind to ask about allergies and provide options for me without even asking! They have a separate dairy free menu and can easily make some dishes dairy free making small changes - they gave me a separate fried chip thing that was sooooo good instead of the flat bread that came w the pork shank (which they still brought for my husband to enjoy).

2 months for a reservation? Yes it really was! Tried to come here last year but couldn't get the booking in time. So glad our friends kept a vigilant eye out for a booking. We weren't really hungry yet because we had a late lunch at the Purple Pig but once we sat down and looked at the menu, we couldn't help it. Shishito peppers, green beans, escargot ravioli, duck tongue, lamb ribs, halibut w/blueberry sauce, branzino w/papaya salad, bocatini, we tried almost the whole menu it seems like! Loved all of it! No complaints on any of the food and service was great as they changed our plates out twice. Just wish there had been more lighting so we could get better pictures of our food.

Saddened to say that my wife and I were greatly disappointed with our meal. Granted I had high expectations, after watching Izard on TV for years, hearing rave reviews from people I trust, counting up the awards, and reading the reviews online. First of, the space is fantastic, and has an amazingly lively vibe. But the food fell short - there is just no way to sugar coat it. The pierogies, squash blossom rangoon, and soft shell crab cake were all overly oily. So much so, the stuffing/meat/focus of the dish got washed out by the grease flavor. The beef tongue dish was scarce with tongue, and had a severely overdressed frise salad. The pig face dish was pretty good, but the fattiness (which ordinarily would've been amazing) was simply too much at that point in the meal.

Maybe she's stretched herself too thin with all these new openings, or was an "off" service, but our meal was very unsuccessful.

Really good food! I ordered the sweet onion brioche, pan seared shishito peppers, and the confit goat belly. The goat belly was truly something else, highly recommend. All the food was outstanding, and the wait staff was charismatic and informative. The noise level at the restaurant was a tad much for me, so if I go again, I would see if I can get a table outside.
Amazing! One of my favorite dinners ever and I like to eat! Surprised by super flavorful and filling veggie dishes.  Aesthetically is beautiful too! Go go go!!!!
AMAZING Experience. Delicious food. You absolutely cannot go wrong with the green beans and the goat belly.

Girl & the Goat was a good experience, but given all of the surrounding hype and difficulty obtaining reservations, I was expecting so much more. The food is good with unique flavors that mesh well together, but I really just wasn't blown away. Servers are nice and know the menu in and out, and service itself is good. Ambiance and decor is good. But the key word for me is just that -- good. We had the chickpea fritter, blueberry pickled pepper corn bread, pan roasted halibut, and kalbi beef ribs. Our favorite was probably the chickpea fritter. The bread was tad dry and salt, the halibut and kalbi had good sauces but otherwise the actual fish/meat itself lacked flavor upon chewing.

All in all, I would like to try this restaurant again as maybe it was just an off-day or we should've tried different dishes, but I'm not sure if I'd be willing to make a reservation 2-3 months in advance just to try it again.

Tonight's dinner was truly amazing !!! I was super surprised to get the reservation for Girl and the goat because I heard that tables here are very hard to come by. The staffs are amazing and very helpful on what to order for first timers. Always tried to call ahead and see if they have open tables, you might get lucky sometimes.

The food here is excellent.  I've had the Pig's Face twice, and it is amazing - perfectly cooked, fatty, delicious pork.  I like the servers too; they're pretty efficient.  

Here's what I don't like:  the clientele is uppity (I felt out of place in a T-shirt, even though that's what the servers wear); the furniture in the lounge area isn't practical (it's kind of hard to eat on a couch); and the portions are tiny (yeah, I know, the dishes are made for 'sharing,' but how can you share a dish that isn't even big enough for one?).

I'd still come back for that Pig's Face anytime.

Overall a great experience and a great place for groups, especially if you like tapas! It's a bit overrated, with some dishes being amazing and some not so much. Here a few dishes that we tried:

Cauliflower: My favorite was the cauliflower, which was warm and very well seasoned. It is not too crunchy but not very soft either (for those of you who like ultra soft broccoli/cauliflower).

Ravioli: 2nd favorite, cooked just right. Comes with crispy/fried onions, adding a ton of flavor.

Beets: I ended up loving their beets even though I've never liked beets before!

Pig face: pretty tasty, but my favorite was that the dish comes with an egg, and anything plus fried egg becomes amazing!!

Sea bass: Sea bass not that impressive, but I am also Asian so a little pickier about my fish. They could've done a better job making the skin more crispier.

Pork shank: quite dry but the sauces it came with were delicious. I'm also a huge fan of naan, which it comes with so it was fine.

You pretty much have to reserve a lot in advance but they sat us on time which we appreciated. Even if they are booked, you should still try to call day of/before bc they sometimes have cancellations (2 separate groups that I know of got lucky and were able to get last min tables bc of cancellations).

Our waiter was friendly and very knowledgeable. Food came out at a reasonable pace, and we really didn't have to wait long. They pretty much serve 1-2 dish at a time so that we don't have a ton of dishes out all at once. Noise level is reasonable; it's not quiet, but not so loud that you have to shout over people.

What a perfect way to end our first trip to Chicago! This was one of my favorite meals EVER and as a chef, those accolades don't come easy from me. We started with the cheesy shishito peppers and the broccoli with the "spiced crispies" spicy puffed rice - such genius! Then we split the soft shell "crab cake," very yummy! For the main we ordered the pork shank with the naan and pickles, green goddes dressing and pickles, it blew my mind and was so fun to build up these little porky naan bites! For dessert, we got the brioche and blueberries (this was a bonus dessert for our anniversary ) and the popcorn and maltballs, it had vanilla malt ice cream with chocolate magic shell (weee!) caramel corn, salted caramel, these nuggets of nougat which were like crack, omg  drooling just thinking about it. The service was also terrific. Truly one of the most thoughtful and inspired menus I've eaten from in a while. Way to go Iron Chef Izzard!!

pics.caption: Popcorn and Malt Ball dessert, AMAZING!

review.des:
We were lucky enough to make a reservation on the day of for a party of 2 at 430p on Saturday. The restaurant got really packed within 30 minutes of opening time for dinner. We ordered 5 dishes between the 2 of us -pig face (with sunny side egg), braised beef short ribs (very tender and with avocado), roasted cauliflower (must get), goat belly (with lobster and crab meat over brown butter), and escargot ravioli. I thought everything was delicious except the escargot ravioli. The way I imagined the ravioli would have an escargot paste instead of a whole escargot right smacked in the middle of the ravioli. For dessert we had the chocolate cake. It was satisfying.

The service was awesome. We had our plates changed a few times in between dishes and had our water filled without being asked.

This place is pretty amazing. Definitely for the carnivores but I was a good sport and the staff was pretty accommodating.  Location is great but I do suggest to Uber or Lyft it as parking is not easy so everything is pretty much valet here and at all the other restaurants here.  But yes a must try to appreciate

Whoever is coming up with the plethora of food and flavor combinations deserves an award. I recommend almost everything on the menu, but a definite must try is the goat confit, branzino, and for dessert, the Pavlova! A must eat place for anyone visiting Chicago.

pics.caption: Wood Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face

review.des: This restaurant has found its way into my top 5 world-wide. The service was impeccable, the food kept-a-comin', we even got a "surprise" from the kitchen with a complimentary appetizer. The pork shank was incredible, and my favorite dish was probably the beet salad. I'm kind of a freak about beet salads, and this was amazing. I asked the server about the cocktail of the day, and it was divine!!!! I can not recommend this restaurant highly enough.
Solid spot . Always has fresh tasty options. I've never had a bad meal here. Prices are fair and food is quality. Worth the wait and service is top notch!

This restaurant never disappoints. It continues to be my favorite restaurant because if the vibe, the staff, the drink menu and the ever changing food menu.  

Choose from a wide selection of vegetarian, fish, meat and daily specials, which always include different goat  dishes.

Reservations are insanely difficult to get on the weekend unless you look to book weeks ahead of time. They will take walk ins but be prepared to wait 1.5 - 2 hours. First come, first served at the bar and lounge area.

Started the night off with a perfectly mixed bourbon old fashion and side of oysters with a garlic mignonette.  

Dinner consisted of:

- roasted cauliflower with pine nuts, pickled peppers and mint.
- wood fired shrimp with pork and peanut ragout & cucumber salad
- duck tongues with tuna and black bean poke and topped with crispy wontons.
- goat ribs with pomegranate and sun choked

All dishes were amazing. Save room for dessert....
The caramel corn & malt balls were incredible! It came with vanilla malt gelato, caramel popcorn with a hard, chocolate shell.

Will be back again and again!

Went here while in the neighborhood and figured we'd see if a table was available as we figured it'd be packed. Luckily it was a nice night and the outside tables were available. Got seated right away  which was a welcomed surprise. My girlfriend had been there before and demanded we get the green beans. Odd but I trust her so we ordered those, the scallops, and the pig face. All were very good, but the scallops were incredible.  Overall it was a great experience and we hope to be back soon.

Incredible food! I got some specials, the scallops, and the lamb ribs- all were fantastic but the ribs were out of this world! They were so tender than you can barely pick them up with a fork without it falling apart. Bit on the pricey side with regards to the amount of food, but my friend and I were happily full on a $100 tab with drinks. Great place. Would recommend to anyone.

This was a great meal during our stay in Chicago. We made sure to reserve seats because we knew this place was popular. We ordered the pig face, goat liver mousse, and pork shank. The pig face and pork shank were some of the best tasting dishes I've had. The pork shank fell right off the bone and came with tasty dips. The goat liver mousse was a little strange for me to eat. I didn't enjoy the taste of it and it didn't really pair well with what it came with. I would say to stick with the pork if you want to keep it safe! Overall an amazing dinner!

One of two restaurants I have urged people to try when in Chicago. You can book a spot on Open Table or just go early. We arrived at 5:30 and were seated immediately. The menu is impressive. Your server will tell you that four people can split 8 dishes. Do not believe it!

We split 6 fabulous dishes and were stuffed like Porky Pigs. We began with the Crisp Braised Pork Shank, simply divine, and the Grilled Baby Octopus which was incredible. But my favorite was a fabulous and beloved dish the Bourbon Butter Goat Belly! My oh my. To die for. All the goaty, buttery bourbony flavors knocked my socks off. Our other dishes, Wood Grilled Broccoli and Grilled Shrimp were yummy as well.

Everything was spectacular and we will not hesitate to return to see the Girl do her thing with her goat! Apparently, no one sleeps as the restaurant is open All. Day. Long.

pics.caption: Bourbon Butter Goat Belly after everyone had their way with it!! My favorite dish!

review.des: Girl~~~~ this goat was very good.  Food was beautifully presented.  A bit pricey and small dishes to share.   Great outdoor dinning and fabulous drinks!

pics.caption: The Highlander.. amazing drink perfect notes of vanilla... Just delicious!

review.des: I believe that this is one of Chicago's greatest treasure and thus far the best place I've tried in my whole Chicago trip conclusion, very nice and elegant ambiance, definitely have a hipster vibe inside. Our waiter was very knowledgeable about the menu and the details of ingredients in every dish. I would highly recommend this place to anyone that visits the Windy City, you guys rock!

Food is great. Loved that server asked right away about allergies (mine is wheat) so she brought a GF menu. We had the beets, the salmon, the goat empanadas, and the pig face. We got pal-sy with the table next to us - a girl celebrating her 21st bday and her mom. Coincidentally, it was also my birthday, which my husband noted when he made the reservation, and the server acknowledged when we sat down.
Our table "mates" (the tables are super close together) offered us some of the green beans, which Stephanie Izard is famous for. They were phenomenal. In addition, our favorite dishes were the empanadas
(Crispy, light, delicious) and the pig face (crispy, fatty, rich). The service was fine. She was nice enough...however, and this may sound weird...but the birthday girl next door got complimentary dishes, a candle in her dessert, and her mom quipped that the dessert was also comped for her birthday when she got the check. Me? Nothing. Nada. Zip. Zilch. We paid full price for everything, and maybe I am "too old" for a candle in my dessert? That I don't really care about, but also having the dessert comped, would have been nice. If you are going to recognize one patron's special occasion, recognize them all. Especially since it is obvious with the tables jammed up against each other. Anyway, I had a happy birthday in spite of this thanks to my husband and kids!

One of my favorite places in Chicago. I wish it were easier to get a reservation.

Quick tip - you can walk in and eat at the Bar area

Extremely flavourful. All dishes were creative and nicely presented. Service was top notch. Casual yet knowledgeable. The noise was so loud I could hardly hear myself think. Wine list was average. Fair price points. Enjoy.

My boyfriend took me here for my birthday and it did not disappoint. We had a very friendly server who recommended all the best dishes. Friendly staff, great drinks, delicious food, great ambiance. We will be back!

This one was been on my list for awhile - I have not seen a restaurant with so many reviews on yelp, so we had to try this out to see what all the hype was about.  Overall experience and meal exceeded my expectations.   Only downside was the non-dining room seating in the lounge, but surprisingly service levels was still very good there.  Waiters still took the time to explain the menu items, provide recommendations, and were back consistently to check on drinks.  The food itself is bursting with flavors and each dish unique.  It's a tapas style restaurant - perfect for sharing within a party.  Note the dishes are a bit larger than normal tapas - the restaurant recommends 2 dishes per person which we felt was just right.  Price point was expected and we felt it was an exceptional meal for the price - overall a great experience and a must visit when in Chicago.

Unfortunately we decided to go at the spur of the moment and did not make any reservations.  It was 10:45pm so we decided to give it a shot.  No surprise - no seats available when we arrived - both inside and outside.  Seemed there were seats available outside but due to the city ordinance could not seat outside anymore.  So we decided to try give the bar lounge area a shot.  Mentally I was prepared for other bar lounges where you had to wait long periods for mediocre service - but was pleasantly surprised when a waiter immediately attended to us for drinks.  Great job by the restaurant to staff waiters in the lounge area and ensure great service levels there.  At the end of the meal we were a bit uncomfortable bending over the table - but the food was worth it.

We went with the waiters recommendations for the dishes-Duck Tongue, Cauliflower, String Beans, Halibut, Galbi, oysters, calamari, hamachi crudo, and lamb ribs.  All dishes were exceptional.  The only one we did not enjoy fully was the raw oysters as they were a bit too briny and seasoning was a bit high on the vinegar - coincidentally this was the one dish not recommended by the waiter.  If I was to rank our favorites - I would say duck tongue is number one as it not something typical and the flavor profile is great - never thought I would like that as I typically do not like the dry preparation in China.  Number 2 would be the lamb ribs - amazing flavor without tons of gaminess and super fall off the bone tenderness.  Number three would have to be the cauliflower - huge flavor -  if you are not a big cheese fan man sure you get it on the side.  Rest of dishes I would also recommend, but those are the three must tries for us.

Amount was perfect for a party of 5 adults and everyone left pleased.  Great food, great service, and deserving of its high rating.  We will be back (hopefully with a reservation next time).

pics.caption: Very old fashioned was very good, but switched to manhattan as this was a bit sweet
Lamb ribs - exceptional and highly recommended
Kalbi was very good - not a top recommendation though - get the lamb instead of choosing between the 2

review.des:
Great food while there. The goat chili, side of broccoli, and also the goat sloppy joe on a GF bun were lovely if not somewhat salty.

Had to wait quite awhile, they were VERY busy.  

But as much as the food tasted good, I would be quite hesitant to go there again. I am quite gluten intolerant and, while they say GF and even had a separate menu, my experience showed they were not as clean their menu suggested. I HIGHLY suggest elsewhere if you are Celiac's.

This was last year so perhaps something has improved...*crosses fingers*
I love their locovore tilt and their waitstaff was wonderful. I hope they can improve this aspect!

Worth every penny they charge. Pure mouth entertainment. We started with dirty martinis with blue cheese stuffed olives, delish! We then devoured more entrees than I care to mention. My favs were the calamari bruschetta and the pan roasted halibut. I can't wait to get back!

Dairy, vegan and gluten free menus available!!! Yum!  I've been dying to go to this place and was so happy when I got reservations for 7 at the last second.  Surprisingly everything seems almost under priced.  The quality of food, service and drinks are outstanding! We ordered a little bit of everything and enjoyed it ALL!! Idk why it took to so long to go here, has to be one of my favorite spots.

Honestly do not think this is worth the months and months ahead reservation and small portioned, yet expensive small plates (though some were indeed quite tasty). For 4 people, our bill was around $200 and we had to stop at McDonald's afterward due to still being hungry

The food here was great, just as others have said. I went with a group of six people, which was great because you get to try more dishes. The plates are small, but if want person orders one or two things, it's plenty of food. The goat dishes were good, but my favorites were the cauliflower, green beans, pig face and the duck tongue. Or server, Kristen, was great and very personable. My only complaint is that it's a bit expensive. Those who can't afford a place like this really miss a nice experience.

It's rare to find a restaurant that does everything well. Service, appetizers, entrees, desserts and drinks all come together at the peak of excellence with Girl & the Goat. I'm big on self reflection, so I can humbly own up to being a tough critic when it comes to food. Trying so many restaurants, has created a standard that can be difficult to meet. Late night convenience aside. ..I try not to hit the same spot twice, unless I find a dish that revolutionizes they way I view food. G&TG is clearly a standard bearer for elevated dining, not just in Chicago but anywhere in the US.

Reservations are a challenge without proper planning, or a little luck unless you're open to 10:30pm on a weeknight. The popularly hasn't driven G&TG to pompous pretentiousness found at some of the highly celebrated restaurants in Chicago.

The menu has been fairly consistent during my last several visits excluding subtle changes due to seasonality. My personal favorites are the Wood Grilled Broccoli, Pan Roasted Catch of the Day, Grilled Ramp Marinated Shrimp and of course the Caramel Corn & Malt Balls. The Salt & Ash is a well balanced cocktail if you enjoy the smokiness of Mezcal. I could go on about other amazing dishes, the strikingly creative paintings or attentive service, but just trust they all make for a hard to beat experience.

pics.caption: Local 75 - Chicago​ Distilling Company Vodka, CH Dry Gin, Sparkling Wine, Lime, Rosemary & Plum Bitters
Hamachi Crudo - Crisp Pork Belly, Chili Aioli & Caperberries
Caramel Corn & Malt Balls - Vanilla Malt Gelato, Popcorn Caramel & Chocolate Magic Shell

review.des: This place was amazing! The space is very chic and trendy but yet casual and comfortable. Wait staff was knowledgeable about the food and made some wonderful recommendations. We had the Sweet Onion Brioche, Blueberry Sourdough, Warm Marinated Olives, Sautéed Green Beans, Roasted Beats, Duck Tongues, Wood Fire Lamb Ribs,  Crisp Braised Pork Shank. Everything was delicious but my favorite dishes were the Duck Tongues and Green Beans. The duck tongues were nice and crispy but soft in the inside, went well with the freshness of the poke. The green beans were super tasty, fresh, cooked to perfection, nice acid from the vinaigrette, they were like nothing I had ever had before. It is a must EAT place while in Chicago!
Definitely a decent place with a different vibe to it.. wife and I went out for our  anniversary dinner also want to see what is the hype about. It was impressive.

Wow! Just an amazing restaurant. Food and service was super.

Arrived without reservations hoping to squeeze into an opportunity. Well this place is popular so be prepared to wait.

We sat in lounge area. Ordered drinks, "Ring of Fire " was delicious. Has a light tang of heat and tasty. Then after 10 minutes the hostess came and offered a table under one condition, we must be done in 1 1/2 cause table is committed. Of course we can finish!

Sat by kitchen. Actually can watch how efficient team works. Very cool. All food is served family style. Frankly it's tasting portions so you can try many dishes.

Our group had food allergies and The server helped that. She took a menu and crossed out all problem dishes. So nice. We ordered halibut, escargot ravioli, kohlrabi salad, pig face and roasted cauliflower. All agreed pig face was the best.

The reviews are correct. You will not regret a meal here.

Nice, great atmosphere, very little amount of food, but quite pricy. Def great place for a date or special occasion. Great interior and workers. It was rly nice I could see the kitchen and observe the process. Quite enjoyable.

Great experience when I dined here during my visit to Chicago.  It was actually highly recommended by some friend as well asl the doctor that interviewed me at Rush!  

Well because it is such a popular restaurant, reservations must be made far in advance, or if you're party is small (1-2 persons) you can most likely grab a seat at the bar or lounge area.  Lucky for me (or unlucky lol) I came by myself and it was very easy to grab a seat at the bar.  

What I loved about the restaurant is that you can order a half order of certain dishes since I was dining alone, which made my experience even better because I was allowed to try more things to eat! yay!  

Food:
- Roasted Cauliflower - with pickled peppers, pine nuts and mint. It was okay and not the best.  Needed a bit more flavor but a great dish to pair with something salty.

- Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face - pork cheek roasted till it was very soft and tender and topped with a sunny side egg with a tamarind, cilantro, red wine-maple sauce and potato stix to add texture. Overall it was a very good dish. My first bite, I immediately thought, damn this is one heavy and fatty dish, but the flavors and texture were all there.  It was just too heavy for me to finish by myself so I stopped after a few bites.

- Bread (It's Gouda) - House-baked bread with gouda and bacon inside the bread.  It was served with smoked lard butter and romesco as spreads for the bread.  The bread came out warm which was the way I like my bread!

- Wood-fired Shrimp - with pork and peanut ragout and mixed with a cucumber salad. This was my most favorite dish of the evening.  That pork and peanut ragout, I have no idea how they made it but it is like crack and I almost ended up licking the entire bowl!  The shrimp was cooked very well and tender with the unique crisp when shrimp is cooked well.  This is something I'd definitely come back for more of!  

Dessert:
- Caramel corn & malt balls - vanilla malt gelato with popcorn caramel and chocolate magic shell. The perfect end to my meal.  Now I usually do not like popcorn, but the waiter insisted that I should try this and I ordered it.  It was so good that I almost devoured the entire dish, but I had to refrain because I did not want to go back to my hotel bloated from over-eating!  The caramel chunks in this dish was my favorite, slightly salty and paired with the ice cream and chocolate, it was just delicious!  Wish I could get more right now!  

Service was great!  Loved my waiter!  He was attentive, friendly, knowledgable of the menu and attended to my need quickly as well as made great suggestions throughout dinner.  

I'd definitely come back here again, hopefully with more people so we can order more dishes to share and taste.  haha.

pics.caption: Caramel corn and Caramel corn & malt balls

review.des: This place is so good that I sometimes schedule to eat here twice when in Chicago for business. Pretty much everything I have ever tried is delicious. I love the concept of small plates. I am a pretty adventurous eater and this place allows me to explore some new food. The items I must order on every visit: green beans, cauliflower, and the pork shank.

Although this is another restaurant of Stephanie Izard from bravos top chef, this is probably one of my least favorite. Don't get me wrong but I love duck duck goat! This place is good but it reminds me of dishes I can make at home. Atmosphere is very full of life but food could use some touches. Still a fan but would like something diff.

pics.caption: Grilled oysters was my least favorite. Wasn't really grilled and just tasted like warm oysters with mayo.

review.des: Came here for our wedding anniversary and had one of the best experiences ever!!! From the service to the food, everything was impeccable!!! The chef's Table was a blast!  Our favorite was the halibut and goats belly amongst the squash blossom crab Rangoon, the raw oysters, cauliflower, shishito peppers, and pig face. Oh and the lemon dessert! AMAZING!!! Seriously, you can't go wrong. Can't wait to try the branzino! Stephanie Izard is incredible! Oh and THE STAFF!!! Thank you guys!!!

6000 reviews don't lie
Each plate was delicious
I can't complain about nothing
Can't wait to come again

The dishes come in special order, supposedly from light to heavy. Here's a breakdown of what we tried and an evaluation of each dish.

Escargo ravioli -1 - plain ravioli sits in very salty liquid. Like pieces of pasta swimming in the Dead Sea.

Halibut -5- really good, interesting combination of fruit and vinegar

Lamb - 3.5 - good, very fatty and sauce is too strong

Goat belly - ? Not sure, I think we are greased out by now

Green bean + a lot of uncessary extra flavor, such as the Mayo looking sauce

Need a lot of alcohol or water to enjoy this meal/ wash down the grease and salt. Otherwise your tongue can get dried out from osmosis.

I would enjoy it a lot better if it comes with bread/ pasta/rice.

Overall disappointment, especially considering the price tag.

Chef Izard's restaurant definitely lives up to all the hype! I came here with a group of coworkers and I have to say that everything is definitely worth a taste. Most of the dishes all have some sort of spin on them. The roasted pig face is a must try the combination of flavors and textures that are made from the pig, the potato sticks and the egg makes it so fun to eat. The pork shank is really good too. It's really filling but so tender and just falls off the bone.

The ambiance of the place also contributes favorably to the experience as the lightning and the seating sets the tone of the meal. The food really is the star here.

Love these guys. Came back for round two. This time at the chef's table...which I never knew existed, but it was pretty neat sitting up in the front and seeing these guys work.

They really know how to take care of you too. They gave me some complimentary perogis because I guess I came back for a second time...but I didn't expect to eat all that food as well as the pig face, green beans, bread and goat empanadas to eat all in one sitting. Oh, and I had some bitter chocolate at the end. So the perogis just put me over the top for this visit.

Again, I had a late dinner reservation sitting, but these guys still take care of you, without the feeling of being rushed whatsoever.

Again, the pig face and green beans are my favorite, and I'll keep coming back for more.

We ordered:

Goat empanadas with miso aioli, grilled mushroom, apple giardiniera:
Very tasty, goat was not gamey at all & the accompanying mushroom & apple added a perfect crunch, but not sure it was worth $16 for 2 small empanadas

Green beans with fish sauce vinaigrette & cashews:
Slightly overly salty; extremely flavorful from the fish sauce; green beans were cooked perfectly. Cashews were super crunchy and nicely coated with fish sauce.

Pan roasted halibut with marcona almond butter, white asparagus, blueberry nuoc cham, beech mushroom:
Perfectly cooked halibut; white asparagus was crunchy and flavorful, blueberry sauce added a wonderful sour flavor, and mushroom was perfectly crunchy. Our 2nd favorite dish.

Seared diver scallops with toasted miso-brown butter, blood orange, smoked beet, pistachio:
Perfectly seared scallops, crispy on the outside and soft on the inside; we cut through them with a fork; beets added the perfect amount of sourness; pistachios added the perfect crunch. Our favorite dish.

Braised duck tongue with tuna & black bean poke, crispy wontons, piri piri:
The dish was a bit too salty. The duck tongue was fried to perfection and a perfect accompaniment to tuna & black bean poke & crispy wontons.

Wood oven roasted pig face with sunny side egg, tamarind, cilantro, red wine maple, and potato stix:
Our least favorite dish as it tasted like we were eating pieces of pure fat. The potato stix added a nice crunch. The cilantro, tamarind, and red wine maple were squirted on the plate as sauce and added a beautiful color. The sunny side egg was perfectly cooked, but got lost in the dish. We were advised to cut the egg and mash all the ingredients and mix before eating. After 2 bites, I was done-- way too heavy.

Atmosphere: causal, relaxing, hipster; the restaurant has 3 sections: bar, lounge, and dining room

Bathroom: clean, all individual stalls, in the basement

Service: very attentive, friendly

Final verdict: definitely a place I would visit again. If you don't enjoy heavy food, avoid the pig face dish.

It took forever to get a reservation here but the food here was so not worth the wait. The amount of hype this restaurant get is a joke. We ordered the green beans with fish sauce, took the first bite, impressive, 3 bites down it gets super salty. It took forever for the pig face to come, nice concept but the pork face was too heavy and greasy. Throughout the whole dinner I couldn't help but drank a lot of water. The food was either super salty or super bland, not worth the hype. Don't want to come back either.

Okay so this is probably the restaurant that I have most wanted to come to in Chicago. They hype surrounding this place is huge. I think it definitely was worth the hype. So I went with a group of four and decided to do about 8 different dishes. We went with the olive yu(zu) focaccia bread. It came with two different spreads, a buyer and lime olive oil.
