Though some things were a bit disappointing here (like the goat belly), the overwhelming positives of everything else about the night outweigh it, and so I give it five stars. I would come back in a heartbeat. Make sure to get a reservation a month out, and don't skip the tongues and face.

Had a spectacular experience here.  Everything from the service to the food was perfect.  Very cool atmosphere! Server was extremely helpful in assisting us choosing dinner. Huge bourbon selection!  Can't miss with the Weller 12!!  If you love chocolate, the Chocolate Pavlova says-a-me is to die for!  Can't even explain how good it was.

Stopped by for dinner with a work colleague. Very happy we did. This place has a great kitchen vibe and the food does not disappoint. The fried oysters were an amazing bite followed up by shishito peppers. Then onto halibut and pork belly. Lastly please order the blueberry desert you will be happy you did. If this is not a five star meal then I guess I don't understand the point system. Cheers to the chef- this place is Top Notch!

I cannot say enough good things about Girl and the Goat! It really is worth getting a reservations weeks in advance!

The dishes are all inventive, a take on new american food. Honestly, none of the descriptions of the dishes sound all that tasty, but take my word for it, order anything, chances are really high that it will blow your mind. In particular, the dishes that sound like they shouldn't be good... those seem to be the best. For example, our favorite dessert was a rosemary gelato and squash cake, flavors that don't sound particularly tasty.. but it was hands down on of the best desserts I've ever tasted.

Also, get the grilled broccoli! I could eat several plates of the broccoli on my own. It's got great grilled, smoky flavor, fantastic crispiness from the rice crispy on top, and creaminess from the bleu cheese sauce. Highly recommended!

Overall, the ambiance is nice, casual, unpretentious, and cosy. The prices are appropriate for the quality of food, and you leave feeling full and exceptional satisfied. Since the plates are designed to be shared you get to try a lot and can leave without all the food envy you might get at other restaurants :)

Over hyped. The art is okay. Potato bread is the only good thing on the menu. Everything else just seems cool cause it is "goat" but lacks flavour and spice and the whole vibe is centered around being goat meat. If that stinks which it does then what can you hang your hat on? Should be called Girl & The Potato Bread
Good food but very noisy room.  Would not recommend for groups, as at peak times you can't hear yourself think

It took forever to get a reservation here and even then it was for 10pm. I am such a huge fan of Stephanie Izard that it seemed worth the wait...and it was!!

The space is dark, cavernous but homey at the same time. We waited a while by the bar area and even that was packed. When we finally sat down we were ready to order and eat!

Though we had been curious about the pig face dish (would we actually see the face with snout and all?!) our server explained to us that it was more of a sausage. Ohhh...that made it just a tad bit less exciting so we decided to go with other dishes like the goat. After all it was the namesake and we felt compelled to order something with goat. The goat belly was good - tender and cooked well but I was not overwhelmed.

The true standouts were the veggie dishes! The string beans with cashews (with a hint of fish sauce?) is one of the best preparations of veggies I've ever had! Equally great were the roasted cauliflower and the beets. I would go back just to eat these veggie dishes alone!

I would love to return one of these days maybe when I can chance it and wait at the bar for a walk in table.

Love the style and service here, make reservations a few weeks ahead
We loved taking the chef suggestions, everything was fun and tasted amazing. Cant wait for our next trip here
This was an amazing place with great service! We had an amazing meal and we sat with a bunch of different people so socializing was fun and seeing what everyone had. Definitely a good place to go!

We ate at this restaurant on a Sunday night and it was packed!  Good thing we had reservations as we were a party of 10!  Our waitress was inventive and charming.  She suggested we order a bunch of different dishes and share them (which is something this group likes to do anyway,especially if the food is very different ).  We had over 20 different dishes - if you can imagine.  The amount each person got varied slightly but was clearly not a lot because the basic dishes were not that large to begin with.  The dishes came out of the kitchen one by one, paced such that we could all discuss and enjoy each one before the next.  Our favorites were the beet salad (fantastic), Goat empanadas (delicious), pork shank (succulent), sautéed green beans (a little salty), breads (especially the peter piper), wood fired lamb ribs, pan fried shishito peppers (yes, some were very hot!), grilled pork bellies, tempura walleye and wood oven roasted pig face (try it- you will like it).  We also had all four of their desserts.  They have an extensive wine menu.  The restaurant is amazingly staffed such that food comes out and then dirty dishes from the previous dishes are removed promptly. It was a wonderful experience and I suggest you give it a try.  Enjoy!!

for one our last meals on the chicago eating tour, we stopped here before heading back to CA! honestly, our reservation was super late (i think around 9:30?) and I was lowkey past my hunger time so I didn't eat much but what I did try was pretty awesome!

We got the blue cheese pierogis, their special johnny apple cheese bread, cauliflower and their pb&j dessert. Their cauliflower was soo delicious, maybe I was just craving veg but it was super flavorful and I definitely think I finished the majority of it! The pierogis were my second favorite as they were pretty unique and blue cheese is not a normal favorite of mine so they made it pretty well.

the presentation of all the food was so nice and the ambiance was POPPIN on a weekday even that late so you know that it's a hotspot!! Hopefully, I can get myself back here to try more of the menu :)
Bad experience with parking!!! Don't park outside the restaurant, there is city's parking lot nearby. Food is good but not worth it! Won't go again!

Absolutely loved the unique items we ordered here (pig face, crab, shrimp, and pork. But if I had one complaint about the experience it would be our waitress. Although she was very knowledgeable and helpful she reminded me of a car salesmen and basically told us to buy more and more. The food was amazing and trying multiple things was great, but ease off making sure everyone gets 4 entrees per person.

It has been my goal for years to eat here when I visit Chicago. It was so worth it... this was the best meal I've ever had. #1 must order dish is pig face. AMAZING! The dishes are meant to share so our waiter suggested that we each order 2 dishes so we had a lot of food and it took about 2 hours to eat it all. I'm still full a day later haha.

Great staff, amazing atmosphere, incredible food. What else do you want for an exquisite and refined outing? Reservations are tough but well worth and the location is superb. Although not the best cuisine in the city and it may be a little pricey for the ingredients, the expertise and creativity is clearly shown in the dishes. Probably not a go-to place for obvious reasons but definitely a restaurant to rave to your friends about. Prepare to share!!

Moving back to Chicago one of the restaurants on the 'try again' list was Girl and the Goat. Having first dined here when it first opened I can attest that the quality remains the same. Obviously. Food was superb.

I ordered the following!

1. Hamachi crudo: crisp pork belly. chili aioli. caperberries
2. Seared diver scallops: english pea-quinoa "tabbouleh" . tahini vinaigrette . chinese sausage
3. Woodfire glazed lamb ribs
4. Goat Empanadas
5. Caramel corn & malt balls: vanilla malt gelato. popcorn caramel. chocolate magic shell

- The hamachi was both light and packed with flavor - those pork belly croutons were lovely and salty.
- scallops are my favorite and I could have eaten 10 plates of these crusty seared mouth bombs.
- lamb ribs were too fatty for my liking but - maybe you like that
- meh on the goat empanadas, i've had better
- THE DESSERT!!! seriously. more of this please

For a 4/5 start restaurant i'm surprised GATG still haven't got the entrance right. Still not really anywhere to sit if your table isn't ready

Service was subpar. I know this is a busy place but we were whipped around by the multiple hands trying to remove our plates and our missing waitress.

Atmosphere is ALIVE!!! love the open kitchen and the music and being close to other patrons you can get a glimpse into what you're about to embark on.

I heard the wait here is insane. So I got in right st opening and took a seat at the bar by myself. No wait!

The pig face is what everyone recommends so I tried it. One happy and very full stomach. I also like the shishito peppers.

I hope to try more dishes next time with a group of people. The dishes aren't very big. Order a bunch of items and share.

Thanks for the memorable food

Great meal with great service! This was one of the places I was really hoping would live up to the hype (first female top chef winner - Stephanie Izard). So I am glad I had a great meal here.

Restaurant is hard to get reservations - at least in a decent time period. We got ours at 945 pm on Friday night despite booking a month out. Place is loud and lively in a dark setting with a large bar and open kitchen in the back.

Service is very knowledgable and helpful. Waters were always filled, dishes changed and food was at a good pace.

For two people you can share 4-6 dishes depending on how rich they are. I think we could have done 5 and been fine.

sweet 'n spicy brioche $5 - honey sombal butter, spring lamby jam. My least favourite. Brioche was dry and the butter was just ok.

goat carpaccio $14 - smoked trout roe. olive-maple vinaigrette. one of my faves! Wasn't sure what goat carpaccio would be like but it was fantastic! Super thing sliced and tasted very clean and  had such a great vinaigrette that just complimented it.

braised beef tongue $12 - masa, beef vinaigrette , salsa verde. The beef was crispy on the outside and the salsa verde paired nicely. The masa chips had a. I e texture.

wood oven roasted pig face $19 - sunny side egg . tamarind. cilantro . red wine-maple . potato stix. Sooo good! Like a perfect breakfast for dinner! The tamarind and the red wine maple is likely what makes this dish. This one is famous for a reason. And no it doesn't look like a pig face.

sautéed green beans $12 - fish sauce vinaigrette, cashews. OMG! This is one dish I will remember this place by. I wasn't sure why people had said the green beans were so good but damn this is one hell of a veg dish. I would eat this everyday. There was something so addictive about this dish. If vegetarian food was like this I would switch teams.

confit goat belly $19 - bourbon butter . lobster and crab . fennel. This is a rich dish. There was a vanilla flavour that I didn't like - subtle but it was there. The crab and fennel was cooked nicely.

salt & ash $14 - benhez mezcal . ancho reyes verde . kings ginger . grapefruit shrub . lime. A refreshing cocktail that was very balanced.

Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face - opened up shot

review.des: I just had a perfect meal at the bar. Full seasonal menu, great service, craft beers. Inventive use of fresh seasonal ingredients like blueberries in the summer to accent both sweet and savory dishes. The lamb ribs were a 10/10

You will need a reservation about two months in advance. We have been a few times and have enjoyed everything we've tried. The waiters are very knowledgeable about the menu, so we've relied on them for recommendations. The cauliflower app, short ribs, and confit goat belly would be my favorites so far. Food is served to be shared.

This would be a difficult place for someone who is picky or likes limited meat items. The food is very rich, so sensitive tummies may struggle.

You know a place means business when you try to make a reservations months in advance and the ONLY time available was 4:45 on a Tuesday.. Although, the restaurant was still a bit empty when we went so if you go at an obscure time I'm sure you'll have no issues with grabbing a table (don't quote me on that though).

The menu is pretty unique and definitely caters more to the meat eaters. With that being said, sorry Shawn C., you didn't get a chance to order all the meat dishes you wanted, but here's what we did order:

- Roasted cauliflower ($13) - I thought the flavors were really unique. I'm a fan of the pine nuts.
- Squash blossom 'crab rangoon' ($16) - We thought this was just OK.
- Pan roasted halibut ($19) - My favorite of the night, really delicious flavors and the blueberry nuoc cham made this really unique.
- Wood oven roasted pig face ($19) - Can't say much about this since all I did was mash the egg around, Shawn C. seemed to like it, though. Don't forget to Snapchat!

I wasn't blown away by everything, but that doesn't mean it wasn't good! So more like 4.5 stars. Overall, I thought we had a great experience at Girl & the Goat and the service was superb. I recommend checking this place out if your taste buds want to explore more adventurous flavors and types of food.

pics.caption: Pan roasted halibut ($19): marcona almond butter, white asparagus, blueberry nuoc cham

review.des:
I wasn't super impressed by the place. I came with a couple of friends and got the brussel sprouts, carpaccio, and some other items that weren't too memorable.

Food was okay, definitely not worth the hype in my opinion. Ambience was cute but so is the ambience in every other restaurant in Chicago.

[ Food ]
-- Roasted Cauliflower [ + ]
( hints of the mint and nuts, well rounded flavors with the parmesan )
-- Sauteed Green Beans [ + ]
( nonintrusive flavors to accentuate the green beans topped with a rich sauce )
-- Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face [ + ]
( approachable dish, great pork texture and packed with succulent flavors )
-- Goat Belly with Lobster [ - ]
( interesting use of flavors, but a bit more buttery than my preference )
-- Forlorn Hope [ + ]
( Great natural wine out of CA )

[ Ambiance ]
-- Intimate setting with open accessibility to seeing the chef's prepare, cook, and plate meals.
-- Lively atmosphere
-- TIP: Chef Seating is brilliant.  Unbelievable experience!

[ Parking ]
-- Street parking that tends to fill up quickly
-- Probably help to arrive ~15 min early

[ Size ]
-- 2 adults

[ Cost ] incl. tax & tip
-- $100

FAVORITE PLACE in CHICAGO. Friendly hosts, knowledgeable sommelier, excellent food, & that's all she wrote folks.  Luckily snagged a reservation about less than a week in advance.  Cannot commend them enough on curating a beautiful dining experience - had the chance to talk with the chefs behind the counter, som's recommendations, philosophy of the restaurant. This is the place to go for any celebration, treating yourself, first date, second date, third date, will not disappoint.  Menu is extensive and each dish coming out looked mouth-watering. We shared the plates and quite enjoyed it. REASONABLY PRICED! Absolutely coming back.  Hope to meet Chef Izard next time!

Phew...

hand cramp.

Yup. I am giving the Girl & the Goat 3 stars. Girl & the Goat is not bad, but with almost 6000 reviews on Yelp and no reservation available (I made reservations 3 months in advance), I expected much more. I think this place is overrated.

Based on ambiance alone, I would give it 5 stars. I love the dimly lit setting and the open kitchen with cool art decor. It wasn't too loud where I could not hear my date talk, but it was loud enough for it to be a fun environment.

Our server was just whatever. He came around to check on us here and there but didn't look like he was happy or enjoyed his job.

Duck tongue 3.5/5 - Fried and crispy. A bit too greasy for my taste. I quickly got sick of it but the first few bites were flavorful.
Goat empanadas 4/5 - One of the better dishes of the night. Must eat it while it's still warm. Very small portion with only 2 empanadas on the plate. While this was good, there wasn't anything unique about it.
Wood grilled broccoli 3/5 - With all of these meat dishes, I had to get one veggie plate. The wood grilled broccoli had little bits of smokey bleu cheese. Average.
Wood oven roasted pig face 3.5/5 - Imagine a thick piece of fatty bacon fried up and then roasted. You get this plate. It has a good mixture of fat, but I felt they needed to add something to balance it all out. It was a bit too salty.
Calamari bruschetta 2/5 - We could've easily passed on this one. The flavored baguette is good, but I like my calamari with a bit more texture. This was too soft and soggy for my taste.
Confit goat belly 3/5 - Nothing special. More fatty cut on a base of puree. I did like the addition of the crab and lobster though.
Chocolately chocolate cake 3/5 - The chocolate cake was very warm, rich, and delish!  The gelato is shiitake flavor and you can definitely taste the mushroom. Quite interesting.

I really wanted to love the Girl & the Goat and I appreciated the innovative approach to these dishes, but nothing really stood out. It is overhyped.

Just flew in to Chicago for the chicago marathon and this was our first stop for dinner in Chi town!
We didn't have reservations and were hoping to get a seat in the bar/lounge and luckily we did!
Then the host came and offered us a table, I think one opened up, service and food quality was definetly top notch! If you're in the area and a foodie like we are stop by and try out some of the signature items!

For the price, there are superior food experiences available in Chicago.

Service: 5/5 - impeccable.

Atmosphere: 3.5/5 - very modern and well designed interior, but lacking any feeling of intimacy and a bit loud for casual conversation.

Food:  3/5 - There were some tasty dishes - green beans and skirt steak come to mind - but overall the food lacked balance.  I am a fan of rich, fatty, salty dishes as much as anyone else, but everything I sampled leaned heavily on those themes.  Could have been an ordering error on our part, but I didn't see or taste much in other areas of the flavor spectrum.  Some dishes seemed to be designed around their talking points and appearance on paper, rather than the actual experience of eating them - however I do applaud the effort of getting those less-than-traditional foods into people's mouths.

Lastly, there could have been more seasonal items / ingredients on the menu.

Value: 2/5 - Just not a good value.  I understand the location, the size, and the cachet of the chef all factor into the price points, but these tick boxes are just footnotes to me in the grand scheme of dining.  The centerpiece is the food.  And that's where GATG fell short.

Good, creative drinks. Solid vegetarian dishes; favorites include roasted cauliflower, wood-grilled​ broccoli, bread options). Good meat dishes include braised beef tongue, duck tongues, and wood oven roasted pig face - this last item not being for those easily turned off by strange textures.

Exquisite food quality and taste. My husband and I were pleased with the service, waiter was great. He gave us very good recommendations and brought the food out on time. I highly recommend this restaurant.

Yep. Its that good.

Ive been here twice and been blown away both times with the food and the service. I definitely recommend leaning on your server to steer you to the exceptional dishes of which there are many.

Girl and the Goat, I'm so glad Chicago has you!

K, so.... (cheese if you get the joke), on my last 5 star review, I made it very clear that it was to be the only one because it is THE gold standard of restaurants, in my opinion.

Well, with much reluctance, and some incredibly impressive persuasion, I find myself breaking my own rules like a flaky politician.

Yes, Stephanie Izard now belongs in the same rankings as Martin Picard in my books.

The restaurant has a surprisingly large capacity of tables, but don't be fooled, you'll still be waiting 2 hours if you don't have a reservation. I recommend Bombobar across the street to keep you busy, if you are also like me, and believe in the art of having dessert before dinner.

Everything on the menu inspires intricacy and adventure. Locally prepared, yet very globally familiar. Here's the summary of our journey through The Girl & The Goat:

Green beans: Gordon Ramsey may have the beef wellington, but Izard has the green bean game on lockdown. Simple yet purely effective. Lightly sautéed with shallots, and tossed with a perfectly seasoned fish-sauce vinaigrette and a nutty creamy aioli. A definite staple at every table in the restaurant.

Grilled broccoli: Very seldom do vegetables get so much love from me but damn, we are on a roll. When I was a kid, broccolis used to remind me of trees. On this plate, they really taste like the trees that were used to smoke the broccolis. 24 hours later, the smokey flavour still sits faint on my breath, and strong on my sweet green memories.

Pork Shank: Yet another staple at Casa Izard. Just know that when the server informs you at the beginning that they will bring out the food from light to heavy, expect this to be the curtain call. Served with flame grilled Indian bread and some kind of chinese hoisin BBQ sauce, and Japanese tasting relish. Shout out to Izard for representing the Asian palette so much.

Chocolatey chocolate cake: 10/10 for the dessert, 3/10 for taking all the anticipation and guess work out with a name like that. Exactly as described, it's a moister and more intense brownie topped with more chocolate crumbs and shiiiiiitake ice cream (yeah what are we not making ice cream out of these days).

Caramel malt bombs: Think Garrett's caramelcorn, getting freaky with some vanilla ice cream, while fooling around with some malt fudge. Throw some chocolate into this ménage a trois, and you have a sexy Chicago scandal.

Photo creds go out to the one who wasn't loud enough to order the food, but made it loud and clear I can't have the photos until they appear here first:
instagram.com/delectable…

pics.caption: One of many photos to come

review.des: I ate at G&TG while in Chicago on vacation, and it did not disappoint. Every dish was interesting and inventive (especially the combos of goat and seafood), but a few stole the show for my husband and I. The goat liver mousse was rich and delicious, and the duck tongues were INCREDIBLE. We also enjoyed the pig face (which  was like an upscale breakfast dish), and the goat belly confit. Our server was attentive and helpful with dish and drink recommendations, and made it a great experience. The atmosphere is fun and noisy, and it was clear that everyone in the dining room was enjoying themselves. We will definitely return on our next trip to Chicago, and will be hoping that the duck tongues are on the menu again.

Very disappointing.

The service was awesome. Don't remember our servers name but he took great care of us.

The food.
We started with the salmon cream cheese bread. It was good but nothing about it was memorable.

Next came the Goat empanadas. This was the best dish of the night. Great flavor. Didn't really understand the playing of cold mushrooms with it though.

Next was the hamachi crudo.
Seriously boring. The only part of this dish I enjoyed was the pork belly. The fish was tasteless. I think some acidity would make that dish go a long way.

Next was the duck tongues.
These were pretty good. Nice bar food in my opinion.

Finished with the Pig Face
Bland. Rich but not flavorful. There was some sauce  in this dish which I thought should have been applied more liberally.

Maybe we just over hyped this restaurant before we came, or maybe we're just spoiled with great food back home but this was disappointing. Great service, mediocre food.

pics.caption: Empanadas. Mushrooms were weird and I love mushrooms

review.des: The food was absolutely incredible. I think we pretty much had one of everything on the menu. Definitely over indulged but that just meant leftovers! The service was top notch. We were lucky enough to just walk in without a reservation and snag a table outside with our dog. Highly recommend and will definitely be returning over and over again.

Really, really enjoyed my meal here. From the sound of it, we got lucky to get a party of 5 in on a Thursday night.

We got a total of 10 dishes, and between five girls, it was a struggle to finish all of the dishes, but we managed.

It's been a while so I can't remember the specificity of each dish, but if you have a chance to get the halibut, GET IT! The server informed us that this dish is served only 4-5 weeks out of the year and was a dish that won on her competition show. It was beautifully cooked.

The scallops were also well cooked as was the calamari on ricotta. Although I'd recommend the scallops, the calamari were too salty but the ricotta and toast were delicious.

Sautéed green beans and the chickpea fritters were amazing! The beet salad was also good. The goat empanadas were delicious! The roasted pork face was crispy and yummy but it came at the very end of our meal and we couldn't enjoy it as much as we should have.

If you can get a seat, do it! It's a very nice meal to celebrate a special occasion or just because it's Wednesday :0)
My first time going I really enjoyed the atmosphere an overall vibe of the place. I would definitely be back for sure.

Some say Girl & the Goat is overrated, but I beg to differ. It is obvious that Stephanie Izard loves to incorporate Asian and Latin American flavors into her dishes. Most of the time I don't like it when dishes at restaurants are 'Asian fusion' or 'Asian inspired.' I often find that these restaurants incorporate Asian flavors in the most superficial way (e.g. teriyaki-flavored something). However, Stephanie does a wonderful job of weaving both of these cultures into her dishes to create something new and delicious.

The menu features tapas-style dishes that are meant to be shared with the table. It's best to come here with a group so you can try a little bit of everything, because trust me -- you'll want to try everything! Doing this also lowers your bill. I came here with 4 people, got 5 dishes and ended up paying around $30, which is wonderful given the dishes and popularity of this place!

I liked all the dishes I tried, but here they are listed from super delicious to delicious  --

1. Duck Tongue - This dish is a perfect example of Stephanie doing a great job of using both Latin American and Asian flavors. The dish has raw tuna diced into cubes along with beans and tortilla chips. The duck tongue is cut into small pieces then fried and goes oh so well with everything. Overall, the dish does a great job of playing around with different flavors and textures.
2. Goat Liver Mousse - The mousse is so smooth and decadent. The bread (or crumpet) that goes with it super addicting. The bread is slightly sweet, chewy and soft.
3. Roasted Beets - Super refreshing and a good dish to clean your palate.
4. Pig Face - This dish is topped with an egg. The meat is super tender and juicy - can be a little fatty and heavy.
5. Goat Confit - The goat meat is super tender here as well; however, it is a little gamey for me. If you like gamey, then you'll love this dish!

This goes into my top 10 best evah meals. I've been trying to get a resi at Girl and The Goat for 4 years. I come to Chicago once a year and have never been able to make it happen, so oh joy, FINALLY!

Everything was amazing perfection. Server Kristen got it kicked off to a great start with what promised to be a really fun time. What a blast she was! Took excellent care of us. Ask for her section when you make a reservation.

We had the most amazing dishes, some great cocktails, had a bottle of wine and a couple glasses to follow once that was gone. We left very happy.  Although we ate quite a bit, the portions are perfect to share, so we weren't stuffed. The food is fun, creative, daring and oh, yes, delicious!

Beautiful ambiance in a lively setting and great people watching. I cannot come back soon enough.

pics.caption: Pig face deconstructed - amazing and NOT a pig face. Other delish parts.

review.des: The portions definitely aren't finer food sizes but average. Overall it was okay. I wasn't thrilled that I had to wait 20 minutes even with a reservation and it's very awkward to be served luke warm water. Would I return? Maybe but definitely not for breakfast.

Over 5 thousand reviews with 4.5 average rating?! I am often disappointed when I actually eat at places with these kind of reviews, but Girl and the Goat does not fail!

Service was perfect, and every food item we ordered was amazing, from raw fish in the Hamachi dish, to the crispy yet juicy pork in pigs face, and even the bread and fries! Some of the items sound a bit funky but just trust this place only makes it taste awesome. Don't forget the dessert menu as well - we ordered apple fritters and it was the best we've ever had!

Be sure to make reservations because this place is absolutely popping. Even when we came at 5 for dinner the bar seating was already full and the wait was an hour.

pics.caption: $5 bread option with amazing dip and butter

review.des: This place is soooooo good! And the service is amazing. Pro tip- get JJ on your serving team. The chicken dish, was the only thing we tried that wasn't up to par. The BEEF PLATE was crunchy yet juicey, with a great citrus finish. The staff keeps you hydrated. They keep you feed. Great Chicago eatery.

It's been a while since I've been back to Girl and the Goat due to reservation struggles; and, let me say, returning here has been one of the better life decisions I've made in some time now. We tried making a reservation for a party of 4 two weeks out, with no availabilities to no one's surprise. So we camped out and waited for the restaurant to open instead. Luckily for us, our patience was a rewarded with a memorable night of mouthwatering dishes--each one better than the next. We started off with an escargot ravioli, which was amazing. Friends and I were pretty much gasping in excitement after every bite of food. The two most stand out dishes of the night were undeniably the goat belly with crab and the halibut. They must be practicing some kind of wizardry back in the kitchen there because this ish is UNREAL.

Can't wait to come back!

The MOST amazing experience EVER!
Our server was adorable and informative, it was our first visit so she was helpful in navigating the menu. The food was exquisite from presentation to flavor - each item was introduced to the table as it was served. We LOVED everything! The halibut, the "Pig Face" and the Goat empanadas.
We kept eyeing the green beans at the table next to ours, so our server made us a little taster plate.
DO it up! Have a drink, order everything & share and have dessert.
This is a special gem of a spot, I'd go everyday if I could!

This place probably doesn't need another positive review but...being newly diagnosed as gluten free I mentioned this sad fact and was immediately supplied with a gluten free menu. Yay! Easy peasy! They also had complementary gluten free bread. Not as good as regular bread but still...it was warm bread. The cocktails were so delicious I had to order two. I highly recommend the mescal and Flora de Cana ones.

I had the short ribs and that was enough to fill me up. Sat at the bar as I was solo. I would love to come back with my significant other. Attentive service. Recommendation: have house sparkling water in addition to flat.
Excellent food and service. Accommodating of a young child.

My sister took me here for my birthday dinner.  We had reservations and it was a great experience.  The seating area was neatly arranged and I did enjoy the ambiance of the restaurant.

The food was shareable plates and unique.  I was a fan of majority of the dishes.  The Goat liver mousse, seared diver scallops, calamari, the pork shoulder and pig face that others recommended on here were all great.  

Next time I go, I will try their drinks.

It was SO GOOD.  We had lucked into the chef's table the evening we went and just about everything we tasted was delicious.  The duck tongue tartare was my girlfriend's favorite.  I loved the roasted pig face.  The servers were also super friendly and helpful addressing allergens or any questions.  Top notch place, great for special occasions or if you can swing many expensive dinners without sweat

One of the best meals I have had in 2017.
Reservation-we made a reservation for 10:45pm, simply because this place is way too popular. Its a place with over 6,700 reviews!But we snatched two seats at 7pm tonight! My only tip is dont give up on better time slots when you already made a not-so-perfect reservation. Trust me, there are people who cant come and if you are lucky and/or dilligent, you can snatch it too!
Food-my boyfriend and I ordered: mr.potato bread (with cheddar and chive yoghurt sauce), goat empanada, roasted cauliflower, chickpea fritter, and grilled cuttlefish. Everything was perfect, especially the cauliflower and chickpea fritter, the best I have tried in my whole life thus far. Highly recommend! The dessert menu looks great but we were just too full. we finished our meal in 45 minutes lol.
The only thing I would say is that its a bit salty and greasy to my taste -but water will help!
Service-flawless flawless flawless! We were welcomed and seated immediately. Our server gave us fabulous recommendations and the waiter was refilling the water all the time.
Memorable experience and definitely would come back!

pics.caption: Cuttlefish was so tasty and complex!

review.des: Visited Chicago for 4 days this fall.  Had one of the best meals of my life at Girl & the Goat.  The Walleye dish is my favorite 6 bites of food I've ever had.  Very highly recommended.

I came here with a group of friends. I've been here before, but during the winter months, but the review is based on my experience on 6/3/17. First off, the reservation was made 90 days in advance. I know people can sometimes score a table by walking in and waiting, but I wanted to be sure we'd have a table during on a Saturday during the Chicago summer. It was well worth the wait. FYI...we were a group of three. Here's what we ordered and the rating:

**Mahalo Cocktail- Be warned that cocktails here are strong, but very good. This was the most like a tropical drink and it was very good, but had a spicy kick, so you've been warned...

My friends are wine and beer drinkers and they were very impressed with both selections. One friend ordered a Blood Orange IPA and she loved it, and the other a cocktail.

**Sweet & Spicy Brioche- This was the only item that I felt like was okay. I thought the honey butter & jelly would be better.

**Chickpea Fritters- Very yummy and crispy on the outside and oh so soft and creamy on the inside. I'm not a Vegan, however, this would be a great alternative to anything cheesy.

**Spring Onion Potato Pierogies- Has a great smoky flavor and my friend who makes homemade pierogies was impressed.

**Goat Empanadas- These are excellent. One of the favorites of the night. Be aware that the order only comes with 2, but our waiter let us order 3 since we were a group of three. I ordered these last time I went and they were even better than I remembered...

**Woodfire Glazed Lamb Ribs- Very good, but I thought it would be better. I prefer Greek-style lamb

**Pork Shank- This is the best thing ever. It's delicious and as long as you eat pork, this is a must have!

We were still hungry so we each ordered a dessert and shared them evenly. We ordered: Chocolatey - Chocolate Cake w/ Shiitake gelato, Caramel corn & malt balls, and Rhubarb & goat cheese Bavarian. All three were delicious, but I love cheesecake, so the cheesecake was my favorite. The caramel corn & malt balls were the most unique dessert.

By the way, once we finished dessert, we were very full, so we had to take a walk afterwards.

Girl and the Goat is definitely one of those places where you absolutely get the best of everything from start to finish. The service was wonderful. Everything from pulling the table out so I could get through without booty bumping another table, bringing out clean/fresh plates for every other dish, and overall helpfulness and positivity of our wait staff - incredible.

The food was amazing. We ordered goat empanadas, escargot ravioli, pierogies, sweet & spicy brioche, roasted pig face, a few other dishes that I don't recall *sorry* but seriously it was ALL delicious.

The plates are definitely small plates so prepare to spend $$$ when you get here. But don't let that deter you from this 5/5 dining experience.

Just when you think the foodie experience has peaked enter Girl & The Goat. It was an amazing experience from the beginning to the end. Our bartender knew everything about the menu and walked us through an extraordinary culinary experience. The restaurant is beautifully done with stunning detail. My personal favorites were the Cauliflower starter and Kalbi Ribs but nobody was disappointed. Great wine selection too!

Make a reservation because they fill up quickly! Originally had a reservation for 11:30 but checked in earlier and they texted us at around 10:40. We walked back and got seated within minutes. They split their menus into vegetables, fish, and meat. On a smaller menu they had their goat dishes. We ordered the raw Kusshi oysters, goat empanadas, pork shank, and pig face (received in this order).

The raw Kusshi were the only raw oysters. These specific oysters were sweet and come with 4 in an order.  I would definitely order again. The empanadas came next, even more delicious than the oysters. They were very crispy on the outside but didn't have that oily feel to it that I expected. They were topped with blueberries and avocados, which added a light sweet touch to it. The meat with tender and has a blast of flavor. Next, came the pork shank. This was the best of the meal. The shank had been cooked for over 12 hours, which allowed the meat to melt off the bone. It came with some naan and two sauces, buttermilk and kimchi buffalo. Personally I liked the kimchi buffalo sauce more, tangy with a tiny kick. The whole combination was without a doubt perfect. Last, we got the wood oven roasted pig face, which came with a sunny side up egg and some potato stix. Personally, I wasn't a huge fan of this dish but I'm glad I got to try it. The face pieces mainly just felt really fatty, but super soft and flavorful. The potato stix were super crispy and complemented the pig face nicely.

Service was on point. Our server made excellent suggestions, empanadas and shank, and he even came to tell us that the kitchen was closing in 15 minutes and for us to get any other orders in! I came with just one friend and we weren't able to finish everything, and the bill was a bit high.  I'd say come with a group of friends so you can order and try a bit of everything, and not drop too much.

***
Came back again and had new experience. My friend called in to make a reservation for 9:30, but we got to the area and checked in early and the hostess actually told us her name wasn't on the list. We ended up just putting our name down and waited for maybe about 1.5 hours, which wasn't terrible. The wait gave us time to show our visitor to a couple more spot around the area. Once we checked back in, the hostess told us, she wanted to thank us for waiting so long, and for the possible confusion with the original reservation, by sitting us at the chef's table, which was perfect for three of us.

Rodrigo was our server and he gave excellent suggestions and explained why he liked them. I told my friends we had to order the shank. We also ordered the broccoli, duck tartare, and the confit goat belly. While all were delicious, I probably wouldn't order the broccoli again. The duck tartare was delcious and was a nice combination with the mushroom and vegetables that it came with. One of my friends absolutely hates raw meat, but says she enjoyed this! The best dish of the night was the confit goat belly. This dish was pretty small but it was an explosion of flavor once you got a bite of it. I'm not a huge fan of lobster or crab, but something about them together made it work. Lastly, we got the caramel corn and malt balls dessert. To be honest, I don't think any of us wanted dessert but Rodrigo suggested it and we have no regrets! The combination of the textures was fascinating. The gelato was so smooth but the popcorn caramel and chocolate brought a slight crunchiness.

While sitting at the chef's table we were able to talk with a couple of the chefs and hear their suggestions. We talked mostly to Alberto who convinced us to get the confit goat belly. He was very patient answering our questions and enthusiastic about explaining the dishes.. He also told us about the most popular dishes and ones we might want to try the next time we go! LAMB RIBS, I'M COMING FOR YOU NEXT!!!

Yes to Confit Goat Belly. Yes to caramel corn and malt balls dessert. Yes to service specifically from Rodrigo and Alberto. YES TO GIRL AND THE GOAT!!

So the food is amazing! I really do enjoy the amount of flavor in the food however don't go here if you're hungry because the portion sizes are absolutely tiny.

I ordered the Pig Face and absolutely loved how it tasted I just wish there was more. It's also very expensive.

The service and food quality are definitely above average. I am not a big fan of vegetables but I have to admit, we got the cauliflower and I was really impressed. We also ordered the pan seared halibut, pork shank, bucateli pasta. Other than the halibut being slightly overcooked, the dishes were cooked well, tasted great and had great flavor profiles. The pork shank stole the show though.  We also ordered the olive bread and it was excellent too. My only reason for not giving 5 stars is due to price. I think for the price point, the size of some dishes should be larger. Bit service and food quality are on point.

Mike and Alfredo... the best service... amazing food and atmosphere- but seriously, we will not forget that service and felt that goal love!! Thank you all!! Loved seeing everyone working together. Mike tho- those tounges... yes
I love the innovative touch, the help from the servers in timing and pairing etc.

Good food, terrible service and terrible atmosphere. Patio outside? Don't kid yourselves - it's a cafeteria-style communal table. It gets better though - wait till the evening critters arrive, you'll have to decide whether to eat, swat insects away, or take turns doing either one. They have literally one waitress managing the tables outside so I guess we can't blame the employees solely. Need more drinks? Savor your current ones until the staff find the time or desire to take your next order.

Advice? Get the food to go. Enjoy the food without the forgettable dining experience.

This certainly ranks in my top five overall dining experiences.
Service and food were all fantastic!
I found the pig face, and some of the goat dishes to be a bit underwhelming.  However, there are some sleepers on this menu!  The tempura soft shell crab was so great we ordered a second!  The escargot ravioli and perogies were also phenomenal.
The deserts were all great with the exception of the goat cheese one.  The shiitake gelato was incredible, a perfect balance of sweet & salty.  

Highly recommended!

The foods are very tasteful however I won't recommend it if you want to eat a lot for a reasonable price . G&G is not a regular restaurant because you must pay for everything including sides and others. Don't expect sides (potato or vegetables ) with ur order and bread for appetizer.
I had a great experience and would do it again the next time I am in ChiTown

They have really great drinks i will give them that.

The service is mediocre.  I ordered off the Vegan menu and let the server know that I am vegan and would like the Vegan burger.  She ordered off the regular menu for some reason and my food was not vegan at all.  I got sick from the food and she was pretty unapologetic!  She said 'i thought vegan was just a preference for you and not your diet'.  whether it's a preference or not, there is a reason why i let her know that i am a vegan and i want to order the vegan burger off the vegan menu.

I have a $100 gift card for this place...but i never wanna go back!

My wife and I finally got reservations to the restaurant....we were seated promptly....our server seemed experienced, and was helpful during our ordering.  That is where the good part of our experience ended.  We ordered 5 dishes for the two of us, unfortunately, we were served all 5 dishes at once!  We flagged down our server, asked that we get some of the dishes spaced, so that we had a chance to finish dishes before they got cold....no dice...her response was "that's the way the kitchen is sending it out".  Needless to say, that did not suit our idea of the best way to enjoy our meal....it became clear that the restaurant's focus was having as many turns as possible, by pushing people out the door.....client satisfaction is not high in the list of priorities.  The two dishes we did get to eat were fine, but not meeting the wonderful reviews we read before coming....i.e. we prefer any number of other restaurants purely on flavor/value/etc.   Needless to say, we will not likely be back, nor recommend that others visit, until the restaurant stops focusing purely on their enrichment, versus the guest experience.
Perfect spot after surprise tickets to see my home team The Miami Heat beat my boyfriends home team Chicago Bulls..,Victory taste GOOD‼

Get reservations way in advance but it's worth it. It's shareables so like tapas so order a few per person but save room for dessert! The cauliflower is a must have, the breads are good too. You can't go wrong with any of the desserts so we got three, the honey thing was awesome, malt thing amazing and the sweet potato cake delish! The drinks were great as well and the service was attentive.

After struggling to secure a reservation over a month in advance and reading numerous rave reviews, we had high expectations for our Sunday night dinner.

We arrived at 8:15 and the restaurant was crowded and noisy. Not only was nearly every seat full, but our table was so close to our neighbours that I had to turn my (rather slim) body sideways to reach the booth, as did the server when she came by to take orders. Not quite what I had in mind in terms of an intimate dinner...

We were told our family style selections would be served as they were ready, and we ordered the recommended 2-3 dishes per person (five in total). The chickpea fritters arrived first, and were delicious, with a delicately fried exterior, a smooth filling, and crispy red quinoa garnish. The goat empanadas and scallops were next and were both lovely, although rushed in their delivery, and the latter, a very small portion. The most highly anticipated dishes of the evening; green beans and pig face arrived last, and were rather disappointing: the green beans were crunchy, and had good flavour, but this was ruined by over-salting the dish (particularly the onions). The pig (not a literal face, but more of a breakfast hash) featured pulled pork that was a bit dry in places and made for a heavy dish to receive at the end of the meal.

We opted to order our server's recommendation of lemon pound cake with cheesecake sauce for dessert, which proved to be refreshing and not overly heavy.  

Overall, the rushed service (in and out in 1.5 hours) and crowded atmosphere did not live up to the experience we expected for small plates at this price point, with this level of hype. Our meal was about $100 with five dishes, one beer, and one dessert (before tip). We had better meals elsewhere in Chicago both in terms of food and ambiance and are not likely to return.

Every time we take a trip to Chicago, we have to go here for the "Pig Face." I know, that sounds disgusting. I'm a super picky eater and I think it's fantastic. The wait it always long-- but your name in hours in advance (no reservation.)

Probably my favorite restaurant in Chicago. The plates are Devine and so much care is put into each menu item. Tons of vegetarian options: The Shishito Peppers and the Cauliflower are great for sharing. The Duck Tongue is one of my favorites - tender meat with a crisp, delicate finish. Great flavor. Pig Face is also another favorite - packed with maple flavor combined with cilantro and the sunny-side egg broken over the meat is a combination like none other. After 6-7 dishes I'm usually so full I can't handle any more food but the dessert is out of the world. Seasonal items change up the dessert menu but my favorite was a sweet potato - brown sugar type dessert with goose berries in each flavor packed bite. Who knew heaven could be found on a fork! 5/5 just for the dessert.

Having watched Stephanie's Top Chef winning season, we've been wanting to try this place for quite a long time.  Since we live out of town, the opportunities haven't been plentiful but with careful advance planning, we managed to get a 6:00 Saturday evening reservation.  The place was jam-packed when we got there but had to wait only a couple minutes to be seated.  As one might expect with a large, filled room, the noise level is pretty high but our table by the front window meant there was no one on one side so we could converse without yelling.

Our server (and all the staff we encountered) was extremely helpful in guiding our choices.  The presentation of each dish was accompanied by a description that refreshed our memories of the menu.  The first two (of 6) dishes came out quickly but there seemed to be an overly long gap before the next batch of 3 came out.  Our overall impression was that the dishes were quite tasty but several were on the oily side.  The green beans and skirt steak were the best of the lot.  We had two goat dishes and because they were highly seasoned, they could have been anything.  I had not had goat before so it could well be goat meat needs a lot of seasoning.  The malt balls dessert was everyone's favorite.

Chicago is a great restaurant town and we have been to 6 Michelin star restaurants and 2 or 3 others we felt were equivalent.  The GATG is one step below the star level and based on this visit, I think that's where it belongs.  As another reviewer noted, at this price point, there are better values for a quality dining experience.

Flawless food and service. The menu was interesting and offered many appealing options. We friend and I could not choose so was asked the waiter for some advice. He was patient, knowledgeable and very descriptive in his explanation of the menu. All of his suggestions were fantastic. I will be returning here again and again!

pics.caption: The lemon cake with sorrel ice cream was a little slice of heaven
Crispy citrus short ribs were a delightful surprise
String beans had good texture and were seasoned very well

review.des: Goat food. If this is goat food, slap a bell around my neck and call me Nanny! I went with my friend, Jim. We ordered everything to share. Normally, I'm fairly polite with taking turns and sharing the "nice" amount. Sadly, I had the feed bag around my face and went nuts! The scallops, fish, bread, salad, veggies, lamb...just wooooow! The chef understands the science of what the palate desires...and my mouth was extremely grateful. Poor Jim...will just have to return with a less hungry, skinny friend.

Let me paint a picture for you fellow yelpers.... I'm not a hype guy, I'm a preparedness guy. I plan on pissing myself at a concert so I wear swim trunks.... now to the Life changing olives. I'll bring you into my element. Never eat olives. I despise them. Although these weren't so bad. Highly recommend this place.
Not worth the hype! Only good thing was the Little Goat latte and that's because they used goat milk as opposed to regular milk. Food was below average.

Had a Very underwhelming meal here last Thursday night.  Been here many times since they opened and the food and value was always amazing.  Well those times have seemed to change.  The Entree Chicken dish was so underwhelming and we didn't even eat all 4 pieces. The desserts were nothing to rave about.  The salad  was my favorite thing we ate and I am not a salad fan.  It's the only item we finished of all the food we got.  180 bucks wish I could have back.  Will have to stick to the diner we're I eat at 2x a week and NEVER disappoints.  Maybe Stephanie is spread too thin with the new opening and all her obligations.  #Datenightfail
Incredible !! No words needed - the food, the atmosphere, Stephanie Izard can do no wrong and frankly If she ran a McDonalds id pay $100 to eat at it

Pretty pricey, but if your into the quality, this place is for you! I'm so thankful, at least the quality goes along with its price. Each one on the list were surprisingly delicious, and it has surpassed my already high expectations. The friendly and quick service was a huge addition too. Will definitely go back.

This place definitely lived up to it's astounding reputation. The moment I walked into this place I knew I was in for an amazing experience. The modern ambiance  alone set the mood. Please note reservations are highly recommended in advance because the seats go fast!!!

So let's get into the good stuff the much awaited entrees:

I started the evening with Cornbread which came with Cherry Relish and Honey Mustard Butter the bread was a melt in your mouth kind of bread.

Now the dishes that were completely mind blowing were the Soft Shell Crab and the Wood Oven Roasted Face Pig. Now that I think about it all the dishes I tried had a melt in your mouth kind of effect. It was one of those evenings that each bite just kept getting better and better.

Of course I topped the evening off with dessert Caramel Corn and Malt Balls and how can one go honestly wrong with this concoction. The answer is you simply cannot.

I love going to a restaurant and the presentation of the beautifully displayed food  matches the quality of savory flavors. I can tell that the Love Potion was sprinkled magically all over Girl and the Goat because I truly fell in Love........

Great great good. Everything in the menus is delicious. We came here and they did not have seating for wheel chair - however within a few minutes they figured out a space for us and accommodated us. The service was great too, definitely will visit when we go back to Chicago.

pics.caption: Option to cook some of the stuff yourself. Guaranteed won't taste the same.

review.des:
Excellent restaurant! Everything we had was fresh, had a certain twist to the food to make it slightly different but not too different to make it taste weird. It tasted like real food and good food at that. The petite Verdot was excellent too and on par with a small winery in Virginia-linden's petit Verdot.

Girl & the goat hit it out of the park. Loved it!

I mean, this place certainly doesn't need another 5 rating star and a whole essay on how smashing it is so I'll say this. If they only have a 10pm res even though you book 2 months in advance, don't question, just go. We had spent the day walking miles and miles around the city and went kayaking so my energy level was spent and I felt like a walking swamp but I am so glad that I recharged for this.

Loved the shishito peppers, goat empanada with strawberries (one of the specials), and the PORK SHANK. Holy mackerel, I could dream of how tender that meat was.
Didn't love the grapeseed bread with oil-- think it made me too full and I would've loved to try another dish instead. Somehow, we were stuffed to the face with just those plates. I wish I lived in Chicago so I could visit all of Stephanie Izard's restaurants but the reality is, I live in Austin, TX and I'm just going to have to live on tacos and BBQ until I can come back to visit.

It only took a weeks notice to finally nab a spot here, and now that Stephanie izard's been announced an iron chef I figured it as good a time as ever to come to one of Chicago's most famous restaurants. Came with 4 for a birthday dinner and we really went all out; ordered 9 dishes and sat with bated breath for it all to come out. The menu is small but focused; there are essentially 5 sections with a few offerings in each one; Breads, Goat, Vegetables, Seafood, Meat. We ordered 2 of everything except 1 vegetable. Every dish had a baseline level of quality that was high; presentation and service were attentive as to be expected. That said if you were to ask me which ones I think were worth it to get on repeat visits I would say much of it was hit or miss.

Breads: A must if you want to fill up at an affordable price. Each is $5, and they come with very different breads. We had incredibly fluffy biscuits with a delicious whipped butter and savory jam, along with a crispy toasted brioche with salmon cream cheese and a giardinera that paired perfectly together.

Goat: Had the Goat belly confit and the Goat pate. The goat pate was...interesting. It came with essentially a large cracker and a bunch of incredibly butter and fluffy rillettes. The actual pate itself was very distinctly flavored with goat, and I think required the accompanying pickled ingredients to balance out its fattiness. On it's own I think the pate was an overwhelming flavor. I'm not sure if I would be able to handle it again. As for the goat belly confit, I had mixed opinions. It was topped with lobster and crab in this light and delicate sauce, and all the components individually where great. I'm just didn't really get the combination together; especially since for a dish that was supposed to highlight the goat belly I didn't really get a big feeling that It was the star.

Veggies: Got the seared broccoli over blue cheese. Actually quite liked this, would be happy eating this again or trying the green beans(which were also recommended and looked good as well)

Meats: We got the pig face and the Duck Tongue. Both were great; despite having fried components they still maintained much of the juiciness and fullness of fatty components melded together with delicious sauces and softer textures. Some of our favorites for the night

Seafood: Soft-shell crab and halibut. To preface, both had pretty small portions; the soft shell crab was essentially one crab partitioned into 4-5 parts; the halibut was a small slice which was cooked perfectly, and served on top of a mixed blueberry and fish sauce base. I think the soft-shell crab was phenomenal actually; crispy as expected but the interior was juicier than any I've ever had. It was a small portion but each bite was worth every dollar. The halibut I felt was a bit more ordinary. The blueberry and fish sauce combination tasted alright, but ultimately wsn't a flavor combo that wowed me. And as for the fish itself, it was moist and flaky, though I was looking for some crispy component(I'm looking for skin here), which was absent.

All in all, I think Girl and Goat is very good, but also a bit overrated. While all the dishes are good, whether or not you will be amazed by certain ones are subject to variability. On the other hand, I was more full than I expected to be. $30 per person got me stuffed, and for high-class tapas, you are not doing bad if you come here for fine dining.

I was visiting Chicago and this was the first time I had a shot at a Michelin Star dining experience near where I was.  You probably need to make a reservation well in advance for a table, but you can walk in and get full service at the bar or lounge.

The hostess was curt, but friendly enough considering they were busy and I didn't have a reservation at 5:30 on a Thursday. The service was phenomenal and despite how busy they were I didn't feel rushed and didn't need to wait long for my food or drinks.

The food was prepared beautifully! I had the lamb which fell off the bone and was like butter.  The escargot ravioli was also amazing and I believe shows what earned this place its star: Creativity.  Looking through the menu there were some interesting flavor combinations that you wouldn't think of putting together, but which balanced perfectly.

I will admit I think the food is a bit overpriced for the portion size, but it was not unreasonable and to be expected of a restaurant with its reputation.

We walked in at 5:30PM in hopes that they would have a table for two, but was told the wait would be two hours.

The hostess had a stuck up attitude and didn't even take down a phone number. When I asked how will I know my table is ready, he said "I'll call your name". So they fully expect you to wait there the whole time, otherwise "hours" can be added to your wait time.

We got seated around 6:30PM on their patio. The seating was communal so there isn't too much space for those who carry a large purse like me..

We ordered the Pig Face, which was really good, but on the oily side. The baby octopus was underwhelming and not as tender as I expected.

My favorite was the Pork Shank, which was enormous compared to the other serving sizes. The pita bread was soft and fluffy and the pork was fall-off-the-bone good!

This being my first time at the Girl & the Goat, I don't know if I'll come back, unless I really crave that pork shank!

They need to work on the service and our waitress had a stress-ridden face all evening. My experience would have been much better if service was better.

pics.caption: My Favorite! Pork Shank! Fall Off Bone Good!

review.des: Very impressed with this discovery! Love this restaurant. The food is wonderful. The atmosphere is charming.  I recommend the pork shank or the walleye. Both exceptional! Highly recommend.

I had the French toast chicken with maple syrup. Awesomeness!

I booked a table a month in advance! The wait for an opening can be hours if you walk in!

I suggest making reservations

I have been here a couple times and don't see what the hype is about. The food is always salty and it's too loud.

However, the short rib and grapefruit is one of the best things I've ever had and would come back for that! The service is always positive too

I've been going here for years and love it! Like a lot of restaurants in the area it's full of tourists, but still easy to get into if you make a reservation ahead of time or want to take the chance swing by. The food does not disappoint and it's a great place to go with friends/family.

After 3 trips to Chicago, I've finally got to try Girl & The Goat! I'm happy that I was able to score a great reservation time. This place really does get busy and people even line up before it opens to score a bar seat. I know this because we came here twice during our trip haha!

The food was tasty and the service was friendly! The restaurant itself is dim and but loud when it's full of diners. Our server was able to bring out dishes continuously without loading out small table. I enjoyed all the dishes we had ordered and I would definitely come back again!

Obviously this place is amazing and it should definitely be on everyone's list when visiting Chicago.  We had Easter dinner here and tried four different dishes the Roasted Cauliflower, Hamchi Crudo, Roasted Pig Face, and the Goat Empanadas. Overall it was a great experience...everything was delicious and all the recipes were extremely inventive!  We loved the complex flavors in each dish, but our absolute favorite was the pig face.  For two people, these four dishes allowed us to be pleasantly full despite the smaller portion size for the Hamachi Crudo.

I would recommend getting a variety of dishes from each section of the menu to mix things up.  Also it's always a good idea to listen to your server.  We had a really hard time deciding what to get (because everything sounded good), so we just took the recommendations from our server and she did not disappoint.

Girl & the Goat is not bad, but with almost 6000 reviews on Yelp and no reservation available, I expected much more. Leaving with a full belly of disappointment, I really think this place was overrated. The pricing and portion can definitely be improved.

I rushed here at 5pm as a walk-in, and got seated immediately. Inside the restaurant was pretty noisy, so we chose to sit at the patio. We quickly checked Yelp to make sure we don't miss out on signature dishes, and orderd the followings:
+ kohlrabi salad: the only thing that was outstanding. The dressing was on the heavy side, but the subtle hint of blue cheese worked wonder with thinly sliced kohlrabi.
+ sweet brioche: it started to go down hill from here.  It came with some green butter which had no taste, and caramelized onion.  The bread had a disappointing texture, and the slightly sweet taste just didn't go well with the really savory menu.
+ goat empanadas: a good dish, but not like, mind-blowingly good, for a place that literally has the word 'goat' in its name. I think it's tough to make good empanadas because the fried corn taste can easily overpower the filling, and they didn't deliver a good empanada here.  The mushroom plated on the side was actually the star of the dish, and helped balance the heavy corn taste and dry goat meat.
+ roasted pig face: ordered this one because it was the most mentioned dish on Yelp review.  Imagine bacon wrap in fat, deep fried and then roasted. It tasted like that.  It's so fat, and there was nothing to balance it. It should have been served with some acidic salad/pickle on the side.
+ goat shank: last dish and the heaviest dish.  I now have serious complaint about how G&TG does pricing and portion. It's supposed to be a tapas type of place, so why would you serve that much meat by itself, and priced it at $26? Also, the dishes here are served one by one, going from the lightest to the heaviest, so even if you order a salad to go with the goat shank, they would not be served together (if you didn't know and didn't ask). The portion and price was for an entry, not a small dish to share. Now the the dish itself, have you had roasted pork from chinatown? This dish probably used the same technique that resulted in extremely crispy skin. However, the meat lacked most, and was a pain to eat with Naan bread (which was actually really good).  There was some nice sauce that came with it, but the dish itself was, again, just out of balance.

I may come back here just for the vegetable dishes.

I was so excited to this place when I was planning for a trip to Chicago. I came to the restaurant around 4:20 PM to get a table for 6 people. There was already a line formed before us (they open at 4:15). We were seated in the patio area. We ordered goat empanadas, and corn bread as appetizers. The wood oven roasted pig face, crisp braised pork shank, pan roasted halibut, oven roasted sepia, and galbi as main dishes; and wood grilled broccoli, and roasted cauliflower as veggie sides. We also ordered Best of Three, Local
75, Ring of Fire and Daiquiri for drinks.

The goat empanadas:
eh, it was okay. I couldn't really taste the goat meat in the empanada. The presentations were fantastic though. It came with strawberries topped with feta cheese!

The corn bread:
it was okay. Just very fluffy bread. Nothing special.

Wood oven roasted pig face:
I really like the two eggs on top of the meat. When you smash the eggs onto the meat, the creamy yolk mixed with the tender meat is very tasteful.

Crisp braised pork shank:
the pita bread that came with the dish was sooo good. Grab a chunk of meat, wrap it in a pita bread, put some sauces and kimchi on it and you are ready for some deliciousness.

Pan Roasted Halibut:
Yum!! This was my favorite dish! The halibut was served on a almond butter and covered with mushrooms and white asparagus, served on a bowl. The flavors of all ingredients complemented each other very well.

Oven Roasted Sepia:
This was my second fav! The sepia was chewy yet smooth to bite. The tomato and avocado was added to enhance the chewiness and intensified the flavor.

Galbi:
It was served on top of 4 corns. As a Korean, I approve this galbi. It was a bit too oily and the meat was too thin for my liking but it was flavorful and was similar to galbi's I had in Korea.

Broccoli:
The rogue smokey bleu sauce well complimented the wood grilled broccoli. I really like the smoked smell of broccoli.

cauliflower:
Wow. The pine nuts went so well with the cauliflower. I'd eat this for a meal any day.

The downside of the restaurant would be:
-REALLY dark bathrooms. I almost tripped over the stairs.
-Pricey for the portion. It ranged from $15-30 and you need to get about 2 dishes per person.

Overall, I enjoyed my dining experience. I'd come back again when i get my paycheck.
Worth the wait. My favorite of Chef Izard's many resturants. Get the duck tongue... it sounds weird but taste amazing!

Hannah behind the bar was awesome. Told her I wanted savory but not heavy. She suggested the duck tongue. What?!? I've never had duck tongue! It was simply amazing! Loved it.

She also suggested the halibut. Although it was great, it wasn't in the same category of what I was looking for. It was delicious, but not as rich as the duck tongue.

Then the dessert. Holy cow! It was a bourbon bread pudding of sorts. I forget what it was called, but I loved it!

Can't wait to bring my wife and daughters in the near future!

YUM! Had to came here during my trip to Chicago as it's one of the most famous restaurants in the city. We were able to get a reservation for 4 at 10pm on a Wednesday night. The food and service was fantastic! The dishes are all meant to be shared, family-style. The waiter suggested we do 1-2 dishes per person. We went above that because why not? We got:

-the cauliflower: insane, who knew cauliflower could be so interesting and delicious?
-shishito peppers: good but nothing that special
-broccoli: so yummy but a little less healthy covered in melted cheese
-chickpea fritters: also unique and delicious
-clam chowder bread: yummy but didn't get the clam chowder part and probably the most boring dish we had of the night
-goat empanadas: YUM but only comes with two so we each just got a bite packed with flavor
-duck tongue: surprisingly tasty! also a larger portion dish with interesting asian flavors
-escargot ravioli: one of my favorites! pasta was so delicate and freshly handmade and the broth was savory
-chicken: well-cooked and tasty, less unique than some of the others but definitely a good chicken if that's your choice of meat
-bucatini: also one of my favorites! you can taste the hollowness of the bucatini and also came with a slightly larger portion
-pig face with over easy egg: a MUST TRY. One of their most unique and very flavorful with crispy potato strings underneath. Also a large portion and we took some leftovers home. Also so colorful on the plate
-the confit goat belly with lobster and crab, sadly this dish came out last so we were so so full by then but definitely one of the classier, elevated dishes. I enjoyed it a lot.

The best part of Girl and the Goat was also the value! Prices were honestly very reasonable for the quality and amount of food. We each paid less than $75 each including tax, tip, and a cocktail each! And like I said, we were even able to take home some leftovers!

Waiter was so friendly and helpful with the menu descriptions and getting our food out swiftly and in the most intuitive order. He suggested the right amount of food and let us know we had ordered a lot (not trying to oversell). 5 stars!

Ohmyyeezzus this place was so freakin good. I tried to get the more popular dishes since it was my first time here and didn't want to miss out on the favorites.
First-the goat empanadas were so tender and flavorful, not a super big plate though everything is meant to share and they're were two and I could have ate about 6.
Second-sautéed green beans, I don't even really like green beans but these were on point.
Third-pig face, do not skip this one, so crisp and devious, I'm salivating right now thinking about it
Fourth- crisp pork shoulder. It fell off the bone and had the biggest portions of the night.

So yeah do yourself a favor and just go..

Stopped by this place last week. It was really good. Boyfriend and I got in without a reservation after waiting in line for 20 minutes. We were told that the wait ranges from 2-4 hours after waiting for the restaurant to open, but we got lucky and they had a cancellation.

We tried the goat empanadas, loved them. Boyfriend still talks about them to this day.
Also had the green beans (on their menu since opening), I thought ti was a little bit salty for my taste; similar taste to asian fusion.
We had the most popular item: Pig face came with an egg and crispy onions and variety of sauces. Probably would be my personal favorite of the night. boyfriend and I both enjoyed.
Our last entree was the pork shank. It came with naan, kimchi, and a couple sauces. I thought this dish was mediocre compared to the pig face and goat empanadas. Did not live up to expectations. The outside was crunchy, but the inside was a bit bland and dry in some parts.
We had dessert: lemon cake with sorbet. We read reviews that people often felt better after having dessert, I did not feel that way. For $11, a cupcake with 2 medium scoops of ice cream, I thought that the dessert did not live up to expectations either. Boyfriend thought the dessert was great so I guess the taste is up to each individual person.

We came for a birthday and anniversary celebration and we were told that that was a special surprise at the end, but our waitress never came by with it. Otherwise, service was relatively good.
I gave this 4/5 since while the restaurant is good and I thought the goat empanadas and pig face was great, I don't think it would be worth the wait, especially since we were told that there would be a special and we never heard back again.

No. Do not crucify me, but yes I am giving girl and the goat 3 stars.
I was here back in 2015 with a friend of mine. It was jam-packed, very noisy, and the waiters were over-and-above-their heads drowning in arrogance. It was palpable. The pork shoulder was the only memorable piece of the uber-expensive dinner!.
The valet, on my way in, was less than polite!. Overall, I was not impressed. However it just may have been a series of unfortunate events.

Awesome experience, wonderful, innovative foods, the most beautiful mussels I've seen on any coast, great service, excellent drinks and wine list.  It's a little weird when you first look at the menu and you realize, holy hell there's goat in everything, how is this going to work out? The name- they're not kidding.  But they pull it off beautifully, every time.

If you are lucky, grab a seat at the bar when you don't have a reservation. We knew this going in that this was a pricey place but we were in town and in the area and tested our luck. The recommendation was to share about five dishes with two people but that didn't seem like worth $$ after seeing the portions. Think tapas in miniature version. Drinks were worth it. And now we can say, "we tried the Girl and the Goat".

When it comes to making a reservation, be on the look out for cancellations since it does happen! I was incredibly disappointed when I saw that the next reservation would be in the next month (October) which is a month wait when I was visiting earlier last weekend (September). Super disappointed that I wouldn't be able to try this restaurant when I was in the city. Luckily, there seemed to have been a cancellation and a reservation spot opened up! Score!

So did the restaurant live up to the hype? Yes, it did and with flying colours!

This is probably my favourite restaurant that I had been to in Chicago... or ever. My biggest tip is to listen to your server for their recommendations- we did that and we were very happy! Our server, Prestley, was incredibly attentive and was friendly.  She checked on us to see how we liked our meal from time to time, and she made our experience a wonderful one.

There were somethings on the menu that had run out so another tip would be to order the ones you want to try first before deciding on other things.

We went all out and ordered these dishes (Please note there was two of us, we were both stuffed by the end! Definitely ate my weight in food.) :
-Goat Empanadas
-Goat Liver Mousse
-Wood-oven Roasted Pig Face
-Bucatini

I tried to my hardest to order the dishes from favourite to least favourite, because even my "least favourite" was a favourite!

The Goat Empanadas definitely surprised me, because you ask "how good can empanadas be?". They were "call home to tell your mother"good, or even  "trade your boyfriend for one" good. The crispy empanadas were served on avocado puree and covered in chopped strawberries, feta and mint, served on a wooden paddle. The flavours were absolutely delicious and complex. The tartness from the vinaigrette sauce brought out the sweetness of the strawberries which paired amazingly with the creamy avocado. The goat meat on the inside was rich and flavourful paired wonderfully with the vinaigrette-coated strawberries, which balanced the flavours with its tartness.

Following the goat empanadas, the goat liver mousse was next. The goat liver mousse was served with fresh bread soft and crispy bread with assortment of condiments such as fruit relish, pickled watermelon rinds, and pickles. The bread was so tasty, I would just eat it by itself but paired with the goat liver mousse was super decadent. This dish is quite big so I do recommend that you order it if there are at least 3 people or else you will be super stuffed.

The wood-oven roasted pig face was something I was anticipating because of all the reviews. The dish was really rich and heavy, personally speaking I felt like the overeasy egg served on top did nothing for the dish other than presentation. The crispy potato sticks added a different texture with made the dish more interesting.

Last but not least was the buacatini. The pasta was clearly handmade which the texture that it had. Typically, I don't like al dente pasta but this time around the texture was perfect for this dish. The bites of heirloom cherry tomatoes and fresh basil gave a refreshing taste to the otherwise a rich dish.

I will definitely be back

pics.caption: Unlike the name, it's not scary.
I'm just drooling at the thought of having another one of those breads.

review.des: Try the wine tasting menu. Be prepared for it to last a while. You must have reservations weeks in advance, but well worth the wait. I cannot say too many nice things about this restaurant. We did a my son's wedding rehearsal dinner in the wine cellar, was fabulous, great food, vegan options, And intimate setting. Well worth the price!

The best shishito peppers I have ever put my mouth! The crispy pork was fall off the bone mouth watering! Wonderful Pinot Noir from Germany. Excellent service! The cherry on the cake was the malt gelato, magic shell with popcorn dessert! Yes, please!!
