I heard that it was not easy to find seats in this hot spot in Chicago, thus I was sooo glad to find 2 spots in OpenTable a day before our arrival at this city. A total memorable experience here!
Goat carpaccio - thought it would have strong gamey goat flavor but not the case at all. The meat itself was tender and light just like beef, and the condiments were savory.
Goat liver mousse - Surprisingly smooth and fine texture that went well with the crispy bread. My boyfriend who didn't like the usual liver flavor thought this dish was excellent as well
Goat Empanadas - some other review said this is their classical dish and I can totally see why! The stuffing was warm, tasty, juicy pulled meat with rich goat flavors.
Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face - the waiter mess asked us to scramble everything before we eat. Messy but tasty! Love the crispy pig face.
Confit Goat Belly - the seafood and butter was great but I'd wish to taste a bit more goat belly

pics.caption: Goat empanadas - avocado smash, grilled pineapple blueberry salsa, queso fresco
Confit goat belly - bourbon butter, lobster and crab, fennel
Wood oven roasted pig face (hiding under the sunny side egg)

review.des:
Girl & the Goat was a great choice for my first night in Chicago. Sat in the patio section with strangers and everyone we talked to was so friendly. This made dinner so much more enjoyable.

The server recommend 2 dishes per person to share family style (Menu selection changes frequently)
They brought the food out from lightest to heaviest:
Blueberry cornbread
Goat empanadas
Grilled tuna
Broccoli
Kalbi short ribs

The goat empanadas, kalbi beef, and tuna were my favorites!

Yes! Go here if you can!!
Food so so so good, ambiance a little loud but also super friendly, servers awesome. They had a veggie menu which was so fantastic and easy.
Get a taste of everything!

One of the best meals I've had. Ever. Our server, Devon, was just as amazing as the food! She had great recommendations and was unbelievably helpful. Bartenders were wonderful while we were waiting as well! Our party of 2 had the cashew green beans, goat belly, lamb ribs, broccoli, duck tartar, and scallops. All of them were absolutely amazing, but the scallops, tartar, and green beans were our favorites. The green beans are one of the top 10 dishes I think I've ever had anywhere. We were visiting Chicago, but this restaurant could just be enough to make us relocate!
Great place. Lots of hype and not sure its worth waiting forever to get in. Of course if you're from out of town and want to try the popular famous places this is right in the wheelhouse.

I so wanted to love this place.

We ordered 8 dishes to share amongst 4 people and were only impressed with a handful of them.  Everything else was ok- fresh tasting, inventive, but not especially delicious.  Unfortunately, because each dish was such a tiny serving size, we each literally only got A bite of each dish we tried.  So, we were left wanting

It was loud enough inside that conversation was difficult to maintain and we were seated at a large table, which was shared with another party. Overall, the ambiance was disappointing.

Our cocktails were quite good, but we opted out of dessert after our so-so dinner experience.

It's definitely a place I'd try again- maybe just a party of 2 and now being more familiar with the menu we could zero in on the dishes we did really enjoy?  But, I don't think I'd return with a group.
Maybe because it was a busy day but the food was really greasy and fries undercooked. I had heard good reviews so I was very surprised.

After a two month wait, I finally got into Girl and The Goat. Considered one of the best restaurants in Chicago, I thought this place would be all hype but I was clearly wrong. Girl and The Goat is truly remarkable because they are getting people to eat uncommon ingredients like pig face, goat liver, and even duck tongue and executing them perfectly.

Make sure to order the duck tongue - this one dish brings together Peruvian and Asian flavors unlike anything I have ever eaten. I also recommend the goat liver mousse since I couldn't stop eating it. This is one of those places where you can order anything on the menu and it will be amazing. Also, the dishes aren't frou frou and don't cost an arm and a leg. My one complaint is that the portions are small and I wish I could Super Size them because I wanted more.

Stephanie "The Wizard" Izard, you enchanted me with your magic and delicious creations. Feed me more goat and duck tongue!

We walked in at about 4:30 on a Saturday without reservations hoping there was any kind of an open or almost open table for 2, and we were lucky to be seated right away under the condition that they needed the table at 6, which was perfectly fine.

We were seated at a communal table towards the back that wasn't really awkward. I was able to watch the crazy line of cooks in the kitchen do their thing as well which was interesting.

We started with a glass of wine and a cocktail. The Morning Ritual was phenomenal, smoky mezcal nicely balanced with sweetness and spice from actual chili peppers, this was a great drink!

Next was the potato bread. This was delicious and a great start to the meal. I liked the yogurt spread but the cheese spread was good too.

The food is served kind of like tapas style, it comes out at different times and it's meant for sharing, but the plates are small, so it was suggested we order 2 each and we did. I had the Goat empanadas and the escargot ravioli, while my buddy had the duck tartare and goat mousse. We both thought the food was excellent. My goat empanadas were fantastic, the goat meat is unique in a really good way, and the whole thing blended together very well with the mushrooms and queso fresco. The escargot ravioli was more of a ravioli soup. The ravioli themselves were really small, and there were only a few of them. The sauce was super super flavorful and rich, a little on the salty side, but not unbearable. I thought the mousse was good too, didn't get to try any of the other stuff that came with it. The duck tartare was a little bit too exotic for me and the aftertaste was strange, my buddy really liked it though, so if you're into the raw meat thing it's probably excellent.

Ordered dessert, as well as a couple of espressos. The tiramisu was fantastic, served in a giant coffee mug with these airy but crunchy chocolate chunks on top, it was excellent and there was a lot of it. The espresso was from Dark Matter, and it was delicious.

Service was good, we didn't need much and the server was knowledgeable, attentive and friendly.

Overall we had a great experience. Girl and the Goat is super unique and I tried a bunch of new foods that I don't think you could get too many other places. The only drawback is that it's pretty pricey and the portion sizes aren't huge, but as I always say, quality over quantity and this place is worth a little splurge.

So much hype, but it was great! We had a 9pm reservation and it was slammed! They seat you pretty close to one another, but we had friendly neighbors who made recommendations. We had the mr potato head bread, calamari bruschetta, potato blue cheese pierogis, scallops, pork shank and caramel malt ball popcorn. All were unique and flavorful- they do a really good job combining flavors and textures. We will be back, and we'll order the bread, scallops, shank and ice cream again. They were stellar. The bruschetta was really good and the goat cheese ricotta wasn't too stinky which I appreciated, but there are so many things to go back and try! The pierogis were really nice with the blue cheese and bright fruit pieces on top but again- there is more to try! The scallops came in this really delicious sauce and they're huge. The spreads for the bread were so good! The shank is huge and we had some left!

Not as big of a fan, they try to give off the presence theyre worth the $ but there is much better out here, trust me, dont waste the $
IF you are wanting to try it, bring your wallet because its expensive. the bar is real cool which is why this is 2 stars and not 1, real cool inside and fun if you are going to the bar, very cool

It was my first time ever coming here and my group had booked a reservation well over a month in advance... let me tell you now that the wait was well worth it.

The dim lighting added marvelously to the very stylish, chic, and modern interior.  It felt very classy and upscale even though casual attire+ seemed to be the norm.

The drink menu was great and there were several great craft beers.  The servers are quite knowledgeable too when it comes to asking which beer on the menu is similar to a beer that I enjoy which isn't on the menu - in more detail, I asked which beer on the menu tasted similar to spotted cow.

Okay, now on the food.  I ordered several items, which included the duck tongues, wood oven roasted pig face, and the raw oysters.  Everything was phenomenal and the presentation was very inviting and beautiful.  I had a little of some other people's food from my group and I was wowed by everything as well: goat empanadas, crisp braised pork shank, and a few more.  Dessert was spectacular too!  

I'm not someone who bends backwards from everything I eat, but this place is truly top notch.

I would love to come back and it would be even better if my next time included a significant other because I know she'll be impressed from this restaurant.  

P.S. The service was great and beverages were refilled consistently.

Amazing and completely worth the wait

We split this between 3 people:
Goat empanadas
Halibut
Goat Pork belly
Broccoli
Perogies
Blueberry sourdough
Escargot ravioli

Also, randomly, also dining there we met Yo-to Ma who was in town to play with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra. He talked to us with a glass of red wine in hand for like 20 minutes! He is a really interesting and good human being.

Wasn't impressed AT ALL! Slightly disappointed because the hype is what made me extremely excited to try this place. I ordered the Lamb ribs, chicken dish(can't remember exact name), fried oysters and Cauliflower. I enjoyed  the cauliflower & fried oysters the most. The food wasn't bad butttt it wasn't GREAT! Think I set my expectations too high! Whomp whomp
Really pricey but an awesome experience - delicious food and worth the cost! We had a blast!

Went in a party of 7 and each ordered two dishes plus bread and dessert. Highlights include: Scallops, Bucatini, Potato Bread, Pig Face, Chickpea Fritters, Goat Empanadas, and Sweet Potato dessert. Staff was attentive and helped our group navigate the options. For sure would come back!

My second time here.  I'm more of an experience type when it comes to food so my first time was mildly positive as all the dishes were fun to try than actually loving the taste.  Only negative back then was the attitude of the server who was a bit arrogant.  Funny to say but it was almost an identical experience, arrogant server and all! :)  Too much hype yet still seems to be going strong.

Warning: Book your table way in advance, or else you'll be stuck with a 4-5 hour wait. I booked a table for 2, two months in advance, and the only time slot left for my date was at 10PM (I checked 1-2 before/after, same situation). When we arrived at 10PM, the place was packed and was still packed when we left around 11:30PM. Worth the wait, worth the visit, worth it all. Service was spectacular - our waiter was very attentive and helpful. All the dish we ordered did not disappoint. This place definitely deserves the spectacular ratings & reviews on here.

All the plates are made to share, and the waiter recommends 2 plates per person. So for two people, we ordered:

Chickpea Fritters: This reminded me of fried tofu - both texture and taste. Crispy on the outside, soft and gooey on the inside. This dish is a great appetizer since it's pretty light (despite it being a fried dish).

Goat Empanada: Sooooo good! This is on the specials menu. The empanada is crispy, topped with chopped strawberries, feta and mint. The meat is very tender and flavorful, but the strawberries, feta, and mint helped balance out the strong goat taste.

Wood Oven Pig Face: Highlight of the night. This was our favorite dish. It's the most recommended on here for good reason. You can't leave the restaurant without ordering it.

Crisp Braised Pork Shank: The meat is soooo tender that it falls off the bone. The pita bread that comes with it is fresh, doughy, and absolutely delicious. There are two sauces, but I didn't bother using either because the meat + pita combo was enough. There is also a side of kimchi.

Didn't really know what to expect other than decent dining fare. I am now a believer. Hands down one of the best dining experiences I've ever had. The pork shank and green beans are must haves. I wish I had room for way more. I'd consider taking a plane ride just to eat here again--it's seriously that good. Here's a tip: if you dislike good food, then skip this place and go to Applebee's.

Pretty much what most people say it is. Very very good restaurant with unique dishes. My wife and I went without reservations and had no issue getting a spot to eat in the lounge area. We didn't mind eating at the low tables in the lounge as we knew it would be a very long wait for a table in the dining area. I totally recommend this approach versus worrying about a reservation or a long wait.

I'm not a veggie lover, but the green beans were the best I ever had. My wife and I shared a few dishes, and they were all unique and very flavorful.

The dessert was also amazing. Wonderful service as well. If in Chicago and especially on the West Loop, a must try.

My husband and I got sick after eating here! I know people love this place but I just don't feel the same way.. the food is very unique and has very nice textures but it's more experimental to me and less about the taste.

By far, this was the best place I ate in Chicago. If you don't have a reservation, I recommend going early and grabbing a seat at the bar! I went at 5PM on a Thursday and got a seat almost immediately.

It was cool because the woman next to me was traveling for work, too, and we were talking about how we wanted to get everything but it would be too much food, so we ended up ordering together and sharing everything! It was kind of awesome.

We got the lamb tartare, roasted broccoli, roasted pig face, goat liver mousse with crumpets (my favorite!), halibut, pork shank and malt balls for dessert. Everything we ate was amazing!

Not to mention, the drinks and service were great, too. This will be the first place I eat at if I ever go back to Chicago. Would definitely recommend!

pics.caption: Goat liver mousse with crumpets. Sooo good

review.des: Visited yesterday for a field trip. Good food, but too crowded with a bus load of kids.

Meeeeeeeee! What a great concept! Fell in love with the place the minute I saw the mascot! A Little Funky goat, so cool. The seared tuna is a must, even though all we ate was fantastic. The raw oyster with the chef vinaigrette was delicious and the pig face was plates so cute we didn't want to eat it (we did and tasted amazing!) the place looks very nice too! Devon was a great server too. She was very nice and patient and guided us through the menu. All her recommendations were on point!

Great atmosphere, phenomenal service, and solid execution with the food. This place is very difficult to get into, so to start make a reservation as far in advance as possible. The pig face meal was my favorite and the pork shank was the most filling. Tapas style which is great because there's so much to choose from and too many good choices!
Fantastic restaurant. Great food. Superior service. Cocktails also very good. Interior space is top notch. Lives up to the hype.
Great overall experience. Tried several plates, a couple of desserts, and a cocktail--all excellent; the chickpea dish was my favorite. Service was spot on, as was the ambiance (upscale, but warm).

WOW! What an amazing restaurant! I came here in the beginning of August with my sister to celebrate a great summer and this restaurant is this the best place to celebrate! The food, atmosphere, and service is perfect. From a very attentive and helpful waiter (when ordering the food and drinks) to amazing red wine and cocktails to unreal food, I could not be more impressed with this restaurant! To eat, my sister and I shared the roasted cauliflower, Calamari bruschetta (which is one of the best things I have ever eaten), what's the dill yo bread, goat empanadas, and the caramel corn and malt balls. The food was amazing and even though we were so full, we ate every bit of our food because we couldn't resist. Make sure to make a reservation way in advance, as this is an extremely popular restaurant . Best restaurant in Chicago, come here!

Food lives up to the hype!

Reservations are hard to come by so book ahead of time! I made mine a month in advance and even then, the best I could find for a Saturday night was 9:30pm.

Food was amazing (tapas style/ all shared plates) - lamb ribs were unbelievably tender and the chicken was so flavorful.

However, the ambience was a little lacking and service was just ok, which is why I took off one star. The tables are so close together (in the couch area) that we needed to move the table just to get to the seat. I also found myself screaming over the neighbors to be heard and eventually gave up...it was far too hard to carry on a conversation like this.

Also, the server had a bit of an attitude. She came by to ask about how we were liking the cocktails...which were not very good. Rather than make a stink, I simply said they were alright but we would be opting for a bottle of wine for the next round instead. I did not ask for any favors - I kept the drink and also did not say anything negative by any means. I simply chose not to reorder it, and honestly increased the overall check by opting for a bottle of wine instead...

But she was short when she returned with the wine and that was the last we saw of her until the check arrived.

Overall, amazing food but service and ambience was lacking.

We made a reservation 3 months in advance for a party of 10, and all we could get was 5:00. That's how early you have to get into this place. It makes total sense after spending the evening here. Our table was near the kitchen and I had a prime view of the action in there. There are a ton of cooks back there! Unfortunately no Stephanie Izard this time but I've heard she's super friendly when she is there. Our server was really great, on top of it but not pushy, gave realistic advice and didn't try to over sell us. Pretty good wine selection, pretty pricey though.
The food was seriously seriously delicious and while it is expensive once you start getting multiple things, I really don't find it to be overpriced for the quality.
Highlights:
Pig Face. It's a must. They serve it to you in a beautiful presentation (see pic), then tell you that you have to cut it all up to get the flavors and textures all mixed up, best thing I had all night.
Calamari Bruschetta. I'll take ricotta on toast any way I can get it but this one was very special.
Bucatini. It's pork shoulder and pasta. Can't pass it up.
Off the specials menu:
Confit Goat Belly with Bourbon butter, lobster and crab, can't go wrong with any of that.
Goat empanadas. Loved the mushrooms and sauces with it.
And dessert: Caramel Corn & Malt Balls. The gelato was perfect with a chocolate shell, caramel corn and what seemed like homemade marshmallows on it too, but they weren't in the description. It was so great, I couldn't stop eating it.
Overall a really perfect place to come for a special occasion!

pics.caption: Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face - sweet, savory, and all the textures on point. A must

review.des: Every item we tried was delicious. Servers were quick and made great recommendations and wine pairings

When in Chicago this is the first place I add to my agenda.  I don't make reservations. I simply go and find a spot in the bar area and I have always had luck.
The place is nice. This place is a "must."

Do yourself and favor and try the Pigs Face Dish!

Yum! Food was awesome. Just like the other reviews. We got the confit goat belly, green beans, hamachi, octopus, sea bass, and bread with honey butter and cranberry. However the service could have been better. We had a reservation for 10:15 pm for a group of 5. We ordered 6 dishes and some drinks and the waiter was so pushy about us getting 2-3 dishes per person. We are tiny women and it was a super late dinner. When we finished, he pushed us to order more and we were full at that point, so we politely declined. When the bill came, the waiter had three drinks on our tab from the table beside us that had just left. That wasn't the best ending. Overall I would return for the food but would appreciate it if the staff were more chill.

It's my first time here and simply have time to kill. Walked in this busy place on the corner and discovered I have a lot to learn about this place, sipping on a IPA Half Acre Vallejo made my afternoon so much better.

Their food menu is extensive give yourself some time to read everything, well I was hungry and then having their own bakery right next to the bar did not side with my plight to feed myself. Ordered a Ruben and I have to say it was Devine maybe godly which ever you prefer

The cloud in this neighborhood is young and lively please don't come here if your grumpy go visit some old age home or something

Was able to get a last minute reservation! We were so happy we got to get this experience! This was probably the best dinning experience I have ever had. The service was awesome! The server walked us through on what we can get since were pescatarian. The roasted beet salad was one of my favorites!  I would suggest to make your reservation a few days before you are in town! Definitely check this place out!

Absolutely amazing!  We started off with the olive focaccia bread on the daily specials menu.  Delicious.  We then had the crab rangoons.  They were like nothing I've ever had before, FULL of crab meat and had butternut squash instead of cream cheese.  Unlike traditional crab rangoons, these were not all cream cheese, but jam-packed with crab meat.  We had the goat empanadas, which were good.  However the crispy pork with homemade naan, kimchi buffalo sauce and ranch sauce was phenomenal!  But the real kicker was the caramel popcorn ice cream.  Yes -- it was as awesome as it sounds: caramel popcorn ball broken up over chocolate-covered ice cream balls, drizzled with caramel sauce.  I can't even explain in words how awesome this was.  You must try it!!!

Finally, Lauren our waitress was so great.  She was helpful and gave us a few pointers for things to check out while we are here.  Thank you so much!!!

Summary- one of the more memorable meals I've ever had, but also one of the most expensive.
Service: 4.5
Food: 4.5
Ambiance: 5
Price: 4 (I knew what I was getting into, but it was still a guy punch to see the $200 bill come out for a meal for 2)

It was so hard to choose what to order, since there were sooo many veg and fish options. We got the fried oysters (which came over egg salad- unusual pairing, but a delectable one); hamachi crudo (a burst of citrus and umami flavor in every bite); roasted cauliflower (very tasty, but seemed like something I could make at home); kohlrabi salad (fresh, delicious, and had mushrooms in it, which always appeal to me); blue cheese and potato pierogis (interesting and unique dish, but not quite as delicious as I wanted it to be. That being said, it was one of my sister's favs of the night); chickpea fritters (a real standout of the meal; crispy and crunchy on the outside, smooth and creamy on the inside, and packed with flavor. My mouth is watering thinking about them); scallops (very tasty, but nothing extraordinary; could have been cut from the meal): and the sticky toffee cake and caramel corn for dessert (highly recommend the toffee cake, but could have passed on the caramel corn). We also each started with the Ring of Fire, a spicy, tequila-based cocktail - top five cocktails I've ever had. And then we also may or may not have split a bottle of rioja. Which was great, but a glass each would have sufficed. C'est la vie.

Overall, I'm so glad I finally got to go and would definitely go back! This meal included some of the best dishes I've ever eaten, and the rest was totally solid as well. Make your reservation now. We were able to get a 4:30 table with just a few days advance notice, but I don't think that's the norm.

pics.caption: Roasted Cauliflower. Delicious, but not something I couldn't replicate at home. Also had mixed feelings about the banana peppers.
Sticky Tasty Crunchy Toffee Yummy Cake (bottom) was incredible. Caramel corn & malt balls (top) were tasty, but not life-changing.
Potato-Blue Cheese Pierogies. Interesting, but underwhelming for me. My sister loved them though!

review.des: We came to Girl & the Goat after an Anthony Bourdain review. We always expect only the best from his suggestions but this was another level entirely. The goat & lobster dish was the second best dish we have ever had in our entire lives. I am 25 and my boyfriend is 29 and we eat out a LOT, so this is an enormous compliment. I feel ridiculous saying this but it was a full body experience - the flavors that came together in that dish were true artistry. The pirogies were fantastic. I would skip the oysters though, there is no reason for them. Absolutely make it a priority to experience Girl & the Goat, there's few of its kind.
Simple dishes with a really delectable twist! Service is excellent. Small menu but sufficient flavors to choose from. Stephanie Izard is a kitchen wizard!

When I travel for work, I always tend to try and find the trendy spots to dine at. A good friend suggested Girl & the Goat for my recent trip to the windy city.

The venue is trendy, upscale, and warm. Greeted at the bar by John, who hands me a few menus. I start to take a look to see what catches my eye.

He offers some solid opinions and advice per my menu questions as he knows it's my first time.

Wood fired oysters - Great salt added by the bacon, could use a little more citrus love.

Seared Diver Scallops -Definitely something that can usually lack so much, however the textures and overall composition add so much to the scallops.

Per John, I order the Pork Shank over the Goat Ribs, and it did not disappoint.

There is a harmonious relationship between the fall of the bone shank in combination with the kimchi and buttermilk dressing - a must try.

Last but not least, I am a sucker for cold dessert... Chocolate Pavlova... enough said.

I will be back, no doubt.

I was dying to try this place after hearing the amazing reviews about Girl & the Goat, and I'm glad the hype wasn't just hype. We got here around 8:40 on a Thursday night, and the hostess told us that it would be around a 2 hour wait. Not discouraged, we strolled around the neighborhood, and ended up getting a seat on the patio in about an hour. I think they may exaggerate the wait because they don't want to disappoint you, but don't let this discourage you if you're planning on walking in!

Now for the food and service. Our server, Jurson, was awesome. He gave us recommendations and checked up on us periodically, and told us to get ~2 dishes per person. I'm just gonna give a little rundown of the things we got.

Tasty buns - a nice appetizer. It comes with tomato jam and avocado butter.

Sweet corn pierogies -  came with a grape melon relish that went well with the pierogi, which was pan-fried, sweet, and crumbly.

Wood-fired oysters - tasty, but not the freshest oysters

Crab Rangoons - one of the best dishes. Perfectly fried and flaky exterior with delicious crab inside

Braised beef tongue - Beef tongue was cooked just right, tossed in a salad of sorts.

Wood oven roasted pig face - looked great, tasted a bit too fatty for me, but still good

Goat confit - also too heavy for my palate. Comes with lobster and crab and A LOT of melted butter.

TLDR: For the price and quality, this place is definitely worth it (bill came out to around $140 for 4 people). Food was great. Service was great. Would definitely come back to try more tapas!

pics.caption: Goat confit with tons of butter

review.des:
Visited Saturday, 1/20/2018. 4:30pm.
There's not much more I can say in positive ways that hasn't been said before. We were downtown and wanted to find something different. Had heard lots of good things about G&TG. We got there at 4:15 & saw they opened at 4:30. We were fortunate enough to score a table w/o a reso.

We really liked the ambience. At first, we were a bit miffed by being seated at "the Chef's table", which is a long, somewhat oversized picnic table with 8-10 other ppl. But because of acoustics, we never really felt like we could be heard by, or hear the other diners' conversations. We were able to hear ourselves w/o having to speak loudly.  

Other than the drinks prices being maybe $2-3 too high and needing a bit more potency, everything else was superb.
2 cocktails
Foccacia
Chickpea Fritter
Duck Tongues (YUM!!)
Scallops
Confit Goat Belly
Coffee/espresso
Sticky Tasty Crunchy Toffee Yummy Cake

Our server, Kelly, was definitely 5-star excellent! She explained everything very well, was most charming and cheerful and seemed genuinely dedicated to making our experience (and her other customers') most enjoyable. Between her, the food runners and busboys, they were extremely attentive w/o being intrusive and it was a smooth transition between dishes without feeling like we were being rushed.

Not cheap, but definitely highly recommended!!

Wow! What a dream of a dining experience!

I was recently in Chicago for an annual meet up with a childhood girlfriend and we were really excited to try this restaurant. Luckily, about a month out from our arrival, I was able to secure a 10:00 PM reservation for our first night in town. It was all that was available but it ended up working out well as a wonderful start to the trip.

As we're both vegetarians, we decided to share a few veggie dishes. Everything sounded so wonderful that we did have a hard time picking just a few.

Warm marinated olives - a wonderful mix of many varieties of thick, meaty olives with sliced garlic and mustard seeds. Just the right starter.

Chickpea Fritters - what a little bit of heaven! I am not exaggerating when I say that I will think of this dish often for the rest of my life. It was perfectly balanced with the whipped feta, crunchy chickpeas, nectarine slices and heirloom tomatoes on the side. A treat for vegetarians and carnivores alike!

Wood grilled broccoli - this was very different but I couldn't stop eating it! The smell was incredible! The crispies were my least favorite part of the dish - they appeared to be Rice Krispy cereal and didn't add much to the dish.

Pan fried shishito peppers - this was my least favorite of the dishes we ordered, but it was also probably because the first two peppers I picked were the hot ones. I didn't notice the miso taste at all, though the Parmesan and sesame seeds were caked on the outsides of the peppers.

Sweet potato pierogis - these were a little treat! Fluffy filling in a light dough with avocado creme and tasty accompaniments. Solid dish.

Peanut Butter and Jellywich - well, this was very interesting! We'd planned to stop somewhere else for dessert but after the dessert menu was dropped at the table, we were so intrigued that we gave it a whirl. Wow, was it zippy! The sponge cake and Concord grape sauce (that had almost a spicy, tingly aftertaste!) with crunchy peanut brittle, brown butter bread ice cream and torched peanut butter marshmallow. Yum!

Service by Owen was top-notch! As we'd both traveled in that day, we were exhausted and opted not to order alcohol. He never made us feel bad or cheap for choosing just to drink water. He also had a lot of enthusiasm, steered us in the right direction with some of the dishes and made small talk in between. Thanks, Owen!

Only bad thing I can say is that the music was very, very loud, though it was very late at night - maybe they tone it down during the day.

One word - amazing! We just finished dinner and could not have been happier! The portions were perfect and everyone felt the perfect amount of fullness after the the meal. We had been researching restaurants for our trip to Chicago and really wanted to go here. So, we made the only reservation they had left - 1030PM. It sounds crazy, but it was worth it! There were 4 of us and we all got drinks and ordered 8 dishes (Roasted beets, chickpea fritters, grilled baby octopus, soft shell chili crab, pan roasted halibut, crisp braised pork shank, goat empanadas, confit goat belly. There was a tie for our favorite dishes - halibut and soft shell crab dishes were the winners! Every dish was AMAZING and I would 100% return here in a heartbeat! There is a reason this place gets so booked up. Do yourself a favor and go!

We also had dessert (all the leches cake, caramel corn and malt balls, berries and cream) and drinks (we all got a cocktail, but I can't remember which ones :) They were al great!)

Definitely try this place!

My experience with Girl & the Goat was sublime. I went there on a date with my boyfriend, and we were absolutely blown away by the creativity and flavor of the dishes. As a vegetarian, I was not limited to only a few mediocre items. The service was outstanding as well. I really enjoyed the casual atmosphere; it's not common with menus like this, and being comfortable helped me enjoy my time there a lot more. I have recommended this restaurant to so many people, and I can't wait to go back!!

Would probably get 4 stars without the 1.5 hr wait on a tuesday night.  Expectations can be a bitch, as noted before in my reviews.

The good:  
Hamachi Crudo
Crisp pork belly. Chili aioli. Caperberries
this was delicious

Duck Tongues
Tuna and black bean poke. Piri piri
Probably the dish of the night.  Perfectly balanced.  Beautifully done.  Definitely the highlight.  

Goat Empanadas
Grilled pineapple-blueberry salsa. Queso fresco
A delight.  Echoed with the taste of the best drunken nachos you've ever had, but without having to be so drunk. Something like that...

The pretty good:
Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face
Sunny side egg. Tamarind. Cilantro. Red wine-maple. Potato stix
Was tasty, but needed acid.  I think this one was a trap.  One note...Was expecting heavenly delights but got simple pretty good.  

The horrible:
We had a take on tiramisu that was an absolute joke.  It was horrible - dry and just...awful.  It tasted like it had been sitting all day in an over-cooled walk-in.  Our waiter gladly took it off our check without prompting us.  Would have preferred a pudding pop - when will they bring those back anyways?  Could be difficult with Cosby's legal troubles, but give the guy a break, maybe...

Overall, this is a good restaurant.  It's got incredible buzz, even on a rainy Tuesday night.  But if you're going to make people wait 1.5-2 hours, the food has to be consistently off the charts to justify the hassle.  I'm glad we tried it, but would not wait again, though would revisit if a reservation was there.  To sum up - It's good, but I am not a  big cognitive dissonance proponent, so will not return unless someone is hosting/and/or will deal with getting a seat.

Being a foodie was Washington, DC I always make it a point to try a city's best food offerings. The moment I knew I'd be going to Chicago for a family reunion, we called Girl & the Goat to snag a table for six (We made our reservation 4 months out). After enjoying 15+ small plates and dessert here, I left slightly disappointed.

The location itself is great. It's a few blocks from the Morgan Station on the Green/Pink Line in the West Loop. It's on W. Randolph with many other highly acclaimed restaurants. The building it's in is beautiful and they design it perfectly from the restrooms in the basement to the open kitchen in the back (Gross, I really shouldn't use the words bathroom and kitchen in the same sentence). The service is great- attentive, personable.

They have a great cocktail menu and their food menu is divided between vegetarian, fish, and meats. They recommend ordering 3-5 small plates a person. There were five in my party so we ordered 15 small plates and it was WAY too much food. For small plates, the portions were generous.

The food itself was excellent, but only depending on what you ordered. Having been to some of the best restaurants in the world, here's what really stood out and puts Girl and the Goat to the top of Chicago's restaurant list:

-Salmon- that sauce. Amazing!
-Green beans- probably the best you'll ever have.
-Seasame pot de creme- just wow!
-Halibut- full of flavor.

The rest of the dishes we ordered were good, but definitely not the best we've ever had our 5 star worthy:

-Corn bread
-Kohlrabi salad
-Broccoli- it was too burnt.
-Chickpea fritters
-Pinn oaks lamb tartare
-Wood oven roasted pig face
-Sea scallops (probably the worst I've had. It wasn't awful, but I've had better in DC and NYC)

All in all, I recommend going here, just know what to order. If you're used to NYC and DC prices, you'll be pleased how cheap Girl and the Goat is.

Girl and the Goat is one of the best meals I've ever had.  Whenever I am in Chicago I come here.  I would recommend making reservations as there is always a line.  And yes, you will need to book it months in advance.

Their pork shank is delicious.  Tender and full of flavor.  Literally falls off the bone.  Everything here is delicious.  You can't go wrong!
Best chilly I have.  Just stopped by in the bar for a drink with my husband and we stayed for 2 + drinks... definitely going back next  visit to Chicago.

All my friends raved about this place. Decided to give it a try on my next Chicago trip. I had to book my Saturday night reservation and the best I could get two months ahead was 11pm! Book your reservations well ahead like 3-4 months. Duck tongue, sourdough, goat empanadas, green beans, cauliflower, fried oyster, pig face and lamb face were all very delicious and lived up to the hype. The waitress recommended goat confit because that was her favorite dish but honestly nobody at my table enjoyed it. Would not recommend goat confit. Duck tongue was my overall favorite!

Everything I ate at Girl and the Goat was a fabulous journey of seasonings and flavors.  My highest recommendation is that you ABSOLUTLEY order and enjoy the goat leg.   Scrumdiliumcious!  If your party is not large enough to finish it, no worries!  Contact me and I'll be happy to take that extra goat off your hands!
Just amazing!  Great service and the food is top notch!  Loved especially the bone marrow starter.

Maybecc kind and XxLike xAdccthat's ommjwhat n hum number Kanchwala said

really enjoyed the cuisine and awesome service from
ordered the oysters with bacon (yum).  goat pate liver mousse, pig face,  hummus and bread,  shishito peppers (a Lil bitter)  and broccoli.  all tasty.

My boyfriend told me he heard great things about this restaurant, so we gave it a try! It was amazing. Staffs were very nice and knowledgeable about their menu, which I appreciated that since I asked a lot of questions. The drinks were also really outstanding. Overall, I loved everything about this restaurant.
I took my son and is girlfriend there. Busy place, but delicious food. Everything there tasted farm to table fresh!
The best ambiance and food! Share a couple of dishes per couple of people. Absolutely loved it!!

Plan ahead, was told the wait would be 2 hours but if you don't care where you're seated make sure to keep an eye open for a spot at the bar area/lounge. Me and my friends were lucky enough to snag a spot and only waited about 15 minutes. Roasted pig face was my favorite dish of the night, we probably ordered 6 to share. Had either 2 or 3 of their whiskey sours, they're definitely generous with their alcohol. Nothing's worst than a watered down cocktail :).

Beautiful dishes, wonderful service, great ambiance. Seldom blown away - well worth the rave.

Roasted cauliflower with pickled peppers, pine nuts, mint - each ingredient was a gamechanger, particularly the mint. Elevates cauliflower to goddess status.

Grilled baby octopus with guanciale, fava beans, pea tips, pistachios, lightly dressed with lemon vinaigrette - as a pulpo lover, this was next level. Complex but not overthought, flavors worked well together, with the pea tips and lemon vinaigrette balancing out the guanciale, grounded with the earthiness of the fava beans, pistachios adding textural interest.

Last but not least, pork shank was pure Game of Thrones inspo. Handsome, massive, perfectly roasted - a dream come true. Paired with buttermilk dressing, grilled spring onion kimchee, an excellent complement to cut through the pork. Loved the perfectly toasted naan that came with.

Can't wait to return for the pig face. Highly recommend.

We were in the city and multiple people had recommended this restaurant so we decided to give it a shot despite not having reservations. We showed up at about 9 pm on a Saturday night and hung around at the bar and eventually got two seats. The bartenders were very attentive and knowledgeable. Cocktails were so tasty and unique. We ordered goat empanadas, roasted cauliflower, calamari bruschetta, and pig face. All the plates were excellent, but my favorite was the bruschetta. Overall, wonderful experience!

Outstanding!! The vibe, the music, the ambiance! This place is fantastic. I've never had such terrific service. From ensuring our water glasses were always filled to the personal attention of the sommelier and our waiter's loving care... this was an extraordinary meal. I get that this is a place that specializes in meat (goat). But as a pescatarian, I can say that I ate REALLY well. The vegetable dishes were delicious and the one salmon dish we had was inventive and tasty. Terrific wine list and dessert was out of this world. Totally worth the 3 hour 20 minute flight from Phoenix. Definitely coming back.

I made reservations a couple months in advance cause my friends and I wanted to celebrate  our work anniversaries.

I see what people are talking about now.

We all arrived for our 5pm reservation but the place wasn't too busy...yet. By 6 it was crowded and people were starting to wait, but the bar is great and they have places for you to relax and drink until your table is ready.

Plates are medium, I'd say, and very shareable for the 3 of us. If it were 4 people, you'd start to push the amount each person could get from each dish.

There were so many options on the menu that looked amazing, but besides asking the waiter for a tie breaking vote, we also used the, "would I ever be able to even come close to making this" mentality.

In any case, each dish we ordered was a perfect balance of textures and flavors. What I love is that for each savory element in the dish there's always a range of mild to noticeable acidity to offer a necessary balance.

Just to list out what we ended up ordering (4 savory, 2 desserts, 1 complimentary dessert): green beans, calamari bruschetta, pig face, pork shank, blueberry bourbon baba, donettes, caramel corn and malt balls. They also serve dark matter coffee. I love the dark and smooth stuff. Staff was amazing and our waiter was so nice to add a complimentary caramel corn and malt balls dessert.

Also, green beans. Such an innocent vegetable, but transformed to such a degree. Give that to a kid and they'll stop complaining about vegetables.

Just to mention our cocktails, in order of bright for spring, refreshing for summer, bold for winter:
Royal Rubus, Putting' on the Spritz, Salt & Ash.
Really good burgers and comfort food. I always take people from out of town so they know what to expect for the rest of the trip.

Always wonderful prices for one-of-a-kind meals and variety, my tongue literally miss that place a lot now that we moved to San Diego from Chicago... The only annoying thing about this restaurant is actually being able to make a reservation :)

If the name doesn't get your kid to want to come, I don't know what will. This place great for a date night with the kids or not. What can be better than small plates where you can try everything, BYOB, bold flavors, amazing amazing bread (which you have to pay for but worth it), and low priced options for a high end place (top price nothing more than $20)? If you're wondering what to get, look no further. All the veggies (cauliflower, green beans, wood grilled broccoli), chickpea fritters, grilled baby octopus, ham frites, and miso butterscotch budino are a few of the hits here. Not to mention, this place has an ENTIRE menu dedicated to goat! Be sure to try the goat empanadas and confit goat belly. If eating goat is the craziest thing you're going to do, maybe take it a step further and try the wood oven roasted pig face. Also, if you're really daring (with kids that is), be sure to get a seat at the counter. Pipsqueak tip: get there early or make a reservation, otherwise be prepared with some activities for a wait!

When I told my friends I booked tickets to Chicago for the beau and I, their responds was.. You must try Girl and the Goat!  When I look on yelp for "top rated" restaurants, Girl and the Goat pops up. When I look on any web blogs or foodie websites, Girl and the Goat is highly recommended. So when we finally worked on our itinerary (which was a week prior to our trip), I was thinking, there is no way I would get any reservations to this place. But some miracle happened, I was able to snagged a reservations on a Monday at 5PM.

After a fun filled day of doing all the touristy things and eating a bunch of junk food. We weren't really hungry when we go there but I made sure we ordered what other yelpers recommend.

Here is what we got:

-Mahalo (Drink)
-Pan Fried Shishito Peppers
-Grilled Baby Octopus
-Duck Tongue (GET THE DUCK TONGUE)!
-Crispy Braised Pork Shank

Every dish was delectable! My favorite dish as you can see from my list of items above is the duck tongue. I know, duck tongue? TRUST ME. Its fried so you won't taste any weird textures but just butter goodness. It's mixed with tuna, black beans poke, crispy wontons and placed on this creamy avocado like sauce. SO GOOD! I would order that dish again in a heart beat. The crispy braised pork shank was our second favorite. It shank was crispy, juicy, fatty, tender and huge,  we were struggling to finish it.

Overall, I am very happy to say my friends, yelpers, foodie websites and blogs did not fail me. This came close to being my favorite meal in Chicago but Kai Zan passed it up by a small percentage. Girl and the Goat, I will be visiting for sure the next time I am back in Chi-town.

Crispy duck tongue with tuna, wonton strips.. Sooooooo good
Another view of the pork shank

review.des: Excited to eat here for months- especially now she won iron chef--Iron Stef.  Definitely make reservations or good luck getting a seat.  The place was busy!!!  Food was great for the most part- we had 16 dishes for a group of 6.  Few of the dishes we found salty- grilled cauliflower especially.  Our favorite dishes were the duck tartare, crispy pork shank, chickpea fritter, grilled octopus and all Tye desserts.

My first time to drive to Chicago and being here in this restaurant but I can say, it's worth the trip! Everything we ordered was absolutely delicious! Definitely going back to this place when I get the chance to go to Chicago again. The service also was excellent!

I've been wanting to try some new places recently, but since 97% of all the new restaurants in CA are poke places, I had to wait until my trip to Chicago to do so.

A visit to Girl & the Goat was a no brainer. Not going there while in Chicago would be like going to the Trump Tower Grill and not getting the infamous Taco Bowl. So, I made a reservation about a month in advance, then abruptly cancelled it since I didn't want to be pinned down to a certain time. We ended up taking our chances at the bar instead on a Monday night, which worked out well as there was no wait.

While we had WOOD GRILLED BROCCOLI (to help combat getting Diverticulitis), let's face it, no matter how good it was, no one is there for that. It's all about going hard for the meat, with these 2 standouts in particular:

WOOD OVEN ROASTED PIG FACE - there are 2 ways to show how much you're truly enjoying food: by taking your time, slowly cherishing each bite like you never want it to end, or by devouring it. Ok, I've heard that moaning is a 3rd way, but that's not something I'll ever do. In this case, we mixed the egg yolk in with the potato six, cilantro, tamarind, and red-wine maple like the server suggested, then finished it off almost as quickly as I change the radio station when a Meghan Trainor song comes on. It had really excellent flavors all around, included a healthy dose of fat (which may not be so healthy), and packed a nice crunch, but I wouldn't have minded if it had more pig in it.

CRISP BRAISED PORK SHANK - it may not look huge in the pics, but this is a force to be reckoned with. This is so filling that I don't know if you could down it quickly even if you tried, so we meticulously carved it up, despite the fact it easily falls right off the bone if you want it to. While the sauce complements the pork well, the quality is at such another level that you can enjoy it without any, which is what good meat is supposed to be all about. Even though it's pork, they could've fooled me into thinking it was goat, if by goat, you mean GOAT (Greatest Of All Time).

It was a lot better than poke too.

OMG OMG OMG!  I loved this place!  The food was outstanding.  We made our reservations a month in advance.  When I got there I got taken right to our table.  Sometimes with big restaurants like this people make you wait a few minutes but this time that wasn't the case.  We came right on in and were seated in between 2 families.  The ambiance was amazing.  I felt like I was dining outside but we were inside.  I don't know how else to explain that but yea.  The waiter came and was great at helping us pick out what to eat.  My boo was a little weirded out by all the strange ingredients but the waiter assured him he would love everything, and WE DID!  

The green beans were outstanding.  I seriously went home and immediately googled how to make them for myself.  I've tried several times but they don't come out like that.

The shrimp was ok.  I think compared to everything else it was slightly basic.

The muscles I really enjoyed but the boo thang didn't.

The open pig face was fantastical!  I loved it.

The goat empanadas were bursting with flavor.  I've never tried goat before and that was a wonderful introduction.

Since it was my birthday we got this birthday treat that was off the chain!  It was popcorn and ice cream which sounds weird but was outstanding!

I also had their version on an old fashioned.  OMG.  After eating all that food, I was so sure I would not still have a buzz from that drink.  Oh but I did.  I don't know what they did to it but it was insane and delicious.  Not a lot of places do classic cocktails well, but they certainly do.

All in all fabulous experience but it's definitely a special occasion kinda spot.

pics.caption: Green beans were insanely good. Obviously.....

review.des:
From my visit in March 2015 - I still dream about this meal!

After having one of the best meals of one's life, you feel compelled to stay up late to opine on the merits of such a meal.

The Girl and the Goat - 2011 best new chef Stephanie Izzard takes you on a journey of asian-inspired dishes that surprise and result in umami explosions.

Dish 1: honey sambal brioche - honey butter . pomelo fresno relish
The brioche - buttery perfection. Layer on honey sambal butter, and the richness coats your whole mouth. Add in the acidic kick of the relish, for a perfectly balanced, rich bite. Buttery, flakey, heaven.

Dish 2: escargot ravioli - bacon . tamarind-miso sauce
The escargot is tender, fork tender. You cut through the rotund middle of the ravioli easily, and ingest the savory pasta. Not a hint of rubber.

Dish 3: roasted cauliflower - pickled peppers . pine nuts . mint
This tasted like pad kee mao. The smartest application of Thai flavors I've ever seen. The cauliflower at the perfect doneness, sliced flat and fried with amazing mint and spice.

Dish 4: goat empanadas - huacatay . grilled mushroom giardiniera . queso fresco
The pickles were a bit overpowering, but perfect when combined with the flaky empanada shell. The goat meat - shredded inside, is moist and flavorful.

Dish 5: sautéed green beans - fish sauce vinaigrette . cashews
Addicting, said the waiter. Crisp tender green beans in a salty, creamy fish sauce.

Dish 6: seared diver scallops - ginger-chili aioli . shiitake . sea beans . braised peanuts
Plump, tender scallops. Carrying on the Thai/Vietnamese influence of garnishes of nuts with a peanut butter based sauce.

Dish 7: roasted duck breast - silver needle noodles . rapini .shrimp-duck jus
This was the only one that fell a little short of the others. Definitely good - just not much duck flavor and kind of bland. Definitely an opportunity to play on peking duck flavors, though no other dish has had expected flavor profiles.

Dish 8: wood oven roasted pig face - sunny side egg. tamarind. cilantro . red wine-maple. potato stix
Mix it all up and get essence of pork in a soft forkful. Not even sure what i was eating - the collagen melted like fat in your mouth - but charred and delicious.

Desserts: Because everything else was amazing.
miso-butterscotch budino
bacon toffee. glazed pineapple. candied cashews

plantain cake
cream cheese-chocolate chip gelato . passion fruit . left hand milk stout

Best $64 (incl. tax and tip) I've spent on a meal to date. GO with a group, so you can try everything!

pics.caption: All of the dishes we had that night!

review.des: Amazing food, great service, it never disappoints! A must try in Chicago. Every time we have visitors we take them there and everyone loves it. Great for cocktails and small bites too.

Food is overrated. It is not worth the price that is the reason I give a 1 star. I got the pork shank and goat empanadas. They both ordinary. With a little of fruit / veggie on the side, no huge differences are there. The texture of empanadas is below average. The sauce for the pork shank is disappointing.

I have found that it is usually a good sign of a restaurant if you call 2 months out for a reservation and the only times available are 4:30 or 9:45.

A few friends and I were visiting a friend that had recently moved to the city and we settled on the 9:45 reservation. We walked in and were immediately greeted and shown to our table. The ambiance was very nice, dimly lit and cozy. Our waiter was very attentive and friendly, also was very helpful with suggestions.

We decided to split everything, as suggested. We started with cocktails and ordered the Ring of Fire. It was a delicious combination of strength and flavor. We continued to order these throughout our meal.

First food item were Raw Oysters. We decided on the Raw Kusshi at the suggestion of our waiter and they were great. One of my friends who is only a fan of raw oysters when they are covered with sauce and on a cracker did not even mind. There was so much flavor with these that nothing else was needed.

Second was the Calamari Bruschetta. This was an amazing dish that I barely got a picture of since we went to town on it as soon as it hit the table. The calamari was cooked to perfection with a nice balance of chewy and melt-in-your-mouth. The apples added a nice touch of flavor and the bread was delicious.

Third we had the Escargot Ravioli in bacon broth. This was also a killer dish that was devoured quickly. The bacon broth really made the dish and incorporated so much flavor and the crispy onions on top were delicious.

Fourth we had the Sauteed Green Beans. These were delicious but probably my least favorite dish. Don't get me wrong this was fantastic, every other item was just amazing that this had to be picked last. The sauce and onions were great on top and definitely not too overwhelming.

Fifth we devoured the Goat Empanadas. There is not much I can say about these other than you absolutely have to try this dish.

Last for our main course was the ever popular Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face. This might sound a little weird but you do not get the actual face of a pig on your plate, it is shredded. This was the perfect way to end the main courses of a perfect meal.

Finally to round out our whole dinner we had to have dessert. We ordered the PB&J dessert, again at the suggestion of our waiter. It was absolutely delicious and the pieces of peanut brittle were an amazing addition.

This was an absolutely amazing restaurant and I would recommend to any of my friends traveling to the Chicago area. Can't wait to come back again!

So so so delicious. The servers were amazing and worked really hard to accommodate our large party. They also helped us with ordering, and suggested what they thought were the best tasting dishes. The broccoli was amazing. I don't know what they put in there, but even the picky eaters In our party that hated vegetables gobbled this dish down in delight and then asked for more. It was quiet dark and noisy in the restaurant (so many people waiting), and the path to the restroom was a little creepy, but all in all this was a great experience.

When we came there it was really crowdy ( I wasn't surprise when you have 6k of reviews) :)
There was no table, but we were completely fine with sitting on the bar. Bartender was really cool guy! Very helpful and drinks were really good. Only minus was food in general overpriced, really fat and nothing special. I ended the evening with heartburn so as mine friend.

If you've never been, you have to try it! It genuinely lives up to its reputation. Stephanie's menu is incredibly creative without being too over-the-top. The food is delicious, and I am a huge fan of the small plates/tapas style food, because you get to try a lot of different dishes. The restaurant does seem to always be quite busy, but if you get there right when they open you can easily get a seat at the lounge or bar to enjoy your food.

pics.caption: Goat Belly: with crab and lobster in bourbon butter– delicious! A must have.

review.des:
10 stars! Seriously, I'm still thinking about our meal there. Amazing.

Everyone I know that has been to or lives in Chicago gave me this recommendation. Based on this being the first place out of their mouths, I decided to go. Plus, it was my birthday. Reservations weren't available for weeks to come so we walked in. We arrived at 6 and the place was already packed. We gave our number to be texted and got a drink down the street. We were texted 1.5 hours later and were seated upon arrival.

We started with shishito peppers and 2 bread boards. We got the "olive you" and "miso hungry." None of my party loved the "olive you" but maybe because we were also having the "miso hungry" which was OUT OF THIS WORLD.

My husband and I went seafood crazy and split the following:
scallops
copper river sockeye salmon
pan roasted halibut

All seafood dishes were unbelievable, but my favorite was the halibut. I almost ordered a 2nd round.

By the end of the dinner, we were stuffed but perused the dessert menu. Nothing stood out, but our waitress surprised us with the "all the leches cake." I'm so glad she did. Although it didn't stand out reading the description, it made up for it in taste. I am so glad we had this. It was the perfect ending to the meal.

Don't even think about it - just make sure you go here during your next trip to Chicago!

Like all the other reviews, there's not much to add that hasn't been said already.

We had the sourdough potato bread, green beans, goat empanadas, pecan blue cheese sweet potato pierogies, and lamb shank. No regrets whatsoever!

Staff was great. Atmosphere was a little loud, but what do you expect with a world class restaurant like this?

Can't wait to come back next time we're in Chicago.

I had to make a reservation about 4 months ahead of time for my husband's October birthday, so I was worried that it wouldn't live up to the hype and the wait time. My fears will ill founded- the meal was incredible from the fresh-baked apple bread to the vegetables to the fish entree to the caramel popcorn ice cream dessert. I was impressed by how flavorful and perfectly cooked each dish was. They have the timing of meals down to a science, and our waiter was friendly and helpful when it came to giving advice on what to order. I enjoyed the ambiance, too. I would absolutely make another reservation here for a special occasion.

The food is great , the staff are so friendly ,
Just hard to reserve a seat !

Its worth the wait !

Hands down this was the pinnacle of my dining experience. Honestly I really wanted to try this for the odd menu options-but after actually eating here all I can say is OMFG. it truly was an experience. The waitress was from my area and had a pleasant personality. She made some good recommendations and I was definitely not disappointed. Our group shared the soft blue crab cake which Waze flavorful and a good basic start to the meal. The second dish was Escargot ravioli. It sounds weird at first but really it tasted like chopped mussels in fresh ravioli. I've had large escargot before and this tasted nothing like that. Our next course was the duck tongue. It was a similar to a delicate small piece of pork belly but with a little more flavor. Then came the actual pork belly which was a little tough and thin than I'm used too but that mishap was forgiven quickly when the server brought out the pigs head. Whether or not it actually was the head of a pig; it had a fantastic flavor and we were back in course. We closed our meal with wood fired lamb ribs. Holy cow they were fall off the bone amazingly tender. Truly set the experience. For dessert we had the happy lemon and it was indescribable. Great balance and flavor all around. To drink I had an Old Fashioned and it was perfect.

Waited several months to come here for our reservation and it was definitely worth it. The pig face, green beans and duck tartare were amazing! Wasn't as impressed about the escargot ravioli or the goat carpaccio.

This was definitely worth the hype and one of the top 5 restaurants I've ever been to. Very trendy busy ambiance (in a good way) excellent service and exceptional food. Will absolutely return again as well as continue to recommend this place to everybody!

Reservations is highly recommended as this place gets extremely busy. Came here without a reservation and was told the wait would be almost 1.5 hours. Lingered around the bar area and managed to find space in their lounge area within 45 mins.

Baby octopus - recommended
Goat & lobster - average. The sea and land combo did not balance the flavor well
Goat moose pate - for the adventurous. I love pate, this one became overwhelming quickly. The bread it came with is very good.
Roasted cauliflowers - recommended.

Overall, quality of food is good. Goat has a very distinct taste, it's either you like it or you don't. Staff was extremely kind. They overheard me debating if I should order the cauliflower or not and when I didn't order it, they gave it on the house for me to try.

pics.caption: Goat liver moose. Only recommend if you like pate

review.des: Every single bite was about 7$ each, and genuinely worth it. I loved everything I put in my mouth. Pig's face, who knew?! Great waitstaff, great drinks. Seating was a bit awkward and close to strangers for my taste but I got over it.

After years and years of anticipation, I finally made it to Girl & the Goat. We went on a random weeknight, and we were seated promptly. Of all the items I'd heard I should order, the pig face was hands down the must-try of the evening. We ended up ordering the wood grilled broccoli (good), tempura soft shelled crab (fantastic), wood oven roasted pig face (very tasty), and the raraouille focaccia (delicious). Overall, we were really pleased with everything we got and the service was good. The food was definitely very good, but I don't think it was anything to wait months and months for. I'll be back when the opportunity strikes again!

I had the most incredible and wonderful dining experience at Girl and the Goat. Everything that was served was absolutely delicious! I came here last night for a Team dinner and we had our own private room downstairs. The exterior is lovely with an outdoor dining area and the room where we dined was lovely and rustic. Beautiful setting on a wood table with candles and a plant in the center.

We met Gary, our go to server for the evening and he was awesome... Really knew the menu well, listened and tended to our dietary needs, and was completely gracious throughout the night.

I asked if any of the amazing-sounding cocktails could be made without alcohol and so I got The Royal Rubus that way. It was citrusy soda with lemon bitters, blackberry and lime. It came in a brilliant raspberry red and was very tasty and refreshing.

Started off with an assortment of breads: One sourdough with little pieces of ham in it, which was okay. I didn't have a ton of flavor but I liked the green peas and ham that came with it. There was also muffin top bread, which was nicely moist and it came with yummy seasoned butter.

Next we had "Fried Naked Cowboys" which were fried oysters with egg salad on the bottom. These came in cute little spoons and one bite form. Even though I'm not a huge fan of oysters, it was quite good fried and the sauce on top worked well with it.

Then there was salad which consisted of fennel, evalon cheese, toasted almonds and blueberries. This was nice and I especially liked the cheese, which was a sweet goat cheese with fruity and nutty finish. It added an additional layer of delightful flavor to the salad.

The goat empanadas were one of my favorite dishes. It had strawberry, white asparagus with it and smashed avocado underneath. The empanadas were perfectly crispy and the goat meat was so very flavorful and melted in my mouth!

We also had green garlic pierogis which was decent, but I didn't taste a strong garlic taste. The filling was like mashed potatoes.

The vegetables we had were cauliflower, broccoli and string beans. The cauliflower dish had pickled peppers, pine nuts and parmesan cheese. It was slightly crispy and had a nice burst of flavor. The broccoli had little crisps and the green beans had yummy cashews!

The entrees were pasta, fish and pork shank. The pasta was spiral with tons of appetizing beef, which was wonderfully juicy and incredibly savory. There were also little orange tomatoes and tomatoes on top that were fresh and flavorful. We also had wild striped bass in a coconut green curry, new potatoes and artichokes. I enjoyed this dish, especially the slightly charred skin on the fish. Last, was the crisp braised pork shank with naan and the following dipping sauces: Grilled spring onion kimchi and buttermilk dressing. The pork was so wonderful and tender!  I loved the crunchiness of it.

After all that, there were 5 different types of desserts. My absolute favorite was vanilla gelato with chocolate shell, caramel sauce and caramel popcorn. This dessert was truly delectable and so decadent. I could have a whole bowl of it if I wasn't already so stuffed. My second favorite dessert was balls of coated gelato with peanut butter inside and candied peanuts. There was also a tres leches cake with strawberry and some pudding, as well as fruity sorbet. It was a nice, light and yummy treat. Then there was a pudding-like dessert with a blend of pure toffee pieces, expresso and vanilla. The last dessert was different and interesting. It consisted of gelatin, blueberries and pieces of meringue.

Each dish from appetizer, to entree, to dessert was well thought out and unique in a good way. All of the food exceeded my expectations and was mouthwateringly delicious! The service was impeccable. Everything came together seamlessly. This will go down as one of the best dinners I have ever had... If I could give Girl and the Goat 10 stars, I would do so without hesitation.

It has been a couple of months since my wife and I were here with friends of ours so my memory will not be great in writing this review however I have to say something of this restaurant.

My wife and I are both huge fans of Stephanie Izard from watching Stephanie compete on the Bravo TV show Top Chef.  If I am not mistaking Stephanie was the first woman to win the competition and at the time I was living in Omaha Nebraska and I was hoping that someone from Chicago would win.

We arrived at the restaurant and were quickly seated.  The cool thing to the four of us in the party is that the restaurant is Stephanie's take on a Tapas restaurant or small plates.  That invites guests to share the meals versus just getting an entree.  I forget how many different tapas that we had however we ordered two servings of the dish of the deep fried duck tongues.  The flavors on all of the dishes were spot on and quite spectacular.  I know I should have written this review right after having dinner there yet I am good at procrastinating on things.

The other enjoyable thing was that the Chicago Cubs showcased various Chicago Celebrity Chefs and Stephanie was the first chef showcased.  One of the dishes available at the Cubs game was something with Pork Belly which how can anything be wrong with Pork Belly??!!!  I look forward to getting back to The Girl & The Goat to enjoy more of the incredible creations that Stephanie comes up with!!!

I felt very brave checking this restaurant.
The food is quite exotic for my taste. But I must admit it was delicious.
I had Hamachi Crudo and popcorn with ice cream for dessert.
Overall nice place, but a little bit too exotic for my taste.

I'm giving it 4 stars because I didn't like how my plates were still on the table when I was presented with the check. Other than that, the food was amazing and it's meant to be shared!!! I would still recommend this place.

pics.caption: Beef tongue, soo amazing must have!!!

review.des:
Ever since Stephanie Izard won top chef, we've been wanting to visit Chicago so we can eat here!  OMG seriously the hype is real!  Yes, a reservation is needed.  It was packed the entire time we were there. Our waiter was awesome.  She was informative and nice.

We brought our 2 young kids here and they loved every dish we ordered.  We got 2 plates of the goat empanadas (my kids loved this!), roasted brocolli with rice crispies (good but a tiny bit salty), pig face (not a big breakfast fan but loved this dish!) , pork shank (NO words!  So tender!) and Caremel & malt balls desserts (Not a huge dessert fan, especially anything with chocolate but this dessert was heavenly and not too sweet!)
The flavors just worked.  I love that she incorporated a lot of asian flavors in her dishes.  The kimchi sauce with the shank was delicious!

Overall, awesome dining experience.  Wanted to go back the next day and try the other items!  Will return if we're in Chicago again.

I rarely ever review restaurants.. but this one deserved it.. had a 7:15 reservation and sat immediately.. amazing service.. attentive but not overbearing.. drinks came lightning fast.. and best of all.. the food. Came out way quicker than I was anticipating.. but in a good way..I was expecting lots of waiting.. but no.. came perfectly timed out.. and the food was amazing.. Perogis and lamb shank were unreal.. goat empanadas were awesome as well.. one of the best dining experiences I've ever had.. deserving of the hype

We popped in without a reservation had a short wait then got seated at the bar. The whole night was uhmazing and we felt like VIP's even at the bar. I don't remember everything we ordered because we went with almost every recommendation of the server and it was all good! The crudo was a fav of mine and crisp pork a fav of my husband. top notch!

I wish I could afford to come eat here more often. alas I'm poor and this place is on the pricier side hahaha. but the menu changes occasionally, the food is always delicious, and the flavor profiles are amazing. make a reservation far in advance cuz this place is always booked!! my friend reserved like 3 weeks in advance and they only had a 10:15pm slot on a Wednesday.

it's tapas style, so small dishes made for sharing. they typically recommend you order double the amount of dishes to people ratio (i.e. 8 dishes for a group of 4) for a full meal. we ended up ordering 4 dishes split between 4 semi-hungry girls and were fine so just see how it goes. the bill ended up being about $20 per person + tip, so not terrible but we only ordered 4 dishes so the more you order, the more expensive it'll be.

we had the wood grilled broccoli, soft-shell chili crab, pig face, and a goat dish I don't rmbr the name of. you honestly can't go wrong, everything is delicious. but whatever you do, you MUST MUST MUST TRY THE PIG FACE.

Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face: Sunny side egg. Tamarind. Cilantro. Red wine-maple. Potato stix

IT IS SO MIND BLOWINGLY GOOD. yes it is actually made of a pig's face. no it does not look like a pig face when it comes out. so you'll be ok!! the complexity of its flavor profile is amazing. I just can't even explain. put it in your mouth and thank me later.

The food is super I mean seriously amazing!!! I've been here twice and every time the food is off the charts. Our server was over the top friendly and wonderful!! In fact the service is fabulous!!! My only complaint about this restaurant is the noise level of this is overwhelming!  Our hears were ringing by the time we left. The tables are wider so we had to talk louder any way but they have got to get some noise absorbers on ceiling or walls. Or get rid of music. Let the food talk. Let the people eat and just enjoy the experience   We loved the fact that we were left with a large bottle of water!!! Nice touch
All time go-to spot. Outside is fantastic if you can get it. Menu is approachable eclectic, with simple ingredients brilliantly compiled. Staff is excellent and cocktails as wonderful as the food.

This was my absolute top experience for dining in Chicago. We had to wait a little while for a table. The atmosphere was buzzy and vibrant. Our waiter was knowledgeable and courteous. He made sone recommendations which were all fantastic. The fennel salad was to die for! I had goat empanadas which was a first. Really yum. I was a little disappointed that they did not have a wider choice of Californian wines but again the waiter made a suggestion and it was a great syrah/Malbec/cab sav mix. Topped off by a complimentary rum baba which was a nice touch by the waiter. I want to go back so badly!
After months of wait, we were finally able to get to this place and we were not disappointed! Amazing food and ambience!

Everything was so amazing! There were 3 of us so we got to taste a lot. We had the beets, the chickpea fritter (probably my favorite), the goat empanadas, pig face (don't pass this up just because of the name), the crispy pork shank, and the goat belly. I recommend every single one. The ring of fire is also an amazing drink if you like something a touch sweet and spicy. Definitely plan to make reservations a few months ahead of time if you want to come here while visiting Chicago.

Finally went with my family. We all thought it was okay. The food was not THAT great, and a lot of us didn't care for most of it. Probably wouldn't go back. The ambiance was cool though. A little too loud to talk.

Good food. Very small expensive dishes. Overpriced, especially for the veggie plates.

The place is completely packed in the evenings, so attention from the staff is scarce.

I'd go back for a late lunch when not too hungry to just sample a few things with a friend.

The Girl and The Goat was a great place to try out. I was recommended by a friend that had visited a couple months before and she loved it so I decided to give it a try.

We had: goat liver, flank, short ribs, and lamb neck. I would put it in this order of enjoyment: Flank, Lamb Neck, Goat Liver, and then short ribs.

Flank: the meat was like Texas brisket. It was so easy to cut and very chewy. Soft to the touch, but there was so much flavor in each bite.

Lamb Neck: This was really good as well. We couldn't decide if this was the flank until we found a bone that looked like a tube for breathing. The meat was tender, and cooked well. I'd get this again.

Goat Liver: it came out with bread and this was more like a spread. There was also raspberry jelly, and I believe apple or pear slices cut pretty thin.

Short Ribs: these were pretty basic (as I ate a lot of Korean short ribs) so if you've never had KBBQ, you can't really compare. It was good, but I've had better.

Would come here again!

I had the best time here. We got to sit at the counter and watch all the delicious foods being prepped. The service was excellent, the cooks friendly and helpful, and the food nom-tastic.

Everything we tried was delicious, but it was a close contest between the pig face (the rendering of the meat and crispiness of the potato stix), goat empanadas (the mushroom topping was the perfect complement), and peanut butter and jellywich (the peanut butter fluff!) for my favorite dish.

I was particularly impressed by how many different types of flavors and textures we encountered during our meal. Each dish felt comfort food-y yet made with ingredients that kept it unique.

My only regret was that I couldn't try more things on the menu.

Girl and the Goat is definitely one of our best restaurants we love to visit. This is so far one of the best restaurants I have visited if it comes to welcome, cozy, warm feel inside. They are always super busy but lately we are going there without reservation to sit at the bar. If you have less then four people there is always good chance to sit at the bar as they have more than a dozen first come first serve sittings. We love to sit at the bar where John the bartender is the best :) Drinks are always awesome. Where it comes to food we are addicted to duck tartare which is phenomenal. It goes off and on the menu so you need to check that periodically. Second place is for the goat pate served with relish and fresh puffed pancakes as well as for the duck tongues with tuna tartare. On our last visit we also tried beet salad and halibut which were also very, very good. To be honest I never tried anything there that was mediocre or not tasty. Every plate is carefully prepared and I like their food is intense and deep in flavor. Cannot say anything about desserts but maybe one day...

Amazing dining experience. All the dishes are absolutely mind blowing. We had a big party and sat at the chef's table and shared several dishes. The lamb shank and the pig face were so flavorful and tender. The green beans and beets sides were wonderful as well and the oysters were to die for.

Make sure you make reservations months in advance! I will be back for sure.
