I don't like Mediterranean food much so I guess this restaurant wasn't targeted for me, but I still think that even if I did like Med food, I would find girl & the goat too sophisticated and over-done for my taste

Stopped in late on a Saturday night just as the kitchen was closing. Luckily the bar was still open and the restaurant was still serving desserts.

I tried the Chocolatey - Chocolate cake. It was to die for. Very rich and served with gelato. If you are in West Loop and need a late night dessert option, I would highly recommend

You gotta go to Girl & the Goat and you gotta eat the pig face. Just do it. Also, the duck or geese tongues, can't remember which - some kind of tongue of a fowl. So good. Everything I've had here is good, starting with the bread and weird butters in the beginning and including the green beans, which are usually one of my least favorite vegetables. I love the communal style of eating and everything about it.

Best food we had in chicago!! Even the butter was the best Ive ever had! Lol. The goat was a little strong for me, but everything else on the menu was AMAZINGGGGG! Even worth waiting til 10pm for a reservation. Dont miss this place in Chicago!

When to Chicago for the weekend and everyone in Miami told me I should eat here. Dining experience was incredible. We were told it was tapas style so we order the oysters, pig face, octopus, scallops, and we left room for dessert which was out of this world. Not sure what is was but I still dream about the 2 dessert we ordered. Definitely a Must if you are in Chicago. Make sure you have reservation otherwise expect to wait about 1 hour

I really can't say enough about the food.  Tapas style but portion size is fantastic.  For 2 people 3 dishes will feed you no problem.  With that said, cocktails are $14 and wine and beer varies from $7 for beer to around the same for a glass of wine.  They have a main menu as well as a changing, seasonal menu with oysters, goat products, and some choice breads.  

The meals ordered consisted of the bruschetta calamari, goat empanadas, roasted cauliflower, and pork shank.  The brushetta came in more of a bowl than your typical plated bruschetta.  The calamari was fresh and not breaded, more in the grilled octopus variety.  Really fresh and accompanied with a nice sauce.  The empanadas had some shredded goat filling and a sweet sauce.  The dish came with  2 empanadas but both were quite large.  Throw in a very unique, fresh mushroom on the plate, and I'm hooked.  Next, the cauliflower were a very good side to any meal.  Light and earthy, yet a weird flavor with mint and pepper combination.  Very weird combination in this plate but it worked.  Finally, the true winner of the day, the pork shank.  This was ordered by everyone it seemed.  Huge bone on pork that just fell off the bone.  The skin had a peking duck crispiness while the pork was a fantastic carnita style meat.  The dish came with very interesting sides as the kimchi sweet potato and buffalo sauce gave the dish flair and a refreshing taste when all combined.  The bread on the side - too good.  Pita wrap which is too good when combined with the pork.  This dish had so many components and opportunities to make side dishes besides the main pork on its own that it just blows you away - must order.

Pro tip is to make a reservation at least a week or more out.  The bar and lounge area is open seating but during the dinner hours an hour wait for a seat is modest.  But they do have full service and 80% of the seats are filled with eaters rather than strictly drinkers.  

My meal was a veggie, 2 large appetizers and a main.  Also 2 cocktails and 2 beers.  At $140, this meal was a steal.  The food is undeniably some of the best out there and the price is certainly reasonable if not cheap.  Girl & the Goat is as good as it gets.

I have to start this review with a word that describes my overall impression of the food at this restaurant: disappointed. The reason is very simple, 3 out of the 5 dishes were ordered were too complex and basically had too much going on... for instance, the fish, you could barely taste the flavor of it because they put 3-4 sauces on top of the dish that completely overpowered the fish. The steak was ok and had some weird sauces too. The goat empanada was fine but again they added some sauce on top that was too much.

The service was good but the tables were way too close to each other. I felt that the 2 tables next to us could hear everything we were saying. The place was packed and tons of people waiting but we we were sited after waiting for a few minutes (had reservations).

Again, all in all, I enjoyed the experience but wasn't impressed with the food at all.

What a beautiful restaurant - great service (although everyone seems so rushed because it's so packed in there) and we got lucky without reservations, getting bar seats as soon as another couple got up.  The cocktails were excellent (and strong.)  We ordered the pig face, roasted peets with creme fraiche (EXCELLENT), and goat empanadas (very good.)  Overall a great experience and highly recommended.

Like everyone else, I'd heard lots about it, but it's not for me.

It's very Chicago-chef in that you get MOUNTAINS OF GOD KNOWS WHAT INVOLVING MEAT. I mean a real mish-mosh. Which, if you're 27 and male, is fantastic. If you're over 40 and not inclined to digest like a boa constrictor, then maybe not so terrific.

My friend had a ludicrous meat mountain in a toasted bun bigger than some pool floaty-rings I've seen, and I had something purporting to be a fish tostada. It turned out there was indeed fish in there. Battered, but nicely. It just took some work to find it under all the avocado and garden of I don't even know what. It's just too much, too much everything. Thinking about it now I suddenly realize that there were good things about nouvelle cuisine. Like you could identify what you were eating and leave without a stretcher.

It was also seriously warm in there. I know there are good reasons to keep the a/c down, but if you're going to do that, windowshades are your friend. And your clientele's.

I will leave the place to the large and bearded.

My wife and I were in Chicago for our anniversary weekend, and came to little Goat on Saturday night for dinner. We couldn't get a reservation, when we got there the host told us he expected a two hour wait. We weren't starving, and are from NYC so no strangers to long waits and decided to wait it out at the bar. DEFINITELY WORTH THE WAIT ( even though we could've easily ordered at the bar much Sooner). Cocktails at the bar were great. My wife had the rum punch and I had the banana rum cocktail, highly recommend both. We were finally seated after an hour and 45 mins. The waiter was very friendly and knew the menu well. We ordered the goat empanadas (delicious), the calamari bruschetta (DELICIOUS),the bucatini ( great), and the ribs (GREAT). We loved dinner so much we went back for a second time the next night ! This time we didn't bother trying to get a table and just set at the bar. Fabian was our bartender and he was beyond friendly. He suggested a drink that my wife wasn't too fond of so he made her another one. This time we ordered the pork shank (yum), the halibut (must have), and the calamari bruschetta again. For dessert we ordered the shortbread which was a little too sweet for us. Needless to say they received beyond 20% tip for their wonderful service. I highly recommend this place for date night. The music is great (old school hip hop which my wife loves), service is impeccable and the food speaks for itself.

I think this is my fiance and I favorite place in the world!  The food is so creative and unexpected.  You order green beans and then you get them and say, my gosh, these green beans are the best thing I have ever tasted!  They are literally just green beans and I would eat hem every meal.  If you are vegetarian, this place is doing some of the most wonderful things with vegetables that have ever been done.  The scallops, cauliflower and blueberry pickled pepper cornbread were just incredible as well.  The deserts at this place are world class, you will think you are in a place that specializes in deserts, they are that good.  The best thing about this place is our server Hunter.  He makes you feel like they opened the place just to serve you.  He always makes the experience second to none.  We love this place, we love Stephanie Izard and we love our server Hunter!

Had an awesome experience here on Wednesday. The mousse with crumpets was fantastic as always. The pork shank was out of this world, especially the butter sauce. The duck tounges were crispy and delicious. Cocktails were also very good, and reasonably priced.

Always worth the wait.

UP, on a Wednesday night! Came around 9pm, no reservations and no wait time. Got a table within seconds, winning.

My sister had just picked me up from the airport, flew in from Kansas City (Go Royals) and the first thing I wanted to try was Girl & the Goat, it's been on my Yelp bookmark for quite some time.. We went out on a whim knowing how busy this place can get, to our surprise we were seated immediately, granted it was with a table of 8 other strangers...we didn't mind.

Girl & the Goat is all about small plates, tapas if you will. You can choose from 3 different sections on their menu, vegetarian, fish, and meat. They also have a separate menu that includes bread, oysters, and goat. We couldn't decided on what to get so we asked our server. He was pretty awesome, I just wish I remembered his name! He gave us one of the best answers I've received. So here's how the convo kinda went down: "Sweety everything on this menu is delicious, you need to order what your taste buds want because everyone is different. I can tell you these items are my favorite but it might not be yours". REALest answer you'll get! I loved that he didn't try to pressure us on certain items and just told us what our heart was craving for.

My sister and I decided to  pick one of each from the first menu. We ordered: the roasted cauliflower, calamari bruschetta, and wood oven roasted pig face, we also ordered the wood fire oysters on the side. Can I just say that everything was quite spectacular?! The flavors and the pairings just went great! I was skeptical of the roasted cauliflower but my sister swore it's her favorite dish and I can see why now. It's packed with crazy flavors! The calamari bruschetta with the goat milk ricotta - delish! Can't forget to mention the pig face...ok ok it doesn't really come out looking like a pig's face. One of their more popular dishes because it's so freaking good! That sunny side egg on top was the cherry on top! The meat was so tender and soft. I loved everything we had!

Next time I'm in town, I'm going back to Girl & the Goat, it's pretty freaking amazing. Oh, I also heard from a little birdy that the owner and chef previously won Top Chef, prettyyyy coool! It gets packed fast so I recommend making reservations....like months in advance or go on a week day when they're not as busy/crowded. Also, Uber/Lyft because I'll just leave you with... street parking/walking far. Enjoy!!

Heard super positive things about this place from a friend back when my boyfriend and I were planning our Chicago trip so we decided to include it in our itinerary! We were told that reservations fill up pretty quickly so we booked ours 2 weeks in advance for a Thursday night at around 8. It was packed but the hosts were quick to tend to us and got us to our table fast.

We ended up ordering 3 things to share: the wood oven roasted pig face, roasted cauliflower, and goat liver mousse! The pig face was DELICIOUS - it came with a sunny side egg and some crispy fried potato sticks, two of my favorite things to eat any time, haha. The mousse was super creamy and rich and came with some crumpets, pickles, strawberry jam, and pickled watermelon rind on a very cute wooden board much like charcuterie style. The roasted cauliflower was also very tasty and a great choice for a veggie dish!

The service was fantastic, the servers were knowledgeable about all the different dishes, recommendations and also tips on how to get the best flavor from our dishes. This place is perfect for a date night dinner and romantic. Definitely a go to foodie stop if you're in Chicago!

pics.caption: The goat liver mousse. Super cute wooden board! Tastes amazing with the fried crumpets and the side condiments are also great additions.
Wood oven roasted pig face!!! Looove how everything blended together in this dish.

review.des:
Cool spot in the West Loop.  Overall, I was very impressed with the service and food.  4.5 stars in my opinion.  

The lady was visiting me on a work assignment in Chicago, and her flight from NYC was delayed 2 hours (thank you, Delta and LaGuardia).  I booked a reservation via OpenTable a couple of weeks in advance, knowing the restaurant's popularity, so it was sad that we were unable to make it on time due to the aforementioned delays.  I called the restaurant to explain the situation and prepared to give away my table.  However, the reservationist was highly sympathetic and told us to come that night whenever we could make it.  Despite the restaurant being packed and showing up roughly 30 minutes late, they checked my girlfriend's luggage at the front door at sat us immediately.  Really classy stuff - we sincerely appreciated it.

The menu is separated into three primary sections: vegetables, fish, and meats.  There is also an array of goat-inspired dishes as well as breads, oysters, and desserts.  Our waiter explained that the majority of plates are smaller with the intention of sharing (think tapas), which was useful advice.  As a result, we ordered a gamut of items and received approval from our waiter, who ensured our selections paired well together.  Again, this was super helpful.

The food was great.  We had the roasted cauliflower, goat carpaccio, hamachi crudo, seared diver scallops, and wood oven roasted pig face.  I really enjoyed the fish dishes, though everything was tasty.  The pig face was also pretty awesome, topped with a sunny side egg.  There was no room in our content stomachs for dessert, though it was tempting.

Thanks again for the enjoyable experience and showing great hospitality towards a couple of out-of-towners.  I definitely recommend this restaurant to anyone local or visiting!

Awesome upscale old shop lunch counter experience with modern twists on old favorites.  Always make a reservation as this place is always packed.  Food and service are both 10/10.  Always get the desserts and try the nachos as they're bomb!

I have been dying to come to Girl & The Goat since I moved her almost 2 years ago. I counted down each minute all day, and couldn't wait to enjoy this amazing meal ahead. I had studied the menu and the yelp reviews and knew I was going to get: The Goat Empanadas, The Calamri Bruschetta, The Pork Shank, and finally the Pig Face. Overall, I would rate my total meal experience a 9, and my total experience an 11.

To start, G&TG had some of the best service I have ever encountered at any restaurant. The servers are extremely attentive. There was never a time that my glass was empty, or that my server was gone too long. Its these kinds of details that make you want to be a regular at any restaurant.

The Goat Empanadas: While I was nervous about trying goat, my nerves were instantly diminished by the incredibly balanced and satisfying flavors that were exploding out of this empanada. This crispness of the empanada was truly beautiful. With each bite, I was left with a smoky aftertaste that was mind-blowing. And I honestly could not get enough of the light mayo dressing (i think thats what it was) that was drizzled on top. 9.4 score overall.

The Calamari Bruschetta: This was extremely disappointing. The calamari itself was cooked perfectly, but the bruschetta as a whole lacked flavor.The bruschetta was topped with a creamy cheese layer that was light and sat between the bread and the calamari. Over the calamari, were apple shavings that gave nice bursts of flavor. This dish was not bad, but compared to everything else that was unbelievable, this did not hold up. 5.5 overall score.

The Pork Shank: I actually have tears in my eyes thinking about this dish. I miss it. The meat is so creamy and cooked so perfectly, that it truly falls off of the bone. It is accompanied by 2 sauces. One, the red sauce, is a lightly spicy sauce that i practically bathed my meat it to. I would have poured the remaining sauce in my mouth honestly if I wasn't on a date. the second, a buttermilk ranch, was good but too creamy for my personal tastes. A carrot salad also is on the plate, and that too is perfectly light and balanced. I would eat that any day. 9.8 overall score.

The Pig Face: WOW! First off, don't let the name scare you. To think the my boyfriend and I hesitated ordering this offends me looking back. It was by far one of the more amazing dishes that has ever graced my mouth. The meat has a over easy egg on top, and both practically melt open with the touch of your fork. The egg was the perfect compliment, and i even licked the plate for more when it was over. ( I have no regrets about that)

Finally the Carmel desert, the restaurant (again being so amazingly attentive) knew it was an anniversary and brought us out a caramel popcorn ice-cream dessert. I do not know exactly what it was but PLEASE order it when you go in. So delicious and a must get!

I can't wait to return and try even more items on that menu!!

pics.caption: The Calamari Bruschetta: ehh just ok

review.des: I don't mean to be a party crasher, but this place is essentially overrated and largely overpriced. The one star is for the service, which was on point. The food on the other hand... Perhaps my expectations were a little high coming in. The shishito peppers were served with a kind of creamy sauce and parmesan cheese. Ok I should have seen this one coming. But seriously ?!? Parmesan cheese on shishito peppers? Maybe next time with bacon and bread crumbs? The lamb ribs were nothing but a delicious piece of fat on a bone, with a subtle sweety/savory glaze. No meat whatsoever. $22 for spiced up lamb fat. Take that, bbq joints. The bucattini were good, a little too tikka masala-i to my taste. Not worth the $$$ for a tiny portion anyway. Sorry girl, no more goat for me ;(

Called ahead by a week to get a reservation for Sunday night and they were full. we got back to our Hotel room after day drinking at Rossi's Liquors (a great bar the y'all should visit, btw) and checked Open Table to see if there were any cancellations. Lo and behold 7:45! We had 10 minutes to down a glass of birthday champagne in the room and then hopped in a cab to celebrate my bestie's 42nd!

Atmosphere was a little hipster, but i soon warmed up because the servers were cool. I wish I could remember our server's name, but he was great-- helping us choose some of his favourites and telling us what others thought of certain items.

I also appreciated the "interesting Wines" section on their list that played host to a Gruner Veltliner, which I rarely see and am a huge fan of. Needless to say we ordered a bottle.

Duck tongues were tender and supple with a delicious sauce. Short Ribs were cooked to a lovely softened on the inside and crispy on the outs with cilantro and a zingy almost vietnamese sauce. I loved the shishito peppers but my friend was indifferent. The pig face was hands down one of the most delicious things I've eaten. Fat was perfectly rendered leaving a silky portion of indescribable perkiness. The egg on top made it an cute play on 'bacon and eggs".
Malt Balls and Popcorn was fabulous, I'm not usually a fan of hipster desserts like this that veer away from the classic party techniques, but I was brought to my knees.

Definitely a restaurant worth the acclaim it receives and well worth a visit in Chicago. Just remember to reserve well in advance. We were planning on just going to the bar and waiting, but I would't have been able to stand waiting that long and the bar seemed very crowded and hectic.

This place is seriously hyped up.

My husband and I were really excited to go here. He's a chef and I'm a big fan of Top Chef.

We ordered five dishes and a glass of wine each. This review is for the food. Of the five dishes we only liked two. The worst dish was essentially a deconstructed street taco. All you could taste was tortilla chips and the meat had no flavor. That was our first dish of the night and it was terrible. The best dish was the goat empanada. That sucker was packed full of flavor and I wish I'd ordered a couple more of them.

I strongly recommend people skip this place and try the Purple Pig instead. Similar food concept and a lot tastier.

I love Stephanie Izard and what she's doing in Chicago. I've been a fan for years and I absolutely love Duck Duck Goat, but wasn't blown away with Girl & The Goat.

A group of us celebrated my husband's birthday there a few years ago. We wanted to be able to share in everyone's excitement, but I thought it was just good. Even booking far in advance we had a very late reservation, understandably, but we're seated quickly and staff was very friendly.

As far as the food, the duck tongues and pig face were delicious, but everything else seemed a bit too salty and over-charred to me. Even broccoli, which I thought would be difficult to me to mess up wasn't easy edible. The server suggested a specific amount of dishes for the table and it was way too much. We of course ate as much as we could, but felt bad to waste.

Nearing the end of our meal a server was a bit optimistic with how many plates they could carry and ended up spilling on our friend's jacket. The manager did come over and give their card for dry cleaning which was nice, as well as a platter of dessert. We unfortunately couldn't finish the desserts either, but appreciated the gesture.

Overall it was a nice meal, innovative dishes, beautiful decor, great staff but some fell a little flat for me. I have been back for drinks in the bar and always have a great time, but we really need to go back for dinner one day.

Great food including the appetizers and the main course..though portions per dish are less but the taste's worth it!! Desserts were also good though they didn't have much variety..!!
Overall a great place but not a place for people looking for a budget friendly meal!!

Sat at the bar, top 5 dining experiences of my adult life (not counting my 9th birthday at Chuck E Cheese).

Lily was our waitress and holy balls is this chick a badass.  She controlled our selections, created a perfect tempo, ensured we never waited a second in between plates and made us dance in our seats.

Here's my hit list:

Cauliflower
Beets
Pig Face (trust me)
Goat Shank
Duck Tongue

...and throw in an old fashioned or a glass of the sparkling rose and now it's a party!

pics.caption: Trifecta. Old Fashion, sparkling rose and wine.

review.des:
Definitely must come here when in Chicago.

So many reviews recommend getting reservations but don't lose hope if you didn't make any plans to come here and just wanna show up. That's exactly what I did. I called the restaurant at 430pm on a sunday to ask about seating and reservations. The lady told me that they were completely booked but i can still walk in and sit at the bar for dinner. The earlier i go there, the shorter the wait time. My BF and I arrived there around 545pm and were immediately seated out on their patio. They still had open seats at the bar but I picked to be outside since the weather was gorgeous. Keep in mind that the patio tables are made up of large picnic type tables so you will be sitting next to strangers and listening to their conversations.

For 2 people, they recommended ordering 4-5plates to share.

In order from most favorite to least favorite:

-Wood fired oysters-OMG, they are amazing! The slight cooking probably brings out a stronger taste in the oysters and it was soooo delicious. The oysters were fresh, succulent and creamy and one of the best things I ate that night. Definitely ties for 1st place with the pork face as most memorable dish. MUST GET THEM!

-porkface- I loved it. Don't recall trying pork face before but the meat has a nice texture and it's also fatty so it was tastyyyy....kinda like porkbelly, but slightly different. I definitely recommend trying this dish if you wanna try something different/slightly exotic yet tasty.

-bucatini- yummy! Mixed with milk braised pork shoulder and tomatoes. It tasted somewhat like penne vodka, but it's bucatini. I've never had bucatini before and found it interesting that the middle of the noodle is hollow. Everytime I slurp up the pasta I can hear it because of the air going through the bucatini. This is probably my 3rd favorite dish that night.

-Hamachi Crudo- it was good but not amazing or unforgettable. There's probably better things on the menu I could've tried.

-goat empanadas- I didn't originally want to get this but since I was at "girl and the GOAT", I figured I needed to try some goat, and alot of yelpers seemed to like this dish. It tasted good and had interesting flavors with the avocado and the strawberries. The goat meat in the empanadas reminded me of pulled pork but with a more gamey taste, but not as strong as lamb. If you wanna try something goat, I'd probably try a different dish. This one was good but wasn't particularly memorable to me. I wish I ordered my original first choice of the grilled octopus instead. I guess this gives me a reason to go back to chicago.

For dessert, the waiter recommended the caramel popcorn with ice cream.dont remember the official name on the menu but it was good. The caramel popcorn went well with the ice cream.

Waiters were nice and attentive.

pics.caption: Wood grilled pork face- MUST get this!

review.des:
Several friends recommended I dine here while in Chicago, so I came with two friends on a Sunday evening. We came shortly after 6PM and the wait was already over two hours, but fortunately, we were also given the option of sitting outdoors, for which there was immediate availability. We got lucky, because one of my friends had to go in for her night shift at 9PM, so we wouldn't have been able to wait two hours.

Though I didn't sit inside, I did get a peek of the interior, and it's quite a large space, with lots of tables and a lounging area with couches. I also went to use the restroom, which was downstairs. I will say that the light at the stairwell is not very bright and I had difficulty seeing the steps, so I feel like this could be improved for safety considerations. I also found it amusing that the restrooms below are individual rooms (probably at least six separate doors) with no gender designation; I've never seen that before!

Our waitress was great. She wasn't overtly friendly, but was very attentive. Our dishes were served by many different people, but each time, they always announced the name of the dish and the primary ingredients, which I think added a nice touch of class. Our waters were also regularly topped off.

Since we were a party of three, it was recommended that we order six plates for sharing, so that's exactly what we did (plus one dessert). I can't remember all the names of the dishes now, but see my photos and their corresponding captions. There is a separate menu of "goat dishes," and the goat liver mousse that we opted for was fantastic! It came with lots of warm biscuits and several sauces/garnishes. All of our other dishes were amazing too.

The presentation of each dish was also very thoughtful. The quality of the ingredients was apparent when you tasted each dish, and while the portions were not large, the three of us were still full at the end of the meal.

Although pricey, our meal after splitting three-ways was only about $40 per person, which was reasonable. I'm glad I went with two other people so that I was able to try so many dishes!

I definitely think Girl & the Goat deserves all of its accolades and is worth checking out!

Our experience here left me perplexed. While we had great service and enjoyed most of the food while we were eating it, the dishes died on my tongue and I'm left with vague memories of flavors and wondering how the reservations are so hard to get.

We sampled the duck tongue dish which was well done. The tongues were crispy and I could have eaten them without anything else. The pig face was the favorite of the table with porky goodness mixed with unctuous egg yolk.

The pierogis were ok but at $16 for the dish definitely not worth it as the fried dough tasted more like an empanada filled with cheese with not much ramp flavor.

The octopus was tender and had a lovely grilled flavor but I felt the sauce might have been a little heavy handed and masked the dish a bit. The worst dish was the ham frites which our waiter vaguely warned us about by saying they were fries basically. My husband still went ahead though. The fries themselves were very good but there was a dusting of ham salt as it was explained to us that tasted like ground up bacon bits. We were talking and did finish the meal more because it was there and not because the flavor rocked.

As I mentioned, we enjoyed the dishes while we are them and the staff was totally on their game. We just aren't talking about the food with watering mouths.

pics.caption: Pig face - as good as everyone says it is.
Grilled octopus - incredible with the fave beans.
Meh pierogies. Green garlic ramp. Not worth the cash

review.des: Love it, the pastry chef here needs a shout out too. Food was great, service was right on point, and loved that atmosphere

Fantastic breakfast @ Lil Goat with a staff that is both efficient, yet not overbearing.  Been there 2x, price is fair for the area. To those looking for cheap eats, this isn't the place, but assuredly you expected that.

This was a unique experience. The menu has a lot of eclectic items from goat to duck to beef tongue. It's a great place to step outside your comfort zone. My boyfriend and I showed up right when it opened on a Saturday at 4:30 and were seated right away. I had extremely high expectations and it fell just short. The service was spectacular and had great ambience, but I thought the food was good, not great.

Food: they have an amazing gluten free menu!!!!  The portion size was also huge for "tapas," at least what I'm used to in NYC where tapas usually means 1 big bite. Here, there was plenty to go around. We ordered 4 dishes for the 2 of us, and it was more than enough. we ordered the green beans, beef tongue, cuttle fish, charred broccoli, and goat belly. The beef tongue was great. It was so tender and flavorful. The menu said it was served with a "salsa verde," but I thought it was more similar to a pesto. Either way, it was still great. The cuttle fish was amazing! It had great flavor. The fish was mostly potatoes with a few pieces of cuttle fish, but I loved the combo of the pistachio and Dijon. So delicious! The goat belly was served with bits of lobster. I actually really liked the goat belly itself. It was tender, but I was pretty underwhelmed by the fish itself. Our waitress said their green beans were really popular, so we decided to give them a try. I was really not a fan. The fish sauce was overpowering and way too salty. I told the waitress I wasn't a fan, and they brought us the broccoli! It was such a nice gesture, but we were unimpressed by the dish :/.

Service: the service was outstanding!! Our waitress was extremely knowledgeable about the menu and very accommodating. We also really appreciated them bringing out another veggie dish after I made a comment about not loving the green beans.

Ambience: it's a big space, but still very cozy. We sat at a large table that we shared with other people, but we were spaced out enough that it still felt intimate enough. They have cool decor and a fun bar area.

Amazing experience!!

Came here for dinner one night after several friends recommended this place. I have to say it did not disappoint at all!

We couldn't get a dinner reservation on opentable or by calling the restaurant, so we ended you winging it and just showed up. Around 8pm it was packed, we stood by the bar lounge area to wait for 2 seats to open up and after about 10min, 2 people left and we snatched the seats right away on the long bench. We ordered a bunch of things to share and our bartender gave us a few recommendations which were exceptional!

Green beans - the caramel iced onion and cashews sauce was so flavorful, nice twist. Perogies - kind of plain but once again the sauce made the dish, so flavorful. Empanadas - one of our favorites. The pig face - holy cow, absolutely delicious! My favorite was the goat belly confit - with lobster, what an interesting combination of ingredients and flavors. Top it all off we got the chocolate mousse with sesame crunch and caramel - insanely tasty!

Service was superb, very efficient and attentive. Drinks refilled without asking, dirty plates replaced with nice clean plates regularly. Even with the restaurant packed and so busy, there was no slack in the service! Kudos!

Highly recommend!

I am so smitted with this place! If you are in town, definitely recommend. Either do reservations or they have an open area at the front (more like a lounge) that's first come first serve seating.

+ Calamari Bruschetta: my favorite of the meal. It was SOO good, and so soft. I love bruschetta already, but the grilled calamari on top was to die for. A MUST GET!!!!
+ Pork: sooo tender. Comes with pita bread to wrap it in.  
+ Goat belly w grab: SOOO YUMMMMSS

Come here!!!! And bring many friends so you can eat everything

COST:
$20-$40 Tapas Style Plates

For my 50th Golden Yelp Review, I need to finally muster up the courage to try and summarize the most delicious meal of my entire existence... so far. I had friends coming over from Los Angeles and a friend swore up and down that we MUST try Girl & the Goat. Frankly, I never heard of the place before she brought it up and from then on, I've had a love affair with Stephanie Izzard and her crazy delicious concoctions.

If you're planning on dining here at all, you MUST make your reservations a few weeks in advance as seats get booked up fast. Either that or you risk waiting for tables as they do take walk in customers as well. Now for the food reviews...

- Olive You
This bread was awesome. Tasted so fresh! Crispy on the outside, warm and soft on the inside. The actual pieces of olives in it were a nice touch!

- Fried Oysters
I didn't think I had affinity for oysters but boy these fried ones are melt in your mouth awesome, literally! They served them in cute little bite sized spoons and I wish we had ordered about ten more savings!

- Seared Diver Scallops
So perfectly cooked even Gordon Ramsay would approve.

- Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face
One of their staple items! I don't even know what part of the pork it was, but it was gloriously amazing. The fried egg on top was the cherry on top. The sauce was delicious and craftfully served.

- Crispy Braised Short Ribs
My pick for the best dish we ate! It was perfectly tangy and sweet. The meat was cooked just right and the sauce paired well with it. Don't tell anyone but I drank the sauce off the bowl! Ha!

- Miso Butterscotch Budino
A perfect dessert to cap off our dining experience here. So deliciously good. I thought I tasted a little whiskey/bourbon in it as well which provided just enough twist to it.

A friend also ordered an Old Fashioned which she though was a little to stiff. I yanked it out of her hands and drank it for myself. A drink can never be too stiff in my books!

Thank you Ana for bringing Girl & the Goat into my life haha! I can't wait to go back.

Expectations were really high and they were exceeded.

Things to know:

1) Get reservations or wait a long time to get in.
2) Reservations are nearly impossible. I booked two months in advance for a 10:30 PM slot on a Saturday night.
3) Come hungry and try everything you can

We got to sit in front of the kitchen in the back of the restaurant in front of all the chefs are they prepared the amazing food we were about to eat.

Drinks were great, but the highlight is the food.

Girlfriend has a fish allergy so the server was kind enough to mark up the menu with items that had a fish component to the dish, which was quite a bit more than I anticipated.

Things we ordered:

- Ham Frites - Excellent french fries, very tasty to start off with
- Goat Empanadas - Also Excellent and very, very flavorful
- Wood Oven Roasted Pig's Face- The highlight of the food and I assume - everyone else would say something similar. Very, very good.
- Carmel Corn & Malt Balls for Desert

Service was excellent. Atmosphere was great. Food was phenomenal. Will be back eventually.

Believe it or not, we got a table for 4 without a reservation!! Having said that, highly recommend making a reservation well ahead in time unless you plan to get dinner at 5:30 pm on a Thursday. The food was fantastic. Very flavorful and just the right portions for sharing between 4. Recommend ordering 2-3 dishes/person. Did not enjoy the rhubarb short cake and the desert selection seemed rather short (less impressive). I'd still go back again!

Part of my plan for a birthday weekend in Chicago was to try Chef Izard's restaurant. SO GLAD we could get in!

The shared plate concept is often not my favorite; it seems like charge a lot of money for very little. However, here server did a great job of suggesting the number of plates to share. We came hungry, left full, and spent about we might have for a "normal" restaurant.

The calamari bruschetta is going to haunt me. It was perfect! Other dishes had considering (actually) licking the plates.

The bourbon butter, yo!!!

Our server, Austin, played along with three goofy gals in town for the weekend. Even posing for a picture with us.

WhenI make it back to Chicago, I'll make it back.

pics.caption: The best dessert!the malt balls. Caramel popcorn, malted milk discs, vanilla ice cream with hard shells.
Confit goat belly with lobster, crab, shaved fennel, and a bourbon butter that will make you want to lick the plate.
Roasted pigface with sunny side up egg and crispy potato strings.

review.des: Everything was delicious...100% worth the hype!  You can't go wrong with any item on the menu.  I definitely need a revisit!

From Greece and New York so have had a million dining experiences - this was hands down one of the best. We said it was a date night when we made a reservation and they had us seated at the chef's table right at the line. All the chefs were working hard and still were eager to talk to us and tell us what they were making! Service was also amazing with Jerson - super knowledgeable and even brought us a dessert sample he thought we'd like even when we weren't sure we could fit it.

In terms of food, we got these and they were all phenomenal:  crispy chickpea fritters, goat empanadas, escargot ravioli, and wood-fired skirt steak.

Highly recommended and can't wait to go again when back in Chicago!
Excellent food. Sat outside. I have the Reuben. It was excellent. The Gooey Gooey cinnabon was a must have

Our party of 3 was told on Saturday at 4:30 that the soonest walk-in seating time was at 9-10pm -- yikes! So we opted to sit at the bar area. There are also some couches in the bar area, so don't feel like you have to eat at the actual bar itself. We were able to sit almost immediately! I was surprised that not a lot of people took advantage of this. We ordered (way too much, but worth it):

Cauliflower - it was roasted and topped with a pickled pepper and grated cheese and pine nuts. It was good, but a little bit of salt would've added a lot.

Kushi oysters - Oh my god yessss. These were so worth it and amazing. The best oysters I've had. It was served with a mignonette sauce, and the oysters themselves were tiny but packed with flavor!!

Goat carpaccio - got to order goat here, right? Thinly sliced raw goat served with thin fried parsnips, vinaigrette, and frise. Very nice.

Duck tongue - We ordered this last minute actually, and this actually ended up being my favorite dish of the night (over the pig face). Don't let the protein freak you out -- it was a piece of deliciously fried and well seasoned duck tongue (it just tastes like regular duck and isn't really any textual differences). Try this!!

Pig face - Overrated. A runny egg covers a compressed patty of pig face parts with some potato sticks. I didn't think this was particularly interesting. Just a standard old-fashioned egg and meaty goodness. It's basically like pork belly.

Pork shank - This was a peculiar dish. It was good but not sure what the vision was. It was a beautifully fried pork shank served with homemade naan (done really well), buttermilk ranch, hot sauce, and kimchi. It wasn't really conducive to being eaten together (naan was cut in small pita-like triangles and didn't open, so not much to stuff?)

Chili crab - I think this is supposed to be Singapore chili crab inspired, but I didn't get any heat at all. It was a fairly sour sauce, and the crab rice just tasted insanely sour and tart. When mixed with the strawberries, rice, and soft shell crab, it was okay.

All the leches - Wonderful end to the meal. Two small pieces of tres leches cake served with a rhubarb sorbet. Nice palate cleanser!

The decor had a lot of dark woods but still a lot of natural light and greens too. Very charming but didn't feel stuffy. Service was good, not exceptional, but food came out pretty quickly, and our waters were always filled.

Girl & the Goat is one of my favorite restaurants in Chicago. It's incredibly high number of reviews and high acclaim don't go unwarranted. It's the place I tell anyone visiting Chicago to go visit for a 5-star meal. I highly recommend going to the bar if you don't have reservations and there's only two of you as you can get full service there and you're much closer to getting a supremely mixed cocktail...I recommend the "Very Old Fashioned".

Heard such great review of this place, super happy to be able to try it! The ambience is great, nice decor and pretty lively. The whole restaurant is pretty much packed at 8 pm on a Sunday. Reservation must be made or else you would probably have to wait a long time.

We ordered 4 dishes for 2: the food was more than enough for us, probably because the pork shank was so big.

1. Grilled beets - very refreshing and a big portion. The avocado Creme was not too creamy and they gave a generous amount of beets. (10/10)

2. Octopus - I didn't try it because I'm allergic to octopus but my boyfriend said its really tender. His only complaint is that there's too much bacon that it overpowers the octopus. He likes the veggies and mushroom in it, though.(9/10)

3. Goat belly - interesting sauce, can't really explain how it tastes but it just tastes so good. Highly recommend this dish as the goat meat just melts in your mouth and the lobster and crab meat is cooked just right (10/10)

4. Pork shank - it's huuuuge. The meat is super tender. Sauce is really nice. However I think the pork is a little too salty (8/10)

Overall - if you're in town you should definitely try this place :D

Was visiting Chicago for the first time and seen many recommendations for this place and I now know why! It was absolutely amazing, great service, amazing food presentation, food was to die for. My mouth is watering just thinking about it! There was two of us, we put our name on the waitlist and came back in about 2 hours

I think this was my favorite meal from my Chicago trip! I had heard of the difficulty in scoring a reservation, and even making it 2-3 months in advance, I could only get a Friday 5pm reservation for 3 people. Luckily, we were able to push it back to 8:45pm because we had a huge lunch lol.

FOOD:
- roasted pig face - DELICIOUS. So flavorful and tender when all mixed together - definitely the highlight of our meal!
- goat liver mousse - served with warm fluffy crumpets/bread, pickled veggies, mushrooms, and slaw - I liked this even though it was gamier than chicken liver or duck liver mousse.
- roasted cauliflower - yummy and perfectly cooked.
- pork shoulder - fall off the bone, super tender and flavorful meat.
- short ribs - I don't eat beef, but my friends enjoyed this.

SERVICE:
Excellent! Everyone is super friendly, we arrived a little early, grabbed a drink at the bar and we were seated at our table at exactly 8:45pm. Food came out staggered, but we never had an empty table waiting for our next dish.

VENUE:
Really cool venue! high ceilings, lots of wood, warm lighting. It feels spacious and open. Bathrooms are downstairs.

Delicious meal and I still dream about all the yummy porky goodness we ate! Super cute goat logo on everything too!

This place met all of our expectations and more! We had reservations, arrived on time and were seated just after getting a cocktail at the bar. Our server was great, looks like everyone there really works well together. If anyone found our water low or a plate or glass that needed to be cleared it was taken care of. The food was fantastic! we will absolutely be back!

We we're here early on a weeknight before a show.  Service was great!  The food was good but almost everything IMHO was a touch underseasoned.  Maby it is the gushing reviews but things  did not live up to the expectation.
the sloppy joe. word. it really was sloppy, so dont get it with your date... lol. amazing regardless.

My boyfriend and I visited Girl &a the Goat after receiving a gift card from out of town family. The food and ambiance were great! Tons of throwback hip hop accompanied by upscale and innovative foods made it a wonderful dinner.

That said, had we not had a gift card I'm not sure if I would have been overly satisfied with the meal for he price we paid.

There are a lot of over hyped restaurants in Chicago but this is definitely not one of them! I got a cocktail and tried a lot of different items on the menu, all of which I enjoyed. I still drool over the cauliflower with pine nuts. So tasty! Everything was delicious and I have no complaints at all.

Got there before 4:30 opening and sat at the bar.  Loved everything, especially what was made there (cocktails and food vs beer and wine).  Came here to say we got great service from Lilly, a brassy, sassy gal who gave us all the attention we needed with menu questions and care to avoid food sensitivities though the place was packed and she was busy.  Looking forward to going back.  Get the ciabatta from the bread menu, green beans from veg menu, halibut from fish/fowl, and beef short ribs from meat! Thanks Lilly!

A good friend recommended this restaurant while I was on a quick trip to Chicago and I'm glad we went. I really like the location, which I'd never been to - there are lots of other bars and restaurants nearby. We were nervous about a long wait, but arrived Thursday night and were able to grab 2 seats at the bar right away. Sometimes sitting at the bar can equal mediocre service, but we had the best waiters. They were very attentive and friendly, and gave great recommendations. We ordered 4-5 dishes, which can end up being a bit pricey for the small portion sizes, but we really enjoyed most of it. The scallops and green beans are Divine. The chorizo flatbread wasn't my favorite. Overall, a great restaurant!

Perfect dining experience! Celebrating Mother's Day/ birthday - Ryan couldn't have made it any more enjoyable. From the oysters, to pig face, to the amazing desserts...everything was delicious! When in doubt, trust your server.  :)

What's not to love about Lady & The Lamb?.... err, sorry, there was definitely a goat in there somewhere I'm sure. We're talking one of Chicago's finest establishments that requires reservations months in advance to get a table, and it certainly hits all the marks as fine, New American dining.

Thanks to Jaymie S. who was visiting from out of town, I got my chance to enjoy this trendy Chicago restaurant.

Having grown up in a Chinese household (holler to my Cantonese brothers and sisters), I am used to eating practically everything minus furniture. A lot of the the selection here focuses on parts of pork, goat, or other meats that the adventurous eaters would find "bold" and "edgy." I just find it an upscale, tapas style of what I've enjoyed growing up.

The menu was split between six different sections, which our waitress gladly explained upon being seated. Between the three of us, we ordered four items: Kusshi Oysters ($12), Confit Goat ($19), Baby Octopus ($16), and finally the ever elusive Pig Face ($19).

The oysters came in four and definitely packed a punch. Be careful to not swallow too much of the tangy sauce at the bottom of the shell. I definitely enjoyed these bad boys. Afterwards, our Pig Face came in- tender pork bits laid over by a sunny side egg. The meat was impeccable, full of flavor, and absolutely delicious. Our order of baby octopus came next and was also very nice, although I prefer mine to be a bit more on the chargrilled side. Lastly, the confit goat came after we had finished the first three, and the bourbon extract made this taste like dessert! Another winner.

I'm thrilled that I got to try Girl & The Goat, and would definitely recommend it to visitors and locals alike that want to splurge out just a bit for a tantalizing set of flavors.

Street parking is available, but be sure to pay the meter!

Girl & the goat is incredible and well worth the hype and wait. I went with two other people (for my moms Birthday), and it was amazing. We ordered the warm marinated olives, the roasted beets, the wood grilled broccoli, the Mr. Potato bread, the scallops, the wood oven roasted pig face, the goat empanadas, the caramel corn and malt balls, and the sweet potato cake. Came hungry, left full. My favorites were the scallops and sweet potato cake! Everything was soooo good though!

pics.caption: Caramel corn & malt balls. Many people's favorite!

review.des: Duck tongue appetizer?!  I mean seriously.  Always an amazing experience at the Goat!

Woah woah wee woah. Stephanie Izard is a culinary genius. Seriously an incredible meal.

The interior is a lot bigger than it seems from the outside, with tons of seating. My friend and I got here right at 4:30 since we didn't have a reservation and were immediately seated; however, it was at a big dining table meant for 10 with a bunch of other parties. A little awkward, but that's what I get for not getting a reservation I guess?

The food is simply to die for. Everything is cooked to perfection and delicious. Pan friend shishieto peppers were great - not too spicy that you can't handle them. I'm not a huge spice person and even I could handle them. Chickpea Fritter was even better, and it had a GREAT yogurt sauce to go with it. The crispy beef short ribs were the best thing we ordered - incredible. Might have been one of the best foods I've ever had to be honest. The stuff was so tender you didn't even need a knife. The bucatini was good, but nothing to rave about. Probably my least favorite dish.

We got the caramel corn and malt balls as a dessert, and they were even kind enough to bring us out a small dish of the chocolate cake with a candle in it for my birthday :) Between the two, hands down go with the caramel corn. The chocolate cake was good, but like the bucatini, nothing great. The caramel corn, on the other hand, was the perfect dessert. I probably could've eaten an entire thing by myself even with our meal.

I will say, I highly recommend a reservation, or at least asking for your own table. One of the parties next to us at the giant table was INCREDIBLY annoying, messy, and kept trying to talk to us....not exactly a great dining experience. I tried not to hold that against the restaurant though (as evidenced by my 5 stars), I think it was just bad luck. Already have a reservation to come back for my masters graduation and looking forward to it!

SO AMAZING!!!!!!! DEFINITELY met the hype for our party of four. One of THE best restaurants ever!!

The goat empanadas, the roasted cauliflower, the pork shank, the butter chicken, the Branzino fish, the sweet potatoe toffee cake..... INCREDIBLE!!!

Their attention to flavors and sauces are impeccable and unique. I'm so sad we live so far away!
We will definitely be back and be dreaming of this place until then
Definitely a MUST of Chicago. Make sure you get there before they open (4:30) and wait in a short line, or make a ressy for your party.

The food was great. Not the standard menu you'd expect from and everyday restaurant but well worth the change. We enjoyed everything we ordered. The halibut was exceptional! The lamb ribs were delicious as well. Definitely give this place a try.
A bit pricey but one of the best restaurant in the city ! We had an amazing time for my birthday !

Cool vibe, nice place to go for dinner with a small group. Just not amazing as I have read in reviews. Service good not great and their creative dishes just don't wow you !! 1 time is enough for this spot but worth going if you really want to

The food was very good but not to die for. The prices were far too much for the small portion size, which allows you try a lot of things but jacks up the bill at a rate that will leave your head spinning.
I took off an additional star for ambiance. It was so dark we could barely read the menus and so loud I could only hear the person sitting next to me, but not others across the table. Almost inaudible music played in the background as people hollered over one another in an attempt to be heard. A really unpleasant dining experience.

Just in case if the 5200+ reviews weren't enough, I'll add one more. After 2 months of reservations, I've finally had the opportunity to try one of Stephanie's Izard restaurants, the first female chef ever to win the Bravo's Top Chef. No wonder there are next to no times available a few months out. One stop inside and you figure out why.

First things first before I get into the food. Service was top notch. Our server, Emily, was very good about replacing our plates with clean ones, keeping our water and drinks filled, and explaining any questions we had about the menu. (Give her a raise Steph!)

Now let's talk about the goodies:
- Old Fashioned ($13)
- Bolt Action ($13)
- Beet Salad ($10)
- Raw Oysters ($12)
- Goat Empanadas ($16)
- Pig Face ($14)
- Pork Shank ($26): The best dish!  

Honestly, there isn't much I can say about the place that hasn't been said already. When we got to the restaurant we were shown to our table immediately and were seated. The table was in a great place for people watching I might add - right at the front close to the front door which I love. Also, I noticed this restaurants is tons of Young Professionals which makes it cool because everybody's age is very similar.

Tips:
- Avoid the 2 hour wait and make reservations asap!
- It's right next to a few good bars!

A must try if you're in Chicago! I'll be back.

Man...what a fun experience! Several of us came out for dinner and thoroughly enjoyed every minute of it!

Each item was cooked and created to perfection! Hays off to the wonderfully creative staff for this excellent experience. We enjoyed these amazing items:

sautéed green beans
fish sauce vinaigrette. cashews

roasted cauliflower
pickled peppers. pine nuts. mint

kohlrabi salad
fennel. evalon. toasted almonds. blueberries

wood grilled broccoli
rogue smokey bleu. spiced crispies

hamachi crudo
crisp pork belly. chili aioli. caperberries

squash blossom 'crab rangoon'
almonds. chive yogurt

pan roasted halibut
marcona almond butter. white asparagus. blueberry nuoc cham

ham frites
smoked tomato aioli. cheddar beer sauce

And several cocktails for each of us. Every bite was delicious!!  It's a great dining experience!

Came here late (10pm) on a Wednesday night with a few co-workers and they were on an hour and a half wait.  This was fully expected as the restaurant is well known to be amazing.  We got a drink at place down the road until our table was ready and were very surprised to see that at nearly 11:10 when we sat down, the place was still packed.  Great sign seeing as how they "close" at 11pm.

Our server was extremely courteous and very friendly taking the time to explain the restaurant to us and the menu.  She flagged a few of their specials, told us that for the 5 of us we probably need 10 dishes and left us to look over the menu.  We picked 10 items and 1 bread and eagerly awaited our dishes.  I'm going to list below the dishes with what I thought, but for the sake of length, I'll give the gist of the review here.  The ambiance was modern and romantic, the service was excellent, the food outstanding.  The only minor complaint i'd have is value.  I realize this place is very famous and on waits until deep into closing time even on weekends, but the price per dish felt high, compared to other tapas places around town that are just as delicious.  I would come back here in a heart beat.  Highly recommend for date night.

**Below is a list of dishes in (roughly) the order we received them.**

Olive You - This was amazing, olive loaf with whipped feta.  Highly recommend

Corn Bread - We got this because one of our party has alergy to gluten.  This was a hit at the table, but personally I much preferred the olive loaf.

Hamachi Crudo - Hands down, the least favorite at the table.  The cripsy pork belly that was served with it as a flavor enhancer was x10 better than the actual dish.  Would not recommend this.

Goat Empanadas - This dish was beyond phenomenal.  It was hard for me to decide on 2nd place for me, but this was tied with the Pork Shank  (below)

Pork Shoulder Buccatini  - My shining star....the most amazing, most delicious and most flavorful dish I've had in a very long time.  I cannot say enough good things about this dish.  My #1 by a very long shot.  I would come back here for just this dish.

Roasted Cauliflower - Exactly what you'd expect in my opinion, but with mint.  Roasted and sprinkled with pine nuts and then cooked with mint.  This was simply OK by my standards, but 2 people at our table loved it.

Chickpea Fritter -  Very tasty, but I could honestly take it or leave it next time.  It definitely hard a lot of flavors in layers, so I recommend trying it, but don't expect to be blown away.

Pan Roasted Halibut - This dish was very good.  3 out of 5 from our table labeled this as their #1 dish of the night.  Personally I thought it was cooked very well, but the real standout for this dish was the sauce it was in...a butter of some sort which I later found out was made with marcona almonds.  I think you could put that sauce on a brick and it would have made it awesome.

Grilled Baby Octopus - Unfortunately I'm not a big octopus fan, so I did not try this.  Don't sue!

Crisp Pork Shank - Tied for my second favorite with the Goat Empanadas.  This was phenomenal.  They serve it with naan, kimchee and this tangerine sauce.  Combine those together and you have fantastic flavor.

Roasted Pig Face - Alright, first of all...I ordered this because people told me "oh, you have to try it!" and I figured, hey....when in Rome.  Honestly...even without knowing what I was eating...I wasn't a huge fan.  Simply, it just didn't taste great.  The presentation is beautiful and they chopped it up for us at the table so it mixes in with the hash browns and egg.  I don't know if everyone was super full at this point or what, but no one was impressed and we even left half of it on the plate.

I was really pleased that they easily accommodated and didn't look down on me for ordering virgin cocktails and vegan food. Both were super delicious! So many vegetarian meals are a menu's afterthought. Not at Girl & the Goat. :)

And the whole thing was much less expensive than I expected for such an in-demand restaurant.

100% worth the hype. We had almost considered not coming and just going to the sister restaurant across the street bc we didn't have reservations and didnt want to wait 2+ hours, but my goddd, I'm so glad we stayed.

Prices are so reasonable and staff is hella cool. Ordered a ton of food but most memorable had to have been the calamari bruschetta... melt in your mouth freaking goodness. Such a simple dish but done so exceptionally well it blew my mind - you NEED to get this. The crisp braised pork shank was also quite a sight and delicious too. Kind of like Peking duck where you make your own "wraps" but this is with naan and you can top with kimchee slash a creamy ranch-like dressing - yummmm! If y'all visiting you absolutely have to eat here!!!!

Every time I come back here I am always open to exploring new options, and each time I am always delighted by the different flavors and presentation. I love being able to circle all of the food that we want for the table on the menu and then leave the order of their arrival up to the kitchen. It usually takes us a bit to actually get a group consensus of what items we want to try (since we usually want to try all of them) but then after we decide the only thing we have to worry about after that is being able to eat it all!

Simply walked in and got a reservation for Valentines Day 2 hours beforehand-the perks of being in the West Loop before 5pm.

Head of House will remember you by name and is prompt and informing.

Atmosphere is casual chic with trippy art and an intimate setting. The seating is cozy but enough to where you don't hear your neighbors entire conversation.

service is outstanding. Water is always filled, drinks are meticulously watched and inquired about, table is wiped down mid-meal. All the staff are very polite and friendly and eager to help you.

Style of meal is small plates. It will be suggested 2 per person for a full serving. For two people we had two entree small plates with two appetizers and a dessert and found it very filling.

Extensive wine menu though we stuck to beer and cocktails. The All Becomes One cocktail($13) is delicious with enchanting presentation.

BACON AND GOUDA BREAD W/ SMOKED LARD BUTTER AND ROMESCO: What a great appetizer for $5! Warm, fresh bread with just enough bacon and melted gouda with a flavorful lard butter and romesco, a nut and pepper spread. Yum.

HAM FRITES: These are thin, crispy fries with what seemed to be powdered ham on them with smoked tomato aioli and cheddar beer sauce. Couldn't decide which sauce was better-great upscale pub appetizer. $7

GOAT RIBS: With bombay​ duck goat jus,sun chokes,and pomegranate. Cooked medium raw, juicy, great lingering flavor. $22

BUCATANI: Pasta with milk braised pork shoulder and pickled gooseberries. Pasta was al dente, pork was succulent, pickled berries were delicious and lent themselves well to the dish but there were only a few. $16

CHOCOLATE CHOCOLATEY CAKE- What a great dessert! made with shiitake mushrooms and comes with black Dog Gelato and chocolate cake crumbs. The waitress will describe this as a deep flavor and it's not pretentious bull! The mushrooms bring out a dimension of chocolate earthyness that you will start craving...$8

We also received complimentary cream puffs post-meal!

Definitely recommend this place, just be smart. Acknowledge that the food is small plates at a higher price, ask your server questions, and your meal will be satisfying on many levels.

The girl and the goat was a Chicago experience I'm glad I didn't miss.  My fabulous boyfriend made a reservation 3weeks in advance which he said is normal for this popping Hotspot.  Everything was awesome. If you're visiting Chicago you gotta go here.  

Must orders:
--The Broccoli
--The soft shell crab
--and absolutely  you can't live without the mouthwatering PIG face dish -  pork cheeks that just melt in your mouth but is also perfectly slightly cripsy as well. Everything complements each other. This dish is just perfect.  You gotta get this.

Chicago. Day 6. Hipster dinner.

Calamari bruschetta (clam + goat ricotta + goat bacon) - 3/5
Goat empanadas (strawberry + avocado) - 4/5
Goat liver mousse (crumpets + mostardo) - 5/5
Goat confit (lobster + crab + Bourbon butter) - 4/5
Pig face (egg + tamarind + potato stix) - 4/5
Caramel corn & malt balls (black dog gelato) - 3/5

Overall, "I'm a fan."

This is one of my favorite restaurants in Chicago. The food and drinks are amazing. I am also very lactose intolerant and I find that a lot of restaurants cannot accommodate my food issues. When I went here, they took out all dairy from my dishes or put them on the side. I got the pork shank and instead of the buttermilk sauce, they substituted it with salsa. This is something the server did without me asking. I thought that was extremely nice. I highly recommend Girl and the Goat!!!
Face your fears and order something daring. I highly recommend the pig face! Their dishes can be somewhat salty, so be sure to stay hydrated with water.

If you don't have a reservation (which is impossible to get), you have the option of sitting at the bar or at the lounge.  It's called "first come, first serve".  However, there is no system to justify who first came, and who gets serve first.  It's a chaos. People end up standing behind you and watching you eat. If you choose eating at the lounge, you'll have a group of strangers share a tiny table.

Servers are nice and helpful.  The food is creative and fresh, but not deserve a second trip.
My favorite restaurant in town! Amazing experience! Order the empanadas and the Pork Shank!

Overpriced. We did not find one item that was a wow or worth a return trip. We had a Gift Certificate and still have $75 left. Doubtful we will find a reason to spend it unless we find ourselves in the area. Tried to use it at one of the sister restaurants and it was NO.

Very very disappointed.
Place is out of this world goodness. If you are a foodie and/or live or visiting the west loop Girl and the Goat should be first or second on your list.

We ordered the sauteed green beans, pork shank, pan seared scallops, goat liver mousse, and lemon make you happy. The sauteed green beans was delicious but a bit overly salty. The pork shank was tender in the middle and I understand the outside is supposed to crusted but their were some pieces which was dry then tender. The pan seared scallops was perfectly cooked. The goat liver mousse itself was okay but the accompaniments were spot on. The lemon make you happy was one of the best deserts of my life! The lemon cake was moist and dense yet fluffy. The cheesecake sauce and ice cream with the cake was a perfect combo.

Wow! Walked in without a reservation, just two of us. Told either a 1 hour wait if we wanted a table or we could sit at bar or lounge and that they serve full menu.
We lucked out and got two seats in lounge area talked to some other nice patrons and proceeded to be amazed by the service and food!
We had olive bread as a starter followed by goat empanadas, fried pig face, cauliflower and then the goat belly confit! Wow wow wow. It was all amazing would go back if I'm ever back in Chicago! The waitstaff was very attentive and answered our questions and explained the dishes. Just lovely!

From the hostess to the waiter and the servers, top notch service. The food was absolutely amazing and such great flavor combinations. The shank is a must here.  Very reasonably priced. We shared 5 plates between two of us and it was worth every penny. You will not be disappointed.

pics.caption: Short ribs with crunchy outside and melt in your mouth inside. Great flavor combination.
Empanadas with shredded goat are delicious! All the plates are great for sharing.
The green beans and cashews is delicious! Huge portion too.

review.des: Came here for my birthday dinner. We were told there was a separate vegetarian menu but there really wasn't (there's a few vegetarian options and a vegan menu). They acknowledged the birthday while seating us but I was disappointed to see they didn't really do anything about it even when we ordered dessert. Unfortunately it was an uneventful night for overpriced appetizers. One and done.
Came here for a WSJ Chef's table. The food was phenomenal, such unique mixtures of flavors, ingredients and preparations. Service was as you would expect, outstanding! Will be back for sure.
This place never disappoints. Amazing staff and phenomenal food.

I think that this may have been the best meal I have ever had. Someone I was able to get reservations for this last Saturday night. I have been a fan of Top Chef for the longest time so I was really excited to get to try some of Stephanie Izzard's creations. I was NOT disappointed.

I was greeted warmly and asked to step to the bar for a beverage while they readied my table. I ordered a "Boondock Saint" bourbon cocktail and was blown away by the flavours. It was beautifully prepared and presented.

Once we were seated, service was attentive. We were never left wanting for water, cocktails, wine... and were rarely left staring at a dirty plate. The dishes are family style, and were were told that 4 dishes will leave a party of 2 absolutely stuffed (no lies... we left with doggy bags). We tried the green beans with cashews and fish sauce aioli, the goat belly with bourbon butter sauce and lobster, the crispy pork shank, and the mussels. Everything was amazing.

I have to say, though, that THE MUSSELS WERE THE BEST THING I HAVE EVER EATEN. Full stop. I am currently salivating on my keyboard.

The atmosphere is trendy, warm, and inviting. I can't wait to go back.

pics.caption: Crisp Braised Pork Shank post deboning
Mussels with sausage croutons was the BEST THING I HAVE EVER EATEN

review.des:
Exceptional meal. Wonderful experience. The combination of flavors and how things were cooked were tremendous. If I lived here, would be a staple.

We shared, green beans, scallops, shishito peppers, pig face, empanadas. All were tremendous. I dont know how they cooked the green beans that they stayed so crisp and fresh. Its the flavors as well as the mouth feel for each dish that makes it so satisfying. Great service and fair price.
Never had a bad experience here, great food and service. Food is well thought out and skillfully prepared, seasoned perfectly. Only thing is the wait for the reservations.

My friend and I had dinner here tonight. We ordered the woodoven pork face, duck tongue, and goat belly. All were amazing and did not disappoint. Rather, they definitely surprised us in all the marriage of flavors the chef managed to pull off in each dish.

However I am giving the restaurant four stars instead of five because of the rudeness of our server. I am not sure if it's because we only ordered three entrees and not a full course meal with drinks and desert or if it's because we are two young looking Asian dudes who aren't to be taken seriously, but I felt we were mistreated. Our waiter gave us sharp remarks when we tried to be as polite as possible. When we asked for the check, he responded "one second" with an annoyed demeanor because he was helping someone else out at the moment, which we genuinely were unaware of. I just felt he could have reciprocated the same respect and gratitude that we showed.

Food: 5/5
Service: 3/5
Averaged: 4/5
Per recommendation We made reservations 3 months ago. Hyped for a good reason. Food was so good.

I've been waiting to come to this place ever since I moved to the area and finally had the chance.  Since there's already a ton of reviews on this place already, I'll try not to repeat myself too much.

It's recommended to order about 2 items per person, so I ordered 5 between my friend and I.  We ordered the hummus bread, octopus salad, broccoli, pork shank, goat belly and a couple of old fashions to drink.  This was more than plenty of food and I couldn't even think about dessert.

First, the service was extremely fast and spectacular. After ordering the food and drinks, we waited not 2 minutes before the drinks and bread came out.  The absolute stand outs were the octopus salad (incredibly balanced) and the broccoli actually.  The blue cheese never overwhelmed the perfectly grilled vegetable.

I'm also a huge lover of everything that is goat and the belly dish was by far the most goaty goat I've ever had.  It melted in your mouth.

This place definitely deserves all of the praise that it gets.  Oh yeah, the soundtrack went from Eminem, Snoop Dog, White Stripes to Weezer.  By the way, the Very Old Fashion was excellent.

Girl & the Goat serves a very competent and thought out meal. This was the restaurant we most wanted to visit on our trip to Chicago (big Top Chef/Stephanie fans) and we definitely weren't disappointed. We enjoyed everything we ate (well, almost everything) and would come back.

But there was nothing about my meal here that had an addictive property; nothing really resonated with me deeply. There was great depth of flavor in every dish, and the flavor combinations were very tasty. I'd definitely want to come back and try other items, maybe I just didn't order the right thing for me.

What I liked:
+ Pretzel bread with honey mustard/thousand island. Lots of horse radish in the sauces. Very tasty and best when eaten with both sauces together.
+ Scallop. Perfectly cooked and seared, great notes of sweetness and tasty sauce.
+ Pierogi. Delicious, but had no sweet potato flavor. You could see the orange of the sweet potato, but we didn't taste it at all. Blue cheese overpowered it, I guess. Very good regardless.
+ Grilled octopus. This was definitely my favorite dish! My gf could taste the lemon, but I wanted even MORE acid. Octopus was cooked so nicely, with great grilled flavor. This is probably the one thing I would reorder if I came back.
+ Cheesecake. Great notes of flavor in this cheesecake, almost burntish. A great finish to the meal.

Average/not great:
- Chickpea fritter. A favorite for most, and my gf seemed to like this one a lot, but it was unmemorable/average for me.
- Goat liver mousse. Our least favorite dish, we could barely eat any of it. The crumpets were fluffy and moist, but "goat" and "liver" just aren't two words that go together for me. Pickled vegetables were nice but didn't lighten up that goaty flavor. This was just a bad order decision on our part.
- Blood orange green tea. I mean... it's just tea.

A solid meal that lived up to the hype for us. Worth repeating to try everything on the menu, and definitely worth a try if you've never been. Next time we'll try Little Goat!

Solo diner so I sat at the bar which had seating available as I came in right at opening time. The service was very attentive, food was brought out quickly, one after another. I've always wanted to try out Stephanie Izard's restaurant and finally had a chance to do it. As a vegetarian, the options were limited to to the veggie side of the menu. The pierogies were really the only substantial item but the fact that I sampled various dishes and desserts was filling in itself. Great combo of unique flavors and textures. They were able to plate mini portions. Nice one-time experience but wouldn't go out of my way to come back.

pics.caption: Olive Yu(zu) Focaccia (Yuzu oil and chipotle butter)
Lemon Make You Happy (lemon pound cake with sorrel ice cream)

review.des: Incredible! We ordered several small plates to share and dish after dish was amazing! Definitely worth the hype.

Wow. Huge kudos to the Girl & the Goat for perfecting so many dishes. While it was difficult for us to get a dinner reservation, we were happy going to the bar/lounge for first come/first serve seating. We sat on the comfy couches in the bar/lounge and did not have to wait a minute to get sat!

Calamari Bruschetta- MUST get. Wow. This bruschetta was out of this world and was an amazing way to start our meal. Generous portions of a soft baguette, topped with soft goat milk ricotta and well-cooked calamari on top. The flavors of the goat bacon bits with the calamari with the green tomato, all worked SO well together.

Roasted Cauliflower- MUST get. Probably some of the best cauliflower I've ever had. Flagrant cauliflower baked to perfection with the mint leaves and accompanied by a nice crunch of the pine nuts.

Roasted Pig Face- MUST get. Definitely lives up to the hype. This signature dish worked so well to have the crunch of the potato sticks, mixed in with the wonderfully tender pork and perfect sunny side up egg. Recommend chopping and mixing everything together to taste the beautiful marriage of flavors!

Grilled Baby Octopus- Very interesting dish with an adventure of flavors. Each bite held something new in store, whether it was the soft grilled baby octopus, crunchy pistachio bits, or smooth flava beans and bean tips. Don't think I'd order this again but was great to try!

Caramel Corn & Malt Balls- MUST get. If you're a dessert lover, this is the dessert for you. Three scoops of gelato come covered in hardened chocolate, accompanied with flattened caramel popcorn bites, and caramel bits. Even if you're stuffed from your meal, you're going to want to try this out! Paired perfectly with a hot glass of coffee.

Having returned and eaten a few more times and many more dishes, I think it appropriate to give Girl and the Goat a third star.  Many of the same complaints still exist (overly salty dishes, veggies outperforming the meat) but there are some diamonds in the rough.  The halibut is freaking amazing and a reason on its own to go to Girl and the Goat.  The Pork Shank, with buttermilk dressing and kimchi toppings is an incredible flavor pairing that isn't over the top.  And the Goat Empanadas are succulent and well seasoned.  I'd also like to mention the Goat Liver Mousse, which comes with fresh-baked rolls, very crispy yet very heavy.

The chili elotes underneath the soft shell crab are much more interesting than the crab itself.  The beef tongue is like a sausage, and I would not have thought the goat loin was goat.  So it depends on what you are looking for and what dishes you order.
It was AMAZING!! Definitely lives up to the hype - the food was all so so good, the waitstaff friendly and knowledgeable, the vibe fun... it's my favorite and I can't wait to be back!

Ah fucking mazing!

Literally booked a last minute reservation on Open Table, and got in for a late night dinner with my cousin. We were both visiting for California, so I wanted to grab some exquisite dinner that I was referred to.

IMPECCABLE service and food.

Beware that all the food is well seasoned! Flavor might be too overwhelming that you catch yourself drinking a whole LOT of water. I kind of felt bad that they kept having to come back to refill our drinks. I just wanted to tell them to leave the bottle of water at the table.

I kind of over ordered, but I did not care since it was delicious.

If you are wondering what to order, the 5 items below will DEFINITELY not fail you!
- Crisp Braised Pork Shank
- Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face
- Calamari Bruschetta
- Miso Hungry Bread
- Pan fried shishito peppers (this might fail you, it was debatable)

I secured a reservation to this restaurant months in advance, and my expectations were so high. Unfortunately the food didn't live up to them. I tried the goat empanadas, green beans, pig's face, and chocolate cake with shiitake gelato. My favorite was the green beans. These were absolutely perfect!
