The empanadas were ok - the pickled mushrooms kind of overtook the dish. And the pig's face was good, but it was also really salty. The chocolate cake was good, but the gelato ruined it. I love mushrooms, but the shiitake flavor was way too strong! It was definitely the weirdest gelato flavor I've tried, and I don't think it worked.

The service was great, though. Our server crossed off everything on the menu that I couldn't order due to allergies. He also checked up on us quite a bit. The ambience is great, too.

It was a challenge to get a table for 4 at here. I booked a table at 6:15pm on Sunday eventaully (yep, lots monitoring there) after we went to a concert in the afternoon.

Both food and services were excellent. The tables would be small if all dishes come out at the same time. However it works out tonight as we cleared out one by one quickly...

Please keep in mind that all 4 of us have the Asian taste buds so this could be a bit biased. Here we go:

Must have: Pig face- the famous pig face was a very good explaination of Girl and the Goat food-surprising and delicious combination of flavors and textures. The pig face was roasted to very tender mixing with running yolk, potato stick and cilantro sauce to bring the fun combination in the month with soft tasted meat (or fat) and crisp potato sticks. I love it. This dish should be very good for your skin per my mom which is a bonus

Duck tongue was fried duck tongue with Tuna Poke, crispy wontons and some (pickled or processed) black beans. Again those mixed flavors and textures gave me a different way to think how the stuff should be cooked and put in a dish together. I never thought Tuna Poke would go so well with duck tongue. I came from a city in China which is famous for salted duck and a whole variety of duck dishes. Duck tongue is also a local delicate. This dish was be praised by my folks at the table which means it was awesome.

Roasted drum fish was Spicy! Not only with the hot peppers and lots of peppercorns. It was roasted perfectly with the brownish crust on the top layer. It looked harmless with the apples slices, sesame seeds and green veggies on the top. Remember to get the yogurt on the buttom. I had a bit cough so didn't get a lot. Have to eat it again. BTW, Halibut was not available due to the season.

Nice to have : Bread is not free. For $5 per serving, we all liked Miso bread. Olive you was good too.
Wood fired oyster was pretty good. Others were thinking those were too fishy. I liked it.
Roasted cauliflower were great too with pickled peppers and pine nuts. I love the roasted and crunchy veggies so this is my dish. I guess my mom didn't like the cheese or peppers.

Might pass next time: Escargot dumplings was good. Maybe I was used to the French style buttery escargot. So when the escarole came out the wraper without any extra flavor or sauce, I was a bit disppointed. Plus I'm not a fan of onions.

We got the pinot noir with our meal which was great. I like our waitress who always appeared at the right time. The bus boy was so nice to refill up my mom's hot water withou asking. An excellent dinner for us indeed. I'm coming back in 4 weeks so will try more dishes for sure.

The food is near perfect. Atmosphere is great. You'll need reservations far in advance, but the experience is worth it. Goat brand restaurants are some of the finest cuisine in Chicago. Try the pig face. You won't regret it.

I LOVED GIRL AND THE GOAT!! I know this place is super booked and needs a reservation booked ahead of time, but my sister and I were in Chicago for a quick weekend trip and we HAD to try it. So we came before doors even open. Luckily, we were able to get seating at the bar. Our waiter was very chill and explained what the popular items were. We took his word for it and ordered:
-Pork Shank (So tender and delicious)
-Goat Belly
-Gouda and Bacon spread with bread (simple appetizer but I loved the spread)
-Grilled Octopus

We also ordered a fish dish and dessert, however I do not recall what they're called :/
BUTT honestly everything was so delicious! Everything was super flavorful and unique in it's own way but not overbearing flavor. I really enjoyed my dining experience here and I'm so glad we were able to experience what all the hype was about! Definitely worth it :) A must try in Chicago! Make sure you make those reservations though.

This place is definitely worth the wait! Anytime friends come into the city or anyone ask for a restaurant recommendation this is the place I mention. Every dish is crafted perfectly. I recently had the roasted beets, grilled pork belly, braised beef tongue, and olive yu(zu) focaccia. 13/10 recommend

For a restaurant this popular I could tell it was less than average. First of all our waitress was so rude and impolite. She was like she wants to get ride of us as soon as possible and when we asked her the same question two times she got so pissed and said in a rude way I just told you! I wish I remembered her name and would mention it here. The food was so creative but the portions were sooooooo small! But the was a lot of creativity in the food for sure.
Somewhat inconsistent from dish to dish although overall a good experience. Dessert was my favorite especially the lemon poppy cake. Also the lamb ribs were incredible.

The food was divine but the service was hurried and uncomfortable.

We walked in at opening hour and were told we could get a table but there was a reservation at 6:15 so we'd have to be gone by then. We figured almost two hours to eat.... no problem. We were rushed through a five course meal like crazy. They brought us each plate before we could finish the one before it. It really ruined the experience for us.  

Amazingly, we were in and out of the restaurant in less than 35 minutes. We appreciated being squeezed in but rushing through it was just unnecessary and made us really uncomfortable.

Full disclosure: I came here a few years ago. I forgot to Yelp and saw a question in my feed today, "Have you been to Girl & the Goat?" I have!

I was visiting from LA for a "Siblings Weekend" because my siblings and I do cool stuff like that, and we all were excited to try this place out. We arrived two hours before our reservation, which sounds crazy, but, believe me, it was completely necessary. We had a drink at the bar and hoped we would somehow miraculously get sat early.

There was this awesome woman milling about the floor making sure people were happy. She got stopped-up by us because we were all rapping about awesome stuff and it distracted her (or maybe this is something she does - it's cool). That's when we learned that miracles do happen!

This woman happened to the be the manager at the time (not sure who is there now), and she got us sat an hour and a half before our reservation (which we were forced to make because this place is so busy - waiting list and such). That's service, dude! Not sure if it had anything to do with being an AMEX special client, but let's just pretend that it's because we and she are good humans.

Food: Just alright. Maybe it was the hype. Maybe it was the fact that our mom is a chef without a restaurant and I would rather have been eating her food, but we didn't get blown away. Really, we are a family of great cooks, so when we eat out, we're particularly critical (constructively!). And I guess that I expected more from this Top Chef Champion. I mean, Top Chef! The food was good, okay? It was. No major complaints. It just wasn't "YAAAAAS!" Could be because "YAAAAAS!" did not yet exist when I went here.

Ambiance is great. The crowd is bustling and energetic. You feel like you're in a special, happy place here.

Go here, you'll enjoy it. Thousands of people do. I'm a food snob sometimes, so I'm snobbing it up a little right now - sorry, not sorry. Overall, great experience. GREAT service! Just truly GREAT.

My first trip to Chicago and my friend and I managed to get a seat outside right away. Points there just for that considering the wait was over an hour and a half inside.

We had a fun group near us, our waiter was great, the food and cocktails were to.die.for. Only passed on dessert due to sheer lack of room.

I would plan an eating trip back to Chicago just for another fun and amazing dinner.

Yum! Finally got to check this one off my restaurant bucket list. My husband and I tried the olive you bread to start (4 pieces of warm flaky bread with delicious whipped feta spread and super olive-y olive oil). We followed that up with chickpea fritters (my favorite!!! I wish I could eat these every day. Can I come in again and order about 10 plates of these?!). These have about 6 pieces of deep fried chickpea goodness with tons of flavorful sauces and veggies. We tried the ham frites next. These were delicious (fries covered in tiny bits of ham and severed with beer cheese sauce and tomato aioli) but very very salty. Finally, we tried the pork shank. We couldn't decide pig face vs pork shank but are glad we went with the shank. It was a ton of food and served with homemade naan bread and dipping sauces. The two of us were stuffed after this!! We even had leftovers.

Prices were better than I imagine and portion sizes were bigger than I imaged.

My only complaint was the service was a bit slow (took around 10 minutes for anyone to greet us at the table) and the crowded tables. If you come with a group of 4 or more, the table sizes look better with more room. The 2 person tables are very cramped.

pics.caption: Ham frites, pork shank, chickpea fritter

review.des:
I'll try to keep this short since what hasn't been already said about Girl & the Goat?  

The restaurant is a located in a small, trendy part of town, and the buzzy atmosphere inside matched.  If you are looking for a quiet place to dine, please look elsewhere.  The acoustics in the room are awful and I had a hard time hearing my boyfriend across from me, but I enjoyed the boisterous atmosphere.   We got there a little before our reservations and had to wait a bit for our table.  Yes, it's that busy, so reservations are HIGHLY recommended.  

I really wanted to love this place, but the food was a big letdown.  Maybe I shouldn't have read all the reviews on Yelp, which had gotten my hopes way up.  We did not go to the Art Institute or Chinatown because we had to make the reservation; that's how high my expectations were.  The restaurant is tapas-style, so we ordered a bunch of little plates.  The wood-fired oysters were great, but the remainder of the meal like the bread and empanadas were lackluster.  

If you want to cool place to get drinks and relax for friends, Girl & the Goat may be a good option.  Otherwise, I think I'll skip Girl & the Goat for the Art Institute next time.

The best option is to come with a small group and share everything you order. The waiter service is professional with their manners and knowledge of the food. Our waitress recommended everything and she was right. The food came to our table one by one from light to heavy dishes.

Must tries: pig's face, pork shank, and the raw oysters

The Pig's Face was my personal favorite because of the hearty flavoring. The pork shank was so tendor. As soon as the waiter stabbed a fork into it, the meat fell apart immediately. The raw oysters had a sauce on top that made it one of the best raw oysters I've ever had.

Remember to make reservations months in advance or go right when they open to get open seating!

The food is just ok...not wildly delicious...just fine. Service is fast and friendly. The cost is up there...valet parking... I don't want to diss this place but there are better options considering the price point.

I went here on a monday night and this place was packed. My parents and I wanted wine and tapas style food. This is the place to go! Be warned this is not a traditional tapas place, they serve unique types of tapas. I loved the different types of food they offered.

We got the escargot ravioli, braised beef tongue (My fave), wood oven roasted pig face, pork shank, raw kusshi, fried old 1871, and confit goat belly (2nd best). Oh and 2 bottles of wine.

I can definitely see myself coming again for some drinks and tapas.

With a very high expectation and a long wait time for reservation, the foods were just okay when finally seated at restaurant. Every dish was decorated in an exceptionally complicated way, though all tasted not bad. I just personally feel they are trying a bit too hard to make the dishes look creative and pretty. I would prefer something looks simple and clean. That being said, foods tasted not bad.

Great vibe. Amazing service. The food is so creative and bursting with flavor. The chickpea fritters were moist with a light exterior crispness. We ordered 4 plates and 2 desserts, which was too much for the 2 of us but we wanted to try a variety of dishes; things we have never cooked. Escargot ravioli, tongue, branzino. All were cooked to perfection with various sauces and vegetables. Our server also brought out complementary empanadas that were delicious. Chocolate meringue with ice cream, lemon pound cake with sorel ice cream and a complementary rhubarb crisp. If you are a foodie you need to eat here. You will not be disappointed. Our bill which included 2 glasses of wine totaled $135 not including tip. Very reasonable for what you get.

Girl & the Goat is one of the best restaurants In Chicago. We were lucky enough to snag a last minute reservation for dinner (at 11:30 pm). If you are headed to Chicago, make sure you make reservations in advance because this place is usually booked solid.  I have to start by saying, I'm a huge goat lover. I mean, I want a big enough property to be able to own some as pets. But I couldn't pass up the opportunity to try one of their many goat options. We opted for the goat belly. It was melt in your mouth delicious. We also tried several other menu items (which no goats were harmed in the making) and they were all amazing. The cauliflower was the most amazing cauliflower dish I've ever had. The halibut was out of this world. The hamachi was light and refreshing but also delicious. The only issue I had was the speed at which our food was coming out. It felt rushed but I bet that has to do with the fact that we had a reservation time right before closing.  I do wonder if earlier reservations felt rushed. Overall, one of the best restaurants we've been to and totally worth the hype.

This place is incredible! One of the best meals I've had in Chicago. The food, service, and ambiance were all excellent. We came here for our anniversary dinner and it couldn't have been a more perfect place for the occasion. We ordered the brioche bread with honey butter which was delicious! We also got the goat empanadas, chickpea fritter, grilled yellow fish tuna, and wood oven roasted pig face. Everything was really well done and the flavors were all unique. Highly recommend the goat empanadas and the chickpea fritter! For desert we ordered the tiramisu which was ok. They surprised us with a mini peanut butter jellyfish desert for our anniversary (which my boyfriend loved - he loves peanut butter so it was perfect for him)! The service was great. Our waitress was attentive and checked up on us frequently. Girl and the goat is pricey and plates are small but for such a nice place with such great flavors, it's worth it!

Girl & the Goat is a Chicago staple and a visit is certainly warranted by domestic diners and those visiting although some advance planning is required (OR luck with a last minute reservation for an obscure time like 9:00pm on a Tuesday).

I digress. Starting with refreshments, the Bolt Action cocktail was akin to a Kentucky Mule with a refreshing mix of bourbon, ginger beer, and citrus.

When it comes to dining here, the portions are small so our waiter recommended we order three dishes each. We opted for 5, which left space for dessert, and ultimately got the following:
-Pork Shoulder Buccatini
-Crispy Beef Short Ribs
-Goat Empanadas
-Crisp Pork Shank
-Pig Face
-All the leches (dessert)

Everything was amazing. If I were to do it over again, we'd probably choose another dessert only b/c the Mrs and I are not big tres leches fans, in general.

Came here for drinks. It was so packed on a Friday night.
They do make some amazing drinks.
The place looks so nice from the inside.
I will definitely come back again.

As I type this, there are over 6,000 reviews of the Girl and the Goat. There's little I can add that will make any difference to the overall body of information available about this amazing restaurant.

I will simply say this: do not be intimidated by the menu. There are things here that you have likely never eaten before. They are combinations of foods that you have eaten that may not seem to make sense, but the flavors will come together in ways that Will surprise you. Everything is incredibly flavorful but not overpowering.

Bring your wallet and bring your sense of adventure because you will need them both but it is well worth your time and money.
Perfect dining experience, every time. Love the green beans, that in itself is a reason to visit. Delicious plates, great drinks and the ambiance is cool but welcoming.
I'd been wanting to try this place for years and it lived up to the hype. Delicious food and delicious drinks. But be sure you make your reservation well in advance.

Girl & the Goat continues to be a West Loop hot spot for a reason. However, make sure you have reservations or you will be smooshed at the the bar with lots of people trying to order drinks behind you. The food is always delicious - make sure to trust your sever on their recommendations and flow of items!

Absolutely fantastic from start to finish!  Knowledgeable and attentive staff, such attention to detail, creative and mouthwatering dishes with lots of gluten-free options, and a hip atmosphere.  Be sure to make a reservation or I can only imagine what the wait time will be!
Well the green beans were absolutely fantastic to my taste, empanadas delicious, scallops perfectly cook, wow love this place. Should try it if you ever in town.
Salty and the pig face was really overhyped. The other foods were good like the octopus and shishiito peppers and cauliflower. Maybe I just heard too much about it and had super high expectations.
very hard to get reservations for but a very popular resturant, just wasn't my cup of tea but my husband loved it, different strokes for different folks, try it for yourself‍

pics.caption: he liked it that's all that matter he wanted to go there anyway!

review.des:
Creative yet unfussy food. Lovely environment and extremely attentive service. All in all, an excellent meal.

Was able to make a same day reservation by obsessively checking opentable for last minute cancellations. tbh I think this happens often because my friend was also able to snag a same day reservation a few days prior.

I really liked the restaurant interior, it feels trendy (rustic chic?), but open, spacious and comfortable. And I loved how interesting / creative all the food was - everything has a twist of some sort, and yet the food didn't feel too "fussed over."

We tried:

Kohlrabi salad (fennel, evalon, toasted almonds, roasted shiitake, apples) - Simple, flavorful and yummy. Came tossed with a white dressing, which I'm usually not a fan of, but this was light and not overwhelming and really complemented the flavors of the salad.

Goat carpaccio (smoked trout roe, olive-maple vinaigrette) - Sharp acid / vinegar flavor that honestly made it impossible for me to tell that I was eating goat. Smoked trout roe was a nice touch, adding a pop of brininess to the vinegar flavors.

Roasted cauliflower (pickled peppers, pine nuts, mint) - A favorite of the night. Sounds so simple but was so yummy. The pickled peppers really added a unique flavor dimension to this dish that worked super well.

Seared diver scallops (toasted miso-brown butter aioli, blood orange, smoked beet, pistachio) - My favorite dish of the night! Perfectly seared scallops and the blood orange was a surprise pairing that I had never had with scallops before and that once again just worked.

Escargot ravioli (bacon tamarind sauce, escarole & celery, crispy onions) - Sounds very interesting in concept, but in execution, I felt like I could barely taste the escargot wrapped inside, and instead was mostly just eating the pasta wrapper.

Wood oven roasted pig face (sunny side egg, tamarind, cilantro, red wine-maple, potato stix) - Don't worry this is not a whole pig's head - more like pulled pork meat mixed with egg. Was told I HAD to get this, but honestly might have been my least favorite dish of the night. It was fine, but too heavy, and not really to my tastes.

Sticky tasty crunchy toffee yummy cake (sweet potato cake . toffee sauce & crunch . brown butterscotch ice cream . gooseberry) - Even dessert was a hit! The sweet potato cake was moist and delicious and the ice scream was pretty awesome - very distinctly salted, but once again it worked, and it was quickly devoured by my dining companions (though tbh I'm not a fan of butterscotch and found the ice cream a too sweet).

Also want to give a shout out to the service - possibly some of the best service I've ever encountered. Warm, and always there if you needed anything (my water glass was never empty), but not hovering to the point that you're uncomfortable.

Wonderfully eclectic menu at this, one of our favorite Chicago haunts!

Do the wise thing and let your waiter or waitress pick the very best items for you. (The menu here changes ALL THE TIME.)

Be even wiser yet and have everyone in your part share the different dishes family style. (Trust me -- this place practically BEGS for that!)

Terrific ambience.
Charming decor.
Stellar service.

Getting a reservation here took an act of Congress, though -- we hated that part. (It really "got my goat, girl.")
The plating was beautiful.. But I have to honestly agree with a lot of the reviews, they put too much salt in their dishes! And soy sauce!

pics.caption: Their famous dish- pig's face. This is an honest review. No bias. I could taste the fattiness of the pig's face which was good.
Escargot ravioli- escarole, bacon tamarind sauce, crispy onions-- i wanted more!! but tbh, i couldn't taste the escargot.

review.des:
The ambiance is sophisticated and trendy. It is a perfect place for a date or to catch up with good friends.

Their meals and the order in which they're served are carefully crafted and planned out. The dishes will arrive one by one how the chef wants them to.

The octopus salad was very good. The octopus was tender and the pine nuts were a great compliment to the dish.

The empanadas came next and it was SOOO DELICIOUS. The goat was not gamey at all. The hot crispy empanada, sauce, mint, shredded cheese, and goat cheese complemented the dish perfectly. All the ingredients worked in such harmony to create a perfect appetizer.

The goat belly and lobster was on the special menu for the day and it was tender and crispy. The dish only came with one slice of goat belly, about four inches long, with pieces of lobster. I liked the ingredients individually but I did not like the butterscotch sauce it came swimming in.

I wasn't too impressed with the Roasted Cauliflower but I appreciated the pine nuts and thin pickled pepper slices. I felt like the dish lacked flavor.

Overall it was a great experience and I would return for drinks and a light snack.

pics.caption: Goat empanada. It was very good and not gamey.
Baby octopus salad. Very tender and good but a lot of acidity in the sauce.
Goat belly with lobster radish and micro greens.

review.des: Amazing food and awesome atmosphere. Best meal we had in Chicago. The shrimp and peanut dumpling were my favorite. We tried the chicken fried rice, meat wonton soup and noodles. Everything was delicious

I wish we didn't have to make reservations and
I wish there was more than one location.
We ordered based on the waiters recommendations and what initially caught our attention.  
Everything we had was amazing!  
sautéed green beans, roasted beets, wood oven roasted pig face and goat empanadas
Can't wait to go back and try more!

Carne here for our 10 year anniversary!

10:45 reservation,  and the place was packed on a Wednesday. Dinner here capped off a wonderful evening,  and honestly was the best meal we have ever had.  Service,  ambiance and food were all excellent.  Even with a fairly lofty reputation,  I think they exceeded our expectations and  wowed us at every turn.

Thank you!
This place has really nice atmosphere. Great cocktails, nice music and friendly staff. I would say pig's face is overrated.Go for the clams bruschetta!! We loved it.

I'm going to start off by saying that this has been the best overall dining experience in Chicago thus far.  This restaurant was highly recommended by a lot of my friends.  I was not family with Chef Izard (from Top Chef) so I wasn't aware of the hype.  I made reservations approximately 1 month in advance for a party of 2 and got a slot at 6:45pm on Friday.  We got there and the place was packed.
Ambiance:  Typical hip/trendy restaurant.  Place was packed.  Volume was moderate but able to hold a conversation.  Tables are pretty close to each other.  Made it difficult to not check out what they other people were all eating.  There were a couple big tables that I saw that could accommodate up to 8 people.  Love the open kitchen.  Bar area was packed as well.  I think you don't need reservation for that area.  
Service:  Fantastic.  We were approached right away by our server.  He was pretty thorough in his explanation.  He requested that we ordered everything up front and he would organize how to bring it out.  Since the food portion was smaller, it was nice not to have all the things come out at once.  The pace of service was really good.  Dishes were cleared right away and water was refilled in a timely fashion.  A+ for service
Food:  Difficult to explain the flavor.  Most of the dishes were really complexed and had a lot of ingredients, but when eaten together worked...Between the 2 of us, we polished off 6 dishes +dessert.  We started off with the Shishito peppers.  They were covered with parmesan cheese and tasted amazing.  None of them were spicy at all.  Best prep of the peppers I have ever had.  Next the Hamachi Crudo...not your typical crudo as it was paired with crispy pork belly.  So it didn't have the clean flavor that I expected but was finished with a pretty salty component.  Eaten separately, they tasted weird, but when eaten together was pretty darn good.  We had some baked oysters (also had bacon on top) that were pretty good.  My favorite dish was the calamari bruschetta.  The calamari was not fried (as I would expected) but was cooked in a butter of sorts.  They you have the bruschetta with goat ricotta and goat bacon and the green apple...when eaten together was one of the most amazing bites I have had.  The saltiness, creaminess, and sweetness all blended together.  So good.  We then had the lamb ribs...I have never had lamb prepared like a bbq pork rib before.  There were 4 pieces of the most tender ribs I have had.  Covered with a blueberry bbq sauce (sweeter side).  Definition of finger licking good!  Finally we had the goat belly confit.  This was served with fennel, crab, lobster, and a bunch of other things.  Meat was super tender.  Flavor was good, but I thought it had a tad too many components.  With both the goat and lamb, neither tasted gamey at all.

All in all, an amazing dining experience.  I would highly recommend for all to try.

Wow! Just wow! Showed up about 30 minutes after they opened and the wait was already an hour and a half. Being that I was determined, I put my name down. We were kindly informed that we could also wait for a spot at the bar. Those were all first come first served status so I was looking like a hawk for a spot. Soon enough one opened and we took over. We ordered the duck tongue which is actually tuna with some black bean poke, sprinkled with piri piri seasoning and some wonton strips to add a different texture to the bites. We were feeling ready for an adventure so we also decided to share an order of goat liver mousse.. yup... you read that right! goat liver!! I will say that alone, it does have a VERY strong taste, way too strong for me but when I paired it with the side dip sauces: apple butter, basil lemon pickles or the pickled watermelon rind, it was just right. The liver mousse didn't taste bad which any of them but if I had to choose one of the sauces I would go for the basil lemon pickles. Being that we had been eating all day, this was a perfect place for a quick mid day snack. I would love to totally come back here again! I regretted not getting all the leches cake for dessert. I opted for a cocktail.

I would highly recommend sharing plates; they are all small portions and it would be great to try everything on the menu!

#65/2016

After so much hype surrounding this restaurant, I couldn't help but expect nothing less than the best. I was sorely disappointed. My friends and I were not able to make reservations before our trip to Chicago, so we decided to put our name down and wait at a near-by bar for 2-3 hours. After waiting for so long, you could say we were a bit hangry. We opted to share everything to get a better taste of their menu. For the 6 of us, we ordered 13 dishes, which I listed below with my opinion of each.

Beets (4/5) - beets were flavorful and dish was light
Hamachi Crudo (4/5) - fish tasted fresh
Shishito Peppers (3/5) - just average and something that could be made at home
Beef Spare Ribs (1/5) - dry and seasoning???
Chickpea Fritters (2/5) - meh
Beef Tongue (3/5) - interesting
Scallops (5/5) - cooked perfectly, we ended up ordering another one of this
Shrimp (2/5) - not a fan, slightly over cooked
Octopus (1/5) - too chewy for my preference
Goat Ribs (0/5) - do not ever order this, I took one bite and refused to eat any other, terrible flavors
Pig Face (4/5) - unique

We also ordered some sort of dessert, which I forgot. We asked our waitress for suggestions on what to order/ what was popular here. I cannot believed she highly recommended the the Goat Ribs. It was so gross. The 6 of us couldn't even finish it and didn't even bother to take it to-go. On top of the meh food, the service wasn't that great either. We had to flag down waiters several times because we needed things. I really wish I didn't spend so much money on my mediocre meal here.

This place was the bomb! We showed up without reservations and found a place at the bar. The server suggested we get 8 plates between four of us. That was spot on - every dish was flavorful, different and well presented. The cocktails were super as well. Highly recommend this place if I'm Chicago

We got a same day 7:30pm reservation here for 2 on a Friday night - so surprised that this was available so we had to take it (assuming someone cancelled last minute as its so hard to get reservations here ever!). We got seated at one of the 2 chef's tables and got to discuss food with the chef's while we ate.

We got the roasted cauliflower, pig face, goat empanadas, one of the 'breads' (can't remember which), and a yummy malt dessert. We also tried several awesome cocktails.

Overall, price here is definitely reasonable and food is great! Restaurant vibe is pretty laid back but definitely nice - the restaurant itself does get pretty noisy, but that doesn't bother us. Go here if you get a chance!

Amazing- we tried like half of the menu when my uncle was in town and took me and some friends to dinner. Every single item was so good and every dish was unique/creative. The atmosphere was great as well!

O. M. G. Yum!! Excellent service and a fun, vibrant and trendy spot with a pleasantly loud buzz of patron chatter, even at 10pm. Seriously - before you dig in, you've gotta try the new Cabernet on the wine list (Errazuriz. Max. 2014. Aconcagua)

What was on my plate?
- roasted beets | green beans. white anchovy. avocado creme fraiche. bread crumb (tasty, but nothing remarkable)
- goat empanadas | miso-blue cheese aioli. squash-apple slaw (sooo good)
- confit goat belly | bourbon butter . lobster and crab . fennel (fantastically rich!)
- caramel corn & malt balls | vanilla malt gelato. popcorn caramel. chocolate magic shell (I should have ordered the full size, enough said)

Such a wonderful meal and experience after a long plane ride. Can't wait to bring husband back.

confit goat belly bourbon butter. lobster and crab. fennel
caramel corn & malt balls vanilla malt gelato. popcorn caramel. chocolate magic shell

review.des: One of my favorite restaurants. Came here for a friend's birthday and really enjoyed everything, including: roasted cauliflower with pickled peppers, pine nuts, and mint; wood oven roasted pig face with sunny side egg, tamarind, cilantro, red wine-maple, potato stix; duck tongues with tuna and black bean poke, crispy wontons, piri piri; chickpea fritter with garam masala yogurt, sugar snap peas, baby squash, sheep's feta, and sev; a chicken entree (I can't remember), and the seasonal goat + blackberry entree. What I really love about this place is that they are so innovative and draw from so many different cuisines while still staying truly American. Food is incredibly tasting and ambiance is very Chicago. Love it and highly recommend.

The food was a bit above average, but we found a strand of hair in the pig face.

We ordered three dishes, the roasted pig face, the goat liver mousse, and the goat confit.

The first dish that we got was the pig face. It was delicious; the pig face was well seasoned and cooked. I liked the crunchy noodles that they put for texture. The sauces were great. I like how they were sweet and tangy to cut the saltiness of the pig face. But we discovered a strand of hair afterward which is really unacceptable for this type of restaurant.

The second dish was the goat liver. I was way too cloy after trying to finish the dish. The liver mousse was already very oily, and they also gave you greasy crumpets which cooked with pork fat! At least they were trying to help with the situation by providing you with different sour condiments like marmalade and pickles.

The last one was the confit. We loved it! I think they have done a very good job putting different things together like crab meat, lobster, and goat. I like the creaminess and sweetness of the sauce. It complimented the meat really well.

Our server, Shikaya, was very nice and friendly. She helped us with the hair situation very well.

I would not recommend this place.

Amazing food. Great dining experience...if you can get a reservation!
Also the diner has the same chef with more casual food but much easier to get in.

I cannot say enough good things about my dining experience here to so it justice. Yes, it is expensive but believe me it is all well worth it. Impeccable service, delectable food, and a trendy environment. I'll be back 100 times over. Do yourself a favor and get the short ribs. Easily the best dish I have ever had. M

This is an amazing experience in dining! A great bar, wonderful dishes , and the baking is over the top! If you are looking to expand your ideas around nest, this is the place! Crowded noisy bar, great wait staff. Superb

Not sure about the hype and the difficulty getting reservations. Ordered all the "favorite hits" off the menu as suggested by friends and Yelp. Everything was overly seasoned and salty. I prefer sister casual dining establishment, Little Goat to this place. I'm glad I got to go once but won't be returning in the near future.

Amazing food, well worth the hype.

We came on a Friday night, unable to snag a reservation ahead of time, but we didn't mind waiting. We put our name down at 7PM, and were told our table would be ready in 2 hours, so we left and came back at 9PM. What's great is that even if they call your name before you come back, they'll leave you on the top of the wait list.

They seated us in front of the kitchen, which was a pretty cool experience because you could see the chefs make the food right in front of you. We ordered 4 items, each ranging $15-$20 (except the bread). Note: bread is not complimentary but it is a must-have.

*Bread (Miso Hungy): the best bread I have ever had - it is light and fluffy and slightly toasted and the miso butter/kimchi relish was surprisingly an AMAZING combination; would give the bread 11/10 hands down

*Pan Roasted Halibut: I was not expecting much, but this dish absolutely blew me away; it was so flavorful and everything was perfectly balanced, leaving me wanting more

*Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face: good, but did not really meet my expectations; the meat was tender and the egg was cooked perfectly, but the entire dish tasted a little bland to me especially after trying the halibut

*Goat Belly: the meat was tender but not very flavorful; the lobster that came with the dish tasted better in my opinion but the entire dish was very buttery and a bit overwhelming and underwhelming at the same time

Overall, I had a great experience and would recommend this place to anyone.
The rumors are true.  This place is worth a special trip.

Girl and the Goat was a pretty good experience - food tasted good and service was great. I'm a bit confused where the hype comes from, though, to be honest. I didn't particularly feel like the flavors or ingredients were SO unique to warrant the ridiculous wait/reservation times or the pretty high pricing. My feeling is that it's a bit overpriced and not as interesting as I'd hoped for - again, a really solid restaurant but not somewhere that sticks out to me in my mind when I think back.

We got there about 10 mins after they opened and had to stand for 2 hours just to get a spot at the bar. Yes it was a Saturday night and we didn't have a reservation, but the fact that they didn't even have a place for us to sit and wait bothered me.

I cheered up a bit once we finally got a seat. We ordered the Olive You from the bread menu which was good. For our main dishes, we got the broccoli, mussels, and pork shank, all of which were excellent. We got espresso and goat cheesecake for desert which were also delicious. We both had a few mixed drinks with our meal too.

Overall, I would come back for the food but the wait was ridiculous especially because we tried to make reservations over a month in advance and they were already booked. We were told they took walk ins but even though we arrived at 4:30 when they opened, the wait was 4 hours already.
Great ambience, very tasty food, and great customer service! I dined here for a business meeting and it definitely did meet my expectations!

The pig face dish alone gives this restaurant a 5-star! It's a MUST get! There's crispy fried hash brown with pork cheek, yummy sauce, and a sunny side up egg. To die for!

One of these days, I will return with a bigger party and order the goat leg :-)
One of the best meals I've had in Chicago to date. I've been here for seven years. Excellent drinks, service and food is just ahhhh. I will definitely go back!

Amazingly great all around - food/service/ambience! Have never been to a restaurant where every dish was devoured and loved, even with picky eaters. We had a special tasting menu. They hit this out if the park, can't wait to come back. MUST GO!! And must make reservations far in advance!
Delicious. Delightful.  Memorable. Expensive.  Worth it.

My favorite place to eat a meal, ever, in the whole world.

Chef Izard and her team have created a truly wonderful restaurant. Fun, intimate, lively, creative - every meal I've enjoyed here has been delicious, entertaining, interesting, and unique.

The staff are spunky & friendly, the atmosphere inviting, the dishes delectable (and seriously, affordable). Make a reservation, for sure. Or, if you feel adventurous, show up solo or with one companion and make a rush for the bar when they open. (It can be done!)

Can't wait until next time.

As I was approaching my 50th bday, we were looking for a great place to have a good meal together on my birthday.  Yelp reviews and The Infatuation helped us narrow it down to a handful of options, including Girl & the Goat.  Boy, am I happy with picked this spot!!!

We made our reservation 6-8 weeks in advance for a weeknight right in the middle of the holidays and had some decent options, but it was definitely starting to book up.

When we arrived, our table was ready within 5 mins of the reserved time, and we had lots of space for our party of 5 people.  The place was hopping with a great buzz set to an ATCQ score.  Loved seeing the kitchen's fires on one wall and the view to the street in holiday lights on the other. Super setting!!

Our server was super-helpful and friendly, without being overbearing or butting in as an uninvited member of our party.  He helped my sister navigate the gluten free menu supplement in a really delightful way.

As for the food and drink, it was among the best I've had in Chicago ever.  The range of flavors and taste sensations was unlike anything I can compare to.  The Chickpea Fritters are bathed in aromatic Indian spices, while the Fried Duck Tongue comes across like an Asian poke bowl, and the Pork Shank is an exquisite assemble-yourself pork version of a Buffalo chicken wing!

Our served steered us to the Green Beans, which we also a big hit. We figured, gotta-getta-goat dish and went for the Empanadas, which were topped with all kinds of tasty cress and set on top of a very flavorful creamy sauce.  The Grilled Shrimp dish was a fireworks display of flavors, including fresh tomatoes, thinly sliced shallots and a whole lot of other awesomeness going on in there.

We had eight dishes for five people, plus desert...and everyone was perfectly fed.  The cocktail menu also doesn't disappoint.  The Ring of Fire tequila cocktail has some jalapeno action at exactly the right pitch to make it tasty and 100% enjoyable.  The Best of Three vodka cocktail is citrusy yumminess with a cuke wedge that always makes things bright.

All around, G&tG is awesome.  A great birthday memory!!

The place is nice and the food taste wise was great the only thing that made the experience less then stellar was the portion sizing compared to the cost it was more of disappointment the waiter recommended three plates per person I would say more like 5 per person. The pricing compares to French bistros in France with  An amuse-bouch. My recommendation is using this as an appetizer experiance that will wow the pallet  and then going to a restaurant near by for the main course.

This is my first time in Chicago and we were highly recommended to Girl and a Goat. I was super hesitant at first because I do not eat goat. The menu is strange but cool. There is a lot of other things to eat. We started with the wood burning fire oysters and the pork belly hamachi crudo. The oysters were really good. So creamy and not fishy. The hamachi was ok. It was interesting the touch of pork belly.  It was a little sweet and salty. For the entree, we ordered the pork shank. Must have! Well cooked and just cool to eat. Overall, it is a place I am glad I tried. Not sure I would crave it though.

pics.caption: Sweet and salty? Hamachi with pork belly.
The pork shank is a must to try!!
If you like oysters, it is a unique twist on the traditional raw.

review.des: Yuckkkkk. Aside from this chef being "famous", why is this such a popular spot? What am I missing? Just moved to chicago, and everyone said I had to come here. From the food to the service to the drinks, misses the mark every which way. The food is so over-the-top trying to be something it's not. Easy, Stephanie.

Came back to GATG tonight for our 20th wedding anniversary.  It's hard to explain that a green bean dish can be so succulent...but it really is...the fish sauce and cashews together with the beans are perfect and the flavor is off the charts.  This is the second time I ordered the green beans and I'm glad.
The goat confit was delicious, mellowed with seafood and fennel and vanilla butter.  
Had the chickpea fritters again...marvelous pillows of great flavor.  

I would come here solely for green beans and chickpea fritters.  I'm going to come back again, as our server told us the menu changes a bit with the seasons.  There were so many dishes I saw that looked inviting....and I want to sample them all.

We got lucky with the open table reservation, but on a Wednesday night. Super packed! Great service.

1. Wood Grilled Broccoli - 3.5
2. green garlic potato pierogies - 4
3. pan roasted halibut - 3
4. hamachi crudo - 4
5. wood oven roasted pig face - 5
6. crisp braised pork shank - 5
7. raraouille focaccia - 2
8. Salt and ash - very smokey
9. High garden - 4
10. Best of three - 4
11. Royal Rubus - 3

1. Wish it was Brussels sprouts which we first hoped it was when it came out. Also a bit on the salty side and heavier (creamy) than a the broccoli dish should be.
2. These are small dumplings. I thought it tasted really good with right flavors only problem is the portion is very small.
3. We didn't care for this dish too much cause it was a tad bit too sweet. (Personal preference though I think some people can really enjoy this dish)
4. That the fried texture of tempura. It was cream filled with a nice taste to it. I really enjoyed it.
5. It's like eating breakfast cause of the egg. It's lightly sweetened with a crunch cause of the fried potato stix. A MUST TRY
6. My favorite dish even though I was stuffed! The meat just fell off the bone cause it was very tender and the sauces (buttermilk and kimchi) went well with the meat and I used the naan to make a small taco. A MUST TRY
7. None of us liked the bread. It was kinda soggy and just a mashup of veggies in it. Not a favorite.
8. Very smokey if you like that. but good flavors
9 & 10.. I like the citrus and bitter drinks so these fit the bill.

Great overall experience.

We were very fortunate to get a reservations here - thanks to our dear friend. We also just finished eating at Duck Duck Goat and everything about that place was exceptional, especially our waiter Jonathan who we asked if he could follow us. When we arrived here we were so excited that unfortunately, a few things changed the mood. The waitress we had was nice, although there were times we felt a bit weird. For instance, I wanted to get a small sample of a glass and she mentioned that the bartender usually doesn't do this (which is odd bc at other restaurants, it's usually not a big deal - even at Duck Duck Goat, they asked us if we wanted to try a sample since we were debating between 2 sparkling wines) Then the waitress asked are you guys going to share 1 glass? I felt a bit offended and thought maybe she thought since we just ate, we wouldn't be ordering a lot of food or drinks... but we ordered more than enough food and drinks. Also, we saw the interaction with the customers next to us and felt we weren't getting any love, which really ruined the entire experience for us.

Onto the food:
Caramel popcorn and vanilla gelato: 5/5 this was amazing!!! I'm drooling just thinking about this dish.
Calamari bruschetta: 1/5 this was highly recommended by our waitress but it was a little too hyped. It had green apples and goat cheese with calamari which was an odd mix. It was sweet and savory at the same time. Not our favorite but the other dishes made up for it.
Pork shoulder: 5/5. Delicious!! (This dish is huge so definitely share!)
Ham frites: 3/5. Love fries but disappointed that they gave us the bottom of the barrel where the fries were very short -  I needed to eat it with a fork.

Overall, I'd give this place another try, but if I had to pick between this and Duck Duck Goat, I'd probably go there and look for my previous server!
Never let me disappointed after so many times. Good restaurant! The only thing I can complain: it is so hard to find a seat! I think they should expand their footprint to other locations
The only bad part about this place is that they do not have copper mugs for the Moscow Mules :( Other than that this place is great. Ambience, food and cocktails are a 10!

I don't know if it's normal to be so obsessed with a restaurant but it breaks my heart this place is over 3,000 miles away from me =( This place is worth every penny. My ranking below on what we ordered:

Roasted Pig Face: Crispy slices of pig face over a red wine maple sauce accompanied with potato stix and a sunny side egg (yolk porn). The pig face is on my list of "best things I ever ate." You HAVE to try it know why.

Crisp Braised Pork Shank: Decently sized pork shank with a side of naan, kim chee and buttermilk dressing. Tender, fall of the bone, ready to devour. The pork shank was my favorite of everything we ordered until the pig face came out, but this still comes in a strong second!

Wood Grilled Broccoli: The most perfectly wood grilled broccoli, EVER. If you didn't love broccoli before, you will after you eat this. I'm not a huge fan of blue cheese so I tried not to get too much of the sauce smeared on the bottom of the plate (if you're not a huge fan either, I would ask for the sauce on the side).

Goat Empanadas: Two empanadas with a miso blue cheese aioli and a squash/apple slaw. I'm neither a fan of goat or blue cheese so this dish wasn't my absolute favorite but even then, I tried a piece and it was bearable. I came with 3 other people who loved them!

Ham Frites: Basically fries topped with fried ham. Two dipping sauces: smoked tomato aioli and cheddar beer sauce accompany the fries. The fried ham was too pulsed to almost a point where it tasted like powdered ham. Our fries were short and tiny which was annoying to eat. I'm assuming we got the bottom of a bag =(

What can I say? There's a reason  the wait for the restaurant seating is a couple months.... but if you're willing to wait, it's worth it. If you're as inpatient as i, fear  not, there's no rsvp for the bar seating (which if you don't mind sacrificing elbow room) is just fine! Some of the portions are TINY (i.e. goat belly confit), so you definitely need to get multiple plates, which  can quickly add up.

On top of the exceptional food (which everyone has already commented on) the customer service is excellent.  I had one bad experience,  and the management quickly responded and remedied the isolated incident. It says something when a company is so responsive and ensures that every experience (first, fifth or fiftieth) is nothing but amazing .

By now everyone has tried this place but me! FOMO, I went.

These were the dishes I had:
1. Braised beef tongue - I liked this dish. The cornmeal chips were interesting/weird at first but I really liked them in the end because they soaked up a lot of the flavor from the dish. The dressing on the salad was mild but good. The beef tongue was nice but I expected more flavor.

2. Shishisto peppers - There are A LOT of peppers in here. For a table of 2, it was too much since it was really oily. It would be nice with a big group because in the end I think I would've appreciated only a couple of bites. Be careful, these peppers are sneaky. Some with treat you nice, some will sear your tongue with heat.

3. Szechuan goat satay - My second favorite dish. The potato puree with the sauce was so comforting. The goat was flavorful. I approve.

4. Pig face sandwich - My favorite dish. Meaty and fatty. If you're a person who trims all the fat from their meat, this ain't for you. But for those who know that fat = flavor, gorge away. The egg is great, the sauce is great, pig out.

5. Bittersweet chocolate with shitake mushroom caramel gelato - People kept telling me, "save room for dessert, save room for dessert!" Well even if I had no room for dessert, I'm not waiting another 2 months for reservations to try it. Dessert was perfect. The brownie was rich and I NEED to visit whichever shop makes the gelato. Banging.

Girl & the Goat was a memorable experience. Maybe it was overhyped for me, but I wasn't blown away. But I still was blown pretty far. I can see myself coming back to try a couple new dishes and that PIG FACE.

pics.caption: Bittersweet chocolate with shitake mushroom caramel gelato. Yummm.
Pig face sandwich. Fatty fatty goodness.
Goat kabob with potato puree. Excellent!

review.des: It's good but overpriced.  One or two of the dishes we had we great (roasted beets), but most were just average or poor (goat belly).  Servings are small.  Overall, the food is really fatty.  It was worth it for one special occasion as a bucket-list kind of thing, but not someplace I'd return.

It is a rarity that I give 5 stars but this experience truly is deserving.  I happen to snag a last minute reservation to Girl & the Goat for early Friday dinner.  Honestly, I was expecting good things to land on our plates but the service really made it stellar.

The moment we entered the restaurant, we were greeted warmly by 3 staff member and we were quickly told our table would be ready momentarily.  The room isn't too big but the tables are well spaced out that it felt more spacious that it probably was... the big windows allowed a lot of natural light that lit all the way to the back kitchen.  Few moments later, we were shown to our table and almost immediately we were given water from another smiling staff member.  Is everyone that happy to working here or is there some requirement to look like you have a resting happy face?

Our waitress was a west coast transplant who clearly loved working in the industry and at the Girl & the Goat. Her knowledge of every dish was exemplary and was able to help create a menu that catered to our preferences while guiding us to some of the more popular dishes that made Chef Izard well known.  We ordered the roasted cauliflower, goat empanadas, grilled baby octopus, halibut and indulged on all the leches and caramel corn & malt balls dessert.  It probably was over the top to have the 2 desserts but we left quite full and incredibly satisfied.

The roasted cauliflower had that nice touch of charring that provides a sweeter and nuttier flavour to the vegetable.  It was balanced by the pine nuts, touch of mint, and peppers.  I really enjoyed this dish.

The grilled baby octopus came next and my partner was terrified of the tentacles.  I ate the first one and I knew it was a winner... tender with a bright citrus note from the sauce and also a savoury note from the guanciale, this was a great dish.  Its a great play on surf and turf.   The pistachios added a nice textural addition.

The halibut arrived next and ... wow.  Stand out dish  for the sauce.  Honestly, I wish I ordered bread to scoop all of the sauce.  I could have embarrassed myself by licking the bowl but I ... didnt.  The halibut was cooked well with a nice sear on one side.  The raw marcona almonds added an interesting textural play... I've never had it in a dish this way.  But that sauce... oh my god.  So good.

We then had the goat empanadas... have to do goat here!  Our server recommended this one as a way to be introduced to the goat flavour.  I would say the texture was similar to pulled pork but closer to a spring lamb gaminess but not quite the same flavour.  Overall, put it in a deep fried covering and voila... you have a great hit.  We enjoyed it for the crispy exterior... the strawberries and feta cheese added some interesting complimentary flavours.

We did have 2 desserts... over the top.  Yes but the all the leches dessert was so worthy of ordering every time.  It's the perfect summery light but bold berry flavour dessert.  It was inhaled by my partner who normally doesnt eat dessert.  I enjoyed the caramel in 3 incarnations in the caramel corn & malt ball dessert ... thick gooey caramel sauce on the bottom, chewy and butter caramel pieces, and caramelized crunchy pieces in the caramel corn.  Definitely a sugary hit but if you love cararmel and ice cream.  It is a must try.

Throughout the dinner, never once did we felt forced to eat fast to turn tables.  The service was always on spot and attentive without being intrusive.  They were always welcoming of everyone around us and it felt like personalized service.  One of the better restaurant experiences I have had in Chicago and I already made my reservations for my next time coming back!

pics.caption: Caramel corn and malt balls with magic shell... A must do for caramel lover.  The caramel pieces hidden among the dessert is incredible.
All the leches cake ... Phenomenal dessert.  The strawberries and rhubarb flavour was the star.  Nice and light for a hot day

review.des: See Jason at the bar and oysters halibut are a must plus try the mixologist - special

One of my favorite meals I have ever had. See below for everything we ordered:

1) steak
2) calamari bruschetta
3) scallops
4) green beans
5) pig face
6) pork shank
7) pork empanada

Highly recommend them all

Best meal I've had in Chicago. Hands down.

I`m still dreaming about my meal. I`ll get to the food in a minute but covering off on the other bases.... Booked a reservation about 2 weeks in advance. Called instead of using Open Table and got my first choice of date and time. Once we arrived we only waited about 5 minutes for them to seat us. Ambiance? Check! We had to sit a bit close to other tables, however we ended up befriending them so it worked out :) Everyone was scouting out everyone else's dishes. The best part? Nobody ordered the same thing. Everything is so good that there is not "one" dish that everyone gets. Our waitress was fantastic- when I told her I had a mint allergy she went back to the kitchen and marked off all of the items I couldn't order (which was sadly a lot). That was great service though. Now... onto the meal.

Wine: Definitely not cheap. I love Malbecs and there were only 2 on the menu, and only one bottle- the Piatelli (~ $60, and one of the cheapest bottles). The wine was fantastic, but if you plan to drink, plan to drop $$

Olive You Bread- The whipped feta was lifechanging. I've now looked up how to make it at home. We finished the whole thing.

Duck Tongue- Now, let me say that I am a picky eater. But I felt so bad for my dining companion since my mint allergy (and inability to eat pork/shellfish) had eliminated 80% of the menu, so I said I would branch out and try one thing. IT WAS INCREDIBLE. The flavor was so rich, and the flavors it was paired with were amazing. I would order it again and again.

Drum Fish- Second favorite thing we ordered. Tied with the bread. Flavors were fantastic and the fish was super mild.

Chicken- Perfectly moist. The fingerling potatoes it came with were also incredible. Comes with 4 pieces, very easy to split and delicious.

Green Beans- The fish sauce was good but had a very very strong flavor. There was also a LOT of it. I could have done with maybe half the sauce. This was also a very large portion.

I cannot wait to come back to this restaurant. Booking my next reservation now.

pics.caption: Olive You bread with whipped feta
Nice of the restaurant to mark up based off food allergies!

review.des:
We were so lucky to be able to dine here on our first visit to Chicago. As a fan of Top Chef, Stephanie Izard was my favourite of all the season winners. Of course, one should not be too in awe of one's culinary idol to overlook missteps or imperfections but more of that later.

We arrived at 4:30pm and sat at the bar as we had no reservation. The restaurant is quite large offering bar, lounge and table seatings. The kitchen is an open concept so you get the sense of what goes on behind the wooden shelves and bench top.

The two wait staff at the bar who served us were both excellent. They were attentive but not too intrusive. Water was topped up without asking which was nice. Orders were taken quickly and they even made recommendations when they could tell we were a little confused by some of the terminology on the menu.

We had four shared dishes - goat empanadas, chickpeas, roasted cauliflowers and our absolute favourite, the halibut.

The empanadas were for my taste, a little bit bland but it was interesting as it came with marinated strawberries and goat cheese toppings - like a salsa, perhaps?  

For dessert which was a highlight for me, was berries and cream -blueberries, gelee with buttermilk meringue. What a way to end a meal! Refreshing and just innovatively put together.

I would definitely return to this restaurant if I am lucky enough to visit Chicago again.
Great food. If you sit by the chefs they interact with you, you get to see how they make the food, and they give you food to try! Great atmosphere and great food.
What can I say that hasn't already been said. I've been multiple times and have not been disappointed. Worth the wait and worth the money.

Absolutely LOVED my experience here. Came for my bday dinner on a Saturday with about 5 friends.. Made reservations about a month in advanced and all they had was a 5pm slot.. Talk about early bird special ..  

We Ordered almost everything! lol kidding .. But seriously, their breads were amazing, the wood grilled broccoli was tender, the sweet potatoes were very flavorful.. The pork shank was to die for.. The pig face was amazing .. Ahh tons and tons of great food and drinks and the staff was a pleasure! Will be returning for the Goat leg!

Nothing bad or anticlimactic will encounter your tastebuds here. Wonderful. Good is beyond amazing. Service may be the best I've ever encountered. Will return for special occasions as long as they are there to host and feed us!

Good luck getting a table! Fantastic 'tapas-style' (shared plates) at what I think is a very good value. I had 2 martinis with our 5 selections and the total bill was more than reasonable. At a place called Girl & the Goat you should definitely get one of the goat dishes. I might be more adventurous next time since I found the goat pate so lovely and palatable. The crispy short rib and smoked broccoli is still memorable, the latter was so JUICY. If 2 of us could have licked our plates we would have.

Girl & the Goat has been around since Stephanie Izard open it in 2010 after being the first female to win Top Chef in 2008.  I've been wanting to come here for quite some time, but it hasn't worked out until now.  Getting a reservation during prime dinner hour isn't easy and I'm not one to plan that far ahead.  

Since they welcome walk-ins, I decided to come early shortly after they opened their doors at 430P on a Saturday night.  The place was filling up already and the host gave us a choice of sitting in the lounge or at the bar.  I opt for the bar since it had a large table top and scored 2 seats at the end of the bar.  The service was great!  Our waitress was friendly and helpful with the menu.  The bus boy cleaned quick and often, removing plates soon after they are emptied.

Kohlrabi Salad $9 - Fennel, evalon, toasted almonds, autumn crisp apple, and shiitake.  This turned out to be my favorite dish of the night!  They flavors in this salad were phenomenal.

Fried Naked Cowboy $12 (4 pieces) - These fried oysters are running up to being my favorite of the night.

Roasted Cauliflower $12 - Pickled peppers, pine nuts, and mint leaves.  I love cauliflower, but mint leaves not so much.  This was good, but nothing great for me.

Seared Diver Scallops $19 - These were good, I enjoyed the Brussel sprouts, but I wasn't blown away by this dish.

Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face $19 - The signature dish of Girl & the Goat.  I think it might have been a little too hyped up because I was a little let down.  The person that brought this dish out said to cut it up and eat it like a breakfast sandwich.  Yeah, it tasted good, but the meat didn't have any special flavor and I tasted mostly egg.  The potato stix were great for texture.

Sticky Squash Cake $9 - Delicious! Love the gelato.

Cocktail - Friends at cascade hollow $13 - Thumbs up to this whisky drink.

The gentleman sitting across from us said the sweet potato bleu cheese pierogi were his favorite of the night.  I'll have to try those next time.  We spend an average of about $50 per person plus tip.  

We found street parking close by which cost about $8 for 2 hours.  I should have Spot Hero it.

Finally i am sitting down to review this place after multiple visits. Recently took a friend for his birthday there and they absolutely loved it.

We ordered roasted cauliflower , chickpea fritter , wood fried shrimp , goat empanadas , short ribs , duck tartare , whats the dill yo , goat carpaccio and chocolatey. everything tasted great and rich in flavor.

Chickpea fritter , empanadas and carpaccio would be my favorite but take nothing away from the rest. I love how there is so much detail put into every single and one can taste each ingredient in the food. A good deal of attention is also paid to the presentation.

The only thing i would say is despite telling them a couple of times that it is my friend's birthday and please send the dessert with a candle on it , it was not done. I believe these things do matter and are a part of good service.

Overall delicious food , must try it at least once.

Girl & the Goat is one of my favorite all-time restaurants in Chicago. I hate to be the cliché, but it is really that good.

Everything you order will be delicious.  My absolute favorite dish is the duck tongues. They are incredible, and I literally dream about them at night. They are also the one dish that I consistently order every time I come here. The pig face and especially the pork shank are also out of this world. You literally can't go wrong.  People rave about their breads, but I personally find them very good but not mind-blowing or worth the stomach space (especially when there are SO many other yummy things to choose from). I love that the menu here is so unique and blends all sorts of flavors. Every time friends who love food come into town, this is my go-to restaurant that I bring them to.

The service overall has always been great. It can be a pain to get a reservation here, but it's not impossible. It's definitely worth it. Highly recommend!
The pig face is amazing, the lobster and goat with butter sauce is unlike any dish I've tasted.  Get there early to sit at bar and eat if you don't have a reservation.

Managed to snag a couple of seats in the lounge/bar area. The green beans were outstanding and stick out to me months later. Everything else was delicious as well. The only thing I wouldn't repeat order is the flatbread.

We sat at the chef's table overlooking the kitchen, and now have a list of what we want to try next time.  They build incredible flavors from simple ingredients and everything was fabulous! Not overrated, it's the real deal.

Chef Stephanie Izard has made a name for herself in Chi-town and this restaurant is proof. Do you wonder if the stories you hear about making reservations months in advance or waiting for a table for 2 hours are true or false? True story. Plan wisely and book early.

We started our trip strong by having our first meal here, though a disadvantage to that would be having a hard time finding a restaurant to trump that experience. The interior itself was casual yet glamorous, and because I like to see all the action, I love that they have an open kitchen which can be viewed from the dining room. Service was fantastic. Thanks to our server Kristen for making us feel right at home and for making the progression of our meal flawlessly on point.  

Almost everything we got was excellent. Almost. The dishes are served tapas style which is best shared like a family. Since there were a total of 4 very hungry people in our party, we pretty much ordered the entire menu.

The Must Haves:

GOAT LIVER MOUSSE ($14) served alongside pickle relish and the most amazing crumpets baked in-house. We almost ruined our appetite because of this which I would gladly do so again.

SEARED DIVER SCALLOPS ($19) cooked supremely well resulting to a perfect buttery jiggle mouth feel. And those Brussels sprouts (wow)...plus textures from the pecans and pomegranate..oh how glorious was this dish!

PIG FACE ($19) roasted in wood oven with tamarind, cilantro, and red wine maple topped with a sexy sunny side up egg that gushed out yellow after mixing everything together. Loved the bold and beautiful flavors that was reminiscent of a dish back home called "sisig" but entirely on a different level. The crunch from the potato stix and crispy parts of the pig face brought another touch of excitement to this plate.

ROASTED CAULIFLOWER ($12) was served in a heaping portion compared to the rest but I'm not complaining. The combination of pickled peppers, pine nuts, and mint just tied everything together into one addicting healthy phenomenon.

CRISPY BRAISED PORK SHANK ($26) was fall-off-the-bone tender that one poke of your fork can tear everything apart. This came with grilled spring onion kimchi but it was the naan dipped in the buttermilk dressing that did it for me. Excellent dish!

The A-Ok's:

GOAT EMPANADAS ($16) didn't really make the goat shine. And just 2 pieces!
ESCARGOT DUMPLINGS ($16) were a little too al dente and subtle in flavor
DUCK TONGUES ($17) aside from the tuna poke, this was very forgettable

Girl and the Goat is the place to be in this Windy City and may have been my favorite stop for eats on this trip.

Made reservations 2 months in advance; normal for popular Chicago dining spots. And it turned out to be a slower Sunday.

We got seated at the Chef's Table (2 high seats at bar level right in front of the line cooks) without any special request. Definitely recommend getting this spot, but it will cause your dinner bill to increase. Must get that, and that, and that too!! The cooks are really fun to banter with and encourage questions. You'll know how busy the kitchen's been based off the number of arm burns they have. Try asking them about their burn policy.

We got some freebies. Cooks gave us one dish after oogling and asking about it. And our waiter did too after discussing two possible dessert choices.

Much has been written about the dishes, so I'll keep it short. Absolutely order the wood fired oysters. I'm more of a raw purist, but the smokey flavor and light garnish on it was incredible. It completely changed my mind about cooked oysters. Thanks to Debbie Y. for that tip!

pics.caption: Chef's table gets you in front of one side of the kitchen.

review.des:
Definitely one of the most famous restaurants in Chicago and it's almost impossible to not try it at least once. We ordered the roasted cauliflower, wood oven roasted pig face, crisp braised pork shank, hamachi crudo, duck tongues, and "all the leches" cake.

1. Roasted cauliflower (4/5): Good but make sure to eat them with pine nuts.
2. Duck tongues (3/5): This dish was tasty but I wasn't really a fan of its texture.
3. Wood oven roasted pig face (3/5): Apparently a very well-known dish, had to get it. It's crispy outside and soft inside, but the combination of sunny-side egg, pig face, and potato stix tastes kinda oily.
4. Crisp braised pork shank (4/5): My favorite dish of the night! The pork shank was very flavorful and braised really well.
5. Hamachi crudos (4/5): This was also delicious but very small portion :( Could have had so much more of these.
6. All the leches cake (4/5): A satisfying wrap-up of the meal. Nothing super special but after lots of the main dish you always have room for some sweets!

Girl and the goat is one of those places thats so well known you kinda get nervous it won't live up to the hype. Well it really did. The food was amazing. As a lot of others have stated the goat empanadas are delicious!!!! If you go you must try those!
Excellent service. Great atmosphere. Food was unbelievable. We shared a variety of dishes with our group, and each was delicious. Highly recommend;)

Lives up to the hype and expectation
Pig face and goat empanadas are a must. Beyond tasty.
Scallops and cauliflower were amazing.
Calamari bruschetta was delicious
Sourdough bread was really yummy but could've done without as it's just warm bread with feta and onion mustard dips. Not worth getting full for the other delicious dishes

Been there twice, came back with a larger group so I got to try more dishes. So far it's an OK place. Not really worth the wait and the price. I mean food is great but things are pretty expected. I think you can pay less for better quality. Service is great though, our waiter is very patient in terms of handling a pretty large group.

pan fried shishito peppers
parmesan.​ sesame. miso
Review: It was definitely something different and it tasted great.

crisp braised pork shank
buttermilk dressing. grilled spring onion and radish kimchi. naan
Review: It wasn't to my likely and the sides that came with the dish didn't make much sense, it just wasn't that good to me.

duck tongues
tuna and black bean poke. piri piri
Review: Interesting take on duck tongue, because it was fried it wasn't as flavorful but overall it was a decent dish.

onion focaccia
caesar dressing. cauliflower giardiniear
Review: It was good, loved the bread.

grilled walter's chicken
green harissa. confit salsify. grilled grapes. black lime gremolata
Review: Very good, well planned out dish and the sauce tasted great.

what's the dill yo?
salmon cream cheese. pickle relish
Review: It was ok, it definitely lacked the salmon flavor.

OYSTERS​
raw
Review: Wasn't good, wasn't as sweet or as fresh as most places.

Overall
Girl & Goat isn't anything amazing but since everyone is hyping about it, why not go visit. It's not a place I would go again unless you know what is good. Due to it's high popular demand, wait is usually 2 months or longer. It's also extremely noisy inside during dinner time, not a place you would take your date out to. Overall, it's ok.
