review.des:
My experience at Girl and the goat consisted of rich elaborate flavors I've not experienced. I can only assume that these creations are unique to this fascinating restaurant. The atmosphere was quaint and intimate.

Our first plate to arrive was the "It's gouda" bread with smoked lard butter and romesco. The bread was a rustic loaf that had a crusty and chewy quality with a hint of gouda baked into it. The real star of this plate was the lard butter and romesco. The smoked lard butter had a delightfully cream texture to it which melded well with the sweet and salty smokiness of the romesco. I easily could have made a meal of just this dish and wish I could buy the lard butter for everyday use.

Following the bread were the chickpea fritters, which were garnished with whipped spiced yogurt, sorrel chutney, and a mango-citrus relish. The fritters had a nice crispy golden brown crust with a velvety filling. The mago-citrus relish had a slight bite to it that added depth to the fritter which, in turn, was expanded by the whipped spiced yogurt. I can't say for sure if the yogurt had a prevalent lemon flavor or if it was the mingling of the relish with the yogurt on the plate that gave it this quality but the combination was delightful.

Accompanying the fritters were the duck tongues with tuna and black bean poke, crispy wontons, and piri piri. At first, this dish seemed slightly intimidating to our group unsure of what to expect. We were pleasantly surprised when it arrived at the table. The dish had an east Asian inspired taste to it. The texture of the duck tongues were evocative of crispy pork cracklings with a slight give to it. This ended up being one of the favorites and I recommend giving it a try.

After the duck tongues were the goat empanadas topped with miso-blue cheese aioli and squash-apple slaw. The savory roasted goat was enjoyably different and wrapped in a perfectly crispy pastry crust that wasn't at all flaky and then cooked to golden perfection giving it a wonderful aroma. The miso-blue cheese aioli gave the dish a twang which was then softened by its creaminess and balanced by the sweetness from the squash-apple slaw. I only wish I could have had more of these fantastic little treats.

Both the red fish and the catfish came to the table at the same time. The red fish was accompanied by Manilla clams in a curry apple broth topped with an herb salad. The dish was very reminiscent of a Thai curry soup. The broth had a very fragrant flavor with a coconut undertone which paired well with the fish which had only a slight flake to it reminding you that it was fish.

The blackened catfish was served on a bed of dirty rice then topped with goat xo and pickled persimmons. This was my favorite plate of the evening. The flavors were well developed to a point that they would change in waves of bold flavors: first a slight sweetness, then a hint of bitter vinegar and spice, followed by a salty savory that rounded everything off in to a pleasant luxury.

After the fish, we received the roasted cauliflower with pickled peppers, pine nuts, and mint. I am always amazed by the versatility of cauliflower, it simply seems to go with everything and can transform a dish or stand out on its own. The fact that this dish was delicious came as no surprise especially with the tartness of the pickled peppers. The texture, however, was a truly delightful addition. The cauliflower was roasted to a state of tenderness, the peppers had a slight crunch, and the pine nuts, a slightly bigger crunch, were wonderful little nuggets of treasure scattered throughout the dish.

Another dish, which was mildly intimidating was the wood oven roasted pig face topped with a sunny side up egg, drizzled with tamarind, cilantro, and red wine-maple, accompanied by potato stix. It is my understanding that this is one of their most popular dishes on the menu. A perfectly cooked egg blanketed the dish to hide the decadent prize that lie beneath a crispy nest like pile of potato stix. The pig face was juicy, fatty, with some bites having a texture that I can only compare to smooth pâté or pork mousse.

Our final plate of the evening was the confit goat belly in a bourbon butter with lobster and crab and fennel. This dish is the very epitome of decadence. Words elude me when trying to describe the transcendent nature of this dish. The savory goat belly is featured in this dish in the form of a compacted molding of shredded meat with a crispy exterior topped by just enough crab and lobster to avoid stealing the focus from the dish's namesake. The entire dish is then drizzled in the richest bourbon butter sauce possibly conceived.

The entire meal was decadent and seemingly hedonistic, appealing to all my senses in such a way that it triggered unequivocal elation noticeable to my dining companions. Our bill, consisting of 8 individual dishes, 2 drinks, and coffee and tea for each of us came to $202. With a well earned tip, it came to $65 each.
Probably the most fun I've had dining out, with exceptional food as well. I couldn't have asked for a better night out.

If you can't make reservations, go early and try sitting at the bar! Or, if you go REALLY early, then they'll let you sit at the tables so long as you are out by the time it is reserved!

Totally worth the wait. The Pig Face and the liver mousse are a MUST TRY!
All the dishes were amazing, but those two are life altering delicious.

Our server was so friendly and knowledgeable, and very patient with us as I was being fickle-minded with what to order. He also recommended a great wine that paired perfectly with the food!

I really struggled to understand the hype about this place and had such high expectations. We had a 9:15pm table, arrived on time and the table wasn't ready. The staff on the front desk had no idea where to tell us to wait and left us hovering at reception until we suggested going to the bar and them coming to find us. The food was really disappointing - nothing you hadn't had before and no wow factor. I wondered if we had ordered the wrong things but after looking at reviews, we seemingly ordered the most popular dishes. They pack the tables in so that you sit right on top of the people next to you and the waiters seemed like they were rushed off their feet with people still being seated at 10pm. Really disappointing experience.
Amazing food! Went on a Sunday afternoon and sat on the patio. Our server was very helpful with recommendations. EVERYTHING was delicious. Highly recommend and will definitely be back!

Walked in around 5pm and oh gosh it was packed for a Wednesday night. No where to stand instead, people waiting outside.

We were told about a hour wait for a table of 2, but told us we were free to snag a spot at the bar or the small tables on the side. Luckily we didn't wait more than 5 minutes! We saw some people finishing up and we politely asked them if they were leave and they gave us their spot.

We came here for a few reason. Highest rated spot in Chicago and PIG FACE!  We weren't that hungry and my friend suggested to share a plate of pigs face. I was like no way and we got our own!

Pig face came with an egg on top and the server told us how to eat it properly. Mash everything and go to town. It was fantastic, fatty but rich in flavor.

Pork Shank.  It was so tender, juicy, and crispy. It pretty much fell apart when we poked our forks into it. I didn't really like the hot sauce that it came with.  But the pickled veggies was great as well. It tasted like smoked kimchi.

What I liked a lot about this place is that with each dish you get they tell you how to eat the dish properly. They also refill your water relatively quick without asking!

Girl & the Goat is amazing! The atmosphere is romantic, but group-welcoming. It is a great place to share with friends. We tried a couple of different dishes that were all good. Our favorite was the wood oven roasted pig face and the chickpea fritters were good too. They had a little bit of an indian vibe. The calamari was amazing. The service was really friendly. The restaurant is near a lot of awesome bars/coffee shops too so there are a lot of options to go hang out before reservations.

Some many options that are awesome but I have eaten everything on the menu and loved everything. The food was heavy like comfort food but I absolutely love anything goat. Plus it's a half mile from my house so in the summer I walk over. This place is has a diner feel but the food will make you forget where you are.
Great spot! Drinks are amazing and food even better! I'll be back soon for sure! And they're open early!
Lovely dining establishment. The pig face is bomb, the other food is delicious. Hyped up? Yes? Worth it? YES. Go with a large group- it's much more affordable and you get to try the whole menu

We have been here quite a few times, and I am never disappointed! It is quite difficult to get in, so make reservations far in advance. The plates are made to share, so you can order ~4-5 for 2 people. However, the vegetable portions are large (and also the best part, in my opinion). I highly highly recommend the sautéed green beans .. crunchy and coated with a nice vinaigrette and cashews which add a sweet touch. The roasted cauliflower is very good as well. As far as meats go, the pork shank is to die for. The combination of flavors and textures makes it my favorite dish in Chicago. Additionally, for a nice restaurant, the prices are reasonable.

I have lived in the West Loop for over 5 years and it took me too long to try out this West Loop staple.  Had some foodie friends come into town from Michigan and we all LOVED this place.  The staff was friendly and the waitress was very knowledgeable. Bravo!

Owned by a Top Chef winner Stephanie Izar. And I kid you not: THE best food ive eaten in Chicago. It definitely lives up to the hype! And should be at the top of your list to eat when in Chicago! What we ordered: wood oven roasted pig face (everybody's favorite), seared diver scallops (my favorite), goat empanadas, sautéed green beans ( on the house!!), what's the dill yo? ( bread with salmon cream cheese and pickle relish)

pics.caption: Oh we went there on their 7th birthday! HBD GIRL AND THE GOAT!
What's the Dill yo? ( bread with salmon cream cheese and pickle relish) We had to order this for 5 bucks but was worth it!

review.des:
After seven years, it seems like the Girl and the Goat is still one of the scarcest reservations in Chicago, but we finally lucked into a table.

The food ranged from good to excellent. The best dishes were a goat liver mousse with some magical homemade crumpets and bits of pickled vegetables and rhubarb, and a set of pierogis filled with spring onion. These were flavorful, made excellent use of summer vegetables and pickling, and generally highly recommended. (Honorable mention goes to my tiki-ish cocktail, the "Mahalo," which was not oversweet, in case you were worried about that, as I was.)

The other dishes, though a little less exciting, were still uniformly very good, sometimes interesting, always hearty and well-seasoned. This is the kind of place you could always take out of town guests and leave them very impressed with what a tasty and fun city Chicago is. (If you could get a reservation, of course, which you probably can't.)

Still and all, on the food alone, I can't rate this place five stars -- not in a city where it competes with Parachute and Topolobampo and Dove's Luncheonette, not on a *block* where it competes with Au Cheval and Lena Brava. The food at the Girl and the Goat is really good, but it is four stars when graded on the Chicago curve, because the Chicago restaurant scene is an embarrassment of riches.

And that brings us to the service. Each individual issue may seem minor, but they added up to an atmosphere of inhospitality: 1, They were more than fifteen minutes late in seating us for our reservation (ironic, given how hard the reservations are to get in the first place). 2, There's no place in the entryway to sit while you are kept waiting fifteen minutes for your table -- a minor inconvenience most of the time, a little less minor if one of the two of you is eight months pregnant. (We did eventually snag a stool-like pillow thing in the bar area, but seating was hard to find there too, because of course it is really serving as a second dining room.) 3, Once we did get to the table, we were noticeably, and unpleasantly, rushed. One set of appetizers piled out on top of the others. One entree rushed out, while we were only starting to nibble on the previous one, with an added injunction to eat the new one right away lest it get soggy. Our server then tried to stick us with a dessert menu while both these entrees were still only half-eaten. (We clocked it at less than 55 minutes into our seating that the dessert menu arrived.)

Now most of this wasn't our server's fault. When we told him to stop rushing us, he did ease off, and did so without being disgruntled or abandoning us entirely, and he twice interjected some helpful pieces of advice into our menu selection. Rather, all of these things seem more like structural issues -- cramming in too many reservations and too many diners, and thus creating pressure to both keep people waiting and flip their tables faster. Given the long-lasting hype for this place, I can understand how things got this way, but the experience lowered a four-star experience to half that.

I'm glad I can cross it off my list, but a little bit of that is because now I don't have to go back.
Tasty menu and good sized portions. Went with coworkers and we ordered the sample menu. I'd recommend this as they have so much to offer.

If you're ever in Chicago, you have to try this place!

This is one of the hardest reservations to get in Chicago, or so I've heard. We were able to get a last minute reservation when someone cancelled but definitely call a month ahead of time.

I love the New American twist they apply to everything they make here. It really is an interesting mixture of tastes and flavors.

Some of the highlights:
* Roasted cauliflower
* Baby octopus
* Pig face
* Duck tongue
* Goat liver mousse
One of the best meals I've had in Chicago! There's not a mediocre plate on the menu, I'd know since I tried them all.

Food Is excellent, although the food portions are light. Not the place to come when your hungry. Wait staff was nice.

I don't think the bartender opened his mouth once when serving me couple cocktails, some attitude problem. Pours were weak.

$150 will go much father even in Chicago steakhouses.
This is the best. From a world traveler to a good old southern boy. All the pork dishes and the halibut are the absolute best.

Absolutely loved the warm atmosphere. Perfect for my date night.

Began with oysters which was a perfect starter.

Goat liver mousse paired with pickled cucumbers, mushrooms and cauliflower giardiniera. The vinegar vegetables complimented the soft, saltiness of the liver paste. This is pretty large portion for 2 but we managed to finish. It also came with a buttery biscuit.

We also had the crisp pork belly and lobster pieces.

Munched on sautéed green beans flavored with fish sauce vinaigrette and topped with cashews. Delicious side.

The wood oven roasted pig face which included a sunny side egg, tamarind, cilantro, red wine-maple and potato stix for a crunch. This sounds odd on paper but the yolk oozes over the pig face and the flavors are phenomenal.

Stuffed but still made it to dessert.

Tried sticky spiced squash cake with a red wine toffee sauce and rosemary-butter pecan gelato. This didn't last very long.. amazing sugar rush!

pics.caption: sautéed green beans\r fish sauce vinaigrette. cashews
goat liver mousse\r cauliflower giardiniera. grilled pickled mushrooms

review.des: Always our favorite choice in the city for a date night! Never disappoints! Perfect for groups or a date night.

Went in around 5pm on a Tuesday and was able to get a table. The food is tapas style and UH-MAZING! I'm no stranger to eating goat and the goat was made delicious. I also tried the duck tongue which was surprisingly very good. I will be back, this time with a reservation

Yes this place remains fresh and awesome.  For being around a while now, they have never gotten complacent or dull.  (Bring back the fried chicken!!)   Recommend you go in the early evening and wait for a bar seat.  save the trouble of waiting days or weeks for a reserved table.  All the staff if encountered there have been great!  Tell your friends, family or co-workers to try this place if they haven't yet, or go back as the menu is consistently updated with great choices!

Service and food are great. Nice cocktail list. Selection of food for vegetarians and non veg. We liked the goat empanadas (only two in a serving); we didn't order much but the four of us were surprisingly full quickly.

The crisp braised pork shank was incredible, the caramel corn and malt balls a.k.a marshmallow ice cream dessert was out of this world. I know now why you have to book weeks in advance. Def a must stop in Chicago

Just had a fabulous meal at Girl and The Goat and can't say enough great things about my experience. The staff was friendly and welcoming and the food was delicious. The beet salad was fresh and creative and the braised pork shank was succulent and flavorful. I can't wait to go back for another dining experience.

Not impressed by the ambiance the lack of space between tables or the food. I do love little goat diner so expected girl and the goat to deliver. As soon as I walked in I was disappointed by the space and how tables are laid out it makes for a very uncomfortable meal. Ordered the pig face and peppers to start and I ordered nothing else after. Not bad but not mind blowing. I also hated the distance you have to walk to a bathroom. This place is overhyped to me. My opinion but obviously a must try for popularity reasons.

I have been waiting a year to go here. That reservations are very very difficult to come by would be an understatement! We walked in one day just to try our luck ,and guess what, we got 3 seats at the bar! Win!

Food: I'm guessing this is what most peeps come for given Stephanie Izard's reputation. It's just alright, nothing outstanding or overtly creative, which is such a disappointment really. Its quite clear the restaurant is running largely on her popularity and that it's on every tourist's must-do list (and mine when I moved to Chicago).

Service: The service staff needs to really raise their game. They were pretty lukewarm to us, and frankly, I didn't seem to think they were even making an effort to make sure everyone was taken care of. This is pretty expensive fare, so you cant afford to have serve staff that's slacking.
This place doesn't disappoint. Amazing combination of flavors that have you scraping your plates. Good beer and good wine. A must in Chicago !

AH-MAY-ZING!

Ugh, ever since visiting Girl & the Goat, I have not been able to stop dreaming about their delicious smoked broccoli, wood fired shrimp, and goat empanadas. Yes, GOAT EMPANADAS!

Everything was great and served in a tapas style fashion, but I'd be lying if I said I shared any of my dishes. They were simply too good. Two of my friends and I shared the caramel corn and malt balls dessert and loved it. It's not a huge dessert, but its definitely good enough for two or three people if you just want a little bit of sweetness at the end of your meal.

I'd advise trying to reserve a table before going, it's definitely busy!

This was honestly one of my favorite dinners. The service is great, our reservation was at 10 pm, and we were the second to last ones to leave. You'd think they would be more aggressive in ushering us out, but they didn't really rush us.

The food was also really good, but like some other people said their timing in when they deliver the courses is off. There was a 15 minute gap between when they delivered two of our courses (when we were ready).

We got the pork shank, pig face, cauliflower, chickpea fritter, goat liver mousse. So many people say the cauliflower is amazingggg, but we thought it was just good. Nothing really stood out from it. The chickpeas was one of my favorite. It's deep fried, and then is wrapped in some yogurt to add moisture, and to add more flavor they sprinkle some mango slices and chutney. Really good. The pig face isn't intimidating since it's not really an entire face, and probably just cheeks. It is quite fatty and crispy, pretty tasty and unique. The goat liver mousse....if you like that kind of spread, you will love this. They give you more than a fair share of spread. The bread that comes with it is amazingggg, think biscuit flavor, but puffier and not as flakey. For those that don't like the liver flavor, they provide additionally sweeter spreads to help lower that flavor. Lastly, the pork shank. Comes off the bone, really crispy skin (think almost Peking duck). The other sauces that come with it don't really compliment it well, but the meat didn't need it.

Almost forgot about dessert. We got the corn and malt ball one...and it is just ice cream and some popcorn flakes. Good, but not too special imo. Came out to be 130 for two people, very fair price imo.

***3.5***

Liked:

Cauliflower dish - cooked wonderfully.

Green beans - although the sauce made it quite heavy.

Kohlrabi salad - the mushrooms or olives didnt help.

Goat empanadas - fave dish ordered.

Disliked:

Beef heart - couldnt even eat one bite of it. The aioli was too heavy and pickled veggies are not my thing.

Goat liver mousse - the brioche was so yummy but the condiments were not would I would pair it with.

Overall a good experience--the service was great and the food was good. I think that the food was overhyped, however. The grilled broccoli was amazing. I would return, if it were not so hard to get a table.

If you are planning on trying out girl and the goat, do make a reservation! Everything was delicious and what we ordered was kinda on the heavier side, but our waiter told us normally table of two orders 4 or 5 dishes. So go with lots of people so you can try the entire menu !! :)

pics.caption: Goat liver mousse. Had to get something goat related
Pork shank (absolute favorite!!!) Tender, falls off the bone and crispy on the outside.
Pig face, taste better than it sounds. Kinda reminds me of pork belly.

review.des:
I had the pleasure of dinning at Girl and The Goat for my boyfriend's birthday. We were lucky enough to sit at the Chef's table and let me tell you, what a fantastic dining experience this was. Not only were we able to eat the delicious food, we also were able to see it being made. And as if working in a busy kitchen was not enough, the chefs still made a point to interact with us and answer any questions we had. If you ever have the opportunity to seat at the chef's table, you SHOULD DO IT!

Here is what we had (sorry for the long list, we a lot J):

-   Pan fried shishito pepper (although I am not a fan of shishito pepper, I have to say that these had great flavors and the dish was pretty big, definitely a plate to share, in my opinion).
-   Wood grilled broccoli (MY FAVORITE DISH! The broccoli was made to perfection and even had spiced rice crispies. At first when I read that on the menu was not really feeling it but when I tasted it, it was sooo good!)
-   Green garlic pierogies (MY SECOND FAVORITE DISH! The smoked tomato-rhubarb relish made the dish for me, as I am used to regular pierogies and this was a nice turn on this dish)
-   Escargot ravioli (although I am french, I do not mess with escargots....at all, however, I wish I did because this dish smelled SO good. My boyfriend totally loved them. If I did not know that there were escargots in them, I probably would have eaten them...I did sneak away a little crispy onion!!)
-   Braised beef tongue (yea, totally did not even look at that one... but, per my boyfriend, it was cooked to perfection and the salsa verde was a great pairing)
-   Sweet onion brioche (this was my least favorite dish, in all honesty. It was good but nothing breathtaking. I thought the smoke salmon cream cheese lacked the smoke salmon flavor and the brioche bread was a bit dry, to my taste)
-   Lemon make you happy dessert (this was delicious! I absolutely LOVE lemon pound cake and this was a hit! The almond crunch that came with it create the perfect flavor mixture and the cheesecake sauce was yummy too. The sorrel ice cream was okay to me. I would probably need to try it again as this was a flavor I was not expecting)
-   Chocolate pavlova says-a-me (I was not into this dessert at all because I do not like chocolate nor sesame mixed with sweets. My boyfriend thought it was delicious and was a big fan of the sesame whip and black sesame brittle, in particular)

In conclusion, we were really happy with our meal and our server (so sorry for not remembering her name) was a delight. She made sure to check on us semi-regularly and provided great information on the food, as well. Icing on the cake, Cassie, the sommelier, provided EXCELLENT wine recommendations for which my boyfriend was OVER THE MOON. She was so nice and she also checked on us, here and there, throughout our meal. Definitely will be back and thank you for your kindness, delicious food and atmosphere!

You can't go wrong with dinner at Girl & the Goat, if you're lucky enough to snag a reservation or patiently wait hours in line. The whole restaurant exudes a casual, rustic vibe. Tables are small and the atmosphere is quite loud, which isn't surprising given how packed it gets all the time. I was very happy with all of the dishes I ordered and can easily see why this place has gotten all the praise and adoration it has, very deserving! If you want to impress a date or have a nice meal with a friend, this is a sure winner.

-johnny applecheese (5/5): served warm and comes with chili cheddar butter (heaven!) and apple butter. You MUST order at least one of their breads and if you're really smart, order two! They're the cheapest thing on the menu ($5) and quite possibly the most memorable and addictive.
-kohlrabi salad (3/5): overall a nice salad with fresh apple slices, but the evalon goat cheese was too overpowering for my liking. If you like the strong taste of blue cheese, this might be right up your alley
-hamachi crudo (5/5): light and refreshing, I just wish the portion was larger!
-goat empanadas (4/5): comes with 2 smallish empanadas, not a lot of goat meat inside but a good introduction to goat meat. Did not taste gamey at all.
-roasted pig face (4.5/5): one of their most popular dishes, definitely must order this! The pig face meat is extremely tender and rich. You mix it with the fried egg and potato sticks.
-chocolate cake with shiitake gelato (5/5): this was amazing! the chocolate cake was warm and I didn't really get any strong shiitake taste with the gelato but it was delicious.

In love with this place! Reservations are pretty hard to get (book at least a month in advance if you'd like a specific day and time) they however take walk ins on a couch dining area and the bar is the full menu. We had the sautéed green beans, hamachi crudo, escargot ravioli, braised beef tongue, raw oysters and the confit goat belly. Everything was amazing here and I would definitely recommend this place. Server even gave us a dessert on the house for my boyfriends birthday (shout out to hunter) and for agreeing with me to pay for the dinner since my boyfriend insisted on paying. The price point of this place is also amazing. You easily get a bang of your buck here!

Great food, great staff and great vibes!
We had some starters , and then full dish, you won't be hungry afterwards !
When it's really crowded, you don't hear each other properly.

Must try if in Chicago. Make reservations! This place reminds me of Bestia in LA. Portions are bigger than I expected (always a good thing).

What we ordered:
Green beans
Shishito Peppers
Halibut
Lamb ribs
Calamari
Very old fashion.

Calamari was slightly salty for my taste buds. Lamb ribs was falling off the bone. Halibut was perfectly pan fried. Shishito peppers and green beans was delicious!

Service was on point. Everyone worked together-changed plates when needed, delivered food on a timely matter, and always made sure our water cup was filled.

Best part! Our son fell asleep right before we arrived to dinner and fell asleep thru out dinner, which was amazing- server knew we will wanted dinner to go faster than usual we wanted to make it thru dinner without our toddler waking up and he did it! If I remembered correctly our server name was Joshua with a beard!

Will definitely go back here if I was in Chicago again!
Amazing place and awesome food. Everything you order is a great new experience. We didn't find a table but sitting at the bar was good, they also have really nice staff.

I read somewhere that a table at Girl & the Goat is one of the hardest to get in Chicago. That being said, I'm more than thankful the bf was on top of it and made reservations well in advance in preparation for our weekend trip. We arrived at 8pm on a Saturday night and it was packed. They had tables outside the restaurant as well that were bustling with people. Seeing how everyone was really lively & jovial, I instantly got the vibe that I was about to have a BAM (bomb ass meal).

This place lives up to the hype. Every dish had great presentation and balance of flavors. I loved that each bite just kept getting progressively better than the last. Service was very efficient and quick - there was always someone around to refill our water or clear our plates to prepare for the next.

Dishes we loved:
- Roasted beets
- Roasted pig face
- Goat belly (best dish of the night!)

Dishes we liked:
- Escargot ravioli
- Braised beef tongue

I wish I had room for dessert but 5 dishes split between 2 people were filling. Plus, I didn't mind the lingering taste of all the amazing food I just stuffed myself with. It was a BAM indeed.

Great food. Nice ambience. They accommodated my 20 something year old niece, my 2 year old toddler, and me without reservations on Saturday afternoon in the Fall of 2017. We were appreciative. So glad that I finally got to try this place....as it lived up to the Hype.
Definitely unique and innovative dishes at this place. Server was very attentive and kind. I would definitely recommend this place over some of the popular yet mundane breakfast places in Chicago!

Yeah it's really that good. Waited for a seat at the bar. John, Hana and the locals looked after me with recommendations. Loved the wood-fired lamb ribs succulent, falling off the bone in a subtle blueberry sauce, the citrus forward escargot ravioli with crispy onion, goat empanada, the bonus calamari on goats cheese bruschetta some fool passed up, the pig face with egg yolk and they finished me off with a goat cheesecake and thin slices of rhubarb and some crunchy stuff. The kind of night when you wish it would never end

Yes. Yes. Yes. Great atmosphere even if you are dining alone. There is a bar with communal seating. The menu had unique offerings and great flavor profiles. I ended up here accidentally but will absolutely be back.

In a city full of amazing restaurants this is undoubtably the best one. The food is incredible and when you add in the drinks, service and ambience it really is not close. They could charge five dollars more for every dish on the entire menu, I promise you will walk away fall and feeling like you got a great deal. There is a reason Stephanie Izard has won every cooking competition ever and the Boka group are the perfect partners. Make a reservation / show up at 4:30 or be prepared to wait.
This restaurant is worth the wait and makes up for all the hype. Although pretty small plates, the menu is delicious and so are the drinks. Great date night spot!

You know a restaurant is on top of their game when you have nothing to say about how the food and service can be improved.

I loved everything I ordered here. Every dish was perfectly delicious. This is an example of a restaurant that has perfected their craft.

FAVORITES (ranked):

1. Calamari Bruschetta - This was absolutely heavenly. The most tender bite-through calamari, delicate goat cheese, and perfectly crisp bread. I'll be dreaming about this dish forever.
2. Roasted Cauliflower - It was full of flavor. I loved the pine nuts on top.
3. Pig Face - This is literally a pig's face. I had no idea what to expect, but it was served with an egg and potato shreds. It tasted a bit like a breakfast hash, but nonetheless very tasty and the meat was so tender.

I would go back every time I visit Chicago.

Pro tips:
- Go right before 4:30pm (opening time) - a line up will start to form out the door and around the corner before it opens, but you'll for sure get seated. I went on a Saturday at 4:30pm and got seated just fine.
- You can order half sizes of each vegetable dish and select fish dishes. The full sizes are plenty so I'd recommend half sizes even if you're sharing.

An amazing Valentine's Day dinner we won't forget. We showed up 15 min early and was seated anyway. Our waiter gave us an additional complimentary dessert- even after we ordered one. 3 plates between 2 people were plenty and they were cooked to perfection.

Must haves: the pork shank, pig face, and any of the desserts. It's a go to spot in Chicago for a memorable dinner!
Girl and the Goat is among the best places I've ever been. Their staff is friendly and helpful, and the food is excellent. I highly recommend this place to any one who visits chicago.
As good as advertised. Variety of small plates. 5 plates for 2 people was perfect. Vegetarian, seafood and meat. Goat and oysters were highlighted. Loved it.

When I decided to visit Chicago, I booked flights and hotel first and Girl & the Goat second. Our experience was really good; service was stellar and the food was pretty unique. We paid around $91 for two people, including 4 dishes, tea, and tip. They call their plates "family-style," but that suggests large portions to me, so I would say they're more tapas style - small, shareable plates more for tasting and less for getting a food coma (unless you have deep pockets). That being said, you can get full if you choose wisely - we ordered the blueberry sourdough bread which was super filling, the duck tongues (nicely crispy and chewy), the pig face (every bite was butter), and the goat empanadas all of which were tasty. Desserts are a little limited, so we opted for tea instead (they serve a brand called Rare Cellar). The tea wasn't as great as the food, but you do get a big cup. Overall, I recommend the place if you can snag a reservation!

When visiting Chicago, my husband and I were excited to get a reservation here based on the reviews. We were both underwhelmed. I don't think we had too high of expectations either.

My husband got the pig face and goat belly. The pig face was incredibly oily. Nothing impressed him with the goat belly either. The wine selection was also mediocre. They served white wine in a stemless glass (call me a wine snob, but I hate that). I got the Brussels sprouts as a side and they were like Brussels sprouts from any other restaurant, nothing intriguing or new.

The highlight of the night was the sea bass. That was a 5 star dish. It had many textures and flavors. If they were all that good I would understand the hype. All in all it was an enjoyable evening, but I would not return.

FABULOUS! It was such a treat to eat at this restaurant tonight with my husband. I have heard so many lovely things about this place, and we finally got to experience those things for ourselves. We started with an old fashioned and a best of 3, which were boozy and a nice way to start the meal. We also decided to have bread instead of dessert, and I think that was a fine choice! The potato bread and sour cream/chili butter that came with it melted in my mouth. From there we had the chickpea fritters which were so fun to eat! Crunchy yet soft and yummy. Next came the cauliflower, which was vibrant and fresh, bursting with flavor! Then came the calamari bruschetta. This was ok, but our least favorite dish of the evening. It was definitely not bad, but it was missing the wow factor that the other dishes had. Finally, we ended with the pork shank. Everything about this dish is perfect. The naan, sauces, and kimchi pair together wonderfully. I cheated on my no meat diet for this and I DON'T REGRET IT ONE BIT. Our server was lovely, water was full, and a great experience was had! Highly recommend for those who want to have some fun trying new things and don't take life too seriously.

Bravo, g&g! You never cease to amaze me, my stomach, or my wallet!

2 of my friends had dietary restrictions (no dairy + pescatarian), but our lovely waitress Alex showed us what could/could not be modified on the menu to suit their tastes.

Roasted Cauliflower with pickled peppers, pine nuts, and mint ($12) -- always a classic and my go-to dish here. The nutty ness of the pine nuts and the mint balance out the peppers. They were so kind as to separate out a portion of non-dairy cauliflower for my friend! What a sweet gesture :)

Wood grilled Broccoli with smokey bleu dressing and spiced crispies ($11) -- delicious like always (hint: the crispies are the best part!) The bleu dressing is subtle and complements the charred broccoli well.

Chickpea fritter with garam masala yogurt, brussel sprouts, feta, sev ($15) -- another go-to dish here. The yogurt balances the feta well and the crispiness of the fritter is so good in contrast to its soft warm insides!

Calamari bruschetta with clam baguette, goat milk ricotta, goat bacon, and green tomato ($17) -- this one was the winner of the night. They some how made cheese and calamari a delicious combination, and for that I salute you, Ms. Izard!

Cape cod mussels with perilla vinaigrette, butternut squash, and chorizo croutons ($16) -- ironically the best part were the croutons. This was a standard dish, and mussels are great but I will not be getting this one again.

Grilled Walter's chicken with fermented tofu jus, chinese spice, grilled fingerling potatoes ($21) -- OMG this dish is MASSIVE. We were already stuffed from the previous 5 dishes and this one was ginormous! As my friend stated "I enjoyed the first few bites but then after that it wasn't worth eating anymore". Will not be getting this dish again.

ON TO THE BEST PART, DESSERT!

Chocolate sorbet (off-menu) -- specially made for my friend with dietary restrictions. I had a bite and it was basically chocolate in ice cream form. Yum.

Peanut butter panna cotta with chocolate covered pretzels, pomegranate seeds, creme fraiche -- although the texture was more budino (oh when will you ever return to g&g??) than panna cotta, it was still delicious. The tartness of the pomegranate was great with the sweetness of everything else and the peanut butter wasn't overpowering.

A+++ Love you g&g.

review.des: My Husband and I decided to take a trip to Chicago for fun, relaxation and to see family. We wanted to get away from our crazy stressful NYC lives. Girl & the Goat was highly recommended so of course we had to give it a try. Not only was the food AMAZING and the atmosphere cool, our waiter Ryan made our experience so much better. He was so nice and informative and he made sure we had the best experience we could have. I wish more people were like him! We would highly recommend this place and can't wait to come back!!!

If you want to be treated like a super star, go with an NFLer like my wife and I did. SOmeone else picked up the check! WOot. But as for the actual food and service, this place achieves high levels of kindness and professionalism despite its affect of being "casual." THe waitress was seamless and deft at accommodating a gluten-free person at the table and the food and cocktails were at the level you would hope a pricey metropolitan hotspot would deserve. This is a place for normies to be impressed and the people bored with their money to feel casual and relaxed.
We came for our 2nd wedding anniversary and absolutely loved it. We got so many different items and all had very unique flavors. One of our favorite places for sure.
Fantastic food, can be difficult to get a reservation during busy times, but the food is fantastic. The staff was very friendly and knowledgeable, and over all a 5 star for the food.

We've gone a couple times, and really love it.  The beans are my personal favorite dish.  The 2nd time, we had a waitress who seemed a little less enthusiastic (I wondered if by not drinking we weren't spending enough, and that's why she wasn't friendlier.)  Our waiter on the first visit was awesome--fun guy, good suggestions.

So good. All the food was great I highly recommend duck tongues they were amazing staff is friendly easy to get to valet is convenient only downside is there's a lot of people in there and it's a little loud

Delightful dining experience from start to finish. Our server Cesar was amazing helping us navigate the menu, offering suggestions and providing detailed descriptions of each dish. Our favorites were Kohlrabi salad, green garlic pierogi, hamachi crudo & the Pig Face. The Lemon Make You Happy dessert was TO DIE FOR. Literally.
Place is good.  We had no reservation, but instead we waited in the line that forms outside the restaurant before they open; We were seated pretty promptly after they opened.  Food is very delicious.

I realize some people will be unhappy with the review, but I have been to G&TG half a dozen times and base my opinion on the collective experience.

G&TG is a bit too tragically hip for my tastes.  The restaurant is tastefully decorated and projects a modern, yet comfortable vibe.  There's a small bar to the left of the hostess stand that is always crowded and there a buzz in the air.  The atmosphere is undeniably fun.

Unfortunately, the food doesn't live up to the decor.  Generally speaking, the dishes pack a lot of flavor (and often, salt), but lack a sense of refinement. More importantly, the dishes are more inventive than they are delicious.  For example, the goat empanadas tasted ok, but were a bit dry and certainly were no better than empanadas I've had at any number of Latin restaurants at 1/3 the price.  Other dishes faired similarly, though it should be noted that the bread is genuinely excellent.

Still, what irked me most was the service.  Once, I asked to hold a menu back after ordering several dishes (in case I wanted to order additional items).  The waitress arrogantly responded "the chef would like you to order everything at once so they can pace your meal for you"...which would have been fine but it is abundantly clear that dishes are served whenever, with no thought whatsoever to pacing.  A dish might be served one minute after another and then there's a ten-minute wait for the next dish (this type of haphazard pattern happened on multiple visits).  

Overall, I like the vibe far more than the dining experience.

Girl & the Goat and their sister location, Little Goat, were two other spots heavily recommended by friends and Chicago-natives. We opted for Girl & the Goat for dinner. They were very accommodating as we had changed our reservation for a later time. We didn't wait too long once we arrived. Seating was intimate. We could have shared meals with our neighbors if we wanted.  

My travel-mates and I ordered an array of dishes during our visit to in July. We had: Goat Liver Mousse, Hamachi Crudo, Soft Shell Chili Crab, Duck Tongues, Crisp Braised Pork Shank, Grilled Baby Octopus. The entirety of our dinner was delightful. Goat Liver Mousse and the Duck Tongues were my favorite. For a group of three, start off with four to five dishes. Order more if you're still hungry afterwards. Portion sizes were moderate to large for a couple of the dishes we had. Service was quick and attentive.

My husband and I showed up at about 5:15 on a Saturday. It was busy, but not packed. We were told as long as we thought we could be done in 1 1/2 hours, we could be seated right away. There was a reservation assigned for our table at 6:45.  We gladly took the table. I ordered the Ring of Fire to drink, which if you like something with a little spice, definitely try it out. We had a super hard time narrowing down to 4 items, but we chose the hamachi crudo, cauliflower, crab rangoon, and goat empanadas. All were good, but we were super surprised about how flavorful the cauliflower was.  The crab rangoon were our least favorite, but still good. Our server wasn't as helpful as some others mentioned in other reviews, but all the other people coming to the table refilling water and explaining food as it came out were really on top of it. I would love to go back to try more dishes!

My friend always wanted to come here and we knew we would have to sit at the bar to eat.  We had great bar service and never felt rushed. Ended up sharing five of the dishes and mixed it up with a cornbread, escargot ravioli, soft shell crab, duck tongue and goat belly dish.  We wanted to try things that weren't everyday items.  We liked every single one of them and each one was well presented.  My favorite was the soft shell crab.

This restaurant is so amazing. If you are nearby and do not go, you are doing yourself a great disservice. The Shishito peppers with miso still appear in my dreams. The crisp braised pork shank... a gift from above. I ate so much at this meal that I felt I might physically explode and yet it was so delicious I could not stop eating. I would sell my soul if it meant I could eat here everyday
What a beautiful and adventurous meal! I loved every bit of my experience. From the food to the cocktails to the service, I was amazed. Chef Izard does it well.

We had a party of 14 for our late holiday party for work. The private room in the basement was the perfect atmosphere for our group. The service was excellent from start to finish. We were having a family style coursed dinner, but also had a few dietary restrictions at our table. Each person was cared for so well with all needs taken into consideration. Replacement dishes were made for those of us with any allergies or restrictions so that we were able to enjoy each course with the rest of our party. It was deeply appreciated that all of our needs were taken to heart without feeling like an annoyance to the staff. We had the best experience we could have asked for and were all very pleased. Not to mention each and EVERY dish that came out was phenomenal. Such delicious food!
Great service . Great experience . Shishito peppers were the best thing on the menu !!!!! Thought everything was great but  I do feel everything was over priced .

I have always been skeptical that Girl & the Goat's reputation lives up to the many month waiting list to get in. But, I have to admit that the entire dining experience was outstanding. The wait staff were friendly, attentive but not intrusive. We were seated promptly once everyone was there and never had to wait too long. The ambience was great and while a bit on the noisy side it was such that it didn't distract from conversation or the experience.

The food was also excellent. There were a surprising variety of dishes to meet everyone's taste. Our favorites were the chick pea fritter, pig face (yes, pig face though no head), pork shoulder, and the goat satay. The desserts were also excellent and bigger portions than I expected.

This is not a restaurant that our family could go to often as it's expensive but we were celebrating two family milestones for our young adult children so it was expected. In summary, an overall beautiful dining experience and would recommend it to anyone.

Maybe it was all the hype that set me up for disappointment ... but I'm glad I went once. Don't think I'd go again. Everything was good ... but I wasn't over the moon for the price or the long waitlist for reservations.

Also, I reeeeaaaallly wish the waitress had specified that "pig face" is not a cute catchy name ... it literally is. Pig. Face. And it was nauseatingly greasy. Eating a plat of butter would have been more appetizing. So yeah ... everything was good EXCEPT that. That was simply awful.

I imagine people that are die hard meat lovers would really like this place. Maybe it's just not my jam. After all the waitress said pigface was their most popular item? MmmmK. Cool. Not for me.

Have dined here several times and even had the pleasure of sitting at the table connected to the kitchen bar. Food is well seasoned and just the right size for sharing which allows you to try multiple menu items. Love the rotating menus makes me want to keep coming back.
So delicious. Worth the wait to get a reservation. Fun atmosphere, and the menu is structured so that you can try many things.
I don't get the allure of this place. The food is good. Not amazing. I've only been here once and I don't really plan on coming back.

Extraordinary service, well rounded servers, and a delicious dinner and cocktail menu.

Highly suggest the green beans and pig face dishes.

Came here with my wife for our anniversary and they didn't disappoint. The pork belly is a must for first time goers here! I'll never forget how good it was, it was like m&ms melted right in your mouth with that savory flavor mmm. Definitely going back again when I get the chance!

a review for the DESSERT & DRINKS

Girl & the Goat was good but I wasn't blown away, perhaps i need to do the full dinner service next time
--miso butterscotch budino: my friend said this was a MUST try and a reason to come to girl & the goat.. it was good but i wouldn't go out of my way to try it
--la paloma: a nice tequila drink, i like em citrusy!

NOTE: they quoted us a 1 hour wait so we just found a spot in the lounge area instead & they told us our table was ready 10 minutes later but we were already settled, so don't be discouraged!

Our first meal in Chicago on Thursday night did not disappoint, but also wasn't as perfect as we expected it to be. There was a bit of a hiccup with our reservation (made last minute by a friend who knows people in high places), so the evening started by us feeling a bit like imposters.

Our server took a while to get to our table, but when he showed up, he was really attentive and fun. We started with the fried oysters with egg salad (stingray something?), and they were freakin' phenomenal: creamy and crispy and salty and perfect. We were told that we needed to try the sautéed green beans, and we're so glad we did because they were heaven in a bowl, and tasted like an umami New Year's Eve party in your mouth. Amazingly, the green beans were our favorite dish of the night.

The next dish, the vitello tonnato was really confusing in terms of concept. They did a thick-cut tartare on the veal, but served it with the thinnest possible tuna tartare chip, so not the best food-to-mouth delivery system. Plus, the chip couldn't sop up any of the heirloom sauce on the plate, so that mostly went wasted. Maybe put the chips on top as a garnish and include some bread? The roasted cauliflower was good, but nothing special. Our final dish, the confit goat belly, which we were really excited about, was not good at all and the worst dish of the night. The goat itself was tender and delicious, but the whole thing came with the most cloying sauce of what seemed like pure honey and ruined the delicate taste of the accompanying lobster and crab. Bummer.

What else? The four cocktails we tried were great, and our two favorites were the gin rubus and the best of three with Pimm's. For dessert, we got the cherry bombe, which was perhaps a spin on tartufo. It was delicious, but the ice cream was so cold/hard-set that it was difficult to eat.

Final thoughts: extraordinary food in an extraordinary space (and worth going to for the green beans alone), but sadly not in the echelon of what we determine to be five stars because of the (above) snafus. We would, however, eagerly recommend Girl & the Goat for anyone wanting a memorable meal in Chicago.
After many years we finally got in! It was worth the wait to say the least. Service was amazing -  we never had a dirty dish on the table and we got new plates between every new dish they served.

I couldn't leave Chicago without trying this restaurant! Book ahead because it's always full. It's a very huge and noisy place but with great effective service. We tried a few tapas and the food is fantastic, fresh and inventive
Highlights:
-calamari bruschetta
-caramel corn and malt balls

The ham frites a bit too salty for my taste
Pig face was 50/50 for us
This place is a must try

This place has close to 5000 reviews and yes ladies and gentlemen, it's a must visit if you go to Chicago.

First and foremost, if you're planning on making a reservation, plan a few weeks in advance. Otherwise, good luck with the wait. The BF and I came on a saturday night around 6:30. We were told that the wait is approx 1.5 hours, as expected, we went to the restroom, came up and saw two spots opened in the sidebar, lounge area. To our surprise, we can actually order food there. Since we didn't want to wait 1.5 hours, we decided to go ahead and have dinner there instead. Score. the full menu was available and we got way too lucky finding a spot there.

We decided to order four dishes to share. Lets just start by saying that dishes are on the smaller side here, so either have a snack before, or plan to have one after. We ordered the following:

Hamachi Crude: delicate pieces of hamachi, maybe six?, pork belly bits, and a chili aoili, with super thin bread croutons on top. This dish was visually stunning. Flavor wise, i think it would have been sufficient without the aioli. I felt that it was too heavy for the delicate fish, but a nice supplement to the meal.

Sauteed green beans: Fish sauce vinaigrette and cashews with green beans, this was super bomb. the flavors were so bold, tangy, sour, and bold. Surprisingly the portion was very large. this was a great dish to start with to cut through the heaviness of some of the other dishes.

Pig Face: This dish was everything and more, It's their version of steak and eggs/spam and egg whatever you want to call it. I love the complexity of this dish with the multi-facet textures and flavors with ingredients that we all recognize. This is a must order. Make sure you mix everything up to get the full range of flavors.

Goat belly: we had the goat belly that night, special for the night. It was a nice slab of tender goat belly, surrounded with bits of lobster and fish with a vanilla bourbon olive olive sauce? This was probably my least favorite dish of the night. The flavors just didn't mesh well at all. The sweetness of the sauce, did not compliment the goat belly as I wouldve liked.

Although this place is super hyped up, it's worth a try. We probably spent about $80 for two people, which isnt too bad (no drinks go).

i would suggest coming with more people just so you can try more variety of dishes and entrees.

Parking is hard to find, take the train instead.

review.des:
This is my first (and probably only) restaurant I would give five stars for. Is it a trendy, hyped-up restaurant? Yes. Is it expensive? Yes. But it's all worth it, and it is a true dining experience.
From start to finish, everything we had was perfect, and it was truly hard to pick a favorite or least-favorite part of the meal. We started with the chickpea fritter, and olives. Our waiter recommended the fritters, and they did not disappoint. From there we also ordered the cuttlefish, red fish, duck tongues, and duck tartare.
I'm not one to allow for atmosphere or staff affect my ratings, but I'd also like to add that the service is impeccable, and added to the already extraordinary experience.

This place is huge and amazing!  I came here with reservations Tuesday night with my sister and husband for my fist time.  This is their 2nd/3rd time!  They tried their best not to over hype the place l, haha, but wow did this place have amazing food!  

Hunter took care of us for the evening and I must say he was phenomenal! We appreciated his service oh so very much!

Here's what we ate:

HAMACHI CRUDO - $16
Crisp Pork Belly, Chili Aioli, Cranberries.
I highly enjoyed the thinly cut yellow fish that had subtle flavored of the chili aioli and citrus from tangerine pieces (I think they ran out of cranberries).  There were some spirits too and the little pieces of pork belly made it nice...but I wouldn't have been fine without it.  It's all about that fish! Great dish!

WOOD OVEN ROASTED PIG FACE - $19
Sunny Side Egg, Tamarind, Cilantro, Red-Wine Maple, Potato Stix.
While smokes this is amazing!!! The flavored and the tenderness and that egg! You mix it all together with that crispy pieces of potato! Oh my goodness this dish is super amazing!!! That red-wine maple gave it that subtle sweetness, and while I may not taste tamarind I'm sure it gave it that tiny kick of tangibles that balance this savory dish out. Oh man this was good!

PAN-FRIED SHISHITO PEPPERS - $11
Parmesan, Sesame, Miso.
They say only one out of a hundreds Shishito peppers is spicy, and when it's spicy, it's REALLY spicy!  In this bowl there were 2 and I got one of them! I should buy a lottery ticket! Actually maybe just. A raffle from some small school charity...heh. Anywho, some of the peppers were red but each of them was covered in the wonderful flavors of Parmesan cheese and miso! This is a pretty greasy appetizer from all the sesame oil but it's fun and full of flavor! It's like playing a roulette game!

GRILLED BABY OCTOPUS - $17
Guanciale, Green Beans, Brussels Leaves, Pistachios, Lemon Vinaigrette.
There's a strong lemon vinaigrette flavor to this but it IS seafood.  This dish is fine but not a favorite for me...it definitely tastes healthier then everything else we ordered too!  Oh and the octopus pieces were tender enough :) it wasn't rubbery or anything.

GOAT SHOULDER - $75
My brother-in-law decided to crazy and order this. I was full by the time this bad boy came out. It was HUGE!!!! It can probably feed 6 people.  The naan pieces were wonderfully fresh, warm and yummy.  The

PB&J - $9
Peanut Butter Cake, Salted Peanut Gelato, toasted Peanut Meringue, Concord Grape.
So this is pretty much a round PB pound-like dense cake, topped with a scoop of peanut gelato, which already melting, sprinkled with pieces of toasted meringue that tasted like peanut brittle but it gave this dessert some crunch, all on a bed of grape jam.  Overall it's not bad and anyone who absolutely love anything PB&J will enjoy this.  But it's not as good as the chocolate truffle cake!

CHOCOLATE TRUFFLE CAKE - $9
"Just the right aMOUND of coconut."
What that means is there is no need for explanation for this amazing dessert anyone who's anyone will fall in love with this. But in case you're curious to know what this dessert is all about, I can tell you!

I think the reason for my next trip to Chicago would have to be because of the girl and goat. Yup.

At nearly 7k comments, GATG doesn't need another  review, yet I'm compelled by yelp to write down something before it allows me to give it a 5 star rating... the service was spot on.. Mike, serving us, helped us choose all the right dishes  and also helped us in selecting the number of plates to be ordered... the roasted peppers, goat empanadas, pork shank and the pig face was all brilliant, but for me, the star of the entire meal was the sweet potato cake and the butterscotch icecream.. simply divine!!! I'd love to have that again, soon...Bonus was the caramel popcorn and the malt balls which was complementary for my husband's birthday....have recommended the place to all the people I know, who haven't made it here yet!

I've been here a few times and I try to order something different every time. So far everything I have tasted was amazing. One of my favorites was the goat empanadas. A must try if you're ever in the west loop.

Overall a good dining experience, and you get your money's worth. Great cozy, homey ambiance, at times gets a little too noisy to talk. Service is very prompt and our waitress was friendly and explained the menu items really well. Make sure to make a reservation *way* in advance because this place is real popular if you can't already tell. We booked this place 1 month and a half in advance for dinner, and expected the food to wow us. For appetizers, we got the Roasted Cauliflower and a grilled octopus dish, which were both delicious stir-fry dish that tasted and looked like they're cooked by a skilled mom, and on the salty side. We also got the Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face, which MELTS IN YOUR MOUTH. The fat and meat just blend into this beautiful mess. Make sure to dip it in egg yolk. The Confit Goat Belly, which is supposed to be one of their namesake dishes, was surprisingly underwhelming. The goat meat was tender, but just didn't go well with the lobster and crab.

Is the experience worth the rave and such long booking in adance? I gave it 3 not 4 stars because of the high expectations - with all the rave and appraisal, we simply expected the flavors to be more balanced and better executed. And note: The dessert portions are for sharing if you barely have enough room left from the meal!! Our waitress told us they are personal sized so we each got one and simply couldn't finish them.

I would let my family starve before I brought them to this over priced craft beer snobbatorium.   While the food was excellent the arrogance of the proprietor and her "your welcome for eating my food" attitude is too much for this guy.  Again, great food but with all the amazing places to eat in Chicago, I should never be made to feel like it's a privilege to patronize a restaurant and spend my hard earned money.

Definitely one of those celebratory places (those places you go to celebrate something,) and I was here to celebrate being in Chicago and for one of my friend's birthday.

I have to start off by saying that I find their logo and the shirts that the workers wear absolutely adorable! I do like the vibe of this place. It also does kinda of remind me of one those places that you bring someone to impress them, but you know what? This place is impressive!

So here's the story of three girls and The Goat, or more like here's what three girls ordered here....LOL...

Hamachi Crudo: Bits of hamachi and very thin croutons. Good, and very refreshing.

Goat Empanada: Figured we order some goat after all it is in the name of the restaurant. My friends are not very adventurous when it comes to food so I figured this would be a good in-between for us, and it was! It was tasty, and I enjoyed the blend of flavors mixed into it. It came with some picked radishes that added a cooling touch to it.

Calamari Bruschetta: Calamaris were not super chewy and just the right amount of tender. The bruschetta or as I like to call it, the bread part, seemed fried instead of toasted. The texture was just right, and you can tell they put a delicious amount of butter on it. Would recommend!

Escargot Ravioli: I do enjoy ravioli, and I do enjoy escargot. I enjoy both of these things separately, and I was very curious as how they would be together. The result was satisfying! The raviolis were tightly packed, and the crispy onions that come with it added a good amount of crunch to it. The sauce was tangy and flavored the dish well.

Roasted Broccoli: YUM. I usually do not order roasted vegetables when I am out, because well, roasted vegetables....LOL, but I was pleasantly surprised here. The broccoli tasted fresh, and it was soft. They had like a kind of rice crispy placed all over it, and there was a kind of blue cheese like sauce to flavor it. I really enjoyed this dish, and it happens to be my second favorite dish here.

Pork Shank: OKAY the star of the show is here. This was my favorite dish here. The meat slid off the bone very easily, and the meat was soft and tender, but not dry. That's very important to me. It came with a nan that seemed to be cooked with alcohol and picked butternut squash. There were also two house made sauces: buffalo kimchi and ranch. Both sauces were great, but my favorite of the two is the buffalo kimchi. I liked making a wrap with the nan, kimchi buffalo sauce and the pork. It was amazing to me that as the dish got cold, the nan did not harden, but remained soft. This dish reminded me of the peking duck, green onion and hoisin in a steamed bun. Both of these dishes, very comforting to me!

Service here was excellent. We had a very friendly server, and our water glasses were never empty. They were always filled without asking. The only thing I regret about coming to this place is not getting an alcoholic beverage, LOL.

Oh yeah, I know this place usually requires a reservation some time in advance, but our ressy (yes, I'm shorting the word to this, hehe) was at 10:15 pm, and we came in right when they opened for dinner and were seated right away.

This place is worth the hype.
My fave restaurant. It never fails. The chickpea fritters are always on point, no matter the seasonal variation.

This place definitely lives up to its reputation. We were with a big enough group that we could try most things, and there wasn't a single item that disappointed. The biggest nice surprise of the night was the desserts were DELICIOUS across the board. Whoever Izard's pastry chef is, I hope to see more of them!
Great sharing plates. Took my parents here when they visited Chicago! Delicious food and great atmosphere. Steph Izards food is amazing.

This was everything we had hoped it was. So good. Everything we tried was amazing. There were 4 of us and we ordered a ton of plates to share. Some of our favorites were the halibut, lamb ribs, pork shank and pig face. Just incredible food and service. So happy we made it there.

"Oh you fancy huh?" That  phrase kept repeating in my head as we were walking to this restaurant. I am a simple man, just steak & potatoes and beer would make me happy for the rest of my life. However, I think you shouldn't be afraid to venture out of your comfort zone and try new things. Remember that variety is the spice of life, and the variety at this place is what makes it absolutely delicious.

We came here to bring our out of town birthday celebrant a little slice of the Chicago food scene, and it didn't disappoint. We went with the Blue cheese sweet potato pierogis, escargot ravioli, and the absolutely wonderful crisp braised pork shank. I went with a nice glass of Three Floyds Zombie Dust beer, and they went with some wine. Oh wait, let me tell you about the music. They played Pharcyde and Tribe Called Quest, and that alone makes this place magical in my eyes.

The food was impeccable and delicious, and the pork shank made my taste buds do the running man. I absolutely enjoyed our dining experience here, and I get it now. I get why Stephanie Izard is held in such high regard, and she is Chicago treasure.

At our son's suggestion, we made G&theG our destination for a family birthday -- and GOODNESS what a perfect place!  The inviting and very eclectic bar, the incredibly well-trained and knowledgeable staff, right down to some interesting menu items, not to be missed.  Too many favorites to name just one -- I can only say, gotta-go-here -- you won't be disappointed!

Come with an empty stomach and a full wallet. My friend and I had a wonderful time here. We're not picky and have been dying to try this place so we just told the waiter - hey, pick a handful of things for us. Our waiter did a great job at explaining the why behind his picks and how the courses will all play out together. Do not forget to leave room for desert. We couldn't decide so we went with two different ones. Overall, a pricey but totally worth it experience.

Huge fan of this place! A friend and I came without a reservation and thankfully were able to get seats at the bar with no wait. We tried the roasted beets, hamachi crudo, and seared diver scallops -- all of which were amazing! The combination of flavors that each dish offered was nothing short of incredible; pretty much every bite was a "wow" moment. Service was great as well. Overall, I'd highly recommend this place if you're looking to experience food with wonderfully unique combinations of flavors and textures, and if you don't mind spending a little extra for it -- I thought it was well worth it and will definitely be back the next time I'm in the area!

For the host that picked up the phone (2x at different times) and say it's an hour wait. Uber there, just so they can say kitchen have issues with gas can't cook food. Could have told us over the phone.

Escargot Ravioli
Bacon tamarind sauce. Escarole and celery. Crispy onions
and the WARM OVEN ROASTED PIGFACE.

Excellent!  You could not ask for a more delicious meal.  braised in pork stock for 12 hours!!!

Really more like 4.5 stars. Made reservations for 4 6 weeks in advance but still had to wait 20 min for our table. Made it up to us by giving us green beans on the house which ended up being one of my favorite dishes. Definitely go with the bucatini! One of my favorite meals I've had in Chicago :)

The food was delicious and portion was very generous. The restaurant also offers a half portions of summer additions. The roasted pig's face was delicious. The restaurant was very busy but service by Zachary and his colleagues remained very friendly attentive. Top-notch! No wonder it is so highly rated in Chicago food scene!

pics.caption: Roasted cauliflower with pine nuts. Flavorful and perfect balance of moisture and crunchiness. The best I have had.

review.des:
The place was on fire the first year it was open. I still remember the first time I went there,  I thought to myself "this is one of the two or three best meals I've had in Chicago!"

It's since settled into a little bit of a inconsistent rut,  but at its best remains one of the premier restaurants in Chicago.  

Good oysters are hard to find in Chicago,  so I'm consistently impressed that G&G is able to find great oysters to serve.  Broiled is great anywhere, but ohh baby I like it raw!

The highlights the last time I went were the beef tongue, duck tongue poke (+++!), and chickpea fritter.  In a stunning failure of my life,  I've been to Girl and the Goat a half dozen times and have yet to actually try any goat dishes.  I'm always so tempted,  but then I see something crazy on the menu,  like duck tongue,  and I have to get it.

It's always hard to get into,  but is worth the effort!

I honestly do not understand the "hype" and 5 star reviews for this restaurant. The overpriced food is mediocre, and the service is absolutely horrible. I am beyond disappointed in this place and am confused at how they have maintained such "high ratings." Perhaps because the restaurant is located in the west loop which is an area of people trying too hard to be with up-and-coming trends so the items on the menu matches to the whole "West Loop" vibe, however, all I saw was disappointment. The only plus I would give this place is the music and atmosphere.

I went to this restaurant on a Saturday evening and had a reservation for three people. My friends and I come from LA,  Miami, and NYC so we understand the importance of reviews and thought that such high reviews for this place was worth us giving it a shot. We were wrong.

When we sat down, we asked the waitress if they served sangria. She responded, "No, this isn't a Spanish restaurant." Her ignorant response from the get-go changed the mood for my friends and I. There are many testaurants who serve sangria and are not "Spanish." It was a simple and fair question we asked. Not only that, but this place serves goat empanadas as well as many other small plates that have a huge Spanish influence on their menu...
In addition to the poor service, this place needs to stop promoting the whole concept of "sharing" the meals because they aren absurdly small. There is no-where on the menu that markets the small plates as tapas so that is misguiding for someone who is looking to actually enjoy a thorough meal without having to spend $100 plus becusee they have to get 3-4 small plates to make it one full meal. My friends and I who don't normally eat that much ended up ordering 3-4 plates each for ourselves and when we left, we went to another restaurant called Au Cheval which is right across the street to eat our actual dinner. I ordered the blue-point oysters for appetizer and they were bland for oysters that were seasoned and cooked. I ordered the goat liver with bread and that was also bland. Their sauces were not bad but the goat liver had no flavor. I ordered the salmon dinner and that was so small I had to order another plate so I got the half grilled chicken (emphasizing half a chicken) which ended up being chopped into 4 very small pieces. The grilled chicken was good but for a main course meal, the small portions should have been served as an appetizer as the size of the chopped "half chicken" are bite sizes. Each time our meals would be served to us, they would put it in the middle of the table and we would tell the staff, "no this is just for me," the staff would still place it in the middle of the table and walk away immedtiately as if they were annoyed with us. I get it--the restaurants "philosophy" is "sharing" but how in the world can you share a plate that takes one to two bites to finish?! After all of that, my friends and I were still hungry so we asked for our check and left.

I see this restaurant being "raved and highly spoken of" for maybe another year or so but I have a feeling the reviews will go lower as the prices and services doesn't validate for the quality of the food. They need to make this known as a FULL TAPAS restaurant and STOP the whole "sharing" of the meals. Our bill for three people  ended up being $250. Unless you have eaten before heading to this place, don't care for the rude service, and are just in the mood to spend a lot of money to listen to music and people watch...otherwise, please, please, avoid this place and go somewhere else. I promise you it is not worth for what you pay for.

If I lived anywhere near this restaurant, I would probably consider doing the following:

1. Working here.
2. Becoming a vegetarian.
3. Eating here for every meal.

That's how impressed I was about this place. I don't think it was mainly about the food (even though most of it was amazeballs!), but it was the experience as a whole. It was seriously one of the best dining experiences I've ever had.

Reservations:
I made a reservations a few weeks before my trip, but unfortunately it was Halloween weekend so the times and dates were not the best. I had to stalk OpenTable for any new changes and I still ended up with an early dinner time. Make sure you book early if you want a desired time and day because this place is ALWAYS busy!

Experience (5 stars):
When we got there, they immediately seated us at what they called the "best seats in the house". I was a little curious about that when they seated us at a counter right in front of the kitchen staff. I'm thinking to myself "How are these the best seats?" Well, they were right. They were and it made our night so much more fun. Special thanks to Chris, Kenny, and Micha (Mika) for being such good dining company/entertainment! They gave us the inside scoop of what to order and hooked us up with some dishes. They were hilarious and so friendly. The staff made it seem like this restaurant was the best place to work in the whole world. Squirting sauce bottles at each other, mocking managers, and just having what seemed like more fun than any patron in the restaurant.

Food (4 stars):
They have ruined vegetables for me and my husband. In my head, how can anybody make vegetables this delicious? To the point where my non-veggie eating husband said that he would eat this in a heartbeat again and again. He even told me that he couldn't go back to eating my vegetables anymore. We ordered the broccoli and cauliflower. Both were perfect cooked. Perfect texture, but the kicker here was the seasoning. The cauliflower had a touch of mint which I thought was genius. It gave it such a refreshing, unique flavor. I would never thought. Our favorite though was the broccoli. Think BBQ broccoli. It really did taste like they put it on a grill with a slab of hot meat. I've never had broccoli this good before.

Another not-to-miss dish is the pig face. Remember the pig face. You will not be disappointed with the pig face. Think an updated version of corn beef hash. When it comes out, you mix everything thing together (the sauces, runny egg, and pig) and then this dish is complete. Wonderful balance of sweet, savory, and crunch. I would be happy if this was my last meal on earth.

I had my first experience with escargot, brussel sprouts, and goat here. All good and made me open to more. This is my ranking of the other dishes we ate.

Escargot dumplings (dumpling dough was extremely well done and soft)
Goat empanadas (not out of this world, but not bad)
Baby octopus salad (too charred)
Ham frites (please don't order this when there are so many other better things on the menu. My husband loves his fries, but this was just basically fries with special dipping sauce)

When we asked for the bill and decided against dessert, our waiter still decided that we couldn't leave without eating something sweet. He brought us a complimentary chocolate cake covered with ice cream, chocolate sauce, and toffee bits. Now that's what I call service above and beyond the call of duty! Such a great way to end a meal!

Overall:
This is a Chicago must! Don't worry about waiting 2 hours or so. It will be worth it in the end. Stephanie Izard is a monster chef. Her food should not be missed.

Tip #1: You can order half portions on certain dishes like the vegetables so you can try more dishes.

Tip #2: It's tapas style so expect to order at least 2 dishes per person.

This is a restaurant you hear multiple things about when looking up best places to eat in Chicago. You'll even find that it's really difficult to get a reservation - we made ours months in advance. The service is good, though I almost felt rushed throughout the entire meal like they were trying to turn the table. Cocktails are good, and on par with other cocktail prices in Chicago ($12-$14). We started with the roasted cauliflower, and dang, they are roasted to perfection. That whole dish was very addictive, and it comes served in a small cast iron. The sauce and seasoning was perfect. We also tried the goat empanadas, because we figured we had to get goat something! They are served with a pineapple blueberry salsa, avocado smash and queso fresco. A delicious queso fresco cheese to be exact. These went quickly. The goat isn't overly gamey like I suspected it to be, but a lighter meat that went very well in the empanadas. The waiter said the halibut was one of the more popular choices on the menu, so we decided to try that as well. It is very light, and served with a delicious almond butter sauce. Lastly, we tried the oven roasted pig face, which is another popular item. It comes served with a fried egg on top, and the yolk just melts into everything. This was my favorite plate, by far. The pig face is so incredibly tender and flavorful. I highly recommend ordering it. There are also some smaller crispy potato stix in there, with a delectable wine-maple glaze on top.
