Girl & the Goat is run by the 2008 Top Chef winner Stephanie Izard and it received the Bib Gourmand from the Michelin Guide from 2011 to 2016 (Chicago had its first Michelin Guide started in 2011). I can't stress how popular this restaurant is because I had to reserve through the OpenTable one month ahead and there was only ONE time slot available.

The restaurant is located approximately 5~10 minutes walking distance away from the Morgan Subway Station.

Menu is separated into various meat and veggie categories - from veggie (e.g. roasted beets), fish (e.g. grilled baby octopus), meat (e.g. grilled pork belly), bread (e.g. Johnny Apple Cheese), oysters (e.g. Wood Fired Eagle Rock), and goat (e.g. confit goat belly). Oh, Girl & the Goat also serves Stumptown Coffee!

***

[Fish] Pan Roasted Drum Fish (autumn crisp apples. szechuan vinaigrette. vanilla bean-herb yogurt - $17): Good and savory fish.

[Veggie] Wood Grilled Broccoli (rogue smokey bleu. spiced crispies - $11): It had such interesting & unique smokey flavors. Personally, I don't think everyone would enjoy this dish.

[Meat] Wood Oven Roasted PIG FACE (sunny side egg. tamarind. cilantro. red wine-maple. potato stix - $19): Noticed how I used capital letters to get your attention? Yes this is a must-order dish. Best dish of the night with melt-in-your-mouth pig face. If you want to know how this dish is created, there's a slideshow ( *** WARNING - GRAPHIC RAW PIG FACE IMAGES *** chicago.seriouseats.com/…)

[Veggie] Chickpea Fritter (garam masala yogurt. brussels sprouts .  winter squash . sheep's feta. sev - $15): Chopped tofu-shaped squash tasted like smooth version of fried potato and this was a pretty delicious dish.

Miso-Butterscotch Budino (sesame gelato. sesame whip. glazed pineapple, $9): Absolutely amazing black sesame gelato (probably one of the best black sesame ice cream/gelato I've had), but butterscotch was a bit too sweet for me.

***

If I had more room for food, then I would actually order couple more dishes. Absolutely incredible & flavorful food and I wouldn't mind come back here for second round if I ever visit Chicago again.

P.S. -  The restaurant does accept walk-in, but expect a long one to two hours wait during dinner time (or you can come here right after it opens their door at 4:30 PM).

P.P.S. - It was ranked 38th on the Yelp's Top 100 Places to Eat for 2016.

pics.caption: Dessert, cheese, coffee, and dessert drinks menu - Oct 2015
Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face (sunny side egg. tamarind. cilantro. red wine-maple. potato stix - $19)

review.des: I like this place when it isn't prime time. Gets loud. However, the food is fresh and tasty, the menu is eclectic (something for everyone), and the attached bakery is wonderful.

I came here while waiting for Au Cheval.  They accommodated me hours prior to my  reservation which was really nice of them.  The food was mediocre, but a place with just under 5k reviews you have to try it.  

Braised beef tongue - This dish was decent, you can pass on it.  
Hamachi crudo - I'd pass on this dish.  It comes with very minimal amount of meat.
Fried naked oysters - One bite of this goodness and you're done with it.  They were decent nothing to rave about.  
Escargot dumplings - probably my favorite dish.  The consistency is the same as dumplings, but obviously with escargot.  
Wood oven roasted pig face - You must try this.  The dish is topped with egg and anything with egg makes anything better!
Confit goat belly - Too salty and not worth the price.  

Overall you get tapa style here, so you'll walk away with a barely filled appetite and an empty bank account.  Service was good and the food came out in a good amount of time.  If you really must get a drink here, it's worth it.

After hearing so much hype about this restaurant, my friends and I had it at the top of our list of places to check out. The only problem is that snagging a reservation at a reasonable time is damn near impossible. We ended up booking 2 months in advance and still had to settle for a 9PM Sunday night time slot haha. By the time it was the weekend we were going, I actually completely forgot we even made the reservation.

All this advanced planning was just building up some massive expectations for the food. But I gotta say that Stephanie Izard and team totally delivered. It was easily one of my favorite meals I've had in Chicago so far.

For as hot of a restaurant this is, I actually thought the prices were pretty reasonable. Our group ordered a ton of stuff and got to try a little bit of everything, and it was still cheaper than a steak at Gibsons.

Food: I wasn't about to make 9PM Sunday dinners a habit, so we made it a point to order everything in sight as if there wouldn't be a next time. Luckily we had a big enough group to even try the massive goat leg too.

Chickpea fritter - A really tasty deep fried ball of hummus basically. Crispy on the outside, and smooth and creamy in the inside.

Sauteed greeen beans - Even though I generally don't like fish, I ironically love the taste of fish sauce for some reason (probably because of Filipino patis), so I enjoyed the salty vinaigrette in this dish.

Roasted cauliflower - They must be doing something right if I actually enjoyed eating veggies. Solid side.

Hamachi crudo - I just saw the words crispy pork belly on the menu and automatically ordered this. I didn't even realize it was a fish dish. I'm not the biggest seafood fan so it was far from my favorite bite.

Escargot ravioli - You couldve filled those suckers with anything and I still would've eaten it. The pasta was thin and fresh, and that sauce that was coating the ravioli was delicious. I just wish there was more.

Goat empanada - It pained me to split the empanada into thirds because it was so good. I could've eaten a ton of these. Crunchy and flaky crust with a juicy, meaty filling.

Ham frites - Eh. They were tasty but nothing more than fries with some sort of ham flavored dust on top. The dipping sauces were pretty money though.

Pig face - I had really high expectations because everyone I talked to and all the reviews I read were raving so much about it. Again, it was tasty but nothing mind blowing. Maybe I don't appreciate jowl meat as much as I should, but when you mash it all together, it tastes like a regular breakfast dish to me. It was like a gourmet version of bacon, eggs, and hashbrowns.

Pork shank - THAT ORANGE SAUCE. What is it?? I still have no clue, but I could literally drink it. There was nothing better throughout that entire meal than dipping pieces of naan in whatever sauce that was. The meat on the pork shank was amazing as well. Nicely crisped outside followed by succulent and fatty meat that fell off the bone. Hands down best dish of the night. I'll order this again and again.

Goat leg - We honestly ordered this mostly for the experience. We had enough people so why the hell not. They brought out a huge board with a big goat leg surrounded by a bunch of different sauces. It also came with some crispy onions and a whole basket of naan. The meat was super tender. In fact, we literally pulled the bone out clean with no effort. Maybe I just like the taste of pork better than goat, but in retrospect I would definitely just order multiple pork shanks next time instead of this. Worth it to try once though.

Overall, gatg is probably one of my favorite restaurants in the city. I'm not the most adventurous eater, so their ability to make me enjoy unique ingredients I wouldn't usually eat is a win. Everything tasted great...Really good contemporary tapas without the absurd fine dining prices.

I've been to a lot of tapas places but this one was amazing. It takes a long time to get a reservation but I was traveling solo and got lucky to get a seat at the bar. This was true culinary art and I'm already diving this place next time I'm in Chicago. The drinks aren't memorable but the food is worth the wait.

Can't go wrong here. We tried Johnny Apple cheese, halibut, senna, cauliflower, goat belly.  Everything was exceptional. Biggest pleasant surprise was the blueberry sauce on the halibut. The cauliflower dish had a bunch of flavors between the parmesean cheese bites and the mint and peppercini bites. The goat belly, crab lobster dish was Delish but it was so rich that it was difficult to eat anything else after. No flaw in that dish but we wish we got the goat empanadas instead. Service was excellent. I'd recommend this place to anyone. Tourist or local.

Coming in to this place I had very high expectations, but I was very open to trying out new things. We ordered pig face, roasted green beans, and pork shank. The presentation was fantastic, but I have to admit that I was a little disappointed with the dishes themselves. They didn't come at the same time and all of them were too salty and oily. The service is pretty attentive as he pours the water on time. Overall an average place. I prefer avec to girl and the goat.

The hype is real. Even the simpler dishes are extremely delicious. Portions are surprisingly big for a tapas-style restaurant. We had seared scallops, string beans, pig face, goat belly, hamachi curso, and bread.

Girl & the Goat is another must try in Chicago! The Purple Pig ever so SLIGHTLY edges out Girl & the Goat but both are delicious. We came to Girl & the Goat after an amazing lunch at The Purple Pig so my tastebuds may have very well been biased.

In order of deliciousness:

*Sauteed Green Beans (Fish Sauce Vinaigrette. Cashews): This was a little bit on the salty side but the flavors were magical - the savoriness of the fish sauce + the rich cashew + fresh green beans...YES. I also love fish sauce + veggies (RIP Red Medicine).

*Wood Grilled Broccoli (Rogue Smokey Beu, Spiced Crispies): There's cereal in my broccoli?! YES. The broccoli was so wonderfully smoky from being wood grilled. Again, a little on the salty side but still tasty nonetheless

*Copper River Sockeye Salmon (Yellow tomato, vanilla bean yogurt, Sungold Salad, Spiced Peanuts): I really enjoyed how fresh this dish was. Beautiful colors with the tomato and cucumbers. Really well cooked Salmon. Why would one order Salmon at Girl & The Goat? When one is too pork'ed about from The Purple Pig.

*Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face (sunny side egg. tamarind. cilantro. red wine-maple. potato stix): I know this is THE thing to get here, so how come it's so low on my list? In my head, I imagined canto-style BBQ with an ACTUAL Pig's Face but of course, that's not appetizing is it? Haha.

*Escargot Ravioli (bacon. tamarind-miso sauce): The idea of Escargot freaks me out but figured that this was as good a time as any to try it. The ravioli was a little too mushy for my liking but, the sauce was divine.

*Goat Empanadas (Smoked Blueberry Tapenade. Avocado): This isn't exactly something I'd eat a lot of BUT I think it's a must try here. I didn't love the whole blueberries but weren't very incorporated in the dish itself. Props for a non-gamey goat though! anddd can't complain about the execution of the empanada itself

Parked on the street (metered) or there's valet.

pics.caption: Copper River Sockeye Salmon (Yellow tomato, vanilla bean yogurt, Sungold Salad, Spiced Peanuts)
Wood Grilled Broccoli (Rogue Smokey Beu, Spiced Crispies)

review.des:
I waited a really long time to come here. My friendly finally got a reservation and I really excited to get the chance. Now, the food is good but I don't see why it gets so much hype.
Staff: Amazing and attentive
Pace of meal: My friends and I ordered a lot of dishes, probably too many for three people, but they simply came out too quickly!!! I felt like every minute we finished one dish the next was at our table and it was totally overwhelming!
bread: Sweet onion brioche- if you ever had brioche, this was just brioche, nothing special.
Vegetable: The vegetable dishes are all solid choices. We ate the following: Shishito peppers (really good but I didn't see the need for the Parmesan), roasted cauliflower (YUM!), and Potato-blue cheese pierogies (I wouldn't order these again for the price, nothing special)
Fish-  The escargot ravioli could have been filled with anything, They didn't highlight the flavor of the escargot and everything was drowned out with the taste of bacon.  
Seared diver scallops- SO GOOD! I love scallops and these were nicely prepared, however, whats with the citrus? The blood orange just didn't work with this dish.  
Seared tuna: Good but small portion and unexciting, I have had seared tuna just as good at a cheaper restaurant.
Calamari Brushetta: I was really excited about this dish but the calamari was a little under cooked and had an odd fishy flavor I didn't enjoy at all.
Meat: Beef short ribs- good but why more grapefruit!!!! I DONT GET IT!! Nothing special
Pig Face: Tasted good but nothing spectacular.
Goat with lobster and crab: The goat was really good but the flavors didn't work with the lobster and crab.
Dessert: Sticku tasty crunchy toffee- OMG ORDER THIS!! AMAZING!
Best part: The staff was really nice and the environment was enjoyable. The meat is all high quality.
Major complaint: Whats with the blood orange and grape fruit making an appearance on so many dishes? It just didn't work and the pieces were too big and drowned out other flavors.

I don't get why this place is so popular. There are many other restaurants that are more interesting with a shorter wait time. I really wanted to love this but won't be coming back anytime soon.
Amazing food, would recommend the pork shank and scallops in particular! They also have a good local craft beer selection, had the Pilsner and Pale Ale.

This place is supposed to really push the envelope but I think the whole thing comes across too "extra". Izard is a phenomenal chef which only highlights my disappointment in what this place could have been. I found portion sizes to be small, service slow, and the restaurant too loud. This is not what I've come to expect from Izard but is my experience after dining here twice. For the record, her other two restaurants are two of my favorite!

Great diverse menu and wonderful food. Service was a little slow but that's because this place was so incredibly crowded for Saturday morning brunch. The food and speciality coffees were worth the wait.

First off... wow. Holy smokes. Booked a reservation about 2-3 months in advance and I'm so glad I did. The restaurant is chill and very welcoming. Stephanie always creates a great atmosphere in all her restaurants and this one shines in particular. The staff was very friendly, knowledgeable and accommodating. We ordered Calamari bruschetta on clam baguette with goat milk ricotta with goat bacon and Apple.

Rogue Broccoli with smokey blue cheese and spiced crispies

Confit goat belly with Bourbon butter lobster and crab

Crisp braised Pork shank with buttermilk dressing with butternut squash and nan

Everything came out fast, food was perfect. Couldn't be happier

pics.caption: Confit goat belly with Bourbon butter lobster and crab

review.des:
I visited with a friend last week for the first time. We were greeted by a team of friendly hosts, seated, and did not wait long before our server arrived. He answered our questions, made recommendations and took our drink orders.

He politely asked that we order everything at the same time, so they can essentially review our order and make recommendations. I think it is to help the kitchen manage the pass and resources, which is fine, but maybe it is for meal planning. He also suggested 6-7 dishes to share between the two of us and suggested a vegetable dish because we ordered two rich dishes (and that is a bad thing?).

We ordered the Soft Shell Chili Crab, Confit Goat Belly, Duck Tongues, and Pig Face, four dishes that we knew we wanted and stopped there. I appreciate the suggestions, but let the customer decide how much they want to order, especially if you want everything ordered up front. We don't want to waste food, right? We will decide how much is enough for us, thank you.

Half way through we added the Miso Hungry bread plate that we seem to have missed on the menu because we felt a little pressured to try and predict how hungry we would be and what we might be in the mood for as we progressed through dinner. The intention is well meaning, but I don't like to dine out like that. I'm here to relax and enjoy. I'm sure the kitchen can handle change and be flexible. This is not a new restaurant.

Every dish we ordered was great, but the Confit Goat Belly, served with crab and lobster was my favorite! The goat belly was so tender and rich and delicious! Amazing dish! The Pig Face was my second favorite. The pig face "patties" are cooked in their wood burning oven and topped with a fried egg and served over potato sticks with a red wine-maple gastrique. The pig face was crisp and yet tender. It was another amazing dish.

The soft shell crab and duck tongues were very good, too, and all dishes were beautifully plated. The duck tongues were so incredibly tender and delicious!

Were it not for this experience with the ordering practice, this would be a 5 star review. If I could give 4 1/2, I would. So consider this a 4 1/2 star review.

Dear Girl & the Goat:
 By all means, make suggestions to the customers and have that conversation about what they might like after they review the menu, but take some of the pressure off and let them order a couple of dishes at a time. They may change their mind and go a different direction. You don't want the customers leaving with regrets, do you? BTW, the 5 dishes we shared filled us, so 6-7 would definitely have been too much, and I was visiting from out of town so leftovers would have been wasted. Keep up the awesome food, though. It was definitely one of the best meals I've ever had!

I know, I know... I really don't know why I have the urge to write a review for this place as it clearly has an exuberant amount of A+ reviews as it's one of the most popular restaurants in Chicago. BUT, coming here yesterday for the first time... im still drawn to do it!

Ambience is fantastic and casual, making it easily adaptable to a girls night out or cute date night!

Plates are shareable, and for two people, I would suggest ordering 4-5 plates. What we got:

-brioche bread
-green beans
-potato pirogies
-goat empanadas
-pork shank

All were individually amazing. I really don't have anything bad to say. Everything was just melt in your mouth yummy and each shareable dish you still felt you had a good amount. Service was great - very attentive! We also got the chocolate cake dessert - holy amaze-balls. We usually skip on dessert and don't usually have a sweet tooth,  but this just opened up a whole new world that I've been missing out on.

Sprinkle in three rounds of cocktails with everything above and our bill came to only $160 (less tip)!!! WAY LESS than what we thought it was going to be, knowing we were leaving full/drunk from one of the top Chicago restaurants!

Cheers to girl and the goat! Also it's true... make a reservation in advance, but they still call people to confirm there reservations as it gets closer to the day of, and so I'm sure you can snag something that opens, but obviously that's first come first serve....

You know a place is really good if they can make plain vegetables like cauliflower, taste amazing!

I came here with a group of 10 after making reservations months in advance. We didn't really understand how to order and the waiter told us that everything is "to share" and made us pass around the menu putting tallies next to the dishes we wanted. This was a bit odd because there were a couple dishes i wanted to share with my boyfriend, and a couple dishes I wanted to have for the table. When asking the waiter we could just order a couple dishes for smaller groups of people at the table (so that everyone could get the dishes they wanted and wanted to pay for) he was appalled and immediately said "everything is to share, the menu is designed that way" well...I get that, but we have a group of TEN. How are we supposed to share, for example, the scallops dish if it arrives at the other end of the table and I was the one that wanted it (and then is all eaten up by the time it reaches my side of the table?) Very weird, I think at a place like Girl and the Goat, the waiter should try to accommodate for the wishes of the guest, even if it is out of protocol.

That being said, when the food arrived, everything was very very good- we ordered the following:
- cauliflower (a MUST get! The char and the seasoning on the dish is amazing)
- onion brioche (very good- but pricey for getting 4 halves of bread with some green butter that frankly just tasted like butter)
- kohlrabi salad (pretty good, probably would not order again tho- tasted pretty plain)
- scallops (really good but only came with two pieces (for $19) and had a strong taste of capers)
- halibut (AMAZING- a must get. comes with the most amazing enoki mushrooms that matched perfectly with the delicate fish. Also, the fish had a perfect sear)
- duck tongue (very interesting, I'm just not a fan of weird meats but this was super savory and well seasoned. the duck was fried and came with some greens and just melted on your tongue!)
- pig face (I think I would pass on this- we ordered this because it seemed to be super popular based on the yelp reviews but I found the dish a bit too salty)
- tempura shrimp (others thought this was amazing but I felt like it was just plain tempura with a bit of a fancier sauce, not worth the price!)

Overall, a very good experience. I would probably come back with a smaller group of people and try other dishes- and perhaps order the cauliflower and halibut again!

So I was lucky enough to get a table here on a weekday night. According to other yelpers, you actually need to make reservations like months ahead.  Although we were waiting for abut two hours.
I do like this place. It was crowded on a weekday night!  The interior was nice and cozy. Service was cool.  Now we can focus on the food. Basically they have 3 main items from the menu and one special menu. So we ordere one from each. Price-wise, it is not expensive only if you compare the portion to the price then yes..
Vegetables- roasted cauliflower, it's simple but was very tasty.
Fish- octopus- the octopus was very tender and not chewy at all.
Meat-beef rib- this beef reminds me some Chinese dish. However, it was pretty tender and juicy.
Special menu- goat belly.. compare to the price, this portion was very small, you will only get two small pcs of meat, but it's worth. I can't taste the stinky of the goat meat. Same like all other dishes, tender and juicy.
So it was one the places must go in Chicago and it sure is!

I've been looking forward to try Girl and the Goat since I liked Little Goat. Verdict: Good, could be better.

Food was unique. Tapas style with a few bigger dishes. As soon as we got seated, we were served sweet potato bread with corn? butter and fruit and nut tapenade (which was so good!). Liked the goat empanadas and the crispy pig face. Also tried the corn pierogies and goat shank. The latter two were ok. Flavors were powerful. However, it seemed that dishes were very similar in taste. I think GG shines on bread and pig face (which I noticed was ordered by majority). It's impressive how SI was able to make goat dishes diner-friendly. They had zombie dust on tap, which was a plus. Pb&j for dessert was yum.:)

Service was ok. Note: GG is popular, and reservations are hard to come by. We got an 8pm table on a Saturday night. Had to wait 30 minutes to get seated. At 8:20, we were approached by the hostess to apologize for the wait, which I think was nice of them to do. They don't take down numbers or give beepers to let you know if your table is ready. You'll have to wait by the door, or if you're lucky, find a space in the lounge/bar area. Dishes come in waves. (Or we just ate too fast, it was tough to keep up). My glass of water was always refilled. Plates were bussed out quickly.

Ambiance was loud and cozy. Too cozy, you can hear the conversations on either side of your table. Iol. I like the decor.

Price was decent. Around $120+ for 2 people, with 4 or 5 dishes, one glass of beer and dessert.

I'm not sure if it's worth coming back, but the second time might be better. We'll see.

You've heard the hype. It's warranted.

I took my girlfriend here for her birthday, she and I had been wanting to go for a while and the birthday thing was a nice excuse to spend a bit. In the OpenTable reservation I made, I mentioned that it was her birthday.

What a great decision that turned out to be. For one, every staff member we came into contact with wished her a happy birthday. Then they gave us the chef's table. And a discount off the meal, just because.

I'm not going to review the food individually, I don't do that. It's good though. Really good. You can trust me.

Oh, and get a cocktail. Why not, you're out to have fun, right?

My husband and I were in town for work and had a few hours to kill, so I suggested we try getting in to Girl and the Goat.  We walked in around 4:45, and they were gracious enough to seat us.  We ordered wine and had lovely conversations with the sommelier!  She had great suggestions that paired with the amazing food!  Our waiter was also incredible, and he steered us towards phenomenal food.  Love this restaurant and can't wait to come back!!!!

Went here on friday night with 6 friends.  Most of us are from the NYC area.  Were visiting.

Will say, one of the top 5 meals of my life.  Up there with places like le bernardin, eleven madison, gramercy without the stiffness.  Really cool place, family style food.  They have 3 sections, veggies, fish and meat.  Also desserts.

We ordered 4 from each section and 3 desserts.  Out of 15 dishes, we thought 14 were spectacular.  My favs were the cauliflower, chickpea fritter, scallops, lamb ribs, chicken and pork shank.

The chicken and pork shank were the best.  Chicken was super juicy and sauce was perfectly light but flavorful.  Cilantro and mint based sauce.  The pork shank was simple but well executed .. fall off the bone and served with a fluffy tortilla.  

For dessert, the malt balls were excellent. Flavorful ice cream.

This place was absolutely fantastic, from the setting to the way you eat here to the food itself it's all top notch.

We started with the cheesy bread and the ham frittes. The fries could be the best fries I've ever had. They use a fine grater on some baked ham and dust the fries with ham. It's delicious and both of the sauces are great, one is a cheese sauce and the other has some spice to it.

The calamari bruschetta was fantastic the cheese compliments the calamari really well. This was my buddy's favorite dish.

The short ribs was an interesting twist on short ribs. There wasn't much meat and it was heavily seasoned. If you get this dish smash up the meat and mix it in with the other things in the dish.

The goat and lobster dish we got was very rich and delicious but you may need a double shot of espresso after eating it. It's very rich but also very tasty.

The pork shank may have been my favorite and the sauce is killer. You really should be required to order this dish when here.

Oven roasted pig face was awesome. I think we were a bit full at this point to enjoy it as much as we should have but it was pretty epic.

Goat cheesecake was amazing! We didn't order desserts but they brought us a plate of this and the brownie with caramel ice cream because we had people from the industry and both plates were awesome. If you have room after eating get the cheesecake and you will be happy you did.

Highly recommend this spot.

pics.caption: Goat cheesecake - if you have room you must get this

review.des: Service was excellent and food choices tasted great. Very fun & eclectic menu. Would 100% go back and recommend you visit.

Your shop is racist, you need to get rid of your host! He gives me and my friend a rolling eyes and cold shoulder when we ask for getting a seat for two hours wait which we are totally fine waiting for it.

Don't get snubbish , you are not making food into golds

If I could give this place a 6th star I would!  Outstanding Service. Delectable food with a great range of options for any palate. Highly recommend letting your server recommend/choose the courses.
Cheers Hunter, for making my birthday a memorable one.
Great food! I had been wanting to try this place out for quite some time! The service was great despite the busy night. I will definitely be back! I will also be trying "The Little Goat". Delicious!

This restaurant has been on my top 5 list in Chicago since it opened. Everything on the menu is excellent and won't disappoint. Some of my favorites are the green beans and the pig face. All the seafood options are always perfect and incredible quality. Don't be afraid to order all the vegetable dishes as Stephanie is the queen of transforming boring food into incredible umami. Most dishes tend to have Asian influence.

Girl & The Goal lives up to their hype. I was able to get a reservation here a couple months ago ON A WEEKEND (the universe was on my side). All the food was impeccable in presentation and quality. The flavors were diverse and interesting. The cocktails were also spectacular.

And the chocolate molten cake was honestly the best thing I have ever eaten in my entire life. How am I to go back to normal desserts?

Highly recommend! Great for a special occasion.

If you can get reservations here and you're from out of town... do it. So glad we were able to. My friends and I actually booked at least 2 months in advance and were successful! On the day of our dinner... We had to push our dinner back an hour or 2 due to our tourist schedule; we were still good to go!

Inside - looks pretty cool. Busy and quite nice. I like the whole set up.

Service - Very good. Our server was attentive & food came out at a good pace.

As for the reservations part - we sat near the front, so I heard a lot of people coming in and some didn't have rezzies. Most of them sat at the bar waiting for a table to open up. That could be an option for you. I personally don't like waiting over an hour for a table.

Food -- our server said 2 per person would be filling enough. But really... it depends on what you order. My friends and I were kind of mislead on portions wise. Haha. Oh well. More food is better than less food.

My favorite dishes...

Crispy Braised Pork Shank - This is entree sized. I thought it was smaller, but when it came out....My eyes were bigger than my stomach. The meat was so good - done just the way I like it. Especially with the sauces & Naan bread. They do include some sort of Mango Kimchi. I don't like fusion Kimchi, so I barely at it, but my friends had it and enjoyed it. I'm drooling just thinking about this dish... YUM. I highly recommend this item, especially if your table wants to do a "share each dish" kind of thing!

Goat Liver Mousse - The bread/mini biscuit came out warm and smelled enticing. The taste of the bread was super good. Imagine a super good piece of bread along with Mousse, Jam, and some sort of Pickled Veggies. AHHH. Melted in my mouth. This dish was pretty big. Definitely shareable. But if one was only wanting this dish and nothing else, go at it.

Grilled Octopus & Spicy Chili Crab - if you like seafood and you like grilled items. I'd get these. Both dishes had bold and strong flavors and they were given in generous portions. The rice in the Spicy Chili Crab absorbed all the ingredients and was delicious. Grilled Octopus was done perfectly. Some places kind of fail at grilling this usually, but not G&TG! MMMM.

^ I should note... I rarely eat seafood. So... my taste buds are different.

Duck Tongues - I kind of thought this tasted like Chicken. I've never had Duck Tongue till now. So... not an expert. Even though to me the name is weird, I still enjoyed the dish. I actually used the sauces included in my Crispy Braised Pork Shank to give it more of a zing.

5/5!

pics.caption: Saw Nat Faxon when we dined here :)

review.des:
I had sky-high expectations for Girl and the Goat, and am also a huge Top Chef fan. I really wanted to love it, but based on what we ordered I don't get what the big deal is.

Goat Empanadas - Very tasty, but not unique enough. You only get two empanadas, and at this price tag they should really be bites of heaven.

Pig's Face - This is like fancy bacon and eggs. It's good, but I had different expectations based on the name. The bed of hashed potato doesn't have much taste or body, and just isn't memorable.

Chickpea nuggets - These things resemble fried tofu, but are a little more like Japanese croquettes. They are tasty with the cream sauce and strawberries, but I don't love it.

Pan Roasted Halibut - The standout dish of the night. The sauce has an Asian-inspired flavor with a barely creamy touch. The fish is cooked perfectly, and is a real treat. I would order this again.

There are a few moments of greatness at Girl and the Goat, but they are few and far between.

Fantastic as always! Lucked out when a reservation opened up for same day Saturday. We ordered Beet salad, Wood grilled oysters, Goat Empanadas, Pan roasted Halibut and Carmel corn & malt balls. Everything was perfect! The goat empanadas amazing, the blueberry takes these delicious eats to another level. But the favorite of the night was the Halibut.  The fresh perfectly cooked fish accompanied by almond butter, white asparagus and blueberry made these already great fish a absolutely phenomenal!  The flavors were outstanding. Always a treat for the palette!

Ehh, this place is over hyped. We weren't able to make a reservation the week before but we came really early (at 5pm) for dinner on a Friday evening and was able to get a seat. Yay! Seems like you need to make reservation one month in advance in order to get a seat. We had a 2 hour dinner limit. Our server was friendly and helpful. You're suppose to order 2-3 dishes for each person. The portions are like tapas style  and to be shared family style. We ordered around 10 items. I don't remember everything we had but I felt half of the dishes we ordered were pretty salty. I did not really have a favorite dish, either. The price tag is up there, though.

Overall just an okay restaurant for me. My co-worker from UK wanted to try this place out since it's so popular and that was the reason we came.

Have you ever wanted to be alone with food?
As in, you don't want people to see the stupid faces and hear the weird sounds you are going to make because the food you are going to eat is going to force you to do some embarrassing things because it is that outstanding.
At one point, I said to my sister sitting across from me - "don't look at me."

I ordered a BoltAction - a lovely bourbon drink with ginger beer and citrus. All around win.  We each ordered about two dishes and shared them all. Sharing is caring folks. We ordered the bread - with a nori infused butter and kimchi.  Oh dear lord the bread..... it was gorgeous and warm.

We sat facing the kitchen - and it was great to see these masters at work!

The food came out in a specific order. The kitchen takes a look at your order and arranges them to come out in a certain way. It is fantastic, because you get one dish, revel in its glory, and then the next comes out when you were ready. Squash blossom crab rangoon, pan fried shishito peppers,   roasted cauliflower, duck tongues (they were so tiny and wee and crunchy), pan roasted halibut, wood oven roasted pig face (yes, and this was the salty meaty pleasure my wanna be vegetarian side forgave me for).

The star of the night for me was the halibut. It had savory almond butter and blueberry relish -- it took all my power to not hoard it and share it. It was probably one of the most perfect bites of food I have ever had.

We ended the meal with coffee and the   caramel corn & malt balls.  And the only thing missing was an order of bread to go... seriously would consider it!

The food is very fresh and creative. Had fire wood oysters, roasted cauliflowers, goat empanada, pig face. The mini lamb ribs on the house, which is so tender and flavourful! Personally think the pig face is too heavy. It would be better to have it with rice or some vegetables. I definitely won't have it again. The rest of the food was all very tasty!

pics.caption: Caramel popcorn with vanilla ice cream coated with chocolate

review.des: If you can get a reservation, make it happen! It can take weeks but worth it. Its a far and classy setting with an extensive menu of delicious sharing plates. I don't eat meat which its famous for but there are some great salads and veg options. I love the broccoli with rice kripies, its grilled well and hearty. They have a great wine list too. I took my parents here, they thought it was going to be super expensive but for the quality the plates are priced very fair.

Definitely a must try in Chicago if you are looking for a nice place to eat. I was worried I wouldn't be able to make a reservation since my party of 3 decided to dine here last minute, but we were able to secure a reservation two days before for 5:15 on a Wednesday night.

The restaurant is spacious, with couches and a bar on the left side to enjoy a drink while you wait for a table. Here is what we got:
Fall-caccia: (3.5/5): This was rustic and comforting but not the best. I think I could've skipped on this. However both the butter and the apple spread were super tasty.
Goat empanadas: (4/5): I liked that this dish wasn't too heavy but was still really full of flavor.
Green beans with cashews (5/5): I had no idea that green beans could be this delicious!! It didn't sound that unique on the menu but when we received it I couldn't stop eating. It's quite a large portion too so I would suggest only getting one veggie dish if you want to try all the other meat dishes.
Diver scallops (5/5): This was my FAVORITE dish of the night, it was probably hands down the most delicious scallop dish I have ever had in my life...and I love me a good scallop. Something about the sweet nuttiness of the sauce was just out of this world. The scallops were also seared to PERfection.
Sea bass (4/5): At first I thought the flavor was just ok, but as I continued to eat I really enjoyed the numbing sensation of the Schezuan peppercorns mixing with the yogurt sauce.
Pig face (5/5): Oh man this was so good too. The addition of the crispy potato shreds is a must, since the pig face is so soft it just melts in your mouth when paired with the gooey egg, so the contrast in texture is wonderful. Another stand out dish.
Pork shank (4.5/5): I really like this since it's a showstopper. This dish is HUGE so make sure to save some room. The naan is so soft and delicious and the pork shank is braised to fall-off-the-bone perfection. I wasn't a huge fan of the "kimchi" that accompanied this dish though. Sadly we had ordered so much before that we couldn't finish this ;(

It is really hard to find a place where pretty much every single dish is so wonderfully executed. Girl and the Goat deserves its high ratings and I would absolutely recommend this place to anyone.

I give it a 4 stars because of price and portion size.. paid $75 for me and my hubby to eat here. Food combinations were unique and tasty, just very small portions. We had the caesar ciabbata bread, calamari brushetta, goat empanadas, escargo ravioli, 1 coffee, and dessert. Don't order the calamari brushetta, it tasted too fishy. The dessert was really good and the goat empanadas. They come around to fill our water every 10 minutes which is nice. Bathrooms were really nice, fancy individual stalls. Will we eat here again? Maybe after we eat a meal, everything seems to be appetizer portions, I would eat the empanadas and dessert again. I recommend the caramel pocorn ice cream dessert.

If you are looking for a dank dish I would highly recommend the pig face. My mouth started watering as my knife sliced the egg yolk on the top of the meat.... Jesus Mary and Joseph. Service was incredible. Friendly staff that helped us decide on the best dishes. Highly recommend.

After all these years, Girl and the Goat is still amazing! I hadn't been here for probably a year and after coming back it was just as amazing!

The bacon cheese bread was killer and a must have! Sautéed Green Beans were as good as ever! I will say that if you are dining here, make sure to ask your server about the availability of the Goat Shoulder! It makes the entire dining experience and it is one that you will want to keep coming back for! Service was excellent, drinks were great, and atmosphere is a home run!

I've been to G&TG twice now over the past four or so years, and I'll answer the first question I get from people (mostly non-Chicago folks): Yes, yes, it is really that good.

There are already a billion reviews of this epic restaurant but hey, let me add my 2 cents.

Ambiance: Noisy as it's really busy all.the.time. Tables are quite close together, but overall it's warm, inviting with a heavy hand of rustic chic. I love how that's a "thing."

Service: Very helpful and friendly. Our server knew the menu inside and out and provided great suggestions all the way through. She even discouraged us from getting too much food when we almost went a little crazy ordering multiple shared dishes.

Drinks: They have a creative cocktail list and plenty of beer and wine options. I went with a wine by the glass but know there's a myriad of alcoholic options for any taste preference.

Food: Oh the food. Shared plates are my weakness so I was delighted to try even more this go around. Some of my faves include:

Cornbread: G&TG shines just as bright with the carb selection as they do with the meats. Give me all the butter. And all the cornbread. Goodbye.

Corn pierogis: The pastry texture was incredible and the rhubarb relish was damn delicious.

Halibut: The version we had last night had all sorts of accompaniments like miso and *almond butter.* Sounds weird? It seemed odd but it honestly was one of the BEST dishes I've had in my life.

Caramel corn and malt balls: The dessert of champions. Amazing gelato and perfect texture with the mixed items in the bowl.

Go ahead and make your crazy early or crazy late reservation at Girl & The Goat and get to eating.

Easily one of Chicago's best and most famous restaurants and possibly one of the best restaurants in the USA. You had better make a reservation well ahead of time before coming here or you are going to have a wait because every foodie and their grandmother has this place on their "must try" list.

First: the location and atmosphere. Located in the west Loop neighborhood a couple miles or so west of Michigan Ave just north of Chicago's Greektown and positioned among a slew of other top notch restaurant destinations along Randolph Street you could easily miss it. The inside of the restaurant is good sized. The lights are dimmed and its fairly dark inside. The noise level is loud here so if you plan on carrying out some good conversation be prepared to yell. Seating includes tables, bar seating, and even couches and arm chairs set up around communal coffee tables for walk ins without reservations. You can see the magic happening in the semi open kitchen from most vantage points of the restaurant.

Next: the service. Service is pretty top notch here. You are constantly being tended to by very professional and attentive wait staff. They are on the ball and constantly checking on you without being over bearing. All of my food and drink orders came out in very reasonable time and your server will even help you plan out a specific order to receive your food in to have the best taste experience. Don't hesitate to ask your server for a recommendation or any questions that you may have about specific dishes as they seem to be very knowledgeable on the menu.

Finally and most importantly: the food. You really have got to be adventurous to truly enjoy a meal here in my opinion. The name of the game is try as many little plates as you can off the menu. A lot of their offerings are rather exotic and include choices like duck tongues or goat empanadas for example. Expand your culinary horizons and try something new! I started my meal with the grilled baby octopus. It was okay but just didn't hold the mind blowing flavor I was expecting it to. Second was the calamari bruschetta which was very good. And for my third and final dish (would have loved to order more dishes but my stomach was running out of room) I had to go with the famous pig face. The pig face lives up to the hype in my opinion. Very tender, flavorful, and unique.

I seriously cannot wait to get back to Chicago and try more dishes here.

Ambience is great, service was excellent.  The first time I was here I thought the food was amazeballs.  For some reason the second time I visited, the food (while still great) was not as fantastic as I remember it to be - maybe I just hyped it up in my head too much or I've just gotten older (had been like 5 years).  There was nothing wrong with any of the food by any means, I think it was just too hyped up with the months long waiting, etc.  Definitely get the pig face (all about the face), that was definitely just as good as I remember it.

I just want to start off saying I rarely give 5 stars. But every single thing was amazing! My asshole boss added 2 more people to our reservation last minute and they had no problem being flexible. Then again- asshole boss- took his time being ready causing us to be 15min late and they were willing to hold the table for 15min! The server was very helpful, kind and nice about everything. Our water and wine was constantly refilled- our sharing plates were switched out every so often- and every single thing that the server recommended was delicious so definitely ask them! Cauliflower, green beans, goat empanadas, goat belly (a must!), the salmon (and I don't like salmon), halibut, duck tongue, beef tongue, bucatini, jasmine tea and rhubarb shortcake. I know I'm missing a couple of dishes but there really is nothing on the menu that you won't like. I was with a variety of people, different ages, men and women, different ethnicities, and different preferences of food and not one single person didn't love everything.

First off, please plan to come to this restaurant weeks in advance, or expect to eat at an off-time. No surprise that this place is popular, it has amazing food, is tastefully decorated, and located close to downtown in a street full of restaurants and bars. Also, wait staff is friendly and efficient.

We had reservations and was able to get seated immediately when we showed up at 9PM. the restaurant was full, but didn't seem overly crowded, and the ambient noise wasn't too loud to have a good conversation with friends. Their liquor, wine, and beer menu seemed decent, but passed on it this trip so no comments there.

In terms of food, we definitely tried almost everything. We started off with both the sweet and spicy brioche bread which was amazing, especially the honey sombal butter. The springy focaccia was decent, but not a big fan of the dipping sauces that came with it.

Since I don't remember the order of all the food, I'll just go down the list of what we ordered:

Pan-fried Shishito peppers - these were amazing. Fried the perfect amount of time, and the cheese was a great complement to the peppers.
Roasted beets - These were decent, the avocado creme fraiche was probably the most memorable part of it. Wonderfully creamy with great flavor
Chickpea fritters - Again, these were good for being vegetarian.
Green Garlic Potato Pierogies - Honestly, everything from here is good. The pierogies were cooked well and the chimi sauce was a great complement.
Calamari Bruschetta - This was probably my least favorite dish. I thought the calamari was undercooked (I see what they were going for, but the calamari ended up being too chewy)
Pan Roasted Halibut - Good, nothing to write home about, but another solid dish
Goat Ribs - This was amazing, fall off the bone tender, with the perfect amount of seasoning.
Goat Empanadas - These were also great, the cook really knew how to fry the empanadas. The outside was crispy, and the inside was very tasty.
Duck Tongue - These may throw you off, but they surprised me again by how tasty they were. They deboned them, and they basically melt in your mouth with how tender they are.

You have to check this place out!

My first time there last night,  6.30.17. It was FANTASTIC.  The food was fresh, the service was impeccable.
We had 515 reservations, we arrived at 520 and were seated immediately.  As soon as we sat down a young man poured us COLD water from a glass bottle.
The server came over right away and welcomed us, explained that the menu is small plate sharing and suggested how many plates to order, etc.
We started with the Foccacia. OH. MY. G-D. It was some of the best bread I have ever eaten. The accompaniments were good but so not needed. It was crunchy and melted in your mouth at the same time. The flavors were rich and fresh and delicate.
The beet salad with suprising bursts of lemon was excellent!
The sushimi came next. I do not eat this but my friend LOVE it, said it might be the best thing she has ever eaten in her life. The raw fish with the crispy pork belly and lace thin crispy bread perfectly complimented each other.
Our wine and water was refilled constantly but without being obtrusive.
Then the potato perogis. Totally home made and fresh and light. The tomato relish burst with crisp, clean fresh ingredients and was a total mouth party. ( yep, I said MOUTH PARTY)
Then the broccoli with smoked bleu. I can eat that everyday! It was different and delicious and interesting.
Then the pig face. Um, it was good.  It was too much for me to handle but my friend loved it. The presentation was beautiful, it was rich and crispy and I understand why people would love this item. ( the face part is what bothers me, eek.)
Clean plates were continuously exchanged.
Then the goat with the lobster and crab. The goat for me was a no-go, the lobster and crab were phenomenal,  the sauce was devine.  We did realize that part of the seafood was undercooked which was disappointing.  We told the server, she apologized and removed the plate. The GM then approached our table and apologized as well.
Then, the dessert. You GUYS, THE DESSERT!
The blueberry burbon was IN-CRED-IBLE. I can't describe it, just go eat it.
The icecream with the homemade caramel corn and malt balls, deeeee-liciious.
The donut with maple, Y. U. M.
The restaurant missed a star from me for 2 reasons. 1. The tables were too close together,  I was practically on the lap of the stranger next to me. 2. I feel as if the menu was a tad too small, a small handful more of chicken/ beef options and a few more non veggie side dishes would be appreciated.
All in all the food was exceptional and the service was great.
Can't wait to return!

pics.caption: Ice Cream with Homemade Caramel Corn and Malt Balls

review.des: I have been here many times and Service is always good sometimes great. I recommend showing up late if you want a table without a reservation. I love sitting at the bar here. It should be obvious but get the goat! Definitely ask the server what to order. I've had amazing meals here and some that are just ok. A little guidance does a long way.
Unique menu.  Portions to share.  Crafted cocktails.  Has a reservation... chose to sit in bar area.  Attentive staff.

The food here is amazing but I hate the family style tables. When on a date or out to dinner with friends I want to be able to talk to who I'm with and not feel like I'm bumping the stranger next to me constantly.

I had been wanted to eat here for months, but could never get a good reservation.

Finally got one!!!

It was wonderful. My favorite part was the pairing of strawberries and avocado on the empanadas. I would have never thought the two were compatible.

Came here on a Sunday evening around 6:30pm and grabbed a seat at the lounge with no wait. We went and ordered 3 vegetarian dishes: the shishito peppers with sesame and miso, the cauliflower and the chickpeas fritter. The chickpeas fritter and cauliflower were delicious (I absolutely adored the cauliflower dish), but I felt the shishito peppers were bland and a bit too seedy. The cauliflower had mint and lemon zest - all together a delicious combination. Service was efficient and ambience at the lounge was perfect.

There are quite a bit of vegetarian options since a third of their menu consists of vegetables. They also have a separate vegan menu. They recommended 5 dishes for 3 people, but I felt like the portions were quite substantial and 5 dishes would do to fill everyone up. I would like to try their meat dishes next time! Girl and the goat does not disappoint!
Great food and drinks. Thought I would leave hungry but I was full and spent less than I expected.  Glad we went early to avoid the crowds

Overall: Worthy of the premiere status that it universally receives from the food community. Simply delicious. A must try in Chicago.

The good: Simply amazing food, the chef's deserve all the credit they have gotten. Every bite was delicious, from the veggies to the meats to the dessert. Such a unique and varied menu as well. The atmosphere is top notch, I love the wooded (some charred) accents and the whole modern feel. Seeing the kitchen is great as well. Initial service was great.

The bad: After we got our meals (before dessert and the check) the waiter became very sparse. We waited 25 minutes between final entree before being offered the dessert menu (which we wanted!). Small amount of space b/w tables. Obviously come with a reservation or a nice long wait.

Atmosphere: 10/10
Service: 8.5/10
Food: 10/10
One of the best restaurants in Chicago, hands down. Awesome food, great staff, and honestly decent prices.

Reservations are hard to snag for the weekends, especially during 6-8pm, but every time I've dined I was lucky enough to score one last minute by checking just days before. The food is honestly amazing, I found myself trying new things that I would never think I'd eat like duck tongue and goat. The duck tongue is so good I wanted to order another one and would even come by myself to eat at the bar!

In my experience I would not recommend ordering any of the options from the veggie menu. Though they recommend about 4-6 dishes, and dishes from each of the three categories on the menu, if you come hungry enough and are looking to explore the veggies are just unnecessary filler. A table next to us even offered us some of theres to which we politely declined, because like the foodies we are, were strategically saving room for several of the highlight dishes.

We tried everything from the empanadas, wood fired oysters, duck tongue, 2 calamari bruschetta's, and the pig face all of which I would highly suggest anyone to try. When we ordered dessert we opted for the tiramisu, and also received a pb&j dessert complimentary from our server. I wish I remembered his name because he was absolutely phenomenal! He was attentive, engaging and had extensive knowledge of the food/drinks, but not overly hovering.

I took one star off because I have only ever dined with one other guest, and in that experience I was disappointed with the seating options available for a party of 2. The long booth with crammed tables between requires physically having to move the table and jimmying your way between other diners. It also takes away the intimacy and experience I expect when going, but I can have fun and enjoy myself anywhere so that's not too big of a deal.

Pretty exceptional! Having known about this place for the past month or so I booked early because this is one of the most sought after restaurants to eat at. With 3986 reviews how do you pass this up?! I think this is the most reviews I've seen on Yelp history!

Taking a quick look at the menu a few items like the pig face and beef tongue may scare ordinary eaters away! But with good persuasion and open minds you could lure your guests and friends to this eatery!  Per the server's suggestion she recommended sharing 6 to 8 plates like family style for a table of four. Bread. Oysters. Goats. Veggie. Fish. Meat. Dessert.

Bread: yo quiero taco bread. Nom mom nom!! A cute little mound of orange-colored possibly tomato bread sliced. Side of cheddar onion dip and pico de gallo. Ate it too fast to realize the taste of the actual bread. The combination of the sides on the bread created a wonderful appetizer. $4

Oysters: Wood Fired. 4 oysters with some white sauce and cooked over a well... Wood fire! If you're not into the texture of the food, the oyster might not be for you. $12

Goats: failed to order something from this section. Boo hoo. The items are quite interesting too!

V:
-pan fried shishito peppers. Served in a bowl with melted Parmesan on top and sprinkled sesame seeds and a miso glaze. Peppers are with stems that are easily broken off and filled with edible seeds. A slight hint of spice. Good dish. $9
-wood grilled broccoli. A high stack of broccoli on top of the rogue smokey bleu cheese and spiced crispies. In a simple matter this is the fancy adult version of broccoli and cheese. Simple dish. $10

F: pan roasted halibut with marcona almond butter on top and pieces of white asparagus underneath with a blueberry nuoc cham to cover. Portion was about a 2x2 measurement. Buttery soft and delicious. The almond butter stood out as a complementing flavor. $19

M:
-grilled marinated pork belly. castelfranco (which is a pale yellow-green leafy vegetable) with green sauce and blackberries. These were thin slices of pork that didn't resemble the pork belly and fat that I'm used to. $15

-sugo. canestri pasta with a meat mixture of beef, pork and lamb with baby carrots and cape gooseberries. An enjoyable wholesome pasta dish. $15

-wood oven roasted pig face. Soft pieces of pork face with a sunny side egg on top and sprinkled tamarind and cilantro. red wine-maple was decorated along with potato stix. I would say this is a flavorful dish that a meat lover would devour. $18

-braised beef tongue. Thin slices of beef tongue and a crispy skin-like layers of something matched the tongue. Almost tasted like crispy duck skin. Could have been a rendition of masa (dough flour or the outside of a tamale) beef vinaigrette and salsa verde were mixed within the entree. A favorite dish of the night! $15

Desserts: beyond full to even enjoy a dessert.

The one incident that was odd was that the server didn't recognize anything about a special benefit via Lexus. If you show your key fob supposedly you were supposed to receive a nice surprise from the kitchen. However, the server did not know anything about it! Bummer!

Ending thoughts: I'm glad I experienced unique tastes for one of the most popular restaurants in the city. Great food selection. One thing you'll notice is the giant girl and the goat wall painting. A little on the dark side. Looking forward to dining here again.

Forgive me for I have sinned and walked out of Girl & the Goat about 5 pounds heavier.  This place has been on my radar for quite some time now, and the only thing that kept me from checking it out sooner was the fact that the menu is a little bit eclectic and I'm absolutely no Andrew Zimmern when it comes to eating.  I came here with a group of 10 people, mostly coworkers and we were assigned a long table in the back near the kitchen.  The environment is a bit hectic but there's definitely something theatrical about watching all the line cooks crank out dish after dish.  We were advised that the dishes are meant to be shared, which most of our table decided to do so, but being the stubborn and picky eater that I am, I wanted to do my own thing.  The entire dinner was about 3 hours, and after ordering everything at once, the dishes started to emerge from the kitchen one by one.  
So here's the run down- I had the pig face, pork shank, and goat empanadas and tried a little bit of the duck tongue.  First with the pig face that has an egg on top- this dish is very rich and fatty and reminds me of a crispy pork belly.  The empanadas was my first try of goat but they were very delicate.  The goat meat inside was like a tender pulled pork that melts in your mouth and surprisingly worked with the strawberry pairing.  And then of course the pork shank- this dish is surprisingly large and filling.  It is well seasoned and fall of the bone and comes with an assortment of sides like sauces and naan.  We even asked our waiter to wrap up the leftover pork shank bone for the dog and he went to town with it.  Some other notables- the raw oysters were supposedly some of the best my boyfriend has had and the scallops were buttery and artfully prepared.  Overall, the food quality was excellent, plating beautiful, and surprisingly the meal cost less than I prepared for.

On my trip to Chicago, I knew I had to go to Girl & the Goat. It's a very popular spot, and you need to make reservations ahead of time. I stopped by on a Monday night, and it was packed.

I ordered the wood roasted pig face, braised pork shank and escargot ravioli. My favorite of the night was the pig face. It comes out with an egg on top, and you mix everything together. It was very crispy and all the favors blended perfectly together. My bf loved the braised pork shank. It was fall of the bone, juicy and tender. The escargot ravioli was cooked al dente, though I couldn't taste too much of the escargot.

For dessert, we ordered the chocolate truffle cake and the waitress brought us the miso-butterscotch budino because it was our anniversary. Both desserts were amazing!!I highly recommend them!

P.S. Service is exceptional here! I really liked our waitress, I forgot her name but she was amazing and very personal.

I've been wanting to go here for years. Although I was excited to go I thought there was no way it would live up to my expectations. Oh it did. The staff was fabulous. Our server proactively pointed out menu items that I might have an issue with (I can't have seeds). We had: wood oven roasted pig face, crisp braised pork shank ( this was amaaaaaazing) mr. Potato bread and goat empanadas. Every single This was delicious and balanced. I also loved my cocktail thyme is money originally I thought this was one of those places I needed to hit just to cross it off my list (like Au Cheval) but I'll definitely be back.

Hands down, best restaurant I've ever been to. Wow! I'd fly back to Chicago just to eat here.

Goat carpaccio is the most delicious plate I've ever eaten.
Been going since they opened the doors...they continue to exceed expectations. Be sure to call ahead and get the goat shoulder...or if you have a big party, go for the leg.
Great dinner place.  My wife and I keep coming back for years now.  Amazing food and service.

Loved the food and service here. I don't think there was a crumb left on the plates after we where done.  Need to have a reservation. Open kitchen looked dramatic. Service was good. I will definitely visit again.
If you haven't been here yet, you should!  There is a lot of hype about this place but it's lives up to it.  Even with a reservation, expect to wait a little bit.

Wow. All I can say is .. wow.

I really didn't know what to expect when my friend and I walked in 15 minutes late (Chicago apparently has traffic, too, something this native Californian had no idea about), but the service was amazing from the get-go. The hostess sat us away from the many groups, and sat us in a quiet corner (thank goodness!) so we could actually hear each other.

We ordered:

- beet salad
- hamachi crudo
- salmon tartare
- pig face
- confit duck belly

Everything was amazing! The beet salad was good, but the white anchovy was too strong for the beets. I LOVED the hamachi crudo and the salmon tartare! The salmon tartare comes in a mini-mason jar with this white sauce (I think it was some kind of aoili?) and chips. YUM!

Also - the pig face. Super greasy and I'm pretty sure my arteries were clogging with every bite, but it was amazing! The confit duck belly was really good, too.

The ambiance was nice, with an average volume of chatter and a liveliness to it that reminded me of LA. The bill wasn't that bad, either! Make sure to make a reservation well in advance -- I am definitely coming back here again!

Sad to say this place is WAY overrated. Went here after visiting Duck Duck Goat, which blew us away, and we were beyond disappointed. We ordered fried pork belly in which does not mention anywhere on the description that it's served on sashimi. That's a huge deal. I do not eat seafood, so it would've been nice to know. That being said the pork belly was literally an inch long and the width of a pencil. Ridiculous. Our server then compared pierogis to empanadas. How can you be a server in one of the hottest restaurants and compare a polish dish to a Spanish dish? I'm polish so this is laughable. The restaurant is decorated nicely, but I definitely would not go back.

pics.caption: Pork belly on sashimi - not mentioned on the menu that it's served on this

review.des: Delicious food and great service! We got some great recommendations from our server. Everything tastes delicious. We got the hamachi crudo, calamari bruschetta, roasted cauliflower, and caramel corn and malt balls for dessert. I would recommend booking a reservation ahead, as it seems to get filled quickly. Cool bathrooms too, individual rooms with toilets and sinks inside!

Finally had dinner here.  It's as good as they say and not at all overrated.

Group of four, staff was super attentive and excellent at describing the concept and the meals and helped with allergies and foods to avoid from the beginning and throughout the entire meal.

We tried a number of dishes, each one was fantastic.  If I could only choose two of the 8 in a return visit - Because we have to try new dishes.

Chickpea Fritters - these are dealing awesome, four on the plate.  Yes.

Pig Face - it's the best damn bacon and eggs you will eat, and it's dinner and that can't be beat.

I am not going to talk each dish.  Just those were my Allstate and I suggest you go as soon as possible and try a bit of everything.
I loved this unique dining experience. It's a must try for locals and out of town visitors. Enjoyable environment and creative menu with a friendly, professional staff.

We came here on a Thursday night at 5:45.  It started to rain about 15 minutes prior to our arrival.  We had no reservations and didn't have to wait with a party of 4, lucky us.  It is quite a hippy type of place.  Tapas seems to be the thing these days, great way to try a variety of dishes.  We had 9 orders, and 2 desserts.  I can only comment on the items I can eat,  

Soft shell 'chili crab' strawberry, crab rice - the soft shell crab was amazing, fried perfectly with plenty of flavor and quite sweet since soft shell crabs are in season, I just didn't think the strawberry, crab rice was the right combination, the rice tasted very vinegar.  

Pan roasted halibut with Marcona almond butter, white asparagus, blueberry Nuoc Cham - the halibut tasted very tender and not fishy, the top of the halibut was crispy given it a different type of texture.  

Grilled baby octopus with guanciale, fava beans, pea tips, pistachios, lemon vinaigrette - the octopus was also quite good, tender and not chewy but a little on the salty side.

Breadstick buns - these were garlic type buns, they were very tiny and cost a lot.

Chocolate truffle cake with just the right amound of coconut - this was very sweet and delicious, I love the coconut combination, presentation was beautiful, ice cream surround by chocolate cake.  

Blackberry shortcake with Thai basil, lime and almond - this was just plain and simple, nothing special.  

Service was quite good.  The average tapas was about $16, the portions are not that big.  For the price, I expected a little more.  

I don't know if this is worth an hour or more wait, I encourage you to make reservations.  You can sit at the bar or the lounge if you don't really need to sit at a table.  It is a decent place but a little on the noisy end, so not sure if it's a good date place.  

Nonetheless a place with 4000+ reviews and 4.5 stars is quite impressive to me.  Two of my friends recommended it to me and I decided to give it a try.  If the line gets too long, there are many highly recommended restaurants nearby.
Their dishes are creative and delicious. But our green beans were way too salty.
Gorgeous decor and fun meals. Vegetarian friendly, too!

The Girl and the Goat was just as amazing as everyone says. Worth the wait! We tried a lot of things on the menu and the empanadas, roasted cauliflower and green beans were my personal favorites! For dessert the caramel corn ice cream was SO good! Can't wait to go back and try more!

pics.caption: All the desserts ... caramel corn ice cream was my favorite!
Loved the green beans and cauliflower

review.des: It's so packed here which makes it hard to get a table here so make sure to make reservations. It's so worth it to try the pig face so many amazing flavors.

pics.caption: Roasted pig face! One word to explain it..Orgasmic..

review.des: Great food! Amazing service, staff were attentive. Our favorite was the duck tartare. Oysters were ok. We ordered the butter chicken and the first order was raw. However the staff immediately apologized and handled the situation extremely well. We left fully satisfied and happy despite a mishap.

My friend was able to get reservations on a Monday night at 10pm, which goes to show just how busy this restaurant is! We were seated promptly, and our server was very attentive and responsive. He explained the concept of the restaurant, and was great in making suggestions.
For three of us, we had about 8 plates...we probably could have done with 6 since there was so much food! But each and every plate was AMAZING!
Highlights:
Pig Face, Goat Empanadas (must try!), and the broccoli
It is well worth the wait!

This is the hottest restaurant in Chicago, so of course I had to check it out while visiting. Reservations are definitely difficult to get, so plan ahead (like really ahead). I made the reservations over a month in advance, and the only time I got was a Monday night at 9:30pm.

Upon arriving, the place was definitely happening. We got seated right away and our server came by to offer us drinks. But of course with my luck, Chef Stephanie was not in the house.

Food was delicious! Definitely need to order the Pig Face. As others on Yelp have written, you don't get the actual face/head of the pig. Instead, you get deliciousness! Just order it!

Another must try for the adventurous are the goat dishes. C'mon, the place is called Girl & the Goat, you have to try at least one dish off the goat menu. The waitress said the safest dish for the not too adventurous was the goat empanada. It was delicious! And you don't really taste the gaminess you expect from goat.

Overall, this is definitely a must-try when in Chicago. So book early to snag a table. But in the case you don't get a table here, you can always go to their diner and bakery that are right across the street (literally).

The restaurant was at a great location and I loved the ambience in here. It was more causal than I had expected but the food was decent. The roasted pig face and cauliflower was amazing but the experience wasn't that incredible that I am in a hurry to go back. I would if they had a groupon deal. #hinthint

First of all, let's pay attention to this name. What an intriguing name! I want to be the girl who eats the goat and just by looking at the sheer number of Yelp Reviews, it's a top restaurant when visiting Chicago.

I was able to get a reservation near closing time but it was so worth it to starve in anticipation! I love the diverse options they have for meats and salads. A classic is the pig face with an egg topped over it. My only regret is that I wasn't able to try more dishes after ordering grilled sepia, goat belly, and a salad. Very tapas style/New American. The street that this restaurant is located on is adorable, and you have to walk around and admire the string lights :)

Dessert really surprised me because the olive oil cake was AMAZING especially with the vanilla ice cream on the side :)

Excellent Chicago restaurant. It is on everyone's recommendation list for out of towners, because it really is that good. Great lively night atmosphere and food to match. I would eat here every time I'm in town if the reservations weren't so hard to nab!

The dishes are really unlike anything you've had at any other restaurant. What's cool is that the servers are seeking constant feedback about the dishes-what we like and don't like, what our favorites were-because the chefs want to improve and know what's popular. Everyone at my table had different opinions (all good ones) but it was cool how they took note of our input. Obviously reserve early, this is definitely a special occasion kind of place.

One friend highly recommended this restaurant before we came here. Unfortunately, we didn't make a reservation but we got seats at the bar right away. The bartender explained us how the menu worked. He said, it's meant to share and we should order multiple dishes. He would course out a little bit for us. It's like a tapa restaurant. We ordered, Cranberry Pecan Rye, Roasted Cauliflower, Blackened Catfish, Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face, Confit Goat Belly and Pb&J. I was impressed the quality of the food and they were delicious. I loved the cauliflower and catfish but I wasn't a big fan of goat meat. It usually tasted gamey. The two of us barely finished all the food but we still tried the dessert, Pb&J since we were visitors. The combination of the texture like grapes, brittle, gelato and cake made this dish interesting. It was supposed to be a sweet dessert but not too overwhelmed sugary in the end.

The service was attentive and efficient. The deco was modern and trendy. The dim lighting gave people some mysterious imagination. I will definitely be back to try more next time.

Made a reservation 2 months in advance to get a Friday 5:30PM slot. I brought my girlfriend here for a birthday dinner and we both had a positive experience. The food was beautifully presented and flavorful; we ordered the chickpea fritters, halibut, roasted pig face, pierogies, marinated pork belly, and budino dessert to end the meal. I was expecting a more intimate setting, however, the tables are packed in very tightly and you can hear all conversations around you, which is the reason for the 4-star rating. Can't go wrong with this venue, make sure you make a reservation in advance.

Best,
Charlie

The food was delicious and the atmosphere was really nice. I made reservations for a Wednesday night for myself and some friends. We were seated as soon as our full party arrived and many of the tables were open. Service was great and food came out quickly. My favorite dishes were the goat empanadas, the beets, and the pig face. If you like bacon you HAVE to get the pig face. Once you get past the name, it was awesome! For four of us, we got about 6 - 7 dishes and a dessert. Some of the portions were a little small, but everything was packed with loads of flavor and we all ended up full. By the time we left, the place was packed - I definitely recommend reservations.

we really enjoy this dinner for the food and service. The waiter is so nice!! My friend could not eat food with garlic and onion, the waiter marked those without garlic in the menu. The price is nice too!
This is one of my fave spots! The shared plates are AWESOME! And the bar is AMAZING!!!
Just the best world city restaurant from a Celebrity chef and still feel like a home place!

What an amazing restaurant. Food, ambiance, ad service were all top notch. I even loved it so much I came twice while I was in town. And would highly recommend it to anyone visiting.
There were three of us and we had about 17 dishes that we shared.
We got he roasted cauliflower, yellowfin crudo, a few of their breads/spreads, some other daily specials, and our favorites of the night were the pig face and lamb shank. Yum yum yum. I already cannot wait to go back.

Loved atmosphere and sat in the bar. Didn't make reservations and tables weren't available for a long time. Ordered the octopus which was probably my favorite dish. Since everything shareable we got 4 different dishes in total.

This is one of the best restaurants I have ever been. Their food is unbelievable amazing, so tender and yummy. The only thing I don't like there - is "they are booked for whole 2 weeks ahead". So if you want to try this place, you have to make reservations at least couple days before.
Go with a large group and order everything on the menu. It's worth giving every single dish a try.

Great atmosphere, fantastic waitress, perfect cocktails, fresh by the glass wine, creative, delicious food, yet still cozy and friendly. We had so much fun here. This is what we are aiming for when we dine out! Save room for the sweet potato dessert if they have it! You can't even imagine how she came up with this recipe. Amazing!

This is probably the first time I had vegetarian food in a restaurant and I loved it!! The fried beans are must haves! Loved the chickpeas fritters.. to summarize amazing food and cocktails.. must try ring of fire!!

Seems silly to add yet another 5 star review for this place but it deserves it. We went in expecting it to be a little overrated since everyone has hyped this place up to us but it wasn't.  Truly the best meal and cocktails we've had in Chicago.
Definitely a top 3 meal for me. Amazing food without being pretentious. Top items are the duck tongues, duck tartare and cauliflower.

I finally had a chance to eat here! Being a major foodie, it has been a long time coming. All the hype is true! The wait is worth it! So many times after hearing so many good things about a place, it has a lot to live up to; and boy did it! My sister and I walked in and instead of having to wait, there were two seats at the bar that we took full advantage of.

While I waited a few minutes for my sister to arrive, I was greeted by the bartender right away- I started with a cocktail that caught my eye called the "ring of fire". It had jalapeño, ginger beer, lime and tequila. It was awesome! After my sister arrived, the bartender went over the men's with us and how it works- plates shared and how things come out separately as he will course them out for us-
We started with the pan fried shishito peppers, moved onto the roasted beets, next we had the roasted cauliflower- last but certainly not list the famous pig face!
All of it was so amazing! Delish! Out of this world! My only issue was that by the time the pig face arrived, I was pretty full.
Can't wait to go back and do it all again!

Food: 5 stars- every bite!
Drinks: 5 stars-unique and wine selection is small but good
Ambiance: loved the vibe- watching the kitchen at work and the bartenders do their thing was entertaining
Service: very knowledgable!

It has been around 3 years since I last came here and I can honestly say not much has changed. I mean that in a good way. The creativity that Stephanie Izard brings to the table is amazing. She still keeps her classics around like the green beans which most people would stab a stranger to get their hands on that fish sauce recipe.
