But the ability for her to show consistency in creative experience puts her in the stratosphere for top Chicago chefs. I'd probably eat anything she puts on a plate even if it started with the word insect. Everything felt the same and I love the open kitchen concept even if that means my hair, coat, shirt, socks, and somehow cell phone have an earthy smoky smell at the end of the night. Best part? It's affordable even if you want to try a number of different dishes. I suggest 4-5 and yes you must get the duck.

One of the three places that were a must-try for me on my weekend in Chicago.

Came in around 8:30 for my 9pm reservation and sat at the bar to wait for my table. Ordered a best of three cocktail as I waited and it was so, so good I definitely recommend this drink for those who like a less sweet drink.

My waiter let me know the portions were a large size and that I could order half portions of the vegetables if I'd like since I was solo dining.

There was so many things I wanted to try on this menu but finally I decided on the wood grilled broccoli and the duck tongues.

I was absolutely thrilled with my decisions! Broccoli had "crispies" and a very mild bleu cheese and was absolutely delicious.

The duck tongues tasted just like excellently cooked chicken skin and were atop a poke/ black bean mix and piri piri sauce. I'm so glad I went with this! I never had piri piri before, but I need to try to recreate this tangy sauce at home soon that's how much I enjoyed it!

This place was way worth the nearly two month wait for a reservation and I will be back to try more dishes on my next visit.
Fantastic place for a drink and some Michelin quality eats. Also great for waiting for Au Cheval!!!

Excellent! Great dining experience. Lucky to find seating at the bar and enjoyed the view and people watched. We ordered escargot ravioli, pork belly and hamachi crudo, brioche with arragim butter and lamb jelly, goat empanadas, and beef tongue. Food was delicious. Thank youfor having us! We look forward to coming here again.

Really awesome ambiance and location in West Loop for Stephanie Izard. We tried so many things and everything was amazing. The surprising new try was the duck tongues which were so tasty, but the crudo was a little over-rated and small for what it costs. The goat as you would imagine is solid...we had the goat ribs which were very flavorful. Definitely fun, great place to hit-up.

DAMN this place was good.

I literally had this spot booked after I booked my flight to Chicago; two reasons - one because I did really enjoy Stephanie Izard's food. I wanted to make sure I could come with some friends so I'm glad I came with my friend Andy N.

We started off with bread (obviously). The miso hungry was so good. It's this brioche (so buttery and good) and the miso butter is so good with it. The kimchi relish was also good, but the miso butter is just so well paired with the brioche. Then we had the escargot dumplings. This was definitely not my favorite. There isn't this great escargot taste and the onions on top weren't crispy. Disappointing. The next dish - the goat loin. The ramp and potato puree - so good with the loin. It wasn't too game-y which I would be afraid of, but it was tender and so good. After, we got the scallops.  It wasn't bad, but it wasn't amazing either. I mean I just love scallops and it wasn't AHMAZING. It was still good. Our last dish was the pig's face. I know that sounds weird, but it's this lovely breakfast-ish dish that you mix together. SO GOOD. Such a great last item to have together here.

Service was good, but not amazing. Our waitress was off elsewhere at times, but we didn't really care since we just wanted our food.

Protip: make reservations (call since you can make them a year ahead of time apparently). GET GOAT!

Food is delicious, service is excellent and decor is beautiful. I can't wait to go back. It's been several months so I can't remember everything we ordered but I know the green beans were perfect. They are good about accommodating food allergies too. My boyfriend has many food allergies and they marked up a menu with the things he could have. It's not cheap but the prices are very reasonable for the high quality food and experience. Highly recommend!

First things first, make sure you book in advance -- as soon as you know you're headed to Chicago and want to dine here. I booked probably 2 months ahead, and got a time near their dinner opening on Friday night. At around 4:15 (opening time is 4:30), I saw that they already had people lined up outside who were hoping to get seats without having a reservation. It looked like they were successful, so if you don't have a reservation, I recommend you go during non-peak hours for sure.

The food was awesome. I love how they crafted their menu items to be moderately-sized dishes (for the most part) that you share with the rest of your group. This lets you sample quite a few things on their menu.

Our waiter told us to not forget the veggies, as their veggie dishes are really excellent. We tried to get the chickpea fritters,  it were told that the tasting of that dish that happened at 4 pm before the restaurant opened pushed the timing of the dish back such that it wouldn't be ready until 9 pm that evening, or perhaps not at all. I thought that was a pretty good move for the restaurant, not wanting to serve a dish that they didn't think was perfect. We ended up getting the roasted cauliflower -- and whoa, I have never been impressed with cauliflower before in my life until that dish came out!

We heard good things about the wood oven roasted pig face, which ended up being pretty good, although very heavy. I would have liked a little more of the tamarind or perhaps something more citrus-y to cut through the heaviness. Although the dish was not large, I felt very full even just after a few bites. Our waiter came by and mixed the dish up for us when he say they we weren't doing so enough, which was also nice.

Finally, we got the goat neck, which we were told ahead of time was a large dish so we didn't need to order much more after that. That was definitely a correct statement -- I never though goat necks were that big! But it was a really good part of the goat which I had not tried before. The meat was super tender, and just came right off with your fork. They prepare the near over a multi-day period and it comes out super rich, a little smokey, but not at all dry. The flavor is excellent, and the sauces paired with it are awesome as well. The vegetables on the bottom kind of got lost with the huge goat neck on top of it, and I would have liked a few more veggies in general. We ended up having to take some goat neck back home with us, and we left with several suggestions from our waiter about awesome goat neck leftover dishes.

Overall, an excellent experience. It seems like their menu changes pretty frequently, because a lot of the dishes mentioned in other posts were not on the menu when we were there. So, it looks like they have good variety in general and do a good job with all of their dishes. I will be back :)

pics.caption: Wood oven roasted pig face -- mixed up

review.des:
I think this is the yelpiest restaurant in Chicago. Luckily I was able to squeeze it in when I realized it was only open for dinner. It opens at 4:30 and knowing how this place is super poppin, there will already be a line when it opens. We got there around 4:25 and those hosts really know wassup. They remembered our group and said that we would be seated but would have to leave by 6-6:30 for reservations. The bar seating is first come first serve but since we had a group of six, we had to get seats and luckily we got eeeet. There is a pretty decent sized waiting area that was crowded when we arrived. You dont put your name down either. We had this goat item and funny thing is I dont like game haha. Derp

1) Chickpea Fritter- Yeah I wasnt feeling it. It tasted too potato-y carby so I wouldnt get it.
2) Green Beans- These were good. You always need some greens in your meal
3) Pig Face- This is the famous one. The meat was tender and nice and having that yolk explode always adds a nice touch
4) Pork Shank- Even though we got the pig face, we ordered the pork shank for mo. The crispy parts on the outside are always the best.
5) Escargot Ravioli- This was my first time trying escargot and I have to say this isnt something I would ever crave. Maybe if you are into it, then this is the place to go
6) Roasted Cauliflower- yummy.

This place is super hyped up and it was good but we got lucky and didn't have to wait...if we did not sure it would have been worth it.
The atmosphere is dimly lit and farmhouse style tables which I really liked. The menu isn't huge which I really don't mind and they had lots of options from meat to fish to vegetarian. There were 4 of us and they suggested getting about 2 dishes per person...it was a lot! By the time the last dish came out we were beyond the point of stuffed.
The sea bass was really good as were the biscuits with the liver mousse...the nice thing about this dish is that it's not just live so if you're not into that there are 3 other non meat spreads. The perogi were not Anyang special and wouldn't get them again.
The staff was pretty attentive and explained the menu well and were friendly.

pics.caption: Liver mousse, biscuits and other spreads

review.des:
Been here twice now, and this place is GREAT for birthdays or when friends visit from out of town. The restaurant has a great vibe. That being said, the food is VERY GOOD, but not mind-blowing. To be honest, I came here with incredibly low expectations for the first time, and was very impressed. But, a lot of my friends who come here with high expectations end up disappointed. The food is new american, the flavors are not going to blow you away, so just manage your expectations.

Here's the food items I had:
1. Chickpea fritters - I would pass on this. Super strong chickpea taste, not very flavorful at all, but unfortunately if you go with vegetarians, this will almost always be ordered.
2. Cauliflower - DELICIOUS, THIS is one of the dishes that is actually very flavorful, and pleasantly surprised me. Definitely order either this or the broccoli, OR BOTH. :)
3. Broccoli - pretty much same comments as the cauliflower.
4. Duck Tongue - First time eating tongue! It was pretty good.
5. Pig Face - MUST ORDER DISH at Girl & The Goat. Definitely a unique item, and always a crowd pleaser.
6. Chicken - Tasted like chicken, definitely a skip.
7. Some seasonal Goat item - Goat with some blackberry jam. Very good! Definitely suggest ordering a goat item while you are here. After all it's called Girl & the Goat....
8. Scallops - looks like these aren't on the menu anymore, but if they come back, get them!
9. Tres Leches Cake - the restaurant gave us this for free, because it was my boyfriend's birthday. SO GOOD!

Also, tip: Online it might seem like you need to make your reservation like 3 months in advance, but if you come at slightly odd times - 5pm or 8-9pm, the wait is only about 30 minutes, which is shockingly low for Randolph Row. That being said, if you are planning this for an event, I can understand you wouldn't want to take the risk.

Oversalted. Underwhelming. Cool Atmosphere with great staff.

Overall, if you go into this with no expectations, then its an ok dining experience. but for all they hype and difficulty getting a reservation, this place falls flat.

We all know how hip this place is right? You are supposed to book a table 2 months in advance. That's actually true  (2 months ago we tried to book and they told us that) BUT yesterday we were in the West Loop and we decided to give them a chance without reservation and we get a table right away (not even 10 minutes of waist) so that's a bit misleading, unless we were really lucky! (That's also a possibility)

Ambience: suuuuper nice, rustic, new yorkish, lovely, cozy, I loved it.

Staff: AMAZING! I don't remember the name of the people who helped us, but they were all great and fast, all of the recommendations were simply perfect for us.

Food: veggie paradise!!! We tried 2 veggie plates (Indian chickpeas and roasted beets) and I don't know how to explain how tasty it was. It was a party of flavors so difficult to explain in words. Then we tried the baby octopus! OMG, it was just just perfect. A bit smoked but not that much, nuts, veggies, everything super flavory. I loved everything. I saw that they change The dessert menu a lot, so maybe this dessert won't always be, we tried the balls of pb ice cream with caramelizad SALTED popcorn.

The price is really fair for what you are getting!

I love you goat, I love you girl
My favorite restaurant. Always consistent. Superb quality. Loud though.

without a doubt one of the most creative and expertly operated restaurants in the city of Chicago. Pig Face is just outstanding.  Actually I've eaten here three times and we've always tried new items, and I've not tasted anything that isn't outstanding.  Must be great to work as a server here, because I cannot imagine more than one complaint a day is heard.  Get to this cool restaurant.  And do not be afraid to order the pig face.
Order and order a LOT. The drinks are good, too. But make sure you get AT LEAST one order of the pig face.
It has gotta be this good to deserve 6K reviews. It did not disappoint. We trustfully enjoyed the duck tartare especially in this summer weather.

pics.caption: Best dish of the night. Duck tartare. Similar sweet and sour taste as tuna poke and amazing combination with broiled Brussel sprout.
Pork face. The egg was great. Patty could be a tit bit more saucy.

review.des:
this place is good, let me start off by saying that.

However, with all the hype and the huge wait lists for this place, I thought this would be a game changer of a restaurant.

It wasn't.

The food is good, we liked all our dishes, but one dish (brussel sprouts) were really salty but we were too shy to send it back. The table next to us (like 10 minutes later) got the same thing and had the same problem and told the waitress about it being too salty. Seems like it was a common problem. She was super nice about it to them and switched it for another dish. So that is good customer service. They are nice here like that.

But the food, it's good. Worth the price? Meh, not really. Definitely go try this place to cross it off your bucket list. But is it a restaurant I will frequent? No. Sadly, this wasn't the game changer I expected from the hype.

Perfect meal last night! I went late night, solo, just to try a few things. Was really blown away by not only every dish I had but by the amazingly welcoming and attentive service. Sometimes as a solo diner restaurants can neglect you a bit but Taylor made sure I was extra looked after. She even split some of the dishes into half sizes for me so I could enjoy more things.
I loved everything but most highly recommend the green beans, the goat belly, and the popcorn dessert. Can't wait to return - a must in Chicago!

Best food I've ever had in my entire life! I took my best friend who was visiting Chicago here and she loved it! We started off with the cocktails: best of three and the smokey autumn. For appetizers, we had the johnny applecheese bread followed by woodfired oysters. The oysters were amazing! Who would have ever thought of adding bacon on top? Next up was the calamari bruschetta - it was packed with flavor! We then had the wood oven roasted pig face. This had to be one of my most favorite dishes. The pork literally melts in your mouth. Then, we had the bucatini and goat belly. If there was one dish I'd have to recommend, it would be the Goat belly. It was drenched in a butter sauce with some crab meat. We ended our meal with the chocolate cake and vanilla ice cream. The ice cream was so creamy and the extra cookie crumbles made the dessert so unique!

Our waiter and the entire staff was very attentive. Overall, I had a wonderful experience and I can't wait to come back!

pics.caption: Best of three and smokey autumn

review.des: Still great.  Mid-October 2016 visit, had the goat carpaccio with smoked trout row, so good.  Would order again.  Goat Empanadas, I can never pass these up, each time they are different, but always good.  Tried the green beans in fish sauce vinaigrette with cashews, good, but not to die for.  Had a great shrimp dish, can't remember the details other than it had peanuts.  Sorry.  They have quite a few menu items that you can get half portions, which is great as a single diner.

pics.caption: Shrimp ??? Very good, but can't remember the name, sorry.

review.des: I think there's a lot of hype with this restaurant. The food isn't bad, but it definitely wasn't the best food I've had in Chicago. Ambience was nice - getting resos was hard. I feel like you should come here once just to say you had the experience and tick it off your bucket list. Had a really nice server - which is always a plus!

Very good place. Visited Chi a few months ago on a whim and had a drink and 2 small plates. I didn't get there until about midnight, and it was still crowded but I was able to get a seat at the bar. The bartender was nice and gave me a couple suggestions, explained their small plates which was exactly what I was looking for. I forget what drink I ordered, but I got the bucatini and broccoli. Everything was really tasty, and had I not been tired from traveling, I probably would have ordered another drink or plate of food. Definitely pricey for the amount but a good experience and I can see why it's so highly rated.

Awesome place. I love the ambiance. Food is very tasty. I definitely recommend goat ribs, halibut, and soft shell crab. Goat empanadas was a bit disappointing.
Make sure you have your reservation. Very busy restaurant.
Chef played well. Must try.

The hype is real people. I dine out a lot, and Girl and the Goat still remains  one of the best/most fun dining experiences I've had in Chicago. The most recent visit was for my birthday and this was by far the most fun! My boyfriend and I had a 10 p.m. reservation (past my bedtime ahh), but we decided to go an hour early to see if we could walk in. We got there at 9 and the hostess was able to seat us right away -- at one of the tables in front of the kitchen. Happy birthday to me!!!

For two people (with normal appetites) they recommend 2-3 plates to share. We ordered 9, and got 3 desserts. Our waitress was really amazing - she sort of had a concerned look on her face when we ordered at first but then politely suggested they portion the veggies to be mini-sized. Okay fine, more room for meat.

We ordered:
Fall-cacia - sweet. savory. fluffy. freshly baked.
Hamachi Crudo - so fresh and so clean. This was good to have as a little starter to the heavier stuff to come!
Kohlrabi - this was good, but it was a salad. And if I had to make room for other things I would skip this one.  
Shishito Peppers - the parmesan crust. Bye.
Octopus - this had potatoes, pistachios and all sorts of interesting stuff going on with it. One of my favorites for sure.
Beets - I have recently been on a beet rampage, and this was delicious!
Goat Empanadas - this is a must have.
Green Beans - I used to think it was weird when people talked about the beans at Girl and the Goat. What could possibly be that great about them?You will be addicted. Get them.
Pig Face - if it is your first time at Girl and the Goat - you must get this dish. If it is not - opt for the pork shank!
Pork Shank - ummm this one is a game changer. This was the last dish that was brought out and we were soo full but managed to eat most of it. It has the most perfect crispy crust on the outside and is fall-off-the-bone on the inside. We legitimately cut it with a butter knife. Also the naan that comes with it is buttery and perfect and something you will dream about. Kimchi BBQ - to die for. I would like a bottle of it.

Desserts:
Malt Balls - FYI, does not taste like whoppers. We were worried that it might but it is much better than the candy. Chocolate magic shell needs to have a comeback.
Beerimisu - lady fingers soaked in milk stout. A craft beer lover's dream and served in the cutest mug.
PB&J Cake - tastes exactly like PB & J but obviously a better, much chef-ier version!

I think I am reaching a character limit soon - but the kitchen table is awesome and everyone was so nice. It was great to watch all the action and admire the insane multi-tasking that goes down. I can't say enough positive things about this place, and whether you are visiting Chicago or live here it should be high on your restaurant bucket list!

It is the highest rated, the best known, and the most recommended restaurant in Chicago at the moment!! However, it's only 4 stars for me (and 2 for my husband)

Reasons? The food depends too much on salt to make the flavors, so by the end of the night, he felt bloated and I got a sore throat from excessive sodium consumption.They tried a little too hard on seasoning, but I still LOVED how their flavors always come in layers.

I would highly recommend their Calamari appetizer (top right). It's not deep fried though, Californians. What makes it awesome is the bruschetta that comes with it. You can't find it done so perfectly anywhere else on this planet!! The crispy pig face and goat belly are  also pretty darn yummy. Worth the sore throat lol

What NOT to order? Roasted cauliflowers. Really. Nothing special about it. Also pan roasted halibut. Meh...

Again I did enjoy my experience with Girl & The Goat very much, while my husband just couldn't wait to get out of the restaurant and head to a hot dog stand LOL will we come back? Nope! But should you try? Yes, since it's the hottest thing in Chicago right now.

The crisp braised  pork shank is to die for. Superb if u like that sort of thing. Like the king of kings pork crackling... great ambience... hipsters ... casual chic... stylishly put together ppl...bar staff can seem snotty... a slight drizzle  of pretentiousness... other than that fabulous food. Our server was great. Plates served consistently... food was great... the kitchen staff work in the open view absolutely slaying it...& owning it..They run like a well oiled machine... turned out great food consistently...I wud fly back for the crisp braised pork shank & the roasted cauliflower. Superb...

pics.caption: Cooks in the kitchen slaying it

review.des: The food here lives up to the hype & the Yelp 5 stars. Make your reservations! Once you check in, you can go have a drink at their bar. The host then looks & identifies you when you're table is ready. (I am sure they put notes about your outfit or physical features). The fiancé and I ordered the confit goat belly, pork shank, & the pig face. I love the details in artistic vision brings the dishes in a timely order that best suits our tasting palettes. We first had the pork shank (huge portion, falling off meat, good but not great), the pig face (amazing, we had no idea what we were eating lol, but it's flavors of explosion was memorable) & the last dish was confit goat belly (the best of all 3 dishes, this dish took us straight to food heaven, a must get if you're here!) Prices were very reasonable for an above & beyond food experience. We will definitely be back the next time we visit Chicago.

FAVORITE RESTAURANT EVER. Go into this place with an open mind because the names of the food are different, however its.just.so.good. My rule is the weirder the name sounds the better it's going to be. Roasted pig face is my favorite. Not cheap, but worth every penny. Stephanie Izard (top chef/iron chef/goddess) is the executive chef here, so you know it's gonna be good.

This place is lovely. Environment, staff, and the food. We were at first afraid we wouldn't get in that thankfully we beat the dinner time rush. Our server was one of the kindest servers I have ever had. She was helpful in suggesting options and overall very attentive to our table. We had the sautéed green beans, escargot ravioli, goat empanadas and our favorite the calamari bruschetta. I highly recommend this place!

Based on the reviews and my friends who have dined here, I think I'm in the minority- but I really get this place was overrated.

I had to make a reservation about six weeks prior to my dining date, which ended up being on a Wednesday at 9:30 pm. Given that fact alone, my expectations were high to say the least.

The venue itself is cool, trendy with a big open dining area and a bar for cocktails while you wait. The service was great too.

The food itself just didn't really do it for me. We had the broccoli - which was the best part in my mind. Additionally we had the frites, green beans and a chicken entree. The green beans were tossed in fish sauce, which ended up overpowering all the other flavors, not in the best way in my opinion. The fries were ok, but really not better than any other spot. The chicken was ok too, I guess my final word is that everything was just ok. Nothing about the meal really wowed me, my date felt the same way.

Hoping to try Duck Duck Goat, around the corner soon. Fingers crossed that it delivers more on the wow factor.

pics.caption: Green beans, little too heavy on the fish sauce

review.des:
Great dinner, portions small, thought it was a tasting menu not a family style dinner menu.
Food was great, but left feeling hungry.
Even the drink portions were small.
Lovely atmosphere and will return!

The food was outstanding. The oysters and duck tartare and goat neck all stood out. The service (Shikaya) was sadly inattentive and grumpy. Can't remember the last time I had to flag down a server so intently just for a drink order.

I was so excited to go to Girl & the Goat. I made reservations about 2 months before on Open Table and had no issue getting a 7 pm time slot for me and a plus one. I couldn't sleep the night before, I needed it to live up to its hype. For starters, the service was awesome. Our server, Owen, was attentive and helpful the entire time. Now down to the good stuff. We ordered the green beans, goat empanadas, and pork shank. The shank was falling off the bone and they give you tortillas to make some pork shank taco ranch goodness holy cow. BUT the star of the show was the green beans. I'm not kidding. I'm the least healthy person I know. They were so good. For the finale we ordered the Carmel corn malt balls which just topped off the night.
Order the green beans and potato bread with chili cheese butter!

This place is great! My wife and I had 4 dishes and dessert and everything was was so just outstanding.

The place was packed so make sure to make a reservation.

Our bartender who reminded us of Kevin Spacey was amazing. Knew how to make cocktails and was an expert with the menu. All of his recommendations were excellent.

This place is a must try!

Five (5) stars and beyond for every food item.

THE AMBIANCE:

Girl and the Goat ("GG") is an upscale restaurant and bar. There is wood, brick, beautiful lighting, and interesting decorations. In terms of the look of the place, if you're from San Diego think Craft and Commerce but a larger space and bougie. If you're from Los Angeles think The Stocking Frame + the upscale feel of Perch.

THE FOOD:

Wow. Wow. Wow. I am in LOVE with GG's food. It was a group of four (4) of us and we tried a lot of things on the menu. The menu is split into vegetables, fish, meat, bread, oysters, goats, and desserts. The food is tapa-style and our waitress recommended getting a good amount of plates to share.

Here is the list of what we tried and my thoughts:

1. Wood Grilled Broccoli: rogue smokey bleu cheese. spiced crispies.
Even the non-brocolli eaters at the table could not get enough of this smokey and creamy treat. The broccoli was perfectly cooked - soft but also dense - and what made me smile were the rice crispies. So random but so perfect.

2. Hamachi Crudo: crisp pork belly. chili aioli. caperberries.
Very light and refreshing. The hamachi was topped with crispy flakes, there were small slices of jalapeños and pineapple, and it also came with pieces of juicy pork.

3. Ham Frites: smoked tomato aioli. cheddar beer sauce.
This platter is fries dusted in bacon with the sides of sauce noted above.

4. Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face: sunny side egg. tamarind. cilantro. red wine-maple. potato stix.
The pig face was roasted to perfection. It was semi-fatty and caramelized. The yolk oozed onto the meat and created creaminess. I loved this!

5. Braised Beef Tongue: masa. beef vinaigrette. salsa verde.
GG is very generous with the beef tongue in this dish. They fry the masa into a crispy chip and the rest of the plate is garnish and greens. the beef tongue was very tender.

6. Goat Empanadas: smoked blueberry tapenade. avocado.
I really enjoyed the empanadas because they were the right amount of crispy and dense. The empanadas came atop a bed of mashed avocado and were sprinkled with cheese. The chef throws some soft cherries on top. The cherries are more juicy than sweet.

7. Confit Goat Belly: bourbon butter. lobster n' crab. fennel.
The goat belly reminded me of the Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face ("PF") but the PF had a caramelized taste. This dish is a surf and turf option and comes upon a bed of what tasted to me like a smooth mashed potato but I could be wrong. Whatever it was, it was yummy.

8. Horchata Rice Pudding: rhubarb semifreddo. cinnamon toast crunch.
Putting my I'm Mexican -I love horchata - I love arroz con leche - bias aside, I can honestly say this is the BEST dessert I have ever had in my LIFE. Rhubarb? Really? YES! What an odd mix of texture and flavor and what a fabulous explosion of deliciousness in my mouth. This cold horchata ball (semifreddo - semi-frozen dessert) that won't melt sits atop a warm rice pudding. On the side they place the rhubarb, which is crunchy and tart, and then on top of it all goes their homemade cinnamon toast crunch in pieces and two big chips at the top. It was ridiculous! You have to try this!!

THE TIPS:

Don't think about coming here - Do it!  Try everything.
Atmosphere and food were both amazing. We were lucky to get right in, I've avoided any attempt to  go here because in the past you could never get a reservation any sooner than a month out.
Unusual modern American cuisine. It's worth your attention, I'm sure that you will not be unraveled. I recommend also try vegetarian dishes.

AMAZING food! If you want a unique dinner experience in Chicago, you HAVE to come to Girl and the Goat!! I've been here for a date night and with friends and both experiences have been truly wonderful. This place definitely has one-of-a-kind menu options and even as a picky eater, I still found items I enjoyed. Even though I didn't eat it, everyone at the table thought the Pig Face was absolutely amazing. Note: this place is super difficult to get into!! You need to make a reservation months in advance or just prepare yourself if you are a walk-in to either wait awhile or sit at the bar (we did for our date night and it was still so fun!)

Girl & and the Goat sure knows how to deliver good meat! Between my boyfriend and I, we ordered the goat liver patê, goat shank, and the famous pig face:

Goat liver patê - it came with a jar of caramelized patê along with ramekins of blueberry puree, rhubarb, diced pickles, and 5 crumpets. The crumpets were so fresh and hot with the perfect crisped edge. All of the accompaniments were the perfect amount of tartness to cut through the richness of the patê.

Pig face - The favorite of the night. Topped with a perfect fried egg, the tender pork was the perfect amount of fattiness that sat on top of some hash for texture, paired with cilantro, tamarind, and red wine sauce. So yummy, we definitely plowed through this quickly.

Goat shank - a very generous portion and a leaner take on goat meat. I loved the summer quinoa salad it came with. If i had to pick one dish to eliminate, it would be this one only because it wasn't prepared in too special of a manner.

Most people seem to order around 5 dishes for 2 people but we were stuffed after these 3. If you want to try more dishes, I would recommend coming in a bigger group since it's a pretty casual rustic restaurant.

Even though I thought all of the dishes were prepared well, I decided on 4 stars because of its lack of fresh/lighter options. They do have vegetable and seafood dishes, but even those dishes seemed heavy-handed with the seasoning and sauces, but to each their own.

Definitely make reservations a few months in advance. I think we made them online 2.5 months in advance and we were only able to get 4:45pm for a Saturday.

pics.caption: Goat shank with quinoa summer salad

review.des: Had a really fantastic dinner here.

This place gets a lot of publicity and it would be easy to get disappointed after all the hype but on a dish by dish basis, the food is amazing. We went as party of 3, but not all of us shared all dishes, which they kind of assume you will do. So you have to tell them because they pick what is served when and the individual dishes were all good, some amazing but the combos not so good: goat carpaccio was delicate and richly flavored and great but served with cheesy strong pepper dish. The cauliflower was great. Best dish was the goat pate by far. Cauliflower was great, grilled oysters. The menu changes a lot so I won't focus too much on individual dishes. The concepts are creative and the ingredients high quality and the care in preparation is clear.
Service was outstanding and they seem to really care about your experience. Just let them know how you want the dishes served and with what.

a very unsatisfied visit (of the past). we will not return.  robot waitress.  got the order wrong.  made sure she charged us for hash browns she forgot to bring.  god only knows what she was doing, food took  F O R E V E R to come out.  in pieces, if I may add.  my sister used a knife to stir in her coffee options (cream + sugar).  another waitress was kind enough to overhear our conversation and apologized and brought us utensils of proper nature.  the scone was delicious.  apple juice was a gourmet bottled juice.  yummy.  but, nope.  not a breakfast joint for us.  distasteful.  i do commend the manager/owner for writing back to us and inviting us back to join her for a meal on her, but that was a pretty horrific visit, and since, we decided not for us again.  however, it is a beautiful joint, well lit, gorg breakfast bar area, very inviting, and is just stunning!  dining out is my life and I love good food and service.  it's how I take care of my family, friends and clients; it's how I expect to be taken care of as well.  not some cocky-jock behavior at a beautiful restaurant.  just makes everything ugly.  sad.

Oh my god.... just... wow. This place is amazing!!! Book your reservations well in advance because you'll be waiting quite some time for walk-ins. The menu is organized by vegetarian, seafood, and meat. Ordered mostly from the vegetarian/seafood sections. Highly recommend the sweet corn pierogies and calamari bruschetta. Save some room for dessert because the caramel corn & malt balls will just be heaven in your mouth.

pics.caption: Sweet Corn Pierogies (top left), Chickpea Fritter (top right), Caramel Corn & Malt Balls (bottom left), Calamari Bruschetta (bottom right)

review.des:
No trip to Chicago would be complete without visiting the famed Girl & the Goat - a foodie must! So, naturally we arranged our schedule so that we could visit this establishment during non-peak hours - as the were no available reservations even one month out! Crazy!

Anyways, we arrived early on a Wednesday afternoon (before opening actually) so that we could secure a spot. Once we were seated we decided to go all out and tried a large spread of items for two (below)

Food
* Honey sambal brioche with honey butter and pomelo fresno relish ($4) 4/5
- Warm and fluffy carbs! Yum! A great way to start our meal.

* Sauteed Green Beans with fish sauce vinaigrette, cashews ($9) 1/5
- It was a pretty substantial amount and more than enough for two to share; however, I wasn't a big fan of the sour taste. It was a bit too strong for my liking.

* Pan Roasted Halibut (marcona almond butter, white asparagus, blueberry nuoc cham) $18 The highlight of the meal (!!!) 10/5
- Our server informed us that this was a seasonal item and that Chef Stephanie won the Top Chef competition with this dish. Well obviously we had to order this and I'm so glad that we did. It was soft and buttery and I could not get enough of it. It was my favorite dish of my trip and I tried a lot of memorable items. If it's on the menu you'd be a food not to order it  

* Wood oven roasted pig face with sunny side egg, tamarind, cilantro, red wine-maple, potatoe stix ($18) 2/5
- This was the most popular item on the menu, but I guess the hype got the best of it. While it was robust in flavor, and I enjoyed the first bite, it was a bit too fatty and dense for me to continue eating more spoonfuls of it. Jeff kept putting it on my plate and I just switched plates with him :P

* Confit goat belly with bourbon butter, lobster n' crab, fennel ($19) 2/5
- It would seem unpatriotic to not try goat as it's in it's name-sake So, based on another reviewer's recommendation we tried the goat belly. Boy was it disappointing. There were too many components and I actually felt that the lobster and crab took away from the star of the plate - though I did like the seafood alone.  

Summary
Even though there were several dishes that I would pass on, The Girl and the Goat is still a restaurant that I would frequent again. The atmosphere is lively and I cannot praise her award-winning halibut enough. I would definitely come again just to eat that.  

Not sure if I'd wait an hour plus during prime-time dinner hours, but I would definitely come again in the mid-afternoon. I may also try the roasted cauliflower as it was also praised highly, but I'd pass on the red meats as I felt they were a bit too fatty and dense for my likely.  

Overall, a fun place! Check it out!

Party of 2, no reservations, Thursday 6:00pm, seated at 6:50.

There is a lot of hype surrounding this Top Chef establishment, but is it worth the wait?  The 'tapas' style, semi-communal feasting arena of sorts separates its menu into veggies, seafood and meat, where diners let the wait staff design the progression of their meals. Don't expect a spread of random chaos!

Food - 75%
---------------------------------------------------------------
Brioche with blueberry jam and butter - so fluffy, good tartness and savory creaminess from the butter

Cauliflower - miss. too heavy for a veggie course and the mint sauce was one-note. It was hard to finish.

Duck tartare - gamey, playful aromatics, multi-textural, clean finish. probably the best dish of the night.

Goat belly confit - It was okay. nothing too special. Straightforward fatty cut resting on a base of puree. The crab and lobster, however, were very much welcome additions!

Pig Face - ah. the pig face. It was INSANELY fatty. But in a good way. Would've been nicely paired with a veggie dish to cut the fattiness. or red wine. It was a slightly different texture from normal fat and wasn't stringy at all. Could've used more of the sauce that it came with.

Overall: probably not worth the 50 minute wait. Make a reservation. Although I am slightly perplexed as to why it's so difficult to get a rez. Maybe it's because of the price point. Certainly good value as you will be full.

I will absolutely agree that Girl & the Goat makes great, innovative dishes. Everything I've ordered from there has been inventive and delicious, namely the wood oven roasted pig face and the crisp braised pork shank.

The only issue I have with the restaurant is that you need to be able to know what you're going to order to put in your dishes all at once. The dishes are meant to be shared, and generally when I go out to tapas-style meals, I prefer to be able to order dishes throughout the duration of my meal. Especially when you are trying a new restaurant with this type of atmosphere, you don't necessarily know how to order.

The first time I went to this restaurant, the waiter said that it was not preferred to order dishes at more than one time, so we ordered what we thought sounded reasonable for the amount of people we had. Half way through the meal, we realized we had ordered way too much food and ended up having to cancel a couple of our dishes. The staff was very accommodating and did not penalize us for shorting our order.

My recommendation if you live in the area and have not been to this restaurant would be to go during lunch the first couple times you attend. That way, you can get a sense of the menu without the dinner rush, so that when you do attend for an evening meal you can have a clear idea of an appropriate amount of food to order.

Overall, definitely a restaurant worth trying, but better if you know what kind of meal you're in for!

Excellent service, great atmosphere, and an even better meal. The dishes were so creative and extremely tasty. The menu had a great variety of vegetarian, seafood, and meat dishes. Overall, this was an amazing experiences. It was well worth the money. We will definitely be back.
If you can't get a reservation, sit at the bar where you will receive full-menu service. The atmosphere is upbeat and lively. The wait staff friendly and helpful. The food is amazing.

I don't think I can ever eat normal food again.

We are visiting Chicago and my son picked out this restaurant. We ordered the multigrain bread ($4), roasted cauliflower ($9), calamari bruschetta($16), oven wood roasted pig face ($18), and miso-butterscotch budino dessert ($9).

All the dishes came separately but very, very quickly. We never finished one dish before the next one came out. All four dishes came within 8-10 minutes.

Multigrain bread came with sour cream cheese with chives and rhubarb spread with mint. It was amazing! Not a big serving but a good deal for $4.
Oven roasted pig face came with a sunny side up egg over it and some sweet/tangy sauces. It was a crispy on the outside but chewy and soft on the inside - probably the best dish of the night.
Calamari bruschetta came at a close second. Sturdy pieces of bread were soaked in sauce and topped with herbs, veggies, and delicious calamari. 4 small pieces were included in the dish.
Roasted cauliflower was also delicious. The pine nuts are an important addition to give you a good crunch.
The miso-butterscotch budino was nicely done with toffee bacon and cashews. The miso flavor isn't strong, but the saltiness stands out to compliment the sweetness of the rest of the ingredients. A great way to end the night.

If you're visiting Chicago it's a place you have to try.

Get a reservation here if you can because you will wait a long time if you go during prime hour.

My friend and I were about 15 minutes late to our reservation and I alerted the hostess that we would be late, also. They were very lenient when we finally arrived and got seated immediately.

Between the two of us, we shared four orders:

Pan Fried Shishito Peppers: this was an interesting twist to just regular ol' peppers. I really like the  unique flavoring of it. Nice little veggie plate to start off dinner.

Hamachi crudo: this plate was pure art, I loved the culinary design of it. It was too pretty to eat but after a few snaps, my friend and I digged into it. The hamachi is very fresh but I just wished they gave us a few more slices to the order!

Goat empanadas: I don't think I have ever had goat so we tried the goat empanadas. It was surprisingly yummy and I loved that it had avocado in it!

Pig face: yes, it's an interesting name but it is what girl & the goat is famous for and I can see why. This was my favorite dish of the night. It came with an egg on top and we were instructed to mix it up before eating. It highlighted so many areas of my taste buds and I could have eaten the entire portion to myself.

For four orders between two people, I was just about full. The food here is small portion and quite pricey so definitely don't come here on an empty stomach. Eating here is more of a culinary experience rather than a place to fill up your tummy.

Ambiance is dimmed lights and very romantic. But my table was terribly close to our neighboring parties so I did feel a bit awkward.

Parking is quite pricey here, $12 for valet but if you don't mind walking about five minutes, there is metered parking about three blocks away on Washington (past the freeway overpass).

The best thing about G&tG is coming in and seeing Chef Izard actually working the line.  A rarity indeed, among the Top Chef glitterati.  She's on a par with another of our TC alum, Harold Dieterle.  She's one of the few TC finalist who are interested in being chefs, not celebrities.  Her cred is legit.  Her food is excellent.  The only thing you can say about the food is that there are some dishes that are better than others, but we haven't experienced anything bad on this menu.  

Here's the 2 drawbacks.  G&tG, with it's location along the Randolph corridor, attracts hipster foodies by the valet truckload.  It's crowded and unbelievably loud -- having to shout to converse with the person sitting across from you.  The other drawback is that G&tG is yet another "small plates" concept.  We've only been here with parties of 4-6.  So, that means you spend as much money as you would for full dishes, but only get a few tastes and go home hungry.  If it's just a twosome, then it could work.  But if you're coming with a group, have dinner before your reservation.

We're looking forward to the day that the foodies' interests wane and they move on to the next en vogue restaurant, chef, food trend.  Then maybe people who truly appreciate excellent food and the hard work of a talented chef will be able to have an enjoyable experience at one of Chef Izard's tables.

I know this restaurant has been around for a while, but I was super excited to eat here. Came from California and this place didn't disappoint.

Wednesday night was PACKED! Had a great server at the bar. We just let him choose the menu.

Started with fried oysters that we light and melted in your mouth.

Fire roasted cauliflower, with some mild pickled peppers we tasty.

My favorite was a braised goat belly with crab and fennel shavings.

The weirdest thing was the fact was we had a very well prepared braised and crispy pork shank and it was served with ranch dressing and kimchi hot sauce.  The hot sauce was great but the ranch dressing fell very short of par.

Overall this places deserves all of the accolades and praise it receives. It was a great dining experience with creative, well balance, and well executed food.

What can I say the the 6500 other people have not already said.  We were visiting in town with friends and could not get a reservation, so we went at 5pm on a Tuesday and we got right in.  They were super nice and told us the only deal was we had to be out by 7pm for a reservation.  Service was great and we did spend the entire 2 hours there.  Everything was amazing but our favorites were pig face, pork shank, green beans, and Carmel popcorn dessert.  Can not wait to come back

My favorite restaurant in Chicago. You pick several dishes to share and they order it from light to rich. There are some interesting dishes such as duck tongues, goat empanadas, and others. Additionally, some good vegetarian dishes including beets. Solid cocktail list.

2 hour wait.
We had a limited time to eat due to previous reservations running late
Food is not a part of our taste profile
Both experiences reflected left a negative taste for my boyfriend and I.

I'm going to rate the ambiance,meal (broken out by dishes), and price below -

Ambiance - I was very surprised that this restaurant had a very up beat feel. They played a good playlist of newer music and it was not too fancy (which was surprising since it is a little pricey). Overall 10/10 for ambiance. It's one of those places you would feel comfortable sitting and drinking for while.

Meals - I will list out the dishes we had.
1. Blueberry corn bread - 10/10, didn't really taste like cornbread but came with a creamy butter and cranberry sauce which tasted great together.
2. Perogies - unsure of the name but it was a vegetable (maybe potato?) perogie. 9/10. No complaints, it just wasn't my favorite dish.
3. Lamb rib - 10/10 the best dish of the night. The meat fell right off the bone. It was so tender and moist.. makes me want to order lamb wherever I go!
4. Goat empanadas - 9.5/10 this was a smaller dish, but I would definitely recommend.
5. Pig face - 10/10 came with a sunny side up egg which surprisingly was a great combo with the meat. It was very tender and tasted just like regular pork.

Price - each dish (which they call tapas) was about $10-25. Our waiter suggested 4-5 tapas for two people. If you do the math, you can see this becomes quite expensive (especially with a few drinks).

Overall I would recommend this place to anyone. With that being said, I wouldn't come here every weekend because of the price, but it is definitely a must try!

Great dating place.

The foods are interesting, but the waiter kept pushing 2 dishes per person, it's way too much!

I would say 3 dishes for 2, with a dessert.

A little over priced.

Went to the Girl & the Goat this past Saturday with friends.  Great food and drinks throughout.  Our waiter guided us through the menu and advised on the number of shared dishes we should be order with the party of 6 we had.  He was very attentive to the gluten allergy which my girlfriend has.

Overall, this was an outstanding experience.  Highly recommend going here, especially to those who have not been there before!
The service was great and the food was delicious. Great diner feel. Nice variety on the menu. Not your typical breakfast food - a step above

It's been a while since I came here, but from what I remember I definitely enjoyed the atmosphere and the food was delicious. Staff was friendly and drinks were flowing.

I need to come back soon to double check if the quality is as good as I remember!

Not impressed. The food is over salted and over flavored. The ravioli with urchin tasted like French Onion soup. Why would you make something with such delicate ingredients taste like French onion soup? Plus it was an over salted version of the soup. The crudo was made of thick slices of fish with some sort of mayo sauce and bacon pieces. Not impressed. Why this place would get such high ratings is a mystery to me. The best thing about the evening was the nice guy I met at the bar. Beyond that I would never come back here for the food. 2.5 stars at most.

Started with cocktails at the bar bc we arrived early. Great service at a busy bar. Drinks were made quickly and tasted great. Hostess sat us right at our reservation time.

The food was excellent. Definitely one of the better meals I have had since moving to Chicago. The pork shank and pig face are an absolute must. Filled with flavor, presentation is spot on, and pacing of dishes were perfect. Kusshi's were fresh with a great mignonette sauce.

The best part of the meal, almost as good as the pork shank, was our server Josh. Super upbeat, extremely knowledgeable of the menu, and very accommodating to my girlfriends allergy. He was also able to offer some off menu cocktails per my request.

Overall an absolutely great experience and will definitely be back.

I meant to make reservations at Girl and the Goat before I left T-town, but, ya know, life. So, I've learned over the years that as a single diner, I can almost always find a seat at the bar. My method held true tonight.

So, the chef, Stephanje Izard (a Top Chef alum, but lots of amazing chefs have never been in a tv competition), focuses on using the whole critter in dishes that walk a fine edge between "What the Hell!" and gastronomic Nirvana. A couple years ago I read a piece by an economist about making the most of your dining experiences. He essentially said, pick the thing that sounds the strangest, the thing you would normally eschew. Well, so far, that theory has served me pretty well, as it did tonight. Iota, however, still thinks I may be out of my mind even though she gobbled stuff down as fast as it came out--of course, this was after she screeched a bit.

We started with yummy brioche buns served with tomato jam and jalapeño butter. Next came the grilled shisito peppers (Iota: Aaaaoootterrrgaaonn? Translates to again? Really?) topped with sesame miso sauce. Completely different experience than at Garces' Mercat a la Planxa.

Then came the duck tongues. It took a bit of convincing to get Iota to slip one between clamped lips, but once she did, her eyes got big, and she grabbed a couple handfuls, which made the guy sitting next to her comment that he'd never seen a chimp with such and appetite (I suspect he'd never dined with a chimp before). This dish was amazing--really. Perfectly balanced unctuous and crispy and fresh and bright. The crispy fried duck tongues were warm and crunchy on the outside and rich as marrow on the inside. They were layered around a tuna-fermented black bean poké tossed with daikon strips and arugula all set on top of a piri piri sauce and topped with wonton strips. (Now, those of you who can't get past the tongue, you'd likely be all over it if I said it was crisply chicken skin instead of tongue, so get over it.)

And then we splurged with dessert--and if you wanna know about that, you'll have to go to dinner with me. I'll just say that the salty sesame spymaster on top perfectly balanced the rich sweetness hiding.

pics.caption: Yummy brioche buns with tomato jam and mild jalapeño butter.
Shisito peppers go to heaven with a thick coat of miso.
Duck tongues--seriously. Try it. You'll like it. Just like Mikey.

review.des:
Most memorable things:

Pig face!!!!!  
What???   That's right!  
Was soooo good!!!  Could eat it all day!!!  

Pork shank was "fall off the bone" delish!!!!  So juicy n tender with a lot of flavor!!  Flavor of the meat, not from salt or seasoning.  

Miso-butterscotch budino was amazing!  

Defiantly will have to go back to try more of the goat dishes.  The ones we had were just ok.  (Goat empanadas n goat belly confit.)

(Some mislabeling of dishes)

I really like this place! We got lucky and got a table without reservation in 10 minutes. If you want to eat their famous dish you'll need reservation because they only make it when you reserved.

I went again recently and the food is still amazing! Got to sit by the chef's table this time and it was an interesting experience. I would highly recommend this place if you're in town!

We went last night to celebrate my friend's birthday, and we had a wonderful experience. It was totally worth it to make the reservation 3 months in advance.

All the food is served family style in smallish portions, and our excellent waiter helped us figure out how much to order. The menu is constantly changing, but we got the beet salad, raw oysters, cauliflower, tuna, goat empanadas, chicken, and pig face. Everything was so remarkable. A lot of the descriptions seem to merge unexpected ingredients, but they always came together perfectly. The standouts were the cauliflower, empanadas, and of course the pig face. The pig face tasted kind of like bacon, but juicer and better.

For dessert, they put birthday candles in a dish with chocolate ice cream, caramel corn, and chunks of salted caramel. It was incredible. We also got a pineapple cake, and we couldn't decide which was better because they were both perfect.

We also tried a few different cocktails, and they all exceeded expectations. Overall fantastic dinner!

Where do I start? Service was spectacular. Leigh was our server and she was very patient with us since it was our first time there and very helpful with her recommendations. We ordered 5 dishes for the 4 of us. I'll just say they were phenomenal. It felt like a party in my mouth every time I tried a new dish. We started with the Roasted Pig Face. Perfectly cooked pork with an over easy egg that complimented the dish. Next was the Pan Roasted Bass. Here's the kicker.... with pork belly. How can that work? We'll, it was delicious. Bass was tender and melted in my mouth. The pork belly was full of flavors. A perfect combination. Then we had the Bucatini. I never tried it before but I'm truly impressed. The braised pork shoulder pair wonderfully with the bucatini. Next we tried the Confit Goat Belly. C'mon we had to try a goat dish. After all Goat is what they are known for. Superb and definitely a great choice. Recommended by our wonderful server! Thanks Leigh! Last dish was the Crisp Braised Pork Shank. A little dry on the outside but the buttermilk dressing made up for it. Oh and the shank was huge..  we were all full by the time this dish came out but we managed to finish the job. Overall, awesome food, great service and cool atmosphere.

One of the best places in Chicago to eat! You won't be disappointed! They change up the menu pretty often but the staple will always be goat. The different combinations and textures of food they combine is unimaginable. Prepare for a taste explosion in your mouth.

I was torn between 4 and 5 stars so I decided to round up and give it 5 stars.

RESERVATIONS: I called to make reservations 3 months before the date.  When booking online it kept saying nothing was available so I just ended up calling.  I would keep trying even a little bit before just in case.  We got a 7:30 pm reservation for Sunday night.

ATMOSPHERE: It's definitely a trendy restaurant with a fairly open inside, open kitchen, lots of tables, dark mood lighting and cook fixtures inside like a large panel.  There is a very cute goat stamp on your napkin and quirky goat related sayings on the server's t-shirts.

FOOD: Again they suggested about 2 dishes per person for our group of 6 but we ended up getting 8 dishes and were satisfied.

GOAT LIVER MOUSSE - served with "crumpets"  or salty biscuits that come out hot.  for us since we had 6 people we asked for 1 more and they gave us 4 more for free! The pate itself was pretty smooth and good, I couldn't tell it was goat versus anything else I've had.  It also comes with three other toppings.  A salsa type, picked vegetables and then a berry jam.  The jam was my favorite to put on top of the pate.  Overall, a good dish and filling!

PORK SHANK - Came last and was our least favorite.  It's big and you have plenty for 6 people but some of it was slightly dry.  Kind of tasted like a turkey leg but much less flavor.  There were fatty pieces but overall kind of stringy.  The naan bread was good, almost more like a pita cut in triangles.  The kimchi sauce was slightly tangy but I liked the ranch/buttermilk sauce better.

PIG'S FACE - Their signature dish, so we ordered 2 of these.  Comes with a fried egg on top and almost like a fatty pulled pork underneath with some crispy onions.  Very tasty, very fatty and very flavorful.  I don't think I could eat more than 1/3 of the dish though without feeling a little OD'd.

CAULIFLOWER - surprisingly really good and refreshing.  it has mint and other spices which help elevate the flavors.  What we liked about girl and the goat was that everything is jam packed with unique flavors. nothing was bland or just "ordinary" but had really good tastes.

OCTOPUS - another one of my favorites.  lots of good flavors, slightly savory with pieces of octopus, fava beans etc.

SCALLOPS - 2 large scallops so splitting between 6 of us meant a small sliver but still tasty.  this one had a different taste than the octopus. If I had to choose I liked the octopus flavors more.  Scallop wasn't overcooked and perfectly seared.

HAM FRITES - basically shoe string cut fries dusted with ham that taste like bacon.  Reminded me of baked potato fries.  The fries themselves were a little hard and not as crispy as I would like but a good staple for a group.  Both dipping sauces were also very flavorful and good.

Overall, we thoroughly enjoyed ourselves here and felt full afterwards.  Definitely recommend!

Again, one of those rare instances I give a 5 star rating.  I got an email 5 weeks ago to let me know I have to work in Chicago.  The 1st thing I did WS to find a reservation at the Girl and The Goat. I could jot find one except for a 1045pm seating. It was kind of late. Yesterday I saw an opening to reserve at 445pm today and I grabbed it. My work ates were all jealous that I was able to dine here. Got the at 430pm, and was warmly greeted, and sat down right away. Everything we ordered was superb. Our waiter Austin, yes like the city was just a great guy. He asked us what we liked and made suggestions starting with the drink. Had a Bourbon smash drink, well a few, and it was delicious.  He sent over a focaccia bread with some melted cheese on top which was awesome to start. Got the shoshito peppers to start..wow. Then came the Divers Scallops.  My dining buddy told me he thought it was the best scallops he ever had. They were good. The strong beans with cashews had a sauce that blended so well, amazing. Next came the lamb ribs which are literally falling off the bone. Then went to the pork shank...it was a culinary divine dining experience.  Finally ended with the dessert, blueberry baba....oh my, what a way to end the meal. Light, with sugar coated blueberry and vanilla ice cream.  Between Austin and the food, we left there si satisfied. By 5pm, the bar area is full and they are eating there, not just drinking. If there is any way you can dine here...You do it!

worth the hype? yeah. We were not disappointed at all. I got really lucky and got a reservation for Sunday at 5pm. My friend and I were excited to try this place since my coworkers were raving about it.

we ordered the miso butter bread, cauliflower dish, octopus and pork shank since all of these dishes were highly recommended by our waiter. we opted not to get goat since we weren't feeling for it.

the meal was amazing from start to finish. the miso butter bread was delicious. They gave 4 pieces of warm brioche. It was perfect with the melted butter. My friend loved it so much she ate my portion of bread and even used the butter spread on our dishes. the cauliflower dish was my favorite. It had a nice smoky and nutty flavor to it that I couldn't stop stuffing my mouth. We didn't love the octopus as much as we hoped to. The pork shank was flavorful and had crispy skin all around for us to munch on. I can see why there's so many reviews. even if a dish didn't live up to the hype the other dishes made up for it.

We were so full at the end so we opted not to get dessert. Oh and I had a bottle of green flash raspberry beer that went well with the meal.

Side note - The tables next to us ordered goat empanadas and loved it

Love this place! Hard to get reservations, but if you make it in, it's worth the wait. The food is all good, I don't think I tried a bad dish. In fact we over ordered and ended up with too much great food (yay for leftovers). The green beans were surprisingly good and would highly recommend those.

So I've been to girl and the goat twice in the past 4 years, and I just say I was much more impressed my first time thee. I still remember the delicious blistered shishito peppers and amazing passion fruit dessert (and completely underwhelmed by the pig face, which was greasy and heavy). However when I went back again in December, the shishito peppers and veal tartare were too salty and the dessert menu was underwhelming. However the perogies and seared scallops were very tasty! I would say to come here with maybe one other person and get a bar seat right away, but probably not worth waiting several hours for.

OMG nothing in this meal could be better.

Absolutely everything we ate and drank was amazing

If I were you I would just eat the pig face like 50 times

The cauliflower was amazing

The green curry with the salmon was fantasy in the best way. Favor full without over spice

It has earned every minute of hype and you should go

The food was as I expected for the hype. We sat down at 10:45p (they serve food until 11)  and have never felt more rushed by a server, or as if my dining in was annoying to him and ruining his night. There were plenty of people throughout the restaurant so we definitely weren't the last lingering customer. Made the experience uncomfortable and therefore unenjoyable. Probably just one bad apple though.

This was the best meal of my life!!  I was lucky enough to snag a 4:30 reservation on Tuesday. Victor was our waiter and he was fantastic. The food: duck tartare, scallops, goat empanadas and confit goat belly were all fantastic!! The star of the show was the duck tartare, we were told that Stephanie just won Iron Chef with this dish - it hits all of the tasting notes you could only dream of!! We also indulged in several cocktails, all were very tasty! Ending the night with the Carmel corn malt malls, OMG amazing! It's worth all of the hype, nice job Chef. I'll be dreaming of this meal until I'm able to return!

pics.caption: Caramel Corn & Malt Balls: vanilla malt gelato. popcorn caramel. chocolate magic shell Blueberry Bourbon Baba: bourbon gelato. whipped cream
Exterior of Girl and the Goat!

review.des:
This has been a foodie destination of mine for years now, and the inspiration behind my recent trip to Chicago. One of my old coworkers (who would dine at Osteria Mozza while I could only afford Pizza Mozza) said this was one of his top 10 dining experiences. #foodiegoals

As soon as my friend and I booked our trip, I immediately turned around and looked for reservations. With a little over a month to go, everything was booked solid except 10:15 Thursday night. Done and done.

The real only hitch was the girl who left me a message to confirm my reservation left the wrong phone # in her voicemail. If that's all I have to complain about clearly they're doing something right.

Our experience was great. There was a slight wait while our table was cleared, so they offered us a seat in the bar and gave my friend the opportunity to order a very stiff old fashioned. Once seated, we were warmly welcomed by our server. My pescatarian friend was a good sport in accompanying me to a goat-centric restaurant and opted for the halibut and grilled octopus. After drooling over the menu for weeks, I stuck to my guns and got the duck tongues, the goat tenderloin and we decided to split the roasted cauliflower. No shame here...we traveled 2,000 miles and figured we'd order whatever we want!!

Everything was delicious. My friend said the halibut was her favorite dish of the entire trip. The octopus was charred yet tender. I usually despise when chefs do "Asian Fusion" but those duck tongues were fried so perfectly and dressed up so nicely that I had no qualms. The goat tenderloin was done perfectly and practically melted in my mouth. The cauliflower made us both feel better that we "ate our veggies."

The real win was dessert. I convinced my friend into splitting the caramel corn and malt balls dessert. A distinguished chef that serves a dessert with MAGIC SHELL is a standout in my book. I also have the biggest weakness for popcorn...when you combine it in ice cream it's pretty much guaranteed to be my pick. This was no exception. The mixture of sweet ice cream and salty popcorn gets me every time.

pics.caption: Caramel corn malt magic shell gelato
Melt in your mouth goat tenderloin
Roasted cauliflower. Pine nuts and mint complement them so well!

review.des: Celebrated the wife's birthday here last night.  Not our first time here, and certainly not our last time here either.  The place is always hopping and it's a tough reservation to get with at least 30 days notice.  Stephanie Izard is a genius and her food is simply amazing.  The grilled cauliflower is so good and I order it every time I come here.  The scallops are delish, the halibut, pork belly, and goat empanadas are all explosions of flavor in your mouth.  Prices are not out of control but portions are small, but the quality, presentation, and flavor knock it out of the park every time!

Incredible experience. We walked in on a Saturday night in February with no reservations thinking we would never get a table since there was a 2 hour wait across the street.
They accommodated us immediately which was great.
The food was unbelievable, especially the duck tongue!
Service was great and a great ambience overall.
Thanks for a great experience!

5600 reviews can't be wrong. I'll keep it short.

If for no other reason than the duck tongues that were available on our visit, this restaurant would hold a special spot in my heart. Luckily we enjoyed all 12ish+ dishes that we ordered. Some, obviously more than others, but the duck tongues were most definitely the highlight.

Service was friendly, atmosphere was unique. The only complaint is a normal one - Our table wasn't quite ready for us when we arrived. We had to wait about 30 minutes before the couple before us cleared out. It's not the restaurant's fault, but it's frustrating none-the-less.  Regardless, it was a beautiful meal.

Everything is amazing.  Make sure to try the green beans.

Hint: During the nicer months you can get good seating outside if you arrive early enough, maybe 20 min before they open.

Also if you can't get in m try The LIttle Goat Diner, everything here is also amazing.

Service was perfect. Water glass never empty. Waitress informed. The two of us shared each plate. Fried oysters with capers served on egg salad on a spoon started us. The kholarabi salad followed. It was a perfect blend of dressing, cheese, nuts and crunchy veggies. Next were short ribs with a tart grapefruit and radish garnish. We then feasted on the braised pork shank. My companion ate an ice cream desert to top off her meal. Our drinks were well done and above par. Great experience.

This place is so popular, the only time I could get a reservation for my table of 5 was 11pm on a Saturday night. Booked a month in advance too! However, I gotta say based on my experience.. it was worth it!! Here is what my table ordered:

- Bean sprout, was okay. Sauce was good and it went nicely with the other dishes.
- Beef tongue, so tender and yummy!
- Pig face, had an egg on top that you mix together. It was good and easily shareable.
- Soft shell crab, surprisingly tasty, soft and crispy!
- Baby octopus, the only dish I didn't love. Way too salty for me.
- Goat belly, my pick and it was awesome! Never had goat belly but I loved it.
- Ended my order with their Ruby don't love me drink. Light and sweet.

Someone from my table also wanted the pork shank dish but heard it was out. However, towards the end our nice server Alex came out with the dish saying they didn't want to disappoint and it was on the house! This dish was pretty substantial, the pork was tender and falls off the bone.

Overall, I had a great time. My favs would be beef tongue, soft shell crab and goat belly. If I came to Chicago again, I would probably try more goat dishes and the fish (which I heard is good too). Would definitely recommend this place as one not to miss!
One of my favorite Chicago foodie spots! Amazing staff and food! Great for date night or a group!

Such unique combinations that are deliciously paired together. Basically just order the whole menu and share! My favorite was the lamb empanadas - the strawberries on it were a game changer and I'm still not sure if the strawberries were just supposed to be garnish. The roasted cauliflower was amazing!! Anyone who can make vegetables taste that delicious is always a winner in my book and worth trying again!

pics.caption: Empanadas and cauliflower was my favorites this time!
Halibut was delicious - soft flaky and not too fishy

review.des:
I've been here twice now, and I have to say that my first visit I felt like I was in a magical foodie heaven. So not sure if coming a second time, that magic wore off somehow? The food fell a little short for me on round two, hence my 4 star review.

First, the interior is nice, but it is pretty typical of most interiors I think for the current trendy restaurant scene. Dark interior, bar area, high ceilings, open kitchen, some exposed brick. And the bar area is pretty small, but if you can't manage to get a reservation (which yes you should be making 2-3 months in advance if not earlier since this place is seriously always booked....) you could try the bar area at off peak times and see if you can snag some space.

Menu wise, I love the small plates sharing concept, and the crispy pig face really is that tasty. The flavors are just all there and so balanced, this dish was great. They make their own breads here as well, and I like that each time I had different bread choices. Their roasted beets were pretty tasty and their chickpea fritters as well. The calamari bruschetta in our most recent visit was a great rec from our server, since that clam juice in the bread is pretty awesome. But the goat empanadas fell short for us and the green beans were just like other green beans we've had elsewhere. So like I said, the first visit was amazing. Something during our second visit just didn't quite wow us in the same way. And for having to make reservations so far in advance, I really would expect no off nights here. But it truly is a Chicago eating gem for a reason!

After many fantastic meals here I've finally decided to give this restaurant the review it deserves.  GIRL AND THE GOAT IS BOMB!! Not just any kind of bomb, really bomb. This time me and my hubby went with 2 friends and between us shared 8 items + 1 dessert. We started with a bread that had a side of mushroom butter and apple sauce, then made our way through kohlrabi salad, scallops, sea bass, goat belly, pork shank and broccoli. Every single item was so well done - flavorful and memorable. The value for the money was fantastic and the service matched the wonderful food. Thanks GATG fam for making this another outstanding experience!

This is a great spot to bring people who are visiting, or to have a special night out it's worth the reservation if you love meat, and want to be a little adventurous. Although it can be a hard table to get, you can always walk in and grab a seat at the bar and enjoy an amazing dinner and drinks, especially their specialty cocktails that are made by friendly and knowledgeable bartenders.

Not a bad place. Definitely a tourist destination. Living in Chicago, I can definitely say there are better places to eat, but they do not come with all the Top Chef advertisement. Honestly, if you live here, I suggest going elsewhere. There are TONS of top-notch eats in Chicago that are at the same or lower price point that you do not have to make reservations for months in advance.

The service was very good and ambiance was good as well. 5 stars for those!
It's been 6 years since we have been and our recent visit, was the same. Perfect!  Service is fantastic and the staff never fail to point out their favorites and make recommendations. I love that.

Reservations get filled quick, so make sure to make one way ahead of time. Keep checking their website though, as time may open up; we were lucky to have booked a day/time on the same week.

The dining experience is family-style; our waiter recommended 4-5 dishes for two people, which was plenty. Food is phenomenal; we ordered the kohlrabi salad, Johnny apple cheese bread plate, crispy roasted pig face, and the goat shank. All were delicious, but we highly recommend the pig face. We also tried the boondock saint cocktail (think holiday-spiced old fashioned) and their signature wine, a petit verdot from Walla Walla, WA (perfect if you like a full-bodied red). To close it all off, we ordered the Caramel popcorn and malt ball dessert - three scoops of malt vanilla gelato drizzled with chocolate shell and sprinkled caramel popcorn crunchies.

Overall a very satisfying dinner, will definitely come back again.

Heard about this place - and heard that everything was good. I heard correctly!  If you come here don't let the names deter you. The Pig Face (yes, that IS the main ingredient, not a cute description!) was my favorite dish of the night!  Duck tongues and goat empanadas were also tasty.

pics.caption: Here's the menu as of Oct 2017. Everything we tried was good!

review.des: Food is mediocre. They don't have sides with their meals...not even a burger. The "smoked" fries are just friends with BBQ seas
Meat dishes are by far the best I've had in chicago. Vegetables leave room for improvement. Overall, a wonderful experience! Phenomenal service.

My boyfriend and I drove up to Chicago to spend 24 hours in. So looking through a few restaurants i wanted to try to go to, Girl and the Goat was at the top of the list. They had one reservation left at 10:30 that we happily accepted. Which we did book out a couple weeks in advance.
Boy, am I glad we were able to get a reservation, this restaurant is fantastic...
I love the innovative thought process behind the creations of the plates. We ordered a few dishes, though not all of them were at the top of the list of what I wanted to try, but unfortunately I have an egg allergy so it ruled some out. The waiter took our menus and marked off the ones that did contain eggs which I sincerely appreciate.
The chickpea fritter was nothing short of amazing, the cuttlefish was the best one I've had, and the duck empanadas were great but not the favorite. We also ordered the daily special which was a ricotta based bruscetta that i thoroughly enjoyed, but my boyfriend just liked it.
Definitely a place that does live up to its hype.

I was pleasantly surprised by the eclectic offerings here. Be prepared to try something you have never tried before (tongue!) or get something plain that has been elevated (dat cauliflower). One of the few restaurants where the price matches the quality of food.
Amazing. Walked in without reservations and they were able to work us in. Everything is delicious. Must do the shishito peppers and the pig face (don't let the name scare you)

Everyone that came to Chicago before me rave about this place, so clearly I had to come try it.  Got a pretty late reservation at 930pm.  

Atmosphere is cool...very loud.

Food

Started off with goat empanadas...ehh not worth $8 each.  Didnt taste very good.  The guac was good though

Got a half order of the cauliflower  that was decent, nothing amazing.

blueberry salad was drenched with dressing.  If you like cheese you would like this because i pretty much got a cheese plate with some very seasoned greens...

Pork face with a fried egg.  This was tasty.  The crispy parts of the pork face are very flavorful.  The guy that dropped off our food suggested us to break the egg and mix it all together.  

Pork shank was good.  I liked the picked vegetables it came with.  The pita bread went well with the dish too.  Wish i got more of the vegetables though.

Black dog sorbet was good.  I think i got a strawberry rhubarb.  It hit the spot.  I just wanted the sorbet and not the dessert they offered that includes the sorbet.

Service

I don't know what you call the guys that drop off your food for you, but they were knowledgeable and told us about the dish and how to eat it when they drop it off.  The main waiter was kinda not there very much.  Not very interested in serving the client.  Had too many helpers doing his work for him.
