After making a reservation three months in advance, I'm not going to lie: I had high expectations for Girl & the Goat.  My friend and I came here on a Saturday night, and the food was excellent.  We had the corn bread, wood grilled broccoli, wood oven roasted pig face, goat belly, and pot de creme, in that order.  We also split a bottle of wine.  My favorites were the broccoli and pig face, but I was truly impressed with everything we ordered!  The atmosphere, although casual, was also comfortable and well-done.  We lucked out by getting a table next to a wall--it gave us a little more space, as the two-person tables were pretty close to each other.

Our server was kind, but the food came very quickly and we certainly felt rushed in our dining, to the point that it affected our experience.  We were just starting to enjoy our wine when the first two plates came out, and then we were still in the middle of our meal when the server brought out a dessert menu.  The check came out, unsolicited and without any sort of "no rush but I'll leave this here for when you're ready" sentiment, about a minute after getting our dessert. And to top it all off, our check was retrieved within about 30 seconds of putting our cards down.  All in all, it felt like the server wanted us to get out as soon as possible.  Especially considering that it is so difficult to get a reservation here, we were hoping to savor the experience a little bit.  But the rushed service definitely took away from the evening, even though the food was amazing.

Every thing is delicious, my family just loved it.  Worth the waiting for a tale.
The food was so nicely presented and the staff was very pleasant.
Hello Roasted Cauliflower....!
OMG. Goat belly with Lobster, Crab, Fennel and Boubon Butter??? Sea bass with yogurt, mint, and vanilla??? Scallops with goat bacon???? Phenomenal!

This still tops my "must try" when in Chicago lists.  Could possibly have the pig face and green beans every night for dinner.  Reservations are STILL hard to come by, but getting there early and grabbing a seat at the bar is my preferred method of choice.  

Can never go wrong with the specials on the menu and their wine selection always has something interesting and affordable.

I can see why this place is a 4*. The food was amazing. We walked in and was told there was a 2+ hr wait, thankfully we got to sit down after 1.5 hr but was told that we only had 1.5 hr to eat as there was a reservation right after us. I didn't really expect them to uphold that time limit but they actually did so we didn't get dessert or anything but that was okay since we felt so completely full.

We ordered the chickpea fritters (my friend highly recommended it) and it was delicious. Very creamy and full of flavor. I wasn't a huge fan of the stone fruits in it but the fritters themselves were amazing.

Our second dish was the grilled octopus. That was also wonderful. Usually the octopus is a little over cooked and blackened but this was wonderfully grilled to perfection. The one thing I didn't enjoy were the blackened veggies with it. Other than that, awesome.

My favorite dish was the goat empanadas. I thought that was amazing. It was on the small side with only two empanadas but I really really enjoyed it.

The last dish we got was the pig face. While it was delicious, it was also incredibly greasy from all of the pig fat. I just didn't like it because it felt like I was eating pure fat in some of my bites but my friend loved it.

Overall I highly recommend it. I would love to try some diff dishes though next time and with more people.

Finally! I have been wanting to eat at this restaurant for months... my experience was worth the wait. The food was everything that I was expecting it to be, delicious, complex flavors, perfect pairings, unique, and beautiful. Definitely, a must try restaurant in your visits in Chicago. However, you must make reservations months ahead as it books up. I had the goat belly YUMMY is the word. I also tried the bruschetta with calamari and lobster YUMMY again. And the bread omg ... the bread was sooo good I ordered some to go. I need togo back and try different dishes, but so far the ones I tried were delicious.

Coming here with a high expectation since everyone is raving about this place.
We ordered several dishes:
- Buns (forgot what was the name)
- Pan Roasted Halibut
- Chickpea Fritter
- Soft shell crab
- Pig face (2 orders)
- Pork shank

Out of these dishes, the pig face of course was the best! The halibut was good also.
Honestly, probably since a lot of people keep saying they are the best, I have a high expectation on this place already.
They were not bad, but they were just okay.

Awesome dining experience! Every dish I tried has fantastic flavors and the menu is very well thought out. Very lovely staff. Also the staff is extremely knowledgeable about the entire menu, including the drinks . Definetly I go back!
An absolutely incredible meal and dining experience.  Make.sure to sit at the bar and have Jason help you. He is awesome!

This place was the best meal in Chicago! Waiter was attentive, fun, outgoing and helpful. We had the citrus bread, pig face, goat empanadas, goat carpaccio, duck tartare, and pork shank. We would choose everything but the carpaccio and pig face and not that they were not good it's just that everything else was AMAZING. The tartare and pork shank were probably two of the best dishes we ever had.

Only thing missing was a goat dessert. I was hoping for a goat cheesecake or goat tres leches, goat panacotta but there was nothing on the menu... boo!

Fabulous place!

After hearing such great things about the Girl & the Goat, I had to stop by here during my visit to Chicago.

Pro-tip: If you're dining solo at the bar, you can order half-size portions of most of the dishes. This allows you to try more dishes off the menu and boy did I take advantage of this. I ordered five dishes + dessert!

I ordered the chickpea fritters, goat empanadas, escargot dumplings, wood oven roasted pig face, and diver scallops.

The chickpea fritters, goat empanadas, and pig face were definitely my favorite. The dumplings and scallops weren't bad, but just didn't have enough of a kick to top the former three. The pig face was the only dish that didn't come in half portions, but I didn't mind that. It was absolutely delicious with so many different flavors and textures all in one.

I finished off with the all the leches cake for dessert. I'm a big fan of tres leches cake in general, so this dish did not disappoint.

I also recommend the Best of Three cocktail.

Definitely come here early. I came exactly at 4:30 pm on a Thursday and was promptly seated at the bar. But there were definitely no more seats left by the time I left around 6.
Great service and great food!! Make reservation days before you want to go to make sure you get a table!

Overall hyped up place. Food is decent and more adventurous than your stock standard place and service was great. The decor was hip and fun but we sat on the patio. Honestly though I love the little goat diner better but it's a good place to try and check out

I made reservations a month ago knowing I'd be in town for work. My sister lives here so we made plans to indulge. We were seated right on time with our reservation. Family style works great when you are dining with family!

The Very Old Fashioned and Mohalo were perfect starts.
Goat empanadas
Ramp pierogies
Macadamia halibut
Roasted cauliflower
Pig face
Chocolate cake/shitake gelato
Toffee popcorn ice cream

We didn't have favorites, because EVERYTHING WAS AMAZING! Our sever was friendly, knowledgeable and so on time. Our neighbors were forthcoming with recommendations and even shared the lamb ribs... OMG! This was an excellent experience and we can't wait to go back.

One of the highlights of Chicago. Well, to start off you will probably need a reservation, sorry.

The wait looked severe buuut luckily we got reservations! We got there late as hell (~2 hours; Chicago metro is a pain imo) but they held them for us. Got seated in communal like area, the ambience was great. The waiters/waitresses are extremely knowledgeable and attentive. Your meals are spaced out and are to be shared among your table.

We started with the olive you bread plate, which came with a warm bread with olives in it, whipped feta cheese, and olive oil..man. I could of ate that all night. It was one of the most simple and delicious combination of things I've ever ate. I wish I had some right now..
We then got the wood grilled broccoli (a summer time favorite), the pan roasted halibut (the sauce at the bottom was lovely), and lastly the very crispy pork shank. If I could complain about anything, I wish that the buffalo sauce that came with the pork shank was a bit more spicy or flavorful. Overall the meals and service were excellent.

I was really reluctant to try this restaurant when my s.o, brought it up. When reading the menu the dishes seemed very eccentric..like successful "Chopped" dishes, very random ingredients. But I really enjoyed every bit. It was recommended to us when told others we were visiting Chicago, and after trying it I'd highly recommend to anyone else visiting.

I've been hearing about Girl and the Goat ever since moving to Chicago - it is a legendary spot for foodies! Coming in at 5pm on a weekday, my friend and I were able to grab the last 2 spots at the bar area and got a bunch of small plates to share. The most memorable dishes were the broccoli and the whole fish. Any of the goat meat items are definitely worth checking out as well.
The food was excellent, but the restaurant is so hyped up that meeting expectations was probably an impossible feat.

After having made reservations months in advance, our hopes were high for the night of  anniversary. We were not let down. Our server David took such great care of us via great wine pairings along our whole tasting journey. He even delivered an extra plate of the AMAZING green beans that we missed ordering, so we wouldn't miss out. Was he ever right! We had potato pierogies, calamary bruschetta, goat empanadas, green beans, braised lamb ribs, & braised pork shank. David & the staff saw my reservation comment on Open Table re. our anniversary & brought us a bourbon blueberry dessert (with candles!) as a sweet surprise. That might be the best meal we've had. Kudos to all at the Girl & Goat!

First time visiting Chicago with my wife and we wanted a somewhat upscale restaurant to dine in for our first night. The atmosphere is lively and the vibe is great. We reserved online and we're seated quickly upon arrival. The Pan Fried Shishito Peppers were top notch! Best I've ever had. Highly recommend starting off with that. The waiting staff are attentively and we had a great time. Will be back again!

I previously LOVED this place but had my first off-experience in 7 years. That bumps it down a couple stars. I'm hoping it's a one/off isolated incident.
Food--ok. Here is the rundown:
Cauliflower was good but mint overtook other good flavors.
Perogis--delicious. Loved these.
Broccoli was awful. It was SO smoky that i couldn't get the charred taste out of my mouth. No amount of vodka nor water would cleanse my palette.
Chicken may have been good but the charred smoke taste in my mouth from broccoli muted my taste buds.

Service was also worse than previous experiences. We had to ask to get a clean plate after the third course...two times before it came justbafter the final course.

The service is usually impeccable so maybe we just had an off section. Or maybe after 7 years, the tight ship Stephanie runs is wearing thin.

I will go back again as this has been a fav le of mine for years
...but it will be the final experience of there is a repeat of tonight.

This restaurant is owned by Chef Stephanie Izard and she has put together really great dishes to excite every part of the palate.

I visited the restaurant over the weekend and did not have a reservation My girlfriend suggested that we try to get there and see if they had openings for walk-ins since it was only 4:30, had only eaten a late breakfast, and were ready to eat. We walked up and were told that a line was forming outside for first come first serve on the wait list. We decided to join the line and were the 3rd party waiting. In less than 15 minutes there were at least 20 to 25 people lined up behind us. This was my indicator that we had probably chosen wisely.

We were seated immediately and greated by our server who was friendly and knowledgeable of the menu. We chose the Bucatini and the Goat Satay as our first two dishes. They were advertised as sharable dishes by our server, so we elected dishes we both had interest in.

The Satay was the first dish we ate and coupled with the puree and other ingredients, the dish was a great start to our meal.

We then went on to the Bucatini. We both agreed that we could have eaten another bowl of this delicious pasta with milk braised pork shoulder and goose berries.

The first two dishes were so good I wanted more! I ordered the scallops that came as a pair placed on a puree. They were amazing as well.

With my meal I chose the 18th street pale ale that is allegedly brewed by the chef and her husband. It was a light and a very drinkable beer with a light touch of hops, but not over whelming like an IPA. I had a second glass as the first went down so easily.

Though much credit goes to the Chef for her creative dishes. The cooks were on point that evening as they delivered a consistent and delicious meal. We both agreed that we will be returning for another go at other items on the menu.

5 Stars

/* AMY & BETO TAKE OVER CHICAGO */
/* Bay Area to Chi town */

The hype is real! Be sure to dine at The Girl & The Goat when visiting Chicago. The food is delicious. Pro tip: make a reservation early as they were all booked on a Thursday night... However, bar is first come, first serve.

Boyfriend and I came to the restaurant around 6 on a SNOWY Thursday and the restaurant was completely booked. Luckily we swoop up a bar seat in less than 5 minutes!

The restaurant is on the small side and very modernly decorated. It does get loud in here, but I didn't mind.

So they serve tapas, aka plates to share. Our server recommended 4 plates for two people for a full meal.

What we ate:

- Olive you bread (cute name!)
Fresh bread with olives baked inside! Came with feta cheese dip and a olive oil dip. Tasty!

- Goat carpaccio
I didn't try the dish, but my boyfriend said it was ok. He's never had raw goat before and it wasn't his forte

- Wood grilled broccoli
This is definitely a winner! Broccoli grilled with crispies and smoky blue cheese.. SO YUMMY. All the flavors went wonderful together.

- Grilled baby octopus
I love octopus and this was great. It came with fava beans, pistachios and a lemon vinaigrette.

- all of the leches cake
This dessert was a leches cake with rhubarb served with strawberry ice cream on the side. This is definitely one of those desserts that just make you close your eyes and whisper "yassss" ;)

Overall, the flavors of all the food I had was ON POINT. the only thing I didn't like was the food was a little bit salty. Whenever I find myself in Chicago again, I will definitely revisit :)

Incredible Experience! Came at 4:30pm on a Thursday and grabbed a seat at the bar. Vinny from Walnut Creek was a fantastic bartender and made the experience amazing. Everything we ordered - pig face, lamb, hamachi crudo, green beans, and duck tongue were absolutely amazing. Would absolutely recommend the lamb, it cannot be missed! Had such a fun night and would highly recommend Girl and the Goat to everyone!

Glad I somehow managed to get a reservation.. glad I got to order.. glad I got to eat.. sad it was all over. Ordered pretty much everything off the menu lol.. loved everything we ordered. If you can get a reservation, go!!!!! It def lived up to the hype!
Excellent place to wine and dine. They have a wide variety of wines to choose from and a nice variety of foods to choose from. Usually featured during Chicago Restaurant week as well! Must try!

I had a solo trip to Chicago and hearing it's a big food city I planned appropriately for a dining and drinking expedition for one.

Unfortunately I did not have drinks at G&tG, but I was helped out by my lovely server, Alex, on how to navigate the menu.

I really wanted the pig face (I mean have you seen it? Who wouldn't??) but she advised against it for a solo diner because it's so rich and filling. this restaurant is meant to be approached "family style" ordering multiple dishes not unlike tapas (but actually good). Some dishes can also be ordered in "mini" half portions which is fantastic for someone who wants to just try something but not necessarily fill up on it.

I mentioned my interest in seafood and she pointed me out to the salmon. I originally looked passed it because I am a salmon and pea junkie at home- I eat it about 2x a week if not more, and have a dedicated shoe box just for my Trader Joe's petite pea collection in my freezer along with my bulk bag of salmon from Costco. Did I really travel halfway across the country to eat what I usually have? Well, thank god Alex was there because because it totally reapproached peas and salmon in a new light. The salmon was interpreted in a Japanese fashion channeling ramen with a rich goat dashi and nori, peas, and popcorn furikake. Lemon zest dots the furikake imparting bright, citrus aromas. The tender, sweet asparagus cuts up the rich flavors like a culinary intermission. This dish was truly an experience!

The roasted cauliflower went beautifully with the mint and lemon. My "least favorite" dish of the night was the goat carpaccio but that itself was fantastic. I'm not much of a goat eater but the meat has a surprisingly mild flavor. Paired with the smoke trout roe and olive slivers, it simultaneously channeled smoked salmon with capers and sashimi at the same time.

Last but not least were my TWO desserts. I do not normally order dessert. I don't even have much of a sweet tooth, but I thought- why not, let's just have the full course. I was eyeballing the horchata rice pudding with the rhubarb semifreddo but Alex asked me to trust her and gently suggested the toffee cake. Best. dessert. ever. The candied cashews were incredible. The toffee cake was incredible. Everything about this dessert was incredible. Once again, I'm not a dessert person, and I would order this again in a heartbeat. She sent out the rice pudding anyways for me to try, and despite being utterly fantastic as well, the toffee cake is where it's at!

I am floored by the quality of food and the level of service for the price I paid. Such quality, well-prepared food in such an unpretentious environment, almost unheard of where I am. I just wanted to cry knowing that I live almost 700 miles away from this place.

I don't like to repeat myself when I travel but honest to goodness, this is not a place you want to skip over if you're dropping into town. I know I'm going out of my way to fit G&tG into my itinerary next time I'm in Chicago (and I will find someone to try the goat leg and pig face!)

pics.caption: Could not finish my double dessert.
Goat carpaccio with olives, frisée, smoked salmon roe.

review.des: My boyfriend & I decided to walk in on a Saturday night & luckily grabbed a seat at the bar within 30 minutes! Every single dish here is delicious. We got-                                                                           fried oysters: unlike any fried oysters I've had, they were perfectly crunchy & the sauce on top had a lot of flavor, we were gonna order the wood fired instead but so glad the waiter talked us out of it!                                                          escargot ravioli: one of my faves! the ravioli was in this delicious onion broth, you'd love it especially if you like french onion soup.                               roasted cauliflower: the peppers in this added a zest to the cauliflower, it was the perfect contrast         confit goat belly: this was our first time trying goat, & it was lovely! The meat was perfectly cooked & the lobster & crab all tasted wonderful together, I'm still dreaming about the bourbon butter         caramel corn & malt balls: unlike any dessert I've had! the chocolate with the caramel corn was perfect, I highly recommend this dessert!

There are not many places where I would wait 2 hours for a table for 2 but this is somewhere special that I would take out of town guests. After living in Chicago for 6 years, I truly believe GATG is the quintessential new American Chicago restaurant. It's classy but not pretentious. The food is creative but also classic.

We ordered the sugo (which I remembered to be just as good as last time), scallops (fresh and well cooked but probably would skip since it's $20 for 2 scallops...), pig face (YES! Get this! I was reluctant too just looking at photos but it's worth it!), and the goat pate (meh...).

I think overall the dining experience here is unparalleled. It's a great place to go to if you want to impress someone!

I don't understand why this place is one of the top restaurants in Chicago!!!! I big time disagree. The place is pretty but doesn't give up to the hype.
Every single dish we have ordered wasn't good at all.
The grilled oysters made me almost want to vomit. They were smelly and disgusting couldn't swallow it at all.
The octopus. Was very salty..
The tongue: which is my favorite dish usually! But This one was inedible.
The shrimp was ok but pricy for an okay 4 shrimp $17
Beet salad! Was the best out of everything $12

We really had such  a high hope to try this place. It was hard to make reservation and we tried our best to make it here... and in the end we didn't only left hungry but with a stomachache!
I definitely do not recommend the girl & goat restaurant!

Hello!  I recently visited Girl & the Goat on a recommendation from a friend.  It was the best meal (my own cooking included!) that I have had in years.  Menu is brilliant, service impeccable, plates were served in such a manner that the combination and order of tastes blended on my palate in a magical and miraculous way.  I wanted to let the chef(s) know that my only complaint was that the broccoli plate and the halibut plate were over-salted.  Otherwise, my experience at this restaurant was perfection itself. I will be recommending this place to everyone I know!

Everything was excellent! Great foods and customer service, we will be back.

Hard to make reservation but keep calling them, they'll make the best effort to accommodate you.

My boyfriend surprised me for my birthday dinner here and we definitely got the royal treatment. We got to sit at the chef's table and watch the magic happen in the kitchen. As we were ordering one chef gave his personal recommendation, the mussels! Get the mussels with chorizo croutons!! We also ordered the pig face, confit goat belly, beet salad, calamari bruschetta and wood fired oysters. All amazing! Their Old Fashioned is tasty and strong. Their desserts were delicious, the cha cha cha chocolate & chorizo dessert was very unique and tasty, a little too salty/sweet. All in all, I would come back in a heart beat!

Great food and great service. Will definitely come again. It was a little pricy, but well worth it! Fun twist on a lot of different items. Like grapes on fish... never thought that would work well... but it did.
Went a few year back, a little pricy but definitely good food. No wonder their reputation.

Liked it... but not sure it was worth the 2 week wait for our reservation. Note worthy dishes: hamachi crudo, oysters, short rib (which was much like a short rib ceviche with grapefruit juice and crispy short rib). Was NOT a fan of the goat empanadas, and I LOVE empanadas. (Turns out I am not a huge fan of goat, which may be affecting my review) Though our food was good and experience was fine, I can't give 5 stars because I truly wasn't "WOWED". ChicAgo is full of incredible restaurants, & though girl and the goat is good, I'd personally leave it for the tourists.
Green beans were put of this world - bucatini was amazing too. Goat empanada was ok, same with the pork shank

This was easily the best meal I've ever had.

The plates are meant to be shared, but I dined alone and it worked out just as well (if not better). My server, Kristen, walked me through the menu when I sat down and not only pointed out her favorite items, but also the ones that she would be able to split in half to accommodate one person. This was so appreciated since I was traveling alone and I had been to other shared plates restaurants that didn't offer this option.

I had the sautéed green beans to start and they were perfectly cooked. They are the only dish that has been on the menu since they opened and definitely worth ordering. I also ordered one of the goat empanadas. It was INCREDIBLE. The meat was tender and the blueberry/grilled pineapple salsa it is served with was awesome. If they sold it by the jar, I would buy them up. My main dish was the pan-roasted halibut with marcona almond butter and white asparagus. I've never had fish prepared this well. Every single bite was better than the last and it quite literally melted in my mouth. When it was time for dessert, I had the caramel corn and malt balls. It was vanilla gelato with a chocolate shell and caramel popcorn bits. I'm glad I opted for the three scoops instead of one because I cleaned the entire plate.

Girl and the Goat lived up to my every expectations and then some. Make this a priority when you visit Chicago! And book WAY ahead of time. I had to make my one person reservation in late May for a table on a Tuesday in July at 8:00 :)

I really enjoyed this restaurant. The ambience is beautiful, feels rustic and cozy.

The server was always attentive and I initially when ordering forgot to mention a food allergy. After ordering 8 different things he ran back to make sure all of it was okay.

The menu is really unique and I was especially in love with the chickpea fritter, escargot dumplings, the short rib.... Very good.

They also have a good selection of speciality cocktails and bottles of wine.

Will definitely make sure I visit this place again.
Fab food! Fab atmosphere! Fab staff! It was worth the wait; celebrated a reunion with dear friends who live over the pond.

My absolutely favorite place while visiting in Chicago. Someone recommend this restaurant to my friend, and we decided to give it a try. Must have a reservation, place is really busy, and I see why.  
We were running about 20 min late, called them, and host was really nice saying they will wait for us. our table was ready as we arrived. Our waiter was friendly, honest, fast and very professional. He recommended us great food and drinks choices all three of us enjoyed . I can't remember what we had exactly , since its been awhile, but I know it was top notch !
I don't know what else to say other than this restaurant is a must-see for anyone visiting Chicago or living here. Already made our reservation to go back in June!

pics.caption: Drunk menu is on point! I tried the "All becomes one" and it was amazing
We got the brocoli, escargot ravioli, and my favorite: the duck tongues with tuna poke
Goat ribs.. first time trying them and they were amazing!

review.des: One of the best dining experiences I've ever had. Everything from the service to the drinks to the food was amazing. Can't wait to go back!

Was very skeptical about going here,  thinking goat may be gamey. Son made reservation and had special order a goat leg.  We also ordered some other dishes - pig face,  green beans and cauliflower. Was surprisingly DELICIOUS!! The vegetables tasted gourmet, so you can imagine if the chef can make plain veggies taste that good,  then the entrees would be superb! I'm sure if I could make veggies taste that good, my kids would've eaten more vegetables when younger.
Now the goat leg - what can I say. It was a great meal made for royalty. They recommend 7-8 people,  but the 4 of us chowed it down with only less than 1/2 lbs. of meat left.  Even the waiter was impressed and underestimated us,  lol. This is one of the places to go if you are ever in Chicago!
This is the place to bring out of town guests. Some of the best that Chicago has to offer and at a very affordable price point.
VERY delicious. We ordered only vegetarian & fish dishes. Exceeded my already high expectations

Delicious drinks! Cute cozy great designed restaurant . Make sure you make reservations in advanced , but I went for drinks at the bar with my friends  and had a great time. Good cocktails , and great service. Ask for what you want and the bartenders will guide you to a great selection.

This whole experience was amazing! Went with my girlfriend for a date night. Didn't have a reservation so we just hovered by the bar until 2 seats opened up (maybe 10 min). The service was great and all the food was delicious. We went with most of the chefs recommendations for dinner: fried oysters (my fave), escargot ravioli, roasted cauliflower, confit goat belly, and Carmel corn + malt balls for dessert.  Would definitely go back!

Delicious small plates. Proper correct saison beer. Sweet dessert. Super service.

Halibut, cauliflower, hamachi, and duck tongues were our favorites.

The Girl and the Goat opened with much anticipation in 2010 after chef Stephanie Izard won Top Chef over another heralded chef in Richard Blais.

The Girl and the Goat kept Izard's momentum going as it was nominated for Best New Restaurant by the James Beard Foundation. Although the restaurant did not win the award that year, Izard did win a James Beard Award for Best Chef Great Lakes in 2013.

Inside, the restaurant is quite dark, with lighting at a premium in the dining room. It is somewhat brighter near the kitchen however. The tables are spaced fairly closely to one another as well. This being one of the more popular restaurants in Chicago, the noise level is also somewhat at a fever pitch.

As with many restaurant now, The Girl and the Goat is a small plates concept. This is good in that you are able to try several dishes during a visit.

The Roasted Beets ($9) was paired with green beans, white anchovies, avocado crème fraiche and bread crumbs. The beets were nicely roasted, tender and sweet. The green beans added a nice crunch, while the anchovies added some salt and funk. The avocado crème fraiche added some creaminess and balance to the dish.

The Pan Roasted Halibut ($19) was nicely paired with Marcona almond butter for some nuttiness and richness. The blueberry nuoc cham added some fruitiness and salty funk, while the mushrooms added some earthiness to the dish. The white asparagus added slight hints of sweetness and more earthiness to the dish.

The Chili Shrimp ($17) was not hot at all, more of a mild heat. The shrimp were fairly large, and nicely cooked. They were still sweet and tender, and not beaten to death with heat. It was paired nicely with the sweetness from the corn.

Grilled Walter's Chicken ($21) was sort of a surprising dish in that is was somewhat soup like. The chicken was fall off the bone tender, with hints of Asian flavors due to the five spice. The fingerling potatoes were nice and creamy.

The Braised Beef Tongue ($15) was very tender and "meaty". The masa was kind of surprising since it was in chip form, but added a nice textural contrast.

The Miso Butterscotch Budino was silky smooth with some saltiness from the miso. The black sesame seeds added a textural contrast and more earthiness to the dish. A very satisfying way to end the meal.

The food here is excellent with execution also being on point. There are a couple seats on each side of the bar which allow a great view into the kitchen. I would try and get those seats if you are a foodie.

Wowza! Girl & the Goat has been on my list for a while now, and let's just say, I wasn't disappointed.

Some girlfriends and I had dinner here the other night and the entire experience was spectacular. We were seated promptly at our reservation time and the restaurant was bustling.

Highlights: everything. Seriously. Everything was superb.

We started with a bottle of pinot noir and the brioche with samba honey butter. Each dish came out as a separate course and we ate our way though the roasted cauliflower, halibut, crispy short ribs, pig face, and grilled octopus. Every dish was perfectly balanced with interesting flavor combinations and just enough acid to round them out. We ended the meal with the miso-butterscotch budino, and called it a night with full bellies.

Me "Pooh, did you like Girl & the Goat?"
Him "It was good BUT $16 bucks for 4 piss a** blue cheese pierogies was outrageous"

Y'all,  we went Tuesday ( 12/5 it's 12/11 as I'm writing this ) and do y'all know he's STILL talking about the 4 little a** rogies LOL; It's become a joke now but foreal...SUPER tiny. Ok, so we're totally into Restaurant Groups and GIRL AND THE GOAT belongs to the Boka group; Our 1st time to the Group... We pull up, walk in, and it WAS PACKED to THE BACK...(Note: make vations aka reservations) it was an 1hour wait BUT they had options...The BAR, so we gladly scurried to the bar, (NOTE: Don't sit at the Bar if you're there for dinner) I have a HUGE pet peeve and that's when the Server doesn't introduce themselves, I ended up asking her, her name way later. So anyway the menu was explained us, she took our order all at once (that was the rule) and it's small plates BUT they pack a BIG punch...we ordered 6 small plates plus bread; we were FULL CITY. Eating, laughing, drinkin, and talking with the Staff,  my luv says "Excuse me" (to our waitress, remember we still hadn't gotten her name) do y'all know she turns around and replies "WHAT?" UGH! My luv says "Damn, she said 'whet' (MOCKING her) it was uncomfortable so we laughed it off because it was busy and maybe she was having a bad night...I Waited patiently like a scavenger before I asked her name because you can't ask AFTER She replies "WHAT" she'd know you were slightly irritated ; Hannah Banana is her name, I added the banana at the end lol. All & All it was a great experience I wanted  some desserts BUT I was too scared to ask Hannah Banana  lol she wasn't gonna "What" me and all orders at the Bar must be taken all at once, bummer but I get it.

All & All it was a wonderful experience the food is amazing even the $16 rogies lol and if you're a veggie like us...you'll enjoy yourself. Oh the "warm olives" are NOT warm they're Scalding burn your tongue off hot but oh so good lol.

Stephanie Izard is the bomb.com
Who is she? She's only the first chick who won Top Chef
Her style is unique filled with passion deftly balancing the savory, sweet and tart
flavors to every single dish.

The menu consist of small plates, so no thing is very bog or expensive. I don't want to bore you with what I ate so check out my photos! All this is delivered in a casual, converted-loft environment with unadorned wood tables and painted concrete floors, illuminated by mounted spotlights, dangling Edison bulbs and some nifty tube lights over a bar and hip hop music in the back ground!

Everyone was pleasant and very informative which made our meal the best!
Thank you again!

One of the most popular restaurants in Chicago for a reason - place is definitely booming with good people and good vibes.

We ordered a lot of food from the menu, and all were very solid. Nothing in my opinion was exceptional, but they were executed well, and I'd definitely return for a casual dinner.

It was a great experience. The food was awesome. They come out shareable for the table. The service was exceptional. Just make sure you book a reservation before you go. This place is always packed. So much so you may just have to go and sit at the bar area, which is usually packed too.

It was really hard to make reservation for this restaurant. We went to this place Tuesday night at 9:30 but many people were still there and we waited for 15~20 minutes. The atmosphere was really trendy. All dishes are served like tapas so you should order more than one dish per person. I tried 4 dishes including calamari, cauliflower salad, pig face and lamb rib. The food was not salty, but perfectly marinated. Ingredients were fresh and well cooked. I recommend lamb rib with glass of wine.

Every dish was amazing, chef really knows how to accentuate the essence of the dish's main ingredient with subtle flavors and textures of the other supporting ingredients. Cassie really knows her wine and Einstein is a very hospitable floor manager. Will def be back next time we're in town!
Delish- goat empanadas were awesome! He'd and neck both delish Fritters were great- avoid the pizza -

Food is delish! Beet salad is absolutely wonderful and so fresh. The whipped goat cheese which comes with the olive bread is to die for.

Atmosphere is trendy. It seems everyone who goes there is with a group. There are no single men or ladies at the bar. This is definitely a cool spot for a date and to see how adventurous your date is at trying different things, such as the Duck Tongue appetizer.

Noise level is very high and loud. It made it difficult to hear my date talk over dinner. And when I talked I felt I had to shout.

Service is good. It wasn't difficult to flag someone down if needed. The wait staff who delivered the food were very knowledgeable of the dishes served.

The best food during my short Chicago trip, including a meal at Alinea! Everything we had was soooo delish! Fried oysters, goat liver pate, roasted cauliflower, pomme frites, goat empanadas, baby octopus, pig face, basically EVERYTHING was sooo freaking good. Chef Stephanie Izard is the real deal. Legit food, affordable prices, and unpretentious service.

You have to make reservations weeks in advance and it's totally worth it. I wish I had enough room for dessert because that butterscotch pineapple sounded so good, but the elastic pants I was wearing could not hold in my tummy long enough for dessert. Chicago is so lucky to have such good food available. Dallas sucks.

pics.caption: Lux Goods! Gin and chamomile and masala work so well together. Had the smoothest bite!

review.des:
Girl & the Goat was a great dining experience with some really unique dishes.  However, I was torn between a 3 or a 4 coming out of here because their menu seemed a little all over the place, the service was polite but not super helpful when it came to actually navigating said menu, and the food was in the end a little overpriced for what you got.

Decided to go with a 4 because the restaurant itself is very cool to be in and the food was at least enjoyable.  I think it suffered due to being over-hyped in general.  I much preferred dining at Little Goat later that week, so this iteration may just not be my cup of tea.

That being said, my favorites of the night were the goat empanadas and the pig face.  Both dishes had amazing flavor and I would definitely order them again!

Every bit as delicious and exciting as I had hoped! I'm a huge fan of Top Chef and make it a point to visit alumni restaurants in Chicago. My friend surprised me with a trip to Girl and the Goat and I was so happy! We tried the wood grilled broccoli, steamed mussels, goat empanadas, ham frites, pig face and the bucatini, and loved every bite. The cocktails are amazing, too! We will absolutely be back.

Came here with a 5 o'clock reservation and was seated right away. I called about a week in advance and was able to snatch this reservation because OpenTable was fully booked already.

This place lives up to the hype and long waits. From what I remember, we ordered the pig face, octopus, crispy duck tongue, empanadas, and the roasted cauliflower. Standouts were definitely the crispy duck tongue and the pig face. Great service and very knowledgeable staff!

Why does this place get som much hype?? Because it's amazing.  The best scallop I've ever had.  The green beans are a dish in itself.  It is hard to get into but you can wait a bit and get a bar seat which still has the full menu.  I've tried most of the menu and everything is a recommendation.  This is truly a chicago culinary experience.  Did someone say Goat Ribs?

How does one end a trip to Chicago in a perfect way? I'll tell you how.. By having dinner at Girl and the Goat. And when I say perfect, I mean it from the first sip of alcohol to the last bite of food.

I ventured in here on a Saturday evening after hearing reading a great article about it. Reservations apparently have to be made at least a few weeks out in order to have a chance at dining here, but I tried my chances at finding seating at he bar.

While waiting for a seat to open up, I ordered the "Thai one on" cocktail which immediately took me to heaven. A mixture of rum, brandy, passion fruit and Thai chili syrup, it's one the best cocktails I've ever had.

After about twenty minutes, a seat opened up at the bar and I got busy on some food. It's recommended you order three dishes since the portions are small, (which is true) so I ordered the chickpea fritters, the crispy beef short ribs and the seared diver scallops.

The fritters were excellent. They are made with a tamarind and mango sauce, which added a sweetness making it perfect. The scallops were unbelievable. It came topped with ginger chili, mushrooms and peanuts. So the taste was about as unique a scallop dish I've ever had. The short ribs, made with a grapefruit chermoula sauce, was the home run dish of the evening as it was definitely the best short ribs I've ever had. Tender, juicy and the sauce gave it an amazing flavor.

Everything's about Girl and the Goat was absolutely perfect, down to the cool r&b music music playing in the background. It's a loungey atmosphere, yet chill at the same time. Bartender gave a thorough explanation of the menu and how each patron should go about ordering. This whole experience was excellent and is an absolute must in my opinion when visiting Chicago.

Girl and the Goat is one of the most popular restaurants in Chicago . Not too pricey for the good food we get . Plates are for sharing . Shishito peppers and the chickpea fritters are lovely . I had one of their cocktails which had Guava in it which I absolutely loved . They are very accommodating . If we don't have reservations , they have a nice lounge area where we can sit and eat . Better make reservations though well in advance for a nice experience . Very nice service too .
This place was absolutely THE place to go for our anniversary - my hubby planned months in advance to get us a seat at the "chef's table."  We certainly had to wait, but it was well worth it!
The best dining experience you'll get in Chicago. The pork shank stands out the most compared to the other dishes, I haven't had anything like it. Cooked perfectly, this did not disappoint.
Everything here was an absolute delight. One after another, each dish contained unlikely combinations of delicious ingredients that just worked. Make sure to try the cauliflower!

Place is overrated and the food wasn't great to be on a waitlist. Our waiter was the best part of the whole night! I would say this place is a one time deal. There are much better tastier restaurants in the city to go and spend your money.

pics.caption: Duck tartare .. pretty sure I got food poisoning from this

review.des: Taking the simplest of ingredients and taking them to levels u thought u could never do. Ordered the corn bread, cauliflower(2 of em), goat belly, halibut, pig face,    And 2 deserts. All of em where exquisite and amplified the depth and level of flavor. You will never look at the food the same way again after eating at her establishment. Will most definitely go again given the opportunity.

pics.caption: Cauliflower, pine nuts, pickled peppers, mint.. How this was cooked and charred us beyond me.. Had to order this twice

review.des: I came for a vacation to Chicago and my friend got us a reservation from a month ago at this restaurant because she said it has good reviews and lot of people is heard good things about it. So, we had our dinner their yesterday and all dishes were unbelievably delicious. Everything was perfect, the food, service, and place. The best restaurant I have ever been to. Amazing

Food was delicious and cocktails even better. Pierogis, roasted cauliflower and hamachi crudo were a perfect trio to split among 2. We got there at 5p on a Friday and were seated right away without a reservation. It definitely was more crowded when we left ~630p so probably best to make a reservation if you can.
The pork shoulder was delicious! Really, everything was delicious. I had to make reservations 2 months out for a 9 pm time but worth the wait!

The private dining experience was to die for!!!! I hosted my wife's birthday there.   Service was top notch, very knowledgable, great interaction with all our guests!   The tasting menu was phenomenal!   The final touch was the braised goat leg!    Trust me when I say this, you will not be sorry for adding it!   It was Awesome!!!!

VEGAN REVIEW - We came here because they offer a separate vegan menu, which I appreciate, since my guests are not vegan.  Overall great service and nice ambiance.  However, the only thing I really enjoyed from the vegan menu was the broccoli.  The bucatini (which I was looking forward to) hardly had any mushrooms or tomato - so disappointing.  I won't be coming back.  I can make all of these dishes at home with more flavor for less money.  Next time I will support a legitimate upscale vegan restaurant instead.

That being said - my non vegan guests enjoyed the meat and fish dishes.

Overrated. Dined last night at 11:30pm booking for a friend's birthday. I took them here because of all the raves and how can one get wrong with a celebrated chef right? We ordered roasted cauliflower, duck tongue and hamachi crudo. All 3 of us didn't like any of them. The cauliflower was just lame. For 3 tapas and a red wine, bill came up at ~150. One of the servers was not very nice too. I was asking if there's something the restaurant can offer for my friend's birthday like a small dessert with candle and the guy just slammed the menu on the table smirking telling me that it's the menu. Not coming back again. Awful experience and food is mediocre.

Flavor is good, but some of the dishes were really sweet. The pirogies came with a sweet blueberry sauce, and the halibut was also served with a sweet Asian sauce. A little too sweet, even for my sweet tooth.

The halibut was barely enough to share between 2 people, even just to taste. My husband enjoyed the pig's face.  The shishito peppers were fine - everything tastes great with Parmesan.

Portions are extremely small. Our server recommended 2 dishes per person. We thought we were pushing it when we ordered 5 dishes for 2 people. Turns out it was not nearly enough. Could not order more because the kitchen was closed by the time we received our last dishes. We had a late reservation of 10:30pm. Would recommend 3-4 dishes per person.
Always delicious! Def go here if you want something tasty & a fun place to dine with friends.

Had one of the best dining experiences of my life! Dined with a group of four... food was amazing, definitely recommended the duck tongue, but everything was/is delicious! Service was great, Victor was on point with timing/service and helping to make our experience great! Also, their new wine director, Cassie, is doing awesome things! Even more additionally, the auxiliary staff were in tune on timing and service too, which is spectacular!!! ...You already knew you wanted to go here before reading my review, so hopefully this just makes you feel better about the decision you were already going to make!
Great food.  Ambiance is perfect.  Always busy so go early.  Able to grab a bar seat if you get there early enough

I was so excited to try this place for my birthday we got reservations about two months ahead since it's so hard to get in but I was still excited. However my server completely ruined the experience. Having been the first time we asked for some recommendations and when I said I didn't like certain things she pushed and pushed so we ended up with some things that I didn't enjoy at all. I could tell she felt bad and she gave us an extra dessert for free which we appreciated. Maybe it just wasn't my kind of food or maybe I would have liked if I ate something else. Considering all the hype surrounding this place I was very disappointed but it wasn't totally terrible probably would give 2.5 stars.

It took us a while to get a reservation at this place but boy was it worth it. The staff was great and the food was even better than what we had imagined.
Highly recommend: Kalbi Short Ribs, Pig Face, Beet Salad, and Green Beans. The Hamachi dish was okay.

This place was on my list for a long while and finally, I made it. Celebrating my birthday all week long last week and I had a blast especially, right here at Girl & The Goat. What a cool place! Based on the pictures on Yelp from other yelpers, not even close to the real life how this place can amaze you. I'm so impressed with this place. First, it was packed because of the restaurant week( no space to walk around when I got in ) I saw people were waiting to get in even the host said there weren't be able to take any reservations till after 11pm Second, the place is so much bigger than what I thought and well put together. There's a small lounge area on the left corner next to the bar, very nice and modern. The decor & art pieces on the wall are so cool.

I felt lucky to have a table for 4pp at 8 pm. after calling them 5 times during the restaurant week ( I almost gave up) I'm glad I kept trying. I made another  reservation ( my plan B) at 10pm at another hot spots right across the street that starts with B and ends with an A but after I saw Girl & The Goat, I called the other place and cancelled. My friends and I spent the whole night there and had an amazing time.

One of the bartenders, Jason made excellent drinks for our group. I stick with 2 of my favorite drinks, Local 75 & Best of Three, seriously amazing! My friends ordered almost everything on their cocktail list just to try out and they really enjoyed everything.

We ordered small plates to share and I was focusing on cocktails ;) All dishes looked great  with a nice presentation. The service was excellent as well. Based on how busy they were that night I was quite amazed how fast we got the food after we ordered. Got a complementary cake/dessert for my BD, Yeah!

The entire area is full of cool spots to visit for a great dining experience but Girl & The Goat is a "must try" visit this place when you get a chance and I'm sure you will have a great time here.

pics.caption: Local 75 & Best of Three. I had too many of those and it was supper fun.
Goat Empanadas. It's a must try!
Not sure what it called but it was dioecious, will find out the name for you.

review.des: Simply put, this place is worth the hype. The food is not only delicious but it is fascinating; I never thought calamari could melt in your mouth or expect shiitake mushroom gelato to work well with chocolate. And yes, they charge for bread; and yes, you should order the bread. It's worth it. Not only was the food amazing but the service was great, too. Trust me (as well as the hundred other perfect reviews) and experience it for yourself.
Everything was fantastic. Service was impeccable. If you haven't been, GO! Seriously, make that reservation and check it out.

We were lucky enough to get a table here during our trip to Chicago. We came with two vegetarian friends, and were worried that they wouldn't find anything they could eat on the menu. Our fears were never realized. They had so many delicious fish and vegetable options. Our favorites were the shishito peppers in cheese and breadcrumbs, and the green beans. I ordered the lamb tartare. It was tender and delicious, so light that I forgot it had meat in it. The seafood dishes were prepared well, with flavors that were bright but rich. The goat belly was meaty and buttery, and was a large portion. I couldn't dream of a more perfect dish. Their house labeled wine was really great and suited all the dishes well.
We finished with the leches cake, which was unlike any I had had before. The rubharb and strawberries made it a much lighter dessert.
If you can get a table, do yourself a favor and go.

I arrived at 4pm it opens at 430pm. There was already a line!!!

But no worries I got seated immediately at 430p. Everyone got seated it seems so come here at 4:15pm latest and you'll get seated

I ordered 3 items off the list. It's all communal food.

First was the duck tongues. Wow get this seriously! It was refreshing and just so unique. There was tuna in it as well. Yum yum I've never tasted anything like this before. Just wow wow wow.  5/5

Second was the pig face. There's an egg that's sunny side up on it. You're advised to mix it all up and eat it. Yummy. 5/5

Third was the goat belly and confit. This was delicious as well. I just wasn't a big fan of the smell for some odd reason but still 5/5

It was a special occasion (told them it was my anniversary with my gf when I made the reservation at 1130p which I cancelled when I arrived at 430p that day instead). They gave us free dessert. Wow wow so 5/5 too.

pics.caption: Free dessert because it was our anniversary. Special and rare.
Goat belly. Order this because you need to eat goat when you're in Chicago.
Pig face. It's not the entire head so no worries. Just the cheeks. Yummy

review.des:
Such a fun place with cool vibes! The food is great and the staff is warm/quick.
We got the spring onion pierogies, the seasonal focaccia, pig face (with something) and the blueberry bourbon baba dessert. Everything was incredible and we absolutely loved them.
Come here. Be ready to wait unless you're lucky like us and you grab a seat at the lounge. .

This place is amazing!
I am dining alone and get seated immediately at the bar. The server recommended me to order 2-3 plates, I usually don't eat meat much so I was like ... whatever !
So I picked two dish: hamachi crudo and goat belly. While the hamachi has interesting combination: hamachi sashimi with the sealed port belly, I feel the port belly has too strong flavor so the fish taste a bit bland. I really love the goat belly dish. The fatty goat belly comes with very refreshing sauce , and with crab and lobster. That combination is super ... very balanced taste !
Funny thing is , after 2 dish I don't feel super full , and they even offer small portion of desserts, how considerate! I had the donut with ice cream and fig sauce. Again very nice combination. The warm and crunch donut combined with the creamy cold ice cream! Nice !
This place reminds me of one of my favorite restaurant in California - Cyrus. The food combination is kind of similar and both offer excellent value vs quality
The only down side if I have to be picky is, their wine selection seems limited specially for glass wine.
So 1 glass of wine , 2 dishes and 1 dessert- total bill with tip is like $70. Good value!
There are over 5,000 reviews of Girl and the Goat.  Crazy!!  So not much to add.  We loved the experience start to finish!  The octopus we had was sensational.

When everyone who has visited the Chicago area before recommends this place, it is a must try! Made our reservation for a table of 4 months in advance *Note: Reservation for 4 made in mid-January for March 11th, 2017 (or that weekend) and only option available was for 11 PM* Given that this was the St Patrick's Day weekend event and Green River dyeing, we knew it was going to be packed.

Entering this restaurant, it was packed to what seemed like all the tables were filled. It's a dark, dimly lit place (given that food pictures don't have much brightness to it).

Now let's get to the food. We asked our server what we should do since we had a table for 4 in regards to ordering. She recommended 2 plates per person and then add on as needed. We ended up ordering 9 dishes total, and ALL 9 DISHES were just as good as others. Plates started coming out and a few at a time, which definitely paced our appetite.

We ordered the Roasted Beets, Chickpea Fritter, Hamachi Crudo, Duck Tartare, Crispy Beef Short Ribs, Duck Tongue, Wood Over Roasted Pig Face, Crisp Braised Pork Shank, and the Confit Goat Belly.

EVERYTHING.WAS.BOMB! My favorite out of all 9 would probably have to be the Pig Face. But no doubt, no matter what you order here, you will probably be satisfied. We ordered 9 dishes for the 4 of us to share and we were pretty stuffed by the time our last dish came out.

Atmosphere was great. Food was delicious. Servers were genuine. 5 Stars from me. Will definitely come back to this place when I get the chance to visit this city again.
Still one of my favorite places to bring friends from out of town. Their food is delish!

I had high expectations ... and this hit every mark. No reservations (it was a last minute trip) but for two, it was easy to find a spot at the bar (maybe we got lucky but we didn't even wait a minute --- just ask, "is the bar open seating? can we eat dinner at the bar?). Note if we didn't find a seat at the bar, it meant a 1 hour wait (we arrived ~6p). Overall the food is inventive, flavorful, and well executed. I would definitely return again. This is what we ordered:

Miso Hungry = If a croissant had a baby with a brioche and somehow formed itself like a cheesy popover, you could almost get to the Miso Hungry Bread. It was buttery, warm and delicious. I would buy this in a bakery if I could. The bread is served with a miso butter and kimchi relish.

Kohlrabi Salad = Sort of a less memorable, filler dish. My friend wanted salad so I said sure. It was well dressed and fresh but hardly something I'd order again. I will give credit though for the addition of blueberries which was a fun twist.

Goat Belly and Lobster = Imagine tender braised goat with the indulgent bit of fat like what you would get with pork belly. Then imagine it's sitting alongside poached lobster. This is like an odd spin on surf and turf but right in every other way. The sauce was rich and buttery with hints of vanilla. Delicious and unique.

Pork Shank = If you're here and you can only eat one dish. I'd get the pork shank. It's a meal in itself (you could probably do fine just ordering 2 other dishes along with this one). It's an enormous braised, tender, falling-apart pork shank served with all the fixings like house-made flat bread, sauces, and grilled vegetables. DIY sandwich, taco, pizza, or whatever you want to call it. At this point, I was already falling over from over-eating, but this was so delicious, I couldn't stop.

My friends and I took a trip to Chicago and heard raving reviews on this place (and we live in California), so we definitely had to try it out! We made a reservation about 1-2 months in advance for 10:15 PM on a Friday night.

The restaurant is located in a little strip of other upscale restaurants. The parking is really bad, so I recommend being dropped off. Immediately after entering, the lighting was very dim and it was extremely loud. The waiting area overflowed into the entire entrance, but we didn't wait long to be seated. We actually got there early and was seated earlier than our reservation time!

*Tip: The restrooms are located downstairs. When you walk in, the stairs will be behind the waiting area to the left. The stalls are separate rooms completely which was kind of cool.

Here's what we ate in no particular order:
-wood grilled broccoli
-goat empanadas
-baby grilled octopus
-calamari bruschetta
-confit goat belly
-wood oven roasted pig face
-all the leches cake

My favorites were the goat empanadas, pig face, and all the leches cake. All of the foods are really unique in the ingredients being used. For example, there were strawberries on top of the goat empanadas, but oddly it went well. I would say pig face is probably the most popular item. It was sweet and tasty. Ending with dessert, the all the leches cake was sweet enough, but not too sweet. It was delicious! My least favorite was the wood grilled broccoli. I love broccoli, but I could hardly taste it. The only thing I tasted was the smoke from the oven. If you're into that, then wood grilled broccoli is for you.

If you're in Chicago and want to dine in one of their many trendy restaurants, Girl & the Goat is a good option. It's very hipster. You'll understand once you read the menu. ;) Overall, it was a pleasant experience. However, I honestly can't justify the price. My friends and I shared everything, but the portions were pretty small, so I didn't really feel satisfied. I would have ordered more food, but not at those prices.

pics.caption: Wood oven roasted pig face - delicious!
Grilled baby octopus - my friends liked it

review.des:
This review is for their group event room "The Underground Goat." The food, service, and setting were all excellent.

Our event was a 15 person wedding dinner.  The lighting, music and decor created a room with much more character than your typical group event room. For our event, the tables were configured to create a large square table which we preferred to breaking the group in half.  The level can be accessed by stairs or elevator and there are restrooms conveniently close to the private room on the same level.

During both the planning stage and the dinner, the staff was exceptionally friendly and accommodating.  Our main server, Lee, especially stood out.  The food was served family style and each course was served in an organized and efficient manner such that we never had one part of the table wondering when their portion would arrive while another part of the table were already digging in.  I don't recall seeing anyone languishing with an empty drink or water glass either.  Everything was smooth and timely without feeling rushed.

The portions were larger than I expected. So much so that the food we set out at another location later in the evening went largely untouched.
And of course, this being Girl and The Goat, everything was delicious.

After years of attempting to get a reservation, I finally had the opportunity to visit while working in the area. The restaurant absolutely lives up to it's reputation! As a person with a mature palate and a willingness to experiment with food, I was right at home. I loved the way each dish infused flavors that you wouldn't dream of pairing together.

My colleagues were all very excited about the experience and I cannot wait to return to try more items on the menu.

Let me start out by saying This place is busy all the time. For a Monday at 815 I had to make reservations weeks in advance. But it's worth the planning. This is the place to go, if you want all the great food and all of the hype. We ordered 2 dishes per person, 4 total to share family style. This is what they recommend and I really agree with it. Pig face, escargot ravioli, green beans, and goat empanadas. They were all amazing. If you are a foodie in the Midwest looking for a place to fufill that craving, I suggest you go here.

We were visiting Chicago and figured dining at the Girl and the Goat would be a good idea. It was more than just a good idea, it was brilliant! Reservations were made 2 months in advance, and we had dinner at 5:15pm on a Wednesday. Make sure you make reservations way in advance or else you won't be eating!

For a group of four people, we ordered 9 items: roasted cauliflower, kohlrabi salad, broccoli, calamari bruschetta, beef short ribs, sugo, pork shank, pig face, and the all the leches cake. The server recommended we order 2 items per person. We definitely could have gotten away with ordering only 6-7 items though! My favorites were definitely the beef short ribs and the pork shank. Those are must haves at the Girl and the Goat. The short ribs were delicate and had a light flavor. The avocado and grapefruit went well with the meat. The meat of pork shank immediately fell off the bone, and it was amazing! It comes on a cutting board which is cool, but be careful so the meat doesn't fall off onto the table! In addition to that, the sugo was especially yummy and meaty. For the all the leches cake, you should eat bits of all the items together because it tastes better that way. Some of the other menu items were a heavier than I would have preferred. The cauliflower was really smokey, and the calamari was too salty for my taste. Overall though, the menu is unique and everything is flavorful.

The atmosphere of the restaurant is quite nice and warm. The lighting is on the dimmer side, which leads to an inviting and cozy ambience. The servers are knowledgable and friendly, and the food is served quickly once ordered. My water glass was never empty and neither was anyone else's at my table. This place makes for a great dinner that you can share with other people!

This is an Anthony Bourdain-blessed establishment, so it's ridiculously popular. I will say the dishes are pretty eclectic, ingredient - wise. Stuff you wouldn't think would go together well. Anyway, the service is great, but the pressure to turn tables is somewhat apparent as well.

It was very good, not great. We waited 15' for our table even though we had a reservation. Had cocktails while we waited - very good, also very expensive. Finally seated the service was good, but almost too much...felt like they were trying to turn the table from the moment we sat down. The food was good, but nothing amazing. Definitely very rich - too much salt, butter and oil tastes good at the table but feels awful an hour later. We might go back off hours.
Another must try when you come to Chicago! Love the atmosphere! love the food! service was amazing! Prices were reasonable, definitely recommend this to anyone visiting chicago!
Go! Go! Go! Go! Go! Go! Go! Go! Go! Go! Go! Go! The worst thing about Girl and Goat will probably be the people you came with. The food and drinks will be a win!

Another great experience at this establishment on a Tuesday night. We came here as part of our wedding celebration which we noted in the Open Table reservation. This time we went with the Miso Hungry Bread, Raw Oysters, Hamachi Crudo (repeat order), Calamari Bruschetta, Seared Diver Scallops, and Roasted Pig Face. The Roasted Pig Face was the highlight, a definite order if you enjoy anything braised pork belly like dishes. The oysters were nicely garnished and fresh as well. The scallops (2 scallops) were also nicely portioned and very enjoyable. The calamari comes in a sizable portion enough to share with 4 people. The calamari was cooked so well and easy to cut through. At the end of the dinner, the staff was kind enough to complement us the Caramel Corn and Malt Balls, an awesomely delicious dessert. From the waitress, busers, and food runners, the service was phenomenal. There are definitely more items I'd like to try next time around.

- Order with a smile

My sister made reservations for my birthday at Girl and the Goat when I went to visit her in Chicago. I'm a huge fan of Top Chef and to have been able to go to Chef Izard's restaurant, it was just the perfect birthday dinner. It wasn't until we got there, did we realize it was served tapas style, small portions of each order. We took advantage of that and ordered practically one dish off each section of the menu.

1. We started with the Herbs of Feta. Fresh bread with hummus and feta oil dip, what a great combination! You can taste the herbs on the bread, and the crunch on the crust of the bread was delicious. I couldn't get enough of the hummus, almost spooned it all onto my plate.

2. Now, I'm not a huge fan of oysters, especially raw but why not just try it in a different way? Fried, you say? Yum, yum! Fried Naked Cowboys was recommended by our waiter and wow! He wasn't wrong. A spoonful of bite sized oysters with egg salad on top, it was just marvelous. Who doesn't liked fried stuff? I would definitely want this again.

3. Favorite dish of the night, Chickpea Fritter! Love the crispy outer layer and then when you bite into it, you get a soft filling of chickpea in the inside. Love the bite with all the other garnishes and vegetables in this dish. Beyond amazing.

4. So other seafood options were pretty typical choices, so we decided to try something new, Pan Roasted Monkfish. It had a great sear to it. Wasn't my favorite, but nonetheless, still really good.

5. Seem like the Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face was a favorite by many reviewers, so it was a must try. As soon as it came out, you could smell the meat. It was topped off with a sunny side egg. There was a mix of fatty parts and tender meat. Make sure to break the yolk on top of the meat so it spreads around the meat, definitely was a good way to eat it!

6. At this point, my sister and I already had a loadful, but that didn't stop us from finishing the rest of our order, which was the Confit Goat Belly. The goat was oh so savory, but it was the lobster and crab with the bourbon butter that made the dish. The perfect representation of a surf and turf.

All the flavors in my mouth was craving for something light and sweet by the end of it, so we ended with a fruity dessert.

7. The Citrus Pavlova, yum yum! Ice cream served with a mix of blood orange, yuzu curd, kumquats, and a vanilla meringue. I couldn't get enough of this. It was absolutely scrumptious. The delightful taste of ice cream paired with fruits. My type of dessert!

8. Now, because it was my birthday, I received a sampler of the Miso-Butterscotch Budino. What a gift! The taste of bacon toffee with glazed pineapple?! The combination of sweet and salty. My favorite topping of it all, was the candied cashews. Perfect end to a perfect birthday dinner!

Now, it's no surprise that the food was great, but the service was just as wonderful! I'm not a huge fan of crowded restaurants, but I didn't mind it here. We were cared for very well. Waiters had great timing in switching out our plates, bringing water to the table, giving recommendations, and making sure we were enjoying our meal. To keep this in memory, my sister and I bought their T-shirts. "When goats Fly"

Definitely have to go back to Chicago to make a stop here again, an unforgettable dinner experience!

Our 1045pm dinner had to be the best 24hr layover dinner in the history of layovers  The staff blessed us with 2 of the only 4 counter seats, and we had a culinary blast.

Eating out is definitely about the whole experience beyond the food these days. The Girl&The Goat delivers on all fronts.

Highlights: 1. Counter seating, 2. Kick ass staff, 3. HipHop in the background, 4. Unfussy, well executed food.

You could not ask for anything else on a night out in Chi-Town. A+ experience all around. Get those coveted counter seats!!

pics.caption: Watching the staff was fun during dinner.
Pastry chef even had time to take our pics! A+ multitasking.

review.des:
Not sure if I'm allowed to write a semi-negative review based on all the hype this place gets, but here goes nothing...

Went here to celebrate me and boyfriend's anniversary. We ordered the grilled baby octopus, pig face, roasted cauliflower, and the olive you bread. And I was shocked by the mediocrity of the food.

To be fair, we enjoyed the octopus and the bread. Pretty solid starts. But we tried the pig face after everyone in the world sung its praise, and I really didn't like it. At all. The pork is super fatty and bland. The drinks were average. The whole experience was disappointing considering we had to get reservations weeks in advance. There are a TON of great food spots in West Loop, but I will not be going back to Girl and the Goat.

Came here for a late dinner after the Fire game.

Service-superb. From the minute I walked in to just before taking my last step out, I felt welcomed with open arms. We had a 10:30 reservation and were late due to horrible traffic yet they didn't give us any problems regarding the timing of showing up, furthermore they didn't rush us into leaving and allowed us to relax and enjoy our meal.

Halibut-to die for! This dish is so well balanced and finger licking good! I could it eat all day long!

Octopus-our table was of 3 girls who all love octopus and we all enjoyed the dish.

The bread was great too with the feta whipped. "olive you"

Wood Grilled Broccoli-not a fan. It was too smokey for my taste and no one else at the table enjoyed this dish either.

Roasted Cauliflower-very good and I'd do this over the broccoli any day of the week.

Soft Shell Crab- a good dish but I could live without it.

Pigs Face-ok, let me start by saying I am a very pick eater, don't enjoy fatty foods, but OMG so good! It is a very interesting dish and I highly recommend this dish. My friend who eats very clean meals only cleared the plate and wants more. I never though I'd eat or enjoy that type of dish, but yes! I will have it again when in town.

We were too stuffed for desert however our waitress insisted we try something since we were from out of town. DELIC!! Honestly the BEST desert I've ever had!!
Caramel Corn and Malt Balls!!!!
I wish I could have this everyday for the rest of my life.

If you're visiting Chicago this place has to be on your list of places to eat. The food! Words can't describe how good the cuisine was. From the appetizers to the main course, I just couldn't get enough. We had a party of 9 which we had to wait to be seated until everyone arrived but during that wait, the staff was very accommodating. Definitely coming back here.

This place is worth all the hype. The Greenbeans and Peppers are so good you could eat 3 orders yourself. The wine list is great and not too expensive. Every meat dish and we basically ordered them all were cocked perfect!

Not only did it live up to the hype --- it put the hype in a cannon and blew it away.

Cocktails - My Little Kumquat and Ring of Fire. Wish I had been the one that ordered the RoF as it was excellent. Kumquat was good too, but very floral from the lavender and honey. Acted as a nice palate cleanser. Both were perfectly balanced between booze and taste.

Food

Olive You bread - Whipped feta will be the end of me. Splendid. The olive oil was great as well, but c'mon, whipped feta! The bread was nice and a perfect vessel for the whipped feta (now I am starting to sound crazy)

Sweet potato bleu cheese pierogies - Perfectly toasted and very good. Just the right amount of bleu cheese on top to add a little bit of punch but not overpower anything.

Chickpea fritters - Falafel-ish, if the inside was smooth/pureed and not gritty like your typical falafel. I loved it.

Calamari bruschetta - The best calamari I've ever had and it wasn't even fried! The goat bacon is a perfect salty complement (and lets me say I tried goat).

Grilled shrimp - Probably my least favorite of what we ordered, but only because everything else was so amazing! Great shrimp, just a little more plain/less flair compared to the other things.

No dessert for us. All in all, definitely a place worth your time! Just be wary of how long it takes to get a reservation (three weeks out for me to get a weeknight at 9:30pm)

Service: 5
Food: 4.5

First off, we totally arrived an hour before our reservation because my watch was still set to PST. I realized this as we were sitting in a taxi from Michigan Ave. But we figured since we were there, we might as well see if we could be seated. The restaurant was already bustling and it was just before 6pm. I told the hostess what happened she managed to find a booth table tucked in the corned for the two of us - yay! (cause that would have been awkward if we had gotten turned away)

The food is tapas style and our server recommend ~4 dishes for every two people. Of the dishes we ordered, by far the best ones were the chickpea fritters and miso-butterscotch budino (dessert). The cocktails were also really well made and worked well with the food. The other dishes, which I honestly can't remember much, were solid, but nothing too special - it's possible we didn't order the best dishes though.

Chickpea fritters were stir fried with a few other veggies and looked a lot like cubes of fried tofu. The outsides were perfectly crisp and the insides had a smooth texture similar to mashed potatoes. It's really important to get an even mix of all the ingredients in each bit. I really liked the touch of bean sprouts and the full chickpeas. Overall, the flavors and textures in the dishes were well thought out and paired.

My favorite was dessert. The budino was similar to a bread pudding with many more textures. In each bite you had spongy cake, glazed pineapple, creamy pudding, crunchy toffee pieces and finally some fresh cream. Uh... how does that not seem amazing?! I didn't really notice the miso taste anywhere, but the dish was fabulous.

While we didn't have anything to complain about with our food, our server did offer complimentary dishes to the tables next to us. In one case, the couple found a hair in a dish. The woman thought it was hers, but the waiter still said he wouldn't charge for it. In the second case, when the waiter came to check on them, a table of three mentioned that they really didn't enjoy the roasted beets. At that point, he just apologized and said he would comp it. Now I wouldn't suggest using these as ways to get free food, but it's a great sign that they really care for their customer's experiences.

While in town for a long weekend visit in June, we reserved a Thursday table at 9:00. We arrived a bit early, so took a seat at the bar to order a drink. (They also offer food at the bar, so people were able to walk right in and eat at the bar.) At our scheduled time, they came to the bar to take us to our seats. From start to finish, our experience was outstanding. Our server was friendly, professional and informative, as was the sommelier, who she went to get when she had trouble opening our bottle of wine. He also was friendly, complimentary on my boyfriend's wine choice, and professional.

The hardest part was deciding what to get, as so many items sounded delicious. We tried the roasted beets and the chickpea fritters, then the pan-roasted halibut and yellowfin tuna, all of which were very good. My boyfriend also had the escargot ravioli, which he really enjoyed. Though we normally don't eat meat, we decided to try the goat empanadas (the restaurant is called Girl & the Goat after all!). They were good, although he enjoyed them more. We also ordered the "what's the dill yo?" bread, which was fantastic. We debated about dessert - the blueberry bourbon baba sounded incredible - but we just didn't have the room unfortunately.

We both immediately said that we'd like to go back, both to try more dishes and eat the ones we really enjoyed again. I can't recommend it enough; it really is worth the hype!

We ordered a lot of food for two people. The portions aren't large so it was feasible. The different flavor plates were awesome. Staff was also very considerate and nice. There was only one goat shank left and the waiter hurried to hold it for us. Overall, we loved our experience. Would totally come back.

Yes! We got a table during our Staycation and our experience lived up to most of the hype.
