I will say that the menu is different and may require some courage, but the flavors are awesome!  Good energy in the room for a Monday night and our server was so helpful, friendly, and just plain enthusiastic.  The pacing of our courses was perfect.  The hummus bread, chickpea fritters, cauliflower, and shrimp were really good.  The Brussel sprouts with pork shank were great together!  The char finish on the shank was perfect with the cut naan/ flatbread and buffalo/kimchee sauce.  The only letdown for us was the Pigface-- salty, greasy, and a disappointing way to end our meal.  Overall, a gem.

Amazing, and well worth the wait. Girl & The Goat lives up to its reputation. Prompt, courteous and well-trained wait staff. Curated menu with seasonal goodies that each bite is interesting, well-seasoned and perfect temperature.

We went on a Friday night and had a 10:00pm reservation. We were greeted promptly, several staffers checked in on us in the very brief 2-3 minute wait, and we were taken to our table.

The ambiance is lovely - warm, dim lighting. Rustic wood tables. Interesting art work.

Our server was warm, approachable and knowledgeable. Her timing was great, too. She guided us through the menu, made wonderful recommendations. We ended up picking out 6-7 plates and asked her to "surprise" us and pick out 2-3 more.

Each plate was incredible. Wonderful flavors, well-timed, gorgeous to look at too. The servers brought out whatever appropriate flatware pertained to each course and removed any barely dirty plates - in a way too that was approachable and friendly.

And - the restaurant remembered when I made the reservation that I mentioned we were getting together with friends we hadn't seen for years. Nice touch, sincerely, mentioning that to our table.

Would be delighted to dine here again!

Worth the wait and even if the only timeslot we could get was the early bird time of 4:30. Share plate style dining, 2 per person is suggested. Craft cocktails were great. Wait staff very knowledgeable and friendly, not pretentious as all. Iron Chef quality dining!! A must try if you can get a timeslot reserved.

Girl and goat!  Stephanie Izard's joint is always busy. It's hard to get a table but you are free to sit and eat at bar or the couch like tables in front.

Anyway it's really good. Not much of a review but we enjoyed everything we ate. Especially the pork shank. Think smaller plates so we shared 4 or 5 plates.

Service is great not rushed at all and I would even ask for their favorites. I highly recommend it.

Girl & the Goat lives up to its hype, great food and service. Our only complaint was the noise level and super dim lighting making it difficult to see/take photos (which is why I gave them 4 stars). The flavors was infused from all around the globe, from Jamaican, Russian, Spanish, Mediterranean, Sichuan, to New American.  My favorites were the veggie dishes, amazing flavors. The fried chickpeas was absolutely phenomenal! The roasted cauliflower left me wanting more. The desserts was mind blowing, especially the caramel corn and malt balls. My least favorite dish was the grilled chicken and squash ratatouille, nothing to write home about. Chef and owner Stephanie Izard is a talented chef and it shows in her cooking. I'm blown away by all the different flavor profile, it was unlike anything I've experienced in California. I look forward to trying her other two restaurants the next time we're in Chicago, Little Goat and Duck Duck Goat.

Went here in a hurry before catching a flight.  Waiter was excellent and understanding of our rush so he brought food out fast as possible and settled our bill fast.  We also went early so didn't have a wait which was nice.  Food was so so.  Focaccia bread was great.  Grilled octopus was great but the soft succulent octopus didn't go well with dry crunchy pistachios.  Scallops also very succulent and fresh but came in a sweet sauce which took away from the deliciousness of fresh and perfectly cooked scallops.  I won't critique any more because a lot of my discontent comes from my personal preference for sweet and salty not too mixed together.  It is a very unique place though and I've never had flavors mixed together quite like this place.  It's a must experience once and then decide for yourself kind of place.

One of the best meals of my life! I am by no means a good expert so it is hard to intelligently articulate what was happening. All I can say is that the diverse textures and flavors were incredible. I was traveling for work so I dined alone. My server was awesome and identified the plates that she could make "smaller" so that I might have an opportunity to try more dishes. After having done some research I was fairly set on my menu. I started with the duck empanadas, then had the scallops, followed by the escargot ravioli snd then finally the pig face. The flavors were so diverse and every component of each plate played a synergistic role, I couldn't possibly pick a favorite. I finished with the a cup of black coffee and the carmel popcorn ice cream. I travel to Chicago every couple of years. I have never eaten at the same place twice.  I will be returning here.

Interesting place, fully packed.. Reserve in advance because it's not easy to get in.  

The food is good, but not as good as what I was expecting.. I went with a group, and we tried pretty much everything.. the goat empanadas were delicious!

This is a great place to share great food.  The schtick: Imaginative takes on rustic ingredients portioned for sharing and sampling.

The loft-like space is a decorated in a contemporary farmhouse style.  Tables are set closely and the noise level is high.  A long exhibition kitchen occupies one end of the restaurant.  There's a nice looking bar and a bustling vibe.

Our waiter was very helpful and suggested that we order 6-8 items for our party of 4.  After ordering the food is coursed for us by the kitchen.  Pretty simple.

Here's what we ate:
Ratatouille focaccia - A nice start to the meal, helped to temper the effect of my cocktail on an empty stomach.
Tempura soft shelled crab with sweet corn elotes - Yes!
Sweet corn potato pierogis - tasty dumplings are always welcome!
Duck tongues with tuna and black bean poke, crispy wontons and piri piri - so good.  Who knew that this "trash" part of the duck could taste so good?  I'm speechless!
Pan-fried shishito peppers with parmesan, sesame and miso - russian roulette on a plate.
Confit goat belly with bourbon butter, lobster, crab and fennel - this was the star of the night in my opinion, unctuous and slightly gamy belly meat with all those other goodies, wow!
Crisp braised pork shank - braised and then deep fried, this generous piece of porky goodness was decadent and perfect with the kimchi and naan bread.
Fried oysters with egg salad and capers - still hungry, we couldn't resist an order of these tasty little guys.

We had a couple of desserts too - some donuts and a popcorn chocolate thing that were honestly just ok.

All hype aside, this is tasty food!

I love this place, and although I still think it's ridiculous that a restaurant be booked with months or weeks in advance, I still recommend try to get here either by booking in advance or by walking in right when they open for a very early dinner.

There are some great veggie options - I am a big fan of their green beans and their roasted beets. Their scallops are fantastic and so is the baby octopus.

Love that you can get many dishes and share - portions are small so it's better to get multiple and try them all.

pics.caption: Roasted beets salad with avocado creme fraiche
Grilled shrimp - slightly spicy but delicious

review.des:
With a name like pig face...it has to be good. Stephanie Izard is my hero. She beat Blais (who I adore) as the first female Top Chef. She used that cash to help open the lovely Girl and the Goat. I've had the pleasure of visiting 3 times during work trips to Chicago, and can't get enough. The vibe is always hopping! The music is always spot on...think the best of Sirius XM Lithium...the 90's...my beloved high school jams. I've eating there at 7pm on a Monday and it's packed. I've eaten there at 11pm on a Tuesday, and yep, the place is still packed. It's beyond impressive, yet great food, great ambience and a great chef will do that.

I've tried about everything on the menu thanks to great colleagues with a shared love for lots of shared plates. I describe everything at G&G as rich. Very rich. Even the beans and broccoli are packed with flavor. I love their shishito pepper preparation more than most places. Other stand outs for me are the hamachi crudo, the infamous pig face, short ribs, and sauteed green beans. Not to take away from many, many great items..but some that rank on top for me.

Thanks Stephanie, for bringing such cool, non-pretentious awesomeness to the city.

The Girl & the Goat is known to out of towners due to the number of reviews on Yelp! but be rest assured it does not disappointment. You have to make reservations way in advance to even get a table at the time you want, it's that popular! The food is very, very flavourful. There aren't too many vegetarian options but plenty enough to choose from and allow the tastebuds to feel alive. By far the shiitake gelato with chocolate cake is my all time favourite dessert! It sounds a bit weird to most people but it is definitely worth a try since it sets the bar for what  the ice cream and chocolate cake (usually brownie) combo should taste like!
The food is over the top... sharing plates every plate we had last night was spectacular..make sure to make reservations otherwise you will not get in

Where do I even begin to talk about Girl & The Goat?! From the moment we stepped inside I was blown away. Friendly hosts, prompt seating and a very attentive server. We sat at the chef's table and got the insider scoop on the line. I am always in awe of food prep and knife skills! The server was very attentive to my strange allergies and the line was so accommodating. I hate asking for anyone to change a dish, I understand they are made a certain way for the best bite but I didn't want to miss out on some of these dishes (allium allergy). The halibut with almond butter was probably the best thing I've ever consumed. I even tried (gasp!) duck tongue! Let me tell you, it was delicious! I knew I would be impressed walking in those doors but I was beyond blown away! Can't wait to make it back here!

We came here with a gift card which was a wedding gift and had a great night.  Made reservations months ahead of time which we didn't care we knew either way we'd end up going.  Our favorite dishes were the pork shank and sea bass.  We left with stomach aches as everything was so rich but it was worth it.  This place delivers on flavor and execution.

Food:  4.5 stars
Service: 3.5 stars

Girl & the Goat has been the one ubiquitously recommended restaurant among people I know in Chicago.

I made a pretty last minute (which in G&G terms is 2 weeks in advance) reservation for 2 at 8:45 on a Tuesday night.

The place was packed from the time we arrived to the time we left (around 10:00 PM), and, like other reviewers said, it's very loud. There was not a seat to be found throughout the entire place. We were seated at a counter in front of the cooks and expo folks. My boyfriend really enjoyed this. I did not like it (I was hesitant openly and orgasmically shove food into my face in front of several complete strangers), but the cooks and expo people were very friendly and informative. At times, they were a little too chatty. It almost felt like we were part of the kitchen, rather than guests. I would not want to sit at that spot again, but I recognize that some people would really enjoy it.

It took forever for our waiter to arrive, and he greeted a large party, which sat after us, before he greeted us. I am aware that it is a hoppin' place, but he did not drop by and say "Hello," for a solid 20 minutes. The rest of the night kind of proceeded like that. The line staff seemed to go out of the way to be friendly, but at times it bordered on intrusive rather than welcoming (our waiter, who disappeared for long bouts of time, literally popped up behind us and came between us to stir our food up; I know he assisting us, but it was a little weird). So the service was not great, but the food....THE FOOD (which, really, that's what we were there for):

We ordered the Pig Face, Grilled Ramp Marinated Shrimp, Goat Empanadas,  raw oysters, and Miso Butter-Scotch Budino. We also ordered the La Paloma and the rum/chili drinks, which were excellent. Almost all of the food had a fairly vinegar-y taste, which I like. The dishes were all savory and had a little salty/vinegar-y kick to them.

Two favorites I want to highlight:
- The Pig Face (don't worry; there isn't anything gross or weird looking hiding under that egg; just crispy pork deliciousness). This was the dish our waiter stirred and cut up for us (again weird...but he was trying to mix up the sauce, meat, and egg). All my favorite breakfast flavors together: savory pork, egg, and sweet maple. Yum.

-The Miso Butter-Scotch Budino was incredible! I had no idea what we ordered, but trust in G&G. This was a dense butterscotch pudding/flan bed covered with bits of toffee, pineapple, sponge cake, and whip cream. I would go back to get this alone. I bet it would be wonderful with coffee.

I would definitely recommend G&G. If I make it back, I hope to sit in a different spot, and I will update if the service experience is a little better than.

Such an amazing experience from start to finish!  We weren't able to get a reservation but friends tipped us off that you can walk in right when they open and they will seat you if you promise to be done before their reservation comes in.  So accommodating and they were really nice about it too.  Our server explained everything perfectly and hit that perfect balance between being attentive and letting us be.  In my opinion, the service is top notch when you never really notice them being there, but your drink is never empty and your table is cleaned off between dishes.

As for the food -- INCREDIBLE!  We started with the bread/miso butter/kimchi relish and it was easily the best bread & butter experience I've ever had in a restaurant.  Went on to get blown away by the goat empanadas (who would've though goat, avocado, strawberries and cheese would all go together so well?), smoky broccoli and the grilled chicken which was delightfully umami-flavored.  We weren't disappointed by a single thing we ordered.  I'd love to go back if we're ever in Chicago again!

I was extremely excited to try this place, since it's lauded as a destination spot in Chicago along with the likes of Cloudgate and Willis tower. Maybe my expectations were too high going in, but overall the food was ohhhhh-kayyyy and everything leaned on the overly salted side.

I started with the goat carpaccio and was very underwhelmed. I like goat. I love carpaccio. But something about this dish turned my taste buds sour...and bitter? I'd prefer it dressed a more traditional way (shaved parmesan, balsamic, and arugula to freshen it up). I understand this place is ~avant grade dining but this wasn't executed well and the flavors weren't balanced in such a delicate dish.

I also had the octopus with brussels sprouts, which was surprisingly my least favorite dish of the night...So. Salty. I could only have a few bites because it was like they felt sympathy for the poor octopus being ripped from his oceanic home and decided to make his resting place equally as salty as the sea. Or tried to drown him in sea salt to make him feel at home in my bowl. Poor thing.

The Pig face was undeniably fat, melted in my mouth and was so delicious! But again, a bit too salty. The flavors in the pork were amazing but the dressings (crispy potato hash) made an already fatty dish even heavier and I wish there was one element to lighten/freshen it up.

Service was good, and the ambiance was lovely. But if I'm ever back in Chicago, I'd pass.

Quick tip: If you don't have a large party (1-3 people) don't bother making reservations. I walked in maybe within an hour of opening for dinner and there were plenty of seats at the bar and in the couch/lounge area.

Secured a next-day reservation at 11:45pm. Totally solid time for dinner, which explains my bad appetite throughout the entire meal.
My friend (a girl) and I got 4 dishes of meat and a dessert. We were just dying afterwards.

~Ambiance~
Reminded me of Bestia in LA. Wooden deco. Modern with a touch of industrial. Dark. Loud.

~Service~
Friendly and helpful. Gives really good suggestion for what's on the menu.

~Food~
1. Calamari Bruschetta (5/5)
Clam baguette. Goat milk ricotta. Goat bacon. Green tomato
God this is one of the best cooked calamari dish i've ever eaten. Juicy and chewy. Even though it keeps falling off from the bread but the creativity that goes into this dish is just so awesome.

2. Crispy Beef Short Ribs (4.5/5)
Avocado. Ruby red grapefruit chermoula
Solid short ribs. Easily pulled apart. Enjoyed the avocado which reminds me of home. The radish and sourness of this dish perfectly balanced the heaviness from the short ribs.

3. Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face (4/5)
Sunny side egg. Tamarind. Cilantro. Red wine-maple. Potato six
The meat was crispy and dotted with pieces of fat. I really like the flavor of the pig face and how they tried to lighten it with the egg. This dish is like a hidden treasure, you'll have to unmask the egg to see what's underneath. Interesting plating. The combination of green and brown sauce made me lose my appetite for this dish. Really enjoyed the potato stix that came with it.

4. Goat Neck (4.5/5) *seasonal*
This is a very very heavy meat dish. It's easily pulled part, but because it came at the end, it's just too much for me to finish and rage about it (after 3 meat dishes lol). Good first impression but couldn't finish coz i've had too much. Reminded me of lamb shank.

5. A blood orange surprise (3/5)
I didn't like the citrus cake that covered the surprise (blood orange sorbet) in side of it. It's not moist enough for my taste. The entire dessert leans toward sour, which is not my favorite flavor but it sort of lightens me up after all that meat i've eaten. Beautiful plating though.

---------------------------------------
I came here again with another friend. Here are some of the other dishes we ordered:

Roasted cauliflower (5/5):
I don't even like cauliflower, ok? But this is so good. The cauliflower is buttery. Topped with pine nuts and mint, it gives the dish an earthy feeling with hints of pleasure and spikes.

Grilled shrimp (4.5/5):
I'm somewhat allergic to the shell of shrimp. My friend who doesn't even like shrimp LOVED this dish. We both did. It's topped with lots of veggies and kumquats. Very flavorful. The shrimp was fresh and crisp.

Dark matter pot de creme (5/5):
I didn't like the dessert last time.
I loved this one.
It's mysterious but also beautiful.
Topped with ginger caramel and sesame (one of my favorite flavor) foam, you have to scoop to the bottom of the cup and uncover the treasure. The combination of sesame, coffee, and ginger caramel was so heavenly. This is a chilled dessert and definitely lightens the entire meal with additional flavor combinations.
Stephanie Izard is insanely talented! It's worth the wait to get a table.

If you've heard of G&tG before then there's nothing new I can tell you about the food. (If you haven't heard: it's fabulous.)

What I can tell you that you might not have heard before is the secret to (usually) getting in: go on a night that a major event is scheduled at the United Center, about 30 minutes before it starts. A lot of event-goers will start their night here, so the place empties out, ever so slightly. The staff will squeeze you in if they are able.

This place definitely deserves its 5 stars in my review! It lived up to my expectations and surpassed it as well. Before I start, just make sure you make reservations to come and dine here otherwise you will be waiting a very long time and might not get a chance to dine until much later in the night.
Service is great the moment you walk in, hostess greets you and makes you feel at home. The waiting area is a big size, they are used to having people wait around for a table, so even that part of the experience is good.
We had made reservations ahead of time through open table and only waited a couple of minutes for our table to be ready. The menu is very diverse, a lot of new takes on your favorite dishes. Things come in a shareable size with the exception of the crudo.
The cauliflower is one of the best things I've ever tasted! WOW just WOW! Soft and crunchy, juicy, you name it... a foodies heaven.
Another favorite was the pork shank. Literally comes off the bone and melts in your mouth! Enough to feed two. The desserts are also great! Pineapple upside down... hands down need to try this when you come in and the chocolate dessert the have is another must try!
Come with an empty stomach and be sure to order as much from the menu as you can because it's all delicious and worth trying!

Being newbie in Chicago eating scene I decided of course put my faith in what I could find online when it came to must try places. Girl and the Goat came up as a must try place recommended by locals as well as good ol Yelp. I had a hard time getting to the place, and for a Wednesday night, the only reservation I could get in was at 1030pm. A scant half hour before closing. I couldn't wait for it to be my sole dinner since it was late so it was actually more of late night snack. I had come very close to abandoning such a luxurious practice as eating 4 meals a day. Also it was  quite far from my hotel, but in the end, Girl and the Goat did not disappoint and it became one of my favorite experiences in Chicago, food or otherwise!

First things first, the staff was very informative, helpful and cheery, I really did feel welcome as my waitress answered my inquiries of what her favorites were as well as on a side note, what else Chicago had to offer. The atmosphere is your typical retro wire coil bulb yellow light wood and iron stylish throwback. Bustling with customers it's a lively place with lots going on. Fine for a date, but be prepared to speak up.

Finally, the food! It should come as no surprise but a place like this is supposed to be a venue for food to be bold, creative and experimental. Small, artful dishes meant to be shared is the motif so savor those bites in between the conversation or just close your eyes and enhance those taste buds like I did. Some dishes can be made as  half portion as my waitress so kindly marked on the menu for me. Still, even the half dishes may be enough to get a taste if you're with someone so you can try more variety. Ask!

Onto the specific dishes I ordered: Escargot dumplings, Wood fired Eagle Rock Oysters, Goat Belly Confit, and finally a dessert (I know, quite the anomaly for yours truly) of the dark matter pot de creme.  The oysters and dumplings came first. The oysters were wood fired, so in between the fried and raw options but nicely done. Served with horseradish, bacon and preserved lemon. Pretty good, though the horseradish could've had just a little more kick, the bacon was perfectly diced to flavor as well as add to the texture of the dish. Escargot dumplings were served with a bacon tamarind sauce with celery, escarole and crispy onions. Dumpling was properly cooked and the sauce was inventive, if a little on the salty side. I found it best when soaked into the crispy onions and greens and applied to a bite of the dumpling. If it had just stopped at these two dishes I think this place wouldn't have quite gotten a 5 rating from me. Quite good and interesting but it was the next dish that really pushed it into the 5 rating range.

I cannot say enough good things about the Goat belly confit. I knew it was going to be an over the top rich dish...bourbon butter? Crab AND lobster? With the fennel covering it it didn't look that heavy but make no mistake, this one will coat your taste buds. Of course, in a wonderfully decadent way...My first bite included a little bit of everything and what I noticed first was the fragrance of the bourbon butter. Food entices all the senses... some more than others but smell is usually a precursor, a tease before taste and texture. This time it unexpectedly stowed away with those two but it turned out to be a welcome guest! I instinctively closed my eyes to enjoy it. If i had been in a conversation with a date, I would have asked for some silence to appreciate it!

After that piece de la resistance I decided that since I was here I might as well try dessert. The dark matter pot de creme looked like your typical pot de creme but I just can't resist things with sesame. It also had some ginger which if used subtly and is just divine. It was on the same level as the first two dishes very good....if not just needed a little refinement for my taste. The sesame brittle pieces could've been slightly smaller and the ginger could've been toned down just a little.

In the end, one of my most memorable eating experiences. It gets the coveted 5 stars not only based on the food which is strong for sure, but on inventiveness and great service. I'm coming back next time I'm in Chicago for sure. There's lots more to try!

Escargot Dumplings with Bacon Tamarind Sauce
Goat Belly Confit with Crab, Lobster and Bourbon Butter

review.des:
This was the best meal I ate during my 5 day stay in Chicago! All of my friends from California highly recommended this place out and said the food was just to die for. Luckily we were able to get reservations for a table of 7 and our whole party really enjoyed every bit of our meal.

For 7 people we ordered 9 dishes and it was definitely enough to share. There was so much variety on the menu, and I just wanted to try them all! My absolute favorite was the Goat Neck ($36), Pork Belly, Pig Face, Short Ribs, & the Green Beans.

I really recommend ordering a goat dish while visiting this restaurant, since it is their speciality. They purchase their goat from a local farm and everything is just really fresh and tender! The meat falls off the bone so easily and every bite is delightful! All in all, everything we ordered was delicious and really worth trying! All the dishes had a unique twist to it that might sound odd at first, but somehow it just goes together magically.

I really recommend visiting this place if you're ever in the Chicago area. I really enjoyed the ambiance of this place and it definitely has a romantic setting. Great place to bond and enjoy some great food with it! I will definitely come back when I visit Chicago again. Hopefully soon!

pics.caption: Pork face in front and pork belly in the back

review.des:
I've wanted to come here for-ev-errrr and finally got the opportunity to yesterday.  We got a helpful hint from a friend that I shouldn't share here...shhhh... but if you go right at 4:30 when they open, you can easily grab a spot at the bar. No waiting, no reso's needed.  So we did that.

We were then treated to the best service by the bartenders.  Super knowledgeable and genuinely interested in giving us a great time.  On their recommendation, we ordered the green beans, chickpea fritters, green garlic potato pierogies, and grilled pork belly (for the bf, i don't eat meat... i made an exception with the fish sauce on the green beans otherwise I'm strict veghead).  Everything we had was exceptional.  How Stephanie Izzard (owner and chef) put the combination of flavors together baffles me.  A chickpea fritter with yogurt and strawberries?!  Smoked tomato rhubarb chimi sauce?  What is happening!?  Don't think, just eat.  Get here yesterday.

The Girl & the Goat is hands down, one of the top 3 restaurants I have EVER been to. This is Top Chef Stephanie Izard's restaurant & it didn't disappoint. I was able to get a reservation after trying for 3 days when I was in Chicago. EVERYTHING we ordered was fresh, flavorful, unique & the presentation was beautiful! The drinks were also phenomenal. We ordered the broccoli w/blue cheese (my absolute fav), goat empanadas (I don't eat meat but it looked delicious), grilled shrimp & the grilled octopus plate. The dessert was a tres leches. The service was top notch. The ambience was dark & rustic. They are BUSY! And for a good reason. Good, well-prepared food w/awesome drinks & even better service. This will be the restaurant I will first reserve when I come to Chicago. Absolutely loved, 5 stars!

Damn, this was so good. I had to lurk near the bar for a while to get a seat at the bar but wow every dish was delicious! Had the cauliflower, broccoli, the scallop, and the calamari. Too many other items I need to go back and have now.... Might go again tonight.

Again visited of my favorite eateries on the planet last evening to celebrate my birthday!! And of course G and G did not let me down!
Huge shout out to Hannah at the bar for being absolutely awesome!
Had the Raw Oysters, Crab and my all time favorite scallops!!
*kinda wish the scallops had less 'stuff' surrounding them... At one time it was just the deliciousness of the scallops.
I even tried my neighbors pirogies which were good as well.
As often stated, this place is a MUST dine in ChiTown.

pics.caption: Hannah at the Bar is an absolute RockStar!
And dessert! Wish maybe they accompanying greenery was decreased a bit... But still out of this world

review.des: This is one of the best trendy restaurants in the west loop. Always stays busy 7 days a week. Juan the bartender is awesome.
The food and service was excellent! Our waitress was very sweet and knowledgeable about the area. The gluten free menu made ordering very easy. We definitely will be back.

So, great reviews plus great pictures, should mean great experience right? Yes and no.  The staff and service were GREAT, very professional. First dish was an empanada  (BEST THING ALL YEAR). Super excited for the next dish.  Then I get the chickpea dish, very very good. Then comes the dish that made me sad, the calamari. The calamari, or should I say rubber. :(

OK, please please for the love of God let the main dish be more like the first and not the....rubber.  The pork shank came and we were, slightly satisfied. We've had pork shanks before and we were expecting this one to be wayyyy better. It was crunchy and stuff, but the flavor was not enough for me to be completely satisfied. I'm hoping this was a bad day, we'll return(mostly because that first dish) and hopefully have a better experience

Had dinner here last night with some friends - enjoyed every bite! The dishes are meant to be shared, so plan on ordering about two dishes per person in your party. It's a local and seasonal menu, so the offerings change frequently. Great service and very cool atmosphere - very much a West Loop vibe!
Been wanting to eat here and finally made it. Came with a group and shared plates. Everything was fabulous, staff was on point, great evening!

After menu-stalking Girl & the Goat for literally years, I was finally lucky enough to dine here thanks to my amazing boyfriend. We had a reservation for 8:30 on a Friday, which was made a month in advance. We waited between the bar and hostess stand for about fifteen minutes for our table to open up. It was very busy, so we felt a little bit awkward and in the way as servers walked by with trays of food. The hostess who seated us identified us and said, "Hi, David, your table is ready," which was a nice touch. We came hungry and were ready to begin our meal!

We waited for maybe ~five more minutes before our water glasses were filled and our server arrived. Our server recommended we order 2-3 dishes each. We decided to forego drinks in lieu of ordering more food (we love to eat!). We ordered six dishes at once and then the kitchen decided which courses should be brought out in what order/combination.

Roasted cauliflower. I've had this veggie menu item in the back of my head for years after reading a delicious description by Candice G., our former Yelp Chicago 'burbs CM. The dish definitely lived up to my expectations! The pickled peppers definitely gave the dish a bit of a kick, but I still consumed it easily (and I'm a heat-averse person). The mint and pine nuts also worked really well with the big chunks of cauliflower.

Chickpea fritters. My boyfriend remarked that the fritters were basically like "fried hummus" and he meant that in the best possible way. The fritters were like eating clouds--so smooth and light! The yogurt, garam masala, rosemary, and green mango worked magnificently. I would definitely order this dish again.

Grilled baby octopus. This was a great dish, but by the time it arrived, I was already almost full from half of the previous two dishes! We got most of it to-go so we could still at least sample the rest of our meal. My only complaint about this dish was that the octopus was a little chewier than I prefer and it was a little overly-salty. Still a great dish, though! I thought there was a pretty liberal amount of octopus (other reviews complained about there not being enough).

Sauteed green beans. My boyfriend was underwhelmed by this dish and we agreed it could have used more cashews. The fish sauce wasn't fishy at all, which was excellent. Even though it was slightly saltier than I prefer, it was still the best green bean dish I've ever had. We took most of this home for leftovers!

Ham frites. The fries were pretty standard in the best way--fairly skinny and not overly crispy or oily. They were covered in what reminded me of a cross between a bacon crumble and fine dust. The ham dust liberally topped the fries and the tomato aioli plus cheddar beer dipping sauces were exquisite. They were very rich.

Wood oven-roasted pig face. This signature G&G dish was a must, so I tried a bite even though I don't eat meat! The sunny-side egg was cooked to absolute perfection. My boyfriend remarked that it was really fatty, which could be interpreted as "either the best thing in the world or the worst thing in the world." It was really, really tasty. The cilantro and red wine-maple were smeared decoratively on the plate.

Miso-butterscotch budino. We were absolutely stuffed by this point, but there was no way we were leaving without trying a G&G dessert. We went with this dessert on the recommendation from our waitress and we didn't know what to expect. (What is a budino?) I still can't really explain it, but it was really great. You can't go wrong with candied cashews!

Overall, this was a really fantastic experience. Some of these bites were simply magical! My only complaint was that there was too much food. Three dishes per person is DEFINITELY way too much. I recommend ordering four dishes total for two people, plus dessert; that would be the sweet spot. Portions are pretty generous. I felt like we got great value for the food + cost. Customer service felt a little off originally because no one acknowledged or apologized for our table being 15 minutes late past the reservation. That being said, even that wasn't enough for me to bump G&G down a star. This is a really fine establishment with mouth-watering food!

This restaurant is modern, sleek and everything that makes an Instagram aesthethic post achievable. Yet, not everyone goes to a restaurant simply for a picture of food but for its consumption so therein lies the problem. Girl & the Goat is tasty but nothing spectacular. I had the empandas which were decent - I have had better and more flavorful. The caulfilower were delicious but five pieces later and cue some horrible heartburn (how in the world does some CAULIFLOWER cause significant heartburn? What oil was even used to warrant it because there were no spices whatsoever on it!) Then we got the goat belly confit which was inedible. Absolutely disgusting and untouched. The meat itself tender but to focus on the tenderness one must ignore the disgusting overpowering vanilla extract placed all over it. There is a time and a place for vanilla extract and it is not meant for a fatty piece of goat.

Now service. Wow. Simply wow. Wow in that I have never been so ignored before in my life at a restaurant. No water refills, the waiter would hang out with the others and actively avoid eye contact. Any questions were vaguely questioned. When told of allergies all we got was a "Hahahaha!" Excuse you allergies are NOT something to laugh about.

Anyway pointof this review is that if you want a nice Instagram post and bragging rights that you ate at an Iron Chef's restaurant then by all means go. But I recommend bracing yourself for getting the cold shoulder (or ridiculed) while chewing on all the Tums CVS has.

If you're looking for unique food, this is definitely the place to go. Bit of a splurge and small plates, but it allows you to try get 5-6 dishes during one meal. Ambiance was great and servers were attentive- especially for going around 10:30pm.
The portions were too small and the service very slow. For the price the place is not worth it.

GET THE PORK SHANK!!! Yuuuuuuuum! I'm not normally a pork person, but the pork shank is amazing!!!! Hands down, order it every single time I'm here. I pair this normally with one of their breads, sometimes what comes with the bread sounds weird, but somehow it works.

We were lucky enough to get a weekend reservation.
I was diligent and got a cancellation.

However ...  we had to wait an hour to get a table. We were 4, so that limited the number of tables we could have, but still I felt they had overbooked reservations to protect against no-shows, but there were none.  I will commend them for comping us drinks and appetizers in the bar after we passed the 50 minute mark.  

Understand that at peak, this place is hip and hopping', and NOT a place to enjoy an intimate conversation, it just too loud for that.  The food is very inventive and flavorful.  There dishes are mostly tapas style, with some that could be a meal for one.  The olives were a nice starter.

The Pig Face everyone brags about tastes a lot like carnitas in a good Mexican restaurant, so stay calm.  We found it to put the brakes on the rest of the meal, filling us up.  Try not to order too many things early on, you'll get full easily.

When we booked our plane tickets for Chicago, I made our reservations here. We were only able to snag a 5:30pm reservation, but I didn't care! I've heard so many good things about this place that I just had to try it.

Service: We were right on time for our reservation and were promptly seated at a table for two. Our server was friendly and very knowledgeable about the menu. She checked in on us but wasn't overbearing. My waterglass was never empty and dirty plates were cleared for new ones after each dish.

Ambiance: This is a nice casual dining restaurant, with a cool interior and an exposed kitchen that was awesome to see. While the size of the restaurant was actually quite impressive, the seating arrangement was not. Our table for two was squeezed in between two business dinners. If that wasn't enough, these guests were obnoxious and the tables were too close together to just ignore the conversation going on just a foot away. This definitely killed the ambiance and quite frankly if the food wasn't as good as it was, could have killed the whole experience. This is my only gripe about this place though.

Food: With just my bf and I, we knew we better be hungry to try the most items. We stuck to all protein dishes and didn't even bother with the veggies and salads. What's cool is that they decide what order to serve you, so it goes from light to heavy. Here's what we ordered (in the order it was served):

Soft shell 'chili crab' (strawberry. crab rice) - this was my pick since I love crab and soft shell crab is even better. Such a unique dish. I've never had soft shell crab like it. The crab was tender and fried for a nice, but delicate crunch. The strawberry added a little sweetness and the rice was amazing. We cleared the bowl pretty quickly.

Wood oven roasted pig face (sunny side egg. tamarind. cilantro. red wine-maple. potato stix) - after reading rave reviews about this dish, we had to get it. Worth it. The meat was moist and tender and the egg just melded the entire dish together. I loved it and so did the bf.

Goat confit with lobster - this was on the specials menu. While probably my least favorite of the bunch because I'm not a huge fan of lobster, my bf took one for the team and just so generously ate the majority of this dish. The lobster was sweet and buttery and the goat was on par.

Crisp braised pork shank (buttermilk dressing. grilled spring onion kimchee. naan) - wow. just wow. so much meat that falls off the bone. I made little pizzas out of mine. I layered my naan with the buttermilk dressing, the kimchee, and topped it off with some pork. Get in my belly.

Drinks: My bf ordered an old fashioned and I kept to my roots with a 21st Amendment watermelon beer.

When it came time for dessert, we took a look at the menu and had to pass. We demolished all four dishes, but it came at a price. Best moment of the night was when we declined dessert and asked for the check, our waitress said, "You guys tried really hard tonight." Nice.

The food was amazing and I can see why it was quickly filling up at 5:30pm. They turn tables over quickly, but don't rush their customers. Fix the seating arrangement issue and I'd most definitely come back. Or maybe next time I'll request a table that's not at a booth.

Everything was great.
Great atmosphere and it was lively without being too loud. It was great for anyone going to dinner, girls night out, date night, or just catching up with a coworker. We were a group of 4 and everyone was super nice to us.

What we ate.....
Octopus: amazing and mix of onions, octopus, peppers, and etc made even the people who didn't eat seafood try it.
Scallops - probably one of the best large scallops I have ever had. Perfectly cooked and seasoned.
Chickapeas - this was not what i expected but was a pleasant surprise! it was eating clouds of tofu or something light. You would not have expected this from reading the description.
Cauliflower - one of the best dishes that was full of flavor and the portion was huge.
Beet salad - get this as a way to keep the dinner light as you will be eating a ton of salt and carbs I'm sure.
Duck - the duck was very good and the portion was a lot larger than I expected.
We also got a side of bread which was good, but not too memorable compared to the other food.

Delicious brunch!!!
I had the shrimp grits and it blew my mind.
Cute atmosphere and fast service.

After looking for a weekend reservation between 7 PM and 9 PM for over 2 years, we finally found one on a weekday.  We were thoroughly excited to finally dine at the much hyped crown jewel of Chicago.  

When we got there, it was a full house, with people waiting at the bar to get a table.  Though we had a reservation, we had a 10 minute wait.  The tables were so closely aligned that my hair was brushing against the person sitting behind me in the other table.  There were also people standing, either waiting for a table or having drinks, right next to our table.  Other than that the ambiance and the service were A one.  We ordered Pig face, Drum fish, Calamari bruschetta, Confit goat belly. The food was very flavorful and rich; a little too rich for my palate.

We would definitely go back, if we can get a reservation that is.

pics.caption: Confit goat belly, Pig face, Drum fish, Calamari bruschetta (clockwise)

review.des:
Food was wonderful and of things I'd never eaten and wouldn't have thought I would like. Go with a group and sample everything if you can.

Make a reservation, months in advance, if you want to eat before 8pm.

Service was impeccable. As soon as silverware hit the floor someone was there to remove it and replace it. If you don't like to eat with strangers right next to you this isn't for you or they won't be strangers for long.   While you might have to share a table with another party it was surprisingly easily to have a conversation with just my group.

There's probably nothing else that needs to be said for a place with 3000+ positive reviews. What I will say is that you need reservations WAY in advance. I made a decision that I was going to Chicago and my first thought was I needed to book a time for this restaurant.  

As such, I was pretty hyped up about finally getting to the place a month later.  It didn't disappoint as the two dishes I tried, the escargot ravioli and pig face, were absolutely amazing. Try and you won't regret it. There were some side dishes on the table from the party I dined with but I was pretty much in my own food zone once my plates arrived.  

Hat's off to you, Stephanie Izard. Next stop, Little Goat!

pics.caption: You can't see it but there's a pig face under that egg.
Escargot ravioli. The tamarind sauce makes the dish!

review.des:
Exquisite food great ambience hard to get a table bit it's shure worth trying!!!
Shishito Peppers, hamachi crudo are a must!

I was pleasantly surprised to be able to score last minute same day reservations for G&G for a reasonable dining hour, 6:45pm last week..  The last time I visited years ago, we snagged one of the first-come, first serve open tables near the entrance that don't need reservations.  It's fine until people start hovering around you waiting for your to leave for your spot.  We checked in a little early, but were seated about 10-15 mins past our reservation time.

It was definitely nice to have the full dining experience in the main dining area.  My only complaint about the seating is how close the tables are, making it especially difficult for someone who's 7 months pregnant, like me, to squeeze into the seat.  Our server was very nice and took the time to explain the menu to my friend, who was visiting for the first time.

We started with the Honey Sambal Brioche - the bread was fresh, warm, and melt in your mouth delicious especially slathered with the honey butter.  I enjoyed the pomelo relish which was a refreshingly light compliment to the butter.  My next favorite dish was the Chickpea Fritter.  It was like a texture and flavor party in my mouth.  Amazing.  My friend's favorite dish was the Crispy Beef Short Ribs, which  were also a nice combination of flavor and texture.  The Pig Face was definitely rich and something to try at least once.  Chopped pig face, aka sisig, is one of my favorite Filipino dishes.  The combination with the crispy potato stix and sunny side egg totally merged my love of sisig with my other love and twist to a staple Filipino breakfast item, corned beef hash!  My least favorite dish was the Grilled Baby Octopus.  It was just oversalted, how could you mess that up?

We forced ourselves to split a dessert, the miso-butterscotch budino, which was recommended by our server.  It was like a pot of liquid gold sprinkled with bacon toffee, glazed pineapple, and candied cashews.  The smokiness and tart of the pineapple really went well with the butterscotch.

I definitely felt at home, eating comforting foods and breaking fresh bread with friends.
Consistent great, inventive takes on diner dishes. Excellent baked goods. Yelp feels this review is too short.

Great food and service.  It is best to go with a few people so you can try multiple items. We sat at the kitchen bar table, was fun to watch all the dishes being created.  We had sautéed green beans, roasted beets, squash blossom rangoon, wood fired whole branzino, bucatini, crisp braised pork shank, and the goat belly.  All were delicious and had so many flavors.  The wine selection is decent with many price points for everyone. It can get very loud when the restaurant is full, so may not be best for a business meal.

Word of advice make a reservation!  I didn't realize how busy this place can get and end up making a reservation a wk in advance and was only able to get a reservation at 10pm on a Thursday for two people... We came early to grab a drink and end up getting seated a little bit earlier.  This was probably my favorite meal in Chicago.  Love the food , the space, and the service.

Portions aren't big which I liked so we were able to had more variety of food.    Presentation and taste was great.  We adventurous and try some of the goat item on the menu and definitely try the pig face.   You wont be disappointed

pics.caption: Bavarian Basil-chocolate gelato. kumquats. Basil-chocolate crunch
Wood oven roasted pig face  Sunny side egg. Tamarind. Cilantro.  Red wine-maple.  Potato stix
Goat empanadas  Miso-blue cheese aioli.  Squash-Apple slaw

review.des:
Service is what sets this place apart.

Nice size space and love the look of the place. We stopped in for a snack and drinks while waiting for Au Cheval.

Ham frites: nice to share. Fries have powdered ham on top. Comes with a nice beer cheese and chipotle aioli.

Nice beer and wine selection. Cool cocktails. Food menu is intimidating and I know a few picky eaters that I probably couldn't take here but it all smelled and looked amazing.

The bar is the place to be tho. The bartenders are so attentive and knowledgeable.

I can't wait to go back!

We walked in at 8.30 pm and were told that waiting for a open table will be 2 hrs!!! We were starving to die and chose to share table outside. It was too dark to observe our dishes and everything got cold before we've done. Lamb chop goes beyond my expectation, it's crispy outside and tender inside with a balance of sweetness and sourness, there was no smell of the lamb at all. Pig face sounds weird but tasted just like pork.
You must come here if you come to Chicago and want to experience fine dining from an iron chef. Everything we ordered was DELICIOUS

Waited two hrs...totally understandable given popular restaurant . Got seated outside. Started drizzling. Was told it is what it is or get on waitlist again. Asked for heatlamp. Ran out propane. Who's running supply chain? Horrible CS and don't even have one propane as stock. Amazing food. Just really disappointing service....did not check up on us...bad attitude. Yup...tipped 5%. Hope it only went towards kitchen staff. Btw...asked for hot sauce n was told I don't need it....I have had enough food to know what I need n don't need with my food

Just in case the first 4900 reviews weren't enough for you, I'll add one more! This place is absolutely off the hook. No wonder there are next to no times available a few months out. One stop inside and you figure out why.

My best have had been here once previously and I dreamed about it for so long that we figured we needed to make a visit on the last stop of our food vacation. I was blown away with what they had to offer.

As we had been stuffing our faces for a few days, we didn't come in as hungry as we probably should have. Recommendation - don't eat for about 8 hours before you come here, there's going to be a dozen things you want to try. We were set up nicely by our waiter who took very good care of us. The drink menu is pretty expensive, with some really nice mixed drinks. I had to very old fashioned and it was excellent. It was probably the least impressive thing that we had there, and it was in the top 10% that I'd had. Winning!

Our culinary experience here included the Pigface, the duck tongues and the escargot dumplings. The pig face is a must try and is a symphony in your mouth. It's a burger like concoction underneath sauces and an over easy egg. It is delicious and definitely worth waiting for. The duck tongues were phenomenal and different than I was expecting. We had them in China previously, and they were basically a tongue that you literally bit the meat off of. These were lightly fried and served in a lovely sauce - absolutely perfect! The escargot dumplings were magical and something well be getting any time we stop by.

Ambiance was trendy with a relaxed vibe. It's a nice mix of music with low light and plenty of chatter.

All in all, as the previous 5K folks have indicated - this is a must try for anyone who eats! Some of the more imaginative dishes we've ever had, done in a way that leaves you wanting more and not feeling pretentious - foodie paradise!
Overpriced, uninteresting food served by unfriendly waiters. Why people wait months to go here is a mystery.

Everything here is delicious. Best meal we had in Chicago. The wait is normally really long, so try to make reservations!

Girl & the Goat is actually easily accessible from downtown via bus or train, so I had no problems getting here as a visitor.

We ordered:
- Hamachi Crudo: This is essentially sashimi and the crispy pork belly actually complemented really well!

- Escargot Ravioli: I was hesitant about this dish since I'm not a fan of escargot, but oh my god, the tamarind-miso sauce is to die for.

- Country fried loup de mer: I really liked all the sides that this came with. I'm a huge fan of sweet and sour, which totally made the dish.

- Wood oven roasted pig face: Highly recommended as well. It sounds like a strange dish, but it actually is quite normal.

- Confit goat belly: This was probably one of our favorite dishes. We loved the bourbon butter and lobster and crab. There is surprisingly a lot of lobster and crab that comes with the belly!

- Miso-butterscotch budino: Best budino I have ever had. The bacon toffee and candied cashews are so delicious, I want a second one!

Highly highly recommended for everyone.

Where do i start ? This place is magnificent, from the food, to the wait staff, the music and restroom. Everything is perfect, I'm actually shocked I haven't ventured to this restaurant before. My wife and I called to make reservations but was told that they were all booked up, and it would be a first come first serve bases. So with that's being said, we still decided to make this place out destination for the night. We checked into the hostess who said it would be a 2 HOUR wait and that we could wait around the bar area. Lucky enough we found two seats for us, granted this place was packed with people all over the place. We proceeded to grab a few glasses of wine and cocktails. They called us over after waiting for about an hour and 30 mins. The waiter Jergen was awesome, he asked if we've had food from here before and explained everything about the menu. The menu is simple and has a wide variety of options to choose from. I highly recommend getting the green beans. The drink menu has a good selection from sweet to spicy drinks. I will say, this restaurant is not for kids so please leave them at home. Overall, I will be coming back to this wonderful place, from the drinks, to the decor all the way down to the restroom this place is 5 Stars in my book.

Finally made it here! Below is the progression of the meal

Roasted Cauliflower
Pickled peppers. Pine nuts. Mint
Surprising how roasting cauliflower can give sooo much flavor. You can really experience difference levels and depth of flavor from the roasting along with the texture and fatty mouth feel of the pine nuts, to the refreshing notes of the mint. yum.

Wood Fired Shrimp
Vadouvan . Colline . Pomelo . Pine Nut Pepita Spice
The aromas reminded me of shell-on grilled shrimp fused with an asian dish, or a thai larb/meat sauce. It was enjoyable but wasn't out of this world. Made me want a bowl of jasmine rice to eat along with this dish.

Goat Empanadas
Miso-blue cheese aioli. Squash-apple slaw
Nice crispy texture that was enjoyable. The goat could have been replaced with pulled pork shoulder or chicken and I wouldn't have known.

Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face
Sunny side egg. Tamarind. Cilantro. Red wine-maple. Potato stix
YES YES YES! Now I understand why this is the one dish I have always heard about when it comes to Girl and the Goat. The presentation is really nice and invites you want to dive right in. You start out by cutting through the yolk of the sunny side up egg, allowing that yellow gold liquid to cascade down on the the crispy fried fatty pork belly hidden beneath on a bed of crispy potato stix, all surrounded by tangy tamarind sauce and cilantro oil drizzle. I enjoyed this dish because it had so much texture going on, and the home cooked comfort food feel when you bite into the crisp pork and the fattiness just envelopes your mouth like a warm food hug!

Service was very patient and explained everything, and price was very fair, I would come back to try some other dishes!

Easily one of the most creative, fun, delicious meals I've eaten, ever.  

While I'm sure that G&TG is great for a date night, I was happy we came with two other couples so that we could try a whole bunch of things. And try we did:

*Olive bread with whipped feta. I'm not an usually olive person and I really liked this.
*Challah with lox cream cheese - so good that people in our party made a special trip the next day to score loaves of this amazing bread.
*Cheese bread with ham butter. HAM BUTTER. Right now, I actually can't think of a thing that wouldn't be considerably improved with some of that ham butter.

*Roasted beets - served chilled. If beets could ever be described as "refreshing", these were.
*Chickpea fritters - one of my personal favorites of the night. I loved the spices on this dish.

*Escargot dumplings
*Diver scallops - I don't like scallops personally but the Mister said they were the absolute best he's ever had

*Ham frites - perfectly crisp fries with ham salt and cheddar beer sauce. All other fries are ruined for me because they won't have HAM SALT.
*Crispy pig face - they tell you to mix the whole lot up so you get some of the crunchy potato bits and perfectly cooked egg in every bite. It was incredible.
*Pork shanks - served with homemade buffalo sauce and ranch so you can make little buffalo wing pork shank bites. Our group attacked this like a pack of starving hyenas.

*Goat empanadas - filled with perfectly braised goat and a delicious blue cheese sauce. I have a rule to Always Order Empanadas, and it's never let me down.
*Goat confit - incredibly tender and rich meat

*Goat cheesecake - a wonderful mix of not-too-sweet cake, smoky beer caramel and meringue beer "kisses"
*Squash cake - maybe my favorite of the three. Perfectly moist cake with beautifully herbal rosemary ice cream
*Brownies with shitake mushroom gelato - what? That gelato was wonderfully weird - completely unexpected but absolutely great.

It was interesting that for a place known for goat (and believe me, the goat dishes we ordered were fantastic) the things I'll be dreaming about for weeks to come were all pork based. HAM FRIES. HAM BUTTER. PIG FACE. BUFFLAO WING PORK SHANK. I would eat these things every day, forever until I died of a pork-induced heart attack. But I would die happy and full, so it would be worth it.

Our server really added to the overall experience - she was great in every way. Dishes were timed perfectly, no glass was left unfilled and she was so much fun. I really appreciated that for all it's popularity, G&TG never felt "attiude-y". Staff actually seemed to enjoy being there and having fun with patrons.

So...for all of this goodness plus a liberal number of drinks, it was (with tip) - $80 per person. WHAT??? Bargain of the century. And that's why you'd better call for reservations the second they open up or you'll be missing out.

Also, there should be more ham-based condiments in the world.

We visited here for dinner with family and inlaws for a special gathering. This experience was nothing short of fantastic. Julia our waitperson was the  best. The entire staff that helped us during the meal was wonderful. Every person that helped servring was aware of dietary restrictions at the table and made sure to let everyone know of any needed alerts.  The food was beyond delicious from the veggies to the duck tongue to the goat ribs. We will be back.

I've heard legendary things about this place before visiting so I knew I had to make a reservation. I made a reservation months ahead of time as my party was a party of 5 and I've heard that the wait can get pretty bad on a weekend for dinner. Showed up and was seated immediately.

This place is sort of tapas style except the plates aren't that small. For a table of 5 (4 girls and 1 guy) we ordered about 8 or 9 dishes to share and trust me we were happy full by the end of it. We got a good share of vegetables and meat dishes. I can't say I remember the names of everything we ordered but the dish with hot, warm, and fluffy bread and pate was most memorable (I love bread). I've never had such freshly baked bread before it was phenomenal. Everything was fantastic. Wish we could've tried the whole entire menu because there's a reason why this place has such high ratings.

The ambience of the place was rather nice too. A bit dark but perfect for a dinner outing. The quality of my pictures were a bit low due to the dim lighting (you know flash photography can be kinda embarrassing at such a cool and hip place). If I ever come to Chicago again, I will DEFINITELY come back multiple times.

What else is there to say about this place that hasn't already been said? Super clean, contemporary decor, flawless service. The food is absolutely amazing. We shared 11 courses between 3 people and they were all fantastic. Top 3 best dining experiences I've ever had. Would recommend and will definitely return.

Oooommmmgeee! So good! I see why Anthony Bourdain highly appreciates this establishment. The food was amazing. The green beans were sautéed just right. The cashews were just an accent of goodness. The lamb shank, just melted in your mouth. My old fashioned reminded me of a whiskey sour.  We were celebrating my birthday, so we were graciously served a bread pudding that would have made my grandmother nod. The staff was friendly and the atmosphere was warm. We had a great visual of the kitchen staff with our seats. I will be back!

What can I possibly say that 3600 other reviewers haven't said??? Food is delishly outstanding and perfectly seasoned. Flavor combinations are unique and well balanced. Short ribs with grapefruit were amazing!
I also digged the booming music and casual atmosphere.

pics.caption: Open kitchen is very fun to watch

review.des: Great service, outstanding and different combination of flavors... works out perfect!! No wonder the chef earned the James Beard Award!!!

Have to say - overpriced and underwhelming.
Very rich, salty food. Would not rush back.

My absolute favorite in Chicago is this amazing restaurant and it beats most Michelin star restaurants in the area hands down by not just it's amazing different menu but also the service. My server took time to properly explain how much and what should I order basis my interest. We celebrated my husband's birthday dinner there and it was worth every bit of it. We ended up not hungry enough for our last dish that we bulk ordered and the server was happy to cancel it. Pretty much everything is good on the menu, but I would recommend the beans, their Gouda bacon bread and the goat dumplings.

Really enjoyed our trip to Girl & the Goat. We started with the goat liver mousse, lovely flavor and texture and sweet. baby. jesus were the crumpets they served with it amaaaazing. The pickled grapefruit rinds were the perfect topper as well.

We also tried the crispy duck tongues, because why not. They were good, and, not trying to be tongue and cheek here (heyoooo) but they really did taste like chicken, and were breaded and fried to perfection.

We ate the roasted beets around the same time - the white anchovies in the beets really set off the flavor, delicious.

We ended with the cuttlefish. It was not my favorite, it was prepared nicely but it was fuuuunkily flavored.

Overall I liked the vibe of this place. Our server was very attentive while still being low-key (the best kind of server). The dishes were all thoughtful, creative and beautifully composed. Oh and the Ring of Fire cocktail was the best. Well worth the money.

I came here as an impromptu date with my fiancé and cousin. We all shared everything family style, and I highly recommend this so you can try more!

I called way too late to make a reservation, but the receptionist told me to come early right when the restaurant opens. I followed her directions and arrived at 4:20 so we didn't even have to wait more than 10 mins.  

I just want to say the sides really blew me away, and I'm giving them 5 stars based on service and these two sides. Cauliflower and green beans. AH-mazing! I would've gladly ordered these two again as my main dish. I'm a veggie-loving carnivore, and the meat dishes are as good as they say. It's just that their veggie dishes are out of this world! Get those sides!!! Tangy, nutty, and delish!

As a starter, we tried the hamachi that our sweet waitress recommended. It came in three pieces, which is perfect for sharing. It had a tangy citrus sauce to it and definitely was a good refreshing appetizer.

For mains, we got the famous pig face, which I enjoyed but did not love. I liked the crispy texture, but I wish it had a little more sauce. The egg yoke didn't cut it for me.

We also shared the goat shank, which was extremely tender, full of flavor, and fell off the bone. I would recommend that as well.

The third main course was another goat dish (since its called girl and the goat, we figured we can't go wrong with two goat dishes), but it was not too memorable since I can't even recall the name or the dish now... Disclaimer I do have a bad memory.

Main thing is, get the cauliflower and the green beans. They will change your life!

pics.caption: A family friend once said, "a meal is not complete without dessert."
Ah-mazing cauliflower side dish. This was life changing dish for me! I would order 2 of this as my main course.

review.des:
What an epic meal!

First of all, David, Alejandro, and Veronica are rock stars!

For the last dinner of my most recent visit to the home of my birth, Chicago, Girl & the Goat had to be it. I'd been meaning to come here for a while now. My brother has been here before many times and could not recommend it enough. Not surprisingly, it did not disappoint.

Pre-Feast:
While waiting for our table, we ordered a cocktail and mine was so freaking good. The drink I ordered was called: Best of Three. It was the perfect pre-meal drink. It was so bright and clean tasting, it cleansed my pallet just right.

The Feast:

Italian Sausage Bread (fennel-stout butter . pickle relish) - The perfect start. The butter I could just eat by the spoon full and I feel similarly about the pickled relish. And the sausage...mama mia!

Nantucket Bay Scallops (french lentils . beech mushrooms . celery root) - This was packed with flavor and the pureed lentils were an excellent compliment.

Roasted cauliflower (pickled peppers . pine nuts . mint) - I don't know how they did it, but the cauliflower tasted as if it's been marinated in deliciousness.

Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face (sunny side egg. tamarind. cilantro . red wine-maple. potato stix) - This was excellent and tasted like the ultimate breakfast.

Roasted Duck Breast (miso-marcona almond butter. rapini. gremolata) - It had good flavor, but the texture of the duck was not great, it was rather chewy. I've had a fair amount of rare-medium rare duck, and this may have been the chewiest I've encountered.

Confit Goat Belly (bourbon butter . lobster n' crab . fennel) - This was good, but sounded better than it turned out to be.

We were fortunate enough to sit next to possibly the nicest dining couple ever. They and their kids ordered a ton and were stuffed. As a result, they passed over a couple of their dishes over to us. These were the:

Crisp Braised Pork Shank (buttermilk dressing . butternut-shiitake kimchee . naan) - Crispy on the outside and juicy underneath, this melts in your mouth. The kimchi sauce was awesome.

Shishito Peppers (courtesy of our neighbors) - These are the best shishito peppers I've ever had. They had a spicy, yet smooth flavor and the bread crumbs and sauce were great.

I had an Omegang beer during my meal. I love Omegang and liked that they have one of their beers here.

Post-Feast: We had no room for dessert so went for coffee only. My brother had an Americano and I went with Espresso. Both were great and the perfect ending to our  epic feast.

Atmosphere: Cool, sexy and I really like when restaurants have some of the cooking on display. Especially with the magic they make here, it was cool totake a peak. Nice wood fire oven too.

Service: As stated in the opening, David, Alejandro and Veronica are as good as it gets! The hosts were nice too.

Despite a couple of the dishes not being on par with the others, they still deserve 5 stars for a classy show of top notch and creative culinary delight in an intimate setting with exceptional service.

Can I say that this place is overrated and overhyped for what it is?  Yes, the reputation is what they are known for and the name of the restaurant is adorable, but it was a major letdown.  The food, dining affair, ambiance and service was of the norm for fine dining, but it lacked spark to make it all the difference.  

Presentation was clean cut for all the dishes and the ingredients used, were gourmet.

Do order up their red wine just because it is red wine.  Their Syrah from Cortona was swell.  The Pig Face is their signature dish.  It was rich with tenderness, had a red wine maple sauce with it, but lacked an umph.  Their Chickpea Fritters were delightful.  I liked the creamy cheese sauce that was on the side of the fritters.  The fritters and Confit Goat Belly, complimented the red wine well.  The Goat Belly was tender and a bit gamey, but not much as I would have preferred.  I liked the chucks of lobsters that were surrounding it as well as the buttery goodness drizzled around it.  

It was a spot on fine dining affair, but it didn't leave a candle lighted spark, unfortunately.

pics.caption: Pork Face with sunny side up egg
Baby octopus mixed in with veggies and mushroom

review.des: The food tasted well. But kinda expensive for the food they have. I would not come back again. But it's worth just trying it out once

First stop after we got off the train, Girl & the Goat! Been hearing a lot about this place and couldn't even make a proper reservation because it was so busy. What do we do? Eat dinner super early at 4:30PM when they first open! Since it was tapas, we got many to share. Here's the deal:

Johnny Apple Cheese: It's cheese butter and bread. Sounds simple enough but it tastes expensive if you ask me! It was a subtle and light cheese spread with some moist, fluffy bread. We're sold! Give us more please!

- Roasted Cauliflower: You may think, why I am I paying so much for some veggies? Well, it was well seasoned and perfectly cooked. I don't think I can do this any better myself. What did they put in this?!

- Chickpea Fritter: It was interesting, but I actually really liked it! I think because it was fried, it gave it an extra crunch but the flavors were really powerful with all their seasoning too!

- Grilled baby Octopus: YUM! It came with a lemon sauce that complemented the perfectly cooked octopus really well. I wish they gave more pieces but maybe it's just my sister that ate them all first...

- Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face: Oh gosh, this was sooo amazing!! The face was one of the most tender meats I've ever eaten. When you dig into it, it feels like a delicacy and you can just taste the care that went into cooking it. So well flavored and melts in your mouth!

- Confit Goat Belly: It was pretty good but I wasn't a fan of the bourbon sauce. I felt like it overpowered the whole dish. However, if you're into the booze...

Overall, fantastic start to my first meal in Chicago. Keep 'em coming!!

we ordered the following:
goat empanadas- literally 2 empanadas for $18! these were good but goat is not an expensive meat and i was pretty shocked at the price point for two dumpling sized, not argentinian empanada sized, empanadas.
beet salad- generous serving of beets, unlike some restaurants that skimp on the beets, served with greens. great, light salad to start the meal.
escargot ravioli- okay, not great
goat belly with lobster and crab- this was my least favorite because it was served with a vanilla sauce!! the sauce on the menu was "brandy beurre blanc" but it was literally like a vanilla sauce. i'm sure it would have tasted good with some ice cream but with crab meat, lobster and goat belly?? it just didn't work.
pork shank- generous serving of a fried pork shank served with naan, a yogurt sauce, tiny amount of pickled carrots and hot sauce. you probably get the most bang for your buck with. wasn't a fan of the carrots but everything else worked really well together.
cake with toffee sauce and gooseberries- this was pretty good but not amazing. i wished they served more ice cream with it because they literally only give you a tablespoon. the gooseberries were a nice addition and it cut the sweetness.

their timing with bringing out the food was excellent and our server was really nice.

overall, this restaurant is worth visiting if you're in chicago but don't expect mind blowingly amazing food.
There food was unique and nicely prepared. The atmosphere was lovely. I was however blown away by the tiny portions (even for Tapas) and the subsequent price-tag. Really Pricey

Great restaurant! Great food. A little noisy though, need to make a reservation if you're going in a group on weekday and definitely on weekend! Their chickpea fritters, braised beef tongue, brioche bread was amazing! Our group tried a variety of drinks, which were all very good!
its OK. Don't get what the hype is about. Also, was jammed into a tiny table along the wall with lots of traffic going by

There's a stuffed pepper appetizer where most of the pieces aren't spicy but there's the random bite that burns your existence.  This is the delightful, sensual, surprising experience of Girl & the Goat.  However, I don't remember much about the goat.

I like how the menu is split into dietary preferences. I could immediately find vegetarian options, and my meat-eating friends were also very satisfied with their own choices. The ambiance was nice for a night out and the food was amazing. Recommend the garbanzo dish.

Amazing place.  Loved the knowledgeable bar staff and well appointed cocktails.   The did was inventive and highlighted goat and pork in delicious, creative ways.   I highly recommend going with a large group (We brought 12, including kids), as it allows you to sample more of the diverse options of small plates.   Our children were very welcomed, with the staff even bringing little plastic cups with the goat emblem on the side - they were a big hit.

One of the best meals we have ever had in our entire lives. It felt like a cabin in the country and a penthouse hotel resort on a Caribbean island at the same time. We are so happy with this place! Worth every penny!

I made reservations for Girl and the Goat nearly 3 months in advance for my birthday and somehow only had the 5pm or 9pm timeslot. I believe reservations go out 3 months in advance so if you want a normal dinner time make it literally 3 months in advance. If you are okay with a super early or late dinner probably not that big of a deal.  I came here with my boyfriend for my birthday and they gave us the "best seat in the house" as they repeatedly mentioned, the "chefs table". (Me as a fine dining noob is all like "wow they must be kidding it's so hot back here we are basically in the kitchen" but my bf my explained it is the most coveted seat in a nice restaurant.. I digress)

They have a great cocktail menu, kind of reminded of Sable (up in River North). For food we ordered shishito peppers, calamari bruschetta, scallops, pig face, and goat skewers. All were absolutely phenomenal. We ordered 1 dish too many for two ppl but you better believe we ate every crumb! My fave was the calamari bruchetta which was prepared much differently from your typical calamari, it was not breaded and deep fried. It was perfectly tender and a unique dish. Since it was my bday they brought me a complementary desert, which was very nice :)
Neat place in the summer. Food is very good.

Couldn't wait to make a Chicago trip to try out Stephanie Izard's restaurant after being a big fan of hers when she was on Top Chef. This was probably the best dining experience of my life! Our party was vegetarian and we were still able to indulge in the unique and tasty items. My favorite was the dessert, so I definitely recommend saving room for the "sticky crunchy tasty toffee cake." It was the best dessert I have had in my life. I also loved the potato bread with the chive yogurt. The space is really cute and cozy. We were in Chicago for a few days, and I looked on Open Table for reservations about a month in advance and there was only ONE slot available at 8:30pm on our last day, so we definitely lucked out. I would suggest booking your reservation at least 2 months in advance to be safe. The service was very prompt, our water glasses were always full and the dishes came out right after the other. I would have appreciated a friendlier and more welcoming attitude though (maybe I'm just spoiled by southern hospitality). My mom is lactose intolerant, and they gave her a vegan menu upon finding this out. I didn't particularly enjoy her vegan broccoli dish, though.

Overall, this is the place to be if you are checking out the food scene in Chicago. The only thing that could have made this experience better would have been if we had met Stephanie! :P
Over priced, over hyped, and not that great. We didn't have anything we absolutely loved. Drinks were ok. Definitely a place that can be skipped.

We were so lucky! Hearing from most of the review we had to book reservation in advance. We came walking by and try our lucky without one. We were told 1 hour wait. We sat at the bar and the server came asking if we wanted to order , it was a full service. Thanks god!
My husband got the pig face. It was delicious!  I got the pork shank. It was very good , but not to the point where I was crazy about it.

Love the food and atmosphere here - great for date night if you can get a table .  The entire menu is really impressive and you can't go wrong with trying anything from it.  Definitely a must visit when in Chicago.
Slightly overpriced. But the burgers are fancy and tasty with not so average ingredients. Should go in with a big appetite to truly appreciate it!

Everybody needs to eat a meal at Girl and the Goat at least once. I try to get there at least once a year and it doesn't disappoint. Get the pig face dish or a seasonal veggie dish - and don't overlook the breads.

This is one of my favorite places in town when you're looking for an eclectic menu with lots of different options and want to share plates. There are tons of different items in the sections of the menu and it's best to go with someone or a group who want to share. On the pricey side of things, but it is worth it. Try every category- the fresh breads, dessert, and of course something with goat. Very romantic and enchanting atmosphere too.

There are a billion reviews on this restaurant and I have been more than 10 times so I am going to keep this short and give some bullet point tidbits.
