Very busy restaurant, everyone tends to reserve months in advance. However, the best way to get in on short notice is to just try to grab a seat at the bar. They have full menu service, and sometimes you don't have to wait at all- if a table opens up they can move your tab.

Food: Excellent food, and the menu is very unique and constantly evolving. The small menu of goat based dishes is a total gem.

The only thing I warn people to watch out for is what I refer to as food bombs. These bombs are dishes that are meal enders. They are enormous portions of a decadent, heavy dish: your palette is fatigued and exhausted and you are suddenly very full and you have only eaten 20% of the plate. Sounds great to maybe just doggie bag and take home. But the overall point is: this place would be a total 5 star place if they just balanced the heavy dishes more and gave smaller portions of those, while increasing the portion size of the some of the lighter dishes.

Anyway: Don't miss out on coming here, you definitely won't regret it.

The moment I hit the ground in Chicago (or rather... the moment I found out I'd be in Chicago) I booked a reservation at A Girl and a Goat.

This is how it works for us foodie travellers... we immediately find the best restaurant in our new city... we put our name on a reservation list some time in the impossible future... and we hope we don't get rolled off the project before we get to experience the food.

This time it worked and I managed to score a crappy time on my last day in the city but I snagged it because the foodie-rumour-mill says it's nearly impossible to get in without months of notice.

I can't even begin to explain the fantastic-ness that is A Girl and a Goat; everything we tried on the menu was off the charts delicious and the recommended wine pairing was bang on.

The cuttlefish was so good that we ordered it twice, the goat liver pate came with freshly baked bread (gluten free if needed), and the entire evening just became a sea of one delicious food after another. Our waiter was chatty and attentive; and everyone around us put up with (and reciprocated) our "what is that delicious looking dish" questions.

I'm glad we put the effort into finding and getting a reservation at A Girl and a Goat; it's worth the effort.
Went here for my birthday and it was nice but a tad overrated. I kind of prefer little goat but great ambience.

Love love love this place ! We been here couple of times and every time I love it here we love the winter menu more than the summer menu . I think the highlight is their mussels in pesto sauce in winter menu. Pig face is also equally my fav . It's a very noisy restaurant is west loop ( given how popular it is ) service is very nice and nothing special about ambience .

I have never written a review before, I downloaded the "Yelp" app just to get my experience across: I am absolutely and utterly disappointed. I had this reservation for over 2 month, totally excited about this famous experience. While, disclaimer: the food was VERY good... I walked out SO dumbfounded by my service (or lack thereof). I immediately informed my family/friends I will certainly never be back and feel totally ripped off. Again, after placing this rez two months ago--tonight, my boyfriend and I were seated at a table that was essentially in the kitchen. Beware! We both wished we would've spoken up but felt too bad making a fuss. This table was an extension of essentially the area where waiters put in their orders--not more than 1 foot from the chefs and stoves. It was so loud and so unbelievably hot we were both sweating by the end of the meal. And, couldn't hear each other for the life of us.

I sent my drink back because it was not what I ordered and received an eye roll from our waiter, who had not been to our table more than twice before this (... keep in mind, our meal was finished. Twice in about one hour.)

I waited so long for my Girl & The Goat experience and truthfully, I think our waiter forgot about us at this "makeshift" table. I couldn't believe they would seat someone there (and we are not picky), especially because we were not walk-ins! Will be most certainly telling more people about our terrible experience. I'm infuriated and disappointed. Money wasted on a hot, loud, ill-served time... completely clouding good food.

Great food and great service. Like others have said, small plates but definitely worth it as they all tasted great. Price was good for the location. Where in downtown Chicago isn't expensive after all? Cocktails were ok, weren't bad but they were a little strong. Would definitely repeat again.
Love this place!!! We all had a wonderful time at this restaurant. Food was delicious, staff was knowledgeable, and competent.  If we return to Chicago, we definitely will go back for more!!

I had very high expectations for this place and they were mostly met, but I expected the food to blow my socks off and it just didn't. We had a party of 6, so I got to try a bunch of dishes, but the only one that was truly memorable was the tomato-apple soup. The texture on the soup was brilliantly smooth and creamy and the flavor had a bit of sweet-tangyness that you don't find in basic tomato soup that was just addictive. We enjoyed everything we got, but I had to struggle to ever remember the other food when I started writing this review. My dish was pierogies with green gaspacho sauce and it was very well composed, but lacked any memorable punch of flavor. My wife got an asian pancake "sandwich" that was craveable, but mostly one-note. Others got french toast, grilled cheese, and a sandwich I can't recall. Everything was prepared well. They clearly have some very competent chefs on staff and a few of the recipes were creative, but mostly the food was unmemorable.

Ugh, okay this has been a dream come true for me. I've been wanting to go to this place and wishing this was back in SoCal!

Pig Face (4/5): the Filipino side of me thinks this taste like Lechon which makes sense since it is pig! I enjoyed it and mixing it up is highly recommended in order to get the utmost flavors. The egg yolk definitely balances out the crispy texture. I enjoy the sauces lingering on the plate, it made me want more.

Duck Tongue (5/5): I enjoy poke especially since I'm from SoCal, these flavors were very important to me and including the texture. Very on point! If you don't like the poke consistency then it may not be for you. It's quite creative since I forgot I was eating duck tongue and I thought it was poke (fish) at one point. It melts in your mouth like butter.

Crisp Braised Pork (3/5): okay this is just another cooked version of the pig face.

Roasted Cauliflower (3.5/5): this helped balanced out the meat entrees since sometimes, eating too much meat loses its flavor haha. Eat it with the pine nuts because eating it alone, it can be a bit salty. Although great side dish for the other meat entrees!!

Girl & The Goat is my personal favorite of Stephanie Izard's restaurants. Chef Izard delivers explorative and excellent small plates that make your tastebuds dance. The well-rounded food is the focus here. The "Don't be curry, be happy" bread to start, goat empanadas, grilled baby octopus, kusshi oysters for appetizers, 'signature' wood oven-roasted pig face for dinner, and the AMAZING miso-butterscotch budino for dessert was plenty for two ravenous appetites. There's always something adventurous and exciting in the restaurant's namesake department: goat liver mousse, goat carpaccio, confit goat belly, goat legs, etc.

Comfortable, lively, and a no-fuss ambiance. This restaurant in West Loop on Randolph St. is a popular one. Reserve in advance. Great quality food without the hefty price tag and disappointment that may sometimes follow upscale restaurants. It's not cheap, but it's reasonable in comparison to restaurants of this caliber.

Bottom line: Girl & The Goat is the crème de la crème of James Beard Award winner Stephanie Izard's restaurants.

I know most everyone loves this place and the food is good but not to die for and is overpriced. The real problems are the acoustics and the crowding. It's very loud and our table was inches away from neighbor. It's the kind of place that has to pull the table out so you can access your seat. Some people might think that's symbolic of something good but it's not fun to literally knock elbows while having to listen to the conversations around you.

I've had the privilege of dining at Girl and the Goat on 3 separate occasions and each time I thoroughly enjoyed my dining experience.

The food is always delicious with great flavors, fresh ingredients and presented beautifully on the plate. I recommend you try: the roasted oysters, pig face, escargot ravioli and the apple buckle (dessert).

The service is always impeccable with the staff being knowledgeable about the menu and what wine(s) go best with what you have ordered. A special shout out to Taylor who is the best server I've countered during my dining experiences in the west loop area.

I highly recommend that you visit this establish because the food is worth the hype. The only reason I'm not giving Girl and the Goat 5 stars is because I HATE how close the tables are to each other.

I've hesitated to review Girl & the Goat for two reasons: 1. what hasn't already been said? 2. I attended a private event so perhaps my experience was different than the typical restaurant-goer. But, here it goes.

In case you didn't read the above I attended a private event in the Underground Goat here last year. Overall it was an great experience, which, how couldn't it be when you are treated to a lavish free dinner at one of the buzziest places in town.

The room itself is definitely tight - it was a full house and it made for a bad set up for pre-dinner drinks/mingling. Once we were seated, it was much better. This is no fault of the Girl's or the Goat's even. Perhaps my hosts over seated the room?

We had a wide variety of the popular dishes shared across the tables. Thinking back on the dishes that most stuck out, I would include the shishito peppers (awesome) and pretty much all of the veggies, the goat empandas (I wouldn't normally eat goat but it was not gamey at all in this preparation), the fried oyster... and the duck tongue, which sorry, I couldn't bring myself to try. Service was nicely done so they brought three or so dishes at a time and well portioned so that everyone got a good taste and no awkward attempting to share something that isn't shareable. Desserts were good too but I missed the description so I had no idea what I was eating and therefore can't pass that along to you here.

To sum it up, it was a fun night in a packed room that left me thinking I'd like to come back on my own time and try out the dining room. I haven't had a chance just yet. Maybe that's why I'm leaving it at four stars because if it was truly amazing I'd have done it already!
One of my favorites in the city. Can't go wrong with most items. Grilled broccoli was excellent. Would skip the pig face - not that great.

I wanted to give this place 5 stars because the food (while not the most abundant selection for vegetarians) was great. The experience was a 3, food was a 4, so I rounded up. Unfortunately our waitress maybe was having a bad day. She offered to make a chicken and squash dish without the chicken.. I asked her to describe it and she said "well it's a bowl of squash". I do appreciate the separation of "veggie" "fish" and "meat"... although the beat salad had white anchovies on it - which they put on the side, and there is another dish with fish sauce on it. It was good, maybe it was over hyped? The chick pea fritters and potato pierogies were phenomenal though.
Our favorite go-to date night! Food and service are always consistent. If you leave without getting the green beans you made a huge mistake!!

We went to this place based on a recommendation from a few friends who went there the day before, so we decided to check it out. As soon as we walked in, I was impressed with the decor- very trendy. We walked in about 10:30 PM after a Bulls game, and already, the place was packed! Since there was no available seating, we went straight to the bar to order drinks.

Looking at the menu, they had only a few imports - one from Holland: Dragon's Milk Ale, which I believe was $12 and one from Belgium: Orval, which I believe was $16. The rest of the beer was domestic. If you ask the bartender for a suggestion, make sure you tell him what you prefer as far as beer goes.

After waiting at the bar for a table, the hostess came up to us and took us to our table. Our waitress explained the menu and was very knowledgeable. The menu is simple. It is separated into three categories: Vegetables, Seafood, and Meat. I like the fact that selecting was easy. It is a tapas style restaurant, so we ordered a few things.

It was definitely unique menu-wise, but nothing was out of this world. My favorite thing was the Calamari Bruschetta, but I still wouldn't say it was mind-blowing or anything memorable. Was it worth it? Not sure, but definitely an interesting experience.
Had my 40th birthday party in the private dining room for 20. Cost a fortune...worth it. The food was absolutely incredible. Service was great.  Ambiance was perfect.

The Johnny Applecheese bread was by far the best part of the meal, don't skip on this. The spicy beer cheese with the bread and the apple butter worked perfectly together. Unfortunately, the bread was the highlight of the meal.

Nothing overwhelmed me. Everything was okay. I had the sweet potato pierogies, which tbh did not taste like pierogies but more like empanadas, as well as the smoky broccoli. Everything was decent, but nothing blew me away. i have no idea why they have the name they do. In my opinion, The Little Goat Diner across the street is a much nicer experience, it's much more creative and interesting for a fraction of the price.

Still one of our favorite spots in the city! The bold and unique flavors are delightful and full of surprise. Service is friendly and the atmosphere is fun for gatherings with friends and out of town guests! Although it's focused on goat... we find their vegetarian options to be very enjoyable.

Third or fourth time here...

Fried duck tongue was delicious... Best thing I've had for a long while

Clam chowder bread, had a smoked tomatoe bacon topping which was awesome...

Pineapple fun side up with macadamia nut praline was a prefect end...

Hamachi pork belly was just good, broccoli ok, goat empanada was tasty

Believe the hype and do what you must to snag a reservation.  I had to call from Los Angeles a month prior, and I was only able to snag a 10:15 pm reservation for a Sunday night...

A red-eye flight from LA, straight to the Bean, aka Cloud Gate, and then to a Cubs vs. Dodgers game (LA prevailed), we arrived at TG&G utterly exhausted but ready for a foodie experience.  The four of us sat down to:

Breads:
*Johnny Apple-Cheese (apple chunks baked in with chili-butter & malted oil)
*Sourdough PB&J (peanut butter with Concord grape "jam")

Starters:
*Beet Salad (with green beans, white anchovy, avocado creme fraiche & bread crumbs)
*Green Beans (fish sauce vinaigrette & cashews)

Mains:
*Octopus (guanciale, Romano beans, Brussels leaves, pistachios, lemon vinaigrette)
*Loup de Mer (country fried with tamarind sweet & sour, cucumber salad, shrimpy fried grains)
*Pig Face (wood oven roasted with sunny side up egg, tamarind, cilantro, red wine maple and potato stix)
*Kalbi Ribs (with roasted corn)
*Scallops (with Cubano pork, apple mojo & pepper-raisin relish)

Desserts:
*Miso-Butterscotch Budino (bacon toffee, glazed pineapple & candied cashews)
*Thai Basil Choco Chip Gelato (bittersweet chocolate & blackberries)

Cocktail:
*The Earhart (Chicago Distillery Ceres Vodka, yellow chartreuse, maraschino, lemon, and lavender bitters)

To skip to the end, unbelievably, this feast for the senses came to only $145.00 and was easily one of the best meals I've had this year!  GO!  NOW!

I was dining with three others, two older folks, meat & potato types who are certainly not "foodies" and a friend who usually follows my lead.  I had to convince the others to try the octopus.  The Pig Face frightened them all, but I had read other Yelp reviews, In particular, Michael U of Las Vegas, and he has impeccable taste...so Pig Face it was (even if I had to eat it all by myself!)

Suffice it to say that everyone was more than pleased with my choices and all tried the Pig Face, which is just as good as others have described.  Don't let the name scare you, it's utterly delicious!

Everything was perfectly executed and enjoyed.  The taste combinations were satisfying enough for any discerning foodie (ahem) and also your meat & potatoes crowd.

My advice, take a few people so you can get a good range of tastes.  Your guests don't need to be particularly adventurous...but if you are the foodie in residence, you'll be delighted.

pics.caption: Miso butterscotch budino heading to my mouth!

review.des:
This place is amazing!  I absolutely love the atmosphere, the service, the drinks, and of course, the food.

We tried everything and will be going back.

Go in a big group, try everything, and make a reservation long in advance.  Enjoy!

Five stars for Girl & the Goat!! Boyfriend brought me here for my birthday dinner. We had a reservation for 9:30, but got seated a little after 10 because we wanted to wait for the table next to the kitchen where all the food comes out. First off, I loved where we sat and it was def worth the wait. You get to interact with the chefs and you get to see your food made right in front of you. It's like real life Iron Chef. Secondly, the service is impeccable. Our waitress constantly checked on us, our finished plates were taken away immediately after our last bite, and our water cups were always filled. Lastly, food was amazing!

- Raw oysters (must)
- Goat Liver Mousse (must but super filling)
- Pig Face (must)
- Roasted Cauliflower (meh)
- String Beans (meh)
- Baby Octopus (meh)
- Pork Shank (meh, but to be fair, it was the last dish that came out and I was so full)
- Shiitake Caramel Gelato Toffee Creme (must)

Boyfriend mentioned that it was my birthday and the veggies and dessert were on the house. Felt super spoiled. Best meal in Chicago for sure!!

The dishes come in special order depending on what you order :

Escargo ravioli -1 - plain ravioli sits in very salty liquid
Halibut -5- really good, interesting combination of fruit and vinegar
Lamb - 3.5 - good, very fatty and sauce is too strong
Goat belly - ? Not sure, I think we are greased out by now
Green bean + a lot of uncessary extra flavor, such as the Mayo looking sauce

Need a lot of alcohol or water to enjoy this meal/ wash down the grease and salt.
I would enjoy it a lot better if it comes with bread/ pasta/rice.

Definitely make reservations here in advance! I made reservations two months in advance for a Monday night at 5:45PM and it was already packed when we arrived. We were super excited because they gave us the best seat in the house which is the table right in front of the action packed kitchen. Prices ranged between $14 - $25 per dish and drinks were $13. Between my bf and I, we shared the following dishes:

- Sauteed green beans ($6, on the house): Thanks to our amazing server for giving this to us to try! The beans are more on the al dente side and the pickled shallots/onions and cashews are super flavorful.
- Chickpea fritter ($15): One of my fave dishes of the night. It was served with a warm salad and the chickpea fritters were so yummy with the yogurt sauce.
- Grilled baby octopus ($17): My least favorite dish but my bf enjoyed it. I found this dish to be too smokey and bitter for my liking. I was also bias and comparing it to the bomb octopus I had the previous night at Purple Pig.
- Wood oven roasted pig face ($19): SO good! The meat was incredibly tender and went well with the crispy stuff (I have no idea what that was). The green sauce was bomb and I wish there was more of it.
- Goat liver mousse ($14): LOVE the bread!! It was like a fancy version of a chinese donut but ten times tastier. The liver was super buttery and the pickled toppings give the dish a punch.

This place is a must go if you're in town. Really cool and hip atmosphere with amazing food. They also have a full bar that I sadly did not get to enjoy because I was freakin' stuffed.

pics.caption: Chefs table w/ full view of the kitchen

review.des:
Chef Stephanie is a genius!  She makes food art because that's how your dishes look when it comes out; a masterpiece.

I was fortunate enough to dine here twice in the dining room (once with a reservation that I had made 3 months in advance, and the 2nd a party had cancelled freeing up a table in the back where you have the few view of the kitchen).  Both times I walked out with a giant smile on my face, and with a food baby.  Foodies, you know what I mean when I say food baby.

My personal favorites here are the following:
Roasted Cauliflower
Wood Fired Striped Bass
Pig Face
Goat Empanadas
Bread (pick one.. any one and it's going to be delicious)

So let's break down flavor profiles of said favorite dishes.

V for Vegetable
If Chef Stephanie tried to feed me this as a child, I might have started loving vegetables earlier in life.  The mint and pine nuts in the cauliflower really brings out a savory quality of this dish.  The mint brightens the dish where the pine nuts brings an earthy quality to the dish.  The pine nuts also gives a different crunch to the dish.  The reviews that came before mine are all true!  This is a dish you must have!

F is for Fish
Don't like the goat liver throw you off.  Whatever pre-conceived notion you have about liver, take that idea.. ball it up.. and throw it away.  Just toss it out!  The sweet, sweet bass with the creamy liver aioli is a match made in heaven.  And the mushroom mole gives this typically light flavored fish an edge.  Chef Stephanie brought a new meaning to surf and turf in this plate.

M is for Meat
Bacon.. sayonara!  Step out of that comfort zone and get the Pig Face.  The pig face is melt in your mouth goodness!  One bite and you'll realize that this is the best cut of pork.  Fatty, buttery goodness!  

Goat Empanadas are topped with grilled mushroom giardiniera and I cannot get enough of it!  This is the perfect dish to break the ice for your friends who are a little antsy around new food.  As another Chef had once said, "If it looks good, eat it!"   (-Andrew Zimmern)  Here's the thing.. Goat meat is a more tender meat that almost has the consistancy of a slow cooked brisket with a milder taste than beef.  They won't be able to tell that its goat.. they'll think its beef.  Then you can drop the bomb that they tried something new!  Help broaden their taste palate!  

And lastly... the bread.  Omg!  The fresh bread is to die for.  The bread menu changes which makes it exciting!  I had the Apple Bread (forgot the exact name), the Jack-o-Lantern, and the Green Bean Casserole.  If I could.. I could've eaten all 3 bread rolls in one sitting but I guess that's frowned upon.

Try to save room for dessert.  The Miso Butterscotch Budino is my favorite of the 4.  Its really hard because the PB&J was a close 2nd.  The crunchy brittle with the soft butterscotch budino... Yummo!  Its a little denser than pudding and the best culinary creation ever!  

The best part of my time here, was that I saw Chef Stephanie!  And she took a picture with us!!!! #geeked #celebsighting #bestnightever

Yes, i am done with my novel.  If you managed to read all this, thank you!  I could go on about this place!  Better yet, I hope this made you hungry and motivated to go here!

pics.caption: Must try a bread. This is green bean casserole bread with green bean relish and caramelized onion cheese

review.des: I wish there was an option to give this more than 5 stars. I was visiting from out of town for a Girls weekend with friends from college. We had originally tried to make reservations a week or two out but there weren't any good times available - so we figured we would just drop in, put our names in, and go grab a few drinks at a bar nearby while we waited. We got into the restaurant and a reservation had cancelled so they said they could seat us. When I say this is the best food I have ever had, I'm not kidding. The three of us split 6 plates and all of them were amazing; goat empanadas, scallops, bread with whipped feta. Our waiter said they change the menu pretty frequently but it won't matter - everything was AMAZING.  Also, my suggestion if you want to go to this place, make a reservation pretty far out. We lucked out with the table but probably would have had to have waited 2+ hours. Still would have been worth it though.

I've head of this plave, but then I went. Our server was a legit expert, cared about the experience, and meant everything he said. Everyone's food was excellent. My chicken sandwich was the best chicken sandwich I've ever had in my life easily. The broccoli side was interesting as hell. Just go. This place deserves every bit of its reputation. Chicago is the best food city in the world, and this is one of our best places. Go.
I enjoyed my time there! It's a must do for tourists in town. The service was great. The atmosphere was very nice as well.

This place was recommended by many of my friends and it did not disappoint. I was told to call and make a reservation months ahead, luckily, the date I was in town visiting was available so we booked it.  The atmosphere is very laid back and chill, the dress code isn't strict and everyone seems to be having a great time. The food is very good and came out one dish at a time. This way, it allows you to enjoy them one by one while enjoying a good conversation with whomever you are with. My favorite dish here would have to be the pig face, the taste is perfect, not too salty and very tender with exploding flavors in your mouth. If you are visiting from out of town, definitely make a reservation ahead of time and give this place a try.
This place is soon good! Definitely bring a few people so you can try a lot of dishes! Pig's face ham frites, and the chickpea fritter dish were all amazing. Their breads and dips are soon good too!

This place is incredible. My dad took me here for Christmas. I can't even explain how amazing and luxurious this food is. Breathtaking flavor and textures all around. This place is incredibly pricey though, so save your money up before you go!! We were lucky enough to get a waitress that did more than impressed. She let us try the signature, off menu dish, Duck a la Carte for free, hooked us up with THREE DIFFERENT DESSERTS, and chatted with us for a long time. I forgot her name, but we owe her one for sure. I SO RECOMMEND THIS PLACE!!!

Wow this place is busy. Glad that I was able to get in and order thru the lounge area. Friendly folks.. Loved the scallops in curry salad but pricey at $18 for just two.  Konrobhi salad just ok.  I like the girl and the goat artwork.  PACKED and difficult to get around. Shows that they have a great following. Make reservations way in advance if you want to sit at a table.

I was there this past Thursday and everything was amazing. The hosts were great, they had us seated writhing 8mins of arrival, and the waitress approached us right away.
She had given us the means and explained how to order and the amount of dishes we needed.
We ordered the cauliflower, pig face, grilled chicken, grilled octopus, calamari, wood grilled oysters, scallops, and fries.
I wasn't expecting the oysters to be raw since it started grilled; they had brought us fried oysters instead. It was served with egg, and it over powered the taste.
The scallops were my favorite dish. They were perfected browned, and had a great texture. The cauliflower was a great pair. The grilled octopus was amazing! So much flavor! They used citrus and pine nuts, wouldn't get enough of it.
I love that they serve small plates. It's great for sharing and gives you the opportunity to try multiple things.
Will be back for sure.

Amazingballs!! Eclectic, creative, a true taste bud excitation. One spectacular dish after another served family style. Trevor was a sensational waiter who complimented the meal perfectly. Perfect nite with friends!

Best food on "restaurant row."  

My former boss and I were fortunate enough to snag a table here during a snow storm and what a treat!!!  We were seated at the portion of the restaurant where you can literally "belly" up and watch the chefs in action!  

The food was BEYOND fantastic and the experience was one I'll never forget!

Yum!!!
The food is really good, especially pork shanks, pig on the face, butter chicken. I really like the cauliflower fry also.

First, let me start out saying how much I have been wanting to come here for years. I live in Nashville, TN and was in town for vacation for the first time in Chicago, so I got my chance and boy was it everything and more I thought it would be. Oh, and reservations are a MUST!

The atmosphere was buzzing at 8:00 PM on a Thursday evening. We waited about 10 minutes for our reservation so we enjoyed a simple cocktail from the bar. I was immediately immersed and drawn to the back of the restaurant where at least a dozen, give or take, people were in the kitchen with a  razor sharp focused sense of chaos.

After we were seated, our server greeted us immediately and went over anything we had questions about and then some. We ordered the scallops, wood fire oysters, shishito peppers, the goat empanadas (on the house which was a fabulous bonus!!), the amazing halibut, and ham frites for dessert.

The halibut by far was the best dish of the night. One of the best dishes I have had in a very long time, actually. Every note sang in unison on my palate. It was perfect.

We ended the night with a great beer our server recommended and was served in a glass that had subtle but the perfect amount of detail. Even our "doggy bag" added a hint of humor.

Over all this restaurant exceeded my expectations from the moment we walked in to the moment we walked out.

review.des: Love Love Love! Came with some girlfriends after being at another spot in River north and it was great! We had already had dinner but ordered some appetizers and wine. The head sommelier, Cassie, came over to our table and introduced herself and give us a mini intro to our wine! it was sweet! I'll be back!
I think the long awaited visit to here created far too high of a bar for this restaurant. It's good, but incredibly greasy and rich. I wish I'd gone sooner before I expected too much out of it.
Ended up at this place since the wait at Au Cheval was 3+ hours. Ordered the burger & fries, along with the tomato soup. Not a bad meal. Will definitely come back and explore other items in the menu.

I love Stephanie Izard and love the food at the Little Goat Diner. I really wanted to like Girl & the Goat, but I think they were overrated. We ordered 5 dishes, and I only enjoyed the duck tongues the most. Most of their dishes were too salty! I had to drink a lot of water to wash down the saltiness away. Overall, the food just tasted decent - not mind-blowing.

We were a bit confused with the naan that came with the pork shank dish, but the pork was cooked perfectly & went very well with the spicy sauce.

Other than that, I prefer eating at Little Goat Diner.

The food and drinks here were so amazing! The service was exceptional, and the waitress was very informed of the menu and made excellent recommendations based on what you were looking for. It was definitely a smaller restaurant than I was anticipating - we sat pretty close to the party next to us. Excellent restaurant, highly recommend!
I want to die and go to heaven after this meal. smoky flavors and rich. ate too much to the point of being sick but worth it.

This was best restaurant we went to during our stay in Chicago.  We lucked out and went on Thursday right when they opened.  No wait and surprisingly wasn't packed.  We ordered five dishes - himachi, beet salad, goat carpaccio, duck tongues, and pig's face.  Everything was delicious and the portions were just right for two people.  Definitely a "splurge", but it was worth it.

This was the best restaurant I have been to in the past year! The food was delicious and unique. There were so many options it seemed overwhelming. Get a few things and share with your party! The cauliflower and broccoli were amazing! This place is SO busy you need reservations! Or you can try to sit in the full service bar and/or lounge. Definitely recommend!

Any place with over 3000 yelp reviews is a must for me when traveling, so I set an alarm, made my reservation 2 months in advance, and made it there last week (October 2014).  Having so much coverage and such a high score set expectations very high, which usually invites an inevitable disappointment, but in this case it met those expectations.

The place is so big that I can't imagine you'd be turned away if you called for a reservation same-day.  I think you'd also do fine if you arrived at opening, or were willing to sit outside on a brisk autumn day.  

Cost/Value: my group of 4 was stuffed and the bill just topped $100 before tax and tip, so I consider that pretty good value.  I think you could dine even cheaper if you stuck with several of the vegetable dishes, one bread, and 1 or 2 meats.  If I lived in Chicago, I'd be here frequently, and that's how I'd do it - focusing on the greens.

Absolutely order a bread, or maybe 2 with a group of 4 - there is a lot of inventiveness in this, and the result is really tasty (not something I say a lot about bread).  JOHNNY APPLECHEESE was my choice and it was awesome.

For vegetables I had the GREEN BEANS (amazing, as stated often here), the BROCCOLI (grilled and with blue cheese - Ummmmm!).  I could have easily gone with the cauliflower as a third choice and become an unofficial vegan without even touching a meat dish here, and still given G&TG 5-stars.

HAM FRITES were good, but I think they fill the belly a bit much.  If you only visit here once, you may want to save room for other items.  On the other hand, if you go with extra veggies, the fries would be a good way to complete the meal.  But you should save room for meats.

NY STRIP TARTARE: amazeballs.  Not ground meat, but sliced cubes.  Didn't think I could find as good as in Paris, France, but it was.

SUGO: had to look up what this was, and apparently it is a type of Ragu (sauce) made (in this case) with goat, beef and pork.  The pappardelle noodles are more like lasagna-noodle size, but again it was delicious.

CRISP BRAISED PORK SHANK is twice the price of most other dishes, but it's a signature item and it is amazingly tasty.  I was a little full at this point in the meal to appreciate it completely, but had I avoided the frites this would have been a home-run.

If I could have eaten anything more, it would have been the naked cowboy oysters, and the budino dessert that gets such universal raves here.  But by this point I was stuffed and completely satisfied, with some leftovers to go.  A perfect meal in a great neighborhood.

If you are ever in Miami, the closest "comparable" place would be Pubbelly, which I also love.

pics.caption: Ham frites, NY tartare, Johnny bread

review.des: This was the best meal I may have ever had. And I've eaten at some of the best restaurants in the world (not meant to be pretentious but only to highlight how amazing the meal was). We had Michael as a waiter. He was working off the bar area.  He may have had made the meal bc he corrected us on what to order - and he was right!! Cannot say enough good things. It was a wonderful dining experience & a wonderful trip to Chicago!

First stop on our touristy long weekend trip to Chicago! We've asked a lot of people for where we suggest to go to on our trip and more than a few say the Girl & the Goat.

We came here at a semi-off time of when it opened at 4:30pm and was so glad we did because the place filled up quick! This place says that it's a tapas place so we thought that we should order more, but the portions are huge considering they're tapas.

Breakdown of what we got:

- Johnny Apple Cheese: aside from the cleverly hilarious name, the cheese butter was sooo good! Total melt in your mouth I can have this as a meal in itself status. The bread was amazing as well. It was super light and fluffy. Great starter.

- Roasted Cauliflower: This was cooked perfectly and had really good flavor. Not just a typical healthy boring cauliflower dish.

- Chickpea Fritter: A lot better than I thought it would be. A lot of good flavors as well and all the veggies were really good.

- Grilled baby Octopus: YUM! One of my favorites. The octopus was cooked perfectly and the lemon-y sauce that the make it with is amazing!

- Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face: Could this be cooked more perfectly??? The pork was super melt in your mouth tender and the skin was perfectly crispy. The sauces were amazing and the egg added a nice touch. A must get.

- Confit Goat Belly: this was cooked pretty much the same way the roasted pig face was and it was just as amazing. I didn't like boubon sauce as much, but the goat and the lobster it came with was really good.

Overall, there are a lot of raves. I would definitely recommend if you are visiting or even if you live in Chicago.

SO SO SO good!  What an experience! Definitely make a reservation (we called 3 months in advance and could barely get in on the night we requested).  The food is so unique and flavorful and they have a ton of veggie options which was great for my Dad.  Such a cool concept.  If you're in the Chicago area and you have time, eat dinner here for sure.  Also a sister restaurant across the street that's more of a diner setting.  We didn't eat there but heard good things.

Goat empenadas, halibut, chickpea fritters -- all delicious. Foods that might take you out of your comfort zone but you won't be disappointed. A little on the noisy and darker side but still an enjoyable experience.

I've eaten here twice and both times felt like I was sucked into some trendy magazine's reviewers poll.  The food is fine.  The service is annoying.  I don't eat goat head, so that's off the table.  Nothing special and would not recommend to friends or out of town guests.

I was lucky to find a reservation for the same week since most people book weeks and months in advance to eat here. Coming here I was expecting an excellent meal and that I did receive. The pig face was moist and really fatty. The crispy pork shank had lots of meat and comes right off the bone. We also order the empanadas and it delicious but only 2 tiny ones in a serving. Also had the broccoli and it was heavy on the cheese. This place does live up to the hype but it's food I can eat maybe once a year.

Fun atmosphere, interesting assortment of food. Must be a real foodie to enjoy the flavors.  I enjoyed it, my kids, not so much.

The service was outstanding. I doubt I'll go back, but it was enjoyable.

I know, I know... it's about time I finally took the time to dine here but who knew EVERYTHING would be so amazing!

Owen was our server and he was so on top of checking in with us and was such a pleasure to chat with. He also made great suggestions!

The ambience of the restaurant is perfect because it wasn't too quiet nor was it too loud.

It was the perfect place for #chicagonom nom and #eatalizing!

We ordered:
Sautéed green beans
Roasted cauliflower
Calamari bruschetta
Braised beef tongue
Crisp braised pork shank
Sticky spiced squash Cake and
goat cheesecake

review.des:
Due to my admitted naivety, this might be one of the more objective reviews about Girl & the Goat you will read.

I came into this meal with very little backstory about Stephanie Izard, other than knowing she won Top Chef and/or Iron Chef (???) at some point and everyone seems to like her cooking. I Googled her mid-meal and I think she was working the night we were there, which means this is a good representation of how things should be/taste on a good night. While I might seem like a rookie to eating good food, the truth is I've been in China for the past five years and I seem to have missed the memo about why this restaurant is so special (it's the goat, right?). I try to identify the most highly rated, semi-affordable places (this is why I didn't go to Alinea) in the cities I plan to visit whenever I come back to the States and this place kept popping up, so I decided to give it a shot.

Our reservation was for 5:30 pm and when we arrived, the restaurant was already packed. We were squeezed into a two-person table with couples on both sides of us, less than an arm's length away. We could hear both couples' conversations clearly and it was super awkward. My wife and I tried to rationalize the lack of space and stifling noise by repeatedly stating that this was a popular, trendy restaurant and we were just lucky to have gotten reservations earlier than 9:30 pm.

My wife wasn't very hungry, but I had already walked like 20,000 steps, so I was starving. We got four dishes: softshell crab, cauliflower, pork shank, and goat empanadas plus the brioche, mainly because it was cheap and had decent reviews.

It was a reasonable amount of food, but I still got gelato at Eataly afterward.

The brioche came first. It was warm and fluffy, and the butter/jam combination was interesting. Definitely worth the $5 we paid for it. The goat empanadas came next. The goat was less distinctively "goaty" than I would have liked (tasted like carnitas), but the combination of avocado, cheese, and fruit salsa made this an excellent dish nonetheless. The softshell crab was fine, but not spectacular or unique. I love softshell crab more than most things in this world, but I wouldn't order this dish again...I'd probably try the calamari bruschetta for a fish dish instead. The cauliflower looked great when it arrived, but the excess amount of cheese made the dish way too salty and covered up the subtly sweet taste that roasting and caramelization brings out in cauliflower. I make better cauliflower at home. We didn't finish the dish. The pork shank was great, but I don't think I've ever had a pork shank that wasn't great; it's a meat that's difficult to mess up due to its high fat content, kind of like a chicken thigh. The buffalo sauce was fine (I would have liked it spicier, but my wife would not), as was the buttermilk dressing. The grilled onion/radish "kimchi" was not kimchi and did nothing for the dish, but I appreciated the extra greens to help with digestion. The naan was charred and chewy, as it should be. There could have been more though.

Overall, this place was decent, but I'm not sure it is worthy of its epic status on Yelp. Also, at $50 per person including tip, I don't think the dishes justify the prices. None of the dishes we ordered included any super premium ingredients (e.g., foie, truffles, caviar, lobster, uni) and they were all pretty small plates. While we were full by the end of the meal, it was mostly because of all the bread, cheese, and fatty pork we ate. The service was fine, but I saw a review that compared it to a three star Michelin restaurant, and it DEFINITELY was not that good. The waitress came to take our order almost 15 minutes after we received menus.

I guess this is a good restaurant to take an out-of-town foodie friend or a large group of yuppies and/or hipsters, but I wouldn't bring my mother (like the person next to us) or someone with whom I wanted to have a meaningful conversation.

I honestly think a lot of the 5-star reviews are due to "group think" and people tend to give it an extra star because they FINALLY got a chance to eat here (usually for their birthdays) after months or years of anticipation. If this restaurant was started by some smelly no-name dude with a gut and an off-putting personality and you came on a random weeknight after a long day of work, things would probably be different.

But yeah, this place is fine.

If you've never had Bestia in Downtown Los Angeles, then Girl & the Goat may come off as a one of the most adventurous journeys you've ever taken your taste buds on...HOWEVER...since I've already experienced the orgasmic, mind blowing, thriller that is Bestia--the Girl & the Goat was simply...alright.

Food wise, like Bestia--tapas style--using a mix of eclectic modern ingredients to spice up  relatively familiar tapas...except everything at Girl and the Goat was 10x saltier than it should have been.

The grilled baby octopus was very soft and tender--but super salty.
String beans w/ anchovy sauce---crisp and fresh--but super salty.
Beef Tongue--mediocre at most--but super salty.
The best was probably the pork face--had a very comforting creamy taste, probably thanks to the egg yolk. --okay salty...
Raw oysters were good and fresh.

Service is excellent.

I had a few other things there but I suppose it was not as memorable as I'd like--but the hype definitely did not meet my expectations.

Get the pig face, the roasted cauliflower and some bread! The food was SO good, even better than I expected-- I've hoped to go to the Girl and the Goat ever since Stephanie opened it, since I'm a massive Top Chef fan--but the service was just ok.

We knew it would be difficult to get in without a reservation, so since we had a more flexible schedule, we set our goal at getting there early. We arrived at about 4:10 on a Friday and there was nobody waiting, so we got to put our names down first. We were told we could be seated right at 4:30 but would have to leave by 6, which was fine, since we had a flight to catch.

We were seated facing the kitchen (awesome!) at a big table that could fit about 8 people, but then about 10 minutes later, two people were seated in the seats facing us (weird!). I'm not sure why they do that, but I still liked watching the cooks work. We saw Stephanie Izard in the kitchen! She was super hands-on, both cooking and expediting. I was too chicken to ask for a picture, haha.

We started with the jack-o-lantern bread ($4), which was super soft (though with a lovely crust) and cheesy pumpkin bread served with brown butter butter. I could have just eaten that for dinner and been thrilled, honestly. They bake it across the street at the Little Goat Diner and it came out really warm. Then we got the beet salad ($9), which was probably the least exciting thing of the night, but it was still good. The wild striped bass was so surprising and delicious-- I didn't know how the mushroom mole and smoked clams would really work with it, but it was such a great combination. The fish was perfectly cooked-- it was soft but had great crisp skin.

Then came two of my favorites: the roasted cauliflower ($10 I think) and the pig face ($15 I think). I wish I could make my cauliflower so well at home! The pine nuts, parmesan, pickled peppers and mint (which was unexpected) really brought the whole dish together. Our waitress encouraged us to turn the pig face into a hash with tiny crispy potato strips and a fried egg. The whole mess was really crunchy and fatty and fantastic-- GET IT!

The goat loin ($22) was good since it wasn't too goat-y. I didn't know you could cook goat medium, but it was basically like a steak. It came with a autumn squash mix and "goat xo sauce," which was mysterious but tasty. However, I couldn't stop thinking about the previous two dishes, which were definitely my favorites!

The portion sizes are really reasonable for a small plates place. With the five dishes (plus bread) that we got, we were stuffed.

Finally, some complaints about the service: The waitress took a long time to take our orders (I think it was around 4:50 when she finally did, and since they wanted us out quickly, I felt like she should have moved things along). This is probably kind of nitpicky, but I didn't like that she said she was there to "hang out with us" that evening. I'm all for casual, but I feel like that's just kind of weird! Also, though she told us to trust her with the food pacing, the first couple came out pretty quickly, then there was a long gap before we got the pig and the goat.

I hope to visit again with a reservation-- I'd love to sit at one of the seats right next to the expediting station, where you can watch everything in the kitchen super closely.

review.des:
Definitely make reservations in advance!! I made a reservation over a month in advance and barely got a 5:00 slot.

After hearing so many good things about this place and how it's Top Chef's Stephanie Izard's restaurant, I was super excited to try this place and had really high expectations. Maybe I expected a little too much because everything we tried was pretty good but I wasn't blown away.

My husband and I shared the following:

ROASTED CAULIFLOWER w/ pickled peppers, pine nuts, & mint. Good flavor. Great for a side dish. It seems like cauliflower is popping up on every menu nowadays. This one didn't disappoint.  

CHICKPEA FRITTER w/ ratatouille, green goddess, & montamore. Loved the green goddess dressing! A small dish, good for a starter. I'd recommend this one!

Pan seared DIVER SCALLOPS w/ smoked uni cream, sugar snaps, bacon plum chimichurri. Yummy! The scallops were cooked perfectly. Had a great flavor too.

Wood oven roasted PIG FACE with sunny side egg, tamarind, cilantro, red wine maple, & potato stix. This is Stephanie Izard's signature dish! And it just sounds so intriguing. Where else are you gonna try pig face?! Overall this dish was delicious! Not gross at all. Don't be afraid to try this one!

CONFIT GOAT BELLY w/ bourbon butter, lobster n crab, & fennel. This was my least favorite dish of the night. It wasn't horrible but I didn't want any more after the first bite. I'd say pass on this one.

Overall, most of the dishes were good but not amazing. I really liked the space though. The restaurant is spacious and has an industrial yet rustic chic, hipster vibe. I think if this restaurant was in LA, it would be like your average new American hip restaurant in west LA. If you're in Chicago, it's good to try at least once so you can experience it, but I probably wouldn't come back.

Best place on Restaurant Row in West Loop, hard to get a reservation but well worth it, always check in to see if their is bar seating.  Great staff and chef, good to hear she is great to her employees.  Great food pairings!

This is the place that everyone raves about and it definitely did not disappoint!  I couldnt call to make a reservation since they open at 5 so YELP was so handy that I made reservations online and it was so simple!  I got a confirmation and everything!  This place is pretty high end and I thought I would have to dress nice but it is a very casual place.  Very cute, romantic, but can get pretty loud!  I came here with my bro, sis, and cousin at 6:30 and we were seated right away.  Our server was very helpful because we wanted to get so many things and is very knowledgeable about how much food we should order.  With her help, we ordered the perfect amount!  We all shared:

Corn Fed Bread ($4)0 goat cheese butter, corn relish.  This was an okay appetizer.  Just your typical bread and butter.  The cheese however was great!

Chickpea Fritters ($13)- These were the best veggie appetizers that we had!  So crispy that even meat lovers would love it!

Sauteed grean beans ($9) This is good after a couple of bites but if you eat a lot, it seems kind of salty

Hamachi crude ($16) crisp pork belly, chili aioli, caperberries.  This dish did NOT seem like $16 bucks because there was just very little on the place

Wood Oven roasted pig face ($16)- sunny side egg, tamarind, cilantro, red wine-maple, potato sticks.  This was super delicious!  Wish there was a little more though.  the face was so tender!

Crisp braised pork shank ($25)- buttermilk dressing, stone fruit cimchee, naan.  Best meat dish we ordered that night!  The meat just falls of the bone and it is so juicy and tender!  I definitely recommend this over the roasted pig face!  

Overall, good place but I probably won't come back here since it definitely leaves a hole in your pants!
Environment is stunning amazing and trendy must try their craft cocktails! An amazing experience! I would recommend to any one

I would say 4 out of 6 of the meals were tasty.

The server was great, but the timing of the meals were lengthy.

Would give it another try, but not at 1045 pm at night.
It's really hard to get a table! So came at 4:30 pm. But it's all worth it! Very creative American food, nice ambiance and wonderful waiters!

Expectations were high and the experience was pure food magic. We had a late reservation so came hungry. The smells capture you as you open the door - we all simultaneously said "oh, it smells GOOD!" With 3 of us in the party, we were able to try 6 dishes. Each one held its own amongst the others - it had its own unique flavors and textures, standing out and fitting in at the same time. I can't think of a time I've been more excited by what I was eating. Servers were great about enabling the experience without extra fuss - the food was the showcase. Well worth about $60 per head (incl 1 drink and tip). A "must" anytime I'm in Chicago!

We had the private room in the basement. 13 course meal. They were accommodating to some folks they may have had an allergy or slightly different tastes. The food was great and the service was perfect. Kept our glasses full!

What can I say? This lived up to every single expectation that I had. For the fine dining experience, it was quite affordable. From the pig face to the goat empanadas, we enjoyed every bite! Will go back as many times as they will allow/whenever I can get a reservation

The food and service was very good but worth reservations months in advance? mehhh The menu is unique and if I could get in without a wait I'd be there in a heartbeat. We are big fans of the Little Goat diner across the street.

The place is also pretty loud so don't expect to do much talking.

Everything here is delicious but a bit on the salty side, still DELICIOUS. I was visiting chicago and my friend made reservations 2 months in advance for a Sunday at 9:30pm for three people. The place was PACKED!!! I think it is always super busy here so make reservations way ahead of time. Decor is super nice and I liked the vibe here.

It's tapas style so you share with everyone. We got 6 dishes between 3 people...I was SO stuffed but I kept eating. Left here with massive food coma.

We got the following:
pan fried shishito peppers- Comes with a bunch of shishito peppers (a little spicy but not too much) covered in parmesan cheese. Very rich and filling.

nantucket bay scallops- LOVE this dish!!! The scallops melt in your mouth and there's a hint of pesto flavor. Mushrooms are to die for.

goat carpaccio- smoked​ trout roe, thinly sliced with fried capers - amazing!!!

wood oven roasted pig face-slices of pig meat with a sunny side egg on top. you mash everything together and cut into pieces- SO GOOD. Meat is on the fatty side so I LOVED itttttt!!! Flavor was amazing.

roasted cauliflower- I don't like vegetables but I loved this!!! The nuts and cheese just are perfect on top of the cauliflower- Decent amount and super rich!

sugo-pappardelle. Rosemary. Cape gooseberrie. The pappardelle pasta is really good mixed with the meat. Loved this dish too.

Overall, the dishes were amazing! The cauliflower, sugo, and shishito peppers were on the heavy side- just a warning. Definitely lived up to its name.

The girl and the goat is an extremely popular spot here in Chicago. My boyfriend and I were visiting for a few days and we were strongly advised to make time to come! Of course when we called to make a reservation the day of, they were booked. The lounge and bar however are first come first serve when you walk in. When we got there the estimated wait time for 3 was two hours. Luckily, we saw this coming and so we put our names down and walked around town for some coffee. We actually got a call back 30 min later!
The host was very kind and welcoming when we got back and the server which greeted us at the table was great. Our waters were constantly full and empty plates were always cleared.
For two people we initially ordered 4 dishes and then later ordered one other dish plus dessert.
We ordered the hamachi which was delicious, fresh, and complex!
Scallops, yummy and light.
Broccoli and blue cheese. Just ok
Pork shoulder, extremely tender. Came with naan, ranch dressing and kimchi dressing. It was also ok.
Crispy beef with grapefruit. Extremely delicious! My favorite of the night. The radishes and grapefruit surprisingly really complimented the beef.
For dessert we had the goat cheesecake. It had a caramel drizzle that was amazing however the cheesecake itself was quite salty.
Finally the cocktails. They were strong! Very good and worth the price !
Overall I think it's definitely worth the wait! And if you can make sure to make a reservation in advance!

pics.caption: Pears of 8 and old fashioned cocktails (strong!)

review.des:
Let's just say, this places lives up to the hype. Get there. Now.

We were nearby in late August and thought it would be a good idea to stop in and make a reservation for the holidays and it was already slim pickins. It was totally worth the wait and we came with a party of 8, which enabled us to partake in a lot of yumminess! I highly recommend you make a reservation and come with a big group, getting to eat that many delicious things in one sitting is just heavenly.

I absolutely love every thing about this place. The decor is stunning, the service is magnificent, and they're very comfortable with food allergies. Our server even crossed out items on my menu that were off limits and noted which items could be altered to remove the allergen.

Every single thing we ordered was amazingly delicious. And getting to try a little bit of everything was great!

We had:
Sauteed green beans - how green beans should taste!
Mrs. Sweet Potato bread - I could have eaten the whole plate.
Johnny Applecheese bread - not super spicy, which was great for me. Yum!
Chickpea fritters - these basically melt in your mouth.
Bleu cheese sweet potato pierogies - I didn't try one of these, but they seemed to disappear promptly.
Escargot ravioli - I love escargot. I would have eaten all of them if they'd have let me.
Calamari bruschetta - tastes good, hard to share.
Braised beef tongue - yummy. More please.
Ham frites - more please.
Wood oven roasted pig face - more please.
Crisp braised pork shank - And more of this too, please.
And something with goat and lobster which was DIVINE.

Of course we also had dessert:
Caramel corn & malt balls - Yummmmm
Dark Matter pot de creme - Yummmmm
Chocolate cake - Yummmmmm

We couldn't have had a better experience and can't wait to come back!

From the atmosphere to the food it was all around an awesome dining experience. I had to sloppy goat with a side of their mac and cheese and my taste buds were jumping for joy with every bite. The prices were reasonable and it was just a different fun place to dine. Definitely recommend it if you are in town looking for somewhere to eat.

One thing to remember: make reservations! For sure this is definitely a place where Opentable will be your best friend and guarantee you a seat. This place is chaotic, it seemed like people were waiting even if they had a reservation. We did make a reservation but it didnt seem like we were going to get seated right away, so we just waited until someone got off the bar spot and sat there. Bar runs in a first come first serve basis, so you have to fight for the seat.

When we sat at the bar, the busser cleaned our spot right away and the server got to us to take the order. The service was prompt and friendly. We ordered the goat liver mousse, which was served with a jar of mousse and breads. Next we got the sunny B breads. The serser failed to tell us that both our dish had breads so we ended up taking the bread with goat mousse home. However the two breads were different styles and I definitely recommend to get the goat mousse since the breads were so yummy and the spread as well. The jellys or sauces that came out with Sunny B were delish and unique as well. Then, we got the roasted pig face since our Uber driver recommended us and we have never even thought of trying face of an animal. The food was amazing! We thought it would be either too chewy or fatty, but their was enough meat and taste to it with a fine, non-disturbing texture. We really wanted to try the duck tongues as well, but we were too full by the time we were done with the pork face.

If I get a chance to be back in Chicago, I will definitely bookmark this place one more time.

Wow just wow!  There are no words to describe how much I loved this place and I'm not sure what I can say that the other reviews haven't said, however I'll give you my experience.  Came here last weekend on a visit to Chicago with my hubs.  It was on my must try list for Chicago.  The only reservation I could snag was 10:15 PM on Sunday night, but hey I'll take it!  We got there at 9:30 thinking we would grab a drink before dinner, but thankfully they were able to seat us early.  We were somewhat worried about the veggie options at a restaurant with goat in the name, however there was a whole column of veggie dishes and even said they could alter some dishes to make them veggie friendly.  Already off to a good start!

What we ordered
Main dishes:
1.  Honey sambal brioche-warm, soft, served with honey butter and this pico type thing; so good:  Grade A +
2.  Chickpea fritters-served with garam masala, yogurt; by far our FAVORITE DISH: Grade A++
3.  Celery and cheddar root pierogies-stuffed with cheese and served with some cream; definitely good but not our favorite:  Grade B+
4.  Pan fried shishito pepper-served with parmasan and miso on top; the BEST shishito peppers I've ever had, these are not your typical shishito pepper (1/2 order):  Grade A+
5.  Roasted cauliflower-served with pickled pepper; this was definitely our least favorite though our waitress said it was her favorite and many others; we didn't like it:  Grade C
Desserts:
1.  Plantain cake-served with chocolate chip gelato:  Grade A+
2.  Miso butterscotch budino-we got it minus the bacon toffee, but still amazing:  Grade A+

Our waitress (Leigh) who was awesome could tell we didn't like the cauliflower, thus took it away and off our bill!  She was attentive and so sweet.  Gave us great recommendations on food and continuously asked if we needed anything else.  She also let us know that you can do half orders of everything including the desserts!  This is a great way to try more stuff!  Our bill for the two of us including two drinks was $78!  Definitely better than anticipated!  

Stephanie Izard you are a genius!  This place was amazing-the food, the ambience, and the service.  This is a MUST TRY if you are in Chicago even if you have to eat at 11 PM!  

Tips:
1.  Get there early and they may be able to seat you sooner then expected or hang out at the bar and grab a drink.
2.  Try half orders of stuff!
3.  Make your reservations early.
4.  Enjoy this fabulous experience!

An outstanding meal.  

It's as good as you've heard it is.

Do you want the pig face?  Yes.  Yes you do.

Joining the masses, the food is delicious. Everything is good. The green beans were the best I've ever had (and as someone who would rarely comment on a vegetable side as if it were notable on it's own, this is saying something), the bread is insane. The drinks are good.

Everything is amazing about the place minus the pain it is to get a reservation. That is truly then flaw. It's hard to get in, unless you're okay with eating RIGHT when they open. If you're game, you can always go and wait for a bar seat, although that can be hectic and ruthless. It's like the Hunger Games.

If you are fancier than I am and you have an in, then go. It's so worth it.

What an amazing restaurant. I recommend the string beans- I could eat them as a main course they were so good! They have the absolute best flavor and they are cooked to perfection. The service was great also!

Certainly a different gastronomic experience. Loved the fried pork shank. Fell off bone. All food original M the homered reservation. Had a great cocktail called ring of fire. Tequila. Fairly expensive.

Sooo hard to get RSVP but lucked out after checking the website for almost a week for a 9 pm dinner.
Heard soo many recommendations about this place.  A MUST WHEN YOU ARE IN CHICAGO AREA.

The Main Dishes here  (also recommended thru Yelp reviews) are:
-Wood Oven Roasted PIG FACE
-Crisps Braised Pork Shank
-Diver Scallops
-Goat Leg (If you have a larger group to share this)

-I also personally ordered the grilled baby octopus which was not bad at all

-Dessert:
miso-butterscotch budino
sesame gelato. sesame whip. glazed pineapple.

Side dishes I heard it was good, but we focused on the main ones which we LITERALLY Drooled by looking at it, then Eating was another story (If you were there with us you would have seen my "OMG DELICIOUS" face expression).

Service was outstanding.  Prices were not Mediocre, Each one started between $ 15 - $ 30 per dish so depending how many are you ordering, plus drinks.  So at least $ 40 per person wouldn't consider overpriced.
This place is amazing!! The food is to die for and the whole restaurant is inviting! Service was great and would recommend to all my friends

Amazing food and service! This was my first time and it definitely lives up to the hype. So much flavor from the normally flavorless cauliflower to the truly incredible goat empanadas to their take on blackened catfish. You can't go wrong! Eat here and your taste buds will be thanking you.

This was a long awaited dinner at girl and the goat.. Well, I should say a quite disappointing one. This place is strict no for vegetarians. As they do no have anything. Though they have a vege menu, it wouldn't be a entree kind, those are just bites. We tried a few cocktails, pretty strong ones, may be not the best to have with dinner. The highly rated restaurant, definitely not my choice.

I was traveling for business to Madison, WI, by way of Milwaukee airport.  Just a day trip. Fly into Milwaukee from Kansas City, drive to Madison for a meeting, then back to MW for my flight home that afternoon.  Fate had other plans. A storm system that consumed the entire region, a cancelled flight, a new/rebooked flight out of Chicago Midway, and a short rental car drive south later, I ended up at Girl & the Goat in the middle of a rainstorm about to embark on one of the greatest meals I would ever eat.
I had heard great things from friends, so I decided I had to try it while I was there, even though I was almost certain I wouldn't be able to get in...  I arrived and after drying myself off in the downstairs men's room, I decided to wait for a seat at the bar (no reservations required).  I luckily chose to wait at the far end of the bar, next to the kitchen and after only 5-10 minutes, a couple stood up to leave, offering me one of their seats.  
4 dishes - Duck Tongues, Magic Beans, Kalbi Short Ribs, & Pig Face changed my perception of what food should be, and I was able to return to Kansas with a full belly, a happy soul, and a story to tell.

The food was uniformly excellent. The string beans with cashews and a fish sauce vinaigrette were perfect. The squash blossoms with crab Rangoon were crisp and perfectly seasoned. The pork shank was crispy, My only complaint was the service. Our servers were like birds of prey waiting for you to put down your utensils to move you through. It sort of felt like an assembly line... very mechanical. They said they wanted to take our entire order so they could pace us through. What it felt like is they wanted to push us through. They said if we ordered additional food we might have to wait for 30 minutes. When we ordered the port shank after the vegetables had been served it came out as a new item in less than 2 minutes. I wish we hadn't felt so rushed and pressured. The bill came as we were eating our dessert. Had it been leisurely enough for us to savor the excellent food I would have given it 5 stars

Absolutely amazing. There wasn't anything that we ordered that we didn't care for. The staff was quick, polite, and gave us good advice as we were a little overwhelmed. So happy we were able to get in on our staycation!

Great, friendly service. Prompt with recommendations from the menu. I also love that the lounge area is fully serviced since we were walk-ins. We ordered the cranberry bread, goat empanadas, goat shank, and beef shank. (I know, impressive menu for two..) Hands down favorite was the goat shank. The meat was tender and slid off the bone effortlessly. Overall, great food and fun vibe. Will easily return.

pics.caption: I'm a fan of bread in general. Love the nutty cranberry mix
Snagged the last goat shank of the night!

review.des: Great food, great experience.  Book your reservation wellllll in advance or you won't get a table!
The atmosphere is different in each dining space. Seriously well done! The food is also amazing. All the details are well thought out.

Making a reservation here is hell, but 3 months out I got a 5:45pm reservation on a Wednesday for 4 people. We were meeting friends that worked Downtown. I arrived early (4:30pm), checked in with the hostess and she said "Just let me know when you'd like to be seated." I waited at the bar and had a drink and a small portion of the green beans. The bartender was possibly the best bartender I've ever had in my life. A few drinks and $60 later we had 3 out of the 4 people for our reservation so we decided to sit. At no time did the hostess ever ask if everyone was there.

We were seated at a nice table up front next to the window. Our waiters name was Jorgan, or something similar to that. It was odd. We placed more drink orders and thought we wouldn't see him for awhile since we informed him we were waiting on our fourth. He stopped by every 2-3 minutes to annoy us and ask if we were ready to order. Finally we said, "it's not even 5:45pm yet, we are waiting for our fourth person." He went away and sure enough 2-3 minutes later came back and sarcastically said "We have another reservation for this particular table at 7:30pm, the hostess didn't know you all weren't here." I said, "The hostess never asked, and again it's NOT even 5:45pm yet!" So at that point he could tell we were all irritated. He still kept checking in, but slowed it down a bit to every 5-8 minutes. He was the worst part of the experience, but the food was amazing.

I enjoyed:

sautéed green beans
fish sauce vinaigrette. cashews

hamachi crudo
crisp pork belly. chili aioli. caperberries

wood oven roasted pig face
sunny side egg. tamarind. cilantro. red wine-maple. potato stix

crisp braised pork shank
buttermilk dressing. grilled spring onion kimchee. naan

Everything was cooked to perfection and delicious.

pics.caption: crisp braised pork shank\r buttermilk dressing. grilled spring onion kimchee. naan

review.des: This is a fantastic spot for adventurous groups of foodies. The crunchy short ribs and pork shank are more than enough reason to become a regular at this great spot. There is a super nice gentleman named Einstein who made our entire group feel welcome and at home. He is a proud University of Southern California alum so if you are a Trojan please say hello and fight on!
Been there done that.  Small small portions, big big prices.  So much ambiance you can't hear the conversation at your own table.  Great chef - just not good experience.

I had high expectations and was not disappointed.

We had: chickpea fritter, braised beef tongue, a massive portion of goat liver mousse (more on that later), escargot dumplings, and for dessert, the grilled baby octopus. The food is exceptional so I'm not going to repeat how awesome every dish is for the 4,576th time, but here are some notes specific to our meal.

We were warned that the goat liver mousse would be "a lot for 2 people" or "were we really sure we wanted that" but the waiter didn't exactly tell us that we would be getting a decently-sized jar (think of a Gerber baby food jar x 2) of mouse with FIVE biscuits. OK, maybe the amount of mousse wasn't that much but for something that rich, when you also have to take down 5 heavy biscuits, it's a bit daunting. Had the waiter been real with us, as in don't get this unless you have at least a party of 3 but realistically 4, we probably would have gotten something else. It was still delicious, though.

The beef tongue was prepared in an interesting way and it was hard to tell it was tongue. The softness of the tongue was lost in the preparation.

If you don't bother to cut open the escargot dumplings, you'd be hard-pressed to guess what it was.

Get the grilled baby octopus. It may sound like an odd pairing but it really works with the pistachios and it's not at all rubbery.

Although I had my complaints, every dish above was still exceptional and I would be happy having the same meal again even if the mousse was a bit too much. That's how good this place is.
Another must when in Chicago! Hip and trendy...and delicious food and crafted cocktails make this a dining experience that will impress!

My wife and I were here recently and the experience and food was amazing.  It just took us a few years to pony up to the reservation months ahead of when we wanted to eat.  Been to many of the restaurants in the family and big fans of each.
Lived up to the hype.  Was able to find a last minute reservation on Open Table.  We had the pig face, pork shank, and goat empanadas. All were delicious. Service was great.

Best food I've ever eaten and great service. It's expensive but totally worth it. My fiancé and I sat at the bar and ate 5 tapas plates and had 2 glasses of wine ($150). If you want a classy place with a trendy vibe, go here.

Maybe my friends and fellow Yelpers hyped it up a little too much.  I expected this to be the highlight of my Chicago trip with my friends saying "the best restaurant you will ever eat at." .. Hmm Ok no

We started with drinks and got a variety of dishes to all share. The pork face was supposed to be a godsend, but little did I know it had the texture of liver. LIVER! This may be a subjective opinion, but I literally cant

We also got the octopus and a variety of other non-memorable tapas. Next time I visit Chitown, I may be more inclined to come here for drinks only.

I think the highlight of the meal was actually watching my drunk friend flirt with our server which was still entertaining.
It's worth all the hype. Literally best broccoli I have ever had in my life, and of course every thing else was delicious!

Sophisticated mixture of texture with unusual pairings.  Balanced.  At least 2 complementary flavors.  I still think it's an excellent value for $$.  

5 dishes for 2 persons was gluttony, plus bread and dessert.

Worthy hearty bigger portions (or grew by 10%):
- summertom bread ($4)
- shishito peppers ($7) is still the best in town and addictive
- octopus ($15) is mixed with bacon and nuts
- escargot ravioli ($15) is plentiful
- date cake ($8) is perfectly balanced and unique

Lean, "that's it?", "how much?" portion:
- 1 soft shell crab ($14)
- Kalbi ribs ($16)
- Stumptown Coffee ($4/cup)

Service and cleanup with multiple plate replacements is unwaveringly great!  The more to enjoy flavors as created.

Venue is loud and table spacing is tight (NY style, pull out table).

The food: 3/5. I feel fairly ambivalent about this places. I've been twice now and the last time I've decided it's not worth my time. We had fries, scallops, trout, pig face and some kind of pork. I know everyone raves about the pig face, but I though it was just average, incredibly greasy and the only flavor and texture came from the shredded fried potatoes on top. Everything else was interesting, but nothing to write home about.

The service: 3/5. The service is attentive, but not very personable. Twice now I found the hostess to have a bad attitude.

Overall: 3/5. G&G is definitely #1 for the most over-hyped restaurant in the city. I'll have to try a lot of other places before thinking about coming back there.

We had a great time at Girl & the Goat. The staff was very friendly and accommodating. They were able to add another person to our reservation with only a few minute wait and our waiter took my friend's food allergies very seriously, instead of brushing them off.

The food was good! I can't say everything blew my mind but I did LOVE the green garlic pierogies. The peirogies were deep fried and crispy and the sauce was bright and fresh-- amazing! We also ordered the olive you bread (super tasty whipped feta), chickpea fritter, calamari bruschetta, ham frites, sugo, and goat empanadas.

I only wish we weren't too full to try some of the desserts!

pics.caption: ham frites and green garlic pierogies
olive you bread with whipped feta and olive oil

review.des: Make sure you ask to sit in Gary's section, he is THE BEST!  Love him!

Solid modern interpretations of farm fresh and goat dishes.  My favorite dish is their roast chicken with Asian flavor influence.  Love most of their vegetable or vegetarian dishes as well.

Where I think they lose a star or two though is value and service.  I will be nice and leave the service demerit vague.

I love this place!!! I've been to several high end restaurants that have all the pizazz, but doesn't deliver with taste. I hate fancy restaurants that give you a tiny portion with ridiculous prices and the dishes don't even taste good. Every dish at Girl and the Goat was fantastic!

We started off with the bread with hummus and a beet relish, which was delicious. I definitely recommend getting a bread to share for the table.
We had 4 people in our party and the shared dishes that we had were:

Hamachi crudo: this dish was good, but I could've done without. It wasn't anything special, but don't get me wrong it was good!

Escargot dumplings: if you want to try something new, you have to get this! I know the thought of eating escargot might scare off some, but trust me, the clam/oyster flavor of escargot is not apparent. Instead, you get a great flavor of the tamarind bacon sauce, crispy onions, and to top it off the awesome texture and taste of the dumpling wrap. Must get!!

Wood oven roasted pig face: this was a great dish as well. You breakdown and mix everything together and the yolk just brings all the flavors together with the pork.

Crisp braised pork shank: this dish is a very good portion. With a table of 4 we were all able to get a good portion of the fall-off-the-bone pork and the awesome sauces they paired it with.

Goat belly confit: awesome dish! The flavors were a little more light and fresh than the roasted pig face dish.

Calamari bruschetta: YOU MUST MUST TRY THIS. I love seafood, but it's so delicate to cook. GATG cooked it perfectly. The calamari was SO soft and flavorful. When you eat the bruschetta and calamari together, the flavor combination is amazing!! We wanted to order another!!

Verdict: I want to go back again tonight, but as you may figure it's hard to get a reservation. With a party of 4, the 6 dishes and 1 bread were more than enough. We were all stuffed and couldn't even find room for dessert. All in all, try to grab a reservation!!
