pics.caption: Bread with hummus and beet relish
Hamachi crudo: this was good, but I would've rather tried something more special for the price. I believe it was $16
Calamari bruschetta: THIS IS A MUST

review.des: I run out of language to describe how good it is. A must-go spot. Very nice atmosphere and really nice service.

I thought it was just A-OK...

A couple months ago, I visited Chi-town with my boo and found G&TG on Yelp. After reading several of the glowing short stories describing their near transcendent experiences crossing into a foodie netherworld of awesomeness, how could we NOT grub there?

Even though many Yelpers warned not too, my girlfriend and I didn't make reservations and took our chances by walking in during dinner time. The host told us that we could wait would be an hour to an hour and a half for a two-person table. She also suggested that we could just sit at the bar (and like most places, did not require an RSVP). Pretty easy choice.

Our server suggested that we order at least a dish from each section (Veggies, Goat, Pork, etc...), and so we did. From what the server told me, the menu changes every several months, but for what it's worth, below is my overview:

Roasted Cauliflower (Mint, Pine nuts, pickled peppers): This was my favorite dish of the night; however, it might have been a tad too salty for my taste. If you enjoy snacking on cauliflower, then this dish is a must.

Escargot Ravioli (Tamarind-miso sauce and bacon): Solid. I appreciate how the raviolis were perfectly al dente. Unfortunately, I thought the bacon was missing from this dish (like LeBron in the 4th Quarter) and can't say if the sauce was very memorable.

Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face (Sunny side egg, tamarind, cilantro, red wine-maple, and potato stix): No thank you. I just feel that it's over cooked and salted. I can't recommend this one.

Confit Goat Belly (Bourbon butter, lobster, crab, and fennel): It was decadent, dreamy, and savory. With these ingredients, it's hard to fail. Not much to complain about here.

Rhubarb Shortcake (Horchata tapioca and "Cinnamon toast crunch"): It was fine. I enjoyed the tart and sweet, but not so much the tough texture. It's definitely interesting, but I wish we ordered a different dessert.

Service: Attentive, friendly, and fast - just simply outstanding!

Atmosphere: Spacious, hip, and loud - it seems like a hotspot for young to mid-age professionals. Trendy decor helps set the mood.

Should you try Girl & the Goat? I think so, if you're a food nerd that makes it a priority to indulge at a restaurant and don't mind paying about $. Would I return the next time I'm in Chicago. Probably not.

Waited to get a reservation and was really unimpressed with the food although it is supposed to be amazing.  Would not go again but I feel like I must be missing something because everyone loved it.... maybe ordered too many rich foods at once.
Awesome food and flavor combos!!! We were lucky enough to walk in and get a table for 3 and it was a wonderful experience.

My husband and I celebrated here a little while ago. Be sure to make a reservation well in advance. The restaurant gets very loud and the seating is very close knit- not conversation friendly. We came for the excellent food and service, so we didn't mind the loud atmosphere or the beer that was knocked over resulting in a messy spill. The server was apologetic, replaced the dish that got soaked and treated us to a delicious dessert on the house. Can't wait to be back

Excellent!

Don't take yourself too seriously. It's an experience, so jump in with both feet!

The food here was incredible and the service was very good as well. Of the seven or so dishes we ordered, the Confit Goat Belly & the Sautéed Green Beans were by far the winners of the evening. The Calamari Bruschetta had a stronger fish flavor than we had anticipated (though was still alright); other than that, everything was truly delicious.

My only minor gripe is the atmosphere; the lighting is very dim, which perhaps adds to the atmosphere until you're stumbling down the stairwell into the similarly dark and rather confusing unmarked bathroom hallway, or your table mates are trying to read their menu and whip out their super bright iPhone flashlight. It's also super cold in here for some reason, so bring a warm sweater.
Great menu...unique. Halibut is fantastic! Start with pan fried shishito peppers then do escargots...kitchen style do it all! The ambiance is very eclectic...hot spot.

This place is a bit over-hyped (and overpriced), but I have to give it to them. At least they were very adventurous with their flavor combinations. Some were not quite successful though... which is disappointing to say the least. Maybe my expectations were too high. Out of 7 dishes only two were a hit and the rest were blah and mediocre. Not bad dishes, but not amazing. I'm usually not a fan of salads but the kohlrabi salad was impressive. Almonds & fennel gave it an interesting taste and texture. The duck tongues was delicious and reminded me of a fried sweetbread (a soft creamy texture inside). Overall, I would definitely give this place a try, but don't have too high expectations.

We waited two months
I expected something grand
But was left with "meh"

The food was tapas
And rapidly brought to us
With a short wait time

It seemed over priced
The servings were really small
With okay flavor

The best meal our night
Was just the cauliflower
And none of the meat

Hold up going here
Until the wait list has gone down
It ain't worth it yet

After trying to get in this place for months I finally got reservation. That's when I knew we were heading to Chicago in November. As like our first trip the weather was warm when we arrived and we were in for a deep polar plung. 65* one day 35* the next. But, we were going to the goat this time. Upon entering this place was hopping and really close to packed. This place is really cool and the wife says that she could see Stefanie in the design. The kind of off the wall design factor from the goofy an massive girl n goat painting on the wall. To the burnt charred wall as we walked into the dining room area. There is also a open kitchen sprawled along the back of the place. We were seated in some very close seating arrangements. A big bench seat with mostly 2 tops with a couple 4 tops shoved in. So the food started out slow. The fire roasted oysters were my least favorite dish of the night. They were nearly cooked with no fire near then. We moved onto the cuddlefish or big squid to me. It was tasty and did have some nice fire char to them. Then came out the roasted pig face/ jowls in my world. It was very tender and cooked perfectly. Not long after came out the dish of the night. The goat belly with lobster n crab with a fennel salad on a butter sauce that was plain n simply to die for. The dish was very rich with a load of crab n lobster. The belly a also cooked perfectly and a mass of yumminess. We did finish this meal with a dessert of apple fritter that were there nothing special but worked. In all I'm glad we got to eat here and if I'm back we will try it again.

pics.caption: Apple fritters with a caramel and sour cream ice cream
The goat bacon with lobster n crab and pickled fennel
The pig (jowls)face with a sunny side up egg

review.des:
As many, many food critic and others on Yelp have noted, this place is amazing. We ordered the pork shank, pork face, and green betweens between two people and that was more than enough food. The green bean serving size is huge, definitely enough for a table of four.

If you sleep late, I'd recommend going to the restaurant an hour before closing to see if any tables open up or if bar seating becomes available. It's almost impossible to get a reservation at Girl and the Goat within a reasonable time frame.

My only gripe is the seating area for tables of 2 is packed very, very tightly. So tight that the waiter has to pull the table out to seat one party member against the wall. The two parties next to you will feel like they're part of your group. Prepare for a long night if one side or both are loud/annoying.

Simply amazing food and service. Top restaurant in Chicago for a reason, and I will definitely return. We had numerous different bites, interestingly, they were mostly the vegetarian ones, although we were not vegetarian. So delicious. Also had the short rib dish. I am not a dessert person, but our table of 4 shared two deserts and those were amazing as well. Can't recommend this enough for a visit. Stephanie Izard and her staff have it figured out.
The cocktails were fantastic, but the food was really forgettable. We ordered lots of different dishes and everything was just average. Will likely not come back unless they did a menu overhaul.

We had a good experience at G&G but I believe it to be slightly overrated. The flavor on most of the dishes we tried married well but the salmon did not, the ingredients clashed and it tasted over salted. The blueberry pepper cornbread was wonderful and the green beans with fish sauce was too. Skipped on desserts because none of them were very enticing.

Oh boy...was this place amazing or what!

Don't be intimidated by "pig face" or other weird names. You just have to jump into it and eat! Be sure to make reservations in advance. I heard they re pretty hard to get.

Anyway..the food was delicious. I could not find one thing that I could complain about for the dishes.

I went a while back but if I'm ever in Chicago I would go again. I remember the cauliflower tasted amazing and the flavors for the dishes were superb. Be sure to also get the pork belly and goat neck.

Worth the hype! We made a reservation as soon as we could to finally check this place out while in Chicago.  Our party enjoyed pig face hash, goat belly, cauliflower, bread, and oysters.  Everything was delicious and I'm glad we went outside our comfort zone.  The cauliflower was surprisingly a huge stand out! Delicious! If you have enough people, split several dishes so you can try more items and be more adventurous. I'd never order pig face on my own but a few bites off our shared dish was the perfect amount, and it was actually really good! Top off the excellent food with great cocktails and desserts! Definitely recommend the Girl and the Goat!
THE GOAT  is the bomb and what an atmosphere of a place 100% try them not just for the food but for the services also will go back and YES i RECOMMEND HIGHLY

Crap. I don't even know where to start.

Okay. Never mind. I know where to start. I have always found people in Chicago to be super-friendly and warm. I hail from the land of polite, which is better than the alternative, but I really dig the genuine feel of Chicago.

The Girl & the Goat wraps up all the feels--and puts them on plates for you.
Seats at the bar are first come-first serve so you never have to worry about reservations if you don't mind the bar. AND, if your iPhone 5s is dying, they'll let you use their charging station at the host station (!) And that's just the beginning of the great service.

I started with the grilled octopus, expertly sautéed with green beans, radishes, pistachios and a light but umami-ish sauce that made me happily kick my legs sitting on the barstool like a kid at the ice cream parlor. They even omitted the pork for me. The bites were cut small which made me wish I carried chopsticks around with me. (It wouldn't be the weirdest thing I carry around in my purse.)

My main dish was the grilled duck with kimchee. Unfortunately, the duck was overcooked (medium vs medium-rare) and the flavors unfortunately did not marry well together. But, unless it's inedible, I'm not sending food back so I decided to stick it out. BUT THEN, [Justin] leaned across the bar to me and said that the Duck Tongue was on its way. (When reviewing the menu, I had mentioned to him how much I loved duck tongue but had decided on the kimchee duck.) I was confused and he said that he could tell I didn't like the dish. WHOA. THAT is service, folks. Really. I don't think I've ever had that kind of service.

10 seconds later, the crispy duck tongue arrives and the other dish is swept away. The duck tongue was surprisingly amazing. The small tongues were deep-fried but still soft and chewy. The beans in the dish made me pause but wow, did it work flavor-wise. In between chuckles, I happily gobbled it down.

On my second beer, I looked at the clock and noticed that I was running a little behind to see the Eddie Izzard show, so I missed out on the dessert that was graciously offered to me boo! It had bacon in it, which I don't eat, but the dessert did have the magical words 'bread pudding.' I bet it's flocking amazing. Someone try it for me and let me know how it is!

G&G, you're officially my favorite restaurant in Chicago. Me love you long time.

pics.caption: Grilled octopus (yes!) duck with Kimchee (...) and an IPA

review.des: I took my brother  there for his birthday and it was absolutely amazing.. Service was great and the food we ordered was even better.  I will definitely go back.

Heard a lot of hype from some fairly cool and respectable people, so we decided to give it a try. Our reservation was made at first availability, some 4 months in advance, so our expectations may have been unreasonably high.

The atmosphere is warm, rustic industrial, and the wide open dining room nonetheless provides a sense of cozy inclusion. This could be heightened by the fact that if you have a 2 top you will sit within 2 feet of the tables next to you. This makes it both easy for you to spy on your neighbors' dishes, and hard for you not to make awkward eye contact. But I mean, it's the midwest, be friendly.

We began with the assorted breads and Kohrabi salad. The salad was underwhelming, but the course was elevated by the excellent fruit jam spreads.

Next the braised beef tongue was exceptional, its deep gamey flavor, along with the vinaigrette and salsa verde paired well with the Malbec.

Finally, the vaunted pig face surpassed expectations. It's the cheek, and it was cooked expertly to a crispy outside and savory, tender center.

Our server was fantastic- friendly, attentive, and knowledgeable of the entire menu.

Food: A
Service: A
Atmosphere: B+

This place was a ton of fun.  I went for my birthday and you definitely have to have a bit of an adventurous palate.  I tried things that I've never had before, the most odd thing being duck tongue on a salad.  It was a nice experience for special occasions and to try new and interesting food.

Top Chef champ Stephanie Izard's Girl & the Goat had been bookmarked as my must visit restaurant for my next visit to Chicago for the longest time!

Love that I can secure a reservation through Opentable, though the reservation was for 10 pm on a weekday.

Love the deco and the vibe of the interior. Dark and Cozy.

We ended up sharing:

Girl and the Goatee from Haymarket/A Little Crazy from Revolution

Duck Tongue ($16)
Goat Carpaccio ($13)
Wood Grilled Oyster ($12)
Wood Grilled Broccoli ($10)
Goat Empanadas ($16)

My first experience of Goat Carpaccios was good. The Empanadas though a little too gamy for me.

The Broccoli was amazing and so was the oysters!

Duck Tongue was perfect beer snack food!

I enjoyed the dish but nothing really wow me enough for me to come back for a repeat visit. The flavours were complex but some of them were not balanced.

A good experience overall though!

Every time we visit Girl & the Goat, it just gets better and better.

Highlights include:

Roasted cauliflower: the mint, pine nuts, and pickled peppers together are a fantastic combination of warm freshness that hits your mouth with great texture thanks to the pine nuts.

Wood grilled broccoli: rich and hearty, if you are a vegetarian who eats cheeses this is a must.

Hamachi crudo: hamachi and pork belly you think? But really, it's delicious.

Save room for dessert, because the carmel corn & malt balls is one of the best things I've eaten this year.

Menu hack: you can order half orders of the veggies, so if you are a couple or a small group, order a few so you can try more of them (as they're SO good!).

The very old fashioned and the local 75 went down just nice as far as cocktails go. Very well balanced as well.

Girl & The Goat (G&tG) is more than just a restaurant.  Since its opening a few years ago, it's turned into one of the top gastronomic destinations in Chicago.  Chef Stephanie Izard has tourists and locals alike eating out of her hand.

Knowing all this, I was thrilled when I was able to snag reservations for 2 at 6:30pm on a Sunday evening.  We arrived ~20 minutes early, and the hostess directed us to the bar, where we sipped on cocktails until our table was ready.

I had the "Longest Summer" (Beefeater gin, Breckenridge bitters, cherry liqueur, lemon), while my friend tried the "Unknowing" (Bombay gin, George Dickel rye, malort, amaro, lillet).  Both packed a very strong punch but were also super flavorful and refreshing on a warm summer evening.

Once our table was ready, we (and our cocktails) migrated over to the dining room and browsed the menu.  Literally every single item sounded to-die-for, but we found a nice combination of plates to share.  The food at G&tG is served tapas-style, which was ideal for people like me, who love to taste and share.

We shared 6 different plates, which ended up being the perfect amount of food for 2 seriously hungry people:

(1) Pan-fried shishito peppers with parmesan, sesame, and miso
(2) Duck tongue with tuna and black bean poke, crispy wontons, and piri-piri
(3) Grilled baby octopus with guanciale, fava beans, pistachio, and lemon vinaigrette
(4) Escargot ravioli with bacon and tamarind-miso sauce
(5) Oven-roasted pig face with sunny-side-up egg, tamarind, cilantro, red wine-maple glaze, and potato sticks
(6) Miso-butterscotch budino with bacon toffee, glazed pineapple, and candied cashews

I can't even begin to describe how amazing these dishes were.  Every single one was rich and comforting and packed with flavor (but never greasy or heavy, despite all the pork everywhere).  Special props go out to the duck tongue, which paired with the wontons perfectly.  I also swooned over the escargot ravioli, which had a gorgeously silky texture, and the pig face, which took the concept of "umami" to a whole new and stratospheric level.

Somewhere in the midst of all this food, we also ordered another round of cocktails.  I had the modified version of the "Best of Three" (gin, Pimm's #1, cucumber, lime), while my friend had the "Taglioni" (Cruzan rum, Aperol, zucca, lime, orgeat).  These were both outstanding, and really attested to the top-notch mixology program at G&tG.

Service was top-notch.  Our server was friendly, prompt, and knew the menu inside and out.  I appreciated his forthrightness about the pros and cons of various dishes, rather than the usual "It's all great!" that I get from most servers.

G&tG deserves all of its accolades.  Chef Izard has created a world-class restaurant right here, and I can't wait to be back!

I was underwhelmed. Maybe because there was so so much hype my expectations weren't well calibrated, but there was nothing special or memorable on the menu. It was all 'good' but not able to justify the price. Little Goat diner and Duck Duck Goat are much better options IMHO!

Amazing...loved everything about it!!  The restaurant is beautiful, service was excellent and the food incredible. I tried to eat light and had only the green beans and halibut. Sauces were incredible and everything was seasoned so well.  I cannot wait to come back!

Definitely a must try when you visit Chicago. I had this place bookmarked for years before finally booking a trip. Reserve your tables ahead of time, I recommend even months before. The entrees are shared plates and they come out one by one.

drink - best of three drink was great, asked the waiter for the sweetest drink

We ordered the sautéed green beans which was marinated in fish sauce, really different but tasty nonetheless

oven roasted pig face was amazing!! Flavors meld together and did the cha cha on my taste buds.  the server mixed together the dish for us before I had a chance to take a picture of it with the egg on top. but I'm sure there are 4,000 pictures of it now.

confit goat belly was amazing as well, but I can't quite remember it..

sweet corn kulfi - fancy take on peanut butter & jelly

Wish i could try everything on the menu, but until next time, Chicago.

Girl & the Goat actually just dominates the West Loop. Along with Avec, obviously.

Delicious bread. Pig face delivered as expected. Also we found Stephanie Izard's roasted cauliflower dish so amazing that we went home and made it ourselves at home: stephanieizard.com/recip…. It's actually beautiful. Finally, our waiter told us that the dessert we tried, Pineapple Upside Down Cake, was one they were testing out. I do hope they decided to keep it.

See you soon!

Does anyone need another review for The Girl & the Goat (G&G)? There are over 5K pics and the menu is tiny--I'm just adding to the noise and I know it. But add I must.

The idea of the "unexpected" keeps coming back to me as I think about my experience with this place.

The food here was such a delicate and thoughtful surprise. Why isn't there a progressive goat-focused restaurant in every city? Chef has taken a humble (albeit delicious) protein and added a shocking lightness to it. Without reading any reviews I felt trust that this Top Chef winner would deliver something thing tasty. I was not prepared to see goat a whole new way.

The dishes all had a clean, light, crispness to them. Particularly the goat shank and the broccoli. There is some recognizable spice in the broth the shank was sitting in that speaks to something primal in me. The empanadas and ham frites (sigh--I cannot believe I ate ham anything) were solid and I liked them. Again, while not on a "best of" list, but in keeping with the theme, both were unexpected--I don't think the "ham salt" sold me, but conceptually, I appreciated how it built on an idea.

Can we talk about the short rib? I had not been eating animal protein and decided to eat some at G&G.  That short rib dish (and that shank) made it worth my while. The light, crispy, and dare I say....buttery pieces of meat were perfectly seasoned and tender and delectable. I'll skip the calamari next time and simply get two orders of the short rib.

Chef is rethinking food and how we interact with it at this place. Goat is a humble and common protein eaten all around the world. Yet in America it is an unusual ingredient to see on a menu. So often we see an ingredient as belonging to a certain people or region or cuisine.  All around me people were falling in love with their dishes. Which says that folks are ready to try something "new" and connect with it.

And when I thought I had had my fill, I had the goat cheese cheesecake. I don't care too much for desert--just not my thing---but this hit all my taste points. Hands down this is my favorite dessert. From anywhere. I hate to admit I miss that salty, creamy caramel with the tart goat cheese cheesecake sitting atop a  pretzel crust. I'm embarrassed that I enjoyed his so much. I'm so glad I don't live in his city b/c if I did, I'd be coming here too often. And eating desert every time.

The ingredient -goat--suggests something heavy and filling and complete. But each bite moves your mind to a new and unexpected place. Even the building is a surprise. It is dark and fairly unmarked. But the moment you step inside it is bursting and alive and warm. Like the food being cooked in the kitchen, it plays on and subverts our expectations to revel itself as something altogether different.

I appreciate the balance and I cannot wait to go back.

My boyfriend and I went here for his birthday after reserving a table over a month in advance and it was well worth the wait. We got quite a lot of food and also received a free dessert for his birthday.

Appetizers:

Oysters- We got the fried oysters and they were delicious. Neither of us are big fans of oysters and were hesitant about these, but these were tasty and there was no visible fishy taste to them.

Bread- We got the Johnny Applecheese, which comes with apple butter and chili cheddar butter. Both spreads were delicious and the bread was warm and soft, which made it perfect as a filling appetizer.

Small Plates: Here's where we went a little wrong- we ordered many small plates as our waitress told us that it would be enough food. However, we quickly realized we had ordered too much as the plates come out when they're made.

Pierogies- This was the dish my boyfriend and I decided we both liked the least. It is a strange combination of flavors, but the sweet potato filling made the pierogies too sweet for both of our tastes. The mushrooms that came with it were delicious.

Wood fired shrimp- This is by far our favorite and we would return just for the shrimp. The amount of seasoning is perfect and the shrimp are cooked very well- not too chewy and a good texture.

Goat Satay- This plate came out last for us, so we were very full at this point. We had both never had goat, but it was quite tasty and not tough. It was seasoned well and not overly salty, which both of us appreciated.

Calamari Bruschetta- The calamari were cooked wonderfully in this dish- not too chewy but not raw. There is not a visible fishy taste on the calamari and both of us -who usually don't like calmari- greatly enjoyed this. There is a lot of bread and it is a little bit of a messy dish.

Dessert:

We got a small portion of the caramel corn and malt balls for free for my boyfriend's birthday. Neither of us are huge fans of popcorn but it tasted quite good. We liked the combination of the hard shell chocolate with the soft ice cream as well as the caramel corn.

We also got the dark matter pot de creme. It was a unique variety of flavors due to the chocolate mousse, sesame bark, and salted caramel. The caramel was very salty, so if you like sweeter caramel, this is not the dessert for you. The strangest part was the sesame flavor as that is not typically imagined as a dessert ingredient. At this point, I think both of us were about to burst so we only split a few bites of the huge cup.

Overall, we greatly enjoyed the meal and left very full. Word to the wise- don't overestimate how much you can eat at once. The plates may appear small but quickly add up.

Food was great but the atmosphere lacked intimacy. There was a lot of hustle and bustle in the restaurant as they were very busy. The food is tapas style which I'm never a big fan of to begin with, I prefer to pick a plate for a few courses rather than keep getting small plates of stuff brought to us. We also had a few drinks which were phenomenal.

Wow!!!!!  This place is a MUST try if you are in Chicago.  This place is a must try in general if you love P-O-R-K.

I came in with high expectations and all my expectations were met.

Venue: (5/5) A trendy bar scene and restaurant scene.  Good for all types: dates, groups.... the people are a mixture of casual but also a mixture of beautiful people.  The toughest part is if you can get a reservation.  

Food: (5/5) Let's cut the chase two things I think are the must orders Calamari toast appetizer dish and the Pig Face.  The rest kind of blended together so I won't even mention it.

I dream of the Pig Face dish.

Service: (5/5) Our server was attentive and nice, the open kitchen allows you to observe the chefs, feels as if it is part of the service.

Go here!!!!!

Amazing!!

We ended up in Chicago but did not plan the trip early enough to get a reservation here so we just did a walk on on a Friday night around 5:30. Got seated relatively quick; only a 15 minute wait at the bar!

Must order: PIG FACE. Seriously. Must get the pig face. It was fantastic.... and amazing and every great adjective I can think of.

Breadstick Buns - FANTASTIC!!! Totally adore the tomato jam that it's served with!!!

Avoid: Chickpea fritters - Overrated. They were creamy and okay. Not much aside from that. The brussel sprout salad that it was served with was great but the fritters were "meh."

Crisp Braised Pork Shank - We had pig overload. It was pretty good but don't waste stomach space on it - stick with something a bit more different.

Fantastic service and amazing food!

i've only managed to get here once the entire time i've lived in chicago, but my god, it was one of the best meals of my life. i ate things i would never think to eat (it was a while ago, but i recall duck tongue??) and was blown away by every single dish. the hype is real.
Calamari bruschetta, string beans, and goat belly were out of this world! Great wine list as well.

pics.caption: sautéed green beans, fish sauce vinaigrette, cashews
roasted cauliflower, pickled peppers, pine nuts, mint

review.des: Delicious!  Must try the green beans and the Pig Face - amazing!  We had other items on the menu, which were all tasty!

There are times when a 5 star rating is well deserved and I can't even put a shadow of doubt around it. This one goes on my list of top restaurants not only in Chicago, but in the world (or at least the parts I've visited).

Came here on a Thursday evening a little past 5pm and was able to find a seat at the bar very easily. There were several others available. The music, the service, the vibe, just spectacular. Amazingly, although packed, it wasn't too loud. The noise level was very reasonable and I can see this being an awesome place to take a date. Of course, good luck getting a reservation, you'll need to plan.

Food wise, don't even get me started. The menu is filled with delicacies. As I've taken a sneak peak at the other yelp reviews, got the pig face. It was nice and fatty, reminded me of pork belly flavor with more texture to it. The duck tongues were also delicious. Basically, you will really have to go out of your way to find something that isn't tasty on this menu.

To summarize, a must go to place in Chicago.
My mom and I both like this creative and amazing restaurant! Every time she came to Chicago she asked for this restaurant.
Outstanding atmosphere, fantastic service, food can only be described as experiential. Must try the pig face!

This place is the must go to spot in Chicago!

Made dinner reservations a week in advance for a Monday and the only available spot was at 9:30pm. We arrived a bit early at 8:30 and we were nicely told by the host that they would not be able to accommodate the early arrival. I looked around the restaurant and it was very believable. EVERY SINGLE table was taken with waiters bustling around.

After a drink nearby we came back at 9:30 and were nicely seated next to another couple that was making out (hahaha). We ordered the sausage bread that came out first... spectacular with the butter! For our main dishes we ordered:

The pig face - with the egg on table we were told to just mash everything up and eat it like a hash. After we did that, it was amazing! I'd have to say it seemed like they used alot of truffle oil and salt. The taste was great but was feeling a bit heavy after haha

The Lamb Shank - BOMB! it was flash fried so it had the crispy outside but was fully juicy on the inside. The pita bread was soooooo dam soft. Get some of the pita bread, put some of the lamb shank inside and then some of the side sauces on the side (THE ORANGE TANGY ONE)..... BOMB!

The grilled octopus: Awesome! Thick pieces were grilled and then sauteed with veggies.. it was the perfect mixture of spices. I'd say just the right amount of everything... spiciness, tangyness and saltiness...

The cauliflower: Not normally a fan of cauliflower but it was super soft so that was a plus... it almost didnt taste like the usual cauliflower so to me it was great! hahaha

The place is super trendy with very fast and attentive service. Overall, one of the best places i've dined at.

I placed my reservation a month in advance after a friend suggested this place as a destination during a trip to Chicago. I was only able to obtain a table at 10:45pm so it was quite a late meal, but Randolph St. felt safe enough for a lone male to make the walk back to Magnificent Mile even after the meal at midnight.

In light of the encouragement and hype, I was excited and did my research on what to order. As a party of one with limited stomach real estate, I would have to choose carefully! At the restaurant, I discovered that many dishes could be halved - half the quantity for half the price - which made my work a little easier. Based on this and the many comments here, I ended up ordering:

- duck tongues (whole portion) -- this came out as a starter.
- broccoli (half portion)
- goat empanadas (half portion)
- tiramisu

One of the commenters here wondered whether duck tongues were actually tuna. While there is actually (raw?) tuna in the dish, my waiter confirmed the fried things are indeed duck tongues! The tongues are warm and tender, and when you bite into them the texture is strangely like ... the feeling of a tongue ... and it is probably the closest you will ever come to making out with a duck. I also felt the broccoli was a highlight. The light char and cheesy sauce make this simple dish special.

The empanadas and tiramisu were good but not nearly as unique.

The server brought a second dessert "on the house" - I observed this happening again a few tables down, and have read about it happening to others here, so it must happen fairly regularly. It consisted of a delicious creamy ice cream, peanut brittle and peanut butter foam of some kind, in a grape / red wine vinegar sauce that was quite creative, bringing a sour taste to an otherwise sweet dish.

The service lived up to its reputation... the server was charming and helpful. The "bonus" dessert was nice, but I hadn't budgeted the stomach real estate for it, so I was not able to finish.

I can't think of any way the service or food could have been better, and I felt the price was fair. But I am knocking off a star because I woke up several hours later, at 4am, feeling nauseous and lost it all to the porcelain throne over the course of an hour. I was not drinking or otherwise sick before or after, and I don't have a delicate stomach - this has not happened to me in a decade. It's hard to pin it down, but I blame the fact that the foods were quite fatty and vinegary - the food perhaps a bit too rich and exotic for me.

In spite of the technicolour finish, I don't regret my meal here - it was a great food experience and very creative - though I don't think I will come back.

Overly hyped so there's usually always a wait. Have a drink and stand around until you're called and the food is pretty good. I've had a really good experience here and I've also had a not so great experience here..Not a first choice but if someone wanted to go I'd go again.
This place has an amazing menu ! I only wish I was around to try more of it!! The service was very attentive but the food was the star !

After trying to get into this restaurant forever, I was invited to a private business event and could not pass up the opportunity. Our event menu consisited of kohlirabi salad with fennel and evalon, goat empanadas with olive tapenade, grilled baby octopus with fava beans and pea tips, roasted cauliflower with pickled peppers, pan roasted seabass with klug farm grapes and a vanillabean-herb yogurt, sauteed green beans with fish sauce vinegarette, wood grilled broccoli with rogue smokey blue, and crisp braised pork shank with stone fruit kimchi, as well as assorted breads and desserts.
Stand outs to me were: the green beans with fish sauce, salty crunchy and surprisingly addictive, the wood grilled broccoli with blue , that char really elevated the flavors, the seabass was cooked perfectly and the grapes were a welcome burst of flavor, and the pork shank was out of this world!
I will definitely come back with people I am more familiar with as I think part of the experience was lost with strangers.
My only unpleasantness comes from the weird tiny little "event space" that they had us in. It is literally a storage room in the basement. We actually joked about it because the walk there  was so bizarre we could have just as easily been led right out the back door or into the pot-washing room, very odd. and the room itself was tiny, I mean TINY. Like should have never been booked for a group more than 10 people tiny. Storage racks of liquor bottles lined the room. And it was SO loud down there the speaker actually had to pause whenever people above us pulled their chairs out.
I will absolutely come back, but I will not attend another private room event.
This place was a breath of fresh air when coming to Chicago. Amazing appetizers and drinks. You must go!

Absolutely a fun and lively place with a great staff as well. Every dish brought out made me just want to order more - already daydreaming of the next time I'll be in town to come back here again! Highly recommended! :)

This is the best restaurant I've ever been to. Each dish blew me away. Never knew how much I could love cauliflower until coming here. Had the pleasure of sitting at the chef's table. This place runs like an extremely well oiled machine. JUST GO.

As a pescetarian (vegetarian + fish), I was worried I wouldn't find enough to eat...

Loved the chickpea fritter plate and the wood fired shrimp plate (even ordered seconds on the shrimp). Not as crazy about the calamari bruschetta but worth trying.

Overall, loved the venue and the food. Will definitely return.

Girl & The Goat has class, sophistication and character oozing out of it like the yolk on a sunny side up egg.

Speaking of which, the pig face with sunny side up egg was phenomenal. This was a delightful mix of buttery and crunchy textures and flavors. If my face tasted anything like that, then I totally get where zombies are coming from.

The broccoli is surprisingly exciting for broccoli. It tastes like a campfire speckled with love. The chickpea fritters are also delicious and creamy, with the right bite and crunch.

The goat belly is like dessert. Enough said.

I wasn't too impressed with the breads or the cuttlefish, but definitely worth a try. The empanadas are also a bit forgettable.

Must order the caramel popcorn dessert thing.

In short, I was definitely impressed. It was fun letting my inner Top Chef foodie shine and really experiencing Stephanie Izard's magic. I will be back!

Every time we come here we remember how solid this experience is. Stephanie knocks it out of the park every single time. Great spot for shared plates and a little adventure. I love the cocktails and the atmosphere. This is definitely a come early spot if you don't have a reservation. The staff really helps make the experience and leaves you wanting to return for more. We recently celebrated my birthday here with friends and can't wait to go back!

What can I say that hasn't already been said? The food was amazing, the service was spot on, and the environment/ambiance ideal. Our favorites were the garlic potato pierogies, focaccia bread, pork shank, and peanut butter and jelly sandwich desert. Two things that were only really good (as opposed to amazing) were the grilled broccoli and the tiramisu desert, but both were still tasty. This place is now on our best restaurants ever list.
Terrible peasant food. Pork bellies and raw duck, although somewhat of a delicacy - you definitely need a stomach for this place. I usually eat clean so after I ate a few dishes I had to leave

When I told my friends I was heading to Chicago, this was the IT place everyone recommended so I made sure to make reservations. We got lucky and got dinner reservations for Monday night. It was definitely packed when we arrived.

To start we had the Kohlrabi Salad with fennel, evalon, toasted almonds, apples and shiitake. One I've never even heard of Kohlrabi, but apparently it's a type of radish. I found the dish to be refreshing and full of flavor. You can taste each ingredient on its own as the dressing is not over powering and when you take each piece into one bite, it creates this wonderful taste. I can't even explain it, but I've never tasted anything like it before. All I can say it was a good way to start the meal.  

Next we had the Pan Roasted Drum Fish with autumn crisp apples, szechuan vinaigrette and vanilla bean-herb yogurt. The fish was cooked perfectly, soft on the inside, but crispy on the outside. This dish was also bursting with flavors, one moment it was sweet (vanilla bean yogurt), next it was tangy (szechuan vinaigrette).

Then we had the wood oven roasted Pig Face everyone talks about. Included with the pig was a sunny side egg, tamarind, cilantro, red wine-maple and potato stix. They advise you mix it all together. The meat was soft and fatty, but when you eat it with the potato six it was crunchy.  
Another dish which was unlike any other with the various ingredients.

For dessert we ordered the one with peanut butter gelato covered in the chocolate magic shell and there were bits of chocolate cake. It was crunchy, soft sweet and nutty all in one. We also ordered the donut holes that were on top of an apple granita. The donut was crispy on the outside and soft on the inside. Eating the donut with the cream and apple granita, was like eating a deconstructed apple pie with a glass a milk. It tasted absolutely amazing.

They recommend two main plates a person, but I enjoy how we shared 3 main dishes and 2 desserts.  Overall I'm impressed by the creativity of the dishes and how the flavors vary. I can't say I've had dishes that tasted just like this before.
Been here 4 times now and is one of my favorite restaurants. Seriously delicious. If you come here and don't get Pig Face / shame on you!

First things first, I can totally understand why you have to make reservations months in advance for this place.  AH-freaking-MAZING.

Let's avoid the fluff and dive straight into the food!

Pan Seared Halibut.  Cooked with almond butter, white asparagus, and blueberry nuoc cham.  How creative!  Nuoc cham is a Vietnamese dipping sauce and S.I. put a spin on it by adding blueberries.  Mind blown!  It didn't really taste like authentic nuoc cham,  which is good because I know a lot of westerners who are not big fans of fish sauce.  The sauce was tart with hints of sweetness from the brown sugar and occasional burst of sweetness from the blueberries.  The sauce married perfectly with the slightly salty pan seared to perfection halibut.

I was stoked to order the pigs face.  All the reviews raved about this pigs face.  I thought  the flavors were amazing but it was personally too fatty.  First, pop that little thought bubble of a pig's head on your dinner table.  The pig's face was a circular disk with a diameter of approximately 3 inches.  Now imagine 1/2 an inch running down the center, that was the portion with meat, everything else was fat.   It was served with a sunny side egg, sauce?, and small crunchy potato sticks.  My adorable boyfriend, who is not an adventurous foodie, reluctantly tried it and said "it's like a deconstructed breakfast."  So cute, he's trying.

Cauliflower, I seriously hate cauliflower, with a passion.  When I asked for a recommendation that was the first ting the server gave me.  Really?  The one thing I detest with my life!  Because I asked I felt that I was obligated to order.   As a result, I am an born again cauliflower fan.  It's roasted with pickled peppers, pint nuts and mint.  The cauliflower had the perfect amount of char and saltiness.  It had hints of spiciness from the pepper which was neutralized with the hints of mint.  Sooo Yum.

Kalbi veal chops with strawberry tapenade.  This is a Korean influenced dish that I could have done without.  This says a lot because I absolutely love Korean BBQ.  I thought the sweetness from the kalbi marinade combined with the sweetness of the tapenade was a bit much.  And the meat was over cooked for my liking.

We also tried the Gouda Bacon Bread which I thought was just bread with some bacon in it.  C'mon you can't really go wrong with bacon.

We had a wonderful dining experience.  Loved the decor and ambiance.  The service was top notch.  These people are on top of it.   During my meal, I often saw a guy walking around with an iPad overseeing the the progress of each table's meal.  

Can't wait to go back.

MOUTH-WATERING food!  Now I understand why my friends made a reservation for this restaurant so far in advance.  The place was packed, and the ambiance so energtic that it made me real curious about the menu.  Our attentive server welcomed us warmly and explained the concept behind the restaurant.  The idea here as to share as many plates as possible, which is what we did.  Let me give you my Top 5:

1. Roasted cauliflower (5/5) - NEVER (!!) have I eaten cauliflower this good.  The texture and flavor and the way it was cooked were unbelievable.

2. Goat loin (5/5) - Seriously... WHO makes goat THIS great!?  Tasted like a well-aged filet mignon.

3. Pan roasted halibut (5/5) - Thinly crusted on the outside, incredibly juicy on the inside, with a hint of sweetness.

4. Seared duck breast (4/5) - Duck tends to be fatty, but nope, not this one.  Very tender, much like the goat loin.  

5. Ham frites (4/5) - Never thought of fries as gourmet food, but the cheddar beer sauce builds a strong case.

The only "half star" deduction I would give is that the portions are a little on the small side for my taste.  But Girl & the Goat retains its five star rating due to its prompt service and the sheer creative approach it took with all of its offerings, especially the cauliflower and the goat loin.  I was left very impressed.  An unforgettable dining experience.
Enjoyable small plates with prompt service. I found the menu full of tempting choices. Plan ahead, save room for the chocolate molton cake.

No doubt why this restaurant is the best in Chicago. Wonderful food & great service
However, I recommend you to take a reservation first or you have to come before 4.10 pm in order not to wait for the table.

pics.caption: Calamari bruschetta  Love goat milk ricotta- soft and creamy.  Personally I don't like tomatoes but this dish can change my mind.
Wood oven roasted pig face  Amazing. The roasted pork is crunchy with tiny crispy potato. The combination of 3 kinds of dressing is perfect.

review.des:
One of my favorite meals in Chicago! I definitely recommend making a reservation for this place in advance.  Even with a reservation, we had to wait a bit, but luckily they have a bar with good drinks :) It is best to order family style at these type of restaurants and they suggest 2 plates per person, but that was a little overboard for us because we ordered some of the larger meat plates.

Favorite dishes/must order:
-Pig face!! Get it.
-Goat Liver Mousse- the crumpets that come with this are SO good.
-Pork shank- aaamazing and falls off the bone.

Other honorable mentions:
-Octopus- nicely grilled
-Beet salad- served with goat cheese, good starter
-Chickpea fritters
-Hamachi
-Roasted cauliflower

Skip:
-Crab rangoon

The service was amazing, the servers constantly refill drinks, and make sure your table is clean. The food however, is a little bit of a weird selection, which is ok. The food tasted fine, but I honestly wasn't blown away by anything in particular, so I'm not sure what the hype was about. I also come from Miami, which is a deeply foodie town with lots of unusual dishes and tapas styles, so maybe that's why I wasn't super impressed. the desserts we tried were mediocre. It's also really loud in there, you have to yell to converse with your party. All in all it was fine, nothing amazing, but the service was great.
Amazing courses. Never tasted such great goat. Nice wine pairings. Wide variety of flavors. Although it was busy they have many dining options and really great service. Would definitely recommend.

Over 3,000 Yelp reviews, what more can I add? I was excited to get an Open Table reservation a week or so before my visit to Chicago. It was an early reservation on a Thursday night, and when we got there I had the sense that we could have been seated without a reservation. That said, by the time we left, the restaurant was packed.

Everything was delicious. The waiter was very knowledgeable and seemed excited about the food when we asked for his thoughts on various dishes.

The only thing I didn't like was the pacing of the courses. We ordered a bunch of dishes to share and the server said he would course them out for us. But because we were there so early and the kitchen was quiet, the dishes came at us like a barrage. I would have enjoyed a more slowly paced meal.

pics.caption: Chef's props, though she was not cooking tonight
Trout with pumpkin puree, Brussels sprouts and pomegranate seeds

review.des: One of the best dinners I ever had. The shared small plates made it an amazing array of flavors. The service was phenomenal.

They say some things are worth the wait...

I had been wanting to visit Girl & the Goat since we moved to the Chicago area a year ago. As a lover of unique dining experiences and fan Stephanie Izard, I knew this would be right up my alley. But, let me tell you - getting reservations is a chore! I scoured Open Table for weeks, trying to snag a Friday or Saturday dinner reservation, as my M-Th schedule is too unpredictable. I didn't even care what time. (Hello, early birds?) Northing. Then, finally, I realized I could call the restaurant directly. I ended up having to schedule six weeks out, but at least I had something on the books.

When our reservation day finally arrived, we had high expectations. And the food and hospitality far exceeded anything we could have imagined!

The servers were knowledgeable, thoughtful, and downright skilled at their jobs. Our server knew every inch of that menu and did an excellent job anticipating our needs.

The food was great. The cocktails were great. (My husband said the beer was great.) The shared plate concept allowed us to try a variety of items, from goat empanadas to sweet corn pierogis to wood oven roast pig face (yes, pig face). But one of my favorite items was one that we almost skipped; do yourself a favor and order the "Olive You." It is a warm bread with olives baked in, served with whipped feta and EVOO, and it was so delicious!

The downside: I can confirm that other reviewers' comments about the restaurant being loud and crowded is 100% correct. My husband actually commented that he was glad we knew each other already (as in, it wasn't a first date) because there was no way we were going to be able to have any conversation beyond a few phrases shouted across the table. Speaking of the tables, they were so close that each time the hostess seated a couple in our area, we watched her physically move the table out from the half-booth so the person sitting in the booth side could get to their seat. In fact, I could have easily rested my elbow on my neighbor's table.

But, does the food make up for the space/noise issues? Absolutely.

If you're visiting for a short time and aren't able to get reservations during your stay, check out Little Goat, instead. Similar delicious food (more causal fare), but much easier to get in.

Love the name, very unique! I was excited to try Stephanie Izard's restaurant after seeing her performance a few years ago on Top Chef. The only times that were available one month in advance were for 10:30 P.M. on a weekday so if you want an earlier time you should probably book at least 2 months in advance.

We arrived early and asked if it was possible to be seated earlier than our reservation time. The host was gracious and said we could wait at the bar and someone would come get us when a table was available. While waiting we tried the Thai One On, a lovely cocktail with rum, brandy, passion fruit-Thai chile syrup, and bitters. The drink was smooth and excellently crafted. It did taste more like a grapefruit infused drink rather than passion fruit though. We were also slightly disappointed that we couldn't taste more chile flavor in the drink.

When we were seated, our waitress explained that all the dishes are meant to be shared and medium size. For our party of 3 6-8 dishes would be a good amount to order. We ended up ordering 8 which left me pleasantly full but with no room for dessert. Our dishes were the raw oyster, goat empanada, squash blossom crab Rangoon, calamari bruschetta, divers scallops, pork face with fried egg, grilled Walter's chicken, and goat belly with lobster. My favorite dishes were the raw oyster, pork face, and the squash blossom. Each dish in general had a lovely presentation and had a kaleidoscope of colors pleasing to your eye. Overall I enjoyed my meal, but I did notice that the dishes got saltier as the night wore on. The goat belly and the chicken were probably the saltiest of all the dishes we ordered. Each dish ranged from the mid teens to low 20s. I think our most expensive dish was the chicken at $21.

The goat is really well executed here. While most goat meat I've tried has that hint of gamey, barnyard taste to it, this goat meat tasted very clean, almost like a richly flavored beef.

Service was excellent. Water was refilled promptly, dishes taken away efficiently, and we were checked up on as needed. The timing of our dishes worked out well since the next dish would come near the end of us finishing our current dish.

The noise level of the restaurant itself was loud, partially due to the full seating of tables and the loud music playing on the speakers, so we had to shout a bit to each other to hear what we were saying. If you are looking for more of a quiet, laid back atmosphere this isn't your place.

Definitely a spot I'd like to try again if I remember to book way in advance!

Overall 4.5 stars.
This place is amazing. Even things that i didn't normally like were amazing here. Such is the skill and pure raw talent of stephanie Izzard and her team

Highly recommended from friends so these two ny foodies decided to try it out! Best service ever - thank you Ryan! We followed recommendations on how to order and rather than convince us to order more, Ryan filled in the blanks on a few dishes and comp'd them. They were actually the best choices (goat empanada and the flank stake). It was un-pretentious, welcoming, delicious, and well worth another trip. Thank you Ryan and everyone else. Our seats were fantastic - two bar seats overlooking the kitchen. Go go go
Over hyped. Will seat you in the kitchen to maximize revenue.  Food was lack luster.

If you are looking for a fun night out,  Girl & The Goat should be high on that list.  While I have never heard of anyone describing Girl & The Goat as a gastropub,  that is what it essentially is. I will admit we came in primarily for that Top Chef experience.  What we found  was a playful menu, fun lively vibe, exceptionally professional service,  and down right banging grub to go with our craft beer.

We were very fortunate to have been seated at 2 of the 4 seats on the kitchen line.  When they say kitchen line,  they are not kidding!  You are right in the chefs faces and what an amazing experience that was for us.  It was incredible to watch these chefs at work.  The amount of preparation and work is apparent.  Throughout the night,  the chefs kept an upbeat pace and were working with consistency and familiar comfortability.  Not gonna lie but I had to control my inner Alton Brown as I was tempted to narrate more than once during the night.

Girl & The Goat does small plates and breaks their menu into vegetables,  fish,  meat, and bread. We ordered a sampling off each section of the menu and found each dish distinct and well executed. Some of the meat dishes when eaten alone tended on the heavy side but went perfectly well with our beers. The big surprise of the night was the broccoli, smokey from the grill and topped with a creamy blue cheese sauce and crunchy flavored rice krispies, it was a taste and texture explosion.  I had never seen Kenny V. devour any vegetable with the same enthusiasm as he devours meat, and here he was spooning heaps of it onto his plate.  

Overall, we came in for the Top Chef experience and sitting at the kitchen line truly delivered.

pics.caption: Girl & The Goat - view from our table

review.des:
Sat at the bar to eat alone.  My server was friendly and efficient.

But ...

My server had to "explain how the menu worked".  Always a bad sign!  Something to do with the need to order multiple dishes in various portion sizes.  I ordered the red fish (in a curry sauce, with green beans and chickpea fritters as sides.  Unfortunately, each item was served sequentially, about 10 minutes apart.  That made the side dishes sequential appetizers.  That's just lax supervision in the kitchen.

Good:

The chickpea fritters were tasty.

Bad, very bad:

Everything else was grossly over salted (as, in retrospect, other reviewers have stated),  The delicate curry sauce for the red fish could hardly be tasted because of the salt.  Green beans were the same.  I only ate a small portion of my food.  My server acknowledged, with weasel words, that the chef was "... known to be salt-forward".  He comp'ed one side dish.

The wine (by the glass) is served in large tumblers (why not a wine glass?) in very small pours.

Avoid this place until a new chef is hired, or until they run out of salt.

Great atmosphere! We sat and ate at the bar as we didn't have a reservation and wait was 3+ hours. Yet we had an amazing time, the bartender was fantastic, our food came out one at a time we did not feel rushed and everything was delicious.

I had been looking forward to eating at Girl and the Goat since I booked my tickets to Chicago several months ago, and I can honestly say that it was worth the wait. Hands down one of the best places I've eaten at EVER! The service was great, we had a very enthusiastic and friendly waiter that was engaging and entertaining. The restaurant itself was spacious and well decorated, a mix between rustic and modern. (The only downside to the decoration in my opinion was the huge well-lit painting that hung on the wall across from me. It was very Tim Burton-esque and a little bit creepy...). As for the food, wow! Every dish was great and none of them disappointed:

Bread: They change their bread menu very frequently, so I won't rave about the Gouda&Bacon or the Maize&Blue, but definitely get their bread! It's fresh and fluffy and delicious.

Chickpea Fritters: One of my favorites of the night! Crispy on the outside and gooey on the inside with shallots to round out the taste.

Goat Empanada: The meat was so tender and the dish itself was very savory. A little on the heavy side though.

Shishito peppers: A great dish to get if you like spicy food and have a large group to share with. It's a very densely packed dish and filled all of us up pretty quickly. Not to mention, the Parmesan crumbles on every pepper were to die for.

Lamb stuffed calamari: WOW! The most tender squid I've ever eaten, and I usually don't like lamb because of the acidic taste to it, but this dish blended the lamb aftertaste really well with the sauce.

Duck tongue: You must get this!! This was my favorite dish of the night; the tongues are crispy and contrasted with little chunks of tuna, mixed with a miso based sauce and peppers that make it sweet, spicy, savory, and just amazing.

Scallops: These are made in a creamy uni sauce with special bacon bits on top. Another fantastic dish for those wanting something on the lighter side and enjoy scallops (which they sear to perfection).

Pig face: Everyone raves about this and rightly so. Enough said.

Desserts:
Sticky date cake: really good but very sweet and heavy. Two bites are enough to be satisfied because of the rich taste.

Rhubarb shortcake: Fresh rhubarb..what?! Definitely more on the citrus side and not as sweet. This wasn't my favorite, but still pretty good.

Miso toffee bacon budino: THE BEST THING IVE EATEN ALL YEAR. It's creamy and sweet with a hint of salt and has the most amazing texture and flavor that just sits on your palette for awhile.

I literally flew from NYC just to have dinner here. It's my go to spot when in Chicago and worth every mile to fly here. Love the food, staff, and ambiance. I couldn't recommend any place more than here and can't wait to be back! Top 3 on my all time list.......and it's it big list!

We went there for a B-Day 2016 and we did like the ambience ,services and good food...
We made the reservation for two months ahead and it made me so curies why is so popular.
Personally I prefer the" Little Goat"better but I would defiantly recommend this restaurant so u can experience the different plates they serve.

You know how it is if you're reading this review - get a reservation, or come here early. Tourists will be here! It's the town's darling restaurant outside of deep-dish pizzerias and probably Alinea, making it a crowded bet.

As for food, my review only confirms how accurate Yelp's recommendations can be. Everything recommended came out acceptably delicious, and all was good except...the goat. The restaurant should really be renamed based on that to Girl & The Pig, but I suppose that's not as catchy. Moving on...

chickpea fritter - garam masala yogurt. brussels sprouts. winter squash. sheep's feta. sev
Yes, please order this. It's delicious I wish I ordered two because it was so unexpectedly good. Reading the description really doesn't do this item any remote justice. The chickpea fritters are these fried cubes of goodness, with everything else serving as a delicious, necessary garnish. I ordered out of faith while doubting Yelp's Chicago tastes, but this did not disappoint.

pan fried shishito peppers - parmesan.​ sesame. miso
Rumor has it that one of every ten Shishito peppers are spicy. I can't tell the difference, but my friend swore the surprise is real. Regardless, the shishito peppers were a fun and tasty appetizer, and one to surprise. They come covered in parm.

ham frites - smoked tomato aioli. cheddar beer sauce
Addicting, quite good, and definitely worth ordering. They don't look at all like what I expected - think French fries with tiny ham bits. Even so, they taste quite good. Don't eat too many by yourself too quickly though, they get a bit salty and in the way that doesn't get washed down by water alone.

wood oven roasted pig face - sunny side egg. tamarind. cilantro. red wine-maple. potato stix
Don't worry, it won't come out reminding you of a dead animal. Various ingredients are chopped up for you to mix tableside, combining into a wonderful flavor of...hearty pig face. And oh, the egg, how I do love egg.

goat empanadas - miso-blue cheese aioli. squash-apple slaw
Oddly enough, I'd been told that the goat dishes at the Girl & the Goat were by far its weakest link. Though this isn't quite the representative sampling, from my experience I'd say this hearsay is true. There wasn't much special about these empanadas at all, and if anything, they reminded me a lot of Taco Bell. But you know, at 11x the price.

petit verdot blend - girl & the goat . 2012 . walla walla
Very tannic, but quite good if you're patient. And hey, a house-made wine is always worth taking a gander!

I made a reservation fairly in advance for dinner's prime time, making for a highly anticipated stop in my Chicago tour. Service was friendly - not in a Michelin way, but more of a local artsy gentrified diner way. Branding was interesting and on point. Interior decor was charming, additional Christmas lights making for an even more enchanting experience. There's a girl and goat painting. Dark wood. Recessed lighting. Tables were a tad small for two, but placed far enough apart that I didn't hear everything said next to me. And most of all, the food was pretty great.

Should out of town-ers come by? Chicago has so many wonderful restaurants to try, so don't feel too bummed if you can't make a reservation. But hey if you can, it's worth a trip.

It's definitely a must to make reservations way ahead of time. We waited till the last minute and was lucky enough to get a late night slot. This place serves food tapas style where you share with everyone. It was suggested that between the two of us, we should get 4-5 plates. We decided on 4 and we were stuffed by the end. Their green beans is a must here. We also got the halibut and the sauce was out of this world. It was a perfect complement to the fish. Our third dish was the pork shank which reminded me of another Filipino dish called crispy pata. The meat was tender and fell right off the bone. Our 4th dish was the focaccia bread with the whipped feta and tomato jam. Our waiter actually forgot about this and had to remind him about it. He took it off our total for forgetting to bring it out which was really nice of him. Had it not been the last thing to come out, we would've finished the bread, too. We were stuffed by the time the bread came out. A must if you're in town and able to get a reservation!

Holy shit yes. The ambience was perfect. The food was perfect. The service was perfect. To quote Ferris Bueller, "If you have the means, I highly recommend it."

As a recovering alcoholic, drinks with dinner are usually coke or ginger ale with lemon. Nothing wrong, but no longer one more interesting flavor for me to enjoy. Not here! They have a delicious mocktail--ginger based with citrus and cucumber.

I tried what felt like one of everything, but since I was eating alone, they portioned every plate out and timed them beautifully so I could enjoy all my dishes and leave only two tiny boxes worth of takeaway. They also worked with me on the pricing so it wouldn't be full price for all the tasting portions I was getting. I was so immensely grateful for this service, as I'd never been, and wanted to try as much as possible. They offered it without me even bringing it up!

Everyone knows their food is the best, but what really made me want to write this review was the service i got tonight. I feel stupid not getting my server's name but she was a warm, kind woman with a ponytail and she is a rockstar. She checked on me just enough that I was never left wanting anything, but not too much as to smother me. She hooked me up with the mocktail and making two dishes that usually included meat be strictly pescatarian for me. She was super kind and made me feel at home although it was my first time. As a server myself, I so appreciated the attention and care paid even though I was there as the kitchens were closing. If there's a way for her to get a raise, I recommend it. I was served by many people who brought my dishes and bussed my table and everyone on staff was delightful and wonderful tbh. The food can be stellar and without a stellar FOH, the restaurant would be nothing. Good for Girl and the Goat that their servers are top notch!

Tip your servers!

Thanks again for a wonderful first experience. I'll be sure to be back very soon.

I made sure I got a reservation to Girl & the Goat once I knew I was visiting Chicago. 3 months in advance and well worth it.

Among the three of us, we ordered the duck tongue, hamachi crudo, goat liver mousse, chickpeas fritters, beef tatare, octopus, and beef hearts.

All I can say is that this is one of of the best meals I had in a long time. Every dish had explosion of flavors and textures. Everything I ate, I shook my head in disbelief, telling my friends that this is some AMAZING food.

Come here and try as many dishes as possible. You will be blown away...and not because it's Chicago.
Must revisit again, steak  was very good.  My friends enjoyed their meal as well. Very good. Good staff

I'm 100% sure there is nothing I could say in this review that hasn't already been said, so simply put, there is no question: this place is a must.

We've been several times and it never disappoints. This time around, we had the olive bread, goat empanadas, baby octopus, escargot dumplings,  calamari bruschetta, and pig face. All fantastic, but the two stand-outs were the bruschetta and pig face (the most popular dish on the menu).

While part of me hates to be just another voice in the chorus of Girl and the Goat fans, there is no doubt that the praise is deserved.

I've been twice and I've never had anything I haven't liked! Service is great! Took my parents for their birthday's and they really enjoyed themselves.

Just go! I promise you won't be disappointed. If you are, you must have burned your taste buds off or have horrible judgment :)

We sat at the Chef's table at Girl & the Goat, which was an incredible experience.  The staff is meticulous about each dish that goes out and the flavors are incredible.  The server was great, super knowledgable & gave us some great recommendations.  I recommend the halibut, which was amazing, the crab rangoons.  I had never tried goat before and the goat empanadas didn't dissappoint.  Great experience and the chef's table is great if you have a party of 2.

The manfriend and I did not love this place at all. We spent so much money here on 5 plates with several drinks and left dissatisfied. We had a reservation but they sat us next to the bar so we could not hear our waiter discussing the menu due to people yapping away right above us -- very displeasing.

Straight to the food:

People rave about their cauliflower..but it's more on the mushy side. Totally not my style, because I'm more of a roasted gal.

Open pig face had to be mixed together...but when it became all mumbled jumbled, I disliked the uncharted taste.

The octopus dish was more on the south east asian style dish and the flavors didn't go well together.

Goat & Lobster dish was so gamey that we left it alone (too irony; not prepared well)

Beef Tongue was probably the best dish of the night. The pickled vegetables paired well together...however, it can do without whatever that fried thing was.

Overall, wonderful modern-rustic-bring-your-new-girl-here type of spot ;)

I have now been here five times (not including a couple of random visits at the bar), and I have to say this is probably my favorite restaurant.  We always have such excellent, knowledgeable servers that give good advise and are helpful.  Our latest visit was last week, the night BEFORE NYE, which was a very cold Saturday in Chicago.  We were super lucky to get one of the spots overlooking the kitchen.  Literally, we had bar type seating with a full view of all of the amazingly skilled chefs working full force on a busy Saturday night.  It was totally awesome.  My favorite dishes this visit were the scallops (I could drink the sauce), the wood fired skirt steak with a caramel sauce (yum!), and the two desserts:  caramel corn and malts balls and the crunchy yummy toffee cake.  These things were all stunningly created masterpieces.  The goat lardo pizza and calamari bruschetta were tasty and delicious but not as amazing as the other choices.  I had a pineapple cocktail, which was perfectly executed, and we order a nice bottle of MI wine!  Cannot wait for my next visit.

Still one of my favorites.  We walked in on a whim at around 5pm on a Tuesday (happened to be in the neighborhood) and were able to be seated within 30 minutes.  The waiter gave excellent advice about meal options and wine pairings.  We ultimately gave him free reign to choose our tapas and we did not regret it.

The food here never dissapoints. The service is excellent. Its definitely a louder, darker environment. Highly recommend getting reservations well in advance. We had the broccolli from the current menu and i camt imagine a better preparation. Desserts are inventive and delicious.

We had reservations here on a Sunday night at 8:30 PM. As we were wandering through the streets of the West Loop, so many restaurants and bars, although open, sat mostly empty. We walk into the girl and the goat in the place is absolutely packed. It was obvious we were dining at and in demand spot.
We sampled a little bit of everything from the veggies, fish, meat and dessert categories. The winners overall for me were the chickpea fritters, pig face and both desserts.
The chickpea fritters were extremely creamy and all the flavors in this dish went together very well. The pig face, although it sounds kind of scary does not come out looking like an actual pig face. The meat is made into patties with that potato sticks in between and an over easy egg on top.
The Carmel corn and malt balls and dark matter options for dessert were both outstanding in their own unique ways.
There were two of us that sampled three different dishes, two desserts and each had a glass of wine and the bill was just over $100. Extremely reasonable for the high quality creative meal you will receive.

Girl & the Goat is a great spot for a celebration, date night, or get together with friends. Despite its name, one of our favorite things is the vegetable dishes. They are delicious and the sauces are excellent. We ate at the chef's table once which allows you to watch the chefs in action and that was a really fun way to do it as well. For larger groups, there are a couple tables that you can reserve in advance and it's a great place to share food and order as a group. Highly recommend!

Went here for my birthday and got seated at the kitchen table. The meal was incredible: the scallops were the best I've ever had, the broccoli had a hint of lemon that was amazing, and the pig face is not to be missed. Bonus of sitting at the kitchen is that the chefs just keep handing you tastes of things that you didn't order but they know are delicious. Phenomenal experience.

Amazing. Everything we ate was like nothing ive had before, and every plate was a homerun. The duck tongues were top notch, and the oven roasted pig face...what bacon wants to be when it grows up. Great service as well!
One of the best meals of my life. Make a reservation and go. Perfect food. Great service.

This place was another place in Chicago, which allowed walk-ins but hard to get a seat. We were lucky to be able to seated outside. However, the weather was so bad and it started raining very hard during our dinner. The restaurant staff were able to seat us near the kitchen afterwards. We ordered the following items:

- goat cheese & sweet corn dumplings (eggplant zaalouk . tzatziki . peach . sungold)
- goat carpaccio (smoked trout roe . olive-maple vinaigrette)
- grilled baby octopus (guanciale . fava beans . pistachios . lemon vinaigrette)
- wood oven roasted pig face (sunny side egg . tamarind . cilantro . red wine-maple . potato stix)
- roasted cauliflower (pickled peppers . pine nuts . mint)

Everything was very good here. However, we felt a little bit rushed at the end.

pics.caption: roasted cauliflower with pickled peppers . pine nuts . mint
wood oven roasted pig face with sunny side egg . tamarind . cilantro . red wine-maple . potato stix

review.des:
we finally got to see what all the hype with this restaurant was about when we were in chicago earlier this month.

it's very hard to get reservations for 2 here - you pretty much have to book 3 months in advance unless you want a 5pm or 9pm reso. however interestingly enough, we were able to book a reservation for 7 online the day before for a 7pm saturday dinner reservation. guess this place really caters to 2's and 4's, so it's incredibly easy to get a reservation during a busy time if you have more people.

as we had a large party, we pretty much got to try everything we wanted on the menu. in total, we tried about 12 different dishes, including the oh-so-savory goat shank (4 lbs of glorious fall-off-the-bone tender meat!).

the group agreed on the following standout dishes:
- roasted cauliflower
- squash blossoms
- pig face
- goat liver mousse (this was my favorite!!)
- goat shank

honestly you can't go wrong as the menu aspires to mix creative flavors together in each dish, so you'll never get something that's bland and trite.

the total damage for 12 dishes divided among 7 people, with ~2 drinks each came out to be ~$75pp after tip and tax. not bad, girl & the goat. not bad at all. highly recommend coming here in a large group though as you'll get more bang for your buck and be able to choose a wider variety of dishes to sample.

This place...the ambiance is fun.  Its cramped, its loud, but inviting.  Im not sure how they pull this off, but they do.  The food is interesting and by interesting I mean they put such unique spins on such basic ingredients, i.e. the broccoli. The shrimp was 5 star worthy alone.  My advice, GO.  NOW.  Well maybe not NOW, bc I don't believe they are open.  Anyway, you get the point.  Enjoy and don't be scared by the rather descriptive/abbrasive names of the dishes.

A fellow Yelper was right to call this a Goatgasm. I would have NEVER expected to enjoy this place as much as I did. Many times, the most talked about, hard to get into establishments are overrated or too fancy to fully appreciate. This is not the case with Girl and the Goat.

I was blown away with 95% of the items we tried. Even the items I would be inclined to pass on the next time were flavorful and memorable.... And believe me, there will be a next time. We re-booked before we left.

I also enjoyed watching the cooks and prep cooks whip it up. There were no measuring cups for anything. They were throwing a pinch of this and scoop of that all night long. Another treat of the night was that a few people in our party of 11 had dietary restrictions (gluten free and Pescatarian). Most of our items could not be modified for them but they prepared a small portion for them when the ingredients allowed them to do so.

Of the 30 menu items, we had 14. Including the coveted, pre order required goat leg.  We also tried all of the desserts.  And we also ordered 2 types of bread. IMO, bread should be free especially if you spend $600. *shrugs

FOOD:

Bread - 3 stars; decent but not worth $6

Goat Leg - 5 stars (was tender like roast and served with bread, boiled egg and 5 dipping sauces) ...Must be pre-ordered and cost is based per .lb.

Fried Pickles -  5 stars

Roasted Cauliflower - 4 stars

Roasted Beets -  3 stars (not a beet fan but they were the best I have ever had)

Sauteed Green Beans - 5 stars (you absolutely have to get them); served with fish sauce and a lemon vinaigrette.

Escargot Ravoli -  4 stars

Duck Tongue - 5 stars (It was the one of the best dishes of the night)

Sugo with Parpadelle - 5 stars (delicious' recommended by the bartender)

Hamachi Crudo - 4 stars

Diver Scallops -  5 stars (* meaty  and served with pieces of bacon)

Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face - 5 stars (the other star of the night.  It was so good. Better than bacon good!) A must try. .... It is a scary thought but one bite will clear your mind of its name.

Lamb Ribs  - 4  stars

Crisp Braised Pork Shank - 4.5 stars

Goat Empanadas - 3.5 stars (good but not mind blowing)

DESSERT:
I do not remember all the names. We tried the Sticky cake, Plantain dessert and Miso Butterscotch Budino. My favorite was the Miso Butterscotch. It was the perfect sweet and salty combo.

COST:
Excluding gratuity, we spent about $50 per person (food only). We all left stuffed and we were sent home with lots of leftovers.

MISC:
The service was great. Our server was on it! She was very accommodating from start to finish.

The place is dimly lit. It was pretty but impractical. Reading the menu was more difficult than it is for a person over 65 to read the last line of letters at the optometrist.
