It was also very loud. Worth the noise though.

The $11 valet parking was also a welcomed offering. Parking can be a bit of a nightmare in this area.
Love the atmosphere ,  I have eaten at the bar several times and had a wonderful experience.

This is my favorite spot out of all the Izard locations. The atmosphere is trendy yet casual. The service is top notch and servers are always going above and beyond to make sure diners are enjoying the experience. Love looking forward to seasonally added dishes on the menu but will always come back for the green beans and goat. This spot has definitely stepped up Chicago's food game. A must when you are in Chicago.

Was excited to visit Girl & The Goat last month for a dear friends birthday party. We were sat in the wine cellar and the service for the party was for kings and queens. The service was impeccable, food/ drinks were delicious and inventive and the overall concept was comfortable. I highly recommend to anyone in chicago that is looking for a great dining experience!

A few months ago, I made a reservation at Girl and the Goat, which garnered a slightly awkward dinner time of 5pm. When entering the restaurant, the first thing I noticed was how dark it was. Although the tables, floors, and roof were wood, the majority of the walls were painted an obsidian-like shade with the exception of a small area of exposed brick. I felt like we were spelunking as we traveled to our table near the back of the restaurant. Very trendy ambience!

Unfortunately, the tables in our area were pretty cramped. The table was scooted out before I could reach my bench seat, and I could easily participate in the conversations of the diners on either side of me. At one point, I felt like scooting our table one inch closer to the one next to us to see if they would be obligated to share food with us, but proper decorum stopped me. The menu is interestingly divided into veggie, fish, meat, and goat.

Shishito peppers - The seemingly small bowl packed a bunch of peppers and some surprising jolts of heat. The top layer was covered in parmesan cheese, but the peppers on lower levels had very little cheese. Most of the peppers were not spicy, but 4-5 of the smaller peppers were FIRE. I was not prepared for the spiciness, so it took a bit for my mouth to recover after a real hot one. Overall, this dish was super oily. The grease took away from the taste of the parmesan and added nothing to the deflated peppers.

Beef tongue - This was one of my favorite things. The quarter-sized pieces of beef were so soft and almost melted in my mouth. The masa chips and salsa verde were bomb. I wanted to lick the bottom of the bowl to get the last drops of the yummy salsa.

Szechuan goat satay - I grew up eating goat, but not like this. Medium cooked goat corny dogs on sprout-covered skewers atop creamy apple-potato puree. There was a lot going on with this dish. I could have done without the sprouts, they did not have enough bite to add anything texture-wise, but the goat was tasty and slightly sweet. The mashed potatoes were very buttery and smooth.

Pig face - Our server said this was world-famous, and I could see why. How often do I eat face? My first bite was all crisp, so I was not too excited, but delving deeper into the food, I discovered more and more elements. The pig face comes stuffed with potato stix, which I think are mini hash browns, and topped with a sunny -side up egg. This dish was very fatty and crunchy and sweet and crispy! There was a lot of flavor to the pork, and the fat surprisingly did not seem too greasy.

Bittersweet chocolate - This dessert was ordered after eyeing our neighboring table's plate. The majority of the dish is a cakey-brownie with a generous scoop of shitake-caramel gelato. I loved the gelato and really enjoyed the saltiness of it which enhanced the dish as a whole. There were different textures to our brownie, and I preferred the gooier parts. I was very pleased with the amount of dessert present and probably could not have finished the entire thing on my own, which I never thought could happen.

The service here was excellent and our served easily answered all of my pressing questions. Even though you must walk down a dark stairway to get to the bathroom, I liked how the bathroom stalls are completely isolated from one another. Overall, a great dining experience, and I want to return to try more dessert.

Wow!! I was in Chicago on business and stopped in hoping for a seat at the bar. Lucked into one within a minute or two. The bartender was great and made excellent recommendations. I loved the food and experience so much I tried my luck the second night of my trip too, a Friday night, and got a bar seat quickly again. The bartender remembered me, which was especially nice for a single out
-of-town traveler. Between the two meals I tried 9 dishes and a killer cocktail. Everything was delicious with two to-die-for standouts: the hamachi crudo and the goat carpaccio. They were both a perfect, subtle combinations of flavors and textures, and beautifully plated as well. I wish I could remember the name of the cocktail. The ingredients sounded like it could be a little too flavorful and sweet and could overpower the food, but it was perfect. It was bourbon-based with  allspice, maple, and a variety of other warming ingredients. Fellow bar diners were really nice too and I wasn't lonely at all. I can't wait for my next trip to Chicago so I can return.

Soo amazing! I was lucky enough to be spoiled by my company and brought here for a fixed menu dinner. Was able to try many dishes and was not disappointed by any!! (I did not eat the meat dishes though... but I heard they were great as well! )

I did not try the drink -- but from what I heard it was very strong.
Lily the bartender was awesome. Ask for her if you are going to have drinks in this place. By the way the food was excellent.

Yes, we made reservations months before our trip to Chicago. We used CTA for transportation, it's a bit away from our hotel. Our reservations were for 5:30 on a Friday night before the Chicago marathon. We arrived in the area rather early and hung out the whole food for an hour!
Anyway, when we arrived on time the place was entirely packed with wonderful, happy people. It's a cool place and very popular.
We got our seats right away on time!
All the workers were right on! Totally cool in this crazy busy place! We were well attended too, for sure.
We ordered four dishes for the two of us. The wood smoked broccoli was great and a very,very large portion. We had the baby octopus which we also thought was great.pan drum fish and goat empladas.
We enjoyed every bite of every dish.
We don't eat pork anymore,but the pork dishes looked really good!

pics.caption: Painting at girl and the goat

review.des:
As a vegetarian, Girl and the Goat was good but not exceptional as my meat eating counter parts probably feel about this place.

We had:
1. Bread and spread
2. Brussel sprouts
3. Wood fired broccoli
4. Chickpea fritter dish
5. Really good dessert!

1 and 2 were awesome!

3 and 4 were tasty but not a must have

Can't remember the dessert name but all of them were amazing! Must have the dessert!

every thing I ate before this was trash apparently, because what I had here made everything pale in comparison! The bartender was rude but the atmosphere was trendy and the food was heavenly. They allow people to order half portions as well.

Favorites include:
Goat Liver Mousse
It's Gouda bread with smoked lardo butter
Duck tongue
Green beans
Roasted Cauliflower
Shishito peppers
Caramel corn and malt balls dessert

Tried, OK:
Pigs face: 2nd time trying, and still meh
Calamari bruschetta; Calamari cooked tender, but didn't feel cheese added anything
Crispy Pork Shank: meat fall-off the bone, but a bit dry
Confit Goat Belly: Goat a bit dry,

Pass:
Wood-fired broccoli: thought the smokiness overpowered the bleu cheese in the broccoli, although husband enjoyed

LOVED IT!

OK.. OK... It's a pain to get a reservation if you are a procrastinator like me and a month in advance got me a 11:30pm reservation on a Friday night but 2 days before my reservation day, I would constantly check on open table for cancellations and finally was able to switch my reservation for 10:30pm!

Once I arrived, I probably waited 30 mins to be seated and tried several things from the menu... Everything was so tasty, I doubt you will regret anything you eat here... A must try is the Escargot Ravioli -- this was definitely my favorite dish -- my mouth is watering!

Make a reservation early!

Very hard to get reservations. If you come right before they open they will accommodate you at a communal table, but you will be rushed. Dishes are eclectic and tasty like pig face and duck tongue, but also very salty. Vegetarian dishes are very good, especially the green beans. Good wine and beer menu and staff is helpful. Imho some dishes work and some don't. Expensive. This is definitely the most crowded restaurant in Chicago and "the restaurant" on the Chicago foodie scene, but I could name a lot more places I like better. Sorry, I think it is way overrated on yelp.

Lots of great reviews for this place! But enough about goat and the girl haha. My favorite hobby? Glad u asked. I'd probably have to say reading straightforward texts 100 times to find hidden meaning haha lol !!

The food is great and the service is very good. However my wife and I felt rushed the entire time. Dishes came out before you had time to savor the last one. Glasses of wine from a bottle were refilled instantly to also move us along. A 5 course meal and the dessert took 45 minutes which may sound great but not for someone who planned a special evening months in advance and drove in from the suburbs. Even though the food was great I would not go back for this reason.

Skip the wait on open table. Walk up on an off night and get seated at the bar or a two top. You'll only have to wait 30 minutes or so and you can grab a drink across the street. Great good. Try everything.

This is my second visit to Girl & the Goat and it just keeps getting better! There is a reason this is one of the top restaurants in Chicago! (and one of the hardest to get into.

Luckily, I made my reservation almost two months prior to my trip to Chicago and was delighted with a quick drink at the bar and promptly seated. The staff was again, top notch.

We started with my favorite from last time, the Naked Cowboy Oysters. These are ridiculous good. I could seriously eat a bucket of these little tasty bites.

We also got the ham frites and the chickpea fritters. Both great. They offer a half order of the frites which was still a large serving, especially for just two of us. They were good, but probably my least favorite of the night. The chickpea fritters, were outstanding.

Next came the green beans. I love vegetables, but it's rare that I'm going to say that a veggie was my favorite dish of the night. But these green beans...kicked some serious ass. The flavor was ah-mazing.

We ended with the pork shank and it was (literally) fall off the bone good. We skipped dessert in favor of finishing off our bottle of wine. While I don't expect a cheap meal when I go here, it was still reasonably priced for what we ate.

I will continue to go here again and again and again. Just wish I lived a tad closer!!

My ode to Girl & the Goat (in haiku form)

Best restaurant here
I don't want to leave this town
Because I'll miss you

Hands down the best restaurant in Chicago IMO. Brought my friends from home here on their recent trip and we all LOVED our dining experience. Everything here is phenomenal - from the service to the food to the drinks to the decor. There's not much to be said (that hasn't already been said), but I guess I'll add some thoughts. We had:

-Rawkusshi oysters
-Chickpea fritters
-Grilled baby octopus
-Calamari bruschetta
-Seared diver scallops
-Softshell chili crab
-Grilled marinated pork belly
-Duck tongue
-Kalbi beef ribs
-Braised beef tongue
-Goat neck
-Wood oven roasted pig face
-Crisp braised pork shank
-Desserts (I forget what we had exactly).

All. The. Dishes. Were. Amazing. If I had to pick my top 3, though, they'd probably have to be the wood oven roasted pig face, the crisp braised pork shank, and the goat neck. The pig face is exactly as everyone describes it - a rich, decadent, flavorful dish that you must get if you dine here. The pork shank was amazingly tender and crispy, and the accompanying nectarine kimchi and buttermilk dressing go great with it. The goat neck was yet another dish that was amazingly tender and tasty, and the vinaigrette goes perfectly with it.

If you can't get reservations online, I'd recommend you walking in and taking your chances at getting a table. Even if you have to wait a few hours, you won't regret it!

Definately worth the wait!!! everything was so delicious and loved the atmosphere! Everyone was so friendly and all the recommendations did not disappoint! must try the pig face and the kohlrabi salad! didn't get the broccoli but saw a lot of people get it.

Having read about this place, Girl & The Goat was on goto list for sometime now. Made sure to visit them during my recent visit to Chi town.

First of all it's hard to get a table reservation even few weeks in advance. I opted to get a spot on the bar, had to wait 20 mins to get that spot. They do have a waiting area with comfy sofas while one waits for the table.Ambiance is lovely out here.

This place is full of activity and is very spacious. The other side of restaurant has a semi open kitchen where one could see the chefs working hard to dish out the awesome food.

The bartender was really helpful and helped me to make selections. The menu is not huge but everything sounds so delicious. Had the following delicacies -

* Wood Fired Oysters
* Goat Belly
* The Pig Face
* Date Cake with Almond Halva

The oysters were baked at the right temperature, goat belly was small but decent. Pig face was a surprise and ended up the most tasty dish which I had. It had that crunchiness which added a twist to it. Loved the dessert too.

With all that food and 2 glasses of wine I was $115(with tip) lighter on my wallet. I would come back.

Truly one of the best meals I've had in a long time. Everything from the goat empanadas, to the escargot raviolis (and I don't generally like snails!), to the braised pork shank was just so well prepared and flavorful. We were stuffed, but made room for desert because everything had been so outstanding and it didn't disappoint. The chocolately-chocolate cake was the perfect ending.

I can't describe how amazing this place is.  The food is out of this world delicious! We had a reservation but it was certainly luck that we got it because this is such a hot spot.  We chose to sit at the bar over the table they had for us and that was the best decision ever! Jason the bartender was so knowledgeable about the wines the whiskeys the gins and of course the stellar food.  Chick pea fritters, the ribs, the pig face, the cauliflower and even a few special extras that they brought to us to try.  I seriously cannot believe the level of service and food.

So I tried this place again after several years, as I found myself in Chicago this week, and this place is always on the "must eat" list for Chicago.  I have to say I didn't remember the food blowing me away then, and my memory was right for once.  Everything was good- but nothing was super standout or memorable to me.  The octopus had good flavors, but it wasn't cooked very well texture wise (purple pig cooked it perfectly yesterday). The broccoli was ok but much too salty. The goat empanadas were pretty good and nicely presented.   I tried the Carmel corn desert thing and that was pretty good.  The standout to me was actually the bar menu.  The cocktails were really great- inventive and delicious.  I think the restaurant is good- but I guess I still don't really see what all the hype is about.

Girl & the Goat prepares some of the best food you will ever have!

Placing reservations six weeks in advance, I was able to secure their earliest opening on a Saturday night: 10:15pm. This place is popular so plan accordingly.

After running through the menu with us, our server suggested we start with the wood fired oysters. Delicate and creamy. A joy to eat! Next came the wood oven roasted pig face and crispy beef short ribs for entree courses. Incredible. Tender juicy head meat layered with crispy potato stix and topped with a rich, runny egg. Their play on breakfast hash. The short ribs, wow! Deboned, fried and plated with lime, thinly sliced radishes and ripe avocado. A favorite of the night.

Plates are served in a tapas style so expect small portions. There's a gluten-free menu for those with allergy concerns and a knowledgable staff able to answer any additional questions.

I'd come back in a heartbeat.

The peppers and chickpea dishes were incredible. You can order half portions, but wouldn't recommend as you'll want the whole dish (it's that good). Scallops were very good, but don't get much for your money. Favorite dish was the short rib, but also really liked the goat dishes too.

Okay I know it's a been a while since I've been here, but hey better late than never right?

The girl and a goat was one of my top stops on my Chicago to-do-list, mostly because I seen it on the travel channel. Unfortunately it didn't really live up to the hype. The wait was pretty long (almost 2 hours) and was packed all the way out the door in the freezing cold with people so I was expecting it to blow me away!

Staff was extremely friendly and knowledgeable of the menu despite it being filled with obnoxiously loud drunk cougars and hipsters. One of the main dishes we tried was the pig face, which just tasted like a really crispy pork rind with an egg on top. We also ordered the roasted cauliflower with mint and pine nuts, the grilled baby octopus (a little fishy for my taste), Diver scallops, duck tongues, and a free dessert thanks to our kind waiter.

..although the dessert accidentally had a piece of pork in it, yuck!

Over all though it just wasn't worth the wait, a little too pricy, and the food wasn't that great nor filling. But as a redeeming quality, our waiter was extremely kind.

Girl and goat is okay to experience once but I don't think I would come back again unfortunately.
I was only here for a lunch! I was able to enjoy a nice salad in a quiet atmosphere ! very superb service!

I haven't written a review in quite a while for 2 reasons (why thank you for asking):
1.) My previous account was attached to a long forgotten email address, and all my reviews were on that.
2.) Discovering hidden gems is fun; flooding them with yelpers makes them less hidden, less special and vis a vis less fun.

My Girl and the Goat experience was so phenomenal I had to write something about it.

My first observation: is that it's hard to get a place to sit without a reservation (granted it was a Saturday night), luckily, as a lone diner I was able to snag a seat at the bar. It's easy to see why, the ambiance is romantic enough for couples, bustling enough for small groups to not ruin the mood and dark enough for solitary diners to face-f**k food without judgement.

The gent at the bar was knowledgeable of all the restaurant had to offer and warned me that some of the dishes were a little bigger and it would affect how much else I could order. Poor soul hadn't seen me eat before.

The dishes I ended up ordering were:
1.) Escargot Ravioli - buttery creamy and quite flavorful. Frankly the pasta was a little heavier than I'd like, it covered a lot of the escargot flavor, but still much yums.

2.) Crisp Braised Pork Shank - this was the dish he warned me about. Typically 4 people share this plate (alongside other dishes), it did not stop me, I demolished it with much enthusiasm. The meat was crispy on the outside, fall-off-the-bone tender on the inside. With naan and some homemade kimchi buffalo sauce it was Peking duck made out pig. Delicious!

3.) Confit Goat Belly - this dish was actually the 2nd to come out but I saved it to the end to review (so that only the diehard readers get to benefit from my wisdom) Bourbon butter, lobster and crab and fennel. HOLY FUUUUU... this was the dish of the night, and possibly the best thing I've eaten in a long while. Tender goat meat sits on a sea of butter with pieces of crab and lobster, I've never had a surf n' turf quite like this, the only thing stopping me from slamming my face into the plate to lick it clean was social decency, and acknowledgment of the cute girl sitting two seats down. ...UUUUCK

Chicago! Well done! You have yourself a gem that I will gladly fly back for.

Cheers!
Excellent food! We had a wonderful waitress who provided fantastic menu recommendations. Keep an open mind if you aren't an adventurous diner. We will definitely be back again!

Hands down the best restaurant I've been to in Chicago. From the food to the service, everything was AMAZING! Our server Ryan was extremely helpful and definitely guided us in the right direction as far as how many dishes to order and what to order. We will be returning!!

Great environment that is calming.

Friendly bar service, a great place to have a bourbon.

Took my staff there for a Christmas party and lots of dish options were available for the more adventurous and plenty of options for the less adventurous.

We tried many different dishes.

Personal favorites were the Shishito peppers, roasted beets, grilled octopus, roasted pig face, pork shank.

We arrived early so had almost no wait.

Bathrooms are lovely and clean, but down a floor.

Amazing restaurant.

The ambiance of this place is fascinating. It has a classy feel but also casual dining feel to it at the same time. Came here with a group of friends and didn't have to wait too long since I made reservations two months in advanced.

We ordered the following dishes: roasted cauliflower, grilled baby octopus, roasted pig face, grilled pork shank, goat empanadas, confit goat belly, short ribs, and aspen ash (goat cheese). There wasn't one dish that I disliked; A few dishes were a bit saltier than the others ones but end of the day, not much to complain about. My favorite dishes:

Roasted cauliflower: YES. I said cauliflower. Caramelized cauliflower with crunch butter, pined nuts, Parmesan, and mint. Exceptional dish.

Goat empanadas: This dish was made to perfection. The pastry was lightly cooked but still had some crispiness to it. The meat wasn't overcooked and was seasoned to precision. This is probably my favorite dish at TGATG.

Grilled baby octopus: this dish was served with braised pistachios, lemon vinaigrette, and some type of pork. (Did a quick google search. Guanciale: cured meat prepared from pork cheek) The grilled octopus paired with the pork is a match made in heaven.

Besides the incredible food at The Girl & The Goat, the service is also impeccable! Our server  provides us with great recommendations and the whole dining experience went smoothly.

PLEASE make reservations 2-3 months in advanced. This place is beloved by locals, visitors, tourists, adults, kids, your dogs, etc. MUST TRY if you're ever visiting the windy city!

I loved the inviting feel of this place, non-pretenious and quite trendy all wrapped into one.  

Now on to the food...since we were at GATG, we had to get one goat dish and I wanted to try other dishes that not other people have reviewed.  My bestest little sister and I decided to settle on the pierogis, scallops, soft shelled crab, goat belly confit, blueberry baba and chocolate cake.  The pierogis were not my favorite because I would have expected a slight spice to the dish or something that would give the oomph like the rest of her other dishes.  The soft shelled crab has this citrus taste that my palate always calls for because it makes me feel like I swallowed refreshing sunshine.   I would say that the goat belly confit is not meant to be shared at first glance, but the decadence of the butter, lobster and crab meat with the salty goat belly worked so well together (a must for anyone that likes pork belly).  I would say my favorite dish was the scallops with the awesome cooling peas (i hope that was done on purpose?)  that made this a great spring dish for my liking with just the right amount of lap xuong (chinese sausage) adding a light sweetness to take this dish up a notch.  The best dessert was the chocolate cake with the yummy cookie crumble crunch that made this dish simple yet textured and made me go back for seconds.

The water was always filled and the silverware/plates was super spot on clean for a busy restaurant.  I WILL BE BACK!

Alright, I'm going to join the 4,000 other people that also think this place is amazing and say, "heck yes, worth your dollars"

4 stars only because the server told us to order too much food. I really enjoyed being able to try some really bizarre cuisine I would never eat anywhere else. Plus the atmosphere is amazing (this is a great spot for a date and a special celebration with friends alike!). Relaxing, upscale, but not snobby. Very relaxed. I loved that part of the experience.

Just go for it. Pay a lot and eat some weird food and drink some good wine! You won't regret it.

One of the best dining experiences I have had in quite some time. We had a party of three that grew to a party of 5. When we called they accommodated our change and said it would  only be 15 minutes later. Already off to a good start.  It started when we sat down. I through a few jokes our servers way and she responded with " my name is Leigh, so here is how tonight is going to go; you're going to throw a few sarcastic comments out and I will do the same and you are going to have a great meal. Sounds good to me. She recommended we get 8-10 courses which we did, and suggested a phenomenal bottle of Tempernillo.  The food is incredible, we had the roasted cauliflower, Pig face, duck mousse, string beans, hamachi to name a few. Each and every course was outstanding. This was enhanced by the impeccable service and attention to detail by Leigh.   First of all, I highly recommend this restaurant as almost 7000 other people have.  Secondly, if you have the chance to request Leigh as your server, do it.

I don't have too many words because everything was mouth watering and decadent.

My roommate and I went here on a whim with way too many options in mind...the waiter actually told us to order less because we were overly ambitious and wanted to try everything.

We started off with the multigrain bread with spring onion cream cheese. Obviously filled our stomach because the cream cheese was delicious. Next, the kohlrabi salad came out... it was SO fresh and delicious with hints of basil. Definitely recommend if you're looking to start out your meal with a salad.

Next, my roommate and I's entrees came out. She ordered the crisp braised pork shank and pan roasted halibut and was basically swimming in deliciousness for an hour. I devoured the spring onion pierogies. They were soft and potatoey and mouth watering. Granted, I was STUFFED but I still ate 3/4 of what was on my plate.

Finally, our waiter brought out small samplers of dessert. I definitely recommend the budino always and forever. The blackberry shortcake was nothing compared to the budino.

We would come here every week if we could... obviously reservations should be made months in advance. We came here because we found a random opening. Definitely recommend with flying colors for vegetarians! Oftentimes, classy American restaurants like this just serve veggies with some random sauces, but Girl & the Goat amazed me throughout every dish that was brought out.

pics.caption: Small samplers of blackberry shortcake and miso-butterscotch budino (budino was TO DIE FOR)
Spring onion pierogies with ramp goddess and rhubarb chimichurri
Crisp braised pork shank with buttermilk dressing, grilled sprig onion kimchee, and naan

review.des:
The almost 3000 reviews do NOT lie. Whenever I asked anyone for recommendations in Chicago, this was the place that came up. I was def NOT disappointed! As you must know, it's tapas style and here's what I ordered:

1) Duck tongue (tuna and black bean poke, crispy wontons, piri piri): tasted exotic but I liked it! I've had duck tongue before and this dish was cooked perfectly. Flavors worked very well together

2) Confit goat belly (bourbon butter, lobster & crab, fennel): my least favorite dish. Maybe I just don't have the palette for it, but the bourbon taste was too overwhelming for me.

3) Wood oven roasted pig face (sunny side egg, tamarind, cilantro, red wine maple, potato stix): This was def the most interesting dish we ordered. I've never had pig face before and although I won't rave about it, I think there is a dish worth trying for all those food adventurers out there!

4) Roasted cauliflower (pickled peppers, pine nuts, mint): This was my favorite dish! I am a huge fan of cauliflower and I'm glad this dish was larger than the rest with lots and lots of cauliflower! I def hogged the plate.

Ordered a beer on tap. They have a HUGE selection of beers and wines. We planned to get here late to avoid the dinner rush but even getting there around 10:30 still meant at least a 40 minute wait. Good thing we were able to snag 2 seats at the bar! The same menu is served there so why wait? Perfect for 2 people! Lots of space to eat and drink. The bartender was very attentive and made sure to always check up on us and refill our water. We were glad to try 4 of their popular dishes. Although we weren't STUFFED, it was a great meal! Took a bus and walked in the snow to get here, but it was worth it!

PS. Their logo of the goat is the cutest thing ever!

Someone please pass the flavor!

I was so psyched to try this place. First of all, if you're going to check it out you need a make a reservation several weeks in advance. I know it's a creation from a former Top Chef winner, Stephanie Izard, so I was expecting big things.

We walked in and it was packed already at 6:30. We were ushered quickly to our small table. The tables are super close to each other, but we managed to sit by each other. The place has nice ambiance, but it was really hot in there. Uncomfortably hot, and I don't get hot easy. The music was loud but the acoustics were horrible. All I heard was a lot of thumping sounds and the words were indistinguishable.

The waitress was pretty good. She explained the menu is small plates style. I ordered a vodka drink with cucumber. It was just okay. My boyfriend wanted a scotch that they didn't carry, so he opted for another brand.

We ordered some oysters, wood fire grilled broccoli, sweet corn pierogies, Serrano bread, and crab rangoons.

The oysters were gross. They were incredibly fishy and I couldn't eat another one. Terrible.

The wood fire grilled broccoli was served in some kind of bland sauce that did nothing for the broccoli. The vegetables were so wood fired that I literally could barely make out the taste of the broccoli. Too much.

The pierogies were fried. I am not a huge fan of fried food, so I was highly disappointed they came out this way. They were served with a carrot relish and basil. This dish at least had some depth of flavor but the fried shell was too much. And as far as sweet corn? Never tasted it.

Serrano bread. I'm thinking spicy and delicious. The bread was a sourdough and toasted with zero flavor of serrano.  It was also so hard I felt like I was going to crack a tooth. It came with some cream cheese spread and pepper relish. It was unmemorable.

I mentioned the hardness of the bread to the waitress so she brought us the rolls with a salsa type mix and ranch dressing. These rolls were at least soft enough to eat.

I got the crab rangoons because my boyfriend wanted to try them. Again, not a big fried fan. I could taste zero crab. It had some kind of avocado cream sauce with it that was so bland it was a waste of calories. The rangoons were filled with cream cheese and that's about it.

Ugh. I can't believe that was a $100 plus dinner for that! What a waste.
Food was great, creative. Happy to see a female chef make it! A bit too crowded and too rowdy, but works with the casual food and price point

pics.caption: They messed up our order though, put cilantro on the wrong dish. Either that or their menu had an error.

review.des: I went to the Girl and the Goat with my fiancé and the dinner was great! Unfortantely, you need to make a reservation about 5 days out, but if you go right when they open at 4:30pm there is a good chance you'll get a table without a reservation. We had the Blue Cheese Sweet Potato Pierogies, which were great. The highlight was the Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face. Normally I am not very adventurous with food, but this was one of the best dishes i've ever had!  Prices were a little high, but average for a dinner in chicago. We will definitely be visiting this restaurant again!

Meh. Ok quality food... but they are definitely pushing it as far as possible on portion size. I'd take a pass. FAR better to be found in Chicago! I feel this place takes advantage of people... but the flavor was pretty good... still not worth it.
Edit: left there... went to green market meat (bbq) just go there. AWESOME!!!! Could have eaten like a king there for same money and amazing flavor.
Avoid this "small plate" place.
I'm skeptical of the reviews for this place. I'm not seeing it at all.

OK,  I'm glad this restaurant is half a country away from me. I was looking for a great place to eat and literally half our office recommended this place. I was NOT let down.  The only thing I have to complain about is the extra exercise I'm going to need to do to make up for those few moments in heaven!  The Sourdough Gouda bread with Bacon Lard Butter was a great way to Start.  The Ducks tongue was fantastic, although I still feel guilty about all the Mute ducks we are now responsible for.  Cuttlefish had a good texture, definitely sweet and the sauce complimented it perfectly.  The Roasted Pig Face and Goat Empanadas were the bomb!!!!  We also had the Cauliflower and Catfish that were both very good, but not quite the 5 star level.  The waiter was great,  I really have no complaints.  Will definitely visit again next time I'm in Chicago.

Girl & the Goat is a must try if in the area. Heck, if you aren't in the area, still go here! Chef Stephanie Izard has put together an unbelievable menu that will please a range of pallets from reserved to the most adventurous! Dishes are served tapas style so order several for the table to share.

Came here with a group of 4 and we tried to pick a good mix from the expansive menu. I was very excited to try a few firsts including duck tongues & escargot!

The duck tongues were ridiculous! Muster up your courage and just try them! They were crispy, delicious and gone in about 45 seconds from our table. They are paired geniusly* with a tuna black bean poke and piri piri sauce.

The other stand out was the crisp braised pork shank - again ridiculous! The meat is so tender, flavorful and effortlessly releases from the bone. I recommend trying the pork on its own to taste the true flavor but then make a mini wrap using the warm naan, kimchi, buttermilk dressing and the buffalo style sauce - it just works!

pics.caption: Crisp Braised Pork Shank - Must Try!
The unbelievable must try Duck Tongues with tuna and black bean poke served over a piri piri sauce

review.des:
Top 5 meal of my entire life. It was amazing from start to end. I am tempted to fly back to Chicago just to eat at this place. If you're visiting Chicago, you MUST eat here.
Decor was very nice as well. perhaps a little loud if you want to have romantic conversation

Make a reservation a couple weeks in advance and everything should go smoothly!

The plates vary a bit in portion size but can easily be enjoyed by a party of four. The pork shank is very filling and meaty - it's my favorite. The only aspect that can take away from the food is that the dishes are generally pretty salty.

My boyfriend surprised me with  trip to Chicago for our third anniversary, and G&TG is where I decided to have our anniversary dinner. Heads up, even a month out, reservations were unavailable, so plan ahead. If you get here at opening, the bar area is available first come, first serve. We were able to be seated at a community table easily, but the restaurant was fairly busy by the time we left (6PM, Friday).

WOOD FIRED OYSTERS: I'm not generally an oyster fan, but these were amazing, and stood out from what you can get anywhere else on the block. Great lemon and bacon accents.
YO QUIERO TACO BREAD: Not even going to try to make this sound classy. This bread tastes like cheese and beef, it's like Taco Bell flavors baked into a soft, round loaf and served with pico de gallo and an addictive cheddar-onion dip. Didn't go with anything else we ordered, but it was a fun start to our meal.
DUCK TONGUES with tuna and black bean poke, crispy wontons, piri piri: A dish suggested to us by our server, this was tasty with southwestern accents and plenty of textures.
ROASTED CAULIFLOWER with pickled peppers, pinenuts, and mint: This is what a vegetable dish should be! Fresh, crunchy, flavorful. I really enjoyed this.
GOAT EMPANADAS with smoked blueberry tapenade and avocado: The dish I was most looking forward to! Two small and delicate handpies, filled with shredded goat. The meat was on the dry side, but the flavor was meaty and complemented well by the fruit and avocado. Wish there was a third empanada for this $16 order.
CONFIT GOAT BELLY with bourbon butter, lobster n crab, and fennel: Underwhelming. The belly was a little overcooked and the flavor profile heavily favored the seafood rather than serving to highlight the goat. This was decent but not something I would necessarily get again.
PAN ROASTED HALIBUT with marcona almond butter, white asparagus, and blueberry nuoc cham: This is not the halibut dish Stephanie Izard won Top Chef with, as another review mentions. Halibut is a fish that is difficult to flavor, and though this dish was plated with a wonderful sauce, the portions of fish that were not submerged were dry and basic. I'm glad we got this dish but again, I'd try something else next time.
CHOCOLATE TRUFFLE CAKE: Chocolate with coconut accents makes this a fun dessert reminiscent of the flavors of an Almond Joy. The cake portion was on the small side, dwarfed by the large scoop of ice cream atop it, which was coated in a Magic-Shell-like splash of hardened chocolate. I liked that this dessert wasn't too sweet.

Service was attentive and friendly throughout, from the ever-present bussers and our designated server, who happily provided us several recommendations for dishes that aren't as often mentioned in reviews. Perhaps as good as the food itself was the community table view straight into the bustling kitchen, making for dinner and a show!
Everything I had was good but nothing was all that great. I did not think this place lived up to the massive hype. I would be willing to give it another try but I walked away rather unimpressed.
Pork shank is the way to go!!! The calamari was amazing as well. Do yourself a favor and skip the goat empanadas...tasty but NOT worth the $8 per tiny empanada.

Able to score a reservation here with my honey during our trip to Chicago.  Read reviews and knew this was a must try.  We had already eaten at The Purple Pig the night before, so expectations were high.

Walked in and this place was packed!  The noise of the crowd overpowered the music, which had a club like beat in the background ... Thumbs down for the music, thumbs up for the cool atmosphere.  We were seated on a row with a ton of other people but I was able to squeeze in and sit beside my honey.

From there, pretty much downhill.  Place was hot inside (my back was almost beading with sweat at end of meal) and the tap water had no ice.  We ordered all of our tapas at once and waited.  The Serrano bread came first, and it was a very hard sourdough.  The spreads were really good but the bread too tough.  Our waitress brought us some rolls instead and that saved it.  The oysters and the crab Rangoon (worst part of the meal) came next and were nowhere near flavorful.  

The sweet corn pierogies had some flavor and the wood fire broccoli was pretty good.  However, I just wasn't satisfied with the taste and price.  I've had much better and now realize this place is over hyped.

Disappointment in all, but at least I had my honey with me.  Won't be back, won't recommend.

Absolutely delicious food and cocktails! They even have a vegan menu. The plates are meant to share and each dish is full of fresh flavors and will blow your mind. Chef Stephanie Izard's restaurant is a must when in the Chicago area!

Absolutely love Girl & the Goat! The service and food are great. If getting reservations are hard to get for the day you're looking for, arrive when they open. They seat tables for the 1st hour their open so you can snag a table quickly before they start seating.
Was there 3-mo ago and ordered two dishes, duck tongue and salad.  Salad was very refreshing, good mixture of vegs.  However the duck tongue was a bit too oily and was disappointing.

6 month waiting period? Are you sure?

Walked in. 90 min waiting? Are you sure? Ok. We'll sit at the bar for now.

Sat at the bar and we got called to a table within 30 minutes. Wow. Maybe it's just a marketing stunt.

Server/Bartender was cool. He seemed very busy. The female that was up there with him seemed much friendlier. The guy didn't smile once. He looked like we were wasting his time. Food here is ok. It's too greasy/heavy/rich for me. They do have a great alcohol/wine selection though!

I'm not sure if I would come back.

pics.caption: Goat ribs. A tad salty but definitely fell off the bones.

review.des: This place is always on point! Whether you want breakfast, lunch or dinner, the food never disappoints and the service is solid.

We had an amazing meal.  My friend and I were in town, and lucky to get a reservation on short notice.  Totally worth it!  It is shareable plates.  Beef tongue, green beans, yellowfin tuna, lamb ribs, and crispy pork shank all were excellent!

Went here for a birthday dinner and I have to say, it was meh. Maybe I was expecting too much because of all the hype but I've had better meals. The drinks were good, service was really great, decor and ambiance was fun and lively. We ordered the goat satay (delicious), blueberry cornbread (fantastic), calamari (pretty awful as half the calamari was undercooked but others were overcooked and it tasted way too fishy), the pork shank (it was meh, a little bland) and the malt ice cream for dessert (not bad). So all in all, it wasn't great but considering the level of service, ambiance and a couple of dishes, it was good. I wouldn't rush back.
Amazing atmosphere and food. Highly recommend the goat empanadas and pork shank. Carmel pop corn dessert great as well. Go if you are a foodie or not :)
All I can say is WOW! Fried oysters, cauliflower, seared diver scallops, crispy beef short ribs (AMAZING), crispy pork shank and caramel corn malt balls vanilla  ice cream with magic shell.

Employees are friendly everything tastes good I come here once a week and it's always great.  Some places like this are hard to keep an ongoing same flavor but this place has nailed it with the empanadas and raviolies

I was a little apprehensive about going here - tourist attraction, overhyped, call it what you want.  I just feared it would be a rip-off and just not worth all the chatter about it.
Boy was I surprised!

First of all, I secured a 6:45 reservation, day of!  Unheard of right? Maybe I was meant to go here!

It had been snowing so I cabbed it from Michigan Ave and ended up getting here 15 minutse before my reservation.  Without knowing it, I walked up to the hostess and told her my party of 2 was here.  She politely nodded and asked if we would want to hangout by the lounge as our reservation was not for another 15 minutes later, which was around when our table would be ready.

We headed to the lounge, and I was pleasantly surprised that they had one waitress dedicated to the lounge area.  How many times have you been in the "waiting room" of a restaurant only to be pissed that there was no waitstaff around?
Anyhow, we started with a round of drinks, and before we were even done, the host came over, politely asked if we'd closed out our tab, and led us to our table.

Initially, I was a little turned off by the table arrangement, we were between 2 other couples, but the maitre d quickly moved the table so I could shimmy-in my seat.  Shortly after, our wonderful waitress came over, gave us many good recommendations, and the feasting began!

We had: scallops, pork shank, lamb ribs, the most wonderful of salads (which I'm kicking myself for not remembering the name to), and baby octopus.  All were delightful.

We also had 3 rounds of adult beverages, that only made the food taste that much better.

When the dessert menu came around, all I wanted to do was order, but my body said NO MORE.  Sheepishly, I told the waitress I just couldn't stomach dessert, at which point she turned and smiled and said "for being such good sports all night, I'll have the kitchen whip you up a smaller portion, on me!"

Basically one of the best dining experiences of my life.

I have been to girl and the goat 3 times (my first time being almost exactly one year ago and my fourth visit will be tomorrow evening). Each time, I've been blown away not only by its food, but also its service. I've never had an empty water glass and the waiters and servers are clearing my plates and checking up on me several times throughout my meal- and never overbearingly so!

Now onto my favorite dish: pig face is an absolute must- crispy patties of pig face, potato sticks, and a perfect sunny side egg with a dressing. Man oh man. Not a huge dish at first look, but it's super filling. Runner ups: any of the fish dishes. I've never had anything but perfectly cooked fish here!

The menu changes seasonally, but there some classics and staples on the menu such as the pig face and chickpea fritters. My recommendation is to try a little bit of each of the categories of food (vegetables, fish, meat, goat, etc) depending on the number of people in your party. G+G recommends 2-3 dishes per person, which is pretty spot on.

The meal is not cheap by any means especially if you order drinks, but in my opinion, coming here is absolutely worth the splurge. Hands down some of the best dining experiences I've had in the city so far!

Girl & the Goat was my favorite restaurant we ate at during my last visit. The portion sizes were really good for a tapa style restaurant. All of the dishes were prepared well, cooked to perfection, and the presentation was on point. Make sure you make a reservation in advance - we made one almost a week in advance and could only get a 10 pm reservation. Fortunately, there was a cancellation and they called us and bumped us up a couple hours. I will definitely be back!

My boyfriend and I went to the Girl and the Goat for our anniversary. I didn't know what to expect at first since I've heard so many mixed reviews about this place from friends not necessarily from Yelp. Some said it was too overwhelming and others said it was innovative. Some said good service and others said bad service. While still others said the food was way too salty. However, I have been wanting to try it since it opened and was very excited he chose to take me here for our anniversary.

The food: The food was amazing! I really have no complaints about how any of the food tasted. The chickpea fritter was my lease favorite and it was still really tasty. The chickpea fritters alone were nothing special. Great texture, but not too flavorful, however, when paired with the yogurt sauce that goes on top it was heavenly. The vegetables that came with it were cooked and seasoned perfectly. The calamari bruschetta was amazing. I love grilled calamari and this is cooked perfectly. The bread was crispy yet soft enough to soak up all the flavor of the bruschetta. It was very good. The goat Carpaccio was also very delicious. It was full of flavor and the goat was very tender. However, the star of the night was the woodoven roasted pig face. When you mix everything together it is unlike anything you have ever had in your life. Truly one of the best things I have ever eaten. It was followed by an amazing chocolate truffle cake, which is devine if you are a chocolate lover like myself.

The service: So the service was a little up and down. We had a reservation, but got there a little early so we sat by the bar area to wait to be seated. They have a nice lounge area with comfy couches. The person waiting in that area wasn't really friendly. She didn't bring a drink menu or ask us if we wanted anything. She just sat at the side of the bar, talking with the bartenders. If it wasn't so busy I wouldn't have minded, but it would have been nice to be acknowledged. It was really crowded in this area, and some people were eating so it got cramped fast, not that I minded, just something to be mindful of. Even when we sat down, the tables are pretty crammed together. Our waitress was top notch. We were little lost since this is a different dinning experience that what we are used to, but she provided us with knowledge. She even helped us make our plate so we had just the right amount of food for the two of us. However, the ending was the best part of our night. We ordered champagne and the waitress asked us what we were celebrating, when we told her it was our anniversary, she smiled and wished us congratulations. We thought that was the end of it, but all of the sudden, they brought us out a 2nd dessert ON THE HOUSE. This was completely unexpected and we felt greatly appreciative. When we thanked her, she said it was nothing and milestones need to be acknowledged. Those are the types of things that keep customers coming back! I will certainly recommend this place to family and friends as well as be back myself.

pics.caption: A 2nd complementary dessert for our anniversary... also delicious!
chocolate truffle cake with chocolate coated ice cream on top!
Pig face with egg on top... no it doesn't look like a pigs face.

review.des: Food was amazing, drinks were amazing, service amazing. Hipster vibe as all west loop is. Place gets super full and kinda noisy, not a bad thing at all, jussayin.

It was phenomenal. Literally every dish was amazing. We had the roasted cauliflower, hamachi crudo, calamari bruschetta, pigface, beef tongue...and a few others oh the oysters those just melted in your mouth. Enjoy it I would recommend it over and over again!!!!

Holy shit. No words to describe the food and experience at the Goat! Actually, "goat" fits perfectly - Greatest Of All Time.

We were lucky enough to be seated at one of the Chef's tables - which was rad - and actually made us order more as we watched them prep and plate everyone's orders. Sit here with caution - food babies are conceived here.

Two of us shared nine dishes (started as five but it escalated quickly!):
- honey brioche
- wood fired eagle rocks
- soft shell chili crab
- grilled baby octopus (favorite)
- braised beef tongue (third fave)
- goat empanadas (second fave)
- sautéed green beans (complimentary)
- caramel corn and malt balls
- olive cake (forget the actual name)

Listing them as favorites doesn't mean anything was short of amazing! I could eat all of those dishes every single day. If I could do it again, I'd snag a pork shank because they looked BOMB but after nine plates, and booze, we were slipping into a food coma right at the table.

As for that three dollar sign up in the corner ($$$), it's not expensive. Coming from Boston, it's way cheaper than a comparable Boston spot. Most plates were $17-$25.

Oh, and I can't forget to give a shoutout to the staff and servers! Leigh was our server and killed it! From opening spiel to drop of the check.

Can't wait for my next Chicago adventure - the Goat will be my first stop.

pics.caption: Chef's Table and soft shell chili crab.

review.des:
This is a must eat if you're visiting Chicago!! This was my favorite restaurant out of all the places I tried in Chicago, and I really wish there was one in LA. This is another restaurant where the wait is ridiculously long so make sure to make a reservation months in advance. I tried to make one about 4-6 weeks in advance, but the date/time I wanted wasn't available so we just decided to go there anyways and see what we can do. The wait for the table was like at least 2 hours so we decided to wait for the bar seating which is open seating (but we put our name down on the waiting list too). We waited about 40 minutes and was finally seated at the lounge area.

We ordered the hamachi with pork belly, cooked oysters (raw was n/a), their infamous pig face, and the roasted cauliflower. I give everything 5/5 as it was spectacular (including presentation) with extremely unique and flavorful taste! The servers were also on point with the frequent refills of water without even having to call for them, even when we sat in the lounge area and not the table area. Surprisingly, my favorite was their cauliflower which was roasted with pine nuts, picked peppers, mint, and chili aioli. It tasted like a baked potato with all these flavorings and even my boyfriend, who at first did not want to order the cauliflower, said this was his favorite dish as well. ORDER THE CAULIFLOWER!! :)

pics.caption: Hamachi crudo, cooked oysters, pig face, & roasted cauliflower. THE CAULIFLOWER IS A MUST. BEST DISH HERE NO JOKE!

review.des: Amazing food and service. Make your reservations way in advance or show up at opening to snag a seat at the bar for dinner.

This place is awesome, depending on what you order. First of all, you'll probably have to wait but lucky for you, their drinks are spectacular. Try the Very Old Fashioned and the Thai One On.

I'm typically not a fan of things like the Chickpea Fritters but omg this dish deserves an award for its complexity and multitude flavor profiles. The girlfriend loved it so much so considered ordering a 2nd dish immediately.

The Pig Face is awesome. Probably the best pork I've ever had. It has that slight crispy texture on the outside and rich, indulgent, melt-in-your-mouth juicy meat in the middle. Heavy, but delicious. They make sure you eat this last.

The Beef Tongue was not as good as what you'd expect at a Japanese or Korean restaurant, freshly grilled, dripping with juices. G&G had their marinated and dry grilled, paired with chips and this heavy cilantro pesto sauce. Not a fan.

The Goat Empanadas were dry and bland. I can name many other restaurants with better.

Had their Goat Brie as dessert and it was decent.

Like I said, it's a fantastic restaurant depending on what your personal palate and what you order. I will return again, but only with reservations.

Disappointing, no desire to come back. I live in Chicago and eat on Randolph street regularly. I made a reservation a month and  a half in advance (the first available). My friend canceled last minute so I came by myself- I thought even better I will really get to experience the flavors and aroma of the restaurant. My excitement dissipated after each dish I ordered.

This is a group environment type of place but people must be leaving hungry? The food is tapas style and the portions are SMALL & EXPENSIVE. I came here alone and I left hungry and spent 100+ dollars! I almost felt like I was missing something that everyone else knew?

I ordered a ton of different plates off the menu and I kept ordering thinking one would eventually impress me...I left feeling duped and depressed that I wasted my money.

The only good thing about the friend oysters were the way they were served creatively on a bent spoon (looking back at my experience this about the only thing I can think of that I enjoyed and thought that's different)

The duck confit was very fatty as it should be but I was expecting more crab the crab was crumbled on more like a garnish than actually making it a part of the dish.

The duck empanadas didn't have much flavor and were a little boring- I wasn't wooed.

I got two other dishes and a dessert that I took one bite of it and pushed it away thinking it wasn't good enough to consume the calories.

All and all I wasn't impressed - I feel like I bought into the hype like tourists. -  I am a local so I just feel stupid for coming here.

I do not recommend Girl and Goat to tourists and friends visiting but I do recommend this Chefs other restaurant across the street Little Goat. I have eaten at her other restaurant Little Goat regularly and it never disappoints.

My favourite place, the jewel that I'm going to recommend to everybody I know that has asked me about my Chicago trip! One of those meals you enjoy that you can literally drop dead right after. I was nervous about getting a table walking in because reviews were stating its difficult to make reservations but they accommodated us at the bar and let me tell you the bar is were it's at. Master craftsmen at work mixing drinks right in front of you and giving you the upmost detail of the items being ordered. You look around and you see entire wait staff and (open kitchen) chefs working in perfect simitry with each other to give you the best service and experience possible. Each dish I felt came in perfect timing upon completion of eating and thoroughly explained in detail when presented with the next dish with advice on how to enjoy it the best way possible. Looking upon the bar you will see a rediculous selection of wines, alcohols, bitters, and my personal attraction the craft beer selection which was also top notch. Beers I never knew existed! Don't come here to order chicken.... The place is called girl and the goat... The confit goat with poached crab and lobster was the piece de resistance! And I hate goat! This restaurant truly perfected it's craft and has made me question (as a cook myself by trade) what I cook on a day to day basis and I would love a job here if I was local to chicago. Bravo I will be back.

pics.caption: I forget what theses peppers were called great to snack on tho

review.des:
Let me start this off by saying that I was starving by the time we had dinner here. We also had drinks before coming. Therefore, I was expecting to be blown away by everything.

Service was awesome from start to finish. It's obvious everyone knows the menu well, and your cup is never left empty. Very important when you're dining out in the heat!

After gathering advice from friends who've eaten here and reading through Yelp, my sister and I narrowed our list down to the duck tongue, roasted cauliflower, halibut, goat empanadas, and pork shank.

Luckily our server advised us that the pork shank was huge and we could probably do without it if we had to cut out one item. Glad we listened!

Oops, this is getting long! Here are my notes in order of how they came out:

Duck tongue:
- by far my favorite
- crispy
- flavorful
- light

Cauliflower:
- big portion
- lots of tasty components, try them all in ONE bite

Duck empanadas:
- great flavor
- a touch too oily

Halibut:
- beautifully cooked
- nice portion
- a bit too salty

Last thing... I would have liked the meal to be timed better. The halibut came late into the meal, and it would have been nice to compliment it with the cauliflower. Overall I enjoyed the meal, but I am not running to go back just yet.

I'm a huge fan of doing things differently but not making food weird. Nothing disappoints me more than pretentious over complication. You'll find none of that at Girl and the Goat (GATG) which delivers on so many levels.

First, ingredients, favors and combinations. It's not everyday you get to choose between beef or duck tongue, or pig face (cheek) or goat belly. For most everyone these would be the last choice on a menu and stoically avoided. The culinary heritage which is GATG knows that these are exceptional ingredients not waste byproducts. Paired with beautiful, fresh ingredients- often seasonal- and textured, multilayered sauces everyone of these is taken to exceptional heights.

Your food is grouped in 3 main categories- vegetable, starters, entrée proteins with a separate menu of goat featured specials. Pick from each group and you are good for the evening.

The wait staff are knowledgeable and bar staff exceptional- training, food knowledge, pairing and mixology background. There's nothing wrong with eating in the bar or lounge as it's the full restaurant menu.  

Love the apple and shitaki mushroom pairing in the kohlrabi salad, Mediterranean sea bass with the spicy base and beef tongue with salsa verde, red onions and moist corn chips are wonderful.

Love the duck tongue- spectacular - and the pig cheek always is a pleaser but perhaps the most difficult dish for many who aren't attuned to sublet complexity.

Other highs are the octopus and mussels. Nothing will disappoint. By far my favorite restaurant in Chicago and a go/to place on every visit.

pics.caption: Great drinks selection and bar staff
Kohlrabi salad with apple and mushrooms

review.des: I would love to give this restaurant more stars! I made the dinner reservation about 90 days in advance because my friend warned me that open tables go quick! When we arrived we were seated quickly and near the bar/kitchen area. I noticed there is a two seat option right in front of the kitchen which would be such a fun date night! Our server recommended we pick out about five or six items to share since the plates are smaller portion size. We ordered the pan fried shishito peppers, roasted beets, pastrami spiced beef heart, goat satay (I think this one was just a daily special), and the wood oven roasted pig face. Everything was phenomenal!!! But the real star of the meal was that pig face dish! Service was a little bit on the slow side at times. The first few dishes came out pretty quickly and then the last couple took a while. Our server disappeared at one point but not for too long thankfully. Overall, my experience here was fantastic and I would love to go back!

The orgasms my mouth received is other worldly. This is a MUST if you live in Chicago or are visiting Chicago. Be prepared to wear clothing that can confirm to your stomach growing, because you will be eating a lot and you will not be able to stop.

We had the Johnny Applecheese, Shishito Peppers, Calamari Bruschetta, the famous Pog Face and the Goat Belly confit with Lobster and Crab.

You CAN'T go wrong with any of those!

This restaurant is truly amazing! Worth the wait, make reservations 90 days in advance to be sure you can get in.  We got the open face pig and the duck tongue and both were superb.  We will make a point to dine here anytime we are in Chicago.

I'm on the fence between 3 & 4 stars for Girl & the Goat. Awesome service. Food's great but not amazing in my opinion. I've heard a lot of good things about this place & everything on the menu sounded amazing so I think my expectations were just too high. If I had to wait for a table, it would've not been worth it; luckily I was able to grab a seat in the bar area right when I arrived.

Ordered too much food again but what's new?!? haha
~hamachi crudo w/ crisp pork belly, chili aioli, caperberries - fresh hamachi; the whole dish is kind of bland for me
~ escargot ravioli w/ bacon & tamarind-miso sauce - delicious! this has to be my favorite dish
~ ny strip tartare w/ smoke uni, apple, shiitake, popiah - pretty good but I couldn't really taste the uni
~ braised beef tongue w/ masa, beef vinaigrette, salsa verde - refreshing salad w/ thinly sliced beef tongue

Valet or street parking only. Beautiful interior. Full bar.

The menu sounds scary (pig face, really?), but when the plates arrive to you-omg, that's AMAZING! Very interesting taste combinations and nice setting. The negative: looking through open table it is impossible to find a table 2 month in advance. I wonder, do people really book and go or just book random slots as an option to have?..
Loved it!!! Good atmosphere, great service, and very very good food. With a good kick to it. Loved the oysters, green beans, skirt steak, and the shank. Will come back.

Girl and the Goat is very popular in Chicago. Reservations can be hard to come by and it makes sense because this place was hopping on a late Sunday evening.
The streets were empty and so wete neighboring restaurants, but when we walked in to the Girl and the Goat, it was alive loud and jam packed. The kitchen is an open concept and the ambiance is nice.
I just felt like it was too loud and cramped. It felt like we were sharing a table with our neighbors.  
The food is fabulous and sort of tapas style. The fried chickpeas were so creamy and flavorful.  Next we shared the escargot ravioli. I loved this dish.  The bacon sauce with the celery, almost gave the dish an Asian taste and some crunchy texture.  The next plate we shared was the Pig Face. The name sounds scary, but was far from that.  The pig face (not an actual snout staring right us) was served with potatoes, sunny side up egg and cilantro.  It was so tasty.  
Our meal ended with some of the best desserts I have ever had.  We had the Dark Matter Pot de Creme and the Caramel Corn and Malt Balls. Let me start by saying I am a sucker for malt anything and caramel corn, so for this to be incorporated into a single dish, rocked my world.  The Pot de Creme was equally delicious and had a more savory flare to it.   The cocktail list was appealing, but we stuck with the house red wine which was enjoyable.
Prices were quite reasonable for this caliber of restaurant.
Service felt rushed and less than personal.  
Overall, very enjoyable meal and phenomenal food.

I can never resist provocative flavors and innovative dishes and Girl & the Goat delivers on both fronts.  

----The Food----
Crisp Braised Pork Shank ($26)- WOW. One bite of this tender, succulent pork shank and I delved into my own happy world--nothing else mattered.  Sharing this flavorful creation will be the worst part of your meal.  The Kimchee wing sauce and buttermilk dressing make perfect, tasteful dips for the pillowy soft naan too.

Roasted Pig Face ($18)- This wood oven dish was good, but fell short of expectations, especially since it's one of the more popular signature plates on the menu. It comes with a sunny side egg,  crispy potato stix, drizzled in tamarind vinaigrette, red-wine maple sauce and cilantro oil.  It's reminiscent of the pig face at Animal in LA, but more subdued in taste.  It's messy, it's good, just not mind blowing.

Grilled Marinated Pork Belly ($15)- Served with radicchio and an aromatic green sauce resembling pureed cilantro and avocado, this pork belly plate had an uplifting, light flavor, but the consistency of the pork belly was oft-putting.  I felt it was undercooked, giving it a chewier consistency than I can bear.  

Confit Goat Belly ($19)- While I'm a big fan of this order, I disliked the tiny portion.  Smothered in heavy bourbon butter and sprinkled sparingly with lobster/crab, it's a comforting plate that didn't taste as gamey as I thought it would.  

Roasted Cauliflower ($11)- Accompanied with pickled peppers, pine nuts and mint, it's a refreshing appetizer that is as good as Bar Ama's in LA.

Pan Roasted Halibut ($18)- I hate fish, but this masterpiece melts in your mouth and makes your eyes roll back to your skull.  Made with marcona almond butter, white asparagus, blueberry nuoc cham, the flavors are wonderfully surprising and unique.  Amazing.
-----
Conclusion: 4.5 Stars. Your inner carnivore will thank you, after giving the Girl & the Goat a visit.  I believe Chef Izard didn't need to be on Top Chef to gain popularity because her evocative and exquisite dishes speak for themselves.  The food, service, atmosphere, and even decor have a boisterous spirit that's contagious--you'll be overjoyed to be there.  I just wish the portions were bigger and the prices were cheaper.

Extra Notes:
-Accepts credit card
-Make reservations before hand! I made mine 3 months in advance
-Fantastic, suggestive service
-Dim-lit, but loud environment--a fun place to dine or date.
-Decor is beautiful in a hipsterish kind of way
-The art work is almost psychodelic
-Restrooms are clean

I have been there twice and both times the food was fantastic. The flavor and plate size was perfect for sharing. I do have to say the table are very close to each other and it make is hard to have a private conversion. In terms of the food this place is 5 stars.

Great service! Your glass of water never goes empty! We ordered the full steens ahead & all becomes one. The all becomes one was delicious! Like our waiter said, full steens ahead is great for rum lovers! I can't thank our waiter enough for helping us with ordering, haha. From me almost ordering a drink I wouldn't like to almost ordering two salads, I appreciated it! But I probably would've been okay with two salads, because OMG the kohlrabi salad was to die for. So, so refreshing and crisp. We finished the whole bowl, and I honestly wanted more for dessert! We also got the roasted cauliflower, prepared like I've never had. I was iffy when I saw the little lively mint leaves in the bowl; I absolutely hate eating mint leaves. I love the flavor of mint, but you can LEAVE the fresh thing out of my plate...except here. Here, it fit so perfectly; subtle and not in your face. We also got the goat belly confit off of the goat menu. I loved the buttery-ness. Last plate was the pork shank. This thing was crispy! This was where things went a little off for me. Maybe I had expected a lot from this since we enjoyed the other three plates so much. The meat fell off the bone, which was a plus, but I didn't get much flavors. The buffalo sauce was different, but not so much in a positive way. We finished off the meal with the caramel corn & malt balls: great. Loved the combo of ice cream & caramel corn. Overall, worth getting through the cold for this place. Also, the ambience is awesome!

Definitely check for open reservations the day you want to go!

Was told to check this out on my trip to Chicago by a fellow restaurant industry friend.

Great atmosphere. Beautifully designed. Lounge areas, couches, ottomans

Goat carpaccio: Wanted for black pepper. Not very exciting or flavorful. Texturally it was fine.

Scallops: No harmony in the dish. Scallops were cooked perfectly, but the elements didn't do anything for me as a whole. Disjointed and disappointing. Couldn't taste the corn nor peaches.

Wine pour seemed short

I liked the silverware?

Been meaning to try this place forever. Girl and the goat fame has traveled all the way to Boston and got me extremely intrigued. I knew of the chef through Top Chef, and everybody I knew gave excellent reviews. My experience:

I wanted to try as many dishes as possible so I ordered half orders when allowed. I ended up settling for Pan Fried Shishito Peppers, Grilled baby octopus and goat empanadas. Maybe my expectations were set too high, but I was expecting a lot more from the food. Shishito peppers were essentially salt, the octopus dish was good but not mind blowing. The only thing that impressed was the empanadas. I wish i ordered two empanadas as opposed to the shishito peppers.

In summary, I had a very underwhelming experience. I'm only giving four stars because of the goat empanada and the service. Everyone was incredibly nice and accommodating. I just sat by the bar so I can't really say much about the table service. I would totally go there again to try other dishes. The goat dish was enough to make me go back and give it another shot
Tons of variety in the menu, with some very creative options. Even the simplest dishes here are delicious; it's always hard figuring out what to order because everything is so good.

My husband and I were trying to get reservations at Girl & The Goat for months to get a decent time for dinner, however whenever we checked, the only reservations available were always after 10pm even during the week.  So finally, we decided to make our reservations two months in advance for my birthday.  After going to dinner last night, I am SO glad we finally had dinner at Girl & The Goat.  The experience was everything and more.

Our service, food and drinks were all amazing.  We were also pleasantly surprised how affordable it was for the quality of food that is served at the restaurant.  We can't wait to go back!  We ordered the below items and we absolutely loved each and every one and would easily order it again.  

Raw Kusshi Oysters
Roasted Cauliflower
Pan Roasted Arctic Char
Diver Scallops
Wood Over Roasted Pig Face
Crisp Braised Pork Shank
Miso-Butterscotch Budino
Plantain Cake

We had an awesome server who was very knowledgeable and very nice.  He heard it was my birthday throughout the course of our dinner and surprised me with a second dessert with a candle which was very nice.  

If you haven't already been to Girl & The Goat, make the reservation even if its a few months in advance and go! You will NOT regret it!

I absolutely loved this place!!! I ordered the calamari, pork shank, and Kalbi beef ribs. I wish I could try more on the menu but I was completely stuffed. The calamari was very fresh and it was not fried like a lot of other restaurants. The pork shank was massive and super fork tender. The Kalbi beef ribs were excellent and flavorful (wish there were more pieces).
Must try the goat burger !! Absolutely scrumptious and huge , burger portions are huge!

The service here was phenomenal. The waiters are very knowledgable about the menu and the service was on point from the start of the meal until the very end. We got the chickpea fritters, which were very creamy and hearty. The calamari bruschetta and the calamari was cooked to perfection. The pork shoulder confit with lobster and crab was also very delicious but slightly on the oily side. The duck tongue dish was by far my favorite. We also got the legendary wood grilled pig face, which was pretty good but not the main star in our meal. Overall, it was a great experience and I would definitely come again.

This place is a must visit. Very fun and creative dinner setting. The plates are small yet sharable, so you want to order about 3 to 4 dishes for 2 people. Each dish was cooked above expectations. Tried goat for the first time, I'm a fan! This place is a bit pricey but worth a try.

Honestly one of the worst experiences of my life!!
Came here with a date who tried to make a reservation on Thursday for Friday night! He was told he wouldn't need a reservation since we were looking to come in around 5pm. Fine! He arrives before I do at 5pm on the dot and asks if he can get a table for 2, he's told it's going to be a couple hours wait!!!???? What?? Why on earth were we refused to book a table the day before & why on earth were we told we'd be guaranteed a table upon entry?? Puts his name down for a table and heads to the bar, i texted him from my cab on route to the location and asked him to ask the bartender if they served Sangria because God forbid it's a beautiful day out in Chicago and I fancy a nice cold, refreshing drink! Gets the DIRTIEST look from the bartender as if to say "If it's not on the cocktail list I'm not making it"
Upon my arrival, I sit down and was greeted at the bar by 3 of the most miserable, unwelcoming, grouchy, judgy and down right rude bar tenders I have ever had the displeasure of meeting! I had my heart set out on Sangria so I needed a minute to decide on an alternative which pissed off this girl so much she literally rolled her eyes at me and walked away. She never came back to me to find out if I'd decided on something so I had to call on the other male bar tender to attend to me! Got our drinks, about 40 minutes later I'm feeling extremely parched and realise I don't have any water! Not only through experience, bar tenders pour you a glass of water the second you sit down and are glancing over the menu, but out of 20-25 people sitting at the bar, my date and I were the ONLY 2 who were not offered water!! This guy was re filling the water glasses of the couple to our left AND our right, casually without taking the time to care that we didn't HAVE any water glasses to top up!!
When I asked him for some water, he didn't apologize for not giving us any, honestly felt like I'd just asked him to give up both his kidneys for me seriously it was SO UNCOMFORTABLE!!! 3 painful and excruciating hours later, we had already agreed that there was no way in hell we were staying there for food, which might I add we planned to have at 5:30pm NOT 8:40!!!!!!!
We kindly declined our table and asked for the Cheque, we paid but before leaving my date stayed at the bar polishing off his drink while he looked after my bag, coat etc. apparently while I was gone he was asked to move!!!!! Oh my goodness me can you imagine!! JUST because we'd checked out, my date was still sitting down when the bar man looked over at 2 women who were drinking behind us all night and said to them and I quote "Ladies these seats here are for you, sorry about the wait these next drinks are on me" Are you effing kidding me!! We were only sat at the bar waiting on a table we thought we were going to be given upon entry because they refused us a reservation, treated us like absolute scum, gave us the dirtiest looks all night & now to top it off you're belittling us in front of other customers playing "good cop" opting to treat them with the courtesy and respect you should have treated us with?? My blood is boiling I can't even tell you! I am NEVER stepping foot in here & will make sure everyone I know does not either!!! Shocked, disappointed and absolutely sickened by this experience!!!
PS. Vegetarians, this is NOT the place for you! But if you enjoy eating pig faces, duck tongues, and fancy being bullied and belittled by bartenders then

Just got back from my feast at Girl and the Goat. I've been to Chicago several times and have never been able to get a reservation. Finally I got one at 9:45 PM and it was worth waiting and being hungry till bedtime. The duck tongue was so perfect and crispy...on a bed of raw tuna and bean salad that just complemented it so well. Also tried the chickpea fritters...as I was traveling and dining alone the waiter made me a special half plate which was perfect. That was also an awesome little starter that I would definitely have again. I received a complimentary scallop, I guess it was the end of the night and they had some left over, but it was very yummy and appreciated. Topped off with a delicious whiskey cocktail and let's say I left full and happy!  Have already booked a group dinner for a return visit in 2 weeks.
Loved the roasted brussel sprouts! The combinations of flavors in each dish are surprising by so tasty. Really enjoyed it.

Right when I walked in, I loved everything about the open layout of the restaurant, the cozy décor, and the modern vibes. We got seated pretty quickly and started ordering  Because the flavors of all of the dishes are so rich, six dishes were filling for the four of us. Some of my favs and some of the ones I will pass next time:
- Grilled Oysters: #1. It is a MUST. Enough said.
