- Pig Face: such a rich, flavorful, unique dish. The flavors really all came together when you mix everything up!
- Lamb Shank: YES! Cooked perfectly, and paired well with the kimchi sauce (which I was hesitant about, but pleasantly surprised)
- Roasted Cauliflower: tasted familiar, but just can't put my finger on it. It was good, but it felt like something I could make in my own kitchen.
- Pork Belly: Surprisingly, raw fish and pork belly go well together. The fish was fresh, the perfect cut, and melted in my mouth. However, I was not impressed with this dish because of the sad portion pork belly. To be frank, the dish came out with what really amounted to one normal slice of pork belly sliced into four mini pieces? Mm...I will pass next time.
- Halibut: loved the fish, but the sauce - wish it wasn't balsamic - it was a little too sweet.

Really good food, small plates style eating, super good vibes and people watching, love the interior space and outdoor eating in the summer. They make a great cocktail. Fits well in the W. Loop location (read: trendy, good food area).

A little over-hyped and terrible to get reservations at, but when I do get a table it does nto disappoint.
Easily one of the most delicious meals I've eaten in months.  The pig face was rich and flavorful, the beet salad was light and fresh.  Truly excellent food.  I'll be back.

Mahhhhh lord! Visiting Chicago for the first time and all my friends recommended this place. Definitely lived up to its expectations! Being Asian, I love pate!!! I know that everyone recommends the pig face and goat shoulder, but the goat liver mousse is to die for!!

Tip: come right when they open

I was visiting Chicago for the weekend for the first time and looked up restaurants to eat at for a  memorable dining experience.  Yelp recommended Girl and the Goat, so I looked up reservations since I don't have much time to be waiting in long lines and finally located a spot at 10:30pm on a Sunday a month in advance.

When I arrived, I was seated right away at an amazing spot right in front of the kitchen where I can witness all the chefs working on the wonderful dishes. Our server was very friendly and helpful with selecting our dishes, we started off with some cocktails and they were delicious.  I ordered oven roasted pig face, bacon topped raw oysters, grilled baby octopus (the best I've ever had!), and goat carpaccio. They surprised us with an extra order of the Goat empanada, on the house! Everything was extremely flavorful and a perfect combination of sweet and tangy, with great texture of soft and crunchiness.

Oven Roasted Pig Face: topped with a sunny side egg, my waiter told us that the best way to eat it was to mash everything up together and mix it with the sauces on the plate for the best flavor, and it was absolutely amazing! Crunchy, soft, amazing!

Grilled baby octopus: the combination of everything is simply the best. ever. MUST TRY!!

Goat carpaccio: super soft slices of goat with Smoked trout roe. Olive-maple vinaigrette..need I say more? perfect appetizer!

I highly recommend to check this place out whenever you're visiting Chicago!

We had our reservation at 10:45 pm. We were sit right after we arrived. We were sit right at the kitchen window, which is super awesome as we can see all the cooks cooking! And it is REALLY COOL!!!!!!

The servers were wonderful! Our server is very enthusiastic about her job and is very knowledgable about the menu as well. After she learnt that this is our first time at Girl and a Goat, she explained the menu to us very thoroughly! We were told we should order 4-5 dishes to share for a party of 2. We ordered the pig face, the goat belly, the halibut and the beef rib. We wanted to order the scallop as well but after the first four dishes she immediately told us that it might be too much for us as the dishes we ordered are all the heavy side.

First, the halibut is to die for. The flavor is so interesting and complicate! You have to try it!

Second, the pig face!!! This is probably the most-famous dish here! It is indeed on the heavy side, but it is really good! The meat is juicy and tender, it is a nice touch to have a sunny side up egg paired with it!

The goat belly was paired with lobster and crab, and braised in lemon-flavored purée like thing..It is just wonderful.

The beef rib was a little bit too salty for me...

Plus, for some reason, we got a cauliflower for free and it is just delicious!!!

Very very good experience here! Will be back!!

This place has been one of my absolute favorites in the last 5 years I have lived in Chicago. It can be hard to get a reservation at times, but I've had my share of luck just walking in (and promising to eat in under an hour!) and immediately getting a table. Almost everything that you order is amazing, but my personal tried-and-tested highlights are the Cauliflower, the Scallops, and (most of all) the Pig Face! Service and ambiance always match the high quality of the food as well :) Definitely try to go if you have time in Chicago!

Well let me just say that I was extremely excited to try out this place after seeing it had over 5 thousands reviews and still average a 4.5 star.  I saved my stomach all day and wanted to end my trip to Chicago with a bang with this restaurant but boy am I disappointed!!!  

Maybe my taste is very contrary to the norm but this is actually my first time leaving a 1 star review for a restaurant since joining yelp.  

We had the goat empanada and it was definitely overhyped.  

Then we had the green beens as a veggie dish to go along with our entrees and that turned out too salty.

Then we had the octopus which tasted burned.

Then we had pig face and this was a complete disaster and super greasy.  

We left everything almost UNTOUCHED and the server and the bus boy showed no concerned wether we are enjoying the servings.  They only asked if we are still working on it?!  And we just said no we are done and they cleared the table and gave us the check.  

On the way out, the managers didn't even ask how was our service.  

Maybe they feel as if THEY are the ones that are needed and that they don't need customers that are traveling and thus just gave us our luggage and said have a safe flight.  

We spent $103 and still gave the server his 20% gratuity so it came out to be $120 Bc I guess HE wasn't the cook.  But he should've checked in on us with our judgements.  But this is definitely the worst $120 I have ever spent on a restaurant.  Again, this is my FIRST time leaving a 1 star review.  I will never return.

Now that girl damn... and that goat!!! I have been here 2-3 times over the past couple of years. Imagine sitting next to the window with that cartoon goat staring at you when it starts snowing. Beautiful experience. Anwayyyyy I am a pretty picky person when it comes to customer service at places that are more expensive. The waiters have always been phenomenal with suggestions and with their explanations of each dish.

My boyfriend and I prefer going to places where you can share the food, so this place was great. No dish stands out as being bad or disappointing but there are a couple I dream about and wake up drooling. I am a self-described carnivore, so meat is my thing. Out of all of the dishes, the Sauteed Green Beans are our absolute favorite. We had to ask for a second helping after scarfing down the first. The waitress even gave us some hints on what made it so great!

Another standout was the Calamari Bruschetta is another standout. Honestly, I am not much of a calamari person unless it is fried. This dish changed my mind completely.

We will be back and are excited to try out some new dishes.

I had been waiting to try this restaurant since Stephanie one Top Chef and it didn't disappoint. I don't get out to Chicago that often and was ecstatic that they were able accommodate our large group only a couple weeks before our arrival.
The restaurant decor itself was fab but the food, as it should be, was the main star.
since we had a big group we were able to try a lot of different items. Below are some of my favs...
Sweet potato blue cheese pierogies
Hamachi crudo
Wood roasted pig face
Goat empanadas
Miso-butterscotch budino
But to be honest you can go wrong with anything on the menu. One of the members of out party was raving about the cauliflower, which came out late and I was saving room for dessert, so I didn't try it.

Love how creative Stephanie is with these dishes at Girl & the Goat.  We live around corner and have been here maybe a dozen times.  My only criticism is every dish is not a hit (depends on person) so restaurant is best enjoyed by parties of 4-6 so you can try/share a lot of the menu.

I've heard so much about this restaurant that I feel ashamed to not have visited them after 5 years in Chicago.... but the problem is I could never get a reservation and I hate waiting.

So I thought well why not try going there at a really off time? So we arrived at about 4:20PM on a Monday afternoon (they open at 4:30PM), and there's already a line outside. Their popularity is really no joke! Luckily though we were seated as soon as we got in, and were told to give the table back by 6PM. This wasn't a problem as the service was pretty attentive and speedy.

The menu: They don't really parse things out by the order things come out, like appetizer, entree, etc., but rather you place all of your order at once and the staff determines the serving sequence for you.

Hamachi Crudo: Very very fresh and tender raw fish, perfectly complimented by pork belly and seasoning. I wish it was a little bigger though.

Roasted Cauliflower: I have seen so many raving reviews about this dish on Yelp, and it def didn't disappoint. Perfectly cooked but not mushy yet cauliflower accompanied by cheese, pine nuts, and a little bit of spicy peppers, with dashes of mint for a spur of flavor.... best cauliflowers of my life!

Roasted Pig Face: By far the best dish for my $$. Two large chunks of very soft and tender pork with an egg on top. It does gets a little heavy and greasy towards the end though.

Goat Belly: I find it funny that this dish is called the goat belly when the actual belly portion is maybe just a little bit bigger than my thumb. I have to say, it IS a great cut of meat, but the size is just..... There were actual crab and lobster chunks though, which is nice, and they just might be bigger than the actual goat in volume.

My only complaint is the dinnerware that they use. I collect bone china and I firmly believe how nice the utensils and plates are is an important part of the dining experience. Of course since Girl & the Goat isn't some ultra fancy establishment I def wasn't expecting like Minton or Royal Albert gilded English plates, but their thick and coarse stoneware plates are like, worse than my college cafeteria's.

A last minute stop for my wife, who has never been here, and I. With no reservation, we sat at the bar for an amazing dining experience. Everything we ate from the cornbread to the adventurous duck tongue was an explosion of flavor that perfectly meshed. Our server/bartender, Jason, had not only great recommendations but also was extremely friendly without being overbearing. The timing of the dishes being served allowed you to savor what we had just eaten without wondering when the next dish would show. An appearance by head chef, Stephanie Izard, who was down to earth and very friendly, was the cherry on top of a wonderful dinner. Definitely don't be afraid to sit at the bar, and hope you get served by Jason!

Top chef winner Stephanie Izard's über popular spot is full of energy: party goers packed like sardines, friendly staff and food bursting with happy flavors!

Don't expect neat presentations: everything here is relaxed and rustic. The staff know the ins and out of the menu, but sometimes hard to flag down because the place is a buzzin!!

Bf made sure to book weeks in advance and we still couldn't dine until 9pm ...on a weeknight.

Dishes range the gamut from healthy eats, to seafood dishes and even a classic pasta ragu, but with a twist.

Every dish we had was stellar! roasted beet salad with white anchovies and avocado creme Fraiche; the kampachi crudo with pork belly; grilled octopus with guanciale and pistachios in a lemony vinaigrette.  The surprise dish is a classic ragu piled atop tagliatelle with Rosemary and caper gooseberries -- savory, delectable to the last bite.

My fave of the night was a cloud-like goat liver mousse. Light and airy, but really decadent in the mouth. I love love love the croquettes and little accoutrements, so pile it on!

There wasn't any space in my belly for either booze or dessert (since we got both at the Aviary prior to coming here) but I'm pretty much sure I would've loved it as well.

Five stars all around.  I'm a happy camper!
