review.des:
Pros
- excellent tapas dishes ( my favorite was the beet salad)
-great ambiance for a meal with both large groups and one on one dining
- hip environment
-great service! Our waitress was extremely knowledgeable about the menu, also gluten free options are available

Cons
- this is not a place you can show up to on a whim, reservations are a necessity

Other:
You won't need as much food as your waitress suggests. Ours told our group of 6 that we would need 11 dishes minimum but 7 was plenty!

I found it very overrated. I had heard so much about the place from so many people that I guess my expectations were high. We tried all the highly recommended dishes but they were all so-so, not as fantabulous as people say. Maybe a one-time visit to check it out for yourself.

Great, great meal with a couple of caveats.  Giving it 5 stars because truly, the food is excellent, but take note: they will rush you and their new pastry chef is a disappointment.

This place isn't a hard reservation to get for nothing. It is a SCENE here, right from the entrance and for the duration.  Nice cocktails, small but decent list of wines. Suggestion from the waitress of 4-5 dishes for 2 people. 4 was absolutely plenty.

Waitress staged the meal perfectly. Chickpea fritters a great and vibrant start to perk up the palette. Incredibly luscious calamari bruschetta, impossibly well cooked with a perfect sourdough actually worth savoring and a ridiculously good goat ricotta.  Pig face as advertised, though it really needed a bit more of the tamarind sauce. The smell was heavenly, the texture like bone marrow with a crunch underneath. Sinful.

The final dish, the goat belly in a vanilla butter with crab and lobster was the best thing I've ever eaten that I never ever want to eat again. Hard to explain but it was so distinctive, so delicious but a once in a lifetime event. Good thing that, because if you are going to have such a dish, the Girl and the Goat is where you need to have it.

The pastry chef has officially changed, so the budino and other appealing treats of yesteryear are no longer there, replaced with truly sad alternatives like a squash cake. Who wants a squash cake in November with the hundreds of other squash dishes already consumed this fall? We demurred, but since it was indeed a birthday, the lovely waitstaff brought us said squash cake to delight. It did have a lovely crunchy counterpart, but it was indeed just a cake that really any home cook could put together for a school bake sale. Not at all en par with the restaurant or the meal.

The other issue was the EXTREME rush of the dishes. They were literally waiting in the wings while we finished a dish and putting the next down. 5 dishes and we were pushed out in an hour. We are not slow eaters. We did not appreciate the extreme pressure to finish. I get it, it's popular. It probably will stay that way whether or not I get to savor my meal, but please: give folks a chance to wax rhapsodic for a few moments before you shove another plate on the table.

Bring your monacle because this place is DARK, so dark I had to ask for a candle, and I'm not sure what they are hiding because the food was beautiful as was the clientele.

Very glad we got here this time in Chicago. It's worth calling ahead, way ahead, to get a table.

Service was impeccable. We were greeted warmly and told our table would be ready in about ten minutes. No problem we had a good drink at the bar. I had s Bombay on the rocks that was a double shot. My friends had whiskey which tasted amazing for a non whiskey drinker.

We started with the hamachi crudo which was fantastic. The first thing I noticed was the size of the crudo it was large pieces of fish that were as fresh as pappadeaux. Then our next course was halibut and pork shoulder. The pork for not being a pork person fell off the bone. It was succulent and fantastic. But I really liked the halibut. It wasn't swimming in sauce like some places and had s great texture. I ordered a lemon drop martini that was superb. Stuff but way too good to not drink lol

We didn't stay for dessert but overall everything was wonderful. I'll be taking my lady here for her birthday :]

We had an impressive 12 course meal and one of the private rooms downstairs. We started off with the assorted house baked breads and the warm marinated olives. First and second course was the kohlrabi salad with fennel and roasted shiitake mushrooms.next we had the goat empanadas and panfried shishito peppers, followed by the wood fire Shrimp and chickpea fritter. We then had  - family style serving of the following plates: roasted cauliflower, blackened catfish, the sautéed green beans, wood grilled broccoli and last but not least the crispy braised pork shank. Everything was excellent and finished off with a selection of desserts.
Fun small plates. Best frog legs I've had. Some plates weren't that great- I don't know why everyone raves about the pig face dish.
The best. You won't be disappointed. I love the non-pretentious atmosphere. Just great food and drinks.

How did I hate thee? Let me count the ways:

- I hated the crowded, cramped floor.
- I hated how deafeningly loud it was.
- I hated that our waitress flatly refused to let us order a third pig face, thrice asserting that three would be too many.
- I hated that they insisted on forcing a family-style experience on us, bringing our food out "from lightest to heaviest" even though we had each ordered separate items not necessarily planning on splitting evenly.
- I hated paying $19 for two- TWO- "divers scallops" which barely outweighed a bay scallop.
- I hated that they flat-out didn't bring my husband one of his dishes. Ever.
- I hated the goat belly confit, which was the most disgusting and confusing dish I'd ever had.

Fun little story on that last one. As we were waiting in the lounge area for our table to be ready, we overheard a girl complaining in a shocked way to her waiter about how bad one of the dishes she had was. There was a nearly-full plate in front of her; she had basically taken a bite and opted out. She went on and on about how bad it was, how none of the flavors went together, and she didn't even need it taken off of her bill, was just so horrified that she had to say something. I assumed she was being pretentious and aiming to have the dish removed from her bill. Then at dinner after I had ordered the confit and we were talking about the girl in the lounge, I started to realize that the confit had been the dish in question. I was open-minded, but trust me when I say it was one of the worst dishes I've ever had. We passed it around the table just so we could have a shared awful experience. My husband captured it perfectly when he said "it's like if a clown college had a culinary division."  It was so wacky and terrible.

I know this comes off as really angry and snide. But it was just a really, really bad dining experience.

If you only read the first sentence of my 250th review, then know this: this is one of the best restaurants I have ever been to. We were able to get a reservation at 10:30. This place states they close at 11 or 12 depending on the day, but that is when the kitchen closes. The place is dark, with dim lighting all around. The dining area is massive, and anywhere you sit, you are able to see the pretty expansive kitchen. The restrooms are very clean and well maintained.

This place serves small plates and each small plate is sufficient for one to two people. All of the items I ordered were great, but if I had to choose one it would have to be the Wood Grilled Broccoli. Without a doubt, it was the best broccoli I have ever had. One bite of it and you instantly taste the transfer of smoke from the wood to the broccoli. It's good by itself, but the cheese that is on the bottom of the plate compliments it. I also enjoyed the ham frites. The fries are thinly cut and comes with two different dipping sauces. I both the sauces, but the cheddar beer sauce was out of control. I had to control myself from not finishing that dipping sauce myself! The Duck tongues were good as well, as the chip gave the soft, delicate meat and good crunch; however, I found it to be a bit too salty for my liking.  Overall, the food here is top class, and I definitely recommend getting at least 4 to 5 plates if you eating with one or two people.

The service here is good. The servers treat you well, give great advice on what you should order, and are respectful and attentive. This was by far the best food I had in Chicago, and the numerous reviews of this place only proves that this is definitely a place to try when in you're in this city.
There is really nothing I can add to the 1,000"s of reviews already posted.  They are consistently amazing, from hosting to food & libations.  That is all.

I've heard that "Girl and the Goat was the best meal of my life" from more than a few people. We tried it tonight and it didn't fully live up to our expectations. The vegetables were amazing. Both the green beans and broccoli had great char flavor, seasoning, and garnishes. The escargot pierogis and goat empanadas were amazing. The calamari bruschetta was lacking in flavor and cold. What really effected our experience was the service. Our waitress was in no way helpful. While she was never rude, she did not give an inviting feeling and shot glances at our family when they inquired about the menu. She rushed our dishes out and we left wishing we had someone else- the sommelier, and runners were all super nice and helpful. Perhaps she was having a bad day, but can we trade for someone that wants to help customers!? Girl and Goat- keep up the great food quality, but don't let your service slip.

Everything we had here was delicious and the service was excellent (friendly and incredibly attentive without being invasive)! Portions were much larger than expected. I would definitely come back. Only slight downside is that it is noisy inside and you're seated close to other tables so having a full conversation can be a slight challenge...but the fact that everything else is so fantastic makes up for this.

Highlights:  
-Bacon Gouda Bread (could you ever really go wrong with this combination of ingredients?)
-Pig Face (I think all the other reviews speak for this)
-Sweet Potato + Blue Cheese Pierogi (interesting combination of flavors that works well)

While the following items were still good, next time I would forego:
-Confit Goat Belly (small portion and too many different flavors that don't quite blend)
-Pineapple Fund Side Up (good but not overwhelmingly memorable)

Okay people. You really need to listen to me on this one... If you haven't visited this place ... you need to GO. Call today and make a reservation for as soon as you can, I promise you will walk away with feeling of pure happiness & maybe even in a food coma .

Here was our visit:

My drink of choice (or should I say what my husband chose for me because I could not decide) was Jack in Detox. It could have been shaken or stirred or whatever a little more because at the top of the drink I thought I was doing a shot every time I took a sip but once I got down a little father, it was amazing.

Miso hungry - BREAD heaven! Well, maybe it wasn't just the bread - the butter - OH HOW WE LOVED THE BUTTER & apple saucish (yep, I think just made that word up) - the apple saucish stuff was delicious.. it was a cross between apple sauce and apple butter so I will go with saucish.

Warm olives - Interesting and not bad at all but they are just olives, you know? Nothing really to write home about.

Fried Naked Cowboy - What? Egg salad & capers on a fried oyster? Who does that? Who thinks of that? The great minds at Girl & The Goat, that's who! It was a party in my mouth.. just different levels of flavor and amazingness.

Pig Face - First of all, I have to give our server props, I don't remember her name but she was awesome! That said, someone ran this to our table & our server noticed right away that the proper way to devour this delectable creation hadn't been shown to us, so she came right over & hooked us up. Every bite we took had a different flavor. Unbelievably delicious. A must try!

Pork Shank - Hellllooooo beautiful! The pork literally falls off the bone and this sauce that they put on the plate with it... OH My GAWD! So delicious - the flavor is spectacular and it has a little bit of heat, perfect for the dipping of the yummy pork.

So - after ALL of that, we were obviously stuffed! I really wanted to try dessert and I am so thankful I did... bittersweet chocolate - um, can I just tell you that is was the BEST dessert I EVER ate!

Oh & before tip we were under $100. Yep, I said it under a hundred bucks.. A few of the best things I have ever eaten & it didn't cost a fortune.

Girl & The Goat.. thank you for making me a happy foodie :)

I can't wait to show my face there again and try a million different things!

Just as good as everyone says. Make sure to go with a lot of people so that you can split as many plates as possible. Be adventurous and be prepared to spend some $$$. Everything about this place is high class!

I was traveling for business with a colleague.  We tried about a week in advance and couldn't get a table for two.  They were booked for the entire week we were in town.  So, when she flew back a day early I went alone.  I went early and was able to find a lone seat at the bar.  Moral of the story is - you better plan far in advance!  The food was great!  I have to say, the dessert was amazing.  Small portions mean you can totally order two of them and not feel bad about it!

Service and food were variable.

We had been waiting at the bar section 15 minutes past our reservation time. No big deal. Two seats open up at the bar, so we decide to sit down. As I'm taking my seat, the bartender approaches and places a napkin and silverware in front of my new seat and says, "You can't sit here. I'm moving somebody to this seat. You had your chance." This caught me off guard and made me a little angry, an emotion that no restaurant wants a customer to experience. Simply put, this was not the best way for the bartender to handle the situation. I understand she was busy, and she may have had a friend visiting whom she wanted to serve. But she should have taken a more polite approach.

We are seated and our server is fantastic. Personable, knowledgable, fun.

We order four dishes: goat empanadas, fried chickpeas, pig face, and pork loin.

Goat empanadas: interesting in that you experience different tastes as you chew and swallow, but wouldn't order again.
Fried chickpeas: safe and somewhat bland. I understand they were trying to showcase their locally grown tomatoes, but the dish lacked gumption.
Pig face: fantastic combination of high end hangover brunch with Chinese takeout.
Pork loin: best pork I've ever eaten. The meat fell off the bone.

This selection, despite the fact that it contained a couple dishes that we didn't necessarily like, was too meat heavy. If we return we would order one or two lighter dishes and one or two meat dishes.

So, to summarize, we experienced two extremes of both service and food. Some were great, some unfortunate.

Just.... so good!

Stephanie Izard has some of the sharpest tastebuds in the food business. The flavor levels and combinations at all of her restaurants never cease to impress me.

I have been here several times and highlights include:

*The rotating breads + butter - do not skip this. Always a favorite of mine.
*Roasted cauliflower - pickled peppers, mint... I dream of this dish.
*Pork Shank - good lord! Make sure to save room and/or have friends to share this one with.
*Goat Empanadas - just damn tasty!
*Dessert - get something. You will not regret it. Take a few laps if you think you are too full. It will be worth it! (caramel corn & malt balls is like childhood in a dish)
*Cocktails - always very good options. Have yet to be disappointed.

We had a good meal. However, I don't think it lived up to the hype. It was your typical trendy weird animal part bistro that is "in" right now, with ok dishes and a side of attitude. The waitress assured us that "the pleasure is all yours". The pig face was a solid attempt at pulled pork that you can get for $20 less at Green Street Meats. Overall, id come back here....in 3 years!

Aside from Alinea, this was my favorite meal in the Chi Town!

// LOCATION // West Loop across the street from Au Cheval and Little Goat Diner.

// RESERVATIONS // Very necessary if its a busy weekend. We went Memorial Day weekend with a large party and made our reservations more than 1 month ahead of time. If you have a smaller party, you may get lucky with walk in.

// SERVICE // Excellent. Your water cup will never be empty and I was very impressed by how the dishes were brought out and staggered so you can build on the flavor compositions and appreciate each dish before sampling the next.

// FOOD //
    + Shishito peppers: Good with a spicy kick
    + Tongue salad: Loved the citrus-y dressing
    + Goat carpaccio: light and refreshing
    + Grilled octopus: Super tender and well flavored
    + Pork shank: ridiculously fall-off-the-bone-shred-it-with-a-fork tender
    + Pan roasted halibut: very savory

*tip: Make reservations!
*tip: Approximately 2 dishes per person is good to start with if you are trying to get full here. Order 2 of dishes you really want to try if you have a party of 5 or more so there is enough to go around.

Was in Chicago for work, so came early and sat at the bar, where they offer full menu service. It is an open space, with views of the kitchen, and a comfortable, roomy bar to the side. The bartender was very friendly, and made me feel comfortable as a single diner. There were others at the bar as well. I had the Boondocks Saint as my cocktail, and still think about it, it was that good! Bourbon, spices, orange twist. Delish.
A guest at the restaurant may order some items as half servings, so I opted for that on two of my dishes:
Roasted Beets: I love them, and they were especially good, along with some green beans and avocado crème fraiche. I also had a half order of the Calamari Bruschetta. I didn't even know that calamari could be so utterly tender! Probably the best I have ever had. However, the rest of the bruschetta was good, but not exceptional. Comes with goat milk ricotta, goat bacon and green apples. Get it for the calamari alone!
My main entrée was the Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face. I had no idea what I was going to see, but it was fabulous. Rich and savory, with pieces of pork covered with tiny potato stix, cilantro, and a perfect sunny side up egg. You cut into the yolk, and let the creaminess of the yolk mix in with the other flavors, and really, it was so good.
I was unable to resist dessert, so I went with the Caramel corn and Malt Balls, and it was even better than I had expected. Malt flavored ice cream, covered with a chocolate hardened thin shell, and tiny squares of ganache that were lightly dusted with malt powder, on the plate with bites of caramel corn that was crispy and just the right size. So very good, especially those tiny ganache squares.
Not terribly expensive, depending on the number of dishes you order as well as the alcohol you consume. I'd come here again, no question. So worth it.

My wife came with me on this trip and she was so looking forward to the goat and it did not disappoint.   Wow amazing.  We ordered 5 dishes and a bottle of wine
Wine was her own blend from walla walla Washington.  Great winery 3 hours from our home in Idaho.  A fantastic blend.  Our waitress was amazing to walk us thru our meal.  
Again Vegies were the bomb. Magic beans, cauliflower, and broccoli the  beans are the best. Had the duck tong loved it my wife thought too greasy. Added a fish so we had the mussels. They were outstanding.   My wife ordered the item free bread. Even I liked it.  
Best meal of our foodie trip

UGH!  GO HERE.  Just do it.

When you go, you must order:

Sauteed Green Beans - my favorite out of everything we ordered
Calamari Bruschetta
Red Fish
Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face
Crisp Braised Pork Shank

The ham frites are fabulous but relatively inside the box.  We ordered them in case some of the other items failed to satisfy.  The goat empanadas were also really good, but like a lot of other yelpers mentioned, I didn't notice a huge difference between these empanadas and others I've had in the past.

My friends also raved about the drinks!  Among the favorites were the Very Old Fashioned and the Boondocks Saints.

For dessert, get the Caramel Corn & Malt Balls.  So weird, but so good.

Was here earlier this year, landing a reservation I booked almost 4 months in advance for a special event.

It was interesting, but I have to say, the food, while inventive and interesting, was overshadowed by the fact that (a) strangers were practically sitting on my lap, (b) the noise level prevented me from having any conversation with my dining partner and (c) the staff were, at best, frosty, if not outright unfriendly.

Glad I tried it, and in general, appreciate Stephanie Izard's ideas. But I think once was probably enough for me (your mileage may vary).

I love the Girl & The Goat and Stephanie Izard... How could you not? Although, how can you get in? You have to reserve a bit advance or make some friends! Izard is meticulous about making sure the food is the best, daily, and you won't be disappointed with your meal! Everything is good here.

Been here 3 times now and think I can give it a fair review.  Girl and the goat was hyped up from the get go but met my expectations. A lot of great dishes but they were hit or miss.

Dishes that really stood out were the grilled broccoli, escargot raviolli, the octopus, lamb ribs,  all the raw dishes (oysters, himachi, trout tare tare).

Some of the other dishes had too many flavors going on that didn't mix well or just had bacon randomly thrown on. The diver scallops were extremely salty the one time I had them.  Breads are not essential. Just filler but the spreads for them can be nice.

As for the goat dishes, not a big fan. That and the pig face are much more a novelty. Try it once and that's it. Definitely a place to go but I don't know if I'll be going back for another pass anytime soon.
Amazing--from cocktails to dinner to dessert. 5 star pleasure, all the way. I still dream about the roasted cauliflower. The halibut was phenomenal. I will be back!

I'm a big fan of Girl & the Goat (and Little Goat).  Had dinner there last night, which was amazing but for how much the bill was, we left slightly hungry, which is a shame.  Service was amazing, the busboy was really attentive in switching out our plates, sometimes in the middle of a course.

Grilled pig face - I order it everytime I come because why mess with a good thing? Delicious!
Mussels - the chorizo croutons and sauce were so good, could have had more mussels
Grilled Baby Octopus - really good but a small portion - Bottlefork has this dish which I actually prefer
Sweet Potato Pierogis - crispy and delicious
Rebirth of Honest Cocktail - really smooth
Friends at Cascade Hollow - probably wouldn't order again, just a bit too sweet for me

Great food. Loved the fried oysters, roasted cauliflower, leek salad. Highlight was the pig face with a fried egg on top, delicious.
Wonderful and fun evening!

I love Top Chef and I love Chicago-native, Stephanie Izard so, I had to come here. Our reservation was at 8:45pm and they called to confirm the day before. I tried getting an earlier time but there was none.

There's ample parking in the area. Make sure you go to the right building though since there's Little Goat across the street with a huge picture of a goat on top that will easily catch your attention. The interior was very nice and we got seated as soon as we got there.

We tried a few things. Tapas-style for about $12-20 a plate and desserts for $8. We got goat empanadas, escargot raviolo, kampachi crudo, goat belly and pig face. For dessert we had PB& J and bittersweet chocolate.

Goat Empanadas:
Goat meat, feta, pickled beets and tzatziki. The first dish that was served to us and got us all excited about this place. 5/5

Kona Kampachi Crudo:
Pork belly, caperberries and chili aioli. From the great empanadas, this dish wasn't as great. Thin slices of kampachi, 4 small pieces of crispy pork belly, some halves of caperberries and 3 paper-thin slices of bread. 3.5/5

Escargot Ravioli:
Escargot inside ravioli with bacon tamarind sauce. The disappointment continues. I love escargot and this was just too heavy because of the ravioli.  The sauce was too thin and runny that it wouldn't stick to the ravioli at all. The idea was great but I think if this was served on individual Chinese spoons, it would've been much better - you get the sauce and the ravioli in one bite. 2/5

Confit Goat Belly:
Goat belly, lobster, crab, fennel in bourbon butter. Lobster claw pieces, chunks of crab meat and a baton of slightly fatty, tender, juicy goat belly. This was one of my favorites from Girl & the Goat. This prevented us from leaving the restaurant. 5/5

Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face:
Pork cheek, potato sticks, sunny side egg (over easy), tamarind, cilantro and red wine maple. Another winner in my book. Breakfast on a plate. Like bacon, eggs and potatoes. Crisp pork cheek and potato sticks, soft egg, sweet and sour tamarind and added layers of flavor from the cilantro and red wine maple. YUM! 5/5

Bittersweet Chocolate:
Shiitake-caramel gelato, brownie and toffee creme fraiche. The gelato was great. The brownie was just alright and there was too much of it. I liked the hint of toffee. Marginal dessert. 3/5

PB&J:
Salted peanut semifreddo, brioche doughnuts and grape granita. I'm not a fan of peanut butter but I was pleasantly surprised by this dessert. Cold semifreddo and granita, and warm doughnuts. The semifreddo wasn't too nutty and the grape granita was perfect with it. Delish! 4/5

Service was great. Bread isn't complimentary. Next time I come back, I'll skip the escargot ravioli and crudo...and get something else.

Girl & the goat was a little overhyped but still so delicious. I wish I could've tried more things but I guess I'll just have to be back.

My favorites:
- PIG FACE - sooooo good, just order it! I wish I got two
- Diver scallops - cooked perfectly and yummy flavors
- Bittersweet chocolate - the dessert melts in your mouth and it's the perfect sweet salty mix

The decor, ambiance and service are all top notch.

If you can't get reservations (because you should make them at least 2-3 months in advance), you can sit at the bar and order the full menu!

pics.caption: All my favorites: diver scallops, pig face and bittersweet chocolate!

review.des:
Best experience I ever had a a restaurant. We heard from a few people we knew that this was the place to go. I did see a mix amount of reviews but my cousin said I had to go. So we tried to make reservations 3 weeks in advance because we heard it was hard to get in and we still only got a 11:30 pm reservation. But we thought hey we are on vacation lets eat something a little earlier it should be ok.

So we get there at 10:45 hoping they could take us early. It doesn't hurt and we were already ready anyways. So we get there and they said they probably cant seat us till 11:30 so we said ok that is fare lets go by the bar area and relax. They do have a lounge area you could eat at that was really empty when we were there but the seating just a little more uncomfortable. But its up to you if you cant get a reservation try walking in and sitting there.

So, as we are getting walked to our table they said its your lucky day you get to see at the Chef's Table. Although this was a cool experience I will say it gets very hot because your so close to the stoves. Also you don't know what to order because a million things come out and EVERYTHING looks so good. So It is a little confusing because your wondering what you should eat.

We had:
The green beans and those were surprisingly really good. I was a little nervous to order them because I felt like they are just green beans but I was so wrong. The combination of flavor was excellent. It does have fish sauce so if your not into that I would not order this.

Complementary: because we were sitting here we did get something on the chef which was the cauliflower which was also very good. The pine nuts give it a nice crunch and it was really good.

Bread: we had the Sweet Onion Brioche Tarragon butter. Spring lamby jam when we were waiting. The bread was average but the onion spread was amazing. It was sweet and it reminded us of something my fiance mom makes. It is a caramelized onion on bread.

Fish - We had the halibut. OMG BEST THING on the menu! You have to have this. I believe it was the best fish I ever had and we live in Vegas and have had some incredible fishes but this was excellent. I would come back here and order 3 of these and just make it my meal. It melts in your mouth and it was just so tasty.

Pig face - so we ordered this because everyone suggested it and it was very good. The meat is tender and juicy. It also has a crunch to it.

Goat- since this is called girl and a goat we thought we had to order a goat dish. Confit Goat Belly Bourbon​ Butter . Lobster and Crab . Fennel was what we ordered. Although the dish looked very pretty it was my least favorite. I would pass on this one. The lobster and crab on the meal is really good but the goat wasn't for me. Its a very small piece of meat and it isn't worth the money your spending on it. Overall our experience was great and I highly recommend this spot. I truly had a great time with my fiance and our waiter was so nice. I wish I got his name but he was amazing!

Ate here while visiting Chicago and WISH this were in DC! We, including my picky 1.5 year old daughter, loved every item we ordered: kohlrabi salad, chickpea fritter, calamari bruschetta, pan roasted halibut, woodfire glazed lamb ribs, and goat empanadas. If given the opportunity, I would go back enough times to try everything on the menu.

Love this restaurant. Been here only two times but both were stellar experiences. Food is amazing and service was good too. The only reason I'm not giving it five stars is cause it's so loud. Challenging for me cause my husband is so sensitive to noise.
Both times we were able to get a table, w/o reservations, by coming early, 4:30 pm, and the last time we sat at the communal table outside which was fun.
Was able to get many gluten free options, even a loaf of gluten free bread, which was great.
Lots of veggie options which I love!  Want to include a few pics here cause the food is so beautiful also but can't figure out how on my phone.

- TIP: The portions are actually fairly generous. When the server says 3-4 dishes per person...that can add up to be a ton of food.

- CON: Service.  One of the few times in my life where service actually ruined a meal.  They require to order everything at once; which is annoying but acceptable when places course everything out correctly.  When we received our main (a hearty chicken dish) before 2 of our appetizers, and our other main (pig face) didn't come out until 20 minutes after we had finished (and were full) from everything else...that odd flow really ruins the experience.  Also our server was absent most of the time; I had to flag someone else down to get a beer after trying for more than 15 minutes to find him.

- BOTTOM LINE: It's really a shame; this place has great quality food, and was supposed to be the highlight of our visit to Chicago, but this particular dining experience was ruined.

I took my customer for a dinner to this place after going through the reviews. I was so lucky to get a reservation on the same day (yeh, I am telling the truth, for the same day) at 4.45 PM. What an amazing experience it was! As several of the reviewers mentioned, the food size is small so you may have to order 2-3 dishes for each person so that makes the per person price to go up as well. But the taste of the food and the ambiance were really good. I will keep going to this place for sure.

I came at around 10 pm on a Thursday and was able to get seated within 10 min, but we decided to stay at the lounge/couch side since the full menu is available there and it was probably easier to hear each other since the restaurant is noisy. If I didn't know any better is think I was at an Asian fusion restaurant. Anyway, nothing here disappointed. And be sure to end with that budino.

JONASAPPROVED!

Great food and service   Certainly a great night out
You will definitely want to try the deserts.

After researching restaurants on yelp and base on my friend's suggestions, we booked a dinner here at Girl & The Goat.  We were only able to find a late reservation online. I found out yesterday that if you just walk in, you might be able to be seated early as they reserve some seats for walk-in.  That's good to know.  We waited at the lounge area with drinks before being called to our table ahead of our reservation.

This restaurant is located in a remote area of Chicago. It's a bit far from our hotel and there weren't much in the area.  We had arrived early to check out the area only to find nothing around so we went inside.

We ordered a couple of beer in the lounge area.  The restaurant is indeed very popular and packed.  Everyone seem to be having a good time with drinks, good food, and good company.  Although big, it felt very cozy inside and I love the music playing.

We were seated next to other couples.  It was very easy to overhear other people's conversations. As others have mentioned here, the dishes are tapa style.  The price range is not too bad as the most expensive was $25 (pork shank).  We ordered 6 total and it came to about $100 plus tip.  Not too bad but it does add up!

We ordered a few dishes:

Roasted cauliflower: This was a very hearty dish.  Pretty good price for the amount you get.  We were full by the time we finished.  It had roasted cauliflower, pine nuts, mint, and jalapeno.  The flavors were good.

Koni Kampachi Crudo:  Light and quite tasty.  There were only 3 pieces of fried pork belly!

Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face:  Not quite what you would imagine.  This was good.  It tasted like stewed pork belly.  You just have to get past the idea.  The three sauces that came with it (cilantro, tamarind, and red-wine maple) were yummy.  The sunny-side egg was perfectly cooked and went really well with the pig face. I would recommend this dish.

Crisp Braised Pork Shank: For the most part the pork was perfectly cook and tender.  Quite tasty too. There's a few dry pieces.  I did not like the squash shitake kimchee.  This was our last dish. We were already full.

Goat Blue Bread with fig butter and fennel onion jam: Love the fennel onion jam!  The fig butter was good too. Wished we could get seconds. Only $4 though.

Butterscotch Pudding was so yummy!  Would have it again.

I would probably come back again if they had more selections. There are so many restaurants in Chicago to try!

pics.caption: Goat blue bread. Love their spreads

review.des: I dined here with 3 other vegetarians and everything was incredibly delicious and flavorful. They not only had many vegetarian options but they also gave us a small menu of vegan options. Every dish was completely different in flavor profiles; we left satisfied and full. I really liked the broccoli and the vegan bucatini the best.

Perhaps there was too much hype for G&G but after trying a 14 dishes, I wasn't impressed enough to give it 5 stars.  But there were some awesome plates:

* Pork shank with kimchi sauce -  The tangy kimchi sauce really made this one shine.
* Fried squash blossoms - I could eat an entire plate of these babies.
* Escargot ravioli - I've had escargot several times in a traditional preparation but this was the first time in a ravioli.  The pasta was perfect.
* Chickpea fritters - Unexpectedly light and airy!
* Goat belly confit - You can't beat pork belly, but good nevertheless.

Had I only tried the plates above, G&G would be an easy 5-stars but these plate were a bit of a letdown:

* Pig Face - 3.5 stars - I was expected to love this one given the ingredients and rave reviews but it wasn't that elevated from a good breakfast once you mix it all together.
* Fried duck tongues - 2.5 stars - Although an interesting protein, the tongues were just crispy bits overpowered by the black bean sauce.  I'm sure the braised beef tongue would be better tongue dish.
* Grilled octopus - 2.5 stars - Slightly tough and I didn't like the combination of grilled veggies.

The desserts were just okay for me but I generally prefer sweeter ones.  I expected the goat cheese one to be right up my alley but it was too tart and goaty for me.  

The atmosphere was classy but laid back and the service was excellent.  The waitress made sure we didn't order too many dishes for our group.

Top notch food & drinks. I met up with my college roomie and we did a little bar hopping and ended our night at Girl & the Goat. We were told just over an hour wait and I convinced my friend to stay, that it was going to be worth it. Everything was really spectacular!

serrano salsa & bread
sweet corn pierogis
diver scallops
roasted pig face
confit goat belly

I couldn't convince myself to get dessert by this point of the night. We sat at the communal patio table out front and it was the perfect night to do so.
I love this restaurant. They have a great atmosphere and best of all they offer a delicious vegan menu! This is one of my favorite spots.
Not a place to go to, if you love Indian food and the masala. The food is kinda bland, there are fruits in everything. It's expensive if you are vegan, not great value for money

Not much to say what hasn't been said. This is a 5 star restaurant and should be on your must visit list if you are visiting Chicago. I made my reservations when I was planning a visit to Chicago. Good thing I guess because everyone I told said "How did you get in? Did you make them 2 months ago or something?" Yes I did.

So I ended up going solo and the waiter informed me that many of their dishes were meant for sharing. The menu had about 3 main sections, if you count meat/goat as one section, and the server recommended I go with around 3. they offered to do half portions so that I could maximize the tasting. The server was against me calling it tapas style even thought with the small plate multi-course style it essentially is.

Here is what I had"

Spanish Harlem Cocktail - Perfect mix of sweetness and booze I was looking for in a cocktail. I highly recommend this drink.

Goat Blue - Focaccia bread with fig butter and fennel onion jam. It is as good as it sounds. I probably shouldn't have ordered this with all the other food but I saw someone else eating and had to try it.

Escargot ravioli - Without knowing that this was escargot inside the ravioli I wouldn't have guessed. So if your not into more exotic food, don't worry it's safe. This was a rich and very flavorful start to my tasting

Pigs Head - Just like the last item, it is not as odd as it sounds. Just some really tender shredded pork at the end of the day. Very flavorful, a must get item if it is on the menu.

Cauliflower - Even if you traditionally don't like Cauliflower like the waiter told me, its phenomenal. I have to put this in the category of a must get item too. Unfortunately I think everything here is outstanding.

Butterscotch Miso Budino - What seems like what would be a simple dessert is still executed flawlessly. When the server told me that it came with a butterscotch candied bacon it was a game changer. The dessert was light enough where I was still able to enjoy it while being slightly full.

No!!!! Just no! Not unless you're a millionaire of sorts, if you're a college student/struggling young adult looking for someplace nice to eat with your friends then keep looking! This place is extremely overpriced and they don't tell you ya gotta order multiple entrees for you to be full. Each one couldn't fill a squirrel. And it's very unique meals so it's not a very accommodating menu unless you grew up eating that hoity toity food. Service was bad too the dude was super slow and like tryna act all super fancy with those big words to describe the food. Idk if y'all feel me but you just gotta b that type of person if you wanna drop $50 a person then make a mcdonalds run immediately afterwards...SMH!

Wish we had "Girl & the Goat" in every single metropole in US. They are the most successful example of a chef owned restaurants. Most of the chef owned restaurants are small and they are afraid of cooking for the crowds but here it is way different. Chef Stephanie Izard proves that talented chefs can feed crowds. I am proud of her and her great restaurant and her team. You must try everything on the menu. I have been there 5-6 times and every time it is a new excitement. Looking forward to dining in again, hopefully very soon.
Wow what an experience! This place is hard to get in but I can tell why. Try it for yourself I guarantee you won't leave displeased.
We tried some small dishes and everything was really good . Goat liver mousse was definitely my favorite!

The menu is extremely well thought out and  both food and drink taste amazing. We ordered the lamb ribs, brioche, and goat empanadas. All were excellent. Unfortunately there was a hair in my lamb ribs but the staff was apologetic and promptly replaced my order. To my surprise they didn't comp the order on the bill, something I assumed was standard across restaurants. Otherwise, great atmosphere and date night spot.

The hubby and I dined the Girl & the Goat three years ago but made the huge mistake of having a large lunch beforehand and early reservation here. We were too full to enjoy the meal. This time, we came starving.

We ordered the three types of oysters (four oysters in each order) which came raw, barbecued and fried. Delicious. We also got the escargot ravioli as well as the goat's liver mousse with its yummy bread, tasty green beans and the famous pig's face. All the dishes were delicious and left us feeling very satisfied.

Great food, great service. They were kind enough to let us grab a table as a walk in and I'm very glad they were. Had the octopus, halibut, goat belly, and the pork shank. Walked out absolutely stuffed and happy. Halibut was the highlight of the meal.

Cocktails were quite good as well.

Ambiance and service were great!  Food came out quickly and we never had an empty plate on our table for more than 10 seconds before someone came by to clear it off. (5/5 stars)

Food was also pretty tasty, but everything was on the salty side so I can't give 5 stars in good conscience.  (4/5 stars)

We ordered the roasted broccoli, shrimp, calamari, pig face, and goat loin. Again, all really tasty, but just a smidge too salty.  Also, I know the pig face seems to be one of their "specialty" dishes, but I thought it was just alright - a little oily and one-note. Next time, I would def order something other than the pig face. Feels like I sort of "wasted" a plate by choosing that.

Would come here again though. If you haven't been, it's worth going at least once.

A much belated review but seeing as I may no longer be a Chicago girl as of soon, I thought it was about time to write this one up! We enjoyed a ton of dishes at Girl & the Goat, and just as well since we might've hit up about half the menu in one visit!

Some of my favorites:
- Start off your meal with the honey sambal brioche bread!  
- Delicious vegetarian options: chickpea fritter, celery root and cheddar pierogies, and the kale salad. I was super impressed with their non-meat options because those were very much on par with their meat dishes.
- Grilled pork belly
- And my personal favorite dish of the night, the crispy beef short ribs!

The seafood eaters at the table further enjoyed the grilled baby octopus, the scallops and the pan roasted trout (not bad!).

The roasted pig face didn't live up to the hype for me. I'm not sure what it was but it left a weird aftertaste in my mouth. I also thought the escargot ravioli was a pretty big miss. I was super excited to try it but in all honesty, I felt like I was eating dirt inside the ravioli (really expensive dirt at that), which was a sentiment echoed by a few of my fellow friends....which naturally, kind of killed the entire dish for us.

Nonetheless, a very successful night of eating your brains out at Girl & the Goat. Very exciting indeed. Can't wait to have a similar night at Stephanie's Izard's Duck Duck Goat upon my next return to Chicago!

We are visiting Chicago for the first time and my friend said this restaurant is a must! So we made a reservation 3 weeks ago for our first night in Chicago. The staff were extremely friendly and gave us exceptional service both at the bar and at our table. We ordered 4 plates which was way too much for me but the fiancé was able to finish my part! Our favorite dishes were the calamari bruschetta and the shank. We thought the oysters were good and the empanadas were ok. We didn't have room for dessert so we said no but our server brought out one to try - the peanut butter and jelly option which we thought was ok (to be fair I'm a chocolate girl). The local draft beer called three half ass and the rose wine were excellent. Really I would give them a 4 and a half!

pics.caption: Calamari bruschetta - sooooo good! Must try!

review.des:
After finally visiting this restaurant I understand the hype about Girl and the Goat!!! The food was delicious and the atmosphere was so fun and inviting. I made a reservation for 8:45 and by the time we left there were still people pouring in and waiting for tables at 10:30!

The chickpea fritters and the escargot dumplings were incredible, and I would 100% reorder both dishes if I go back! I also tried the pan fried shishito peppers and the grilled baby octopus and both were amazing.

I have to say though that the best part of my meal was the dessert. The Pot de Creme was one of the best desserts I have ever had and I would highly recommend it if you like sesame flavors!! I would go back just for this dessert.

Overall, I had a great time and would love to go back sometime soon. It was a lot louder and more casual than I was expecting but I loved hearing the R. Kelly and 50 cent playing in the background. I would definitely recommend this restaurant!l

pics.caption: escargot dumplings (you have to get these!!!)
pan fried shishito peppers - so good and spicy

review.des:
Ham Frites and Pig Face. This is all you really need to know about this restaurant. I've been to G and the G several times (and through several iterations of the menu) and I always ALWAYS get these two dishes.  

Aside from my obvious affinity for pork, I'm also a big fan of veggies and I find they do veggies really well here. This is important because with such a deliciously meat heavy menu, you definitely need a little levity. Honestly, I don't think I've ever had a bad dish here. The only note I would make is to either come hungry or bring all of your closest friends because you're going to want to try everything and the portions are pretty decently sized.

We took my mother in law here when she was in town. she liked it as much as we did. it was not what i expected but very pleasantly surprised as i did not know what to expect. we ordered 1 to many dishes so be careful when you order as not to be led to order too much food. very tasty.

Excellent - easily 4.5 stars

My favorite dish that came to the table was far and away the calamari bruschetta. It was perfectly cooked and the flavors were so on point I could have eaten just that and left on cloud nine. Others at the table loved the oven roasted pig face, which, while incredibly rich, was a really great dish.

The roasted beets were the only real miss. I don't know what I missed but they tasted like pickled beets. They weren't bad at all, but I wouldn't recommend them.

Oh, and the pineapple fun side up dessert was probably the best dessert I've had in my life. Seriously, it was delicious beyond words.

Loved the chickpea fritters and the goat empanadas. Also loved the sugo... so glad the waiter recommended it. Only thing I didn't love so much was the broccoli dish (waiter recommended it, was healthy but not as wow as all the other dishes). And loved the service.

I was alone on a business trip. A great waiter helped me secure a spot at the bar. I loved the thoughtfulness of this restaurant in offering half portions for singles so was still able to a few dishes vs just one app and entree :) Yum!

I have wanted to come to this place since Stephanie won Top Chef. So I came with very high expectations. Being from Austin, the food scene is very rustic New American. I made my reservation two months in advance for my husband's 30th birthday dinner. The ambiance is dark inside. We came at 930p on a Tuesday and the restaurant was jam packed. Let me warn you, the portions are actually very generous. We ordered 6 dishes between two people and were almost miserably full. We started with the olive bread. I have not had bread this perfect since I was in Rome and Paris. Kudos! Then we had the oysters with bacon and hollandaise, this was fair I thought, not mindblowing Then we got the octopus. An ABSOLTE MUST when visiting this restaurant. Another mindblowing moment. The charceuterie plate was fine...nothing much to speak of. Then we got the green beans as well as the pig face. Another two absolute musts! At this point we were very full and the waiter brought us toffee ice cream with popcorn. It was great. Overall a lot of homeruns but there were some low points as well. I must be honest and since I eat a lot of this type of food in Austin, I didn't find it very different or as exciting. However, the food was fabulous and I would definitely come back (1000+ miles) for the bread, octupus, and green beans. The food was yummy! Great for a fancy date night.

I've been to Little Goat numerous times and wasn't a big fan (read my Little Goat review). However, I'm a fan of Girl and the Goat. I came here for meeting dinner and we had a customized menu (not sure what the regular menu had to offer). Unfortunately, i wasn't able to take photo of each dish (due to professionalism for this dinner). Overall, it was served family style and each entree mostly veggie dishes were well balanced with flavor. If you have nut allergy, you may have challenge with the menu. Overall, will come back and try something different! BTW, i heard it's really hard to score a reservation.

House bread - it was delicious and hearty. Warm and soft complimented with cream cheese butter and tomato.

warm marinated olive- Usually not a fan of olive, but these were plump and juicy like a cherry.

kohirabi salad (fennel, evalon, toasted almond) - Flavorful and refreshing greenies.

Grilled baby octopus (fava bean, pea tips, pistachio, and lemon vinaigrette) - one of my favorite!! the octopus was not too well done and soft. I really like the compliments with the octopus.

green garlic pierogies (rhubarb chimichurri) - Favorite... the pierogie was lightly fried and was soft with potato inside. Love it!

roasted cauliflower (pinenuts, mint, pickled peppers) - Good, but doesnt stand out.

pan roasted halibut (marcona almond butter) - Good and cooked just right.

sauteed green beans (fish sauce vinaigrette and cashews) - Good  and doesn't quite stand out.

wood grilled broccoli - least favorite and too salty. No thanks

crisp braised pork shank (buttermilk dressing, kimchee sauce, and  naan) - LOVE IT - pork was soft and tender. It was nicely presented. I recommend skipping the buttermilk dressing and kimchi sauce, which doesnt compliment too well with the pork shank. The pork itself can be eaten alone.

assortment of dessert - consist of 4 different ice cream/gelato desserts. All 4 were quite similar (complimented with some sort of chocolate with vanilla ice cream)  and was really good. I had wish the waiter gave us an explanation of each dessert.
Was here for a continuing education dinner and the food and service were expectable!! Well done!! Will recommend to anyone!! The desserts are amazing!!

Yes, it's as good as people say it is. When my group went here on a Sunday night around closing the place was still packed. Service was professional and the food was excellent. The pig face and goat empenadas were the favorites of the night.

Food and service are great.  Goat pate is one of our favorite dishes in Chicago.  Call far ahead if you want a reservation as it is impossible to get in on opentable, but they take phone reservations much further ahead than they open the on line reservations.  Has maintained very high food quality despite being around for several years, unlike other restaurants.
Order the weird stuff. Portion sizes are a little small, but that is my only complaint. Everything was at or above expectation. Great Old Fashioned.

This is the restaurant of Stephanie Izard (winner of Top Chef 2008) and we were excited to try her food while visiting Chicago. Despite the hype, this place is very down-to-earth and informal so though reservations are highly recommended, you could still get a table with good timing.

Food: 5/5
Dishes: Hamachi Crudo, Shishito Peppers, Goat Empanadas, Pork Shank, Budino
Everything was delicious and the Hamachi Crudo and Goat Empanadas gave me goosebumps. The flavors and textures all sort of dance on your tongue. It looks like simple, rustic food but it has various layers of complexity that make it surprising and so delicious.

Warning - the Shishito Peppers are freaking spicy!

Service: 3/5
The service wasn't bad, it just felt kind of awkward for me... and it isn't their fault! Our waiter was clearly a seasoned veteran and knew how to handle customers but the charm levels were a bit too high for me. It felt all very artificial and way too slick for my taste. It was impressive but I'm not fond of that kind of service.

Atmosphere: 3/5
The space feels like a barnhouse, hip and rustic. My complaint is that the air vents were right over our table and it was freezing cold but if you went further in the restaurant it was very warm. Also, it was so loud... it is hard to have a conversation here.

Value: 3.5/5
Each dish is around $15-20 each and they are tapas so you would have to order 1-2 dishes per person. Given the size of the dishes and price, I felt it was a tad expensive. However, the quality of the dishes were very high! I just wish it wasn't only a few bites of deliciousness for that price.

One of the 3 best restaurant experiences of my life! My wife and I celebrated our 15th anniversary here and were seated right next to the kitchen. We had a front row seat to all the action and loved every minute. Our server, Kristen, was amazing and the food was out of this world. We particularly loved the pig face, roasted cauliflower, lamb ribs, goat belly, and soft shelled crab. I would skip the potato pierogi, given the other outstanding choices. We will definitely be back again someday!

My boyfriend and I ate here this weekend and it was INCREDIBLE. We made reservations over a month in advance and had been looking forward to it for weeks. It did not disappoint! The ambience and decor were fabulous- what a great date spot. We had a Friday 10:15pm reservation and the place was still hopping when we left at midnight. The service was excellent and the food was delicious.

Our only complaint was that the drink pours were far from generous, particularly given the steep prices on liquor.  My boyfriend's Macallan 12 was $19 for about 1.5oz and my wine was a very modest pour as well.  Overall, though, we had a wonderful time and will be recommending G&TG to our friends!

pics.caption: grilled walter's chicken with ramp mole, ramp giardiniera, ramp buttermilk, and grilled asparagus
yo quiero taco bread with cheddar onion dip & pico de gallo
crisp braised pork shank with buttermilk dressing, grilled spring onion kimchee, & naan

review.des: This is the best restaurant in Chicago and possibly one on the best meals I've ever eaten. Would recommend to any person in the area and is worth the trip to Chicago for this meal. Pig face and pork shank we're amazing and goat empanadas we're also amazing. Absolutely brilliant combinations and flavors.

pics.caption: A million flavors in my mouth. Goat empanadas are legendary.
Pig face is amazing and flavorful

review.des:
Good? I wanted to lick the porcelain plate clean white, but people were watching.

No reservation. Walked in and sat at the bar next to two people traveling into town for work and have eaten here multiple times. I ordered five different dishes (I'm a bigger guy - figured fancy restaurants has small portions - and they do), but my favorite was the roasted pig face and rhubarb ice cream cake. Flavor titillated my mouth, and I was instantly infatuated.

Menu was broken out into easy sections (i.e. veggies, seafood, meat, bread, etc.). Awesome service. Urban contemporary feel. The name "Girl" represents her as the owner and "goat" is the interpretation of her Persian last name from what I understand. She is a competitive winning chef named Stephanie Izard that won Top Chef and owns multiple restaurants under her portfolio.

No doubt about it, I'll come back again next time I'm in the area!

Girl and the goat was one of the highlights of a fantastic trip to Chicago!!! From the cocktails to the food to the service, everything, and I mean everything, was 5 stars for me!

Make reservations, like yesterday, and you can message me and thank me later! :)

We ordered;
- duck tongue
- fries
- octopus
- halibut
- pig face
- roasted cauliflower

It was my first time having duck tongue and all I can say is, WOW!!! Who would have EVER thunk that duck tongue and raw tuna would go so well together?? Well, it does! It is perfect in every bite. The duck tongue was a little salty but the raw tuna evened it out so well. The fries were good, too! They came with a side of two different sauces; one that was a cheese sauce and the other, not sure what it was other than amazing. Octopus was also delicious, halibut was flaky and perfectly cooked. Pig face was exactly what I expected it to be.. Fatty and succulent. It also came with a fat egg on top so u mix the two together and there you'll have the most amazing pig face you'll ever touch base with. Roasted cauliflower was perfectly seasoned and had the perfect bite to it!

I also ordered a Manhattan cocktail and an old fashioned. Both were top notch.

Service is something to definitely write home about. In between these plates we ordered, our servers made sure we always had clean plates! They would switch em out with every 2-3 new food plates they brought out to ensure the flavors of each plate didn't mix. Our waters were never even close to empty and with every crumb, our server made sure he wiped that off asap! I was so impressed by the food, the decor, the service, everything!!!! So impressed, I would have to admit that this is the best dining experience I've had in a LONG time! I mean talk about impressed from the minute we stepped in to the minute we stepped out! It's been 2 days since
I've been back home in dallas from Chicago and I'm still raving about girl & the goat!

pics.caption: Pig face.... Hiding underneath the fat egg :)

review.des:
Much louder than desired but with food this good and service this attentive, I can forgive it.

Shared the following plates, all of which were delicious (though all--except the salad--were quite rich and heavy):
-goat liver mousse
-wood oven roasted pig face
-goat empanadas
-kohlrabi salad
-sweet corn pierogies

Girl & The Goat: Extraordinary, Unique & rather Adventurous.  

I've been here twice now and i really wanted to write a review so that others could have the same experience that i had here (or even better)! So the reason it took me forever to try this restaurant is because i had always heard that you needed to book it a couple months in advance. Not necesarily the case though! The first time i came, i was able to sit in the lounge area which freed up after about 5 mins. Sweet! The second time i made a reservation about 2 weeks from when i went. So where there's a will, there's a way:)

Onto the food...
DELICIOUS!! They had such unique items on the menu. I dont usually like to try daring, new types of food, so i definely went out of my comfort zone. I am SO glad i did! My favorite dish was the Pigface. I'm normally a fish & chicken kind of person, but let me tell you-the Pigface was so tender & flavorful. It was definetly a hit. I've also tried the Beef Tongue which did not dissapoint. I normally dont eat pork-but the the Pork Shank was out of this world. The meat just falls off of the bone-thats how tender it was. The Chickpea Fritters was a light item that we had as an appetizer-not bad. Both times i went i didnt have dessert because i was THAT full.

All in all, I HIGHLY recommend Girl & The Goat whether you are a local or if you're visiting Chicago for the weekend. It'll be worth your time!!

We have eaten here 4 or 5 times now, outstanding each experience.  I like that the food choices change every couple of months so I always try something new!  I tend to stick to my favorites at certain restaurants and that I should probably change that :)  One of the owners has been there every single time and is busting his butt doing whatever needs taking to be taken care of, serving food, bussing tables, always with a smile.  I was lucky enough to get what I consider the "best seat in the house", two barstools with full view of kitchen only once, that of course I took a pix of!

Must haves roasted cauliflower, Sugo and Braised Pork Shank.
If you do not have a reservation and are in the area around 4:30PM-5:30PM,you  will have better luck finding a find a spot at the bar.

The wait is very long if you do not have a reservation. And people will grab your seats if you are not in attack mode. What they will make you do for food.
The food is good but the hype is too much. Its expensive too. With tip we paid hundred dollars.
We got the soft shell crab (good flavour, but could have been crunchier), goat confit (good), halibut (good, not great) and the pork belly (did not really like this dish.The castelfranco was bitter. The green sauce and caperberries were not working together)
For dessert we got the budino. This I must say was excellent. Best of all. Overall not bad.
The Pig Face is hands down my favorite dish I've ever eaten! This place is not overrated - it lives up to the hype. If you are in Chicago, go go go! You won't regret it!

I went for a few of the goat menu bites and loved the goat carpaccio and the goat empanadas. The carpaccio has an amazing salty edge from the smoked trout roe garnish. I also had the green beans which I would highly recommend getting. I paired with the All For One cocktail. Delicious!

I snagged a seat at the communal lounge area to have a meal before my flight back to San Francisco. When I was searching for a good final dining experience, this place popped up and also came highly recommended from people I knew in town. It's been steadily popular over the years and I can see why. Great ambiance and service, interesting and shareable menu, tasty cocktails.

I met some friends there while on a business trip.   Food was delicious,  we were stuffed but could not stop eating.   We ordered about 6 dishes for 3 of us and that was plenty.   I was pleasantly surprised by the chickpea fritters.
Food was good but definitely not worth the hype. Try once if you can survive the bill at the end of the meal!

I miss this restaurant.  
I had great time with my friend.
Amazing food !  What a nice service guy.
All of really Great food in my life.
Pig face is the best !
When i wanna order cauliflower but closed kitchen  (so sad) i will try next time ! ;)

This place is the it place to be in Chicago isnt it? Every time I've walked by it's been crazy crowded. I looked at the resys a month out and usually 10.30 is the seating you can get. Crazyness. Having done a small food run and eaten at a few other places prior. this was the last dinner I'd have on the list. Having flown in from Copenhagen, Im was still a bit on European time but that didnt stop my appetite. Of course the place was full when I walked in but the bevy of hosts said to eyeball the bar and sure enough a spot opened up.

I sidled up to a number of crazy characters and even though it was decently deep, the bartender spotted me right away. We were off to a good start. If Im going to a place with goat in the name, im gonna get something with goat in it:

Confit Goat Belly
bourbon butter, lobster n' crab, fennel

Goat and Lobster? Fuck yeah. That's second only to Kobe Wagyu fed Lobster!

Make no mistake this was a rich dish and if I hadnt eaten at 3 other places I'd still say so. I washed it down with a  Chicago Derby: Four Roses Bourbon, Demerara, Mint. Tasty all around. Im not sure how I would have fared with a party bigger than myself but being along at the bar led to many a conversation with people around me and a fellow who was in from NYC and was doing the same food jumping I was. Service is solid considering the crush that they deal with constantly. Bartenders were especially astute and attentive just when they needed to be. Some day Ill try a normal dinner go, but until now I was pretty satisfied and stuffed with my last of the dinners in Chicago.

This was the best meal I've ever had. Period. It beat out Mozza and Bestia in Los Angeles. It's rare to find a fancy restaurant that can be inventive (i.e. not be Italian or steakhouse) but still appeal to the masses. Everything on this menu is creative and full of shocking flavor but doesn't leave you surprised or curious. You won't think: Oh! that was good but not sure I would have it again. Instead you'll scream: That was amazing and I want MORE. The portions are generous and the pricing is so on point. I wish they had appealing cocktails but wine is probably best so it doesn't interrupt the array of flavors you'll encounter. We got the blueberry goat cheese empanadas, the lamb shank, the halibut with almond butter, the sugo. ALL were amazing but we couldn't finish the last course (lamb shank) because we were stuffed. I honestly don't think you could go wrong here, ordering blindly.

We sat at the communal table but didn't mind. Everyone there was so happy because they were also probably eating the best meal of their lives. The communal experience actually amplified the funness of the night!

PS We came at opening time on Saturday and put our name on the list and went across the street for happy hour. It worked well and our wait was less than an hour.

Phenomenal dinner and experience!! Food was just as expected... unique ingredients and delicious!!

Food- sharing plates (larger than tapas, smaller than entrees). For 2 ppl we ordered 5 dishes, plus brad and dessert. Left feeling full (not overtly stuffed) and satisfied!! Bittersweet chocolate dessert was ah-mazing!!!

Ambiance- exposed brick on the ceiling, wood everywhere. Very cool. Very city.

Make reservation early!! We were fortunate to get a table for 2, but I've heard (and saw) the communal seating tables. If you're not into that (which I'm not- especially when you are out for an expensive meal)- be sure to make the request.
