review.des:
I didn't think this was possible after last nights incredible meal at Purple Pig, but this was, by far, the best dining experience this world traveling foodie has had in his life.

From the moment we were seated at the chef's table, to the top-notch hospitality provided by our server Taylor, to the 4 additional dishes that were brought out throughout our meal compliments of the chef, absolutely hands down the best dining experience in my life! And I haven't even gotten to the food yet.

Oh my god the food! Exquisitely prepared and presented, absolute culinary perfection. I can't imagine anyplace (certainly no place in my beloved homes of Seattle and San Francisco) will be topping this experience anytime soon.

If you're anywhere within 2 hours of Chicago get yourself a reservation. If you're traveling to Chicago, make your plans around your ability to get a table here. If you're not planning on traveling to Chicago it's time you did. Call and find out when you can get in, and then book yourself a flight. You won't be disappointed, I promise you.

Still my favorite "fancy" restaurant of all time. The flavors burst out whenever you take a bite and the dishes are unique and well presented. It does get a bit pricey, but you're getting the best of the best here.
Come with girlfriends. Everything taste so good. It is a little noisy inside and we have to shout at each other to have a conversation.

I totally get the hype! We took our chances and just showed up around 9 pm on a Tuesday. We luckily walked right in and got 2 seats at the bar, which is first come-first serve.

Drinks = excellent! I loved the Lux Goods, which is gin with a little kick.

Food = amazing! The Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face and the Confit Goat Belly were two of the most incredible dishes I've ever had. Both full of flavor and textures! I would strongly recommend. The Escargot Ravioli and Broccoli were both great too, but I'd be willing to try something else recommended from the veggie and fish options.

Dessert = The Best! I would be fine with having the Miso-Butterscotch Budino as the only dessert for the rest of my life!

Cheese = I love that they have after-dinner cheese options for those of us that don't always want sweets. We got a creamy and a stinky, both equally as delicious. Sorry, I don't remember the names, we only asked for creamy and stinky!

Bartenders = Informative, attentive and entertaining!

Awesome Food, Great Ambience and Excellent service! We visited the restaurant for my wife's birthday & had a wonderful evening!
We would definitely recommend the Pig Face and the Ring of Fire Cocktail.

Why do people rave about this place?

Two weeks in advance for a reservation on a Monday night and we only get 10:30pm. Must be good right?

Meh.

We ordered the popular items from escargot dumplings to the pig face. Nothing was memorable or that great. I thought everything was too rich and salty, there also weren't too many light options. Service was good though but don't be too heartbroken if you haven't tried this place yet because it has 5000+ reviews on Yelp and 4.5 stars. You'll be fine and better off.

On my second visit, I've figured it out.

Girl & the Goat's formula is this...

Bland food + Powerful sauces = Hype

Virtually every dish on the menu is tasteless, unless you soak it in whatever butter, sauce or syrup comes on the plate.  To me, that's a failure.  It's almost like the kitchen was out of spices, oils or marinades.

I even took a stab at the famous pig face... and it tasted... like nothing.

The broccoli tastes like it was soaked in water that had been filtered through a campfire.  "Extra carbon with your veggies, sir?"

The ham frites were an awesome concept - fries garnished with ham dust.  But there's only so much vaporized ham you can eat before the novelty wears off.

Just like my first visit, this place is *loud*.  I simply nodded and smiled at my friend across the table.  I hope he wasn't talking about anything sad.  His body language didn't seem to indicate so.

This emperor has no clothes.  I'm done with this Girl and her Goat, too.

I'm not one to freely fall into the buzz of restaurants that everyone tells me "YOU HAVE TO TRY." All I can think is DON'T TELL ME HOW TO LIVE MY LIFE.

In this case, on this single rare occasion after two months of making a reservation and forgetting about it until the week of then scrambling to change my plans to try it, they were right. Damn it, they were right.

The food is amazing. The atmosphere is awesome. The drink list is on point. The bathrooms smelled nice. The soap smelled better. The sun was out (side and I couldn't see it, but it was nice that it was out.)

Everything about the experience was incredible. I would make food recommendations, but there is enough of that in other reviews and, honestly, everything was or looked amazing so it's kind of hard to strike out.

Pro tip: make a reservation now without even thinking about it, then wait for your nice surprise on the random day you chose months into the future. It's like your own personal secret food holiday.

I am changing my review to now a 5 as we went back a second time last evening and sat at the bar for dinner. We were very luck to get in as reservations needed months in advance. It is a very cool restaurant that is actually hard to describe. Hip, vibrant and almost " cultish" with foodies in a very popular part of town.. I had read many of the reviews and was very interested to experience it. So, after two visits, here it is, Very nice and knowledgeable servers with a vast knowledge of the menu and experiences.  We asked our server for recomendations and he could not be more willing and helpful. He did a great job as one dish was better than the next. Since it is smalll plates you get to share with your partner which I am not a fan of but for this experience it was great. We had a very good time the first time at the restaurant as we did not know what to expect but loved the second time here. I guess we were just more comfortable the format and menu.  We now know why this is one of the best unique dining experiences in Chicago.

Girl & the Goat did not disappoint whatsoever. We showed up a bit early for our reservation but were seated right away. Amazing service from Owen, and the rest of the staff were extremely attentive as well. Some of our fave dishes included the green beans, bucatini and the sweet potato cake/toffee dessert (can't remember exact name). The wine list was very impressive, but as a beer drinker I was wishing they had a larger selection!  Overall, this famous spot lived up to their reputation and I cannot wait to come back!

I've had a chance to go to the Girl and the Goat and now it's been a few years since I've been there. My husband were visiting Chicago and this was a place I really wanted to go back to. We had a great experience with everything except one dish. We ordered the green beans (always great), the sea bass (pass), the goat belly with lobster (yum), the bucatini (divine) and the pork shank (my favorite). The dish we would pass on was the sea bass. The seasoning on it was so strong that you could not taste anything but the seasoning which is a shame on such a delicate dish. We also had the Petite Verdot that is made by them in partnership with a vineyard in Walla Walla and it was so yum. We moved to Washington 3 years ago and when you smelled and tasted it, it was just like Washington. The only critique I have of this restaurant is that everything is so heavily seasoned that it feels a bit hard to find a progression of flavors. There is a need for some things that are more delicate in flavors. They could be on the menu and we just ended up ordering things that were heavier.

Stephanie Izard is a genius!! Everything has perfect flavor and seasoning. We ordered almost the entire menu (minus about 4 things) and I was pleased with practically everything. Also, one of the items we wanted to order, the waiter suggest a replacement but he ended up bringing out the first item for us to try anyways on the house!! We ate for about 3 hours straight before we
rolled ourselves out of there and I was completely satisfied.

this is my second time here, and I am in love all over again. this place is by far on my top 5 places to eat.....in the world! I was worried that I would get stuck, waiting forever, but luckily I decided to come during game 7 of world series between Cubs and Indians, and the place was 3/4 busy.....which is incredibly rare.  

I ordered the fried duck tongue, the blackened catfish, and pan fried shishito peppers....amazing.  

first, the duck tongue....doesn't sound good...but the bartender swore that I would be blown away.....and I was. amazing flavors. Fried pieces of shallots and duck,  black beans, tuna, and a ridiculous sauce that was sour, salty, umami, and a hint of sweet..ridiculous......

Fried shishito peppers in misogyny, really good but too spicy for me. that was not on the dish, it was superb.

since I needed some veggies, I got the great beans....man...that was stinking good. I could be vegetarian if this is what I had to eat for the rest of my life. so good.

lastly, blackened fish. lightly Pan fried, flakey...with a nice light sauce drizzled over the fish and celery and dirty rice at the base. amazing. I inhaled the whole dish.

i was a total pig tonight...and it was worth it.

I travel every 3 or so months and whenever I'm in a new city- Chicago being a first I always check out what's raved about throughout the city. This place certainly didn't disappoint! Everything I ordered from the green beans, pigface or belly was absolutely fantastic! Myself being partial to the greenbeans. It's a louder restaurant so I'd recommend if you can making your reservation a day or so in advance and eating later in the evening.

My daughter took me here for dinner. We started with the clam chowder bread then for dinner we split the wood grilled broccoli and crisp braised pork shank. We were stuffed. Everything was delicious but we both got tummy aches later in the evening.

For the price - I expected more! A lot more. Not so much in food quantity, but perhaps a lower cost for the same amount of food.

I also expected acoustical tiles to soften the noise.

It was too loud!

Okay! I guess were supposed to be there for the food - who needs to talk with your guest? I do! I like talking with friends and family.

The food was tasty, but again nothing to write home about. Since, I'm not a beef or goat or pork eater, (I do eat seafood), I expected phenomenal veggies  and really, on a good night I've cooked just as well.

My rule of thumb when dining out - don't eat what you can cook at home.

The waiter, was pleasant, but didn't so much attend to me - I think he had me pegged for just a guest of the other folks - when actually, he should be pleasant and kind to everyone, not those who are having glasses of wine.

The chefs were interesting to watch - it had to be hot in their kitchen - which was open, so in that regard it was entertaining, but again not worth the price of groceries for a month and half.

Perhaps the problem is me. I need to pick places to dine, rather than my adult children who are trendy - I'm just not with it.

Another place not to bring mom and dad or the crew that's over 50.
Excellent service. Food was amazing. We really loved the oysters, bread and duck. Highly recommend.

Good Lord- I love this place!

I can't believe i'm saying this but the green beans...the best.thing.ever. I couldn't stop eating them.

The goat belly is delicious, heavenly.

I can't even recall everything that we made but...yum!

Oh, the sweet potato bread--- any bread-- go for it!

You won't be sorry.

Girl and the Goat definitely lives up to the hype. I booked a table at the end of the availability window for a "just because" night out on a Thursday. Our waiter was very well-versed on the house-specialty drinks, the menu for the night, and wine menu. Between the two of use, we got two "mains" and a few smaller plates (though most of their dishes fall under the shareable umbrella) and we're quite content. The shishito peppers were especially nice, as was the pork belly and the wine our waiter recommended paired well with both. All around an superb experience
Went there to celebrate the life and guess what? Everything we had there it was incredible delicious! My friends were so happy and we are planning to go back there!

I convinced coworkers to check this place out after all the hype it received and honestly it is worth it. The menu is unique and shared plates style. The staff is friendly and knows about the menu as well as cocktail menu. Every dish we tried is crafted so well and tastes amazing. We couldn't stop talking about each dish. Try EVERYTHING and don't be afraid to try something new. You will not be disappointed.

Super fantastic. If you can, get one of the four seats that are at the kitchen. Watching the guys make the food, rave about the food, and talk with you about how orgasmic the food is something special. Califlower, ribs, scallops, tartar, halibut -all winners. Unique, too difficult to recreate at home and beautiful to behold. Did I mention hip and cool too? Even the music was fun and eclectic (The Smiths, Space Hog, etc.)

For an extended wedding weekend in Chicago, one of my not-so-secret favorite cities (sorry, New York), Don M. and I decided we'd hit up one of the well esteemed restaurants this city has to offer. That alone wasn't an easy task, as I had recommendations to try many places and we were on semi short notice.

What more can I say about this restaurant? We were excited to take our seats, even though our seats were at 10:15pm on a Sunday. What can I say, even with 2-3 weeks notice that was the only reservation available! Taking our seats was even harder than that, though-10:15pm on a Sunday it was packed like sardines, couples waiting ahead of us for what seemed like a while for their tables. We didn't get our seats until 10:45. Thank you for the free bread as a token of your apologies. I would've preferred the sparkling wine you brought to the couple beside us, but I won't complain too much.

When finally sitting down, we were surprised to get a look at the menu-not many dishes over $15 on the whole thing. I was expecting to pay more, I'll put it that way. We were advised to go for about 2 dishes per person, and we did. Sticking to our pescetarian lifestyle, we chose the grilled octopus salad (sans ham), soft shell crab rice, ramp and rhubarb pierogies and the sesame shishito peppers. We enjoyed two cocktails with this meal, and we weren't really feeling like drinking more that night, though the wine list was nice.

The standout dish for me was the sesame shishitos and soft shell crab. The crab was the smallest portion by a lot-one pan fried soft shell served on top of sticky rice-though it was delicious I wanted more of it. The shishitos were opposite; it was a huge crock of small delicious peppers. Usually, when I have a dish of shishito peppers, it comes with like, 9 peppers. There were dozens here. They were smothered in cheese and sesame and were amazing.

We ended the night with cinnamon toast crunch rice pudding, again with rhubarb. There was so much rhubarb! I appreciated the ultra seasonal ingredients, but like 3 of the 5 dishes contained rhubarb. I guess they had a plethora of it that night.

Overall, I did enjoy the meal, and once we were seated everyone was attentive and kind. I didn't enjoy waiting, standing next the the bar breathing over other diners for a half hour after our reservation time. I get that it's busy but it can get a bit unreasonable to continue taking reservations when you don't actually have the space or the staff. Coming from a city full of delicious food and fine dining, I feel like this experience just wouldn't be as acceptable in Philly. But I get that we're not in Philly. So be it.

This is THE place you need to go to when you are in Chicago. Make reservations now-like yesterday actually. We made reservations a month out and still had a late night dinner - 10:30! Totally worth the wait. Here's why:

We started our meal with the Serrano bread and corn cream cheese with pickled relish. Then we had broccoli with goat cheese (amazing! second favorite item of the night), ham frites with beer cheddar and smoked aioli sauce (okay dish-the sauce was the best part), goat belly with lobster and crab (awesome), and baby octopus (not chewy/tough) with green beans, pistachios and lemon vinaigrette (our favorite of the night). Order dessert!! We had...half of a serving of peanut butter brittle with candied popcorn, peanut butter fluff and maple syrup and half of a serving of blackberry shortcake with Thai basil and lime. Order an alcoholic beverage if you're able. You won't be disappointed!

The atmosphere is casual. The sounds from the kitchen, other customers, and music was loud but not uncomfortable. Friendly staff and they made appropriate recommendations.
Amazing food!! Best food I've ever eaten. Everything is so flavorful. Portions are small so you would need like 5-6 dishes per couple but so worth it!!! Highly highly recommend

Okay - been dying to try this place for years. We ordered (per the server) plates to share. Everything was perfection. Cauliflower- amazing. Chick Pea cakes - delicious. Goat chorizo pizza - literally licking my plate. We shared several dishes amongst three of us and it was very satisfying. Service was stellar. Place has great service and energy. Kitchen was timely and amazing

May have been the best meal I have ever had. Oysters, Goat Belly, Broccoli, Green beans and Goat Shank. My favorite was the Goat Belly with crab and lobster but we we so impressed with the veggies. Outstanding food and service. Cannot wait to come back. If you can get a table or a spot at the bar make it happen.

I know Girl and goat already has ton of great reviews and mine is just one other but I just couldn't stop writing this after how much I enjoyed my dinner last night... If there is something called food porn, this is it.... Me and my date thoroughly enjoyed and savored every bite of all 4 dishes we ordered...  They are perfect share size portions for 2.

We reserved our table about a month ago for a weekday late night dinner date and that's why probably we got lucky to get a spot.. It's a pretty crowded place and was packed full house for a late dinner but the service was still exceptional... Our waitress was so pleasant and nice and she suggested our items and they were right on...

1. The bread with cheese and apple sauces was so delicious... The bread was warm and fresh out of oven..
2. Then we next had Shishito peppers and goat empanadas.... OMG the flavors were unbelievable and orgasmic...
3. Last came chicken which our waitress said will be coming last as it takes 40mins to prepare... So by the time we enjoyed our other 3 items chicken dish was ready it was sooooo yummy with the charred grill taste with amazing sauce and potatoes.... It was heavenly.... I was so tempted to bite on the charred meat on the bone so bad but refrained from doing it...

I cannot really tell which is my favorite because we both enjoyed every single dish down to the very last bite and we're too full to try any desserts...

We did valet parking which was good for 4hrs so took a nice walk right there after being so full with the biggest moon sighting....

Over all a great dining experience and an amazing date night...
Celebrated a birthday here and absolutely love this place!!!!!!!!!!! I will definitely be back

Nice place if you can get in, we ended up being lucky and got in close to there closing time, and it was a weekday. This was my second time there. I love the presentation, the cute small dishes, and the way you share everything. The calamari is fresh, and tender. Everything had a fresh taste about it, It's still crowded, even after all these years that it has been here, but worth it.

This place is overrated. I don't understand what the hype is all about. Went here for dinner with my husband and a friend. My friend got here first and they refused to sit her because all the parties were not present.
Anyway, we ordered 5 dishes, grilled baby octopus, pan roasted halibut, hamachi crudo, wood oven roasted pig face and walter's chicken. They said the dishes here were shareable and honestly the quantity was pathetic. I don't understand how it is shareable when it is not even enough for one person.

The flavor of the food was blah. I couldn't even describe because there was no taste to it. Just blah, boring. The service wasn't good either. And for the price we had to pay, $100 for 5 pathetic-mediocre-sized entree, it was a joke. I was so disappointed that I didn't feel like taking a picture of anything here. I would not come back here again.

I went in on Thursday for a date night with my hubby.  We arrived about 5:30 and were seated immediately (they told us we had to be gone by 7:15, but that was more than enough time for us).  I haven't been here in a long time because my first experience here wasn't exactly stellar.  This experience was probably worse, but I spent less money this time so I wasn't quite as upset.  

I don't get this place.  Seeing all these rave reviews really shocks me because I don't think the food is that great.  Yes, there are weird things combined together, but that doesn't great food make.  For me the food is just ok, the service is terrible, the ambiance is ok (minus the microscopic tables).  If the tables need to be pulled in and out for people to go to the bathroom that means there's to many tables crammed in there.  Anyways about the food, we had the apple smacks bread which was actually delicious with both of the accompanying spreads and for me was the highlight of the meal.  We also had the goat empanadas which were my second favorite and the sweet goat cheese wontons and the Skatewing which were just ok at best.  

The service was horrendous, I had the three in one cocktail to drink which was ok, but not great.  The waiter took forever to bring that and my drinks.  Then he disappeared before we could even order.  When he came back he commented about how he had been away forever.  Duh!  It wasn't really an apology, but more of a statement of the obvious.  This was frustration since we had been given a time limit by the restaurant and our waiter was moving at a snail's pace.  Overall, I will not be back.  I like little goat and I will patronize that restaurant but this one is just not for me.

I had been dying to go to Girl & the Goat for weeks, and it did not disappoint!

The atmosphere was cool, the beer list was long and the food was delicious. I've eaten at my fair share of restaurants offering small/shareable plates, and this was one of the best values for the price. I enjoyed every single thing that I tried, including the ham frites, pierogis, goat belly (small portion but delicious) and calamari bruschetta (sounded strange but was absolutely delicious!). Great variety of options for vegetarians as well.

In love. From the moment I got out of the car, I knew this was going to be an INCREDIBLE evening.
We went later in the night, hoping to get a table. This place stays booked. It's because they're doing food, hospitality, and family, well. Really well.

The patio still had patrons as we walked to the front door. They were on a 45 minute wait at like 9 oclock on a Thursday. This place is worth the wait. It's some of the most interesting, delicious, and mouth watering food I have ever had the pleasure of enjoying.

Do yourself a favor and check it out.

review.des:
It's been a few years, but everything we ordered was sooooo good.

I wanna go back for those goat cheeks... omg so good.

I was so excited to go see what all the hype was about in this restaurant and I was incredibly underwhelmed.  It is good, not great, and not a place I would return to.  
We got served immediately which was nice (reserved).  We ordered the cauliflower because it had received so many raves.  It was not interesting.  It was lacking in flavor and really tasted like what I would eat if I was on a strict diet.
The mussels were excellent, the best part of the meal.  However $16 for about 8 mussels seemed a bit steep.
The crispy beef rib (?) was fine.  Yes it was tender and all that good stuff, but again the flavors just were flat.
Wine pours are minuscule.  We were talking presented a dessert menu but thought it was probably not the best idea based on the rest of the meal, so we went elsewhere.

**INNOVATIVE AND EXCELLENT FOOD IN CHICAGO**

With all the high accolades and reviews, I was looking forward to this particular dinner.

TAXI
====
Around $10 from downtown.

AMBIANCE
=========
Spacious, dark, and trendy.
Casual upscale.

FOOD
=====
RAW KUSSHI ($12 for 4)
Muscatel mignonette and tarragon went well. Sweet with a tang.
RATING: 4/5

GRILLED BABY OCTOPUS ($15)
With guanciale, favas, radish pods, pistachios, and a lemon vinaigrette worked out perfectly on our taste buds. Loved the texture, flavor, and creativeness of this dish.
RATING: 5/5

WOOD GRILLED BROCCOLI ($9)
With rogue smokey bleu and spiced crispies?! Just like Bill and Ted's adventures = EXCELLENT.
RATING: 5/5

WOOD OVEN ROASTED PIG FACE ($16)
YES,  with a sunny side egg, tamarind, cilantro, red wine-maple, and potato stix! It was meant to be. This was a spectacular dish filled with rich flavor and cooked perfectly.
RATING: 5/5

DESSERT
========
GOAT CHEESE BAVAROIS ($8)
This was a FANTASTIC and gorgeous (but simple) dessert. Imagine a brown sugar cake layered with fluffy goat cheese, blueberries and caramel krispies. Not overly sweet, just right. I can eat two of these.
RATING: 5/5

SERVICE
========
Our server, Gary was friendly and efficient. I liked his style. Especially the green shoes.

OVERALL
==========
Had a great and memorable dinner. It's loud here. Not ideal for romance (if you wish to talk to each other for example), but great for groups.

Chicago is winning us over.

HIGHLY RECOMMEND.
The wine list alone is enough to go there. The food is fanatic. Vegetarians welcome! Meat eaters delight. Three cheers to Adam for Killing the cocktails.

I like restaurants that serve little dishes so you can sample a little bit of everything.  The great thing about this restaurant is that every little dish is unique and delicious!  My favorites here:
* Wood-Oven Roasted Pig Face, Sunny-Side Egg, Tamarind, Cilantro, and Red Wine-Maple Potato Sticks
* Chickpea Fritters, Garam Masala, Summer Squash, Rosemary-Tamarind Yogurt, and Green Mango
* Escargot Ravioli, Bacon, and Tamarind-Miso Sauce

There is a really creepy goat and skulls painting by the front door, but I won't hold their taste in art against their taste in food.

WOW WOW! What a spectacular dining experience! So we got reservations for this restaurant about 2 months in advance but it was certainly worth the wait. Since it was two of us our waitress recommended ordering 4 dishes. We also ordered the olive you bread which was just scrumptious.
We started off with a beef dish, forgot the name but it was with corn and okra, don't see it on the menu here but boy was that good. Then came the calamari bruschetta which was quite interesting as I've never had calamari with cheese like that before. Then came the confit goat with lobster and crab. Let me tell you. Probably the best thing I've ate in a very long time. It literally melted in my mouth and had this hint of sweetness that I just could not figure out what it was. This is a must order!!!! The last dish was the pork shank, and clearly by this time we were stuffed but we worked our way through half and it was nice and crisp on the outside and tended and juicy on the inside.
Finally, since this reservation was hard to come by we thought why not go ahead and order dessert even though we were full and had food left over. It was some type of malt ice cream with caramel popcorn and chocolate and it was divine.
We definitely didn't need all 4, could've ordered 3 but that could've been due to the fact that all our dishes are meat lol. Hopefully we get another reservation in the next few months because we have to go back to order anything we didn't before and get back that confit goat! You need it in your life!!!

I like Girl & the Goat, but honestly just find everything to be slightly above average. I don't see the quality or creativeness that you'll find at scores of restaurants elsewhere, and will only go if I'm forced to through some event.

I can totally see why this place is tough to get a seat in. The food was absolutely fantastic - it was the best meal we had in Chicago during the week we visited. Not one dish was less than excellent (and we ordered a LOT of them). The drinks were strong, the service was wonderful. We will definitely be returning the next time we're in town!

Service amazing.

Ambiance wonderful.

Wine list is great.

Cocktails perfect. Seriously perfect.

The food and the care put into the food and the experience is foody heaven. This is the whole package.

We sat in the lounge area as there were no tables available. We were incredibly impressed with the service as well as the meal. We ordered many dishes, and the waitress did an amazing job of taking initiative to spread them out so that we didn't have too much food at once. The kohlrabi salad was amazing!

Truth is... as a foodie... I was overwhelmed.  Just blown away.  The whole thing was an amazing experience.

There's lots of reviews (almost 4000) to figure out what you need to know... here's what I want you to know:

It's a little cramped, but if you have any personality, you can make friends... which makes it fun and intimate.  

The food comes out in courses... one at a time... so sit back, enjoy a drink, and enjoy the experience.  It's going to take an hour or two!  Speaking of which... the HEAVEN drink was exactly that!

Reservations apparently have to be made at least a few weeks out in order to have a chance at dining here, but you can use rezhound like we did... and got good seats near the kitchen so I could watch the magic!

What can I say... Stephanie has it figured out!  5 STARS across the board!

Roasted Pig Face is the must order on the menu if available. Absolutely fantastic. It may be hard to get a reservation and almost impossible to go and want to wait, but if you get a table this is some of the best food in the city.

The Legendary Girl and Goat. I've heard about this place for so long and today I finally checked it off my list.  It's a very nice establishment with a classy atmosphere and a tapas style menu. Many of the entrees are goat themed and done very tastefully. It's not an inexpensive meal, but I felt it was well worth the price and a true Chicago dining experience.

As I said before the meals are served tapas style. If you go with 3 other people the portions are perfect for tasting. I recommend getting two plate ls per person and if you all order something different the meal can be really comprehensive.  They also bring out the entrees in a staggered manner so not to bombard you with all items at once. I can't say if there is a methodology to the order they get received, but it worked out well.

Let me see if I can remember what we ordered. The Miso Bread, Goat Tongue, Beef Tongue, Goat Empanadas, Baby Octopus, Goat Stomach, Pig Face... the list is actually embarrassingly long. But I will say that each dish was really delicious, the presentation was superb, and the portions got me to full while allowing me to try everything.

Even on a weekday making a reservation is a must. I doubt you can get in the door without one, but maybe you know a guy. They do offer valet parking at about $14 for two hours so bring cash if your driving. Parking in that area can be a real pain without valet.

The dessert menu didn't really wow me. It was well thought out and again the presentation was really nice, but some of the combinations didn't mix well with one another. They have a black olive ice cream that actually made me gag. However maybe your more adventurous or maybe you really love black olives. Either way, there are a few options, maybe one will get your goat, see what I did there?

Overall for 4 people the meal came out to just under $400 for a healthy amount of food and a few round of drinks. Not an average priced meal, but this experience was far from average. Dress up, bring your fattest wallet, and go nuts at Girl and Goat, it's one of the places to eat in Chicago and I think you'll be happy you did.

Excellent food.
We had the chickpea fritters
Beef short ribs
Calamari
Goat empanadas
Caramel malt balls.
NONE OF THESE DISAPPOINT.
Everything was high quality, perfectly flavored and cooked. The goat empanadas made my taste buds jump and skip

If you come to Chicago, you must eat at Girl & the Goat, whose chef recently won Iron Chef (certainly well deserved)! Phenomenal meal - best green beans I could imagine, escargot ravioli in an amazing sauce (which I tried to scoop with my fork. You wouldn't be judging me if you'd tasted it), pork face with a fried egg, and pork shank with veggies and naan.  We finished with vanilla malt gelato served under a chocolate shell with popcorn caramel sauce, caramel corn and malt balls.  We rolled out of there with our minds totally blown!

This trip we came to Chicago one night early just to eat here again, and - oh my gosh - it was SO worth it! Sitting at the chef's table was a great experience; it was so neat to watch the chefs work and get to ask them questions! We struggled between having the same things that blew our minds last time and trying new things. Ultimately, trying new things won out, except we could not forgo the green beans in the fish sauce - just too good to miss! We also had a mini of the roasted cauliflower with pickled peppers and mint, the maple glazed lamb ribs, goat belly with crab and lobster, and goat empanadas with blueberry and grilled pineapple slaw atop smashed avocado. We followed up with chocolate cake and shiitake gelato on top of toffee creme fraiche, drizzled with salted caramel and a mini of the vanilla malt gelato we had last time! Minds blown again! Life goals: Be able to fly into Chicago for the night just to eat here!

DO NOT MISS THIS! These were easily my two favorite meals of all time!

pics.caption: Chocolate cake and vanilla malt ice cream

review.des: My daughter took me here for my birthday and it was amazing! Just missed the dessert, it had an ingredient I am allergic to and even when I told them they forgot it. Anyways I loved the place and the dark lights.

Let's review the food/experience piece by piece here:

Bread - We tried the taco bread and it was fantastic. It was served with a delicious cheese spread and salsa. This was my second favorite dish of the night, and it was only $4.

Pan fried shishito peppers - These were just okay. I liked them, but not enough to make them their own dish. It would be better if these were just a side that came with something else.

Hamachi Crudo - Easily the least value, and least favorite dish of the night. Given that the first ingredient listed is pork belly, I expected to actually get a fair amount of pork belly along with the "crudo" portion, but this dish comes with ~3 tiny pieces of pork belly. It came with a few crazy thin shavings of bread, and the raw fish which was pretty bland.

Goat Empanadas - These were really good. They came with healthy amount of guacamole that pairs well with the empanadas. The meat inside was tender and flavorful.

Wood Fired Halibut - One of the best pieces of fish that I have ever had. Very moist and the sauce was incredible. Order this for sure if you are a fan of fish.

Wood oven roasted pig face - This was good, but after all the hype and seeing thousands of pictures/reviews for it on here I thought it fell flat. It just tasted like a bacon and egg breakfast that you can get at any place in the city.

Atmosphere - Looks cool on the inside, tables are super close together and it's pretty loud. Depending on the table you get, it can be hard to hear your server. The other part about sitting so close to people is you hear their conversations whether you like it or not. And the table next to us was three women fighting through their entire dinner. Not necessarily the restaurant's fault, but a byproduct of cramming tables so close together.

This resturant definitely deserves a 5 star! This place is good! Everything we ordered on the menu was great. The waitress had told us they change the dishes on the menu often, once a month? So everything I saw on yelp and orginally wanted to order wasn't available anymore. But everything we ordered from the current menu and recommendations from the waitress turned out great!

This place takes months to actually get a reservation. Lucky my boyfriends friend had an extra reservation and it just so happened we were in town that same week, it was definitely fate! Haha Our reservation was at 10:15pm, we arrived at 9pm expecting to wait around for our table. But we were seated within 5 minutes. It was definitely our lucky day!

We got drinks. I got the "Lux goods" for $13. The drinks are good. Nice and strong lol

This is a very cute place. Lights are dim. It's a little loud, but just speak a little louder to your party and it should be fine lol

I will definitely recommend this place to anyone visiting and will definitely be coming back to this place again. I just have to be sure to make reservations once I order my ticket lol

OH MY GOD.
Seriously. This place is amazing. A friend recommended it. We almost didn't make it because a reservation is almost impossible. Instead, we stalked the bar and grabbed 2 chairs after 15-20 minutes. It was so worth it. While the menu is pretty unique and a bit shocking (so many goat dishes), we ordered the broccoli, halibut, and pork shank. All 3 were amazing. So much flavor and soooo good. I highly recommend it.

I feel so bad for writing a 3 star review for Girl and the Goat. I came here last Thursday with the boy for our anniversary.

Along with a bottle of wine, we ordered the grilled oysters, scallops, lamb tartare and pig face. We were pretty disappointed with the oysters and lamb. Ruxbin has better grilled oysters. The scallops were quite good and the pig face was alright. The wait between the oysters/lamb and scallops/pig face was pretty long. Service could have been a bit more attentive. However, they did provide a complimentary dessert for our special occasion which was nice.

Maybe I've just built this place up so much in my head that I was bound to be disappointed. I just thought that with such a standout place like Girl and the Goat, anything we ordered off the menu would be fantastic?

However, I am willing to try again! Preferably with more people so we can try more of the menu.

Excellent, excellent, excellent. Everything was executed flawlessly. They got us in without reservations at 6:15 pm - just asked us to be out within 1.5 hours. Done! The waitress recommended an exquisite red wine, and she bent over backwards to accommodate food allergies, preferences and diets. My favorite dish was the goat empanadas. Second favorite was either the pan seared halibut or goat satay. The veggie dishes were good - roasted cauliflower, broccoli, shishito peppers - but not great (cauliflower was the best of the bunch). There were three of us and we couldn't finish it all and didn't have room for dessert. Noise level is a little high, but forgiven for such an incredible meal.

This was excellent! I was impressed with the service and the food. We had reservations but ended up sitting at the bar to eat. I recommend trying the bruschetta calamari, one of the best things I've tried. Duck tongues were amazing along with the pork shank. Great vibe, food and drinks.

Green beans. Delish!
Cauliflower   - the the best ever
Beet salad.  Well balanced and yummy.  
Fried pickles.   Small bites.  Great sauces.  
Bread of the day.  Yum yum
Ham frites.  A fave.  
Duck tongue.  DO IT!
Falafel.  OMG.  
Skate wing.  Smallest portion.
Squash blossom.  Creamy goodness.  
Corn kulfi.  Great flavors.  Could have 3!
Budino (bacon) dessert.  Creamy.  Can't taste bacon.  

Every.   Single. Dish. was absolutely absolutely delicious.   We were dining w a chef friend who also had only positives and not a single issue.  Fast and hot.  Perfectly seasoned.  
This was all our 5th time here.  Never does this place disappoint.   With drinks our bill was 160 for the 4 of us. Portions were great.  Will be back!!!

oh yeah, it's good.  A little pricey.  Best pork.  Bread is fantastic.
Love the change of menu.

Decided that my 10th (or so) trip to Girl & The Goat was a good time for my first Yelp review.

If you are not arriving at open to sit at the bar I would highly suggest a reservation if you are looking for a table during prime dinner hours. I made this reservation about two months in advance for a 5pm table for two on a Tuesday- reservations for later in the evening are more readily available on OpenTable.

In all of my experiences at G&tG the wait staff has always been top notch. They've been extremely friendly, polite, and knowledgeable about the food. Most importantly they are always present and the service is fantastic.

If you are reading this you already know that plates are meant to be shared with the recommendation being that two plates per person should be plenty. My wife and I ordered 2.5 plates per person and it was plenty of food, even if it might not seem like when you order.

My favorite item last night was the grilled ramp marinated shrimp. The char on the shrimp along with the ramp chili sauce was a great combo.  Chickpea fritters have been a staple of every trip to The Goat. Other highlights last night were the wood fired oysters with a little horse radish and bacon, as well as the goat empanadas.

The ham frites are the only item I would say are just fine. They are certainly different than most other items on the menu, but might have worked better if we had ordered the whole chicken or goat loin rather than eating them on their own.

As a bit of a beer aficionado I was hoping for a bit more from the beer list. You'll find some very common, big name craft beers, which is not necessarily a bad thing but I was hoping for something a bit deeper. There are enough local breweries represented on draft or in bottle form (Three Floyd's, Metropolitan, Off Color, BuckleDown just to name a few) to keep those looking to try new beers happy.

Fun place, but rough around the edges
--------------------

So our group of 6 decided to come for dinner after hearing rave reviews.
Very busy place to be sure. No ability to add an extra person to our reservations.

We got an extensive, wide spread, from all 3 columns of their menu - V(egetarian), F(ish), M(eat).

I'm not going to bore you with each and every dish we got (14 I think), so I will condense the highs and lows.

Highs
1. James Beard award

2. Some dishes were hits. The pork empanada was one of the most delicious on the menu. So was the roasted green bean. The pork cheek was deliciously tender, and topped with a perfect sunny side up egg. The pork shank was again perfectly crisped on the outside, and fall-off-the-bone tender on the inside.

3. No automatic tip on a party of 6. Which is good because other places slip that in - and then have another tip line for unsuspecting patrons.

Low
1. Didn't turn AC on. Sounds weird given the outside temperature was in the 40's, but don't forget they have multiple sources of heat-generation - ovens, lights, human beings. It was uncomfortably stifling when you put all three together.  Your clothes smell like food afterwards, which is not the case at other upscale restaurants (see capital grille)

2. The olive appetizer has pits. I repeat, they still have pits!  Yes it's partially my fault for not checking, but examining my food under a microscope is not the first thing that comes to mind when I'm having a conversation with my dinner mates. The lukewarm response from the waitress (oh yeah, they have pits. You ok?) was a classic WTF moment.

3. The ?busboy pouring water spilled all over the table. Accidents happen, but it didn't help that he was speeding through the pour (so my part of the table was partly soaked)

65 bucks per person before tip.

Loved the food here, especially the pork belly  breakfast! Order it if you love that pork. Went with a friend for brunch
and we had a great time!

Amazing. Not just a dinner but an experience! Worth the two month wait.

Definately try the pig face. But the cocktails are delicious too.

holy mother of god
that was some good stuff
service was attentive
place was noisy
which i like
food was plentiful
varied
delicious
wish it was in my neck of the woods

This place lives up to all the expectations I had for it. The food is unique and delicious. I highly recommend the duck tartar. The unique combination of flavors definitely sets this dish apart. My other favorite was the pig face. Trust me, it's incredible. I was admittedly very skeptical of this dish but had heard from several others that it was one of the best items they had on their menu. And I couldn't agree more. My husband and I split five dishes, which was more then enough food (keep in mind, this is a tapas-type restaurant). We also came here for our anniversary and the server brought us a free dessert- definitely a very nice gesture! We definitely plan on coming back here, and highly recommend this place to others!

Went here for my birthday last year. Good atmosphere, friendly staff, and the food was AMAZING! We tried a lot of things on the menu and everything was perfect! I also had a cocktail and it was delicious! Tried all the desserts and they were nothing short of amazing! Highly recommend, would definitely go here again!

One of our best meals here. If you can get a reservation, book it as soon as you can because it's very very difficult to get a reservation here (at least 2 months in advance).

Service was 5/5 - our waiter was extremely helpful (and descriptive) about the dishes, and helped us make some difficult choices on the menu. We found a hair in one of the dishes, and the team handled it very professionally - within minutes our whole table was cleared and reset, and we had a new dish set out for us.

Food was also 5/5 - the flavours, quality, and preparation were all perfect. Highlights were the halibut, the pig face, the pork shoulder, and the bavarian dessert.

Get in if you can!

Whole experience was outstanding. My teenage daughter can't eat dairy or egg, which can be a challenge, especially at nicer restaurants. She has never been taken care of better!  They have both dairy free and vegan options that are simple modifications of their main dishes, which meant we all got to enjoy the delicious and unique flavors of their culinary team. And the wait staff made sure to point out anything she needed to avoid when each dish was brought it to the table.

There's over 5,000 reviews for this place so let me add my two cents. Came here after a 2 months(?) prior reservation. Got seated and was welcomed by a super friendly server, bravo to you. She recommended 2-3 plates per person, and for a family of 4, we got 7 plates. Amongst them were: grilled broccoli, roasted cauliflower, braised beef tongue, pig's face, halibut, goat belly, and soft shelled crab. Everything was great; portions were small but this is where quality over quantity comes into play. Everything was packed with flavor. Winner of the night had to be the goat belly. Though, a small piece split amongst 4 people, the flavor was SO rich and the buttery lobster that complimented it sealed the deal. There was a nice vibe, with an open kitchen.
Horrifyingly delicious pigs face. Enough said?

This place is by far my favorite restaurant. I get so excited talking about Girl and the Goat! It inspired me to come here because of a Bourdain episode of Chicago. Many people believe this place is over rated due to the 3 month ahead reservations or 3 hour waits for walk-ins but it is truly worth it. This place amazes me due to its unique combinations of flavors and dishes you will never find anywhere else!!!! It is deff. A place you have to come with an open mind to...Who would of thought duck tongue with tuna, or lamb tartare, or hamachi with pork belly or even pig face with an egg on top! Only Chef Stephanie, And thats why the Boka crew is working with the Top Chief. The food is deff worth the wait and its expensive price. I can taste the hard work and dedication in each dish.

If you live in Chicago or even visit. You must try Girl and the Goat!

Let me start by stating that goat meat is the best red meat on the planet. Yes!! I love it more than beef, lamb & kangaroo.

Unfortunately, most Indian/Pakistani restaurants in Downtown are mediocre when it comes to goat. I hate (a very strong word) it when some advertise goat and serve lamb instead.

Now back to Girl & the Goat. Like most folks, I had to book a table about a month in advance (no issues with this). It was packed & loud. Tables squeezed too close to each other (issues with this). Hence, I don't recommend it for a romantic setting.

For appetizers, I ordered the chickpea fritter, it's amazing!! Goat carpaccio & liver mousse were nothing extraordinary.

I'll give this place another try. Probably, with a larger group to feast on the goat shoulder. Also, to try the pork shank.

Overall, there are other options in the West Loop. Just for the goat, I think it's highly overrated!
Just as good as I'd heard. Creative but grounded in classics. Friendly expert service. Generous portions. Pricing was actually lower than I'd expected for this level of cuisine. Highly recommended

I am just going to pile on to the thousands of other gleaming reviews of this restaurant. Girl and the Goat offered an unparalleled experience between the food and drink selection and the atmosphere.

Make. A. Reservation. We tried to walk in and get a table at 8:00 on a Saturday night (yes, we are aware) and there was going to be about a two hour wait. That actually is somewhat low, all things considered. We were very luck to grab a bar seat and order from the counter instead.

The draft beer selection is meticulously thought our and those limited options were all great for us. We also had the empanadas (must try) and the pork fries (they have freakin' powdered ham on top). While just stopping in for a snack, I can confidently speculate that the rest of the menu would follow suit.

Also, take time to watch the kitchen execute. It is a symphony of movement and harmony without much talking (or yelling for that matter), which shows how seriously and professionally these artists take their careers. When they put that much into their food, you are going to get much more OUT OF THEIR FOOD.

Great job guys!

Since I went here, I can only think about going here again, if you are ever in Chicago you HAVE to go here. It is a destination spot ( along with the bean & sears tower)

I made reservations for a Thursday night since my friend was coming in town, and I was only able to get reservations at 10:30 pm, which isn't the best time but oh well, next time I will probably try and get earlier reservations.

We got here a bit early, and they seated us right away.
My friend and I tried to look up the menu online, but that didn't work out, so we spend about 10 min. perusing the menu.

We settled on

Goat carpaccio - the slices of goat were so thin it was flimsy, I was literally scraping it off the plate . Slightly acidic, and a perfect way to round out the rest of our more heavy dishes.
Goat confit belly - my least favorite dish , the goat wasn't that tender, and the entire dish just didn't live up to any expectations.  I was hoping for a crispy fatty piece of meat, but it was just dry and not good at all.
Wood oven roasted pork face - TOP DISH MUST ORDER. the pork is SOO TENDER AND FATTY. The egg and crispy potato pieces are just ridiculous.  My friend and I devoured this dish.
Warm brioche - It seemed a bit pricey to me to pay $5 for bread, but this brioche was like a popover x 10, so imagine a popover with tons of lovable fluffiness inside. yes that's it.
Sauteed green beans - who knew green beans could be so delicious???? Fish sauce and green beans are now something that I know go together.. probably the best veggies I have ever had, I do wish I had some rice to go with it though.

Dessert

Miso buttersctotch budino - butterscotch pudding with bacon toffee pieces, with the moist cake in the middle.
Citrus fruit pavlova - I liked this soo much. the ice cream was so fruity and citrusy, it was the best dessert to end the meal.

Bill was $60 each including tips. not bad for one of the best meals in my life.

Coming here again, going to try every single thing on this menu before I move out of Chicago.
One of the best restaurants in the city. A landmark. Make resos early and bring an open wallet.

Like everyone told me, this is the place to go when you're in Chi-town. And so I went. Everything was delicious, flavorful, and satisfying. From start to finish, I have no complaints about any of the dishes I tried. I def should've gone to G&TG with more friends so I could try more dishes.

Make a reservation or try to get lucky and score a seat at the bar.

Minus one star cuz I had an upset stomach afterwards but I'd do it all over again for the food.

We made reservations two months in advance for Friday night. Unfortunately we had to change them last minute and ended up with a late Monday reservation. When we got to the restaurant, our table was ready but it was a two person "bar" table in the corner facing the kitchen. I was grateful they could accommodate us last minute but you could tell our seating was where they stick walk-ins and last minute accommodations. Kind of in the corner yet still in the middle of all the traffic. And the kitchen was hot. It didn't bother me, though, cause I'm always cold and the kitchen staff was very friendly.

We ordered five meals between the two of us: chickpea fritter, escargot ravioli, crispy beef short ribs, honey sambal brioche, and confit goat belly. The waitress said she would choose the best course lineup and would take care of us. The first meal was the crispy beef short ribs. They were definitely crispy on the outside but not as tender as I'd like on the inside. The sauce was tangy yet sweet with pops of grapefruit and avocado. The sauce was real good.

Crispy beef short ribs: 7/10

Then came the chickpea fritter. So delicious. It came with tons of fixins which was like an explosions of flavor with a little spice.

Chickpea fritter: 9.5/10

Next came the star of the show: escargot ravioli. It was very light with the perfect chewiness of the escargot. The escargot was very traditional garlic and butter and the whole plate had onion crisps on top. It was by far the best part of the meal.

Escargot ravioli: 10/10

A surprise (complementary) fourth meal of wood grilled broccoli followed. This was probably due to us making friends with the kitchen staff who was responsible for the broccoli order. We were pretty excited! It had a nice smokey flavor to it and the blue cheese sauce and spiced rice crispies were the perfect complement. If I were to go again, though, I would probably pass on the broccoli and explore other menu items.

Wood grilled broccoli:  7/10

Finally came the confit goat belly. The goat belly had a crispy exterior but the middle melted in your mouth. It wasn't as fatty as pork belly that I've had in the past, but still good. The star of the plate was the lobster n' crab that accompanied the goat belly.  This was so rich and delicious, especially with the bourbon butter sauce.

Confit goat belly: 8/10
Lobster n' crab in bourbon butter: 10/10

Overall you can see the meal was pretty great. The waitress asked if we were full (which we were) but we asked what happened to the bread. She said "oops" and asked if we wanted it now. Personally I don't think bread is the best way to end a meal so we decided to skip it. She then brought us our check, which was correct, but she didn't provide any concessions for messing up our meal. We did get a complementary dish, which was awesome, but we also didn't get to try something we really wanted. At least give us the iced tea for free! Overall I do want to go back and try some of the other plates but I wouldn't classify this experience as breathtaking.

There isn't anything I can say about this place that hasn't already been said. Girl and the Goat is a well-oiled machine. The food and service is impeccable, the ambiance is wonderful, and the experience is totally worth the splurge.

My husband and I sat at one of the intimate 2-person chef's counter seats, so we got to watch the kitchen staff at work. The staff is so hard-working, and during a busy dinner rush, they have absolutely no downtime. Color me impressed.

Simply put, Girl and the Goat served me one of the best meals of my life.

I saw several Yelp Elites praise this place and definitely had to check out what all the hype was about. My girlfriend and I went here Sunday night and thank goodness we had a reservation on Opentable because this place was packed. Luckily, there was valet parking in the front and we were seated promptly by the host. The interior is well decorated and is dimly lit, perfect for a romantic date night. In addition, the menu is organized pretty differently because they are grouped by vegetables, fish, and meat. The waiter was extremely kind and recommended that my girlfriend and I order 2 dishes per person. We ordered the chickpea fritter, wood oven roasted pig face, goat empanadas, goat belly, and the oysters. The chickpea fritter is extremely soft and melts in your mouth. It was lightly fried and came with a pretty good portion size as well. I highly recommend this for the vegetable dish. The pig face was also really good because it came with a perfectly cooked sunny side up egg and had nice fried crispy strips. My girlfriend thought this was the best dish of the night and I have to agree. Unfortunately, the goat dishes were a bit underwhelming. The goat emapanadas only came with 2 pieces, but they were well stuffed with goat. It tasted a bit too salty, but the sauce balanced it out well. Also, the goat belly came with an extremely small portion, and the butter sauce did not pair that well with the dish. However, the goat belly was well cooked and soft. Lastly, we ordered the oysters and got to try all 3 different cooking styles for the oysters. My girlfriend thought the fried and raw oysters were equally good, but I definitely think the fried oysters tasted best. The oysters came with a large portion and all of the oysters were extremely tender. Overall, Girl & the Goat is surely a must try if you're in Chicago and it lives up to its well known Yelp status.

It was a B+ but not and A. And although some of the dishes were really delicious, I also am rating this place based on the expectation of it being one of the most unique, and best places in town. So I'll go down list of where it did or did not meet that high level.

When I arrived I noticed the restaurant was way more casual than I expected. No big deal, I'm open minded. But then my table was right up next to another table with crazy little kids, there were some guys around us wearing workout clothes, and some others that look like they were at the beach all day. I'm not judging your outfit, at all, but it made the scene feel a bit like your local Applebee's. Just sayin.

Our waitress was friendly, talkative, and knew every in and out of the menu. Loved that. She gave us solid instructions and brought out our plates in the perfect order/pairing. BUT it felt a bit rushed. Like every 2 minutes before we could even clean our small plates they would replace them, bring new food, and be on their way.

Food -- I'll list highlights first. There were some really fantastic dishes here that cant be ignored. (1) Pork Shank with Naan - biggest plate of food we got, one of the best I've ever had. (2) Fried Oysters, I think it had a name - comes out on twisted spoons with a sauce. Very cool. (3) All the breads were addicting. (4) goat empanadas - wish more than two came out because we all loved them (5) green beans were glorious. seriously awesome.. The chicken plate was a bit small for what I expected. The fries were decent.

They made killer drinks here too. Can't go wrong with any of them. Had the pudding dessert, it was hard to beat.

I'd go back here, for sure.

This popular  hipster spot is lauded by many.  Good original foid meant ti be shared.

Service is always consistent and friendly.

Loses one star for the loud volumn and hard seats.

I respect the concept and skill involved to present such exquisite dishes that are tasty.  That said, I don't like food with too much salt.  Food like that is a red flag to me and let's just say I felt like I had minor food poisoning after the experience as did my friend who dined with me.  Whatever I put in my body did not bode well, which is a sign that something was up.  

Everything was delicious, but I am not sure it's worth the sodium overload and gastrointestinal problems we experienced right after dining.

My friends and I came here on a whim after work one day, just to try our luck. They originally told us it would be an hour and a half wait, but then mentioned there was a bit of room in the lounge area to sit. The menu was the same and there was no wait, so we took the offer with no hesitation. The best way to eat this menu is tapas style, so the four of us girls got drinks and each ordered a dish to share. We tried the escargot ravioli, the pan-roasted halibut, braised beef tongue, and the springy focaccia and there was not one I did not like. They were all crafted to perfection and we all enjoyed our meal immensely. Definitely the kind of restaurant to go to for a culinary experience and value quality over quantity. I will try to find my way back here to eat again soon.

Had to wait for half an hour despite having reservations, but we were comped a pretzel bread and salad, both of which were delicious. Ordered the octopus and pigs face. Both were oversalted, and octopus was very oily. Enjoyed the tastes and the contrast in texture, particularly in pigs face. Service was excellent!

My first review since moving to Chicago, and it sets a pretty high bar for my future food expeditions! I've eaten here during previous visits and I must say the food seems even better than before. The flavors are fantastic and the atmosphere is great, albeit a bit loud. There are so many reviews already so I won't add much except to say I definitely appreciate the Vietnamese undertones of several dishes on the menu. I will mention we asked for mini portions of some veggie dishes and our server acted like he didn't know what we were talking about...but ended up getting them for us anyways. The portions were perfect for the two of us so I'll forgive that awkwardness.

Pig face. Get this.
Halibut. Get this.
Butterscotch Budino. You MUST get this.

Make reservations well in advance unless you like waiting or can sneak into a bar seat.

review.des:
Girl & the Goat was our first stop after landing in Chicago's O'Hara Airport, and one that we'd been anticipating for over a month; after all, we had to make reservations that far in advance in order to get a table even at 10PM. Avid followers of Top Chef will recall Stephanie Izard immediately; she was the winner of Season 4 - the first female chef to achieve the title of "Top Chef". Since then, she's successfully opened Girl & The Goat, her most popular restaurant, as well as Little Goat, and published her first cookbook (Girl in The Kitchen) in 2011. Needless to say, our expectations going in were quite high.

Despite our reservation, we weren't seated until 10 or 15 minutes afterwards, which normally wouldn't have been an issue, but given the already late time, was made dramatically more painful. Regardless, we were promptly seated by our cheerful server, who gave us a quick overview of the menu, including the shared plates format as well as some highlighted dishes. After perusing the various section (split out between Vegetables, Fish, Meats, Bread, and of course Goat headers), we decided on five plates to share, which were brought out intermittently throughout our meal.

First to arrive was the Hamachi Crudo, a plate consisting of four slices of hamachi topped with a handful of diced crispy pork belly, a chili aioli, and a few pieces of thinly sliced, toasted bread. On paper, the dish sounded far more attractive than the actual taste. I missed a noticeable punch of acidity that should have accompanied the hamachi, and the pairing of pork belly and fish easily overwhelmed the latter. The sliced caperberries were a creative addition, but one that I failed to see the utility of, especially as it further served to mask the flavor of the hamachi. Thankfully, the Nantucket Bay Scallops were much more successful, as the sauteed scallops were paired with earthy beech mushrooms and a creamy french letil puree, followed by a slight lift with the celery root.

I'm grateful we added the Ham Frites to our order, as we were given a generous serving of thin fries which came with an accompanying Smoked Tomato Aioli, as well as a Cheddar Beer sauce. I would have appreciated a simple side of ketchup, though, as both sauces were rather heavy, especially in conjunction. It was a stark contrast to our final two dishes: first, the Roasted Duck Breast. The protein was cooked to an enviable medium, and topped with a garnish of rapini, peppers, and crispy rice noodles. The miso-marcona almond butter was relatively faint, although it did pair well with the sauteed onions and broccolini that formed the base of the dish. Less impressive was the Goat Belly confit, a dish that took a small portion of confited goat belly topped with an overzealous amount of sliced fennel and a nearly indistinguishable serving of lobster and crab. The goat belly was on the tougher side, and the already distinct gaminess clashed with the brininess of the shellfish.

In hindsight, perhaps my biggest complaint about Girl and The Goat, aside from dishes that scored across the board in terms of successfulness, was the relatively small portion size of each plate. Despite having five shared plates, we were still left wanting by the end of the meal... not a desirable outcome after spending nearly $100 on just the food. Perhaps I'm just biased, but I don't see why the restaurant has been met with such widespread acclaim; unfortunately, since it's also a lengthy plane ride away, I may never know.

This was easily the best meal I've ever had in my life. We had a short wait past our reservation, but were promptly seated and greeted by our wait staff. We had a 13 course meal - each was so delightfully and methodically prepare. Pig face or duck tongue was clearly the favorite of the group. Great ambiance, better service, and delicious food. Izard is working wonders at this joint. Recommend with two thumbs up!

pics.caption: Pork shank with homemade ranch, naan, and a Kim chi sauce
Fried short rib with a twisted pico

review.des:
Was so excited to finally try this hard to find reservations place. Walk in- obviously the place is booming! Modern - rusty looking, busy, loud..
Got lucky to get the only two seats by the kitchen, so was an experience watching them cook.
Service was pleasant and fast.
Drinks were good.
Food.. Read tons of reviews here, knew exactly what was gonna have:
Duck tongues- sounds weird, but o m g- must be the best thing on the menu;
Goat empanadas- tasty;
Green beans- good side dish, fun to eat;
Pigs face- looks amazing, but we didn't even finish. Too filling, slightly too greasy for our taste, good mix of textures though.
Dessert- we were watching the girl making them all. So after that pigs face the last thing you want is another filling desert. Chose spuma something (comes in a large coffee cup)- wow! Left me wanting more. Light, refreshing and o m g so tasty!
Perfect ending.
I'm not gonna say I haven't had a better food. Cause I did. But it was a different tasty experience.
You should try too. FYI- weekends are booked way in advance. Make yours early!

pics.caption: Duck tongues; Goat empanadas; Pigs face, spuma dessert

review.des: Had such a blast eating here w my friends last night. First time as an adult in Chicago and this place was perfect. We ate the raw oysters, scallops, shishitos, halibut (sublime), brocccoli, pork belly w strawberries, and this delicious goat cheese dessert w rhubarb. Some really inspired dishes. Keep it up, Chef. I'll be back...

We came across this place while planning our recent trip to Chicago and decided that we should absolutely go here after having read the reviews. At first it was fully booked and we couldn't find a table on open table but we kept checking in case anything opened up. Eventually we found an opening for 9:15pm Sunday night. Tip: Reserve a table beforehand because the place is pretty busy and packed. We were seated a little after 9:15 and our server explained how the servings worked. Great service. For 2 people, If you are an average eater, I'd recommend ordering 3 dishes plus one small plate and then go for the dessert in the end. Per our server's recommendation (which was in fact 5 main dishes for 2 people), we ended up ordering 3 main dishes with one small plate and a dessert to share but that came out to be a bit too much for us.

"Olive you" bread was delicious. Soft and crusty with olives in it and served with whipped feta and olive oil on the side. Whipped feta was so mouth watering there was no trace of it left in the end.

Main dishes: chickpea fritters - rich, dense with soft and creamy texture. Absolutely yummy. Not to be missed. The garam masala yogurt is delicious.

Next came in wood grilled broccoli. It was decent. Though not as good as chickpea fritters or the bread.

The last main dish was roasted cauliflower. It was a bit too salty to our liking and the peppers added more to it. Apparently this is one of the most liked dishes here but it just wasn't that for us.

The dessert we ordered was caramel corn and malt balls. The vanilla malt balls and the chocolate shells were to die for but the popcorn caramel was a little too sweet and caramelly.

Overall nice food, energetic and vibrant ambience, good service. I'd definitely go back there the next time we visit Chicago.c
Tried 1 year ago . The goat empanadas and pig face are really not my taste . I mean I ordered one and it's really awful and I tried another one. I don't know why it rate so high . It doesn't worth.

The service was casual, concise and attentive.
The dining room was a bit noisy but I think that's what they are going for; an unpretentious meeting place with excellent food.

The pig face. Yes, the hype was real.

Nice spot... Trendy vibe... And EXCELLENT SERVICE! Multiple servers tending to me, assisting me with the menu and making recommendations. I love it when a server is knowledgeable about the food, the bar and everything else under the roof. It suggests a general interest in what they're doing and a quality level of service. Don't remember their names but... They were great! I wasn't really trying to spend my rent money on tapas, just to be hungry again in 30 mins... so I tried the microscopic serving of fried oyster "crumbs" and bounced. They suggest ordering 3 items off the menu "for a fuller dining experience" but everything is about $14-$18 so you almost have to eat first and then drop in to appreciate the flavors and efforts of the chef. Would def return, but with the sugar daddy in tow...

pics.caption: Fried oysters. Look closely, they're two left there...

review.des: This was an epic dinner! As Owen our amazing waiter would say! Grilled octopus and the cauliflower were amazing and great together ! The ring of Fire was the best drink I have ever had! Pork shank so amazing the flavors and the combo were sooooo delicious ! One of the best dinners ever! Got off a plane to come straight here with our luggage ( they checked for us)!

I took my hubby here for his birthday. I have some weird food hang ups, like I don't eat fruit in food, I don't eat white sauces or most sauces for that matter, so when I first looked at the menu I was a little skittish about finding dishes I would enjoy. The husband will try anything. We shared the ham frites (I'm a sucker for fries and these were crispy and hot), the braised beef tongue, the pig face, and the goat belly. All of the dishes were good. The pig face was definitely our favorite.

To be honest i was slightly hesitant coming here. However, it was fantastic. I can't remember our waiters name, but he helped contribute to the great experience. He explained how it worked to us and guided us through the whole meal. The food was delicious. Such crazy combinations that all end up working great together. My personal favorite was the sweet potato pierogi . We are a family of five and two of the three children do not eat much besides Kraft mac and cheese, but they liked some of the stuff! We did then only order six dishes. When asked if we wanted dessert we said no. Only to later want another one of the dishes we had, again. It was the short ribs. The staff happily brought back plates and silverware for us. The whole experience was one to remember and hopefully repeat!

Really excellent restaurant. While I'm no foodie by any stretch of the imagination, I know what I like.  The decor inside was one of the most beautiful that I have ever seen in restaurant decor.  Very simple, beautiful dim lighting and awesome bar layout.  My husband and I had the Ring of Fire cocktail while we waited and asked for it to be extra hot.  The bartender was happy to comply!  Drinks were lovely.  We had a reservation for 8:45 but had to wait 45 minutes for the table.  The waitress was very good and happily answered all the questions we had.  We ordered the ribs, the goat mousse, the halibut and the roasted beets.My favourte was the mousse which was really exceptional.  We went on a Thursday and the place was jam packed.  Definitely recommend reservations.

Omg where to start!?  I've been wanting to try this place for as long as it's been open but of course I needed to wait for the opportune moment when I was in Chicago (thank you work conference!).

I had made reservations three months early and even then the times available were either super early or super late (sign of popularity in my book).

We arrived at exactly 10pm on a Friday night and were shown to our table immediately.  We were lucky and got the "chef's table" which gave us a front row seat to the open kitchen.  Being the Top Chef fan that I am, watching the chefs work the line made me feel like I was deep in the culinary trenches with them too!  It truly was a foodie's dream come true.

Our server was sweet, knowledgeable, and was the least bit pushy. Food came out as they were ready but was fine since it's served tapas style and helped pace our intake, ie. we didn't rapidly overstuff our faces.  Food was amazing. Each dish different but also worked in union. Ingredients I never would've had together, worked so well. Of course we had to try a goat dish--the goat empanadas were so approachable. I normally despise the gamey taste of goat but this almost tasted like pork and was not tough at all.  Our other four dishes included the kohlrabi salad (refreshing), chili shrimp (flavorful), calamari bruschetta (unexpected but yummy combo), and duck tongue (wow!!!!).   Dessert was the chocolate cake and I believe I floated up to the stars after the first bite. Talk about explosion of flavors.

Ambience was made up of clubby music with the industrial rustic look. Sort of overdone but I didn't mind it.  Bar scene seemed ongoing when we first arrived but petered out by the time our dessert came. Maybe they have good cocktails?

Overall I'd come a million more times and would recommend to everyone!

My boyfriend brought me here for my birthday dinner and WOW!  This was the best meal I have had in Chicago.  I can't say it beat out Bestia in LA, but I will have to do some more due diligence, heh.  We ordered:

1)  Raw Oysters - Neither of us has any use for oysters other than raw, and these were best either of us has ever had; even better than when you are on the coast and get them locally)

2)  Sauteed Green Beans - These were so good, that I used a 'copycat' recipe to re-create them for our family's Christmas dinner!

3)  Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face - I did not intend on eating something called 'Pig Face,' but oh so glad we did.  The flavors of this dish, along with the amazing textures were heaven in our mouths.  Choose this over the pork belly, you won't be disappointed!  

4)  Goat Empanadas - These were very good, not as exceptional as the other plates, but very good.

5)  Goat Belly Confit - Not a fan of fennel, but with the lobster, crab and bourbon butter, the flavors complemented each other.   (Also choose this over the pork belly)  

6)  Crispy Pork Shank - Crispy, and so tender it fell off the bone!  

7)  Dark Matter Pot de Creme - We saved room for this indulgent birthday treat, thank goodness!  I love sesame candy, and this had the thinnest, most delicate sesame candy - wonderful flavor, and perfect ending to a truly fabulous meal.  

Our server was laid back and knew her shit, which is always appreciated!  We brought some of the food home; and the shank was still amazing the next day, prepared with egg for brunch.  

...I wonder if they have any tables available for dinner tonight.

pics.caption: Roasted Pig Face, as its meant to be eaten - OMG
Happy Birthday to me!  - Dark Matter Pot de Creme

review.des: What a great place. Located on restaurant row on Randolph. Reserve early!! Good space within building and nice decor. Menu was filled with delicious sounding choices comprised of multiple ingredients. Tapas or small plates style. We loved each of the 9 dishes we ordered, including 2 desserts. Super wine selection with highly rated wines from inexpensive (relatively) to pricey. Service was excellent. Loved this place and will return!!

Stopped by for a quick snack before dinner we enjoyed the wood fire oysters partially cooked it came out perfect not shriveled or dried out. Sprinkled of bacon made it delightful. We also tried the octopus it was delicious citrusy flavor I also like it  because it had a nice salty taste and I think it balances well with the lemony citrus flavoring. Goat belly was very moist and it laid in a butter sauce which complimented the crab and lobster well

My wife and I had a great experience.  The food and service was excellent. It was nice to see everyone around us enjoy the atmosphere and great food.  I would definitely recommend this restaurant to all my friends.
It was a long wait but the food is divine.  Unusual flavor combinations that surprise and delight!
Delicious! Getting a reservation was not easy but the food was great. The seating was definitely tight but worth it.
It's been 2 years since I last visited and it really seems like they've gotten lazy. Everything felt over seasoned and relatively one note. Service was good.

I loved the interior and the food was great.
I loved the staff's tee uniforms - (every staff had different goat pictures)
