Stopped in on a Thursday evening and found space at the bar pretty easily.  The bartender knew the menu very well, he recited the ingredients of each dish.  Started out with the marinated olives and a glass of scotch.  The bartender timed the dishes that followed perfectly... mini dish of the goat empanadas, mini dish of the lamb ribs, and finally the pork shank.  All of the food was fantastic.  The lamb ribs stood out the most for me... very tender, came right off the bone, and had a great texture throughout.  Definitely headed back and getting a full order of the lamb.  Took it all in with a few glasses of Malbec.

Just a quick update from my previous review. Honestly, everything I've had there I would have again. This time, we had shisido peppers, pierogies, crab Rangoon, halibut, something raw I can't remember, and chick pea fritters. We were still hungry by the last course, so we decided to order all three of the breads, which weren't too pricey, and we enjoyed the mall-the buns with a tomatoey sauce were generally agreed to be the best. The Rangoon was the least exciting, not a ton of flavor really just fried, so it wasn't bad, but nothing to write home about.

We got the berry short bread for dessert. The butterscotch thing was better, much more interesting and flavorful, but the shortcake was very good for a short cake dish, and they did a lot with it-fresh berries, cream, almonds for a much more interesting texture, and some berry sorbet or ice cream.

Like last time, I'd say the drinks were the least exciting part of the meal. They were Alright just not super interesting or flavorful. The great fruity one was sort of watery.

Again, the service was excellent, they were totally on top of water refills and play changes. They also never seem to rush people, and a meal there naturally ends up being about 2 1/2 hours, which is really nice for having dinner with friends.

Oh, and we sat outside this time, it was the perfect night for it, and everyone was very solicitous about our comfort with respect to the heat lamp.

This place is always packed and yes you need to make reservations ahead of time (I suggest 8 weeks if you want your preferred date/ time), but it's worth it.

Service is great and food is good- the menu changes slightly from time to time, but you really can't go wrong with whatever is on the menu. I highly recommend their cauliflower, calamari and olive bread! The goat meat is good but not so good as expected. Portion is just right. If you go in not starving hungry, then 1~2 dishes per person, plus an order of the delicious olive bread, should be enough. It averages about $20~30 pp for dinner.

Only one star off for the crowded seating. It's difficult to get out without bothering someone sitting at the next table.

This place is worth every bit of the hype and glory. We made reservations (table of 4) about 2 weeks in advance. Only time they had was 9:15 on a weekday. We arrived 15 minutes early and they seated us right away. Hosts at the desk are very welcoming and hang your coats. The place was lively and packed at 9 pm on a Wednesday. Music was not overbearing. It had an energetic feel once you sat down and arrived. The menu was diverse but interesting. We ordered 6 plates for the table (including dessert) which is needed in order to be filled. Each plate came at a separate time making it like a 6 course meal. The food was magisterial to say the least. Best dishes are the escargot ravioli and hamachi crudo. Avoid the grilled butter chicken, as it is pretty good but a lot of bone. And it come with no rice or naan to soak up the great sauce. Beef tartare is good and the beet salad is decent (not a fan of either but enjoyed both). The dessert was superb. It was ice cream with chocolate domes and caramelized popcorn. The food came out very quickly. We ate each dish at a time with none served together which I liked. Server was helpful but pretentious. Total price for 6 dishes and drinks was $134 including tax and tip. Overall a must try when visiting Chicago.

Way overrated! Food is over priced and the portions are very small. My fiancé and I went to this place based off of trying their sister restaurant Duck Duck Goat, which is fabulous! But this place was nothing to brag about, the food is not accurate based off the menu description. We ordered the Crispy pork belly and it came served on Yellowtail sashimi. No where in the description did this small plate say it was served with fish, my fiancé doesn't eat any seafood so this was a huge surprise to her and I. Overall the reviews are not an accurate description of the experience we had, waste of $50 we won't be back.

Short Ribs 10/10
Green beans 9/10
Pirogies 9/10
Goat loin 8/10

Highly overrated.

We ordered 4 dishes which were a little under $20 each:
- Grilled baby octopus - way too salty & not a lot of octopus
- Crispy Beef short ribs - the best dish we got. Super tender and flavorful, but super small portion size
- west coast mussels  - good amount of mussels & the chorizo croutons were also very good. This dish was also a tad bit too salty
- Goat empanadas - decent, but there wasn't anything special

The portions here were small & I thought the food itself was subpar to the price & portions.

I also felt the environment was too crowed for a fine dining experience.

It was good to experience, but will not be coming back.

Believe the hype. I went in last night knowing full-well this place's reputation. I tried to keep my expectations from being too high in case I ended up being disappointed, but man, was I ever the opposite. Pretty much everything was delicious and creative and unexpected. My girlfriend and I got the goat carpaccio, duck tartare, calamari bruschetta, the grilled broccoli, the pig face, and the gjetost dessert.

I will say that, despite how many times I've seen it mentioned here, I'd advise against the pig face, not because it wasn't tasty but because it wasn't particularly interesting. If you want something that's just pleasantly satisfying, it's a fine choice, but that's probably not why you're thinking about going here.

Everything else was absolute out of this world. Not having had much goat, the carpaccio was incredibly rich and flavorful with an unique maple-olive vinaigrette. The calamari on the bruschetta was the most flavorsome piece of cooked squid I had ever had on top of a rich base of goat milk ricotta and sprinkled with these scrumptious little bits of goat bacon. I don't know what they did to that broccoli - maybe it was the grilling - but that was the most savory preparation of broccoli I've experienced. I don't mean salty, I mean it was like eating a cross between broccoli and a grilled steak. However, far-and-away, the best dish of the night was the duck tartare. The raw duck meat was tossed with a bit of sesame oil and served with mushrooms, charred brussels sprout petals, a slightly spicy mayo, and some thin, crispy duck fat-fried lavash. All the flavors and textures came together into this perfect bite. There are a handful of dishes I've had in my life that have stuck with me years after I've eaten them, and this has definitely been added to the list. Oh yeah, and the dessert was amazing too. Apple cake with your usual warm baking spices, crunchy candied almonds sort of like a brittle, and this ice cream - not knowing my Norwegian foods very well, I had to look up what gjetost was (it's a cheese) - this ice cream was savory and rich and sweet and had a bit of a dark sort of brulee'd flavor to it. This was another dish in which all the flavors worked together to create something magical.

I've seen people say this place is over-priced (though any nicer restaurant has a few reviews that say that). Over-priced is a totally subjective thing. Is it expensive? It's not cheap. Are the portions small? They're not enormous. If you want to fill up on one dish, you're in Chicago, get a steak or deep dish pizza, I don't know. You go to Girl and the Goat to try a bunch of things and experience flavors and combinations of flavors (and parts of the goat) you've never experienced before.

About a month prior to visiting Chicago, I tried to book reservations for our party of 6, but there were no available reservations. So I informed my group that we will just arrive when it opens at 430pm and hope for the best.... and it looked like a lot of others had the same idea. We arrived at 425pm and there were several other parties waiting to be seated and people just kept coming in... and for good reason. The food is phenomenal and I would def come back to Girl & the Goat each time I visit Chicago.

Our waitress Lindsay (who was so cool and fab, by the way) told us that we should typically order 2-3 plates for person. It really depends on the plate because we had 6 people and ordered 7 different plates, but 9 total and we were stuffed!

Dishes by order of deliciousness:
1. wood oven roasted PIG FACE  (don't expect a pig face though - the name is deceiving, but still my fav dish)
2. goat neck
2. wood fired rappahannock oysters
2. goat liver mousse
2. confit goat belly
3. kona kampachi crudo
4. diver scallops

I know I have several dished listed as number 2, but I couldnt decide because they were so awesome. Pig face gets number 1 spot by itself because I was tempted to come back the next day and order it to go for my flight home.

The atmosphere was so casual, yet trendy. It was laid back, but you wouldnt expect to see any bums there. I highly recommend going when they open if you dont have reservations. The place gets packed and bumping very quickly. The interior is beautiful. The host and hostesses were friendly even when I came in with my group of 6 and no reservation.

Girl & the Goat.... I will be back!

pics.caption: Kona kampachi crudo - crisp pork belly. chili aioli. caperberries
Wood oven roasted pig face - sunny side egg. tamarind. cilantro. red wine-maple. potato stix.
Goat neck. blackberry jus. snow peas. cabbage. ramps

review.des:
Very upscale, rustic food in a fun, unpretentious setting! And modestly priced to boot!

Upscale? Rustic? Sound incongruous? You've got to try it to believe it!

Every dish new and inventive. Multiple layers of complimentary flavors make you say "how'd they ever think of that?" I got lucky and ate at the kitchen bar spot (thank you James) where I could watch all the action. The space is inviting, the decor comfortable and the service was friendly and well timed. I felt as if I'd been invited into a friend's kitchen for dinner.

I've been fortunate to eat at a lot of wonderful spots around the world but must say this place is unique and memorable. A must do for foodies!

Definitely worth a try when you are in Chicago. We got the pig face, seared diver scallops, pan roasted halibut, duck tartare, duck tongues, sautéed green beans, roasted cauliflowers. Everything was delicious. The service was awesome too, Cassie was awesome!

This is an incredible restaurant that we patronized very often: the creativity of the food, the uniqueness of the ingredients and flavors, the wine selection, the gorgeous decor....I can't stop raving about this place!
The wood oven pork face tasted great like everything we tried there.
The Squash Blossom Rangoon is light and flavorful.
The desserts have the right amount of sweetness and explosive combination of flavors.
The breads are inventive and so good.

Our favorite place to be seated are the booths. We also tried the bar and the other tables.

The service is excellent.

The restrooms are clean.

It is one of the best restaurants I experienced worldwide.

We parked on the street.

The point of improvement was their green beans sautéed in fish soy with sliced almonds on top. The portion was small and over-priced.

This was my favorite meal when visiting Chicago.  Really lives up to the hype.  Will def come back here again if I'm ever around. Recommend everything.

Bread with corn cream cheese and relish.  Good bread, spread not too creamy, with a bit of crunch and tang from the relish.

Smoked oysters.  Right balance of tart from the lemon and fat/crunch from the bacon.  Cooked perfectly - not mushy or rubbery.

Potato pierogies.  Flaky outside, creamy inside with a nice contrast of crunch and acidity from the radish layered on the bottom.

Scallops. Seared and seasoned to perfection. Loved the different textures and sweetness of the fruit.

Pork.  My least fav, but still OK.

PB&J dessert.  Not too sweet.  Exactly what you'd expect and want.
Little Goat Diner has been a favorite of mine; so glad I got to try girl and the goat! Totally lives up to the hype. Loved the duck tongues, ring of fire cocktail & calamari bruschetta

Ok, we are Top Chef die hard s . We saw Stephanie win as the the first woman-Chef. We were so excited to dine at her Chicago restaurant - we are Californians . We booked about 7 weeks  in advance of our trip and could only get a 9:30pm reservation. That was ok because we really wanted to dine here. We arrived on time and were seated at a 2 top table in a very tight corner and we had 3 in our party, which we made the reservation for. Our server was nice enough and helpful with suggestions but we barely saw her all night. The rest of the staff felt like hawks watching our table to grab plates the second we were done. As our last course (our 6 items) was the pork shank. Delicious, but only comes with one piece of naan bread and we needed a second piece of bread which took over 10 minutes to get and by then the pork was cold. Overall the food was tasty and creative but over all experience was sub par. Disappointments from Cali.

Want to feel like Anthony Bourdain while rubbing elbows with Chicago's 30 something elite packed bar.. try this place. seasonal menu. Like tapas, get 5 plates between 2 people but charred broccoli or any veggie for that matter tastes just like it sounds and even for the adventurous palate duck tongues are really hard to swallow without a mantra of its just calamari *grin*. Great deserts, LARGE portions, farm to table quality, clean and posh.

This was a fun experience with excellent food.  It's becoming very popular and its getting harder to get a table here.  But it's worth it even if you have to sit at the bar.

The seafood dishes were really tasty with deep flavors. The house wine was very good and paired well with the food.  Some of our favorites include the scallops which had great flavor and texture, and the grilled octopus was amazing.  

They serve small plates which are perfect for trying multiple dishes.  I'll be back.

OK -- so... the food was pretty tasty. Not I am going to want to come back here every single day, but it was worth checking out. Definitely worth going with a larger group to keep costs down. The 4th star is really for the server, who was super duper nice.

A must have in Chicago. Portions are small so we tried several dishes, including raw oysters, wood fired oysters, goat confit, duck tongue, and roasted pig face. Everything was amazing! Had a few cocktails and dessert as well. You can't go wrong with anything you order. Order many things and share. It's all good.

Never been and can't wait to come back.  Only issue is that I live in SoCal so can't get back to Chicago soon enoght.  This place is F'ing AWESOME! Everything TASTY!  Thanks a billion Chef and staff! Speechless bc so damn good!!!

pics.caption: Heaven! Enough said but Yelp requires me to bla bla bla bla bla. Just keeping it real since da '70's. Boom!
Thanks Chef. Love you mean it

review.des: There's definitely a buzz in the atmosphere in this popular spot, but the food was overly salty in my opinion. It is good quality though and service level is average.

You will be hard-pressed to find a restaurant as effortlessly "hip" and cool as the Girl & the Goat.  The area is open and although incredibly popular, even at 10pm, it never feels crowded.

Get a beer on draft if only to enjoy the glasses with the clever goat logo on them.

The service - We waited about 20 min after our reservation time for our table because people just don't seem to want to leave after eating (always a good sign) and the hostess was very empathetic about the wait. The waitstaff is willing to explain the eclectic menu and were accommodating. They spaced out our plates really well. Also, we were celebrating a wedding anniversary and they went out of the way to make a special dessert with candles.

The food - Please order the Pig's face. It fulfilled all of my breakfast-for-dinner dreams, was the best single bite of the night, and was not served as a full pig's face which was appreciated. Other highlights were the olive bread and the lamb tartare. I ate a goat belly, still not really sure how I feel about it but combined with the texture & flavor of the fennel along lobster/crab meat it ranks as one of the more interesting things I've eaten.  Only disappointment as a Pennsylvania resident was the pierogies. The fried aspect was overwhelming and they didn't offer anything 'tasty'.

I want to go back the next time I am in Chicago to explore more of the menu!

If you don't have reservations, the wait is around 1-2 hours. Overall, great experience and I'd come back.
Our orders:
Grilled baby octopus: 8/10 octopus was cooked to perfection but the sauce was a little too salty for me.

Manila clam 'bruschetta': 9/10 fresh cooked clams with goat liver mousse baguette.

Roasted cauliflower: with pickled peppers and pine nuts. 10/10

Wood oven roasted pig face: with side of egg, potato sticks. 10/10! This was my favorite entree! Crispy potato sticks are sandwiched between two crispy pork.  I would come back for this for sure

Confit goat belly: 10/10 cooked in bourbon butter with lobster and crab.

You cannot hear in this restaurant.  The poor waitress could not even hear us to take our orders.  The food was ordinary but our group did not enjoy the space because of the loudness and our hearts went out to the poor waitstaff.

Wow, this is one of the best restaurants I've ever been to! My 2 friends and I ordered 10 different items and had a delicious family style dinner! My favorites were the duck tongue and goat belly w/ crab&lobster.  The famous pig face was also delicious, but it was pretty heavy being one of the last dishes that came out.  Would love to come here everytime I visit Chicago!! Definitely worth the splurge.
Amazing- pricey but worth it! Try the pig face- sounds gross but a great experience!

One of the best meals I've had. Reservations are definitely recommended. Ordered empandas, pig face, pork shank and string beans which were out of this world. Very memorable meal. Service was very good.

Came here for a quick lunch with my dog. Yes, I go on lunch dates with my dog!
Food wasn't bad, but quality did not match the price. I did like that they gave me a bite to give my pup!

I thoroughly enjoyed Girl and the Goat. Best thing: a lot of their plates can be ordered as half portions, so definitely ask in advance about that. I really love small plates, so this was the perfect place for me!

Shishito Peppers: AMAZING Parmesan cheese crust. A must try.

Wood Grilled Broccoli: These have a really really intense smokey flavor. I would pass on this next time.

Chickpea Fritter: We got this because everyone seems to rave about this dish. It was very interesting with a neat mix of ingredients and flavors. Has an east Asian flare.

Frog Legs: Yum! Super good...just watch out for the little bones.

Honey Sambal Brioche: Definitely get this...the bread is delectable. One of the best plates we tried.

Goat Empanadas: Really unique idea and super tasty.

All in all, I really appreciated the creativity of this restaurant. I highly recommend this for the ambiance and the amazing small plate options. You can't go wrong with any of the choices, as everything is a little daring with a really nice mix of flavors.

So far beyond what could have anticipated. Came here for 25th Wedding anniversary.  I am a gluten-free pesectarian and my wonderful husband loves all things to eat. Our server, Taylor, and all the other folks who delivered food, explained which items were gluten-free (even Separated one entree for my non-gluten free husband so he could have the bread crumbs!!)

So service EXTRAORDINARY...and food other-worldly. We had the blackened broccoli (AMAZING), the cauliflower (do NOT miss this) and my husband ordered the goat empanadas. He is a total foodie...I don't think of myself that way UNTIL now. My scale has shifted.

DO NOT MISS THE GREEN BEANS!  You are in for a treat. Prepare to share extraordinary veggie and meat dishes.

Set aside your expectations and prepare for the extraordinary. We had no reservations, anticipation and in thirty minutes our minds (and taste buds) blown. Total Chicago MUST.

The Girl and the Goat here is rich and savory, if you're looking for on date, then this would be the ideal place. If you've never been, stop what you're doing and make a reservation in few weeks advance.

Dining here is a must while in Chicago! I'd list my favorite dishes, but it does change seasonally. Just know that whatever is on the menu, it's going to be delicious.

Tip: reservations do get booked way in advance online (Opentable) but if you give them a call directly, they might be able to squeeze you in. I got a reservation that way about 2 weeks before my trip.
Food and service were amazing. Took my sister for her birthday and it was worth every penny.

First, I was very happy securing a reservation here during the busiest times in Chicago, St.Paddys weekend! Jumping on the bandwagon...this place is awesome!!! The atmosphere is rustic modern but very warm. Our server David was great, he made some amazing suggestions, prompt, and courteous. We had the Goat Empenadas, Chickpea Fritters, Bleu Cheese Sweet Potato Pierogies, Citrus Brioche, dessert, and drinks. Everything, I mean everything was delectable!

Outstanding food and unbelievably fast service. The bartender did a superb job with the drinks as well. Unfortunately we had to eat at the bar because there was an hour-long wait for a table but it was overall still a very good experience. The sweet potato pierogi, oysters, short ribs and cuttlefish were all very flavorful. I would recommend sharing the dishes because of the small serving size.  

D. West

This place was booked a month in advance by my friend for our trip to Chicago. It was quite good.
The concept is more so to share with one another (like Tapas).
The bread is lovely and comes with two types of butter none which is your basic butter.
We ordered two sets of bread which meant 4 types of butters.
The calamari bruschetta was great and they had no problem putting the bacon on the side.
Beet salad was super and they certainly didn't skim on the beets
the schezuan tasting fish was an experience for me. I really wasn't sure what was going on. As my tongue had a bit of a numbing sensation...new to that flavor.
I'd recommend it but would gladly try other places.
Great vibe. Young 30 somethings and up.
Just don't forget to make a reservation.

Ate there a few months ago. Didn't need a reservation -- a friend and I just walked in one night and were immediately seated.

The dishes were generally good, though I wasn't taken aback by the quality of the food. I enjoyed my meal, but I think my feelings about the place are best portrayed by the fact that I don't really remember what I had there. I recall eating the honey brioche, which was decent. I had the Duck Tongues, which were both interesting and delicious. I also had the Loup de Mer with mustard seeds, which I didn't care very much for. I'm not sure what the other dishes were -- I remember having some goat, which was good, as expected, but not so good that I remember the particularities of it. No dish stands out in memory as particularly amazing or commensurate with the hype this restaurant generally gets.

I think my ambivalence about Girl & the Goat can be explained by the fact that much of the menu (when I was there) had a subtle citrus-theme to it. I was told that this theme was a subtle inspiration from Mexican cuisine -- I don't know if that's true or not. In any case, I'm generally not too keen on citrus-type flavors at dinner, so maybe that explains why I was not as blown away as everyone else.

Fun and fabulous restaurant. Make sure u make a reservation early it fills up fast. We ordered a bunch of plates and shared amongst four girls so we could try everything.. Months later and I'm still dreaming about their Mushrooms!!!

We popped in at the last minute without a reservation and seated at the bar within twenty minutes, which was w pleasant surprise. The chickpea fritters were absolutely fantastic - we didn't expect the veggie dishes to take the day, but they really did. The broccoli was awesome too. The pig face was very good, but it's so freaking rich, a bite or two was enough. Great cocktails and service.

This is it, folks. Book your reservation months in advance because all the hype is for good reason.

Fantastic dinner during a recent quick trip to Chicago. Arrived 20 minutes early because surprisingly our bus ran on time. We were still seated within 5 minutes which was the first sign of a properly ran establishment (opposite experience from the previous night in which we were asked to come earlier, agreed to come 30 minutes earlier, only to be seated 15 minutes late tsk tsk, Frontera). Back to Girl & the Goat....

Our server was on point - so informed on every single menu item. Even though our party pretty much knew what we were going to order a month in advance, our server was still able to educate us on the prep and cooking process for every dish we asked about as well as all the ingredients and the flavor combinations. Well done on teaching the staff all about the menu (including the beers and wines). Everything we ordered was amazing (kusshi oysters; honey sambal brioche; hamachi crudo; grilled baby octopus; wood fired scallops; crisp braised pork shank; goat belly). I don't think you can go wrong with this menu - just order stuff you like to eat and prepare to be in flavor heaven.

Pricing is very reasonable. Most dishes are under $20 with the exception of the heartier meat options being a bit more and the veg options averaging $10 each; oysters were $12 for 4; glass of G&tG petit verdot blend was $15 and quite good; a few beers on tap around $6 - the 4 of us had our fill of food and drinks for under $225.

I don't get out to Chicago often, but we are already planning our return next year and Girl & the Goat will definitely be one of our dinners.

pics.caption: Crisp braised pork shank. Buttermilk dressing. Grilled spring onion kimchee. Naan.
Grilled baby octopus. Guanciale. Fava beans. Pea tips. Pistachios. Lemon vinaigrette.

review.des: Amazing dinner. Went in for a drink before dinner elsewhere and ended up staying there and had an amazing experience at the lounge. Duck tongue was the highlight followed closely by the tartare. Small plates that are meant to share. We had 4-5 plus drinks. They have a whiskey based drink that is to the most delicious drink I've ever had. Must try and it's no wonder they have the rating with over 6,000 reviews!

This was my highly anticipated spot when coming to Chicago. I made reservations 3-4 weeks in advance. Had it our first night and it did not disappoint. It was even blown away. Food and service was top notch. I came away a bit overwhelmed of how good it was. I can't wait to return again.

Such good food, and great service. I made a reservation two months in advance on OpenTable, and very glad I did!

My boyfriend and I were sat at the chef's table, which is basically bar seating right in front of the open kitchen. As huge fans of the show "Chopped," it was like the show on steroids. We could ask the sous chefs anything about our meal, and we did!

We tried:
Olive You bread--baked sourdough bread with olives, whipped feta and olive oil
Wood-fired oysters--nice and bacon-y! With a delicious horseradish sauce
Wood-grilled broccoli--roasted over an open grill with smokey bleu cheese. I'm not even a fan of blue cheese, but YUM.
Grilled shrimp--served on a bed of lettuce, peppers and veggies. My favorite thing of the night
**BONUS** a server brought us over a tasting of goat empanadas, on the house! Really good.
Roasted pig face--everyone raves about this, and it was really good. Very rich, though, and we realistically didn't save enough room for it.

You can't go wrong with this place, though! Our server Hunter was great. Highly recommend.
We had a great dinner here 2 years ago. Stephanie Izzard just beat 5 other chefs on Iron Chef Gauntlet, to move on to the finale!

Very good ambiance. Not a great place to go if you are a pescetarian and/or vegetarian. Most of the items have meat incorporated in them so it makes it hard to order that many items off the menu. Everything we tasted was pretty good though but I just felt limited in my options. I would say that I liked what I ate for sure but just wish there were more vegetarian options (especially since this is a place that makes food fresh). They had a tough time swapping out ingredients in many of their dishes. I probably would rate it a 3.5 but I'm sure if I ate meat it would be closer to a 4.5 total hence the 4 star rating

Hands down one of the best restaurants I've ever been to. The calamari bruschetta was amazing...but the halibut was on a different level. One of the most amazing meals I've ever had. Had to order another round because it was so phenomenal. Wow!!! Awesome job chef!

Ps: had to add that the goat belly with the lobster and fennel was out of this world. Can't wait to come back.

I strongly recommend going somewhere else. After making reservations a couple of months in advance and seeing thousands of sparkling reviews, I had really high hopes going into this. Unfortunately, the meal was vastly underwhelming. I really don't understand what everyone sees in this place.

The good: our waitress was exceptional. She was attentive and friendly and even steered us against ordering more food based on what we still had coming, which was a nice surprise. The cocktail list is also quite unique - I had an absinthe drink and it was delicious.

The bad: most importantly, the food just was not exciting at all. I'd say it was average at best. The crudo had little to no flavor, the acidity of the chimichurri clashed with the pierogies, the pig face was good but nothing to go back for, and the goat liver mousse, a rich and heavy spread, was served with heavy and rich buttery crumpets, which was a terrible pairing and frankly an amateur mistake. I don't even remember the 5th thing we ordered and we were there less than a day ago. That's how disappointing it was.

Aside from the lackluster food, the atmosphere is very loud and cramped and there was someone at the table every couple of minutes refilling the one sip of water you just took, wiping something off the table, or taking the plate of food you just had brought over three minutes prior. This was quite annoying and made it hard to hold a conversation.

TL;DR - the food is bad for what you're paying, the atmosphere is loud and annoying, and you're getting duped by all of these good reviews if you still decide to go there.

I went again over the weekend since my family was visiting from out of town. The entire experience was one of the family favorites for their visit!

We arrived at 4:30pm. WAY too early to eat, so I just put our name down and we grabbed a drink across the street. By the time we got back, it was 5:15pm and they said it would be a 2 hour wait. WHAT??? Uhmm...OK. We'll just hang around and see if spots open up at the bar. Oh wait, what? Someone cancelled? OK! We're down to take that spot! It was right in front of the kitchen area, so it was cool watching all the cooks do their thang. I enjoyed my Best of Three last time, so I had two of those to enjoy with my dinner.

Since we had more people this time, we were able to order a lot more dishes to try. The pig face is still my favorite out of all the dishes. HAHA. But all of them were excellent! We had to go with the bread, pig face, and cauliflower. Our server recommended the green beans, and I am SO glad that he did. It was my next favorite veggie dish.

The sea bass was delicious, flakey, moist, and very well balanced with all the other ingredients on the plate. I don't even remember what was on there, but it was gobbled up in a hot second. The roasted chicken came with deep fried pickles -- we weren't too impressed with the chicken, and it was red. We are ok with a little bit of pink, but we weren't comfortable with that amount of blood on our poultry. We sent it back and asked them to take it off our receipt. I wish they would have been a little more apologetic about it (because everything else was excellent)...we're not the types to be all finicky with that kind of stuff. Eh. Whatevs. Overall, we had such a great experience that it didn't dampen our spirits.

I almost forgot. We got one of the goat dishes. I am not a huge fan of goat, so I only tried a taste of the Confit Goat Belly. I'm sure for goat lovers out there, they would have loved the dish. My dad certainly did.

What a great place!

Fellow Yelpers indicated that showing up before the restaurant open and waiting in line to get in was the only option to get into that local sensation restaurant. They were right!!! We showed up at 4:15pm, waited in line until the restaurant opened at 4:30 promptly and immediately got in!
Some people ahead of us were trying to get a table, slowing down the process, but once we understood the bar was indeed first come first serve, we grabbed two stools and happily sat at the bar counter. I thought it was ridiculous for people to start dinner at 4:30pm, but once we decided to shift to a late lunch, it gave us an excellent reason to venture out and try that supposed "must" in the Chicago restaurant scene. We were not disappointed.

They serve the full menu at the bar. And you get your drinks (very good BTW) much faster there too! They have an impressive collection of beers for those who like ale!

Food was everything the other reviews say. Very original and really good. My favorites were the chickpea fritters (totally random but oh-so-yummy!), the goat empanadas (which I wasn't sure they'd be a big deal when we ordered, and boy I am happy I was wrong!) and the goat neck with its quinoa tabouli.

They tell you everything is meant to be shared. True.
But a word of caution on the goat neck: it is humongous. For 4 (or more!) people to share (not 2 as we were told). It's just a large large larrrrrge portion. Of deliciousness that is. The meat was incredibly tender, seasoned to perfection and the accompaniments made the whole thing be a feast for your tastebuds. Just waaaay too large of a portion. It seemed wasteful. And that's why I took away one star. Well that and the having to book weeks in advance to get a table at a regular dinner time. It's just silly.
Great food, a little pricey for the portions. Not many vegetarian options aside from some appetizers/side dishes. Fun place to try and experience.

It is very, very hard to get 5 stars from me. I can think of 2 occasions...dinner at Moto (Chicago) & Fiola (DC) as times when 5 stars were just not enough. Here is a third. Fantastic. Jason at the bar was extremely helpful in helping me balance me with drinks & it could not be better. Highlight was the Duck Tongue although the Hamachi Crudo & Goat Empanadas were close behind. Could not recommend highly enough.

Exceptional food, great atmosphere, helping make chicago a foodie town.

It took me a few years to make it to this place, but I'm so glad I did. The atmosphere is rustic and relaxed, reminds me of a restaurant you'd find on the west coast. the menu is a mix of very innovative items -- every one more delish than the last.

The area around here is great too. I came here with a group of friends for dinner, and we ended up hanging around the west loop all night. definitely a must-try in chicago

Let me just start off by saying that I wanted to give this place a five-star review SO bad.

My mom and I were visiting from California, and we had made a 5PM reservation for a Wednesday. When we came in, we were seated immediately, but I did notice quite a lot of empty seats. I'm not sure if they were for walk-ins, but I still think that it was good that we had a reservation. The restaurant itself is huge and beautiful, and I loved the atmosphere of the place!

This restaurant serves food in small dishes, so for two people, the waitress recommended three to four plates. We ordered the roasted cauliflower, the confit goat belly, the pig face, and the grilled baby octopus. Before I get into the food, I have to admit that the service here was AMAZING. The waiters and waitresses were super attentive and catered to our every need!

Okay on to the food. The roasted cauliflower was SO GOOD. I wish I ordered two plates of that stuff! It was nice and smokey, and with the pine nuts and mint = DELICIOUS! The pig face was pretty good, but I don't really like the fatty-ish pieces of meat, so in retrospect I probably shouldn't have ordered this... The confit goat belly was delicious! The sauces that came with it were really interesting and I recommend that one. The only one I don't recommend is the grilled baby octopus. We were recommended this one by the waitress, and I thought the flavors were a little bit too strong altogether. It was little too salty, bitter, and while it wasn't bad, I just did not like it that much.

Overall, it's a great restaurant to check out in Chicago, and if I ever find myself in the Windy City again, I will make a trip here!

Tasty, tasty, tasty! Also saw the owner, Top Chef winner, Stephanie Izard as she was standing next to me at the bar for quite a while, mingling with her friends.  Had to get the famous pig face!  Was it delicious, yes it was! Small portion, but if it was any bigger, it would be too heavy!  Also had the cauliflower (too much cheese), baby octopus (delicious!), goat meatballs with a blackberry cabbage slaw ( not memorable), fried pickles (way too much batter) but superb dipping sauces, Sticky date cake (YUMMMMM!) and the butterscotch budino (interesting, but not worth getting again).

I think I could have had a way better tasting experience by ordering a few other dishes, but the few ones that I did have that were amazing are enough for me to rave about this place and come back when in the area!

The food is absolutely outstanding!  We started with the raw oysters which were the best oysters I've ever had; I am sometimes a little iffy on them.  Next we had an olive bread with a whipped feta spread which was delicious.  Then came the kohlrabi salad which I enjoyed more and more with each bite.  The seared diver scallop were outstanding, my only complaint is that I wish there were more than two scallops.  The crispy short ribs were my least favorite item of the evening, and I can't even say anything bad about it, I just liked everything else better.  We finished our dinner with the goat confit; truth be told, I didn't need the goat meat, the sauce was to die for I would have been happy with just that, ha!  We debated between the goat cheesecake and the spiced squash cake and our server swayed us toward the squash cake. I'm glad he did, it was just the right balance of savory and sweet, warm and cold, soft and crunchy; very well done! For drinks we tried the little kumquat, an act of rebellion, and the best of three.  Hands down I would recommend the best of three, its a great cocktail.

The service was very professional and quick, as soon as we finished a dish it was promptly cleared and another dish appeared..  I enjoyed the upscale, yet comfortable and welcoming vibe.  We were late for our reservation due to traffic, but when I called they were very understanding and appreciative of the call, when we arrived we only had to wait a few minutes.  In my opinion, that is great customer service!

GREAT SERVICE, just OK food. Too long in California to be impressed with lame pseudo-Chinese food. Everything tasted more or less the same.

Still, the experience was nice because the service, somehow while they were completely packed, was fantastic!

Burgers were great as usual. Never had a bad burger at any of the Shake Shacks I have visited from New York to Vegas and now Chicago. The staff was very courteous and the food was fresh. Shake Shack is far superior to In N Out and Five Guys.

When in chicago, make sure to add girl and the goat to your MUST GO RESTAURANTS. and dont forget to reserve early. Got lucky to get a Wednesday night reservation 2 days prior but when we got there the place was packed. Valet parking is available for those who are driving. Very nice customer service, food was amazing- despite for tapas servings, 4 plates were enough for 2 people. Drinks were strong and not diluted. Get the pork shank and oven grilled pig face! Was not really impressed by their dessert but still this place meets beyond expectations.

pics.caption: Hummus bread, pork shank, oven grilled pig fave, chick pea fritters, scallops, all the leches cake

review.des:
So I always think it is tough for a joint when they become famous and people start hearing about it. The standards are raised one notch and through all the hype it becomes difficult to manage. I will not lie in that I had major hopes for this restaurant as we even made reservations a month in advance. We were able to snag a 8:30 PM reservation for a party of six and made our way over in the freezing cold on Thursday night for dinner. The joint itself is very large and the décor is great providing a hipster vibe and not being too pretentious. We arrived and were greeted immediately by the hostess who told us it would take a few moments for our table to be set up. After our table was set, we were brought over and our server approached us immediately. She was super sweet and was very helpful in explaining all the menu items including providing her recommendations.

After perusing the menu for a bit we first decided on a few bottles of vino which is obviously always a great choice. We then started diving deep into the food and after a bit of thinking we decided to go with the honey sambal brioche, don't curry be happy, pan fried shisito peppers, roasted beets, wood grilled broccoli, chickpea fritter, Hamachi crudo, grilled baby octopus, ham frites, duck tongues, confit goat belly, sugo, and a few desserts. The breads were the first to come out and the honey sambal brioche was just solid. The honey butter was perfect with it and the bread was fluffy and delicious. The don't curry be happy bread was fine and good but nothing that really stood out in my mind. The shishito peppers were da BOMB. Yeah they were probably the best shishito peppers I have ever had with the right amount of spice complimented by the parmeasan. I could eat this dish alone for days. The roasted beet salad was surprisingly solid and I was a fan at how they brought in all the flavors together. The Broccoli was ok but personally I thought the smokiness was a bit too strong which drowned out all the other senses. The ham frites came out and these things were just killer also. Big fan of the tomato aioli sauce and the sprinkling of toppings on top was just perfect. We devoured these pretty quickly. The Hamachi crudo then came out and this sashimi paired perfectly with the pork belly. Again a well executed dish but for me nothing abnormal. The baby octopus was the next dish on the table and this dish was well executed. Delicious and the combination of flavors was perfect and the veggies were sautéed perfectly. The duck tongues were the next to join the table and obviously most of the folks at my table were a bit scared to try this... but this is pretty common dish I feel. I thoroughly enjoyed the flavors of this and the poke was the perfect pair to this dish. Again this is definitely executed well if you are able to get over the fact that you are eating tongue haha. Be adventurous yelpers!! The confit goat belly was tender and just solid all around.

This is not a pretentious place where they spend hours on plating they are looking to make good quality food and they are very good in this space. This place was solid and its unfortunate that were just a few dishes that did not jive with me but the ones that killed it were absolutely delicious. Still a great place to go and it is not overhyped by any means. Definitely a spot to try

Baaaaaah to the goat.    

Condescending elitists that wasted my time.

While walking by here the name sounded familiar so I pulled up some reviews.  Walked in and looked at the menu.  While they were not open to the public for dinner door was unlocked, I walked in and they took my reservation in person right there inside the restaurant.  Told me that arriving early would be fine.  So went home, got dressed and excited.    Called to move the reservation up a bit and was told that is fine, come on by.  They rebooked to the earlier of three options.  Cool.

So we jumped on the pink line and were there in 20 minutes.  Not only did they give our reservations away (violating a verbal contact), the jack ass that told us we would now have to wait an hour at the bar was pompous and snotty.   He though it was funny to fuck up our plans with a smile obviously displaying that he enjoyed it.

To try to compromise we offered to shop in the area on foot and have them call us as we didn't want drinks or to hang out at the bar for an hour.   The snotty condescending jack ass smiled when he said "we don't have time to call you."

In order to help others avoid this situation I'll probably book a good number of reservations where I may or may not be able to show up.  If they don't have time to call to confirm, what will they care?  

Future diners that get the tables I reserved, you are welcome.  And snotty self important man turning people away with personal glee and a grin, kiss my ass bro.

Stopped by on a Monday night without reservations, but we were able to get seated at 4:30 (opening) as long as we were out by 6 p.m. I was so happy they were able to accommodate us after hearing all the great things my friend had to say about this place (then I realized this is Stephanie Izard's place and I HAD to come). We were seated at a communal table, which was fine by me.

Before coming, I had done my research aka read through Yelp and knew what I wanted before we were even seated. The hostess was super friendly and kind, and so was our server Kelly. She asked if we were first timers and gave us a great run-down of the menu, which is always appreciated when you're new to a place.

La Paloma: I asked our server if this or the Local 75 was more sour and she pointed me to La Paloma. Loved it and it was definitely perfect for my tastes -- I like my cocktails sour and tart to the point that I can't taste the alcohol in it :P
Hamachi Crudo: Even though the pork belly was very good, I wasn't impressed by this dish. Hamachi and crispy pork belly make a surprisingly delicious combination, but this didn't live up to the "hype" of Girl and the Goat for me. I'd skip this dish unless you really love hamachi and/or pork belly.
Goat Carpaccio: We though since we were here, why not try some goat. The boyfriend and I both never had goat before this and thought we'd go all out with raw meat. Good dish, but nothing impressive.
Roasted Cauliflower: Almost every Yelp review mentioned this dish, so of course we had to get it. And finally, a dish that lived up to my expectations! This was my favorite dish of the night and I could've just eaten three orders of this and been happy. The mint, pine nuts, peppers were perfect with the roasted cauliflower -- such a unique, great combo. This is a MUST ORDER dish.
Pan Roasted Halibut: Yes. Yes. Yes. I'm not a big fan of fish, but this was SO good. The fish was a touch overcooked (dry =/) but the sauce fixed that problem. The menu says the fish comes/is cooked with a marcona almond butter and blueberry nuoc cham, which reminds me of a ponzu-y flavor but more sour and pungent.
Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face: The boyfriend was hesitant about this after I told him I wanted to try it. Days before we hit up Girl and the Goat, he goes on Google and reads about how the dish is made, which really does involve cooking the pig's face. When the dish came, that was all the could think about and could only eat so much. He was definitely overthinking it and weirding himself out, but I loved it. It has a taste that reminds me of teriyaki, but I can't quite put my finger on what food it reminds me off. But whatever. It's delicious. Order it.

While some dishes were underwhelming, the overall experience was great. Our water was constantly refilled and they switched out our dirty dishes three times. Kelly came back and checked on us a few times -- not so much that she was annoying, and not so little that we felt she forgot about us.

I'd definitely come back again if I'm ever in Chicago again!

I have to start this review by saying I typically LOVE girl and the goat and have had numerous positive experiences in the past. However, last night my experience was sub par at best. I have multiple food allergies and intolerances, which I am fully aware can be time consuming and frustrating to the chefs and the wait staff.  I do my best to be as low maintenance as possible. My server was annoyed and not accommodating when I asked for dishes to be made without certain ingredients. She even told me they would not accommodate the things I was asking. (Ie- green beans with out aioli sauce because I am Dairy and egg free). I will definitely be back because the food is amazing, I just hope my service is better the next time around.

It really is as fantastic as everyone says it is. And what's more is the service! Our server, Rodrigo, just took the experience over the top!

My sister and I were visiting from Los Angeles and as soon as we booked our flight, the next thing we did was book a reservation at The Girl & The Goat! We booked well over 2 months in advance and the only available time slot on a Saturday night was 10:45pm so we took it! It was well worth the wait!

Chef Izard's menu is thoughtful and creative with lots of interesting flavors and ingredients - yet somehow everything is approachable and un-fussy. The ambience of the restaurant is equally un-fussy and laid back - a place where you can go with a group of friends or out for a nice date.

My sister and I wanted to try a variety of items so we chose: the olive bread w/ whipped feta, the green beans w/ cashews, the halibut, the duck tongues and the goat empanadas. In addition, Rodrigo was kind enough to treat us to the cauliflower (as we debated between that and the green beans) and a side of the crumpets (the table next to us ordered the goat liver mousse and we were so curious about the crumpets served with it, as we didn't know what they were).

Every dish we ate was delicious, flavorful, properly seasoned, well executed and plated simply but beautifully. You really can't go wrong ordering anything on the menu. We really appreciated the playfulness in many of the dishes, such as the addition of tuna and daikon in the duck tongues dish or the strawberry and avocado mash on the empanadas. My only complaint is that I was far too full to indulge in any dessert, so I guess that just means I'm going to have to come back.

Dining at Chef Izard's restaurant is truly a treat. In addition to creating memorable meals, the Girl & the Goat's hosts and waitstaff are all excited and passionate about what they do and it shows. Although it may be a while before I'm back in the windy city again, I recommend everyone treat themselves to a meal here as often as they can!

I will also be posting a separate review on the Little Goat, as I had time in my trip to have brunch there, as well as pick up some Goat swag and a wookie pie from the bakery!

This girl loves her beets and I just had the best beets ever at Girl and a Goat.  (My husband would argue that there is no such thing as a good beet.  Fine by me as I got to devour the entire bowl myself). In addition to the beets with avocado cream we also enjoyed the roasted cauliflower and the pork shank (both excellent) and the halibut.  I was a little disappointed in the halibut preparation - the fish was cooked perfectly, but the sauce was overpowering IMO.  Our waiter was lovely, answered our many questions, and never rushed us even though they were clearly busy.

I celebrated my BF's birthday here last night! It was so wonderful! From the front desk to the table all experience are fantastic!  Our server Josh is extremely nice and friendly! He even offered us a birthday dessert after meal~ which really made our night! We came here for the pork shank! It  totally worth the waiting!

Wow..... Thought I was going to G & the G to write the Obit.....you know the mega successful, can't get a reservation, slapping it together, tough sh*t snobatorium that happens to almost every restaurant after about 3 years of being on top, boy was I wrong!

Snagged a spot at the "chef's table" and witnessed the back of the house makin it happen!  Preparation was spot on..... The sous chefs were "bustin it" all the while carry on some friendly conversation for me and by gorgeous wife!

Service overall was impeccable and diversity and flavor of the plates were unsurpassed in a city of fantastic eateries!

G & the G you're good and quite possibly getting even better!

Stephanie..... You still reign supreme in Chi-town and after all these years still taking on all comers with a cool calm confidence guaranteed to please!

Went here on a Friday night after making a reservation a few weeks out.  Food and service were great. Atmosphere is pretty good but this place is quite loud.  Relatively expensive but not unexpected for what you get nor how popular this place is.  My only complaints are the prices are a tad high, and volume is too loud.  Homestead on the Roof (on Chicago) is our go to date night spot for similar food.  They're tied in my mind for quality of service and food, and while presentation is better on some dishes at Girl and the Goat, we have to leave homestead as our favorite for price/ambiance/availability.

We've been at Girl and the goat couple of times and the menu changes every time .
Food is tasty, fun, and very fresh!
I like their contemporary presentation and mix of different flavors.
Place like this we like to share the table among 4 people. This is optimal way to try many dishes.

One star out because of the noise and reservations. It is impossible to have a conversation there.
I think if we could get a reservation there 2-3 weeks in advance would go more often.

Why is there not an option for 10 stars - shit make it 100!!! This is by far the best meal and experience I've had since we moved to Chicago! My husband has been wanting to go here and I was less than enthused - I mean I'm not the most adventurous eater (pizza and hamburger girl)...but the hubs is and so I booked it to celebrate his birthday....and holy mcguiver?!?!?! Why didn't we go earlier?!?! the staff - they are a well oiled machine...I mean legit the waiter Mike...his recommendations were off the chart amazing and I went with every single one of them and was NOT disappointed in fact found out this girl loves duck and cheese ice cream! Then there was the entire kitchen staff...I swear I don't know how they do it...totally working together as a team - a team of badass chefs! They were busting their buts in there and everything we ate was delicious!!! I never lacked for water, was constantly given clean plate, the food was perfectly portioned and damn it was all delicious (how does not one item suck?!?!) and all the dishes came out perfectly timed...then their was he bar staff my drink was on point...the staff that sat us (chefs table say what and although I totally owned up to hubs telling him I didn't book it, it made me wife of the year in his eyes) thank you so much to the entire team for a kick ass experience and dinner! I could go on and on...but forget reading this go book a table ASAP and you won't be disappointed!!!

I absolutely love this place.

I've been multiple times and it's been one of the best dining experiences I've ever had. The wood fired oysters and bruschetta calamari are just the start to a fantastic menu served by an outstanding staff.
Granted, the price is considerable and it's hard I get reservations (though the lounge is always an option on short notice) but if you're visiting Chicago and have only one night for a nice dinner, this is the place you want.

In a city of great restaurants, Girl and the Goat still stands out. A giant among giants.

Never had Goat Chili before and this is the best chili we ever had!!  Trust me, I've had my share of chili. Had the braised beef sandwich , can't remember the name of it but it was spectacular!   If you go to the bakery area, there's a bar we sat at. Had the Summer Crush cocktail- Delicious!  Definitely coming back!

Wonderful dinner last night. Great engaged staff. Couldn't find a table on Opentable but we showed up and they helped us make it work by giving us a 90 minute time limit (no sweat). Definitely made sure we had some Goat Loin which had an awesome sweet soy sauce to it. The calamari was the softest I've ever had but the Octopus was way too salty, that was the single let down. Also worth mentioning is the Pig Face with Egg - yummy. I had a Chocolate Mousse with OLIVES for dessert - the olives were not too overwhelming but there's a hint of "something's different". All around, I'm very glad I made it to Chicago's top place.

This is a must-go in Chicago! The drinks were perfect and the food you'll remember for a lifetime (because it's so unique!). Try the Crispy Pig Face! I was hesitant at first but when I took my first bite I realized it was bomb.com. Next get the Chickpea Fritters and the Miso-Butterscotch Budino! You can't go wrong with anything here.

Street parking will probably be impossible but I don't trip about that. I just did valet parking; there will be a few valets out in front who are super gracious. In fact I liked them so much I tipped generously.

The wait can be 1-2 hours but I don't trip about that either. This was my #1 food & drinks spot on my travel itinerary and it was worth it. My bill came out to $120 or so. This place proves that Chicago has the best food in the world.

Had a delicious late night dinner here. The only time we got a reservation day of was for after 10pm.  

We had a random assorting of which the following I recommend: kusshi oysters, octopus (has bacon!), miso bread with kimchi relish, olive bread, shrimp with spicy sauce and ramps.

Not spectacular: shishito peppers (large portion, maybe too large), roaster cauliflower (great taste but really is just grilled cauliflower)  

I heard the liver mousse was fantastic. You cant skip dessert! Tres leches cake with a almost pickled rhubarb with straweberries and strawberries sorbet was solid but the chocolate pot de creme was unworldly. Magic foam over soft delicate chocolate with unexpexted crispy pieces at the bottom.

We've wanted to come here for years and it was worth the wait! We basically tried the entire menu as we no longer live near Chicago. We were disappointed in the fire roasted oysters, not the sweet flavor of oysters like normal.
The following dishes are worth a try if on the menu:
Blueberry halibut
Soft shell crab (perfectly cooked crab and the bed of corn underneath was amazing)
Beef ribs (small but flavor explosion)
Pig Face (yum yum)
Pork Shank (huge portion but melt in your mouth)

We started with a bottle of sparkling wine from Spain which was crisp and refreshing. Cannot remember the other wine but they had a nice selection. Great wait staff as well.

Finally tried this place couple of weeks ago and it was an experience that I never tried before.  It was tasteful and cooked just right for your taste buds.  The potion isn't huge like most restaurants these days but the amount they give you is enough for you to feel full.  I guess it depends what you order. it's not one of those places where you feel like going to eat elsewhere after....that also depends on how big of an eater you are and this place is more classy. so if you like to eat burgers and fries, go elsewhere.

The atmosphere is dim and loungy (mostly by the bar) but when you go sit, there is more lighting and a bright colored painting that goes with the name of the restaurant.  The wooden theme is intriguing and goes very well with the Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face meal.

I attached some photos of few of our meals..

The pig face lives up to the hype. I have only been here once and it definitely left an impression.

If the reservation list wasn't so long I would come much more frequently.

Sooooo much has been said about this place, I almost feel like I shouldn't bother to review. But this is my favorite restaurant of all time, so let me give a couple of hints and tips:
-Get reservations or get ready to be waiting at the door when they open. Start planning at least three months ahead.
-Parking is horrid, even with the valet service. Take a taxi or public transit.
-I've seen people in formal dresses and I've seen people in jeans eat here. The waitstaff wears t-shirts, but the food suggests you should at least put on a blouse.
-Get bread, even if it sounds like the most plebeian thing in the world. The things this place can do with butter are otherworldly. The bread has been my favorite part of every meal here.
-Go here. Just do it. Shell out the money, it's well worth it. This will be one of the best meals of your life.

Long time Chicago resident, first time at Girl and the Goat and was not disappointed. The food and experience are equally amazing but our server is the reason for the heightened review. Good hospitality, which is central to the restaurant experience is very much about character. I unfortunately did not catch her name, but she provided recommendations, was attentive, and acknowledged our young daughter's requests. I can say the same about the food and hospitality at Duck Duck Goat and Little Goat as we have been frequent guests. Stephanie Izard and her business, culinary, guest engagement team, ect. have done some amazing things in Chicago. We will continue to support these lovely establishments!!

We got the Duck tartare, marinated olives, oysters (the ones with bacon), and wood fired skirt steak. I wouldn't order the olives again but everything else was really good. The olives weren't bad, they just weren't great. The duck tartare and oysters were my favorite!

really creative and great food.  I like the atmosphere, and the edginess of the West Loop.   You can walk here from the Loop, or take the Green Line.  This is really a can't miss on any cutting edge Chicago restaurant tour.

The restaurant is sooo popular.
Well we came just the time.
No line no waiting.
And also enjoy the delicious food here~

I really like this place. I Have never had a bad time here. The food is fun to order because it's different and creative. Of course some dishes are better than others but the atmosphere is so lively it's just a great place to spend a  night out with friends. That is if you can get a table. It's a bit of a Lord of the Flies situation with the first -come first -serve seating at the bar, but with some patience and a solid strategy and I've always been able to eat here when I wanted to.

Firstly the dining environment is spot on for a meal with friends or alone. Great lounging spaces to traditional seating to bar seating. Not a corner that feels awkward. Second, Service was really honest and friendly. Thirdly the food was on point. I loved that there were menu items that you could order as halves. So I was able to try more dishes at once. My fav dish was the shrimp. Empanada flavour OK but shell was a bit dry and thick. I prefer a thinner and crisper shell. Wasn't a huge fan of the cocktails and the espuma caramel desert was superb a bit too sweet for the portion size. To finish the entire portion you might want to order some coffee! Overall yes.

pics.caption: Beet salad and shrimp half order in view

review.des:
okay. I walk into spaces like this and think they're going to be overrated as heck but the food is....not. it is really, really good. the crowd is AWFUL but what can you do, I assure you when I am dictator of Chicago I'll gladly purge the west loop yipster crowd but until then, c'est la vie.

I urge you to order STRATEGICALLY because this food is RICH. they serve things in order from light to heavy, maybe request that your server alternate because by the time the goat liver mousse came I almost was going to die, and I came in a ragingly hangry pregnant person.

here is what we ordered, I recommend ALL, I and others have tried to replicate the roasted cauliflower salad with little success, good luck to you though.

-hamachi crudo
-pan-fried shishito peppers
-roasted cauliflower salad
-green garlic pierogies
-calamari bruschetta
-pan-roasted halibut
-ham frites
-goat liver mousse
-pig face

I minused a star because the people who hang out here are dweezils (a LOT of capris, for some reason. that was strange. not like, mom-capris, or euro-man capris, like....1998 capris. idk, the west loop is weird!!!)
Pretty good overall. We had a reservation at 8,  and probably didn't get seated until 8:45. They gave us an app on the house though, which was a plus. Hard to get a reservation

Delicious food. Everything we ordered was delicious. Make sure to get the green beans appetizer.... AMAZING! Atmosphere was relaxing and enjoyable. This place is a perfect location to meet up with friends.

We were completely blown away by this place.  We made reservations approx one month in advance for a 6pm slot, prior to going the show Book of Mormon.  I'll start by saying we were seated at the front of the house, near the entrance windows.  The seating was very tight, but the service was quick.  Despite the restaurant being full to capacity, the waitress was extremely attentive.

The drink menu is extensive, we elected to go with some of the craft beers on tap.  They were delivered in the appropriate types of beer glasses, perfectly chilled.

Now the Apps.....we ordered all vegetarian items...starting with the bread with butter....it was so amazing, it melted in our mouth....next we had the chillies with parmesan cheese...OMG...it was the most amazing preparation of green chillies I have ever had..they were perfectly flavored with just the right amount of spice....the perfect accompaniment to a cold beer.  

After that we had the chick pea fritters....it was like I died and went to heaven....I am embarrassed that someone in the USA took an Indian classic and elevated it to a heavenly level.  The perfect blend of spices and soft and crunchy....I was blown away....

The last app we tried was the cauliflower, it was good, not my favorite, my wife loved it, but I think it was ok.

As for dessert we tried two different items....both were spectacular.  I wish I could remember the names.....but it doesn't really matter...the take away from this review is that everything at Girl & the Goat is outstanding.  One the best restaurants I have been to in the Chicago area.

pics.caption: Cauliflower dish, my wife loved it
Bread with butter...Make sure you get it, perfect way to start your meal

review.des: This place is so good. I've been a few times now and love everything. Great place to share some small plates in a cool atmosphere with great wait staff and bartenders.

Had such an amazing dinner at Girl & the Goat with my brother, sister in law and parents a couple weeks ago.  There wasn't one thing I had that I didn't enjoy.  The great thing about this restaurant are their terrific veggies.  I have never had such awesome cauliflower.  Crazy, but of all the things we had that was my favorite thing!  next time I am getting my own bowl, no sharing!!  The ham frites were also excellent as we had to get 2 orders.  Oh and the challah bread was also so good.  Nice and warm with a great crust and served salmon cream cheese.  It was amazing. I was only mad my dad kept eating it.  We had a bunch of other things - short ribs, duck, escargot ravioli and one of the fish dishes.  All were great.

The customer service here is lovely.  We had such a nice server who put up with my dad who is not used to eating at restaurants where pig's face is served.  Additionally, they sent my brother signed menus signed by Stephanie b/c she was not at the restaurant when we were there.  So awesome of them!!!  Great customer service.

Overall, I cannot wait to go back, it was certainly a memorable experience.

pics.caption: Well, we already started digging-in but this is the roasted cauliflower. It is amazing!!!!
Ham frites!! Totally amazing!!!! We ordered 2 of them :)

review.des:
I've been here twice and both times were perfection in terms of service and food. So far me and my friends have tried:

1) Honey sambal brioche
5/5. The bread was fluffy and delicious enough to eat on its own. Add honey sambal butter and some relish to that - perfect starter

2) Crispy beef short ribs
3/5. This was served on top of avocado and some salad which was acidic - nice way to cut through the fattiness of the avocado and round the dish up. We liked it a lot, but I'm giving it a 3 only because there were other dishes that left more of an impression

3) Scallops
5/5. The scallops were cooked to perfection - nicely salted and the charred top was crunchy. I would recommend this to anyone who enjoys a good seafood dish. I really don't think you would be disappointed

4) Pan fried shishito peppers
3/5. These were also nice to try and sort of unique! If you wanted to try a "new" vegetable dish here with a large group, this might be it. However, it gets only a 3 in comparison to the rest (sorry I'm not sorry)

5) Country fried loup de mer
4/5. The portion arrived larger than we expected! Fish was fried to perfection and the salad/rice nicely complemented the dish. I would've enjoyed this more if I wasn't stuffing my face with (7) - don't skip the list yet!

6) Goat medallions
2/5. I had this more than a year ago and it doesn't seem to be on the menu anymore (good). It was too rare for my liking and just pales in comparison to whatever else I was pigging on. I honestly just remembered I did not enjoy this.

7) Roasted cauliflower
6/5! I cannot comprehend how a dish this simple can be so satisfying and addictive (and not to mention, that has a recipe openly shared by Izzard herself!). This is the granddaddy of them ALL. I would say one portion is good for a group of 4. Please don't deprive yourself by sharing this with too many people. I would NEVER go to Girl and the Goat and NOT order this.

8) Miso butterscotch budino
5/5. BACON TOFFEE. It was savory and sweet (both in the right amounts), and pretty unique! Also another one I would definitely get if I were able to get a reservation tomorrow. Apart from this and the free birthday dessert (ice-cream brownie that tasted like truffles? not bad but wouldn't order it on my own... sorry :( ), I've not tried any other dessert. It's going to be a challenge to not order this miso one though.

Can't wait for my next visit! Till then, lots of time at the gym.

pics.caption: Our favorite dish across two visits. Roasted cauliflower
Country fried loup de mer. Portion was larger than expected!

review.des:
I can truly say this is one of top ten restaurants I've been to in my lifetime. I am fortunate to have secured a reservation here on our short trip to Chicago. All the menu items were super inventive and tasty. My favorite out of the seven dishes my husband and I've tried was the pig face, and my least favorite was the goat belly; however, my husband thought the exact opposite (his favorite was the goat belly and he liked pig face the least). We do still agree that all of the dishes were scrumptious and above par. This really goes to show that Girl and the Goat has something special for every palette.

The servers were extremely friendly (they even do a coat check check for you), music was hip, and the atmosphere was lively yet intimate. I highly recommend this to everyone visiting or living in Chicago!

pics.caption: Miso caramel forgot the exact name but incredible refreshing dessert!!

review.des: The goat confit was my absolute favorite. Sure, go ahead and try the pork shank like everyone says, but that was no where near in comparison to the goat confit. We were looking for a vegetable to much on to break up the heavy dinner. Ended up going with the green beans. Eating that dish alone will make you a vegetable lover. Loved the atmosphere of the restaurant. There was a 2 hour wait on a Tuesday night for a table, so we opted to sit in the lounge area. I'm glad we did because we had nice comfortable couches to sit on and great company. The server was very attentive and always made sure that our drinks were full. You can't go wrong with any cocktail on their menu. The goat and the girl should definitely be on the top of your restaurant list if you are visiting from out of town!

This is hands down the best dining experience I have ever had. The service was phenomenal, the food was amazing, the atmosphere was perfect. I've dined at restaurants all across the city and none of them compare to Girl and the Goat, even ones that are more expensive. Do your taste buds a favor and make a reservation ASAP.

By far the best place we ate in Chicago. We ordered way too much food, but this was no fault of the waiter's. He said we should order about 4 plates to share between our table of 2, but we decided we wanted to taste test a bit and ordered 6 plates. The food was absolutely fantastic. We had the green beans, the broccoli, the sweet potato pirogies, the calamari bruschetta, the bucatini, and the pig face. I'd say the green beans appeared to be their most popular dish, and for good reason. We ended up wrapping portions of 4 separate dishes to take back to the hotel.

Our waiter, Josh, was awesome and was extremely helpful in the ordering process. The time between vegetarian/fish dishes and the meat dishes was quite long, but it gave us time to talk about the savory flavors of each. We plan to bring some friends here when we come back to visit Chicago. This place is a must-go.

Btw, it was a Tuesday night, and it was absolutely packed. We were only able to get a late reservation at 9:15 (reserved weeks in advance) but there were still people flowing in even after we left.

The date started out strangely when I went to order 2 drinks at the bar - one for me and one for my date.  As I placed my order the bartender basically rolled his eyes.  OK I thought - this is what I get when I come to Randolph yet I know the food is worth it so I power through.  He then informs me he "never saw my date" and therefore I cannot place an order for two beverages.  He repeats himself so basically everyone in ear shot can hear him say he thinks I'm making up my date.  Now maybe I'm a little sensitive to that coming off being single for 3 years and realizing how restaurants treat single women.  I'll own that part.  But what kills me is that there is a better way to relay a company policy to a paying customer besides making her feel stupid in front of a crowd of people.  G&G is a place I tend to take all my out of town guests - romantic or not.  I used to love that it was on Randolph in the heart of things and that my guest would feel like they are seeing some cool part of Chicago.  My boyfriend just recently moved to California and while visiting I thought I would take him somewhere we didn't get a chance to go while he lived here.  When my invisible boyfriend gets back to the bar, I tell him what just happened. He is less than pleased yet handles the situation for us with grace.  Please remember that ordering two cocktails at G&G sets you back about $30 so I guess I expect some level of customer service for $30 drinks.  Or I'm just getting old (I'm 34) and my time in the west loop has passed.  Either way, couple this with an apathetic waitress, not being able to hear my date and my time is over at G&G.  I'm so glad I caught her in her heyday a few years back.

Hands down the best meal I had in Chicago and maybe the best meal I've had in 2016 so far.  Seriously there were times when I'm sure I cried tears of joy because of the pure perfection of some of the dishes.  Ambiance and service were all A+, and if there was a grade higher than that I would definitely award it to the food.

Stellar standouts include the duck tongues and the braised beef tongue, which may sound a little too adventurous for some but I'm telling you -- and everyone else I know -- that these two dishes were mindblowingly, insanely delicious.  Also, the black olive ice cream (provided by Black Dog) was the best way to end a delightfully gluttonous meal.

Reservations are highly recommended -- especially if trying to eat here over the weekend!

The shishito peppers and our drinks were amazing. The pig face was too greasy and too salty. I was expecting a crispy pig face but it was more like a burrito pig face! The escargot ravioli was salty due to the miso but it was rather boring. The staff were helpful but it is a relatively loud place. We were very impressed by the shishito peppers. Get it!

Omg I don't even know where to start! Love love this place! Best to make reservations but me and my boyfriend decided to come early. Just our luck, we found some seats by the bar and was able to order from there! Everything was just wonderful!! My favorite would be the cauliflower and pig face! Oh let's just have the pictures do the talking!

One of my favorite restaurants in Chicago! Have made 5 or 6 trips in the last few years and every experience has been amazing. Have not once been disappointed. Some of the must haves include the pig face, beef tongue, and goat empanadas. Oh and the pork shank, off the bone, is always unbelievable. Having tried most of the menu items, you really can't go wrong. Can't wait for my next visit!

If you're ever in Chicago you must come here. Worth the hype. The dishes are small so you can get several and share them. We loved every single dish that we ordered. Taco bread, chickpea fritters, goat empanadas, halibut. All amazing. We were scared to try the pig's face but it ended up being our favorite dish. So good!  We ended the meal with the miso butterscotch budino.

We didn't have reservations, so we got there at 4:30pm. We were seated within 15 minutes. They gave us an hour and half time limit to eat, which was more than enough. The servers did a great job of bringing out the next dish just as you were finishing up the one in front of you.

Don't leave Chicago without trying this place.
Wasn't too impressed after hearing all the hype. Food was decent, but have been to many better places in Chicago.

I was SO excited to come here... and was finally able to snag a 8:15 PM spot on a Sunday evening. I had heard so many amazing things about this place. Two of my friends even told me it was the "best meal they ever had", so my expectations were really high.

I ordered 5 dishes:

-bread: it was the first dish that came out and surprisingly (and a bit sadly) may have been my favorite dish of the night. Although it was a bit oily, it was absolutely delicious and the two spreads that came with it were amazing as well. AND it was only $4!
