Girl & the Goat escargot ravioli with bacon, tamarind-miso sauce.
Girl & the Goat wood oven roasted pig face with sunny side up egg, cilantro, red wine-maple, potato stix.

review.des:
Amazing food, great service. Went for lunch during the middle of the week.

This place is definitely worth the hype. Their salads are amazing and I had one of their lattes to go. Definitely will be going again.

The only reservation over a MONTH in advance was at 11:30PM.  Bananas.  Better be good.  Better not be a complete salt lick.  Many of the items were.  

I can see why GG is popular: great energy, maybe too much?  We had a group of overgrown cougars cackling over our table, yes they attach small counters on the side of some tables.  URGH.  Prices, can't be beat, I think it was about $150 for 9 items, two glasses of wine and a beer.  

My problem?  Too much creamy sauce, too much salt and too many fried toppings.  Overdone comfort food.  

I really enjoyed the pig face, beef cheeks and cauliflower.  The rest were really heavy and the escargot ravioli, the flavor of the bug were lost.  

Would venture back, but only if an early time were available and would only order a few bites.

This place is pretty well known and for good reason. The food is delicious, creative, and locally inspired.

We went without a reservation, with a hope and dream that we could get in, and sure enough, we did. There was some magic to that...beyond what could be explained in a Yelp review.

The menu has a good variety of selection to meet whatever you're looking for - vegetables, vegetarian, vegan, paleo, unique, local. There are small plate options, so you can try several dishes without having to settle on one dish you want to try. There is a special "goat" menu, which didn't show prices on it when we were there. Regardless, we ordered the mysterious goat shoulder. We were warned that it was large, and we were confident (maybe overconfident) that we could eat all of it. We also ordered some other small plates with it - a beef tongue dish with chimichurri, some roast cauliflower, and a seafood dish. We enjoyed those dishes and then came the goat...which was basically a baby goat braised, on a platter, and served with several dipping sauce options. It was amazing. Melt in your mouth, and flavorful sauces to pair. It was also huge! We made a very small dent and then took the rest to go.

Though the price wasn't listed on the menu considering it was basically an entire small goat, the price shouldn't have surprised us. ~$90 for just the goat. Girl and the Goat, be clear from the get go - put the prices on the menu. There is no need to hide the fact that you get enough goat to feed a family or two and that you'll have to pay for it as if you're buying dinner for a family or two!

(Come on #Chicago- is that all it takes to impress you?!) #GirlandtheGoat

Girl and the Goat is (supposedly) all the rage in Chicago. I had to see for myself what this venue had to offer. It was hard to schedule a table with only a few days to pick from, but not impossible. So far so good. They also let me change our party reservation from 2 to 3 at the eleventh hour. Good stuff.

The dining space was warm and well lit but very noisy and tight on space. We never got comfortable especially where leg room was concerned.  As soon as we were seated, water was poured and the waiter started to explain the tapas style menu. We asked about their recommendations and popular dishes, but with a revolving menu, it is plain to see what favourites have made a lasting impression on city diners.

APPETIZERS

We opted for the MUSHROOM BREAD variety and enjoyed the moist warm bread, and the tomato olive drizzle almost as much as the mushroom paste. Nothing extraordinary, but a great alternative to regular bread paniers. They recommended the hummus version but we went against the grain on this one, pun intended.

THE GOAT EMPANADAS were next up. These were slightly too salty but well dressed with a cream cheese onion and tomato garnish that dialed down the sel. Pretty good.

GOAT LIVER MOOSE- This was a popular dish. We ordered it later because we realized we had more room after our entrees, but I'm glad we did. The crumpets were warm and gooey, and the grilled orange-rines compot was my favorite spread. The pickled cawliflower and regular pickles were not a delectable match at all. The Goat Moose jam, was just a-okay.   Truthfully,  I could have eaten the biscuits on their own so this item is still worth the buy but not the fuss.

THE BABY OCTOPUS also failed in my eye. Greatly in fact. This new addition to the menu needs to be taken back to the drawing board. The shallots, beets, and bean salad was too acidic, though I liked their treatment of the green and white beans (blanched to perfection). The octopus had no taste, especially after our wonderful octopus treat at Carnivale the night before (see my full review).

ENTREES

THE BEEF CHEEKS are actually on the entree menu but the serving is so small, even for a tapas approach, that nearly marked it down as an appy. I really enjoyed the fun textures here- slippery beef, crunchy oniony stix, all swimming in a broth bath. This was one of my favorite dishes but I was the only one so satisfied. The rest of the table did not enjoy this plate at all.  

ESCARGOT RAVIOLI- The snail was tender and chewy, and well seasoned, but the sauce was, again, way too salty. We could barely finish this plate, small as it was.

Going by previous yelpers' enthusiasm, I knew I wouldn't leave without trying the infamous WOOD-ROASTED OPEN PIG FACE. As per usual, the waiters encouraged us to mash it all up for a full flavour explosion.  I did enjoy the combo of the fried eggs, potato stix and the barbecued meat, but this is nothing you couldn't pull off at home, and that says a lot about a dining experience. Bold creation, puttered execution.

DESSERT

MISO-BUTTERSCOTH BUDINO- When it came time for dessert, we had room for one and only one pick, to be shared three ways. We took Antonio's recommendation and gave the Budino a try.  I liked the marriage of bacon toffee and cashews, and the feel of foamy whip on candied pineapple, but I didn't get butterscotch in my spoonfuls.  It was a nice finish but didn't taste as good as it sounded or looked, a theme for the night I'd say.

Overall, the fusionistic approach to menu and meal creation is admirable, and service and staff give you a pleasurable dining experience , but most of the courses didn't impress us, and NONE impressed ALL of us.

Everything comes in a small portion and I can't help but think this is part of the marketing genius behind this restaurant cause we could not have eaten many bites of any of it.

I will add that this was a midway value given the number of courses we had and our $60 bottle of wine- three diners parted with $75 each after a handsome tip. Not bad.

At the end of the day, fancy titles don't mask what's really going on here. An interesting menu born out of a creative mind but not worth more than a free trial. Even the waiter had to admit the ''drip coffee'' was nothing more than coffee on marketing steroids.

I RECOMMEND: The empanadas to meat lovers and the breads and cheeses to vegetarians.

EXTRA TIP: Ask your waiter what's new on the menu since it changes, and stick to the old!

The family and I ate dinner here last night.. The food here is incredible, I love the manner in which they bring the food out, there style is called topaz if I recall correctly. The servers bring one menu item out at a time.. We order the sautéed string beans!( which by the way are remarkably delicious) the pasta cheese ravioli for my son..(mom and dad tasted the pasta repeatedly) lol.. The beef tongue was better then I expected.. It was my first time tasting beef tongue. The chicken dish was also very good, it had a bit of Rosemary in the seasoning.. The goat potion was small but it was also our last dish, we were all so stuffed from the entire meal.

Great place!!!

P.S. They frown on walk-ins!! Make a reservation

We went there for my birthday around Valentine's Day and it exceeded our expectations with the amazing service. The atmosphere is very lively but being served delicious food by people who take pride in their service. The food is outstanding and for a popular restaurant, the prices are very reasonable. We can definitely see us going back.

Spectacular dinner.  Make sure to try the peppers for an app, halibut is a MUST, and string beans.  Need a cocktail?  Grab a old fashioned, properly made and delish.

Can't go wrong here-  very impressed.

Only note to the restaurant- the broccoli was too smokey.  Almost a burned taste.
In a word YUMMY...go early!  Great combinations of food components you've never thought of marrying together.

This place was amazing and it was definitely worth the wait to finally come here! Our service was excellent and our waiter had great recommendations and was very knowledgable about everything. I had the rotating cocktail but the whole cocktail list was interesting and there were others I wanted to try. Great wine list too. We shared the yellowfin tuna, the cauliflower, the braised beef short ribs and the goat empanadas. For 2 people four plates were more than enough. We also split the ice cream sundae dessert that had toffee and caramel corn on it. Delicious! Would love to go back and try more things!

I know, I KNOW. It's not new and everyone has eaten there. But Girl & the Goat is sooooooooo good. I've heard great reviews. And the restaurant in West Loop has been there for years. However, it was my first time and I hope to God it's not my last! Initially I wanted to go there for Valentine's Day, so I called in December to make a reservation but they were all booked up. I took Feb 13th, Monday night, because I could not wait any longer even if it was a weeknight at 9:30pm. Service was good as expected. I did not enjoy sitting so immensely close to the table next to us. The restaurant is a decent size but the seating is ridiculous. Lets talk about the food. Hands down the best cooked food I've had for the price. I was surprised when I saw the check. I was expecting it to be way more expensive (disclaimer: did not get any alcohol) because the quality of food was fantastic. We ordered and shared everything. Started with Citrus bread, then cauliflower, Beef short ribs and walter's chicken. Ended the night with chocolate dessert. My favorite dish of the night was the Beef short ribs, hands down. The cauliflower was no joke either. I've never had cauliflower that I actually enjoyed before. I think I'll be going back soon, I need more!

My roommate and I had to book our reservation a few months in advance. We went in the middle of the week ~9pm and the place was PACKED. It was quite noisy, but we didn't mind. The service was good and prompt, especially considering how many people there were.
We had the goat empanadas and goat carpaccio and both were great. The empanadas weren't necessarily anything too special though. I was really looking forward to ordering the pig face after hearing so many good things about it, but sadly the restaurant was out. We ordered a miso caramel budino for desert we both enjoyed the interesting combination of flavors. I would definitely go back just to try the pig face!

There is such a thing as too much flavor.

I didn't realize G&G was Tapas-style until the server informed us (I obvi didn't do my Yelper research). Sharing bites from small-dishes as they come is not my ideal dinner setup. The entire meal felt like an appetizer.

We ordered a lot, and you kind of have to if you want G&G to be a meal and not just a snack. Everything was really, really flavorful. The vegetable dishes stood out to me more than the seafood/meats. Lamb shank was great, and if/when I come back, I might just order that for myself and not share at all.

Halfway through dinner, I just wanted bread on the side to help balance out the richness of every. single. bite. Actually, bread would've been too much. I just wanted a bowl of dough to munch on. My tongue was yearning for a scoop of vanilla bean ice cream by the time we got to dish 6 out of 10. I needed a counter food, and that's all I could think about -- that's how tastebud-numbing G&G is.

G&G is a good restaurant, great even. You just have to be into that kind of dining, and I recognized that it's not my thing. I'd very much rather have a single plate that I can focus on, and be able to taste the original flavor of whatever I'm eating with the help of spices/sauces, not the other way around.

Never had goat. Never knew what to expect. Never even had any background history of this place or its chef. But boy am I glad I came here with my boyfriend. Possibly one of the best meals I have ever had. Ever!! Got a last minute booking cause there was snow storm warnings in Chicago.
We arrived earlier than opening hours but they allowed us inside (lucky since it was snowing). And seated us before our reserved time. Our waitress was lovely attentative, gave us plenty of recommendations and even a suggested order of food (light to heavy) so that our palates wouldn't be over stimulated. We ordered the bread (which is freshly baked), goat loin, green beans, pigs head, and goat belly. Everything was amazing. The texture of the pigs head was intriguing and very rich. The goat loin was probably my favorite, really well flavored and balanced.

We tried off and on for a couple years to get a reservation and once we did, Girl and the Goat did not disappoint. Great food drinks. It's a little loud but that adds to the experience. You can also go to the bar if you don't have a reservation and get the same menu. It's a pretty popular and crowded place so don't count on getting seat though.
I'm in love with this place. Everything I ate was amazing. The service was fantastic. The atmosphere is wonderful. I'd give them 6 stars if I could.

pics.caption: Frogs legs up close - beats chicken wings any day
Pan fried Florida Frogs legs with perilla and jicama - delicious
Kohlrabi salad with fennel, evalon, toasted almonds and blueberries - delicious and unusual an awesome combination

review.des:
I wanted to like this place. So much. Maybe my expectations were a little off the charts because I had heard so many raves about how amazing the place is. To me? There are better places in the West Loop that you can find. The food wasn't bad, but it wasn't fantastic either. Another yelper had made a comment that if you're hungry, be prepared to spend.

Pros: Cute ambiance, friendly staff. Our waitress (I wish I had gotten her name) was very thorough and helpful when recommending selections.

Cons: I'm not opposed to dropping money on good food, but to me the food just wasn't worth what we paid.

Probably wouldn't go back, but recommended if you're not too hungry and interesting in getting the whole trendy atmosphere/interesting people/place-to-be-seen experience.

Midwesterners are SO MUCH NICER than Californians...at least to solo diners at one of the hottest restaurants in the city.

After being told the bar was my best bet in snagging a seat on a busy Thursday night and advised on which bar diners were almost finished with their meals, I waited diligently behind a couple who were paying their bill. As soon as they stood up to leave, the hostess flew to my side, thrusted a newly-vacated chair toward me and told me to sit down quickly before other waiting patrons tried to steal it away. I was quite touched by the gesture, which I've never experienced in California. This alone warrants a five-star rating.

The food definitely matched the tone of the excellent service. I sampled several small dishes and everything was superb, with the goat belly as the obvious standout. This is seriously not to be missed! Must I also mention that the specialty cocktails were extremely addictive, thanks to the bartender who kept me liquored up and hydrated all night. Drunk and alone....nice!

To sum up my experience in a few words: dine unaccompanied like a stupid loser, receive special treatment. Try it sometime.

There are levels to this comfort food and I'm glad I came here. This place is quite busy and offers a unique menu. See below.

Food:
Fried oysters - delicious; must try
Sweet potato pierogis - good but not excellent
Squid with ricotta and apple on bruschetta
- best dish of the night with a very umami taste; I can die happy now
Goat liver mousse with crumpets and pickled sides - good but the crumpets made this dish a bit too fatty and oily
Goat belly with crab and lobster - delicious
Escargot dumplings - very good
Blood orange surprise with cake and custard - very good

pics.caption: Goat belly with lobster and crab

review.des: I had the pork shoulder bucatini, goat belly and the chocolatey cake and omg, it was heavenly. I only wish I didn't eat lunch so I could eat more for dinner.  Service was great.

Girl and the Goat definitely lived up to my expectations.  Kind of in a run down neighborhood frequented by hipsters, it looks like a good place to mug someone!  Besides the neighborhood, you come into the restaurant and you're welcomed by something that is what you would expect to see in village (NYC that is).  There is ample seating, a large bar area, and the vibe is definitely where the cool kids hang out at night.

Girl and the Goat is a tapas style restaurant and for men that means high prices and tiny plates that could leave you hungry at the end of the night.  I had the goat empanada, pig face, and their bread.  Paired up with some cocktails and it was well over $100 for the evening but I couldn't have been happier.  The bread here is fantastic, the pig face was delicious, and the empanada......well it was good but not worth the price.  The drinks they make are strong and the service is up to par kicking out dishes quickly and the waitstaff being attentive.  Great place to take a date no doubt.

First time visit last night. The positives were a very nice room, vibrant atmosphere but not incredibly loud, good service and really good food. I had the roasted beets and roasted pig face. Now the bad, and it was really bad. Most of the custom created cocktails with nicer liquors were $12-$14, about what you'd expect at a nice place. So I ordered a well gin martini, about the simplest drink possible: standard gin, vermouth and an olive. They charged $14, a surprise and an absolute ripoff. I'd go back to eat, but not to drink.

Wow wow wow my husband and I just happened to stop in and got lucky with a place to sit at the bar ! Our waiter I wish I remembered his name was outstanding !!!!!!!! The food was amazing and different ! I was freaked at first by the menu seeing things like (pig face) I'm not one for out of the box food ( it really meant bacon and eggs) lol the green beans are literally to die for and the crispy pork shank bomb.com we will definitly b going back!

We had the pleasure of getting a reservation for this place on this our 2nd trip to Chicago. I love to wide open expanse of space. The burnt wall in the center as a focal point was really amazing and totally unexpected from the outside appearance. Take time to watch they the open kitchen to see them execute the details of the dishes. It's cool to watch while you are waiting on the food. We ordered a variety of food from both the fish and meat menus, Wood fire oysters, Cuddle fish, Pig face, Goat belly, Apple fritters. All which were all good but the goat belly dish was by far the star dish of the evening for me. This expertly cooked goat belly was paired with melt in your mouth lobster and crab meat and fennel cream sauce that set it off perfectly. While super rich in flavor you just couldn't help yourself to not keep eating until the plate was clean!
I cannot wait for our next trip here to see what else they come up with!
OVERRATED!!! From the bread, salads to the main course. Service was good otherwise not worth it. Sorry!

We had dinner at Girl & the Goat on a Monday evening and had an enjoyable meal.

Décor: The inside of this place is not "huge" but they fit a lot of tables and make good use of the space. The bar, as well, is decent sized. One of the first things you notice is that the kitchen takes up the entire back wall - you can see them cooking/preparing/etc. It gives the place a really cool vibe. Additionally, it is decorated as a semi-industrial feel, another hipster holdover. But I liked it a lot, it's a cool atmosphere and very conducive to having an enjoyable meal.
Bathroom: well kept and clean

Staff: Our waitress was super friendly and very laid back. She gave us some good recommendations on the menu and did a great job of spacing things out over the meal. The support staff also did a wonderful job of taking away dirty places and replacing them with new ones, in addition to keeping a fresh bottle of water at the table (leaving a bottle is a great touch!).

Drinks/Food: We started with a bottle of wine and moved right into the meal. We had: warm marinated olives (tasty), sautéed green beans (great flavor and sauce but VERY salty), roasted cauliflower (pretty enjoyable), wood grilled broccoli (same, decent), chickpea fritter (different and tasty), cape cod mussels (yum, but needed some more broth), calamari bruschetta (SO GOOD!), seared diver scallops (perfectly prepared and tasty!), Nantucket bay scallops (just so-so when compared to the diver's), ham frites (very tasty and salty), Sugo Pasta (very tasty and enjoyable), the goat neck (unbelievably tender and juicy, wow!), and the sticky squash cake (a nice finish, very great flavor!). The portions range in size but we left full, and with leftovers (we probably ordered too much). Everything had great flavor but, overall, there seemed to be a lot of salt used in a variety of the dishes. It seems, however, that you cannot go wrong with anything on the menu.

Value: This place is a bit pricey but not over the top. The service is solid and the flavors are enjoyable - you end up spending more but you get a decent bang for your buck.

Many a person has raved about this place, and I was afraid it would be over-hyped, but it delivered and I wouldn't be opposed to dining here again in the future.

The worst thing about dining out in Chicago during a short trip is the plethora of choices. Well, we were finally able to snag a table at G&G and boy were we excited! Unfortunately, we had to wait about two hours, so we ended up filling up on beer down the street. Regardless, when we finally received the coveted call, we chugged our brews and ran across the street to be seated right away.

The waitress commented positively on my buddy's Dr. Who T-Shirt. I think he should have got her number. Anyway, we ordered the Johnny Apple Cheese, Pierogis, Goat empanadas, and the Pig Face.

I feel guilty about this, but my favorite was the Johnny Apple Cheese bread. Maybe it was the booze's influence, but this warm delicious melty fresh bread was perfect for post-imbibement fulfillment. Pierogies were decent, goat empanadas were.. plain, really. And Pig Face? You have to try it.
Phenomenal place with phenomenal food. Me and my girl ended up going here because the line was long at au Cheval.  I would highly recommend.  But do be prepared to spend a lot.

What an amazing restaurant. It is tapas style and the food is mind blowing. They had this broccoli dish that I swear tasted just like BBQ ribs! Idk how that is possible but it was just spectacular! There is a crazy wait list and reservations are usually booked about a month or two out so you will have to wait if you want to try this place. Never the less the food and service were so great that it deserves all 5 stars!

Yum...  Octopus is a must.  As are squash blossoms.  Also get the olive bread.  Holy goat that stuff is good.  Was pleasantly surprised by the service as well.  This place has got it down.  Keep up the good work.

I love this place! When I lived in Chicago we frequented it at any chance we could get (and our wallets could take!).

Some advice - be sure to make a reservation a few months in advance, and also know that the timing will be limited. We usually opted for a 10:00pm reservation. Pro-tip: ASK FOR THE CHEF'S TABLE! It will not disappoint. We loved sitting there and asking those in the kitchen what they were making. It's such a fun experience.

The price is right on for the quality of the ingredients. We always end up ordering entirely too much food...but how can you not when the menu is so good? Definitely cannot go wrong with anything. My absolute favorite is the pork shank and the peppers.

Phenomenal service and wine selection. Go check it out if you're a foodie :)

Crossed another one off my Bucket List.  We celebrated a graduation on 6/10 with 11 adults and 2 children.  Our server was a 10 out of 10.  We were a very lively group and she provided friendly and professional service.  She helped us set our course for the evening.  My wine and water glasses were never empty and it was a pretty warm day.  We had all the favorites including the green beans, broccoli, olives and peppers.  We also sampled the oysters, raw and wood fired.   They just kept bring plates of the most delicious food.  For seafood courses we tried the halibut and soft shelled crab.  We then moved on to the pig face, port shank and duck tongues.  The goat empanadas were fantastic as was the goat leg.  We passed around several desserts.  Every dish was unique, balanced and cooked perfectly.  The space is trendy and interesting.  Service was perfection from the moment we walked in until the moment we left.  Thanks G&TG, job well done!

I don't know if we just ordered the wrong thing, but after months of anticipation to finally go here, I left feeling disappointed.

The wood grilled broccoli was okay for a couple bites, but the smoke flavor was overpowering and there's no way we could eat the massive plate of smoky broccoli between two people. It got disgusting fast, I wouldn't recommend it. The chickpea fritters which were probably the best part of the entire meal, and our neighbors got the cauliflower and wouldn't shut up about how good it was. We should have got that instead of the broccoli.

We also tried the pig face after the rave reviews here on yelp. It was good, I would recommend it if you haven't had it yet, but I don't think I'd order it again. I also wasn't a fan of the scallops here, they were a little overcooked. The goat dish with a berry dressing we ordered was good. I don't see it on the menu now so I don't remember what it was called.

I guess I can say I've been here now, but it didn't live up to the hype.

For Valentine's Day me and my boyfriend wanted to go to au cheval, however the wait was longer then anticipated.  Instead of waiting we decided to go to another restaurant nearby, which happens to be girl and the goat. This place had great reviews so we decided to give it a try. We ended up loving the experience, food, and ambiance. This place is a little on the pricey side but the food is phenomenal.
The one you need make reservations one month ahead. Very nice restaurant, awesome service and amazing food. Come and try, share with your friends.

I came back to Girl and the Goat in late July, making two trips to this restaurant in two consecutive trips to Chicago. I liked it the first time around, but this second visit really knocked my socks off.

Venue was great, service was great, and we were able to adjust our OpenTable reservation up to a decent hour at the last minute (we were only able to get a 9:15 a month in advance). We came with a party of four for Tristan C.'s birthday and had a wonderful meal.

The drinks were nice. We had a round of cocktails then broke into a bottle of red wine. I really liked the Tagliolini, a smooth boozy drink with Cruzan aged rum, aperol, zucca, lime, and orgeat. The Bolt Action was another pleasant cocktail, with Old Forester bourbon, Blenheim's, lemon, and Angostura bitters. I forget what wine we got, but it was good.

The food was excellent across the board. We had a handful of dishes I loved on my first visit in 2012: the pan-fried shishito peppers, the ham frites, the sugo, and a variation on the chickpea fritter, with ratatouille, green goddess sauce, and MontAmore cheese. Everything else was new to me.

We started with the summer tom bread, which was not complimentary. It came with tomato oil and spring onion cream cheese, and I have to admit it was worth paying for. We also wolfed down the spring onion pot stickers and the goat empanadas. The pot stickers were pleasant, sweet and vegetal with ripe corn, rhubarb, dandelion greens, and sunflower seeds. The goat empanadas were a highlight of the meal, one of the best goat dishes I've come across in my admittedly limited goat-eating experience. The empanadas were crisped golden, and they came with a harmonious mix of grilled blueberries, miso-harissa aioli, and a farm veggie slaw. The goat was savory and flavorful but still quite easy to eat.

We moved on to some grilled kalbi beef ribs, a fancy restaurant rendition of classic Korean barbecue, served with sweet corn coblettes and a charred okra relish. The kalbi was tender and glazed thick with sauce, and the sides were interesting and very on point. Shifting to seafood, we had some wood-fired scallops and tempura soft shell crab. The scallops were silky and supple, and they came with sugar snap peas and a bacon currant chimichurri, all in an irresistible smoked uni cream sauce. The soft shell crab was also nice, though probably the least memorable dish of the night. It came with sweet corn elote and a shallot aioli.

The pan-roasted halibut might have been my favorite dish of our meal. The fish was perfectly cooked, moist and flaky and full of mild flavor. It came with Marcona almond buter, white asparagus, and a hauntingly delicious blueberry nuoc cham sauce. Dinner ended with the crisp braised pork shank, which was probably overkill. It was a huge portion of juicy pork, served with naan, buttermilk dressing, and stone fruit kimchi. It was impossible to finish, but certainly worth a strong effort.

We shared two desserts, one of which was comped for Tristan's birthday, presented with a candle. The first was the bittersweet chocolate with Thai basil-chocolate chip gelato and blackberries, an excellent chocolate dessert with an unusual mix of complementary flavors. The sticky date cake was even better, a sweet, addictive, dense little cake served with blueberry preserves and a side of MontAmore gelato. I was really into that light cheesy gelato.

We had a great time at Girl & the Goat, and I'd love to come back again on my next trip to Chicago. The restaurant was fun, and the food was innovative and delicious. Can't ask for much more than that.

I've been trying to make it to Girl & the Goat for over 3 years. I've made reservations in the past, but something has always come up and I've never been able to go. Probably because you have to make reservations MONTHS in advance if you want to get into this place, at least on a weekend. So finally, I walked in without a reservation at 5:40pm on a Thursday night and found two open seats at the bar. HALLELUJAH.

DRINKS
I ordered two drinks ($13 each) - the Spirit & Spice with gin, averell damson plum, sage, and lime; and the Act of Rebellion with pisco, cinnamon, thyme, and lemon. Both were good, neither tasted boozy, but I did get tipsy. I preferred the Spirit & Spice by a good margin, but that's just me.

FOOD (in order of how it arrived from the kitchen)
Goat Liver Mousse - with pickles and the most delicious biscuit-type bread. I was OBSESSED. I could eat this all day long, and I'm not typically into liver.

Grilled Baby Octopus - with guanciale, fava beans, pea tips, pistachios, and a lemon vinaigrette. My boyfriend apparently hogged the octopus, so I thought it was heavy on the bacon, but still completely delicious. Definitely in the top 5 octopus' that I've had.

Roasted Cauliflower - with pickled peppers and pine nuts. Holy crap, I loved this dish. The pickles totally made the dish, but then again I love pickles. It's also a huge portion, so we took about half home with us!

Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face - with a sunny side egg and potato stix. This was a very enjoyable dish, but it was my least favorite of what we had. The egg was really distracting and overpowering for me. I probably wouldn't order it again if I had the choice, but I would certainly eat it if put in front of me.

Overall, great dining experience. I don't understand why it's so much harder to get into than any other nice restaurant, but it's certainly worth sliding into a seat at the bar!

Not that Girl and the Goat needs my review, but I thought it was a great dining experience. The food was very good, especially the crumpets and the hamachi, but everything was above board.

I also found the decor extremely charming. If I could move one of those giant wooden tables and chairs into my own house ...

The service was also impeccable.

Waiting months for a rez may be a bit excessive (especially since I think hype can kill your experience), but I hear you can get tables on shorter notice if you're willing to eat early or late (read: 10 PM).

We were lucky and got inside without reservation - premium seats - right in front of the kitchen.
Staff was super friendly and professional. Food was exceptional. People inside - friendly and with good vibe.
We ordered roasted beets, escargot ravioli, and wood oven roasted pig face. Salad was good, ravioli - yummy, pig face exceeded expectations. I was a little bit nervous about the pig face, thought I was about to see an actual face. What a relief when server brought a dish without a pig head ;)).
With every dish servers gave a short presentation of the dish explaining what it includes and how it was cooked. I loved that.
After consuming all of the above, we decides to order roasted cauliflower. It was outstanding!
I cannot wait to come back!

So, its been almost 3 months since my legendary (in my head anyway!) foodie crawl though the Windy City.  I've never done anything like that before, and I wasn't sure what to expect.  It turned out to be quite the experience-- great eatin', hospitable people, and a beautiful city.  My friend and I ended up with the perfect itinerary-- we tried many places but were hardly ever too full and got a lot of walking in between.

The #1 spot in Chicago for me, the place that lingers above all others as a food memory (even months later as I write this from halfway around the world in the Middle East) is G&tG.  

The food was SO tasty, this was to be our only evening meal and so we ordered quite a few small plates to share.  The way chef Izard puts tastes together is so amazing!  We started with shishito peppers (pan fried with parmesan, sesame, and miso), diver scallops (pan seared with cubano pork, apple mojo, and pepper-raisin relish), and a loaf of johnny applecheese bread (served with chili-cheddar butter and malted oil).  Yum! To wash it down, I ordered a glass of rose and my friend went with the house (goat) red.

Moving onto our next course, we went with the confit goat belly (bourbon butter, lobster n' crab, and fennel) and pig face.  I hadn't heard of pig face before, but this was the 3rd one I've had this year-- the first was at Animal in LA in June, the 2nd earlier in the day at Purple Pig.  All delicious, so big fan of the "Pig Face" now!! :)  At G&tG, it was wood oven roasted with a sunny-side egg, tamarind, cilantro, red wine-maple, and potato stix.  Hom Nom!!

We finished with the pb&j dessert-- salted peanut kulfi, concord grape granita, and brioche donuts.  Perfect finish to the perfect meal.

Besides the excellent food, service was steller! Our server, Kelly, was so warm and friendly and we discovered she's originally from Vashon Island in the Pac NW ;).  After hearing how big of a fan I am, she even asked Chef Izard to stop by our table before she left for the night. Stephanie is as down to earth as I had expected but she looked so tired that I decided not to ask for a picture as planned.

Finally, the atmosphere was packed and buzzing, with the kind of vibe of a great (not merely good) restaurant.

With an extensive menu which I get a feeling is seasonal, G&tG is the kind of place I'd return often if I lived local, in order to try it all!  It easily gets my #1 vote of the 17 places we tried... ;)

Girl & the Goat is an amazing spot, and at almost 4000 reviews, it should be!  The restaurant is very hipster and has a dark lit atmosphere.  To eat here will set you back about an hour or so wait, even with a reservation, however we go really lucky to find a spot at the bar and got seating almost immediately, which we later passed on to someone else who did the same thing.  The shank is a must here as well as the roasted cauliflower.  Their renowned top chef really knows how to make a great dish.  Had a great experience here and recommend to any local or tourist.

We came here on a Saturday at 6:30 with friends for my husband's birthday. The restaurant was pretty crowded, but we had a reservation and were seated once our whole party had arrived. Our waiter was friendly and helpful with good recommendations from the menu. We had the brioche, cuttlefish, catfish, cauliflower, pig face, crispy short rib, and the lamb empanada for our meal. The citrus brioche was disappointing. The bread was dry and lacked the buttery taste we were expecting. However, everything else was very tasty. The cuttlefish had a great char. The catfish came on this really well seasoned rice. The cauliflower is always good with the pine nuts and peppers. If veggies were always this tasty, I could probably make myself eat more of them. The crispy short rib was also a stand out. Very tender and nicely refreshing with the avocado and radish. The pig face was tasty but the flavors were not very complex. The lamb empanada was also tasty and comes with 2 so you can share it pretty easily with 4 people. For dessert, we shared the pineapple cake and the caramel popcorn dessert. The pineapple cake was the favorite and was so delicious. I could eat another portion of that all by myself. Pretty much everything on the menu sounds good so you can't really go wrong. Come with friends so you can order lots and share things. Portions are on the smaller side so you'll have to order about 6 dishes for 4 people.

Dinner at this restaurant capped off our visit to Chi City, and I'm so glad that we made this reservation on the recommendation of a friend right after she found out we were going on this trip. Boyfriend had made the reservation as a late birthday gift to me -- and we had to make it about 2 months in advance.

We lucked out and were seated right in front of the open kitchen, so we had a first-hand view of everyone preparing and serving the food. We sat in front of the salad/tartare chef and the dessert chef. If you can manage to snag this seat, then I highly recommend you do! The chefs were so nice and were more than happy to provide answers for any question that I had (including, but not limited to "what are you doing," "what's that," and "did I order this?").

We ordered the wood grilled broccoli (with rogue smokey bleu sauce and spiced crispies), goat liver mousse (served with watermelon salad, smoked pear mostarda and crumpets), and the wood oven roasted pig face (with sunny side egg, tamarind, cilantry, red wine-maple sauce and potato stix). We were also comped a plate of pan fried shishito peppers because our waitress felt that they would be a good compliment to our other dishes. And I also received a little complimentary dessert of the peach and blueberry crumble with honey graham cake and goat cheese gelato as Boyfriend had put down that it was my birthday as the special occasion :)

Gonna break it down by dish here, but for an early tl;dr -- IT WAS ALL AMAZING AND YOU SHOULD DEFINITELY GO IF YOU GET A CHANCE TO.

Wood grilled broccoli -- this was probably Boyfriend's favorite dish of the entire evening. He was IN LOVE. Normally, we're not big fans of bleu cheese, but the dressing on the grilled broccoli was light enough not to be overwhelming and perfectly complimented the grilled taste of the broccoli. This was an amazingly light appetizer that we inhaled.

Goat liver mousse -- I was honestly worried that this was going to be waaay too rich for me to enjoy (like the duck liver mousse I've had at State Bird Provisions -- too rich to finish), but it wasn't too rich at all! I mean, it's rich -- but not so much that you felt as though it were coating your throat and arteries as you swallowed. It was AMAZING when you spread it on the crumpets and topped it with the smoked pear mostarda, which cuts into the richness just enough that all the flavors blend together and take you away to heaven. Not even kidding.

Pan fried shishito peppers -- I was worried this dish would be spicy but it wasn't at all! The exterior is crispy and interior is tender, the peppers are perfectly pan fried and retain an incredible amount of flavor, perfectly complimented by the parmesan, sesame and miso. Seriously, I'm sitting here drooling as I'm thinking about it.

Wood oven roasted pig face -- hands down, probably the best part of the meal. It was so tender and flavorful and amazing. Not actually a pig's face looking back at you (I don't know why I thought this was the case, but I did), but think more like cabeza meat in Mexican dishes. What with the sunny side egg and the "potato stix" (a fancy way to say hash browns), it was like a super succulent breakfast dish.

Peach and blueberry crumble with honey graham cake and goat cheese gelato -- so glad I only got a taster dish of this as a birthday freebie. I never would've finished the full-size dish as I was already stuffed to the seams from the meal itself. This is a pretty rich dessert because of the gelato, but the crumble and cake help to cut it just enough that you're not overwhelmed.

Seriously, this is a 5-star place. Come hungry, leave happy. And, honestly, it doesn't really break the wallet for the quality of food that you're getting! If I ever visit Chicago again (and I will!!), I'm definitely make this a regular stop!

pics.caption: The only photo I took because I was too busy inhaling the food.

review.des:
I am stuck in a jam on this review. While the place was ok, I tend to think it took a ding because of how hyped it was. It took forever just to get a reservation.  I wanted to try the Pig Face, but I wimped out. We got to sit at the chef's table, so that was pretty cool and got free dessert at the end.

Overall the food was good, but not memorable. I eat out a lot, so that is important to me. The portions are small, but meant more for sharing. The decor of the place is nice, and the atmosphere is pretty inviting.

I had several mini portions off of the menu. This option is offered at the bar as a singles option. For the price, it's a nice way to sample the menu. Overall there was nothing here to die for as many exclaim. It was good food, don't get me wrong, and the service was excellent and attentive, but $9 for 2 medium shrimp, and about the same for cauliflower, and an empanada each makes this a solid 3 star.

The food here is delicious if you can find a place to sit and eat. If you don't have reservations, then I recommend going with a small party (2 people), so you can wedge your way in at the bar or lounge area.

Now about the food...
My hands down favorite dish is the wood oven roasted pig face. There was once when it was a bit too salty, but it has otherwise never disappointed. I also love the deep fried cowboy oysters. Raw oysters are always a good choice, if you're into that... I just wish the serving size was bigger. Most recently, I had the braised pork shank and it was phenomenal! The meat fell of the bone and went perfectly with the buffalo sauce, blue cheese, kimchee, and naan. All of the flavors come together in an amazing way. The sweet corn esquites chili shrimp was also pretty decent. None of the veggie dishes were very memorable. Now I usually stick to the meat and fish dishes.

I highly recommend trying this place out. Come hungry, so you can order a lot and try a little of everything. I always walk in with a party of 2 to 3 people tops and see how bad the wait is... If it's over 20 minutes, then there are plenty of other places on the same street that you can go to as an alternative.

Went for dinner on a Friday night in the summer. Walked in around 930pm and asked for the wait time for a table of two. The hostess calmly said 1.5 hours.

We decided to stalk the bar and wait for two seats which took 10 minutes. Bartender was so nice and personable. Drinks were different and delicious. Food was so good. We had the olive bread, wood fire oysters and pig face. On top of that, the bartender brought over two additional dishes...yellowtail tuna and pork belly (yum) and roast cauliflower with picked peppers (also yum). Food, service, drinks and atmosphere was amazing.

pics.caption: Olive bread. Bread was steaming hot and delicious.

review.des: To be honest, there's not anything more for me to add that almost 6,000 people haven't already raved about. Trendy but inviting decor, incredibly personable and efficient team, and food that I'd come back for any given time. I can't wait for my next opportunity to enjoy this gem!

pics.caption: Caramel corn & malt balls. Not much of a chocolate fan, so this was a caramel lovers dream! Texturiffic!
Crisp Braised Pork Shank. To. Die. For.
Goat Empanadas on the left, Roasted Beets on the right, What's The Dill Yo in the background.

review.des: The staff is incredibly friendly and helpful. The place itself is cool and the food is delicious. We ordered the miso bread (meh. Nothing special), chickpea fritters (would definitely get again), roasted broccoli with krispies {literally Rice Krispies } (good but would not order again), the halibut with blueberry compote and a bunch of other things (1000 times YES. Order this.), and the vanilla malt dessert and all the leches dessert (both were GREAT. If I had to choose one I'd get all the leches again). The chef likes putting something crunchy on every plate (I.e. The krispies on broccoli, noodle things on some dishes, caramel popcorn on one of the desserts) - little goat across the street is also the same chef. Would be interesting to try. The prices are relatively high but the food is amazing.

pics.caption: Caramel corn malt ball dessert. Whatever the little chocolate squares are...give me more of that cause they're GOOD.

review.des: Wonderful dinner tonight, with impeccable service by Owen (who even posed for a photo with us!). Goat carpaccio, pig face, and cauliflower were all amazing. Desserts were pretty darn good, too.

pics.caption: Wonderful dinner w impeccable service by Owen (who even posed for a photo!). Goat carpaccio, pig face & cauliflower were beyond delicious.

review.des: I rarely repeat restaurants, but Girl & the Goat had me coming back! Went a second time for boyfriend's birthday. We sat by the special chef table by the kitchen the second time but we weren't a fan.. It was hot and loud so we asked to be moved. The bread is delicious, but fills you up too quickly.. save room for the real food! The pig face is scrumptious and the chickpea fritter is super original! The desserts keep changing more frequently and can be hit or miss so choose carefully!

I don't really dig on chef driven restaurants like this.  It is usually a lot of hype.  Girl and the Goat had great food, and lived up to the hype.

The food was excellent, just small.  I realize that I am paying for a name, and that it is small plate, and I am paying for the experience, but I thought that by dropping over $140 for two people that I would at least leave full.  We had 1 drink each, so I don't know where that money went.

Parking is terrible, so if you drive you might as well valet. Halsted can get nasty, so watch out for that.

The food was great.  Pig face was great.  Goat Empanadas were great. Cauliflower was great.  The rest of the food was great.  I can't fault the cooking because it was awesome.  Portion sizes were a little lacking, but maybe that is just me.  

My wife had a great time, loved the food, and left completely satisfied with the entire experience.  If she gave this review it probably would have been a 5 star.

To quote my waiter tonight, She's either mad or a genius! Well awesome waiter (Brennan was totally great as was his trainee), Stephanie Izard is an evil culinary genius....minus the evil part! They don't let just anyone win Top Chef.

It's been a year since my last review so thought it was time for an update! The pig face remains my favorite dish at Girl & The Goat. Do not skip this when you go! Topped with a sunny side up egg & other yummies, this dish is mouthwatering and every bite is out of this world.

Tonight I tried the bloody mary bread which I'd never had before and it did not disappoint. They bake their bread perfectly with every bite being so soft with scrumptious worcestershire butter to top it off. You must get one of their breads when you go! They always offer three choices for $4  - ever changing flavors, and those ever changing flavors are so unique. I also tried the sugo tonight which I had never had before. Personally I'm not into the gooseberries but sans that touch this dish was delicious!

We shared five dishes + bread between the two of us tonight and left completely stuffed beyond belief. Note to self for next time: Four dishes + bread will suffice---- it's just so hard to pick between trying new things and sticking with my tried & true favorites. Our bill including tax & tip was $52 each, not bad at all for a fantastic meal!

Girl & The Goat remains not only a Chicago hot spot but a top culinary destination for amazing food and service. I recommend it to all tourists and people who live in our fantastic Chi City who haven't gone yet...What chu' thinkin!? Get there now!

The menu changes all the time. I love this place- see my prior reviews.  Here's what you should get:

Chickpea fritters
Duck tongue
Pig face
Pork shank
Butterscotch bodino

I have been dreaming of visiting this place ever since I watched the season of "Top Chef" that Stephanie Izard won.  She created things on that show that I couldn't even imagine:  I knew her restaurant would be amazing.  It is.  

Great lighting and cozy tables and a real Chicago feel.  We were lucky enough to slip in at 4:30 without a reservation, as long as we promised to leave by 5:30.  My little party of 3 felt like we'd won the lottery!

We stuck to the safer dishes (chickpea fritters, etc) and stayed away from the adventerous goat and pig-face dishes (yes, really).  I'm sure they would have been amazing, but my two friends and I were not in the mood to explore.  While our lack of adventure definitely limited our menu choices, everything we had was positively delicious.  Small, but tasty portions.  

For dessert, we went whole hog and ordered the caramel popcorn with homemade ice cream and magic shell. OMG!!!!!   It is the stuff of fantasy.    Truly magical.  

So glad we had a chance to go.  Service was impeccable, btw.  Valet parking was reasonable and quick (nice on a brrrr cold night).

I had been to the sister restaurant (Little Goat) for brunch once and wasn't too impressed. I decided to check out Girl & the Goat after the Blackhawks game with a friend. The service was decent- there were a few times we wanted to get the servers attention but he was grabbing things off a table or walked by but didn't stop to check if we needed anything. The food was great. I will rate them from best to least best. Red fish, Roasted Cauliflower, Goat empanadas, and Crispy beef Shortrib- all good choices. The vibe was one that I liked and I enjoyed my visit but not in a rush to go back.

Very good place I loved it
Just a little Bit to expansive
Still I'm going to come back

This place really is as good as everyone says it is!

Before my trip to Chicago, we tried making reservations but the host said they're booked for the next month. We were a little disappointed, but determined to find a way to dine here! We wanted to give this place a shot and see if we can snag a table before they open and to my surprise, there was a already a line outside! I'm thinking to myself, there's no way we can get a table now. Luckily, they allowed us to dine for an hour and a half..... what?!?! SCORE! Good thing we already knew what we wanted to order.

We got the wood oven roasted pig face, of course, crispy duck tongue and the beef short ribs. Oh my goodness... my mouth is busting with flavors. Every item we had was savory ... the texture, the sauces.. not sure how to say it to you, but the ingredients complemented each other really well. The duck tongue was by far my top favorite; must try!! I can see why everyone is raving about this place!
Best restaurant in Chicago. Everything we ordered was fantastic! Make sure you make reservation and order hr pig's face!
Great restaurant with some superstar dishes.  Some dishes just fell a bit flat, just could have used better seasoning.  Overall worth the experience.

This place is hands down one of my favorite restaurants in Chicago. I've been here on several occasions and it gets better every time. They definitely don't skimp you on the portions either. Book your reservations a few weeks in advance. They also have a small section is that first come first serve. Or you can wait later, around 10pm, and get seated.

Food that I've had and would recommend:
- Shishito peppers (one of my favorite dishes here)
- Roasted cauliflowers
- Wood grilled broccoli
- Grilled baby octopus (ridiculously good)
- Calamari bruschetta (loaded with flavor)
- Oven roasted pig face (so tender...wish I could eat every day)
- Pork shank (this is pretty big and slightly crispy skin)

The caramel corn& malt balls dessert has been sold it every time, so never had a chance to try it out.

Ooooooooverrated! I had high expectations for this much lauded restaurant but over the course of the meal, I realized they were not going to be met. The ambiance was nice and the service was decent although the pacing of entrees was problematic. We had two vegetarians in our party and all their dishes were brought out first and then they sat and watched the rest of us eat for an hour. There were some standout dishes including the chickpea fritters, diver scallops and calamari bruschetta. The escargot dumplings we tasty but nondescript and lacking unique flavor. The drum fish was well prepared but the flavors were jarring and unpleasant.  The pork shank was tasty and worked well with the kimchi sauce and the pig face had a good flavor with some crispy bits but also hunks of mushy fat which detracted from the overall dish. The goat belly with lobster and crab had great ingredients but was excessively rich and lacked balance. The breads were flavorful and warm with well matched spreads, our favorite was the sourdough olive with whipped feta and Greek olive oil.
Overall, this was a "one and done".

This is by far my favorite restaurant in Chicago and I make sure that we go to it at least once each time we visit. They are great at accommodating one's dietary restrictions and there is a plethora of vegetarian friendly options. Their cauliflower dish is beyond amazing. Everything we have tried is so innovative and the flavors are bold but delicious. In fact, currently booking another reservation as we speak.
I don't get it. It was loud, crowded and understaffed. I thought the food has been better at every other Fulton Market restaurant I've been to (most of them cheaper!)

If you're in Chicago, Girl & the Goat is a MUST try! I was expecting it to be overhyped, but everything was delicious! I was trying to book reservations a week in advance with no luck. So I went in on a Friday night and waited no more than 20mins for a seat at the bar which worked out fine. Our bartenders were very nice, accommodating, and fun to watch. One was dancing and they would be throwing glasses of water to each other.

Now on to the food..

- Pig Face - OMG best thing here! You MUST get this. It was ridiculously tender and so full of flavor. The egg was cooked perfectly and it's meant to be dug in and 'messy'. So good!

- Nantucket Bay Scallops - the scallops were cooked well, but I didn't care too much for it.

Steamed Cape Cod Mussels - plenty of mussels and the sauce was soo good with their bread. I couldn't get enough of it. Also, a good portion for sharing!

Crisp Braised Pork Shank - This was hugeeee. I was sharing with another person and we couldn't finish it. This was also very tender and fell off the bone perfectly. I wasn't a huge fan of the buttermilk dressing that it came with though. However, when eaten all together with the naan like a sandwich, it all came together quite nicely.

Overall, a great experience and would definitely want to come back just for the Pig Face!

Food was excellent. Service was also excellent. Obviously, make a reservation ahead of time. Started w an old fashioned which was made delicately. Citrus brioche w miso paste - I would skip in next time but I'm not big on bread when you have a big dinner ahead. Cauliflower was excellent and so were the perioglies or however you spell it. But I would get the fennel salad (starts with a k) because I loved it. Great blend of flavors and unlike a salad you'd get elsewhere. The entrees we chose were the pig face- which is decadent but not something you want more than 3 bites of because of its richness. Everyone talks about the pigs face but let's talk about the pork shank. That was MONEY. Great meal, great experience. Next time will come back with room for dessert. I recommend this place for groups because it's great for sharing and you will go into comatose if you try to share with one person.

If you dig decently priced foodie style food that will delight and surprise you, go here. Wave your finger randomly at the menu and eat things. Or ask the server what you should have. My favorite is the Pig Face and the Scallops, but I haven't had a bad dish here. Even the bread is freaking delicious. The servers are friendly, but not overbearing. The atmosphere is lively, but still intimate. The prices are reasonable and the dishes are interesting. If you're in town, make a reservation. Seriously, just go. Now.
Amazing unique food, small plate style which was great as we could try a lot of stuff!

3 words..... Miso Butterscotch Budino.

I went to this spot twice in 3 days. Thank you, Stephanie! This dessert should NEVER be taken off your menu. I'm addicted, and need more of it in Seattle.
ambience and food are excellent. much of the "exotic" food are just Asian.

Since there are already so many reviews, I'll keep this short and simple.
To be completely honest with myself, I thought this place was a bit overhyped. Everything was good, but none of the dishes blew my mind except the halibut. I'd totally do the pork shank over the pig face. Goat empanadas were a bit too small for me. Peanut butter butter bread I thought wasn't too tasty but filling. Bread wasn't super aromatic/fresh/buttery or anything and the butter I thought could have more peanut flavor and I didn't like the grape bits. It was a little salty. Bill came out to $100 with tip and tax and I thought I had better meals with this price point. However, this place is by no means bad. It's good still, but don't go expecting to have a revelation about food.
Unbelievable atmosphere and food. Great wait staff. Awesome experience and we definitely look forward to returning.

Excellent service (the second night), beautiful food, and a menu with something for everyone. I'd recommend the goat empanadas every day. Four stars for two reasons: 1. though the filling in the pierogies was delicious, the acidic sauce was overpowering 2. We tried to get a table the night before and couldn't get in, and the bartender was super unpleasant when we asked for a drink. We decided to leave and come back the next day.

Girl and the Goat might be one of the few oft-mentioned restaurants that truly lives up to the hype. It is the complete package for a fancy dinner and worth every pretty penny.

Getting here takes some advanced planning- takes a while to get reservations and you must order the goat leg in advance. Bring at least 6 people so you can enjoy the goat leg and some other small dishes.

The decor is gorgeous,  with lots of espresso wood and brick and high ceilings.  

The food. The food! Favorite small plates- pig face,  green beans (how do they taste that good!?), broccoli, and scallops. Delicious but couldn't beat out the others: squash blossoms and peppers.

But the goat leg!  On a wooden board with an array of the fluffiest flatbread,  sliced eggs, fried onion, dipping sauces,  and the most tender tasty meat on a leg ever. Oh my goat. This is a must.

This ranks as one of my favorite meals of all time. I wish I had the budget to do this a lot. It was pricey but everyone left stuffed and there was even goat left over to take home. If you are in Chicago this place is not to be missed for a special night out.

Really long wait. Definitely make reservations ahead of time!

The highlights of the meal:
- Crispy duck tongue! The strips of fried wonton skins were a good compliment to the dish. And it was definitely well balanced w/ the poke poke.
- Oven roasted pig face. Two slabs of crisped pig face sandwiching a bed of potato stix. And that sunny side up egg sitting happily on top? Just let all the flavors melt in your mouth...
- Pan-fried shishito peppers. Fried well while mixing in w/ that cheese. Pretty dope. Spicy, cheesy. Yum!
- The cauliflower. Wow. Fried & tossed w/ the pine nuts & pickled veggies. A nice tang w/ that crunch.
- The pork shank. That meat just fell off the bone & melted in my mouth... And that bread... What a nice warm pillow... *drool*
- Chocolate cake. THERE'S CRACK IN THAT BASIL ICE CREAM. Holy crap. What a nice surprise the chocolate cake dessert brings. The flavors are well balanced w/ the berries, cake & ice cream.
- The blueberry & peach crumble. Buttery crumble w/ every bite of warm blueberry & peach filling.

Definitely worth trying but I'm not sure if you want to wait to be "waitlisted" without a ressie so I highly recommend making one or going at 4:30 PM when they open...

I can't even figure out how to write down all the wonderful things that you can get at girl & the goat! Steph, the chef, was one of my favorites on top chef so getting to eat at her place was definitely a bucket list item. Since it would
Take me days to write about each dish I'll just list the Best things:

cauliflower dish, goat belly, olive bread with whipped feta, halibut dish, green garlic perogies, grilled octopus

Service here was also top notch! Our waitress was incredibly knowledgable about everything on the menu and even helped us pair our wine with the different dishes.

Fantastic experience - family style meets haute cuisine. We ordered 10 items for four - 9 exceeded our expectations because the blend of flavors was surprising but flavorful (think scallops with Jamaican jerk spice and coconut, skirt steak with cucumber, tuna with pickled peach salad...). The ambience is inviting - a bit noisy if you have difficulty hearing in crowded rooms. Our server, Devon, was great; knowledgeable and fun.

Came here after the 2014 Chicago Marathon for a 4:30 reservation and felt that it was a GREAT place!  I came all the way from Boston and booked this reservation months in advance; they gave us the first seating of the night and our waiter was attentive, knowledgeable, and great and educating us on the menu.

The La Paloma cocktail was amazing and they have a great hard cider selection with local ones made in Michigan.  We had the cauliflower, octopus, trout (which was the best), and the pig's face. I ate everything except for the Pig's Face.

The best part of this restaurant is that its actually QUIET and you can HEAR you company. I am only 27 but I still have such a hard time hearing people when out at restaurants + I loved how easy it was to hear my friends and cover comfortably from the marathon over cocktails and good food.

I am extremely healthy so found the food a little too greasy for my liking but overall A+ and would for sure come back again! I highly recommend and love how its large, has nice bathrooms, and the wait staff was really nice!

For SURE will come back again!
Tamara

Everything you've heard about this place IS TRUE. The hype IS REAL.

Food: 5
Service: 5
Ambiance: 4.5

I had my birthday dinner here and enjoyed every minute of it-- from the second we were seated (very promptly even though we were 25 minutes early) to the dessert and sparkling wine at the end.

Everything we had was delicious but I'd particularly recommend the pan fried shishito peppers, grilled baby octopus, escargot dumplings, and wood oven roasted pig's face.

Brava!

Went to girl and a goat yesterday, truthfully quite disappointed. We ordered olives, fries, grilled octopus, pork shank, goat carpaccio and dessert- dark matter.
The dessert and pork shank were wonderful, grilled octopus was good, while fries were disastrous. Have tasted worst flavored fries !
Also we were sitting across from the door, which at the rainy and cold day like yesterday was very unpleasant due to frequent cold inflows. We asked to be moved to another table - but we weren't accommodated. A little discounting experience to say the least....

Get ready for a flavor-explosion-party-in-your-mouth!  We got lucky and got reservations last minute!  Make sure you get a reservation ahead of time, like in days..  The wait was long, but well worth it.  Packed with friendly service and great ambiance, a hot place to be to hang out and enjoy!  We had a great time and our server made it even better!  We had the following:

- Pretzel bread with thousand island sauce; this was awesome, but we had to lay back on the bread to eat what's in store for us!

- Roasted Cauliflower: consists of pickled peppers, pine nuts, and mint; honestly this was okay, I actually did not want to continue to eat it because it was not that great

- Kona Kampachi Crudo: crisp pork belly with chili aioli and caper berries; delicious and great on textures, very light

- Diver Scallops: served with XO, pork sausage, shiitake, bok choy, and butternut squash; delicious scallops, but can pass on especially for the delicious meats here!

- Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face: consists of sunny side egg, tamarind, cilantro, red wine-maple, potato stix; OMGee delicious!  talk about a flavor explosion of delicious and a great contrast of textures, a MUST ORDER!

- Crisp Braised Pork Shank: consists of butternut squash-shiitake kimchee, buttermilk dressing and nann; another OMGee! Order this delicious and tender piece of meat thingy, you will not regret it, if you do not like it, just go ahead and ship me the leftovers ;)

- Confit Goat Belly: with bourbon butter, lobster and crab, and fennel;  also very good, how can you say no to goat belly??

Ah, I was so, so happy that I got a reservation here last minute, very so happy.

Summary: What I enjoyed most about each dish is its complexity and perfect balance of different textures and flavors. The chef did not let us down on any dish and we had a lot for two people! Highly recommend.

Detailed review below.

We made a reservation for three a week ago via Open Table for our trip to Chicago from PDX.

They called us two days prior to confirm our reservation which we did and asked for a high chair as we would be bringing a baby as our third and the girl on the phone happily said no problem.

Upon arriving at 5:45, the restaurant was packed and bustling with music and chatter of all the customers. This was my third day in Chicago and I gotta say coming from Portland I think I'm spoiled with food because nothing has really impressed me so far but is the place I was waiting for!

We were seated very quickly to a perfect corner booth table for the three of us and none of the staff looked annoyed by our baby and in fact were all very friendly and smiling to her.

Water came quickly as did menus, we glanced over all the yummy options and made or choices. Miso Hungry (bread rolls with pepper butter and jam), green garlic pierogies, grilled baby octopus, wood oven roasted pig face, and goat liver mousse.

Our server Calvin was SOOO awesome. He told us that a few of our choices were very rich and recommend we switch a few things so we switched the roasted pig face and liver mousse to the Pork Shank and goat belly. He said that the mousse is so rich that it's usually something people come in for happy hour and just share one plate.  His choices were perfect but by the time the pork shank arrived I could only eat a 1/4 of it as we were stuffed.

Dessert we had the date cake and that was bliss as well. This restaurant meets and exceeds its reviews and the staff and hospitality were all at or above expectations.

I highly recommend this restaurant if you are coming to Chicago.

This place is worth the hype. Get a reservation 3 months or so in advance on Open Table and take your favorite people with you to share some amazing food. You MUST try the halibut. It is one of the best things I've ever tasted. Enjoy!

Not a lot more I can say about this place that hasn't already been said. I want to come back every time I'm in Chicago so I can eventually eat the entire menu.

Came here with a coworker super late on a Tuesday (10:55, thanks for seating us guys! You da best) and the place was still bumpin. Our server was a bit miffed to have a table seated so late but she did her best not to be too pushy, not her fault the kitchen was about to close so we needed to make quick decisions.

We went for meat on meat and ordered 4 meat dishes to share: crispy duck tongues, lamb tartare, lamb-stuffed calamari (we love lamb, obvs), and the seared scallops. It was all really, really fantastic. I even enjoyed the crispy duck tongues despite the presence of cilantro, which I hate.

Hands-down favourite was the lamb tartare, followed closely by the lamb-stuffed calamari. How they manage to keep the calamari from getting rubbery while warming through is beyond me, but they were amazing.

These 4 dishes between two people was a relatively light meal, good for a late-night dinner. If you're really hungry you might want to order another 1 or 2 dishes. I had a cocktail with gin and grapefruit that was delicious. I will be coming here for sure the next time I'm in town.

Prices were reasonable for an upscale place in a major city. Not cheap by any means but I didn't think anything was exorbitant. Thank you, corporate expense account.

Worth the hype--this is my 9th top chef restaurant and I've yet to be disappointed by anyone from the show. Although their PR is great, the chefs have very very real chops.

I started with raw kusshi oysters. Can't go wrong with these. Clean tasting not too briny maybe a tad overloaded with horse radish but I'll forgive the heavy handedness.

Dish two was the fried chickpea fritter. Unfortunate they called it a fritter because this is much more refined and nuanced that any old fried doughy thing you've had before. This is perfectly light and delicious--melts in your mouth. The bed of brussel sprouts and greens also compliment the fritters.

Next I had the escargot dumplings. The sauce was pretty freaking amazing. I only wish the dumplings had more texture ? The escargot was also not discernible for me ..

Finally ended with the infamous wood over roasted pig face. My Filipino kababayan will find this similar to a sisig but elevated in a pretty ridiculous way. Crispy, unctuous and perfectly porky if you must get one thing please get this. Though the tamarind sauce is good I wish it had a bit more acid. I also think the fried egg is extraneous ... Maybe if they served this on a hot plate sisig style and put a raw egg on top I'd appreciate the addition of the egg.

Finally ended with some tea and the chocolate truffle. Great dessert but not too out of the box or crazy inventive.

I had the pleasure of dining alone and my server Kristen was awesome. She told me the dishes could also come in "mini" sizes as I was dining alone. This allowed me to try a lot more variety and try a larger scope of the menu. Props to her and chef Izard for this option.

Overall I'd definitely be back.

INSIDER TIP for the bourbon lovers: if you're waiting for a table and trying to kill time walk over to Elliot Graham's bistro down the street. They are currently serving pappy van winkle (!).
Not exactly a donkey but still makes me long for the Tiajuana days of my youth.

Was NOT disappointed.

This place has so much hype but was 100% worth it. We had a reservation on a Tuesday night at 10pm, decided to try to get in a little early and were seated almost immediately around 9:15. That's not to say it still wasn't pretty crowded.

The service and ambience was amazing! Our waiter was really friendly and knew the menu extremely well. He also seated us directly in front of the open kitchen which was pretty awesome.

We ordered the pan fried shishito peppers, calamari bruschetta, crisp braised pork shank, and goat carpaccio. We also had the all the leches cake and berries & cream for dessert. Everything was absolutely delicious!

Probably the best scallops I have ever tried when I had my first experience at this restaurant it was fantastic by the second time it was even better not only is the food delicious but they have fantastic martinis fantastic cocktails great food great service I was able to enjoy it with really close friends as well

Girl & The Goat doesn't miss a step. Wine. Bread. Mains. Dessert. They're all delicious and perfectly prepared and served.

Normally I'm against filling up on bread before a meal, but it would be remiss to visit Girl & The Goat without ordering one of the starter loaves of bread. We tried the Johnny Applecheese: made with apple and white cheddar, perfectly crusted on the outside and soft and warm on the inside.

The main menu is split into three categories - vegetable, fish and meat - based on the primary ingredient. Dishes are meant to be shared, though they seem more like comfort food than tapas.

We started with the pan fried shishito peppers, which were full of flavor, but not necessarily spice (unless you happen upon a rogue pepper). Peppers are prepared with parmesan, sesame and miso to make for an incredibly savory dish.

We also ordered the chickpea fritters served with tomatillo-tomato jam and montamore. The fritters were slightly crisp on the outside and pillowy on the inside. The sweet jam and soft, creamy cheese paired nicely.

The standout, though, was the Mt. Lassen trout served with pumpkin brandade, fried brussels sprouts, candied pecans and pomegranate seeds. This dish skillfully combines flavors - warm pumpkin, earthy sprouts, tangy pomegranate - and textures - flaky trout, smooth brandade and crispy, crunchy garnishes. It's one of the best dishes I've ever eaten.

If you're dining at Girl & The Goat, you need to commit and not skimp on dessert (it's just understood that you'll be more than full when you leave). We sampled both the PB&J and the apple buckle. The PB&J was a deconstructed version of the childhood favorite with brioche doughnuts, salted peanut kulfi and concord grape granita. The PB&J was good, but I much preferred the apple buckle. With warm apples, oatmeal-graham streusel and a heaping scoop of Black Dog brown butter gelato, it was the ultimate fall dessert.

What's best about Girl & The Goat is the attention to detail in the restaurant itself and in the kitchen. This level of care creates a dining experience that is high quality without feeling stuffy.

review.des: Well worth alllll the hype. We got the goat leg and it was a FEAST. Be sure to call ahead and place your order if the leg is what you want, but EVERYTHING was absolutely incredible. Can't wait to go back!

Now I know why it's always been impossible to get reservations to this place: Girl & the Goat was awesome. One of the best non-Michillen-stared restaurants I've ever been to. I'd recommend everyone in Chicago or traveling to Chicago to go to Girl and the Goat.

Ordering here is a bit "tapas-like" - order a few different things and share. I'll list what we got, and rate each from 1-10

Oysters: 10/10
Beet salad: 10/10
Shishito peppers: 8/10
Grilled octopus: 9/10
"Pig face": 8/10
Pork Belly: 8/10
Bay scallops: 10/10
Goat carpaccio: 10/10
Goat empinada: 9/10
Cheese selection: 9/10
PBJ dessert: 8/10
Chocolate and shiitake dessert: 9/10
Miso and pineapple dessert: 10/10

Girl & the Goat is a place you have to go to. Food, service, atmosphere all great. I was blown away by the quality of this place, and can't wait to go back next trip to Chicago.

I was fortunate enough to attend a 13 course tasting dinner at GIrl & the Goat and I already put my name in for a reservation! Everything was truly of the highest caliber and I could not believe the creative depth of each concoction. I truly cannot remember all 13 of the dishes but there were a few standouts that are extremely memorable. Do. Not. Miss...the broccoli. I know you may hate broccoli, but I guarantee you that even the staunchest of veggie haters will enjoy the broccoli here at Girl & the Goat. It is smoked with pine nuts, blue cheese and I don't even know what else. I could have eaten the entire plate that was brought to our group of 20! Other standout dishes were the shishito peppers-perfectly spicy in some kind of amazing cheese, the roasted cauliflower (yes, I really like my veggies!) and the green beans. For our non-herbivore friends, you must get the goat empanadas, they are so yummy and very unique in their flavor. I know Girl & the Goat is famous for their pig face but you should also check out their butter pork shank; it's really like eating caramelized pig off of a candied bone. I am not the biggest pork fan but that stuff is amazing. The fried oysters were also some of my favorites, with their contrasting textures of crunchy/chewy/buttery-all deep fried and popping with flavor.
All in all, I cannot wait to go back to Girl & the Goat and try everything else on the menu. I can see why this restaurant has the stellar reputation it has, they know what they are doing, and then some!

A place that is famous, always busy, makes a ton of cash, and is generous enough to squeeze you in at 4:30 when it requires reservations? Yes, yes, yes! That is awesome and I love it! They let us sit at a big table with other guest and told us we needed to be done by 6pm, easy enough for me.

So they do the shared plate concept here, so it is best to get a few dishes to try. The menu is very unique so I would encourage others to enjoy the creations they offer you.

-Beet Salad was very good, had a nice dressing and delicious avocado with it. One of the best salads I've had.

-The ham frites were a standard raiser when it comes to fries/frites. Please if you love fries, order this for me and thank me later? They come with two sauces. I could kiss these fries and not feel ashamed.

-If you see pig face on the menu it's safe to say you will most likely strike up a conversation with your table and server. Of course we had to try, it's served in patty form, fried potato sticks, with a fried egg, and served with a little sauce. You mix it up and eat it, trust me it is good.
