-Finally the pig shank, very tender and then fried right before serving. Very good flavor and crunch too it, had two sauces that come with it as well. Really impressed with all of their dishes, I was so full after eating this one.

Excellent service from all of the staff members, I had such a wonderful experience here. Can't wait to go back and try some more!

Every element of Girl and the Goat is 5 star-- service, food , atmosphere, knowledgeable staff, it's simply amazing. Corn bread with cherry garnish was divine! Duck tongue, Hamachi, Soft shell crab with coconut rice, and pork shank... All perfection! Go there, you will enjoy it!

pics.caption: Enjoying the corn bread the next day!

review.des:
A man's angle:

Great if you are a sophisticated,  martini drinking, uber riding, peacock wearing urbanite. If you are of a utilitarian mindset, however,  I'd recommend you walk a block over to green street smoked meats.

I went here for my woman's birthday. There was a 3 hour wait. The food was served in many small servings and we were to share each plate. This is apparently common somewhere over yonder in Europe. Unfortunately, I'm American. Each plate was a tease! The food tasted very good and was of wonderful quality but it just gave me blueballs of the stomach!

I did manage to get full. However I certainly took the scenic route to get there. This place is only recommended if you are in the dog house or a fancy sort of person.

One of the best meals I have had anywhere.  Unique, full tastes.  I never thought that I would say that a vegetable (the green beans) are brilliant.

Wine list is good, but pricey.  Skip the house red - It's a an odd mixture.  .

Second year in a row went there for my birthday. Again, delicious meal and drinks. Did not regret any of the dishes we tried. There were some new dishes on the menu (yum shishito peppers!), finally tried the goat empanadas (great!). Pork shank as good if not better than we remembered it! Unless you have dietary/religious restrictions, everyone should try it.
Great burgers, great duck liver hash. Great beer selection. Not a fan of the long wait and the pretentious servers.

Meat gluttons, you have met your match. A menu that will make your mouth water.

While the term "pig face" can make some people squirm, it is a delicious, savory dish that won't disappoint.

The service and wine pairing were spot on.

So lucky to have snagged a reservation here! (Or actually, my bf did for mu birthday). In case you are wondering, they dont do anything special for birthdays, but they will add a candle to whatever dessert you order.

The waitress recommend we order 2-3 items per person for a full meal, since everything is tapas style. However, id disagree. The two of us would have been plenty full for about 3 dishes between the two of us.

We ordered the green bean casserole bread to start, delicious! There was cheese and mushroom baked in, with great sour cream and green bean tapenade sides. The two of us ate the entire loaf, uh oh.

Then we got the goat liver mousse with crumpets. They are generous with the crumpets. Everything was delicious, but there was serious carb overload by this point. We only ate one crumpet each and saved the rest to take home.

Highly recommended to us by friends were the chickpea fritters. I wasn't a fan. This was probably my least favorite.dish. it pretty much tasted like fried mashed potatoes.

The pig face is a must order. It was my favorite of the night. So delicious with just the right fat to meat ratio. The egg and potato hash went really well together with the meat.

By this point, we were stuffed.. but had still ordered a pork shank. It was huge. It was OK, but can't compare to the pig face at all. The portion for this was huge!!

To top it off, we ordered the caramel budino. Yum yum, highly recommend!

I suggest coming with a larger group so you can try more.items. everything is delicious!!!

Love the atmosphere, and the food was incredible. I could eat the Calamari Bruchetta for every meal for the rest of my life. We went with a large group ~10 people, and ordered nearly everything on the menu. It ended up being very expensive, since we got 2 of most of the things we ordered. It was nice to be able to try so many items but definitely busted my dining-out budget. It was worth it though since there wasn't a single dish that I didn't like out of all the ones I tried!

When you have a meal at a Top Chef winner, you know that you are going to go in with a series of expectations. 1) It is going to be an awesome meal, 2) It is going to be an awesome meal, and 3) It had better be an awesome meal or else I might cry. Well, when a friend I was visiting suggested we go to "Girl & the Goat" I immediately thought, you couldn't get a table at Next or Alinea?

Well...the thought immediately escaped me because I am a huge fan of Stephanie Izard and needless to say, it is hard to get a table at Girl & the Goat as well.

We started with the raw Kushi oysters with a muscatel mignotte and shaved horseradish. While it might not sound the like the best combination or one that makes sense, it works. It work's really well. The briny flavor of the oysters was brought to life and complemented by the sweetness of the mignotte wine and the shaved horseradish brought a nice heat that toned down the briny flavor you would come to expect. Needless to say, the oyster was beautifully cleaned and shucked. I would eat this over and over again.

The beet salad with the avocado creme fraiche and green beans was a nice break to the meal and the earthiness of of the beets were brought to balance with the creaminess of the avocado and toasted bread crumbs brought cohesiveness to the texture.

Sweetbreads, calamari, and lamb can all scare a diner on its own. Yet, feelings of intrigue caught our eye because ask yourself, where else would you find a combination like this? It was good....it was really good. I won't even bother trying to describe it, just get it.

The Pigs Face was another stellar dish and while the sunny side egg might come across as unrefined, it was rustic. It was flavorful and not one to pass up on. The crispy pork flavor and the saltiness of the egg were brought together with the sweet tamarind and the bite of cilantro.

Cocktails were beautifully done and craft styled. The wine list is nothing to sneer at to, however I'd probably pass on it and stick to the good stuff!

Service was stellar. From the time we arrived to the moment we left, we felt welcomed. Our server clearly knew the menu and took the time to understand what we were looking for and provided honest feedback which in turn enhanced our dining experience. Water glasses never went empty and plates were carefully cleared away. It showed not just a considerate server, but an attentive support staff.

The ambiance was gorgeous and comfortable. The beautiful details and the use of light and natural pieces really made you feel as if you were at the chef's home. The noise level is a little loud, but the feeling bodes well to a celebratory dinner with friends or a romantic moment with that special date.

I'm not going to lie and say it was the best meal I ever had, but it is damn up there and you can bet that the next time I am in Chicago, I will be heading to the phone and making a reservation. You'll find me there.

I'm going to keep this short.
Tapas style dishes and everything is good. Everything. You want to go to here.

I've been hesitating on writing a review for this restaurant because I had so much to say!

Overall, the restaurant was phenomenal and exceeded any expectations I had. All the dishes were crafted with such casual mastery--the simplest menu items when combined became exquisite and well-balanced dishes. I was amazed at the thoughtfulness of each dish.  

Dish descriptions:

Roasted Beets with green beans, white anchovy, crème fraiche, and bread crumbs. This dish was light and refreshing. I love beets so I was happy, but the bread crumbs added a slightly weird texture.

Chickpea Fritter. I am not really sure what was in this dish but it had an Indian food taste to it. Our two Indian food companions were impressed and overjoyed. Mmm... so savory.

Trout Tartare with marinated clams and remoulade. This dish went quick. I have never had trout tartare so this was quite a treat--fresh, vibrant, with a hint of tartness.

Grilled Baby Octopus with guanciale (Italian cured meat--Googled that one), pistachio, beans, and lemon vinaigrette. When our dinner companion, who has a quieter demeanor usually, took a bite, he slammed both of his fists to the table, and screamed "This is so good!" For me, this dish represented the genius of the menu. This hodgepodge of ingredients came together and did a lively square dance in my mouth. I can't even begin to describe the magnificence of this dish--every bite was a little different and never ceased to impress me.

Confit Goat Belly with lobster and crab, goat butter, and fennel. We wanted to be a bit adventurous and also to partake in the namesake of the restaurant so we tried the goat belly dish. This was a nice rich dish with the butter and belly, but was not too memorable for me.

Wood-Fired Walter's Chicken. I have no idea what was in this dish, but it was spectacular. I usually don't like to order chicken at restaurants but this dish was out of this world. The chicken was tender, moist, and rich with comforting flavors.

Pig Face. Mmm... with a name like that, how could you not order it? This was a fun and playful dish that brought tons of meaty goodness and gooey egginess.

From now on, I feel like no visit to Chicago is complete without The Girl and the Goat.

I can say one thing for all who dares to go here: Come here expecting you will have to wait 1-3 hours before you get seat in the restaurant or even the bar!

Overall, my friend thought the food was A-OK, nothing special. But I will say in my opinion its place to take to impress all your out-town friends, which I did.

Also if you don't eat pork, then more than likely the rest of food, will not impress you as it did not for my non-pork eating friend.

The goat dish we got was good, which was called: Confit Goat Belly. Interesting flavors of bourbon and caramel, a bit weird at first, but I liked it!

Overall, their breads are legit, and so their wine list. Friendly service, but the wait was tooo long, unless you made reservations 6 months ago!

Now, I was lucky enough to come twice to this elusive hotspot without any struggles: once, for a work team dinner and the second, on a whim, after my roommates colleague couldn't make her reservation. Normally, the waitlist is three months long, which sounds painful and risky to me.

When I went for my work dinner, at 9 pm, they didn't seat us until 9:30 because they were still wrapping up with another party, which was fine because we just had drinks at the bar. For the food, we ordered around two of around 17 dishes (one version had to be nondairy for a coworker) and everyone had a couple bites of each dish.

Amazing and I can see why people rave about this Chicago must! Top standouts go to the fried egg topped pig face, of course, crispy duck tongue, the buttery goat belly lobster n crab, and pb&j. When I went with my roommate, it was hard to just order a couple of dishes, but hands down, my favorite dish was the NY strip tartare! The mushroom elevated the pants off this dish.

Obviously, Girl and the Goat is a meal you can only treat yourself to once in a while, but I recommend going in a larger group and eating family style.

I hope to return again!

pics.caption: These sea scallops will melt in your mouth and they're perfectly paired with mushrooms and this asian sauce, yummmO!
The duck breast with sea glass noodle, wow! Loved the thai crispies
The plantain cake dessert: everything you could wish for - decadent cake, ice cream and a crunchy topping!

review.des: Seriously amazing. Our favorite restaurant hands down. We show up just as they open and grab a seat at the bar to order off the full menu without the hassle of a reservation!

Interesting presentation of food, served up family style. Innovative preparation - fusion cooking infused with Asian spices. Being Asian, it leaves my palate sort of confused - which might not be a bad!

Having said that, this is definitely a place to experience at least once in Chicago.

After reading all the reviews I was very excited to try this place!

Reservations: Tried unsuccessfully to make a week day dinner reservation about a week in advance. The hostess kindly suggested stopping in early in the week and try for a walk in table which we did. We arrived about 5:45pm on a Tuesday and were offered immediate outdoor seating. We opted to wait for inside seating and after about 20 minutes we were able to snag seats at the bar.

Seating: Reserved seating is obviously the best, but there is also a good amount of first come, first served seating at the bar and you can also order food in the lounge area by the entrance. There are two additional pairs of bar style seating in the back at either end of the kitchen (I believe also first come, first served) that provide a great view of the chefs at work and a bit more privacy than the seats at the main bar. If I came without reservations again I'd go for these kitchen view seats!

Food:

Johnny Applecheese bread with chili-cheddar butter and malted oil: Our bread came out fresh and piping hot! My friend and I really liked the chili-cheddar butter, malted oil was whatevs. Recommended.

Wood oven roasted pig face with sunny side egg: A mix of crispy and soft textures, rich and flavorful. Sunny side egg is great on anything! Smaller portion. Would recommend this slightly above the pork shank for flavor and uniqueness.

Crisp braised pork shank with buttermilk dressing, butternut shiitake and naan bread: You get a lot of tender meat with this dish which literally falls right off the bone! Buttermilk dressing was a little bit like a raunch sauce (good). Naan bread was just perfect, warm and crispy with a soft inside. You'll definitely want to share this with 2-3 people. Recommended.

Roasted cauliflower: This was maybe the most surprising dish of the evening. The cauliflower was very well seasoned and had a nice peppery flavor. Very hearty and a surprisingly large portion, would also suggest sharing this with 2-3 people. Recommended.

Our service at the bar was good and we didn't have to wait long for each dish to come out. Kitchen staff appears to be working very efficiently!

Overall, glad I tried it but I don't feel the need to eat here again in the very near future.

I love this place. Must go for vegetarians too! Great ambience, really tasty options even for vegetarians, perfect selection of wines and excellent service. It's a hustling and bustling restaurant with hard to get reservation. I would say price range is $30-$50 per person which is totally not bad if you are going out on a nice date :)

Stopped here on a Friday night while in Chicago on a solo trip.  This place was happppppening. There were a lot of people waiting outside and inside. I was able to get a seat right away at the bar, which was exciting. The bartenders weren't the friendliest bunch...at least not on that busy night, but I had a great time regardless. Had the beet salad, the hamachi crudo, an empanada, pig face, pb&j for dessert, Italian grandpa for a cocktail. My favorite dish of the night was the hamachi crudo. The service at the bar was ok, nothing great. What impressed me about this place the most was the atmosphere. Definitely worth a stop.

Best food ever!!! The nachos  The service is wonderful, and if you're lucky, you get to meet Stephanie! My sister and I went there and she gave my sister as a present her book with an autograph! It was great!

I really wanted to like this place so that I can part of the cool crowd. The (bar) service has been very good both times. But the food has way too much salt and way too many things/ingredients going on. We left feeling sick both times, and def not going back.

HUGE THANKS TO JAMES AT THE FRONT!!!

Tried getting a reservation here for 4, but could not be accommodated at our preferred time to attend the Beyonce concert we were in town for. Luckily there is a walk-in section of the bar so we decided to try our luck.

When we arrived, we were told there might be a bit of a wait to get seated. A little deflated, we could only wait as we cabbed it there.

Thankfully, JAMES at the front was able to get us seated within 5 minutes of stepping into the place AND put in a special request to have our dinner rushed so we could make the concert! THANKS JAMES!! YOU ARE BEYOND AWESOME!!

Alejandro was one of the busboys who was very attentive at our table with clearing dishes and especially with refilling water. Each time someone got up, there was also someone who came around and refolded your napkin, which was nice.

This was a tapas style place and we ordered 11 dishes. The food was ok, but the service for us was top notch! From JAMES at the front to Alejandro helping our with our table, the service could not be beat. I would recommend this place as it has decent sized tapas for sharing for 4 and gives you the ability to try tons of things!

This review is long overdue, butttttt after 2 months 3 weeks 5 days 3 hours, thirty minutes and 23 seconds of patiently waiting, I finally made it through the doors of Top Chef winner Stephanie Izard's infamous yet oh so elusive restaurant. What can I say that hasn't already been said in the 4000+ reviews of this establishment? Absolutely nothing! Oh, but make sure you get the oven roasted pig face. I know, I know, everybody and their mama recommends it, but seriously it's...LIFE. CHANGING.

A few other dishes I tried -- Corny goat bread. Fried naked cowboy oysters. Sugo. Pig face. Diver scallops. Kalbi ribs. Goat empanadas. Goat belly confit. Walter's chicken. Baby octopus. Crab rangoon. Green beans. Crisp braised pork shank. Chocolate galangal. Miso butterscotch budino. Goat cheese bavarois. Corn kulfi. Best of three cocktail. Pig face. Pig face. Pig face. Pig face. Pig face. Pig face. Pig face. Pig face. Pig face. Pig face. Pig face. Pig face. Pig face. Pig face. Pig face. Pig face. Pig face. Pig face. Pig face. All nothing short of amazing. Did I mention pig face?

Venture outside of your culinary comfort zone and be sure to ask your server for suggestions. They really know what they're talking about!

Oh, and don't forget -- order the pig face! That is all. *drops the mic*

The best part about this review is that I was sitting with a minority owner when I dined there last.  He's super down-to-earth and would never say "hey, I'm somebody..." so when the waitress got sh!tty about us 'camping' at the table I just had to laugh at myself.  I know you need to make a buck, but you don't need to be a Bizzy 'bout it.  He made your job possible and waiting tables made college possible for me.  My kindly capitalistic FU was to hand her $20 and explain that "I'm renting this space" so I could end the constant passive aggressive behavior trying to usher us out.

You catch more flies with honey people...

Went into this meal with a great deal of anticipation and hype. I'm a big Top Chef fan, and all my Chicago friends had rave reviews for the Girl and the Goat. I will say all my expectations were met, and then some. We came on a 4:30 reservation, which we had made 2.5 months in advance. Yeesh. But was it worth the trouble? Yes, it was.

Our party of 4 decided to try a number of different dishes:
- Summer Tom Bread: Right amount of chew and density, and the tomato oil was delicious
- Blue Point Oysters: Came with bacon and horseradish, just the right consistency
- Squash Blossom Rangoons: Stuffed with crab, and had a great crispy and creamy texture, without being too greasy
- Shishito Peppers: Spicy, but the parmesan had a nice cooling effect.
- Roasted Cauliflower: I thought the mint would be too over-powering, but the pickled peppers had a really good acidic balance and thought the the pine nuts added a good amount of texture
- Goat Empanadas: Goat was just the right texture and not too dry. The slaw it came with was great and provided a creamy texture that was just right
- Pan Roasted Halibut: One of my favorite dishes of the meal. The almond butter, soy, and mushrooms had a very unique flavor and texture that I had never tasted before.
- Confit Goat Belly: Delicious, and slightly leaner than pork belly.
- Wood Roasted Pig Face: My favorite dish. Pork cheeks were amazing, the potato sticks created a crispy texture, and the egg on top just made everything better.

Dessert:
- Miso Butterscotch Budino: I'm a big chocolate aficionado, but this was great. The creaminess and candied cashews were just unreal.
- Bittersweet Chocolate Brownie with Basil Ice Cream: One of the more unique desserts I've ever had. The basil wasn't too overpowering and went well with the bittersweet chocolate.

Service was great with recommendations, and the waiters were like ninjas with the water. While the large painting on the wall was a bit harrowing, the decor, overall, was very simple and I always really like the open kitchen concept.

Overall, I would definitely recommend this if you can get a reservation, which doesn't really need to be said with all the reviews on here, but just putting that out there. I will definitely be back next time I'm in Chicago, if I remember to plan ahead.

pics.caption: bittersweet chocolate brownie with basil gelato, and blackberries

review.des: Too heavy and too salty. Fine to experience once, but the Little Goat is better quality for 1/4 of the price.

Different. Amazing. Flavors that you can't believe come out of dishes.  The place has an old smoke house gone to the quirky side with a Tim Burton flare.  The grilled baby octopus, sauteed green beans and smoke goat pizza all a must.  Our waitress was like having a chef wait on us, she was impressively knowledgeable for a group of foodies.  This is a must when in Chicago!

Finally had the chance to go to Chicago and I had to come here! Food, service, ambiance was amazing! We started off with the ham bread and the goat liver mousse, the ham bread could have used more ham in it but it was good. the goat liver mousse was amazing! If you like liver/pate you have to try it! Next we got the green garlic perogies and the grilled baby octopus :) who doesn't love potato dumplings! The grilled baby octopus was by far one of my favorite dishes! Main dishes we got the roasted pig face and the crispy pork shank! Both were fantastic! I am so glad I could finally come here and try Stephanie Izard's food!

Bill was over 300 bucks for dinner for 2--with a bottle of wine. Was it worth the money? God no. Was it delicious heck YES. We tried a bit of everything. Even the bread was divine. All of the food was jam packed with flavor you really enjoy the experience and savor it all. Gave my tastebuds orgasms.

I brought some guests from SF here for dinner. So it was the first time for 3 people in my group and the third time here for me. The evening started a little dicey. We arrived on time for our reservation, however, we had to stand and wait for about 30 minutes until we were seated. No explanation, no offer to have a seat at the bar/lounge area because it may be a while and no suggestion to perhaps order a drink while we wait. Luckily, the food made up for the bad first impression. I started off with the ring of fire cocktail, which I enjoyed, but I didn't really think it was spicy at all. On to the dishes. We ordered the johnny apple cheese bread, pan fried shishito peppers, hamachi crudo, escargot ravioli, blackened catfish, crispy beef short ribs, crisp braised pork shank, confit goat belly and caramel corn & malt balls. This was the perfect amount of food for 4 people. We definitely were stuffed to the brim at the end of dinner, but didn't waste much. The johnny apple cheese bread was good, however, they don't provide enough bread to use up all the spread. The shishito peppers were nothing special. Hamachi crudo was really good and had nice contrasting textures.  The ravioli, catfish and short ribs were all good, but not amazing. The crisp braised pork shank was a very large portion and was very tender. I don't actually like goat, but the confit goat belly was very good, too. And how could you go wrong with any dessert with caramel corn?! I've always enjoyed Izard's use of different textures in her dishes and her use of acidity and tartness to cut through the heaviness of some meats. My whole party was impressed by the meal and some even proclaimed this to be the best dinner they have had in Chicago. Definitely worth the visit.

The wood oven pig face and pork shank get all the love, but the real out-of-this world dish is the sauteed green beans with cashews and fish sauce. It will blow you away guaranteed. It's amazing how something that simple can be that great.

Really great ambiance and a lot of drink choices here. My only tip would be to make reservations well in advance, as it fills up quickly.

pics.caption: Braised pork shank, buttermilk dressing, grilled spring onion kimchee, and buttered naan. At this point, my mind exploded.

review.des:
It was ok, but I wasn't blown away. I had read rave reviews about this place and we were planning a trip to Chicago so I made a reservation. The trip was 3-4 weeks away and there was only 1 time available (10:30pm) so we went for it.

We arrived 20 min early and were seated right away. The restaurant had great atmosphere, it felt warm and inviting. My boyfriend and I love cocktails and theirs did not disappoint. Food on the other hand was just ok. I had run the marathon and I was starving so we ordered 5-6 plates to share. I honestly can't remember a dish that stood out or that I'd want again. I do remember reading amazing reviews on the pig face and both my boyfriend and I did not really care for it. It was heavy and greasy, I don't think we even finished it.

I can't say I'd never go back, but there are so many great spots in Chicago that I'd rather try first.

Can't believe it's STILL this hard to get a reservation here - it's definitely holding onto it's hip reputation.  Went with a group and we got a bunch of plates to share - they ended up bring pretty hefty portion sizes so I was annoyed that they told us we had to order everything up front... we never would have ordered so many "small plates" if we knew their true size - since we couldn't take leftovers home we ended up wasting a bunch of food.  I understand it's easier on the staff if we order everything ahead of time but I felt we were somewhat misled and ended up with a bigger bill and wasting almost half of those last few dishes.  Service was very good and attentive otherwise.  

The run down on what we ordered:  The kohlrabi salad has olives in it!  Beware!!!!  I'm not subtracting any points for this because not everybody hates these foul morsels as much as I do.  The escargot ravioli was very earthy and well-prepared.  Cauliflower was savory but excessively and unnecessarily oiled. The shishito peppers were ok but also really oily I'm not a fan of pools of oil at the bottom of my dishes.  Don't get me wrong I eat cream and butter and high fat content but I don't think it's appetizing when the oil is gathered there at the bottom of the bowl.  If that's where it collects - why not use less?  Scallops were bomb tho as was the fish.  Not a terrible meal but a lil over hyped I guess, which is why I went with "A-OK" for my review.

So we decided to go here after seeing Bourdain go on his layover to chicago. We sat at the bar and the bartenders were helpful in helping us decide on our drinks for the evening. As far as food, we had a feast. The oysters were good, small, fresh, and tasty. The grilled baby octopus was amazing - just enough salt that wasnt overwhelming, perfectly cooked. The wood oven roasted pig face was unbelievable. The pork shank just added to the our theme of pig for the night. The sticky squash cake was our dessert. No words to describe this other than you must order it for dessert. Probably the best restaurant ive been to in chicago

pics.caption: The pork shank. A lot to eat but i would say its a must
The pig face that won the chef the top chef. Amazing dish

review.des: OMG??!?!?!?! Ill finished this is the Morning but this place is efn awesome! My favorite Emma days favorite was the green beans for Copart show was awesome. I'll finish it tomorrow but I tell you right now it's fucking awesome

This is one of those restaurants that you hear about over and over and are super, super amped to try when you get a reservation. I studied the menu, read the Yelp reviews and listened to locals to decide what to order.

- Sauteed green beans - green beans are cooked perfectly, but the sauce is a bit too creamy and rich for my taste
- Chickpea fritters - most disappointed by this dish given all the rave reviews I'd heard. A bit dry.
- Hamachi crudo - tasty, but nothing out-of-this-world special
- Grilled baby octopus - super, super good. Loved the lemon-y flavor
- Braised beef tongue - tasty, but could have used more actual beef tongue
- Crisp braised pork shank - by far the best thing we ate all night. The portion is quite large and it is cooked to perfection. I didn't love one of the sauces so appreciated that it came on the side
- Goat - truffle? Can't recall what was in this but it came last and was unbelievably rich - too much so, in fact. Unfortunately was unable to enjoy it.

The Girl and the Goat is a super trendy, fun restaurant with great service and a fun ambiance. The food is definitely above average, but I'm not sure it's worth the hype. That said, I would still suggest going if you are thinking about it so you can decide for yourself.

Amazing restaurant and amazing food! Girl and the goat is a must when in Chicago! Ambience is great, pretty loud, so not very intimate. Definitely a nice casual spot to eat and hang out with friends. We had the calamari bruschetta, confit goat belly, and the wood oven roasted pig face. The dishes are pretty small and are meant to be shared, 3-5 dishes for 2 people is normal. All three were phenomenal, but for me, the pig face was nothing like I've ever had. Crispy slices of pig face, with sunny side up egg, potato stix, and red win-maple, that are meant to be mixed together, wow! The bruschetta, with the clam baguette, goat milk ricotta, and goat bacon was delicious! The goat belly with lobster and crab, sitting in a pool of bourbon butter, though probably not healthy, was amazing! Lol. All three were full of flavor and unique in their own ways. If in Chicago again, this will definitely be my first stop!

This place is like an american tapas restaurant to me. The dishes were small portion, so we follow the server's advice to order a little bit of many things.
We ordered sourdough bread, oysters, baby grilled octopus, pig face, and one more but forgot the name of it. I guess that dish was the least impressive one.

Every menu I've tried was so-so.  Pig face could have been better if it weren't too greasy.  I wanted to wash my palate off with the cocktail that I ordered, but that made it worse.

The grilled baby octopus was too burnt. We both couldn't eat more than a bite. The server noticed that we weren't happy with that dish right away and tried to fix it for us, but we didn't want to order anymore.

I am giving 2 stars, because of their top notch service! I never had to ask my water glass to be filled, the server was very knowledgeble about their menu and so on. Also, they deducted the burnt octopus off of the check even without us asking for it.

However, overall it was a very dissapointing visit for me. I was very excited to try this place, but would not go back again.

One of my favorite meals in Chicago. The wait was unbelievably long, I came by myself but had to wait around 45 min to get a seat at the bar. However, the service was great. Several dishes on the menu were able to be halved, so I ended up trying 5(!) plates: the goat empanadas, broccoli, escargot ravioli, bucatini with pork shoulder, and malt balls dessert. Everything was incredible, and I ended up having snack for the next day. My whole bill for five half-plates was about $40 (excluding tip), which is way less than I would have expected for a meal of that quality.
This place was worth the wait and lived up to the hype.  Wow.

Lives up to the hype.  There are a ton of things on the menu and we ordered 9.  I can't name all 9 but there are some dishes that are worth remembering.  Scallops, pig face, goat poutine, beef tongue over fried chip and the quail.

Do make sure to try and get reservations because this place gets packed.

Girl & the Goat hardly needs my recommendation, but gosh the food here is incredible. I ate there last night with a rather large group (six people) and we had a phenomenal experience. The goat necks were a particular revelation. Additionally, the service was phenomenal. Once my wallet recovers I'll definitely be back. Menu prices may be steep, but the food was worth every cent.

First of all, kudos to the chef! I grew up eating goat and there were times when it was not a pleasant experience. Goat empanadas anyone? I recommend trying that.

My fiance liked the green beans while I liked the miso hungry bread. It was too loud though, maybe because it was a Friday night. And our tables were too close to the the couples on either side, you can hear their conversation so clearly; it can be distracting at times.

I would still recommend this place. Just remember to reserve a month in advance.

During my most recent business trip to Chicago, I managed to meet with two friends who'd never been to Girl & the Goat. I was excited to share G & the G with them as I had a memorable meal last year. Turns out, this would be my best meal over the weekend, even after dining at Alinea during the same trip.

This time, we weren't so lucky just walking in and getting a table. We got there around 7:30 pm and were told a table wouldn't be available until 10:30 and we'd be better off trying to find a spot in the bar & lounge area. We waited 30-45 minutes before two finally left, and the three of us nabbed their spot. I ended up not having space at the table and had to eat off my lap... Nevertheless, the food was amazing.

I ordered a glass of Schloss Schönborn 2006 Estate Riesling Kabinett, and we started off with two breads, the Gouda Bacon and Busta Rye (both $4 each), and Ham Frites ($7). I preferred the first bread over the latter, since it was served with smoked fat back butter. However, I still like last year's Peter Piper bread better and was disappointed they didn't have it this time. The ham frites is simply fries served with ham bits and smoked tomato aioli and cheddar beer sauces. Pass on that next time.

For our mains to share, we got my favorite Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face ($16), Crisp Braised Pork Shank ($25), and Hamachi Crudo ($16). The most overrated was definitely the hamachi and I wouldn't order it again; it was good, especially since it was served with pork belly, but it wasn't all that special. The pig face was just as good as I remembered it, if not better; however the winner of the night was probably the pork shank. Wow. Dressed in buttermilk and served with grilled spring onion kimchee and deliciously pillow-y naan, the meat was so tender and fell right off the bones. I'm salivating just thinking about it. Definitely a must-order.

As my motto is "there's always room for dessert", I of course, ordered dessert. Per our server's recommendation, I got the Rhubarb Shortcake, which was also amazing. Not too sweet and the "cinnamon toast crunch" made for a tasty contrast to the horchata tapioca.

Service was satisfactory and pretty good, considering we were sitting in the lounge area. The timing between dishes was perfect for us, since we were sharing our table with others and didn't have much space (which is why I ate off my lap). The most plates we had on our side was probably three at a time, so it was very manageable.

Whether you're a local or visiting from out of town, G & the G is a must-stop.

Michelin: Bib Gourmand (2014)

Truly one of the best meals of my life - impeccable service, lovely ambiance, and the most creative, delicious menu. This is the kind of restaurant that makes it difficult to order because you know everything will surpass your expectations.

Highly recommend the ham bread and goat empanadas!

Girl and the Goat called us a week ago confirming our reservation for last Saturday. We originally planned on going yesterday so we had to cancel our reservation :( (when you make the reservation 3 months in advance sometimes you mix up the day you are going). Sooo we decided hey why not just walk in! After reading other reviews we planned on waiting an hour and a half (which was also the est. wait time) so I looked up other places to grab a drink close by. There are so many!!! We went to RM Champagne Salon (so cute highly recommend!). Went back in an hour and grabbed a drink at the bar there. Not even half way in we were called!

Now onto the food...I rely heavily on my fellow yelpers so I ordered what everyone recommended. Chickpea fritters, pig face, pork shank, ham frites (that's because I love French fries) and ended with the bittersweet brownie basil gelato dessert. EVERYTHING WAS AMAZING. The best was the pork shank (OMG I NEED THIS AGAIN). The dish we could have lived without was the dessert. Maybe next time go across the street to little goat and get dessert. Will be back again!

pics.caption: Ham frites and pig face! Both amazing!

review.des:
OK so where do I start. I came here with very high expectations following a two month long reservation that only was available to make at 4:30 in the afternoon.
When I arrive there was a long line allreadyto enter the restaurant.
As soon as we came in everything was well organized everybody knew what they needed to do and waiters and the hostesses were on Spot. The food was more than what I expected. Incredible. The service was provided by Peter, he knew what to offer and recommended us everything. And boy, everything was awesome. If you are visiting Chicago please do not leave without dining in this restaurant.

Still amazing!

Went back a couple of months ago and was equally impressed if not more than my first time a couple of years ago.

This time around had Friday night reservations. The only available time was for 10:30pm. It worked out. We hung out at a blues bar first and then headed there.

It was crazy busy with no sign of winding down. The decor is outstanding in a hip industrial style. I would say GATG is basically infinitely trending. It's always like it just opened except it has been open for a while now.

We started with the onion bread and ordered the goat cheese tortellini, shrimp ceviche, scallops, octopus, escargot ravioli and pork ribs. Yes, it sounds like a lot but it really is not. Portions are small and meant to be had tapas style.

We had the quatro leches for dessert. Everything was unusual and delicious as usual.

Ms. Izard did not disappoint again.

Make sure you check out the very cool bathrooms downstairs!

Friday, 8:30PM.
Customer rep: Jill.

Looooong wait, opted for communal seating near bar instead.

Quickie:
+Good food
+Amiable service
+Clean
+Stylin' decor
+Hummin' tunes

And then...?
Make reservations. If not, hope for communal seating. Girl & the Goat reppin' Chi!

**********
Stuffed my face in:

1. Goat empanadas
    +Flaky, meat didn't overpower fried goodness
2. Pot stickers
    +Unique, nice flavor profile
3. Scallops
    ++Hot dang this was good - tender and savory in the right way
4. Pork shank
    +Naan was buttery, soft (amazing)
    +Interesting sauces (buttermilk and kimchi puree)
    -Kimchi (lacking some punch)

I've been here twice: once, a friend kindly bought me dinner to celebrate, another was for a date's birthday.

The menus vary -- looking at today's menu I recognize only a few dishes, but a few important memories stand out:

It's a beautiful place. It's warm and inviting, the food and drinks are delicious and comforting and you will leave feeling stuffed and thankful.

Some of the food isn't objectively delicious but you should try it anyway. Two "misses" in my opinion have been very thought-provoking: an amuse bouche of roasted goat, melon, and kimchi, was "interesting" but not "evocative," flavorful, but not "symbiotic;" a deconstructed apple pie with a big globe of blue cheese gelato was simply disgusting--I still took a few bites after coming to that judgement-- but I can't stop talking about how disgusting and strange it was even years after.

Like many places, your food will occasionally be slightly over-cooked or over-salted, and many of the flavors can be heavy-handed. But you'll keep eating, even when you aren't completely convinced what you're eating is delicious, and that's a unique talent for a chef to have.
As if this needs to be rated at all. This place is probably the best food in Chicago. Expensive and worth it. Make sure it's a special occasion.

Yum Yum Yum

I beasted here. I placed a reservation a month in advance, and we still had to resort to a late dinner time...9:30 i think our reservation was for 2?

We beasted on Roasted Oysters, Goat Carpaccio, Crudo, Dumplings, Scallops, Kalbi Ribs, Broccoli, Pig Face, and Budino.

The broccoli was just a bit too much food for us. It was too filling for the lack of protein. Overall, to be honest, I don't remember each of the dishes individually. I just remember they were all yummy and i'll be back again the next time i'm in Chicago.

Stephanie Izard - You ROCK!

My sister and I waited 3 months for a reservation!  Boy, was it miserable waiting outside these past 3 months!  ..Just kidding!

Girl and the Goat is part of that newfangled new wave genre of food called "New American."  What defines New American you ask?  Uhhh well it's "twists" on traditional "American staples," which usually aren't originally American anyways!  They tend to add stuff like esoteric vegetables you've never heard of but are grain staples in 3rd world countries and now we are rendering the crop unaffordable to the locals--I'm looking at you quinoa...  Anyway, I digress.

Seeing as I'm not European, I could not wait until our 10 PM reservation to eat a real meal.  So my sister and I subsisted on appetizers and dessert:

Appetizers

Chickpea Fritter - Through the dim romantic lighting, it looks like deep fried tofu, but it's not.  It's deep fried chickpeas, alongside a lot of crunchy and semi-crunchy things--onions, tomatoes, stonefruit (It's so dim that I'm not sure what that actually was while eating it..), and sheep's feta cheese.  All of it was bathed in garam masala yogurt.   It's okay.

Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face - You surprisingly don't see a pig's face when they present the dish to you.  It appears to be pork, probably from the facial region of a pig, with an egg cooked sunny side up, alongside a smattering of other seasonings..  This stuff is GOOD.  It's very rich.  They added "potato stix," which appears to be an filled potato thing shaped like a thin noodle that adds a lot of crunch to the dish..  The texture of this dish is DELECTABLE.  This dish would be GREAT hungover on a Saturday morning for the yuppie hungover crowd reading this post..

Desserts

Sweet Korn Kulfi - This is their take on peanut butter and jelly.  They have peanut butter ice cream sitting on a wafer-like cookie, with grape jelly surrounding the dish..  This is an interesting dessert, and I would recommend it for novelty's sake, but I felt like they could have added more crunch to this to make it better.

Chocolate Truffle Cake - This is the standard chocolate lover's dessert, with added crunchy texture..  I feel like there's not much to say about a standard chocolate dessert?  It's well done here, but it's not out of this world good or anything.  

Sooo...

The theme of my time here was CRUNCH CRUNCH CRUNCH.  Texture appears to be the new food fad I guess?  I don't know; I'm not rich enough to go to these sorts of places regularly..

If you can wait the 3 months (or jump the line with a friend who has been waiting already and broke up with their girlfriend a week ago and needs someone to fill their spot), everyone should go!

We arrived at the girl and the goat without reservations, but we came just before they opened for their dinner service and was able to get a seat right away.  This place was amazing.  It's sort of like a tapas style restaurant where you can order multiple dishes and share.  If there is one thing you order please order the on seared halibut with blueberry Nuoc Cham sauce and Marcona almonds.  It's to die for

This was my first time at girl & the goat and holy crap it was amazing.  I honestly ate so much and so well that I was full till the next afternoon. Every course we has was perfect and out waitress was wonderful.

I love the look of the restaurant. It was gorgeous and open but not overly noisy. We were treated so well and never waited for anything. The best moment of service came when a dish we had ordered turned out to have oranges in it. My friend was allergic to oranges. The waitress brought a separate dish on the house for my friend to enjoy.

I cannot stress how amazing this dining experience was. I'm looking forward to going again. Yes, it's pricey, but it's not something you're going to eat every week.

Great food and real cool atmosphere! We came in without reservations and were told it would be over an hour wait. Luckily we found chairs by the bar and ate there. Had the goat empanadas, fries, pork shank, broccoli, and the short rib appetizer. Everything was great, but the pork shank was especially amazing. When I got done with the shank, the bone was so clean you would have never thought meat had ever been attached to it. Really loved this place!

Blah. I really wanted to be astounded and flabbergasted by the creativity and execution of this menu. Maybe we picked the wrong dishes...there were only 2 of us and there are a dizzying number of choices to select from!

We had made a reservation on Open Table about a month out, and then 2 weeks from reservation I called to ask if our time could be moved earlier, and they were able to bump it up an hour. Waited a bit for our table to be cleared, and then we ordered:

Cocktail with Gin, Kumquat, Lavender - 3 stars
Very strong (good) and quite sweet (eeks). Lavender was hardly present.

Olive Bread with Whipped Feta - 5 stars
Bread came out hot, wish it had a couple more olives, but had great flavor and chewy texture. Whipped feta was amazing...cream cheese but better.

Crispy Beef Short Ribs - 5 stars
Started off with the best dish of the night. The meat was extremely tender, and the exterior had a satisfying crunch. Avocado and grapefruit provided silky texture and acidity.

Goat Loin - 3 stars
5 very rare slices of goat loin that were not especially flavorful. Served with an apple slaw which helped it out, and a ton of sauce.

Roasted Cauliflower - 3 stars
Tasty but nothing mind-blowing...it's roasted cauliflower with pine nuts and supposedly mint (did we get any?). You can make this at home easily.

Grilled Baby Octopus - 1 star
So incredibly salty, there was no nuance of flavor, just a sodium-fueled assault on your taste buds. Also, where was the octopus? It was tossed in with green beans and guanciale to the point that it was unrecognizable :-/

With tip, the final amount was a bit over $60 per person (for 2).

Ambiance was excellent, the interior design is fantastic and the service was good. I will give it another try because I really want to join the chorus on this one, but first impression was just average.
GATG has a great decor & some interesting small plates. My experience was average in customer service and food. The bacon-slated frites were very flavorful.
Overrated and our server was super pretentious. He basically ushered us out of the restaurant. Dont get the peppers unless you want your mouth to be on fire the rest of the meal.

We just took our chances and showed up without a reservation early on a weekday evening. After a delicious cocktail at the bar we were shown to a table...if we promised to be done in an hour and a half ;) no problem!

We ordered an assortment of small plates, about three a piece. Our friendly server coursed them out for us in the most enjoyable order!

The roasted cauliflower with pinenuts was memorable. As was the pork face...but every dish was fab.

A must eat in Chicago!

Don't buy into the hype.

Considering the long wait times to get a table here, I expected more.
Staff were wearing sweatpants and T-shirt uniform.
Meal was good but didn't blow my mind.
I really wanted to like it but nothing made me want to come back, really disappointing.

Another example of the Chicago food scene were hype outweighs substance.
Food was great more like tapas size so be prepared to get several dishes. Service is good, place gets busy, I would recommend calling ahead and getting reservations.

I heard this place gets crazy packed so I did what any crazy person would do....show up exactly at opening hours which was 4:30.  Okay, I also finished exploring everything on my schedule and had nothing else to do =/

I guess nobody eats this early because it was somewhat empty.  Anyway, I sat at the bar because that's what I've been doing during my trip here in Chicago.  

Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face- So tender and flavorful.  
Goat Belly- Delicious

Service was just as good as the food.

WOW! Absolutely amazing restaurant. We came in on a Friday afternoon at 5 and had no reservations but got seated right away with the sole condition that we give up our table after one and a half hour (seemed fair!). The restaurant has a nice hip ambiance with high wood framing, exposed dramatic ducting, big faux-stone accent walls and intimate lighting. Our waiter was great. We ordered the following:

Tapas:

The scallop: 5/5. Best scallop I've had. Particularly loved the juxtaposition of the tenderness of the scallop with the crunchy walnuts and charbroiled Brussels sprouts.

Goat empanadas: 4/5 warm and comforting. Perfect hint of gamey meat. Could use a kick of some kind.

Broccoli: 4/5. I love the smoked blue cheese complimenting the broccoli. It gives it mass. However while the stem of the broccoli was crunchy, the rest was rather soggy. Would have been a 5 otherwise.

The chicken: 5/5. WOW! It takes some serious skills to get a chicken to be that flavored and juicy. This bird was cooked with love....and I'm in love with it!

Goat belly: 3/5. The goat and lobster combination was daring. However, I felt like there was some cheating in this dish. A lot of the flavor relied on the fat grease taste. It was a little heavy for me.

Cocktails:

Best of Three: 3/5 Easy drink to start with. Nice, smooth and citrusy. Goes down fast.

The Innovator: 5/5 Nice and meaty. Definitely has character. Good Jim beam kick in the beginning with a soothing pear citrusy finish.

Beauty in the Dark: 5/5 Fun and slightly bubbly. Carries you on a high note throughout. Good to get your taste buds energized for the meal.

Rebirth of Honest: 4/5 Perfect drink to end the meal with. Nice balance between the bitters and the creme de cacao. Quite overpowering though. A dessert by itself. Wouldn't go well with another dessert dish.

Desert:

Doughnut holes: 5/5. I know doughnut holes are inherently delicious but, wow..... These are spectacular.

Chef Izard has great attention to detail. Her menu is excellent, filled with little exciting surprises. I would encourage her to introduce a couple more of the non-pork dishes. Come to LA please!!!!
They boiled the broccoli to a pulp and served thick factory farm chicken.  Perhaps avoid Saturday night?
I couldn't wait to come here for dinner. It was superb! Every dish was incredible. The Asian pancakes dish was sublime. And the friendly staff was on point. Seriously a fantastic experience.

I lived in Chicago last summer and this place was high on my list. On a Wednesday night my husband and I wanted a late dinner so we wandered over and were lucky enough to get a table. We had the chickpea fritters, escargot ravioli, and the pork shank. The pork shank was the obvious stand out of the meal. It's tender, HUGE, and comes with a ranch and a buffalo sauce, kind of like an XXL chicken wing (but so much better).

We recently went back and grabbed a seat in the bar area for drinks and snacks. We had the shishito peppers and ham frites. The frites were good, but pretty classic french fries. I only wish the beer sauce they came with resembled more of a beer cheese, but really it tasted like a lightly flavored aioli. Honestly the roasted tomato aioli that came with it was better. The shishitos, while very good, range in spice, so it's a bit of a Russian Roulette. I'm not one for a lot of spice so once I almost lost my tongue on one pepper, I called it quits, but my husband was happy to finish them off. They have a nice selection of wines and some really interesting cocktails--I was particularly impressed by a bubbly from New Mexico (I didn't even know they made wine). Really I can't imagine anyone doesn't want to come here, so you're probably reading Yelp to solidify your desire, to which I say, do it. It's worth trying at least once and you're sure to experience new flavors and maybe even find a new favorite dish.

This restaurant is superb. As of right now, I am the fullest I've ever been after a meal and it's because that even after my stomach was like, "No, stop eating, I am full!" my mouth was still like, "GOTTA HAVE EVERYTHING." All of the food was sinfully good. On top of that, great service that was attentive throughout the meal even though the restaurant was quite big and had many diners in it.

My boyfriend and I came here mostly knowing what we wanted to try (because I had stalked Yelp endlessly after finally snagging a last minute reservation a few weeks back). We decided on Italian sausage bread with fennel butter and pickled spread (sad that the Applecheese bread was not there), green beans, the broccoli, the trout with clams and goat liver mousse, and of course, the pig face.

The bread: filled with delicious pieces of sausage, but I was not as into the butter and pickled spread as I thought I would be. However, the bread itself was so good that in the end I was glad that the butter was so mild because it allowed me to taste the meaty flavor of the bread. My boyfriend, who is really into bread, really enjoyed it as well.

Broccoli: SO, SO GOOD. The dish looked deceptively simple but we actually finished the whole plate! There is also a lot of broccoli, by the way. We kept trying to figure out how they made it so deliciously smoky, but we couldn't! The slight tanginess from the blue cheese and the rice krispies added flavor and texture depth. Delicious.

Trout: another winner! The fish was cooked PERFECTLY with crispy skin on one side. It fell apart when poked with a fork, and we mixed it with the mousse and clams and it was so creamy, yet not overpoweringly rich. Still super decadent though. I was so surprised at how well it meshed with the slight flavor of goat! Another great dish with flavor and texture depth.

Green beans: simple veggie dish, BUT SO DELICIOUS. I think I was surprised at how tangy the sauce was - you can definitely taste the fish sauce! The beans were also snappy, fresh and juicy so they were a delight to eat. Not sure why the cashews were included though - felt a bit out of place.

Pig face: favorite dish from the night! So rich and delicious - we polished it off in 10 minutes even though it was the last dish to arrive at the table. Ridiculously, sinfully good. ORDER IT.

Overall, amazing experience! The restaurant has such a cool vibe (romantic... but also loud???), definitely a must-visit for any Chicago foodie. I'd come back in a heartbeat... well, after I digest this meal first.

pics.caption: pig face aka the most delicious thing you will ever consume

review.des: we've wanted to eat here for years and we were not disappointed. The family style ordering allowing everyone to taste a number of items is great because everything they put on that table you will want to try. I'd highlight specific dishes but honestly, everything was outstanding! The green beans with fermented tofu sauce were a definite epiphany for me wow! who lnew veggies could be so amazing? I won't even go into the squash blossoms. I could eat the chicken everyday and not get tired of how delicious it was. If you live in Chicago, go here. If you don't, travel to Chicago and go here. It's that good.

This place was my favorite stop in Chicago. We came a little before they opened at 4:30pm on a Wednesday and they were able to squeeze us in before a reservation (reservations were book until November so I suggest booking ahead of time or making the time to come before opening). We had to be done by 6pm which I didn't mind because let's be real, I would be more upset if I couldn't eat here.

We shared a long table with three other two-persons groups which turned out to be really fun.  My girlfriend and I were embarrassed to take photos of our food because we were sitting in front of two businessmen and didn't want to seem so basic but then one of them pulled out his phone and took a photo later. hahah Oh well, the lighting was pretty dark in there, it wouldn't have done any justice to our amazing dinner.

We ordered the goat belly (a bit heavy, and there was some sweetness to it?), pig face (order this if you don't plan on ordering anything else I list - this is the best thing we ordered and omg, TRUST ME YOU WILL THANK ME AND EVERYONE ELSE ON YELP WHO SUGGESTED THIS), chickpea fritters (quite amazing and a great appetizer to start off your meal!), escargot dumplings (pass for me, I like my escargot buttery and drenched in pesto lol), and finished with the chocolate truffle cake that came with some peanut butter marsh and toffee bits (I checked their menu online and the name and description don't match, but this is amazing).  We also shared some food with the businessmen across so I was able to try the roasted cauliflower (loved!) and grilled baby octopus (nothing out of this world).

I paired all the food with their very own blend, petit verdot blend, which I quite enjoyed because it wasn't too dry and had a slightly sweet taste to it.

The fact that we didn't wait long, we had great table mates (Thanks Joe and Mike if you ever read this - you guys were awesome!), waiter recommended the best selection (which in Chicago, not that many people did this..... a lot of the times people just said, "well, you're the one eating it." OK COOL. THNX) made this place such an A+ for me.  Ugh, definitely wish I had more time and stomach to try everything else!

The Girl and the Goat remains one of the top restaurant experiences in Chicago. Stephanie Izard's innovative menu and style is a fresh as ever. The restaurant is modern, stylish and fun.
The wait staff is fantastic. Everyone goes out of their way to make you feel at home, advise you about the menu and then deliver the multiple courses in a highly synchronized way appropriate to the food and your preferences.

We had quite the trek coming from the W Chicago City Center. About mid-way through our walk over, it started dumping buckets of rain. Storm of the century!!! Not a cab or Uber could be found so we continued walking. Our clothes and shoes were completely soaked through!

Once we made it in and had some wine and amazing food, we felt a ton better! Every dish completely wowed us except the kalbi which was just average. It lacked a bit of char and smokey flavor but it was tender and had the right flavors. We also tried some absolutely fantastic bread that came with a corn relish. The breads here are a must!

I wished I lived next door to this place so I could try every item on the menu over and over again.

chickpea fritter
tomatillo-tomato jam . green goddess . montamore

wood oven roasted pig face
sunny side egg . tamarind . cilantro . red wine-maple . potato stix

grilled kalbi beef ribs
sweet corn coblettes . charred okra relish

goat empanadas
huacatay . grilled mushroom giardiniera . queso fresco

I had been meaning to come here for years and years, and finally had the opportunity this week. I went all out and got drinks and three courses...all for myself. Don't judge until you've tried it!

The entire menu sounded great and it took me forever to decide. I ended up getting the lamb carpaccio, the pig face (to die for), and the squash cake. Everything was delicious and super savory. I would definitely order the pig face again (a sentence I never thought I would type), but I would probably stray to other parts of the menu for an appetizer of dessert. Still an amazing place with great service and ambiance.

We had wonderful service. Ordered the Ring of Fire cocktail- if you like tequila and a little spice the this drink is for you. The best cauliflower and beets I've had. The short ribs were tasty- falls apart yet crispy on the outside. Scallops had a real rich savory flavor and cooked perfectly. Didn't care for the octopus. Overall a great meal.

Absolutely one of the best restaurants in Chicago. It's a must visit. Friendly service, great vibes, and amazing food.

Definitely try the Pig Face, the Crispy Braised Pork Shank, and the Grilled Octopus. But honestly, you cannot go wrong with anything on that menu. The Girl & the Goat has perfected it all.

Service par excellence! Josh is knowledgeable and take his every recommendation. Anything ordered per recommendation (cauliflower &a octopus) wuz on point. Pork shank was heavy, will not get again (he recommended the pork face which we regret not ordering). The pork belly lobster crab meat appetizer thing was oily and heavy (he warned us). Ordered a muscle appetizer, decent and portion was good considering it was fried. Cocktails are unique and I am a drunken pirate afturrrr jus one. Holla atchyo gurl.

pics.caption: Don't get oily lobster pork belly crab meat appetizer thing

review.des: Love, love, love this restaurant. Great atmosphere, wonderful service, and an eclectically incredible menu. We started out with duck tongues, Gouda bread (yum), and ended with the goat belly confit. The wine list was thorough but not overwhelming. Amazing experience. Will definitely go back next time we're in Chicago.
This place was fantastic. Great food, cocktails and atmosphere. We went with a party of six and had a great time. The service was perfect, they couldn't have done anything better.

pics.caption: We had a party of six and ordered 12 sharing dishes. Everything was perfect!

review.des: One of my favorite places in the city. Go for the experience.   Food is great and atmosphere is really fun. Great for date night or groups. Three month reservation needed in advance in my experience.

Wow. I came here for a friend's birthday dinner, and boy, am I glad we're friends. I still can't believe how she got reservations for so many people. Instead dining in the noisy, crowded upstairs area, we were guided downstairs into a private wine room with a huge table. It was an intimate, special place where you could already get a sense of the food you were about to eat.

We had so much delicious food. I can't even begin to describe. There wasn't a dish that I disliked.

We started off with assorted breads. The cheddar bread was my favorite, but there was also one with tzatziki sauce and hummus, and another with peanut butter butter and some berry sauce.

The assorted olives were delicious! Not to salty and a great variety makes me a happy girl.

A nice refreshing dish is the kohlrabi salad. A perfect combination of crunch and sweetness, I thoroughly enjoyed this dish.

The grilled sepia is wonderful. The flavors are all there. Another favorite was the chickpea fritter. Crispy on the outside and soft on the inside. I personally love cauliflower, so that dish was amazing for me.

The goat leg was good-- I've never had goat before-- but I'd rather stick to the rest. I think I may also have been way to full by this point to thoroughly enjoy it.

Dessert was also yummy. The lemon cake was one of the best I've had. There were so many others I can't even remember. They were all very innovative. One even had goat cheese ice cream.

Definitely worth the trip and wait. Try and make reservations!

Loved it! Came here not expecting too much actually but ended up really enjoying my meal. Tried the scallops, pig face, and goat cheesecake--delicious! Wish there was a little more sauce on the pig face though. Good for sharing. Entire meal was less than $50.

Came here by myself and was able to sneak in at the bar with no wait at all on a Friday night. If you are a solo diner, they offer a few of their dishes in half portions which is really great!

I spent 3 days in Chicago over the Memorial Day holiday and I had a lot of great meals, but this was by far the best.

A girlfriend and I were visiting a friend from college who had moved to Chicago not too long ago. He's been here a couple of times and knew to make reservations for us on a Saturday night. We were seating almost immediately. It is quite dim and quite loud inside. I was fine with the noise because we were definitely having drinks at dinner and some inebriated bonding time. The restaurant has the feel of a fancier restaurant but also very personable and cozy. It's not pretentious and I liked that.

What we ordered in the order it was served:

Bacon gouda bread with butter and romesco - The bread is very tiny, only four slices, but very savory. The romesco was heavenly.

Goat carpaccio, trout roe, fried capers, olive-maple vinaigrette - Loved the combination of the thinly sliced goat with the vinaigrette dressed greens and fried capers. This plate is smaller and lighter than most on the menu.

Goat liver mousse, picked rhubarb, blueberry, crumpets - I loved this one even though I am not a big fan of liver. Cut the crumpets in half, spread some goat liver mousse, and top with either pickles of the blueberry spread. DE-LICIOUS.

Shishito peppers, parmesean, sesame, miso - I'm a big fan of shishito peppers especially when they make it like this at restaurants. However, I thought there was a tad too much parmesan and HOOOOLY SMOKES these were hot! I feel like the really spicy ones are one in a million but I got at least 5 in this little bowl of peppers. We didn't finish half of it because my mouth was on fire and I couldn't taste anything else after.

Halibut, almond butter, white asparagus & Cauliflower, pickled peppers, pine nuts, mint - These two paired very well together. Tactfully served, guys!

Pork shank, spring onion kimchee, buttermilk dressing, naan - At this point, my stomach was about to pop. The pork was very tender and went well with everything else. I wish I had more room to eat a couple more bites!!

It's recommended 2 plate per person. We went with 7 total because the bread and the carpaccio were on the smaller side. The three of us also shared two bottles of white wine (one very acidic one and another Greek wine I really enjoyed). Our server was great and contributed to such an enjoyable dinner atmosphere. He made it a point to get to know us and gave us spot-on recommendations!

Girl & The Goat is a must try in Chicago, but don't forget to call ahead!

pics.caption: Pork shank, kimchee green onions, buttermilk dressing, naan

review.des:
Absolutely adored this place. I went on a Tuesday night at 8pm and the place was PACKED! I put my name in for 3 and they told me an hour, so I decided to grab a drink elsewhere and come back as the bar was jam packed too.

We finally sat around 9:15pm. The place is super trendy and fun, awesome place for a date or girls night out. It was super loud and noisy though, expect that, but they played some super cool 90s throwbacks, which I heard when the place finally started to die down around 10:30pm & it's totally worth the loud noise. They have an awesome wine menu and I was happily taken aback that our waitress, Danielle, knew every single bottle from top to bottom. A+ right there! She also knew the menu really well and was eager to give suggestions on what we should order and what not to order.

We started out with the ham frites, which came out right away. OMG were they tasty. Loved the smoked tomato aioli sauce. We ordered way too much food for the 3 of us, but everything was delicious: pan seared scallops, pan fried shishito peppers (yum!), chickpea fritters (delicious), & pork shank (the buttermilk dressing was so good!)

In a nut shell, the menu is very fun and eclectic, the food is very filling but delicious, our waitress definitely knew her stuff, ambiance is super fun and trendy. Definitely worth checking out!

Six girls, one goat. Yea, I guess it sounds a little dirty but I'm talking about a nicely slow cooked, fall off the bone, meaty, goat LEG. So get your mind out of the gutter! ;-)

What else can I say that hasn't already been said. Nothing...except that the leg was the mother f'n BOMB!!!!! For those that don't understand that kind of lingo, lets just say it was tastier than your average home cooking.

This place is definitely worth the trip and the money, so I would definitely recommend making reservations and ordering the leg dinner. Make sure you try more than one small plate and do like we did....order all the desserts so everyone can try them. Keep in mind that you can't walk in off the street and order the leg, you have to order it in advance for that exquisite flavor.

Same as most people , had to do reservation months in advance, it was for My B-day back in July, last year.  Big expecations , but not my kind of food. But againg a great ambiance, great service, recomand for people to go there......

Trendy. I don't eat meat so there wasn't much for me to choose from on the menu. However, I found the salad (kale) to be good. I was there for a work related event and would recommend it if you're wanting to check it out.

Went with a group for the leg of lamb dinner.  Note you need to book for a group well in advanced for this special meal, but well worth it.  Delicious!  The servers were great, very personable and the setting was very cozy.

So far in my nearly 2 years in Chicago, this has been my best restaurant experience.  It's a small plates restaurant, so definitely come in with the mindset to be adventurous with the foods that you try.

First off, the cocktails are fantastic.  I had the vodka & pimms drink with cucumber and it was very refreshing!  We started off with the corn fed bread which comes with a goat cheese spread.  It completely hit the spot to start us off.  Every type of plate we had here was different and unique; between the stuffed lamb calamari (yum) to the beef ribs with okra over corn on the cob.  These are all plates that you can't get anywhere else.  While the signature dish to get is the "roasted pig face," I preferred the braised pork shank.  The meat on the pork shank basically falls off the bone it's so tender.  That paired with the bread and sauce is my favorite dish there.

Don't overlook the vegetable plates though, I know I know, broccoli and green beans are the green vegetables that you would normally avoid as a kid, but I'm telling you the broccoli with cream sauce and the green beans are unlike any other vegetables you've had before, they're seasoned perfectly.  

The service here is definitely something to take note of, they came 3 times during our meal to change out our dirty plates to clean ones.  The service was excellent, I felt like a queen.  We finished with the butterscotch dessert, it was pretty good but would have been better if it was served warm.  It's a combination of textures; cake, nuts, and butterscotch pudding with a really great flavor.

All in all, my favorite restaurant experience from the great service, to the variety of food, to the ambiance.  So glad that we were able to get a reservation in, folks this place fills up fast.  By 5:30pm on a Wednesday, people were waiting for tables.  My expectations were high coming in but they were met and I left needing a nap from the amount of food I ate.  All so good!  Yum, can't wait to come back.

pics.caption: Pork shank with bread and spicy sauce
Broccoli with cream sauce at the bottom

review.des:
It was perfect. I'd say top 5 dining experiences of my life.

After months of prowling opentable, I secured a late Thursday night dinner, 9:30pm, and the place was PACKED... and stayed packed well past closing time too. We were graciously seated at the chef's table.. or as close to it as we were gonna get. Our waiter was lovely, as was the friendly grillmaster who managed to chat us up while cooking up a storm. I am so deeply sad I am terrible with names... because they were truly wonderful.

We ordered the whitefish, goat belly, pig face, beef tongue. Also received complimentary oysters, cauliflower, and cake!! Everything was like "oh wow.. this is.. how in the world did they.. this is so freaking amazing" good. I don't think you can really go wrong with ANYTHING on the ever-evolving menu. Everything was so different, and our waiter was knowledgeable and thoughtful enough to sequence it alternating the rich/heavy with the light/fresh dishes. Only regret is that they'd run out of goat ribs right before we ordered, and we weren't able to fit more in our bellies!

Thank you, thank you, thank you, Girl & The Goat for a seriously wonderful and memorable night.

Ok so no table cloth and ambiance is so so. But man you can't do better than this food. A little bit pricey but the wait is months so what choice do they have.  Healthy ish and more delicious than I thought it could be. I love cooking and this is a cooks temple.  Planing next visit now.

Though the cocktails were very well crafted, the portions were too small to feel like we would enjoy staying for a meal. This is a great place to start a night out on the town and meet-up spot if you're ok with standing for a bit. First come first serve seating at the bar... and people camp out.

Granted I have only been here twice. Once, during the first month it was open (2010 I think? My memory is fading..), and last year.

I have never made a reservation, and both times we have been squeezed in, no problem other than the standard roll of the eyes. I imagine not for me, but rather for the intense process of squeezing a delightful individual such as myself into a tight booking schedule. Mainly because after a few minutes I could see the host's eyes light up, like "YES, I can get you in!" Whew, it's not me, it's you guys. I hate being a burden!

Anyway, both times food was just okay. I feel a little upset about this. We (gladly) paid for bread service, not the best. Fancy sounding, but 'eh (for Chicago). Broccoli, shrimp, duck, pork shank... all... just fine. Wine list, and cocktails to be honest, were both so freaking amazing! But not comparable to other meals I have had in Chicago. I almost feel like G&G is resting on its laurels. Actually, what laurels? I was here during the beginning! The diner across the street owned by G&G is sorta cool.

5k reviews? no one is reading this! So I'll stop now!
wonderful experience!! amazing food, staff was phenomenal. we sat at the chefs table. the kitchen staff was entertaining! defining make a reservation. i've never seen this place not packed!!

The food was amazing! I LOVE it! Great place, they are really attentive to their clients!Our waitress was awesome as well. I have a bunch of food allergies and she was so kind to go through everything and make sure what I could and could not eat. Super sweet!

Do you like meat? Do you like things that leave grease stains on your shirt? If you said yes to any of these questions then this is the place for you!

Although some dishes look small, do not let it fool you - this food is heavy and it will sit in your gut all day until it becomes a greasy condensed "kid" you will drop off at the "pool" later...if you know what I mean.

Anyways here's what we ordered and what I thought:

Escargot Ravioli - meh meh meh. Sort of bland, chewy, and didn't really work as well as I would have hoped. Would have been better if there was some more moisture like a white wine buerre blanc with shallots or something. Instead it had some sort of odd sauce that left everything a bit dry

Roasted Pig Face - Greasy bits of yum. After eating this you will feel as if you had just eaten taco bell sober. You will be oddly satisfied but have the saltiest grease hangover you can't even imagine. Definitely tasty and worth it if your cholesterol hasn't reached a dangerously high level

Crumpets and Goat Liver Mousse - MY FAVE DISH. The crumpets were so fluffy and buttery and the mousse was absolutely divine. I could swim in this mousse. If you like pate or any sort of liver you will love this! ABSOLUTELY LOVE. The apple butter on the side is to die for. Literally consumed within a minute

Crispy Pork Shank - rather than a description here's my thoughts "dear lord this is large. are pigs this large? I didn't know they were this large. OH GOD ITS LIKE BACON ITS A BIG GIANT CRISPY PIECE OF BACON. why don't they sell this everywhere? I would have this for breakfast - 'yes I would like 2 poached eggs and A CRISPY PORK SHANK'"

Roasted Duck Breast - so mediocre I don't even remember enough to describe it.

Overall this place is a solid 3.5 BUT I'm giving it a 4 because the mousse is my life. I wish I could ship that mousse to my house every day. I would literally eat it for breakfast, take the jar with me and lick it clean while I drove to work...just saying.

pics.caption: Crumpets and Goat Liver Mousse - absolutely divine.
Roasted Pig Face - sooooo fatty T_T

review.des:
My flight to Chicago was delayed for 2 hours but it did not stop my husband and I come here for our reservation at 10:45PM even though we had to drag our luggage here due to delay. We cabbed here right after the airport because once we missed it, we would not be able to get a reservation for another month! Our effort was paid off.

First of all, I was shocked the restaurant was HUGE. It looks like it could be an old warehouse-turned-restaurant and still, you have to wait hours to get a table and month to book a reservation. The bar scene is very vibrant too with tons of people at the bar drinking. The restaurant is pretty noisy so I would not categorize this as an upscale dining spot but the food is undoubtedly top-notch.

We started our late dinner with their homemade onion bread. It is a fritter I think because it is so buttery and crusty and their homemade butter dip and tomato spread were beyond the world amazing. It is a must get on the menu.

Then, we got the the Ham frites. They are the bomb! I could totally taste the ham-infused juice in the fries and they are crispy and smell of delicious ham. We also had the grilled baby octopus with snow peas and they are delicious as well. Then, we shared a plate of green beans drilled in some mysterious sauce with some walnut. They are very good but I think it is a little too salty. For entree, we got the Pig Face like everyone else raved about and were delighted we listened. The pig face comes with really soft and slow cooked pork with sunny side up egg and crispy taro fries. It is absolutely to die for. We also got the goat belly and it is equally amazing.

Too bad we were too full and too tired to order desserts. Till next time!

I went in October 2015
