Goat empanadas: very tender meat, crisp and buttery crust, amazing blue cheese aioli sauce complimented everything very well. Flavorful, not too salty. Delicious

Beets: best beets I've ever had. Mixed with green beans and a leafy green with a creme fraische avocado purée, lemon, and the perfect amount of course salt sprinkled over the dish. Amazing

Scallops: SOOOO fucking amazing. Deliciously flavored, perfectly cooked. Roasted brussel sprouts brought out the nuttiness, emphasized by pecans, and refreshingly balanced with the right amount of tart pomegranate

Five stars because EVERYTHING was on point. I'd happily go again if I find myself in Chicago.
Highlight of my last business trip. Looking forward to returning next time I'm in town. Good place to go when you're on your own.
This restaurant is amazing! Everything we are was fantastic and we were able to sit at the chef's table. Such a cool experience! Be sure to make reservations far in advance

Amazing food!! Hadn't heard about this place but when I was looking places up on Yelp this one came up. So I made reservations and I'm glad I did. Everything we had melted in our mouths and kept us wanting more. Service was excellent. I will add pictures of what we ate and I highly recommend it.

pics.caption: Duck face with an egg on top. I was skeptical at first but had to because when in Rome. Never regretted it, so amazing
Appetizer of fries that had two dipping sauces

review.des: Girl and the Goat, had fantastic service, a cool environment, good food and the waiter provided really good service.  We love to eat tapas, but this place made the experience better than just food.  The server timed the plates well so that we ate at a good pace and in an order that made sense.  We will def go back when we visit Chicago again.

I really enjoyed G&TG's creations! And I was unbelievably happy to find out that they had a vegan menu.

I'm mostly writing this review to note that I wish there were just one or two more dedicated vegan items (as it seemed like a lot of them were regular menu items with a few pieces left off) because adding more flavor/texture dimension at a place like this is always so much fun! But, yes, this was very delicious for a special occasion. I would absolutely recommend trying at some point if you're in Chicago.
Get the pork face and pork shank!! They are the best! The atmosphere is great but there aren't a lot of tables. Be there early or make a reservation ahead of the time.

Wow, this place was incredible! I walked in with some coworkers and ended sitting in the lounge area where you can order from the full menu. The service was wonderful and exceeded expectations. Must try the flank steak, chickpea fritters, broccoli, and potato bread. Will come back again!

Well,  I've been waiting to try this place and finally was able to last night. In one visit I went from curious onlooker to rabid fan.  I would seriously put this up with some of my favorite restaurants - top 10 for sure - maybe even top 5 - no joke,  this place was that good.

Where to start. .. the decor - awesome!  Dark"burnt" timbers form a massive focal point at the center of the restaurant - maybe only upstaged by the vibrant open kitchen. Really beautiful place.

The staff and service?  Absolutely spot - on!  Everyone we encountered had that service superstar sixth sense of just "getting it" - perfectly balancing casual and professional - but mostly just being hip,  fun and normal.

But that all aside,  this place is ultimately about the food - and their kitchen rocks!  I won't describe all 13 small plates we ordered,  but here's a few highlights:
- Kohlrabi salad with apples,  fennel and shiitake
- Himachi crudo with crisp pork belly
- Pan - roasted halibut with white asparagus
- Sugo (like braised beef gravy) over pappardelle
- Confit of goat belly with bourbon butter,  lobster and crab

One was better than the previous - everything melted in your mouth (literally) - the flavor combinations at times were downright stunning!  

Let's put it this way - when I write this much about a place and haven't even mentioned beverage? ! You know I must have loved it - and how could I not,  when their background music included Biggie,  Johnny Cash and The Cure? !

Great,  Great restaurant worth all the praise they receive.  If you haven't tried, you have to!

It's my Birthday!

That really has nothing to do with this review, I just thought y'all would like to know.

Okay, maybe it has a little to do with my birthday. You see, I had originally made reservations for G&G back in 2010 for March 30th, 2011. My reservation was later cancelled for an unknown private event that they were hosting on that date after my reservation had been taken only by mistake. I worked at a restaurant at the time and though I felt a little sour, I understand how mistakes can happen. Plus I drove by on the night of my B-Day last and found out that the secret private event was the Top Chef finale.... Okay fine, I guess that might be a little more high profile than little ole me... and it only took another year before it all ended up working out.

Yesterday I was treated to one of the nicest dining experiences I've had in a long time (Thx, Mark S!). Coming from a serving/bartending background, I always appreciate when servers look comfortable at work- ie, super cute goat guy on a thin black tee and jeans. They basically had me at their uniforms, which are pretty damn similar to my everyday attire of a bunch of stuff with animals on it, and nothing to fancy schmancy.

The food on the other hand... a little more dressed up. Like, I thought I looked nice until I saw what my dinner was wearing. Our server said that for 2 people 4-5 plates is usually plenty... so naturally, we went with 6... and a dessert. Here's the birthday run down:

- Fresh baked bread with coffee spread = whoa. Whoa-ho-ho. Unbelievable. Eating this reminded me of Halloween time and seeing one of your friends in a costume where you might see them everyday in regular life but in costume they're barely recognizable... and they look so good you can't stop staring and creep them out. It's like that. How could this taste so much like coffee and not like bread or artificial coffee flavoring and why can't I take my mouth of it? And then I start creeping out other diners with my enthusiasm for eating it. By far, my favorite item of the night... and I don't really even like bread.

- Fresh baked maize bread with avocado yogurt... Daaamn is all you need to know.

- The famous cauliflower: Parm cheezy and delish. I preferred the bottom bits without the cheese and with the mint leaves, but my cauliflower hatin' counterpart LOVED the cheese and scarfed his portion down and then some with jubilant fervor.

- Warm marinated olives. Whodathunk olives would taste even better warm? I guess they work on the same level as salted nuts. You MUST get an order of these bad boys to munch on throughout your meal. Plus, a million of them come in an order so it's a nice little time sucker... and they don't forget to provide you with a little pot for the pits so you don't end up with a plate full of spitty, gnawed on pits.

- Roasted beet salad with crunchy-ness and green bean biz-nast. Okay, obvi that's not what it was actually called but I've been working a lot and sleeping a little so my mind was in a bit of a daze but what I liked about this beet salad, as the world's biggest beet fan, is that it wasn't a bunch of mixed greens with a few beet bits- it was 100% Beet by volume and only had a light sprinkling of mixed greens on top for color. Just beet it? Don't mind if I do.

- Artichoke... something? I dunno. I just glanced at the menu quickly and when I saw olives, beets, and artichokes (3 of my top 5 favorite foods) I know which plates would be called upon. If I had to describe the artichoke dish I'd say it was like a pasta that looked like individually wrapped candy packets filled with nutty goodness. Hehe... she said 'nutty goodness.'

To be honest, I didn't really read the full description of anything I ordered. There was so much going on as far as atmosphere and the best playlist ever! Seriously, I think I looked around and at some point in the night, I'm pretty sure every person in there had uttered the word's 'it's like I made this playlist"... sure you did, buddy. I was thinking the same thing about myself and then while I was looking around I realized that though I LOVED every song, I'm just not nearly cool enough to be able to devise a playlist of that magnitude. It was a scene alright, but still cool enough that you can pull a mix of really dressed up people to really casual peeps and still have everyone feeling comfortable. Then again, it's dark and loud as f*ck so everyone seems about the same level when you've got those two things going.

And I probably don't have to mention this but I will anyway- the beer list was quality, my Tequila Fleur got my kulo buzzed, and our server was a God damned peach if I've ever seen one.

It would take a plague of epic proportions to keep this (now 1 year older) Miss away from G&theG for too long. In fact, I actually logged onto Yelp and made my OpenTable reservation while I was only 2 plates into dinner at GG. I'll see you in 3 more months when I celebrate my 2_ and a quarter birthday.
We made reservations 3 months in advance and I was wondering if it would be worth the wait. It was. Period. Fun menu. Great staff. Enjoyable dining experience that left us wanting to come back again.

pics.caption: The best dessert known to man or woman.

review.des: This is a good restaurant. Don't see why the waiting list is 2 months but obviously it is worth it for many people. The service we received was marginal but the food we ate was delicious. It was great to have different tastes on the palate. For the price however, we could have gone to better restaurants in town.

One of the best meals I've had in a long time. I mean it with all my foodie heart.

I got lucky because we were driving back from Green Bay after the Packers-Dallas football game (3 hours away) and made a 9:15pm reservations on Open Table (so glad they have this because I wouldnt even thought about going here without a reservation knowing how busy they are!!).

The dishes we got --
- Wood fired old 1971: lightly cooked with fresh horseradish and bacon bits. The only 'cooked' oysters I've ever eaten and liked.
- Parmesan Cheese bread - amazingly light and tasty!
- Hamachi Crudo - tasty and a good dish but there were many more good dishes.
- Wood oven roasted pig face - OMG! the meat is crispy and the egg on top supplements the pig perfectly. One of the BEST dishes of the night.
- Confit goat belly - If not the best dish but second BEST dish behind the Pig Face but the goat belly tasted amazing with the lobster and crab bites. A well rounded dish!

Desserts:
Cheese with Honey - VERY good!
Icecream with mushroom - dont remember the full details of the dish but it was very tasty and a great end to the meal

Overall, I am very very happy I was able to eat here.
I would highly recommend this restaurant to anyone living and/or visiting in Chicago. I'm sad I live in SF :(
Might have to plan a summer trip........

I had my rehearsal dinner here, and I have to say it was the best experience we could have had.

The meal was done family style which normally would have been a problem since I have two family members with severe allergies, but G&G said it was no problem, asked where those two were sitting, what their allergies were (ahead of time) and prepared a separate menu just for them.

There was plenty of food and the service was incredible.

Highly, highly recommended.

I am so, so, so saddened to be one of the (apparent) few who isn't absolutely losing my mind over this place, but unfortunately, I'm just not. I'd like to chalk it up to a combination of mishaps and a bad server, but regardless my evening was a massive disappointment based on all the hype. Myself and my family made this reservation months in advance to celebrate a combination of an anniversary and a birthday, which we had even indicated with our reservation. Needless to say, we went preparing to spend a lot of time and money enjoying ourselves and the restaurant but we did not get that opportunity.

We were somewhat awkwardly greeted by our server Alex upon our arrival. We needed a few minutes to peruse the menu of course, but when we told her the plates we had picked out, she was quick to ask if that would be enough. I said, "Why don't we just start with that for round one?" to which she insisted we tell her what we're considering and that some of our choices would be too similar, then suggested significantly more expensive plates in their stead. We felt incredibly pressured to choose our entire dinner while she impatiently stared at us, so unfortunately, we did. We ordered the green beans, the fried oysters, the pig face, the hamachi crudo, and the goat belly (on special that evening). As our ordering went on, Alex took on a more and more disdainful look and could not have turned on her heel faster once we were done ordering. At this point her attitude already put a horrible taste in our mouths, no pun intended.

From then on, the food experience itself just sputtered. The green beans came out first, which I thought was a strange choice - while good and full of umami flavor, at the end of the day, they are simply green beans - why bring those with no protein on the table? Shortly thereafter the oysters arrived at our table - four TINY morsels with as much breading as oyster, with one fried caper on each, nestled into a massive bed of what I can only call potato salad. It seriously tasted like supermarket potato salad - no contrast or pop at all - and it completely overwhelmed the oyster. My parents were kind enough to let me have at the extra oyster and the only way to enjoy it was to pull it out of its gloppy potato nest, pry off some of the breading, and get about one second of enjoyment out of what should have been the star. So disappointing.

I don't think I'd even gotten to the fourth oyster when the pig face was arriving on the table (we are talking the third dish arriving in about five or six minutes since the first). My stepdad had asked for an extra egg which turned out to be a great idea - pro-tip! - because the runny yolk absolutely helps bind the dish together. The pig itself is so fatty and delectable, especially with the maple pairing, that it's not hard to see why this dish is a favorite here. However, based on the description I was really hoping for a pop of the tamarind or cilantro but both were woefully lacking as evidenced by how thinly their sauces were distributed on the plate. Maybe they were overwhelmed by the potato "stix", I'm not sure.... But without one of these flavors to set it off, I can really only call the pig face an above average hash.

Again, while we were not even halfway through this dish came the hamachi crudo, which flavor-wise was the real triumph of the night, though yet again, suffered from what I think was a real issue in proportioning. It came with caper berries, pork belly, micro herbs, and a fantastic chili aioli (though this sauce had no heat whatsoever). The hamachi was of GORGEOUS quality and the accompaniments were well chosen, but simply so sparse in comparison to the amount of fish. The caper berries were already tiny, yet had to be sliced into slivers for all of us to be able to taste them properly in conjunction with the fish and aioli. The pork belly pieces could not have been even a half inch long and there were three on the plate, so again, they had to be cut as small as possible.

And yet again, while we were still enjoying what had so far been our favorite, the goat belly made its way out to the table, which was by far the richest dish and a worthy way to end the night. While the portion is VERY small (the three of us had about a bite and half each, if that), the flavors are super heavy and indulgent -  tender confit goat belly, lobster, bourbon butter, and just enough greens to lighten it up... Slight recovery. But as soon as it was done Alex was coming around to ask if we wanted anything else (we didn't) and then hastily brought us the check. Keep in mind we had not even been in the restaurant for 45 minutes at this point - I hadn't even finished my tiny cocktail. Then after the check had already been dropped off she came with a small plate of dessert and the most awkward, "Happy... happy day" and fake smile I've ever had to endure. I don't know what we did to earn her disdain but it just capped off a poorly spaced and plated experience.

I happened to have a meeting in the area and thought, why not. I was able to find a seat at the bat within 15 mins, it was a Thursday around 7 and you don't need a reservation for that.  
The waiter was very friendly and made some good suggestions. Everything I ordered was just too salty I had the green beans and the duck with kimchee. The duck was good but the Kimchee was just bad. I've never eaten anything so salty in my life, my tongue literally hurt by the end of the meal.  I really wanted to like everything because I had built it up so much in my mind, but it just didn't work for me. Im not gonna lie I will go back with a group, just to be able to try different things.

Service is def a 2-3

I have been to many places in my short life  and I must say I get that you are busy- but the fact that you act like I'm an invisible wall?! Please I'm wearing red lipstick and am ready to go

Food is a 5

But service at the bar a 2. Bartender could care less about a tab close than filling orders

Server?! You're cool but you could give less of a shit because we're a party of two

Manager? You should have comped the first drinks but you just got us the bill something that didn't need your attn

Disappoint

Best place. There may be some seats at the bar if you're a walk-in, otherwise be sure to place your reservation at least 3 months ahead of time. Ordered the empanadas and the pig face. No regrets! Would do it again!

We were sooooo surprised to find this gem! Owen our server was totally delightful.
We ordered martinis and olive bread to start and wow! We are from Orlando and very big on the quality of customer service! I'm sure glad we have this a try and hope to see Owen again! What an experience

Everything was great. I never write reviews on Yelp, but this is an exception. We didn't have a reservation on a Saturday so the wait was 2 hrs. Nonetheless, it was worth it! We got 1 starter, 5 dishes, and 1 dessert. YUM!

I know I'm in the minority here, but I thought this place was way overhyped. Take it with a grain of salt since I don't like olives (and they're everywhere here), but I won't be going back anytime soon.

My bf surprised me for my birthday by taking me to this place. I heard it took him months to get a table around dinner time on a Saturday.  I would consider this place as tapa style as the food portions were on the smaller side. I can't exactly recall the names of everything we ordered, but EVERYTHING was tasty! One dish that I do remember was the escargot dumplings. I was surprised at myself that I enjoyed that dish. It had an earthy taste, but the bacon offset it. I definitely recommend this place to others, and hopefully would enjoy the savory experience as much as I did.

If you're coming to Chicago... You must eat here! Reservations need to be booked in advance; 3 months, or call daily to see if someone cancels, which is what we did and got lucky. Order recommendations include: nutter butter bread, pig face, green beans (a little salty), pork shank, peanut butter pana cotta. The pork dishes are very similar to lechon. So yummy!

Came here on Saturday night- long wait in front, so we chose the table in waiting area.
Ordered drinks- tasty.
Pig face- Love it!!
Dessert- ice cream made of goat milk- nice.

I feel spoiled. Now that I've had the opportunity to dine here, I do believe Girl & The Goat has ruined me for all other dining experiences. The ambiance is great. It's upscale without being pretentious. Service was impecable.

Having done my homework before coming, I knew the menu and had a good idea about things to order based on reviews found here. Surprisingly, some of the dishes I was most excited to try turned out to be my least favorites (mind you, still delicious) and the items I was on the fence about trying, ended up being my absolute favorites! In order of favorites - it goes like this:

duck tongues - 5 stars
wood oven roasted pig face - 5 stars
kohlrabi salad - 5 stars
crisp braised pork shank (this is so high up here because of the onion kimchee, yum!) - 5 stars
goat empanadas - 5 stars
pan roasted halibut - 4 stars
roasted cauliflower - 4 stars
grilled shrimp - 4 stars
sauteed green beans - 3 stars
confit goat belly - 3 stars
escargot ravioli - 3 stars
fried pickles - 3 stars

Highly recommend to go with a group of people so you have the chance to try a little bit of everything. We were a group of six and that was perfect! Can't wait to return!!!

This is our favorite restaurant for date night in the city. The food is well worth the prices and the staff is always pleasant and quick to check our table, refill drinks, offer suggestions and answer any dietary-related questions. A++++

Finally got to check it out! Exceeded our expectations on everything from the service, atmosphere and food. We were lucky enough to grab seats at the bar and Jason was our waiter. He was great and made the experience all the more fun. Can't wait to go back.

I feel like my second experience here was nowhere near as great as my first. Though my service was still top notch and the sommelier made excellent recommendations, the food was not as great as it was during my first visit (two years ago).

Some of the fishes were great but others were just ho hum! Hopefully they get it back up to speed soon as I do love it here.

Food recommendation: the pork shank.

Another overly hyped place. I've gone here 3 times. First time because it was overly hyped by the unusual names and because the chef was on a cooking show. Super disappointed. It did not live up to the hype at all and said I would never go there again. Over priced, under delivered. The second and third times were because of work events that were held here, so I had no choice. However, I thought it would be a great way to give this place another chance... sure enough. I was not impressed at all. We spend thousands at this place for one of the work events. Many of my colleagues and I agreed, it was just OK. There is nothing special about this restaurant people. I know, if you come to Chicago, you want to go home and tell your friends you went here and had something called pig face or something, but it's NOT THAT GOOD. Can't wait for the hype to be over so they can replace it with a better restaurant.

Let me start off by saying I HAVE NEVER BEEN SO ANGRY WITH FOOD BEFORE!

Seriously.

Everything here was delicious and I was shaking my fist while eating because I couldn't believe how amazing our meal was! My boyfriend said he made the reservation for us a month ago, but trust me, it's definitely worth the wait! We've eaten at tons of different restaurants but this one takes the cake thus far. From the moment you walk in, to the friendly staff, to the freakin' delicious food, it really can't get any better. Whatever you're doing Chef Stephanie, please, keep it up!

We started off with the serrano bread. Holy cow. I tried it first with just the roasted corn cream cheese, then once you put the pickle relish on it-flavor explosion in your mouth!

For veggies, we ordered the chickpea fritter, which was recommended by our server, DEFINITELY WAS NOT DISAPPOINTED! This by far was my favorite dish out of the whole meal. We also ordered the sautéed green beans. I know what you're thinking..."green beans? there's no way they were that good." Well guess what, also another flavor explosion! I don't how how they do it but they made it so you can't really taste the fish sauce but it was so delicious!

I ordered the chili shrimp for my entree-if I could have licked the plate clean I would have. But you know...couldn't really do that seeing as that I was on a date with my boyfriend and all....But anyways! He ordered the pig face and said he really enjoyed it! (I didn't try it because I'm a pescetarian.)

So yes, go, make your reservation for this place now. You won't be disappointed. And if by some super slim chance you are...then there's something wrong with you!

If you've ever been asked "what's the strangest thing you've ever eaten?" and your best answer was, like, "a turkey burger?" you need to come to Girl and the Goat.  Update that answer to something like "Duck Tongue" or...you know..."Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face."

Yes that's a real thing.  Yes, it's one of the best items on the menu.

It's really hard to get a reservation at normal eating times here, but my work team and I had had a really busy day with a really late lunch, so we grabbed a drink in the area and then headed over late (930/10pm) and got a table pretty easily.  All the food was delicious - chickpea fritters, beet salad, sea scallops, and some of the aforementioned adventurous choices to name a few.  Since you're order so many things, the check adds up pretty quickly, but YOLO right?  That's what the kids are saying these days?

Food: 5/5
Value: 4/5
Service: 5/5
Atmosphere: 4/5
Came here for a romantic Valentine's Day dinner! The food was just amazing, I was so happy with the service, the music was on point, the ambiance was just perfect! Please check this place out!

I arranged a reservation at the Underground Goat for a company event and we weren't disappointed.  I had to feed people with a wide variety of tastes and a few allergies and everyone was stuffed.  The only reason I didn't give the full 5 stars was because the main dish was served at the very end and we were all too full to finish the goat leg.  Also, we were all from out of town and couldn't take the leftovers home but I really hope our server took it home for his family like we asked.

Anyway, aside from that the menu was choice and I loved the way the chef paired the ingredients.  Who would've thought egg salad and oysters went together!?!

To die for!!
Havent been back in awhile, but only because i dont have time, this place is amazing and everything i have ever had was so delicious

This has been on my list of places to go in Chicago for some time. I lost a bet and owed a friend dinner here. I've never been so glad to loose a bet. It started out wonderful because we were in one of the Expo seats. Overlooking he kitchen was amazing.

We were given a free serving of cauliflower, which was great. The service was super, but the food stole the show. The got ribs were nearly the best thing I've put in my mouth. I also loved the pig face so much. I will be back.

What can I say that hasn't already been said here. This place is a need to go place in Chicago. I'm glad I talked to a girlfriend of mine who has been here because I tried to book a month in advance on their online system (for a sunday) and it was booked, so I called and luckily they had a place open for me. So, plan accordingly. This place is very popular with tourist and locals.

Overall my experience was great, the food was to die for, and the service was pretty on point. Our waiter was very good about making suggestions and letting us know what food options we had and how many dishes would be good for a party of two. This place is like most hip new chicago restaurants as it's tapas style, so you share plates.

Since it was only my boyfriend and I, we ordered the forest gump (yummy bread with different spreads, I think one was a pea and garlic puree and the other was a butter with carrots, whatever it was the bread was amazing), wood fired scalops, roasted cauliflower ( I would eat this over and over), and their famous pig face. It was a meal that was unforegetful. All the taste came together perfectly in all the dishes.  I still can't believe I ate pig face, It kind of tasted like a fattier version of pork belly.

For dessert, we had this parfait type thing with butterscotch and cashews with bacon toffee. Whatever it was, it was amazing. My boyfriend and I were fighting over it.

Overall, the meal was amazing and I would come back. Food is also very afordable, you're looking at 8-20 dollars for most dishes.  This place definitely lived up to all its hype.

I guess I do not get it, or I am a little jaded. I do not call myself a foodie, but I have dined out allot and allot of places. Girl and the Goat is definitely a place that has to be experienced, and the chef/owner deserves every bit of the praise she has gotten. My girlfriend had been there before as had our other couple. She was not keen on returning, but I made her, because I had not been.

The room is causal, vibrant and busy. The hostesses are pleasant and inviting. The wait staff is personal and attentive, and everything is crack professional.

The food is hit and miss. The 4 of us had 8 shared plates. The halibut was the best I have eaten. The scallops were great. Fritters were OK, the skirt steak tough and OK, the pig face was interesting and good, but I would never order again, and the lamb stuffed calamari was god awful. Someone was definitely  having a 420 afternoon when they shoved some lamb into some scrap squid laying around and called it a dish. lamby and fishy at the same time.

Beer selection is good, as are the drinks. All in all, expensive and you will leave hungry. Dinner for 4, $246.

So glad that I did my research before arriving in Chicago so that I could try this great restaurant!  Really loved the whole setting and our server was great.  My favorite way to eat is shared plates and I was thrilled to get to taste so many different items.  My two fav's were the Chickpea Fritters and Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face. OMG - fabulous!!

I really liked Girl & The Goat and would surely return when in Chicago again. Fabulous, energetic, buzzing atmosphere with friendly staff at every turn.

We arrived on time for our 745P rez (made via OpenTable a night or two prior). Our table wasn't ready so we grabbed a couple seats at the bar, before we could finish our drinks the hostess had come to let us know they were ready to seat us.

As first timers we ordered some of the more popular menu items:

- Roasted Cauliflower (pickled peppers, pine nuts, mint)
 delish!!!

- Sautéed Green Beans (fish‌ sauce vinaigrette, cashews)
  the fish sauce is quite flavorful but may be a little much for some palettes

- Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face (tamarind, cilantro, red wine-maple, potato stix)
  the mix and mash concept of the pig face with the sunny side egg was fun, the thought of these two words "pig face" are what inevitably prevented me from finishing this dish, tasty nonetheless!

- Goat Empanadas (marinated sheep feta, pickled golden beet, tzatziki)
 Simply delish! Great texture and flavor

- Bread w/ Spelt grain
  too heavy - pass! Unless you show up shit faced and are looking for the absorption factor

- Scallops (sweet curry, sweet onion-bacon, papadum)
  sampled these from the kitchen but didn't order. Tasty! but not sure I'd need an entire order, may be too much unless you really like scallops

The cauliflower and goat empanadas were my fav out of the above.

Great beer/wine and cocktail menu.

Skipped dessert because we were too full from the above and a couple drinks.

Restrooms downstairs were tidy, valet was helpful and got us into a cab within seconds of exiting.

Great place! the entire vibe reminds me very much of one of my most fav restaurants in LA. Tapas style dining is always a good time!

We made our reservation about 2-3 months in advance. It's a cute place...gets pretty noisy even at 10pm.

We started off with their freshly baked bread, mushroom soup butter & tomato sauce dip, and a bacon butter. I really liked the mushroom soup butter.
The razor clams were flavorful but only came 3 in an order. The escargot ravioli was nothing special. I'd rather have escargot without the pasta.  The white fish was in a creamier sauce. It was nice and crispy on the outside and flakey on the inside.
The sugo was ok. It did come with a good portion of meat though.  Confit goat belly was good. The smoked wings had a nice smokey flavor, but I wouldn't recommend getting it here when you have all the other foods to try.  
The pig face, which everyone recommends, was delicious. The crispiness of the pork was perfect. The braised pork shank was a sizeable portion and was very flavorful as well.

I already made a second reservation for this restaurant and will be back here this weekend!

Like everyone else, I too read the reviews and just had to try out Girl & the Goat. It did not disappoint!

We made reservations and while our table was being cleared we grabbed drinks at the bar. The La Paloma was exquisite. It was fresh, fruity and bubbly.

There were so many good recommendations on Yelp that we struggled with choosing the best dishes to try out. In the end we went with the Ham Frittes, Goat Empanadas and Pork Belly. All lovely, all delicious, all worth eating every single bit of food. I feel like everything has already been said on the food. Buy it. Eat it. Love it.

I have to make a side note here. My husband doesn't like what he calls "fussy food". He loves a good steak paired with a nice wine. After reading the reviews, he wasn't sure about Girl & the Goat  -- see entries describing pig face -- so he actually went to Shake Shack first and ate a burger (just in case)! Well, lo and behold he orders himself the pork belly and ate every single bit of that dish. He loved it and said we would definitely go back. So if you've got someone in your life who usually shies away from new American, rest assured that it passes the steak lovers test!

Then came dessert. Okay, I love some dessert so their chocolate cake was FABULOUS. A fantastic scoop of coconut gelato dipped in dark, crunchy chocolate with warm flourless chocolate cake underneath. Good God Lemon! Add fudge and coconut cream and you are in heaven. I didn't want to share, I'll tell you that much.

If you get the chance make a reservation and go. You will not be disappointed.

If the first 1300 reviews didn't sway your opinion...I'll toss a pebble into the pool, it's that good.

Daphne L. procured reservations on a Sunday Funday, but we decided to forgo those and sit at the raised bar, which was great. The Lounge Area is always first come, first served, and we enjoyed the sight lines and the social aspect with other diners.

Super Highlights:
Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face- (see pic) this dish came with special instructions to break the fried egg and swirl all of the ingredients together. The meat was as tender as oxtail, and the dish was worth the visit alone!

Grilled Pork Ribs- big meaty ribs with perfect seasoning, this was one of my choices, and it did not disappoint (and I've been all over in Memphis, trust me).

Goat Carpaccio- Daphers' husband was eyeing the carpaccio on the menu, and it was a great choice. Who doesn't like a carpaccio? Very good.

Escargot Ravioli- the last of our truly standout dishes was the Escargot Ravioli. The sauce was so good we didn't leave any behind.

Dishes that did not blow me away:

Chickpeas Fritters- were just okay. I had read so much about them,  but they just seemed out of place at Girl & the Goat.

Hiramasa Crudo- Fish! At a meat restaurant! This dish was good, but again, slightly out of place here.

Sauteed Green Beans- My Facebook was blowin' up when I asked what I should order at GatG, and Green Beans was second only to the Pig Face. What? I'm a passable cook and I've learned how to saute green beans in coarse ground pepper,  sea salt and lemon juice or a splash of white wine vinegar too! Nah, not that amazing.

The drink menu is really stellar and the Firestone IPA paired well to cut through the meat and richness of the sauces.

I forgot to mention our server on the Sunday night we were there, she was working the bar and lounge area, and was great! And others that brought dishes to us never did the dump and run, and everyone was so professional and friendly. Well, except maybe the slight cattiness from no less than four hostesses, that could probably be done away with. Everyone else was the tops!

There, pebble thrown in the pool, now get yourself to Girl & the Goat!

I made reservations about a month & a half in advance. I'd been here before so I knew to be prepared with a reservation :)

My favorite dish to get here is definitely the CRISPY PIG FACE! So. amazingly. delicious. They do such a great job of combining contrasting textures and flavors. When I look for a crazy good meal, I'm all about texture and almost every dish I've ever had here has been done just right.

My other two really close favorites are:

-Escargot ravioli (my friends didn't like it bc of the idea of it, but I LOVED it. More for me.)
-Cauliflower with pine nuts (Lots of flavor)

If you're going to Chicago, make a reservation way in advance. Then get there early and have drinks at the bar and their comfy waiting lounge.

pics.caption: Going in on that Crispy Pig Face

review.des: Great spot to grab dinner. Dress is pretty casual, so one can always be comfortable in jeans and a nice shirt. Ambiance is nice, the place is always packed so there is a lot of activity going on. Menu is pretty diverse and their use of goat meat is seen in a variety of dishes. The shishito pepper appetizer are incredible. Overall a great Chicago spot, and one I am happy to give 5 stars to.

Wow, this place is amazing.

Came to eat here as a part of my spring break trip with a friend of mine (we were restaurant hopping at great places), and I LOVE this place. The waiter there was very, very knowledgeable and suggested all the right things, and answered all the questions we had. I was glad I listened to his suggestions. I had the prosciutto, and a couple of other things, all of which were good. I feel bad because I can't exactly remember the name of the dishes that I had. I was going to write the review after I got back from spring break which was in January, but the fact that I still wrote a escrow about this great place even after a couple of months hours to show that this place really leaves a good impression on you. Definitely recommended! It's suggested that you bring at least two friends if you want to try a bunch of different plates!

So not much to say here, lol. Amazing food, amazing drinks, amazing staff. Let's just say, I'm embarrassed at how often I eat here but if it were financially feasible,  I would come here at least twice a week!

Food is amazing and imaginative. Fun place to people watch. You just need to make reservations so much in advance. I enjoyed it but probably won't go back in a while. I prefer  Little Goat. It is more casual, less expensive, fun week night hipster place and kid friendly.

I really wanted to check this place out and figured with all the rave reviews of it would be busy. Then I discovered that it's the restaurant of a Top Chef winner, so thus even busier and more hype.  Disclaimer: I ate here about a week ago and I don't recall all the dishes.

First off, I went there on a Friday at 4 pm (which is when it opens) and it quickly became packed.

Service: unbelievable. My rocks sized glass never went empty. Not once.

Food: For two people, we ordered a salad and three meat dishes and it was the perfect amount.
- Beet salad: honestly, highlight of my meal. I don't even remember what was in it but I know it was crispy, fresh, and delish! I ate here a week ago and I'm still thinking about it.
- Pig's face: Served with an egg, this dish was so comforting for some reason. This was my favorite meat dish. And this was one of three that I had.
- Duck breast: Served with kimchee.
- Goat belly: Served with lobster, it was a delightful surprise.

Ok, I don't remember the details of the dishes, they were all great. The beet salad and pig's face was by far my favorite. It was agreed that the duck breast was our least favorite (but still delicious).

I'll definitely be back, update my review, and likely try Little Goat across the street (owned by the same chef).

Service was great, but the food was just beeeeh:) Not sure what the fuss is about. We tried almost everything on the menu, as we were in a group of 11. With every dish that came i was more and more disappointed. Mind not blown. Way overpriced too. Not my cup of tea. Some of my friends liked it, so i understand mine is just one person's opinion.
Love this place.  One of my all-time favorite restaurants ever!! Their diner location across the street is equally fantastic!
I would recommend this restaurant to all, the name is weird but the food is fabulous.. The service is very attentive..

Amazing! We took our server's suggestion and got 5 small plates. Everything is delicious and fresh. Wait staff was attentive. We ordered the beets, cauliflower, pierogies, pig face, and goat empanadas. Reservations are a must.

So, let me start by saying I did not make the reservations for this place. My colleague had made reservations and invited me and some fellow colleagues to dinner. His exact words were "you gotta come, it takes moths to get a reservation." Prior to the invitation I did not know anything about this restaurant but I quicly did some research and decided to give the place a try.

When I arrived I was asked to wait as my tables cleared. I, along with my colleagues was forced to wait about 20 minutes despite the fact that we had reservations. Once we were finally seated we were given the menu and the food looked delicious. I ended up getting the salmon but my colleagues got the pig face, which I hear is very tasty.

Overall I thought the food was very good and the service was acceptable besides the long wait for the table. The menu is delicious but the appetizer menu is underwhelming. For a restaurant that is in such a high demand amongst the affluent, the appetizer menu is suprisingly skimpy. This is the only reason I would take points away, besides the service.

Excellent!!!  My first experience was the best and I think my expectations are too high now. Food is always delicious and interesting though.

Hard to get a reservation. Usually a couple weeks out. If you go right when they open you can have dinner at the bar. That's usually what we do.

This old Goat still knows how to put out delicious food.  An oldie but goodie that always impresses.  The beet salad, fritters, pork shank and lamb ribs.  Those ribs tho.  Those ribs!!! Fall off the bone goodness, sticky gooey deliciousness.  I ordered some to go and murdered them before bed.  I mean, i expected lamb ribs to be lean with little to no meat but i was dead wrong.  Found my new guilty pleasure! Even the dessert was da bomb...aptly named the bomb i think.  When you're looking for next level food at less-than-alinea-prices, this is the place for you.  Steph (best friend in my head), i heart you.  You know what you're doing, Girl and the Goat is a true gem and must be experienced by all.  Be back soon! Located in the chic west loop area on randolph, there are tons of other good eats in the area but this is my diamond in an ecclectic rough.   So good!

In short, food was just OK and the restaurant was loud.  Certainly not worth the 5-6 month wait for a reservation.  Classic example of hype without the the product quality.  This area of the city has many other cool places that are better.  On the plus side, the service was very good.

I was at a loss for words eating my meal. All I could do was moan in satisfaction .
started with the ring of fire and smokey bandida. dope cocktail ideas very innovative and delicious af.
We had the charcuterie plate for starters which included goat liver foi gras and it was the most delectable delight of the whole dinner. Rich and creamy , light and smooth. It melted  in my tongue. with a thin layer of fat on top without any heaviness in all the decadence.

the goat carpaccio was amazing , perfectly balanced flavors in every bite. the grilled baby octopus was charred and tender . the pork shank was the main entree and while good, the least of my faves. definitely worth the hundreds we spent .
Great food. Great Bartenders and service! Goat Neck is on point as well as the kholrabi salad.

Food was absolutely delicious and I would definitely go back! Such a unique menu and the service was great. My favorite small plate was the mussels. What a treat!

I wish it wasn't so hard to get in because I would be here all the time.

Well, in the words of 4,000+ other reviewers, this place was AH-MAY-ZING!!! This was a unique experience, to say the least. So my good friend and I plan on going out for dinner one month in advance. Then, about 30 minutes before I need to pick her up I start Googling good dinner places. Since I'm an aspiring adventurous foodie and want to impress her with my choice, I start to feel the pressure. Thankfully, I found this place and when I mentioned it to her, she agreed and said she wanted to try this place out, too!

So we arrive about 7:30 pm on a Friday night. We had no idea that you needed reservations to be seated soon. We sign in and order drinks... we could talk for hours so we get a-talkin'. Then, we take a little break from standing and manage to snag a stool and corner of the couch. Then we upgraded ourselves to seats on the couch while we continue waiting... Total wait was about 3 hours - we're nuts, I know! But when you are one of two girls that waited to hang out for months and finally got out you would have waited, too!

Finally, the heavens open up and we get called. We close our bar tab (they insisted) and we head over to what are considered "one of the best seats of the house." I doubted it, but they really were. We got seated at the 2 person bar just to the left of the kitchen/food prepping area. Wow! Our server, Lee, was the absolute best! (Somebody give that girl a cookie or gold star.)

We get the run down on how the menu works, etc. We order a few dishes (pig face, hot peppers, pork belly...). Because of our "patience" they gave us a couple free dishes and a sampling of their dessert! We were blown away!!!

I immediately put in a reservation for my anniversary coming up in 6 weeks? I snagged a Saturday reservation, but at 10 pm - I'll take it! We got the same great service and honored our request to sit at the little bar. I will definitely go back and now I heard about The Little Goat across the street and I'm sure it's great!

Can't remember the last time we had a meal this good. Lives up to all the hype and more. We couldn't get a reservation forever so we just decided to eat early at 5 pm and really enjoyed the experience...kinda different but it was well worth it, and the service was terrific as well. Steph and her team are really doing some great things there!

We were so disappointed. We read such amazing reviews and thought about this our whole pre-trip. As soon as we walked in, we should have known that a huge restaurant like this would not have been an intimate dining experience. Our server didn't check on us once after any of the meals came. She (no joke) gave us the dessert menu as soon as our 3rd dish arrived when we said we thought we were getting full. She didn't explain or dive into any of the dishes or how they were prepared other than to say "veggie, fish...meat section". The ambiance is super cool. The place could have been great. Prices were very reasonable for the scene. Just felt rushed and the food/service were sub-par. Maybe we just expected too much??

Girl and the goat is truly worthy of all the praise. Somehow my girlfriend was fortunate enough to nab a 630 reservation on a Monday night and we finally got to eat here. Our server was awesome giving us suggestions on how to order.

We started with the kohlrabi salad which was the first time I've ever had an Asian inspired dish with cheese in it. The cheese was subtle and the salad fresh and flavorful. Wouldn't order again though.

The tortone was house made sourdough with cream cheese and pepita spread. It was solid but it was nothing compared to the onion bread dish which is a brioche bread. It is crispy on the outside kind of like a muffin and combined with the butter and sweet chutney, it was one of my favorites.

We got the escargot ravioli. And for 15 dollars you only get 4 ravioli which is kind of a bummer. The snails were tender with a nice light chew, and the bacon sauce with wonton crisps on top provided a savory crunch.

Next came the infamous pig face which was truly like bacon on steroids as another yelper mentioned. It was thicker, softer and more tender than my normal bacon experience. With the egg on top mixed in, it was a winner.

Final main course dish was the duck tongue. The tongue was cut and fried into small pieces. Each bit was light airy and fried perfectly. Mixed with the black bean and tuna sauce, it was a great way to finish off the main course.

Save room for dessert! The butterscotch budino is one of the best desserts I've had. I don't even know what a budino is, but it was like whipped butterscotch pudding-Amazing. The plantain cake was wonderful too!

Girl and the goat is awesome. I'll be eating onion bread and pig face in my dreams until the next visit.

Girl and The Goat was an amazing experience-- we had 10 plates between 5 of us and it was a good amount of food (we could have done with 8 perhaps) but the menu has so many wonderful things to choose from that we couldn't help ourselves! The service was outstanding.

This review is long overdue.
When I first planned my June trip to Chicago, the main restaurant I kept hearing about was Girl & the Goat.  It took months to finally get a reservation & I was thrilled to finally see what everyone was raving about.  I had heard great things about Stephanie Izard and was looking forward to trying out her restaurant.  We arrived for our 5:30 reservation on time and was seated promptly.  

Our waitress was a sweetheart, sadly I can't recall her name.  She did a great job explaining the menu and making suggestions on what the most popular dishes were at the restaurant.  We started off with a cucumber drink that was refreshing & not overly sweet.  Our waitress along with the rest of the staff kept checking on us throughout the meal and making sure we were ok.  While I truly appreciated the service, I wish I could say the same about the meal.  This had to be one of my most disappointing meals in a long time.  I hate to say it, but I fell for the hype.

The bread tasted as if it was baked solely in butter.  I'm usually a big fan of bread, but even I couldn't muster any enthusiasm regarding it.   Our waitress saw that we didn't like the bread and so she took it back and made suggestions regarding the other  bread listed on the menu.  Since we had already ordered a few other dishes, we told her it was fine & we would just wait for the other dishes to arrive.  The chickpea fritter soon arrived.  Out of all the dishes we ordered, this was the one I liked the best.  The chickpea was crispy and flavorful and blended well with the other flavors on the dish.  The next dish was the Grilled Baby Octopus, it was charred and left a bad aftertaste.  I'm a fan of Octopus, but this wasn't prepared well, it was too way charred to enjoy.  The goat was gamey and didn't have good flavor.  Lastly, the wood oven roasted pig face arrived.  I was so hoping that the meal could be salvaged with this last dish, but as the theme  continued for the whole evening, each dish got worse as we moved along.  Even though it's been months, I still remember this last dish.  The pork was soggy and you couldn't taste it because the egg overpowered the dish.

I chose this restaurant because of the four thousand reviews it had.  Most of the reviews claimed they loved the whole experience and how the food was absolutely delicious.  Unfortunately, I can't say the same.  The restaurant I was looking forward to the most for my whole trip, ended up being the most disappointing.  Girl & Goat, your staff was amazing, but food wise, I'm not a fan.

I'm just at a lost for words. I've always been a picky eater and had always been looking for a place with exploding flavours in their food. What can I say? Girl & the Goat seemed to go beyond my standards. Though the ingredients may sound like they won't work together, the blend of tastes creates such intense flavour that I fell in love at first bite. Man I sound like the rat from ratatouille, except I don't have his culinary talents.

Note though that I would highly recommend reserving a table. It's a highly popular restaurant and although it's quite a bit away from the city, it always seem to be packed. So definitely reserve and don't be surprised if you'll have to reserve 3 months or so in advance. It's THAT popular and for a good reason.

It's a family sharing kind of dining so all of the dishes are shared amongst yourselves. here are the dishes we've ordered:
[Wood-oven Roasted Pig Face]  [Crispy Beef Short Ribs]  [Chickpea Fritter]  [ Escargot Ravioli] & [Duck Tongues]
The best was definitely the [Duck Tongues] and [Wood-oven Roasted Pig Face]. Do keep in mind that some of these items are seasonal! For example, the [Crispy Beef Short Ribs] is definitely a winter only dish. Some of these dishes may sound a little scary, I mean duck tongues and pig face? But fear not! Although they may sound a little gnarly, we weren't actually served an entire pig face nor were we served with scary looking duck tongues! All of the dishes looked absolutely amazing and no where near scary. Once I took a bite, I forgot all about what I was eating but was just enjoying the deliciousness and the combinations of all the flavours.

I literally can't recommend this place enough. It's absolutely amazing with absolutely delicious dishes! Definitely give it a try no matter how far away and out of the way it is! Totally worth it, and to ensure a seat, make a reservation. Highly highly highly recommended.

This place definitely lived up to the hype. Before going to Chi town for a weekend getaway, I asked friends for restaurant suggestions. Girl and the Goat was suggested by all of them. It was meant to be when I was able to get reservations while we were there.

Here's what we ordered:

- hiramasa crudo - delicious! perfect mix of crunchy with cracker, freshness of the fish  and the pork belly was a nice touch
- fried oysters - who would've though egg salad and fried oysters  go well together? this was really good and pretty light for being fried
- grilled baby octopus - one of my fav dishes of the night! super flavorful with an amazing mix of textures using really fresh veggies and nuts and perfectly tender octopus
- roasted cauliflower - you can't go wrong with roasted cauliflower. the pine nuts were a nice touch
- goat empanadas - this was the least favorite dish. too gamey
- grilled pork ribs - perfectly tender, meat-falls-off-the-bone pork ribs with a delicious sauce
- pigs face - didn't know what to expect when we ordered this but was pleasantly surprised. it was delicious! we just wish it didn't come at the end when we were all super full

the desserts were a little disappointing. we got the red tea creme brulee and berry cobbler. we weren't super impressed by them and didn't finish them. you know a dessert isn't good when it's not gone.

prices were pretty reasonable, drinks were good and service was great. i wish they would open one in LA so i can eat here all the time!

Food is delicious and service was excellent. Our server was able to snag the last Roasted Pig's Face for us the night we went - which is a MUST TRY. I was pleasantly surprised about the chickpea fritters, really loved it!

Make reservations! I made mine 2 months ahead and still was only able to get a 9pm time slot.

It was the best food we(family of 3) have ever had. Then while we were waiting for the check, our waiter brought us a dessert on the house which knocked our socks off! The service was amazing! The food was amazing, waiting for food was never even thought of. Go to this restaurant!!!
This was written by my 11 year old daughter and she's very picky. My wife and I couldn't agree more.

This restaurant will blow your mind! The service is not over the top yet perfectly mindful, the atmosphere is clean and fun, last the food oh the food....... The ingredients are bold yet delicately handled if that makes any sense. The oven roasted pork is moist and perfectly seasoned. The brussel sprouts are unforgettable! I strongly suggest you try this place everyone in our party was happy including my boy friend whom is never happy with steaks at restaurants and his he said was cooked perfect. All together one of our favorite places to eat thus far. If we lived here we would be regulars!

After a 5 hour wait on Friday night I was seated with four of my friends for what I was sure would be a fantastic birthday dinner. Girl & the Goat of course did not disappoint.

We were able to get in the bar area around 9 on Friday and ordered from a small but delicious and diverse cocktail menu. Although they were unable to make me a gin egg white cocktail, which I was dying for I ordered a Thai one on which was an incredible and sweet rum and brandy drink that packed a serious punch. I enjoyed every solitary sip of this cocktail and my friends seemed to be enjoying their as well.

When we were seated we went through the menu and had to narrow down our choices. The menu is large and diverse and full of delicious sounding items. We picked a bread, an oyster, two veggies, two fish dishes, two meats and a goat dish. I was pumped.

The johnny applecheese bread was served first with a cheese butter and malt vinegar and arrived warm and fresh to the table. I would lick the cheese out of the dish and order two more loaves of bread. Off to an amazing start.

Next our oysters arrived, they were fresh tasting and my friends liked them a lot but I just didn't enjoy that they were warm. I would however, absolutely try the other varieties they offer.

Here is the real sad thing about Girl & the Goat, the veggie dishes are so insanely good that when you finish them and get to the meat dishes, even though you are absolutely stuffed you still want more of that insanely delicious cauliflower. That is a standard and if you don't get it there is something wrong with you. We also had the goat cheese pierogies. Rich and delicious and holy crap yummy.

Next came the fish dishes. Grilled baby octopus and calamari bruschetta. The octopus had a great cook and rich flavors. The calamari bruschetta was nuts, at this point I was so drunk from yet another strong drink I was enjoying but I can surely remember that the presentation was great and the flavors spot on - a highlight.

After that we did a "dual of tongues" by ordering both the beef and duck tongue dishes. The duck was interesting, cut in strips and fried and the tuna in the dish was spot on, would absolutely order again. The beef tongue I remember being good, but I also can't really remember it, so let's just say it was the miss of the evening.

Our last savory was the goat belly. I can't even start with this dish. The fat from the belly and then it is literally SWIMMING in a crab, lobster, fennel butter sauce. I would sop this up with that cheese bread and then I would die and go straight to Heaven and BEG for a stair master. Literally one of the most delicious dishes in the entire city of Chicago and I have had some things.

For our last course we ordered both the pb&j and the seasonal apple dessert. I am telling you, run to get that apple dessert. I ordered a sauterne to go with it and it was the icing on a perfect birthday dinner. oh, and the pb&j was delectable as well. The wait staff is also friendly and the service is prompt. These dishes were a ton of food but also a great amount for a table of 5 people and all and all when split that many ways is a great price. The hype is absolutely real, if you love food, the goat is a spot you must check out, even if you wait 5 hours, you will not regret it.

Oh man... what a great experience.  For out of town visitors we were able to pull reservations even though we heard of the possible 2 month waiting list... and entered with little problem and seated promptly as we always arrive on time.  Service was beyond excellent with an upbeat trendy vibe.  I could write pages on the food but that should be something experienced and not read. Words don't do great food justice. If u find yourself in Chicago, squeeze in some time for the girl and the goat they're so baaadddd...

I live in Saint Louis and come to Chicago often for both business and pleasure. Every time I've been in the Windy City for the last two years I have tried to get a reservation here at the Girl & the Goat. Each time I was meet with disappointment, as no tables were available.  This visit I was determined to get my G&TG fix.

I already had an early dinner at one of Chicago's chic new restaurants, but thought why not at least visit the Girl & the Goat for a cocktail. My hotel was only a mile from the restaurant, so I enjoyed a  nice evening stroll. When I arrived, I shared my story with the host and said I just wanted to sit at the bar to experience Girl & the Goat.

When I took my seat at the bar, I knew I was in trouble. The aroma of the food, the hustle and bustle of the servers going by with incredible looking plates was so tempting. How was I only going to have a cocktail?

I glanced over the cocktail menu and being a fan of vodka I quickly ordered a "4 in the same". After my bartender presented me with my refreshing cocktail, he asked if I'd like to see a food menu. I responded, "sure why not". I figured it couldn't hurt, but boy I was wrong. Once I started reading, the more I wanted to eat dinner again.
I knew I could not eat big, but now I really wanted to eat at least "something".

Being a big fan of mussels, I thought that would be a safe and good way to go. They serve their steamed mussels with "goat sausage croutons", which are amazing. I loved the mussels, they were huge and the croutons had flavor beyond belief. I have never had goat before, and now I can not wait till my next time. The croutons and the mussels were a perfect tease until my next visit.

pics.caption: Steamed Mussels with goat sausage croutons, cilantro, Ceasar.

review.des:
Considering the hype and accolades- my boyfriend and I were lucky to snatch a dinner slot the night of, at 11 pm. I guess people make reservations well in advance. Although it was a late dinner it was worth it.

We started with the goat empanadas- since goat is in the name. It was tender meat stuffed inside the flaky crust...but the pico de gallo on top of the avocado was an interesting accompaniment. I would have opted for something else on the side.

He got the calamari bruschetta. We've tried numerous calamari appetizers, and a variety of bruschetta... yet this one was identifiable unique. The creamy goat milk ricotta mixed with the charred calamari was a delicious fusion.

I got the chili shrimp with cayenne and sweet corn mesquites. The cayenne sauce complimented the sweet corn very well. The shrimp were grilled to perfection with a bold smokiness.

A harmonious and experimental blend of flavors. The hype is self-explanatory.

This restaurant deserves 5 stars hands down. SO GOOD. Mad respect to the executive chef and Top Chef winner, Stephanie Izard.

We made a reservation 2 days before, and the only time left was 11:45pm on Friday (I didn't know ahead of time how busy this place gets). We decided to walk in on Friday at around 8:50 to see if we'd have better luck. The wait was supposed to be 1 hr 45 min, so we found a seat at the bar. Decided to grab a couple light dishes to start: ham frites and chickpea fritter. Both were very good. We could tell right away this was going to be a good experience. After about 1.5hrs, we got seated. Here's what we got and the order it came out:

Pan roasted halibut - amazing! Literally every ingredient just melded together and worked so well. We cleaned the plate, including the garnishes.

Confit goat belly - my first time trying goat. I was hesitant because I don't like gamy meat (like lamb), and I just had this perception that goat would be way to gamy for me. But oh man, this was cooked so perfectly. If you ever want to try goat, this is the place to do it. Crispy on the outside, soft on the inside. And the garnishes, again, really enhanced the dish.

Pig face - this was surprisingly my least favorite of the night. Just didn't do it for me. Maybe I don't like eating fat as much as most people here on Yelp). I just can't eat fat. And pig face had a lot of fat. A lot.

Crisp braised pork shank - this was also very good. Crispy on the outside. Meat just falls of the bone. Came with two sauces, kimchee, and naan. I wish it came out earlier cuz we didn't do it justice. We were so full by now we couldn't finish it.

Miso-butterscotch budino - what is this and why is it so good? A lot of people were ordering this, and the waiter said it's the most popular dessert on the menu, so we tried it. Wow. So many flavors that worked so well together. Cake, butterscotch, bacon toffee, pineapple, cashew. Perfect blend of sweet, tart, and salt.

I can easily say this is one of the best restaurants I've ever been to in my life. A little on the pricier side but worth it.

Last night's meal was a disappointment. We were here a couple of years ago for my birthday and the meal was fantastic...then. However tonight's meal was exceedingly salty, the dishes seem far less inspired, and the surly waitress was clearly interested in our eating and leaving quickly to free up her table, which we did not do!

First and foremost we ordered fried oysters which never came to the table; spirits and alcohol were yummy but the bread course was utterly bland.

Baby octopus was tough and bland and the ancho pepper dish is boring and not very tasty. I will say the chicken course was delicious and so was the cauliflower but as dishes continued to come out of the kitchen they excited us less and less. The best part of the meal was dessert after which we hung out and conversed for 45 minutes to the chagrin of the waitress. I say when you're paying $300 for a four- person meal you should not be rushed out -- and we took it upon ourselves to ignore how we were clearly being ushered out of the restaurant, and we lingered. Too damn bad -- there were plenty of tables still open at 9:45 PM so buzz off!

As we gathered our things and left, the one thing that came to mind was how much more inspired the food is and how much more I love Izzard's restaurant across the street "Little Goat" with none of the fanfare and all of the taste!

This is what a restaurant should be. Pricey, but good food and a real treat.

The only problem is that getting a reservation is a pain....
The the corned beef hash is insane, once my husband I took our kids there and we literally got 4 orders of the corned beef hash.
Food wasn't bad, but definitely not worth the price or the small portions. I've heard nothing but good things about this place, but it was pretty disappointing.
Incredible service to match the food, a must if you can get a reservation! The drinks are also spectacular.

Everything was absolutely incredible.  My fiance and I arrived for our 5:15pm reservation, and were delighted with the surprise of sitting at the chef's table.  Win!  

The cocktails were perfect, food was divine, atmosphere super fun, and service outstanding.  We'll definitely be back!

I had a reservation for this place in LATE MAY... made back in FEBRUARY. And I would say that the wait was absolutely worth it. (I've heard from others that you can call and try to get last-minute reservations from cancellations.) Despite the fact that we were crowded in elbow-to-elbow and overhearing other patrons' snarky comments ("I am morally opposed to taking pictures of food," said one as I pulled out my iPhone for a quick Instagram snap), I had a very lovely experience here with my boyfriend.

I verrry much enjoyed the roasted beets, especially with the extra crunchiness from the bread crumbs! The goat carpaccio was a well-balanced dish with a tinge of sweetness from the maple vinaigrette. At the recommendation of the waitress we also got the tempura-fried sugar toads (puffer fish), which were crispy as well as tender. And of COURSE everyone here on Yelp raves about the pig face (contrary to my expectations, you do not get served a pig head... I have no idea where I got that impression). The plantain cake dessert was diviiiiine, a wonderful concoction with cold and warm textures, and creamy and tart flavors.

Hooray for Stephanie Izard!

One of my favorite restaurants!
I have recommended it to many of my friends and they loved it!
When I first went here I was little bit intimidated with some of the dishes and the ingredient that went in.  For me I like trying new things but I was a bit scared.  
I tried it and it was honestly so amazing! We tried many different dishes in the menu since its kind of a tapas restaurants.
I like this place because food is good and interesting.  It is out of the ordinary.
Lot of people go here and I like the ambiance. Not classy but more like a loud bar with really really good food! haha
However I did have one friend that told me it was a little bit too salty and her and her family did not enjoy it.

Love:
- extensive cocktail/wine/beer list
- knowledgable and attentive waitresses
- their dishes are tapas sized and sharable
- menu is divided by veggies, meat, seafood, etc
- I love my cider
- PIG FACE - with sunny side egg, tamarind, cilantro, red wine-maple, potato stix. They instruct you to destroy it completely to oblivion...
- ARCTIC CHAR!
- SCALLOPS!
- Goat carpaccio was not gamey and was surpringly tasty
- DUCK TONGUES! SO GOOOOOOD. I still dream about it.
- Save room for dessert -- gelato, cheese galore

If you know you're going to Chicago, make reservations ASAP!

lifeonmacro.wordpress.co…

My friend and I got to the restaurant at 6pm on a Thursday night, and it was an hour wait. However, the servers also suggested waiting at the bar area because they also serve food there as well. We were able to find empty couch space and ordered our food. Our server tells us that we would need to order about 3-4 dishes for two. But we only ordered two things, as dishes are very pricey here.

We started off with the hamachi. This was just ok. I thought there was too much sauce and the pork belly was too salty. And our next dish was the pig's head. It was really flavorful and I liked it. However, the party next to us did not like it at all. They claimed it was too fatty for them. They really enjoyed their green beans though.

There is a reason this place is rated so high on every review source you seek out. It's not only one of the best in Chicago but one of the best in the country/world (and I've been luckily enough to eat and drink in over 65 counties). The best part, it's not pretentious in the slightest. Good food, food flavor, perfect balance. The goat empanadas and oven roasted pig face are arguably the best dishes on the menu, but all hold up as "wow worthy."

Make reservations for a special occasion or any random Tuesday. It's worth it.
Not a fan of goat going in, just had apps and cocktails, and was swayed! Will be back for more:)

Great meal, drinks and service. We were sat facing the kitchen  - all the staff near us were friendly and offered recommendations of their favourite dishes. It was fun to watch them piece them together.

I wasn't too keen on the legendary pig face though, to be honest!

I was lucky to get a reservation the day of, so it was meant to be!  The food was so creatively prepared and delicious.  Kudos to the chefs!
We tried so many dishes, and none disappointed.  The goat wasn't even gamey.  I definitely want to come back again during my stay in Chicago.

Outstanding food, great service and delicious drinks. One of my favorite restaurants. Only con is you need to reserve a table weeks in advance. It is well worth it. The oysters were west coast, creamy and refreshing. The ravioli had an escargot filling which was very rich and tasty. The goat empanadas and skewers did steal the show. The desert was great too, just ate it so quickly that I was not able to take a picture of it.

My husband and I went to the Girl and the Goat after waiting a little over three months for our reservation - It was worth the wait.  Wow!  Our reservation was on a Monday night at 6:30 and you would have thought it was a Saturday night.  The place was packed.

We ordered diver scallops, crispy duck tongues, kalbi style beef ribs, wood oven roasted pig face, bread with pecan butter and apple butter, confit goat belly with lobster and crab and smoked goat rilette empanadas.  My favorite was between the scallops and the goat empanadas.   My husband's favorite was the beef ribs.   Although they were my favorite dish of the night, they were the best ribs that I have ever had hands down.   The duck tongues were great.  I loved the roasted pig face - so delicious!!  The pecan butter and apple butter with bread was also delicious, almost like dessert.  I also loved the goat belly with lobster and crab!     We did not have actual dessert because we were happily full.

The service here is excellent.   Our waitress was extremely attentive and offered good recommendations.   Stephanie Izard was there and it was cool to see her and get a picture with her as I am an avid Top Chef fan!

I highly recommend this restaurant!   Plan ahead!  You may have to wait several months :)

Great service and great atmosphere. My favourite dish was the goat empanadas!!
I was able to get a seat at bar right at 4:30 without a  reservation. It's best to arrive at 4:15 and once it's 4:30, you seat yourself at bar.

This is a bit overdue... but that place deserves all the praise they can get! The ambiance, people, knowledge, service, drinks and the food... ahhh, the food. Everything is superb!

I threw my birthday party in their private room downstairs a couple months back. Had 19 people and one of the best nights of my life. Yes, it's pricey, but YES, it's worth it - SOOO worth it! Every bite was worth it!

The whole process of finding out info/pricing, food options/pairings, drink options, minimums, limits, etc. and then actually booking, was very smooth & easy. Communication with Ashley and Brandi was great and they answered my questions very quickly. Then a couple months passed, and March came.. and it was the day to celebrate. No snow storms can keep me, or my family and friends, away!

When I got there, I was warmly greeted and taken downstairs, had a little bit of time to get the room decorated (you can bring balloons and some signs, etc - it made it so much more intimate/personable). Then I was introduced to my waiter for the evening, one of the nicest people I met in the industry, Gary (thanks SO MUCH for everything that evening, Gary - and thanks for letting me throw confetti all over the place!).

Full bar (so many delicious sips, by glass or bottle!), 13 course menu (some of the best food I ever had - everything was made to perfection!), amazing company & incomparable service, made the night one that I will always remember.

Thank you G&TG - I will definetely be back, as soon as I can get in :)

pics.caption: Just a sample off of a 13 course menu... deliciousness in every bite! yum!

review.des:
I was brought here by my wife for my birthday. Gotta say, it was pretty amazing.

First, the reservations - she made a reservation for March in November, and STILL couldn't get her preferred time slot. So plan far ahead.

I will start with the only real negative of the meal, which was the very beginning before being seated. We always arrive promptly for reservations, and we did again this day. Do most restaurants not expect this? Because we STILL had to wait 20 minutes for our table to be ready, and the waiting area is not comfortable at all.

Ok, but moving on, pretty freaking great. Drinks. I had a very old fashioned. Strong, well made, consistent flavor throughout. I don't remember what my wife had, but she liked both. Importantly, the waitress recommended the first cocktail based on our food orders, and it went very well with the first few dishes to come out. Beer list is small - stick to wine or cocktails.

Food was good, much as expected. Remember they are small plates - we had 5 dishes for 2 people, plus dessert. Oysters were well done, hamachi crudo as well. In terms of size, the brocolli dish we had was actually large, and DELICIOUS. Wood fired with rice crispies and blue cheese. Get it. Pig face was very fatty, flavorful. Not life changing, but worth trying. The sweet potato pierogies were forgettable, skip them.

For dessert, we ordered the goat cheesecake. My god, how well done. Very sweet, nicely salty. Came with these little 'kisses' that tasted so bitter from the beer mash. When mixed with the cake, it was phenomenal. They brought me something for my birthday, too! A squash cake. Sincerely one of the best desserts I have ever had, although I was pretty sauced by then. Highly recommend.

Service was consistent and good throughout. Waitress had thoughtful recommendations, was personable when she spoke and sparse when not needed.

All in all, very impressed. If you can get a table, I definitely recommend.

I've been here twice now, and both times have been such a treat. I highly recommend coming with a bigger group (4) people, because you can share more plates and try more dishes. Couple dishes that I highly recommend: the duck tongue & the roasted pig head. Both were savory, perfectly cooked, and delicious. The challah bread is very good. Even though we ordered 8 dishes, those three were the standouts in my mind. I also had the very old fashioned, which was boozy and delicious.
Service is also on point! Servers consistently brought clean dishes between the shared plates, and our waitress kept up with our ordering of new food, questions & drink orders.

I had a very enjoyable dinner. I would recommend the pork face, confit goat belly, and mt. lassen trout. The sauteed string beans is a very generous portion and it was very filling. beet salad was also very good. Ended the night with miso-butterscotch budino - loved the candied pineapple.

pics.caption: beet salad (loved the hint of lemon). I mixed it up before taking the picture...it looked a lot better when it arrived

review.des:
Girl & the Goat is effing uh-mazing.

This was everything it was hyped up to be. The dining experience is unlike anywhere I've been. Our first time here and we had the chance to sit at the chef's table - highly recommended if you want to experience awesomeness in the making. You are literally 1 foot away from the kitchen and get to see the food go from nothing to something. As a fan of Top Chef, I was super stoked to be able to dine at a winner's real estate.

1. Make reservations.
I hear people book dates up to a month in advance - I got lucky and found a reservation one day in advance. If you have a table of two, request the chef's table :D

2. Order multiple dishes.
I'd recommend a bread, 2 veggies, and 2 meats or 1 fish and 1 meat - all for a table of two. Those 4-5 dishes are somewhat small portions but lets you sample multiple flavor profiles. I'd recommend the sautéed green beans, pan fried shishito peppers, wood oven roasted pig face, gouda bacon bread.
