3. Finish with dessert.
The plantain cake is impressive. I enjoyed every single scrumptious bite. The cake (banana flavored) is topped with chocolate chip ice cream, then surrounded by passion fruit sauce. The dessert was not too sweet, and was perfectly balanced with the tartness from the passion fruit. Great combination. It's like peanut butter & jelly round 2, or burgers with pickles x 1000 - it just works.

This place is a must try - not if you're in Chicago, but in your entire lifetime. It's no surprise everyone talks about Girl & the Goat.

pics.caption: Green beans are a must have.
Wood oven roasted pig face. Chef's table view included.

review.des: The food on the whole was solid. Goat Belly was highlight, but overall, everything was extremely salty. They very nice, however, to accommodate me and allow me to bring in an outside birthday cake. It's a fun and obviously popular spot, but did not deliver on the hype. I would pass on this next time.

Like this place doesn't need more reviews. This is a MUST GO TO PLACE.

My cousin made reservations about 1 month in advance for a Monday at 6:30 pm. When we arrived there were people waiting trying to get into the place. This is a trendy location but may need a tad bit more lighting. I had to use my phone to see the menu.

We tried...

- Bread bread bread! Freshly baked bread with homemade spreads - ugh, so good
--- there was hair in our spread and we informed our waitress. She took the plate back and gave us more bread and spread. A moment later, the manager comes out apologizing. Now that's great service.

- Hamachi Crudo - fresh and tender raw fish that complimented the crispy pork belly and caperberries. This dish kept me wanting more.

- Grilled Baby Octopus - this wasn't under cooked or overcooked... It was cooked to perfection! The flavors blended well. I especially liked tangy taste from the vinaigrette and the crunch from the pistachios.

- Seared Diver Scallops - the scallops were delicious with the uni cream. I just wished the scallops weren't so chopped up.

- Goat Liver Mousse - Goat is an acquired taste, especially goat liver. I usually have no problem eating liver but this goat liver was something else. The liver mousse was smooth and creamy, however, the flavor was too strong and rich for me and the rest of the party except for my boyfriend. He was happy he didn't have to share.

- Goat Carpaccio - thinly sliced and seasoned well so I didn't quite tasted that goat taste.

- Goat Leg - This was SOLD OUT! I am coming back just to try this!!

The meal was spectacular and the service was excellent. Definitely coming back here the next time I'm in Chicago just to try the rest of the menu (especially that goat leg). Chef Stephanie, you're amazing.

Outstanding food, great service and delicious drinks. One of my favorite restaurants. Only con is you need to reserve a table weeks in advance. It is well worth it. The oysters were west coast, creamy and refreshing. The ravioli had an escargot filling which was very rich and tasty. The goat empanadas and skewers did steal the show. The desert was great too, just ate it so quickly that I was not able to take a picture of it.

I'm going to give this place another try. Don't get me wrong, this place is great and delicious but I believe my date and I just chose the wrong combo of dishes to eat from. My review is honest but please make your own opinion of this place!

The ambiance is great. I loved the lighting and the over all energy of the place. If you look around you can see across the restaurant and see the oven and the kitchen bustling. You can also see lounge areas where people are sitting on couches and eating. The restaurant has a range of seating, from the intimate tables for 2, to huge parties having a good time.

The wait wasn't long at all, and I went on a Saturday. The service was great and the price of the food reflect the care and love they put into it. I personally left a little bit unsatisfied due to portion sizes and I discovered the pig face dish wasn't for me. but hey! I love being adventurous!

Simply excelent. One of the best dinners ever. Everything is tasty and well done. We tasted four different plates and all of them were awesome. The service is correct and efficient. Will go back many times

Believe the hype! This place is legitimately one of the best restaurants I have ever been to in Chicago. It was perfect from beginning to end! I started with the "Best of Three" cocktail. It tasted and smelled awesome! My group treated the food as a Tapas so I will put down my favorites. I found reading Yelp reviews helped me pick out the right dishes!

Pig Face (not as gross as it sounds)
Lamb Ribs
Sauteed Green Beans
Ham Frittes
Pan Fried Peppers
Potstickers
Any of the Desserts!

I wasn't a big fan of the fish dishes, but then again I am not a big fish eater! Our server was phenomenal and recommend the perfect amount of food. I also liked that she came off as sincere and not a pretentious hipster.

The only real downside I could find was the price. Some things are worth the money, but a $9 Alagash is a little out there! I would rather give this more like 4.5, but I would give it the benefit of the doubt!

Believe me, it is that good!

Ok, I get it. I get why this place is so hard to get into. Everything is delicious, every dish is thought out and perfectly homogenous. I really do get it.
Make a reservation though, no place is worth waiting 2 hours to eat.

This is probably going to be the longest review I've ever written. Cliff's notes at the bottom. We visited G&TG twice in a four-day trip to Chicago recently after the first meal was one of the best meals of our lives from a food, service and atmosphere perspective.

The only reservation they had available for our entire trip was at 10:45pm on Friday. We get there and our table is the best in the house, looking right into the kitchen. The cooks talked to us throughout our whole meal and were an entertainment act in their own right.

First we ordered the goat empanadas with a Harissa aioli, grilled blueberries and a summer slaw. Then we got goat cheese and sweet corn dumplings with tzatziki, eggplant, peach and sungold tomatoes. Then the most popular item on the menu: the wood oven roasted pig's face with sunny side up egg, tamarind, cilantro, red wine maple sauce and potato sticks.

Our waitress sent us over a free order of sautéed green beans with fish sauce vinaigrette and cashews. We order a half portion of dessert, which was bittersweet chocolate cake with some macerated raspberries and basil gelato. Waitress sends us an order of her favorite dessert: butterscotch pudding with sautéed apples, whipped cream and cocoa powdered cashews. Everything was phenomenal. So naturally we had to come back two nights later.

On our second trip, we ordered the fried duck tongues with tuna and black bean poke, crispy wontons, and piri piri chilis. Next, we got the pan roasted halibut with almond butter, white asparagus and blueberries. Then the wood grilled broccoli with smoky bleu cheese and spiced rice krispies on top. Next, the roasted cauliflower with pickled peppers, pine nuts and mint. Then the confit goat belly with bourbon butter, lobster, crab, and fennel. We finished it up with an order of the peach and blueberry crumble with a honey graham cake and goat cheese gelato.

Cliff's notes: Everything we ate the entire time was phenomenal. Our favorites were the goat empanadas, the pig's face, the duck tongues, and the peach/blueberry crumble. I wish I could eat here every day. Giving this place a five-star review makes me want to go back through my old five-star reviews and make them all four-star reviews.

pics.caption: wood grilled broccoli with smoky bleu cheese and spiced rice krispies on top
pan roasted halibut with almond butter, white asparagus and blueberries
fried duck tongues with tuna and black bean poke, crispy wontons, and piri piri chilis

review.des:
We were visiting from DC and obviously wanted to get the best foodie experience while in Chitown. This was hands down one of the best.
To be honest I'm not a fan of oysters, but I actually enjoyed their oysters- super flavorful with something of such an eeky texture.
The pork belly, was deliciously cooked and so so flavorful.
The calamari bruschetta was such a unique combination , and oh so yummy! It wasn't chewy and tasted delicious with the goats milk ricotta AND goat bacon- yes yes yes!
Finally the Goat Ribs- save the best for the last! They slid off the bone. I'm not kidding they just glided off. Once off the bone we were advised to mix everything together- sauces, and slaw with the meat.
It was deliciousness in my mouth! Between three people the ribs were a pretty sizeable portion.
The PB and J cake was a yummy dessert to finish off such a meaty meal. It literally tastes like a classic PB and J Sammie, and the peanut butter icecream is something unique and so tasty that I'd have it by itself too!

pics.caption: Slide off the bone goat ribs

review.des: Until we ate here, I wasn't sure this place was worth the hype--but it is. The restaurant is busy, loud, and fun. Our server was knowledgeable and charming. The food was fantastic. This place is well worth the trip.

Now this is the type of restaurant I really like.  The kind with sharing plates, so you get to try a bunch of dishes or just have a reason to pig out.  I've been wanting to try G&G since the joint opened and glad I did.  The food, the service, everything was great.  It sucked that it took a 2 month reservation to get a table, but not a big deal.  I also tried randomly going without a reservation on a weekend night and there was a 3 hour wait.  Yup this place gets packed!

Their menu is exciting, with a lot of interesting dishes to try.  It was tough not ordering the entire menu, but we still ended up ordering a lot.  Order a few large plates and a bunch of small plates.

My favorites:
- Old Fashioned Bread w/ bourbon butter & orange-thyme marmalade - freshly baked bread and tasty spread.
- Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face
- Sauteed Green Beans
- Hiramasa Crudo w/ crisp pork belly
- Fried Pemaquid Oysters w/ egg salad & capers
- Escargot Ravioli
-  Confit Goat Belly w/ lobster n' crab & bourbon butter

The Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face was so damn delicious!  The only downside is the dish only has a few bites.  Next time I'll know to get a second serving.  Can't wait to go back and see what's new!

I have been dying to go to GATG for ages. We stopped in around 7 on a Monday to pick up a gift card for a Christmas present and decided to try and get a table. Great tip: if you have a small party (we were just 2), you can sit at the bar! We sat within 10 minutes of sitting down.

The food was nothing short of spectacular- so inventive, unique and flavorful! We tried:

-Cheese bread with tomato jam and ham butter: the ham butter was one of my favorite parts of the whole meal! If I could spread it on every bread ever that would be ideal. The tomato jam was good acidic addition.
-shishito peppers: WOW. Great bang for your buck, a lot of peppers come in an order. The parm and miso work in a way you'd never expect. Some are spicier than others, and it balances out to a great, even heat
-chickpea salad: the yogurt dressing contrasts really well with the hot chickpea fritters and crunchy salad
-pork shank: pork was unbelievably tender, just falls off the bone. This was the least adventurous of the items we ordered, but the quality is undeniable
-ham frites: this is the only thing I wouldn't order again, they're basically fries. You get a huge serving though, so it would be good for a group.

Overall, 100% recommend this, but I'm sure You didn't need to read another review to tell you that.

I think this place is overhyped. The staff left something to be desired. Everyone I encountered was aloof and not overtly friendly which completely contradicts every single other dining experience I've had in downtown Chicago this trip.

We were excited to try this place after seeing it atop all the "best of" lists. Be aware that the meals are not meals. They're more a la carte servings. We were told for four people we'd need to order 8-10 plates.

The bread was good, veggie plates were okay, meat plates were good. Nothing was outstanding. No reason to be as hyped as it is.

The decor is very nice and this place seems great for parties. The only thing I didn't like was the table my family and I sat in. We had a party of 8 and we sat in a very large table so it was very hard for us to talk to each other since we had to scream at each other in order for us to hear one another since the atmosphere was really loud. The food portion is small and I mean small. Comparing this dish size to diner's dish size the portion is literally 1/3 of it. If you're going to this restaurant as a party if feels as if everyone takes one bite out of each dish and it's completely gone. The food quality is good, the only thing that really disappointed me was the escargot ravioli. It's a small ravioli with only one small escargot in it and it tasted quite bland. I expected much more flavor. I really recommend the calamari. It was very tasty  that my family and I devoured it. Another thing I recommend is the sauteed green beans which was also very tasty. I would only come here if I was invited to a party but otherwise this place didn't meet my expectations.
Overrated in a big way.  The combos of mains and sides don't work.  The dishes don't even look good.  I don't understand why anyone goes to this place.

Girl & the Goat is a really beautiful restaurant. It is located on Randolph / Halsted. My friend and I went there a month ago, and we really love it. The atmosphere, food, and service were really nice. I am thinking to go there again for sure.
I read the about Girl & the Goat on the internet, and people wrote good things about the restaurant. My friends and I got there and we already love the place from outside. The size of the restaurant is not that big but they can fit a lot of people in there. The cool thing was you can sit in front of the kitchen if you'd like. The kitchen is surrounded by clear glasses as a culinary arts student I liked seeing the kitchen from where I sitting. When you walk in the first thing you see is the reception and the bar. I really liked the bar. For example, the background of the bar is all covered with alcohol bottles. The only thing I didn't really about the atmosphere was the lights. It is kind of low and that's what makes the restaurant little bit darker.
The system of service is Russian style. The food comes to the middle of the table, so you cannot just order for yourself. That is why people usually order a lot of things so they can taste everything. We ordered a bunch of stuff but my favorites are the duck tongues, crispy beef short ribs, mussels and calamari bruschetta.  I was in love with their desserts. Their presentation and the taste was amazing. There were four choices and we tried all of them. My favorite was the chocolate mousse.
The servers are extremely nice to you, which is awesome. They're very helpful with everything. For example, it was our first time there and we didn't know what to get and he told us which ones are the best ones. He always provided his recommendations. After we ordered our foods, our server brought us olive oil and bread, they were so delicious. Moreover, the service was really fast, I liked how the foods came really fast.
I highly recommend everyone to go there. The atmosphere, food, and service are amazing. By the way, we made a reservation a week before we went there because the restaurant is usually packed and it is really hard to find seats without a reservation. Just don't forget to make a reservation before you go, and the price range is from $15 to $30. It can be a very salty check if you go just by yourself or with someone else. I recommend people to go there with a big group of people.

Finally! I've tried to come here on numerous occasions, but due to Girl & the Goat's overwhelming popularity, reservations need to be planned over a month in advance to have dinner at a normal time.

Well... here's a tip. If you don't mind eating early or late, you can probably just walk in without a reservation at around 4:30 PM or 11:30 PM and get seated pretty quickly.

Service: impeccable, friendly, drinks always filled without asking, and waiter offered great recommendations
Decor: rustic yet classy, wooden tables, open concept kitchen
Food: farm to table, tapas, freaking delicious

We were told it's typically two dishes per person. We ordered 7 dishes between two people and we finished everything. We were super stuffed, but super satisfied. The menu changes regularly and I honestly think you really can't go wrong with any of the items on Girl & the Goat's menu. Even dishes that you might be skeptical about will win you over with one bite.

Finally got a chance to come here last night! I made reservations about a year ago (just kidding it was only 3 months ago) but it was well worth the wait.

Started off with their famous bread app, it was good, I mean it was bread with some relish spread, alright, pretty interesting..

Then We moved to their fennel salad which was good.

Baby Octopus was very good, highly recommend.

We also had the goat empanadas, pretty good.

The show stopper was the shank. The shank was sooo good! It's a lot of food, so if you get it, just be ready to eat a lot...

I'll definitely be back next time I can plan a dinner 3-4 months out in advance.

Just the thing the Girl and the Goat needs--another rambling 5-star review! Sarcasm aside, there are a lot of reasons why G&G has such great ratings; I'll make this quick.

Food: Definitely some of the best in the city.

Must orders:
Italian Grandfather cocktail (they get set on fire and have booze to last the whole meal)
Halibut (flavor is amazing, cooked perfectly)
Short Ribs (could eat sooo many of these)
Chocolate Truffle Cake (if you like coconut--it's like a delicious take on a Mound's bar)

Honorable mentions: Beet salad (subtle, but great), Goat belly (very rich) Miso Butterscotch Budino (very caramel-y)

Wait time: 0 minutes. I called at 2:30pm on a Tuesday and was able to place a reservation for 2 for the same night. Date and I came early, expecting to hang at the bar for a bit, but we were seated right away at the chef's table. Unique experience--got to chat up the chefs and the staff!

Service: Outstanding, bend-over-backwards good. Ended up receiving several plates courtesy of the kitchen.

Girl and the Goat--worth the trip! If you have the flexibility, try calling 48 hrs or less in advance for a table--there are usually cancellations.

Delicious and unique food.

I would recommend making a reservation because the wait time without it will be long. But it is totally worth every second of the wait.

You will not get a reservation unless you call light years in advance.  But 10:15pm is usually open but note, the kitchen will rush your food out because they all wanna go home by 11:15.  There are cabs parked outside to take you home if you don't have a car.  

Warning, this is a very gluttonous eating.  Prepare yourself for fatness and high cholesterol.  I came here because of all the hype and was some what let down.  There were just so many fried items, aiolis, and bread on the menu.  Maybe I just ordered wrong.  All my dishes came w/ some sort of bread/pita/crumpet, 2-3 different aiolis, and a fried component.  Anybody can put an aioli together and toss everything in the fryer... Towards the end, my stomach yearned for some healthy salad or vegetable to soak up all the oil and fat I just consumed.  

Just go and see for yourself but if you're in for variety and timely, well executed meal, go check out The Purple Pig.  It's out of this world.

pics.caption: Crispy braised pork shank that's thrown into the fryer w/ kimchi aioli & pita (it was okay)
Holy crumpets w/ goat liver pate
Fried duck tongue (yes, each little tongue is 1 duck, kinda creepy, eh?)

review.des: I have been here three times. Huge fan - delicious. Love the cauliflower and the goats menu. Also a huge fan of Little Goat Diner.

this place was amazing when visiting Chicago! I had a last reservation on friday night and we waited a bit which was fine becasue we hung out at the bar and had a few cocktails and watched the kicthen from a far. We ended up getting the Chefs table near the kitchen which won me over! All the chefs were extermely nice and offered us tasting dishes. we asked questions and were happy to answer them! this place is busy so if you want to have dinner make a reservation and enjoy the food!

Hmm - heavy heavy heavy heavy is the best start to reviewing this one I can make. The staff was fantastic - the vibe inside is great. Drinks are awesome. Our awesome bartender said 4-6 dishes for us two - and that was his only poor side of information for us anyway. We got through 1/2 of the 4th plate and almost threw up - have not been this full since my last recklessly painful thanksgiving. I'm writing this the day after and I still don't feel right.

I get it - cool collaborations of ingredients on a single menu. But the price of heavy recipes is something to consider before ordering in bulk. In hind sight this was a night to get a couple plates and drinks and see how it goes from there.

The 2 stars are for the effort - but I can do without the heaviness.  I would hate to see the nutritional information on this place.

Yum! I had the pleasure to have dinner here on my last night in Chicago. Every plate that we had was unique and tasty. The server told us to order at least 6 dishes so that we can have a taste but instead we had order more than that. My husband and I wanted to try everything. The size of the plates are tapas size. I know I wasn't able to get full off of 2 plates but I'm glad that I was able to try everything that I wanted to try here. The atmosphere is nice as well and the staff took care of us very well.

*If you're reading this right now, stop and go make a reservation*

Girl & the Goat is definitely the kind of place you want to make a reservation for. I made the mistake of waiting until the week I wanted to come in to make one and of course - all seats were taken.  This place is always packed even though it is huge. It is dimly lit and v v v trendy.

My friends and I were l lucky enough to get seats at the bar on a Saturday at 8PM. Call it good karma for the girl's debit card we found and returned earlier that day.

Loved the bartenders - they are professional and fun and had great cocktail recommendations and banter.

My friends and I ordered 3 best of threes (ketel 1 vodka, pimms #1, cucumber, line) - very refreshing cocktail

We ordered:
-sauteed green beans - you would think this would be boring but DAMN i still remember how good these green beans were!
-hamachi crudo - great quality fish - dish was on the smaller side so i wouldn't recommend getting if you are very hungry
-wood oven roasted pig face with an egg on top - you MUST get this - it was absolutely delicious - great mixture of flavors
-grilled octopus - very good

Everything came out in a timely manner even though the place was packed. Staff was very friendly and even gave us some recs for bars to go out to after. Definitely stop in if you are visiting Chicago *with a reservation!

PRO TIP: go to little goat for brunch if you can't get into girl&goat, it's right across the street!

Price point: w/ drinks and 4 dishes split 3 ways ~$40pp
Excellent food. Almost Tapas style. Looking forward to going back to try more dishes.

The first time I visited, I was very impressed although the food was a little on the salty side, but overall very good.

On my second visit, the food was mediocre.  Focus is on being trendy and not so much the food.
Simply Awesome.   The food was superb, the service excellent and attentive.  Nice wine list but a bit over priced.  But a great dining experience

Really amazing food overall with tiny portions.  3 people share a dish is fine.  4 is stretching it.  

Great:  pig face which is great after a few drinks, goat belly, shishito peppers with parmesan, bread with miso butter and relish, miso budino dessert, lamb stuffed calamari which was really tender, roasted cauliflower with pine nuts

Ok:  goat mousse was ok but it's worth ordering so you get some carbs, goat carpaccio which was beautiful with all the garnish but so thin I really couldn't taste it

Excellent service and waitress paced our dinner perfectly.  Great wine list with affordable choices.  No wonder it's impossible to get a table here.

so, i don't really know how to rate this. The first time i came here, it was amazing. We shared a bunch of plates and it was perfect. Everything had a wonderful & diverse flavor. But upon my second visit, everything was super salty. I hate when things are oversalted & it seems to be a trend in Chicago lately.
I ordered the beet salad-which was excellent last time because of the creamy dressing on it-but it was so salty, i couldn't taste any flavor besides the intense salt! Mind you, this was at 11 pm, so i understand if the kitchen was slacking a bit, but this is one of the best restaurants in Chicago, so i was certainly surprised. Our second dish was also a miss, the crudo. The flavors were great, but lots of salt again. The bacon & gouda bread was good, but how could you mess up bread? Service was outstanding as always. Will be back, but with caution....

I heard there's a 2-3 month wait to get a reservation here, but I was looking for a place to eat on Open Table and I got a reservation for four that night. So keep checking online this place is worth it.

Here's a list of what we got:

-Hamachi crudo (crisp pork belly, chili aioli, caperberries) - This came with four tiny tiny pieces of pork belly..and I mean the size of a small paperclip. It was delicious but I wish the pieces were a lot bigger.
-Diver scallops- delicious, but it wasn't something so unbelievable or unique that you can only get here.
-Duck tongues - this sounds unappetizing, but you have got to try this. It freaked me out that they were shaped like tongues, but you'll get over it because it tastes amazing!
-Wood oven roasted pig face - also delicious! We got two for four people which was more than enough because it got a tiny bit too salty towards the end.
-Roasted cauliflower - good! This helped balance everything out.

For dessert:
"coffeecake" semifreddo
bittersweet chocolate
sticky date cake
miso-butterscotch budino
Just get them all! They were all delicious, I especially liked the coffeecake.

pics.caption: wood oven roasted pig face (sunny side egg . tamarind . cilantro . red wine-maple . potato stix)
diver scallops (sweet curry . sweet onion-bacon . papadum)
roasted cauliflower (pickled peppers . pine nuts . mint)

review.des: I've eaten here several times and never been disappointed. Escargot ravioli was a standout at one visit, and the I could eat goat empanadas every day.

Went to this place during Thanksgiving vacation. Talk about mind blowing! The food was amazing, the staff was professional and I left that place with a reminder of why Chicago has one of the best food scenes in the country.

This place is definitely worth the hype! I would drive the 8 hours just to eat here again. I was only able to get reservations for 11pm on a Friday night. We showed up a bit early and they were able to take us earlier than expected. The service was excellent. Knowledgable about the menu and very attentive. The roasted pigs face, soft shell chilli crab and miso butterscotch budino are a must! We also had the grilled pork belly and fried oysters. They were very good but not noteworthy. The restaurant itself is gorgeous. It does get busy but I still felt like I could still comfortably talk with my friends. I can't wait to come back here!

pics.caption: Roasted pigs face, grilled pork belly, soft shell chilli crab, fried oysters and miso butterscotch budino.

review.des:
Love this place. Everything we ordered was perfect!

I was surprised we were able to make a reservation. I checked on a Saturday for a reservation for the upcoming Monday.. And we found something! Granted it was a 5pm reservation. But what the heck. We went for it.

My favorites were the Pig Face, Skirt Steak, and Goat Empanadas!  You must order these dishes!

The drinks were good.. Nothing too out if the ordinary. My husband ordered the old fashioned, my best friend ordered the Paloma, and I just ordered a glass of wine.

Be prepared to spend some money.. The dishes are priced a little high and the portions are small. But definitely worth it when you have a taste of each dish.

Went here with about 10 of us (including my 3 year old)... we got the goat leg ordered in advance and it was delicious. We ordered far too much food but have to say it was delightful and rather tasty!
Innovative selection of meats, fish and veggies. A trendy must try restaurant with great service and atmosphere. A bit pricey for the size of serving. Very popular expect to be on a wait list.

Party of 4.
Wild anticipation and goosebumps for this long awaited feast.
It did not disappoint!

Our server was great at explaining how the courses go about, along with portion size, beer choices, etc. We basically ordered about 12-15 dishes such as:
  Mussels, kalbi, pork ribs, pig face, confit pork belly, green beans, dessert sampler, etc etc.

To sum it up, we ate every type of meat, every part of it (tongue, cheek, face), got our veggie intake as well (delicious, garlicky green beans), and couple rounds of beer to wash down the greasy, gluttonous goodness.

Thanks to Miss AF, we were fortunate to get extra special entrees and a dessert platter featuring their popular items.
I can write so much more, but the other hundreds and hundreds of 5 star reviews mirror my every thought and joy for this joint.

Thank you Stephanie for your glorious creations!! Don't stop what you're doing!!
G&G

pics.caption: Getting ready to get our G&G on!!

review.des:
I had the opportunity to dine at this spot TWO nights in a row..and based on previous reviews, this was a remarkable feat.

Both experiences were..incredible.

Each night I had their spicy tequila cocktail, and it was perfectly made. My colleagues and I shared goat empanadas, beet salad, the "pig face", crispy short ribs, shrimp bruschetta, chickpea fritters, and sautéed green beans. All were delicious and unique small plates. However, the green bean portion was out of control! It was literally a platter of green beans.

Anyway, this place is highly recommended! Tip: go for an early bird dinner or sit at the bar to ensure you'll get in because it will get packed.
Food, drinks, service, atmosphere........AAAAAMAZING!!! My favorite restaurant in Chicago!
If it's your first time trying goat, you have to try the goat empanadas! The oysters are melt in your mouth amazing too. Service was great!

This may be my only 5 star rating in my yelp profile.  And they are worth it.    This is my wife and I's favorite restaurant and that's saying a lot considering the list if restaurants we've been to.  

Pig face is a must!!!     After two years tonight we are making another trip there tonight.  Very excited.

pics.caption: Pig Face (talking about the dish not Paul and Micah)

review.des: If I could do less I wouldn't do 1 star. Horrible Service, Not able to accommodate large crowds Above 20 ( under any circumstance even when given 1hr and 45 minute call in advance notice or didn't want too. Improper serving and order prodigal. So even with a reputable name what a let down on Everything else so much more but NOT worth the typing or space because you get the idea. So even trying to support neighborhood business the Horrible Service and attitude makes it unworthy. You don't have to be in Foodservice to Give Good Customer Service.

We only come for special occasions because getting reservations is a bit like winning the lottery. But if you get in, the payoff is worth it. Had the best birthday here ever. I blabbed that it was my B-day thinking Id get a piece of free cake or something, but what I got was so much better. They sat us right in front of the kitchen so we got to watch and interact with the amazing cooks there. They put on such an awesome show of skill, it was a joy to watch. On top of that they were super friendly, and you can tell they were proud of their work.

Have you tried the food? Holy cow, it's so good. Try the duck tongues, pig face, broccoli, shishito peppers, goat carpaccio. The list of outstanding menu items is about as long as their whole menu, so you cannot go wrong. I'm stunned that it's not more expensive. Of course it winds up costing a lot when you attempt to eat your own weight in food (we have to since we don't know when we'll get back in!)

Overall, just an awesome time. The waiters, hostesses, even the water guy are all super cool and friendly. Can't wait to come back and eat more!

My wife and I have been wanting to try this restaurant ever since we decided to take a trip to Chicago. We were advised by a Chicago transplant to book reservations months in advance in order to get a spot here (and we did). The atmosphere of this resturant is spot on. Dim lighting but not too dark, eclectic musical selections (From Alabama Shakes to Jay-Z), attentive and knowledgable wait staff and host, clean (individual) restrooms, open bustling kitchen (all equipped with brightly colored hair bandanas) and of course THE FOOD! The selection and variety of dishes are unbeatable and the wait staff recommends dishes based on taste, texture, and timing. We decided on HamFrites, Shishito Peppers, The Calamari Bruschetta and the Confit Goat Belly with Lobster in a Butter Reduction... It was SO worth it. The temperature of all the dishes were spot on AND the serving were defiantly shareable. The Confit goat belly melts in your mouth and is full of flavor BEST DISH by far, however all of the dishes blew me away. Defiantly worth it and will make another appearance here on our next visit to Chicago.

pics.caption: #HamFrites #ShishitoPeppers #CalamariBrushetta #ConfitGoatBelly with Lobster in a Butter Reduction... It was SO worth it.

review.des: Steph Izard can do no wrong. Amazing balance of flavors in every dish. Unusual flavor combinations are on point. Fish and blueberries? Trust me. It works.

I enjoyed the scenery of the establishment. It was very modern yet comfortable. My order consisted of the escargot ravioli, ham frites, and the green beans. Every item was very tasty. If you like a hint of pork in all your food, this is surely your place. Flavors blended well together. My fiance' ordered the  crisp braised pork shank and the texture of the food was wonderful. rested well in your stomach and was not harsh at all. The bread on the side was a nice touch. The only thing we did not care for as much was the chocolate cake with gelato ice cream. The only reason is because we personally do not like the blend of sweet and bitter flavors together.

Beyond exceptional customer service! Reservations book months in advance, but they do take walk-ins. We waited for 2 hours in a cozy corner where we could order drinks (quite the selection) Some people even ordered food and sat there for dinner (low-set chairs and tables alongside wall). Each plate is well portioned for two people, we ordered 4 dishes to share and our bill was around $60-70. If you're in West Loop, check this place out! Worth the wait.

When we visited Chicago, Stephanie Izzard's restaurant was definitely at the top of our list. We were unable to make reservations but I had read that sometimes if you check their Facebook, they'll post last minute openings so luckily we were able to come in on a Sunday night on our last night of the trip.

Ambiance is nice, definitely dark so expect to use that embarrassingly bright flash if you're trying to take pictures. From what I remember, service was great! Oven roasted pig face is definitely a must-try! But everything we ordered was pretty delicious. A little disappointed by dessert as nothing really jumped off the menu and screamed, "order me!" Got the date cake anyway and it was alright.

Would definitely come back to try more stuff of the menu!

This place gets rave reviews for an obvious reason, so I'm just going to talk about what I ordered. Ham frites, escargot dumplings, chickpea fritters, duck tongues, wood oven roasted pig face and goat carpaccio.

Ham frites - comes out really fast, fairly salty but if you like salty fries you will love this
Escargot dumplings - fantastic fusion of eastern & western cuisines, small portion, worth a try
Chickpea fritters - not my favorite but the brussels sprouts and feta combo was good
Duck tongues - crispy, flavorful, delightful. Tasted similar to chicken cartilage
Wood oven roasted pig face - I've heard a lot about this dish so I had high expectations. Tasted fantastic, little oily given that my friends and I were getting very full by the time this was served. Delicious nontheless, egg and potato went well with it.
Goat carpaccio - one of my favorites that night. Again, small portion but definitely should try. Where else can you try raw goat meat?

Also, it was a busy Friday night but my party magically only had a 2 hour wait when we signed up at 6pm. We ended up getting drinks at restaurants and bars around the area (Blackbird, Takito, etc) and it was incredibly fun. I would totally come back again but the 3 month reservation vs. 2 hour wait is a little ridiculous. Trendy restaurant in a trendy area - worth a visit.

Given the hype, I was a bit disappointed with G&G. The menu was exciting, but the execution on some dishes was flawed.

Highlights were the duck tongues and pork face. Both were well-composed, tasty, and texturally interesting.

The beet salad was bland despite listing anchovies as an ingredient. The octopus was over-seasoned and chewy. The halibut was dry.

Overall the meal was enjoyable, but fell short of the hype and the prices.

Loved the space, service was very good; my husband and I enjoyed the halibut (small plate) and pork shank (pretty large plate) very much. Cauliflower (also a pretty large plate) was good but a bit too salty for us; chickpea fritters were good, but I probably would not order again. An anniversary dessert was a lovely touch, and delicious!

OMG. Impossible to make reservation. Need to plan in advance for couple months. Place is very nice. The food is unbelievable. It's a great place for a date or brig someone out of town. Portions are really small :-) but amazing and delicious. We spend $160 for 4 people. Left hungry, but happy :-) Will come back

I have been looking forward to coming to Chef Stephanie Izard's restaurant for so long. I loved the vibe of this place, cool music and relaxed atmosphere. Everything we ordered was superb but I have to say the stand outs were the Pig Face ( don't get intimidated by the name because this dish is magnificent) and the scallops. The roasted beet salad was very refreshing and if you are a fan of bleu cheese then I recommend the broccoli with bleu cheese. I don't know if you actually can go wrong with any dish here but I look forward to trying them all some day. Happy eating!

Not a surprise that this places is well deserving of the 5-stars I'm giving it. Girl & The Goat easily has an incredible take on fusions and creativity on their dishes. Not too many places offer the diversity and risky ingredients like pig face on their menu. As a foodie, I welcome these risks.

The G&G really lives up to its hype and experiencing it firsthand you'll understand. The environment really lends itself to a family style setting which is influenced in their portions. So best come hungry and with a horde of people to taste everything.  

I recommend three dishes: Escargot Ravioli, Goat Belly with Lobster and Crab Meat, and Oven Roasted Pig Face.

The escargot ravioli will nail you with an experience that you haven't had ravioli before. I mean a miso tamarind broth? What the shit?! That's French-Italian-Japanese fusion dish right there. Its got that good good. I won't even describe the other dishes because it's really pointless to write how amazing this shit is.

pics.caption: Goat Belly with lumps of crab meat and Lobster.

review.des: Disappointed when the The White Chocolate Grill in Schaumburg went out of business. Naperville experience proved to be a pleasant experience with great food. However, the blonde brownie was a HUGE disappointment. Brownie was cold, tablespoon of ice cream, splash of chocolate and not but a few sprinkles of white chocolate. I have had this dessert more than a dozen times - what makes a great experience is from START to FINISH. Our wait staff knew we were celebrating a mile stone birthday, the unfortunate thing about being served a bad dessert is that you could have had a wonderful meal with great service, but the last taste in your mouth is what you often remember.

The original plan is au cheval but you know ... We just went cross the street without a reservation. Luckily there are several empty seats at the bar. We ordered 4 dishes and all of them were good. 1. bread and salmon cream, salmon cream was well paired by the sweetness from the relish. 2. oyster, very fresh. 3. pork shank, crispy and little chewy on the outside and very very tender inside. It can be very hot so be careful on the first bite. The kimichi sauce was not spicy at all but very flavorful to dip the naan wrapped pork. 4. lamb belly with crab and lobster, the lamb was just melted in your mouth and it was balanced with a refreshing fennel flavor. Thought this could be a heavy dish but not at all, it just felt like a seafood dish on the rich side. Service was nice and will go again to try other things on the menu.

One of my friends who is originally from Illinois recommended this place to me. I had already ready reviews on this place by then, so I was super excited to try it when I went on vacation to Chicago.

The food at Girl and the Goat is amazing! Every dish had something special and you could taste all the flavors. A few of my favorites were the salmon and pig face. I normally do not enjoy salmon, but this dish was cooked to perfection! So so delicious with the tomatoes (also another item I normally do not enjoy). The pig face is excellent. It is a little fatty and very rich. I loved it and so did my friends who have never had pig face.

I definitely would reccommend trying as much as you can. The plates are small, so order about 3 plates per person. The reviews do not lie, this place is worth the month in advance reservation!

pics.caption: Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face - Really delicious. Very fatty and rich.
Escargot Ravioli - My least favorite dish, kind of bland
I believe this was the Copper River Sockeye Salmon. Salmon was cooked perfectly with so many flavors! A must try!

review.des:
I'll keep this quick.  I am not a real foodie but I love to eat good food.

The food here was amazing, and for the price it's a MUST TRY.  Chill atmosphere and the plates are small and meant to be shared.  Came with 8 people and got around 14 dishes.

For sure get the:
-Pig Face
-Pork Shank
-Scallops

i just don't get it.  Tried it out three times.  Food was not great, most dishes overly salted.  Atmosphere was too loud to hold conversation.  Great, "pig face".  I guess it's cool if you haven't tried many foods.  Pork cheeks, other parts of the head used by many cultures.  Sulz in Austria, Sultze in Germany, testa en cassetta in Italy.  G&G's is not quite meat in aspic, but saving bits of food (non-prime cuts) and turning them into something delicious is as old as the hills.  Problem is, G&G misses on most dishes on the delicious part.  Over hyped.
This was good, but not amazing. Maybe my expectations were high. I liked the ambience. Make reservations ahead of time.

One of the best restaurant experiences I've ever had. No wonder they have a James Beard award + 4.5 stars on Yelp!

The inside looks modern with a wooden interior, lounge chairs, open kitchen, and private bathrooms downstairs.

My fiance and I came in on a Monday night around 7PM and were quoted a 1+ hour wait time. Luckily, we found 2 seats at the full service bar and opted to eat there. Justin, the bartender, was awesome. He was talkative, gave great food suggestions, and even dessert on the house!

We ordered oysters, the beet salad, beef tongue, skirt steak, diver scallops, and escargot ravioli. My favorites were the Beef Tongue & the Skirt Steak which were both super tender! I wish I could have ordered more because everything on the menu looked delicious! Next time, I'll try the cauliflower and goat mousse.

If you are ever visiting Chicago, this place is a must! But try to make reservations in advance!

This place is great!!! Such an experience and EVERYTHING was good!
We went here on a late holiday gathering for our office.
The food impeccable! But above all the service. I have a mushroom allergy and before I said anything our server( I forgot his name but I'm sure the universe will pay it forward) asked if anyone had allergies. I was the only one. He marked my menu and crossed out everything that had mushrooms and let me know which ones they could make without. EVERY SINGLE PERSON that brought a dish to the table knew I was allergic and let me know if I could eat that dish or not. EVERY SINGLE PERSON. I felt extremely comfortable and had no fears that someone might slip.. they were on it. Awesome place ... awesome food... awesome staff. Worth it and I will be back again.
Just a great restaurant all the way around, from the food to the service this place really does impress.

This is my absolute favorite restaurant in Chicago! I have been here countless times and I have never been disappointed. I love it so much that I have a tattoo of the goat!

Stephanie Izard is truly a magician with food. She knows the perfect flavor combinations and knows just how to present the dishes. I try to go there at least 1 time every 3 months.

Make sure that you make reservations far in advance because it books up quickly but I'll tell you, it is totally worth every penny and every taste bud on your tongue will dance!

Dinner with the Husband:

I've been here twice. Yes, you may have heard to make reservations ahead of time. If you do that, make two reservations and then cancel one of them closer to date, or gift it with a gift card for a foodie friend. Otherwise, go in and steal a seat at the lounge-which seats up to 40 people, or go to the bar-both providing full service. They don't do wait lists, but your wait can be up to an hour. If that's the case, walk a block down to Nellcote for a drink and come back.

A little fib they tell you: 'The meats take long to bring out so start off with an appetizer'.  Not always true- even on the busiest nights. The breads are okay, I would skip the 5 dollar breads and go straight to the appetizers. Everything you get is delicious, everything you get is different, and you can't get anything you get and say 'it takes like something i've had at.......' because Stephanie Izard perfected the menu, and she continues to perfect it as it does change here and there.

The cocktails are STRONG...I would settle for a glass of wine next time because it was hard to drink, and I can take strong drinks. They have a great beer list too.

My favorites off the menu were the chickpea fritters, lamb ribs, goat empanadas, and goodness, honestly, don't remember everything else delicious I have ordered. Service is pleasant. The wait staff dresses casually, and they all know the menu real well, and you can definitely ask for their suggestions.

More tips:
-Try to get to the chef's table. You may score complimentary drinks and tastings and get the secret to how to create your own girl and the girl food at home while chatting with the chef's.
-Instead of ordering everything at once, order a dish or two at a time. You may surprise yourself with how full you can get!
-Eat slow and share! The dishes are not overwhelmingly huge!

Go out afterwards, Randolph street is a great restaurant area! Little Goat across the street has  a wine bar too.

I dined here in late summer, but I have been meaning to post this review here ever since.  My Girl & The Goat reservation that I scheduled two months before the date was at 4:30 p.m. We arrived promptly and didn't leave until 7:45 p.m. That is three hours and fifteen minutes of sheer gluttony. Our server, Hunter, didn't mind at all.  In fact he encouraged it. The dining experience is mainly tapas (small plates), meant to be shared and enjoyed over time. It is best to start with the lighter fare, and to work your way up to the heartier, meatier dishes. We did just that.

Our starters were the pan fried Shishito peppers, served with parmesan, sesame and miso and the "Corny Goat," which is French bread served with goat cheese butter and corn relish. Next was the grilled baby octopus, which included guanciale, favas, radish pods, pistachios, and lemon vinaigrette and cofit goat belly, served with bourbon butter, lobster 'n crab, and fennel. So far, so good. We were off to a fine start, and I was already starting to feel satisfied, yet edging towards full.

Now comes the heavy lifting. We opted for the wood oven roasted pig face, served with a sunny-side egg, tamarind, cilantro, red wine maple, and potato sticks. It was tender and flavorful. We also opted for the Pinn Oaks lamb tartare, prepared with sweet corn tapenade, tuna aioli, and water crackers. Although I was on the brink of exploding, I was extremely satisfied and felt very content. I sat back in my chair, closed my eyes, and savored every last bite. To finish our meal, we decided upon the miso-butterscotch budino: bacon toffee, glazed pineapple, and candied cashews, as well as the milk chocolate and galangal napoleon, served with blackberries and passion fruit.

Throughout our meal, we tried a variety of different drinks: "Blood and Goats," a concoction of Monkey Shoulder Scotch, Leopold Tart Cherry, Savannah Madeira, and orange; "The Lake Effect:" Journeyman Rye, FEW Gin, Chrysanthemum Honey Liqueur, and lemon; and "The Foghorn:" also FEW Gin, Cocchi Vermouth, Luxardo cherries, and orange bitters.

My two-month wait time for a reservation was well worth it.  There are so many more places to explore and eat in Chicago that I believe I would be perfectly content finding a new spot, every night for one year. Windy City, I don't know how you manage to do it every single time, but you really do blow me away.

I don't know how they do it! This place was amazing!
My father and I walked right in and got seated at a communal table. We love the concept if communal seating, because we love to interact with the locals and chat with them about the area. We ordered Paloma's to drink, and they were awesome! Instead if rimming the glass with salt, they add a little salt right into the drink! Brilliant!
We shared small plates including the green beans, scallops and Arctic char. All amazing dishes! Those green beans deserve an award! The flavors! Just delicious! Service was great, and the atmosphere was awesome!

Super trendy! The plates come out in random order and you share with the table which was fun. Everything we had was delicious and very creatively put together. The braised pork leg was to die for (sauce was ok, I'm from Texas and it could have used some BBQ sauce instead) the roasted pig face was also very good, soft tender pork in a delicious sauce. The vegetables were great, the shrimp was good and the Chocolate Malt dessert was the best! We ate and drank so much we couldn't move by the end of the night. Tried tons of new things and thought it was all great!

pics.caption: Braised Pork Leg. Meat fell off the bone it was so soft and tender!

review.des:
Im not sure where to begin! This place is absolutely amazing! If you are an adventurous eater, and into "different" things, than this is a place that I would put on your list when in Chicago.  

The owner is Stephanie Izard, who won Top Chef (the Bravo TV show), she opened the Girl and The Goat, back in 2010.  While doing some research for our trip, this place kept coming up! Then one night, we were watching a show on FoodNetwork, and yet again, we saw this place! After reading some reviews on yelp, I called (a month in advance) and made a reservation!

After taking a look at the menu, we decided on a few different things.  I should mention that these are all small dishes, so our waitress recommended we order between 5-7, which of course we did! We ordered the Spring Onion Pierogies, Goat Empanadas, Squash Blossom Crab Rangoon, Grilled Baby Octopus, the Tartare Special, and one of the bread specials, that I can remember at the moment! Everything was so AMAZING!!! Perfectly cooked, perfectly seasoned, and a decent portion! Definitely enough for two people to share! We also, had two cocktails (La Paloma...yes!!!!!) and for dessert we had the Chocolate Truffle cake, which, well, just try it!!!

All in all everything was amazing! The atmosphere is pretty awesome as well, lots of seating, open kitchen concept, so you see all the chefs working, which I personally enjoy.  Our waitress was fantastic, so sweet, so informative and so attentive!!

If you plan on coming, MAKE A RESERVATION!!!!!  

Enjoy!

Reputation of G & the G is very well deserved!  They had to be phenomenal if I couldn't get a reservation until July, right?!!  We swooped in at 5 o'clock, and they were able to squeeze us in, but gave us a 2 hour time limit, which I was totally fine with.  Very interesting they have small tables, but also large community tables, which I don't know why more restaurants employ this act.  It made for a friendly dining experience, plus you get to see what everybody else orders without looking all creepy! I swear I don't do that...

Servers were beyond friendly, helping us out, stating it is family style, and an enjoyable experience. We did not have any dishes with goat in it, but we had quite the plentiful array of food. Started with a simple multi-grain bread, but it came with a very tasty cream cheese type spread, which if I had it my way, I would slather all over other things like... more bread or a bagel. Next was the grilled ramp marinated shrimp, grilled baby octopus, which were just all-around delights.  The octopus had the grilled crust and flavor, but nice and chewy in a lemon vinaigrette with pistachios and other little tidbits that kind of got lost.  The shrimp was perfectly cooked, but since I enjoyed the octopus so much I forgot what the shrimp came with other than a slight kick.  I love me some pork belly, so I was excited for their take on it.  I was sadly disappointed with it.  It was really good, but it didn't wow me.  It was different with some kind of green sauce (avocado and cilantro puree? that wasn't very flavorful), and some blackberries.  The skin was crispy but the pork meat of it was a little overcooked rather than melt in your mouth. If you like pork belly, I would still consider ordering it.

But the next two dishes were probably the most popular among all patrons because it seemed like I saw them bring out these dishes every few minutes.  My wife loves green beans, so if it's on any menu we usually order them, and they were really good!  Simple, yet very plentiful so I can see why so many order it.  The menu says sauteed, but there were some grill marks or some blackening on the tender beans that were cooked in a fish sauce vinaigrette and cashews.  I have to experiment to make this for us, it was that good!  Not overly salty since it was fish sauce, it made for a nice side dish.  But my favorite dish was the wood oven roasted pig face.  What the what?  No, it's not lord of the flies kind of thing.  It was beautiful!  My wife makes fun of me when I say you can make any dish good if you put a fried egg on it, but this really made the dish THAT much better! Big plate, loads of crispy pig face goodness with a tamarind sauce, cilantro, red wine maple sauce, and potato stix.  Just cut that sexy egg yolk and let the music begin!  The egg adds a richness to go with everything and just made me a happy camper.

We finished our meal with the miso-butterscotch budino with bacon toffe, glazed pineapple and candied cashews.  It was like a creme brulee, which really doesn't give it justice.  It was slap yo mama good! I didn't want to share!

This was one of the best meals I've ever had, and I won't hesitate to come back to Chicago. But bring that credit card, getting this many dishes plus drinks was quite a bill, but worth every penny!
This is probably one of the best meals I have ever had. I ate things that I never thought I would eat. The service was also impeccable

My wife and I weren't that impressed with Girl and the Goat. We heard great things about it, and based on the difficulty of getting a reservation, we anxiously awaited a delicious meal. While the service and atmosphere were great, we found the food to have little tasted outside of the salty sauces and glazes that everything was drenched in.

I get the hype. This place is good, but for all the recommendations I got to go visit from various friends and Yelpers- I was underwhelmed.

I made my reservation for a party of 4 on a Sunday night about a month in advance and the only time slot available was 8:45pm. My friends and I were visiting for the weekend, so making a reservation was a must. Even at 8:45pm we overheard the hostess say to walk-in group that the wait was an hour.

Service is great and our waiter was very helpful in suggesting popular dishes. On our visit, we ordered: Goat carpaccio, Bay Scallops, Octopus, Green beans, Shishito peppers, Hamachi Crudo, Braised Beef Tongue, and Pork Belly.

Overall, I thought the dishes were way too salty (where's the rice or toasted break when you need them?!), and after the 3rd or 4th dish, some dishes started to taste the same. My favorites from our visit were the green beans and pork belly. These two had the best flavors apart from the other dishes we ordered. From all the reviews, I was expecting each dish to be exciting and unique in it's flavor - this is where I felt the most disappointed.

For a party of 4, we were advised to order around 8 dishes to share, and at first I thought it wasn't going to be enough food, but it ended up being the perfect amount to fill all of our bellies.  If you have room for their desserts, definitely give them a try. We had the Sticky Squash Cake and that was probably the best part of the meal.

Girl & The Goat is a Chicago classic. Super hard to get a reservation (unless you get lucky and score seats at the bar) so make sure to plan in advance to get a reservation. The food is incredible. The cauliflower and octopus are both top notch, but whatever you order will not disappoint! The service is excellent, great drink menu and wine list. Overall ambiance is very cool. Great options for vegetarians!

After hearing so much about the Girl & the Goat, I HAD to try this place out. The Girl did not disappoint; she lived up to the hype.

My friend and I arrived on time for our 8:15pm reservation, but we were told that the restaurant was running a little late. We decided to get a drink at the bar. Whatever I had, I didn't like it though.

We got seated at around 8:30pm, and we ordered the following:

Corny goat bread-- Delicious goat cheese spread with corn relish. Worth the price? Maybe not, but it was a great starter.

Wood fired wiley point oysters with horseradish, bacon, preserved lemon-- I like this too, but I also think that I could have done without.

Goat carpaccio with tongue-olive vinaigrette and smoked roe-- This was one of my least favorite dishes. I got all excited because I thought it'd taste like a steak tartar, but it didn't really, and I just didn't really like it.

Sauteed green beans with fish sauce vinaigrette and cashews-- Yum! Worth the price? Probably not. As someone who practically grew up on nuoc mam, I loved this dish. It was a bit salty though. The cashews were great with the green beans, and I suddenly felt the urge to add cashews to my regular cooking ingredients.

Wood oven roasted pig face with sunny side egg, tamarind, cilantro and potato stix-- Possibly my least favorite item. I felt as though my fellow Yelpers steered me wrong on this one. It wasn't anything special, and it tasted like bacon and eggs to me... It might just be because I'm generally not a breakfast fan. Who knows. I didn't really like this dish.

Confit goat belly with bourbon butter, lobster, crab, and fennel -- My absolute favorite dish. I think my friend would agree with me on this one, and I'm glad we ended our meal with this. It had the right amount of buttery and savory goodness. Just oh, so good!

If I was rating just the food itself, I'd give the girl four stars, but the experience that night was just dream-like. We had an excellent server, and I loved our next table neighbors. I normally don't end up chatting with my dining neighbors at all, but there was a strange coincidence that night. My friend and I bumped into a lady that sat right next to us at The Purple Pig just a day earlier. Funny thing? Her name was Jennifer. I was never a Jennifer, but I usually love people with a similar name. Ha! Our neighbors on the other side of our table were fantastic to talk to too.

I'd love to come here again one day.

pics.caption: goat belly confit with lobster fennel and butter

review.des: Girl & the Goat has incredible food. Word of advice, if you want to try this restaurant you'll need to make reservations months an advance. It's entirely worth it though.

Can't say anything more than what has been said here already. Great food and service. Poor value due to the small plates and very high prices. The servers recommend that each person order two plates each and then share with your table mates. We were a group of six and that two plate thing just didn't work.
The folks at the host station were kinda rude and too business like. Yes we were 10 minutes late but I called ahead and told them. I want to feel like they're happy I'm there spending plenty of my money.
My car came out of the valet with a bunch of mud on one side of it...where did they park it??
Five stars for the food and service.
Two stars for the value. $9 bucks for a small loaf of bread???
One star for the host stand.
One star for the valet.
Next time I'll try the G&G Cafe across the street.

Went in for our anniversary. Made a reservation for wife and I. They called two days out to confirm.

They surprised us with the chefs table. Was completely blown away by this gesture and so appreciative. We live around the corner in the west loop and know how hard it is to get a table but we will gladly go back.

Everything we had was superlative. Menu changes with seasonal fare to fit what is fresh so expect changes often and for them to probably be amazing always.

First class place.

Fantastic meal and experience!  I made our reservation months in advance, so we'd been looking forward to eating here for some time.  From the moment we walked in to the moment we left, everything was exceptional!  We sat on the end of a row of half booth/half chair seats, so we technically had three seats at our table.  I didn't notice the noise that so many people have referenced, but that may be because we only had one table next to us.  Service was prompt and excellent.  I'd say it was some of the best service I've ever received at a restaurant.  We started with drinks, one of which was recommended by our server.  They offer shared plates and our server recommended two plates per person.  We ordered the sauteed green beans, pan roasted halibut, the roasted pig face, and the goat empanadas.  Everything was so delicious!  Very strong and rich flavors.  I'd have to say my favorite of the dishes we tried was the halibut with the empanadas right behind.  For dessert we had the chocolate truffle cake.  I'm not a big fan of coconut, so I was a little concerned I wouldn't like it, but it truly was just the right amount.  My only complaint of our experience was we waited a little long for my boyfriend's second drink, but other than that we really enjoyed our meal.  I'd say it's one of the best meals I've had in Chicago.

Big thanks to the G&TG hostess staff for graciously  accomodating my rather last minute request for a dinner reservation while the Open Table app was down...not to mention seating us at the ideal table for a party of three!  

My out of town guests & I had a truly wonderful time and raved over everything from the cocktail & vino selection to each menu item we experienced...true palate paradise!  Though we sampled a good portion of the menu from apps thru dessert, there's simply too many delectable delights to endulge via a single sitting, especially when considering each new dish is seemingly better than the previous...as if by design. Oh yes, I shall return!
Overhyped and overseasoned.  Just goes to show you'll never go broke selling salt!

Our trip to Chicago was a bit spontaneous so we couldn't get reservations here. Knowing how hard it could be to sit without reservations, we arrived early at around 5pm on a Friday. Luckily, there was barely a wait for the bar at this point so we were able to snag a seat (first come, first served) within 20 minutes.

The drinks were really great and refreshing - perfect for the humid weather that weekend!

Now for food:
- Chickpea fritters: Yes! This was so good. The fritters were perfectly fried, and that yogurt sauce is to die for!
- Shishito peppers: Also a tad bit heavy, but I loved the flavor of the miso combined w/ the peppers. I probably wouldn't order it again, but it was good.
- Diver scallops:  The flavor was great (uni cream - yum!) and plum lended a nice tartness. The menu didn't mention that this was primarily a pasta dish so we were left wanting a bit more scallop at the end. A great dish though!
- Pig's Face: Overall a pretty disappointing dish. The flavor itself was pretty good, but the dish was far too heavy and rich for my liking.
- Goat empanadas: One of my favorite dishes that I tried. The goat was tender and flavorful, and the "salsa" was fresh and sweet.

We were extremely full after these 5 dishes. I'd definitely go back again to try other items on the menu even though the pig face was a miss for us.

After hearing all the great things about this place, we made a reservation to eat here at 8 pm on a Thursday night, 2 hours after we arrived in the amazing Chi City.

Luckily we made a reservations because this place was packed. It's sister restaurant across the street was packed as well. We were greeted with very friendly staff and seated about 10 mins after we arrived.

The ambiance is on the romantic intimate side. It's dimly lit with candles on your table.  It does get a bit loud just because of the amount of people around you. The tables are close together too. When our waiter was taking the next table's order, we couldn't squeeze in or out to use the restroom, we had to wait until he finished so we could squeeze between the limited space between each able.

Our waiter nicely explained the menu to us since it was our first time dining at the Girl and the Goat. It's broken into 3 categories: m, v, f. M for meat, v for vegetables, and f for fish/seafood. Each category includes appetizers and entrees, which are not distinguished. They menus are paper menus and you can circle everything you would like to order making it simpler. They also have a small menu with their specials listed.

What we ordered:
1. roasted cauliflower- 2 stars. Pricey appetizer of cauliflower that was burnt. We didn't not enjoy this dish despite all the recommendations by other reviewers. But our cauliflower came out black, crisp, with not much flavor except a burnt charred taste.
2. Chickpea fritters- 3 stars. The chickpea fritter was very interesting. It was perfectly fried with a light crispy exterior with the mushy chickpea inside. However, it didn't have much flavor. It was like eating deep fried battered hummus.
3. Hamachi Crudo- 4 stars. fresh slices of hamachi along with some fried pork belly. This was a flavorful, fresh, and light appetizer.
4. pan seared diver scallops- 4 stars. The scallops were cooked perfectly, nice smooth and silky with lots of flavor. But it was on the salty side.
5. NY strip tartare- 4 stars. Overall a great appetizer. The steak was very tender and flavorful. A very simple and delicious dish with complementing textures and flavors to share and start your meal.
6. Wood oven roasted pig face- 4 stars. Delicious dish. The egg was cooked perfectly and the pork was tender juicy and very flavorful.
7. Crisp braised pork shank- 4 stars. Also a very delicious dish. The pork shank was very tender. The kimchee butternut squash was our favorite though, very creative with a nice crunchy texture and pickled perfectly. Artistically put together, this dish was one of the highlights of our meal.
8. Johnny Applecheese bread- 5 stars. Handsdown DELICIOUS!!!!! I highly recommend this dish. We were fighting for every crumb. Perfectly baked bread with amazing flavor and soft fluffiness on the inside with a great crunchy crust. It comes with chili cheddar butter and malted oil, both were delicious. I preferred the chili cheddar butter though. Very different and unique.
9. confit goat belly- 3.5 stars. We had to order a goat dish. We wanted the goat leg but they were out. So sad. So we went with the goat belly. The goat belly was delicious, but they only give you a little bit. It can be salty if eaten by itself. But it came with good size pieces of lobster and crab. But it really was like appetizer sized.

Their food was good, some dishes more so on the saltier side. However, the portions are like tapas and on the pricier side. We had a party of 5 and none of us left full, but it kept us satisfied for a few hours. They also have a great list of beers and wines to choose from with average prices.

Overall, we had a great experience, but we left a bit disappointed. From all the great reviews, we expected something more outstanding. I honestly felt this place was just average.

First things first, make sure you book in advance -- as soon as you know you're headed to Chicago and want to dine here. I booked probably 2 months ahead, and got a time near their dinner opening on Friday night. At around 4:15 (opening time is 4:30), I saw that they already had people lined up outside who were hoping to get seats without having a reservation. It looked like they were successful, so if you don't have a reservation, I recommend you go during non-peak hours for sure.

The food was awesome. I love how they crafted their menu items to be moderately-sized dishes (for the most part) that you share with the rest of your group. This lets you sample quite a few things on their menu.

Our waiter told us to not forget the veggies, as their veggie dishes are really excellent. We tried to get the chickpea fritters,  it were told that the tasting of that dish that happened at 4 pm before the restaurant opened pushed the timing of the dish back such that it wouldn't be ready until 9 pm that evening, or perhaps not at all. I thought that was a pretty good move for the restaurant, not wanting to serve a dish that they didn't think was perfect. We ended up getting the roasted cauliflower -- and whoa, I have never been impressed with cauliflower before in my life until that dish came out!

We heard good things about the wood oven roasted pig face, which ended up being pretty good, although very heavy. I would have liked a little more of the tamarind or perhaps something more citrus-y to cut through the heaviness. Although the dish was not large, I felt very full even just after a few bites. Our waiter came by and mixed the dish up for us when he say they we weren't doing so enough, which was also nice.

Finally, we got the goat neck, which we were told ahead of time was a large dish so we didn't need to order much more after that. That was definitely a correct statement -- I never though goat necks were that big! But it was a really good part of the goat which I had not tried before. The meat was super tender, and just came right off with your fork. They prepare the near over a multi-day period and it comes out super rich, a little smokey, but not at all dry. The flavor is excellent, and the sauces paired with it are awesome as well. The vegetables on the bottom kind of got lost with the huge goat neck on top of it, and I would have liked a few more veggies in general. We ended up having to take some goat neck back home with us, and we left with several suggestions from our waiter about awesome goat neck leftover dishes.

Overall, an excellent experience. It seems like their menu changes pretty frequently, because a lot of the dishes mentioned in other posts were not on the menu when we were there. So, it looks like they have good variety in general and do a good job with all of their dishes. I will be back :)

My coworkers and I were looking for a cool spot with small-plates, cocktails, and a couple vegan options, and we were pretty sold after looking at this menu.

They don't take reservations, so we weren't surprised with the 2 hour quote for a party of 6-8. We didn't mind since the lounge area had big squishy couches and table service. As busy as they were, the service in the lounge was exceptional. My water glass was always full, the tapas were timely, and the cocktails kept coming. Which made it all too easy to try them all:) Our favorites were the Ring of Fire and the Local 75.

We devoured the olive bread with hummus, chickpea fritters, wood grilled broccoli, grilled shrimp, roasted cauliflower, and the goat liver mousse (which was just a little too weird for me--although the crumpets that came with were mind blowing! Like, seriously..) We also LOVED the house made pasta with mushrooms and blistered tomatoes.

2 hours + 6 rounds of cocktails and 12 share plates later, our table was ready. We didn't even care. SO LEGIT.

If you're a fan of breakfast for dinner, you must try the Pigs Face - crispy hash and pig topped with an over easy egg - amazing! We  also tried the miso halibut which I loved because of the peanut sauce and mushrooms. The roasted cauliflower had a good kick and the hint if mint was a nice surprise.

This might be one of the top 5 restaurants!

Excellent but expensive food! We had spongy focaccia (yum), spicy chorizo flatbread and lamb ribs - all really excellent - well worth the price. The local beers are great and the service was exceptional.

What a great place!  We sat at the bar to eat and had fantastic service from a great bar tender.  He was very knowledgeable about all of the dishes and of the wine offerings.  The food was fantastic and reasonably priced.  Definitely recommend checking it out!

Overall, I had an amazing experience at this restaurant.

First, the food was presented extremely well. Not only that, but the food was cooked and seasoned perfectly! I'd say that we got a great deal for the price paid.

Second, the service here is amazing. Our waitress was very knowledgeable of the menu. At one point, I didn't like one of the items we ordered, so she quickly recommended a different dish which she promptly brought out. On top of that, she didn't charge us for the dish we didn't like.

Other things to mention would be the artwork. This place had some really weird art, but that's not a bad thing!

This place is incredible. Every single dish (even the ones that sounded a little whack) were total culinary experiences. Though pricey, there is so much thought and care that goes into each dish! My fiancé and I literally mused aloud over every single dish at how insanely good each thing tasted. Our reservation was super late but the restaurant was still packed and our service was still top notch. Our waiter gave us thoughtful suggestions and had our food come out in order so that nothing clashed with each other. All in all it was one of the best culinary experiences I've ever had and am dying to go back. If you're visiting or looking to blow your mind with good food, this is your place.

Dinner at Girl & the Goat was one of those meals where you're happy to pay the bill when it arrives.

It's a beautiful space, buzzing and busy, with an open kitchen. The service was great.

Everything is small-ish plates served family style, which is my very favorite way to eat. All the food was interesting, original, and delicious. Some favorites were the Sauteed Green Beans (fish sauce vinaigrette and cashews), which were perfectly crisp-tender and ridiculously flavorful and Sugo (pappardelle with meat sauce, rosemary, and cape gooseberries).

The Bolt Action cocktail (Wild Turkey Rare Breed, Blenheim's Ginger Ale, lemon, Angostura bitters) was amazing! And this is after having drinks at The Aviary, so it's saying something. The Spanish Harlem (Olmeca Altos Plata Tequila, Combier rose liquer, lemon) was nice as well.

Overall, a really enjoyable evening.

What a great ambience, however the food didn't match hype.

The goat belly is probably the only thing writing home about.

It might be worth trying once, but not repeating.

Place is great. Me and the lady enjoyed it. She was happy so all is well for me. I enjoyed the food and it wasn't horribly pricey for the selection. I'd take this over Alinea any day. Well, I'd take La Pasadita tacos over Alinea over any day so what do I know.

Everything I thought it would be! The ambience, service, and most important of all food! Truly a foodie paradise. Good to go with a group of friends so many dishes can be tried. For the two of us, we ordered around 6 dishes which was plenty, do allot sometime for the wait because it is at least an hour, at peak times 2 hours.

Interesting menu. Liked the food a lot, just had a hard time with the atmosphere. I know people love restaurants with energy but I had a sore throat after a night here, I found myself yelling to be heard over the din. Oysters were particularly memorable. Good service.

One word: Heaven! Yes, it can be hard to get in, and reservations would only help if you're looking at like 4 weeks ahead, but there is a reason for that. Most new restaurants in Chicago lose their hype in a year or two, but not this one.

I went there for a birthday dinner with friends and everything was delicious. We had shishito peppers for appetizer. My friends ordered pork shank and goat belly and I had beef ribs. We shared the entrees and each entree was great. Great atmosphere. It's a little far for me but was worth the trip.

What can I say, it's The Girl and the Goat! It lived up to all of the hype! It was definitely worth waiting months for a reservation! Absolutely everything on the menu was superb and the service was outstanding!  I didn't get to take pictures of the food because the dishes were passed around our table so quickly.  You MUST try this place when in Chicago!

The dark and gourdy pumpkin rum cocktail their serving right now is DANGEROUSLY GOOD. You could put away 3-4 of those and not notice.
Pig face - Duh
Chick pea fritters - FAVORITE DISH
Green beans - a must
Broccoli- I would pass on this again
Trout - most flavorful full I ever tasted

Sigh. I've been putting off writing this review, because I have so much respect and awe for Stephanie Izard and this visit was so disappointing...especially compared to my first visit to G&G a few years ago. I was with a couple of friends on this visit, so we were able to order quite a few dishes for sharing.
