All of them sounded intriguing...Olive You Bread; Goat Liver Mousse; Confit Goat Belly; Wood Grilled Broccoli; Squash Blossom Crab Rangoon; Seared Diver Scallops; Grilled Walter's Chicken. Unfortunately, except for the Confit Goat Belly, everything fell flat. (But I will say, the Confit Goat Belly was amazing!! I could have had 7 dishes of that, and gone home happy.) In addition, our meal was so rushed, it was off-putting. Our first dish came out at just before 7PM, and our last dish came out at 7:24, even though we asked the servers a number of times to please slow down the delivery of our dishes. (We had even ordered a bottle of wine before we started our meal, so it should have been obvious we weren't in a rush.) So, all in all, quite a disappointing evening. With so many other wonderful restaurants in that neighborhood, I would recommend trying someplace else.

My 5th time here and I'm still amazed. Being a vegetarian you'd think you wouldn't have options here but I'm never disappointed. Breadstick
Buns. Johnny Applecheese (bread). Chickpea fritters andddddddd sweet potato blue cheese pierogis... O.M.G.

Does this place have Michelin Star?  With the number of people who travel to Chicago just to go here, it must.
If the owners of this place opened up a hut in the middle of the worst part of Chicago, I would risk my personal safety to eat there if it was only open from 1am to 3am.
One of the best meals I've ever had, though the long planning needed for a reservation and the value-for-money bring it down one star. Favorite dishes: octopus and duck tongues.

Absolutely fantastic! Came in with high expectations and definitely was not disappointed. Was able to get reservations for a Friday night a week before, apparently that's pretty rare, and I can see why!

The atmosphere was very nice. Classy, yet casual feel to the place. The service was fantastic! Everyone was so attentive and never let an empty glass or finished plate sit for too long. Something I really enjoyed was how one plate was brought out after another, and not all at once, and when they brought a plate, they would tell you exactly what was in it.

Now to the best part.... THE FOOD. Everything we had was phenomenal! For four people, our waitress recommended seven or eight plates, which ended up being the perfect amount because everything comes as "small" plates to share. Here's what we ordered:

Miso Hungry Bread: Great way to start! The bread was so fresh and warm and paired perfectly with the pickle relish.

Squash Blossom Ragoons: Really great flavor. The crisp outer shell went together perfectly with the soft, warm crab filling. The almonds were a nice addition in flavor.
Could have done without the green goddess sauce, though.

Spring Onion Pot Stickers: These were really good as well. There was a perfect filling-to-dough ratio.

Ham Frites: I'm not a fan of french fries, so I didn't try this one, but the other members of my group said they tasted like french fries with bacon, but better.

Oven-Roasted Pig Face: Oh boy. This was amaaazing! The crispiness of the pork with the creamy texture of the egg made for a heavenly combination. I read a couple of reviews that said this dish was too salty, but I didn't think so at all.

Roasted Cauliflower: Probably the best tasting cauliflower I've ever had. Seasoned perfectly and roasted so it was soft, but not mushy.

Grilled Skirt Steak: It was grilled to perfection, but the sweet cherry tapenade made this dish great. It's funny because they are two flavors you woudn't expect to work well together, but gosh was it great.

Pork Shank: My favorite of the night, hands down. Melt-in-your-mouth delicious! I could have eaten this whole thing by myself.

For dessert, the rest of my table ordered the bittersweet chocolate and loved it! The chocolate mousse, blackberries, brownie, and basil-chocolate chip gelato paired together quite nicely.

We will definitely be coming back to try the other dishes!

It was Sunday night in Chicago and I was on the hunt for where to have dinner my last night in town.  After considerable head scratching and debating with myself in my hotel room I decided on Girl & the Goat to start my night.

My first tip to anyone reading this that might be in town on a business trip like I was: Dont even try to make last second reservations on the weekend. This place is extremely busy and for good reason, the food was outstanding! (I'll get to that in a minute). If you only have a small group I would recommend walking in sometime around 6 PM and asking for a table. You will likely be told that there is a 1.5 to 2+ hour wait which is to be expected, however the actual wait time based on my experience and some other locals I had spoken with was considerably less (half the estimate). In addition, the planed wait time will allow you to walk right across the street to the Highly reviewed Lonely Wolf Bar to sit down and Sample some of their excellent cocktails while you wait.  Don't worry, Girl & the Goat will text you when your table is ready and your blood alcohol levels will be pre-primed for the experience!

Now onto the important part, the food...

Because I was dining alone (I cleverly evaded my colleagues' typical business trip steak dinners) I decided to splurge on three of their top-rated dishes. Each one of them was unique, complex, and beyond impressive.  Here are my thoughts on each:

Wood Oven Roasted Pigs Face:.

Even during my preliminary research the thought of pigs face in a dish admitting only made my stomach turn. I have been to many pig roasts and I'm not a freak that generally eats the face and eyes the roasted pig (although I will grab at the rest of the pig like a crazed zombie).  This dish easily surfaced as my favorite throughout my meal. As you can see in the countless photos on yelp the pig faces is served topped with a fried egg. The flavor of the warm yoke blends with the fat in the slice of pork so well I having trouble putting it into words... Add tamarind, cilantro, and red wine-maple;  It was heavenly.  Just order it.  No more questions please.

Pan Roasted Halibut:

The halibut was outstanding, initially slightly salty and quickly transitioned into spicy and sweet with marcona almond butter, white asparagus, blueberry nuoc cham, The ginger,and the mushrooms just added to the variety. It was incredibly complex and delicious. I would order this again in a heartbeat.  

Grilled Baby Octopus:

The baby octopus dish was served with fava beans, pea, pistachios and a lemon vinaigrette.  I LOVED the use of the fava beans In this dish. I have ordered octopus countless times over the years in many countries and this was easily the most unique presentation I have encountered. Very good.

If I could add a + to the end of my 5 stars I would.  A meal like this in New York City would easily have cost double the price. Follow my advice, walk in, reserve a table, and go get drinks across the street while you wait for a text message. I promise you you will not be disappointed. 5+

Next time I am in Chicago I will be back 100%

review.des: Simply amazing!! Staff knows their menu, perfectly plated and served according to its light to heavy fare.

So my actual star review would be 4.5, and it comes very close to being a 5. The ambiance is great, it's lively but not overwhelming, you can definitely tell this is one of Chicago's hottest restaurants, and it does live up to the hype. We ordered 4 dishes for our meal, but abstained from cocktails and dessert (too full for dessert), the portions were good sized (especially the vegetables) and we felt it was more than enough food for two healthy appetites (I am a relatively large man and my dining companion is a petite woman).

For our meats we ordered goat belly with lobster, and lamb ribs. For vegetables we ordered cauliflower and green beans. We also ordered onion bread to munch on before our meal. Both my dining companion and I agreed that the vegetables outshone the meat dishes. While the meat dishes were both very delicious, the vegetables had more exciting flavor combinations, especially the green beans which had a deliciously acidic fish sauce vinaigrette. The cauliflower was also extremely good, with great flavor and a little spice. The goat belly was tasty, with a sweet flavor and good texture. It was interesting paired with the lobster meat, I wouldn't have thought those two proteins would go together, but it worked. The lamb ribs were more disappointing. While good, they didn't pop like the rest of the meal did, and it was a little hard to eat, especially since all the dishes are made to be shared.

Overall, I highly recommend this place, and think it deserves its reputation. Next time I go I definitely want to try out the dessert menu.

review.des:
Being a Top Chef fan, I made it a priority to make sure I got a reservation here when planning my trip to Chicago. I called 3 months in advance and was able to secure a 9:30pm reservation for a Saturday night. The place was packed when we arrived, we waited probably 10 minutes before a table opened up. The dishes are on the smaller side in terms of portions, but they are meant to be shared so it's better to come with just a date or small group.

Here's a rundown of what we ordered for the two of us:
- Chickpea fritters garam masala, sugar snap peas, rosemary-tamarind, yogurt, served with green mango: I'm a huge meat lover but this vegetarian dish was actually my favorite of the night. The dish wasn't too heavy even though it was fried and the flavors were delicious.
- Wood-fired oysters (special) bacon served some kind of aioli: Pretty good but I think I prefer my oysters with a more simple preparation as the oysters themselves got a bit lost with the other rich flavors.
- Escargot ravioli with bacon, tamarind-miso sauce: Very solid dish with great flavors, probably my second favorite of the night.
- Grilled baby octopus with guanciale, fava beans, pea tips, pistachios, lemon vinaigrette: The girlfriend didn't like the burnt/bitter flavor of one of the vegetables in here (not sure what it was). I thought the dish was pretty well-balanced and offered a nice change of pace.
- Wood oven roasted pig face with sunny side egg, tamarind, cilantro, red wine-maple, potato stix: Elevated comfort food dish that was definitely the heaviest course of the night, I thought the octopus dish actually eats pretty well with this one as the acidity in that dish helps cut through the richness of the fatty pork.
Miso-butterscotch budino - bacon toffee, glazed pineapple, candied cashews

For dessert, the girlfriend was having trouble deciding between the horchata rice pudding served with semifreddo and cinnamon toast crunch or the miso butterscotch budino with bacon toffee, glazed pineapple, and candied cashews. We ended up ordering the rice pudding but they actually threw in the other one for us for free! :) Really glad we got to try both as they were both phenomenal courses to cap off a fantastic and memorable meal.

pics.caption: Horchata Rice Pudding and Miso Butterscotch Budino

review.des: I have to give Girl & the Goat 3.5 stars overall. When planning out our trip to Chicago, I was most excited to try this place since I'm a big fan of tapas style restaurants. It was our last night in Chicago and we walked almost 2 miles just to try out this place. The place itself is beautiful and it reminds me of rustic/hipster restaurants in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, NY. Overall, I thought the food was okay but it didn't "WOW" me. Our waitress recommended 2 dishes per person and we did just that and we left very full. We ordered the Chili Shrimps, Kalbi Beef Ribs, Pierogi, and the Halibut. I think the halibut was my favorite dish because the fish was very delicate and cooked perfectly with assorted mushrooms on top. The pierogi were more like empanadas with potato cream fillings garnished with pickled corn and carrots. The Kalbi were very fatty pieces and also very salty. The chili shrimps were surprisingly mild in flavor and lacks the spicy kick in chili. Also, did anyone notice that there were no goat dishes on the menu? I was excited to try goat dishes...but I guess I'll have to try it elsewhere.

A close friend of one of my classmates was in town, and we wanted to take him somewhere special in Chicago for the night. We didn't have any reservations in advance, and called a few places. (Somehow) Girl and the Goat had space left for a same-night reservation that Monday! I've heard that people have had to get reservations months in advance so I guess we just got super lucky.

I immediately liked the rustic/country feel of the restaurant, and I was impressed with the good service. Our waitress told us that for four people, we should order between 8 and 10 dishes. However, being poor med students and not too terribly hungry, we decided on 6 - two appetizers and one dish selected by each of us. This turned out to be the right amount. We followed the style of sharing the dishes family style, but some of them were seemed hard to share just given their structure. We tried:

1. Crisp Braised Pork Shank
2. Wood Fired Walter's Chicken
3. Seared Tuna
4. Spring Onion Pot Stickers
5. Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face
6. Ham Frites

We tried to decide on a favorite dish but couldn't really agree because they were all so delicious. If I had to choose a personal favorite, it would have to be the Pork Shank. The meat was so tender that it melted in my mouth, and the bread that came with the dish was just astounding.

I would have liked to rate them four and a half stars, but decided to round up to five rather than round down. Although the food was delicious, I wasn't really surprised by anything I tried. It was about what I expected it to taste like. All in all though, Girl and the Goat is a must-try for any Chicago resident. Just be sure to make reservations a loonnggg time in advance!

I usually don't write a review if I've only been somewhere once, but Girl and the Goat definitely deserves a good recommendation! Met up here with 4 of my friends and tried a little bit of everything. Our server (who was absolutely amazing- Matthew) suggested about 8-10 dishes for our group, which happened to be the exact perfect amount. Everything we had was great- scallops, pig face, cauliflower, lamb shank, etc etc etc) and we practically licked each plate clean. Desserts were drool-worthy. Matthew paid very special attention to my friend who has a nut allergy and went above and beyond for us. It was one of those experiences where the food was phenomenal and the service was totally sublime. We can't wait to come back!

I got lucky one night eating here without a reservation! Usually this place is booked up even 3 weeks in advance. I was with my brother and we sat at the bar which had plenty of space to enjoy your plates (unusual for bar seating). This place has a very adventurous menu so is not suitable for picky eaters. My favorite dish was the duck tongue! I really appreciated the creativity that goes into making each dish as unique as they are. It is definitely unlike any other restaurant in Chicago, and I would advise everyone try it but definitely plan ahead of time! We tried a majority of things on the menu and didn't come across one we didn't enjoy.
Such a beautiful experience, and all of the food was to die for.

Ahhh so good. My mouth still waters from the thought of this place. We had 1030pm reservations! & nearly cancelled & we were so happy we didn't. Our party of 6 ordered so much (tried to get the whole menu/spectrum: bread, veggies, goat, pork, chicken, fish, lamb) & even the few plates we didn't LOVE we liked a lot. Our alcoholic drinks were on point. We enjoyed our server (Josh)? When it came down to dessert, he recommended we choose from his fave 3 & we ended up getting all of them because he steered us in the right direction all night. We are from out of town & wished we could come back every week. Hands down the best meal of our trip!
Make sure you get a reservation - it is well worth it. We went for our anniversary and had a blast. The food was wonderful and inventive and so tasty!

The best restaurant in Chicago that's not a price fix.  Everything is great here.

Try the pig face.

Valet is a must in this bustling area.

Do not settle for little goat diner.  It is not the same.

Excellent food, nice casual ambiance, great service!

What else can I say which hasn't already been said? Our situation was kinda unique though, because we were sitting outside, enjoying our Goat Carpaccio and Grilled Baby Octopus, when all of a sudden, it started pouring. Freakin' unpredictable Chicago weather! Despite the fact that this place was crazy busy at this point, the staff was able to somehow accommodate us with indoor seats. We had to wait about 10 minutes, but we didn't mind.

Once we sat down again, we had our Pig Face and Grilled Cauliflower, both of which were extremely tasty. The Pig Face had a wonderful texture -- a mix of crunchiness from the deep fried pork and gooeyness from the egg.

They also have a good selection of beers. I would love to come back here again on my next trip to Chicago and try the rest of the menu (both food and drinks).

So I feel like we cheated a bit here, given that we'd heard so much about the Girl and the Goat from friends and that it's so highly reviewed. Nevertheless, we always choose 1 great restaurant to go to every time we visit my parents in the 'burbs (We're from Denver) and the Girl and the Goat had finally come up. In debating ratings, hubby and I agreed on a 5 because we simply could not think of a single dish that was anything less than excellent. The blueberry jam with the bread was rich, the bread itself having the right amount of butter. The green beans have ruined me for green beans ever again, with their delightful cashews and savory sauce. The chicken had just the right amount of smoked flavor to reflect a wood fired approach without being too smoky, and the halibut was polished off in seconds flat by my other half. We also loved the Pierogis and the service was on point (helpful without being obtrusive and with great (and enthusiastic) explanations of every dish). So many other nice touches, such as the fact that our water glasses never had the chance to be empty, the drinks were perfectly mixed and the server brought out a free birthday dessert for my husband (I'd noted it was his birthday in the reservations).

Along those lines, be sure to save room for dessert! We ordered a second blackberry cake  in addition to the budino (which wowed with its salty butterscotch flavor and homemade whipped cream) and both were incredible!

Really hit and miss with the food!  

Service was great, but prices felt a bit high since not all the food was impressive.

Let's start off from "good" to "meh" :

Confit Goat Belly ($19): Bourbon Butter, Lobster, Crab, and Fennel. This was the highlight of the night! The goat belly was very flavorful and slightly salty, but the sweet lobster and crab pulled it all together.  Recommended :)

Goat Empanadas ($16): Marinated Sheep Feta, Picked Golden Beets, Tzatziki. This was one of the favorites of the night. It was a great blend of flavors, but the portion size was a little small considering the price.

PB&J ($8): Salted Peanut Semifreddo, Concord Grape Granita, and Brioche Donuts. This was perfect! Love all the individual tastes...but combined, it's the perfect mix of sweet, salty, and tangy all at once.  Yummy!

Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face ($16): Sunny Side Egg, Tamarind, Cilantro, Red Wine Maple, and Potato Stix. This tasted like breakfast in each bite lol. Just like bacon, eggs, and hashbrowns.  It was good, but I wouldn't order it again.

Kona Kampachi Crudo ($16): Crisp Pork Belly, Chili Aioli, and Caperberries. This was ok..everything tasted good, but the combination wasn't perfectly orchestrated to me.  I'd pass on this one.

Escargot Ravioli ($13): Bacon and Tamarind-Miso Sauce. This was just ok...the sauce was a bit runny and didn't compliment the escargot in my opinion. Pass!

Bittersweet Chocolate ($8): Shittake-Caramel Gelato and Toffee Creme Fraiche. Just like it sounds...bittersweet. It was a little more on the bitter end for me...I'd pass on this one too!

So if you have better luck than me, you could have a better experience.  But since not all the food was up to par in my book, I started thinking about the money being spent.  

Great food could merit the over $120+ tab...but this did not.

review.des:
Girl & the Goat lived up to its amazing reputation.  While it is a spendy restaurant, the food and drinks were worth every penny.  We had a beer, cocktail, and shared about 5 plates.  Our check was just under $100 before tip.  

I made reservations in September for mid-November.  My only options, for a Thursday night, were 4:30 p.m. or 9:30 p.m.  If you want a prime dining time, you are going to have to book really early.  We were running very late and didn't arrive until after 5:00 p.m., but I called ahead to let them know and they said that our table was secure.  We received outstanding service from the time I made the call until the moment we left for the evening.

Our waitress made us feel very comfortable and welcome at Girl & the Goat.  She even graciously took a photo of my husband & I (like total tourists, we are!), and she made some recommendations from the menu.  Here are the dishes we tried:

Goat Bleu Bread.  A dense bread with robust blue cheese flavor, carmelized onions and I believe a bacon jam.  I generally despite onions, but I could not get enough of this bread or the onions & jam.

Pork Belly.  The size of the dish was deceiving as it was the most "artistic" looking of the bunch.  Our waitress recommended it when we told her that we like sushi.  Every ingredient in all of the dishes are chosen intentionally and you could really taste it with the pork belly.

Goat Empanadas.  How do groups of more than two share these?  These were my favorite dish.  It's a good "starter" dish for anyone who is fussy about their food.  Basically it is goat meat (which isn't at all gamey or weird) in an empanada crust.

Pig Face.  So crunchy, so flavorful!  I will never look at a pig's face the same again.  When served, it is not actually on the pig's head, so the faint of heart need not worry.  It's just another part of the pig, and quite possibly the BEST part.

Cauliflower.  The best vegetable I've ever eaten.  I believe it was made with parmesan, pine nuts, and some other stuff.  The portion is huge and definitely enough for four people.  The cauliflower had a surprising spiciness to it as well.

There is a short list of cocktails and beers, including Three Floyds Gumballhead.  Thanks to Ericka A.'s recommendation, I had the "Best of Three" cocktail which was light, refreshing, very slightly fruity and complimented my meal well.

I would go back to Girl & the Goat in a heartbeat.  Usually with spendy restaurants, I go once and check it off of my list, but this place is worth attending regularly.  Three ladies at the table next to us (on a Thursday) were inquiring with the waitress about reservations on Sunday, only 3 days later!

Amazing service and food.  Definitely consider Girl & the Goat for a birthday, anniversary, or "just because" kind of night.

One thing I noticed about Chicago's cuisine is that they sure do love their tapas. Portions are pretty small so you must order a minimum of four to five dishes between two people to get full.  The girl and the goat specializes mainly in GOAT (DUH) and pork. I was excited to try this place because this was the highest rated restaurant from all the restaurants we went to in Chicago (btw I'm A tourist here) but definetly wasn't the best restaurant that we tried.

We tried the Chickpea fritters. The chickpea fritters was very well seasoned and they made it so that the taste resembled meat. It was served with a tangy yogurt sauce which balanced out the deep flavors of the chickpeas.

Grilled baby octopus- good but heavily seasoned with salt. Ordered a brioche bun because it was too salty to eat alone. Their breads all come with unique home made butters and sauce to accentuate the taste.

Also tried the goat confit with lobsters and the goat empanyadas. The best unexpected thing was the empanyadas. They were Perfect. HIghly recommend the empanyadas.

"Goats gone wild.  Whatever floats your goat.  Ride the love goat."  I walked into The Girl & the Goat and saw all the wait staff in witty t-shirts.  Those who know me (and my yelp reviews) know I love a good pun.  So like Christopher Boone (from The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-time) seeing 5 red cars in a row, I knew this was going to be a Super Good meal.  My group of about 14 people couldn't get a reservation 1 week before our arrival in Chicago, so we opted to arrive at the restaurant at 5pm to sit at the bar and lounge area.  By 530pm, the establishment was bustling.  

Corny Goat Cheese Mousse.  Spread offenses aren't the only thing that has made a comeback.  I find myself ordering different spreads at different restaurants and this blend was top notch.

The Goat Leg.  I swore this monstrosity weighed a couple of tons.  It is served on a cutting board with 5 different dipping sauces.  Each individual had a favorite dip that they preferred.  However, the dressing wasn't needed because the meat falls right off the bone and has enough gusto to bring mute tongues back to life.

Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face.  This will melt your face off.  Everything is better with a runny egg.

Kalbi Style Beef Ribs.  Stick to the ones from Korean restaurants.
Hiramasa Crudo.  We made a mistake and thought that the pork belly was the main ingredient in this dish.

Softshell Crab.  I dare you to find me someone who doesn't love softshell crab.  Dare you.

Braised Beef Tongue.  Eating this will have you speaking in many different languages wondering how something can taste this good.

Escargot Ravioli. Snails move too slow for my taste, but it seems my friends enjoyed this dish.

Etc, etc.  My group ordered more items which either 1. Escapes me at the moment or 2. Was off the main menu and I did not write it down.

After all that, how do you have room for dessert?  Thank goodness I did because the G.O.A.T. (Greatest Of All Time) dessert is The Girl & the Goat's chocolate bouchon which consists of foie fluff, salted toffee, milk chocolate sorbet, and gooseberry compote.  After the first bite my mind was reeling.  Then I battled depression because the caloric count must be through the stratosphere and because I would have to fly to Chicago just to have another taste.  Oh, the pork fat doughnuts were hypnotizing as well.

The servers knew the extensive menu like the back of their hand.  They were quick to take our orders and refill our waters but also friendly to share some laughs.
Fabulous. Pricey but worth s splurge. The pig face and bone marrow may not sound good, but they are amazing. Go.
This place is amazing!!! Everything i tried was delicious.  Give this place a try... you won't regret it!

When I was in Chicago, everyone said to try this place and I'm glad I did. I tried making reservations, but of course, they were fully booked for 2-3 weeks out so we decided to come by right when it opened at 4:30pm and got a seat at the bar. It worked perfectly and I was surprise that a lot of people were there on the dot doing the same. Our waiter/bartender was super sweet - every single one of them. We had actually been eating right before we came to this place so we weren't super hungry, but wanted to try a few dishes. We got the infamous pig face, wood fired scallop in uni sauce, oysters, and butterscotch miso budino to share. Everything was DELICIOUS - especially the pig face and budino. It was very different from anything I've eaten and I was left fascinated by the dishes and wanting more! MUST TRY IF YOU'RE IN CHICAGO!

pics.caption: Pig face - scrambled up and ready to eat

review.des: It's been a few years since I last came here. Never quite managed to write about it. This restaurant is exceptional. In a way that would make every major city proud. The service, although fine, isn't quite at the level of the kitchen or chef's creativity. A relatively small price to pay for a memorable meal.

Girl & the Goat lives up to my high expectations!  The ambiance is both perfect for a date, and just a friendly get together. All good is served as family-style tapas.  One small thing I noticed is that each dish was customized to our group - 4 of us and 4 pieces- unlike most tapas places when you sometimes have to split 3 pieces between 4 people. Dishes we tried were the green beans, cauliflower with pine nuts, pierogies, duck tartar with pickles gooseberries, goat empanadas, beef tongue, lamb shank, lamb ribs, and the halibut.  Everything was outstanding!  If I had to pick a favorite, I'd say the duck tartar is a can't miss. All cocktails were fantastic. We tried 4 off the menu and all were excellent!

My friends and I visited this place over the weekend.  We were unable to make reservations, so we braced ourselves for a possible 2-hour wait.  We got there and were informed that it might be a 45-minute wait.  We went to the bar, ordered drinks, and maybe 15 minutes later were told that we would be seated because someone had cancelled a reservation.  Great for us!  We ordered the shishito peppers, the pan roasted halibut, goat empanadas, soft-shell crab, and peanut butter bread.  The shishito peppers and the halibut were AMAZING! If I were to rate Girl & the Goat solely for these two items, I would give 5 stars.The empanadas were good, peanut butter bread, and crab were good, but I probably would not order them again.

I've never had a bad meal here.

Seriously, EVERYTHING IS DELICIOUS.
I go two-three times a year and I always order the pig face, the shishito peppers, and  the oysters.

With this two month wait, you just gotta plan out your night.
1. Stretch out your stomach with lots of salad the night before. You'll feel better about it when you're shovelling large quantities of food into your mouth at Girl and the Goat.
2. Ladies/gentleman, wear an empress shirt. The fabric and shape should be forgiving. People will wonder, what's going on under there. Pregnancy? Food baby? A humble person with rock hard abs? Perhaps.
3. Literally order anything on the menu. You will not be disappointed. I have a rule about going to a restaurant. I never order something I can't make myself.
4. Always order dessert. This is not your regular, "local bakery items but pricier. Expect delicious weirdness and you shall receive.

This has to be on my list while I'm in Chicago! And it did not disappointed. We came on a Monday without a reservation at 5pm. Thank God, NO WAIT!
We started with roasted cauliflower. It was delicious!!!!!! It turned the non-cauliflower-eating-me to eating almost half of the dish. We also had the grilled baby octopus. It was so good I almost wanna get another order and take it on the plane with me. The mix of different flavors in the dish makes it very interesting and refreshing. And they were not cheap about the octopus.
We then share the very popular dish the pig face. I don't think I can describe this dish. We finished the whole thing within 5 mins. So there.....
I really love this place not only because of the food, it's also the unpretentious environment (thanks to the cute decor and friendly staff) and the generous portion of the food. I definitely need to come back here for many more times whenever I am in CHI town again!

After hearing all the hype for years I finally gave this place a shot and wasn't disappointed! The dishes were creative, integrated, and quality. I especially loved the goat kabob with tahini special and the pork belly. The fries didn't seem anything special, but...well, they're fries. Prices add up quick but it's no different from the rest of the neighborhood so you know what your getting into. I also appreciated the efforts to build a varied and unique wine list. While there are some hits and some misses, that comes with the territory. I'll definitely be back!

I was scared to order the escargot ravioli only because I had a bad experience  with escargot when I first had it at another restaurant years ago (think of the pieces of shell that are in a bite when they don't shuck oysters well...the same happened with escargot shells). To my surprise the ravioli was very tasty and didn't have that nasty chewy consistency. The goat belly had a nice crispy outside to it and paired great with the crab and lobster. The service is of a luxury restaurant. Our table was always cleaned and our drinks were always replenished right away.

Two words... PIG. FACE.
The food here is inspiring. The dishes are so thought out and flavors so developed. The food is not unique just for the sake of being different. It's unique because someone thought outside the box when building this menu. Service, cocktails, atmosphere and food are all money.
I can't wait to go back next time I'm in Chicago.
I've been multiple times and it does not disappoint. My favorite dishes are the calamari bruschetta and the wood oven roasted pig face.

Such a delightful meal. Had to wait an extra half hour to get the Chefs table, but it was worth it. Chefs were friendly and made us some delightful dishes. Everything was a highlight and you cannot go wrong here. For the pricing its totally worth it and will be back again soon.

Absolutely  Amazing !!!   14 entrees with 7 hilarious co-workers...BEST TIME EVER !!! Such a timely rotation of the different selections !! Ohhh and the crumpets ..the salmon butter o m g !!!....everything was amazing...the green beans were delicious x 10000. This is a great spot for a cool crew to explore creative dishes..i can wait to return..

We were looking forward given the amazing reviews on Yelp. We tried two weeks ago. It was bad, but we were not so hungry. Tried last night again. Well, it was worse.

- Oysters were NOT fresh. Seriously, this ruins a night.
- Pig face... ours was pure fat. No meat. We expected a fatty dish, but we also expected flavor and some meat.
- Goat Confit - well, it was just butter.

We asked our server about the meat and he replied: "It happens. Can't change it, house is too busy tonight."

We must be missing something.

This place lived up to every expectation I have ever had after constantly hearing rumors about this place.

Our waiter, Gary, so friendly!

Ambience: warm, welcoming and somewhat country-chic.

appetizer: started with oysters with a bit of aioli on them. They were my least favorite but an awesome starter.

Octopus. Holy moly! Mouth-gasm!

side dish: cauliflower. omg. I am such a veggie lover and these were like nothing I've ever had. Who knew cauliflower with peppers and mint could be so tasty?

Dinner: goat belly with lobster and crab and duck breast.

Dessert: whatever the last one on the menu was. By this time I was so high on the food I can't even remember what it was called.

We already made a reservation to return on 4 months.

Bravo, Stephanie!

I don't know what I can say about this place that hasn't already been said, but I can agree that it is an AMAZING, transcendent dining experience.

Getting a reservation in a timely manner is hard, but it's worth the wait. As a vegetarian, I did love everything on the menu (except the wontons), and so did my vegetarian dining companions. The desserts were to-die-for. The dessert wine was to-die-for. This is a place that is good for groups, and great for sharing. And the server on my first trip here, Brendan, made our experience truly truly magical. As I said, transcendent experience.
Simply outstanding! The food was amazing! Great service-the waitress was really fun and was on top of her game all night. I would highly recommend.

Here's how you get a table at this place for 2....make a reservation at least a month in advance!  It's really hard to get a quick reservation... but once you've made it, you're golden.  Lucky for me and my bf, we got a reservation a week before, only because I was watching the reservation page like a hawk and I managed to squeeze us in at 4:45 on a Monday.  But it was delicious!!  We got:

-apple smacks - ginger butter and apple sauce with nice warm bread.  Since it was fall, this was a great appetizer that incorporates all that warm fall flavor.  The bread even had pistachios in it!

-the roasted cauliflower - it's more complex than it sounds!!  There's so much in it!  Pickled peppers, pine nuts, mint, cheese.. you'll love it.  SO GOOD!

-lamb ribs - its one of the larger plates that this restaurant offers and definitely one of my favorites.  The lamb meat literally fell off the bone!  It was nicely marinated and omg.. soo soo good.

-wood oven roasted pig face - OMG...  i know its a must to get a here and I had to try it.. but they're right.. it's a must try!  It sounds weird.. but you don't really see the pig face.. it's more of a portion of it.  It's very well done and the flavors are amazing.  I was like.. where have you been all my life?

If you're wondering why we got so many plates for 2 people, but this place is family style, so they don't really give you big portions.  This was just enough for the 2 of us.  We left feeling full and satisfied.  I highly recommend this place.. DELICIOUS!

As far as I'm concerned, The Girl and the Goat is a must try for any visitor (or resident) of Chicago. Just make sure you secure a reservation well in advance, otherwise you will be mad dogging those at the crowded bar area to quickly finish up and leave, as I unabashedly did.

I tried two items on the menu. The first was the delightfully complex Kona Kampachi Crudo. The raw fish was light and refreshing, but when paired with crisp pork belly, it became a delicious play on surf and turf. The contrast in flavors, textures, and temperatures was amazing. The chili aoili added spice and richness, the pickled caperberries provided just the right amount of acidity, and the bread crisps gave the dish another layer of texture.

The second item I tried was none other than the Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face. After seeing Anthony Bourdain eat this on The Layover, I knew I had to order it. But to be honest, the dish was little more challenging than I thought it would be. The pig face was really intense, gamy even. The trio of sauces -- tamarind, red-wine maple, and cilantro -- helped to offset the pungent flavor of the meat, but I found the first two a tad sweet, even when mixed up with the glorious yolk of the fried egg on top. Finally, the fried potato sticks added much needed texture. I loved it for its bold (dare I say, in your face?) exoticism, but the sheer decadence of this dish makes it one to share and not hog to yourself.

The decor is very hip and modern, and the service was what one might expect from such a red hot spot -- a little vain, a little aloof, a little haughty. But I still had a good time and will surely come back the next time I'm in Chicago.

4 1/2 stars

After hearing all the fuss, we decided that we needed to experience Girl & the Goat on our trip to Chicago.  I was pretty pleased.  Despite attempting to make a reservation weeks in advance, we were only able to get a table for 4:30pm.  We ordered:

- Johnny Applecheese bread - tasty, sweet, and savory.  Served with chili-cheddar butter and malted oil.  This is the only way to eat bread.
- Roasted Pig Face - crispy, amazing fatty flavor (but it got kind of boring after a few bites; better to be shared with 4 or more people)
- Wood Grilled Broccoli - the broccoli was INSANE.  I don't even like broccoli but it's the best I've ever tasted.  Smoky and tender.
- Confit Goat Belly - did not enjoy this.  Too rich and buttery, and they used WAY too much vanilla.  Lobster was rough and rubbery; the whole dish was a mess.
- Braised Pork Shank - incredibly juicy and tender, outside was crispy and fall-off-the-bone.  Great presentation.  It came with bland naan, 2 unappetizing sauces (buttermilk and spicy sauce), and their version of kimchee (not edible).

We were stuffed by the time the Pork Shank came out, but indulged anyway.  The service was amazing and spot-on.  Our waitress was wonderfully gracious, very friendly, and enthusiastic about her work.  She made some great recommendations.  They also have a great beer and wine selection.  And the interior is very cozy and rustic.  Lots of wood and natural fixtures.

My only complaint is that some of their dishes are too flavorful.  There is too much going on and there is too much contrast within their dishes.  There is not much subtlety and cohesion so it feels forced and chaotic.  For example, the Braised Pork Shank on its own was wonderfully delicious and worth ordering, but everything it came with did not fit at all.

Overall, I had a great experience.  This is a great establishment and I would love to come back next time I'm in town.  I want to try all that Girl & the Goat has to offer.

pics.caption: Confit Goat Belly - too much vanilla flavoring

review.des:
I wanted to LOVE this place so I could agree with all of the hype.

I was a little let down. We went with 5 people for my birthday and got 2-3 dishes each. The only thing I left leaving truly enjoying was the goat liver mousse and the goat cheesecake. The green beans were also good.

There is sauce on everything, which normally is great. But then they don't bring fresh plates after each "round" unless you ask for them. I would think they wouldn't want your sauces all mixing together. Also bizarre that there were no spoons on the table considering the level of sauce.

One of the things that stuck out in a negative way was the hamachi crudo and the ham frites. The crudo was just very...odd. Slimy and luke warm. The smoked tomato aioli that came with the frites was downright terrible and the flavor stayed in my mouth for a long time. It must have been completely over smoked. To me it tasted like that fake bacon stuff you'd put on a salad mixed with mayo. Completely overpowering.

I also got a bad oyster.

If a friend asked me to go again, I'd go, but I certainly wouldn't encourage it.

Service was excellent and the music was good.

After missing out on dining here last year for my bday I was lucky to get a reservation this time around. Our experience was very positive, the tables were all occupied but it didn't feel stuffed like some places get. The decor was nice as well, it was modern without being pretentious. The lighting was dimmed but reasonably and the tables are well lit so you have no trouble seeing the menu or food as with some establishments. The staff was great, they knew the menu and did an excellent job describing and recommending from the selection.

We started off with a couple breads that were nice and warm, one of which had a mushroom butter that melted wonderfully. Next we had the hamachi crudo with crispy pork belly, pan fried shishito peppers, and the kusshi oysters. The crudo was fresh and went well with the pork belly, and the peppers while not spicy had a nice smokey flavor that married perfectly with parmesan. The oysters weren't bad but I couldn't taste what it was served with, possibly due to the smokey peppers I had just eaten. Next up was the wood oven roasted pig face and the lamb ribs. I like how the pork, egg, and potato stix all come together when mixing it all up. The crunchiness, soft egg, and savory flavor made for a nice combination. The lamb ribs were very tender and moist, and the fat wasn't excessive or off-putting which can happen with some lamb rib dishes.

The sauteed green beans with fish sauce vinaigrette was cooked perfectly with the perfect amount of sauce, not to mention served in a hefty portion for sharing. What I thought was excellent was the buffalo stye pork shank, it was one of the few dishes I've had that attempted to capitalize on the popularity of 'buffalo style' and successfully hit the mark. The naan was soft, sauce was flavorful and not overbearing, and the pork had the fried texture you would expect without becoming too dry. Our server was nice enough to tear the shank apart for us too for easy sharing. Our final dish was the confit goat belly with bourbon butter and lobster and crab. We liked the taste but honestly expected a larger portion. The goat belly seemed more like typical goat meat than belly, but having never had goat belly our expectations were based on pork belly.

We finished things off with two desserts and two cheeses, and our server was kind enough to bring an extra dessert with a lit candle after my mom spilled the beans about it being my birthday. The cheeses were Kunik-Pasteurized Goat and Dunbarton Blue-Raw Cow, the blue was really mild with few veins. I highly recommend any of their cocktails, each of us ordered something different and they were all worthy of repeating.

Apart from the difficulty of getting a reservation and the limited portions of some dishes I found Girl and the Goat to be a definite hit. If you're willing to gamble on a walk-in and have the ability of doing something else to kill the time I overheard someone with a 90 minute wait. Hey, that's better than dining at 4:45 or 10pm like I was seeing.

pics.caption: confit goat belly with bourbon butter, lobster n' crab, and fennel
sauteed green beans with fish sauce vinaigrette and cashews [left], Pork Shank with naan, squash kimchi, buffalo sauce [right]

review.des: Girl and the Goat definitely lived up to its hype! I went on a Friday night with my husband and a friend, and even at peak hours we were able to get a spot to eat at the bar without a reservation. We split multiple dishes and had some great cocktails. Some of our favorites were: sweet potato bleu cheese pierogies and goat empanadas. Great music and ambiance, and even better service from behind the bar!

We have been here countless times, and each time I love this restaurant more and more! I cannot begin to tell about each experience or plate we have had so many. We have had intimate two person dinners, family dinners and birthday parties.  We feel we know some of the wait staff who have been around since the opening and it's always funny to have that recognition when dinning. Their wait staff has always been insightful in explaining any changes to the menu and making recommendations. I also like how they stagger the dishes and time them perfectly throughout the experience. They have a food service system that works despite the obvious, they are always slammed.

Over our visits a few of the dishes had remained on the menu, they are just so good! My overall favorite I get every time are the Sautéed Green Beans! I just cannot get enough of the warm beans marinated in the flavorful fish sauce. I also recommend the Shishito Peppers and the Chickpea Fitters. They are fun dishes to share with the table (or keep for yourself!).

My boyfriend and I usually stick to the fish dishes on the menu because he does not eat meat. As these change all the time I cannot specifically list the best here. However, we have never had a dish we did not like. I do eat meat, however, and feel it a duty to try some of Stephanie's interesting meat creations. I have tried the pig face (pig cheeks) and a pork belly dish. As expected, no complaints from me!

Depending on how hungry we are we always try at least one of the bread and butter pairings, many times we cannot make up our mind and just get all three.

On to dessert, just order dessert! I had one of the best desserts I've ever had at G&G. It has been on the menu twice and if it ever reappears, get it! (a dark flowerless chocolate brownie with caramel and topped with shitake mushroom gelato (yes shitake mushroom). The flavors worked so well together it was amazing). I asked for this dessert once when it was off the menu and the staff checked in the back and at least brought me some leftover shitake gelato.  Score!

Last, G&G also has a knowledgeable revolving beer menu for the craft beer geek in our group and a nice wine list for the more refined. Make reservations in advance or take a chance to find a seat at the bar. I've never seen the restaurant empty or with room to move around. The smells and dark wood create a warm welcoming atmosphere that's laid back but still remains a part of the go-to-be-scene crowd. Have fun, try new things and enjoy yourself!

We somehow grabbed reservations at Girl and the Goat through American Express concierge service. We were visiting Chicago for the weekend & it definitely elevates our Chicago experience. This restaurant was incredible!Our service was exceptional, and since both of us went to school in Virginia, we bonded and she even let us try some of the appetizers on the house (shh). When I mentioned to some of the Chicago natives where we dined, they were awestruck and complimented our choice and asked how we snagged a ressy (which instantly mad the experience better). We honestly ordered the entire menu, but the dishes that really stuck out were the green beans (with this RIDICULOUS fish sauce viniagrette), the pork shank & the apple bread. I definitely recommend this restaurant! Until next time, Chicago!
The ambience is great, friendly and helpful staff, delicious options, lots of space, wonderful place to eat.

pics.caption: Wood oven roasted pig face. sunny side egg. tamarind. cilantro. red wine-maple. potato stix
Goat empanadas. miso-blue cheese aioli. squash-apple slaw
Sweet potato bleu cheese pierogies. mushroom cream. maitake mushroom ragout. apple

review.des: Enjoyed our meal here and the drinks at the adjacent bar. Bartender very friendly as well. I would definitely go back. There is a wait, so be ready..

I was blown away by Girl & The Goat on my first visit last year but this time, not so much.  The place is still packed and you still have to stalk OpenTable to get a reservation but instead of being this new place where locals hang out, it seems like it's become the place for tourists who think they know the "secret" restaurants that only locals go to.

My biggest complaint is that the menu hasn't changed in over a year.  In fact, when the waitress asked us if we had been here before and told her it had been over a year, she said "Oh good. So you're familiar with the menu". That was a bad sign. You have a restaurant that is supposedly run by an award winning chef who is always on the lookout for new dishes and your menu hasn't changed in over a year? Not good. The pork shank was still incredible but everything else was average and boring. Duck tongue tasted like some sort of fried meat but was way too acidic. They proved once again that seafood is not their strong point with the ahi tuna. While the tuna was decent, the mushrooms ruined the dish. Bread was boring and desserts were sub-par.

Your "newness" has worn off, Girl & Goat. So many other places are doing what you're doing now but instead of changing and keeping ahead of everybody, you've decided to settle for "middle of the road".
Me and my husband went here with a few friends and the food was amazing. Highly recommend it and especially if you wanna try new interesting things. For example their beef tongue was really good

Definitely worth the hype.
My friend called each day twice a day till she managed a reservation within a week of our trip to Chicago, which is impressive considering you have to book almost a month in advance.
We ordered several vegetarian dishes and one goat empanada dish and each one blew us away.

They did a great job of staggering each dish so we would all pass it around, savor it for a while and as we were getting low, the next one would arrive in perfect succession.

We meant to try the goat belly but we were so full we had to cancel it! Every dish was packed with flavor. None of us at the table like cauliflower but it came recommended so we all reluctantly tried and it turned out to be everyone's favorite dish of the night.

The bread app was fantastic, the goat empanadas just melted in our mouths, and the ramp salad was so well-rounded with the smoked blueberries.

I can't wait to be back!

Great service!  Definitely overhyped, but then again, what can a Top Chef winner really wow with?  Some items were fantastic (grilled beet salad, green beans, pork shank, duck breast, and beef tongue.)

The desserts are AMAZING!!!

Try for yourself for an experience and bragging rights to your co-workers. But do not hype yourself up as you may not be super impressed.

4.5 stars, but I will round it up to 5 stars! Make sure you make reservations!!

Delicious! Great food, ambiance, and service!!

Between 3 people, this was the perfect amount.

Ordered: The dishes are served tapa styled, so it is best to order and share!

1) Chickpea fritter: 5/5 Wow, amazing! Highly recommend this dish!
2) Roasted cauliflower 3/5, a little disappointed; The cauliflower could have been slightly more roasted
3) Wood fired scallops: 4/5 The flavors were amazing!! Uni!
4) Pan roasted halibut: 3/5 Slightly disappointed b/c there was TOO much going on in this dish
5) Crisp braised pork shank: 4/5 Another amazing dish
6) Miso-butterscotch budino: 5/5 I am not a fan of cooked fruits, but I was pleasantly surprised how great this dessert was!

Drinks are awesome. Food is good but very inconsistent. You order one dish and its huge shareable plate, another dish for the same price is literally 2 think pieces of lunch meat on a plate with some sauce. The empanadas were great.

The food was incredible, pretty decently priced for the quality, the service was impeccable and the ambiance is great!

There was a group of 4 of us and here's a list of what we got:

1. Warm marinated olives- best olives I've ever had probably because you usually get your olives cold but these just melt perfectly in your mouth. The portion was your average olive plate size

2. Pan fried shishito peppers- very good, but VERY spicy so be careful. Good size plate

3. Wood grilled broccoli- AMAZING with melted cheese in the bottom, good size plate

4. Seared diver scallops- delicious, but it only comes with 2 of them so not the best for sharing

5. Hamachi crudo- very fresh but not enough, only comes with 3 small, thin strips so not a very shareable plate

6. Ham frites- typical french fries but they were small, nothing crazy or different, not really worth getting

7. pig face- very tender , it comes with an egg on top and don't worry it's not actually the face of a pig. The amount was perfect to share between 4 people or else it wouldn't been too filling

8.Goat empanada- I liked this one but it only came with 2 empanadas

9. Sugo- one of my favorite dishes! it's a pasta with tender noodles, beef and what tastes like a bolognese sauce and carrots, the portion was perfect

If you live in Chicago or are visiting please try to come and eat here, you won't regret it!

There is nothing negative to say about the Girl and the Goat!!! Love love loved it!!! The food was all EXCELLENT!!! Went with a large group which was nice because we got to try so many different things. Not that I would not go with a small group but the large group enabled us to try so much! We basically let the waiter order for us and he hit a home run with all his suggestions!! Getting in is not easy so I hope someday I will be able to go again!!!!

This restaurant is off the charts delicious. I almost didn't go because they didn't have any reservations available while we were in town on a Sunday or Monday. But the three of us walked in and lucked out with seats at the bar. The food was outrageously delicious--every single bite. I can't recommend this restaurant enough. I hope she opens one up in Connecticut where she grew up so I can go more often!!

Walked in on a Wed night (10:30PM) and got seated at the bar right away. Halibut and lamb ribs were cooked to perfect doneness and tasted excellent.

But can do with out the hoyty toyty PhD garnishes - almond butter with white aspargus morcora churm what???  

Service was very friendly and beers good. But room, music, and scene too hip for this old fart that wandered in just for a midnight snack.

My friend made a reservation here about a month in advance for 7 people to have dinner on a Thursday night in September. The wait was absolutely worth it!! Love the family style eating concept -- all dishes are made to share. They recommend ordering about 2 dishes per a person. We ended up ordering probably 3 per a person and went absolutely ham (pun intended) eating everything.

Here are some of the table's favorite dishes:

1) The Pig Face -- the absolute winner...tastes better than bacon, if you can believe it!
2) The Chickpea Fritters -- you'd never expect something like this to be amazing, but it really left a presence on me -- so soft and tender.
3) The grilled octopus -- the sauces and the vegetables mixed with octopus were delicious
4) The steak ribs -- juicy, tender, and the corn is a plus
5) The Halibut -- the balsamic vinaigrette on the bottom of the dish really made this so flavorful!

The ambiance is great too. Check out the creepy goth goat painting on the side lol -- It can get pretty loud, but who cares? The food is what you're there for anyways!

I really liked dining here. It's a unique experience. The service is impeccable. The food is delicious. It's not a place I would go if I were really hungry and looking to chow down. It's a place I'd go to try new foods and enjoy the presentation and service.

I was impressed with GATG. I was surprised at the affordability. Based on the amount of praise and demand for reservations here...I expected it to be way more expensive. We were able to order and try a lot of dishes, grab cocktails and a bottle of wine without breaking the bank

Quality and Creativity was great. We even went to Duck Duck Goat the following night. I liked GATG better.

I'd come back here if I was in Chicago more often but there seems to be so many restaurants we would like to try.

This place is a no brainer...make reservations far in advance if you want a decent time.

Definitely worth planning ahead and making reservations here.
1. Shishito peppers: A bit salty, but so much intense flavor. I personally love my food covered in salt so I didn't mind the heavy hand in the salt jar.
2. Roasted Cauliflower: good, but just a bit too much cauliflower for me.
3. Kohlrabi salad: bright and refreshing.  Good palate cleansing dish between heavy meat dishes
4. Hamachi Crudo: sweet mary moses. I had to restrain myself and let other people taste this one. Delicious.

I can't remember what else we had, but everything was definitely on the heavy-flavored side of the scale, which for me, IS ABSOLUTELY PERFECT!
I like the family style and casual atmosphere of the restaurant. The drinks were on point, as well as the prices!

My boyfriend and I went here to celebrate our anniversary and we were not disappointed! We did not make reservations and decided to go there right when it opened. We were really lucky and got a seat at the bar area.

First off the service was phenomenal! The bar tenders were super nice and very knowledgeable about the menu and answered every question that we had. Also we didn't feel rushed sitting at the bar and the dishes were evenly spaced for us to enjoy each one. Also the cocktails were amazing!

Here is what we ordered:

Corn fed bread: Definitely enjoyed the goat cheese butter. Good to try but wished I skipped it to order another delicious dish

Escargot ravioli: Served in a a tamarind miso sauce. Very light and I liked the play of the pasta in miso.

Duck tongues: the bartender recommended it and we were not disappointed! There were so many complex flavors with this dish. The duck tongues were fried to a nice crispy texture and pairing it with the tuna poke and crunchy vegetables created great texture. Definitely my favorite dish of the night

Confit goat belly: Another delicious dish! It had a consistency like brisket and I really enjoyed the lumps of lobster and crab that came with it. The shaved fennel added some texture to the goat belly

We were quite full after that but we got dessert on the house.

Miso butterscotch budino: amazing!!!!!! the combination of the the glazed pineapple, bacon toffee, candied cashews and butterscotch pudding with a little bit of sponge cake was something that I never tasted before. If you get this dessert you need to eat all of the components at once and experience a sweet and salty complex flavor.

Many thanks for the delicious dessert.

Overall definitely worth the hype!

If this place wasn't open late, I don't think I could have experienced it since it's so busy. After trying it out all the buzz around it makes perfect sense.

Everything I tried was great, but the pork shank was unforgettable. It was perfectly cooked and it pulled apart effortlessly. Along with the sauces and naan bread it definitely hit the spot and I highly recommend you try it.

innovative menu, well executed, with a great feont of the house and superior service.

this is a well oiled machine putting out GREAT small plates.  this is as good as it gets a restaurant that is great food but not fine dining.

what was really impressive is the way the bar is integrated to the restaurant.  really a team effort with drinks coming out quickly.

really really forst rate from top to bottom.

word to the wise:  dont be put off by the names.  for example, the duck lips.dont have duck or.lips...

OMG the ribs are out of this world!!!!!!!!!!!!!!   I could eat them daily!!  Everything has it's own little spiced twist.   The staff is friendly and loves to joke n make you feel welcomed.  Even ordering on the phone is fun with them.

Defiantly worth checking them out.  You won't be disapointed at all!!!

Amazing food.
Great Service.
Make a reservation in advance.

It can be crazy hard to get in with a reservation here- we had to eat at like 9:30pm, no joke -  and the food is pricey and pretentious - ora king salmon tartare? please! - and the menu is off puttingly exoti - goat belly and mousse liver, yummy! And yet, this was one of the best culinary experiences of my life! Many foods that I normally can't stand were somehow made delicious. I had delicious goat stew and beef tongue and there was even escrgot that I managed not to throw up upon immediately viewing. Bring your wallets, open mind, a BUNCH of people to split the bill with and you're all set! FYI - these are snaller plates too so it's like literally one to two bites person if you are planning on sharing multiple dishes.

Went to this restaurant with a group of 4 and was absolutely blown away. The set up of the restaurant is smaller sized plates that you can share amongst your group, having four people was perfect because it allowed us to try lots of different dishes. Was impressed with everything, but three really stood out to me that are MUST HAVES: crisp braised pork shank, calamari bruschetta, and roasted cauliflower. The pork shank was one of the most tender pieces of meat I've ever had and was literally falling off the bone; along with the dressing and naan, the dish was out of this world. The calamari bruschetta was perfection; baguette with a goat milk ricotta and the most amazing grilled calamari to top it off. The roasted cauliflower was just ridiculous; doused in a bread crumb butter (we actually loved this dish so much that we ordered a second round). I promise you cannot go wrong with any of these dishes. Overall, very cool vibe, amazing food and service, and will definitely be coming back. If you're looking for a drink, I would highly recommend their Old Fashioned.

The ratings are real!  It's a great thing to checkout when you are visiting Chicago.  Be sure to reserve early as its a very busy place!

Food= Amazing.
Service = Amazing.

Choice on the menu can expand a bit, some items are not as original.

Amazing food, but you already know that. Just want to give a shout out to the staff (especially Justin), they are so friendly and knowledgeable and full of cool stories. Highly recommend eating at the bar and making some new friends.

PS try the halibut

Food was pretty good, but no hurry to return.  Busy Sunday night, but our reserved table was terrible -- one of a number right up against the railing dividing the seating area from the bar, and drinkers elbows were in our table space all night.  Also, the bathrooms reeked of pee; you could smell them from the top of the stairs drifting into the waiting area.
4 stars for salty, roasted food. Still a ways to go to become worthy. I don't get it why people still think charring a food makes it better...

Really good but heavy food. Only need 4 plates for two people (unless you are really heavy). Everything was awesome except the fried chickpeas. Desert was great too. But was so full after desert that I had to roll home!

Price is respectable too - 5 plates (including desert) + 2 cocktails ~ $100.

I called three months in advance for G&TG for a 7pm Sat reservation and that time wasn't available.  Even crazier, when we got there on time, we were told it would be another half hour until our table was ready.  Given all the hype around this place...  I sure as heck hoped that it would be worth the fuss, and overall, I think it was.

The food itself is what I'd call creative gastropub tapas.  Lots of small dishes that you and a partner can assemble Kore or less into your own distinct tasting menu.  The real rock stars we had we the kholarabi salad, the grilled broccoli, the halibut, and last but not least, the infamous pig face.  Everything else was good, but not necessarily unique.

Service is what really what granted G&TG the 5 star nod.  From the food to the wine, we felt like we were treated like royalty by servers who knew the menu like an Encyclopedia Britannica.  Honestly for the price, this place is a steal on taste and experience.

One word of advice though...  Skip the dessert.  All of them were bland and not really up to the rest of the meal.

Bright side:
I got the goat burger and also a lot of stares. The burger consisted of a beef patty, a pile of braised goat, shredded goat bbq, bacon, onion, and peppers wedged between 2 buns. It was at least 10" tall. And it was delicious. I packed half of it and ate it as soon as I got home.

Downside:
The server was slow at refilling our waters. The bloody mary I got was not good.i

Made the reservation long before we got to Chicago and so glad we did. Everything about this place is off the charts. The atmosphere is very cool and our server Taylor was outstanding. The menu was so unique and the food was perfect. We tried things I never thought I would eat in my life but was so glad we listened to our server. We had the Goat Empanadas, Wood Roasted Broccoli, Pan Roasted Sea Bass and the Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face with sunny side egg. For dessert we had the PB&J and the Cojeta-Black Pepper Gelato Pie (don't ask, just order it and enjoy).

Had we stayed in town longer we certainly would have gone back but the place is so awesome you have to make reservations way in advance or you'll never get in. We LOVED the whole experience!

I came to Chicago for a weekend and coming here was one of the things most people recommended. Tonight met and surpassed all my expectations.

Even though we could only get a reservation for 11:00 pm, the kitchen was open and everyone was very energetic and attentive. We ordered 5 dishes for 4 people. These are the 5 dishee in order from the one we liked the best to the -still great but not as great- one:

1) Crispy beef short ribs
2) Pig face
3) Drum fish
4) Goat empanadas
5) Grilled baby octopus

Our waiter, Owen, was extremely helpful with our selections and made this experience even better for us.

We also ordered these 3 desserts (also in order):
1) Sticky spice squash cake
2) Goat cheesecake
3) Chocolate Bavaria

I will definitely come back next time I'm in Chicago.

I was really curious about G&G since some of my friends loved it and some just thought it was okay. All I gotta say is that the veggie dishes are better than the meat ones in my opinion.

I thought the pig face is over-hyped (yelp.com/biz_photos/qjnp…).  It wasn't bad, just thought it'll be amazing from all the talk about it but I still dream about how yummy some of the veggie dishes like the cauliflower (yelp.com/biz_photos/qjnp…) or chickpea fritters ( yelp.com/biz_photos/qjnp…) were. My fave protein dish was the goat belly confit which was amazing ( yelp.com/biz_photos/qjnp…)

Overall, a good experience. I definitely won't mind coming back.

pics.caption: yuzu harissa . fried pickles . kohlrabi . grilled naan

review.des: Amazing food!! If you the American version of crispy pata & lechon..& string beans with fish sauce .. This is the place for you!!! This place needs rice!!

This place is AMAZING!  LOVE, love it.  I've been twice, and each time just loved everything.  If they have the roasted brussel sprouts GET THEM!
It is hard to get reservations, but there are always a few walk in spots, and you can eat at the bar, so give it a whirl!

Ok so there is a ton of hype for this place and unfortunately my husband and I were not in awe. Service is great --super friendly waiter and our water was constantly refilled too. However, while the food was plated nicely it was meh. We ordered the green beans as it seems everyone's reviews raved about them. While it was a large portion they were so so salty and we were unimpressed. We had asked the waiter if we could do a half portion of anything since some people on Yelp had done that. He said they only do that for single diners but after our first course he said he had spoken to the chef and he was sending a half portion of the cauliflower out to us on the house. Very nice touch but again it was pretty salty. We also ordered the halibut (good but small portion for the price), pig face (pretty tasty but kind of salty), and the goat loin. The goin loin was probably the best and quite unique. The pea puree alongside it was very tasty. The chocolate cake with shitake gelato was fairly good. Would I go back? Probably not. It was really dark, loud, and did not live up to the hype.

+++
- Grilled broccoli was top notch

++
- Bartenders know how to make a drinik or two, my Old Fashion was amazing
- Rhubarb shortcake dessert was all sorts of delicious without that filling feeling
- Pig face tasted like bacon
- Calamari was good, I liked the presentation (not the traditional rings), and the lamb filling was a tasty compliment

+
- Gotta get a goat dish, I got the empanadas. It's kind of small, order something else if you intend to share

-
- Crab rangoon didn't have much crab inside

TIPS:
- You can eat in the bar waiting area on the side
- Food, for the most part is pretty big portion, I'd recommend 1.5 orders pp

I went in with medium expectations (ignoring the hype) but was actually very impressed. All of the dishes were well executed, cocktails were great, and service was about as good as you get outside of Alinea. The prices are reasonable and we were able to try a lot of different items and just shared them between the four of us.

The food was excellent.  We managed to get a reservation on fairly short notice for a Thursday night (wanted to do Christkindlmarket, but it was too cold) so we ventured over to G&TG and was not disappointed.

Food: The Chickpea fritters were unreal.  Extremely flavorful and melted in your mouth.  The Porkface was definitley something to write home about.  Even my reluctant companion tried it and agreed it was excellent.  

For dessert, she ordered the Apple Buckle and despite having split 5 dishes, we still managed to finish it.  

All in all, go there, leave happy.

After living in Chicago for 2 years, you don't not hear about the Girl & the Goat in reference to restaurants. Time and time again, I've been hearing "have you tried the Girl & the Goat" yet and it got slightly frustrating considering you can't get a reservation for months in advance. Not to mention, after grazing through the menu online, I just thought it may be another overrated restaurant that people just feel the need to talk about. Boy, was I wrong! This is truly a must-try!

Well, my boyfriend and I finally made the decision to go right before I moved out of Chicago, and I made a reservation way in advanced (about a month and a half for a Thursday res).

The food. I was very pleasantly surprised at how amazing every single dish was. And my other surprise- the portion sizes! Normally at these types of restaurants you get 1 tiny piece of what you ordered just to have a taste and you spend an arm and a leg for that tiny morsel of food. Here, the sizes were great!

We ordered 4 dishes for 2 of us and you nearly had to roll us out! And it wasn't as pricey as you would imagine either. So very happy about all of the above. My boyfriend admitted that this was one of the best meals he's ever had, and that says alot!

We ordered:
- Sautéed green beans - very delicious and surprisingly generous portion! Sauce is different but good and the peanuts were good addition as well
- Wood oven roasted pig face - okay, you cannot come here and not get this. I admit, this scared me, but this is one of their most popular items so we couldn't resist. And I tell you, it was amazing! Chop it all up and mix together and every bite is a treat! Very clever ingredients in there and a must-try.
- Goat empanadas- this was more delicious than I had thought! Happened to be my second favorite dish!
- Braised Pork Shank - amazing and HUGE... we still ate it all..
- Pan roasted seabass. light and amazing!

Due to the generous portion sizes, this was enough food but also gave us a good range of the menu to try, so I was satisfied. All and all, what a great experience and now I will be one to say "have you tried G&G yet, because it's unreal and definitely not overrated". I can't wait to  try other dishes on their menu!

More than lives up to its reputation. I recently moved to West Loop and have been lucky enough to enjoy Girl & the Goat three times this summer. Each time has been phenomenal.

When a restaurant has this much hype, it's nearly always fantastic. But I rarely want to return so soon. And that's what impressed me the most about Girl & the Goat - I would eat here as often as I can get in and afford to. The flavors are unique, the atmosphere is unpretentious, and the price is reasonable for the cuisine.

There's plenty of info on here about the food, so I'll keep it simple. I'm typically a beef/pork type of guy, but I'd be happy ordering from just their vegetable and seafood menu. It's the flavorful sauces that make the dishes, which are accentuated best with the veggies and seafood. Highly recommend the grilled baby octopus and pan-seared halibut. Not to take anything away from the meat entrees - the signature pork face and goat dishes will not disappoint.

What I'm trying to say is come hungry and order everything. A group of 4-6 friends who are open minded to trying unique food is ideal.

AMAZING! This is probably my favorite place in Chicago right now. We started off with the miso bread which was pretty good. I wish they had more kimchi relish with the bread though. I feel like we finished all the relish after eating half the bread. Then we got the pan roasted halibut, which was SO GOOD. I definitely recommend getting this dish. The blueberry added a perfect hint of sweetness to the fish. Afterwards came the calamari, which was also great. Personally, I thought the calamari by itself was just okay, but when you ate it with the bread that it came with, it was elevated to a whole new level. We rounded out the savory foods with the pig face. The pig face is one of the classic dishes here and it lived up to the hype. The savory flavors along with the mixture of soft and crispy textures was a perfect match. Dinner ended with the dark matter pot de creme, which was by far the weakest dish of the night. However, every other dish was so good that I have to give this place 5 stars.

I was planning a trip to Chicago, and eating here was my #1 priority. I made a reservation as early as OpenTable would allow (100 days in advance). Though it was a good meal, in the end I have to say that for me Girl and the Goat is overrated.

These are the dishes we got:
Fried pickles
Pig face
Scallops
Cauliflower
Kalbi ribs
Skate wing
Squash blossom Rangoon

They were all... pretty good. I liked them. Were they what I expected of a place getting national buzz? Not really. Our group was split on opinions of the fried pickles, the pig face was fun (because it's fun to say pig face). The kalbi was fairly fatty and oily - I know these are part of why it's not a prime cut, but the portion we got didn't seem like it was cooked at the level of the rest of our dishes.  Sorry I don't have more details; on our brief trip to Chicago we ate very well, and I have to say none of the dishes here stuck in my mind in the days afterward.

Our waiter was nice and went along with our people-from-out-of-town schtick. However, I think there are some serious issues with their allergy menu philosophy. The gluten-free menu was a version of the regular menu with a bunch of asterisks that basically mean they have gluten in them (took a few trips to the kitchen to figure it out). Might be fine for people with a mild sensitivity, but it's depressing to see a majority of dishes have malt vinegar and soy sauce on a gluten free menu (both are solidly not gluten free). It seems clear they did their gluten free menu as a sop to fad dieters and not to serve people with actual dietary needs, and have not trained the staff on food allergens. On the plus side, the gluten free bread they brought out was good.

My expectations my have been unrealistically high. But honestly the next night we went to Farmhouse in River North / Near North and I liked everything about it more than Girl and the Goat (they even have a direct competitor in the above-the-neck pig parts division, a great pig ear dish that beats GatG's pig face hands down). If you're looking for a Top Chef restaurant worth traveling for, Talde in Brooklyn is way better as well. I wish I could have as glowing things to say as everyone else, but sometimes the dream doesn't match the reality.

We pulled up to valet and were immediately greeted by a pleasant man who wished us a great night.  This set the tone!  We walked in and took in the gorgeous setting.  Fun and casual, but trendy and contemporary.  It seemed all of the patrons were enjoying  themselves.  PLUS, most of them were beautiful.   We were seated immediately and for the next several hours were treated like royalty.  Our server was Austin and he seemed to be like a vapor.  We never noticed him hovering, yet, each time we needed something he was instantly there.  His suggestions were perfect and his humor was record breaking quick.  He too was a member of the beautiful people club.  The food was exceptional.  The sweet potato plate was awesome and the pigs head thingy was "lick the plate" delicious.  Oh!  The pork shank is a must if that sounds like something you might like.  This restaurant made me feel like it was an amusement park.  Every last detail was set in place for you to enjoy yourself.  And not just have fun, but have fun and stay as long as you like.  We'll be back and we're coming with more people!  Our valet guy must have been prophetic!  We truly had a great night!

Drinks were aaamazing.  Got the earhart.  Sister got a concoction the bartender made which was "little bit of lemon and all booze" really yummy (pink in color- not on the menu).
