The bartenders are knowledgeable about both food and drinks. We got here at 8 PM and was an hr and half wait. Thankfully, we stalked people at the bar and got 2 seats and ordered dinner.

We got the pig face...so yummy. You have to break the yolk and mix it all. We also got a goat dish. Unfortunately I can't recall the name but it was the last item on the goat menu (with tamarind).  That was really yummy. Lastly we got the pork shank. We both agreed that it wasn't note worthy. The red sauce made the dish salty and if you eat the pork alone, it is bland. However, after we had a couple drinks and the first two dishes, the pork shank was too much for us to finish.

I'd def come back again.

If you live in the West Loop or plan to visit, this is a must visit. Girl & the Goat features shareable small plates with an explosion of flavor. If you can't get a dinner reservation at a normal time, consider arriving at 5pm (when they open) and you will likely get a table. Friendly staff and the food hasn't disappointed.

I love this place. The consistency of great food and great service make this a truly amazing place.  
We started with the olive bread which was very rustic and wholesome and some fresh cocktails. The vegetables here are amazing, we had the green beans, cauliflower, and the woodfired broccoli.  All of them were delicious but the broccoli was probably my least favorite thing of the meal. I mean, it was delicious but everything was so good, something has to fall to the bottom of the list.  
The fish course was the grilled baby octopus.  I really enjoyed it but there was a bit much salt, it nearly overpowered the vegetables, but did compliment the octopus.
We moved to the roasted pig face which is so decadent i can't even begin to describe how you barely even need to chew it! This is my favorite meat dish on their menu.  We also had the goat belly which is light and the lobster works well with the flavors.
One of the people in our group is a big desert person so we all stuffed ourselves a little more with the goat cheese cake, which is very good and not too sweet, the pot de' creme, which has a deep espresso flavor, and the squash cake which was the best of the group.

I highly recommend this establishment to anyone and everyone.

I wanted to treat my family to a nice dinner while we were here in Chicago. After asking for their preferences seafood (Halibut) was the overwhelming favorite. I went ahead and did a search on Yelp and G&G came up. The reviews were quite good so I decided to make a reservation but anything after 6pm was booked so we had to settle for something at 4:45pm. The atmosphere/decor was a bit too drab and dark but I figured that we were there for the food and not the decor. Our waiter was nice and informed us of how the menu works, he recommended that we order 6 plates for the 3 of us to share. We basically ordered the more talked about dishes, pig face, chicken, Tuna, pork belly, etc. All the food was tasty and overall it was a good but not great experience. My biggest complaint is that if you're looking for healthy portions this is not the place to find this. By the way, if you need to use the bathroom you might want to take a flashlight. It's pretty dark down there. I would definitely have hesitations recommending this place because when I compare it to other restaurants that I've tried this place comes up a bit short.

This time I came here with my wife (her first visit).  I have to say that I was a bit disappointed.  The food was all good but not nearly as good as I remember it being during my first visit.

We had the following:

Tomorrows Crouton - aka bread with Parmesan butter and a side of caesar dressing - decent starter

Roasted Cauliflower - this was good but needed a little salt.  I tend to like things a bit more salty than my wife but even she agreed

Goat empanadas - very good.  Lite flaky crust and awesome stuffing.  For sure one of the best bites of the night.

Scallops - the scallops were cooked perfectly and were, by themselves, very good.  I felt the sauce/broth they were served in was a little bitter.

Sugo - pappardelle noodles in a meat sauce (bolognese style).  Very good and we'd order this again.

Pig Face - this was probably the biggest disappointment between visits for me.  I remember loving this dish, but then again on my last visit I had been well served at the bar for about 2 hours before eating!  My wife felt it was greasy and I have to agree.  

Butterscotch Budino - this is awesome!  I ordered it last time and it was just as good as I remember it.  Be sure to save room!

Overall, the service was good and the food was well done and good...just not great.

This place is always a hit! I have never had a bad experience here. The food is delectable, especially the shishito peppers and green beans. Don't pass those up! Reservations are tough but if you go early or late, it shouldn't be a problem. We even brought our 6 month old and they were super accommodating which is always nice! I would skip the cocktails and go for wine.

Visited Chicago and my friend had made resos here a month in advance. This place is so delicious. Started with wood fire grilled broccoli that I'll probably remember my entire life. The pig face was incredible as were the other smaller dishes like beet salad and another pasta. Deserves the hype and the service was amazing!

Great service and knowledgeable staff. Although the food is solid, I don't see how this restaurant stands out above the crowd of other similar American new restaurants in Chicago or other major cities. Best dish was the squash cake with rosemary butter pecan ice cream.

pics.caption: Green beans with fish sauce and cashews- umami
Goat satay with an Asian slaw and mashed potatoes- yummy

review.des:
Truly, truly, amazing food.

Had a first date here a couple weeks ago, sat at the bar, and was astounded by every dish. While portions are small and the price is hefty, every dish is worth every single penny.

Omg!!!! This place is worth the wait!! Everything is amazing!! I went with a group of 6 people and we managed to destroy the menu!! The wait for the food was not that long and as soon as we started trying things we all fell in love!! Definitely a go to spot!

Came here because I heard the hype but didn't believe it.  I am from. New York City.  We have GREAT food.  Since Chicago pizza really can't stand up to New York pizza , I thought this place was just hype.  But I have to admit when I am wrong. I SKIPPED DESSERT AND WENT BACK TO TE MAIN MENU BECAUSE  IT IS THAT GOOD.  

I in Chicago for work so I dined alone.  I ordered :

Roasted cauliflower.  Top top notch. It is so full of flavor. It literally  fills your mouth with full on taste overflow !   It smells like a craving you didn't know you had until just now.  Then you taste it.  It is full. It's salty but not too much.  The pine nuts add a smooth nutty balance.  And then you taste the hint of fresh mint.  That was just the roasted  cauliflower.

I think because the cauliflower was a very taste bud overload, the next plate paled in comparison. The confit goat belt with lobar  and crab came next. It was indeed great but when tourists is already so excited from the tasted cauliflower , anything that follows will def not compare.  The goat belly was good, very good but it didn't blow my mind.

So the waitress asks me if i would like dessert.  I say no....gimme back the main menu!  The best culinary decision I made in my life.  Because I am sitting here by muskeg, I have been yelping this place.  Talk about the duck tongue prevails.  So that's what I order in lieu of something sweet.   And I was wowed !  The piri piri sauce was perfectly balanced - full, salty enough to bring out all the flavor! I done a lot in NYC, but this Chicago dish beats them all. Ducks tongue.  It's so tender and mixed  with fresh bits of tuna and died wonton strips.  Just do it. Order one of the best dishes you'll ever have.

This New Yorker will def be back at the girl and the goat.  I can't wait for my next culinary experience here!

I can write a whole novel about this place because I feel like everyone needs to know how great this place is.

I think part of the mystery is to just go for it and order what makes you smile!

To be honest, everything I ordered was nothing short of extravagant! I did not order a bad plate at that place, so that is why I want to leave it to you to do the ordering.

I do have to say that we did get the Budino for dessert and it was absolutely life changing. At least for me it was... the texture, the depth of flavor, and artistic presentation is incomparable.

Every time I go back to Chicago, my first reservations I need to make is for this spot!

One of the best places I've ever eaten at! I've only said that about one other place!
solid and a okay for sure. really a 3.5 but yelp needs more 3 outta me.

I finally made it past the three month waiting period to snag a table at the utterly hyped Girl & The Goat.  I would highly recommend you to make reservations to avoid the long lines and ensure yourself a table, especially if it is for a larger party.  I came here with a party of five on a Wednesday evening.  The dim overhead lighting and wooden furniture gave off a rustic vibe.

The rotating menu is separated into three sections: vegetables, seafood, and meats.  The food is served family style, so the server recommended about 8-10 dishes for our party to share.  We decided on:

Fried Pickles: served with shallot aioli and yuzu harissa sauce.  The pickles were not overly breaded, so you still have that crunch and sourness from the pickles.  If prefer a more citrus and creamy texture, dip it in the shallot aioli.  But if you want a more of a spiciness and tartness to your pickles, go ahead and use the yuzu harissa sauce.      

Sauteed Green Beans: dressed up with fish sauce vinaigrette and topped off with cashews.  This is definitely one of the top dishes I had tried here.  The green beans were cooked perfectly, so they still had that crunchiness to them.  The sauce they used must have been crack because none of us could stop eating them.

Goat Empanadas: on top of marinated sheep feta, pickled golden beets, and tzatziki sauce.  The goat meat wasn't gamey at all, but rather really tender.  The cheese, beets, and tzatziki sauce gave off a creamy texture to the whole entrée.

Wood Fired Wiley Point Oysters: topped with horseradish, bacon, and preserved lemon.  I didn't eat this entrée due to allergies, but my friends did.  They weren't a big fan of it only because the oysters were warm.  I guess raw and warm oysters don't go well together.

Kona Kampachi Crudo: accompanied with crisp pork belly, chili aioli, and caperberries.  The presentation on this dish was amazing, as well as the taste.  The kampachi was really fresh and had a really smooth texture to it.  I was a little worried that pork belly would overpower the taste of the fish, but it didn't.  It just gave the whole dish that extra crunch.

Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face: tamarind, cilantro, red wine-maple, and topped off with a sunny side egg and potato stix.  Oh my, I think I would have to say this is the best tasting dish of the night.  Everything about this dish was on point.  You pretty much have to break the egg and mix everything together.  The pork was really tender that it just melted in your mouth.  There wasn't enough of this dish to go around.

Braised Beef Tongue: served mixed with masa, beef vinaigrette, and salsa verde.  I never had beef tongue so I have nothing to compare it with, but the tongue was really tender.  There were so many different textures and flavors incorporated in this dish: crunch from the masa, spice and smoothness from the salsa, and a touch of sourness from the vinaigrette.

Grilled Skirt Steak: served with a root vegetable salad drizzled with cajeta.  This wasn't the best tasting steak in Chicago, but it was still good.  The steak was cooked beautifully at a medium rare.  I also like the touch of sweetness from the cajeta.

Overall, my experience here was amazing.  The Girl & The Goat is definitely worth the wait and the hype.  The server here was really attentive and knowledgeable about everything on the menu.  He always had a smile on his face and didn't let the busy environment frazzle him.  The food here was remarkable.  There are so many different flavors and textures that will tickle your taste buds.  If you are on the fence about giving this place a try, just take the leap.  You won't regret it.

Great atmosphere with a nice range of cocktails and specialize in their whisky and bourbons! I personally had the Ring of Fire which was like a pomegranate margarita!

Their menu is great for sharing. We had the roasted beat salad which was amazing! We also had the calamari bruschetta and the goat empanadas and I would recommend both!

I would also recommend making a reservation because the place does get full quickly! (Understandably so!)

We were in last Saturday for a friend's birthday.  We've wanted to try this place for awhile with the hype of it being Izard's joint.  Have had little goat which was okay, so was hoping this knocked it out of the park.  I was somewhat disappointed.  

We tried 7 different dishes, beef tongue, duck tongue, Korean short ribs, calamari bruschetta, roasted beet salad, Walter's chicken and the raw oysters.  The only dish I personally enjoyed was the beet salad.  The rest were fine, just underwhelming for the price.  The short ribs had zero meat.  The oysters were mini-sized.  

The service was fine, the kid was nice and helpful, but did find ourselves filling our own wine glasses a few times.  The ambiance was good.  Restrooms could have been cleaner and fresher.

It's one of those places that you go once unless you eat out every night and live in west loop.  Too many places to try in the area and all over the city when you live in the burbs.

Amazing food, service, and table! We were able to get the chef's table and see all the action in the kitchen! We ordered 5 different dishes and they were all amazing. The drinks were amazing, the dessert was amazing - loved everything.

They take reservations (book months in advance) and asks for the chef's table if there are just 2 of you!

Great ambiance,great food, great service.

Definitely a go to place always when I am in Chicago ....

For my weekend trip to Chicago, I was desperate to eat the best of what the city has to offer. I tried making a reservation one month in advance, only to realize that it was already fully booked, except for the 11 PM time slot. Seeing as I'm typically sound asleep by then, we decided to just try our luck at 4 PM on a Friday. It was raining, and the hostess graciously let us wait inside before their official opening time. Before I knew it, my name was called, and I felt like I had won the lottery.

We were seated at a communal table facing the kitchen, which I appreciated because we could see our dishes being prepared. The space was dimly lit, which makes it difficult to take any food pictures, but creates an intimate atmosphere. We ordered the green beans, goat belly, and pig face.

The green beans dish was HUGE. It had a strong Asian influence to it, maybe fish sauce? The two of us barely finished half of this dish, and I definitely tried, since I needed my daily serving of veggies. My boyfriend asked me if we should offer some to our table companions, but I thought that might be creepy, so we refrained.

The goat belly was one of their specials that night. I was worried that it would be too heavy, but it was surprisingly refreshing, and didn't taste fatty at all.

The star of the show was the pig face (which our waitress assured us would not look like an actual face- phew). It was served on a bed of crispy potatoes, topped off with a fried egg and a mysterious green sauce. We were told to chop it all up, mix it together, and get a little bit of everything in each bite.  I know this dish has been raved about plenty, but OH MY GOD I can't even begin to explain the flavor explosion that took place in my mouth. The pork was melt-in-your-mouth tender, and combined with the runny yolk and the texture of the potatoes, reached absolute perfection. There's this scene from Ratatouille where the grumpy food critic takes a bite of ratatouille and is immediately taken back to his childhood memories. Strangely enough, I was reminded fondly of my mom's Chinese braised pork dish.

There was no way we were passing up on dessert. Our server recommended the miso butterscotch budino with no hesitation. It was layered with cashew cake, bacon toffee, miso butterscotch pudding, pineapples, and whipped cream. The pudding was at the bottom, which I didn't realize until after a couple bites in, but it elevated the dessert from great to phenomenal.

Food, service, and atmosphere were on point. I'd absolutely return for more, with reservations 2 months in advance ;)

My husband brought me to the restaurant for my birthday tonight.  We had been talking about this spot forever.  Reservations were hardly ever available.  He booked this 2 or 3 months out.  I am a huge Top Chef fan so I was rating to go.  Ate light all day so I was ready!

The atmosphere. Is nice but a bit cramped.  Go in a group larger than 2 so you can get a good table.  Otherwise they squeeze you in.  Be prepared to make friends with your neighbor.  Our's were very nice.  

Bread was good but the jalapeño butter had no flavor.  I was waiting for the hints of honey and heat.  The tomato jam was bland.  But the bread was warm and the presentation was great.  

I had the oysters with bacon.  They were tasty.

Unlike others my 3 stars is not due to bad service, atmosphere or bad food.  It was just so incredibly underwhelming after the hype.  Maybe we picked things and played it safe.  We had the beef ribs which were just shaved , paper thin slices of beef.  They were very well seasoned.  The grilled corn on the cob was good.  One piece was inedible it was so hard.  But it was a flavorful dish.  

The beet salad was well balanced but it was a beet salad.  The salmon was very rare.  Ok for me.  My husband not so much.  But again good flavor but no wow factor.

I guess what I am saying is go for a good meal and good time.  I don't think it will stand out in your mind.  When I walked out the first thing I said was I am glad we finally came.  What you want is wow I cannot wait to come back and try....

This place gets quite glowing reviews, but the taste can be eccentric to some of the guests. First the positive, we were a bunch of graduating students, and our waitress was fantastic. She gave us great recommendations on food and even offered us some free desserts to celebrate the occasion. These small gestures really go a long way in demonstrating the class of this place. In addition, this place is lively. I really enjoyed the atmosphere, especially that you can see the cooks and the kitchen clearly.

Now moving on to some improvements, most of the dishes we ordered were quite good including the octopus and lamb. I was however not a big fan of the goat milk ice cream dish and some of the beets dish. The flavors can be on and off. Some dishes tasted great! Others just tasted a bit forced. Nonetheless, the combination of a cool atmosphere, caring waitresses, and decent food would relax and charm everyone.

Pricing wise, this place is also quite decent. The food is meant to be shared tapas style, so order many and share amongst yourselves. Most dishes are between $10-20 and are very decent size for sharing. Definitely ask the waitress for some of the recommendations as I found them to be quite good.

Girl & The Goat provides an excellent dining experience. Make a reservation now so you can enjoy all of its goodness in like, 3 months. My friend and I were both in Chicago for the weekend and luckily -- scored a reservation from a local friend who decided he didn't want to go to G & G. Score. The service was impeccable. We received honest recommendations from our server-- much appreciated guidance and direction for the two of us who were having trouble making decisions.

4:15 to Georgia and Bolt Action -- both delicious.

Miso Hungry - seriously, I didn't think bread could taste this good.

We loved everything: crudo, kohlrabi salad, empanadas, chickpeas -- but the sugo paparedelle was really the highlight. A ragout done perfectly -- I don't think I've had pasta this delicious since I was traveling in Tuscany. It was that good. (Note - I found the kohlrabi and empanadas to be a bit on the salty side. Not totally unacceptable, but dangerously close)

The meal was completed with a perfect dessert (the chocolate one) -- my friend believes it's the best dessert she has had in her life. That's a big statement, but it was this perfect collision of sour, sweet, salty goodness.

And, a rarity (at least, I find), a perfect, unburned espresso at the end. Le sigh.  

Yahoo! Get there, you'll love it.
Everything was excellent.  Having to make reservations months in advance not so good.

My aunt and uncle were visiting from Israel and they asked me to take them somewhere delicious and quintessentially Chicago. With only a few hours to book a reservation, I took a chance on the website and saw a last minute spot available for Girl & The Goat.  After hearing stories about months long waiting lists, I couldn't pass up the opportunity.

From the first step inside you know that this place is something special. It blends something of Chicago's storied working class reputation with the city's trendy up-and-coming elite.

The food was delicious as well as reasonably priced for the quality of the flavor profiles. The dishes were served tapas-style, so that the table could share and savor each dish. The service was friendly and attentive. Our waiter did such a good job of pacing the dishes and choosing the order of them that we had to call him an artist!

My favorite dish was the sugo, with the most unexpected and bright gooseberries. My aunt and uncle's favorite was the calamari bruschetta, which had the feel of biting into a leather chair next to a fireplace on a cloudy day in a house by the seaside. Coming in at a close second was the roasted cauliflower.

Next time, I would order a second helping of the bread and do without the grilled chicken and grilled broccoli.

Was it the best ever??  Um not necessarily.  I only say this because this restaurant is considered one the best in the WHOLE city and while they are well trained service is top notch quality is definitely high, it was not everything I wanted it to be. lol  So aside from being able to say "I made it into G&theG" It's not somewhere I would go to often.  I would place this restaurant in the got to try for yourself category, as it may not be everything to everyone, but at least you can say you ate here. =D  I am grateful to all that Stephanie Izard and the Boka Restaurant have done to bring excitement and quality eats to our fair city of Chicago!  I do want to try the new Chinese place that might be more up my alley!!!

Amazing food and warm atmosphere!

Food favorites!

Sweet potato bleu cheese pierogies - Excellent! Mouth-watering without the bleu cheese overpowering anything.

Calamari bruschetta!

Definitely worth the dining experience!

Ambiance is excellent. Very clean , modern, open kitchen. Food was excellent.  We had the duck tongue. Crispy and delicious.  Open pig face was fantastic and pork shank.  If coming with a large group , call ahead and get the full goat.

Incredibly accommodating to the gluten-free customer. I am a very sensitive Celiac and didn't experience any reaction to their food. We were completely blown away by the complexity and portion size of their dishes. Highly recommend the beet salad, the blackened cat fish, and the pig face. Their gluten free bread is also very moist and delicious. Trust me this a great option for any Celiac. Their cocktails are also very creative and delicious. Definitely one my top 10 favorite restaurants I've been to in the US.

This restaurant has stirred the holy spirit in me, you know, the one that makes you want to move to another city and start a new life? Perhaps I'm using the phrase incorrectly...

Anyway, I was in Chi town for a business trip and thought this was the absolute best place I ate all week. I started with the Goat Carpaccio. HOLY SHITSICLES it was a mouthgasm. Dressed perfectly with citrus, capers, and crispy wontons. Order two, I'm not kidding, you will want it.

Next came the crab and goat cheese filled squash blossoms drizzled with local honey. Round two mouthgasm, the flavors were delicate, no ingredient overpowered the other. Unfortunately, since squash blossoms are only in season for a short time I don't believe it is on the menu any longer.

I finished off with the miso covered shishito pepper, and the confit belly. Both extremely delicious and to die for. The best part about Girl and the Goat is that almost everything can be ordered in half portions. Take advantage and try as many things as possible. I'm not sure it's possible to have a bad meal here. I am looking up Chicago rent prices ASAP just so I can be close to this restaurant.

My friend made reservations for 2 in advance for a late night dinner and drinks.  We had high expectations for G&G and were both super excited to try the food.  Though the restaurant was packed, it was relatively quiet.  We sat in a small table in the corner of the restaurant.  I really enjoyed the warm, cozy atmosphere and classy decor.  

We ordered old fashioneds and looked over the formidable menu.  I asked our waitress for recommendations, but she was not very helpful.  Actually she came off super arrogant, in a bold and impudent way.  The shishito peppers came first.  Huge portion but the ratio of cheese and miso to the amount of BURNT peppers threw me off.  The goat empanadas were really tasty.  I like them flaky but these were doughy.  Let's talk about the calamari bruschetta though, and how it was one of the most savory things I've ever ever ever tasted.  I couldn't get enough it, and I will definitely order it each time I come back.  We also ordered the crispy pork shank which was flavorful, but I wouldn't get it again.  

Overall we had a nice meal and enjoyed ourselves, but G&G didn't live up to the hype.  Maybe we ordered the wrong things...maybe the waitress should have given us a little more insight on the menu instead of saying "I can't really make any recommendations".

Oh, and the old fashioneds were underwhelming.

Small plates... huge, stunning, glorious flavors!!!

Love, love, love this place... I would consider moving back to Chicago just to eat here more often.  THIS is what a restaurant should be... creative cooking... consistency... courteous staff... a true celebrity chef... but one who lives up to they hype and the... dare I say it... genius.  Everything is so clever and well thought out... the flavors meld and burst and just make me happy.
This time there were four of us, so we got to order many more dishes... While some rise to the top, slightly more than others... everything is superb.

When I was here last summer I fell in love... Nice to know some relationships can go the distance...

Pan Fried Shishito Peppers With Parmesan, Sesame and Miso - This was on the menu then and is a must have now... So tasty.  I love these peppers simply and traditionally grilled with soy sauce... but this combo is stellar.

Sauteed Green Beans With Fish Sauce Vinaigrette And Cashews - Yeah, we all agreed this would get anyone to eat their green beans.  And we had this last time, too.  So good!

Squash Wontons With Mushroom Ragout - Simple... Delightful, but got lost a little bit because the other dishes were so much bolder.  I could have lived without this one.

"Falafel" With Peanut Hummus, Cucumber, Apple Salad, Crisp Pita and Marinated Mozzarella - Another really good dish, with a lot of flavors, though the first two will overshadow most things.

Grilled Baby Octopus With Guanciale, Beans, Pistachios and Lemon Vinaigrette - Could have used more octopus, but this was one of the evening's favorites.

Diver Scallops With Pumpkin Brandade, Fried Brussels Sprouts, Spiced Pecans and Pomegranate - Man I love scallops and I think we all liked this dish the best of all!  This was just a perfectly balanced plate, where each flavor lifted the next  to amazing heights.

Kalbi Beef Ribs With Sweet Corn Coblettes and Grilled Okra Relish - Another super tasty dish with great flavors.

Crisp Braised Pork Shank With Butternut Squash-Shiitake Kimchee, Buttermilk Dressing and Naan - The meat literally fell off the bone and was the second favorite dish of the night.  Tender, stunning and so tasty.  Mmmm...

Confit Goat Belly With Bourbon Butter, Lobster n' Crab And Fennel - The portion on this was a little small and would have been a better split for two instead of four, but damn was it delicious.  Thought we might fight over this one... almost did.

For dessert we got two things...

Miso-Butterscotch Budino With Bacon Toffee, Glazed Pineapple and Candied Cashews.  This was sweet heaven.

And while I was initially not excited about the PBJ Dessert With Ice Cream And Donuts, it, of course, won me over!!!

Once again, from perfect start to perfect finish, this spot has proven to be one of my most favorite dining experiences... EVER!

My wife and I had a fantastic meal here during our recent trip to Chicago.  We were able to walk in and get a table for 2 on a Saturday night - the key was getting there around 5:30.  We had drinks at the bar (definitely try the Obligatory and the Lux Goods) and our table was ready in about 45 mins.  

The food and flavor combinations were truly unlike anything I'd ever had before.  Every item is sized for sharing, so you're well set-up to try several different things. There were just 2 of us, so while we would have eaten literally everything on this menu, we had to settle for 5 items:

-Roasted Cauliflower with Pickled Peppers, Pine Nuts and Mint: I could have eaten a bucket of this stuff. The mint really makes this dish.

-Hamachi Crudo: This would have been a fairly ordinary crudo preparation, but then they went and included pork belly, and the crudo ceased to be ordinary.

-Grilled Baby Octopus: perfectly cooked.  The lemon vinaigrette really brightened the flavor of the dish, and the pistachios added a nice crunchy contrast.

-The Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face: No great way to describe this (other than it's not actually a pig face), but as others have said, just order it, eat it, and thank me later.  Amazing.

-Goat Confit: Yes, there was goat.  Yes there was bourbon butter.  Yes there was Lobster?  Yes there was Crab?? So so so good.

We actually managed to have room for some dessert, so we shared the Chocolate Truffle Cake which was - surprise - ridiculously good.

Service was super fast and friendly, plus they easily accommodated my wife's gluten allergy.  

Chicago has tons of good food options, so I sort of feel like on the rare instances I visit there I should be sure I always try new places... but Girl and the Goat is so good, I may have to make an exception and make this a go-to.  Can't wait to go back.

My gf keeps taking me to all these expensive restaurants even though i'm perfectly fine with eating fast food. $10 as opposed to $130 sounds great to me, but I actually don't mind this place. Maybe it's the hype, she was on Top Chef so has to be good. Or could be the positive reviews from friends and other elite members, but I've been here twice and I don't mind paying that much (well I mind but I'm just a tad more ok with it). Went here in April and came back last weekend for my GF's birthday. Plan in advance, you have to make reservations months ahead of time. This review will just be for this most recent trip since it's still fresh in my mind.

The menu changes slightly (last time I had the pork shoulder but now it's pig face) but this is what I had. Ordered the sweet corn goat cheese wontons. Really good, liked it a lot. No meat though but exactly what you would expect. Also got the grill seared shi tuna. That was alright. Pretty much just raw tuna that is slightly cooked covered in a sauce. The diver scallops were delicious. My only problem there was that it was $17 for 2 scallops. Yea they were big but whoa, 8.50 for one. yikes.

Kalbi beef ribs were next. They were alright too. I like the taste but I mean you could go to a KBBQ place and it would taste the same to me. Last was the wood oven roasted pig face. Our server said that was the most popular thing on the menu. To me it was alright. I'm not a fan of yolk so I don't like runny eggs. I also don't like tamarind. So whenever I tasted those (you just mash everything together) it was eh. But the pork was really good though, as was with the shoulder last time.

Got the Budino dessert. Forgot what was in it but there's bacon and toffee in it. Delicious. Got it last time too and didn't even want to try anything else. Def recommend that one. For drinks I got an iced tea and I don't think it's free refills since once she took my glass, I never got another 1, so be aware of that. And that was like 4 bucks already. Overall it was $130 for like 5 things, a dessert, iced tea, and a glass of wine. Special occasion so I was ok with it but whoa, quality over quantity for sure. Love the service here though, both times it has been excellent. From the waiters to the bus boys, everyone is on point.

By far the BEST dining experience I have ever had while dining alone (which is fairly often because I travel for work).

I went on a Wednesday night at about 6pm and all the tables were full. I planned on sitting at the bar anyways and found one seat open. The bartenders are so attentive and within seconds I was asked if I wanted just a drink or the food menu as well. He even asked if I had any dietary restrictions/allergies--I know this is such a minor detail but this made me really happy! It is so incredibly rare for restaurants to ask this upfront. I believe the only other time I was ever asked this upfront was when I was at a Michelin star restaurant in SF. I am severely allergic to nuts and so 95% of the time I'M the one that has to ask them if the dish I'm looking at has any nuts and it can be sort of a guessing game. He gave me a marked-up menu detailing any dishes that had nuts which genuinely made me happy lol.

They talk you through the menu if it's your first time there, which was nice! I ordered the Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face and the goat belly--BOTH WERE AMAZING. I can't even describe how much I loved these dishes. Perfect balance of flavor. I did find the vanilla in the fennel sauce for the goat belly to be a little weird, I think just because I don't like sweet in my savory foods. I still ate it all though haha. I had mentioned it was my first time in Chicago ever and so they even gave me their Sauteed Green Beans on the house!! That was delicious too but between my other 2 entrees, I only finished half of it. The Sauteed Green Beans is definitely good for 2-3 people as a side. For dessert I got the Caramel Corn and Malt Balls, but like a mini portion of it because I was saying how incredibly full I was. I love caramel corn and the saltiness of that with the vanilla malt gelato was really yummy. A lot of times I dislike desserts because they're too sweet but this was just right.

For drinks, I'm terrible because I can't even remember the name of the drink I ordered and it's not on their online menu. I just remember it had gin and tasted really good. I asked for a second drink--anything that he felt like making that had gin--and he made me The Last Word cocktail. My first time trying that cocktail ever but it was strong (in a good way) and yummy! Being at the bar by myself, I did watch them make tons of drinks and I can tell they used some really high quality stuff and knew what they were doing.

Really really wish I had a longer stay in Chicago just so I can eat here again. I don't know if it's just cause I was from out of town or if it seemed sad that I was eating by myself or something but they went above and beyond to make my dining experience so excellent.

I have eaten here a few times so far and have to say the food is really very good. It's not life changing like some people make it to be but then, is there such a thing as life changing food? Cocktails are very good as well with ample options for wine lovers. Ambiance is casual in a high end setting if that makes sense. Taking one star out for sheer the effort it takes to get in on weekends.

I don't think I can say anything that someone hasn't already said. Its just great. Get the green beans (I hate green beans but these were out of this world), the pig face and the empanandas. Its loud, crowded, and busy but thats what you get for a super popular restaurant. Good luck getting a reservation at a normal time!

I love this place - I just wish it was easier to get reservations or tables!

The first time we went, we got chef's table and got to try a lot of stuff.  The grilled octopus is my favorite.  Pig face (I know, sounds not too appealing) - SO good.

Very nice vegetarian options as well.

GREEN BEANS! That is all I can say is the green beans were to die for! I went here for my graduation dinner, I had to make my reservation for 2 months in advance so there is that, and then they tried to stick my party of 3 with my boy friend who is thin but 6'2" at a table meant for just two people. So we had to wait a bit longer to get a real table for us to sit at but it was so worth it.

The plates are not small and not big so they are good for sharing because you get enough and are not super full! Everything we tried was delicious while some were better than others. The green beans though we're the prize winner for this meal! And when a nice occasion comes up again we'll probably go back. Just not a place to eat every night for my pocket book.

Wow -where to start.  First, our server was outstanding.  kassie was suggestive and knowledgeable of all their offerings and paired our meal beautifully.  We were a group of six and ordered 16 dishes and four desserts, so very little was missed.  Everything was well above average.  Great vibe.  Great atmosphere.   Don't miss this one.

I'm usually not adventurous with my food.  On the side is very big with me, but not here.  I have enjoyed every meal that I have had here.  I like the small plates that I can share.

The service has been great every time!

Amazing!  Fantastic service and food that delighted the palate.  We ate calamari bruschetta which had great flavors and was a hearty size.  The broccoli was a smokey mouth full of flavor. The goat empanadas were delightful and fun.  The highlight was the pig face.  It was layer after layer of flavor.  We completed the meal with the pineapple fun side. The gelato and macadamia and pineapple cake were wounderful.

This place is really, really good. The green beans should be renamed Slap yo Momma. And the Pig face is a must order. Had the Ring of Fire drink and went perfect with meal. Thinking of moving to Chicago after this.

Girl and the Goat was an amazing experience. The ambiance is amazing with a great crowd of people. We attended on a Sunday evening and we had great service, the food was wonderful and we had a great time.

I fell in love with Chicago one magical weekend several summers ago.  Girl & The Goat contributed no small amount to my affection for this city.

The pig's face dish stands as a monument to flavor and creativity.  Even now, I remember mixing the yolk in so that each bite was a mind-blowing mix of crunchy texture and savory bits of meat.  

We came back the next day, with no regrets dining here twice in a 3-day weekend.  When we let the waiter know how excited we were to be back again, they gave us an extra dessert (on top of what we had already ordered), which we certainly did not need but greatly appreciated.

If I ever fly to Chicago on a whim, perhaps stumbling upon last-minute deals, it will be to come back here.

This place is probably one of the most Yelped about restaurants in the world. As a result, the reviews are a little all over the place, and generally depend on one thing: expectations.

The Girl and the Goat is NOT a fancy restaurant. It's a modern, open-kitchen machine that turns out small plates/tapas-style for tables to share. If you're up for a loud night of cocktails and sampling with a group of friends, this is a perfect place to go. If you're looking for excellent food to impress a significant other, I probably wouldn't go here unless your date is a sucker for creative foods. It's loud. Very loud. Even at midnight when the doors shut and prevent further patrons from entering! We got our reservations on Open Table about 6 weeks in advance after I had stalked the website for awhile. I think going at 4pm is also another viable option for procuring some space.

I'm surprised by the reviews that purport that flavor was lacking in these dishes. To me, the unique and powerful flavors were the hallmark of this food. Every dish had a very distinctive flavor profile that was unusual in some way -- and most of it worked, although on one dish it didn't. As for each dish:

Pig face: slow-cooked pig cheek, and it was very good. It's basically a glorified roast pork. But the best part about the pig face was the little fried potato straws and the fried egg on top. The textures came together in a wonderful, crunchy, mushy way that I really enjoyed. This is definitely a dish worth getting. On the salty side.

Roasted Cauliflower: Roasted and slightly carmelized cauliflower tossed with heaps of parmesan cheese, olive oil, pine nuts and mint. Mint!! This really gave the vegetable an unexpected kick, and those dainty pine nuts knocked it out of the park. The downside to this was that it was swimming in oil. It was way too greasy. Gives me great ideas for making cauliflower at home.

Squash blossom: A hollowed out piece of squash stuffed with crabmeat, dipped in tempura and flash fried. Of course, delicious. Lacking body in flavor though. The filling was kind of bland. Texture was great. Only two pieces in a serving. Wouldn't necessarily order it again.

Goat confit: Strange combination of confit goat belly (small piece, preparation similar to the pig's face, slow-cooked), lobster, ginger and some other bright citrus/cilantro flavor that didn't quite work in the end. Enjoyed the goat belly itself, but thought that the accompaniments detracted from the main attraction. Maybe they are afraid people won't be used to the strong flavor of goat?

Butterscotch budino: Probably the best dessert I've ever had. GET IT!! Even if you're full, just get it. It's so light and refreshing. Light-as-air whipped Italian custard with cinnamon, carmelized cashews, butterscotch sauce and pineapple chunks. It was incredibly refreshing and the mix of creamy, tart, crunchy and sweet were perfect.

Overall, we enjoyed our meal at Girl and the Goat. I didn't enjoy the fact that it was a loud machine. It wasn't a relaxing meal. But definitely something I'm glad we did!
Be bold! Go right ahead. Love the blends of food. The more exotic, the better. Like the guy next to me at dinner said "I didn't even know ducks have tongues! But this is great!"
We came here for our celebratory wedding dinner. All the hype is real. Service was amazing, and oh....the food was bomb !!

Foodie Central.  All sorts of delicious small plates.  Chef Izzard puts a South Asian flare to some of her dishes, which is refreshing.  The fritters and cauliflowers are a must...and definitely try one of the goat dishes.  Softshell crab was very tasty as well and I hear the pig face is a must-do.

FYI -- the bartender, Justin, was a pleasure.  Vert nice guy and a great mixologist.

After having been to Little Goat and being a ... wait for it .... little disappointed, my expectations for Big Goat and Girl weren't high. And that was a good thing.

My wife and I came here on a whim Saturday evening (that's a stretch) at 5 p.m. I knew they had one or two tables reserved for walk-ins (reserved... for... walk-ins? Whatever.) so we took our chances. Chances were not taken, however, because we got a spot at the bar for two right when we walked in. I don't usually dine at the bar because it can be cramped, but my wife sat next to a huge wooden pillar so that meant only my side was met with another tush. The major pro of eating at the bar was the quick, attentive and lovely service. We never had to wait for anyone to come to our table, take our drink order, leave, come back, etc. It was brilliant! Loved it! Might even do it again!!!

The food lived up to every standard I heard of G&TG. Except one dish... the roasted cauliflower. Seriously. How can roasted cauliflower be so freaking DELICIOUS??!! It's a bulbous bland bunch of white.... that exploded with flavor bite after bite. Other standouts included the octopus (so tender!), corny bread and empanadas. The skate wing was in a too-rich-for-my-blood cream sauce, but wifey loved it. The only downfall for her, though, was the SURPRISE! chili flakes nestled between some bites... being that she doesn't do spice, it was an assault on those tender taste buds, so some time had to pass before she could resume the good chow.

I definitely recommend Girl & The Goat. And while we didn't have ANY goat, or any beef... pork... meat-things, it was a fantastic experience. And vegans - fyi, they have a vegan menu if you ask!

For the two of us with 5 small plates, dessert, two beers and one glass of wine it came out to $50/each. I think that's a damn good price for one of America's most-talked about restaurants.

Oh, and ps: It's really pretty inside.
Attended. A corporate dinner here in one of their private rooms with a kitchen. Unforgettable!

Shishito peppers were mild and delicious. Forget using a fork, just grab the stems with your fingers and nibble the peppers off. The wood fired conway cup oysters were the perfect starter. The Confit Goat Belly (special) had a nice sauce made with bourbon butter and morsels of lobster and crab, topped with ribbons of fennel. Charred pork belly had an intense rich sauce and would've been terrific with a bowl of white rice. Had to try the pig face because of the previous reviews. I rank that fifth out of five. The bread for starters was crusty and soft on the inside, with a slight sourdough taste. Perfect for two. Go with the intention of sharing dishes because its more fun and you get to try a greater variety.

pics.caption: Charred pork belly, spring onions, tangy jus, sunflower seeds
Shishito peppers with, Parmesan, sesame and miso

review.des:
Finally. Waited for 2 months and still the only slot available was 9:30 a Tuesday night. Despite awkwardly long reservation times, I was thrilled (and hungry!) when we finally made it there. Although we arrived on time, our table was not ready and so we waited in the bar with a cocktail. Had my usual lemon drop martini which, to my disappointment, was made without sugar rim. But perfectly tart and for sure made with real lemon juice.

We went on to pick 5 courses to share among the two of us. Nothing was bad, and one course was outstanding: a goat with bourbon butter and lobster. The sauce was to-die-for and we even found ourselves pouring the remaining vegetables on the plate to cover then with that beautiful flavor... Without embarrassment. The lobster, however, was to my taste quite abundant.

One other course I remember was wood oven roasted pig face which without doubt was delicious, but would have suited way better as a hung over breakfast a late Sunday morning.

I probably wont go back since I find it ridiculous to wait for a table for two months. But, if it wasn't for that. Sure, why not.

Fun place, cool decor, nice array of culinary delights.

Things to try: Pan Roasted Drum Fish, Olive You bread, Crispy Beef Short Ribs, Oysters!

Ambiance of this space is beautiful. It's classy, but not pretentious at all. Here's what we ordered (table of 5) and ranked in chronological order of what we liked best:

1) Sweet corn goat cheese wontons - Of the 13 dishes we ordered, this was my favorite and I normally don't even like goat cheese! The mix of the sweet corn, tomatoes and, popcorn (yes! delicious and unexpected) was perfect.

2) Escargot ravioli - the tamarind-miso sauce gives this dish a very rich flavor.

3) Roasted cauliflower - in the span of 2 days I had 3 different roasted cauliflower dishes: Purple Pig, Gilt Bar, and here. The cauliflower at Girl & the Goat was definitely my favorite.

4) Kona kampachi crudo  - dish is small, but the fish was so fresh

5) Pig face - it was good, but I can't say it was my favorite dish. We weren't sure how to eat the dish. The waitress told us to mix everything together: "the messier it looks, the better it will taste!" Truth.

6) Crisp braised pork shank - fall off the bone delicious. The meat is a great pair with the naan and sauces

7) Kalbi beef ribs - very tender and the okra was a nice addition to the plate

8) Culture club - we started off with the culture club. The bread (baked in house) was so soft and paired so well with the butter and pickled raisins.

9) Grilled baby octopus

10) Confit goat belly

11) Fried pickles - the shallot aioli and yuzu harissa (2 sauces it came with) tasted odd on its on. Dip the pickles in both sauces at once; they taste better combined.

12) Sugo

13) Diver scallops - dish was still very good, but nothing special

Last note: do not skip out on the miso-butterscotch budino. I came with very high expectations and left incredibly happy. All the dishes here are solid.

Wow. There is a reason this restaurant is award winning! I added my name to the waiting list months in advance, and it was definitely worth it. The two of us got the beet salad, halibut, green beans, baby octopus, and pork shank. The amount of food was perfect (more beans than we were expecting, but no complaints here!) and everything tasted wonderful.

This was named as the best restaurant in America and the food is worth the hype. We had the pig face,halibut,pork shank,cauliflower and all were good. The halibut was very delicious but portion size was smaller compared to the others....

Went on a Saturday at 4:30pm without reservations. It would have been an hour to wait for the dining area or find an open spot at the lounge or bar area. We sat at the lounge just the two of us and it was nice. The sofas were comfy.

Waitress and waiter we had weren't very friendly or smiley at first but warmed up to us as the meal progressed.

Rice should have came with the food :) but that could be just the asian in me. Also every cooked dish was just a tad too salty.

We ordered

House blend juice: yum! Make sure to mix!

Bread: there was a cheese bread that was delicious

Raw oysters: hubby enjoyed it. i don't like when it is even a little fishy and leaves fishy aftertaste which is what happened.

Goat belly: very tender, one of the best entrees we ordered

Roasted pork belly? a bit too crisp for my liking and not the best here. would rather eat it at an authentic chinese restaurant or over ramen at santouka.

Grilled baby octopus: second favorite dish this evening. the octopus was cooked perfectly and not too chewy! yay! would be good with rice.

Goat carpaccio: meat was good and tender. dressing on top was too sour for me. i think i am still more of a beef carpaccio fan.

Roasted cauliflower: third favorite dish this evening. i could do without the sprinkled cheese? on top but still very good. and we got a lot! we saved it to eat with the cooked meat dishes we ordered. it would be good with rice too.
Goat Empanadas & halibut were out of this world. Highly recommend. You may wait, but your patience will be rewarded

Ok so either this place is way overrated or I had my expectations set way too high.

I made reservations months ago after hearing how amazing it is and how hard to get rez.  Well the day finally came and.....not all that impressed sorry!

We tried to order one from each category: got the rye bread- average
Goat empanada- it was good, all components, so ok but just one
Roasted cauliflower- prob the highlight of the menu honestly
Roasted duck with the kimchee- yuck, sorry

We didn't want to end on that note so we got dessert, one was a hit one was a miss.

The rhubarb cake was amazing I will say. They have it in this horachata tapioca- wow. So good I would go and just order that next time.  Then it ordered the date cake with the butter gelato- no. A total miss. Wish I didn't end on that note.

My friend and I agreed that Little Goat across the street is probably better than here and you don't have to fuss with advance reservations!

Sorry- I'm a foodie and I was expecting so much better.  Or maybe I need to try other items but didn't look like I was missing out on much else.

I will say, our bill was decent even though we ordered quite a bit.  But anyway I look forward to Little Goat next time. And maybe here for the rhubarb dessert.

pics.caption: Rhubarb cake in horachata tapioca- wow

review.des:
One of the best restaurant's I've ever been to.
Everything we ordered, back to back, consistently was delicious!

What we ordered:
beet salad (refreshingly tasty)
spring onion pierogies (was scrumptious)
seared diver scallops (Delicious scallops but it felt like dog food the serving ceramic also felt a bit like a dog bowl) Please fix the bowl.. haha
braised beef tongue (so tender and crispy)
wood oven roasted pig face (melt in your mouth HEAVEN) FAVORITE must get!
confit goat belly (best goat i've ever had- crispy and tender)

cajeta-black pepper gelato pie (Tasty but not a huge fan of their black pepper but some people might love it.

This place is all that it is cracked up to be.   We had:
PigFace, Beef Tongue with Frisée and Potato Crisp,
Ham Frites, Multigrain Bread, Yo Quiero Taco Bread, Pierogi, Goat Empanadas, Goat Carpaccio, Warm Marinated Olives,  

Dessert:  Buddino and Blackberry Shortcake with Blackberry Mint Ice Cream (picked from Stephanie's magical secret garden)

I'm going to keep it real and not go all food critic, but the food was EXCELLENT.   Stephanie Izzard and her squad should teach a life course on the importance of Balance when creating a dish.  Each dish was executed perfectly, piping hot and balanced flavors of sweet/salty/hot/cold/rich/acidity.  I've never had a meal like this.  She makes Emeril restaurants look like Playschool Kitchens.

Simply Awesome.

P.s.  I am sensitive to rich foods but had zéro issues with fat or greasiness at this place.

DROOL.

I made reservations about a month in advance just to make sure I'd be able to try this place. I'm from LA and have had my fair share of good food, but I must say, this place blew me away. I went with a group of 5 and we ordered a good portion of the menu. It's tapas style and each dish just got better and better.

The reviews don't lie, order the pig's face! The pork shank was one of my favorite; the meat was so juicy and tender. Given the name Girl & the GOAT, you should definitely try a goat dish-the empanadas were delicious. I thought it might taste like lamb (which I'm not a fan of) but if it did, the flavoring hides it well. Pork belly and duck tongue was just as tastey.

And don't forget your veggies! Shishito peppers and green beans were on point.

There's always room for dessert...the rice pudding and butterscotch budino is a must! My sister, who's favorite meal is dessert, rated those as some of the best she's had. ENJOY because I sure did.

Duh.

(Yelp wants me to write a longer review, but come on. Hoping this is enough words now.)

A lot of fancy restaurants, such as G&G,have one thing in common: small portion and over-decorating on the plate.

I want down to earth, normal people size entree, without all the grasses and colorful stuff on a piece of meat.
This place is for girls and goats, that is where the name is for.

Amazing. Stephanie Izard is so incredibly nice and she came to our table during dinner and chatted for a bit.

What we ate:
Grilled octopus- amazing. Literally the best octopus I've ever had. Cooked beautifully.

Goat Neck- must get. almost tastes like pot roast. Incredible. Melt off the bone, so good.

Shrimp- excellent, on a bed on corn. It was a favorite for a couple people.

Cauliflower- good, but I don't love cauliflower enough to appreciate it.

Pig face- good, but surprisingly not the star of the show.

Salmon tartare- I thought it was excellent, but if you don't like the taste of raw salmon this is not for you.

Breadstick buns- you have to eat these! It's like an Olive Garden had a baby with your moms rolls.

Peppers- good, not great.
Love love love the decor inside and the food. I believe their menu changes seasonally so if you don't go for awhile the food choices will be different.

Good restaurant and scene.

The crudo and pig face are the clear winning dishes here.

It can be a little loud, it can be a little crowded, it can be a little over hyped but then again Izard won top chef for a reason and is a celebrity chef. Deal with it.

-1 for dessert not being anything to write home about IMO.
Great atmosphere and great food. Pork shank was meaty, well cooked and flavorful. Loved their old fashioned and goat satay. Easy spot to want to revisit.

this place is ah-maze-ing!! be sure to make reservations weeks ahead of time. I went with a group of 6 and it was perfect. it's tapas style so I could recommend ordering a bunch of different plates and tasting each one. every plate is unique and flavorful. best experience ever. will def visit this place when I come back to Chicago. in my picture I circled what we ordered.

Was lucky enough to score a reservation the day prior. Tried nearly everything on the menu (all amazing) and had an awesome cocktail. G&G is obviously a very well known and crowed place but definitely worth it.
If I had only one restaurant to eat from for the rest of my life, I would choose Girl & the Goat!! Get here!!

Simply amazing. I rate the atmosphere and the food outstanding.

My favorite restaurant.

This place is amazing! Breakfast all day and not just your usual stuff. They have all the typical breakfast and diner offerings plus some really unique stuff like 'This Little Piggy Went to China', with Sichuan sausage. I had the 'Kimchee, bacon, eggs, pancake, Asian style breakfast thingy' which was amazing. Highly recommended! My waitress was also quite friendly and informative. Definitely going back.

pics.caption: Kimchee, bacon, eggs, pancake Asian style breakfast thingy

review.des:
FINALLY! After waiting for months, we got a reservation to Girl and the Goat. I was super excited, since I'm a huge fan of Stephanie Izard and absolutely love Little Goat across the street.

G&TG is a small plates restaurant, where you order a few to try and share among your dining companions. Prices are pretty steep, but you get high quality food. Husband and I are teetotalers, so we opted not to get any drinks (good thinking, since they were $13 a pop) and ordered a few plates to share.

We got the goat belly, goat empanadas, hamachi crudo, calamari bruschetta, ham frites, and duck tongues. One thing I noticed at the end of the meal is that they progressed our meal from lightest to heaviest. I thought that was pretty cool (husband said he would have preferred the opposite, but he would have gotten The Itis after the first course, I guarantee you). I enjoyed everything, but there were some dishes I enjoyed more than others.

The goat belly was delicious, as always. The bourbon butter it was in was very sweet and too weird for me. I also could have sworn I tasted peanut butter in it! The goat empanadas were funky but tasty. I ate the avocado/blueberry sauce that was leftover with a spoon. The hamachi crudo was the star of the night: light fish with little pieces of pork belly and chili aoili. The calamari bruschetta was soooo oily. It was delicious, don't get me wrong, but it was swimming in a pool of oil or butter, maybe a bit of both. It made me glad I don't have my gallbladder anymore. The ham frites were tasty shoestring fries with some kind of ham salt, served with smoked tomato aioli and beer cheese sauce. The duck tongues were great! They just tasted like fried clams. There were little pieces of raw tuna mixed in as well. We didn't get dessert, but instead opted to go across the street to Little Goat and get a Choco Taco sundae.

Another thing worth noting that I appreciate: they leave a wine bottle of room temperature water at the table. As someone who is overly sensitive to cold drinks, this was a life saver. I killed two bottles of it.

I feel like I won the lottery!  I came, I ate, I loved!

Since moving the Chicago, Girl & The Goat has been the one restaurant I always wanted to try but never thought I would actually get to.  I mean who knows what they are doing 3 months from now that they can make a reservation that far in advance?!?  Okay, I might be exaggerating a bit...but this place is in serious demand.

With just the brother-in-law in town, we decided to see how busy it was.  It couldn't have been later than 8pm.  It was BUSY.  But we were feeling lucky.  We were hoping to grab an open seat at the bar.  First come, first serve.  The bar was completely full.  No more than five minutes went by when somehow by luck or magic, a couple finished right before our eyes.  I felt like I was sliding into home, for the WIN, as we slid into our coveted bar seats.  

We started with a cocktail, from the Aged barrel list...my BIL is fancy like that, he's good people to know.  We ordered a variety off the menu; roasted cauliflower, escargot ravioli, pork shank and goat empanadas.  Every dish was rich with flavor.  I loved everything, but the pork shank was probably my favorite.  The meat was falling off the bone it was so tender.

Pricey?...You betcha.  
Worth the month long reservation wait?...Um, how bout a late night walk-in attempt?
Worthy of the hype?....Hellz Yeah!

I put off going for years because it was so difficult to get a reservation, and I'm so sorry I did!  Girl & the Goat is one of my favorite restaurants in Chicago.  For my first visit I obviously couldn't snag a reservation at the last minute while a friend was in town, so we sat at the bar (make sure you get there right at 5 if you want to ensure a seat) and had the most amazing experience.  Our bartender recommended several dishes to us - each one better than the last, and she even comped us a few.  The atmosphere and service were impeccable, and the food combinations were out of this world.  I now see why it still takes forever to get a reservation after years, and why Stephanie Izard is so famous.  I loved listening to all her employees talk about her with such admiration; she treats them well and has remained humble and down to earth despite her fame and success.  Girl & the Goat will become a new staple, not only because the food is some of the best, but because it is a restaurant that I want to support.
My bf and I waited months to get in and it was worth it.  Loved the menu and atmosphere. Get in early before it gets packed. Highly recommend the pigs face and the oysters

Dear Girl and the Goat,

Although I may be your 2,258th admirer, I would like to declare my love for you regardless of the competition. I don't write love letters often, but you are worth it!

Everything was amazing. I sat outside in a communal table and shared the space with five other of your fans. Tried the octopus, oysters, a few cocktails, and your famous Pig Face. You impressed me with your creativity and innovation. The food was absolutely sexy. When will I come back to Chicago to see you again? I hope very soon.

Please accept my upmost love and admiration.

Love,
Gloria C.

I understand the reason for the hype! Went last night for dinner (after making a reservation about 4 months ago) and had a blast! I was a little unsure when I saw "Goat Face" and "Goat Belly" on the menu, but figured it was a good time to expand my senses. Both were phenomenal! The cauliflower was also an excellent "goatless" addition.  
What really set the experience above most was the staff! They were all so so nice & fun to talk to. Just a very fun & enjoyable experience all around. Make a reservation now!!

I've been waiting to go here for years now but I've never been able to make a reservation because you need to do it 3 months in advance and I never know my plans that far out. So I finally decided to just go early at 5pm and wait for a table. Luckily there were 2 seats open at the bar so we took those instead of waiting 1+ hours for a table. The bar was nice and the service was good so it was no problem. Like I said, I've been wanting to come here for a while, so I had big expectations for this place. Overall the food was really good, but not as amazing as I had expected.

Steamed west coast mussels: 5/5  My only complaint is that they give you 2 little pieces of bread and there's so much delicious sauce to soak up! We tried asking for more bread but they won't just give you a few slices, they make you purchase one of their specialty breads.

Goat blue bread: 5/5 Although originally a little upset we had to purchase more bread for our mussels, it was worth it. The fig butter it came with was delicious and creamy...I might have even taken a few small spoonfuls of it when the bread was gone

Escargot ravioli: 2/5 Super disappointed with this one. I normally like escargot but whatever was in this made it literally taste like dirt. Avoid this dish.  

Sauteed green beans: 5/5  SOOO GOOD! If all vegetables were this good I'd be a vegetarian

Pig Face: 4/5 Flavorful dish that you mix up like a hash

Goat shank: 4/5 Tender and fell right off the bone

All I can say is wow! I had an truly amazing culinary experience at Girl and the Goat last night.

My friend and I arrived at about 20 minutes early for our reservation and were immediately seated at the Chef's Table! I've never eaten at a Chef's Table before and eating at the Girl and the Goat's Chef's Table as my first try will definitely be hard to beat...

My friend and I decided to try five different menu items and chose to go with the sauteed green beans, wood grilled broccoli, grilled baby octopus, braised pork shank and duck confit. I loved how when we ordered our waiter told us he'd know the best order to bring everything out in, the order he served them totally surprised me but I ended up loving it!

All of the food we ordered had so many amazing and unexpected flavors. Highlights were the smoke blued cheese sauce that came with the grilled broccoli, the fish aioli on the green beans, and the amazing acidity of the grilled baby octopus.

We were also lucky enough to get two dishes on the house including the empanadas and a chocolate cake dessert served with mushroom ice cream. The empanadas were my favorite dish of the evening and I loved the tzatiki sauce that they were served with.

Additionally one of the best parts of the meal was being able to sit at the Chef's Table and talk to the chefs as they prepared our fabulous meal.

Finally, the service was fantastic and it only made an already great experience better. It was truly a joy and definitely one of the most unbeatable dining experiences I have had.
Favorite spot in the entire city of Chicago. Haven't had a single bad item yet. Easily been there 25+ times.
Amazing dishes, great wine selection, and good mixed drinks. I will be back, thanks for the great experience! The haddock was my favorite!

One of the best restaurants I've been too loved every moment of it and hoped to be back soon! The staff were friendly and made me feel right at home! Please try the goat shoulder I have a good amount left over and it's delicious!
Came in for apps during the evening rush. We got a table with the sun blaring in our faces and they promptly moved us without question.  Had a sausage platter and the bone marrow which was delicious!
Just go.  It's everything that you have heard, but probably better.  It shouldn't be this good but it is.

I'm pretty sure I could have eaten the entire dish of Shishito Peppers all on my own. In fact, I might have, I'm not sure. I was too busy eating them to notice that a certain someone was sneaking bites of my spare rib. OMG. It was all so good. That being said, Purple Pig and RPM knocked this place out of the top two of food-ventures. That doesn't mean I didn't love Stephanie Izzard's place. It just means I loved the other two that much more. Take it as you will.

(For those following along, yes I did gain something close to 10 pounds on this trip alone.)

I just don't get the hype.  There are a couple of really great things on the menu, and the wine list is great, but after three attempts I am still not impressed.  The Little Goat is far cheaper and in my opinion, a better meal.

Simply amazing. It is not an understatement to declare that every dish hits every note of a wonderful and well-balanced dish that is only achieved by great chefs.
Recommendations:

-Roasted Cauliflower  is a must try. It comes with picked peppers, pine nuts, and mint. Crunchy, salty, savory, and delicious. Nutty, minty, perfectly cooked

-Sugo, similar to braised beef gravy over pappardelle

-Crisp braised pork shank: Dressed in buttermilk and served with grilled spring onion kimchee and deliciously naan. Meat was very tender.

Roasted Pig Face: this dish is to be celebrated and a must try. A dish I want to try everytime. Super tender meat,

Wood Grilled Broccoli: rogue smokey blue, spices crispies

Grilled Baby Octopus

Pan Roasted Halibut - cooked to perfection earthy smoky, sweet savory. Another must order.

Braised Beef Tongue - salty crunchy sour from the pickled vegetable, herby...

Miso butterscotch budino - bacon toffee, glazed pineapple, candied cashews.

Some have said this is the best restaurant in Chicago. I'll have to respectfully disagree. Don't get me wrong - it's good, a great experience, and I'd recommend going at least once. Each plate is very unique, and comes pretty much separate from every other plate.

The breads at the beginning are awesome, and come with two sides - if you order all three, you can mix and match and get great flavor combinations. They recommend the pig face, and brought it to my 5-person group last. Kind of a coup de grace. However, none of us were crazy about it. Sure it was kind of like bacon, but overpriced bacon. The sugo was tasty, but not much different from a regular ragu sauce. The mussels were just...mussels. Sauteed green beans surprisingly probably the best thing we had. Chickpea fritter was definitely solid, but just like anything similar on Devon Street. Duck tongues...what can I say? First time with duck tongues. Didn't hate 'em. And the goat empanadas - I should clarify that the restaurant's not goat-centric - but these were pretty darn good. We didn't have drinks, but there were some tempting cocktails on the menu.

Everything was masterly prepared, but too few things really jumped out in a good way.

Fantastic! I loved everything!!...small plates to share, desserts, the people, service, artwork. I was so engaged in the food that I did not think to take photos as we were all digging into every plate.  I plan to go back again and try some of the meat dishes as we focused more on the appetizers, vegetable and seafood small plates and desserts!  The raw kusshi oysters were like little delightful explosions in my mouth and had to order more. The roasted beets and wood grilled broccoli had me going back for more and loved the hamachi crudo, grilled baby octopus and seared diver scallops!!  Also had the goat empanadas - yummy.  To top it off, really enjoyed the sticky spiced squash cake. I'm still dreaming about the night!

pics.caption: Save room to enjoy ad many plates as possible!

review.des:
It's one of those places that's on most of my friends' must-visit list, and I do want to see them, so I've ended up here many times over the last couple years.  The food's been consistently good, and I do have a fav dish, so I'm ok returning.  Once we did a walk-in and got a table right away, but we've mostly sat at the bar, and that's been much more enjoyable for me.  It's a casual and comfortable environment, everyone's been very friendly.

The menu changes often, but the goat menu is pretty consistent.  The empanadas are tasty, the beet salad is great, soft shell crab, roasted cauliflower, etc.  Have liked everything there, but my hands-down favorite is the goat liver mousse which I get every visit.  That's a whole entire meal, since no-one ever wants to try it, and I get it ALL to myself.  Those pillow-soft crumpets are sooo delicious.  The plates are a decent enough size that 2 or 3 people can get a good taste.

I made reservations for 7:30pm last Wednesday and we got there right on time but waited about 20 minutes for our seats as the general manager came up to us saying he had given our table away- never had that happen before, and odd it happened as such highly-acclaimed restaurant.  But we got seated right after he talked to us and it wasn't a big problem since I wasn't as hungry.  PLUS, we got seated two tables away from BOBBY FLAY so got to spy on what he was eating.  The service was spot on throughout our entire meal, a smooth-flowing restaurant.  They did not take a dish off our table until we actually finished eating the entire dish which I appreciated, and our dishes came out well-timed.

The chef here does flavor and texture combinations really well.  All the dishes had an interesting mix of ingredients I would never think to put together, and she adds different elements to make the dishes texturally perfect (all dishes had some kind of contrasting texture- like smooth w/ crunchy, crispy w/ creamy, etc).  Here's what we got in order of what I liked the most:

The PIG FACE- one of the BEST MEAT DISHES I've had in a LONG time.  Stunning, my first bite was heavenly I must say.  It's basically like two circular slices of moist sausage on top of swirls of tamarind, cilantro, and some other sauce, with crispy potato stix and a runny egg on top.  The meat was super moist, fatty and flavorful, combined with the crunchy potatoes and creamy egg- amazing.  The texture of the entire dish was perfect.

Chickpea fritters- a MUST GET at this restaurant- it's this creamy hummus-like inside fried in a crispy batter on top of a tomato stew with fresh green chickpeas, sliced pickles and mozzarella.

Goat Cheesecake- DELICIOUS.  It was a simple deconstructed cheesecake with a circle of creamy, light cheesecake, on top of a delicious graham cracker crumble with caramel sauce and roasted beets.  

Roasted cauliflower- great mix of cauliflower, mint, and pine nuts.  I'm a sucker for any cauliflower dish but they made it really well here.  I loved the addition of the pine nuts and the hint of sweet mint.

Kohlrabi salad- a mix of greens, thin slices of kohlrabi (like white radish) and almonds.  My friend said she thought they put too much dressing on the salad, and I would agree, but it was really good and a unique dish- very refreshing, loved the crunchy almonds.

Grilled octopus- this dish was a bit salty for my taste since it had guanciale (like prosciutto) it just made it a bit too salty for me.  But the octopus was really fresh and I liked the beans in the dish.

pics.caption: The amazing and texturally phenomenal pig face!!!!
Octopus- very fresh but a little salty

review.des: Came here for a special dinner and it was even better than expected.  Will deffinitally come again.

Wow we are so lucky! Got a reservation through Opentable 2 days before our visit! Whenever we visit Chicago, this restaurant is always on the top of our list. I have been here at least 5 times.... And I live in California. I go here more than some restaurants in SF.

The signature dishes that are a must: braised pork shank, Roasted cauliflower, & Wood oven roasted pig face!
(You can read more in my previous review.)
They are always good & You will never be disappointed... Ever!

Service is top notch.

Will I ever come back? Heck Yeah!!!!

Thank you Stephanie!

Exquisite and well worth spending weeks refreshing OpenTable trying to fit in a reservation for the weekend I visited Chicago.  The quality of service matched the quality of food.  My boyfriend and I loved the "All the Leches Cake."

I came here with five other of my friends. We had heard of the hype and booked our reservations over a month in advance.

As a group we got the following:

Roasted cauliflower
Sugo
Braised beef tongue
Pig face
Pork belly
Mussels
Cheese pierogies

The pig face and beef tongue were amazing. The pickled vegetables went really well with them. The cauliflower, however, was a bit too mushy and soft for my liking. Also I found the pork belly to be a little too salty. The rest of the food was okay but unmemorable to me.

Overall the food was good but not spectacular and certainly not worth the hype. With that being said, I think that everyone should try this restaurant as it is hyped for a reason. The flavors are very unique and interesting but just didn't work for me.

My second time visiting and it's just as good as I remember. Great wine selection and fresh seasonal ingredients crafted in a new American menu. small plates perfect for sharing.  Easy to find a seat at the bar if you only have 1 or 2, but more than that you'll need a reservation which is hard to come by if oh don't plan ahead.

It wasn't bad, but it wasn't good enough.  

Good thing I didn't read through all the Yelp reviews prior to the meal; otherwise, my expectations would have gone through the roof!  After waiting several months for a reservation (dinner at 4:45pm, no less), and after having shelled out $50pp on dinner, I would have really liked to be blown away by the exquisite combination of culinary flavors and textures.  Alas, I was left disappointed.

G&TG serves small plates; it's recommended to order 2-3 per person.  We tried a bread (the spence wheat, which came with peanut butter butter and honeycomb - yum!) and 8 dishes.  The chickpea fritters and kalbi beef short ribs with corn fell into category 1: "mmm, this is tasty".   The grilled octopus, pan roasted walu, escargot ravioli (seemed undercooked), pork ribs, pigface with sunny side up egg, and pork fat doughnuts fell into category 2: "interesting plate, but the combination of flavors is okay...".  The pigface tasted a little vinegary, the escargot was a little chewy, and the walu and pork ribs were kind of just there.

Service was good.  The waiter was enthused and attentive; those bringing out the plates give you a detailed description of the dish, but it's hard to hear and/or they don't speak particularly loud and clear, so listen closely!

P.S.  The girl is the goat.  Izard = goat in some other language, and the original "Drunken Goat" name was already taken by a cheesery or someplace or other in California, so after a cease and desist letter... G&TG it is!

pics.caption: pigface with sunny side up egg

review.des: Stellar. Pig face and goat belly addictingly delicious. Halibut was divine. Dessert malt ice cream dish was inspired. Dessert brandy was the only unremarkable thing.

a bit pretentious but worth the wait...
