Course 3: Driver Scallops - this may have been the only mediocre dish of the night, and by mediocre, I mean it was only very good instead of amazing.  I've had perfect scallops in a variety of places, and these scallops were perfectly cooked but there was nothing special or unique about this dish.  The kimchee and the rapini is a tasty accompaniment, but to be honest, I was tempted to leave the rest of the dish when the sepia came out and just focus on the new and shiny dish at the table.

Course 4: Grilled Sepia - I had never had sepia prior to this visit and it has a very firm consistency similar to octopus but the taste of this dish was so different, we had no problem with ordering both.  The tomato base of this dish was very tangy and tasty and again there was the presence of extreme lemon.  It was tough to choose a favorite, but I think this might just be my favorite of the night.

Course 5: Charred Pork Belly - This dish was just for my fiance, but I tried a bit of the flavor and it was excellent.  A nice robust charred flavor that was not too hearty or overwhelming.  He loved the dish.  Pork belly by nature is extremely fatty so he left a good deal of the fat pieces left on the plate, but he certainly licked the rest of it clean.

Service was wonderful.  We were at a communal table 4 unrelated parties of 2 all seated together, but it still somehow felt intimate enough for just me and my fiance even though we were sitting next to each other.  It was a friendly atmosphere and we enjoyed conversation between ourselves, as well as with the other patrons at the table.  Our waitress was very helpful with advice and recommendations.  The chefs sent out some complimentary fries with various dipping sauces for the table (to promote the social atmosphere) but the ladies in the corner seemed to think it was only for them and sequestered the plate between the two of them.  Clearly, they weren't locals.

5 courses and 2 drinks came out to under $100 for the two of us and we easily could have gone with one less item.  I was so happy to finally experience the food that lived up to the hype at Girl and the Goat, but I have heard from many that they also have had the same inconsistent experiences.  The only reason this isn't a 5 star for me, is because with the frequency with which G&G is constantly changing their variety, they seem to lose a little bit of credibility for always being consistent in their offerings.  I'll happily come back in another 6-8 months and look forward to whatever batch of creations Stephanie Izard has come up with at that time, but I'm not sold yet on G&G being a dependable mind-blowing experience in every visit..

One of my favorite dining experiences.  I've been here 3-4 times but haven't been around in 2 years so this isn't a new review.  Waiters are always knowledgeable and drink selection is deep.  The only gripe I have is that I feel that everything is slightly too salty here.  Maybe it's just me but I realize that I have to drink a lot of water when I'm here.

My husband took me here on a date, and we sat at the chef's table. He isn't a foodie, and even he could tell the food was above and beyond fabulous. Our favorite was the trout, but even the homemade bread was noteworthy. I so hope to return on my next trip to Chicago.

My daughter took me here for Christmas and I loved the menu, atmosphere and food. We were a little disappointed that because we had the earliest reservation we showed up about 15 minutes before they opened and they wouldn't let us in. We had to stand out in the cold until they opened.  They would have been smarter to let us in and allowed us to have a cocktail at the bar ($$$$).  I would still go back because the food was awesome.

Fan-flippin-tastic.

Somehow my mom squeezed us in because of someone's last-minute cancellation.  Super lucky.  

3 of us shared a bunch of stuff.  I really appreciated our waiter's insistence on not neglecting the vegetables.  The broccoli was one of the best things I have ever eaten in my life.  The pig face was amazing as well.

I also liked that the waiter was enthusiastic about the food, had great suggestions and was so chill that he really allowed us to enjoy our meal.

The Grilled Walter's Chicken with Ramp Mole, Giardiniera and Asparagus was fantastic! The Honey Sambal Brioche was delicious!!!!!!!!

Have an appetite - so much food and flavor!!!!
Stopped in for burgers and were happily surprised to find this gem of a place. Have been back twice since then and everything we have had has been consistently great.

Awesome awesome food they did a great job perfecting everything that I tasted there, can't wait to go back and try some more stuff that I haven't had but for right now I have to give it A5 Star for food , as far as Ambien it's not a bar type of place but if I'm grading the food five star all day long

This place is booked up for 3 months for a reason. They have the most unique and amazing dishes in Chicago. I have had everything on the menu and the pig face is my favorite. They only serve craft beer that is mostly international.

The dishes are a little pricey but the quality of food is worth it. This food will change your life and is the type of place you bring your wife for your anniversary. But you can also come here a get booth seating and get something fast if you are craving their vegetable, meat or fish menu. West Chicago is the place to be right now and the girl and the goat is a main attraction.
Perfect dairy free menu and meal.  They had a special dairy free menu printed and could not have been more accommodating for dairy free.  Amazing meal.

Made reservations back in March for a party of 7, and I have been eagerly anticipating this restaurant.

My review is focusing on service, which is why I am only giving this place 3 stars.

We were a group of 7, (3 couples and 1 extra person) and we all have different dietary restrictions.
3 are non seafood eaters,  2 were pescatarians,  and the other 2 just don't eat beef  or pork.  There weren't a lot of plates that wouldn't accommodate all so the shared plates concept had to be split for us in 3 groups, so 3-2-2.  we figure we would just split the tabs that way too.

We asked if that was okay and we were discouraged from doing it. The reason we got was because of timing of the plates, but that didn't really matter to us, so we were like...okay....   (personally i think i twas more the POS system, but if she had told us that rather than timing that would have been fine..)
We ended up doing it that way anyways with a plan that we would figure the check out ourselves, then we could tell her what was going on what card.

Ordering was an issue.  To start, we wanted to order 3 orders of the honey brioche, and 2 of the frites bc those we could share it among everyone.
Our waitress discouraged us from ordering that much, so we went with 2 orders of the brioche, and then 1 of fries.

After we got the bread and frites,  we were left with uneven numbers, so we did go ahead and order another order of bread,  and another order of fries. So it was pointless for her to discourage it.

When we ordered our mains, we also had some issues.
After the group of 3 and 2 ordered,  that left the last group of 2.  Everything they would ask for she would discourage because someone else at the table already ordered it.
This left them for limited options so they had to go with something they didn't want to get enough food for the two of them.

When the plates came, they were pretty small, so not really shareable among 4 people,  so discouraging that they order two of them was incredibly pointless.  

Unfortunately the service really killed the night for us.

The food was actually really good. I was in the group of 3 of meat eaters , and we got the shishito peppers, beef tongue, pork belly, and pork shank.  The Old Goat cocktail was SO good!

The honey brioche was delicious and their fries were super crispy. It was all really really good.

I just wish our server let us order what we wanted rather than having a disagreement with everything.

I can't believe I have never written a review for G & the G! Shame... seeing that this place has already garnered 1000+ reviews filled with lavish praises, what more can say...

Some useful tips:

1) If you want to dine at prime time, make advance reservations. And I mean like 3 months ahead. Their availabilities are shown on OpenTable 3 months out. We make our reservations 3 MONTHS in advance each time so that we can eat at a more normal time say at 7pm. If advance reservations that far out don't work for you, your options will look like either a 5:15pm or 10:15pm seating, IF you're lucky enough to even have those availabilities left to choose from.

2) If it's just two of you in your party, I highly recommend requesting for kitchen counter seats. They have two sections of kitchen counter seating; one at the entree section (right side) and another at the dessert/appetizer section (left side). Either side is great though the right side has more stuff going on (think sizzling, grilling, etc). Each time we dined at the kitchen counter, we received a couple of additional dishes with compliments of the kitchen. This is a very nice gesture of the restaurant as it creates a somewhat personal and appreciative relationship. During one of our meals at the counter on the right side, we had a great interactive dining experience with the chefs as well.

Despite G & the G being such an overly hyped restaurant in Chicago, it has a lot to live up to. And it does!

This review is wayyyy overdue!!!  My first time in Chicago and I am in love with this city!

Our first meal in Chicago was at the Girl and the Goat.  Usually I breakdown my meal and rate each course, but with the ever changing menu my suggestion is just to go. Just go!! The food is incredible, ask your server for suggestions. They will sound weird and creepy and you will ask yourself "what am I going to eat here?" but trust me...everything will be delicious!  

Delicious!  And afterwards you will long for the Goat, it will visit you in your dreams and if you're lucky...someday you will return.

Overcrowded, overrated.
But the green beans really are as good as they say (whoever said that about green beans before?!)
This was the second time coming here and it never disappoints. The food was delicious and service is always outstanding and prompt. The goat empanadas are always my favorite! Check them out :)

The general consensus seems that if you don't have a reservation just stake out a spot at the bar.. if you go early/ right when they open you'll probably be able to grab a seat immediately.. during peak dinner times the bar area is completely crowded and people start waiting around you while you're eating so they can grab your seat when you leave..

was in chicago for the weekend and one of our friends recommended this place so we had it on our list of places to eat at before we left.. my friends and i sat at the bar about 10 minutes before the place officially opened.. for three girls we ordered about 6 dishes.. the waitress said it was a tapas style plating system and ~2 plates per person is enough.. 6 dishes for 3 girls was MORE than enough food.. we were so full by our 4th plate... but we had to keep eating so we could try everything.. some of the foods are a bit on the saltier side.. but all in all it was a highly enjoyable meal.. the more memorable thing about this place is their bread.. order one of their bread dishes.. the accompanying sauces are so delicious!!!!! i think i dreamed about the bread that night.

I had been trying to get reservations for a couple of months and took a chance and showed up right before they opened and was able to get squeezed in at the communal table before another reservations. I never really like sitting at a communal table, it seems like you are always squeezed in, but that was not the case here. The table was huge and enough space between the other parties so you didn't feel like you were on top of them and with the open kitchen right behind the table, we could not hear the other guests at the table.

Food and service were excellent. Our plates were exchanged out after each course and water glass never went empty. Impressive beer list too.
We started with the roasted beet salad. The sardines mixed in added a nice saltiness to the dish. Then we had the Arctic Char. Up next was the fire roasted broccoli. The rice krispies on top added a unique texture that went well with the broccoli. To round out the main meal we had the pork shank. It was crispy and the kimchee butternut squash cut the fattiness and richness of the pork nicely.

At that point I didn't think I could eat any more, but we decided to get some coffee and the bittersweet chocolate dessert. I was a bit worried about the shiitake caramel gelato would not taste well but the flavors melded well and complimented the chocolate cake.

Its been a week since we went and we are still thinking about our meal and cannot wait to go back again.

a few notes: i might not be the right person to attend a meal here as i'm not really enchanted with goat as a meat (it's too gamey for my taste) but that being said, they did have some non-goat items on the menu.
-roasted pig face was by far my favorite thing we had (this carried the meal in my opinion)
-goat empanadas (not a huge fan, boyfriend liked them though)
-hamachi (fine)
and we had maybe one other dish that i can't quite recall...what really did stand out to me though wasn't the quality of the food (it was fine, no strong feelings either way) so much as it was the fact that we were seated nearly 40 minutes late for a reservation - nothing irks me quite so much as being seated late for a reservation. while i understand that sometimes this happens with popular places, it's kind of a night killer if you're planning to go anywhere else.

I've tried to go here before I moved away from Chicago (sniffle sniffle). So I knew when I came back for a visit, I wanted had to use that opportunity. There were so many great things about this place, I don't know quite where to begin.

The place is swanky with a capital S. Dark woods, dark atmosphere, and beautiful people. The service was spot on. The waitress was super friendly and no pretensions. She answered all my friend's requests regarding her allergies and even provided a menu with the ones that my friend could enjoy.  You can tell when people are excited to work where they work.

So being a table of four girls, we tried tons of dishes. I think that's the way to go but if you have only two, I suggest ordering 2-3 dishes so you can try a bunch of things. The dishes that stood out were the crispy pigface (salty, crispy, delicious!), the green beans, the mushroom (they were very savory and rich) and the pork shank that came with kimchi butternut. I cannot say it was kimchi, but it was the perfect accompaniment for the rich dense, savory pork shank with fresh crispy Indian bread-naan.  Oh yeah, I also loved the goat confit. I know the girls were squeamish about trying goat but you cannot go to Girl & the Goat and not try a namesake protein. It was so good!

The drinks were spot on too, they had a great selection of wines and cocktails. Being a glutton, I had one of both and tried the Goat red wine. What can I say...it had nice balance and freshness that helped the meal. Yes, it's loud. Yes, it's crowded. Just go there an experience for yourself.  You will enjoy it if you give into the experience.

Girl & the Goat is a Chicago must try. Reservations are difficult to come by but I've never had much of a wait as a walk-in. The servers, food runners, and bussers have always been very friendly and knowledgeable. No one there ever appears to hate their lives. A very positive atmosphere.

My most recent visit was as a two top walk-in at 1700. We were immediately seated at a common table of eight. The one and a half hour time limit was more than enough for us to comfortably finish three drinks a piece, share eight dishes, and amusingly watch the couple across from us get a myriad of gluten free and other great accommodations. I've never been disappointed by any of the dishes. My favorites are the Chickpea Fritters, the Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face, and the desserts. The ingredients are always well plated, fresh, and well paired. As with any restaurant I advise that you do your research before going but this is one of the few places you don't have to feel bashful about asking. Hope you enjoy it
I LOVE THIS PLACE! Great food and service.  I could live here :)  My stomach is always happy after I eat here.  The wood roasted pig face was orgasmic!

Shortest review in my body of work on Yelp!: Good.

Reasoning for the short review: everyone reviews this place.  (I might be convinced to revisit this review at some point, but really, I have a lot of energy for a pho place that just blew my mind, and Yelp! just prompted me on this place when I signed into my account.)

Hipster Factor: Medium to High.

Revisit this place? Definitely.

Most amazing food I've had in a while. Halibut and Goat belly out of this world. Great service, great food, will definitely come back next time I'm in Chicago. Thank you!! People giving bad reviews are stupid and ignorant.
Fantastic time at this restaurant with my mom and a few girlfriends. We tried a lot of different foods and shared. The atmosphere was relaxed and the food was superb.

I am a frequent Chicago visitor and had heard/read some very nice things about this place and was naturally very excited to check it out.
Made a reservation a week in advance for a Thursday evening.
 The ambience is very upscale yet I couldn't help but feel that the place was very congested. We were seated at a table in the corner. It was dark enough there for us to not be able to read the menus. Upon request , we were moved to a brighter spot and the server casually remarked how there should have been a candle where we were originally seated.
 The menu had a lot of variety both in terms of food and drinks. We decided upon six small plates between two per the server's recommendation along with bread and dessert. However, a couple of weeks later I can't even remotely recall what we ordered or what the small plates consisted of. The food was indeed very forgettable. The best part about my dinner was the Belgian beer I had.
  I spent about $130 on a dinner for two, wasn't impressed and wouldn't be going back.
 The service however was excellent and the ambience was great. Hence, the two stars.
 I wouldn't recommend this place at all though.

What fun. We dropped in and easily got  great space at the bar.  The bartender really knew the menu and guided us to a few great selections. Food and drinks were superb! Looking forward to my next visit.

One of my favorite restaurants in Chicago!  Stephanie Izard's culinary mind is incredible.  Part of the BOKA restaurant group.  Service is impeccable every time I go.  The menu changes but never disappoints.  I have sat in the dining room and most recently at the bar, amazing service and experience in both locations.  At the bar, we had the pleasure of being served by Lily.  Lily is prob one of the best servers I've had.  The staff here knows their stuff.  She was kind enough to go through the menu, recommend a bottle of wine (2006 Basel Cellars), and let us taste one of the beers on tap.  Perfectly informative!  Once our bottle was popped it was time to get down to business.  We ordered....Roasted Cauliflower (half order) cooked to perfection.  Roasted Beets (half order) that were so fresh.  Celery root & Cheddar Pierogies (half order, two), kind of a combo between pierogie and empanada, really good!  Seared Diver Scallops, two come w the order and they are HUGE.  Seared perfectly.  Duck Tongues, HOLY DUCK these were delish!  First time eating duck or tongue and I am glad I did.  Crispy Beef Short Ribs, like perfect meat croutons. I dream about these short ribs.  And last but not least we had the Confit Goat Belly.  The bourbon butter made my mouth water.  I will not wait a year again before going back!  

They open at 4:30 and have a line by 4:45.  Either make reservations or prepare to enjoy a cocktail while waiting for your table.  The house cocktails are on point.  Most of which designed by the awesome bartenders (shout out to Tony).  I've seen all kinds of attire.  Staff wears jeans and t-shirts but the food commands more than shorts!
An absolute treat...the food was delicious and creative. Duck tongue, open face pig, oysters, chicken and the bartender was lovely..this is a must stop. Certainly a repeater

Service was great, our waitress was on top of everything. Love the idea of small plates also. Unfortunately, I thought some of the food was too salty for my taste. But a great place to come for a drink and small bites.
Love this place! It's American fun past time food and it's amazing with the twist they put in all their dishes!!
Delicisious veteranian entrees.  I don't think it ever gets old.  Great ambiance.  Love this place
This place is wonderful. If all you order was the side of bread, you would be satisfied. The pig face was extradionary. Everything was top notch.

Managed to waltz in here one night without reservations at around 10pm, woo! Love the inventive menu. We totally over-ordered. The waitress suggested two plates per person, 3 plates if you're a vegetarian. I accidentally ordered 4 plates because I didn't think bread counted. Turns out it was 2 plates too many. Next time I'd just get one of the bread dishes plus one veggie.

The "not Campbell's" bread was amazing. Broccoli cheddar bread served with a salty mushroom butter and delicious tomato oil. I think it was only like $4 too.

My other fave thing was the grilled broccoli. Almost as good as The Publican's take on broccoli. Such flavorful, charred goodness.

The mushroom ragout was a bit of a disappointment--I found it to be too salty. Seemed like it needed more of ravioli pieces to balance it out. I enjoyed the chickpea fritters, but they seemed particularly pricey at $11 for two little fritters.

The cirtrusy, spicey Tempest cocktail was fantastic. Friendly server, though we thought it was a bit odd how she never asked us how the food was. Looking forward to returning and ringing up a much smaller bill now that we know how few plates we can handle!

If one likes to suck on a salt-lick as a hobby then you'd love this place.  After the salt-heavy dinner, I was quite worried my blood pressure would skyrocket.   Everything tasted the same....salty. To the point I can't comment on any other flavors in the dishes I tried.    Service was quite polished even though I sat at the bar.  Not sure I'd want to give this place a second chance.

At this point a 5 star rating is almost redundant, but I have to update my review for this last dinner experience.

This was my fourth time at G&tG and this time we were seated at the Chef's table.  I didn't even know they had a Chef's table.

We had:

- roasted beets - beets are so in right now (apparently), and this was an excellent presentation.

- chickpea fritters - I know I should try new things, but every time I come here I get this.  The texture and flavors make this a must have.  

- confit of duck leg - the duck was good, but I loved the bok choy & maitake.  Maybe it's the Asian in me.  

- goat empanadas - gotta get something made w/ goat here and this is another dish I always get.  Perfect outer shell, tender goat meat inside, and delicious sauce accompaniment.

- not campbell's bread - okay, how do you make bread that soft and melty on the inside?  I don't even want to think about how much butter goes in there, but it's worth it for every moist and delicious bite.  The spreads of "tomato" and "mushroom" soup are also beautifully inventive.

- pan fried shishito peppers - this was gift number 1 from the kitchen.  There were a few peppers in the bunch that had a nice heat to them.  It was like finding a delicious spicy treat.  A little heavier than I usually want my vegetables though.

- sugo - this was gift number 2 from the kitchen.  My favorite part was the balance of flavor from the gooseberries.  The pappardelle was perfectly cooked and the gooseberries nicely balanced out the meat ragout type sauce.

- pumpkin pie gelato - ended our night with this dessert number.  It's not too sweet and the cayenne (I think) gives the sweet a nice kick of spicy.  It wrapped the night up nicely for us.

Whenever I try to explain to someone how much I love G&tG, they always ask, "what kind of food is it."  I have no idea how to describe the flavors, mostly b/c I don't know what half the ingredients are.  But I have yet to bring a friend here who wasn't impressed.

How this is a "bib gourmand" and not at least a "1-star" Michelin makes me question Michelin's methodology.  Get it together guys!

I'm torn between stars here. While the food and cocktails were of very high quality and very creative, I think they were much too expensive for the quantity. Plus is they take reservations but I would take the Purple Pig over Girl and the Goat anyday. This place is docked for being too expensive compared to other tapas places that also serve exceptional food for a much more reasonable price.

Ladies and Gentleman,

This was the best meal I have had in my 28 years of life.

My husband and I come from a land of chain restaurants and "Try hard trendy restaurants" that fail within 6 months. We always try to eat at OUR new "hot spots" and are always dissapointed, but The Girl & The Goat? Not dissapointed at all.

We had a reservation on a Monday night at 6:15, we arrived about 10 minutes early and we're seated immediately at a small table right behind the hostess stand, which was plenty comfortable even though we were seated almost right next to another couple. It was loud but not so much that we could not hear each other speak. The atmosphere was nice and trendy and pretty casual.

We each ordered a cocktail, my husband had their version of an Old Fashion, and I had their Tequila cocktail, both were very good. We ordered the food all at once.

Bread rolls
Peer ogres
Calamari Bruscetta
Pork Face
Goat Empanadas

It all was amazing. Even the bread was absolutely perfect, just enough butter a day garlic and came with a perfect tomato paste. My favorite was the Calamari dish, every component together was the best thing I have ever had, a close second was the Pork face, my husband's favorite. If I had to pick a least favorite it would be the goat empanadas, which don't get me wrong, we're very good, just not GREAT in my opinion. They just didn't have the flavor everything else did.

The service was so quick it was almost unbelievable.

We ended with a dessert, the PB&J. It was absolutely the best dessert I have ever had. Just try it.

This was the best meal, and the highlight of my trip to Chicago.

small dishes/ order alot!!! this place is fukn amazing. go with friends since every dish is meant to be shared! this place has soooo much flavor everything is amazing and im not kidding please make sure to try the fried oyster and the kholrabi salad this is the best restaurant in the country!!!!

Many reviews for this place so what should stand out??

I came here last night for a special occasion and LOVED IT!  I made reservations well in advance and arrived early.  The staff was awesome to us and seated us right at 4:30pm.  We caught a glimpse of Stephanie but didn't get a chance to chat with her of snap a pic with her considering we are huge Top Chef fans.

The only complaint I had was the table we sat at was a little wobbly and our drinks were spilling.  The floor was a rustic wooden plank that of course has it's inherent unevenness - no problem as the waitress and a busboy adjusted it quickly.

The waitress went over the menu with us and gave us some pointers on how much to order and what we'd like.   LOVED EVERY CHOICE

We ordered the following:

Pretzel appetizer - awesomeness with French dressing and flavored butter

Wood fired wiley point - Horseradish, bacon and oysters??  Yes please

Hiramasa crudo - pork belly enough said

Diver scallops - perfectly cooked and HUGE

Wagyu tartare - my favorite with great flavors mixed together

Broken arrow ranch quail - red pepperocinis and grapes SUPERB

Smoked goat rillette empanadas - absolutely awesome - must get item

The place was packed, the atmosphere was awesome, the food was impeccable, and the staff was great.  We'll be coming back soon to get the highly acclaimed pig face!!

This is without a doubt a foodie experience. Everything we ate was original,  tasty and fun. There are too many options to explain all of them but I recommend going with something you haven't had before...goat belly? Pig face? Try it! You won't be disappointed. Get some bread too, the specialty butters are worth it. All plates are meant to share so get around 2-3 per person. Lots of specialty beers to go with a full compliment of wines and cocktails.

Vibrant and energetic scene too...this place is noisy and full of life. Not the place for a quiet conversation.

Reservations can be made through Open Table but given the demand, you will have to do it a few months ahead of time.
The place to be in Chicago, I love the baby octopus!!

Really really really really really good!!!
I hardly ever go out to eat so I decided to splurge on a late lunch early dinner. I didn't have a reservation but yet the bar and patio still had available seating.
The bartender was really nice and  knowledgeable about the menu. And even made me a G&T even though it wasn't on the menu.
The seabass was amazing as were the olives. The atmosphere is really nice and yet somehow low key.
If I could I would absolutely come here everyday. Definitely worth a stop if you have the time and money!
I couldn't have asked for a more perfect meal. The portions were just right to share and the medley of flavors in each dish were spot-on and balanced. Definitely a great "date night" place!

Pig face.

Every trip requires at least one helping of pig face. If you're my friend, Clayton T., then you need two per meal.

I've been here four times now and the pig face is the single best dish I've had in Chicago. Sure there are plenty of other dishes that are great (the shishito peppers, cauliflower, and cod cheeks come to mind), but this review will center around the revelation that is "pig face."

First or all, what comes in the pig face? Well, you start with a symphony of fatty pig parts found on the pig's face (snout, tongue, cheek, etc.) and you use it to sandwich some crunchy twiggy potatoes. What do you serve under this facial sandwich? A trio of sauces (a tamarind and black garlic sauce, a cilantro oil, and a red wine-maple gastrique). To top off this gluttonous assortment is a runny-ass sunny-side up egg. If you're a pork lover, this will fill that void that can't be filled by even the bacon-iest of bacon. It's that porky. It's perfection.

It's also relatively affordable. At only $16, you can order yourself a plate (forget sharing). Do this. Do this every time.

This is really all I have to say about Girl & The Goat. The pig face speaks for itself. What about the ambiance and decor and whatnot? Doesn't matter. Your focus will all be on the pig face.

TL;DR - Pig face.
It's as good as you've heard. I can't remember all the things I tried, but 100% of them were great.

Girl & the Goat is legit, even at 11pm. This was OMG DELICIOUS!

my favs/must-try dishes:

- Beet Salad-- so refreshing, so good! MUST GET!
- Diver Scallops-- SO GOOD! love the kimchi/avocado addition. 2 large scallops, over a bed of spinach. Enough for everyone to try.
- Steamed and fried Clams:  Both steamed and fried in one dish. The aioli was a little more than I would prefer (maybe ask for light aioli), but this was still DELISH!
- Wood oven roasted pig face: SO SO SOOOO good. mix it up with the fried egg and it is legit.
- Sugo: this was a thick pasta dish with a meat sauce over it... this was surprisingly delicious!!  Another must-get.
- Crisp braised pork shank: meat SO good it slides off the bone. Comes with nan and sauces.

good dishes:

- charred pork belly: I've had a lot of pork bellies... this was good, but not a "OMG must-try".
- roasted cauliflower: good veggie dish to compliment the entrees.
- grilled baby octopus: I am very critical about my octopus... and I didn't love this dish. For my palate, this was a tad too salty. Coulda lived without it.

5 stars in my book: great food, great wine, great decor.  Next time I'm in Chicago, I'm coming back!

Worst moving experience ever. They broke several things and furniture in the move, severely damaged my new wood floor and the worst part was they never solved any of it. They never paid back or accepted any of the charges, they only fixed 2 expensive furniture they broke but everything else was ignored, like if I was lying about them being responsable. They also didnt plan for the move, so they brought the wrong size truck, not enough material and took more than twice the time they said it was going to take them. Therefore the building charged me for a penalty fee that they never reimbursed either.
I will not recommend this service to anyone. I have done several moves, even across countries and this is by far the worst experience.

Just had a great dinner at this spot! Very hip atmosphere and the food is amazing. Well worth the almost 4 week wait! The server EMILY was very attentive and friendly! Everything that we ordered was cooked and served perfectly!

What we had: Roasted cauliflower, grilled baby octopus, wood oven roasted pig face and the confit goat belly.

Would defiantly go back
I come here quite often on Saturdays. I absolutely love the food and environment. It doesn't take long for your food to come after ordering. Absolutely one of my fav breakfast spots.

I am not adventurous. My sister wanted to come here, so I went along. Service was good, and the food looked good. The beer selection was adequate.  Try the green beans. I never thought to put cashews with green beans, but it totally works. I don't think I'd go back, but I'm a picky eater. It was good to check it off the so-called "bucket list."

We've been here three or four times and have tried pretty much every dish on the menu.  The best are always oyster rockefeller, beans, and cauliflower.  The rest are good, but these three are the best (IMO)!

This was a great bar! (but not a great restaurant) The portion of food was kind of small and the price was expensive for it. However, it tasted really good! by the way, it's very noisy when I was there around 10pm. Not sure what the circumstance might be when earlier.

The food was amazing and we were treated to the left side chef's table for our anniversary, without asking! Everything from the wood roasted oysters, the squash blossom crab rangoon, and the roasted pig face was awesome. A wonderful dining experience.

I have been reading about Girl and the Goat for years, so as soon as my trip to Chicago was planned Lindsay K. and I made reservations well ahead of time to dine here. Our reservation was at 7PM on a Wednesday night. When we arrived, the dining area and the bar were both packed. As soon as we sat down, we noticed the fun music in the background. Wait for it...R. Kelly "Ignition Remix!" Needless to say, the atmosphere was absolutely perfect for us! We also heard Snoop Dogg and the song "Freshman" by the Verve. Couldn't have asked for a better random selection of tunes!

Our server gave us a good run down of the menu and answered any questions that we had. We never had to look around to find him or get his attention when we needed something. The food came out in a timely manner and we didn't end up with all of the plates at the same time which is a big pet peeve of mine.

Here's what we ordered as described on the menu:

Pan fried shishito peppers - favorite dish of the night AND of my trip to Chicago! This is a must try.

Wood over roasted pig face - very tasty and topped with a perfectly cooked fried egg.

Goat liver mousse - very rich, but delicious dish. It came with apple butter, pickled mushrooms, and crumpets. This is a large portion and was almost too much for two people. FYI - My dining partner likes liver, but did not enjoy the goat liver.

Goat empanadas - this was good, but I wouldn't order it again because there are so many other things on the menu that I would love to try.

Miso-butterscotch budino - I'm not a dessert person but this was one of the best desserts I've ever had. It had bacon toffee, glazed pineapple, and candied cashews. Everything worked so well together!

Both the food and the service were 5 stars. I had a wonderful experience!

I was recommended the Girl and the Goat months before coming on my trip to Chicago. Luckily I booked my reservation at that time, because I have heard it can be difficult to get reservations here. The place is a cozy, open spaced atmosphere with pleasant staff. You feel comfortable and not at all rushed when you are eating.

The drinks are flavorful (and strong).   DInner is served tapas style, so it is good to go with a few people to explore more of the menu. Everything I tried below was delicious:

chickpea fritters
diver scallops
grilled baby octopus
escargot ravioli
wood oven roasted pig face
oysters
goat empanadas

I would definitely come back next time I visit Chicago. Just plan ahead with reservations (though I heard there is bar seating that does not require reservations).

We waited a long time for a table on a Saturday evening but it was worth it. While waiting for our table, we were able to sit by the bar and order a bottle of wine. When we were finally seated, we realized we had the best seats in the house - we were right by the chefs who didn't fail to entertain!

The big hits of the evening:
1) sauteed green beans (fish sauce vinaigrette . cashews) - normally, we aren't fans of green beans but we could come back just for this dish. on its own. over and over.
2) wood oven roasted pig face (sunny side egg . tamarind . cilantro . red wine-maple . potato stix) - we ate this just because of its name. it turned out to be amazing. it is a signature dish of the restaurant and definitely lived up to its reputation.

A must-try staple of Chicago in the up-in-coming West Loop. Creative dishes in an industrial space. The green beans in fish sauce - which sounds intimidating - is one of my favorite dishes. My only complaint is how impossible it is to secure a reservation here. At least on OpenTable it's booked for months in advance, and can be a bit loud and crowded when you do get in (you may be seated inches from the next pair of diners).

Perfection.

From the wonderful warm but modern decor to all of the friendly people working there and most importantly the delicious food - it was a perfect night.

We had the cauliflower, goat empanadas, pig face and scallops. All perfectly executed and delicious. My fav was the pig face with the cauliflower coming in at a close second. We also had to get two desserts, clearly. Double chocolate cake (holy moly) and pumpkin gelato were a perfect ending to our meal.

Can't wait for the little goat! Bahhhhh!

We visited this place last night for a really late dinner. We made it 15 minutes later than our scheduled reservation due to a late train, but our hostess was so nice about it. They seated us immediately and did not rush us just because the kitchen was going to close in 15 minutes. They assured us that although we had to place the order all together, they would pace out the flow - and they did! Excellent food and exceptional service!!! We ordered for the Summer in Peru cocktail (I think that was what it was called) which was refreshing. We wanted to eat light so we just got two dishes - the roasted cauliflower and the wood oven roasted pig face. They were so, so good!! Great flavors and neat  presentation. There are many options for vegetarians to choose from here. We ended our meal with delicious desserts . I got the caramel corn and malt balls. The popcorn caramel served with is is YUM! My husband ordered for the dark matter pot de creme which was served in a cappuccino mug! So cute and yet so bold in flavor!

pics.caption: Corn bread with a cherry relish and a honey butter
Couldn't resist ordering the same desserts again ... Caramel corn & malt balls

review.des:
After reading all the gushing reviews, I was expecting a lot... so maybe my two stars are a bit harsh but I was really unimpressed.

My wife and I went here two days ago. We had been wanting to go for a long time, and we could only get reservations for 4:30pm on a Tuesday afternoon for dinner.

I just didn't get what all the hype was about. We ordered several things - chickpea fritters, pig face, ribs, oysters, scallops, and bread. Pig face and ribs felt too rich. Oysters were tiny and not particularly well prepared. It felt kind of cheap that bread is something you order. They had three types of bread, we had the sour one - nothing special. The fritters were good, probably the best thing we had. We had the brownie for dessert, which was very good.

The service was pretty bad. We felt rushed the whole time. We had come for a leisurely meal. We had a fairly expensive bottle of wine ($75 - Obsidian 2011, which was great) and wanted to enjoy things. The server kept rushing us. It was clear they wanted to keep the tables moving. She also asked that we order everything at once, and it made us feel like we couldn't order more if we wanted. I probably would have ordered more because we were still hungry, but we didn't ask. Our total bill was a little more than $200.

I'm a little late writing this, but it wasn't on my priorities to do since once again, the hype of a popular restaurant had me disappointed.

I think it's my new thing to not like restaurants that everyone else loves. My mom and I were super excited to come here after all the rave. In Girl & The Goat's defense, we were exhausted from her trip of playing tourists and weren't completely starving. Maybe things would have turned out differently if I had 10 hours of sleep after a long spa day.

That being said, the food is strange which I appreciate, but mediocre. I've had so many amazing dishes throughout the Chicago area and none here were included in that list. In fact, I can't even remember what I ate besides a cauliflower dish with way too much mint.

Skip the crazy wait at this place and go up the street to Sepia.

ZZZZZZ... huh? what?
Oh yea, I went to the Goat yesterday. A $65 /person snooze fest.
And so loud, why bother to have shared plates? You can''t hear the other people at the table say "this is good, have some."
I guess I am not the targeted diner. The food at Publican is so much better and the selection of "shared plates" is better at Meson Sabika.

Some good things though:
I was using a  cane and the staff was great about clearing a path to the bathroom for me. All the staff, not just one person.  Nice touch and good training.

The goat empanadas and pork cheek were really good.
Everything else- just ok. Just ok enough that I just can't work up enough passion to even mention what else I had.

The indifferent:

If you are a fan of sour beers, don;t order the "Monk's cafe Flemish sour", It's not sour.
MIxed drinks were said to be "killer" by Chicago Mag. I had the one with vodka, Pimm's, lime and cucumber. Its was ...ok.  This morning, I can't actually tell you what it tasted like so quickly It faded from memory.

We waited 6 months for a table- for 3 hours of averageness.

Girl & the Goat offers a great lunch experience. When I need to meet clients or friends in Chicago's West Loop, this is one of my first picks. Food choices are rich. You can even get a whole wheat bun if you decide to go the hamburger route. Wait time is sometimes long because this is a popular place. The location is a quick walk from Downtown Chicago. Looking forward to my next visit.

If the first 1600+ reviews didn't sway your opinion then mine certainly will (yeah, sure).  

Three of us showed up without a reservation at 4:30 on a Friday night and were shown to a table.  They told us that the table was needed for a reservation at 6:15 but it was all ours till then.  

The server was very....um...enthusiastic?  Helpful, friendly, interested, quick, all good things you look for in a server.  We each ordered a drink from the specialty cocktail menu.  I chose the Double Standard and it was good.  When it was time to order a second drink the server offered some unsolicited (yet welcome) suggestions and I ended up trying a Kentucky Mule, which so tasty I had two.  

We ordered 2 dishes each for all of us to share.  I don't remember any of them being disappointing in the least.  We had the escargot ravioli, wood grilled broccoli, kalbi ribs, roasted pig face, smoked goat empanadas, and some kind of oysters (can you guess which ones I ordered?).  I don't remember what was atop the oysters, but I do recall the server saying "and here are the blah blah oysters.  Topped with blah blah, blah, cilantro, blah, and love".  Which prompted me to say "oh, I'm allergic to love" (I crack myself up).  My favorites were the escargot ravioli, kalbi ribs, and the pig face.  The peaches and corn dessert was delicious.  I wanted to whisper sweet nothings to it and make sure it knows how much it means to me.  We also had some kind of cheese cake that was good, but not my favorite.  

The decor of the dining room is dark, warm, and inviting.  There is seating at a raised bar facing the kitchen where you can watch the magic happen.  We were seated at a corner booth table that was cozy but comfortable.

Everything was great, the food, the service, the decor, the company.  There were plenty of items on the menu that I could've snarfed and probably loved, I'm sure at some point I'll be back.  Honestly, I'll probably just be back for that peaches and corn dessert.
Completely worth the wait. Incredible food, interesting pairings, and top-notch service.
Really consistently good, if kind of overrated. You won't regret going.

The most amazing restaurant experience I have ever had! The staff is SO welcoming and kind. Our bartender, Lilly was so helpful and made sure everything was just as we wanted it. My husband and I also got to meet and take a picture with Stephanie Izard who was extremely nice and genuinely happy to meet us. The food was beyond delicious. We got the bacon and horseradish oysters, shrimp tempura, escargot ravioli, duck tar tar, and yellowtail crudo. All were excellent. For desert we had bourbon ice cream with blueberries and a brioche-type bread--I don't usually get desert but this was delicious. I would come back a million times if I could. What a special night!

Not only one of my favorite restaurants in Chicago, one of my favorite restaurants in the world! This place is incredible and every dish is better than the last. Piece of advice, make a reservation as far in advance as possible. We are here two years ago and thought it was crazy that we made a reservation a month in advance for 10:00pm,  but again this time made it a month in advance and it was for 10:30. This place certainly lives up to its great reputation, and that is proven by how in demand its reservations remain. The food is different, creative and absolutely delicious! I won't bother recommending too many dishes since everything is so great, but will say my absolute favorite was the goat empanadas. They were fantastic. We also loved the goat carpaccio. Just go! You will love it.

Went here for a birthday dinner with my boyfriend. I've heard a lot of hype about the restaurant, so we had high expectations. The service was friendly, personable, no complaints. We ordered 5 of the sharing dishes. The bread was wonderful (it's bread--great), shishito peppers were good but greasy and there were a ton of them, although that isn't really a problem. The goat empanada was very good, the pork belly was actually hard to chew, stringy, the octopus had a bitter green leaf in the salad that overwhelmed everything else on the plate, we tried to eat around it. Good wine list, food was only okay. It was nice, the restaurant is lovely, but nothing was outstanding and I'm happy to say that I've tried it, and never go again. A perfectly fine experience, not memorable or exciting.

Another great restaurant on randolph, what can i say.

Listen, you need to make reservations ahead of time, i mean way ahead of time. 1 to 2 months.  If you want to eat at a decent hour.  

My girlfriend and i went for an anniversary, the staff hooked us up with the seats right up to the kitchen.  Watching them work was so cool and they were very friendly. They will make conversation and are totally chill if you get a chance to sit there.  They may even five you a small free dish, jackpot.

It lives up the hype, most dishes are small and you can share. Was more affordable than i thought it was going to be.  

Ill be back.  In a month or two ;)

I was never able to make a reservation to eat at a regular dinner time. I come around 4:30-5 and get a bar seat. But it's sooooo worth it. The food, textures,smells that you get with each place is mind blowing. I never had a bad meal here. Cocktails: they r very ,very frugal with each drop they pour, it's by the oz and not a drop over a little annoying on my point of view. The bartenders are not very friendly. I will still go back with out of town friends  for the experience.

food were delicious, although its little hard to get into, but it was worth it.
the halibut , and duck were my most fav dishes. must try
Great dishes, great drinks, and a very accommodating kitchen to meet all your dietary/allergy restrictions. That last is a real treat in an increasingly intransigent artisanal world!

Wow, Yelp certainly did not disappoint! Of course, I was unable to get a reservation here during my weekend trip to Chicago so our party of 4 arrived at 4:30PM on Saturday and got seated right away!

Almost everything we ordered was to die for, namely the scallops, fresh bread (they usually have 3+ different types with a pairing of sauces), and the pork. Although I love my veggies, all the vegetarian dishes were my least favorite out of the bunch.

Plating and attention to detail (not to mention their cute goat mascot) really set this establishment apart from the rest in this city of tapas. Interior is rustic but comfortable and our server was phenomenal.

MUST try, definitely one of the highlights of our trip!!!

This was probably one of the most amazing dining experiences that I have had in my entire life. It can be a little tricky to get into, but trust me its worth the wait.
The staff was attentive and friendly, the drink menu was amazingly well thought out. Make sure you ask for advice from your waiter on what to order as everything comes in different sizes. I will also say that every dish we had was mind blowing. We did not order the pig face because of the reviews on yelp. We didn't miss it though.
Yum I must go back.

Exceptional service and food. Had Calmari (so good!), bread was amazing with the sauces, Beef ribs were good but needed more okra, Perogies were good but needed more sauce.

Dessert menu needs something better - only gelato and one or two other ones

You cannot go to Chicago and miss this place! One of the best meals I've had, hands down. We didn't have a reservation and walked in, they told us the wait would be an hour to an hour and a half but that we could snag a spot at the bar if a couple seats opened up. It was a bit competitive to get a seat at the bar with other diners doing the same thing so you had to be on your A game! We ended up waiting about 45 minutes with our drinks which was not bad at all. The bartenders were friendly and really knowledgeable about the menu, they suggested we get 4 dishes to share and it was a perfect amount. We had the goat empanadas, green beans, pig face, and the halibut. All amazing! The halibut and pig face were my favorites but I don't think you can go wrong here with any of the dishes! Definitely recommend!

pics.caption: Pig Face- so tender, don't miss this!

review.des: We loved this place. My girlfriend is adventurous and generous but I'm a picky eater and a cheapskate. We both left happy and full! Very good food, very cool atmosphere, totally fair price. We have now booked our wedding in the private space across the street (Little Goat Kitchen and Terrace)! Thanks Chef Izard! Highly recommended :)
My experience at Girl and the Goat was incredible. I went with my husband on our 2 year anniversary and the food and atmosphere were truthfully nothing short of magical!

During my 3 day Chicago trip with my girl friends, this was our NUMBER ONE place to try while we were in Chicago. I mean with the most and top rated restaurant in Chicago, who wouldn't want to try this place?

With the high recognition and popularity, the restaurant was already filled with reservations and we weren't able to reserve until 11:30PM. But who cares, we scheduled around our reservation to make sure we were here.

The service was great, our waiter was SO nice (so sad that I can't remember his name) and recommended all the right dishes for us.

I'm actually writing the review a year later so I forgot all the things we ordered but let me tell you... EVERYTHING we ordered was on point. Food is amazing and the ambience is very hippie and casual and opens late.

I will definitely come back next time I'm in town.
So good, everything, their dark matter pot de creme dessert is something I still dream about.

Wow .  I can the food was 5 stars as well the sevice and bar.

The pig face, the hamachi, octopus..........the pbj dressertwas just a great. Great great experience

When Fulton Market might be known as the Chicago Street of fine dining, Randolph St can be considered the hip one. Girl & the Goat is no super fine dining by any means but it's also not the cheapest, and on any given night this place is brimming with crowds and activity. Girl & the Goat has met much success, enough to open additional spawns like Little Goat nearby. We definitely enjoyed our time here in the hip not-too-cheap not-too-expensive restaurant scene.

Menu is divided by veggies, seafood, and meats. Figure on buying 2 or 3 plates per person. It's weird because nothing in the menu particularly screamed out at me. It was if I wanted everything and nothing. Most of our picks were based on recommendations.

-=-Best Bread and Butter ever-=- We're just starting our meal and already the bread and butter is freaking good. It's your basic onion bread but it came with 2 spreads.  I didn't care much for the Pepper Chutney, but the tarragon butter omg. That butter spreads so nicely and has a smooth hint of greenery freshness, Dude, what a way to start.

-=-Scallops in Curry Sauce-=- This looked more like a stew, but it was good. All the crunchy on top made it fun to eat.

-=-Braised Beef Tongue-=- Looks like salad with a few slices of meat on it, with the meat being a crisp beef tongue. Really I preferred the scallops more to this.

-=-Shishito Peppers-=- So much parmesan cheese on this, and it made it so good. There was so many peppers in there that maybe 4 or 5 could have enjoyed this plate together. Good filler if you just need substance.

-=-Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face-=- The most hyped dish and with an equally alluring name, but you can just consider this like cabeza. For those wondering, there's no actual face looking at you. That dinky egg on top hid an equally dinky piece of meat below. It was still good, but not worthy as the grand finale to this meal. You still need to get one though.
The food is delicious. A carnivores delight. The chef is on the cutting edge. It's just a little rich...pun intended.
Amazing food.  Fantastic cocktails.  Stephanie stopped at our table one time to ask if we had any questions about the food and check how we were doing.

We dropped by on a early Saturday night around 5 PM and the restaurant was already fully packed.

The service is nice. The waiter gave helpful information as how much to order and gave some good recommendation. She also allowed us to order a half size portion, so we can taste more dishes.

The best dish is I had is the goat carpaccio. Very well balanced flavor, the mixed ingredients all work together with minimum seasoning.

Duck tongues is also nice. it is crispy and flavorful.

The olive you bread has tender crumbs and crispy crust with olive inside. Very tasty. A single serving is small and only good for 2 person for tasting at best.

The pan roasted halibut has some execution issue. The two piece were not cooked consistently. One was over cooked, while the other one was oaky. The flavor is nice though.

Grilled baby octopus is the least like dish for me. It is over seasoned with salt and vinegar. Also, it blends all sorts of Asian vegetables in one dish. I think it is trying to do too much in one dish.

The wood oven roasted pig face is pretty heavy. The flavor has some subtle Chinese dish influence.

Overall, the dishes are flavorful. I will come back.

Alright...probably the most recommended restaurant in Chicago.  Big West Loop location.  Big celebrity chef status.  After many attempts to get a res i finally managed to tonight.  A little over stimulating as far as vibes go, but i get it...its an enterprise and they're hustling hard.  Never did my meal feel poorly paced and our server, Ryan, was on the ball...just mentioning the previous because it is not a very 'intimate spot' if that's what you're looking for. Food was outrageously awesome.  I can't say that enough.  Each dish was more fantastic than the last. Not cheap, but not out of range.  Eat here, but wait for the right chance.  Bring some friends, share all your dishes, and eat some goat parts.

it was pretty pricey, and i had noooo idea what i was eating half the time, but it was pretty good! the service was very, very fast when you were actually at your table. if you don't like close sitting, this place isn't for you :( but, the actual small plates were awesome and their dessert was lovely. i'd probably choose the little goat over this place, because i'm more into diner food versus small plates/sharing. however, the atmosphere is great and the service is quick.

i suggest that if you have a reservation you don't get there too early! you're going to have to wait until the time of your actual reservation :)
Enjoyable and slightly exotic tapas like menu. Good choice if you are willing to try something new. My personal favorite pig cheek ... Yum...right off the skull...even better. Know your food!

Our meal was tremendous. Started with the whipped feta and bread, amazing!! We had the halibut, goat belly, and cauliflower, finished with ginger donouts and popcorn brittle. Every dish was outstanding. Chef Stephanie, winner of Top Chef is truly a culinary artist. The sevice was excellent with Owen, he felt like a friend by the end of our meal. The menu at the Little Goat across the street listed complex ingredient combinations in casual presentations diner style. Duck Duck Goat, Asian flair, all in the same neighborhood, is her newest restaurant. I wish we had another day to try all three. Next time Chicago. Go to one of these three spots! Wow!

My husband and I walked in, to eat at the bar, easily on a Wednesday night. The berries and brie burger was to die for. The bar staff were nice and helpful. The ambiance was pleasant. Looking forward to coming back for a sit down meal!

For a place this difficult to get reservations, the food better be good. And it was. If you can't get reservations, you can actually sit at the bar and order off the same menu.

Had the
- mushroom ragout- different mushrooms in a creamy sauce
- cauliflower- probably some of the best I've had
- mussels- wish this came with more bread to sop up the liquid
- braised goat belly with seafood- also delicious but probably my least favorite- the dish didn't seem to make much sense
- braised duck- easily my favorite thing I had. I would go back just for this!

By the end of the meal I wasn't even talking, just smiling.

When visiting Chicago and asking people what are must visits, Girl & the Goat came highly recommended. I definitely was excited to try it and from the moment I walked in the door I had high hopes. The ambiance is just my style. Dark interior mixed with a rustic feel - thumbs up!

Food wise... I don't know if it was my palette coming in but everything just tasted way too salty. I think it might of been the Cauliflower because it was WAAAYYY too salty. Overpoweringly salty.  I couldn't really enjoy the rest of the dishes because my tongue was coated with salt. Pig face - it was ok but tasted salty as well. The actual meat had a bit of an aftertaste kick, but if you like livery types of flavor then this might be your dish. I must say the winner of the night was Crispy duck tongues - YUM. The slices of duck tongues were a treat mixed with the some of the pickled veggies. For dessert the miso-butterscotch budino was fantastic. Definitely muted my palette after such a heavy meal. I loved the bacon toffee that complimented the sweetness of the ice cream. The cashews also gave it a nice crunch!

Overall experience was great. Service was great. It would probably be a place I'd tell people to try.

I'm one of the few not obsessed with Top Chef, but I"ve been eagerly waiting for Stephanie Izard to open this for quite some time now.  I like good food, I'm a girl and I like goats (or at least goat cheese when I"m not pregno) so my expectations were pretty high. And they've been even higher since reading the fabulous Yelp reviews since Girl and the Goat opened their doors a few weeks ago. Would Girl and the Goat live up to all the hype? YES, it sure did...

My friends and I were lucky enough to score 7pm reservations on a Monday night here. Perhaps an easy task when it comes to most restaurants, but we're talking about the hottest restaurant in town.

We were greeted by the most awesome waiter ever, Meadows, who was one of the few they moved from their other restaurants (Boka, Landmark, Perennial).  A meal with Meadows is a blast...this alone is worth 5 stars, but it turns out the food is just as good as the service.

My party of 3 shared the following:
* Bread with whipped liver butter (i could have eaten 18 loaves of this bread)
* Chickpeas (one of my favorites of the night)
* Peppers (tasty, but my mouth was on FIRE)
* Soft Shell Crab served with corn (my absolute favorite of the night- incredible!)
* Skate Wing (loved the octopus that came with it)
* Seared Scallops (the butter on this was heavenly)
* Smoked Goat Pizza (eh, could have done without this one)

Meadows also had the bartender whip me up a virgin cocktail, which was so good that my non-pregnant friends had drink envy. I was nice enough to let them both have a sip.  Fortunately, they seemed quite content with their wine.

We couldn't stop raving about every single bite of this meal...and even whipped out our calendars to see when we could come back for more deliciousness! Well done Stephanie...this was worth the wait!

*
Everything we ordered was wonderful! We went around 4:30 right when it opened because we didn't have reservations and were seated right away. I highly recommend halibut and shrimp!

Took the time to find the reservations for my boyfriends birthday a few months in advance. Glad I did, this is a restaurant he has been wanting to visit, and cross off the list. We arrived early, and the place was crowded - expected, but I was excited and it was a friendly and energetic ambiance. We checked in and figured it wouldn't hurt to ask about the chef's table. The hostess was nice and gave us a time measurement, and regularly checked in with us. We waited a bit longer than we wanted, but it was totally worth it.

As soon as we sat, our waiter arrived - Brennan who was just wonderful. So very wonderful. We started with drinks, eagerly looked through the menu, and asked the advice of the chefs in front of us. WHAT A VIEW!!! We decided upon the oysters, the confit goat belly, the green beans (easily my favorite), baby octopus, and the crispy pig face. The pig face is a must! It is crispy, fatty, deliciousness that just melts in your mouth! Our waiter brought over some empanadas - because we JUST had to try them. We ended the night with the bittersweet chocolate cake things with shitake - carmel gelato. It makes no sense, but its delicious.

I'm tempted to start looking for another reservation now just so I can return in a few months when the menu is different because of seasonal change! Love this place, wish I could be a regular.

pics.caption: Pig Face - this is a MUST

review.des: The food here is wonderful. It was really cramped though. I'm not a huge fan of sitting elbow to elbow with 2 other strange couples. But if that doesn't bother you or you're feeling lucky enough to get a real table, by all means pleas give it a shot :)

Amazing. You are well taken care of even if you are a walk in without a reservation. The food and cocktails have great flavors.

I recommend the best of three cocktail with grilled octopus and the pork shank. The escargot ravioli was delicious and our dessert, bittersweet chocolate cake was the perfect end to a fantastic meal! Great atmosphere I highly recommend an evening at The Girl and the Goat!!!!

Decadent plates and unique flavors clearly stood out when visiting this gem. A large variety of cheese platters will have you wanting to come back to try all of them! Full bar only compliments this fabulous tapas establishment. The only downsides are the long wait to get in due it being immensely popular given its location.

We sat at the bar to eat because this place is usually packed with a 3 hour wait.  Well now we know why.  Even though we sat at the bar, the wait staff was attentive, fast and friendly and the food was spectacular. The host seemed a little snippy but that could easily be overlooked after you try their Miso Hungry Bread as an appetizer. It was the warmest brioche and probably the best bread I've had at a restaurant. It came with this fresh blueberry jam and smooth chili butter (not spicy which I'm okay with it).  I had the pig face with potato sticks and fried egg.. A fully realized dish. Perfectly cooked and flavored. Truffle cake was also a delight.  I'm looking forward to our next visit.

First dinner in chicago with my wife and family. Hands down one of the best places to eat! You have to eat anything that has pork in it! The last dish that came out was on the bone and by far the best meat I have ever eaten!
The mood was dim lights and great for a date night or for a group for a high class dinning experience. And the waiter was extremely helpful in deciding what to get! Make a reservation as early as you can, you will not regret it!

This fantastic and quaint restaurant is a must stop at in Chicago. Had the opportunity to go there for a business dinner, which was held in the basement room. Every course was delicious and an incredible dining experience.

Again - the hype.  I just don't get it.  What tha???  Really??

Let's put it this way - I just expected a HELLUVA lot more than what got delivered based on reviews and people's insanity to get a table.  

We got there at 4:30 and sat at the chef's table with 4 other couples we didn't know.  Whatever...it would have been nicer if they were more talkative but oh well.

The drinks are fantabulous. And our waiter was so nice and just as cute as could be.

But the food was eh.  Eh.  It wasn't bad.  But it wasn't like, OH MY GOD!!! THIS FOOD IS THE BOMB!!!

I don't know if people just overlook the "Eh.ness" of the food because of the reputation or if I'm really just a food snob and require excellence for my taste buds.

Whatever the reason, I won't be back.

Great food. Awesome service from the reservation to wait staff to food. Ordered 5 of their most popular dishes for three of us. Olive bread, Chick pea fritter, green beans, halibut, pig face, and pork roast. Everything was amazing except for chick pea fritter. It was just a bit too salty for me and I didn't care for the texture even tho I love tofu.  Halibut was one of the best things I have ever had in my life. Perfectly balanced in flavor, cooked to perfection.  Amazing. Pig face was such a surprise - think of it as the best eggs and bacon combination you have ever had... Awesome.  We finished the meal with chocolate pot de creme and chocolate gelato with caramel and magic shell.  The gelato dessert was so innovative and surprisingly good. It was one of the best meals ever and when we got the bill for $130, I was even more impressed at how they chose the keep the prices affordable.

Mistakes happen...it's apart of the industry and with that in mind I've written this review. Came here as a suggestion from multiple friends I didn't look into the place so I was at fault for assuming an early dinner would be an easy thing to accomplish. This place was packed at 6 on a Saturday with a 2hr wait so patience and perseverance plus hope led to landing bar seating.

Started with cocktails both were great had an old fashion and bolt action (memory may be wrong on the name) and bread order of miso butter and kimchi "relish" (quotations appropriate as this is essentially pico de gallo with a goju chang sauce drizzled over the top, not even mixed and I don't know how you get to loosely defining something as kimchi without fermentation or even a type of cabbage) miso butter was perfect and the brioche the same and amazing together and the "relish" had good flavor but the cucumber was a bit too pronounced (my personal opinion as I'm focused on spice with kimchi in mind).

Next was the beet salad that included frisee, green beans, bread crumbs, white anchovy, avocado creme fraiche. The flavor on this was good but the salad was over dressed and the green beans overcooked but oddly some were and some were not but I know it happens so no big deal there my main issue was the white anchovy which I was looking forward to as white anchovy are great so I was eagerly searching but nothing and so I came to the conclusion that they must be apart of the dressing but I knew better as they aren't cheap and they sure deserve more respect than being pureed into a salad dressing and then I found it one piece smaller than the 1/4 sliced beet and that was it so I was left wanting but entrees were next so hopes were high.

For entrees I ordered the scallop dish which comes with pea tendrils, fava beans, and smoked tomato rhubarb relish (should be called a compote why is relish having issues tonight), and brandade (salted cod & potatoe pureed together). The promise of this dish was so high I mean smoked tomato and rhubarb I was sold but alas the plate came and it was wilted pea tendrils covering everything without a bit of direction or reason so I moved things around and began tasting each component fava beans and pea tendrils under seasoned, brandade salty of course but I expect some control here but maybe it's being left salty was to balance with the under seasoned greens and beans (nope had a salt lick by the time I finished) smoked tomato and rhubarb absolutely amazing not too smokey not too tart it was great, and the scallops were cooked and seasoned perfectly overall I appreciate the direction of the dish but it fell short.

Second entree my girl (not very experienced in casual fine or fine dining) got the wood oven roasted pig face which comes with tamarind cilantro, red wine maple, potato sticks, and a fried egg. Very nice plating everything looked great so time to dig in and it goes down hill immediately cut into egg and yolk stays still(I chalked that up to possibly too long in the sally or too long waiting under the heat lamp) didn't think it would be that much of a factor but that was until the pig face (assuming cheek based on the size and I'm sure tongue would have been mentioned) it was jerky(even had a two top next to us get the same dish and exclaim how dry theirs was) but she was fine with it and said it tasted good still (refer to my above statement of her lack of experience plus this note of well done steaks are her preference..I still love her) so this was a severe disappointment.

Dessert save the day please..ordered the dark matter pot de creme which came with sesame spuma, ginger caramel, and sesame brittle this was perfect. Spuma was exactly what you want the flavor was sweet and the sesame was light but present and not too much when combined with the brittle and not lost when combined with the creme and the caramel had a great texture a ginger note. I'd certainly order this again.

Overall  we were able to enjoy ourselves but it took more effort to do so than is expected due to the acclaim of this establishment but the layout, decor, and music was very comfortable which helped. The direction and composition of the menu clearly require a high level of execution and I'm sure there has been, but not tonight. Apologies for no photos I forgot.

Hands down one of our favorite restaurants in Chicago.  The food, cocktails, and service is always on point! They even have a lactose-free menu....what!!?? Don't be scared off by that for those of you who are lucky enough not to have this allergy...my husband was impressed and he is the king of "no menu alterations please".  I think we've tried everything on the menu and cocktail list  and have never had anything to say less than exceptional.
Nice place, hip waitresses! The food is good comfort food

I've had nearly everything on the menu and it's all amazing. There isn't a single dish that has let me down. You can throw darts at the menu and you'd at the very least get the best meal of your life. AT THE VERY LEAST, you'd get the best meal of your life. This place is JUST THAT GOOD. I don't even dare describe any of the dishes I had for my words would not do it any justice.

I don't live in Chicago and this place makes me wish I did. You don't even break the bank by going here (average of 30-40 per person spent after tax and tip with no drinks). I've spent more at other places but the taste and value here is simply amazing. Whenever I go to Chicago, I will make sure to eat here at least once.

Straight to the point:

Bread - forgot the name but the two spreads were delicious. The bread had a crispy crust but extremely soft and warm interior. I bet other breads are equally great.

Veggie - roasted cauliflower. Can't say I'm a fan. Appreciated the pine nuts and the kick of pickled peppers but honestly cauliflower is still cauliflower. Still better than broccoli would have been.

Seafood - scallops. OMG OMG OMG. You have to get this. Tender, sweet, fresh and juicy, and perfectly seared scallops, partnered with the contrasting textures and flavors of pine nuts, pomegranate, and fried brussels sprouts. Everything was perfect. The reduced pumpkin sauce was the right amount of richness and fragrance.

Meat -
Pig face - a must-have I suppose. Meat almost melted in my mouth. Creamy sauce and potato sticks made it more interesting. Egg could have been runnier. I'm Chinese though, so I was disappointed when I did not see a whole pig face.

Duck leg - after the pig face, this dish was just like a deja vu. You can definitely tell the ingredients are fresh and top-notch, but the treatment is pretty similar - they seared the dug leg, slow cooked it perfectly so it was tender and juicy (coz the searing locked the juice in) but the sauce was strikingly similar to the pig face sauce. The bok choy was thrown in there for a reason that I cannot quite fathom...

Desserts - butter peanut custard. Guilty pleasure to the extreme. Oatmeal-peanut crumbles paired with honey yogurt custard. This is warm BTW. Add on the cold apple sorbet/Italian ice, it was just like three desserts in one bowl.

Bottom line:
1. Start looking for a reservation now for a dinner in about two months - unless you don't mind eating at 4:30 or 9:30 on a weekday or 9:30 on a Sunday.
2. Very very good ingredients. I think if you try their goat dishes, you will appreciate this even more. But with other meat dishes, I personally would enjoy more varieties of flavors than creamy butter.
3. Their menus change very frequently, which sucks, for my wallet.
4. Lovely ambiance and better than Avec but still very intimate seating. So don't make the mistake that we did - comment on how the couple next table ordered a $80 wine while we were contemplating going to Binny's afterwards.
Good - Not great, but good.  Pricey - so I did expect a bit better.  I enjoyed my dinner and the surrounding.  Very Dark in  the dinning room.

The halibut was dry, the chicken moist but the sauce over salted, the pirogies were nothing special, and the goat satay was appealing.  The server raved about the green beens and these were fresh and nicely cooked, but they were not amazing. Each dish was served at the correct temperature, and except for the dessert, everything did taste fresh. The caramel corn and malt balls were terrific, but the butter cake was dry and the ice cream freezer burned.   Our server was initially incredibly attentive, and when we brought issues to his attention he smiled and acknowledged but never
said he was sorry. One of our dishes was never brought to the table, over all I was disappointed.  Stephanie, you need to keep a more watchful eye on the kitchen.  Most guests seemed fine with the food, but also the vibe was trendy, and inviting, hence the overwhelming amount of under 30 crowd who were just happy to have a table in the crowded room.
There's a lot of hype surrounding this place so naturally we went in with very high expectations. Our expectations were met. I loved everything I tasted. Try it at least once.

This has been on my foodie bucket list for awhile and I was not disappointed. In town for a meeting so six of us came in for dinner and even without a reservation, had an outstanding experience eating in the bar. The service was on point and the food...annexing. We tried too many things to name, all totally satisfying. Wish I lived here! I'd definitely come here often!

Three months ago we made a four person reservation at Girl & the Goat.  We had to settle on a 9:15pm Thursday time slot because the place was so booked; obviously, one comes to expect that a place so booked must have magnificent food and maybe service to match -- sadly, that was not the case at Girl & the Goat.  Food was mediocre at best and service held no passion.  It was clear that the service team just wanted us in and then out; I left believing that no one in the restaurant actually cared if I enjoyed my experience.
    The table settings were a sharing plate per person, a set of silverware, a glass cup, and a napkin.  When we sat down we were told that we had to order everything at once and that our server would course our meal out for us.  We asked if we could order things after each course, but that request was denied.  This was the second red flag of the night; the first being a rude hostess when we showed up early.  We then devised which courses we would order.  We were informed that we should order two per person, so we ordered 3.33 per person (10 courses) since we were eager to try the cuisine of the highly publicly acclaimed Girl & the Goat.
    Our first course was warm marinated olives; these were pretty good, but also extremely simple (which was expected and not a problem).  Next came the hamachi crudo with crisp pork belly, chili aioli, and caperberries;
